title: Computers Hit Around Globe By New Form Of Old Virus
description: A new version of a malicious computer program known as Nimda is making its way through the world's computer networks, computer security experts said yesterday.

title: Candidates Clash Over Campaign Finance
description: A visibly angry Michael R. Bloomberg unleashed a series of attacks on Mark Green yesterday. He accused him of failing to disclose campaign finance information and suggested that he was behind the publication of a 1998 deposition in which Mr. Bloomberg said that he would need ''an unimpeachable third-party witness'' to believe an allegation of rape at his company.

title: Sports of The Times; Midnight Thunder In the Bronx
description: Whenever Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig hit late-inning home runs to win a Yankee game in that long-ago era of day baseball, it was known as Five O'Clock Lightning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPTON, BILL
description: LIPTON-Bill. Actor on radio's Golden Age shows ''Let's Pretend'', ''Road of Life'' and countless others died in Portland, Oregon on Oct. 29, 2001 after a 40-year battle with Parkinson's. Survived by his son David, daughter-in-law and two grandsons. Bill, his talent and his courage are remembered fondly by fellow Pretenders.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: Study Looks At Absence Of Referrals By Doctors
description: When people in health maintenance organizations are allowed to see specialists whenever they want to, without being referred by a primary care physician, they do not flock to the specialists' offices, a new study has found.

title: Renaissance Man Has His Own Renaissance
description: Bob Brenly was sending mixed messages to Miguel Batista, and he seemed to know it. For a week, Brenly, the Arizona Diamondbacks' manager, had said he preferred to start Batista in Game 4 of the World Series. But with a chance to take a 3-1 lead on the Yankees last night, Brenly started Curt Schilling on short rest instead.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing on the Media Business page on Tuesday about the naming of top managers at the Zenith Optimedia Group, a joint venture media agency company, misstated a title of one executive and the city where another is based. Simon Lloyd will be deputy chairman, not chairman, at Zenith Optimedia in addition to his other duties. Steve King, whose titles include director for business strategy and development at Zenith Optimedia, is based in London, not New York.

title: A Rare Leader Tries to Save Mexico's Fallen Party
description: Her party may be near collapse, but Beatriz Paredes refuses to indulge in eulogies.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ruling In Zimbabwe Terror Case
description: A federal judge has dismissed civil charges of murder and torture against President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe, left, and Stan Mudenge, the country's foreign minister, but ruled that their political party is liable for damages in a class-action lawsuit filed by citizens of Zimbabwe. The plaintiffs, all members of an opposition party, alleged that Mr. Mugabe and other members of the ruling Zimbabwe African National Union-Patriotic Front organized a campaign of terror preceding parliamentary elections in 2000. Under federal law, the court had jurisdiction because Mr. Mugabe and Mr. Mudenge were served with the lawsuit during a visit to New York last year.

title: BEST BUY TO PAY $250,000 TO SETTLE HARASSMENT LAWSUIT
description: The Best Buy Company agreed to pay $250,000 to settle a government suit that accused the company of allowing a black employee to be harassed. Best Buy, the electronics retailer, agreed to pay the money to the worker and provide training for all workers at its store in Oxford Valley, Pa., on their obligations and rights under federal civil rights laws, particularly with respect to racial harassment, according to the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. The company said it settled to avoid protracted litigation. The commission sued in September 2000, alleging that managers at the Oxford Valley store were either aware of, condoned or participated in racially explicit, insulting and derogatory comments against the employee.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Broadcasters Sue ReplayTV
description: The three biggest television networks -- ABC, CBS and NBC -- filed a copyright infringement lawsuit yesterday against the maker of a digital device that functions much like a videocassette recorder. The complaint was filed in the Federal District Court for Central California against ReplayTV Inc. and its corporate parent, Sonicblue Inc. ReplayTV makes a device much like the better-known TiVo unit that records television programs on a big hard disk. ReplayTV, however, recently introduced a new version of its machine that allows users to set it to skip advertisements and to transmit recorded programs to other people over the Internet. An intriguing aspect of the lawsuit is that NBC, which is a unit of the General Electric Company, is an investor in ReplayTV, as is the Walt Disney Company, which also owns ABC. CBS is owned by Viacom Inc. Seth Schiesel (NYT)

title: Inventories Play Role at 2 Clothing Makers
description: The Jones Apparel Group, a maker of women's career clothing, said yesterday that quarterly profit fell more than half after costs to clear out excess inventory rose. The Tommy Hilfiger Corporation, a clothing company known for its red, white and blue designs, said earnings increased 6.7 percent.

title: Sizing Up Budget Cuts and Answering Criticism About Experience
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with Michael R. Bloomberg, the Republican mayoral candidate, conducted yesterday by reporters and editors of The New York Times.

title: Game 7 Would Be Classic Duel
description: THE World Series schedule still lists Game 7 with an asterisk, as in "if necessary," but the rival managers were acting yesterday as if it was inevitable.

title: Paul Warnke, 81, a Leading Dove in Vietnam Era, Dies
description: Paul C. Warnke, who was the highest Pentagon official in the Johnson administration to question openly the aims and conduct of the Vietnam War and later, as President Jimmy Carter's chief arms-control negotiator, sought to trim American and Soviet nuclear stockpiles, died yesterday at his home in Washington. He was 81.

title: Citing Safety, City Will Cut Work Force For Recovery
description: City officials have ordered the Police and Fire Departments to reduce the number of officers and firefighters recovering remains at ground zero, a decision announced amid new concerns about polluted air at the site.

title: Rabbi's Accuser Is Hoping For Profit, a Witness Says
description: A surprise, last-minute defense witness in the murder trial of a rabbi testified today that the prosecution's prime witness hoped to profit from the case with a book or movie deal.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Agency.com Sale Is Finalized
description: Stockholders of Agency.com, an Internet consulting company, approved the sale of the company's remaining publicly held shares to Seneca Investments, a holding company formed by the Omnicom Group and Pegasus Partners. Seneca will buy the 34 percent of Agency.com stock that it does not already own for $3.35 a share. In April, the Omnicom Group, which owns advertising agencies like BBDO Worldwide, formed Seneca as a holding company for Internet consultants. In addition to Agency.com, it also took minority stakes in publicly traded Internet agencies like Organic in San Francisco and Razorfish in New York. Agency.com said in May that its founders, Chan Suh and Kyle Shannon, had agreed to sell their shares, accounting for a stake of about 20 percent, to Seneca. Although Agency.com was an early leader among New York e-business consultants, it has struggled with a sharp downturn in corporate spending on Internet initiatives. Agency.com shares ended the day -- their last day of trading on the Nasdaq exchange -- at $3.34, unchanged. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Alcatel Plans To Eliminate 10,000 Jobs
description: Alcatel, one of Europe's largest makers of telecommunications equipment, said today that it would eliminate an additional 10,000 jobs and that it expected to report a loss of $4.5 billion for the year.

title: World Briefing
description: AFRICA

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANFIELD, FRANKLIN O.
description: CANFIELD-Franklin O. Peacefully on October 29, 2001 in Montreal (Quebec) Canada in his ninety-first year. He is survived by his loving daughter Hope (wife of Jacques Tetrault), his grandchildren Ian Ogilvie (husband of Marran Humphrey) and Annie Tetrault & his great grandson Angus Ogilvie. He is also survived by his sister Elizabeth (wife of Clyde Smith). A private funeral service has been held and a memorial service planned for May 2002 in Montreal will be announced later. In Frank's memory a donation to Pianofest, 1701 East 12, apt 21 T.W., Cleveland, Ohio 44114, U.S.A., would be much appreciated.

title: The Afghan Front: Lessons of Vietnam
description: To the Editor:

title: William E. Sauro, Times Photographer, 78
description: William E. Sauro, a photographer for The New York Times and other news organizations, died on Saturday in Mission Viejo, Calif. He was 78 and lived in Laguna Woods, Calif., and earlier in Kendall Park, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CELLIER, JACQUES
description: CELLIER-Jacques. On October 27, 2001. Survived by his nephew, Claude Cellier and family and his many friends. We will never forget Jacques, with his passion for life, intelligence, mischievous nature and ''larger-than-life'' personality. Jacques added a dimension of excitement and fun to all of our lives and set an example with his brave attitude towards life. Services will be held at 11 AM, Friday, November 2nd, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Denmark: Premier Calls Quick Election
description: Prime Minister Poul Nyrup Rasmussen called an election for Nov. 20, saying that waiting for a mid-March deadline would force four months of campaigning on the country at a time of uncertainty brought on by the terror attacks of Sept. 11. The Social Democratic Party of Mr. Rasmussen, prime minister since 1993, has been regaining ground in opinion polls. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Brenly's Good Moves Don't Matter
description: In the first World Series game ever to stretch into November, Joe Torre and Bob Brenly sat in their respective dugouts last night scrutinizing the fruits of their strategic decisions in Game 4.

title: The Worry Trap
description: From the very first day we've heard the news: Now America can live the life the rest of the world lives -- bombs, poison, dread, fear, sacrifice, loss, threat -- the new global accompaniment to life's ordinary routines. Nowhere is this news less welcome than in the American suburbs, along quiet, leaf-strewn streets, our Elysian fields spilling out beyond the horizon line, miles from ground zero, but suddenly, and to every resident's dismay, implicated in the whole raucous, atrocious business of terrorism.

title: Big Blasts, Big Rally, Tied Series
description: The dynasty Tino Martinez and Paul O'Neill and Derek Jeter helped build over thousands of innings, in hundreds of games, was almost out of time. The Yankees were two runs down with two outs in the bottom of the ninth in Game 4 of the World Series last night, about to be pushed to the brink of elimination.

title: Bush Seeking House Allies On Airport Security Plan
description: Preparing for a politically charged battle over how best to protect the nation's airports in the wake of the Sept. 11 attacks, President Bush and his allies brought pressure on moderate House members today to defeat a plan to make 28,000 airport security workers federal employees.

title: The SoHo Grand Retools for the Ironically Earnest
description: The lounge trend has hit the six-year-old SoHo Grand Hotel, where the former dining room on the second floor has been turned into the grand lounge. (Lounges are to finger food what dining rooms are to sit-down dinners.) Here, the retro look is something other than the ubiquitous midcentury modern found in other new lounges. The designer, William Sofield of Studio Sofield, was inspired by the SoHo hotels of the 1870's. ''We wanted it to celebrate the pan-culturalism from that time and the exotic elements of the cast-iron buildings,'' he said. Shades of brown and camel add modern opulence. The tte--tte sofa, below, was re-covered in chocolate velvet. The crackle-finish tables in gold and brown lacquer, the Lucite lights and the sofa, in a bold Greek key pattern, were all custom-made. Add animal-print pillows and artists in ironically earnest eyewear, and the place feels like home, a very hip home. At 310 West Broadway (Grand Street). DONNA PAUL

title: Victim's Neighbors May Handle the Arrangements
description: The worst had happened, and now it was time to plan the funeral. Kathy T. Nguyen lived alone, so the grim task fell to her neighbors and friends.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANFT, MORTON (MARK AND MORTY HALL)
description: HANFT-Morton (Mark and Morty Hall) at 68 years. Beloved husband of Gail. Devoted father of Seth and Bruce. Cherished grandfather of Tyler, Noah, Joshua, Cassidy & Ethan. Dear brother of Carolyn Kessler. Service today, 1 P.M., ''Parkside'' Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, New York Opposite Kings Plaza.

title: Editors' Note; Today's Sections
description: News of the Sept. 11 attacks and their aftermath continues to appear in Section B; index, Page B2.

title: Protests and Firing of Cabinet Plunge Georgia Into New Crisis
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 1  Already wracked by new tensions with Russia and a brewing guerrilla war, Georgia descended further into political crisis today after a police raid on a popular television station set off mass protests and the dismissal of most of the government.

title: Unleashing Her Inner Child
description: UNSETTLING times call for uncommon salves. So when the events of Sept. 11 forced the students of Public School 234 out of their TriBeCa school and into temporary quarters, Maira Kalman, the children's book author, was one of several volunteer artists who came to the rescue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALBERT, HENRY DAVID
description: ALBERT-Henry David. (Formerly of Rockville Centre, New York). Born Feb. 11, 1918 in Brooklyn, NY, died peacefully on October 22, 2001 in Orlando, Florida. Beloved husband of sixty years to Doris. Devoted father of Dr. Stephen Albert (Carol) and Nancy Cuniberti (Kim). Cherished grandfather to Jonathan (Rika), Daniel, and Dr. Matthew Albert (Molly), Leigha, Michael, and Rebecca Cuniberti. Adored great grandfather to Jesse and Tyler Albert. Dear brother to Sidney Albert (Sara) and Beverly Lazarus (Spencer). Henry was the former President of Allen Industries in New York City then became the Division President of the Dayco Corporation in Dayton, OH., and later General Felt Industries in Orlando, FL. His generous spirit will be missed by all who knew him. Friends may make contributions in his memory to: Jewish Family Services of Greater Orlando, Inc., 2100 Lee Road, Winter Park, FL. 32789.

title: 70's Radical Pleads Guilty in Bomb Plot
description: After two decades as a fugitive from charges that as a young radical she had plotted to bomb two police cars here in 1975, Sara Jane Olson abandoned years of denials and pleaded guilty today to two felony counts before a stunned courtroom.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Pennsylvania: Bias Case Settlement
description: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission said the Best Buy Company has agreed to pay $250,000 to resolve a racial harassment lawsuit. The commission filed a lawsuit last year against Best Buy, accusing managers at its store in Oxford Valley, Pa., of knowing of, condoning or participating in racially explicit comments against Baron Fralin, a black employee. Best Buy agreed to pay him $250,000 and to train employees on their obligation to keep the workplace free of racial harassment. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Now Arriving, On a Fast Track
description: AT a railyard here across the bay from San Francisco, a Southern Pacific freight train gives a quick horn blast and begins its run across the Central Valley of California. Nearby, a brightly painted Art Deco passenger train chugs and clangs as it climbs past gold rush landmarks like Emigrant Gap on its way across the Sierra Nevada.

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIA

title: A Political Rise Built on Discipline; Under McGreevey's Self-Deprecation, The Heart of a True Political Animal
description: Even as a political neophyte back in the summer of 1989, James E. McGreevey found it easy to sidestep the toughest questions.

title: Bridgeport Mayor Indicted on Corruption Charges
description: Joseph P. Ganim, the mayor of Bridgeport and until recently a leading Democratic candidate for governor of Connecticut, was indicted today on a raft of federal bribery, extortion, mail fraud and racketeering charges.

title: Looking for Options for the 2002 Yankees
description: Paul O'Neill will play his last game in Yankee Stadium tonight, and Tino Martinez and Chuck Knoblauch could soon be playing their last games for the Yankees. Within the next five days, Yankees officials will begin planning changes for 2002, with an emphasis on upgrading the offense, adding power, increasing the collective on-base percentage.

title: Economic Scene; Rich nations have been too insensitive to poverty for too long; the situation can no longer be ignored.
description: FEW would dispute that terrorism and violent religious fundamentalism, however complex their causes, grow best in the soil of poverty. The Sept. 11 attacks raise this issue to a new level of importance. More than any other single event, the attacks show how interconnected the world truly is. High on the new agenda has to be attention to the world's poor.

title: Justice Department and Microsoft Are Seen in Tentative Settlement
description: The Justice Department and the Microsoft Corporation have reached a tentative agreement to settle the long-running antitrust suit against the company, people involved in the talks said today.

title: Assessing Risks, Chemical, Biological, Even Nuclear
description: Since being jolted by the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11 and the persistent, mysterious spread of anthrax, the government has been struggling to discern what weapon, if any, might be aimed at the nation next.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURKO, MARVIN H.
description: BURKO-Marvin H. Age 75, of Bronx and Wesley Hills, New York, died peacefully on October 31, 2001. Survived by wife Ruth, sons and daughters-in-law Elliot and Stephanie, Mitchell and Lynn, grandchildren Daniel, Nicholas, Max, and Hayley, sister Elinor, and nieces and nephew. Funeral on Thursday 1:00 PM, GarlickRiverside Memorial Chapel, 1439 Unionport Road, Bronx, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBERMAN, NORMAN
description: LIEBERMAN-Norman. On October 31 at 73 years. Beloved husband of Helen. Devoted father of Lawrence, Jeffrey, Shari Franco and Abram. Cherished grandfather of John, Michael, Heather and Lynne. Adored great grandfather of Matthew & Evan. Dear brother of Gloria Burg. Service Friday 10AM, ''Parkside'' Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, NY, opposite Kings Plaza.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LITTLEFIELD, EDMUND WATTIS
description: LITTLEFIELD-Edmund Wattis. Prominent business executive, civic leader and philanthropist, died on October 27 of lung cancer in Burlingame, California, at the age of 87. He was born in Ogden, Utah on April 16, 1914. He graduated with great distinction from Stanford University in 1936, a member of Phi Beta Kappa, and earned his MBA from Stanford in 1938. During World War II he served as an officer in the U.S. Navy and with the Petroleum Administration for War. Mr. Littlefield joined the Utah Construction Company in 1951 and became General Manager in 1958. In 1976 the company, then known as Utah International Inc., merged with General Electric Company in a deal valued at $2.2 billion, then the largest merger in U.S. corporate history. At that time, Utah had become the most valuable and profitable of all mining companies headquartered in the United States. Mr. Littlefield served on numerous corporate boards of directors including Bechtel Investment Company, Birmingham Steel, Chrysler Corporation, Del Monte Corporation, Federated Department Stores, First Security Corporation, FMC Gold, W.P. Fuller Co., General Electric Company, Hewlett Packard Company, Industrial Indemnity, Santa Fe Southern Pacific, Utah International, and Wells Fargo Company. He also served on the Bechtel Board of Senior Counselors. The Management Center at the Stanford Graduate School of Business bears his name. He also served as a Stanford University trustee, a regent of the University of San Francisco, a trustee of the Cate School, president and director of the San Francisco Chamber of Commerce, director of the California State Chamber of Commerce and the San Francisco Symphony. He was Chairman of the prestigious Business Council, of SRI International, and of the Beavers. He was the recipient of many awards during his lifetime, among them, the Ernest C. Arbuckle Award from the Stanford Graduate School of Business, and the 1977 Award from the National Conference of Christians and Jews. Mr. Littlefield was an avid hunter, fisher and golfer. He was a popular member of the Bohemian Club and many other clubs in California. He is survived by his wife of 56 years, Jeannik; three children, Edmund Jr. of Arlington, Washington, Jacques of Portola Valley, California, and Denise Sobel & her husband Norman Keller of New York City; and six grandchildren, David, Scott, Keith, Naomi, Allison and Heather. A memorial service will be held on Friday, November 9 at 3:00 PM at the Stanford University Memorial Church with a reception to follow at the Arrillaga Alumni Center on campus. Guests are advised to park at Galvez Field (Campus Drive at Galvez Street). Shuttle service will be provided. In lieu of flowers the family requests gifts to Stanford University, Office of Development-Memorial Gifts, 326 Galvez Street, Stanford, CA. 94305-6105; or Ducks Unlimited Inc., 3074 Gold Canal Drive, Rancho Cordova, CA 95670-6116; or a charity of your choice.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Wall Street is stunned and angered by the Treasury's action on long-term bonds.
description: WITH fears mounting that nine interest rate cuts in almost as many months may not be enough to rev up the United States economy, the Treasury Department added some high-test yesterday to the Federal Reserve's fuel mix. Unfortunately, Wall Street got run over in the process.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHALIT, BENJAMIN
description: SHALIT-Benjamin. The Board of Governors and members of Montammy Golf Club express their deepest sorrow at the passing of their beloved member and extend their heartfelt sympathy to Elsa and the entire family. Kenneth R. Orr, President

title: No More Mr. Nice Guys for Nets
description: BOSTON, Oct. 31  Todd MacCulloch, a mild-mannered funny guy, tussled with Indiana center Austin Croshere in the Nets' season-opening victory over Indiana Tuesday night. Kerry Kittles, his jaw steely and eyes flaring, got into a quick confrontation with Jeff Foster before Keith Van Horn intervened in the fourth quarter.

title: These Legends Are Life-Size; That's a Lot For a Photo
description: What becomes a legend most? Firefighters in bunker gear, dusty with ash from the World Trade Center ruins. Bomb squad investigators in Kevlar vests. Police pilots in chopper helmets. Ambulance workers draped in stethoscopes.

title: A Lesson With All the Bells and Whistles (Really)
description: I HAVE never forgiven my otherwise wonderful parents for not sending me to piano lessons. Rather than spend time with a therapist discussing this, I decided to take matters into my own hands. When a press release crossed my desk announcing a new keyboard from Yamaha that promised to teach me how to play, I eagerly called to request a demo unit. I was finally going to fulfill one of my dreams (not to mention rid myself of childhood anger). And I wouldn't even have to change out of my pajamas.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Unexpected Loss At Qwest
description: Qwest Communications International, a large provider of local and long-distance telephone service, surprised investors yesterday by reporting an unexpected loss in the third quarter. Qwest, which is based in Denver, lost $142 million, or 9 cents a share, compared with a loss of $248 million, or 15 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Revenue was virtually unchanged at $4.77 billion. Joseph P. Nacchio, Qwest's chief executive, said in an interview that the loss resulted from a slowing economy and hesitation by customers to acquire long-term capacity contracts on the company's network. ''We are clearly disappointed with our results in the quarter,'' Mr. Nacchio, above, said. ''But we had strong recurring revenues and we're confident of our company's strength going forward.'' Qwest shares fell $3.05, or 19.1 percent, to $12.95. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Let the Cars Squeal
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHSTEIN, FREYDA (AKA FREDDIE SIMON)
description: ROTHSTEIN-Freyda (aka Freddie Simon). Died in her sleep on October 28th, 2001 in Venice, Italy while on a cruise. She is survived by her two sons, Daniel and Aron. She had a performing career as a folk singer on her own radio program on WNYC, and as half the folk singing duo, ''Frey and Martin''. A graduate of The High School of Music and Art and Carnegie Mellon University, she was one of the first women to have produced a daytime drama serial, and moved on to become an executive at Paramount Television. She served as Vice President of Network Development for David Susskind at Talent Associates and Time/Life Productions before moving to Los Angeles and establishing ''Freyda Rothstein Productions'', executive producing over 40 television movies, many based on true stories, often controversial. ''Crisis at Central High'', the story of integration at the high school in Little Rock, won a Christopher Award and an Emmy nomination. In 1990 she affiliated with Hearst Entertainment, maintaining a successful career decades past the age considered employable in this youth dominated medium. Nothing stopped her-not being a senior citizen, not having a leg amputated in 1997 as a result of vascular disease. In 2001, she made two movies for ''Lifetime''''Dangerous Child'' and ''Snap Judgement''. In addition to her impressive television credits, she was known as a quilt collector. Quilts from her collection are peridically displayed at the Museum of American Folk Art in NYC. Feisty, fearless and fun loving, she'll be deeply missed by the cast of thousands who admired and loved her. She withheld nothing but her age. A memorial service will be Sunday, November 4th at 2PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Anthrax Forcing a Constant Rethinking of Policies and Procedures
description: First, people with the sniffles were told to stay out of emergency rooms. Public health officials warned about the dangers of widespread, precautionary use of antibiotics. When anthrax was discovered in an office, noses were swabbed.

title: Left in Nasser's Exhaust at Ford
description: Jacques A. Nasser, Detroit's New Economy chief executive officer, lasted longer than the new economy. But not much.

title: Sports of The Times; New Month, Old Tricks From Yanks
description: THE calendar had turned to a new month for the World Series. Derek Jeter was batting where baseball had never gone before, because of the layoff after the September attack.

title: OPEC President Says Cartel to Cut Output Starting on Jan. 1
description: Underscoring the growing resolve among the largest oil-producing nations to shore up declining prices, Chekib Khelil, the president of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, said today that the group would reduce daily oil output starting on Jan. 1.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: The Amsterdam office of Beyond the Line, part of the Young & Rubicam Advertising unit of Young & Rubicam, will become the Amsterdam office of Brand Buzz, the worldwide nontraditional marketing agency division of Young & Rubicam. Kees Klomp continues as managing director of the office. Young & Rubicam is part of the WPP Group.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLADSTONE, ROSE
description: GLADSTONE - Rose. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother, sister, aunt & friend. Memorial at Gilda's Club, 195 W. Houston St., Friday, November 2nd at 1:30PM.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HARTIG, HERBERT
description: HARTIG-Herbert. November 1, 1991. Hi Pesty. The borogroves are all mimsy. How uffish. Naom

title: The Sleeping Giant Wakes
description: LAST week the city's real estate market rose from its knees and walked again -- not with a swagger or a strut, but with the tiny, halting steps of a toddler.

title: Martinez and Jeter Rescue Yanks, Even Series
description: The dynasty Tino Martinez and Paul O'Neill and Derek Jeter helped build over thousands of innings, in hundreds of games, was almost out of time. The Yankees were two runs down with two outs in the bottom of the ninth in Game 4 of the World Series last night, about to be pushed to the brink of elimination.

title: Avista Shares Fall 12% to 21-Year Low
description: Shares of the Avista Corporation fell 12 percent today, touching a 21-year low, as the owner of utilities in the Northwest posted a third-quarter loss and cut its profit forecast for this year and 2002.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARBE, WILLIAM A.
description: BARBE-William A., Clayton, Dubilier & Rice, Inc. mourns the passing of a close friend and dedicated colleague. His grace, courage, humor and compassion will always be an inspiration to us. Our hearts and prayers are with his wife Nancy & three sons, Robert, Chase and Reed. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Greenwich Hospital Home Care Hospice Program or the Brain Tumor Center at Duke University.

title: Two Designers Whose Aesthetic Hearts Beat as One
description: Buying furniture from interior designers is like adopting a puppy from veterinarians: they can expertly assess how the addition will fit into your home. Two such professionals, Michael Reeves and Robert Marinelli (above, behind Mr. Reeves's Carnegie Hi-Back chair, $4,105), opened the RM/MR store in the meatpacking district last month. ''As an interior designer, I often couldn't find a plain sofa my client could embellish around,'' Mr. Reeves said. ''It was the same for Robert.'' Mr. Reeves, based in London, and Mr. Marinelli, based in New York, designed most of the furniture in RM/MR, and their aesthetics match as neatly as their palindromic initials. The walls are earth tones, and the concrete floors are a translucent metallic bronze. Mr. Marinelli's Rio cocktail table is $5,500. The lamp is $880. RM/MR 433 West 14th Street (10th Avenue), (212) 414-0488. AMY GOLDWASSER

title: Airports Press Ahead on Wireless Access
description: HIGH-SPEED wireless data networks, which many airports once saw as the perfect intersection of traveler, revenue and technology, have faced serious hurdles this year, including the demise of some Internet service providers and a lackluster response from travelers with laptop computers. Yet a handful of companies continue to expand their networks.

title: Be on the Lookout. We Can't Be Specific.
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Heading for the Exits With 81 Games to Go
description: WHERE were all the people going? It was 67-61 at the end of the third quarter Tuesday night in Madison Square Garden, and the hometown darlings in the opening game of the N.B.A. season were beating the Wizards and their wizened sorcerer before a sellout crowd of 19,763. The game was hardly in the bag, but you wondered if some of the fans were. Otherwise, why were they heading for the exits as if it were a fire drill -- or had a sale of Willis Reed shirts broken out on Seventh Avenue?

title: A Wisecracker, a Woman Who Loved to Give and a Jimmy Buffett Fan
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Screening, Not Cipro
description: To the Editor:

title: Input Devices Call On a Little Muscle
description: AMONG the many changes the Microsoft PowerPoint presentation software brought to public speaking was the introduction of that oft-repeated phrase ''Next slide.'' That is what speakers have to call out to their assistants unless they have a computer keyboard at hand.

title: No Mideast Analogy
description: To the Editor:

title: License Plates, Do Your Job
description: To the Editor:

title: Birthday Presents That Won't Be Ignored
description: EVERY year during the height of the autumn birthday party season, I suffer flashbacks. Whether this mental quirk is the result of sheer exhaustion from ferrying my 4-year-old to so many celebrations, I cannot say. But I do know that on a recent weekend morning, as we drove directly from an amusement park to a strobe-light-fun-house bash, I suddenly had visions of a troubling toy I had not thought of in years: the Tinkerbell-like Flying Thing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHALAN, FLORENCE D., MONSIGNOR
description: COHALAN-Florence D., Monsignor. The American Irish Historical Society mourns the loss of its longest serving Executive Council member, Monsignor Florence D. Cohalan, the son of Judge Daniel Cohalan, a great figure in the fight for Irish freedom. Monsignor Cohalan served for over 50 years as a leader of the Society. Kevin M. Cahill, M.D. President-General

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILLER, ARTHUR
description: HILLER-Arthur. We mourn the passing of Arthur Hiller, cherished father of our friend Bonnie Lipton, National President of Hadassah. We send our heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. May they find comfort among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem and be spared further sorrow. Marlene Post-Kalman Sultanik Co-Presidents, World Confederation of United Zionists

title: Saudis Freeze Funds Of 66 on U.S. List
description: Saudi Arabia has ordered a freeze on the assets of people and organizations that the United States has identified as sponsors of terrorism, Bush administration officials said today.

title: The Afghan Front: Lessons of Vietnam
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Imposes a Second Duty On Canadian Lumber Imports
description: The Commerce Department accused Canadian lumber producers of unfair trade practices today and imposed a double-digit duty on their exports to the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALTER, NELLY
description: WALTER-Nelly. Columbia Artists Management Inc. was deeply saddened by the loss of our longtime friend and colleague, Nelly Walter, on October 25, 2001. Miss Walter joined CAMI in June of 1946, only a few days after she had escaped from war-torn Europe and arrived in New York. Her extensive background and experience in classical music made her an enormous asset to the company, and in 1963 she became a vice president. During her fifty-two-year tenure here, Nelly Walter helped to build the careers of such artists as Leonard Bernstein, Renata Tebaldi, Cesare Siepi, Mirella Freni, Teresa Berganza, Giulietta Simionato, Irmgard Seefried, Montserrat Caballe, Jose Carreras, Placido Domingo, Leontyne Price, and many others. Despite her stature and success in the music business, she remained intensely private and always maintained that her job was to keep the spotlight on her artists. She worked harder and kept longer hours than many of her coworkers who were decades younger. When she retired in May of 1998, she was ninety-seven years old. She celebrated her 100th birthday this past January. Nelly Walter set an example of professional excellence and personal integrity for all of us who knew her. Her death is an enormous loss to her friends, her artists, and to the music industry. Ronald A. Wilford, Chairman and CEO, and The Board of Directors of Columbia Artists Management Inc

title: Argentine Leader in Talks to Avert Default on $132 Billion Debt
description: President Fernando de la Ra held intensive negotiations today with opposition governors, national labor leaders and legislative leaders in an effort to find support for a new economic plan and debt restructuring to prevent a default on Argentina's $132 billion public debt.

title: When the Camera Itself Boasts a Signature Style
description: Digital cameras combined with Webcams are the surf 'n' turf of personal technology: perfect for those who want a little bit of both but not too much of either. Last week, Logitech released two new combo cams -- the ClickSmart 310 and 510 -- that are designed more as digital cameras than as traditional Webcams. Both are priced at consumer-friendly levels, $79 and $149, and have specifications to match, good but not spectacular. Bruce Friedricks, director of marketing for Logitech's video division, said that the ClickSmart line was aimed at users who want to share their pictures via e-mail or by posting them on the Web. ''These are people who want to share the pictures right away with friends and family and don't want to wait for prints to come back,'' he said.

title: Continental Airlines Net Falls And America West Has a Loss
description: Continental Airlines said today that its third-quarter net income fell 98 percent, making a small profit with help from bailout money from the government. America West Holdings, a regional airline service, posted a loss as its ticket sales and fares fell after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: A Curfew Stands
description: A court challenge to a curfew and no-protest zone instituted by Mayor Paul Schell of Seattle during 1999 protests at a World Trade Organization meeting was rejected by a federal judge on Tuesday. Judge Barbara J. Rothstein of Federal District Court said the order banning protesters from a 24-block area was tailored to protect public safety and did not violate the First Amendment. The ruling will probably affect several suits by more than 600 people seeking damages from the city for being barred from the zone.

title: Below Ground Zero, Silver and Gold
description: About two weeks ago, a security team spotted scorch marks on a basement doorway below 4 World Trade Center, on the east side of the ruined complex, according to officials.

title: When a Killer Disease Held a Continent in Fear
description: POX AMERICANA

title: Warning on Funds for Employment Centers
description: Officials have warned the Giuliani administration that it is jeopardizing federal financing for its new one-stop employment centers because the one already operating in Jamaica, Queens, appears to be flouting federal guidelines.

title: Several Agencies Are Cutting Jobs
description: Layoffs are being made at several agencies.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 5 about a news briefing on the first of the series of pulmonary anthrax cases quoted incompletely from two comments by Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services. Parts of the incomplete quotations were repeated in an article on Sunday about the nation's minimal experience with anthrax.

title: INSIDE
description: Microsoft and Government Reported Near Settlement

title: To a Saudi Prince Bearing Gifts
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Passengers From Tokyo Are Detained In Seattle
description: F.B.I. agents and customs officials boarded a Northwest Airlines flight from Tokyo at Seattle-Tacoma International Airport today and removed two men in response to a biohazard threat, the authorities said. Passengers were held aboard the plane for two and a half hours.

title: Fighting Off Zombies and Insults From TV Hosts
description: THE town of Silent Hill is one creepy place. A thick, swirling fog blankets the town, headless zombies spit acid, and everywhere you go there are mysterious squealing and banging sounds. As a resort town, the locale of Konami's action-adventure game Silent Hill 2 leaves something to be desired, but as a setting for a horror game it is ideal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOULD, J.
description: GOULD-J. Spencer, 79. Of 47 Club Drive, Kensington, husband of Mary (Tredennick) Gould, died on Saturday, October 27, 2001 at New Britain General Hospital, New Britain, CT. He was a certified public accountant, whose career began with David Kessler in Albany, NY. He was a Partner in Meech and Harmond of Buffalo, NY, when it was acquired by the international CPA firm, Arthur Young Co., in 1957. In his 25-year career as Partner at Arthur Young Co., he served clients including Morgan Stanley, AMF, Arrow Electronics and Todd Shipyard. He retired from Arthur Young Co. in 1982. Mr. Gould was Chief Financial Officer for the Stanley Works of New Britain, retiring in 1987. He was a director of IMO Industries in Laurenceville, NJ and Arrow Electronics of Melville, NY. The funeral will be held on Thursday, November 1, 2001, at 10:00 AM in the First Church of Christ, Congregational, Court St., Middletown, CT with Pastor John Hall officiating. Burial with military honors will be in Walnut Grove Cemetery, Meriden, CT. Contributions in his memory may be made to Syracuse University, c/o Elizabeth B. O'Rourke, The Faculty Center, Syracuse, NY 13244.

title: CALENDAR
description: Art and Technology

title: Del Monte Foods Reports $800,000 Loss
description: The Del Monte Foods Company, a leading producer of canned fruits and vegetables, had a loss of $800,000 in its fiscal first quarter after spending more on marketing.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Scientists Link Tumors To Bone Marrow Cells
description: Scientists have found that cells from the bone marrow play an essential role in building the blood supply on which tumors depend. Their findings, they say, open a new avenue for attacking tumors by thwarting the bone marrow's contributory role.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: Challenge To Voting Machines
description: Less than a week before Election Day, Nassau County's Democratic Party filed a lawsuit yesterday challenging the way voting machines are handled, citing a potential for vote tampering. The suit seeks to remove from each machine a key known as the zero key, which is used to reset the vote counter. Most counties, the Democrats said, store the key separately during and after elections. In Nassau, however, anyone able to open the back of the machine, including poll workers, can reach the zero key. The party and its chairman, Jay S. Jacobs, filed the lawsuit in State Supreme Court here. A spokesman for the Nassau Republican chairman, Joseph N. Mondello, declined to comment until he could consult with the party's elections commissioner. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: World Champion Dies of Brain Injuries
description: Rgine Cavagnoud, the world champion super-G skier, died here this morning as a result of brain injuries from a collision in training.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: As Anthrax Cases Mount, the Tranquil Rhythms of Suburban Havens Are Disrupted
description: Four mail centers have been closed in central and southern New Jersey. Millions of pieces of mail remain signed, sealed, and waiting to be delivered. Six postal workers have apparently contracted anthrax, including one from the Camden area who was added to the list today. One woman from the Trenton area, unconnected to the postal system or the news media, has tested positive, too.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Reprieve For Hynix
description: Hynix Semiconductor won another reprieve with approval of a rescue package that guarantees $500 million in loans from its principal state-owned creditors. The package also provides for banks to exchange about $3 billion in loans for equity in Hynix Semiconductor, whose total debt is now about $8 billion. It said a broad coalition of creditors had agreed on the latest plan for its financial revamping. Four government-controlled banks, notably the Korea Exchange Bank, the lead creditor, as well as the Korea Development Bank, a government institution, played a major role in final acceptance of the plan, which was opposed by a number of creditors. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERRO, G.P. ''CHARLIE''
description: FERRO-G.P. ''Charlie'', 76. Of Boca Raton, Florida passed away on Monday October 29, 2001 in Florida. For service information please call Babione Funeral Home, 561-395-8787.

title: A World Series Wish
description: To the Editor:

title: Midnight Thunder in the Bronx
description: Whenever Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig hit late-inning home runs to win a Yankee game in that long-ago era of day baseball, it was known as Five O'Clock Lightning.

title: Kidd Again Shows the Nets The Importance of a Leader
description: The Nets have played two nail-biting games. They trailed by double-digits Tuesday night, and they led by a large margin tonight. But they now have two victories.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARNKE, PAUL C.
description: WARNKE-Paul C. Kalkines, Arky, Zall & Bernstein LLP is deeply saddened by the death of the father of our partner and friend, Stephen A. Warnke. We send our love and respect to his family.

title: Plan for More G.I.'s on the Ground, Economic Slump, Anthrax Unease
description: The United States shifted gears in its military campaign against Osama bin Laden and his Taliban protectors. Officials said that more teams of American advisers will be slipped into Afghanistan to work with rebel militias like the anti-Taliban Northern Alliance.

title: For Many of Those Held in a Legal Tangle, Little Is Revealed
description: With hundreds of people detained since the Sept. 11 attacks, and many of them still in custody, there are profound differences in their legal situations -- depending on their nationality, why they are being held and where.

title: President Took Mound at 60 Feet 6 Inches
description: An assistant for President Bush appeared in the clubhouse shortly before Game 3 and asked for a couple of gloves so the president could warm up before throwing out the ceremonial first pitch. His practice paid off: President Bush fired a strike, showing good velocity.

title: National Briefing | Education: Student Poll On War Issues
description: While college students overwhelmingly support sending American ground troops into Afghanistan, nearly 7 out of 10 oppose reinstating the draft, a nationwide poll shows. The poll, commissioned by the Institute of Politics at Harvard University, found that 71 percent of men and 49 percent of women would serve if drafted. Seven out of 10 college students say they have donated blood, given money or volunteered in relief efforts since the Sept. 11 attacks. The survey of 1,200 undergraduates, conducted by the Boston firm of SWR/DellaVolpe from Oct. 17 to 25, has a margin of error of plus or minus three percentage points.

title: Corrections
description: Achart in Business Day on Tuesday showing the percentage of households in selected areas that subscribe to cable and satellite television services carried incorrect figures from Nielsen Media Research and misidentified the markets with the highest concentrations of subscribers. A correction in this space yesterday also misidentified the market area with the largest percentage of cable subscribers. A corrected chart appears today, on Page C5.

title: Footlight
description: Cosmopolite

title: Rookie Lifts Panthers Past Rangers
description: If the Rangers are to transform the culture of losing that has permeated the organization for the past four seasons, Coach Ron Low has often argued, they are going to have to make Madison Square Garden an uncomfortable place for opponents to play.

title: Athletes More Concerned About Security in Salt Lake City
description: With every high-alert warning issued by the United States government, with each new case of anthrax that materializes, the threat of terrorism in America is causing Olympic officials and athletes around the world to rethink their participation in the Salt Lake City Olympics in February.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Prime Time for a Change

title: America Online as VCR And Social Secretary
description: The flying saucers -- those ubiquitous free America Online CD's in the mail, mall and magazines -- are back as AOL gears up to distribute Version 7.0 to the public.

title: To a Saudi Prince Bearing Gifts
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Profit Down At Deutsche Bank
description: Deutsche Bank, Europe's biggest bank, said third-quarter earnings fell 49 percent, dragged down by losses from investments in telecommunications companies. Profit dropped to 303 million euros ($274 million), or 79 cents a share, from 591 million euros, or 1.21 euros a share, in the period a year ago, said Ronald Weichert, a bank spokesman. Deutsche Bank had to write down the value of investments after the stock markets slumped. The company, based in Frankfurt, has been shedding 2,600 jobs and closing branches to trim costs as revenue declined.

title: Supreme Court Debate Focuses on Procedural Problems in Affirmative Action Case
description: Anyone who visited the Supreme Court's borrowed courtroom this morning expecting to hear a constitutional debate about affirmative action in federal contracting was in for a surprise.

title: Iranian Soccer Fans Celebrate; This Time, No Protest Breaks Out
description: Iran's Islamic authorities, disturbed by recent clashes this month between soccer fans and security forces, deployed a heavy police presence to avoid any repeat tonight and took the unusual step of delivering a huge cake within the city to mark a religious holiday and thus lend any celebrations the veneer of an official occasion.

title: On a Taliban-Guided Tour, Facts Prove Elusive
description: For the Taliban's purposes, which were to stress the morbid toll of civilian casualties, they picked a good day to provide outsiders with their first look at what three and a half weeks of American bombing has done to Kandahar.

title: Moss Returns to Jets Practice
description: The Jets' first-round pick in the N.F.L. draft last spring, Santana Moss, who had knee surgery during the first week of training camp, returned to practice today. Moss said he was hoping to be back for the Jets' game at Miami on Nov. 18. Miami is Moss's hometown and he played at the University of Miami. Moss was told last week by his surgeon, John Uribe, that he could begin cutting and running pass routes.

title: People
description: * Robin Webster, president and chief executive at the Interactive Advertising Bureau, New York, is taking a leave of absence for family reasons, the association said. Greg Stuart, a board member, will serve as interim head.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DETERMANN, PATRICIA MARIE (NEE FAHEY)
description: DETERMANN - Patricia Marie (nee Fahey). After a quiet, courageous battle with cancer. Native of L.I., NY. Beloved mother of 11 heartbroken children, 25 grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Leaves behind a husband of 52 years, Herman Determann.

title: Healthy Chebet Is Set To Go the Distance
description: Joseph Chebet is an enigma. A 31-year-old Kenyan, he is a marathon runner who seldom runs marathons or any other races. In addition, he is coming off two racing years ruined by injury and illness. Still, Chebet ranks among the men's favorites for Sunday's New York City Marathon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'CONNELL, ADELE Q. (NEE QUILGAN)
description: O'CONNELL-Adele Q. (nee Quilgan) 91 of Little Silver NJ formerly of New York City NY. On Tuesday October 30, 2001. Wife of the late James Timothy O'Connell, former Under Secretary of Labor during the Eisenhower administration. Father of (U.S. Army Ret. Col.) James T. O'Connell, Jr. and daughter-in-law Pauline O'Connell, Miss Katherine O'Connell, Anne Latona and son-in-law Donald Latona, Dorothy Cherry and Mary O'Connell and son-in-law Peter Grua. Grandmother of ten, great grandmother of seven. Visitation at the John E. Day Funeral Home, 85 Riverside Avenue, Red Bank NJ Friday 2-4 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Saturday, November 3, 2001 at 9AM at Church of the Nativity, Hance Road, Fairhaven NJ. Burial St. Raymond's R.C. Cemetery, Bronx NY. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory may be made to Mount St. Vincent's College, 6301 Riverdale Avenue, Riverdale NY 10471, or the Little Silver First Aid Squad, 543 Prospect Avenue, Little Silver NJ 07739 or the Visiting Nurse Association of Central Jersey, 141 Bodman Place, Red Bank, NJ 07701.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEINBERGER, ELIZABETH, M.D.
description: KLEINBERGER-Elizabeth, M.D. Professor Emeritus of Psychiatry at the Mount Sinai Hospital, died on October 28, 2001. Beloved sister of Helga Kleinberger-Speer. Interment private.

title: Bloomberg Stresses Private Business As Key to Revival
description: Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that the city's looming financial crisis, while serious, was not unmanageable and that private businesses, not aid from the federal government, would ultimately determine how well the city comes through it.

title: Final Event of Season Is Lacking Some Drama
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 31  Compared with other years, there is a shortage of drama heading into the season-ending Tour Championship that begins Thursday at Champions Golf Club.

title: Name It to Save It
description: THE house, a 40-year-old suburban split-level with detailing reminiscent of a Swiss chalet, looked like the last building that architectural preservationists would care about. But more than a dozen of them were focusing on a photo, trying to come up with a catchy name for the building's style.

title: The Afghan Front: Lessons of Vietnam
description: To the Editor:

title: MITSUBISHI BROADENS NO-INTEREST-FINANCING OFFER
description: The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation's United States sales unit broadened an offer that includes no-interest financing to all 2001 and 2002 models and extended it until Nov. 30, following larger automakers' incentives. The offer includes no down payment and no monthly payments until 2003, Mitsubishi Motor Sales of America Inc. said. The move follows the extension of no-interest loans by General Motors, Ford and DaimlerChrysler's Chrysler unit.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The recession has begun.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, AUGUSTA L.
description: GOLDSTEIN-Augusta L. Passed away on October 28, 2001. Born October 18, 1916 in New York City, where she lived for all but several years during WW II when her work with the Federal government took her to Washington, DC. Augusta had a long and proud career as Executive Secretary to the Hon. D. N. Edelstein. Augusta loved to do crosswords, play Scrabble, visit with friends and pursued interests in art and interior decoration. Augusta traveled extensively, both vacationing abroad and visiting family around the U.S. She was also active in HIAS. August was predeceased by her parents Sam and Sadie as well as her brothers Sidney, David and Phillip. Survivors include her sister-in-law Selma Goldstein of Reno, NV, and many cousins, nieces, nephews, grand nieces and grand nephews. A graveside service will be held at 1 PM Friday, November 2, at Beth El Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. Please call 800-522-0588 for directions.

title: A City Begins to Confront Its Racist Past
description: When Stan Rebert returned home in 1971 after finishing law school at Boston University, few people spoke of the race riots here in the summer of 1969. For three decades, a pair of homicides went unsolved, the cases seemingly buried along with the victims.

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of yesterday, 4,685 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, ROSE
description: KAUFMAN-Rose. Beloved wife of Sol. Devoted mother of Harvey and Alan. Loving grandmother of Jack, Julie, Ezra and Noah. Service Friday, 9:30AM, Norman L. Jeffer Community Chapels Inc., 4620 Fort Hamilton Parkway, Brooklyn. 718-853-4000.

title: Essay; Pushto Comes to Shove
description: Most people in Afghanistan including Taliban soldiers, suffering civilians and wavering warlords -- have one link to the outside world: shortwave and AM transistor radio. No television, FM, newspapers or Internet. Radio is it.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: Don't Forget Us, Bomb Victims Say
description: Kenyans wounded in the 1998 bombing of the American Embassy in Nairobi accused the United States government of failing to compensate them while rushing to the aid of those injured in the Sept. 11 attacks on New York and Washington. The victims insisted on cash payouts and dismissed as paltry the more than $40 million the United States has spent on medical care and reviving businesses. ''We consider Americans to be generous people,'' said Simon Maina Macharia, who suffered head and hand injuries. ''I think they can help us.''

title: Schumer and Mrs. Clinton Want F.B.I. to Share Facts
description: With strong bipartisan backing, New York's Democratic senators, Charles E. Schumer and Hillary Rodham Clinton, called for legislation today to encourage the F.B.I. to share information on terrorism with local and state police by removing legal barriers to such cooperation.

title: Pushing Limits, Finding None; Bold Rising Star at Lockheed Is Point Man on Prize Contract
description: To some of his colleagues at the Lockheed Martin Corporation, Charles Thomas Burbage seems to have come right out of the pages of ''The Right Stuff,'' Tom Wolfe's homage to the test pilots who broke the sound barrier and took the United States into space.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Tuesday showing the percentage of households in selected areas that subscribe to cable and satellite television services carried incorrect figures from Nielsen Media Research and misidentified the markets with the highest concentrations of subscribers. A correction in this space yesterday also misidentified the market area with the largest percentage of cable subscribers. A corrected chart appears today, on Page C5.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Last Missile Silo Destroyed
description: Ukrainian and American officials gathered 180 miles south of Kiev on Tuesday to witness the destruction of the nation's last intercontinental ballistic missile silo, a symbolic act that left Ukraine officially a non-nuclear state. Officials pressed a button to blow up the silo, the last of 170 missile sites inherited when the Soviet Union collapsed in 1991. Ukraine long ago returned all nuclear weapons to Russia and had since destroyed its nuclear bombers.

title: Anxiety Infuses November Art Sales
description: Christie's offices in Europe began getting panicked telephone calls two weeks ago from alarmed collectors who had received envelopes from Christie's in New York containing a mysterious white powder. A woman from Lausanne, Switzerland, was so concerned she called the police.

title: Be on the Lookout. We Can't Be Specific.
description: To the Editor:

title: Hothouse Romantic Brooding Under the California Sun
description: For 17 years the Southern California sun did its best to warm one of Central Europe's darker and more troubled souls. Messianic, self-absorbed and ever conscious of his enemies, Arnold Schoenberg arrived here in 1934. He had set out on a course of composing that, in his words, would guarantee ''the hegemony of German music'' for a century to come, but now the Germans were at his heels.

title: National Briefing
description: NORTHWEST

title: Reader's Digest Reports a Loss
description: The Reader's Digest Association had a fiscal first-quarter loss as sales fell 9.8 percent. But its shares rose 13 percent after the company said second-quarter results would be better than forecast.

title: Profit Increases 25% at Martha Stewart
description: Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia said yesterday that third-quarter profit climbed 25 percent as magazine advertising sales increased.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Long Economic Expansion Ends With Quarterly Drop

title: Sight of a B-52 Makes Northern Alliance Troops Shout With Joy
description: Lumbering across the sky, the mammoth plane with four long white exhaust plumes confused Northern Alliance soldiers here at first. They had seen scores of American F-16's streak by and a smattering of B-1 bombers soar high overhead.

title: Authorities Say California Bridges May Face Threat
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation issued an alert to law enforcement agencies in California today, warning of a possible threat to suspension bridges on the West Coast in early November.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Loss At Deutsche Telekom
description: Europe's biggest phone company, Deutsche Telekom, had a record 1.8 billion euro ($1.6 billion) loss in the third quarter because of costs tied to the acquisition of VoiceStream Wireless in the United States. Deutsche Telekom has posted losses for four consecutive quarters as it spent $35 billion on VoiceStream. The company, led by the chief executive, Ron Sommer, also bought mobile-phone licenses for $15 billion last year, which added to its debt. Deutsche Telekom's loss including gains and charges was 750 million euros in the quarter, said a spokesman, Ulrich Lissek. The company earned 4.1 billion euros a year earlier. Excluding the gains, analysts were expecting a loss of 1.38 billion euros.

title: Quiet Aqueduct Sees A Much Busier Future
description: Stephen Diliberto recognized the overcast skies and the cool air that greeted the 44-day fall meet at Aqueduct. After all, Diliberto, an 83-year-old retiree, has rarely missed opening day. It's what lies ahead for this track in the South Ozone Park section of Queens that he cannot envision: video lottery terminals, as many as 2,500 of them, sharing space with horseplayers.

title: World Series Audio: Game 4
description: Postgame audio from Game 4 of the World Series between the Yankees and the Arizona Diamondbacks provided by SportsAudio.net.

title: U.S. SEEKS CHANGES IN GERM WAR PACT
description: In the wake of anthrax attacks that have killed 4 and sickened some 12 others, the Bush administration is discussing new proposals with its allies that would make it a crime for individuals to buy, build or acquire a biological weapon for terrorist attacks.

title: A House Whose Rooms Serenely Climb the Walls
description: It took nearly 30 years for Wall House 2 to make the leap from blueprint to reality. By September, when it was completed in Groningen, the Netherlands, its architect, John Hejduk, a former dean of Cooper Union's architecture school, had been dead more than a year. The house, with rooms suspended from a wall, had more than 12,000 visitors in one month, said Steven Hillyer, the acting director of Cooper Union's Architecture Archive and curator of ''Wall House 2: John Hejduk,'' an exhibition of 40 photographs, illustrations and architectural models opening on Tuesday at Cooper Union. Mr. Hejduk designed more than 40 Wall houses, but No. 2 (known as the Bye House for its original client) is the only one that has been built. ''Life has to do with walls; we're continuously going in and out, back and forth, and through them,'' Mr. Hejduk wrote in Progressive Architecture magazine in 1974. ''A wall is the quickest, the thinnest, the element we're always transgressing.'' Muted, saturated colors define the curvy rooms. The bedroom is green, the dining room and kitchen are lavender, and the living room is yellow. The studio is terra cotta. Niek Verdonk, a Dutch architect, and Thomas Mller, a German architect, executed the design of the house, with its stucco walls, which cost $600,000 to build. It is to be sold with a proviso that the public can visit it one month a year. Through Nov. 30 at Cooper Union, East Seventh Street at Third Avenue. Free. Information: (212) 353-4220. ELAINE LOUIE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOBER, BERNICE
description: SOBER-Bernice, 86. Passed away on October 30. She is survived by her son, James, and her two-yearold granddaughter, Simone, and sister, Sylvia, & many other loving family & friends. Funeral services at Campbell's, 1076 Madison Ave. (81st Street), Friday, 3 PM.

title: Perle Surrounds Copland In a Program of Contrasts
description: Before he performed Copland's sprawling Piano Fantasy in the Great Hall at Cooper Union on Thursday night, the pianist Michael Boriskin informed the audience that William Masselos had given the world premiere of the work in New York 44 years before, to the day.

title: Hearst-Argyle Reports Loss
description: Hearst-Argyle Television reported a third-quarter loss yesterday and said that it expected revenue in the fourth quarter to drop as much as 21 percent. The third-quarter loss was $6.8 million, or 7 cents a share, compared with a profit of $9.1 million, or 10 cents, a year earlier. The company said sales fell 19 percent, to $145.2 million, from $178.4 million. Hearst-Argyle, which owns 28 TV stations and 2 radio stations, expected a profit of 1 cent to 5 cents a share in the fourth quarter.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: To Prune or Not to Prune

title: To a Saudi Prince Bearing Gifts
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Electronics Slowdown
description: Hurt by a downturn in spending for computers and electronics, Sharp and Pioneer reported lower earnings for the six months ended Sept. 30 and cut their full-year outlooks. Sharp, Japan's largest maker of liquid-crystal display screens, said net profit fell 14 percent from the similar period a year earlier, as sales of the screens fell 29 percent. The company also cut its full-year profit outlook 40 percent. Pioneer, a big maker of audio equipment, said profit slipped 23 percent in the half year, and it halved its full-year earnings forecast. Also yesterday, the Japan Electronics and Information Technology Industries Association said shipments of personal computers dropped 22 percent in the period from July to September from the comparable period a year ago, the first decline in three years. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPRINGER, JOHN SHIPMAN
description: SPRINGER-John Shipman. Of New York City on October 30, 2001. Husband of June (Reimer), father of Gary, Alicia and Cynthia, grandfather of five. Also survived by brother Dr. Wilfred Springer and wife Elizabeth, sisters-in-law Theresa Springer and Marilyn Hogan and many nieces and nephews. Native of Rochester, New York. Long time member of New York theater and film community. Visitation Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Thursday, November 1 from 2:00-4:00 and 7:00-9:00 P.M. Mass of Christian burial, St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Ave. at 66 St., Friday, November 2 at 10:00 A.M. Donations can be sent to The Players, 16 Gramercy Park, New York, NY 10003 and to The Harm Reduction Coalition, 22 West 27 St., New York, NY 10001.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Former Foes Discuss Alliance
description: Leaders of the governing African National Congress and the New National Party, which created apartheid, met to discuss forming an alliance. The New National Party pulled out of the Democratic Alliance, the nation's leading white opposition party, after its leaders clashed. Dozens of New National Party members oppose the proposed partnership with the African National Congress but congress officials said they were willing to consider it.

title: Rising Muslim Power in Africa Causes Unrest in Nigeria and Elsewhere
description: After Friday Prayers recently, hundreds of Muslims gathered in front of the emir's palace here and held a peaceful demonstration against the American campaign in Afghanistan. But the peace in this ancient Muslim city, already tense from a recent surge in religious clashes elsewhere in this West African nation, did not hold.

title: Brenly's Good Moves Don't Matter
description: In the first World Series game ever to stretch into November, Joe Torre and Bob Brenly sat in their respective dugouts last night scrutinizing the fruits of their strategic decisions in Game 4.

title: Connecticut Death Tied to West Nile Virus
description: A Connecticut resident who developed neurological symptoms in late September and died in mid-October is presumed to have died of West Nile virus, health authorities said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NORDOS, GLADYS
description: NORDOS-Gladys, 89. Died August 29, 2001. Widow of Wilbur R. Nordos, Director (1966-72), Division for Intercultural Relations, NYS Department of Education. Survived by 3 daughters, 6 grandchildren. Burial, November 3, 11 AM, Tongore Cemetery, Olive Bridge, NY. Service, 12 PM, Olive Bridge United Methodist Church. Memorial gifts earmarked for child victims of World Trade Center disaster to United Lutheran Appeal, 366 North Broadway, Jericho, NY 11753.

title: Colombia: The Next Oil Patch
description: With its unending guerrilla conflict, difficult geography and bureaucratic hurdles, Colombia has struggled for years to attract new foreign companies to explore for oil and to keep those already here.

title: Be on the Lookout. We Can't Be Specific.
description: To the Editor:

title: The Afghan Front: Lessons of Vietnam
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Media Acquisition
description: An Irish billionaire, Tony O'Reilly, is selling his 40 percent stake in Wilson & Horton, publisher of The New Zealand Herald, to another company he controls, APN News and Media, publisher of several newspapers in eastern Australia. APN will also assume 29 million Australian dollars ($14.6 million) in long-term debt. Analysts said the deal had no operating synergies that would allow cost-saving measures and might be a prelude to an acquisition. APN's deputy chairman, Ted Harris, said the new media company would have a stronger platform for growth.

title: Battling the Skepticism Of a Global TV Audience
description: CNN yesterday broadcast the latest images of bombing damage in Kandahar, panning across scenes of rubble and destruction on the streets of the Afghan city. The network then quickly switched to the rubble of the World Trade Center in New York City as the anchor, Bill Hemmer, reminded viewers of the deaths of as many as 5,000 people whose ''biggest crime was going to work and getting there on time.''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Rum For Sale
description: Diageo will begin talks this week to sell its Malibu coconut rum, in an effort to appease United States regulators, who last week blocked its acquisition of the Seagram beverage assets on anticompetitive grounds. By selling Malibu, Diageo is hoping to overcome concerns about its dominance in rum. Through Seagram, Diageo would acquire Captain Morgan, the world's No. 2 rum after Bacardi. Bidders for Malibu, the No. 3 rum, include Pernod Ricard, the French company with which Diageo is already dividing some Seagram assets; Fortune Brands; Brown-Forman; Allied Domecq; and venture capital firms. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Schools to Resume Field Trips
description: Public schools on the Upper West Side and in part of Harlem have been told that their students can resume field trips on Monday, the district superintendent said yesterday. Trips had been canceled because of fears that children would not be safe in the wake of the terrorist attack in New York City.

title: Former Congressman's Son Opposes Councilman's Aide
description: Campaigning outside a supermarket in a Queens neighborhood in the backyard of Kennedy International Airport, Joseph P. Addabbo Jr. seemed to have no trouble being recognized by a large number of shoppers. Many stopped to wish him well in his race for a City Council seat against Joann Ariola.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Accounts On U.S. List Frozen
description: The government has frozen 24 bank accounts linked to individuals or groups that the United States suspects of having terrorist ties, the federal prosecutor's office said. The accounts, all connected with the 39 people or groups on the second of two lists issued by the United States, have been blocked indefinitely while the Swiss ask the United States for evidence against the account holders. There was no information on how much money is in the accounts. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor's Nominee Approved
description: The City Council, on a technicality, failed to stop a mayoral appointment yesterday, even though a majority of the Council opposed the nominee. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had nominated Jane Gol to the City Planning Commission. Ms. Gol, whose term will expire in June 2005, will replace Kathy Hirata Chin, the commission's only Asian-American appointee. Several council members had objected to Ms. Gol because, they said, the appointment would make the commission less representative of the city. A Council majority voted against Ms. Gol. But a few of those voting against the appointment abstained from the required vote to file the measure, nullifying the vote's defeat. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: In America; Hungry and Jobless
description: ''Our members,'' said John Turchiano, ''have never been in this position before.''

title: Rivals Are Moving to Lure Top Authors From Penguin
description: Rival book publishers hoping to lure best-selling writers like Tom Clancy and Patricia Cornwell have quietly begun attempting to poach authors from Penguin Putnam as Phyllis Grann departs as the house's longtime chief executive at the end of the year.

title: The Afghan Front: Lessons of Vietnam
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Sets Nov. 30 Deadline For Economic Stimulus Plan
description: Confronted with the firmest evidence yet that the country has slipped into recession, President Bush demanded today that Congress break a partisan deadlock and send him an economic recovery package within the next month.

title: Stem Cell Registry to Be Posted Within a Week, Official Says
description: A much-anticipated registry of human embryonic stem cells that could be used for federally financed research should be available to scientists and the public within a week, a government health official said today.

title: Dubai Clinic Denies Report Bin Laden Met With CIA
description: PARIS  A wave of skepticism and outright denials greeted a French newspaper report Wednesday that Osama bin Laden had been hospitalized in a Dubai clinic for kidney care for 10 days in July and met there with a U.S. intelligence operative  just weeks before the Sept. 11 attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon.

title: Brothers Act Behind the Scenes to Build a Taliban Alternative
description: Soon after 10-year-old Joseph Ritchie arrived in Kabul with his parents in 1957, he fell in love with Afghanistan.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Rockville: Ex-Sheriff's Court Case
description: A lawyer for a former sheriff accused of embezzlement and corrupt election practices has asked a judge to dismiss charges against his client. Thomas White, who was Windham County high sheriff from 1998 until the sheriff system was abolished in Connecticut last year, is charged with depositing campaign donations and other funds into his personal bank account. Mr. White's lawyer, Joseph Courtney, said the practice was not illegal and had been widespread among deputy sheriffs, none of whom has been arrested on similar charges. Mr. White is scheduled for trial Dec. 4. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, ROBERT Z.
description: ROSENTHAL-Robert Z. The Directors of the Zeitz Foundation express our profound sorrow at the passing of our dear friend and colleague. He will be sorely missed, especially his warm friendship and good cheer. We extend our condolences to his sons, Joseph and Robert and his entire family.

title: Entangled With War on Terror, Threat of Global Recession
description: For seven weeks now, President Bush has been preoccupied with managing a global war on terrorism. With the announcement today that the American economy shrank in the third quarter, he is faced with managing another complex and often intertwined crisis: The prospect of a global recession.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROWAN, HELEN G.
description: ROWAN-Helen G., March 27, 1911October 23, 2001, leaves two daughters, Helen Downey McCooey and Margot R. Horn, four grandchildren Melissa, John, Erin, Victoria; four great grandchildren Gregory, Christian, Andrew, Chloe; a sister Sr. Mary Jude, RSM. Memorial Mass on Saturday, November 3rd at noon, Sacred Hearts Church, Southampton, NY. Memorial donations may be made to the Helen G. Rowan Memorial, C/O NY Horse Rescue Corp., PO Box 435, Manorville, NY 11949.

title: Giving Home Offices A Little Flexibility
description: EIGHTY-TWO percent of Americans say they have a home office, according to a study released last month by Logitech, a computer accessories maker in California. Even though the study showed that some people have a whole room to work in, many have to carve out a niche in another space.

title: A Bad Day for Attendance in City Schools
description: Public schools throughout New York City reported unusually high absentee rates yesterday, with only 62 percent of the city's 1.1 million students showing up for class.

title: A Large Family of Glasses, Each With Its Own Personality
description: Sets of glasses are often variations on a single shape. Not so the new Liquids Glass collection created by Defne Koz, a Turkish designer working in Milan. The Liquids forms are mouth-blown and finished by hand. There are 12 in the set, including from left, short water, $17, tall water, $45, and champagne, also $45. The line of lead-free crystal falls into a niche between machine-made stemware, up to $28 each, and other handmade glasses like Baccarat, which can cost more than $100. At Melissou, 200 Mott Street, (917) 237-0790. STEPHEN TREFFINGER

title: From Thailand, Adventures In Collective Storytelling
description: In ''Mysterious Object at Noon,'' the director Apichatpong Weerasethakul has devised a distinct kind of entertainment. Early on in this hybrid documentary, made in Thailand, a young woman who is not an actress relates a horrible incident. Her father, short of money to get home from a trip, sold her to her uncle. As she gets through the story, questioning her own worth, the off-camera director asks her a peculiar question: ''Now, do you have any other stories to tell us? It can be real or fiction.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAGAMATSU, GEORGE R., M.D.
description: NAGAMATSU-George R., M.D. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family acknowledges with sadness the passing of our dear friend and longtime colleague, George R. Nagamatsu, M.D., a former member of the medical staff at Beth Israel's Singer Division for many years. To his wife, Kazuko, and all of his loved ones, we extend heartfelt condolences. Matthew E. Fink, M.D. President and CEO Sidney K. Stein, M.D. President, Medical Board Donald W. Hoskins, M.D. Chief Medical Officer and Medical Director Harris M.
