Nagler, M.D. Chairman, Department of Urology Robert L. Salant, M.D. President, Doctors Alumni Assoc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAIM, VICTOR
description: HAIM-Victor. It is with deep sorrow that we record the untimely passing of our esteemed member Victor Haim and extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Mary and children Marc, Robert and Jacqueline. Old Westbury Golf & Country Club Frank D'Ambrosio, President Charles Baraf, Secretary

title: Doctors Say Call to Get Flu Shots Could Backfire
description: Infectious-disease experts say problems could arise from the advice offered by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and some doctors, who have suggested that people be vaccinated against influenza so they do not confuse early signs of inhalation anthrax with a case of the flu.

title: U.S. Will Buy Asian Wheat to Give Afghans
description: The Bush administration said today that it would spend $11.2 million on wheat and other food supplies from Central Asian countries for immediate shipment to Afghanistan to avert a worsening hunger crisis there.

title: Public Apprehension Felt In Europe Over the Goals Of Afghanistan Bombings
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair began yet another diplomatic mission today -- this time to the Middle East -- but at home and elsewhere in Europe, public unease with the course of the war in Afghanistan and its rationale was on the rise.

title: Tough Economic Times Ahead
description: Yesterday President Bush bluntly encouraged Congress to ''get to work'' on an economic stimulus package and bring a bill to his desk by the end of this month. The matter is indeed urgent, and the combination of quick action by Congress and steady rates from the Federal Reserve offer the best hope for turning the economy around.

title: U.S. Team Reaches Final Of Bermuda Bowl in Paris
description: An American team advanced to the final of the Bermuda Bowl for open teams at the world championships here today. The United States No. 2 team began the day with a 23 imp lead against Poland, lost 10 in the first segment of 16 deals, but surged to a 36 imp victory at the finish.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GEORGIA-PACIFIC GROUP, Atlanta, the world's second largest lumber and paper company, said it would close two plants, one in North Carolina and the other in Wisconsin, and lay off 231 workers because of reduced demand for hardboard, which is used in furniture and car interiors.

title: H. Gerard Bissinger II, 75, Former Bond Firm President
description: H. Gerard Bissinger II, a former president of the municipal bond firm Lebenthal & Company, died on Oct. 25 at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 75 and lived on the Upper West Side.

title: MKS TO BUY EMERSON ELECTRIC FOR ABOUT $251 MILLION
description: MKS Instruments Inc., a maker of instruments used to produce computer chips, agreed to buy a semiconductor-equipment manufacturing unit of the Emerson Electric Company for about $251 million in stock. The purchase will be completed in the first quarter and will add to MKS's profit next year, the company said. Emerson will own 12 million shares, or about 24 percent of MKS's stock, after the sale. MKS will also assume 3.5 million in debt. Emerson's ENI unit, based in Rochester, makes solid-state radio frequency and direct-current plasma power supplies for the semiconductor industry. Emerson, based in St. Louis, is the largest maker of motors for telecommunications and computer networks. MKI is based in Andover, Mass.

title: Corrections
description: A film review of ''Donnie Darko'' on Friday referred incorrectly to the age of Duran Duran's song ''Notorious.'' It was released in 1986, not in the 1990's, and was therefore correctly used in the film, which is set in 1988.

title: John Springer, 85, Hollywood Publicist, Dies
description: John Springer, a press agent who represented a galaxy of stars (including Marilyn Monroe, Judy Garland, Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton) and closely guarded their secrets, died on Tuesday at a hospital in Manhattan. He was 85 and lived in Manhattan.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: CANADIAN DOLLAR DROPS. The Canadian dollar fell as slowing economic growth make Canada a less attractive place to invest. In New York, the Canadian dollar settled at 63.01 cents, down from 63.38 cents on Tuesday.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Executive Resigns
description: Sir Peter Bonfield, chief executive of British Telecommunications, said he would leave the company in January, a year before his contract expires. The decision is an about-face for Sir Peter, left, who two weeks ago said he would remain until the end of his contract in December 2002. The company said it had not yet named a successor. Under Sir Peter, the company invested in Europe, Asia and the United States, eventually amassing more than $40 billion in debt. A sharp downturn in the fortunes of telecommunications companies has forced British Telecommunications to sell many of those assets. Its longtime chairman, Iain Vallance, resigned in April, and its chief financial officer, Robert Brace, left a year ago.

title: ALLTEL TO BUY ABOUT 600,000 PHONE LINES FROM VERIZON
description: The Alltel Corporation agreed to buy about 600,000 local telephone lines in Kentucky from Verizon Communications Inc. for $1.9 billion in cash, an Alltel spokesman said. The transaction follows CenturyTel Inc.'s agreement last week to buy 675,000 Verizon lines in rural Alabama and Missouri for $2.16 billion. Alltel is a rural telephone services provider based in Little Rock, Ark.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Profit Shortfall
description: Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria, Spain's second-largest bank, has followed its rival, Santander Central Hispano, in announcing lower-than-expected profit so far this year, saying nine-month net income rose 16 percent, to 1.82 billion euros ($1.67 billion). Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria said profit for 2001 was expected to rise 16 percent, down from the 24 percent forecast by the bank and analysts, partly because of the creation of a 200 million euro special contingency fund. Santander, Spain's largest bank, also issued a profit warning this week. Emma Daly (NYT)

title: S.E.C. Opens Investigation Into Enron
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has opened a formal investigation into transactions among the Enron Corporation and partnerships headed by Andrew S. Fastow, the company's former chief financial officer, Enron said yesterday.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: $15 Million For 'Wrong Man'
description: A federal jury in Chicago has awarded $15 million in damages to a man who served 15 years in prison for a killing he did not commit. The man, James Newsome, 46, was sentenced to life in prison without parole in 1979 and was released in 1994 after fingerprint technology determined that another man was the murderer. Last week, the same federal jury found that detectives rigged the lineup in 1979 so witnesses would pick Mr. Newsome. The city has said it will probably appeal the $15 million verdict. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDOR, CHRISTINA
description: SANDOR-Christina. Born Satzger von Balvanyos in Vienna passed away on October 26, 2001. She was widowed to Archduke Carlos Habsburg Bourbon, once claimant to the throne of Spain and married to Gyorgy Sandor, renowned concert pianist and protege of the composer Bela Bartok. She is survived by her two daughters Alejandra & Inmaculada Habsburg and her son Michael Sandor. She is also survived by her grandchildren: Alejandra, Carlos, and Pedro Riera & by Carlos, Juan-Leopoldo, and Anthony Dobkin. Her greatgrandchildren are Mar and Violeta Montaner and Laura and Blanca Riera. She is also mourned by Jose Maria Riera, John Dobkin, and Eunice Sandor and by Baldo Montaner, Mireia Mateu & Alienor Benoist. Carmen Galicia, who cared for her with great love during her most vulnerable years, grieves with us as a member of our family. Her memorial Mass will be held at St. Thomas More Church, 65 East 89th Street on Friday, November 2, 11 AM.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of All Saints' Day, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Numbers Prove U.S. Economy Has Retreated
description: The longest economic expansion in American history has ended.

title: Bioterrorism And Anxiety Are Swelling Prescriptions
description: In the period of anxiety and bioterrorism after the attacks of Sept. 11, many Americans have turned to prescription drugs, according to new data from IMS Health, the nation's leading supplier of pharmaceutical information.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMILOW, ALEX
description: SMILOW-Alex. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun mourns the passing of the beloved brother of our devoted member, Herman Smilow. We extend our condolences to the entire bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Rabbi Joshua Lookstein, Chaim Edelstein, President

title: Ensuring a Safe Flight
description: WASHINGTON -- The Sept. 11 terrorist attacks laid bare long-known flaws in airport security and rendered them intolerable. President Bush opposes a complete federal takeover of airport security but, to see the security problems addressed, might sign legislation establishing such a takeover. That shouldn't be necessary.

title: Spencer Enjoying His Role This Year
description: Shane Spencer severely damaged his knee in July 2000, which abruptly terminated his season and then made him hesitant to return and witness the American League Championship Series. But Spencer eventually convinced himself that being with the Yankees was the right place for him. He was a member of the team and he deserved to be a part of the celebration.

title: Bush Team Rejects U.N. Plan To Condemn Anthrax Attacks
description: The Bush administration has rejected a proposal by France to win Security Council condemnation of the anthrax attacks in the United States, senior administration and European officials said today.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Publisher Plans E-Books For Children
description: Random House said yesterday that it would begin selling children's books in electronic format on Nov. 13. The books, for children ages 8 to 18, will be available in the Microsoft Reader, Adobe eBook Reader and Palm Reader formats and will sell for $3.99 each, Random House said. Random House, a unit of Bertelsmann A.G., will initially offer 17 titles from children's authors like Gary Paulsen, Christopher Paul Curtis, Patricia Reilly Giff and Philip Pullman. The books will be sold through online retailers and Yahoo's eBooks Shopping Web site.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Let the Cars Squeal

title: To a Saudi Prince Bearing Gifts; A Friend in Riyadh
description: To the Editor:

title: Yanks' Power Gives Pitcher a Lesson
description: The Yankees provided another lesson last night in the continuing education of Byung Hyun Kim. There was the 22-year-old Kim, the first South Korean-born player to appear in a World Series, dominating the champion Yankees. He was one out away from putting his team one victory from a World Series title.

title: Lyrics for Windows
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PREM, FRANK HERBERT III (TERRY)
description: PREM-Frank Herbert III (Terry). Age 37, of Housatonic, MA, died on October 24, 2001 of injuries sustained in an automobile accident. He is survived by his father, F. Herbert Prem Jr., and his stepmother, Patricia Ryan Prem of New York, NY; his mother, Barbara Herrick and stepfather, Scott Herrick of West Stockbridge, MA; and his sister, Julia Nichols Prem of Housatonic, MA. Private services Wednesday, October 31, at South Berkshire Friends Meeting House, Great Barrington, MA. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to The Terry Prem Scholarship Fund at Freedom Institute, 515 Madison Ave., New York, New York 10022.

title: METROSTARS ELIMINATED
description: The MetroStars were defeated by Millonarios of Colombia, 1-0, last night at Giants Stadium before a crowd of 7,721 and were eliminated from Copa Merconorte. Johan Viafara scored the goal two minutes into stoppage time to advance the Colombians to the semifinals, where they will meet Nexaca of Mexico.

title: A Fall Classic: Yanks Win, 4-3
description: One more out was all Arizona needed. One more out and the Diamondbacks would take firm command of the World Series.

title: U.S. Says 3 Detainees May Be Tied to Hijackings
description: Attorney General John Ashcroft disclosed for the first time today that the government had apprehended suspects who were believed to have had advance knowledge of the Sept. 11 hijackings.

title: Beelzebub, Pussycats and Bomb Squads
description: Twenty-four hours after turning Yankee Stadium into a fortress, New York's law enforcement agencies faced another daunting task last night: securing the Village Halloween Parade, a raucous street celebration that has no physical perimeters, no entrances or exits, but rather winds through an entire Manhattan neighborhood.

title: Several Agencies Are Cutting Jobs
description: Layoffs are being made at several agencies.

title: You Clocked What? For Marathon Runners, It's Gun vs. Chip
description: OFFICIALLY, it took Katherine Tromble 3 hours 32 minutes 39 seconds to run the Marine Corps Marathon last weekend. But ask her about her finishing time and she will lop off the 39 seconds.

title: Practice of Shooting Down Drug Planes in Peru Seems Sidelined
description: The Bush administration should not resume its policy of helping shoot down planes suspected of carrying drugs over Peru until safety procedures are radically improved, the Senate Intelligence Committee said today.

title: Turkey to Send Forces to Afghanistan
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 1  Turkey said today that it will deploy 90 special forces troops to Afghanistan, making it the first Muslim nation to join the American-led attacks on the Taliban and Osama bin Laden.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORNREICH, JOANNE
description: KORNREICH-JoAnne. Beloved wife of Morton, devoted mother of James and Meredith, Thomas and Barbara, and Nancy and Robert Rieger, adored and adoring grandmother of Todd, Jennifer, Maggie, Caroline, Adam, Zachary, Molly, and Alex, and dear friend of Larcenia. Services Friday 11:30 A.M. at Temple Emanu-El, 2125 Westchester Avenue East, Rye, New York. For information call: Plaza Jewish Community Chapel at 1-800-227-3974.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELLER, MONA S.
description: FELLER-Mona S. Of Riverdale, NY, formerly of Jersey City, NJ. Beloved wife of the late Dr. William Feller. Devoted mother of Patricia Neistadt of Riverdale, NY, Karen Mitnick of Haworth, NJ and Bruce Feller of Wayne, NJ. Loving grandmother of David, Meryl and Barbara Neistadt, Erica and Emily Mitnick. Sister of Syd and May. Services on Friday 11:30 AM at Riverdale Temple, Independence Avenue, Riverdale, New York.

title: Shopping Lists for Troubled Times
description: THE day after the terrorist attacks in Manhattan, Ilene Walerstein, a 40-year-old marketing manager, was evacuated from her apartment because of a bomb threat at the Empire State Building nearby. Since then, Ms. Walerstein has made a few decisions about the technology she wants to purchase. ''Larger electronics and appliances are just not a priority right now,'' she said.

title: Miscellany
description: * Frankel, Chicago, part of the Publicis Groupe, agreed to acquire Creative Alliance Marketing and Communications, Southport, Conn. Terms were not disclosed. Creative Alliance will be renamed Creative AIMSM and operate as an autonomous unit of Frankel.

title: Ads Are Crowding Batter's Box on TV
description: On Sunday during Game 2 of the World Series, I saw them: those gargantuan ads squatting behind home plate. Bigger than the Big Unit, more distracting than Elmer Fudd singing the lead in ''Otello.''

title: Technology Shares Rebound, With the Nasdaq Up 22.79
description: Desperate for good news, the stock market at first rallied yesterday after the Commerce Department reported that the nation's gross domestic product declined in the third quarter, but less than Wall Street economists and analysts had feared.

title: House G.O.P. Would Lend, Not Give, Money to Insurers
description: With time running short, senior Republicans in the House of Representatives are preparing a financial assistance plan for the insurance industry that, unlike the White House and Senate proposals, would have the government lend rather than give the insurers money for any future terrorist attacks, Congressional officials said today.

title: Shoah and Computers
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Chip Outlook Remains Dull
description: The Sept. 11 terrorist attacks deepened an already steep slide in chip sales for 2001, and any recovery in 2002 will be slight, a market research firm predicted. The firm, Gartner Dataquest, which is based in San Jose, Calif., said worldwide semiconductor revenue would be $147 billion this year, a 35 percent decline from last year, the industry's sharpest downturn ever. Even if demand improves, the report said, the average selling price of chips will continue to cut into sales through year's end. Gartner forecast mild growth next year of 3 percent, to $152 billion. An improved economy, pent-up demand for electronics and personal computers, and new technologies like next-generation cellular networks will lead the chip industry to 30 percent growth in 2003, Gartner said. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: ALLIED WASTE SHARES FALL 22% AFTER EXECUTIVE RESIGNS
description: Shares of Allied Waste Industries, North America's second-largest trash hauler, fell as much as 22 percent after the president and chief operating officer, Larry Henk, resigned. The stock fell $2.53 to $9.93 and was the biggest decliner on the New York Stock Exchange. Mr. Henk's resignation was announced late Tuesday, eight days before the company was scheduled to report third-quarter earnings. Henk, president since August 2000 and chief operating officer since February 1998, left immediately to ''pursue other interests,'' the company said in a statement. An Allied Waste spokesman, Michael Burnett, declined to elaborate.

title: To a Saudi Prince Bearing Gifts
description: To the Editor:

title: Appeals Court Is Rejecting 8 Convictions In '96 Crash
description: The maintenance company that mishandled airplane parts that caused the ValuJet Airlines crash five years ago won a reversal of eight of nine criminal convictions today. And a lawyer for the company said that state officials had agreed to drop a murder charge against his client.

title: To a Saudi Prince Bearing Gifts
description: To the Editor:

title: Bullpens Make All Difference Yet Again
description: The Yankees have built a dynasty with baseball's best bullpen, shortening postseason games and suffocating opponents. So when their invincible endgame finally showed a crack last night, the Yankees' championship run appeared ready to break with it.

title: Symphonic Variations
description: To the Editor:

title: Martinez and Jeter Pump Life Into Yankees Just in Time
description: Tino Martinez swung at the first pitch he saw from Byung Hyun Kim, sending it over the fence in center field, sending Yankee Stadium into a frenzy and keeping the Yankees from dying in the bottom of the ninth. Kim needed one more out to put the Yankees in a perilous position last night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENWOOD, EDITH
description: GREENWOOD-Edith. The Education Legacy Fund (ELF) of the Metropolitan Chapter of the American Society of Interior Designers mourns the passing of its beloved founder. She was an active interior designer and teacher and died after a brief illness at the age of 86. There will be a memorial service at Temple Sharay Tefilah, 79 St. and 2nd Ave., on Friday, at 1:30 PM. Contributions may be made in her honor for student scholarships to ELF and sent to the NY Metro Chapter of ASID at 200 Lexington Ave., NY, NY 10016. Her Friends & Colleagues at ELF

title: Web Addresses Sprout New Suffixes, Needed or Not
description: DURING the height of the Internet gold rush, the virtual equivalent of a miner's plot of land was a snappy Web address ending in .com.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Georgia: Protest Over Raid On TV Station
description: Thousands of protesters jammed downtown Tblisi, demanding the resignation of the interior minister and chief prosecutor over government efforts to shut down the Rustavi-2 television broadcasting network. The security minister resigned after admitting responsibility for a police raid on Rustavi-2, which has often criticized President Eduard A. Shevardnadze's policies. Mr. Shevardnadze said he would not permit a crackdown on the free press in Georgia. The police said they had raided the network to investigative its finances. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: First Extradition To U.S.
description: A South Korean man has been returned to Los Angeles as the first person extradited under a treaty signed by the United States and South Korea in December 1999. Kang Hyun Gu fled to South Korea before the treaty was signed while free on $2.5 million bail. An American citizen, he was said to have hoped to obtain Korean citizenship after a court in Los Angeles convicted him of rape, kidnapping and robbery. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOMZE, HOWARD J.
description: BOMZE-Howard J. On October 31, 2001. Beloved husband of Wendy Lee. Loving brother of Robert Martin and good friend to many.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Paterson: Judge To Rule Soon In Homicide
description: A family court judge said yesterday that he would announce next Wednesday whether seven teenagers, ages 16 and 17, who are charged with murder in the fatal beating of a homeless Paterson man should be tried as adults. The decision by the judge, Nestor F. Guzman of State Superior Court in Paterson, will essentially determine whether the teenagers will face 30 years in prison if convicted, or be tried as juveniles and face up to 10 years. The judge is to hold a similar hearing this morning for five 15-year-old defendants, whose cases require different legal standards. Boris Moczula, the acting prosecutor, has said he feels obligated to seek adult charges because state law says that juveniles 14 and older should be tried as adults in certain serious, violent crimes.

title: THOR TO BUY AIRSTREAM, BECOMING TRAVEL TRAILER LEADER
description: Thor Industries, maker of Airstream recreational vehicles, agreed to buy the Keystone RV Company for about $145 million in cash and stock to become the nation's leading maker of travel trailers. About 55 percent of the purchase price will be in cash, with the rest in stock, Thor said. Keystone, a closely held company based in Goshen, Ind., is expected to have sales of $380 million this year, up from $246 million a year earlier, Thor said. The companies expected to close the sale by Nov. 9. The merger will give Thor a fourth of the travel-trailer market, the companies said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TORREY, PETER MACGREGOR
description: TORREY-Peter MacGregor. Of Greenwich, CT, died of cardiac arrest on Tuesday, October 30, at home, at age 74. Born June 9, 1927 in London, Mr. Torrey was a son of the late Clare M. Torrey and Lillian K. Andrews. He grew up in New York City and New Canaan, CT, and graduated from the Phillips Exeter Academy & Princeton University. He worked at Lord & Taylor for 26 years, leaving in 1975 as Executive Vice President. He then was President of Bonnie Doon Hosiery Co. for 13 years. He was predeceased by a daughter, Alison Torrey, & his wife, Barbara Stewart Torrey. He is survived by three children: Dr. Stephen Torrey of Cheshire, David Torrey of Greenwich, and Lynn Torrey Boyd of Stamford. He is also survived by three brothers, two sisters, and six grandchildren. Memorial services will be held at 3:30 PM, Monday, November 5th at the Second Congregational Church, 139 East Putnam Avenue, Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Friends of Greenwich Point, P.O. Box 711, Old Greenwich, CT. 06870, or to the American Heart Association by calling 1-800-242-8721.

title: The 'Unveiling' of iPod
description: To the Editor:

title: Execution Set In New Mexico Draws Rarity Of a Challenge
description: At 7 p.m. next Tuesday, Terry Clark is to become the first prisoner executed by New Mexico in 41 years.

title: MAKING THE MOVE WITH: Eddy Curry and Tyson Chandler; Raise High the Roof, Realtor
description: WHEN he moved from his family's apartment in working-class Calumet City, Ill., last summer, Eddy Curry, 18, had a vision for his first home. ''I wanted to build a huge mansion with a pool,'' he said. ''Then I calmed down and started looking at condos.'' When Tyson Chandler, 19, left his family house in Buena Park, Calif., he wanted wide open spaces.

title: Struggling to reformulate public relations campaigns after the attacks of Sept. 11.
description: If there had been a theme for a gathering this week of the nation's public relations industry, it might have been ''Spin physician, heal thyself.''

title: Casino Bill Was Passed After Big Push By Lobbyists
description: Gambling interests mounted one of the broadest, most expensive lobbying campaigns in the state's history this year, pressing for the aggressive expansion of gambling that Gov. George E. Pataki made law today.

title: At Jackson's Request, ABC Cuts A Song Out of a Concert Tape
description: Representatives for Michael Jackson have forced ABC to remove a performance by the singer from its taped version of the ''United We Stand'' concert only one day before the show was set to be broadcast, ABC executives said yesterday.

title: A Puzzling Anthrax Death
description: The death from inhalation anthrax yesterday of a woman who worked at a hospital in New York adds a puzzling new dimension to the anthrax scare. Hers was the second case of anthrax in recent days that seemed to fall outside the previous pattern of contamination that exposed only people working in government offices, media companies and postal facilities. The two cases have raised troubling new questions as to how the anthrax is being spread and whether ordinary citizens are now also at risk. The answers will not be known until medical detectives complete their examinations, but there are reasons to be optimistic that these cases do not signify any major change in the small-scale nature of the anthrax attacks that have terrified the public.

title: Bronx Woman Is Fourth to Die From Anthrax
description: The 61-year-old hospital stockroom worker stricken by New York's first case of inhalation anthrax died early yesterday, the fourth fatality nationwide in a still-unfolding anthrax scare that has turned into an even more troubling mystery.

title: Corrections
description: Correction: Satellite vs. Cable Subscriptions -- A chart in Business Day on Tuesday showing the percentage of households in selected areas that subscribe to cable and satellite television services carried incorrect figures from Nielsen Media Research and misidentified the markets with the highest concentrations of subscribers. This is a corrected version.

title: Cheap and Easy Routes To a Videoconference
description: Q. What would I need to hold a videoconference with a friend on a home computer?

title: Schundler Gives Big Edge To Democrats on Spending
description: With just six days until New Jersey elects a new governor, Bret D. Schundler sounded today as if he were already composing a requiem for his campaign, offering up the sort of explanations and consolations that are normally given on the Wednesday after an election, not the Wednesday before.

title: A Player to Make You Blue (Or Teal, or Mango Yellow)
description: When a new digital music player lands (and that's about every week), there are three questions to ask: How big is it, how much music does it hold and how much does it cost? The arrival of the new Bantam Interactive Explor BA350 provokes another question: What color is it?

title: Afghan Art Dispersed by The Winds Of War; A Nation Loses Its Heritage To Smugglers and Dealers
description: On a recent visit to a London antique dealer, David Kamansky, director of the Pacific Asia Museum in Pasadena, Calif., was presented with a shoe box. Inside, covered with flimsy paper, were fragments of a 2,000-year-old ivory casket, decorated with intricate Indian carvings, unmistakably part of the famous Begram collection that once belonged to the Kabul Museum in Afghanistan.

title: AUTOZONE EXPECTS FIRST QUARTER TO EXCEED FORECASTS
description: AutoZone Inc., a leading auto-parts retailer, expects income in the first quarter of its fiscal year to rise more than forecast after sales rose and the company controlled expenses. The company is projected by analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call to earn 57 cents a share in the quarter, which ends Nov. 17. AutoZone earned $53.8 million, or 46 cents a share, the period the year earlier. Same-store sales have increased 7 percent to 8 percent so far this quarter. AutoZone said it has improved its gross margin. Strong cash flow also allowed AutoZone to reduce more debt than a year ago, the company said. Prior stock buybacks are adding to earnings, the company said.

title: Robert Rosenthal, 87; Ran Apparel Stores
description: Robert Z. Rosenthal, the former president of Martin's, a family-owned chain of women's apparel stores in Brooklyn, Long Island and New Jersey, died on Saturday at a hospital in Sarasota, Fla. He was 87 and moved to Sarasota from Sands Point, N.Y., in 1986.

title: Union Chief's Battle Is With the Postal Service
description: WILLIAM M. SMITH, president of the New York Metro Area Postal Union, squints hard behind his aviator glasses and confirms that disgruntled is just the half of what he's feeling these days. George W. Bush is not, he huffs, the only president at war with ''evildoers.''

title: U.S. Will Increase Number of Advisers in Afghanistan
description: The Pentagon is planning to expand the number of advisers working with anti-Taliban groups in Afghanistan, and they will move with the rebel forces when they start to advance against Taliban troops, a senior military official said today.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Videotaping Minus Tape, With a DVD
description: UNLESS looking sheepish in public is your idea of fun, it's best to avoid making predictions about the future of technology. If, cornered at a dinner party, you absolutely must prognosticate, you should probably stick to relatively safe bets like these: Sony will make more compact things, Apple will make more beautiful things, and Microsoft will make more money.

title: Technology Briefing
description: HARDWARE

title: Pakistan Atom Experts Held Amid Fear of Leaked Secrets
description: Pakistan has arrested three of the country's leading nuclear scientists and held them for questioning for most of the last week in connection with American concerns that nuclear weapons technology could have found its way into the hands of Osama bin Laden and the Taliban rulers of Afghanistan, officials in Pakistan said today.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Nomura's Profit Falls
description: The operator of Japan's largest brokerage house, Nomura Holdings, said profit fell 90.4 percent in the six months ended Sept. 30 as trading in equities slowed. Nomura earned 11.3 billion yen ($93 million) in the half with brokerage commissions falling 38.3 percent. Japan's stock market lost about a quarter of its value from April to September as the benchmark Nikkei 225-stock index fell to an 18-year low after the attacks in the United States. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Caribbean Savings
description: Luxury hotels have to trim prices, too, in this rocky tourism market, and the savings are in the three-figure range when they do. Island Destinations, a tour operator in Larchmont, N.Y., has savings up to 45 percent through mid-December at deluxe resorts in the Caribbean and Mexico. At Cap Juluca on Anguilla, for example, rates start at $350 a night between Nov. 17 and Dec. 20; at Little Dix Bay on Virgin Gorda in the British Virgin Islands, rooms start at $205 a night through Dec. 15. Caneel Bay, on St. John in the United States Virgin Islands, has rooms starting at $225 a night through Dec. 15. Rates are subject to availability and most do not include tax and service. Information: (877) 902-2525 or www.islanddestinations.com .

title: Wild Kingdom in Two Acres
description: IT'S a bit of a shock, at first, to see Diane Ackerman's garden. Ms. Ackerman, a poet and author of 18 books, talks plenty about squirrels and deer and hummingbird feeders in ''Cultivating Delight: A Natural History of My Garden,'' just published by HarperCollins. But she writes about them, along with her roses and her peonies, as if she were exploring the wild beauty of some just-discovered Amazon.

title: Restoring Confidence in Air Travel
description: With many Americans still too worried about the level of airport security to resume flying, and Transportation Secretary Norman Mineta acknowledging ''intolerable'' lapses nationwide, the House of Representatives has an opportunity today to help restore the public's confidence in the nation's aviation system. It ought to pass legislation identical to the aviation security measure passed unanimously by the Senate on Oct. 11.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: States Ask for More Time to Review Microsoft Settlement
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The 18 states involved in the government's landmark antitrust lawsuit against Microsoft today rebuffed repeated requests by the software giant and the Justice Department to join the tentative settlement they had reached a day earlier.

title: Ensuring a Safe Flight
description: The Sept. 11 terrorist attacks laid bare long-known flaws in airport security and rendered them intolerable. President Bush opposes a complete federal takeover of airport security but, to see the security problems addressed, might sign legislation establishing such a takeover. That shouldn't be necessary.

title: It's Decision Day for the Managers
description: On the last night of his Yankees contract, Joe Torre sat in the home dugout watching his players bat against the pitcher who plunged them into their worst hitting funk of the season. In the first year of his first managerial contract, Bob Brenly sat in the visitors' dugout watching his starting pitcher of choice hold the manager's reputation in his right hand.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEVENS, LEONARD D.
description: STEVENS-Leonard D. Of NYC. On October 26, 2001 at 84. Beloved husband of Evelyn, devoted father of Joanne, dear brother of Evelyn. He was a native of Harlem and graduated from City College Class of 1942, served in the Army during WW II, took over as co-owner of the Hunt Printing Company, now one of the oldest business establishments in Harlem. Viewing Thursday, November 1, 4-7PM at Mt. Morris Ascension Presbyterian Church, Mt. Morris Park West and 122 St. Services to follow.

title: Amid Trade Agenda Talks, Sharpened Focus on Rich-Poor Disputes
description: With only a week to go before trade ministers are scheduled to gather in Doha, Qatar, to try to set the agenda for a worldwide trade accord, actions the United States has taken since the terrorist attacks appear to have widened the gap between rich and poor nations and persuaded some negotiators that the meeting could become a casualty of war.

title: The Language Weapon
description: To the Editor:

title: Rumsfeld Says the U.S. Is Ready to Send in More Ground Troops
description: The United States is poised to introduce more ground troops into Afghanistan to act as liaison and targeting agents with forces opposed to the Taliban, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today.

title: Like That Other Dame, She's Definitely No Angel
description: When Paula West strikes a sultry pose, rolls her eyes and flashes an impish half-smile, the ghost of another woman named West (Mae), tints her thick velvety voice a delicate shade of blue. This San Francisco singer, who is appearing at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel through Dec. 1, loves lolling around in songs, finding their sexual undercurrents and executing discreet vocal bumps and grinds while joyfully riding them downstream.

title: E.P.A. to Adopt Clinton Arsenic Standard
description: The Bush administration, which prompted an outcry by suspending a Clinton proposal on acceptable levels of arsenic in drinking water, has now decided to adopt the proposed Clinton level after all.

title: Trump Shares Fall Along With Bonds
description: Shares of Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts fell 20 percent yesterday after the chairman, Donald Trump, said on Tuesday that the company might not make a scheduled $90 million interest payment next month and might seek to restructure the debt.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Ex-Military Chief Interrogated
description: The former military chief General Wiranto was questioned by prosecutors about $5.3 million that was siphoned out of the state planning agency in 1999. He told reporters he had taken a share of the money ''to secure democracy'' during the independence vote in East Timor that year, which was organized and financed by the United Nations. He denied that the money had been used to arm and support government-backed militias that ravaged the territory after failing to derail the vote through intimidation.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Tuesday showing the percentage of households in selected areas that subscribe to cable and satellite television services carried incorrect figures from Nielsen Media Research and misidentified the markets with the highest concentrations of subscribers. A correction in this space yesterday also misidentified the market area with the largest percentage of cable subscribers. A corrected chart appears today, on Page C5.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Police Clash With Muslims
description: A five-day-old curfew in the western city of Malegoan and surrounding villages was briefly lifted but reimposed to avoid further violence between the police and Muslims. Twelve Muslims were killed there last week during protests against the American bombing of Afghanistan. There have been anti-American rallies in Hyderabad and New Delhi, but only in Malegoan, which has a history of clashes between Hindus and Muslims, have people died.

title: Chairs on Their Last Legs? A Remedy (For Tables, Too)
description: Broken rungs, scratches, knicks, dents, stains, cigarette burns. Furniture Medic, an international network of 600 furniture restorers, handles such problems in the home if possible or, if not, in the shop. Carlton Reeves, who owns the company's Manhattan franchise, charges $55 for home consultations, to be deducted from the $90-an-hour cost of repair. Telephone consultations are free. Big refinishing jobs (stripping, sanding) must be done at the shop. Donna Martinetti, an owner of Furniture Medic's Rockland County franchise, said regluing chairs is her most common shop repair. Information: (800) 937-3783 or www.furnituremedic

title: Good Connections (and $30) Secures an Afghan Expedition
description: For the first time since the war began, Western reporters this week entered the Afghan city of Kandahar, sending out images of the battle on ABC News, CNN and the BBC and other outlets.

title: Signs of Anthrax Found in F.D.A. Mail Rooms
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1  Signs of anthrax were reported in four more government mail rooms in the Washington area today. But officials said no new illnesses have been reported since a New York City woman died of anthrax early Wednesday.

title: Israeli Strikes in the West Bank Kill 6 Palestinian Militants
description: Expecting to be killed by Israeli forces, Jamil Jadallah, a member of the Islamic militant group Hamas, had his picture taken a few days ago for the poster he knew would be made to commemorate his ''martyrdom.''

title: A Benefit for  'ers of Art and New York
description: Not to be outdone by rock stars giving concerts, fashion designers donating clothing and even New York delis offering free food to police officers and firefighters, the New York art world is doing its part to raise money through exhibitions and auctions for victims of the World Trade Center attacks.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: E.T.A. Supporters Arrested
description: The police have arrested 13 members of two prisoner support groups, accusing them of belonging to the armed Basque separatist organization E.T.A., which has killed some 800 people in its 30-year struggle for Basque independence. The groups said the arrests were politically motivated; the government argues that many legal organizations that share E.T.A.'s aims are in fact part of the armed group. Emma Daly (NYT)

title: Carnegie Delays Opening of Additional Hall
description: The opening of Judy and Arthur Zankel Hall, the new underground 650-seat concert space at Carnegie Hall, has been postponed nine months until September 2003, when it is hoped that the city's economic climate will be more receptive to it, Robert Harth, the executive and artistic director of Carnegie Hall, announced yesterday.

title: A Distinct Style In Odd Shapes And Lightning Leaps and Turns
description: The plate was full when Garth Fagan Dance, a company in more than splendid form, opened a two-week season at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday night.

title: COMCAST HAS LOSS IN ACQUISITIONS AND UPGRADE COSTS
description: The Comcast Corporation, the cable-television operator seeking to buy AT&T's broadband unit, had a third-quarter loss on acquisition and upgrade costs as sales and cash flow beat analyst estimates. The loss was $106.8 million, or 11 cents a share, compared with net income of $1.25 billion, or $1.29, a year earlier, the company said. The Philadelphia-based company offered to buy New York-based AT&T's cable unit, the nation's largest, for stock and assumed debt now valued at $51.2 billion. AT&T rejected the bid in July. Comcast's operating cash flow, or earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, rose 17 percent to $705.8 million from $605.7 million. The company was expected by analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call, to report $680.4 million in cash flow.

title: Pushed Higher by Microsoft, Indexes Post Solid Gains
description: The stock market rose sharply today, led by a surge in technology issues, as Wall Street anticipated that Microsoft ( news/quote ) and the Justice Department would finally settle the long-running antitrust case against the software company.

title: The Afghan Front: Lessons of Vietnam
description: To the Editor:

title: An Estate Lives On, Thanks to Apples
description: FROM Route 9H, you can just glimpse Talavera, a yellow, Greek revival mansion with white trim and fluted columns. The house, serenely overlooking the Catskills and the Berkshires, seems deliberately hidden as you wind your way up a long driveway. Only as you reach the foot of the spacious lawn does Talavera reveal itself in all its faded elegance, subject to the inroads of time but occupied in unbroken succession by the Van Ness and Philip families for nearly 200 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEYER, GEORGE
description: FEYER-George, October 21, 2001 in New York City. A devoted husband of the late Judith Hoffmann Feyer (d. 1982) and of Marta Kleyman Feyer. Loving father of Robert P. Feyer and father-in-law of Marsha N. Cohen. Delighted and proud grandfather of Daniel J.C. Feyer, Stephen L.C. Feyer & Jonathan C. Feyer. An internationally acclaimed pianist, nightclub entertainer and recording artist, he brought pleasure to countless thousands of his fans with his unique style of piano and vocal entertainment. A caring and generous man, he also gave of his talents to patients at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital and other health care institutions. Private funeral services were held in San Francisco, California. A memorial to remember his life will be held at 1:00PM, Saturday, Nov. 3, 2001 at the Feszek Club, 344 E. 69th St. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions in his memory be made to Princeton University (P.O. Box 140, Princeton, NJ 08544) or to your favorite charity. For information, call 415-931-2201.

title: The Computer That Wore Galoshes and a Raincoat
description: It is easy to spot weather fanatics. They have thermometers hanging in every window in the house, talk insistently about isobars and know the clothing preferences of every anchor on the Weather Channel.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Suit On Commandments Display
description: A Montgomery lawyer has filed a federal lawsuit challenging the display of the Ten Commandments on a monument outside the state's main judiciary building. The monument was erected there in August by Roy Moore, chief justice of the State Supreme Court, who has championed the display of the commandments. But the lawyer, Stephen R. Glassroth, a state sentencing commissioner, said the monument constitutes an endorsement of religion and gives the impression that adherence to Judeo-Christian beliefs provides an advantage to those seeking justice in the state. David Firestone (NYT)

title: Cowboys Need to Know if Leaf Can Do It
description: The Dallas Cowboys are expected to start the little-known quarterback Clint Stoerner at Giants Stadium on Sunday, but it is his understudy, the well-known and well-traveled Ryan Leaf, who has the Giants' attention.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Science Times on Tuesday about the effects of turmoil in the Middle East and Asia on archaeological expeditions misstated the date that the Crimean War began. It was 1853, not 1854.

title: A Nation Challenged
description: Planning and Diplomacy

title: U.S. Will End Regular Sale Of Long Bond
description: The United States retired the old faithful of the bond market yesterday, ending the regular sale of 30-year bonds after a quarter of a century.

title: National Briefing | Education: Drop In Crime Against Students
description: The percentage of middle- and high-school students who reported being victims of crimes on school property fell to 8 percent from 10 percent over the four-year period ending in 1999, the most recent year such figures are available, federal officials reported. While students in all grades reported that they felt safer in school in 1999 as compared to 1995, the number of high school students who said they had been threatened with or injured by a weapon in school remained constant, about 8 percent. Jacques Steinberg (NYT)

title: Saints' Brooks Is No Longer a Question
description: The New Orleans Saints were one of three teams (along with Pittsburgh and Tampa Bay) that were forced to deal with a 21-day gap between their first and second games of the season because of the Week 2 postponement and a subsequent bye.

title: Disease Experts Struggle to Help Doctors Discern the Early Flu From Early Anthrax
description: With the flu season approaching during a period of fears about inhalation anthrax, a question inevitably arises: When are flulike symptoms something to worry about?

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Riverhead: Man Arraigned On Abuse Charges
description: A Long Island man was arraigned yesterday on charges that he abused a 4-year-old girl whose father he had met in an Internet chat room, prosecutors said. The man, Bruce Wernick, 44, of Valley Stream, who has pleaded not guilty, would face at least 25 years in prison if convicted of the several charges he faces, including sex abuse and sodomy, said James M. Catterson Jr., the Suffolk County district attorney. The girl's father, whose name was withheld to protect the child's identity, was arraigned last month on charges that he abused the girl and tried to swap her over the Internet. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: What's in a Product Name?
description: Since the unveiling of Apple's iPod music player last week, there's been quite a bit of speculation about its name. What could the weird little term iPod signify, anyway?

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Technology Briefing column of Business Day last Thursday about Brooks Automation's purchase of PRI Automation, a rival maker of chip manufacturing equipment, misstated the location of PRI's headquarters. It is Billerica, Mass., not Toronto.

title: Allied Domecq Consolidating Roster
description: Allied Domecq in London is consolidating the roster of agencies that handle its worldwide spirits and wine accounts, with billings estimated at $478 million.

title: Poetic History Of the Heart
description: Is it possible that our great-great-grandchildren will learn more about our times from the music and incantations of our poets than from our novelists? Since love and death are the parents of poetry, it's probably not surprising that people are turning to it for solace and understanding these days. Poetry is such a worthwhile tool to help decipher emotions that it's unfortunate that it takes a horrific event to make one focus suddenly on this art form. But maybe its popularity has been creeping up on us for a while and we weren't aware.

title: Sterilized Mail To Be Scanned For Evidence
description: Nearly 70 tons of mail that was shipped to Ohio for decontamination will be trucked back to Washington and scoured piece by piece for anthrax, law enforcement and postal authorities said today.

title: Monitors That Do Everything Except Slice and Dice
description: Multitaskers may have to sprout another arm or two to keep up with a new series of monitors from Samsung. The SyncMaster 151MP and SyncMaster 171MP can perform quadruple duty. Not only can the new Samsung screens handle typical computer chores, they can also show television programs using a built-in TV tuner and video inputs from a VCR, camcorder or DVD player, and can handle high-definition television, or HDTV, broadcasts.

title: Tokyo Journal; The Minister's Misfortune: Not-So-Civil Servants
description: After the headaches of being Japan's foreign minister, Makiko Tanaka was looking forward to a perk: attending the annual fall garden party held at a palace here on Thursday by Emperor Akihito and Empress Michiko.

title: World Series: Game 4
Skyline of Twins
Slide Show: Feast for the Eyes
Slide Show: Down Mexico Way
Slide Show: Arch Types
Master of His Domain
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: We Need Answers on Anthrax
description: To the Editor:

title: Little Miss Sunshine as Urban Sprite
description: Jean-Pierre Jeunet's ''Amlie,'' a sugar-rush of a movie, has what could be called meticulous clutter, a placement of imagery that covers every square centimeter of the screen. Mr. Jeunet's sense of humor gives the movie heart; his real affection for the medium can be seen in all the funny little curlicues and jottings around the action.

title: Rebel Chief Flees Raid By Taliban
description: An anti-Taliban leader, Hamid Karzai, was said to be alive and well inside Afghanistan today after reports that there had been a fight between his forces and the ruling Taliban militia.

title: A Partnership Forged To Thwart Terrorism
description: Attorney General John Ashcroft and Robert S. Mueller III, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, went over the checklist one last time together.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Channeling Cultures

title: Corrections
description: Atranscript of excerpts yesterday from an interview with Michael R. Bloomberg, the Republican mayoral candidate, misspelled the surname of a former New York governor he cited as a politician who moved from private business to public service. It was Herbert H. Lehman, not Leahman.

title: A Job for Jimmy Carter
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Clinton Library Lawsuit Rejected
description: The State Supreme Court cleared the last legal obstacle to groundbreaking for the Clinton Presidential Library by upholding the City of Little Rock's method of seizing land for the complex. In a unanimous decision, the court ruled that the city had properly used its eminent domain powers to acquire 2.9 acres from Eugene Pfeifer III for the 28-acre project. Groundbreaking is scheduled for early December. Kevin Sack (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOYLE, MICHAEL
description: BOYLE-Michael. FDNY, Engine Company 33, lost his life on September 11, 2001 while heroically saving others in the World Trade Center. Michael was born on August 8, 1964 to James and Barbara Boyle in Queens, NY. Michael graduated from Westbury High School and Cortland State University. Michael was the owner of Westbury Beverage and worked for the Uniformed Firefighters Association Local 94. In 1996, Michael was appointed to the FDNY, his lifetime dream, and was assigned to Engine 33 on Great Jones Street, Manhattan. He also served in Ladder 35 at Lincoln Center and Engine 226 in downtown Brooklyn. Michael was a champion Marathon Runner and was in training for the NYC Marathon to break three hours. Michael is survived by his parents James (retired President of the Uniformed Firefighters Association Local 94 and Engine 217) and Barbara; two brothers, James (Sgt. NYPD) and Peter (owner of All Island Beverage); two sisters, Mary Lynch and husband Brendan, and Jeanne Boyle, Esq.; two nieces Amanda and Diana; many uncles, aunts, and cousins, and his Special Love, Rosemary Kenny. Michael was a loving son, a wonderful brother, a special uncle, devoted to Rosemary. He had a unique way of touching the lives of everyone. A future labor leader. He was a true friend, will be deeply missed, but forever remembered. God Bless You Michael. A memorial visitation will be held at the Donohue Cecere Funeral Home, 290 Post Avenue, Westbury, LI on Sunday from 2-4 & 7-9 PM. Memorial Mass Monday, 9:30 AM, St. Patrick's Cathedral, New York, NY. Donations may be made to the Arce Boyle Memorial Fund c/o Collern, O'Hara, Mills, 1225 Franklin Ave., Garden City, NY, 11530, and would be greatly appreciated.

title: Oprah's Club: The Reluctant Member
description: To the Editor:

title: Step Right Up! On Show in Iran, Sins of Uncle Sam
description: ''Bang all your strength on America's head,'' reads the sign over a carnival game that entices visitors to pound on a devilish face wearing a hat with the American flag. Another attraction challenges players to shoot balls into Uncle Sam's moving mouth using an air canon.

title: So Many Doppelgngers, But Only One Will Survive
description: The climactic duel in James Wong's flashy science-fiction romp ''The One'' finds the Asian martial-arts star Jet Li doing battle with himself on multileveled catwalks inside what looks like a giant boiler room on the fritz. Elaborately punctuated with electronic beats and by explosions that produce alternating showers of sparks and rain, the sequence has the look and sound of a pop ''ballet mchanique.'' At moments it even suggests an aerialist ''Singin' in the Rain'' for the kickboxing set.

title: 'A Breeze From the Gardens of Persia' -- 'New Art From Iran'
description: Queens Borough Public Library

title: John P. Roberts, 56, a Producer Of Woodstock and Its Revivals
description: John P. Roberts, a promoter of the Woodstock Music and Art Fair in 1969 and a partner in its revivals in the 90's, died on Saturday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. He was 56 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Dalmatians Not for Sale
description: A bright red 1926 Ford Model T fire chief's truck with the chief's white helmet still on the seat, a collection of antique toy firetrucks, an 1890's hose cart that required the brawn of 14 male pullers -- these are just a few of the holdings in the Sag Harbor Firemen's Museum on Long Island. They were assembled by Thomas W. Horn Sr., a former fire chief who this year celebrated his 50th anniversary on the 165-member Sag Harbor Fire Department. Chartered by the state Legislature in 1803, it is the oldest volunteer squad in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANASHOWITZ, LEON
description: MANASHOWITZ - Leon. Our heartfelt condolences to Steven and his family, from your family at Prestige Theatre Parties. Tuddie, Lenny, Jen, Pat & Margo

title: Share Prices Gain on Prospect of a Microsoft Settlement
description: The stock market rose sharply yesterday, led by a surge in technology issues, as Wall Street anticipated that Microsoft and the Justice Department would settle the long-running antitrust case against the software company.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: September Chip Sales Off 45%
description: Worldwide chips sales in September fell 45 percent, compared with the year-earlier month, a trade group said yesterday. The Semiconductor Industry Association said semiconductor revenue declined to $10.22 billion, from $18.44 billion. Sales were 2.5 percent lower than the $10.44 billion reported in August, but the severity of the month-to-month decline diminished for the third consecutive time. The Americas, down 59 percent from September 2000, were the hardest hit, followed by Europe, down 42 percent, and Asia, down 31 percent.

title: Reviews of Current Releases
description: For all New York Times film reviews since 1996, go to the Film Archive .

title: Despite Hot Start, Isles Think They Are Being Ignored
description: Chris Osgood, the Islanders' goaltender, has returned here for a big game Friday. He says he is excited, but apparently not for the reasons that make this game a little different than past Islanders-Red Wings matchups.

title: Trouble in Deploying Commandos Is Said to Hurt U.S. Air Campaign
description: The American military's growing ability to bomb front-line Taliban forces accurately in northern Afghanistan has been delayed for weeks by difficulties in infiltrating up to 100 elite American commandos, senior Pentagon officials said today.

title: Nature's Bounty: Birds and Solitude
description: Just about every morning, a little after 5, Pete Dunne walks the same isolated road with his three Labrador retrievers. At some times of year it's dark, but the road is paved, so he doesn't stumble, and there is no traffic. At other times he sees the dawn. Always he listens to the great horned owls hoot and soaks up the solitude.

title: Rivera Quits CNBC Show To Cover War For Fox News
description: Geraldo Rivera, the longtime television host, said yesterday that he would leave his top-rated talk show on the business news cable channel CNBC to join the Fox News Channel as a war correspondent.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Economic Outlook Gloomy
description: In his annual budget speech to Parliament, the finance minister said he expected the economy to shrink by 7.3 percent this year. Simba Makoni said prospects also looked grim for 2002 with the economy expected to contract by 5.3 percent next year. More than 600 companies have closed over the past year and farm invasions and political violence have sharply reduced foreign investment. Mr. Makoni said 75 percent of Zimbabwe's 12.5 million people were now living in poverty.

title: Charges Dismissed in Columbia Sexual Torture Case
description: A Manhattan judge dismissed all charges yesterday against Oliver Jovanovic, a Columbia University doctoral student accused five years ago of the sexual torture of a woman he met on the Internet.

title: CHARTER COMMUNICATIONS CUTS 2001 SALES FORECAST
description: Charter Communications, the cable television operator controlled by the billionaire Paul Allen, cut its 2001 sales forecast yesterday and posted a wider third-quarter loss. Sales are expected to rise 12.5 percent to 13.5 percent, down from 15.5 percent, as consumers cut spending amid a slowing economy. The company's third-quarter loss widened to $317.4 million, or $1.08 a share, from $210 million, or 93 cents, a year earlier. Carl Vogel, Charter's chief executive, pledged to help stem the decline and said customer demand for new services was strong. The company has systems in St. Louis, Boston, Fort Worth and Los Angeles.

title: Drug Issue Casts a Shadow on Trade Talks
description: Boniface Chidyausiku does not remember exactly when the dispute over setting aside patents that limit cheap drug supplies grew so contentious that it began threatening to derail a new round of global trade talks set to begin next week.

title: Bloomberg and Green Clash Over Capability in Debate
description: Mark Green and Michael R. Bloomberg tore into each other's character and credentials in an often fierce debate last night that laid out differences between the two mayoral candidates over how the city should rebuild downtown, and the best way to repair New York's troubled public school system.

title: Mattingly Turns Coy About Yankee Coaching Job
description: Don Mattingly was a roving hitting instructor for the Yankees this season and has been credited with helping Tino Martinez emerge from a hitting slump when he counseled him in June. Mattingly, who threw out the first pitch before Game 5 last night, was asked if he is any closer to deciding whether he would like to return to the Yankees as a full-time coach.

title: Bin Laden Letter Calls Upon Pakistanis to Defend Islam
description: Western and Arab news organizations today received copies of a letter handwritten in Arabic, carrying Osama bin Laden's signature, that urges Pakistan's Muslims to defend Islam against what it called a Christian crusade.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Commuting; Putting Traffic Tell-Alls to the Test
description: WITH fewer vehicles on the streets since Sept. 11, traffic seems to be moving faster in Manhattan, but car-occupancy restrictions, ever-changing emergency rules and backups at security checkpoints can cause delays getting on or off the island. What's more, driving in the other boroughs and through the suburbs can be even more frustrating than before, as bans on trucks snarl traffic miles away from the affected bridges and tunnels.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: National Guard For Nuclear Plant
description: Gov. Mike Huckabee activated a unit of the National Guard to bolster security at the state's only nuclear plant after the plant's owner, the Entergy Corporation, asked for help. Neither Mr. Huckabee nor the company gave a specific reason for the move. The plant is in Dardanelle, about 60 miles west of Little Rock.

title: Mix of Routine and Urgency At Sole U.S. Maker of Cipro
description: Behind a heavily guarded gate here, workers file into a sandstone building that is so nondescript it does not even have a name, only a grid number that marks its place within the sprawling North American headquarters for Bayer Corporation's pharmaceutical division. Bayer officials are loath to divulge even that number out of security concerns.

title: Dr. Jeffrey Isner, 53, Creator Of Cardiovascular Procedure
description: Dr. Jeffrey M. Isner, who wedded gene therapy and cardiovascular medicine to create promising treatments for heart and circulatory disease, died on Wednesday at his home in Weston, Mass., near Boston. He was 53.

title: Excerpts From Debate on Airport Security Bills
description: Following are excerpts from the House debate yesterday on airport security, as recorded by The New York Times. The speakers are Representatives Richard A. Gephardt, Democrat of Missouri, the minority leader; John L. Mica, Republican of Florida; James L. Oberstar, Democrat of Minnesota, and Don Young, Republican of Alaska:

title: Groups Seek Safer Storage Of Spent Fuel
description: For years, opponents of nuclear power have raised questions about the safety of spent radioactive fuel rods stored at plants around the country. And for years the response from the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has been the same: the threat of terrorism on American soil is too remote to make it a significant worry.

title: Workers and Residents Are Safe, Officials Say
description: Environmental and health officials sought to assure a City Council committee yesterday that there were no indications of serious long-term health risks to workers or residents at or near ground zero, amid growing concerns to the contrary.

title: Kim Fails in Second Chance Against Yanks
description: Miguel Batista, who has played for six different major league organizations, one of them three different times, epitomizes the class of players known as journeymen. Check a lexicon of baseball terminology, and his picture will probably be next to the word.

title: War Wins Supporters In Pakistan
description: The Pakistani government appears to have abandoned any immediate hope of uniting rival Afghan groups in a new government, Western diplomats said today. Instead, they said, it has shifted toward increased support for American bombing as the best way to topple the Taliban.

title: The 'Selfishness' Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: Know Your Tenants
description: To the Editor:

title: Mail Delays Are Minimal, Despite Anthrax Problems
description: Postal authorities across the country said today that the mail was moving reasonably well, despite the discoveries of anthrax at mail centers in Washington, New York City, Maryland, New Jersey, Indianapolis and Kansas City, Mo.

title: The Mystery Of Kissin On Display
description: Evgeny Kissin, now 30, has been known to American listeners on recordings since he was 18 (earlier recordings were released later), and he has been a regular visitor to Carnegie Hall since 1990. But there remains something mysterious about this young pianist, something that puts his performances at an emotional distance that can seem downright odd, given the fiery Romanticism and monster technique that drive his playing. Those qualities were intact and fully on display when he played a demanding recital at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday. And yet for all the grand gestures, few moments were moving or illuminating.

title: Bubbling Up
description: Sarah Jessica Parker, below with Kevin Chamberlin, stars as a whimsical woman in search of herself in ''Wonder of the World.''

title: Arizona's Supporting Cast Draws Mixed Reviews
description: The Arizona Diamondbacks often seem more sideshow than team, rambling from town to town with a pair of flamethrowers who overwhelm hitters as if they were helpless milk bottles. As the Diamondbacks marched to the World Series, the players insisted that their team was much deeper, with vital contributors throughout the roster.

title: The Big City; In Debate, Candidates Go Against Type
description: YOU may have heard that the mayoral election is a contest between a smug veteran Democrat and a novice Republican with a penchant for putting his foot in his mouth. But that was not how it played on television last night.

title: Times Appoints Head of TV Unit
description: The New York Times has appointed William M. Abrams president of its television production unit, New York Times Television.

title: Singapore Telecom Buying Stake In Indonesia Cellphone Company
description: Fresh from a $9 billion takeover last month of Cable and Wireless Optus in Australia, Singapore Telecommunications said today that it would pay $602 million for a 22.3 percent stake in Indonesia's largest cellular operator, Telekomunikasi Selular, now held by Royal KPN of the Netherlands.

title: Sports of The Times; Guess What? Those Yankees Just Did It Again
description: Much has been made about Wednesday night's being one of the historic, classic, definitive Yankee World Series games of all time.

title: City Offering Work for Some On Welfare
description: The Giuliani administration is quietly offering thousands of city jobs paying more than $9 an hour to welfare recipients who are reaching their five-year limit on federal cash assistance just as the city's economy sinks into recession.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in the Technology Briefing column of Business Day on Wednesday about the third-quarter financial results of Verizon Communications misstated them. Profit declined by 46 percent; the company did not report a loss.

title: Text: The Mayoral Candidates Debate Public Safety, Education and Each Other
description: The following are excerpts from the New York City mayoral candidates debate yesterday between Mark Green and Michael R. Bloomberg, sponsored by the Campaign Finance Board, the League of Women Voters of the City of New York, WABC and WNYC- Radio, as recorded by The New York Times . Diana Williams of WABC was the moderator.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Congressman Decides Against Senate Run
description: Representative Peter A. DeFazio, left, a Democrat, has decided not to run for Senate against the incumbent Republican, Gordon H. Smith, and will instead seek re-election in the Fourth District in southwestern Oregon. He had left open the possibility of a Senate bid after Gov. John Kitzhaber, a fellow Democrat, declined to run. Mr. DeFazio would have faced Secretary of State Bill Bradbury in a Democratic primary. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORNREICH, JOANNE
description: KORNREICH-JoAnne. Beloved wife of Morton, devoted mother of James and Meredith, Thomas and Barbara, and Nancy and Robert Rieger, adored and adoring grandmother of Todd, Jennifer, Maggie, Caroline, Adam, Zachary, Molly, and Alex, and dear friend of Larcenia Petty. Services Friday 11:30 A.M. at Congregation Emanu-El, 2125 Westchester Avenue East, Rye, New York. For information call: Plaza Jewish Community Chapel at 1-800-227-3974.

title: Ruling Sets Stage for E-Mail Trial
description: Earlier this week the United States Supreme Court declined to review a Seattle case involving a state's ability to enforce its own Internet law in borderless cyberspace.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in the Company News column of Business Day yesterday about an acquisition announced by MKS Instruments Inc., which makes equipment used to produce computer chips, misidentified the business being bought. It is a unit of the Emerson Electric Company that makes equipment for manufacturing semiconductors, not Emerson Electric itself.

title: Dike Blair
description: Feature

title: Verrazano Closed on Sunday
description: The Verrazano-Narrows Bridge will be closed to traffic in both directions for the New York City Marathon on Sunday, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday. In previous marathons, Brooklyn-bound lanes on the lower level of the bridge remained open.

title: Domestic Warnings, a Baffling Death, Help From Turkey
description: For many Americans, an unsettling aspect of the Bush administration's warnings about an imminent terrorist attack has been the lack of specifics. Where? How? No one said. Now a prominent official, Gov. Gray Davis of California, has provided some details. But the federal authorities cast doubts about their reliability, leaving the public as uncertain as ever.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Job Cuts At Bank
description: Deutsche Bank plans to shed about 4,500 jobs, bringing announced reductions to 7,100, to save money as profit at Europe's biggest bank drops. The total cuts will pare the company's work force 7 percent. Deutsche Bank's chief executive, Rolf Breuer, may have to take more steps to lower spending after third-quarter earnings fell 49 percent, investors said. About 3,300 of the job losses will affect the private client and asset management division. And 1,200 jobs will be erased in the DB Services unit, which runs groups like human resources and internal computer networks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBINS, EVA
description: ROBINS-Eva. Eve was a labor arbitrator, friend, mentor, traveler, pioneer & crossword and Scrabble fiend. She was loving, unpretentious, steadfast, ethical and had a wonderful sense of humor. Her sisters, brothers, nieces and nephews will always treasure her influence, guidance, support and nurturing. Services will be private and a memorial service will be scheduled in the future. Contributions may be made to the Macular Degeneration Foundation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARNKE, PAUL
description: WARNKE-Paul. It is with deep sadness that we record the death of Paul Warnke, a courageous man who applied his great intelligence and deep compassion to the cause of world peace. We extend our condolences to the family of our valued friend and colleague, Stephen A. Warnke. Dennis Rivera, President On behalf of the 210,000 members of 1199 SEIU New York's Health & Human Service Union AFL-CIO

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARTLETT, JOHN M.
description: BARTLETT-John M. Died November 1, 2001, in his 88th year. He is survived by his brother, Edmund Bartlett; nephews, Marshall and Edmund III, and five greatnephews and nieces. Services 11am, Sunday, November 4, St. James Funeral Home, 631-584-5200 Route 25A, St. James, NY.

title: Bush, in Reversal, Seeks Rules for Enforcing Biological Treaty
description: Reversing earlier objections, the Bush administration said today that it would work with the international community to come up with a tough new enforcement plan for the landmark treaty that was to rid the world of biological weapons.

title: Frank Holliday -- 'Trippin' in America'
description: Debs & Company

title: THE FIGHT AGAINST TERRORISM / Changing Focus : War Transforms the Anti-Globalization Crowd
description: PARIS  After its sudden rise, anti-globalization activism has been stunned into a phase of relative quiet by the terrorist attacks on New York and Washington.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Honduras: Storm Leaves Thousands Homeless
description: Six days of relentless rain from a tropical storm have claimed the lives of six people and left 20,000 homeless the government said. Four people have also died in Nicaragua with more than 5,600 made homeless as floods swept the Atlantic coast. Both countries have declared national emergencies. The storm front has now moved north. David Gonzalez (NYT)

title: Pride, Sorrow and Unity at California Home of Slain Afghan's Son
description: The last conversation started like a typical father-son chat. Abdul Haq gently scolded his 16-year-old son for not having called in two or three weeks, expressed concern about his well-being and asked about his studies. Then it was the son's turn to worry.

title: Demand Far Exceeds Supply for Flu Shots
description: For weeks, Dr. Guy S. Mayer and his associates have been telling anxious patients cramming into their office in Park Slope, Brooklyn, that they cannot prescribe the antibiotic Cipro because the patients do not have anthrax or are not at risk for exposure.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Jefferson's Effectiveness Evident After Just 2 Games
description: Before the Nets' victory over the Celtics on Wednesday night in Boston, point guard Jason Kidd wondered whether he should tell the rookie Richard Jefferson just how he felt about him.

title: We Need Answers on Anthrax
description: To the Editor:

title: Turkey Says Troops to Join U.S. Campaign and Train Anti-Taliban Forces
description: Turkey said today that it would send 90 Special Forces troops to Afghanistan, making it the first Muslim nation to join the American-led attacks on the Taliban and Osama bin Laden.

title: Massachusetts Clears 5 From Salem Witch Trials
description: More than three centuries after they were accused, tried and hanged as unrepentant witches on Gallows Hill in Salem, Mass., five women have been officially exonerated by the state.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLEMAN, SHELDON T. JR.
description: COLEMAN-Sheldon T. Jr., 77. Of Greenwich died Oct. 31, at home. He is survived by a daughter Kim Coleman of Pacific Palisades, CA; a son S. Nicholson Coleman of Greenwich, CT; a brother Henry S. Coleman of New Canaan, CT., and four grandchildren. A memorial service will be held Monday, Nov. 5 at 11:00AM in Christ Church, 254 East Putnam Avenue, Greenwich, CT 06830. Memorial contributions may be made to the church.

title: Familiar Anthrax Strain Is Seen in Woman's Death
description: Health officials investigating the death of a hospital worker in Manhattan said yesterday that the strain of anthrax bacteria that killed her was indistinguishable from that mailed to Tom Daschle, the Senate majority leader, and media companies in Florida and New York.

title: When Mom's New Husband Is a Killer
description: Like most movie reviewers, I sometimes get letters from readers chiding me for giving away too much of the plot and spoiling the suspense. Before you read any further, I would like to suggest that any such complaints regarding ''Domestic Disturbance'' be directed to Paramount Pictures, since the movie, either to save audiences' time or to protect critics from unjust accusations, gives everything away as soon as it possibly can.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLSTEIN, SARA C.
description: OLSTEIN-Sara C., 97. Widow of Joseph, mother of Harriet Mendelsohn (Allan), the late Judith Olstein, grandmother of Rachel Cabrera (Allan), great grandmother of Jared. Services Sunday, November 4, 11:30AM, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 St, NY

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: State Bans Shark Feedings
description: The State Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission gave final approval to a ban on shark-feeding sessions, calling unacceptable any practice that modifies natural feeding habits of marine species. The commission emphasized there was no evidence of links between the feedings and recent shark attacks in the state. Scuba-boat operators who favor shark-feeding tours argued that the practice is not dangerous to the public and have sued to overturn the ban, which takes effect on Jan. 1.

title: Antitrust Deal Is Called Big Victory for Microsoft
description: After more than three years of litigation, repeated courtroom setbacks and failed settlement talks, Microsoft is apparently on the verge of emerging largely successful from its long antitrust battle. Microsoft's tentative agreement with the Justice Department would not require it to alter the design or development of its products and would not change its strategy of aggressively moving into new markets.

title: World Briefing | Europe: England: Euthanasia Case To Go To Top Court
description: In a ruling that will test England's law banning euthanasia, the Law Lords of the House of Lords, the country's highest court, agreed to hear a terminally ill woman's request to allow her husband to help her die. Diane Pretty, 42, suffers from motor neuron disease and is paralyzed from the neck down. She is seeking to have her husband Brian be immune from prosecution for assisted suicide, which carries a maximum 14-year jail term. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: No Ferrer, So Latinos Hold Nose And Choose
description: On a lunch break from her job as a preschool teacher in the Bronx, Brunilda Montalvo carefully pondered the question of whom she would vote for in the city's mayoral election. As her body twisted and turned on the concrete bench outside Hostos Community College, so did her thoughts. Ms. Montalvo, a lifelong Democrat, is a voter in distress.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALDRICH, LARRY
