description: ALDRICH-Larry. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art note with sorrow the death of Larry Aldrich. A benevolent early patron who believed passionately in supporting the art and artists of our time, Larry vastly enriched the Museum's collection by enabling the first acquisition of works by such artists as Brice Marden, Agnes Martin, Frank Stella, and Tom Wesselmann. Larry will forever be remembered for his foresight, generosity, and spirit. Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Agnes Gund, President Glenn D. Lowry, Director The Museum of Modern Art, NY

title: With Push From South Africa, Rivals Share Power in Burundi
description: With South Africa and its eminent statesman Nelson Mandela shepherding the way, a power-sharing government took office today in Burundi, even as negotiators were still struggling to broker a cease-fire in the country's civil war.

title: Rene Cox
description: Robert Miller Gallery

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Lima Journal; At Sato's Place, Great Seafood and a Secret Is Safe
description: Every big-time spy, diplomat and shady character in Lima knows that when it is time to seal a deal, you go to see Humberto Sato and have him cook up his luscious lobster balls and prawns grilled in garlic.

title: The Orphans of Sept. 11
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Syracuse: Prison Term In Asbestos Case
description: In what prosecutors call one of the nation's biggest prosecutions of the asbestos industry, a business executive has been sentenced to more than five years in prison for illegally removing asbestos from more than 1,000 buildings throughout New York State. The business executive, Joseph P. Thorn, 39, former owner of A+ Environmental Services Inc., was convicted last year of violating the Clean Air Act by sending employees into asbestos ''hot zones'' without needed respirators, and of falsifying medical clearance evaluations and air monitoring records. In his sentencing on Tuesday, Mr. Thorn was also ordered to pay $300,000 in restitution and forfeit nearly $1 million for money laundering.

title: Yes, This Is About Islam
description: LONDON -- "This isn't about Islam." The world's leaders have been repeating this mantra for weeks, partly in the virtuous hope of deterring reprisal attacks on innocent Muslims living in the West, partly because if the United States is to maintain its coalition against terror it can't afford to suggest that Islam and terrorism are in any way related.

title: Some Shaker Gifts That Are Anything but Simple
description: We can all use instructions now and then, explanations of how things work, directions on how to proceed. That's what maps and manuals are for, science and codes of ethics, even certain kinds of art.

title: United Loses $1.16 Billion and Talks of Worse Ahead
description: The UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, reported a record loss yesterday for the third quarter in the wake of the terrorist attacks and predicted that the current quarter would be even worse.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Mortgage Rates Decline, Igniting a Refinancing Wave

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEFFNER, NETTIE
description: GEFFNER-Nettie. Loving mother of Carol & Edward, grandmother of Mira, Marina, Marco, Roberto, and Dario, died at age 90, October 31, 2001. She was a passionate New Yorker who loved the drama and excitement of the city. The family will sit Shiva at the home of Edward I. Geffner, 160 Riverside Drive, NY, NY, 10024. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Project Renewal, 200 Varick Street, New York, NY 10014, or The Porphyria Foundation, P.O. Box 22712, Houston, TX. 77227.

title: We Need Answers on Anthrax
description: To the Editor:

title: Kim Fails in Second Chance Against Yanks
description: Miguel Batista, who has played for six different major league organizations, one of them three different times, epitomizes the class of players known as journeymen. Check a lexicon of baseball terminology, and his picture will probably be next to the word.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, H. HERBERT
description: HARRIS-H. Herbert. Central Synagogue and its Brotherhood record with profound sorrow the passing of their longtime member H. Herbert Harris. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family. Peter J. Rubinstein, Rabbi Samuel Wasserman, President Victor Muskin, Brotherhood President

title: Jones Set To Replace Armstead For Giants
description: There is a self-portrait by Dhani Jones that will be displayed soon in a museum at the University of Michigan, his alma mater, and where he starred at linebacker.

title: Mussina and Bullpen Keep Game in Reach
description: The Arizona Diamondbacks proved last night that their starting rotation was more than Curt Schilling and Randy Johnson, as Miguel Batista outpitched the Yankees' Mike Mussina into the eighth inning.

title: Vivendi in Talks on TV Production Unit
description: Vivendi Universal of France, Europe's biggest media company, is seeking a greater role in the television production business that was sold to USA Networks four years ago.

title: World Series Audio: Game 5
description: Postgame audio from Game 5 of the World Series between the Yankees and the Arizona Diamondbacks provided by SportsAudio.net.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Long Island City: New Head Of School Unit
description: The New York City School Construction Authority yesterday appointed as its president and chief executive Ronald A. Gottlieb, the former owner of a company that had worked on several major Board of Education construction projects. Mr. Gottlieb, 54, left, replaces Milo E. Riverso, who resigned in September. Mr. Gottlieb sold his company, R. A. Gottlieb Inc., in 1999 to a unit of the Skanska, a Swedish construction company.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: KLM Expects A Loss
description: KLM Royal Dutch Airlines said it expected to report a loss before interest and taxes for the full year, as passenger traffic remains depressed after the Sept. 11 attacks. For the three months ended Sept. 30, KLM said net income declined 77 percent, to 27 million euros ($24 million), or 56 cents a share, from 118 million euros, or 2.52 euros a share, last year. Sales fell 2.1 percent, to 1.86 billion euros. Since Sept. 11, KLM, one of Europe's largest airlines, has cut seating capacity, laid off 2,500 employees and cut fares in Europe 25 percent. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: The Thrills Are Over At Mount Airy Lodge; Once a Favored Honeymoon Retreat, A Troubled Resort Closes Its Doors
description: In the end, love was no match for the mildew.

title: Prosecutor Acknowledges Chief Witness in Rabbi's Trial Is a 'Little Wacky'
description: The prosecutor in the trial of a rabbi accused of ordering his wife's murder acknowledged today that the state's chief witness was a liar who was a ''little wacky'' and had a ''strange rsum.''

title: New Mining Rules
description: To the Editor:

title: Yes, This is About Islam
description: ''This isn't about Islam.'' The world's leaders have been repeating this mantra for weeks, partly in the virtuous hope of deterring reprisal attacks on innocent Muslims living in the West, partly because if the United States is to maintain its coalition against terror it can't afford to suggest that Islam and terrorism are in any way related.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. The ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: An Honestly Grateful Man

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Court Extends Free Speech Protection
description: In a setback for the movie industry's efforts to block distribution of software that can break through copy protections on DVD's, a California appeals court overturned on First Amendment grounds an earlier order that barred publication of the program. Movie studios have argued that the software is a tool and as such is not subject to free-speech protections. But the California court ruled that the software code was ''pure speech,'' and could not be banned from publication before a ruling is made on its legality. A decision on whether it violates movie industry trade secrets is still pending. Amy Harmon (NYT)

title: Strategy Shift Puts Pictures With Words
description: Sizing up a strategy that has produced mixed results for others, British Telecommunications is weighing adding television to its existing mix of telephone and Internet services.

title: RENT-A-CENTER AGREES TO PAY $12 MILLION IN BIAS CASE
description: Rent-a-Center said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $12.25 million to about 4,600 female workers and job applicants and change its training policies to settle a federal sex-discrimination suit. The proposed settlement, filed in Kansas City, Mo., might also cover plaintiffs in a similar sex-bias case pending in East St. Louis, Ill., the company said. Rent-a-Center said the settlement, which is subject to court approval, does not require it to admit liability. The women had contended that the company systematically harassed women, fired pregnant employees and subjected women to offensive sexual language. The settlement fund would be split among women who were employed or sought jobs between April 19, 1998, and Oct. 1, 2001.

title: Taliban's Foes Call Bombing Poorly Aimed and Futile
description: At first glance, the scene along the Taliban front lines appeared to be one of utter devastation: huge circles of charred earth, the footprints left by a daylong assault by American B-52's.

title: Air Force Set to Run Recruiting Campaign
description: The Air Force will begin running on Sunday the first phase of a $50 million recruitment campaign aimed at Americans 16 to 24 years old.

title: Brenly Used Schilling With an Eye on Game 7
description: Arizona Manager Bob Brenly won the battle with his decision to start Curt Schilling on abbreviated rest in Game 4 of the World Series, but might he lose the war because of his desire to use Schilling again on short rest if there is a Game 7?

title: Tania Bruguera -- 'La Isla en Peso'
description: LiebmanMagnan

title: Mahathir's Malaysia: No Gays Allowed
description: Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia, who has made homophobia a national policy, said today that even a British cabinet member would be ejected from his country if he arrived with a ''boyfriend.''

title: A 24/7 Superwoman, Living La Vida Loca in Style
description: I'M not usually quite this hysterical,'' Vera Wang says on a recent afternoon, having just wrapped up a meeting with ad agency people, assistants and a photographer, plotting the mood of her bridal advertising campaign for fall 2002. ''It's been insane. You missed about 10 dresses on the floor.''

title: It's All About Motherhood, The Young, Accidental Kind
description: Riding in Cars With Boys

title: ROBERTSON STEPHENS SAYS IT WILL LAY OFF 300 WORKERS
description: Robertson Stephens Inc., the securities unit of FleetBoston Financial, is laying off 300 people, or 24 percent of its work force, a company spokeswoman confirmed yesterday, as stock sales and mergers decline. Robertson Stephens, which caters to technology companies and was a beneficiary of the Internet boom, is reducing its staff to 950 people worldwide. The layoffs this week, affecting all areas of the firm, bring total job cuts to 600 this year, more than one-third of Robertson Stephens's work force. Most of the new cuts will come in the firm's San Francisco headquarters, the spokeswoman said.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits yesterday about the use of computer chips to time marathon runners misspelled the surname of the head of the rules committee of U.S.A. Track and Field. He is Robert Hersh, not Hersch.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, SHEILA
description: DAVIS-Sheila. Young Israel of Fifth Avenue mourns the death of the sister of our esteemed member, Dr. William Silver, and extends to him and the family our heartfelt condolences.

title: Technology Briefing
description: SOFTWARE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KREEGER, HENRIETTA
description: KREEGER-Henrietta. On October 31, 2001. Beloved wife of the late David. Loving Mother of Robert, Douglas, Harold and Alice. Adoring grandmother of 10. Dear mother-in-law. Cherished aunt. Devoted Friend to many. She was a pioneering educator in learning disabilities & an incredible baker. Graveside funeral service Sunday 2:00PM at Westchester Hills Cemetery, Hastings-on-Hudson, NY.

title: Sharon Harper
description: Whitney Museum of American Art

title: A Voyage to the Outer Limits of Hilarity
description: BREATHLESSNESS, vertigo and that scary-sweet exhilaration of being out of control: there are few highs to equal the experience of floating in the upper altitudes of comedy. In the spectacularly funny new revival of ''Noises Off,'' Michael Frayn's peerless backstage farce, there are moments when everyone -- onstage and in the audience -- seems to be riding the same runaway roller coaster.

title: We Need Answers on Anthrax
description: To the Editor:

title: Terror Inquiry Is Using Law On Sedition
description: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan said yesterday in a newly filed court document that among the offenses being investigated by the grand jury looking into the Sept. 11 terror attacks was whether there was a ''seditious conspiracy to levy war against the United States.''

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: M.A.D.D. Retrenches
description: Hurt by a sudden drop in donations, Mothers Against Drunk Drivers said it is closing offices for 4 of its 11 chapters in New Jersey. The Hunterdon-Somerset, Camden-Gloucester and Sussex chapters have already closed their offices, and the Morris-Passaic chapter office in Morristown will close soon, said Tresa Hardt, a national spokeswoman for the organization in Irving, Tex. Ms. Hardt cited a shift in contributions to other charities after the Sept. 11 terror attack. She emphasized that the chapters remain open but that they could no longer afford commercial office space. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CAL-MAINE FOODS, Jackson, Miss., the country's largest egg producer, said it had decided against taking the company private, citing poor economics and general market turmoil.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Boldface Names column yesterday about job changes by cable television anchors misidentified the network that Paula Zahn left in September. It was Fox; CNN was the network she joined.

title: Home of the Heisman May Have to Shut Doors
description: The venerable Downtown Athletic Club, home of the Heisman Trophy, is faced with extinction if its financial woes are not resolved.

title: Colin Keefe
description: ROMEarts

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAWITZKY, SHERRY
description: KAWITZKY-Sherry. On October 31, 2001. Her heartbroken husband Ronald, her children Simon and Deanna and her sister Karen Bressler mourn her untimely passing after a long illness. Our doer, our provider, our comforter is no more. We will never understand why. Only our love for her, and hers for us, can sustain us. Rest in peace our darling. Service Sunday, 11:45AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REARDON, JEAN ELLENBURG
description: REARDON-Jean Ellenburg. Of Hingham, Mass. On October 30 after 60 vibrant years. Beloved wife of Blasdel. Mother of Blase, Sean, Chris, Kevin, Tim. Grandmother of Isabel and Daniele. Manhattanville College, 1962; Art Academy of Cincinnati, 1988. Artist, designer. She imbued all she did with grace, color, and beauty; her spirit shone even in her sudden illness. Funeral Mass Saturday, 11am, St. Paul Church, Hingham; visitation Friday, 2-9PM in Jean's home. Gifts in her memory may be made to St. Paul's, the Hingham Library or Kids Helping Kids (Cincinnati

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: When Shakespeare Could Use a Warning Label
description: If poetry is crucial to your appreciation of Shakespeare, you can pass on the ''King Lear'' by the Belgian theater troupe Needcompany, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Harvey Theater through Sunday.

title: Juan Bosch, 92, Freely Elected Dominican President, Dies
description: Juan Bosch, a prolific writer who in December 1962 became the first freely elected president of the Dominican Republic in 38 years -- only to be toppled by a military coup after seven months in office -- died yesterday in the capital, Santo Domingo. He was 92.

title: Senator Offers Farm Bill, Retaining Subsidies, as a Compromise
description: The chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee today introduced a new farm bill that retains most of the current subsidy system and offers new conservation programs for all farmers.

title: VENATOR, ONCE WOOLWORTH, IS NOW FOOT LOCKER
description: The Venator Group, the country's leading athletic shoe and clothing retailer, is changing its name again. Starting today, the company will be known as Foot Locker. The Venator name was adopted in 1998 as the company, formerly Woolworth, distanced itself from a 117-year tradition as a discount general-merchandise retailer. Venator has divested nonathletic businesses during the last few years, focusing on its Foot Locker, Lady Foot Locker, Kids Foot Locker and Champs Sports athletic-wear stores, the company said. Venator, based in New York, said in September that it had completed the sale of its Northern Group casual clothing business to York Management Services' Canadian affiliate for undisclosed terms. Venator shut its Northern Reflections stores in the United States in the second quarter.

title: Corrections
description: The Making Books column in the arts pages yesterday, about the solace of poetry, misstated the title of a poem by William Butler Yeats that has often been quoted in the days since Sept. 11. It is ''Easter 1916,'' not ''Easter 1960.''

title: Congo's Leader Fears His Nation's Crisis Has Lost U.N. Priority
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1  It was not so long ago that Joseph Kabila's country, the Democratic Republic of the Congo, commanded the world's attention. His father, Laurent Kabila, had overthrown the corrupt dictator Mobutu Sese Seko in 1997, only to have his rule challenged by invading armies from Rwanda, Burundi and Uganda, and to be assassinated less than three years later.

title: Nets' Kidd Chosen For Team USA
description: The next N.B.A. version of Team USA has its first seven members, with Jason Kidd of the Nets at point guard, Reggie Miller and Ray Allen at shooting guard and two players with Indianapolis connections -- Jermaine O'Neal and Antonio Davis -- at center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUNIN, GEORGE H.
description: LUNIN-George H. On Tuesday, October 30. Adored husband of Sylvia (Altshuler), and children Barbara-Jane (B-J) & Dov Frishberg of New York City, Dr. Mitchel & Susan Lunin of Newton, MA and Scott & Halli Lunin of New Jersey, and grandchildren Jesse, Sam, Justin, Zachary, Noam, Russell, Avner, Eric, Adam, Sloane and Sabrina. Services were held in Massachusetts on Friday, November 2. The family will be at 600 W. 115th St., Apt. 93 Sunday through Tues. evenings, 6:30PM-10PM, and in Livingston, New Jersey Sun. & Mon. evenings, 6:30PM-10PM. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be made to Habitat for Humanity or a charity of one's choice.

title: More Gloomy Economic News as Consumer Spending Slumps
description: Manufacturing last month turned in its worst performance since the 1990-1991 recession after consumer spending showed the biggest drop in almost 15 years, an industry report showed today.

title: Monsters of Childhood With Feelings and Agendas
description: Freaks, mutants and misshapen creatures shambling off to work -- no, it's not a documentary about rush hour on the New York subway system. This is the premise of Pixar's newest brightly colored, computer-animated feature, ''Monsters, Inc.''

title: The Mayoral Candidates Debate Public Safety, Education and Each Other
description: The following are excerpts from the New York City mayoral candidates debate yesterday between Mark Green and Michael R. Bloomberg, sponsored by the Campaign Finance Board, the League of Women Voters of the City of New York, WABC and WNYC-Radio, as recorded by The New York Times. Diana Williams of WABC was the moderator. More excerpts are available at The New York Times on the Web at www.nytimes.com.

title: States Biding for Time to Study Microsoft Settlement Plan
description: The 18 states involved in the government's landmark antitrust lawsuit against Microsoft rebuffed repeated requests today by Microsoft and the Justice Department to join the tentative settlement they reached a day earlier.

title: Corrections
description: A brief front-page report yesterday about Game 4 of the World Series referred incorrectly in some copies to the number of innings pitched by Mariano Rivera of the Yankees. It was one, not two.

title: Bloomberg and Green Pound Away in Debate
description: Mark Green and Michael R. Bloomberg tore into each other's character and credentials in an often fierce debate last night that laid out differences between the two mayoral candidates over how the city should rebuild downtown, and the best way to repair New York's troubled public school system.

title: Martinez Saves the Yankees, and Perhaps His Job
description: Jim Leyritz hammered a home run in the last game of the 1999 World Series, thundered around the bases with his burly chest puffed out as the Yankee Stadium crowd exploded, and against all logic and reason, the Yankees' owner, George Steinbrenner, ordered his executives to sign Leyritz to a $1.25 million deal for 2000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANSOOR, MENAHEM
description: MANSOOR-Menahem. Age 90, Professor Emeritus, died October 21, 2001 in Madison, WI. A noted scholar, he founded the Department of Hebrew & Semitic Studies at the University of Wisconsin and taught there for 30 years, helped establish the significance of the Dead Sea Scrolls (NYT, August 13, 1956, p. 1), and wrote over 80 books and articles. He is survived by his wife Claire; daughter Yardena (Michael Phillips) and two grandsons, Gordon and David Phillips of McLean, VA; and son Daniel (Joyce Rothschild) and two granddaughters, Jesse and Emma of New York City. Memorial donations may be sent to the Mansoor Scholarship Endowment, University of Wisconsin Foundation, P.O. Box 8860, Madison, WI. 53706.

title: Ulster's Peace Effort in Turmoil as Protestant Is Blocked in Vote
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Nov. 2  Protestant hard-liners today blocked David Trimble's bid for re-election to Northern Ireland's highest political post, throwing the province's peace effort into turmoil after it had achieved new stability with the start of Irish Republican Army disarmament.

title: Toxic Twins Trade Places and Do Battle
description: There's no place like home, especially if that home is anything like Tromaville, N.J., the rockin' 'n' rollin' self-proclaimed Toxic Chemical Capital of the World. If you would like to visit the place, one way, according to the latest installment of the ''Toxic Avenger'' films, is to grab yourself a pair of ruby slippers and do as Dorothy did in ''The Wizard of Oz.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  URISH, FRANK
description: URISH-Frank. Age 99, died October 19. Born in NYC, he founded the Glo-Mark Products & Company in the 1950's. He is survived by his loving wife of 72 years Eva, his daughters Martha Glaser and Virginia Walzer, seven grandchildren and 15 great-grandchildren.

title: Vital Lessons For These Times
description: Given the mission of National Video Resources, the events of Sept. 11 and afterward have been a kind of call to duty. Established in 1990 by the Rockefeller Foundation, this nonprofit organization spreads information about independently produced films and how communities and individuals can use them to throw light on race relations and other issues.

title: Oprah's Club: The Reluctant Member
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Shell's Profit Falls
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group said third-quarter profit fell 17 percent, a consequence of lower energy prices and a reduced demand for chemicals. Net income, not including one-time charges, fell to $2.69 billion, compared with $3.25 billion in the period a year earlier. That is the first year-over-year decline in quarterly profit since the first quarter of 1999. The industry is suffering from a glut in chemicals and a general decline in demand for oil following the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks and a slowing world economy. The Royal Dutch/Shell Group is a Dutch-British corporation. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Clinton Backs Green, and Koch and Carey Give Their Support to Bloomberg
description: In a day of dueling big-name endorsements, Mark Green won the backing of a former president yesterday over a meal of chicken and ribs in Harlem; Michael R. Bloomberg got the support of a retired governor and a retired mayor who reminisced about World War II and their political legacies on the steps outside City Hall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANCIA, LILLIAN (NEE KOPEC)
description: LANCIA-Lillian (nee Kopec). Beloved wife of the late Ugo. Devoted mother of Elaine Hurst. Also survived by loving grandchildren William, Emily and Michael. Reposing Scotto Funeral Home, 106 First Place, (nr Court St.) Brooklyn, until Saturday. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Charles Borromeo RC Church, 9:30AM. Visiting Friday, 7-9PM.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Woman Hit By Subway Train
description: A Bronx woman was seriously injured after she accidentally dropped her cellphone onto a subway track, climbed down to retrieve it and then was struck by an oncoming No. 4 train at Grand Central Terminal, the police said yesterday. The woman, Laura Goldstein, 22, was listed in serious but stable condition last night at Bellevue Hospital Center with cuts to her head, the police said. Ms. Goldstein was waiting for the northbound train shortly before 10:30 p.m. Wednesday when her cellphone fell onto the track, they said. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Mr. Rumsfeld chooses the targets in America. This is our country. We know it best. If I were the defense minister of America, I could use his weapons better than he.''

title: Cantor Survivors on a Mission; Rebuilding the Firm, and Remembering Those Lost
description: Almost every day, Chris Crosby turns in his chair at Cantor Fitzgerald's technical center in Rochelle Park, N.J., to ask his buddy for help -- for one sweet instant forgetting his friend is dead.

title: New Video Releases
description: Town and Country

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: President Urges U.S. To End Attack
description: In her first state of the nation address since assuming power just over 100 days ago, President Megawati Sukarnoputri called on the United States to bring its attack on Afghanistan to a quick end. Under pressure from Islamic militants here, she has backed away from her initial support of the United States. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Comments by 70's Radical Cast Doubt on Plea Deal
description: A day after the one-time radical Sara Jane Olson entered a surprise guilty plea to charges that she plotted 26 years ago to bomb two police cars, then renounced the plea outside the courtroom, the judge in the case called a meeting to examine the validity of the plea.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Asia: South Korea: Bank Merger
description: The Kookmin Bank merged with the Housing and Commercial Bank, creating Korea's largest commercial bank. With assets of $142 million, Kookmin Bank and Housing and Commercial ranged among South Korea's healthiest companies, but Standard & Poor's rated the new bank as slightly below investment grade. The company was expected to become stronger as it combined operations of many of its 1,124 branches. The government owns 9.6 percent of the bank's shares, less than its stake in other banks taken over during the Korean economic crisis, but enough for ultimate control over policy decisions. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DAVISON, CHARLES HAMILTON
description: DAVISON-Charles Hamilton. December 20, 1926-November 2, 2000. In loving memory from his family

title: Oprah's Club: The Reluctant Member
description: To the Editor:

title: Setting Forth, the Wind in Her Sails
description: ''I am a tall glass of sparkling cider,'' announces Cass, the exceedingly whimsical heroine of David Lindsay-Abaire's exceedingly whimsical ''Wonder of the World,'' which opened last night at the Manhattan Theater Club.

title: For the First Time Since Ike, a Whiff of U.S. Deflation
description: DEFLATION. To a generation raised to fear inflation, the opposite -- prices falling across the economy -- has a certain attraction. Paying less must be good.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Governor Studying Budget Cuts
description: Gov. Gary Locke's budget office is reviewing ''very difficult'' budget cuts suggested by state agencies as ways to deal with a $1 billion budget deficit that could be created by the faltering of the state's economy. The seven largest agencies were directed to trim 15 percent of their budgets, a total of $577 million; $470 million would come from the Department of Social and Health Services alone. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Air Force Set to Run Recruiting Campaign
description: The Air Force will begin running on Sunday the first phase of a $50 million recruitment campaign aimed at Americans 16 to 24 years old.

title: BUSH'S APPROACH ON PLANE SECURITY CHOSEN BY HOUSE
description: Heeding President Bush, the House today approved a Republican bill to place the federal government in charge of airport security without turning 28,000 baggage and passenger screeners into federal workers.

title: The Rise and Fall of Enron
description: Earlier this year, most companies would have loved to have Enron's problems. Californians resented the energy trading company's huge profits during their energy crisis, and Democrats in Washington raised questions about Enron's influence within the White House and about the cozy relationship between Enron's chairman, Kenneth Lay, and Vice President Dick Cheney. Nobody seemed better positioned to thrive during the Bush presidency than this Houston-based apostle of deregulation.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Chechnya Death Toll
description: The Kremlin said that 3,434 Russian soldiers had died in Chechnya and more than 11,000 had been wounded since Russia mounted its second military operation there, in October 1999, but an association of soldiers' mothers, citing hospital and morgue records, estimates that up to 10,000 Russian servicemen may have died. Sergei Yastrzhembsky, a government spokesman, said that 11,000 rebel fighters had been killed in the latest war. Human rights groups say that tens of thousands of civilians may have been killed and wounded in the two wars.

title: 240 New Firefighters: Bricks for Rebuilding a Department
description: It was a day of heroic salutes and somber remembrances yesterday, as 240 probationary firefighters graduated and prepared to take their place in a department still grieving the loss of hundreds of its veterans in the World Trade Center attack.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Sports of The Times; Facing Big Unit Again
description: AT a skinny 6 feet 10 inches, he's the tallest pitcher in major league history, a flamingo with a flamethrower. And when Randy Johnson is up there on the mound, as he will be tomorrow night in Phoenix in Game 6 of the World Series, it's as if his pitches are coming down from the top of nearby Pinnacle Peak or Superstition Mountain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEUMANN, EVA
description: NEUMANN-Eva. On October 31, after a long illness. Loving daughter of Lotte Berman. Beloved friend of many friends. Service Friday 12 noon at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street & Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Firefighters Are Arrested During Protest at Ground Zero
description: Abrief but emotionally wrenching scuffle broke out yesterday morning between New York City firefighters and police officers at the scene of their shared grief, the World Trade Center disaster site. A dozen firefighters were arrested and five police officers were injured in the incident, which rattled the city's top officials and laid bare the frustrations of the living who are unable to bury their dead.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSER, FELICIA
description: MOSER-Felicia. Town and Village Synagogue-Tifereth Israel mourns the loss of its longstanding member and extends heartfelt condolences to her family. Rabbi Laurence A. Sebert Rabbi Abby Sosland Cantor Shayna Smith Dr. Lewis Freedman, President

title: Surrounded by Terror but Ready to Die Fighting
description: When Leon Uris wrote ''Mila 18'' 40 years ago, the Holocaust was a painfully fresh event. His fictional rendering of Jewish resistance in the Warsaw Ghetto was populated with defiant men and women who would rather die fighting Nazis than succumb to humiliation and deportation. The book's lusty and fearless heroes and heroines provided a deliberate counterbalance to the numbing images of skeletal victims and survivors of the Nazi camps, following up on Uris's popularization of the brawny Jew in ''Exodus,'' his best-selling novel about the creation of the Israeli state.

title: Police Overtime Since Attack Creates Retirement Incentive
description: The New York Police Department expects to pay up to $1.7 billion in overtime this fiscal year, a sum more than five times the record overtime it paid last year to officers who worked extra hours or extra shifts.

title: Incredibly, Yankees Rally In 9th Again and Win in 12
description: Scott Brosius returned home at 2 a.m. yesterday, still overwhelmed by the enormousness and drama of Tino Martinez's game-tying home run in the ninth inning of Game 4 of the World Series. Brosius could not sleep, so he called a friend on the West Coast. ''Have you ever seen a game like that in your lifetime?'' Brosius said.

title: Yankees Rally in 9th Again and Win in 12
description: Scott Brosius returned home at 2 a.m. yesterday, still overwhelmed by the enormousness and drama of Tino Martinez's game-tying home run in the ninth inning of Game 4 of the World Series. Brosius could not sleep, so he called a friend on the West Coast. "Have you ever seen a game like that in your lifetime?" Brosius said.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: ADT To Sell Face Recognition System
description: Tyco International's ADT Security Services unit, a leading vendor of airport security systems, said it would add face recognition technology to its surveillance offerings. ADT will resell a system made by the Visionics Corporation in which networks of video cameras can rapidly scan the faces of passers-by to identify airport employees or criminal suspects by matching their features to images in databases. Terms of the marketing alliance were not disclosed. Visionics shares, which rose 71 cents yesterday, to $16.57, have nearly quadrupled since Sept. 11.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: A Lifeline From The U.S.
description: The government announced that remittances from Mexicans living in the United States would top $9 billion this year and probably replace tourism as the nation's second-largest source of foreign revenue behind oil exports. So far this year remittances have increased 35 percent over the same period last year. Graham Gori (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANTER, BURTON W.
description: KANTER-Burton W. Beloved husband of Naomi (nee Krakow), loving daddy-o of Joel (Rickie) Kanter, Janis (Tom) McCormick & Joshua (Catherine) Kanter, dear grandfather of Jeremy, Laura, Daniel, Tatum, Reese and Peapod, fond brother of Carl and Jerry Kanter. Services Friday, 1 P.M., at Chicago Sinai Congregation 15 W. Delaware, Chicago. Entombment Memorial Park Mausoleum. In lieu of flowers, contributions to charity of choice would be appreciated. For information: The Piser Chapel, 847-679-4740.

title: Devils Win Sixth Straight Behind Brodeur
description: Phoenix goaltender Robert Esche displayed the letters NYPD and NYFD on his blue mask for his visit to Continental Arena tonight. But his tribute to the New York City police officers and firefighters hardly mattered to the Devils, who scored three goals in a four-minute span before the game was 13 minutes old.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: After 10 years on the corner of Jane Street and Hudson Street, Mi Cocina had become firmly established as a cozy neighborhood spot. The prices were low, the dcor humble, the kitchen not terribly ambitious in its approach to Mexican food. Jose Hurtado-Prud'homme, the chef and owner, decided to make a change. Several changes, in fact. He enlarged the dining room, adding a lounge up front. He moved the front door from Jane to Hudson. He invested heavily in tequilas, putting 60 of them on the menu, and in Mexican wines. And he threw out the old menu, putting in its place a much more extensive list of regional dishes, some of them modernized, some not.

title: Better Cars, Cleaner Air
description: As chairman of the Ford Motor Company, William Clay Ford Jr. said all the right things about the environment. As its new chief executive officer, he'll have the power to put his words into action. His challenge is to prove that an enlightened executive can turn Ford into a responsible corporate citizen.

title: Flags, Mom and Apple Pie Through Altered Eyes
description: IN an uncanny boon for the Guggenheim, if you're cynically minded, the fortuitous arrival of the two-year-old Norman Rockwell traveling exhibition in New York after Sept. 11 gives everybody in town a chance to contemplate through altered eyes the Rembrandt of Punkin Crick, as a critic acidly dubbed him years ago.

title: Bush Plans Speeches With Coherent, Unified Message
description: President Bush is planning several major speeches next week to counteract what some administration officials say has been a muddled effort to project a coherent, convincing message to Americans about the war in Afghanistan and their safety at home.

title: Struggling Justice Bumped to No. 7 Spot
description: Joe Torre opted to start David Justice in Game 1 of the World Series on Saturday, figuring that Justice had had success against Arizona Diamondbacks pitcher Curt Schilling. Not only did Justice make an error in right field, but he went 0 for 3.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, KATHRYN
description: FISHER-Kathryn. Of San Carlos, CA, passed away November 1, 2001, formerly of Miami Beach and Elkins Park, PA. Survived by her husband, Philip, her son, Herbert (Lilliann), daughters, Barbara (Conny) Raitzky and Jane (Larry) David, grandchildren, Colin, Cliff and Mallie. She was the most gentle, kind, loving person who never complained about anything. She will be sorely missed.

title: Michigan Resort
description: Winter in northern Michigan may not make a lot of people jump. So the 660-room Grand Traverse Resort and Spa is dropping its rates from Nov. 1 to Dec. 25. Rates begin at $89 a night in the hotel and $119 in the Tower. What is there to do? Indoors, there is swimming, tennis and spa treatments. The resort, on East Grand Traverse Bay in Lake Michigan, also has a cross-country ski center that opens in mid-December, weather permitting. Information: (800) 748-0303 or www.grandtraverseresort.com .

title: Martinez Will Start Game 6
description: Joe Torre announced he will start Tino Martinez at first base tomorrow in Game 6 against the Diamondbacks' Randy Johnson. Randy Velarde played first base in Game 2 against Johnson and went 0 for 3.

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Chrebet Is Unsure Of His Role With Jets
description: It was not so much that Jets receiver Wayne Chrebet was sitting on the edge of his sofa, watching his team's offense stall against Carolina last Sunday while he was home nursing a concussion, that worried him. It was that Chrebet's buddies seemed to have a direct pipeline to the Jets' play-calling.

title: Privatization Snag in South Africa
description: When South Africa announced this week that the initial public offering of Telkom South Africa, by far the largest telecommunications company south of the Sahara, would be delayed yet again, the news threw cold water on the whole privatization effort here -- not to mention the national budget.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'CONNELL, ADELE Q., (NEE QUILGAN)
description: O'CONNELL-Adele Q., (nee Quilgan), 91. Of Little Silver, New Jersey, formerly of New York City, NY on Tuesday, October 30, 2001. Wife of the late James Timothy O'Connell, former Under Secretary of Labor during the Eisenhower Administration. Mother of (U.S. Army Ret.) Col. James T. O'Connell, Jr. and daughter-inlaw Pauline O'Connell, Katherine O'Connell, Anne Latona and sonin-law Donald Latona, Dorothy Cherry and Mary O'Connell and son-in-law Peter Grua. Grandmother of ten, great grandmother of seven. Visitation at the John E. Day Funeral Home, 85 Riverside Avenue, Red Bank, NJ Friday 2-4 & 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Saturday, November 3, 2001 at 9AM at Church of the Nativity, Hance Road, Fairhaven, NJ. Burial St. Raymond's R.C. Cemetery, Bronx, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory may be made to Mount St. Vincent's College, 6301 Riverdale Avenue, Riverdale, NY 10471, or the Little Silver First Aid Squad, 543 Prospect Avenue, Little Silver, NJ 07739 or the Visiting Nurse Association of Central Jersey, 141 Bodman Place, Red Bank, N.J. 07701.

title: TV Ratings Increase
description: Game 4 of the World Series generated a 15.8 Nielsen rating on Fox, a 26 percent leap over the 12.2 rating last year for the comparable game between the Yankees and the Mets.

title: Watching Terror on TV
description: To the Editor:

title: In Bridgeport, Mayor Resists Call to Resign
description: The day after a federal grand jury indicted him on numerous corruption charges, Mayor Joseph P. Ganim called a news conference today to state once more that he was innocent and to challenge Gov. John G. Rowland's demand that he resign.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Anti-Torture Bill Passed
description: Parliament has passed legislation that outlaws torture and permits Ireland to ratify a 14-year-old United Nations convention against torture, Justice Minister John O'Donoghue said. The move will allow Irish courts to try people for committing torture anywhere in the world, with a maximum sentence of life imprisonment, and overrules extradition agreements if a subject could face torture once extradited. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Arizona's Supporting Cast Draws Mixed Reviews
description: The Arizona Diamondbacks often seem more sideshow than team, rambling from town to town with a pair of flamethrowers who overwhelm hitters as if they were helpless milk bottles. As the Diamondbacks marched to the World Series, the players insisted that their team was much deeper, with vital contributors throughout the roster.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUMNER, JANET
description: SUMNER-Janet. The Board of Directors and members of the Salmagundi Club deeply regret the passing of their beloved member since 1973. Edward Brennan, Chairman of the Board

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of yesterday, 4,651 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11.

title: Enron's Shares Fall and Debt Rating Is Cut
description: With investors absorbing news of a formal Securities and Exchange Commission investigation and a downgrading by another large credit-rating agency, shares of the Enron Corporation fell 13.7 percent today, giving back most of the gains from Wednesday's rally.

title: ALBUM OF THE WEEK
description: DAVD GARZA: -- ''Overdub'' (Lava/ Atlantic). Here's a jump on the inevitable critics' lists of great albums overlooked in the last year. ''Overdub'' came out in early summer, but its witching-hour blend of Led Zeppelin-style whomp and soul-scented swoon sounds even better now, when night comes earlier and mystery hangs in the air.

title: To Sway Russia, Bush Will Propose Cuts to Nuclear Arsenal
description: President Bush will decide in the next few days how deeply to slash America's nuclear arsenal as part of a new understanding with Russia on missile defense and strategic nuclear arms, officials said today.

title: Bush Keeps a Grip on Presidential Papers
description: President Bush signed an executive order today to allow a sitting president to keep secret the papers of a previous president, even if a previous president wants his papers made public.

title: Car Tips From Readers
description: From choosing a car to advice on leasing, readers share their insights and answer fellow readers' questions.

title: Deer Dies After Crossing Manhattan Roadway
description: A deer that had apparently been wandering around Washington Heights in Manhattan died yesterday after being struck as it crossed morning traffic along the Henry Hudson Parkway, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLORIO, JOHN J.
description: FLORIO-John J. Age 33, Firefighter Engine Co. 214 (''The Nuthouse''), tragically in the line of duty on September 11, 2001 during the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center. Beloved husband of Shari (nee Goldman). Devoted father of Michael and Kylie. Loving son of John and the late Patricia (nee Cooper), and Ginny (nee Di Petrillo). Dear brother and brother-in-law of Elizabeth and Don Kiel. Proud uncle of James and Danielle Kiel. Dear son-in-law of Steven and Esther Siegel. Dear brother-in-law of Wendy and Scott Goldman. Also survived by many cousins. Reposing Friday at George Werst Funeral Home, Cooper Avenue at 72 Street, Glendale, New York, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. A Mass of Christian burial Saturday, November 3, at Our Lady of Hope R.C. Church, Eliot Avenue, Middle Village, NY. Interment Calvary Cemetery. ''Forever a Hero.''

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: German Leader Courts Beijing
description: In a three-day visit to China, the end of an Asian tour, Chancellor Gerhard Schrder of Germany is cultivating economic and political ties. Mr. Schrder praised China's leaders for supporting the war on terrorism, but the main focus was on business: he watched German and Chinese business leaders sign agreements for investments and trade worth several billion dollars. China has avidly sought investments and high technology from Europe, in part to reduce dependence on the United States.

title: University Foundation Says Geron May Lose Stem-Cell Rights
description: The University of Wisconsin's patent licensing foundation is threatening to revoke at least part of the Geron Corporation's exclusive commercial rights related to human embryonic stem cells, a development that could throw the promising field of research open to other companies and academic researchers.

title: Anatomy of a Game-Winning, Series-Tying Homer
description: As Game 4 of the World Series played out, Derek Jeter paused a couple of times to note that Manager Joe Torre's contract was about to expire at midnight. At 11:55 p.m., Jeter sat next to Torre, who had all but completed negotiations for a contract extension, and said, "Only five more minutes to go."

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Massachusetts: Symphony Cancels 'Klinghoffer'
description: The Boston Symphony Orchestra, citing ''proximity to the events of Sept. 11,'' has canceled performances this month and next of excerpts from ''The Death of Klinghoffer,'' an opera by John Adams about the 1985 killing of Leon Klinghoffer, an American cruise ship passenger, by Palestinian hijackers. The opera was perceived by some as overly sympathetic to the hijackers.

title: Blair Tries to Lift Mideast Peace Talks From 'Low Point'
description: Declaring relations between Israelis and Palestinians to be ''at a low point,'' Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain warned today that the conflict had global stakes, as he pressed both sides to stop fighting and start negotiating.

title: INSIDE ART
description: Donors Bestow A Rare Stella

title: We Need Answers on Anthrax
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about H. Gerard Bissinger II, former president of the Lebenthal municipal bond firm, misstated the given name of his surviving son. The son is H. Gerard Bissinger III, not Gerald.

title: Cacophony In Three Parts
description: Richard Linklater's small, incisive film ''Tape'' puts a friendship between two male buddies and a woman they once loved under a microscope and finds the same festering resentment and struggle for dominance that Neil LaBute uncovered so brilliantly in his movie ''In the Company of Men.'' ''Tape,'' adapted from a play by Stephen Belber, is set entirely in a motel room in Lansing, Mich., its three characters' hometown. By the end of the film, the vicious mind games played by these former high school classmates have destroyed any illusions that the feelings they have carried around for one another in the 10 years since graduation are benign.

title: Even the Diamondbacks Call Game 4 a Classic
description: There was a moment in the sixth game of the 1975 World Series when Pete Rose turned to Carlton Fisk as if he were just a fellow baseball fan. What a great game, Rose said, even though Fisk was his rival and the stakes were high. Rose's Reds would lose to Fisk's Red Sox, but Rose knew history when he saw it.

title: U.S. 'Advisers': A Tale of Saigon
description: To the Editor:

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: Rest Time For Nathan

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COPELON, HERMAN
description: COPELON-Herman. The Board of Governors and Members of High Ridge Country Club acknowledge with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Herman Copelon. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved family. Richard J. Bornstein, President Leon Fassler, Secretary

title: LOSS ESTIMATE GROWS AT CREDIT SUISSE FIRST BOSTON
description: Credit Suisse First Boston has more than doubled its estimate of third-quarter net losses, to $400 million from the $187 million it had predicted three weeks ago, according to a statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The company, the investment banking unit of the Credit Suisse Group, will post a $25 million net loss for the first nine months of the year, according to the statement. The company said the losses were primarily the result of difficult market conditions affecting the industry in general.

title: Seeking Long-Distance Solace
description: For a week after Sept. 11, Chris Bilsky was too distraught to train. ''Running seemed trivial,'' said Bilsky, 38, of Manhattan, who lost several friends in the attack on the World Trade Center. ''I felt that in honor of the people who died, I shouldn't run.''

title: Lansing-Dreiden
description: Lawrence/Feuer/LaMontagne

title: CALIFORNIA LEADER WARNS OF THREAT TO STATE'S BRIDGES
description: Gov. Gray Davis warned today that there was ''credible evidence'' that terrorists were plotting a rush-hour attack in the next seven days on one or more of California's most prominent bridges, including the Golden Gate and Bay Bridges.

title: Foreign Affairs; One War, Two Fronts
description: A month into the war in Afghanistan, the hand-wringing has already begun over how long this might last. Let's all take a deep breath and repeat after me: Give war a chance. This is Afghanistan we're talking about. Check the map. It's far away.

title: Vital Lessons for These Times
description: Given the mission of National Video Resources, the events of Sept. 11 and afterward have been a kind of call to duty. Established in 1990 by the Rockefeller Foundation, this nonprofit organization spreads information about independently produced films and how communities and individuals can use them to throw light on race relations and other issues.

title: Survivors Recount Fierce American Raid that Flattened a Village
description: Mehmood is that rarity in Afghanistan, a man of means. And so when American air raids began to strike at the center of Kandahar, he thought it best to move his wife, children and relatives here to Chowkar-Karez, his ancestral village.

title: Vehicle Sales for October Were Highest Ever in U.S.
description: Sales of cars and trucks in the United States soared to the highest monthly level ever in October, automakers reported today, but they were spurred by deep discounts that foreshadow trouble in the months ahead.

title: Trysting in a Cemetery Where Death Is a Metaphor
description: FALLING ANGELS

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Cuteness Computerized

title: A Sample of the Riches From a Scottish Trove
description: Frustrated by his inability to draw, the English scientist William Henry Fox Talbot found a way to do so with light. By inventing the calotype, he could make multiple positive prints of those drawings with light from a paper negative. Talbot created images of undeniable artistry in the early 1840's, but it was a team from Scotland, Hill and Adamson, that turned the calotype and photography into a formidable art form.

title: Threat of Nuclear Terror Has Increased, Official Says
description: The Sept. 11 attacks on the United States have increased the chances that terrorists might try to use nuclear weapons or materials, or attack nuclear power plants, the director of the International Atomic Energy Agency warned today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAHN, DR. FRED I.
description: HAHN-Dr. Fred I. In New York City on October 31, 2001. Fred was a psychologist in NY for 45 years and touched many people's lives. He loved life, great food, travelling, antiques, his family and his cat. He is deeply missed by his wife Barbara, brother Bill, children Hilary, Gregory, Scott, Graham and granddaughter Hannah. He wrote poems for his family and a book for his patients. Services on Saturday 2 PM at the home of friends, 255 W. 88th St., #

title: Transcript of John Turmel's Visit to the Drug Policy Forum
description: On Tuesday, October 23, the NYTimes.com's Drug Policy forum hosted John Turmel, a marijuana legalization activist. This discussion was one in a continuing series organized by forum participants.

title: Editors' Note; Today's Sections
description: News of the Sept. 11 attacks and their aftermath continues to appear in Section B; index, Page B2.

title: Security Lapses Close Terminal
description: Federal security agents ordered an American Airlines terminal at Kennedy International Airport evacuated at 4:30 p.m. today after they decided that passengers were not being screened properly, said Laura J. Brown, a spokeswoman for the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: Print Fair
description: Lyden Gardens Hotel

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article in Business Day on Saturday about the stimulus package passed by the House of Representatives misstated a tax specialist's estimate of how much money states would lose in revenue if, as the bill proposes, companies were allowed to accelerate write-offs for purchases of new equipment in the next three years. Robert Greenstein, executive director of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, estimated that the provision would cost 44 states and the District of Columbia a total of $5 billion a year, not $5 billion apiece.

title: Net Climbs 18% at MBIA, a Bond Insurer
description: MBIA Inc., a bond insurer, said today that it had an 18 percent increase in third-quarter net income because of additional municipal bond insurance sales and refinancings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELLER, MONA S.
description: FELLER-Mona S. Passed away peacefully on October 30, 2001. Resident of Riverdale, NY, formerly of Jersey City, NJ. Beloved wife of the late Dr. William Feller. Devoted mother of Patricia Neistadt of Riverdale, NY, Karen Mitnick of Haworth, NJ and Bruce Feller of Wayne, NJ. Loving grandmother of David, Meryl and Barbara Neistadt, Erica and Emily Mitnick. Sister of Syd and May. Services today 11:30 AM at Riverdale Temple, Independence Avenue, Riverdale, New York.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Argentine Leader Announces Debt Revision and Subsidies
description: In a last-ditch effort to avert a costly debt default, President Fernando de la Ra tonight announced a partial restructuring of Argentina's crushing $132 billion debt and a package of subsidies for the poor and tax breaks for businesses.

title: New York May Get More Than Bush Promised
description: Leading New York lawmakers emerged from a meeting at the White House today saying they had been told that New York would receive more federal relief aid than the $20 billion that President Bush initially promised after the World Trade Center attack.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURKO, MARVIN H.
description: BURKO-Marvin H. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Marvin H. Burko, beloved father of our devoted members, Elliott and Stephanie Burko, grandfather of Daniel, student of our Leon and Gina Fromer Religious School, and Nicholas. Deepest sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: Husband's Crimes Are Not Expected to Hinder Pirro's Re-election Bid
description: A year ago today, Jeanine F. Pirro's husband was sentenced to 29 months in federal prison for income tax fraud, casting doubt on the political future of Ms. Pirro, the Westchester County district attorney and a rising Republican star.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONLON, MARTIN J.
description: DONLON-Martin J. Of Douglaston, New York on October 31, 2001. Husband of the late Dorothy J. Donlon. Visiting in the Doyle B. Shaffer Funeral Home, Little Neck Parkway and Northern Blvd, Little Neck, NY on Friday 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass on Saturday 9:45 AM in St. Anastasia RC Church. Interment Nassau Knolls Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISNER, JEFFREY MICHAEL, M.D.
description: ISNER-Jeffrey Michael, M.D. The staff of the Zena and Michael A. Wiener Cardiovascular Institute of the Mount Sinai Medical Center mourn the passing of our friend and colleague, Jeffrey Michael Isner, M.D., Professor of Medicine, Tufts Medical School. Dr. Isner was an outstanding clinician and pioneer in cardiovascular gene therapy research. Our profound condolences to his wife Linda and children. Valentin Fuster, M.D., Ph.D. Director Cardiovascular Institute Mount Sinai School of Medicine

title: NBC and Amazon Aim Store at Viewers
description: NBC Connect in New York, the division of NBC sales and marketing that develops multimedia advertising packages, and Amazon.com, based in Seattle, have agreed to create an online store that will enable viewers of programs on NBC broadcast and cable networks and stations to buy merchandise mentioned in or related to those programs. The store will operate through Dec. 30. Though terms were not disclosed, NBC will receive part of the revenue from sales generated by the store.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, REBECCA Z.
description: SOLOMON-Rebecca Z. Died October 25. Loving mother of Susan Hamilton, ''Nana'' of Matthew and Emily Hamilton. Sister of Sema Unterman and Jean Kurnit, aunt, colleague and friend. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Operation Frontline, 111 Osage Street, Building D #

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCUS, ROBERT P.
description: MARCUS-Robert P. The Palm Beach Country Club expresses its sorrow at the passing of its esteemed member, Robert P. Marcus, and extends sincere sympathy to his family and friends. David S. Mack, President Michael Stein, Secretary

title: TV Station Raid in Georgia Leads to Protests and Cabinet's Ouster
description: Already racked by tensions with Russia and a guerrilla war, Georgia descended further into political crisis today after a police raid on a popular television station set off mass protests and the dismissal of most of the government.

title: INSIDE
description: Tour at U.S. Embassy in Iran

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREGORY, SAGE BEDDINGFIELD
description: GREGORY-Sage Beddingfield. Of Beacon Hill, Boston on October 30, 2001. Six months old, precious daughter of Sacha and William (Terry). An angel put to rest, treasured by her maternal grandparents and uncle, paternal grandmother, aunts and cousins. Memorial service at Trinity Church, Copley Square, November 3 at 2:00 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory to Cardiac Intensive Care Unit Fund, In Support Of Research For Pulmonory Hypertension, C/O Icaren Engelbourg, Children's Hospital Trust, Children's Hospital, 300 Longwood Avenue, Boston, MA. 02115.

title: In Overheard Calls, Terrorists Spoke of Major Attack, Officials Say
description: Government officials intercepted telephone conversations in recent days in which members of Osama bin Laden's terrorist network, Al Qaeda, spoke urgently of an imminent attack against American targets even larger than the Sept. 11 attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, senior government officials say.

title: NORTHROP RESTATES PROFIT AFTER SHIP PROJECT STOPS
description: Northrop Grumman restated third-quarter profit yesterday after stopping work on two ships for a cruise company, American Classic Voyages, which filed for bankruptcy protection last week. Earnings fell to $79 million, or 84 cents a share, from the $117 million, or $1.28, previously reported, Northrop said. Northrop said the revised results reflected $60 million in costs to stop work on the ships. American Classic filed for Chapter 11 protection after failing to get a federal loan to complete the ships. It also sought continued financing from United States Maritime Administration, which declined to guarantee the financing.

title: Berkshire Set To Acquire Apparel Giant
description: Berkshire Hathaway, the holding company and investment vehicle controlled by the billionaire Warren E. Buffett, agreed today to pay $835 million in cash for Fruit of the Loom, the underwear and apparel company that is now operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.

title: Drossin Is Lacking Experience, Not Talent
description: On the track, Deena Drossin has won the last two United States titles at 10,000 meters. In cross-country, she has won the last five United States titles. But the marathon? Never, she said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBERMAN, NORMAN
description: LIEBERMAN-Norman. On October 31 at 73 years. Beloved husband of Helen. Devoted father of Lawrence, Jeffrey, Shari Franco and Abram. Cherished grandfather of John, Michael, Heather and Lynne. Adored great grandfather of Matthew & Evan. Dear brother of Gloria Burg. Service Friday 10AM, ''Parkside'' Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, NY, opposite Kings Plaza.

title: A Nation Challenged
description: Airport Security

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: AUTO RACING

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAIM, VICTOR
description: HAIM-Victor. On October 31 at 83 years, survived by his wife of nearly 56 years Mary, by his children Marc, Bob and Jackie, and by his eight grandchildren. Services Friday at 1 PM at Riverside Chapel, 55 Station Plaza, Great Neck.

title: Board to Regain Use of 2 Schools Near Ground Zero
description: Public School/Intermediate School 89, closed since Sept. 11, will be returned to the control of the Board of Education on Monday, Chancellor Harold O. Levy said yesterday.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Loss Narrows At Priceline
description: Priceline.com, the Internet travel agency based in Norwalk, Conn., reported a third-quarter loss of $3.59 million, or 2 cents a share, compared with a loss of $199.1 million, or $1.19 a share, a year earlier. The company said it had reduced costs as bookings declined. Sales fell 12 percent, to $302 million. Priceline.com reduced expenses by shuffling executives, laying off 38 percent of its staff and shelving expansion plans. The revamping, intended to lower annual costs by $70 million came after a string of complaints and publicity about customer service and the closing of an affiliated company. Shares of the company fell 41 cents, to $4.40.

title: Goldman Sachs Hires Senior Executive
description: In a sign that not all hiring has stopped on Wall Street, the Goldman Sachs Group has hired Alison J. Mass, a high-ranking employee in the investment banking operation at Merrill Lynch, for a new senior executive position.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Cabinet Gets Anti-Corruption Measure
description: Legislation to reform government procurement procedures has gone to the cabinet for ministers' signatures, a key step in final approval of a measure aimed at reducing corruption and increasing transparency in government purchases and contracts. Passage of the legislation is part of Turkey's efforts to ensure continued financial aid from international lending agencies.

title: For D.A. in Suffolk and Westchester
description: The noisiest election contests in Suffolk and Westchester Counties this fall are those for district attorney. Both races pit active Democratic challengers against veteran Republican incumbents. Here are our recommendations:

title: Terror Tops Rivals' Agendas in New Jersey
description: ''If you get elected, what is the very first thing you are going to do?''

title: Pakistani Atomic Expert, Arrested Last Week, Had Strong Pro-Taliban Views
description: Sultan Bashiruddin Mahmood, a nuclear engineer who was one of three Pakistani scientists arrested last week because of their suspected connections with the Taliban, is an expert on nuclear weapons production, but also a fundamentalist Muslim with unorthodox scientific views, scientists familiar with the Pakistani scientific circles said today.

title: CITING SLOWDOWN, BEA SYSTEMS WILL CUT UP TO 330 JOBS
description: BEA Systems plans to cut as many as 330 jobs, or 10 percent of its staff, to cope with a slowdown in software sales. The company will have $15 million to $20 million in costs related to the job cuts in the fourth quarter. Before one-time costs, profit in the third quarter, which ended Oct. 31, was 5 cents to 6 cents a share on sales of $217 million to $221 million, based on a preliminary review. Analysts had expected the company to earn 8 cents on sales of $253.5 million. In the third quarter last year, the company had net income of $8.24 million, or 2 cents a share, on sales of $224 million. The company, whose programs help Internet sites and Web programs run faster and avoid shutdowns, said corporations were reducing spending on software and taking longer to approve purchases.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: WPP Loses Challenge
description: British regulators upheld a ruling that ordered the WPP Group to proceed with a takeover of the Tempus Group. WPP, the British advertising company, has argued that the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks hastened a decline in the advertising market and hurt Tempus's business of buying advertising space for clients. Last week, after regulators ruled that WPP must proceed with the $635 million acquisition, WPP said it would appeal the decision. The Takeover Panel, Britain's regulator of mergers and acquisitions, said it heard arguments in the case on Wednesday and voted to dismiss the appeal. The panel said it would provide both parties with detailed reasons behind its decision early next week, at which time WPP has the option of lodging another appeal. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Businesses Seek Aid
description: A group of small-business owners whose companies were hurt by the Sept. 11 attack traveled by bus from Manhattan to Washington yesterday to lobby Congress for federal aid. The owners of 48 restaurants, shops and other businesses in Lower Manhattan urged lawmakers to approve legislation being drafted by Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and Representative Jerrold Nadler, both Democrats from New York. Their bill would provide as much as $1 billion in grants rather than loans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHSTEIN, FREYDA (AKA FREDDIE SIMON)
description: ROTHSTEIN-Freyda (aka Freddie Simon). Died in her sleep on October 28th, 2001 in Venice, Italy while on a cruise. She is survived by her two sons, Aron and Daniel. She had a performing career as a folk singer on her own radio program on WNYC, and as half the folk singing duo, ''Frey and Martin''. A graduate of The High School of Music and Art and Carnegie Mellon University, she was one of the first women to have produced a daytime drama serial, and moved on to become an executive at Paramount Television. She served as Vice President of Network Development for David Susskind at Talent Associates and Time/Life Productions before moving to Los Angeles and establishing ''Freyda Rothstein Productions'', executive producing over 40 television movies, many based on true stories, often controversial. ''Crisis at Central High'', the story of integration at the high school in Little Rock, won a Christopher Award and an Emmy nomination. In 1990 she affiliated with Hearst Entertainment, maintaining a successful career decades past the age considered employable in this youth dominated medium. Nothing stopped her-not being a senior citizen, not having a leg amputated in 1997 as a result of vascular disease. In 2001, she made two movies for ''Lifetime''''Dangerous Child'' and ''Snap Judgement''. In addition to her impressive television credits, she was known as a quilt collector. Quilts from her collection are peridically displayed at the Museum of American Folk Art in NYC. Feisty, fearless and fun loving, she'll be deeply missed by the cast of thousands who admired and loved her. She withheld nothing but her age. A memorial service will be Sunday, November 4th at 2PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Corrections
description: A transcript of excerpts yesterday from an interview with Michael R. Bloomberg, the Republican mayoral candidate, misspelled the surname of a former New York governor he cited as a politician who moved from private business to public service. It was Herbert H. Lehman, not Leahman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARRELL, HAZEL (NEE MEDFORD)
description: FARRELL-Hazel (nee Medford). Of Freehold, NJ and Woodhaven, NY, October 31, 2001, in her 88th year. Beloved widow of James E. Farrell, whom she married on her 21st birthday in 1935. Devoted mother of Carol and Walter Bennett, of Freehold, NJ; Margaret and Gerald Nelson, of Brooklyn, NY; and James E. Farrell, Jr. and Gail Farrell, of Garden City, NY. Cherished Nana of Maureen Bennett, Alison and Brett Weisberg, Kathleen and Keith Daly, Michael and Tracy Nelson and Caroline Nelson; and Jamie, Christopher, Brian and Kaitlyn Farrell. Proud great-grandmother of Victoria Grace Daly. Loving sister-in-law of Mary Farrell and Mary Doolittle. Retired employee of NYC Transit. Native of Brooklyn, NY where she was born on June 9, 1914. Friends may call Friday 2-5, 7-9 PM at the Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, 29 Atlantic Avenue (at RR Plaza), Floral Park. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated Saturday 10 AM at St. Anne's R.C. Church, interment Cypress Hills Cemetery.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Somalia: An Effort To Make Peace
description: The president of Somalia's transitional government met with opposition leaders in peace talks organized in neighboring Kenya, but most of the country's key warlords stayed away. President Abdiqassim Salad Hassan, who controls pockets of the capital of Mogadishu, sat down with members of the rival Somali Reconciliation and Restoration Council. Kenya's president, Daniel arap Moi, who called the talks, beseeched the parties to lay down their guns. ''How long do you want this situation of misery to continue?'' Mr. Moi asked. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Clusters of Illness Suggest That Most Infections Came From Two Mailings
description: The known cases of anthrax fall into a pattern suggesting that most, perhaps all, result from two mailings, one on or around Sept. 18 and the other on Oct. 9, according to data issued yesterday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARUCH, SULAMITA (NEE BALAGURA), M.D., PH.D.
description: BARUCH-Sulamita (nee Balagura), M.D., Ph.D. Dr. Baruch was Adjunct Associate Professor of Physiology at Weill Cornell Medical College. We deeply regret the passing of our beloved colleague of many years, an accomplished scientist and teacher, and extend our condolences to her family. Erich Windhager, M.D. Professor and Chairman, and Faculty Department of Physiology and Biophysics

title: Soaring Continental Trade Produces Deadly Squeeze at Alpine Tunnels
description: Anyone looking for clues about why Europe's Alpine tunnels suddenly seem more dangerous would do well to come here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAUGH, SAMUEL GOODRICH
description: WAUGH-Samuel Goodrich, 75. Of Southport, CT died on October 31, 2001. Memorial service Saturday, December 1, 2001 at 11:00 AM in Trinity Episcopal Church, Southport, CT. The Spear Funeral Home of Fairfield, CT (203-259-0824) to be contacted for further information.

title: Norway and France Well Ahead in Bridge Tourney Finals
description: Norway and France appeared to be headed for their first victories in the World Bridge Championships here today.

title: Exploring the Zoo, Sleeping With the Homeless, Wishing on a Star
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEINLERER, NITZA
description: KLEINLERER-Nitza. It is with profound sorrow that we record the passing of our beloved teacher. Devoted to Temple Shaaray Tefila's Religious School and its children for over a decade, Nitza's daily presence in our school will be sorely missed by all. We express our heartfelt condolences to her entire family. Rabbi Jonathan A. Stein Rabbi Sharon Forman Ellen R. Saxl, Co-President Michael H. Laufer, Co-President

title: Getting Ready for a Ground War
description: As the airstrikes in Afghanistan near the end of their fourth week, American military planners need to step up preparations for what is almost sure to be the next phase of the conflict, an intensified ground campaign against the Taliban's main urban strongholds and the hillside hideouts of Osama bin Laden's terrorist network, Al Qaeda.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEIL, HELEN LADER
description: WEIL-Helen Lader. Passed away on October 27, 2001 at the age of 86. Wife of the late Richard C. Weil, beloved mother of Francine McGriff, Denis, Roland and Marianne Weil and grandmother of Kimberly, Darcy, Nell, Carrie and Cassandra. Also survived by brother Lawrence Lader. Formerly of Pound Ridge and NY, NY and Sarasota, FL, Helen attended the Ethical Culture Fieldston Schools and received an undergraduate and Master's degree in Art Education from Teachers College, Columbia University. Helen had a long and diverse career in the arts as an award winning exhibiting painter, craftsperson, art educator in Westchester and NYC schools and a registered art therapist in NY. She will be deeply missed by all who knew her. Services are private. Contributions may be made in Helen's name to the American Parkinsons's Disease Association.

title: Sympathetically Portraying Black and Gay Men
description: Patrik-Ian Polk's ''Punks'' opens with the voices of its main characters -- four black and Latino gay men living in West Hollywood -- rating the sex appeal of various African-American celebrities, from Puff Daddy (who is decidedly not their type) to LL Cool J (who emphatically is). Their candid, sexy talk sets the tone for the rest of the film, which is admirable for its candor, its good humor and its bravery.

title: Old-Car 'Bible' Is on the Block
description: HEMMINGS MOTOR NEWS, which calls itself ''the bible of the old-car hobby,'' is for sale.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Verizon Acquires Wireless Operations
description: Verizon Wireless said it had agreed to acquire wireless operations in California, Georgia, Ohio and Tennessee from Dobson Communications for about $465 million. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: The Show Must Go On Through Tight Window
description: In the aftermath of the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, the National Horse Show's board of trustees considered canceling it. Madison Square Garden officials were eager to know if the horse show, the nation's oldest and most prestigious, would go on as scheduled today through Sunday at the Garden. Gene Mishe, chairman of the show, feared that canceling might jeopardize the show's future at the Garden. During its 118-year history, all but seven shows have been held there.

title: Back Pain Hampers Woods At the Tour Championship
description: With pain piercing through his lower back, Tiger Woods endured a round today that tested his resolve as much as his talent.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Former Party Leader Cleared
description: Prosecutors closed investigations into Wolfgang Schuble, former chairman of the opposition Christian Democrats and a possible challenger to Chancellor Gerhard Schrder in next year's election, citing a lack of evidence that he lied about accepting a cash donation of $46,200 for the party in 1994. Mr. Schuble was forced to quit as party leader last year after revelations of illegal campaign donations taken by Helmut Kohl when he was chancellor.

title: Levine Leads a Celebration of Schoenberg
description: A few hours after the Sunday meeting at which the board of the Boston Symphony made it official that James Levine would be that orchestra's new music director, Mr. Levine led the Met Chamber Ensemble in an all-Schoenberg concert at Weill Recital Hall.

title: Art in Review
description: Print Fair

title: Fed by Low Rates, Refinancing Surge Is Helping Economy
description: Home mortgage rates have fallen sharply in recent weeks to the lowest levels in several years and are expected to drop further this month to rates not seen since the 1960's.

title: Jobless Rate Jumps to 5.4 Percent
description: Providing the starkest evidence yet of the economic damage caused by the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, the government reported today that the already-weak American labor market shed 415,000 jobs in October, the largest one-month drop in more than 21 years.

title: With a campaign promoting a new cola product, Pepsi declares that it's time to smile again.
