description: AMERICANS may not be feeling very upbeat in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 attacks, but the Pepsi-Cola Company is moving ahead with a new product and a characteristically whimsical, Pepsi-style advertising campaign that is intended to make people smile.

title: YES Deals Yankee Games
description: The YES network is expected to announce after the World Series that it will sell an estimated 25 Yankee games to CBS-owned Channel 2 next season. YES will retain about 125 games to carry on cable. The remainder are reserved to be shown as national games on the Fox network and ESPN.

title: Even Now, A Skyline Of Twins
description: They were the two. But they were not the only.

title: U.S. Groups Have Some Ties to Germ Warfare
description: In the six years since Timothy J. McVeigh used a truck bomb to destroy the Oklahoma City Federal Building, domestic antigovernment groups have spoken of the inevitability of using biological weapons.

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Bills Require C.I.A. to Share Its Information on Foreigners
description: Lawmakers from both parties are pushing immigration legislation that would require the Central Intelligence Agency to make information on suspected terrorists available to the officials responsible for admitting foreigners into the United States.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Suits Over War Shrine Visit
description: More than 600 people, including relatives of people killed in World War II, have filed lawsuits against Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi, saying his August visit to a war shrine in Tokyo was unconstitutional, officials said. The suits ask the courts to ban Mr. Koizumi from visiting the Yasukuni Shrine, which honors Japan's war dead including war criminals executed after World War II, and seek damages for psychological suffering caused by the visit.

title: National Briefing
description: NORTHWEST

title: Knicks' Anderson Eager To Make His First Shot
description: Shandon Anderson could laugh yesterday. But it was not so amusing on Tuesday night when he endured a miserable Knick debut at Madison Square Garden, or even in the locker room after the game when teammates perused the stat sheets and offered some subtle jibes.

title: Enshrouded in Mysteries And Reveling in Oddity
description: Artifice was in overabundant supply in dances presented by American Ballet Theater on Tuesday night at City Center. Some of it was honestly come by, as in Robert Hill's new ''Marimba.'' Some was not.

title: In a Surprise Move, AOL Replaces Its Chief Financial Officer
description: In a move that caught investors and analysts by surprise yesterday, AOL Time Warner replaced its tough-minded chief financial officer, J. Michael Kelly, transferring him to the company's America Online unit, where he will become chief operating officer.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Prosecutor Named To Terror Unit
description: A veteran prosecutor in the United States attorney's office in Manhattan has been appointed co-chief of the office's unit specializing in terrorism cases. The prosecutor, Kenneth M. Karas, replaces Patrick J. Fitzgerald, who was confirmed last week as United States attorney in Chicago. David N. Kelley continues as the other co-chief of the unit. Mr. Karas, 37, joined the prosecutor's office in 1992 and has been assisting in the investigation of the Sept. 11 attacks on New York and Washington. Earlier this year, he helped try four men charged with conspiring with Osama bin Laden in the 1998 bombings of two American embassies. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: An Emotional End For All the O'Neills
description: Pat O'Neill started crying in August. That is when he finished coaching a traveling team of 16-year-old baseball players in Ohio and had time to think about the future. That is when Pat realized, really allowed himself to ponder, that his little brother, Paul, was going to retire at the end of the season. That, Pat kept reminding himself, would change his life and change so many lives.

title: State Budgets Facing a Fall In Revenues
description: Even before accounting for the fiscal devastation caused by the Sept. 11 attacks, state governments were facing the deepest budget shortfalls in at least a decade, according to a survey released today by the National Conference of State Legislatures.

title: N.F.L. MATCHUPS WEEK 8
description: SUNDAY 1 P.M.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ruling On Postal Worker's Death
description: Medical authorities have ruled on the cause of death of a Manhattan postal worker whose sudden illness and death on Oct. 10 was once suspected of being linked to anthrax-tainted mail equipment. The New York City medical examiner's office has concluded that Laura Jones, a supervisor at the city's largest mail-sorting center, the Morgan Mail Distribution and Processing Center, died from complications from high blood pressure and heart disease. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Knoblauch Finishes in Starring Role
description: Chuck Knoblauch was benched again last night. The season is ending, Knoblauch's career with the Yankees is ending and he watched Game 5 of the World Series from the dugout. Manager Joe Torre has lost confidence in Knoblauch because he has been hitting too many fly balls, not the way for a leadoff hitter to get playing time.

title: Parallel Universes That Sometimes Collide
description: Audrey Tautou, the young French actress who suggests a cross between Audrey Hepburn and Giulietta Masina, may be the queen of art house serendipity. She stars in two movies opening today: Jean-Pierre Jeunet's ''Amlie'' and Laurent Firode's ''Happenstance,'' both of which are, coincidentally, about coincidence. Both films imagine Paris as a buzzing hive of wistful humanity ruled by accident and fortuity, in which the tiniest actions yield complex and unexpected, but generally happy, results. ''Amlie'' was a big hit in France and will, quite deservedly, receive a lot of attention here, but ''Happenstance,'' a quieter, less visually extravagant entertainment, should not be overlooked.

title: Mail Throws a Wrench Into College Admissions
description: The snarl in mail services in a number of areas on the East Coast is complicating the admissions process for some students and colleges.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VINIK, JULIUS
description: VINIK-Julius. October 31, 2001. Devoted husband of Bertha Vinik. Loving father of David, Lisa and Josh and father-in-law of Zion, Debra & Melissa. Proud grandfather of Tamar, Tali, Taryn, Leor, Roni, Samantha and Zachary. Ordained Rabbi, former Brooklyn Supreme Court Judge. Services at 1 P.M., November 2nd, Menorah Chapel, 2145 Richmond Ave, Staten Isl,NY.

title: We Need Answers on Anthrax
description: To the Editor:

title: New Head of Mosque Wants Proof
description: The recently installed imam at New York's main mosque does not hesitate to condemn the World Trade Center attack. But then he also emphasizes that America has presented no proof of authorship in attacking Afghanistan.

title: Game 5: Yankees Rally Again
On the Street: Move Over, Goblins
The Ethnic North
Fear Factors
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Bin Laden's Statement
description: Following is the translated text of Osama Bin Laden's latest statement, as posted on the British Broadcasting Corporation's web site.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Wyoming: Arrests In Theft Of Weapons
description: Military officials said an airman assigned to security details and a civilian were arrested in Mexico with guns stolen from a nuclear missile control center in Nebraska. Officials at the F. E. Warren Air Force Base in Cheyenne, which oversees the Nebraska center, said the men, Airman First Class William Kelsey, 21, of Rochester and Ryan Walenter, 23, of Waukegan, Ill., were taken into custody near El Paso after Mexican authorities found them with semiautomatic rifles, a machine gun, handguns, night-vision goggles and grenades.

title: A Shameful Vote on Air Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Money Found For Swissair Units
description: Swissair averted a new grounding after its three ground-services units found financing to meet the government's conditions for releasing the first part of a $600 million credit line to keep the carrier flying. SR Technics, its maintenance operation; Atraxis, its reservations and ticketing service; and Swissport, its baggage handing unit, had been running low on cash, but the Swiss government said it would not open its coffers unless the cantonal governments and banks assured liquidity for the three units. Crossair, the former Swissair regional airline, that is slated to take over Swissair's long-haul flights next year, had warned that bailing out the service companies was key to keeping its planes in the air.

title: Without U.S. Support, Pashtun Rebel Leader Is Finding Few Allies
description: A leading anti-Taliban commander now on a clandestine mission to rally support in southern Afghanistan must persuade potential allies that the United States will provide the kind of military support that so far has gone largely to the main rebel force in the north, say relatives familiar with his plans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTAVELA, MARIE T.
description: ALTAVELA-Marie T. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Marie Altavela, associated with The Times for 32 years until her retirement in 1979.

title: Court Voids Law Banning Cross Burning
description: In a case with echoes from the civil rights movement, the Virginia Supreme Court struck down a state law yesterday that banned cross burning, saying the federal Constitution protects speech no matter how offensive.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Unilever Profit Sinks
description: Unilever, the big food and soap company, said that third-quarter net income fell 42 percent on higher costs after spending $25 billion on acquisitions last year. The company repeated, however, that it expected full-year per-share earnings, before one-time items and good will, to rise at least 10 percent. Net income dropped to 493 million euros ($445 million), or 0.49 euro a share, in the quarter. Interest payments and good will charges are six times higher since the takeovers of Bestfoods, SlimFast and Ben & Jerry's. While adding to costs, the new units also helped Unilever's 400 top brands increase sales 4.7 percent in the quarter.

title: Ernest R. Hilgard, Leader in Study of Hypnosis, Dies at 97
description: Dr. Ernest R. Hilgard, a highly acclaimed experimental psychologist and a pioneer in the scientific study of hypnosis, died on Oct. 22 in Palo Alto, Calif., where he was a professor emeritus at Stanford University. He was 97.

title: National Briefing | New England: New Hampshire: Treatment In Anthrax Cases
description: Gov. Jeanne Shaheen has asked the new director of homeland security, Tom Ridge, to set consistent policies on anthrax cases. In a letter, Ms. Shaheen, a Democrat, wrote that both the State Department's visa processing center in Portsmouth and a post office in Manchester received mail from the Washington mail center where anthrax killed two people, but only the visa employees were told to take antibiotics. Julie Flaherty (NYT)

title: U.S. Widens Net to Snare Terror Assets; Expands List
description: The Bush administration imposed stringent financial sanctions today on the anti-Israeli organizations Hamas, Hezbollah and 20 other suspected terrorist groups, significantly broadening the campaign to seize terrorist assets beyond groups with links to Osama bin Laden's Al Qaeda network.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Wisconsin: State Starts Hiring Freeze
description: Faced with a budget shortfall estimated to be as much as $1.3 billion, Gov. Scott McCallum ordered a hiring freeze for state employees. The freeze will go into effect on Nov. 12, and the governor said it might last indefinitely. Public health and safety positions are exempt. Mr. McCallum has said the move could save the state about $10 million.

title: A Showcase of Stamina to a Film's Score
description: American Ballet Theater's final novelty this season at City Center is Kirk Peterson's ''Amazed in Burning Dreams,'' an athletic workout that makes the best of the score Philip Glass wrote for Paul Schrader's film ''Mishima.''

title: Marathon Is to Be Run Amid Tight Security
description: Tomorrow's New York City Marathon will be the most heavily secured in the race's history, with thousands of police officers deployed through the five boroughs, the rivers and skies guarded and 30,000 prescreened runners permitted to carry just one transparent plastic bag each, officials said yesterday.

title: Sandy Lehmann-Haupt, 59, One of Ken Kesey's Busmates
description: Sandy Lehmann-Haupt, one of the Merry Pranksters on the novelist Ken Kesey's boisterously psychedelic bus, which helped define the hippie way of life as it emerged in the 1960's, died on Oct. 28 at a hospital in Callicoon Center, N.Y., near his home. He was 59 and had succeeded in leaving behind the troubled 22-year-old who rode the bus on trips both physical and metaphorical.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Jobs Data May Worsen
description: Irish unemployment rose to 3.9 percent in October, up from 3.7 percent six months ago, and the number of people claiming unemployment benefits rose by 2,600 over the previous year, the first annual increase since 1996. But the new figures, from the government's statistics office, do not include the 1,200 job cuts announced on Wednesday in a range of industries from mining to manufacturing. Nor do they include more than 2,000 job cuts planned at Aer Lingus, the national airline.

title: Disparate Works Connected By Barely Visible Threads
description: At a glance, Kurt Masur's program with the New York Philharmonic on Thursday evening looked oddly diffuse. The opening work, Susan Botti's ''EchoTempo,'' which had its world premiere, is a kind of double concerto for voice and percussion. Rachmaninoff's ''Rhapsody on a Theme by Paganini,'' with Olli Mustonen as the piano soloist, rounded out the first half and after the intermission Mr. Masur conducted Liszt's ''Prludes'' and Prokofiev's ''Scythian Suite.''

title: U.S. Vehicle Sales in October
description: The auto industry sold cars, sport utility vehicles, minivans and pickup trucks at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 21.3 million vehicles in October, up 24 percent from a year earlier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HICKOK, ROBERT THARP
description: HICKOK-Robert Tharp. Of Oyster Bay, LI, on November 1, 2001. Husband of the late Dortha Mae (Hutchinson). Father of Sallie Ward (Vernon), Dibbie Barden (Wally), Margee Styles (Eric), and Nancie Hickok Tynan (Bill). Grandfather of eleven. Greatgrandfather of seven. Brother of Ada and Althea. Former president and CEO of Bates Fabrics. Family will receive friends at the First Presbyterian Church of Oyster Bay, Sunday, 2-4 PM. Donations may be made to the Oyster Bay Rotary Club Scholarship Fund. For information, call Francis P. Devine Funeral Home.

title: Love 'em or Hate 'em, It's Been Quite a Run
description: The day before the World Series began, Curt Schilling dismissed the notion that the Yankees were some supernaturally special team. ''When you use the words mystique and aura,'' Schilling, the Arizona pitcher, said, ''those are dancers in a nightclub. Those are not things we concern ourselves with on the ball field.''

title: Palestinians on Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEGER, THOMAS G., M.D.
description: STEGER-Thomas G., M.D., 32. Died suddenly on October 23 in Durham, North Carolina. Dr. Steger attended elementary and middle school in Scarsdale and graduated from the Scarsdale High School in 1987. He graduated with honors from Northwestern University in 1991 and with honors from the NYU School of Medicine in 1995. He completed a residency in Orthopaedics at the Barnes Hospital in St. Louis, in June, 2001, where he served as Chief Orthopaedic Resident. At the time of his death, Dr. Steger was a Fellow at the Duke University Hospital Medical Center where he held the first Fellowship in Trauma Orthopaedics. Dr. Steger is survived by his parents Nancy and John Steger of Scarsdale, his sister Katherine of Montreal and by his grandmothers Mrs. Wilma Steger of the Bronx, NY and Mrs. J.D. Gunther of Bloomfield, CT. A memorial service will be held at 10:30 AM on November 17 at The Church of St. Pius X in Scarsdale. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Dr. Thomas G. Steger Orthopaedic Trauma Fund, Dept. of Surgery, DUMC, Box 3704, Durham, N.C. 27710.

title: What's in a Name Change? Just Ask West Paterson
description: The way John Heinz sees it, this may be the time that his hometown finally changes its name. A maintenance worker and lifelong resident, he sees the BMW-driving newcomers from New York living in spacious new subdivisions, wanting little to do with ''West Paterson,'' a name that conjures images of the grittier city to the east.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Supermarket Venture
description: Royal Ahold, the giant food distributor, agreed to combine its supermarkets in Central America with Costa Rica's CSU into a joint venture with 253 stores and annual sales of $1.3 billion. Ahold and its existing joint venture with Guatemala's La Fragua will each own a third of the new venture with CSU, which will own the remaining third. CSU is the leading food retailer in Costa Rica and Nicaragua and also owns stores in Honduras, Ahold said in a statement. ''Among the objectives of the joint venture are the further improvement of customer services, ongoing organic growth in existing markets and the development of retail activities, directly or through partnerships and acquisitions, in other countries in the region,'' Ahold said. CSU owns 128 supermarkets and hypermarkets, with 92 stores in Costa Rica, 20 in Nicaragua and 16 in Honduras. The company has annual sales of $720 million, Ahold said. La Fragua, 50 percent owned by Ahold, has 125 stores in Guatemala, El Salvador and Honduras. CSU and La Fragua employ a combined 15,000 people.

title: Opponents' and Supporters' Portrayals of Detentions Prove Inaccurate
description: The government portrays the arrest and detention of more than 1,100 people in connection with the investigation of the Sept. 11 attacks as evidence of its fight against terrorism. Civil liberties groups argue that the widespread arrests are a sign of a dangerous erosion of rights.

title: Former Officers Get Probation in Beating
description: Two former police officers who were accused of handcuffing and beating a Bronx woman after she asked for their names and badge numbers have been sentenced to probation and community service.

title: A Mainstay of U.S. Job Creation Is Hit Hard by Sept. 11
description: The services sector, which has been America's main engine of job creation since World War II, has been dealt a powerful blow by the events of Sept. 11.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WHEELER, FRANK R.
description: WHEELER-Frank R. November 3, 1989. Not a day goes by. Miss you and all the fun. Love always, Sis and The Kid

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISMAN, GUSSIE S.
description: WEISMAN-Gussie S. Died on November 1, 2001, in Orlando, FL. Graveside services will be held at Knollwood Park Cemetery (Cypress and Cooper Ave.), Queens, New York, on Sunday, November 4, at 1:30PM. Information: Louis Suburban Chapel, 201-791-0015.

title: Homeland Defense
description: To the Editor:

title: BAFFLED F.B.I. ASKS FOR AID IN SOLVING RIDDLE OF ANTHRAX
description: The director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that after weeks of investigation, the government had no idea who was behind the anthrax attacks, and he appealed to the public for help in solving the case.

title: Corrections
description: Apicture yesterday with the Lima Journal article, about a Japanese- Peruvian restaurant, carried an incomplete credit. The photographer was Ana Cecilia Gonzales-Vigil.

title: Questions Intended to Sow Doubts About a Candidate
description: The mayoral campaign of Mark Green began broadcasting a television advertisement yesterday called ''Questions.''

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It is not good news for America.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEE, LINDA C.
description: LEE-Linda C. The Fordham Law School community records with profound sorrow the tragic loss in the World Trade Center of Linda C. Lee, Class of 1994. She was a multi-talented and caring person. We extend our deep sympathy to her family. John D. Feerick, Dean

title: Management of Space Station Is Criticized
description: The International Space Station program has been so poorly managed that NASA cannot estimate exactly how much the project will cost or how it will pay its share, an independent task force said today.

title: Japan Blocks Trip By Foreign Minister
description: Makiko Tanaka, Japan's foreign minister, had a shakier hold on her job today after ruling opposition legislators joined forces to deny her permission to travel to participate in the opening of the United Nations General Assembly.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Marks & Spencer Sells 9 Stores
description: The troubled British retail group Marks & Spencer has agreed to sell its nine Spanish stores to El Corte Ingls, Spain's leading retailer, for an undisclosed sum. The deal will safeguard the jobs of around 800 Spanish employees of Marks & Spencer, which has had profits fall and is selling its European operation to focus on its core food and clothing business in Britain. Rapidly dismantling its operations on the Continent, Marks & Spencer agreed last month to sell its 19 stores in France to Galeries Lafayette and said it would shut four stores in Belgium and two in Germany.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANASHOWITZ, LEON
description: MANASHOWITZ - Leon. Our heartfelt condolences to Steven and his family, from your family at Prestige Theatre Parties. Tuddie, Lenny, Jen, Pat & Margo

title: A Shameful Vote on Air Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture yesterday with the Lima Journal article, about a Japanese-Peruvian restaurant, carried an incomplete credit. The photographer was Ana Cecilia Gonzales-Vigil.

title: Early Turnovers Accelerate Nets' Collapse
description: The Nets' brief but giddy ride clunked into a pothole tonight.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Ready To Freeze Assets
description: After a long delay, Indonesia said it would issue a decree allowing banks to freeze assets of terrorism suspects as the United States has requested. Officials said several bank accounts were already being investigated for suspected terrorist links.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REINSCHREIBER, SYLVIA ELIAS
description: REINSCHREIBER-Sylvia Elias. On Friday, November 2, of Riverdale, NY. Beloved wife of the late Seymour. Devoted mother of Amy (Jerel) Zoltick and Laurie (Ron) Weinreich. Also survived by two cherished sisters and one brother. Loving nanna of seven grandchildren. Services Sunday, November 4, 12:30 PM at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Twin Towers At the Center Of Legal Brawl
description: The battle over who will bear the costs of the destruction of the World Trade Center and who will control the reconstruction of lower Manhattan -- already a full-blown brawl involving legions of lawyers and lobbyists -- is continuing to escalate.

title: Experts See Record Default In Argentine Debt Revision
description: Wall Street economists and local analysts today portrayed a new Argentine effort to restructure the $132 billion national debt as tantamount to a default and the largest financial collapse of any country in history.

title: Meddling in Nicaragua
description: To the Editor:

title: RICOCHET, A WIRELESS CONCERN, SOLD TO AERIE NETWORKS
description: The remaining pieces of Ricochet, the high-speed wireless network run by Metricom Inc., were sold yesterday to Aerie Networks, a privately held network services company. In a deal approved in federal bankruptcy court in San Jose, Calif., Aerie Networks successfully bid $8.25 million for Metricom's assets, including equipment, patents and customer lists. Margaret Sheneman, a lawyer for Metricom, said Aerie Networks assumed none of the $800 million in claims filed by Metricom creditors. Metricom, whose service had more than 50,000 users, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in July and shut down its network in August. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: U.S. Widens Search For Terrorist Assets
description: The Bush administration gave the Treasury Department authority to seize assets of 22 suspected terrorist groups, including two Muslim organizations, Hamas and Hezbollah. The move broadened the antiterror campaign beyond Osama bin Laden and Al Qaeda, and signaled the administration's growing confidence in the stability of the antiterror coalition.

title: Experts Say It's Unlikely That Hospital Worker Was Victim of a New Anthrax Attack
description: With no new cases of inhalation anthrax appearing at city hospitals in recent days, health investigators and other experts say it appears increasingly unlikely that the hospital worker who died this week had been the victim of a new anthrax attack that could have affected large groups of people.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: Knicks Pay for Failure to Make Free Throws
description: The inability to hit a clutch free throw, sink a critical jump shot or stop a 6-foot-3-inch point guard from powering to the basket cost the Knicks tonight.

title: Governor Candidates Saturate New Jersey With Last-Minute Commercials
description: On cable television these days, New Jersey voters can see Ben Stein, the conservative comedian game-show host, sarcastically quizzing a class of high school students about James E. McGreevey, the Democratic nominee for governor, in a political commercial for Bret D. Schundler, the Republican.

title: State Plans Rebuilding Agency, Perhaps Led by Giuliani
description: Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday that he would create an agency to rebuild Lower Manhattan, and people close to him said that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani might ultimately head it.

title: VANGUARD GROUP USE OF S.& P. INDEXES IS BARRED
description: A federal appeals court upheld a ruling that the Vanguard Group, the second-largest United States mutual fund company, may not use certain Standard & Poor's indexes to create exchange-traded funds. The court found that Vanguard's use of the S.& P.'s indexes for exchange-traded funds was not authorized under licenses S.& P. granted Vanguard for its mutual funds, according to a statement from McGraw-Hill, the parent of S.& P. The decision is a blow to Vanguard, which had planned to offer an exchange-traded fund version of three of its mutual funds that track S.& P. indexes. They included the $77.8 billion Vanguard 500 Index fund -- the largest United States mutual fund. Vanguard is based in Valley Forge, Pa.

title: Crash Injures 4 Assisting Secret Mission
description: An Air Force Special Operations helicopter crashed during a nighttime incursion into northern Afghanistan today, injuring four crew members, one of them seriously, in what the Pentagon said was a weather-related accident.

title: Editors' Note; COMING ON SUNDAY
description: 'NO FUN' CITY

title: A Shameful Vote on Air Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: Now at the Helm: the Master of the Pause
description: The Leipzig Gewandhaus Orchestra, after nearly three decades with Kurt Masur at its head, appeared at Carnegie Hall on Monday and Tuesday under its new music director, Herbert Blomstedt. He is a different kind of musician: perhaps cooler, certainly more willing to take the long view, readier to let the music go on its own course. Sometimes he seems its benign observer more than its generating force.

title: G.E.'s Tax Breaks
description: To the Editor:

title: What if Cipro Stopped Working?
description: Cipro, despite its current fame for preventing and treating anthrax, is in danger of becoming a casualty of what might be called the post-antibiotic age. Bayer, the maker of Cipro, also sells a chemically similar drug called Baytril, which is used in large-scale poultry production worldwide. The widespread use of Baytril in chickens has already been shown to decrease Cipro's effectiveness in humans for some types of infections.

title: U.S. Is Using More Drones, Despite Concern Over Flaws
description: The Air Force is moving rapidly to send more unpiloted surveillance aircraft to Afghanistan, even as the Pentagon's chief tester has raised questions about their ability to operate at night, in bad weather and over long periods of time.

title: Party Machine A Ballot Issue For the G.O.P. In Nassau
description: Voters will not find it listed on the ballot, but the fate of the nation's premiere political machine -- the fabled Nassau County Republicans -- is riding on Tuesday's election.

title: Rookie May Get the Call To Face Cowboys' Allen
description: When Michael Strahan was a rookie, he was afraid to walk into the locker room, not knowing what type of hazing awaited him. These days Strahan does not torment young players but gives them the sage advice of a nine-year veteran.

title: Despite Governor's Alert, It's Business as Usual on 2 Crowded Bay Bridges
description: This morning, as Jason Velasquez headed from his San Rafael apartment in his wife's year-old Camry to cross the Golden Gate Bridge, he first heard the reports of possible terrorist attacks on the bridges during rush hour. In a panic, he turned back and switched to his Ford pickup.

title: Soriano's Small Mitt Makes a Big Play
description: Alfonso Soriano lingered in the Yankees' clubhouse early this morning, still wearing his grass-stained sanitary socks and an unconquerable grin, and he pulled his glove out of his locker -- the glove he used to save the Yankees in the 11th inning in Game 5 of the World Series.

title: At Home Abroad; A Strangled People
description: Jewish settlements in the West Bank are often described, and justified, as simply places for Israelis to make their homes in otherwise unused areas. When you see the settlements in and around Ramallah, a principal city of the West Bank, the reality is quite different.

title: Rabbi Eliezer Schach, 103; Leader of Orthodox in Israel
description: Rabbi Eliezer Menachem Schach, a leader of the strictly Orthodox Jews in Israel who wielded powerful influence over the country's politics for more than two decades, died today in Sheba Medical Center in Tel Aviv. He was 103.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPRINGER, JOHN
description: SPRINGER-John. Grateful loveSylvia, Myrna, Lana, Helen, Lillian and Zactay.

title: Woods Is Improved, But Verplank Is Better
description: The health of Tiger Woods improved today, but so did the play of Scott Verplank.

title: An Indian Novelist Turns Her Wrath on the U.S.
description: Arundhati Roy, the lyrical novelist, has morphed into a rebel with many causes. Lately, as India's most passionate polemicist, she has raged against the bombing of Afghanistan, which she calls ''another act of terror against the people of the world'' by the American government.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KOHN, LEONORE S.
description: KOHN-Leonore S. Precious Mom. Deeply missed. We celebrate your life Nov. 5, 1911-Nov 18, 1998. Love always, Barbara & Peter

title: Cincinnati's Revival Sags Under Weight of Falling Revenue
description: The two new stadiums along the Ohio River in downtown Cincinnati are supposed to anchor a complex of condominiums, stores, offices, restaurants, parks and a world-class history museum. But between the stadiums, the six-block stretch of riverfront is barren and paved over, serving only as a makeshift parking lot.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENGLISHER, ELIHU B.
description: ENGLISHER-Elihu B. The Board of Directors, staff and members of the YM/YWHA of Washington Heights and Inwood deeply mourn the passing of Elihu B. Englisher, husband of the late Dorothy Englisher, father of Larry and Martin G. Englisher, the agency's Executive Vice President. Mr. Englisher was an early & very loyal supporter of the agency. Beginning with his sons' registration in nursery school he assisted with fundraising efforts, especially with bazaars. A merchant in Washington Heights for many years, he was well known to neighbors & customers alike. He shared his skill, warmth and humor with all around him. Our deepest condolences to his family. Services Sunday, November 4, at 11:00 A.M., Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, New York City. Deborah Katznelson, Sr. Associate Exec. Director Dr. Ruth Westheimer, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, AUGUSTA
description: GOLDSTEIN-Augusta. October 28, 2001. In memory of a loyal, longtime and dear friend who will be sorely missed. Signed with love and tears. Betty Ellerin, Selma Pundyk, and Jean Roberts

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the evacuation of an American Airlines concourse at Kennedy International Airport misidentified the company that was found by the Federal Aviation Administration to be improperly screening passengers there. The company was Worldwide Flight Services Inc., not Worldwide Security.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Ban On Smoking
description: The Supreme Court imposed a nationwide ban on smoking in public places, including hospitals, buses, trains and libraries. Its decision was a response to a public interest lawsuit filed by a leader of the opposition Congress Party in Bombay. The court has taken an active role on issues of public health. It has recently been pushing Delhi to replace all its highly polluting diesel buses with ones that run on compressed natural gas.

title: Poll Finds Gap Narrowing For Bloomberg and Green
description: New Yorkers now believe that both Michael R. Bloomberg and Mark Green are qualified to be the next mayor of New York, amid signs that Mr. Green's contention that Mr. Bloomberg does not have the skills or experience to run the city has not taken hold, according to the latest New York Times poll.

title: TRUMP HOTEL'S DEBT RATING REDUCED TO LOWEST LEVEL
description: Trump Hotels & Casino Resorts Inc.'s debt rating was cut yesterday to the lowest level by Standard & Poor's after the company failed to make a $90 million interest payment due Thursday on $1.3 billion in debt. S.& P. reduced the corporate credit rating and senior secured debt on the company, headed by Donald Trump, two notches, to ''D'' from ''CC.'' The next interest payment is due Dec. 15. The missed payment sets Mr. Trump up for his second major debt refinancing in 10 years. On Wednesday, Mr. Trump, chairman of the company, said he was withholding scheduled interest payments on $1.6 billion of debt because he wanted to amend the terms.

title: Sports of The Times; For Yankees, Is It Simply In the Stars?
description: IN the split second of a sudden, early-morning outcome, you have to make a quick decision: winners' clubhouse or losers'?

title: Friends Help Spoil Run of Isles' Osgood
description: Kris Draper is an old pal of Chris Osgood's. They call each other every few days, and their wives sat together at the game tonight. That did not matter once the game began. Draper had to help the streaking Detroit Red Wings win another game, and Osgood, a goaltender, was in his way.

title: Experts on Islam Pointing Fingers At One Another
description: If many of the country's specialists on Islam and the Middle East are getting more public exposure than usual, the debate over who's right has also been heating up. One well-known expert in particular is blaming what he sees as the establishment in the field for failing for years to predict the danger of Islamic extremism.

title: Firefighters in Angry Scuffle With Police at Trade Center
description: A brief but emotionally wrenching scuffle broke out yesterday morning between New York City firefighters and police officers at the scene of their shared grief, the World Trade Center disaster site. A dozen firefighters were arrested and five police officers were injured in the incident, which rattled the city's top officials and laid bare the frustrations of the living who are unable to bury their dead.

title: Game 5 Ratings Increase
description: Game 5 of the World Series generated a 14.4 Nielsen rating on Fox, up 10 percent from a 13.1 for the comparable game last year.

title: A Nation Challenged
description: Fighting Anthrax

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROKER, AL, SR.
description: ROKER-Al, Sr. The Faculty and Staff of the NYU Child Study Center mourn the loss of Al Roker, Sr., beloved father of Al Roker, one of our steadfast supporters & special friends. Al's energy, enthusiasm and generosity for children in need are an enduring legacy and memorial to his father. We extend our sympathy to Al and the entire Roker family. Brooke Neidich, Chair Board of Directors Harold S. Koplewicv, M.D. The Arnold and Debbie Simon Professor of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry Director, Child Study Center New York University School of Medicine

title: CONTRACTORS TOLD TO END WORK ON FIBER-OPTIC NETWORK
description: Qwest Communications International Inc., which posted an unexpected third-quarter loss earlier this week, told contractors to stop work on its fiber-optic network to pare costs. A spokesman, Tyler Gronbach, said contractors and vendors who perform support and maintenance jobs received a memo yesterday telling them to suspend work immediately on their projects. Mr. Gronbach did not know how many workers would be affected. Qwest, whose 190,000-mile fiber-optic network spans six continents, cut planned capital spending for 2002 to $5.5 billion from $7.5 billion.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Companies May Produce Components
description: Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Mitsubishi Electric, Oki Electric Industry and Nippon Avionics will begin making components for the air defense systems used on American-made Aegis destroyers, the Nihon Keizai newspaper reported yesterday. The companies, which will make about 30 percent of the computerized systems that are used to control radar and missiles, will sign licensing agreements with Lockheed Martin, which provides most of the parts of the Aegis systems, the paper said. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: No Cease-Fire For Ramadan
description: Separatist rebels and military commanders in this overwhelmingly Muslim nation said they would not declare a cease-fire in Aceh Province during the Muslim holy month of Ramadan, which begins in two weeks. Fighting in the long-running conflict continued through Ramadan last year. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Loss Narrows At B Sky B
description: New subscribers and increased revenue from online services helped the British Sky Broadcasting Group narrow its first quarter loss. The company, a digital satellite venture controlled by Rupert Murdoch and his News Corporation, said it lost 94.8 million ($139 million), or 5 pence a share, in the three months ended Sept. 30, compared with a loss of 128.9 million ($187 million), or 7 pence a share, in the period a year earlier. Revenue gained 24 percent to 643 million. B Sky B said it added 45,000 customers in the period, bringing the total number of subscribers to 5.5 million. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Bad Economic News, Troops on the Golden Gate, Angry Firefighters
description: There was more economic fallout from Sept. 11, none of it good. The government had already reported that the economy shrank over the summer, for the first time in eight years. Now, the word from the Labor Department was that 415,000 Americans had lost their jobs in October, the most for a single month since 1980. The unemployment rate jumped half a percentage point, to 5.4 percent, well above the 3.9 percent rate just 13 months before.

title: Loss to Testud Costly for Capriati
description: The season that began with such precision and jubilation in Australia ended quite differently for Jennifer Capriati yesterday in Munich. For the second time in a month, she was beaten in the quarterfinals of an indoor tournament by Sandrine Testud of France, and this loss could cost Capriati the No. 1 ranking for the year.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ROHM & HAAS CO., Philadelphia, a maker of specialty chemicals, acquired a packaging adhesives business with about $10 million in yearly sales from Benjamin Moore & Co., Montvale, N.J., a paint maker. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Trip to Game 6 For Victims' Kin
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani will travel to the World Series game in Phoenix today with about 30 relatives of police officers, firefighters and emergency workers who were killed in the Sept. 11 World Trade Center attack, according to Matthew Higgins, the mayor's press secretary.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Joblessness Touches 7.3%
description: Unemployment in Canada reached its highest level in two years last month, climbing to 7.3 percent from 7.2 percent in September. The number of jobs was little changed, but there was a marked shift from full-time to part-time employment. Regionally, October's jobless rate varied from 4.5 percent in Alberta, where oil and natural gas activity has buoyed business, to almost 16 percent in Newfoundland. Canada's economy has been at a virtual standstill since last spring, with Statistics Canada this week reporting an insignificant, 0.1 percent rise in gross domestic product in August. The weak economy and low commodity prices have pushed the Canadian dollar down sharply.

title: Panama City Journal; 12 Years Later, Scars of the U.S. Invasion Remain
description: Sayira Marn's hands still tremble as she recalls the Americans' invasion of Panama in 1989 and how her impoverished neighborhood, El Chorrillo, was caught in the cross-fire.

title: Suddenly, Americans Trust Uncle Sam
description: The titles of the new releases say it all: ''The Trouble with Government,'' ''Disaffected Democracies'' and ''Why People Don't Trust Government.'' This fall a host of new books with a variety of new theories tried to explain a well-established, generation-long trend: Americans' steadily declining trust in government. Then September's terrorist attacks turned prevailing ideas about people's faith in their political institutions upside down, along with so much else.

title: Women in Afghanistan
description: To the Editor:

title: O'Neill Finds It Tough to Take Off the Pinstripes
description: A batboy collecting laundry reached for the pinstriped jersey that lay near Paul O'Neill's feet early this morning, and O'Neill raised his hand slightly. ''Wait, wait, wait,'' O'Neill said, and he asked the batboy to leave the jersey alone.

title: Retired Officers Raise Awareness on Television and Hackles at the Pentagon
description: Every day, Pentagon leaders give a televised briefing to explain the latest developments in the war in Afghanistan.

title: Stalemate in Congress Irks Security Experts
description: With Congress in a stalemate over whether to federalize airport screening workers, experts warned yesterday that major gaps remained in aviation security nearly two months after the terrorist attacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENDER, GERTRUDE
description: BENDER-Gertrude. Beloved wife of the late Meyer. Devoted mother of Stephen and Maxine, and Alice & Bernard Klausner. Adoring grandmother of Lee and Jane, Dr. Evan, Sharon, and Jay Ira and Jodi Klausner. Cherished great grandmother of Justin and Noah. Services at ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1895 Flatbush Avenue (at Ave. L), Brooklyn, NY, Sunday at 1 PM.

title: Correspondent; Up With Moguls! Exploit the Rich!
description: This is not an endorsement of the candidacy of Michael Bloomberg in next Tuesday's New York City mayoral election. For endorsements you have to go next door to the editorial page, where, if you are a candidate encumbered by great wealth, you may be subjected to the biblical eye-of-the-needle test. This is an endorsement of the idea of Michael Bloomberg, meaning the idea that it would not kill us to have a few self-made billionaires in our political life.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Westpac Profit Jumps
description: Growth in home loans and credit card lending contributed to a rise in 2001 earnings for Westpac Banking, one of Australia's largest banks. Net profit rose 11 percent to 1.90 billion Australian dollars ($964 million) for the year ended Sept. 30. Westpac lent 14 percent more to homebuyers in the most recent year, aided by five interest rate cuts from Australia's central bank in 2001 and a government bonus for first-time homebuyers. Credit card loans rose 20 percent. Bad debt more than doubled, however, and totaled 433 million Australian dollars ($219 million). The bank's chief executive, David Morgan, predicted a double-digit increase in per-share earnings growth in 2002. The bank's stock price closed at 14.92 Australian dollars ($7.57), just below a record high. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SILVER FALLS 2.3%. Silver declined as demand from photographic film makers fell. The December contract dropped 9.7 cents, to $4.11 an ounce on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange.

title: The Civics of Flu Shots
description: With politicians and federal health officials at odds over the rationale for getting a flu shot, and with the flu season fast approaching, what is the average citizen to do? Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has urged all New Yorkers to rush out and get flu shots so that there will be less chance of confusion -- in their minds and the minds of their doctors between the symptoms of flu and the early symptoms of anthrax infection. He makes it sound like a civic and patriotic duty -- ''it's good for you . . . and it's really good for the city.'' The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has retorted that, no, there is simply not enough flu vaccine available right now for everyone in the country to do that. The supply should go first to those at highest risk of developing serious complications or dying. That makes it sound like a civic duty not to get vaccinated if your only purpose is to relieve any anxiety or confusion later over symptoms that might indicate an anthrax infection.

title: Muslims Nurture Sense of Self on Campus
description: The morning that Sarah Karim first decided to wear a traditional Islamic head scarf to school, she tied it on outside her house so her father wouldn't give her grief. On the way to the bus stop, she told her mother she had covered her head only because it was cold outside. And when her other relatives found out about it, they warned her that she would never be able to attract boys.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Editors' Note; Today's Sections
description: News of the Sept. 11 attacks and their aftermath continues to appear in Section B; index, Page B2.

title: Volunteers Line Up to Test Smallpox Protection
description: Six student volunteers became the first people to receive smallpox vaccine here today as part of a study to determine whether existing stockpiles of the vaccine can be stretched to protect more Americans from bioterrorism.

title: Equities Withstand Some Shaky News on the Economy
description: Stocks picked up some modest gains yesterday as investors looked beyond a spate of bleak economic news, including a report that the American labor market shed 415,000 jobs last month, and pinned their hopes on a recovery in 2002.

title: It's Savings Over Sorrow as Apartment Hunters Consider Battery Park
description: They do not necessarily want rooms with a view, but they definitely want rooms.

title: A Generous, Friendly Dose of Experimentalism
description: At the annual Bang on a Can Marathon on Sunday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, David Lang, one of the organization's three artistic directors, asked for some audience participation. ''Everyone who's been here before, I hope you'll notice someone who hasn't been here before, and that you'll walk up to them and give them a big kiss,'' he said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASSANO, CATHERINE G. (CASSIDY)
description: CASSANO-Catherine G. (Cassidy), 69. Of Toms River on November 1, 2001. Wife of Peter V. Cassano. Mother of Anne Cassano-Conklin & Ronald Conklin, Jeanne Cassano & Jeff Carroll, Karen Cassano and James Petto, Julia Cassano and John Graziano, Ellen Cassano & Peter J. Cassano. Grandmother of twelve. Funeral will be held at D'Elia Funeral Home, Route 70 & Vermont Avenue, Lakewood, NJ on Tuesday at 8:30 AM. Mass, Tuesday, 9:30 AM at St. Lukes RC Church, Toms River, New Jersey. Entombment to follow at St. Mary's Cemetery, Lakewood, NJ. Visitations Sunday and Monday from 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM.

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of Thursday, 4,651 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11.

title: Analysts Worry of Ripple Effect In Argentina's Latest Debt Plan
description: Argentina's newest proposal to reduce its debt burden might lead to a default that could make it very difficult for emerging-market countries to borrow in the future.

title: U.S. and Norway Are Tied With Only 32 Deals to Go
description: It sounded like an international soccer match, with the home fans cheering wildly, but it was in fact the Vugraph theater at the world bridge championships here today. ''Allez, la France!'' was the chant as the French women's team seemed en route to victory in the final of the Venice Cup. They led into the final session of 16 deals by 47 imps, but their German opponents, playing superbly, surged to win by just 2 imps, one of the closest margins in a final in the history of the game.

title: A NATION CHALLENGED
description: Copter Crashes; Crew Saved

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOYLE, MICHAEL
description: BOYLE-Michael. FDNY, Engine Company 33, lost his life on September 11, 2001 while heroically saving others in the World Trade Center. Michael was born on August 8, 1964 to James and Barbara Boyle in Queens, NY. Michael graduated from Westbury High School and Cortland State University. Michael was the owner of Westbury Beverage and worked for the Uniformed Firefighters Association Local 94. In 1996, Michael was appointed to the FDNY, his lifetime dream, and was assigned to Engine 33 on Great Jones Street, Manhattan. He also served in Ladder 35 at Lincoln Center and Engine 226 in downtown Brooklyn. Michael was a champion Marathon Runner and was in training for the NYC Marathon to break three hours. Michael is survived by his parents James (retired President of the Uniformed Firefighters Association Local 94 and Engine 217) and Barbara; two brothers, James (Sgt. NYPD) and Peter (owner of All Island Beverage); two sisters, Mary Lynch and husband Brendan, and Jeanne Boyle, Esq.; two nieces Amanda and Diana; many uncles, aunts, and cousins, and his Special Love, Rosemary Kenny. Michael was a loving son, a wonderful brother, a special uncle, devoted to Rosemary. He had a unique way of touching the lives of everyone. A future labor leader. He was a true friend, will be deeply missed, but forever remembered. God Bless You Michael. A memorial visitation will be held at the Donohue Cecere Funeral Home, 290 Post Avenue, Westbury, LI on Sunday from 2-4 & 7-9 PM. Memorial Mass Monday, 9:30 AM, St. Patrick's Cathedral, New York, NY. Donations may be made to the Arce Boyle Memorial Fund c/o Collern, O'Hara, Mills, 1225 Franklin Ave., Garden City, NY, 11530, and would be greatly appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHONBERG, LILLIAN
description: SCHONBERG-Lillian. On November 2, 2001, at the age of 89. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Devoted mother of Allan and Colleen, Edward and Alice, Kenneth and Catherine. Dear sister of Bertha, Helen and Anne Franklin, Raphael & Martin Cohen. Loving grandmother of Carrie, Thomas, Michael, Stephen, Dorothy and Chad. Adored great-grandmother of Catiana. Services on Sunday, at 12:15 P.M., at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, LI.

title: Russian Seems to Rule Out Chance of Arms Pact at Summit Talks
description: Russia's foreign minister appeared to rule out today the prospect that President Bush and President Vladimir V. Putin would sign a major arms-control agreement when they meet this month at Mr. Bush's ranch in Texas.

title: In New York, a Room and Parking
description: With slowing traffic into Manhattan nowadays, commuting by car can be a nightmare. The 701-room Radisson Lexington Hotel, at 48th Street and Lexington Avenue, can reduce the number of trips with a three-night rate of $333, plus tax, that includes valet parking, good Monday through Thursday (extra nights are $111). The rate is for two in a room, so go ahead and carpool. Regular rates are $379 a night; (800) 448-4471.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: Arrests In Killing Of Soldiers
description: The Nigerian police said they had arrested 4 people connected with the killings of 19 soldiers last month in the central state of Benue. The killings led the army to begin a three-day attack on 16 villages and towns, where hundreds of civilians were massacred. The abuses were the worst under the country's 30-month-old civilian government.

title: National Briefing | South: South Carolina: Thurmond Backs A Successor
description: As expected, Senator Strom Thurmond has endorsed Representative Lindsay Graham in next year's election to succeed him. Mr. Thurmond, who will turn 99 next month, issued his endorsement at a luncheon in his honor in Washington on Thursday. Both men are Republicans. Mr. Graham, 46, noted that Mr. Thurmond was already in office when he was born. Kevin Sack (NYT)

title: Kim Learns How Cruel The Game Can Be
description: On Wednesday, Byung Hyun Kim stared in disbelief, walked around the mound at Yankee Stadium in a zombie state and pulled his cap over his eyes with his right hand as his glove shielded his head. Tino Martinez had just homered with two outs in the ninth inning, tying Game 4 of the World Series. Derek Jeter later homered off Kim, the Arizona closer, in the 10th inning to win the game.

title: Sept. 11 Casts a Shadow on a Tax-Curb Referendum
description: With images of firefighters from beginning to end, there is nothing subtle about an advertisement now on television here in Washington, paid for by opponents of an initiative on next week's ballot that would limit property tax increases to 1 percent a year unless otherwise authorized by a public vote.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Tunnel Safety Measure
description: To make trans-Alpine traffic safer, Swiss officials have decided to alternate the flow of traffic and permit trucks to travel only one way through the San Bernardino tunnel, the main north-south artery since a major accident last week closed the nearby St. Gotthard tunnel. The measure is intended to prevent head-on collisions and keep traffic under control. Truck traffic has jumped at the San Bernardino since the closing of the St. Gotthard tunnel 10 days ago. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Air Canada Puts Best Face On a Big Loss
description: It's bad, Air Canada said today, but not quite as bad as we thought.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Changing Of The Guard
description: The Royal Ulster Constabulary, the predominantly Protestant police force established in Northern Ireland after partition from Ireland in 1921, will be officially replaced at midnight tonight by the Police Service of Northern Ireland, a new force called for in the 1998 peace agreement and intended to be more representative of the province's population. The first of 308 recruits, 154 of them Catholic, are to start training tomorrow. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Road Runners Club To Honor Giuliani
description: In recent years, the New York Road Runners Club has presented its annual Abebe Bikila award for dedication to running to retired runners like Bill Rodgers, Frank Shorter, Alberto Salazar, Grete Waitz, Ingrid Kristiansen and Lisa Ondieki. The only winner who was not an elite runner was Fred Lebow, the impresario of the New York City Marathon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAUCH, FRANCES BREWSTER
description: RAUCH-Frances Brewster, 88. November 1, 2001 at her home in Bryn Mawr, PA. Born in New York City on September 2, 1913, she attended the Brearley School and graduated from the Foxcroft School, Middleburg, VA. with the Class of 1931. She received a BS degree from Columbia School of General Studies and an MA from the University of Pennsylvania. She is survived by her husband of 60 years, R. Stewart Rauch, Jr; a sister, Katherine B. Whipple of Gladwyne, PA; 5 children, Eleanor R. Crosby of Long Lake, MN, Rudolph S. Rauch III of Cold Spring, NY, Susan P. Rauch of Jackson, WY, Sheila R. Kennedy of Cambridge, Massachusetts, and Benjamin B. Rauch of New York City; nine grandchildren and one great-grandchild. A Memorial Service will be held at 11:30 AM on Tuesday, November 6th, at St. Christopher's Church, Righters Mill Road, Gladwyne, PA. Burial private. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to: Philadelphia Zoo, 3400 West Gerard Avenue, Philadelphia, PA. 19104.

title: On the Front Lines Of the Anthrax War
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBINS, EVA
description: ROBINS-Eva. Eve was a labor arbitrator, friend, mentor, traveler, pioneer & crossword and Scrabble fiend. She was loving, unpretentious, steadfast, ethical and had a wonderful sense of humor. Her sisters, brothers, nieces and nephews will always treasure her influence, guidance, support and nurturing. Services will be private and a memorial service will be scheduled in the future. Contributions may be made to the Macular Degeneration Foundation.

title: Talk About Terrorism Puts Heat on Gov. Davis
description: Gov. Gray Davis presided today over a feel-good session on how to right the badly listing California economy, but no matter how hard the business and labor leaders here tried to focus on tax credits and accelerated spending, the talk inevitably veered toward terrorism -- and Mr. Davis's sudden, ticklish problem with that issue.

title: Montclair Back Boldly Rushes Into the Spotlight
description: Hanif Suluki, a running back for Montclair (N.J.) High School, seems to do everything well. Suluki, a senior captain, can elude or run over tacklers. He works to make those around him better, but he is also capable of taking over a game.

title: What These Yankees Have Done for Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Experts Agree On the Need To Safeguard Nuclear Sites
description: Experts at a conference here on nuclear safeguards were divided today on whether the use of nuclear materials fits into the plans of Osama bin Laden and Al Qaeda. But they agreed that improved safeguards of fissionable material and nuclear power stations were urgently needed.

title: Warlike Aggressors, But in Fantasy Only
description: The affluent, self-satisfied 1990's spawned a paradoxical response: hard rock that inflates private feelings of victimization into a self-pitying rage. The songs are tantrums in search of a target, lashing out at family, ex-girlfriends and general human duplicity.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Jobless Rate Rises to 5.4% As 400,000 Are Dismissed

title: Justice Dept. Alters Stand On 3 Detained
description: Backing away from remarks by Attorney General John Ashcroft, the Justice Department suggested today that it did not know whether three Arab men now in custody in Michigan had advance knowledge of the terror attacks of Sept. 11.

title: Rangers Have Chances But Don't Convert Them
description: The performance was not the problem for the Rangers tonight, just the result.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Charges In Anthrax Hoax
description: The authorities in Arapahoe County, near Denver, plan to charge a 10-year-old boy who they said put a white powdery substance in a film canister and pretended to find it at his elementary school so classmates would perceive him as a hero for finding anthrax. The boy's name was not made public, and the authorities would not say what charges he will face in juvenile court. The boy has not been taken into custody. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARRELL, HAZEL (NEE MEDFORD)
description: FARRELL-Hazel (nee Medford). Of Freehold, NJ and Woodhaven, NY, October 31, 2001, in her 88th year. Beloved widow of James E. Farrell, whom she married on her 21st birthday in 1935. Devoted mother of Carol and Walter Bennett, of Freehold, NJ; Margaret and Gerald Nelson, of Brooklyn, NY; and James E. Farrell, Jr. and Gail Farrell, of Garden City, NY. Cherished Nana of Maureen Bennett, Alison and Brett Weisberg, Kathleen and Keith Daly, Michael and Tracy Nelson and Caroline Nelson; and Jamie, Christopher, Brian and Kaitlyn Farrell. Proud great-grandmother of Victoria Grace Daly. Loving sister-in-law of Mary Farrell and Mary Doolittle. Retired employee of NYC Transit. Native of Brooklyn, NY where she was born on June 9, 1914. Friends may call Friday 2-5, 7-9 PM at the Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, 29 Atlantic Avenue (at RR Plaza), Floral Park. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated Saturday 10 AM at St. Anne's R.C. Church, interment Cypress Hills Cemetery.

title: Registry of the Bereaved
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. and Microsoft in Deal, but States Hold Back
description: Microsoft and the federal government, long bitter legal enemies, walked into a federal court together today and announced that they had settled their epic antitrust dispute. State prosecutors who had filed a parallel antitrust lawsuit declined for now to endorse the deal and persuaded a federal judge to give them until early next week to formulate a response.

title: A Call to Hire 'Singaporeans First'
description: SINGAPORE  Although it is assured of an easy victory in Singapore's general elections Saturday, the government of Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong is having to fend off potentially damaging opposition charges that it favors foreigners in the job market at the expense of citizens.

title: A 'Butterfly' With Substitutes at the Top
description: In this World Series season, Richard Margison should get an M.V.P. award from the Metropolitan Opera. After singing Pollione in ''Norma'' on Wednesday, the Canadian tenor stepped into the revival of ''Madama Butterfly'' on Thursday as Pinkerton the operatic equivalent of pitching two complete games back to back.

title: Away From Taliban, Recurring Evidence Of Ethnic Harmony
description: In this mud-brick hamlet tucked away from the front lines, the villagers view the ethnic bloodletting raging in this country with an innocent incomprehension.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about life in St. Louis since the terrorist attacks misstated the location of the Dutchtown neighborhood. It is on the south side, not the north.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: Pakistan Releases 3 Scientists Questioned on Ties to Taliban
description: Pakistan said today that three nuclear scientists arrested 10 days ago for questioning about their relationship to the Taliban rulers of Afghanistan were released on Thursday night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIESEN, IRVING
description: WIESEN-Irving. Devoted husband of Tobie A. Loving father of Barbara Prager & Jeremy Lester Wiesen. Grandfather of Karen Balliett (Will), Emily Prager and Gavin B. Wiesen. Great-grandfather of Adelaide and Charlotte. Brother to Eleanor Leff. Graveside service to be held.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Education page on Wednesday about the Brooklyn High School of the Arts, which has a curriculum focused on building preservation, misidentified the source of the proposal for such a school. It was City Councilman Kenneth Fisher of Brooklyn. (Kate Burns Ottavino, director of preservation technology at the New Jersey Institute of Technology, is developing the curriculum.)

title: Have Gun, See Sheriff In Oregon
description: The sheriff of Clatsop County in rural Oregon has proposed organizing armed volunteers to help deal with the threat of terrorism.

title: Southern Stories, on the Stage and on Their Own
description: Fiction and drama cohabit the world of literature, siblings really, and though drama is the elder it is generally the stage that borrows from the page. The adaptation of novels and stories has become a well-plied genre, usually not with the spur of homage so much as of making a new work.

title: What These Yankees Have Done for Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Martin's Game Absent From Nets' Quick Start
description: AUBURN HILLS, Mich., Nov. 2 — Kenyon Martin is a rhythm player. And after the first two games of the Nets' season, Martin, the No. 1 draft pick last year, seems as if he has none.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Insurer Will Cut Jobs
description: Prudential, Britain's second-largest insurer, said it would cut 2,100 jobs and sell its property and casualty unit to the Credit Suisse Group for 353 million ($517 million). As part of the sale, an additional 1,200 jobs will be transferred to Credit Suisse's Winterthur Insurance division. Prudential, which has been losing market share to rivals CGNU and the Legal and General Group, is slimming down to focus on life insurance, which is less volatile than the property and casualty segment. It wants to cut 175 million in annual costs by 2004.

title: CUNY Raises Tuition Rates For Foreigners Here Illegally
description: After a policy review prompted by the events of Sept. 11, the City University of New York is about to raise tuition for students who are illegal immigrants.

title: U.S., Irritated by Criticism, Calls Envoy Home From Venezuela
description: Showing rising irritation with one of its most important oil suppliers, the United States has ordered its ambassador to Caracas to return to Washington for ''consultations'' after President Hugo Chvez of Venezuela condemned the Afghanistan campaign as ''fighting terrorism with terrorism.''

title: Trying to Show Who's Better Suited to Inherit a Legacy
description: The mayoral campaign of Michael R. Bloomberg, the Republican candidate, began broadcasting a television advertisement on Thursday called ''Every Step,'' which suggests the election of his Democratic opponent, Mark Green, would jeopardize the legacy of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Charity Game Today at Hofstra
description: Hoops for Heroes, a charity basketball game benefiting the children of victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center, will be held today at the Hofstra Arena at 4 p.m.

title: Net Income Was Lower For Cigna In 3rd Quarter
description: The Cigna Corporation, a leading provider of health insurance, said today that its third-quarter profit fell 2.9 percent, as the cost of medical care rose and life and disability insurance claims increased after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: McGreevey and Schundler Place Election Day Hopes on Minorities
description: With polls and campaign-spending data giving the edge in Tuesday's gubernatorial election to James E. McGreevey, the Democratic mayor of Woodbridge, perhaps the only thing that could hurt his chances is an anemic turnout among his supporters.

title: What These Yankees Have Done for Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Gas Will Be Used to Kill Bacteria in Senate Office Building
description: Workers from the Environmental Protection Agency finished sealing the doors and windows of the Hart Senate Office Building today with sheets of plastic and duct tape to make it airtight in preparation for a novel house-cleaning.

title: U.S. Orders New Aid to Help Avert Famine in Afghanistan
description: The Bush administration said today that it was spending $8.2 million in emergency aid for Afghanistan, most of which would be used to buy trucks to transport 30,000 tons of wheat immediately to northern Afghanistan. It was the second emergency purchase this week intended to avert what the administration is now calling famine conditions.

title: Decision Nears In the Inquiry Over Torricelli
description: A long-running federal investigation into the activities of Senator Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey has reached a critical phase, with prosecutors close to a decision about whether to seek his indictment on evidence that he took thousands of dollars in gifts and cash from a political donor, people involved in the inquiry said.

title: Eileen Shanahan, 77, Former Times Reporter
description: Eileen Shanahan, a reporter for The New York Times who broke ground in the male-dominated world of economic news and later a news executive at other papers, died here today. She was 77.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAWITZKY, SHERRY
description: KAWITZKY-Sherry. On October 31, 2001. Her heartbroken husband Ronald, her children Simon and Deanna and her sister Karen Bressler mourn her untimely passing after a long illness. Our doer, our provider, our comforter is no more. We will never understand why. Only our love for her, and hers for us, can sustain us. Rest in peace our darling. Service Sunday, 11:45AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: An Enforceable Ban on Bioterror
description: The attacks of Sept. 11 and the spread of anthrax have forced the Bush administration to reconsider its ill-advised antipathy to strengthening the 1972 treaty that bans the development, production and possession of biological weapons. This week President Bush proposed ways to assure international compliance with the accord. Unfortunately, the suggestions still leave the United States opposed to a critical enforcement mechanism.

title: Quarterly Net Drops 71% at Wackenhut
description: The Wackenhut Corporation, the No. 2 provider of security guards, said today that its profit fell 71 percent in the third quarter even as revenue rose at all of its businesses.

title: As Troops Guard Major Bridges, a Warning Is Debated
description: Caravans of armed National Guard troops and Highway Patrol officers fanned out across bridges in California's largest cities today to guard against potential terrorist attacks that Gov. Gray Davis suggested on Thursday might be imminent.

title: Unionist Bloc Stalls Latest Ulster Peace Bid
description: Northern Ireland's embittered politicians once again confounded hope today by contriving to stall the peace process only days after the start of Irish Republican Army disarmament had rekindled visions of progress.

title: Three Titles to Become One After Judah Meets Tszyu
description: LAS VEGAS, Nov. 2 — So many different titles, so many different champions. How does a boxing fan keep track?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, GEORGE M.
description: KAUFMAN-George M. The trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art are deeply saddened by the death of George M. Kaufman, passionate collector, generous benefactor, and longtime friend. He was, together with his wife Linda, a member of The William Cullen Bryant Fellows, the Friends of The American Wing, and the Visiting Committee, Department of American Decorative Arts. He underwrote the publication of The 18th Century American Furniture Collection, and he endowed two galleries for the display of 18th century American decorative arts. His rare intelligence and infectious enthusiasm will be greatly missed. Philippe de Montebello, Director Morrison H. Heckscher, Chairman of The American Wing

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEDIGIAN, CARL J.
description: BEDIGIAN-Carl J., Firefighter, FDNY, Engine 214, Brooklyn, NY. Died bravely in the line of duty on September 11, 2001 at the World Trade Center. Beloved husband of Michele. Cherished son of Dolores. Loving and devoted brother of Joseph and Robert, and brotherin-law of Richard and Yahira Becker, and Vivian Bedigian. Adored son-in-law of Evelyn and Richard Becker. Dear godfather of Jayden R. Becker. Treasured nephew of John, Louise Duane and Sue Beik. He will always be in our hearts. Visiting at Papavero Funeral Home, 72-27 Grand Avenue, Maspeth Sunday 2-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral Mass Monday, Saint Cecilia's Church, at 10 AM. Interment Greenwood Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to E214/L111, WTC Memorial Fund, 495 Hancock Street, Brooklyn, NY 11233, would be appreciated.

title: Unemployment Jumps to 5.4%, A 5-Year High
description: Over 400,000 Americans lost jobs last month, the most for a single month in more than two decades, as businesses responded to a deteriorating economy with a surge in layoffs.

title: Blunt Words To Describe Grim Reality At the Site
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani often begins his sentences with the phrase, ''The reality is.'' Yesterday, the reality he had to gingerly, but firmly, convey to embattled New Yorkers was that the work being done on the spot where the World Trade Center once stood -- a place at once a burial ground, crime scene, tourist attraction and development site -- is no longer principally a recovery operation, and has not been for some time.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a roll-call listing yesterday for the House vote defeating a Democratic-backed bill on aviation security rendered the votes of the Missouri delegation incorrectly in some copies. Of the Republicans, Todd Akin, Roy Blunt, Sam Graves and Kenny Hulshof voted against the measure; Jo Ann Emerson voted for it. The Democrats -- William Lacy Clay, Richard Gephardt, Karen McCarthy and Ike Skelton -- all voted yes.

title: ALUMINUM COMPANY TO CLOSE PLANTS IN CALIFORNIA
description: Alcoa Inc., the biggest aluminum maker, said yesterday that it would close plants in California and France that make aircraft parts, eliminating about 450 jobs, because of slowing demand from aerospace companies. About 150 positions will be cut in the City of Industries, Calif., plant and 300 jobs at a factory in Lecreusot, France. Production will be transferred to other plants. Airlines have slashed flights by a fifth and canceled orders for equipment and replacement parts after a decline in travel after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. Alcoa's profit fell 7.9 percent in the third quarter because of lower aluminum demand. The company is based in Pittsburgh.

title: Our History Is in Our Mail
description: The other day I opened an envelope I had received in the mail from a stranger. Inside, I saw a letter explaining the contents, but I ignored it to take out something else. I had recognized my father's handwriting at once: the sharp, angular slant of the script, the confident rhythm of a man who wrote letters often. And I recognized my grandmother's writing paper.

title: Knoblauch Is in the Mood to Reminisce
description: The conversation took place after batting practice Thursday night, an unplanned discussion between two players whose futures are uncertain and who decided to take 10 minutes to at least remember where they have been. Chuck Knoblauch and Scott Brosius do not know where they will be next year, but they could have chatted for 10 hours about where they have been.

title: Michelangelo of the Hard Sell; He Closes Deals on Trophy Cars, and Owns the Buyers
description: Tony Razzano is a used-car salesman on the Gold Coast of Long Island. He is moving high-end hey-notice-me-cars even in these spooked economic times because, he says, he understands a basic concept of Long Island life:

title: Trader by Day, D.J. by Night, And a Cherished Only Son
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Travelers Stay Home
description: The number of Japanese who went overseas in September plunged 21.5 percent from the month a year earlier, the largest monthly slide since March 1991 during the Persian Gulf war. More than 1.3 million Japanese traveled outside their country in September, but the Sept. 11 attacks in the United States led thousands of others to cancel their travel plans. Japan Airlines and All Nippon Airlines have since scaled back their trans-Pacific flights and Hawaii will lose $1 billion this year because so many Japanese are staying away. Nearly 18 million Japanese traveled overseas last year. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: The Threat of Attacks
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing
description: AFRICA

title: Schilling Insists He Will Be Able to Start a Game 7
description: Arizona Diamondbacks Manager Bob Brenly realized that whatever moves he made during the World Series would be magnified, so when he chose to start Curt Schilling on three days' rest in Game 4, he expected questions. But Brenly never anticipated announcing at a news conference that Schilling might not be available to start a Game 7, a statement he abruptly retracted a few minutes later.

title: 5 Bosnian Serbs Guilty of War Crimes at Infamous Camp
description: In its first major trial to address the prison camp system set up by Serbs during the Bosnian war, the United Nations tribunal today convicted five Bosnian Serbs for their role in the most notorious of the camps, a place of death and torture, set in an old iron ore mine in the village of Omarska.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN RISES The dollar dropped against the Japanese yen as consumer spending fell and unemployment rose, adding to evidence the economy is shrinking. The dollar fell to 121.63 yen from 121.95 yen on Thursday.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: An Awful Lot Of Zeros
description: Acknowledging that it has failed to curb its high inflation rate, Turkey issued a new 20 million lira bank note yesterday, worth about $12. ''It's sad to have your signature on a note with seven zeros, but bringing this bank note out is a technical necessity,'' the deputy central bank governor, Aykut Ekzen, said. Like all other Turkish bills, the new note bears the picture of the nation's founder, Mustafa Kemal Ataturk. The new bill is the highest denomination, though its value against the dollar is less than the 10 million lira note was worth when it was issued two years ago. Douglas Frantz (NYT)

title: USX-MARATHON TO BUY CMS WEST AFRICA HOLDINGS
description: The oil company USX-Marathon said yesterday that it had agreed to buy CMS Energy's stakes in oil and natural-gas fields and methanol and gas-processing plants in West Africa's Equatorial Guinea for $993 million in cash. Marathon, which is based in Houston, will get the equivalent of 250 million barrels of oil, increasing its global reserves by 20 percent, Clarence Cazalot, Marathon's president, said on a conference call. The purchase is expected to close in January. The acquisition will double Marathon's West Africa output, a spokesman, Roger Holliday, said. The company has stakes in fields off the coasts of Gabon and Angola. CMS, a Michigan utility owner, is shedding assets outside the United States to expand its North American businesses.

title: INSIDE
description: Cross Burning Permitted

title: A Shameful Vote on Air Safety
