description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Missouri: Nuclear Waste Transport
description: Gov. Bob Holden said recent terrorist threats should prompt the Energy Department to review its practice of transporting nuclear waste across the country. The governor accused the department of breaking an agreement earlier this year by sending a shipment of nuclear waste through the state during a period of heavy traffic. In a letter to Energy Secretary Spencer Abraham, Mr. Holden wrote that the transport of nuclear waste through heavily populated areas should be reviewed. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: The Law of Computer Evolution and the Law of the Land
description: Yesterday, the two parties in United States v. Microsoft reached a compromise that could bring the three-year-old case to an end. But nothing will undo the conclusion that Microsoft used monopoly power in violation of the Sherman Antitrust Act. In fact, the proposed compromise could have a significant effect on how Microsoft conducts its business.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Fears Of TB Epidemic
description: The rapid spread of the AIDS virus in Russia has set the stage for an epidemic of tuberculosis unless medical officials move quickly to contain both diseases, an article in the British medical journal The Lancet stated. Tuberculosis readily infects people who have depressed immune systems, and Russian and American researchers who studied Orel Province, southwest of Moscow, found that H.I.V. infections there had risen almost 34-fold from 1997 to 2000. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: For Neighborhood Watch Groups, New Interest, New Mission
description: With its lush trees, spacious homes and broad green lawns, this well-heeled Boston suburb seems an unlikely haunt for terrorists.

title: In a Breakthrough, of Sorts, Arafat and Peres Shake Hands
description: It is a measure of the stagnation of the Middle East peace process that a handshake today between the Israeli foreign minister, Shimon Peres, and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, should be regarded as progress.

title: In Michigan, Very Different States of Mind
description: Although the skies were overcast, the man who called himself John Spirit wore sunglasses as he scanned the perimeter of the traffic island for potential vandals. He was protecting ''The Spartan,'' a 10-foot ceramic statue of a barely clothed warrior near the football stadium of the Michigan State Spartans. The autumn wind swirled dead leaves around the feet of both ''The Spartan'' and John Spirit. Both stood strong and vigilant.

title: Pakistan Businesses Receive Anthrax-Tainted Letters
description: In the last 10 days, three businesses in Pakistan -- a bank, a computer company and a newspaper -- have received letters with suspicious powder inside.

title: Allure Must Be Covered. Individuality Peeks Through
description: WHETHER they call it "observing purdah" or "hijab," the meaning is the same: a traditional Muslim woman's obligation to hide her physical beauty from men to whom she is not related. But there are many interpretations of what is required among the Afghan refugees now living in Pakistan.

title: CAR MAKER'S ATLANTA PLANT TO IDLE 2,100 WORKERS
description: The Ford Motor Company will close an Atlanta car plant for a week starting on Monday, idling about 2,100 workers, to reduce production because of lower orders from rental-car companies and businesses. The plant makes the Ford Taurus and Mercury Sable sedans. United States auto sales surged 24 percent last month, and Ford's sales nationwide rose 36 percent in October, helped by no-interest loans. Orders from rental-car companies and businesses looking to add to fleets slid 30 percent last month and have been declining since July as a slowing economy reduces travel demand and prompts companies to scale back on purchasing, a Ford sales analyst, George Pipas, said.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Idaho: Hearing On Term Limits
description: The State Supreme Court heard opening arguments in a case concerning a term-limits law that could keep nearly half of the Legislature off the ballot in next year's elections. Passed by voters in 1994, the law limits state and local elected officials to eight years in office. In the case before the Supreme Court, the state is appealing a district court ruling that the law violates elected officials' constitutional rights. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLYNN, MARTIN J., M.D.
description: GLYNN-Martin J., M.D. On November 1, 2001 of Rockville Centre, NY. Beloved husband of Mary (nee Gallagher). Loving father of Mary Laine (Walter), Martin J. (Maribeth). Cherished grandfather of Martin, Sarah, Christopher, Matthew and Michael. Reposing at Macken Mortuary Inc., 52 Clinton Avenue, Rockville Centre, N.Y. Sunday 2-4, 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass on Monday 11 AM at St. Agnes Cathedral, Rockville Centre, New York. Interment St. Catherine Cemetery, Springlake, New Jersey.

title: What These Yankees Have Done for Us
description: To the Editor:

title: A Latin Excursion for a Band That's Partial to Brass
description: In several ways, the Carnegie Hall Jazz Band was well positioned to put on a Latin jazz program like the one it offered Thursday.

title: Uzbek Who Exposed Rights Abuses to Be Honored in New York
description: After a long wait, an Uzbek human rights monitor who had been invited to the United States to speak about his imprisonment and torture at the hands of the security police here has been granted permission to leave the country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAFRAN, FANNYE R. (NEE RATNER)
description: SHAFRAN-Fannye R. (nee Ratner). Beloved wife of the late Nathan P. Loving mother of Joseph (Marla) Shafran, Paula Krulak and Joan (Rob Haimes) Shafran, devoted grandmother of Roger (Francine) Krulak, Robert and Lora Krulak; Ilana, Eric and David Shafran, great-grandmother of Julian Blaine and Chloe Victoria. Dear sister of the late Leonard, Charles, Harry, Max and Joseph Ratner, Irene Zehman, Doris Sukenik and Frieda Isenstadt. Services will be held Sunday, November 4 at 2PM at the BerkowitzKumin-Bookatz Memorial Chapel, 1985 South Taylor Rd, Cleveland Heights, OH. Interment Bet Olam Cemetery. Family will observe Shiva at the residence of Mr. and Mrs. J. Shafran. Friends who wish may contribute to the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation, The Cleveland Hearing and Speech Center or Fuch Mizrachi.

title: WHITE MOUNTAINS INSURANCE TO START NEW COMPANY
description: The White Mountains Insurance Group Ltd., an insurer run by the former Geico chief executive, John Byrne, is raising $1 billion to start a new insurer based in Bermuda amid industrywide price increases. The new venture, to focus on providing property-catastrophe coverage to other insurers, will be led by Anthony Taylor, former chairman of Wellington Holdings P.L.C. and an insurance executive with 25 years of experience at Lloyd's of London. The move will bring to about $7.5 billion the amount of new capital raised in the insurance industry to take advantage of rising rates after insurers were hit with as much as $70 billion of losses from the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: Tiffany to Open First Store in Beijing
description: Tiffany, the luxury-jewelry retailer, said today that it would open its first store in Beijing to cater to a growing number of affluent customers in China.

title: A Shameful Vote on Air Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLSTEIN, SARA C.
description: OLSTEIN-Sara C., 97. Widow of Joseph, mother of Harriet Mendelsohn (Allan), the late Judith Olstein, grandmother of Rachel Cabrera (Allan), great grandmother of Jared. Services Sunday, November 4, 11:30AM, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 St, NY

title: Mayor Pleads Not Guilty To Charges Of Corruption
description: Moments before pleading not guilty to a host of corruption charges in Federal District Court here, Mayor Joseph P. Ganim of Bridgeport was relaxed enough this afternoon to work the courtroom, warmly greeting supporters and members of the press and pantomiming to the courtroom artist to sketch him with more hair.

title: Machado Gets His Chance To Start at Guard for Jets
description: They regard themselves as tough guys who think. It is a major reason the same five players have started every game on the Jets' offensive line since the start of last season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAIM, VICTOR
description: HAIM-Victor. We join Mary, Caron, Marc and all the family in mourning the loss of Vic, a man of unrivalled good cheer and joie de vivre. Muriel and Howard Weingrow

title: A Council Race in Queens Offers a Rare Choice of Party and Politics
description: In a city where hotly contested City Council races between Democrats and Republicans are few and far between, one race in northeastern Queens offers voters a distinct choice not only in party, but also in the political backgrounds of the candidates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, ABRAHAM
description: WEISS-Abraham. On November 1, 2001. Beloved husband of Ruth. Loving father of Wendy Greenberg and Debra Weinberg. Dear father-in-law of Joel Greenberg and Laurence Weinberg. Devoted brother of Lillian Aronson. Adoring grandfather of Victoria and Barry, Andrew and Sarah. Greatgrandfather of Daphne. Service Monday, 11:15AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: City Closer To Opening New Centers For Jobs
description: The city's Human Resources Administration took another step yesterday toward opening several new job centers, after finishing public hearings on a group of contracts.

title: Religion Journal; In Devastation's Shadow, A Landmark's Renewal
description: The terrorist attacks of Sept. 11 could not irreparably disrupt life's rhythms, not even in Lower Manhattan's ''red zone,'' the area around the World Trade Center. Tomorrow, Trinity Church, at the upper end of Wall Street, will open for its first service since the attacks.

title: Exogenous Is Euthanized
description: The filly Exogenous was euthanized yesterday because of complications from a brain hemorrhage resulting from a fall before the Breeders' Cup Distaff last Saturday at Belmont Park.

title: A Bad King (Richard III) Comes in 3's
description: Richard III, at least as portrayed by Shakespeare, was one nasty guy, except to the director Andrei Serban. In an energetic adaptation now on view at the La MaMa Annex, Mr. Serban has turned the blood-drenched king into three nasty guys.

title: G.O.P. Moderates See Dangers in Bush's Stance on Aviation Security
description: Shouts of victory rose up in the West Wing on Thursday night as the House passed a Republican aviation security bill that President Bush had battled for, even as he fought his broader war against terrorism.

title: Election Choices
description: New York City voters will have a lot of choices in next Tuesday's election, including an array of local contests and ballot proposals. Here are our endorsements in some of the most heavily contested City Council and other races and propositions to change the State Constitution and the City Charter.

title: Corrections
description: A column on Page 1 of Business Day yesterday about the specter of deflation misstated the last time the quarterly change in prices for personal consumption spending was negative. It was the second quarter of 1961, not 1954.

title: Searching for an Explanation, The Yankees Find Only Belief
description: Scott Brosius' home run landed in the left-field stands, and as frenzied fans began shaking Yankee Stadium on Thursday night, relief pitcher Mike Stanton paused to catch his breath in the bullpen. For the second consecutive night, a Yankee had hit a game-tying home run with two outs in the bottom of the ninth inning of a World Series game.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Company News column of Business Day yesterday about a third-quarter loss estimate by a Wall Street firm misstated its name. It was Credit Suisse First Boston USA, a unit that includes most of the United States operations of Credit Suisse First Boston -- not Credit Suisse First Boston itself. The report also referred incorrectly to an earlier estimate. No such estimate was made.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARNOLD, NED R.
description: ARNOLD-Ned R. On Nov. 2, 2001. Retired Queens entrepreneur, philanthropist and community leader. Life trustee of New York Hospital of Queens. Six term past president of Queens Chamber of Commerce. Beloved husband of the late Julia. Loving father of Pamela A. Dawson. Devoted father-inlaw of Arthur D. Dawson. Beloved grandfather of Alex. Devoted brother of Hy Arnold. Reposing at Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, 149-20 Northern Boulevard, Flushing, New York. Visiting on Monday 2-4 and 6-8. Funeral services on Tuesday at 10 AM. Entombment at Pinelawn Memorial Park. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Julia and Ned R. Arnold Center for Radiation/ Oncology at New York Hospital of Queens.

title: From Bipartisan To All Partisan On Air Security
description: In the battle this week in the House over aviation security, the very survival of one group of businesses was at stake: the private security companies that employ screeners at airports around the country.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HERRMANN, RICHARD A.
description: HERRMANN-Richard A. November 3, 1999. Dear Richard, we miss you so. Forever and always, with love. Marilyn, Rachel and Amy

title: Unity Dinner for Green Is Anything But, With Ferrer Absent
description: A ''Unity Dinner'' for Mark Green's mayoral campaign did not quite live up to its billing last night. Leading Hispanic officials, including Fernando Ferrer, boycotted the event to show their continuing anger and suspicion over tactics used in the runoff election between Mr. Green and Mr. Ferrer, the Bronx borough president.

title: Minority in Strife
Paid Notice: Deaths  STEGER, THOMAS G., M.D.
description: STEGER-Thomas G., M.D., 32. Died suddenly on October 23 in Durham, North Carolina. Dr. Steger attended elementary and middle school in Scarsdale and graduated from the Scarsdale High School in 1987. He graduated with honors from Northwestern University in 1991 and with honors from the NYU School of Medicine in 1995. He completed a residency in Orthopaedics at the Barnes Hospital in St. Louis, in June, 2001, where he served as Chief Orthopaedic Resident. At the time of his death, Dr. Steger was a Fellow at the Duke University Hospital Medical Center where he held the first Fellowship in Trauma Orthopaedics. Dr. Steger is survived by his parents Nancy and John Steger of Scarsdale, his sister Katherine of Montreal and by his grandmothers Mrs. Wilma Steger of the Bronx, NY and Mrs. J.D. Gunther of Bloomfield, CT. A memorial service will be held at 10:30 AM on November 17 at The Church of St. Pius X in Scarsdale. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Dr. Thomas G. Steger Orthopaedic Trauma Fund, Dept. of Surgery, DUMC, Box 3704, Durham, N.C. 27710.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANNHEISSER, ELAINE
description: DANNHEISSER-Elaine. 1923-2001. We will always remember you and the joys of young life we shared growing up together. With Love, The Masia Family

title: A Builder of Paradoxes That Turn Viewers Inward
description: THE artist Roni Horn is dreaming of a book that never ends. In this visual equivalent to Joyce's ''Finnegans Wake,'' the reader turns page after page only to arrive back at Page 1. She is also dreaming of an exhibition that isn't an exhibition, in which water runs through a building -- or rather not water itself but images of water.

title: A Cuban Master's Progeny Bear Her Art in Their Bones
description: I did not see Alicia Alonso perform during her glory years in America, three decades that ended in 1960 when she returned to her native Havana to devote her full energies to the Ballet Alicia Alonso. My first live encounter with her extraordinary artistry was in 1971, when the Ballet Nacional de Cuba, as her company was then called, performed in Montreal. That was the closest the state-supported troupe could get to New York because of the turbulent political relations between the United States and Fidel Castro.

title: Old-Fashioned Sounds From Masters of Electronica
description: APHEX TWIN and Richie Hawtin, two of the most important figures in contemporary electronica, have spent a decade celebrating software. On their intriguing, often mysterious records, they've created their own sonic vocabularies through electronic experimentation. Now both producers are back with ambitious new albums that betray an unexpected fascination with hardware. Aphex Twin's ''Drukqs'' is a two-hour panegyric to the piano, while Mr. Hawtin's ''DE9: Closer to the Edit'' expands the musical horizons of a more modern instrument: the turntable. Each album takes the producer's chosen musical instrument as its starting point, then follows the trail of inspiration out into the world of electronics.

title: Dancer Pays Tribute To Victims of Sept. 11
description: IT was because of skinny legs that Maxine Sherman's doctor ordered her to go to ballet class. She was 8 at the time, and he commonly prescribed dance for increased leg strength. There was no way for him to know, of course, that this particular girl would take to dance with such fire and joy or how she would use it to get through a difficult childhood.

title: RITE AID SETTLES
description: The Rite Aid drugstore chain has agreed to pay $150,000 in fines to the state to settle a suit over overcharging customers who lacked prescription drug benefits. According to a spokeswoman for Rite Aid, this practice was discontinued in June 1998, when Rite Aid changed management. Rite Aid, which is based in Camp Hill, Pa., has 177 stores in New Jersey. The settlement concludes a three-year investigation by lo sukellthe state Consumer Affairs department. Jo Piazza

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BASSIOS, CHRISTOS
description: BASSIOS-Christos, 89. On November 1, 2001 in Ioannina, Greece where he lived in retirement. He was a longtime NYC resident, a WWII veteran and P.O.W. He will be greatly missed by his loving wife, Filomila and his beloved daughter, Penny.

title: Jets Will Find Nothing Is Simple in the Big Easy
description: There was a lot of talk about perceptions last week. The perception that the Jets' offense is uninspired and one dimensional. The perception that they are somehow not worthy of a 4-3 record. The perception that there is an elite group of N.F.L. teams and the Jets need to beat one to give legitimacy to a season that is floating on the bubble of parity.

title: In the Region/Changes at the Top?; Unaccustomed Vulnerability in the Luxury Market
description: DURING the two weeks after the Sept. 11 attacks on the World Trade Center, the suburban real estate market around Manhattan ground to a halt. ''We were numb'' is a phrase heard repeatedly. Since then the lower and middle range markets have returned to some semblance of normalcy, but the top of the luxury market, traditionally impervious to economic conditions, has begun to show unaccustomed vulnerability.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTS, JOHN
description: ROBERTS-John. The Trustees and staff of Expeditionary Learning Outward Bound mourn the loss of John Roberts, a trustee and friend whose intelligence, humor and grace set him apart, and at the same time connected him to us and to everyone. We offer our sympathy and support to his wife Rona, his daughter Jennifer and his son Douglas. Lee Klingenstein, Chairman Greg Farrell, President Expeditionary Learning Outward Bound

title: A Helping Hand for New Yorkers
description: At every hour, Robert Tucker knows where he is welcome. On a nearly deserted subway car at 3 a.m. At a cafeteria for the elderly poor at noon.

title: The War on Civilians
description: Robert D. Kaplan replies:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COHEN, HARRIET G.
description: COHEN-Harriet G. Nov. 3, 1983. In cherished and loving memory of our dearly beloved mother, grandmother and sister-in-law. Always in our hearts. Sadly missed. Richard Jay & Hope, Lindsey and Ashley, and sister-in-law Lucille.

title: Van Gogh, This Time In Crayon
description: Coloring books might be a welcome change for children who have been drawing skyscrapers since September -- especially now that the latest books have moved away from coloring-as-usual subjects like Barbie, Pokmon and Winnie the Pooh.

title: Struggling to Be Both Arab and American
description: The national anthem was a given. So was the flag. But the planners of the Arab American Political Action Committee's fourth annual banquet were stuck on one detail: What to put on the banner behind the podium?

title: The Real 'High Artist'
description: To the Editor:

title: The Final Fronton Nears Its Final Days
description: THE sanctuary of professional athletes, the locker room, is often a noisy place. Card games, practical jokes and loud banter characteristically can be heard from behind its closed doors.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION & POETRY
description: COURTING LAURA PROVIDENCIA

title: Footlights; A Future in Doubt
description: The Bridge Gallery in White Plains was fashioned from the long passageway between the Michaelian Westchester County Office Building on one side and the Westchester County Courthouse on the other. With the passageway now closed for security reasons, the gallery's future is in doubt.

title: A Muscular Lobby Rolls Up Its Sleeves
description: WITH anthrax spores turning up all over Washington, plenty of people are heading out of town.

title: Unfriendly Witnesses In Togas And Boots
description: THE committee feeds its witness the usual threat, wrapped in an un-nourishing promise: Cooperate and we'll be lenient. Just confirm what we already know. Name your friend as a traitor.

title: Jordan Lifts Wizards Out of Their Mediocrity
description: Matt Harpring was holding Michael Jordan down in the third quarter, using his forearms and his quick feet to stay with him. The crossover dribble did not freeze Harpring. Jordan's bobbing head did not rattle him. Nothing from the past was working.

title: Van Horn Leads Nets' Surge Past Hornets
description: The Nets returned to running tonight. They ran with abandon and used their stifling defense against the Charlotte Hornets to create easy baskets for themselves.

title: OUT THERE: Colombia; Who's the Fairest of Them All?
description: ANDREA PAOLA GARZN, tall and impossibly thin, takes her beauty seriously.

title: The Next Front: Our Driveways?
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Dreams for the Montclair Art Museum
description: FOUNDED in 1914, the Montclair Art Museum, New Jersey's first, is well known for its collection of American and Native American art. But these days, it looks more like a hard hat zone than a residence for American masterpieces.

title: Bin Laden, in a Taped Speech, Says Attacks in Afghanistan Are a War Against Islam
description: In an attempt to play to Arab and Muslim popular opinion, Osama bin Laden portrayed the American military campaign in Afghanistan as a war against Islam, saying in a videotaped speech broadcast today that the Afghan people had done nothing to deserve such an onslaught.

title: A Treasure Trove Of Ottoman Arts Over the Centuries
description: THE exhibition of Islamic art, ''Empire of the Sultans: Ottoman Art from the Khalili Collection,'' which opened at the Bruce Museum of Arts and Science in Greenwich on Oct. 27, is rich and has an impressive sweep. This treasure trove of a show contains more than 200 objects pertaining to religion, warfare, science and daily life that span the 600 years of the Ottoman Empire.

title: A Capra-esque Breakout for 'the Prison Guy'
description: FRANK DARABONT has to have one of the most consistent career arcs of any living film director. He first came to the world's attention with his 1994 adaptation of the Stephen King period prison story ''The Shawshank Redemption'' -- a huge hit that garnered seven Oscar nominations. Not one to rest on his laurels, however, and clearly sensing that the public appetite for Stephen King-based period prison movies hadn't quite been satisfied, Mr. Darabont leapt into the breach in 1999 and gave us ''The Green Mile,'' another King novel, also set in prison, in period.

title: The Temperature's a Lot Warmer but the Mission's the Same: Hunting Down Terrorists
description: When 23 American military advisers arrived in the Philippines last week, they slipped into the southern city of Zamboanga, wearing civilian clothes and ducking reporters.

title: A Story of Witch Hunts That Still Has Resonance
description: BONNIE J. Monte, artistic director of the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival here, announced the group's plan to produce ''The Crucible,'' by Arthur Miller, about six months before Sept. 11. Yet the choice makes utter sense as a commentary on current events.

title: It's Time for Teamwork on New Drugs
description: NOTHING weakens our faith in the sanctity of intellectual property like a little bioterror. After anthrax started killing Americans, the Bush administration put the arm on Bayer to provide Cipro, the best-known treatment, on the cheap, lest the company's patent be abrogated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALL, JULIA ELIZABETH
description: HALL-Julia Elizabeth. Passed away at her home in NYC at age 83, on October 29, 2001. Born in London within the sound of Bow Bells. Daughter of Harriett Cass Newman and Harold Newman. Longtime UN staff member, painter, photographer and world traveler. Julia is survived by her son John, her daughter Catherine, her grandchildren Andrea, Alex, Sebastian and Drew, and by her brother Harry and sister Millie. A dear friend to many, she will be deeply missed by us all. A memorial service will be held at the United Nations Chapel, at 777 UN Plaza, on November 20 at 1 PM. Contributions in her memory may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Love in the 21st Century
description: Your special issue (Oct. 14) was provocative and liberating. You satisfyingly avoided the tyranny of ''normal,'' cookie-cutter couples, following the worn paths of coupledom. To hear the couples you featured talk about how they have veered off that path and still make it work provides the sort of optimism and open-mindedness that we could use more of these days.

title: Turn, Turn, Turn: A Greenmarket Comforts
description: THEY line up quietly, patiently, clutching bouquets of broccoli, fat tomatoes and recently baked loaves of bread at the Brooklyn Heights Greenmarket. Even with the wearing of the season's first hats and gloves and the wintry whisper of early darkness, the market's faithful gather here for a fall ritual that's one part solace, one part understated adventure.

title: Voters on Tuesday Will Choose Mayors in Houston, Atlanta, Seattle and Miami
description: When Houstonians go to the polls on Tuesday, they will do more than decide whether Mayor Lee P. Brown should serve a third two-year term at the helm of the nation's fourth-largest city.

title: G.O.P. Not Relying on Aid From Bush in '02 Elections
description: Despite President Bush's colossal job approval ratings, many Republicans who are running in the midterm elections next year say they do not expect him, even if he remains enormously popular, to help their own campaigns.

title: Johnson Could Have Been Pulled for Game 7
description: Joe Torre watched batting practice intently last night. There was no one around him as there almost always is. No Don Zimmer. No Lee Mazzilli. No reporters. Torre stood 10 feet from his players, his arms on the batting cage, and looked as intense as a manager who had to make last cuts.

title: Arch Types
description: This fall, black and white are to fashion as glass and steel are to Calatrava's architecture.

title: Visitors From Pennsylvania Come in Peace, Bearing Money . . .
description: To be a good American these days is to spend money, especially in New York. And so to be patriotic, last weekend a caravan of 22 buses took 1,100 shoppers from in and around Scranton, Pa., into the heart of the city.

title: Anthrax Discovery Closes Mail Center
description: A mail processing center that serves most of southern New Jersey was closed last night after anthrax spores were found on a mail-sorting machine, officials said. The center had been shut down and reopened last week after an employee showed symptoms of anthrax exposure.

title: Abstract Paintings That Cross Barriers of Time and Place
description: RECENTLY, when I was browsing through an art magazine dated Summer 1989, I stumbled upon a Lufthansa advertisement that showed a shark suspended in a glass and metal tank filled with oxygenated water -- an image that immediately brought to mind the art of Damien Hirst.

title: Change in Ownership, a Rise in Luster
description: REMEMBER Mannino's, the sophisticated pasta and pizza spot on South Oyster Bay Road in Hicksville that opened about eight years ago? A recent visit there revealed that everything had changed except the name. It looked the same, aside from the absence of the prominent pizza oven, but differences dominated: ownership, chef and menu.

title: Oct. 28-Nov. 3; A Confusing Guilty Plea
description: Sara Jane Olson abandoned more than two decades of defiance by pleading guilty to charges that she had conspired to bomb two Los Angeles police cars in 1975, when she was associated with the radical Symbionese Liberation Army. But she then undercut the deal by announcing that she was innocent and had changed her plea only because, in the current crisis, anyone charged with terrorism could not receive a fair trial. Her reversal appeared to anger the judge, who said she would have to return to court and explain if her plea was still valid. James Sterngold

title: 'Coming Soon!!!'
description: READ ME

title: Under Suspicion
description: BY ORDER OF

title: Indian Point Power Plant Should Be Shut Down
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION & POETRY
description: THE BRIDGE

title: The Next Front: Our Driveways?
description: To the Editor:

title: The New York Times Top 50
description: The New York Times's computer football ranking is based on an analysis of each team's scores with emphasis on three factors: who won, by what margin and against what quality of opposition. The quality of an opponent is determined by examining its record against other teams.

title: A Costly Home Away From Home
description: WHEN Anders and Yvonne Iversen transferred to Larchmont from London last year, they were told they could spend up to $3,700 a month on rent, and the company would pick up 75 percent of the cost.

title: Television, Like the Country, Loses Its Footing
description: FIDDLE-DEE-DEE, war, war, war,'' Scarlett O'Hara said at the start of ''Gone with the Wind.'' ''I get so bored I could scream!''

title: INVESTING WITH/Clifford Greenberg; Baron Small Cap Fund
description: MANY investors in small-capitalization stocks look for rapidly growing technology and biotechnology companies. But not Clifford Greenberg, who runs the $600 million Baron Small Cap fund.

title: The Heroic Men
description: To the Editor:

title: China's Villagers Vote, but Its Party Rules
description: Ignoring a light drizzle, the people of Quanwang lined up on the grounds of a silk factory and, for the seventh time since 1987, elected their village director and governing committee.

title: Drugs Aside, Drugstores Feel the Pain Of Prudence
description: ON the face of it, the nation's big drugstore chains, which generate $180 billion in revenue, would seem to be immune to turns in the economy.

title: Revel With a Cause
description: Midway through the 1930's -- what Auden called that ''low dishonest decade,'' when the civilized world was working itself up yet again for one of its paroxysms of self-destruction -- the American food writer M.F.K. Fisher, then in her 20's, left her professor husband in Dijon, France, and the prospect of afternoons in a brown satin dress nibbling on marshmallow salad with other faculty wives, to pursue a relationship with a friend she had fallen head over heels in love with, an artist named Dillwyn Parrish.

title: Job Growth and Unemployment Tick Upward in Westchester
description: As layoffs continue around the nation, job growth in Westchester was measured at a record high for the month of September, according to the New York State Department of Labor, although the numbers don't reflect changes in the economy since Sept. 11. The department reported 419,300 jobs in Westchester currently, 4,700 more than in September 2000.

title: Don Bosco Tops St. Joseph With a Strong Second Half
description: Don Bosco Prep upset St. Joseph of Montvale, the No. 9 team in USA Today's national ranking, 28-7, Friday at Montvale, N.J. The victory came only six days after the Ironmen edged Bergen Catholic, 14-13, in Oradell. In two weeks, Don Bosco has won two road games against two of New Jersey's top teams.

title: Mussina Mastering New Pitch
description: Mike Mussina throws two types of curveballs that break downward, sometimes as slow as 70 to 72 miles an hour and sometimes as hard as 82 to 83 m.p.h. The Diamondbacks' hitters appeared to be very surprised in Game 5 when Mussina started throwing a pitch that broke straight down at 88 to 89 m.p.h.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the re-emergence of traditional notions of masculinity misstated the political stance of Camille Paglia, the social critic and professor of humanities at the University of the Arts in Philadelphia. She says she is a libertarian and an enrolled Democrat, not a conservative.

title: In Japan, Beef Business Sinks in a Sea of Skepticism
description: Across Japan this week, television stations ran advertisements saying beef was safe. Supermarkets posted red, white and blue signs inviting shoppers: ''Please have worry-free beef, American beef.'' McDonald's ran full-page newspaper advertisements, announcing: ''McDonald's uses only beef from Australia, where the mad cow disease does not exist.''

title: Got Time? Elaine Stritch Has a Few Things to Say
description: THERE just may be too much Elaine Stritch to squeeze into a two-hour revue. Distilling all the juice of her life into a standard-size container is, it seems, like trying to pour 10 gallons of fizzy water into a Dixie cup. What do you do with all that extra carbonation?

title: What's Changed, and What's Not, Around Town
description: Finding Bargains

title: Editors' Note; A Nation Challenged
description: News of the terrorist attacks and their aftermath appears today in Section B; index, Page B2.

title: Around the Island
description: Aeroflex (Nasdaq: ARXX) of Plainview said on Tuesday that it had received orders worth $5.4 million for its satellite instruments from two major satellite manufacturers, which it did not name. . . . Arrow Electronics (NYSE: ARW) of Melville reported a $14 million loss for the third quarter on sales of $2.2 billion. Last year during the same quarter, Arrow, an electronics distribution company, reported a profit of $101.9 million on sales of $3.3 billion. . . . On Oct. 24, 1-800-Flowers.com (Nasdaq: Flws) of Westbury reported a net loss of $8.9 million for the second quarter. Jim McCann, the company's chairman and chief executive, said that he was nevertheless ''very pleased'' with the results, which included increased Internet sales and a record second quarter revenue of $79.2 million. . . . The United Capital Corporation (Amex: Afp) of Great Neck said on Tuesday that its net income for the third quarter had risen to $5.2 million, or $1.11 a share, up from $4.7 million or 99 cents a share in the same period last year. The company owns and manages real estate and sells transformers and automotive products. Compiled by Warren Strugatch

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KOHN, LEONORE S.
description: KOHN-Leonore S. Precious Mom. Deeply missed. We celebrate your life Nov. 5, 1911-Nov 18, 1998. Love always, Barbara & Peter

title: Frank Craighead, 85, an Outdoorsman and a Protector of the Grizzly, Dies
description: Frank Craighead, who with his identical twin, John, performed a 12-year study of grizzly bears in and around Yellowstone National Park that was credited with helping save the species from extinction in the lower 48 states, died on Oct. 21 at a nursing home in Jackson, Wyo. He was 85.

title: Continuing Ed
description: A WOMAN'S EDUCATION

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEKER, SONIA
description: BEKER-Sonia. The staff and advisors of The Corinne Goldsmith Dickinson Center for Multiple Sclerosis at the Mount Sinai Medical Center extend their collective expressions of sympathy and condolences to the Beker and Grundman families on the loss of Sonia Beker. Harvey Beker is a respected friend, colleague, Board member and generous philanthropist to the Center. May the family be comforted by their loving memories. George J. Gillespie III Clifford H. Goldsmith Co-Founders Fred D. Lublin, M.D. Director

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION & POETRY
description: SMALL GODS OF GRIEF

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNGKEN, HEBER W., JR.
description: YOUNGKEN-Heber W., Jr., 88. An internationally known educator, researcher, and university administrator, died October 22 at his home in Peace Dale, RI. He was the son of noted pharmacognocist Heber Wilkinson Youngken and Clara Eastman Youngken. Youngken devoted his life's work to the field of pharmacognosy and natural products chemisty. He was the author and co-author of over 180 publications dealing with the sources, chemistry, and pharmacological characteristics of plants. He was the author of ''Pharmacognosy,'' J.B. Lippincott, PA, 1951, second ed. 1965, a textbook, (with R. Pratt), and ''Organic Chemistry in Pharmacy,'' J.B. Lippincott, PA, 1949 (with Wilson, et al), among other texts. His writings appeared in numerous national journals including the ''Journal of Natural Products'' and the ''Herbalist.'' He also contributed to research findings in the field of drugs derived from marine organisms. Youngken was the recipient of numerous awards, including the American Pharmaceutical Association Newcomb Award in Pharmacognosy, and achievement awards from the American Society of Pharmacognosy. Youngken served on review councils of the National Institutes of Health and the National Science Foundation, and was a principal researcher of numerous grants for studies in the field of natural products. He was a member of the revision committees of the ''United States Pharmacopeia'' and the ''National Formulary'', and frequent consultant to members of the drug industry on botanical drugs. Youngken came to Rhode Island in 1956 as the dean to establish, organize and develop the University of Rhode Island College of Pharmacy after 15 years in the pharmacy faculty at the University of Washington in Seattle. Under Youngken's leadership the URI pharmacy college grew in teaching, research, and service from 9 faculty and 135 students to 33 full term and 18 part time faculty with more than 600 undergraduate and graduate students at his retirement in 1981. Its faculty and graduates have gained worldwide recognition for excellence in pharmacy research and the related health sciences. He was a visiting professor at the University of London, 1970 and the University of Cairo, Egypt, 1977, '79, '81, and '85. Nationally prominent in pharmaceutical education and research, Youngken chaired or served on various committees representing the American Pharmaceutical Association (APhA), the American Association of Colleges of Pharmacy (AACP), the Academy of Pharmaceutical Sciences, the American Society of Pharmacognosy (former president), the Society of Economic Botany, and many others. In 1953 he published one of the first papers in the United States to promote the concept of clinical pharmacy and the student externship programs. In 1958, he founded the Pharmacy Clinic at URI for continuing pharmacy education, now dedicated in his name. In 1994, the medicinal plant garden at the University of Rhode Island was dedicated to Youngken. A new faculty chair at URI, known as the OmarYoungken Distinguished Chair in Natural Product Chemistry, was created in his honor in 2001. Youngken served in the US Navy during World War II in North Atlantic convoy escort duty, later achieving the rank of Captain in the US Navy Reserve. He held degrees from Bucknell University (AB), the Massachusetts College of Pharmacy (BS), and the University of Minnesota (MS, PhD). In 1982 he received an Honorary DSc from the University of Rhode Island. Youngken is survived by his wife Daphne Goodwin Youngken, two sons, John Ronald Youngken of New York City and Richard Charles Youngken of Wakefield, RI, and two granddaughters, Kelly Goodwin Youngken of Arlington, VA, and Abigail Bouldin Youngken of Greensboro, NC. A memorial service will be held at St. Augustine's Church in Kingston, RI at 3:00 P.M., Monday, November 19th.

title: . . . Or Not
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAHN, FRED I., M.D.
description: HAHN-Fred I., M.D. You challenged us to challenge ourselves to be the best that we could be. Your tutelage and wisdom will continue to be the wind beneath our wings. Your Forever Grateful Patients

title: A Pioneer Funeral Director Gets a Plot to Call His Own
description: Nearly 70 years after his death, Frank E. Campbell, whose namesake Manhattan funeral home served the famous and revolutionized the industry, can finally rest in peace himself.

title: Oct. 28-Nov. 3; Energy Giant Suddenly Flailing
description: Can Enron survive? The comany, the nation's largest energy trader and a major backer of President Bush, has been pummeled by a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation and an unusual $1.2 billion reduction in shareholder equity from deals with partnerships involving its former chief financial officer. Based in Houston, Enron used to be considered all-powerful in natural gas and electricity trading, but now investors are waiting to see whether it can retain its investment-grade credit rating. If it doesn't, other traders may refuse to do business with it and lenders may demand immediate repayment -- putting Enron's existence in jeopardy.

title: Fewer Guests At His Table
description: WITH crime in Suffolk County at a 30-year low and the conviction rate for the district attorney's office hovering around 97 percent, the re-election bid of James M. Catterson Jr. this year should have been a relatively easy one.

title: Ways, New and Old, To Protect Food
description: Concerns about germs have driven companies to add antibacterial agents to products like cleansers and soaps. But new fronts in the war on bacteria have opened in the weeks after Sept. 11. Some government officials have warned that the food supply is vulnerable to bioterrorist attack; in particular, scientists have said fresh produce could be contaminated with salmonella or E. coli.

title: On Tuesday, DiFrancesco May Be the Real Winner
description: ''It's not there,'' an anonymous member of Bret D. Schundler's staff told The Washington Post last week.

title: Travel Advisory: Correspondent's Report; Washington Makes A Patriotic Pitch
description: FIRST there was the terrorist strike on the Pentagon. Then there was the anthrax attack on the Senate. Threats of new terrorism mean that tours of the White House and the F.B.I. have been shut down indefinitely. The city's close-in airport, Reagan National, has only limited operations.

title: Rumsfeld Visits Russia and Central Asia to Bolster Coalition
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld, beginning a whirlwind trip through Russia and Central Asia, met President Vladimir V. Putin in the Kremlin today for what both sides indicated was a productive discussion of arms control and the war against terrorism.

title: Plan A Is Schilling. There Is No Plan B.
description: PHOENIX, Nov. 3  The Curt Schilling saga has spun through the World Series, making Arizona Diamondbacks Manager Bob Brenly almost as uncomfortable as Yankees batters.

title: Womraths, The Final Chapter
description: Womraths was never a superstore. A good independent bookstore, perhaps. But no more.

title: Love in the 21st Century
description: As a young woman of 17, I eagerly read your couples issue from cover to cover. It was intriguing and offered many ideas about love today. There were articles on love and relationships about 30-something singles who identify with ''tribes,'' children who ''married'' at 5 and Hy Kaplan, who keeps on dancing at 93. But I noticed an important omission: teenagers.

title: Basque Rebels Start to Look A Little Bit Out of Date
description: Smoke rising from an underground parking lot in central Madrid one month after the Sept. 11 attacks in the United States signaled defiance in the war against terrorism from the Basque separatist group E.T.A.

title: The Owner Who Overpaid for Rodriguez Irks His Peers Once More
description: Borrowing from ''The Ugly American'' of several decades past, Tom Hicks is becoming the Ugly Texan to other baseball people.

title: Against the Tide, Two Movies Go to War
description: IN the chaotic first days after Sept. 11, Hollywood pushed back the release of movies with extreme violence and suddenly inappropriate plot lines, such as ''Collateral Damage'' with Arnold Schwarzenegger, about a terrorist attack.

title: It's Not Silly Season? Just Read This
description: IS it just me, or has the Garden State somehow crossed over into its own private Twilight Zone? Suddenly we seem to have gone from being just occasionally weird to being everyday weird. Maybe the now-fading aura of Halloween week has something to do with it, but I suspect it's more than that. I suspect that strangeness is the new status quo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLACK, JAMES GORDON
description: BLACK-James Gordon. Of New York City passed away at his home on October 31, 2001. He attended the Rectory School and Phillips Academy, Andover. He was a lieutenant and pilot instructor in the U.S. Navy during WWII and then was associated with Air France for many years. A devoted Board member of the New England Society in the City of New York, he was also a member of the Racquet & Tennis Club, Devon Yacht Club, Military Order of Foreign Wars, Naval Order of the U.S., and the Sons of the American Revolution. He was the son of the late Marion Clausen Black and the late Witherbee Black, and the brother of the late Beatrice Bremer. He is survived by a brother, Witherbee Black Jr, of Johns Island, FL, a sister, Barbara Ware, of Shelburne, VT, five nieces and many other family members and friends.

title: Exploring Around The Edges
description: I DIDN'T intend it to be so metaphorical. But in the middle of planning a day that would teach me something about the city where I have lived the last 10 years, I looked over my itinerary and realized something: I had accidentally planned a back-to-school day.

title: A War? A Rich Candidate? History Repeats Itself
description: A wealthy businessman, unseasoned in politics, runs for mayor of New York. A candidate declares that, had he been mayor at the time of the city's devastation, he would have done a better job than the current officeholder. As crisis envelops the nation, the sitting mayor of New York attempts to change basic rules of governance.

title: Making a Career With One Eye on a Gender Gap
description: WHEN I feel scared that my voice is not meant to be heard, it doesn't come out so smoothly,'' said the choreographer Ellis Wood, 36, on a bright October day in an empty cafe in Little Italy. ''But I have an intense need to speak.''

title: Completely Overwhelmed, Yankees Now Turn to Clemens
description: PHOENIX, Nov. 3  The Yankees established their unorthodox strategy in Games 4 and 5 of the World Series, waiting until the last out of the ninth inning before mounting memorable comebacks. When the ninth inning of Game 6 rolled around tonight, finally, their task was a bit more daunting. They needed 13 runs to tie.

title: F.Y.I.
description: An Accident, Maybe

title: Fear of a 'Dark Winter,' Talk of Ground Troops and an Idle Alliance
description: As worrisome as anthrax is, the government has begun preparing for a possible bioterrorism threat that is even worse. Remember smallpox? More than likely, you don't. It was eradicated 21 years ago. The United States stopped immunizing people against it in 1972. But that does not mean the disease went away.

title: Cosmic Stuff
description: THE UNIVERSE AT MIDNIGHT

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, ABRAHAM
description: WEISS-Abraham. On November 1, 2001. Beloved husband of Ruth. Loving father of Wendy Greenberg and Debra Weinberg. Dear father-in-law of Joel Greenberg and Laurence Weinberg. Devoted brother of Lillian Aronson. Adoring grandfather of Victoria and Barry, Andrew and Sarah. Greatgrandfather of Daphne. Service Monday, 11:15AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: An Old-Time Melody With a New Twist
description: A 14-year-old girl with talent to spare dreams of becoming a singer, only to discover that her disapproving mother was - news flash! - once teenage singing sensation herself. That's the premise behind ''The Wilde Girls,'' a Showtime movie that has its premiere tonight at 8. And for the movie's stars, Olivia Newton-John and her 15-year-old daughter, Chloe Rose, the story has a special resonance - but not in the way viewers might imagine.

title: U.S. Team Wins Top World Bridge Title
description: An American team won the world bridge championship here this afternoon, defeating Norway in an exciting final of the Bermuda Bowl for open teams.

title: Q and A
description: Mont Blanc Tunnel

title: In Miami, Candidates Promise What They Won't Do
description: A striking aspect of the race for mayor of Miami is how much time the candidates spend promising what they will not do.

title: Truly Tragic Writers
description: To the Editor:

title: Travel Advisory; A Modern Copy Of Ancient Masters
description: In 1879, 8-year-old Mara Justina Sanz de Sautuola was searching a cave with her father for prehistoric relics when the lamplight picked out images of horned animals on the cavern ceiling. They had discovered what came to be called the Sistine Chapel of Paleolithic art.

title: Hijackers' Meticulous Strategy Of Brains, Muscle and Practice
description: American Airlines Flight 11 was in line for takeoff from Logan International Airport, the passengers already reminded to turn off personal electronic devices, when Mohamed Atta, in seat 8D in business class, dialed his cellphone for the last time.

title: Love in the 21st Century
description: Your issues of Sept. 23 and Oct. 7, following the World Trade Center massacre, made me proud to subscribe to your publication. Your Oct. 14 issue, on the other hand, demonstrates why so many societies hate America.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: AN UNEXPECTED LIGHT: Travels in Afghanistan, by Jason Elliot. (Picador USA, $18.) The author journeyed to the remotest reaches of a remote country just before the Taliban takeover, and his account blends history with intrepid travel writing in describing the nation's striking contrasts, its people's suffering and its collapse under the weight of civil war. ''His experience of ordinary Afghans' cheerfulness, humor and graciousness in the midst of loss and desolation'' seems ''heartbreakingly apt,'' Jason Goodwin said here last April. '' 'An Unexpected Light' is often unexpectedly funny and constantly perceptive, but it is also profound.''

title: Oct. 28-Nov. 3; Marijuana Crackdown
description: Through raids on a cannabis club, a doctor's office and a patient-run marijuana garden, the Bush administration has begun its first major crackdown on the distribution of marijuana for medical purposes. The rush of enforcement, three years after the last federal raid of a California medical marijuana cooperative, marks the Justice Department's renewed attempt to impose federal drug laws in states that have legalized the drug's use for the sick and dying. The administration says it is enforcing a May Supreme Court ruling that there is no ''medical necessity'' exception to the federal marijuana laws. Greg Winter

title: Completely Overwhelmed, Yanks Turn to Clemens
description: The Yankees established their unorthodox strategy in Games 4 and 5 of the World Series, waiting until the last out of the ninth inning before mounting memorable comebacks. When the ninth inning of Game 6 rolled around tonight, finally, their task was a bit more daunting. They needed 13 runs to tie.

title: Tszyu Stuns Judah in Controversial Finish
description: In a swift, stunning and certainly controversial upset, Kostya Tszyu knocked out Zab Judah of Brooklyn with a second to go in the second round to capture the undisputed 140-pound crown at the MGM Grand Hotel.

title: After Trade Center Scuffle, Charges Are Dropped or Reduced
description: Charges against a dozen firefighters arrested in a scuffle with police officers during a protest at the World Trade Center disaster site were dropped or reduced yesterday, but the anger that led to the confrontation lingered in firehouses across the city and there were warnings of more trouble to come.

title: On the Airwaves In Afghanistan
description: To the Editor:

title: Footlights; A World Premiere
description: Michelle Ekizian is a Mamaroneck composer who has been awarded both a Guggenheim Fellowship and the Prix de Rome. Most of her large-scale works reflect her Armenian heritage. On Saturday at 8 p.m., Ms. Ekizian's new work, ''Cantata No. 1: A Saint Gregory Moment,'' will have its world premiere at a free performance by the Brooklyn Philharmonic at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in Manhattan.

title: Runners Put Fears Aside In Support Of New York
description: For today's 32nd annual New York City Marathon, the organizers accepted 34,000 to 35,000 entries. They said the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11 led to few dropouts.

title: The Uncomfortable question of Anti-Semitism
description: When I was growing up, my father would go to bed with a transistor radio set to an all-news station. Even without a radio, my father was attuned to the menace of history. A Jew born in Vienna in 1924, he fled his homeland in 1938; his parents were killed in the Holocaust. I sometimes imagined my father was listening for some repetition of past evils so that he could rectify old responses, but he may just have been expecting more bad news. In any event, the grumbling static from the bedroom depressed me, and I vowed to replace it with music more cheerfully in tune with America. These days, however, I find myself on my father's frequency. I have awakened to anti-Semitism.

title: Reckonings; Making Windows Transparent
description: Anyone who has spent time trying to make sense of the Microsoft issue realizes that this is one case in which the clich is true: there are no good answers, and all one can do is try to choose the lesser of several evils. I like the apparent settlement reached last week better than I liked the solution that Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson tried to impose last year, but I would be the first to admit that this answer has its own problems.

title: Science and Mining
description: To the Editor:

title: Deep-Running Similarities Link New York's Mayoral Rivals
description: Mark Green and Michael R. Bloomberg say they would be very different mayors at an enormously important time for New York City, when an economic downturn, the aftermath of the terror attacks and considerable shortcomings with the schools seem to demand exceptional qualities in the city's next leader.

title: Disputes Erupt on Ridge's Needs for His Job
description: Not since the Second World War has anyone been given such enormous responsibility to protect the nation's homeland security as Tom Ridge. Yet day after day, Mr. Ridge, the strapping former governor of Pennsylvania, does something unheard of in Washington: he begs Congress not to give him more power or more money.

title: Alicia Cheng, Michael Rubens
description: Alicia Yin Cheng, a daughter of Mignonette and Richard Cheng of Ann Arbor, Mich., was married yesterday to Michael Stewart Rubens, the son of Donna Rubens of Manhattan and Dr. Alan Rubens of Tucson. Roy D. Phillips, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated at Hacienda del Sol, a Tucson resort.

title: Robin Johnston, Adam Tweedy
description: Robin Elizabeth Johnston, a daughter of Patricia Starr Johnston of San Francisco and the late Kenneth S. Johnston, was married yesterday to Adam Bridgeman Tweedy, the son of Wendy and Jeffrey Clarke Tweedy of Bedford, N.Y. The Rev. Mary Lou Cook, a nondenominational minister, officated at La Postada de Santa Fe, a resort and spa in Santa Fe, N.M.

title: Map of Love
description: AGAINST LOVE POETRY

title: Love in the 21st Century
description: I was looking for an uplifting message about American couples, particularly in the face of our nation's recent tragedy. I ended up angry at your choices. A middle-aged couple who survive only through the benefit of prescription drugs? A lesbian and transsexual with relationship complications worthy of a soap opera?

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION & POETRY
description: BLACK HOUSE

title: Valerie Hillings, William Scheessele
description: Valerie Lynn Hillings, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. E. Joseph Hillings of Alexandria, Va., was married yesterday to William John Scheessele, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Scheessele of Charlotte, N.C. The Rev. Joseph Vetter, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Duke University Chapel in Durham, N.C.

title: Field Trips Are Another Casualty of Attacks
description: THIS was the year that 14 students at Litchfield High School were especially excited about. It was suppose to be their turn to go to Spain for the first time as part of a foreign exchange program. But while the band and chorus may still go to Montreal, the Spain journey is far less certain. The Sept. 11 terrorist attacks are the reason why.

title: Love in the Time Of Coloring
description: Deirdre Dolan's article about young Sean Leo and Sarah Cohen-Smith has a charming quality of innocence about it. One aspect, however, was disturbing. If a camp throws a prom for teenage campers, that is one thing. But for 9-year-olds?

title: Teaching to the Test
description: To the Editor:

title: Peruvian Leader's Image Problems Add to Political Woes
description: Peruvians, who are not known for their punctuality, have a new explanation for their tardiness. When late for an appointment, they now typically say they are on ''Toledo Time'' or ''Cabana Time'' a reference to the town where President Alejandro Toledo grew up.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the election campaign for district attorney in Westchester referred incorrectly to the position held by Tony Castro, the Democratic candidate. He is no longer an assistant district attorney in the Bronx. He resigned on June 8.

title: Somali Leader Makes a Plea For America To Re-engage
description: The president of Somalia's transitional government says he understands why his country is getting the cold shoulder from the United States. His anarchic homeland is still overrun with well-armed warlords, just as it was when 18 American soldiers perished on the streets of Mogadishu, the capital, eight years ago.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 21 about the play ''Wonder of the World'' at the Manhattan Theater Club, starring Sarah Jessica Parker, referred incorrectly to her most recent stage appearance. She has indeed appeared onstage since the 1995 ''Sylvia'' -- in ''How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying'' and ''Once Upon a Mattress,'' both in 1996.

title: What to Tell a Child; Taking Account Of a 'Hidden Life'
description: To the Editor:

title: Travel Advisory; Holiday Weekend Is Parks' Open House
description: No admission fees will be charged for entrance to the parks, monuments and memorials of the National Park Service over Veterans Day weekend, Nov. 10 to 12, in an effort by the Department of the Interior, which administers the National Park Service, to promote national unity, hope and healing.

title: Political Briefing; Baltimore Mayor Bucks the Trend
description: For almost two years, most talk about the 2002 governor's race in Maryland has centered on Lt. Gov. Kathleen Kennedy Townsend.

title: Christina Orwicz, Michael Gantcher
description: Christina Elizabeth Orwicz, the daughter of Maria and Zbigniew Orwicz of New York, was married last evening to Michael Jeffrey Gantcher, a son of Alice and Nathan Gantcher of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Richard Jacobs officiated at the Pierre in New York.

title: What to Tell a Child; Another View On a Museum's Expansion
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAWITZKY, SHERRY
description: KAWITZKY-Sherry. On October 31, 2001. Her heartbroken husband Ronald, her children Simon and Deanna and her sister Karen Bressler mourn her untimely passing after a long illness. Our doer, our provider, our comforter is no more. We will never understand why. Only our love for her, and hers for us, can sustain us. Rest in peace our darling. Service Sunday, 11:45AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about a sense of quiet in New York museums and other public places misstated the location of the Museum of Jewish Heritage. It is at 18 First Place in Battery Park City, not 1 Battery Park Plaza.

title: Frugal Gourmet; Digesting Guangzhou In Bite-Size Pieces
description: ON the train from Hong Kong to Guangzhou, China, I daydreamed of dumplings. Fat, puffy ones, baseball-size, stuffed with tangy minced pork. Glossy transparent Ping-Pong balls filled with crunchy water chestnuts and peanuts. Bite-size mouthfuls of shrimp, squid and chicken wrapped in thin rice dough.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, WILLIAM
description: FRIEDMAN-William. On October 27, 2001. Loving husband of Diana; beloved father of Peter and Beth Friedman; devoted grandfather to Rebecca Sarah and Adam Isaac Friedman. Services were held on Tuesday, October 30, 2001, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, New York City.

title: Not Much in Common Except Beautiful Music
description: THE world of jazz has seen its share of unlikely partnerships, both professional and personal. Rarely, though, has there been one quite so improbable as the brief collaboration between Billie Holiday and Artie Shaw, who worked together for eight eventful months in 1938.

title: A Winning Wine List
description: For the 20th straight year, the wine list at the American Hotel in Sag Harbor has been cited by Wine Spectator as one of the world's great wine lists.

title: Rebecca Odes and Craig Kanarick
description: ''SHE swirled into class late, like a tornado, with a whirlwind of hair flying, and my impression was 'Wow, this woman is completely interesting,' '' said Craig Kanarick, recalling his first encounter with Rebecca Odes, then a student in his New York University course on interaction design in 1996.

title: Kenny and Whitman, Together Again
description: The Environmental Protection Agency is beginning to look a little like Trenton South.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Page 36 of The Times Magazine today about the prospects for New York City under its next mayor includes an outdated reference to pre-election polls. In a survey completed by The Times on Thursday, after the magazine had gone to press, Michael Bloomberg, who trailed Mark Green considerably in previous polls, closed the gap to five percentage points.

title: Secret C.I.A. Site in New York Was Destroyed on Sept. 11
description: The Central Intelligence Agency's clandestine New York station was destroyed in the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center, seriously disrupting United States intelligence operations while bringing the war on terrorism dangerously close to home for America's spy agency, government officials say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEHRU, BRAI KUMAR
description: NEHRU-Brai Kumar. Died on October 31st in Kasauli, India. Farewell to our beloved Bijju, you will be with us forever. Deepest sympathy to Fori and all our Indian family. Jimmy and Henry

title: These Boots Were Made for Flaunting
description: REMEMBER Frye boots? I got to thinking about how badly I wanted a pair when I was in high school. They had to be a specific clunky style that everyone else had. And they had to be the exact shade of buttery tan that everyone else chose, the color that contrasted perfectly with faded bell-bottom jeans.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the history of patriotic art referred incorrectly to the origin of the famous photograph of the raising of an American flag over Iwo Jima. The photographer recorded the raising of a second, larger flag to replace one raised at the same spot earlier that day, Feb. 23, 1945; the photograph was not staged. The article also misstated the number of servicemen in the picture; there were five marines and a Navy medical corpsman; two men were mostly obscured.

title: BackTalk; Today's Marathon Is About Survival
description: The New York City Marathon has always mirrored the mood and spirit of the city. Today's race will be no exception.

title: Easy Part Of Season Is Over For Miami
description: So much for the honeymoon. After feasting on Rutgers, Troy State, West Virginia and Temple, the Miami Hurricanes are rolling up their sleeves for heavy lifting.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-4-01: Portfolio; The Floating World
description: The fighter pilots on an aircraft carrier get the air time, but they're just a few of the thousands of Navy personnel who make the ship a self-contained city. The U.S.S. Carl Vinson -- one of the world's largest mobile manmade structures, now positioned near Pakistan in the Arabian Sea -- is typically home to a crew of more than 5,000 men and women and more than 70 aircraft (F-14 Tomcats, F/A-18 Hornets, EA-6B Prowlers, SH-60 Seahawks and others). These are a few of the groups that keep the ship running.

title: OPINION; Baby Boomers Betray Old Ideals
description: OPEN spaces and seemingly untouched land are priceless treasures that could very soon become a fond memory. The current pace of voracious development on Long Island is erasing both the land and water that not only enhance our life, but are essential to it. Unfortunately, for many, they won't be missed until they are completely vanished.

title: Afghan Rebels Seem a Reluctant Force So Far
description: The rain was pouring, the mud was ankle-deep, and the first of winter was biting the air. At the rebels' training and supply post here, it was a little too much for the soldiers to bear.

title: Our Towns; A Nassau Republican Follows Marx (the One With the Cigar)
description: LIKE Groucho Marx, Thomas Gulotta, the Nassau County executive, must be going. Mr. Gulotta, a Republican, is the top elected official in this Long Island suburb, home to the nation's oldest, most powerful Republican machine, but if he doesn't go soon, there may be few Republicans left here. Like Groucho, who could take dear old Huxley College and blissfully destroy it, Mr. Gulotta ran a wealthy county in a time of unprecedented prosperity and oversaw its near fiscal ruin, and now, his fellow Republicans say, he must be going.

title: Calcavecchia Battling to Overcome Heel Pain
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 3 — In his first eight tournaments this year, Mark Calcavecchia was playing as well as any golfer in the world, with four top- four finishes and a victory at the Phoenix Open. In 14 tournaments since mid-April, however, Calcavecchia has just one top-10 finish, and he has missed the cut five times.

title: Haute Cuisine
description: When you move from just sharing cubicle space to sharing meals, work becomes your home away from home. Designers are no different, except instead of having late-night pizza deliveries, many of them have in-house chefs. And the food that's prepared is just another way to communicate their taste -- albeit on a gut level. In fact, what's on the table is as much an indicator of the company culture as the clothes they put on customers' backs. Here, some of the favorite dishes of the most opinionated taste makers in fashion.

title: Oct. 28-Nov. 3; Burundi Grasps at Peace
description: The long-awaited installation of a power-sharing government in Burundi only illustrated the hurdles still facing the small central African nation, where civil war has killed an estimated 200,000 people over the better part of a decade. Moderate factions from the majority Hutu ethnic group agreed to the three-year transition government, but the main Hutu guerrilla forces have not. The pact was brokered by Nelson Mandela, former president of South Africa, which has sent hundreds of troops to guard Hutu leaders returning from exile.

title: PART-TIME PROFESSORS PROTEST
description: A group of adjunct and part-time college professors rallied this week on the steps of the State House for better pay and working conditions. The rally was held as part of Campus Equity Week a nationwide campaign organized by unions and higher education groups. According to a report released last year by the state Commission on Higher Learning, roughly half of the state's 17,800 public college teachers work part-time. The average salary for full-time professors in New Jersey last year was $96,428 while part-timers earned up to $2,500 per three-credit course, the report said. John Holl

title: A Theater Troupe That Gets Inspiration Through Religion
description: AT 8 on a recent Monday evening, the storefronts of the few businesses -- a video store, laundromat, post office -- in the Oakdale Gardens Mall on Oakdale-Bohemia Road here were dark. But a light shone in the lobby of the Creative Ministries Performing Arts Center. Inside, more than two dozen performers were deep in rehearsal for the group's productions this month of ''Crazy For You'' and ''Winnie the Pooh.''

title: Giuliani Is the Leader Of a Special Fan Club
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani led a group of 25 family members of victims of the Sept. 11 attacks to see the end of the World Series. Giuliani and the families flew a donated Continental charter flight from La Guardia Airport to Phoenix. Giuliani sat in a field box at Bank One Ballpark and the families were guests of Major League Baseball in its hospitality suite.

title: The Spy Puzzle
description: Much is expected of the Central Intelligence Agency these days, probably too much. As a pivotal front-line organization in the war against terrorism, the agency is supposed to detect and prevent new terror attacks, help locate and perhaps even kill Osama bin Laden and let President Bush know if the anthrax in the mail comes from Iraq -- to mention only a few of Washington's expectations. These are lofty demands to make of an institution that before Sept. 11 was still struggling to reinvent itself a decade after the end of the cold war. As much as the nation may yearn for a crack intelligence service that can save the day, there is no such outfit in Washington at present.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRUG, JACK
description: KRUG-Jack. Age 80, died October 27, 2001, in Seattle, WA. He filled the roles in a man's life. Son, brother, friend, WWII bombardier with General Chennault, husband, father, uncle, grandfather, greatgrandfather. The interment is at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ, Sunday, November 4, 2001. Love and Memories, Thelma and Louis Wexler Sally and Murray Krug Helen Welsch Carol and Lawrence Krug

title: Over the Volcano
description: UNCLE TUNGSTEN

title: Word for Word/Sept. 11 Seminars; Academe on War: Man (and Woman) The Psychobabble Detectors!
description: AMERICA is at war, and following suit, the nation's professoriate is rapidly deploying courses. Notably, the University of California at Los Angeles has just launched 49 undergraduate seminars across a range of disciplines to address ''the innumerable issues arising out of the events of Sept. 11.'' The courses include ''Navigating Between Blithesome Optimism and Cultural Despair'' and ''Implications of World Crises for Student Stress and Academic Achievement: Coping Strategies.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Page 42 of The Times Magazine today about ''The Simpsons'' misspells the surname of the actor who provides the voice for Homer Simpson. He is Dan Castellaneta, not Castellenata. A picture caption about the show's creative team omits the member standing leftmost in the back row. He is Mike Scully, a producer-writer.

title: Renchburg's the One!
description: THE REHNQUIST CHOICE

title: On Once-Bawdy 42nd Street, The Last Dirty Picture Show
description: Perhaps Peep-O-Rama, at 121 West 42nd Street near Avenue of the Americas, never meant to make history. Awkwardly sandwiched between a Tad's Broiled Steaks and a Touch of New York souvenir shop, its neon red-and-black marquee is kept unlighted, day and night. Inside, the workers behind the counter are polite but reticent.

title: Big Is Beautiful, O'Neal Has Decided
description: The season is less than a week old and already the whispers have begun about his considerable girth. How heavy is Shaquille O'Neal, and didn't the Los Angeles Lakers center say he was going to report to camp this season much leaner and lighter?

title: In Brief Talk, Arafat and Peres Discuss Their Cease-Fire
description: Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, and Foreign Minister Shimon Peres of Israel had their much vaunted meeting today, however brief, discussing how to widen their corroded cease-fire and to restart political negotiations.

title: English Lessons
description: OLD MEN AT MIDNIGHT

title: U.S. Special Forces Soldier Is Rescued From Afghanistan
description: A member of an American Special Operations team suffering high-altitude sickness was evacuated from Afghanistan in an emergency rescue operation, military officials said early today.

title: Oct. 28-Nov. 3; A Crisis in Georgia
description: As Mikhail Gorbachev's foreign minister at the fall of the Soviet Union, Eduard Shevardnadze helped preside over one of the world's most peaceful revolutions. Since taking over the tiny ex-Soviet state of Georgia from an ousted president in 1992, he has lost its western flank to separatists, failed to thaw frozen ties to Russia and presided over a thoroughly corrupt, somnolent economy. When federal security police raided a television station that is his severest critic, ostensibly looking for fiscal misdeeds, thousands of Georgians jammed streets to demand his resignation. Instead, he fired his government. Michael Wines

title: The Sac Comes Back
description: In with the old, out with the new. This month, two icons in pocketbook history are being revived from a time before baguettes and bowling bags were even a glint in a fashion victim's eye. Coach is reissuing its popular Duffle Sac (above), the large, slouchy leather bag seen on the shoulder of many a Cond Nast editor in the 70's and 80's. In calf, suede or jacquard, it comes in red, camel, black and blond, with the trademark barrel bottom, thick adjustable shoulder strap and bridle buckles ($228 to $298, depending on size and material, at Coach stores).

title: Investing; Learning to Love Fannie and Freddie
description: MAE WEST undoubtedly had something other than the stock market in mind when she declared that ''too much of a good thing can be wonderful.'' But it is a sentiment that pretty much describes the way Wall Street's security analysts now appraise Fannie Mae, the giant mortgage company.

title: Looking for a Way Home for the Holidays
description: AS a convert to Hinduism, Douglas Brooks normally regards the holiday season skeptically, as a curious and overly commercial artifact of American life. This year, however, he feels the need to mark the end of the year meaningfully. So Mr. Brooks, a professor of religion at the University of Rochester, has created his own ritual.

title: Rumbles Of Warning As Housing Weakens
description: THE already sinking American economy is developing a new leak.

title: Julia Scharankov, Edward Russell
description: Julia Diane Scharankov, a daughter of Ruth and Roman Scharankov of River Edge, N.J., was married yesterday to Edward Garrett Russell, the son of Josephine and Edward Russell of Crosspatrick, Ireland. The Rev. Ronald Franco performed the ceremony at St. Paul the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: Slide, Jeremy, Slide
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An answer in the Q. & A. column last Sunday about ''no pet'' clauses in co-op leases reversed the references to actions that must be taken against violators within 90 days in the boroughs. It is in Manhattan and the Bronx that both a notice of termination of the proprietary lease and eviction papers must be served; in Queens, Brooklyn and Staten Island, only the notice of termination is required.

title: Your Ad Here
description: THE BULGARI CONNECTION

title: Yanks Seem to Capture the Magic in a Moment
description: PHOENIX -- This is what the Yankees do to teams during the postseason, frustrate them, antagonize them and, always it seems, defeat them. This is what the Yankees do to opposing fans, too, forcing them to watch every out of every game, regardless of what the score is, with a sense of fear. What are the Yankees going to do next?

title: Control of the State Senate Hinges on a Handful of Races
description: The campaign between James E. McGreevey and Bret D. Schundler is no longer the most interesting governor's race in New Jersey.

title: Cultural Evolution
description: RED DUST

title: Corrections
description: A listing of Enron Corporation board members last Sunday with an article about the company's financial problems misstated the directors' role in dealing with them. An Enron spokesman said that he was ''unaware'' of any actions by the board, not they had taken none.

title: Hogwarts, Middle Earth And Other Getaway Spots
description: HOLLYWOOD would love to know what America wants to see at the movies this holiday season. (If only we knew ourselves.) Some big films have been moved to 2002, in hopes that times will be better or, as we say wistfully every day, ''back to normal.'' A few serious, possibly Oscar-worthy pictures will open over the next two months, but the sure thing this season is fantasy. Thank God for Harry Potter and hobbits and time travel and terrifying stories set in a distant future that has nothing to do with us.

title: Who Are Terrorists?
description: To the Editor:

title: Music Listings
description: Opera

title: Staci Perlmutter, Steven Marlowe
description: Staci Dana Perlmutter, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Perlmutter of Toms River, N.J., is to be married this afternoon to Steven Richard Marlowe, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward Marlowe of Short Hills, N.J. Rabbi Richard Hammerman is to officiate at the Tribeca Rooftop in New York.

title: As Movies Began to Talk, The Effect Was Visible
description: IN Fritz Lang's film ''Spies,'' one of the last great silent films, there is a droll sequence in which the hero (Willy Fritsch) visits the apartment of the heroine (Gerda Maurus) and, sitting down opposite her, tenderly takes her hands in his. It is afternoon. Their acquaintance dates back only to the previous night, when she ran into and then out of his life after firing a gunshot at his next-door neighbor.
