Somehow Mr. Fritsch has found Ms. Maurus again, and he doesn't want to let go. And he doesn't.

title: To Protect Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAMBARDELLA, ELIZABETH B. (NEE CORR)
description: GAMBARDELLA - Elizabeth B. (nee Corr). Of New York City and Brant Beach, NJ, on November 2, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Anthony P. Gambardella. Loving mother of Angela Lisciotto and Nikles Gambardella. Dear niece of the late Martha and Nikles Tsikourias. Also surviving are four grandchildren. She was an entrepreneur for many years in the gourmet food promotions industry known throughout Manhattan. A Mass of Christian Burial will take place on Tuesday at 9:30 A.M. in St. Michael R.C. Church, Cranford, NJ. Visitation will be on Monday from 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. in the Dooley Funeral Home, 218 North Avenue, Cranford, NJ. In lieu of flowers contributions to either Susan Komen Breast Cancer Foundation or to the Cabrini Hospice in the memory of Anthony P. Gambardella would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERMAN, CLARA
description: SILVERMAN-Clara. Clara Cohen Silverman, age 89, of Slingerlands, NY, died Monday, October 29, 2001. Mrs. Silverman was born in New York City and had resided in the Albany area for the last few years. She resided most of her life in metropolitan NY. She was a graduate of Hunter College in New York City. She had been employed as a school teacher in the New York City school district for many years. She taught gifted children and had a great impact on many of her students. She was proud to be teaching French to one of her companions at age 89. She was also a member of the Mensa Society. She was married to Benjamin Silverman until his passing in 1967. She is survived by her loving daughter, Marilyn Gordon, and her husband Steve of Slingerlands, loving grandmother of Barrie Jason Roer, sister of Bernard Cohen of North Miami, FL, and aunt to Marsha, Susan and Franye. Services were held at Congregation Ohav Sholom in Albany.

title: Oct. 28-Nov. 3; Massacre in Nigeria
description: Soldiers went on a three-day rampage in central Nigeria; it was the worst abuse by the military since the country, Africa's most populous, ended nearly 16 years of military rule in 1999. Apparently retaliating for the killing of 19 soldiers, hundreds of soldiers killed at least 500 civilians and destroyed countless buildings and houses in 16 towns and villages in the rural state of Benue. President Olusegun Obasanjo said the soldiers had acted in self-defense, leading many to question his control over the army.

title: FOLLOWING UP
description: After Losing His Wife, He Won a Drug Battle

title: Whistle While You Work and Other Disneyana
description: ON Oct. 26, the Sheraton Long Island became the happiest place on earth, at least for 300 people for about six hours. These folks, who had paid as much as $200 each to the Hauppauge Industrial Association to learn how to do business a little more like the Walt Disney Company, paused at a registration desk as a woman sporting mouse ears signed them in. Then they sat down to hear Joseph F. Gardner talk about what he called ''the Disney magic.''

title: Raises for Public Servants
description: To the Editor:

title: Oct. 28-Nov. 3; Recession: Almost Official
description: The Commerce Department reported that the economy shrank at an annual rate of 0.4 percent in the third quarter. It was the first decline in eight years, and for many analysts, confirmed that the economy was in recession. The most popular definition of recession, however, requires a contraction for two straight quarters -- a standard that cannot be met until the year's end. So this might be the best way to think about it: by the time the downturn officially becomes a recession, optimistic analysts say, it may already be over. David Leonhardt

title: A New Yorker From Adelaide
description: AFTER watching an advance videotape of ''Lantana,'' an Australian mystery due out on Dec. 14, my companion said of Anthony LaPaglia, who plays the movie's central character, ''He had a good Australian accent.''

title: Private Sector; For a Hardened Lawyer, A Tender Personal Moment
description: David Boies, the master litigator who helped the government battle Microsoft and seems to be a fixture in every big legal battle these days, is rarely at a loss for words. But he choked up twice and was forced to pause during an emotional acceptance speech last week in Manhattan.

title: GOING OUT
description: An guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEGRO, ADRIANA
description: LEGRO-Adriana. In loving memory of Adriana, her family will hold a memorial service Saturday, November 10th at 1:30 at The Church of Blessed Sacrament, 152 West 71 St., New York, New York.

title: 'The Kennedy Men, 1901-1963'
description: Twelve-year-old Joseph Patrick Kennedy may have been dressed like a young gentleman, but he walked with the bold strut of an Irish tough full of the lore of the streets. As he hurried down Webster Street, his blue eyes exuded a hungry intensity for whatever life might offer. He was taller than most boys his age and had reddish hair and an abruptness to his features that left him just short of handsome. His strong, willful face had already lost whatever boyish innocence it once held.

title: A Varied Menu, Pork Chops a Specialty
description: AFTER a day of shop-hopping through Litchfield, we found ourselves at dinner time in New Milford at Kaleidoscope, a smart new restaurant nestled into a hillside locale across from the train station.

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of Thursday, 4,651 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11.

title: Weight Watchers Expands Its Stock Offering
description: Weight Watchers International of Woodbury announced on Monday that it would expand its public offering by including the shares owned by its largest shareholder, increasing to $400 million the amount the public offering is expected to raise.

title: The Agony and the Comedy of Three Men in a Trench
description: WHEN war broke out between Serbs and Bosnians in the former Yugoslavia in 1992, the Bosnian film director Danis Tanovic was a 23-year-old student in Sarajevo. In the span of a few weeks, after the siege of Sarajevo began, he watched both his hometown and his youthful idealism go up in flames.

title: In My Tribe
description: I was delighted to find that Ethan Watters (The Way We Live Now) has a name for the people closest to him, without being blood relations: he calls them his urban tribe. New to Southern California, I am pleased to have friends far from my East Coast roots. Perhaps this network has distracted me from finding a permanent mate, but I wouldn't trade my own tribe, a supportive and productive group of smart people, for anything. We all look out for one another in the uncertainty of our 30's and 40's.

title: Anthrax Pranks? You've Got to Be Kidding
description: SO this guy in New Jersey puts grated cheese in an envelope, addresses it to a friend in California and get this writes the name ''Mohamed'' in the corner.

title: The Will to Rise
description: VERNON CAN READ!

title: Little-Known Alliance Party Rescues Ulster's Peace Pact
description: Northern Ireland's political leaders came up with a last-ditch method to save the province's power-sharing government tonight just hours before it faced collapse. The government had been brought to the brink by its opponents' earlier success in blocking the re-election of its leader David Trimble.

title: Brothers In Search Of Truths In Local Myths
description: BEFORE the Coens, the Hugheses, the Quays, the Wachowskis and the Farrellys, there were the Tavianis, Paolo (born in 1931) and Vittorio (born in 1929): the greatest cinematic brother act since Louis and Auguste Lumire, who pretty much invented the movies just over a century ago. And when the Tavianis are at their best -- in pictures like ''Padre Padrone'' (1977), ''The Night of the Shooting Stars'' (1982), ''Kaos'' (1984) and ''Elective Affinities'' (1996) -- they seem very much like the Lumires: the images and sounds they capture are so strange, so fresh and so unaccountably beautiful that you can almost believe that they, too, were present at the creation.

title: The Candidates on Major Issues in the Mayoral Race: An Overview; Labor
description: MR. BLOOMBERG -- He said he would work closely with the municipal unions to increase efficiency to help ease the city's budget strains. He supports a hiring freeze for all municipal employees, including teachers, suggesting that he would also favor using attrition to cut the city's budget deficit. Although almost all municipal unions have endorsed Mr. Green, Mr. Bloomberg insists that labor leaders like him because they know that his business experience can help create a smoother-running city.

title: Sleeping Patterns
description: Nap Time's flannel pajamas carry the summer craze for toile straight through winter. They come in pale pink with a moss green pattern or mint green with a lavender pattern. The tops are trimmed with piping and ornamented with bows at the sleeves, and the bottoms have a ribbon drawstring ($68 at Anthropologie). Cozy and absurdly feminine, the pajamas take toile back home -- where it perhaps should have stayed in the first place.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINEMAN, STEPHEN JOSEPH
description: FINEMAN-Stephen Joseph. 63, of Bronxville, NY,on November 1, 2001, from kidney cancer. Husband of Dr. Beverly; loving father of Rebecca, Jeremy and Jonathan. Mr. Fineman was a graduate of Cornell University in Engineering Physics and was a Guggenheim Fellow in Aeronautical Engineering at Princeton University. Graveside service to be held Tuesday, November 6, 1 PM, Pine Knolls Cemetery, Hanover, NH.

title: No. 1 With a Shrug: Davenport Reaches Top
description: Lindsay Davenport had just hit the flat backhand winner down the line that made her, not Jennifer Capriati, the No. 1 player in women's tennis. Davenport walked calmly to the net without smiling, shook Kim Clijsters's hand after a 1-6, 6-3, 7-6 (3) victory and then snubbed the chair umpire, Anne Lesserre-Ulrich, on the way to her seat.

title: BENEFITS
description: Puppets and Other Art

title: Celia Silke, James Hurley
description: Celia Ann Silke, a registered nurse, and James Patrick Hurley, a New York fire lieutenant, are to be married today. The Rev. Thomas Flynn is to perform the ceremony at St. Barnabas Roman Catholic Church in the Bronx.

title: Private Sector; The Morning Run, for a Cause
description: Lean and mean in the boardroom, Niall FitzGerald, the co-chairman of Unilever, has been getting into fighting form outside the office to run in today's New York City Marathon. Mr. FitzGerald, 56, has been running the five and a half miles from his home in London's Chelsea district to Unilever's headquarters, where a chauffeur hands him a briefcase and a business suit. A former pack-a-day smoker, he started running in the 1980's while working for Unilever in South Africa. A pulled hamstring almost made him quit the 1997 London Marathon, until a runner dressed like an octopus passed him. Mr. FitzGerald figured that if the octopus-clad man could finish, so could he. This year, Mr. FitzGerald has an added incentive: $2 million he raised from corporations to be donated to children's charities. ''I'm looking forward to participating, and hopefully to finishing,'' he said. Suzanne Kapner

title: Your Mother's Enduring Charms
description: Charm bracelets seem to pop in and out of our lives like a handsome ex-boyfriend, from the late 1990's Parisian travel-souvenir variety to last year's ''theme'' bracelets. This fall, expensive charm-laden bracelets were to have been the it accessory, including Louis Vuitton's $25,000 extravaganza and Bulgari's round pendant version, at $400 to $1,200 per charm. But the charm bracelet as originally conceived -- buy the bracelet, collect the charms -- is now proving both more affordable and more popular. Shoppers seem especially fond of vintage charms from the '40s and '50s. Even men are embracing them, hooking charms onto jean jackets and leather wristbands.

title: Coming to Terms With Ground Zero Terror in a World Apart
description: As a working architect here in this ruggedly beautiful haven for dropouts from the American mainstream, Michael E. Reynolds never did think much of skyscrapers.

title: Crime
description: The exquisite sensibility of Magdalen Nabb's police procedurals has all to do with the feeling of displacement that haunts her sensitively observed characters. Beginning with Salvatore Guarnaccia, a self-contained Sicilian policeman who finds himself a foreigner among the quick and garrulous citizens of Florence, the most sympathetic characters in Nabb's 12th novel, PROPERTY OF BLOOD (Soho, $23), are the ones who hover just outside the social order of this elegant city, imperfectly understanding and never quite accepting its unwritten codes.

title: Once Braced for a Power Shortage, California Now Finds Itself With a Surplus
description: By now, as the last of the Indian summer heat finally leaves the Central Valley, California was supposed to have suffered through a long hot season of electricity blackouts and price gouging, putting the world's fifth-largest economy in further peril.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FRENCH, RICHARD F.
description: FRENCH-Richard F. Director of Juilliard's Doctor of Musical Arts program 1987-1993. A musical tribute honoring his memory takes place Tuesday, November 6, at 5PM in Juilliard's Paul Recital Hall, 60 Lincoln Center Plaza.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NATION, DOUGLAS P.C.
description: NATION-Douglas P.C. Age 59. Died Sept. 2nd, 2001 in Switzerland. He was a Senior Managing Director at Bear Stearns, NYC. He is survived by his wife Caroline, his two daughters, Tanya & Charlotte, and his aunt, Mary Wallace. A memorial service will be held at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, 921 Madison Avenue, at 11:00 AM, Nov. 8th. Donations to US Court Tennis Preservation Fund/Douglas Nation Fund. Mail to USCT Preservation Fund, in care of The Racquet Club of Philadelphia, 215 South 16th Street, Philadelphia, PA. 19102.

title: Oct. 28-Nov. 3; Milosevic Hears the Charges
description: The international war crimes tribunal in The Hague usually waives the recitation of indictments. But for one defiant defendant, who has refused to accept legal representation that would ordinarily review the charges, the tribunal made an exception. Slobodan Milosevic, the former president of Yugoslavia, was forced to listen to the full text, delivered in his own language, of two indictments. The reading of the charges -- including murder, torture, plunder and rape in Croatia in 1991 and Kosovo in 1999 -- lasted almost four hours.

title: In New York Schools, Afghanistan Aid Flops
description: In the three weeks since President Bush asked every American child to donate a dollar to help Afghan children survive the winter, more than 200,000 envelopes bearing well over $1 million have poured into Washington from around the nation. But in New York City, it seems, relatively few children have heeded the call.

title: Reds Born For Venison
description: November's chill awakens a hunger for game. Hunting a red is easy at Rosenthal Wine Merchant, experts in French wines that express vineyards' characters. Its delicious '99 Domaine Monpertuis, Vignoble de la Ramire, Ctes du Rhne ($9) was born for venison. Decanted, so is the weightier '96 Domaine Faillenc Sainte Marie, from Corbires ($9.50). At 318 East 84th Street (Second Avenue).

title: Mayo With A Slice Of Life
description: I was delivered out of Texas to Manhattan in the early 1950's, having escaped what I call American survival cooking -- barbecued or fried haunch of whatever, corn smoldering in its own husks, grain mashed into a flat fried cake, vitaminless vegetables cooked senseless and tables always decorated with red and yellow condiment bottles.

title: A New Kind of Mexican Revolution Hits the Screen
description: THANKS in part to Hollywood's global dominance of the movie business, Mexico's film industry, once one of the most vibrant and prolific in the world, was in the doldrums for much of the last half of the 20th century. But in the 1990's, circumstances conspired to allow new directors and films to put the country back on the world cinema scene. Features like ''Amores Perros,'' ''Like Water for Chocolate,'' ''Danzn'' and ''Cronos'' proved popular not only with critics but with domestic and international audiences as well.

title: A Time for Movies to Matter Again, if They Can
description: I THINK many of us who have ever felt concern for or pride in American movies understand that this is the crisis.

title: Grounded
description: Airliners don't go to heaven when they die; they return to earth. Since Sept. 11, the Mojave Airport -- an aviational salvage yard in the desert about 100 miles north of Los Angeles -- has been filling up with unneeded planes. Six or seven land daily, and sometimes twice that many, the mute mechanical victims of hard times and public fear. At the moment, there are about 200. In most cases, their fuel tanks have been drained and their cabins sealed like tubular tombs, a storage procedure the industry calls ''pickling.'' All shined up with nowhere to go, the planes, in their stillness, are spooky. When stock markets drop, no one knows where the money goes -- it vaporizes. But when thousands of flights are canceled, the castoff energy takes a physical form. The loss in this image is palpable, the loss of raw human activity. They seem almost dejected, these planes, like grounded children. They long to please us, to show what they can do. And maybe, should things pick up again, a few will get that chance. Their fuel tanks will be refilled and their hatches unlatched, and their masters will strap themselves into their cockpits. And they'll soar. For now, though, they sit, and you sense that it's hard on them. Walter Kirn

title: Postings: Co-op and Condo Housing Conference; Parking Issues And Dog Tales
description: From the prosaic -- ''Parking Issues'' -- to the idiosyncratic -- ''Dog Tales'' -- the Council of New York Cooperatives and Condominiums will offer a variety of discussion groups at its 21st annual housing conference next Sunday at Hunter College.

title: Widow Runs in Political Fast Lane
description: MOST first-time candidates could only dream of the kind of press attention lavished on Maria McHugh.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LESSER, ARNOLD
description: LESSER-Arnold, 84 years old. CPA for sixty years. Beloved husband of Sarah, devoted father of Barry, Shellie, Fern, Mindy and Alex and David Trocker; loving father-in-law of Audrey, Roy, Norman, Alicia & Amanda; loving grandfather & great-grandfather. Services on Sunday 11:30 AM Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 Second Ave, (near East 10th Street), New York City.

title: Streetscapes/25 to 41 Harrison Street; A Historic Renovation Improving With Age
description: BUILT almost two centuries ago, the simple brick houses at 25 to 41 Harrison Street were singled out for preservation in the 1960's in an urban renewal district in which hundreds of 19th-century industrial buildings were demolished. At first, this peculiar little enclave, in the shadow of the giant Independence Plaza housing project, had a synthetic character, but the passage of time has gradually added the patina of age.

title: Loving Hands
description: From the first pat of butter to the big cleanup later, the heart of any dinner party is the handiwork. The photographer Martin Parr focuses on some tender moments in London town.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POSTER, DOROTHY C.
description: POSTER-Dorothy C. Died on October 30, 2001. Dr. Poster practiced psychotherapy for many years in New York City. Her passing is deeply mourned by her husband, Carl B. Zuckerman, and nieces, Joanna, Enid, Debra, Susan and nephew, David. Private services were held.

title: Hollywood in Wartime: Lessons of Pearl Harbor
description: ON Dec. 7, 1941, the Japanese attacked Pearl Harbor. On Dec. 8, a Warner Brothers employee filed a report on a property called ''Everybody Comes to Rick's,'' which the studio released in late November of the following year, drastically altered to reflect the demands of the time, as ''Casablanca.'' Everybody knows the story of how Rick, a cynical nightclub owner whose credo is ''I stick my neck out for nobody,'' rediscovers his essential nobility and sacrifices self-interest to the greater good. The basic story line would become a staple of wartime American cinema -- the film historian Thomas Schatz said it ''signaled the wartime conversion of Hollywood's classical narrative paradigm'' -- and would help make Humphrey Bogart one of the top movie stars of the era. In retrospect, ''Casablanca'' can also be seen as a metaphor for Hollywood's own heroic contribution to the war effort.

title: Tania Shinkawa, James White Jr.
description: Tania Naomi Shinkawa, the daughter of Donna Shinkawa of Princeton, N.J., and Teruo Shinkawa of Tokyo, was married yesterday to James Joseph White Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. White of Davidsonville, Md. The Rev. Wayne Meisel, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Princeton University Chapel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROKER, AL, SR.
description: ROKER-Al, Sr. The Faculty and Staff of the NYU Child Study Center mourn the loss of Al Roker, Sr., beloved father of Al Roker, one of our steadfast supporters & special friends. Al's energy, enthusiasm and generosity for children in need are an enduring legacy and memorial to his father. We extend our sympathy to Al and the entire Roker family. Brooke Neidich, Chair Board of Directors Harold S. Koplewicv, M.D. The Arnold and Debbie Simon Professor of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry Director, Child Study Center New York University School of Medicine

title: About the Weddings
description: The Times's wedding reports remain available all week on the Web at

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.

title: Manhattan Journal; Tale of Past Jewish Life, Told in Tile
description: A clay pipe or a pottery shard is a fine day's work for an urban archaeologist. Celia J. Bergoffen found a bathhouse.

title: A Patch of Dirt With a Haunting Past
description: NICHOLAS EVANS-CATO has been painting pictures of the same triangle of dirt for five years. Today the object of his affection -- an awkward lot at Hudson Avenue and Front Street in the Vinegar Hill section of Brooklyn -- is filled with sickly grass, robust weeds, automobiles, old socks and a deflated Wilson football.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANASHOWITZ, LEON
description: MANASHOWITZ - Leon. Our heartfelt condolences to Steven and his family, from your family at Prestige Theatre Parties. Tuddie, Lenny, Jen, Pat & Margo

title: Who Best Protects Shareholders? The Shareholders
description: GIVING shareholders more rights is good for a company to do.

title: Political Briefing; Name Recognition Shapes Illinois Race
description: Election Day is still a year off for the 2002 Illinois governor's race. So how is it shaping up this early?

title: All Creatures Great and Small
description: A WEEK and a half after the attack on the World Trade Center I spent several days exploring Blackbeard Island off the Georgia coast with my boyfriend, John. It's a national wildlife refuge, a landscape of salt marshes, oak forests, deserted beaches and, in late summer, millions of mosquitoes. Visitors are allowed on the 5,186-acre barrier island, managed by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, from dawn until dusk and it's accessible only by boat, or in our case two kayaks.

title: Not Vietnam
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We don't train when it's raining.''

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Jerry Stahl; A Funny Thing Happened
description: IN the lobby of the TriBeCa Grand Hotel, the author Jerry Stahl prepared to head out to Irving Plaza on Tuesday evening, to introduce a lineup of hot-shot urban writers reading comic passages from their works.

title: A Child's First Thanksgiving
description: The first dinner party most children attend is the family's Thanksgiving meal. Prior to that, he or she may make cameo appearances at cocktail parties and suppers, where the kissing of scented adults posed in clouds of cigar smoke may seem quite sensational, or tedious, depending on the child's social inclinations and whatever might be playing on the television in the nursery.

title: Oct. 28-Nov. 3; Israeli Troops Remain
description: Israeli forces remained in Palestinian-controlled territory more than a week after the Bush administration first demanded they withdraw immediately. Last Sunday, two Palestinian gunmen opened fire in Hadera, killing four Israeli women, and injuring 30 people. Later in the week, soldiers killed at least eight Palestinians, including two who Israelis said were about to carry out a suicide bombing. Israeli officials said their forces would leave as soon as the Palestinians complied with treaty obligations to crack down on militants. Prime Minister Tony Blair of England pronounced the conflict to be ''at a low point.'' James Bennet

title: Bridges and Streets to Be Closed for Marathon
description: Several bridges and streets will be closed today during the New York City Marathon. These are the major ones:

title: BEST SELLERS: November 4, 2001
description: Weeks

title: Former Reliever Aches As Kim Suffers the Pain
description: George Frazier sat in his home in Tulsa, Okla., on Thursday night and watched devastation strike one of his fraternity for a second successive night. Byung Hyun Kim had just given up his second game-tying two-run home run with two outs in the ninth inning in 24 hours.

title: Political Memo; Bridgeport Mayor Joins Indicted List
description: IN 1999, it was Paul J. Silvester, the former state treasurer and political acolyte of Gov. John G. Rowland, pleading guilty to federal bribery and racketeering charges. A year later, it was Ben F. Andrews Jr., who ran for secretary of state in 1998, indicted for taking kickbacks from Mr. Silvester.

title: Looking Again at J.F.K.
description: THE KENNEDY MEN

title: Crisis Through a Generational Lens
description: WHEN I first noticed that older people appeared to be reacting more calmly and rationally to the horrific events of Sept. 11 than many people in their 40's and 50's, I didn't give it much thought.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KREEGER, HENRIETTA
description: KREEGER-Henrietta. We extend our sincere condolences to our dear friends Douglas Kreeger and Wendy Durst Kreeger, and their family, on the death of his much beloved mother, a pioneering educator in learning disabilities. Frances Degen Horowitz, President, The Graduate Center, CUNY

title: Look to Castro
description: To the Editor:

title: Patriotic Songs
description: The State Theater in New Brunswick will be the site of some patriotic melodies next Saturday. That is when John McDermott, one of the so-called Irish tenors, though he was born in Scotland, appears as part of his national tour in tribute to United States war veterans.

title: Private Sector; Great Expectations at GE Medical
description: YOU think Jeffrey R. Immelt has a tough job, following Jack Welch as chairman of General Electric? Try being Joseph M. Hogan, who is following Mr. Immelt as chief executive of GE Medical Systems. Mr. Immelt does not have his predecessor looking over his shoulder. But Mr. Hogan reports to the very man who turned GE Medical Systems, once a lackluster group, into an $8.5 billion powerhouse.

title: Vanessa Pino, Christopher Lockel
description: Vanessa Cecilia Pino and Christopher A. Lockel were married yesterday by Arthur Eccleston, a Roman Catholic deacon, at St. Patrick's Cathedral in Manhattan.

title: American With Dashes of the Tropics
description: JESSICA'S NEW AMERICAN GRILL in Baldwin is almost too good to be true. Situated at 614 West Seaman Avenue (516-771-3520) in a working-class neighborhood, it serves dishes that are far better than many fancy Island restaurants charging twice as much. Mark Haber, the young chef and co-owner, paid his dues and learned his craft in Florida and in leading local spots like Tupelo Honey, Coyote Grill and Abi Qu.

title: DataBank; A Stumble, Then a Rally Amid Bad News
description: By conventional logic, the stock market should have sagged throughout last week as investors were hit with a steady barrage of dismal economic reports. There was almost no encouraging news from corporate America.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Rutherford; A Patriotic Town With an Easy Commute
description: A GRANITE pillar capped by a flame-shaped light and carved with the words ''To Rutherford's Glorious Dead'' looms over the intersection of Park and Passaic Avenues, in front of the Rutherford borough hall. The monument to World War I fallen is one of a half dozen war memorials near the two-story 1901 brick structure.

title: Designing Man Meets 'The Women,' and Fur Flies
description: ISAAC MIZRAHI squints into a full-length mirror at the actress Jennifer Tilly and fiddles with her skin-tight skirt. ''If you want a slit in it, it's O.K.,'' he finally allows.

title: The First Supper
description: Martha Stewart need never worry about competition from my family.

title: Even a Crowned Head Can't Save a Margarita Palace
description: El Teddy's, the popular Mexican restaurant in TriBeCa, has long furnished patrons with a sense of urban sophistication along with its renowned margaritas. But the restaurant lacks the ''historic fabric'' to merit city protection, the Landmarks Preservation Commission has decided.

title: Hands Out, Even in a Time Of Crisis
description: WHERE'S Frank Capra when you need him?

title: As American as Pot Pie
description: Diners are seeking comforting, familiar food served in a soothing atmosphere, and with patriotism high, these cozy American restaurants fit the current mood.

title: The Mayoral Rivals
description: Although their campaigns have highlighted their differences in background, Mark Green and Michael R. Bloomberg are not unlike each other in many significant ways.

title: An Uncertain Future For a Link With the Past
description: PLEASANTVILLE'S second-oldest building, which dates back to 1786, may soon be demolished, sparking protests from neighbors who want to save it.

title: In This Battle, No Shots Fired in Anger
description: EVERYTHING looked authentic except for the minivans that hauled in the artillery, the portable bathrooms and the video cameras that seemed as common as canteens. Assembled at Ward Pound Ridge Reservation in Cross River were more than 2,000 re-enactors, all in Revolutionary War era regalia to mark the 225th anniversary of the Battle of White Plains. For two days last weekend they bivouacked and battled and provided visitors with a living history of the era and the battle, where 1,500 of Washington's Continentals stalled the advance of several thousand British troops.

title: Travel Advisory; Help for Navigating Northeast Mass Transit
description: A new Web site, www.ez-ways.com, created to help users of mass transit in the Northeast, was rushed on line after the attacks on New York and Washington. EZ-Ways, which updates public transit changes and comes up with itineraries, started Sept. 24, about three weeks early, to help deal with confusion over recent disruptions in travel, said a spokeswoman, Thalia Cady.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARDIN, CHARLES ROE JR.
description: HARDIN-Charles Roe Jr. Age 80, of Basking Ridge, NJ, on Thursday, November 1. Husband of Jean Sherrill Hardin. Father of Katharine Hardin and the late Andrew Sherrill Hardin. Brother of Dorothy Dillon and William Hardin. A memorial service will be held on Monday, November 19, at 11 AM, at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, Gladstone, NJ. Memorial gifts may be made to Navy/Marine Corps Relief Society, 801 North Randolph, Suite 1228, Arlington, VA 22203-1978, or Newark Museum, 49 Washington St, PO Box 540, Newark, NJ 07101. For information contact Bailey Funeral Home, Inc, Peapack, NJ.

title: Two Steps Removed
description: To the Editor:

title: Concourse Shut In Baltimore After Woman Skips Screening
description: Federal aviation authorities evacuated a Southwest Airlines concourse of Baltimore-Washington International Airport this morning after a woman bypassed a security checkpoint, officials said.

title: Exploring Around the Edges: Listings and Information
description: P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center, 22-25 Jackson Avenue (46th Avenue), Long Island City, Queens 11101; www.ps1.org . Open noon to 6 p.m. Wednesday through Sunday. Suggested donation, $4.

title: One Man's Essential Manhattan
description: AUTUMN in New York. Has there ever been a time when that phrase sounded more bittersweet? Crisp fall days have always been perfect for seeing this city, the cool snap in the air drawing you outside for a walk through Central Park or down Fifth Avenue, and museums and restaurants and theaters and clubs luring you inside to take off the slight chill, to fill your stomach and raise your spirit.

title: What to Tell a Child
description: To the Editor:

title: A Clogged Market
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the Ruth and Sherman Lee Institute of Japanese Art in Hanford, Calif., misspelled the name of the valley in which it is located. It is San Joaquin, not San Joachin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZWEIFLER, DR. LEONARD J.
description: ZWEIFLER-Dr. Leonard J. On November 2, 2001. Beloved husband of Perri. Loving father of Jordan. Dear brother of Irving and Lorraine. Devoted uncle, cousin and friend. Service Monday, 1 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: The Boston, A Portrait On Records
description: WITH America's leading orchestras making ever fewer recordings for no longer thriving classical-music labels, the orchestras have begun producing recordings of their own. Of special interest are ''historic broadcasts'' being made available for the first time: performances that potentially reconnect to past glories and also, at best, capture the frisson of edge-of-the-seat music-making better than any studio product, however perfectly patched together.

title: The Nation; Patriotic Partisanship On Capitol Hill
description: EVER since the terror strikes of Sept. 11, President Bush, like some latter-day George Washington, has tried to position himself as a man above party, the commander in chief, for whom politics itself is slightly dclass.

title: Front Line Of Famine In Ethiopia Is the Soil
description: A fight against famine is being waged here but without the heart-wrenching sights the world has come to know: no communal feeding centers, no bloated bellies, no mounting death toll.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOFSKY, MARILYN (NEE DOPPELT)
description: KOFSKY-Marilyn (nee Doppelt). Died on October 29, 2001, surrounded by her adoring family after a long illness. She was a loving and devoted wife, mother, grandmother, sister, friend and teacher. In 25 years as a teacher in the Oceanside Public Schools she touched the lives of hundreds of students and colleagues. Marilyn understood a basic and essential fact of life-by giving of herself she enriched and nourished the lives of others. By giving of herself her spirit and essence will endure and be carried forward. Marilyn built a legacy of a loving and devoted family. She is survived by Herbert, her husband of 52 years, her children, Larry, Susan, Martin and Karen, her grandchildren, Michael, Debbie, Allison, Matthew, Hillary, Morgan, Sean, Stefanie and Mackenzie and her brother Morton Doppelt. Memorial contributions may be made to Hospice Care Network, 900 Merchants Concourse, Westbury, NY, 11590, or Adelphi New York Statewide Breast Cancer Hotline and Support Program, Adelphi University School of Social Work, Garden City, NY, 11530.

title: Catching the Retreating Sun for Fresh Greens
description: ALIGHT frost has turned most of my vegetable garden to brown vines, but the collards and mustard greens love the cool weather. It's satisfying work, pulling up the old tomato and bean vines, and raking in winter rye seed, so that this green manure, or cover crop, will enrich and lighten the soil.

title: Street Life, Uptown and Down
description: SOLEDAD

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION & POETRY
description: SAD BASTARD

title: Seeing the Causes Of Resentment
description: To the Editor:

title: Genius Down Under
description: Does art matter? It mattered so much that it terrified the Soviets and Nazis into controlling it, and the Taliban, by blowing up ancient Buddhist sculpture, into destroying it. Allowed to, art will endure longer than politics and national borders, longer than Ozymandias. But can creativity that vanishes quickly be considered art? Of course. Take a live, unrecorded performance. Take dinner.

title: Coming Soon: Harry Potter And Hollywood's Cash Cow
description: Harry Potter has overcome a three-headed dog, giant spiders and the evil Lord Voldemort. But now he may finally have met his match: Warner Brothers.

title: FOOTNOTES
description: Resources, references and the back story behind the story.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORTALE, PETER KEITH
description: ORTALE-Peter Keith. Age 37. Missing since September 11, 2001, World Trade Center. Resident of Manhattan. Native of Philadelphia, PA. Devoted husband to Mary Duff. Loving son of Mary Ortale and the late Gilbert Ortale. Dear brother to Cathy Grimes, Mary Malitas, Julie Ortale and Gil Ortale. Adoring uncle to Maurice, Georgia, Everhett, Alex and Nina. In-law to the Ortale and Duff families. Friend of everyone lucky enough to have known him. Celebration of his life Tuesday, November 6, 2001, 10AM, Saint Patrick's Cathedral, 5th Ave at 50 St. Peter worked for Euro Brokers and was last seen helping others out of the World Trade Center. He was a Duke Athletic Scholar and a graduate of the Penn Charter School in Philadelphia, PA. Contributions in his honor may be made to William Penn Charter School, c/o Peter K. Ortale Scholarship Fund, 3000 W. Schoolhouse La., Philadelphia, PA 19144.

title: Travel Advisory; Deals and Discounts
description: New York isn't the only destination trying to attract visitors. Several others are working with hotels and attractions to assemble package deals.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the history of patriotic art referred incorrectly to the origin of the famous photograph of the raising of an American flag over Iwo Jima. The photographer recorded the raising of a second, larger flag to replace one raised at the same spot earlier that day, Feb. 23, 1945; the photograph was not staged. The article also misstated the number of servicemen in the picture; there were five marines and a Navy medical corpsman; two men were mostly obscured.

title: Bess Frelinghuysen, George Ratliff
description: Elizabeth Brady Frelinghuysen, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Frelinghuysen of New York, was married yesterday to George Whittenburg Ratliff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey L. Ratliff of Amarillo, Tex. The Rev. Philippa A. Turner, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

title: A Late Comeback For East End Stripers
description: It was the best of years and, for obvious reasons, the worst of years. I am talking not just about world events, but about our local champions in pinstripes -- the striped bass.

title: Affairs of the Horse: 2 Centuries of Images
description: WHAT does it mean to be an American?

title: A Hofstra Education With an Asterisk
description: MEMBERS of the inaugural class of the Hofstra University honors college await midterm grades this week while happily awarding top marks to the new college, which has promised them enriched academics and individually tailored cultural and social experiences.

title: Oct. 28-Nov. 3; Action Behind the Scenes
description: Publicly, the White House says to expect no great breakthroughs when Vladimir V. Putin of Russia arrives in Washington this week. Privately, each country is maneuvering as fast as it can. Mr. Bush thinks the Russians are willing to allow him to go ahead with antimissile tests, even if they violate the Antiballistic Missile Treaty. In return, the Russians think America will deeply cut its nuclear arsenal (something the Russians want to do also, to save money), usher Russia into the World Trade Organization and begin to integrate the country into Europe. David E. Sanger

title: Pure, Simple Revenge
description: To the Editor:

title: Making All Sounds Equal
description: WHO is the most influential European composer of the moment? A few names come to mind, but none more immediately than that of Helmut Lachenmann. Many of the most energetic composers under 40 have studied with him, and his music has been a subject of intense debate and excitement for the last quarter-century and more: most recently, his opera ''The Little Match Girl'' was making a stir in Paris two months ago. His importance as a provocative teacher and guide alone should have brought his work more attention than it has so far had in this country. Given, in addition, his music's richness, variety and communicative drive, the neglect becomes truly bizarre.

title: Rachel Bloomgarden, Bryan Spielman
description: Rachel Eva Bloomgarden, the daughter of Dr. Kathy Bloomgarden and Dr. Zachary Bloomgarden of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married yesterday evening to Bryan Charles Spielman, a son of Dr. Rima Spielman and Herbert Spielman of Long Beach, N.Y. Rabbi Ezra M. Finkelstein officiated at the Century Association in New York.

title: Corrections
description: A credit is omitted on Page 3 of the Travel section today for two pictures with a brief article about a math exhibition at the Exploratorium in San Francisco. The photographer was Lily Rodriguez.

title: Sehorn's Successes and Failures Magnified
description: Jason Sehorn concedes that the catcalls he hears from the stands have changed. He used to be called an overrated pretty boy.

title: Raising The Roof
description: Is it a bird? A plane? No, it's probably a building by Santiago Calatrava. The 50-year-old Spanish architect and engineer, who is based in Zurich, has spent 30 years designing structures like bridges, train stations and airports that combine technological daring with an artist's grasp of gesture and natural forms. Some of his designs are kinetic, with roofs that open and close or sunscreens that move with the light. Although he is inspired by great building of the past -- Gothic architecture, late-19th-century railway stations and the bridges of engineering greats like Frei Otto and Robert Maillart -- Calatrava will often explain his design ideas with a physical movement, say the flapping of a wing or the folding and unfolding of two hands in prayer. It is this scientist-humanist approach that has sent Calatrava soaring to superstardom.

title: Witasick's Rough Outing Raises Sore Point About Pitching Staff
description: Jay Witasick invited the best of George Steinbrenner last night.

title: U.S. Pondering Saudis' Vulnerability
description: The question is asked quietly by policy makers inside Washington's official corridors, and loudly by television and newspaper experts: Is Saudi Arabia heading for an Iranian-style Islamic revolution?

title: Measuring The Stride Of a Giant
description: THE New York Philharmonic season, so intricately woven as an elaborate farewell to Kurt Masur, began to unravel before it had even started. In response to the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, Mr. Masur and the orchestra scrapped a gala opening concert nine days later in favor of a memorial performance of Brahms's ''German Requiem.'' And three days after that, the Philharmonic announced that the 74-year-old Mr. Masur, who canceled two weeks of appearances with the orchestra last season for unspecified surgery, was canceling two more weeks in December for transplantation of an unspecified organ.

title: Personal Business; In the Great Job Desert, Some Hidden Oases
description: THE news on the job front has not been good. Employers have cut hundreds of thousands of positions this year in response to the weakening economy, especially after Sept. 11, and there are more reports of corporate retrenchment almost every day. The unemployment rate has risen to 5.4 percent, near a five-year high, and is poised to grow.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Investing; The Choices Grow For Betting on Japan
description: INVESTING in Japanese equities is not for the faint of heart. Once the envy of the financial world, Japan has limped through the last decade, undone by a chronic banking crisis, policy missteps and a global slowdown. The benchmark Nikkei 225-stock index is toying with 18-year lows, and pessimism about the country's future has risen to record highs.

title: Business; A Phone Upstart, Still Annoying the Giants
description: THROUGHOUT Chicago, where Ameritech is the reigning local telephone company, billboards popped up during the summer showing the face of the tough-talking football legend Mike Ditka. ''Make the smart call -- bench Ameritech,'' he says on one of them. ''Staying with Ameritech is just plain dumb,'' he advises on another. And last week, a new series of billboards began appearing in the city, as well as in Detroit and Pittsburgh, recommending: ''Choose Wisely. Because Now You Can.''

title: Rain, Sleet, Snow and Now This . . .
description: THE white postal van that had been inching along Clarksville Road stopped by another mailbox at the edge of an expansive lawn. Ken Langbein reached out the window and filled the yawning box with letters.

description: RADNER-Sanford. Of Upper Montclair. Professor emeritus of English, Montclair State University, age 69, of cardiac arrest on November 1, 2001. Husband of Susan (Goldman) Radner. Funeral services are private. For information, Caggiano Memorial, 62 Grove St, Montclair, NJ 07042.

title: Davida Sidrane, Bret Hogan
description: Davida Jennifer Sidrane, the daughter of Michelle and Alan Sidrane of Brooklyn, is to be married tonight to Bret Marshall Hogan, the son of Catherine and Thomas Hogan of Kearny, N.J. Rabbi Gerald I. Weider is to officiate at the 200 Fifth Club in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PREM, FRANK HERBERT III (TERRY)
description: PREM-Frank Herbert III (Terry). Age 37, of Housatonic, MA, died on October 24, 2001 of injuries sustained in an automobile accident. He is survived by his father, F. Herbert Prem Jr., and his stepmother, Patricia Ryan Prem of New York, NY; his mother, Barbara Herrick and stepfather, Scott Herrick of West Stockbridge, MA; and his sister, Julia Nichols Prem of Housatonic, MA. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to The Terry Prem Scholarship Fund at Freedom Institute, 515 Madison Ave., New York, New York 10022.

title: That One Show
description: To the Editor:

title: Sunny California With Southern Gothic Shadows
description: THE setting for ''Pasadena,'' the new Friday night soap on Fox, may be Southern California with its perpetual sunshine, its towering palms, its Spanish colonial estates and luxuriant bougainvillea, but the atmosphere is something else, something more mysterious and harder to put your finger on. Something more Flannery O'Connor than ''Beverly Hills 90210.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, CAPTAIN PATRICK J.
description: BROWN - Captain Patrick J. FDNY. Heroically died in the line of duty at the World Trade Center on September 11, 2001. A 21 year veteran of the FDNY. Proud Captain of Ladder 3, former Captain of 69 Engine, former Lieutenant of 28 Truck and former firefighter of Rescue 2, Rescue 1 and 26 Truck. Patrick was one of the most highly decorated active members of the FDNY. He was also a decorated Marine in Vietnam, and award winner of the Silver Star. Patrick also received the Holy Name Society Man of the Year Award. Patrick is survived by his father John (Retired FBI) & his mother, the late Ruth. Loving brother of Michael Brown, M.D., former Firefighter of Engine 37 and his wife Janet, his sister Carolyn Negron and her husband Hector. Memorial visitation will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Wednesday, November 7th and Thursday November 8th, 2 to 4 and 7 to 9PM. Memorial Mass Friday, 2PM, at St. Patrick's Cathedral, 5th Avenue at 51st Street. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to Ladder 3 Assistance Fund, 108 East 18th Street, New York, N.Y. 10003.

title: Thabo Mbeki and AIDS
description: Thabo Mbeki's views on AIDS have drawn so much criticism that he has lately kept them to himself. Last month, however, the South African president gave two speeches that showed he remains badly misinformed about a virus that now infects one in four adult South Africans and will kill between five and seven million over the next decade, the vast majority of them poor black people. Mr. Mbeki downplayed the problem, exaggerated the toxicity of antiretroviral drugs and suggested that advocates for treating the disease are racist.

title: Los Ebanos Journal; Echoes of Sept. 11 on the Rio Grande
description: Turn off Route 83, the highway that parallels the Rio Grande here; head south through a stretch of sorghum fields and mesquite; and the road ends at this bucolic river crossing between Texas and Mexico.

description: Bernie Williams was late to Bank One Ballpark today, arriving shortly after 4 p.m., less than two hours before the start of the game.

description: A city councilman and a city attorney are facing off in Tuesday's mayoral election, but their contest also amounts to something of a referendum on what is referred to here as ''the Seattle Way.''

description: Nearly a week after 15 Christian worshipers and a police officer on duty outside their church were gunned down in the southern city of Bahawalpur, Pakistani officials say they have no firm suspects in the killings.

Their roster is so untalented that it is actually considered inferior to that of last season's 15-67 club.

The score went back and forth, back and forth, back and forth, building the tension and the emotion as 75,262 fans alternately held their breath and screamed.

title: Maintaining the Merit Raises
description: Despite the weak economy, most large companies plan to continue with merit raises. While 20 percent said they would reduce their merit pay budgets, the median increase will be 3.8 percent to 4.0 percent, about the same as last year, according to a survey by Andersen, a financial services company. The survey, of 57 companies with median revenue of $1.5 billion, was conducted after Sept. 11. The results were released last week.

description: A new Congressional report has found that the vast majority of brokerage firms have no procedures in place to prevent money laundering.

description: IN less than three weeks, New York City kicks off the holiday season with the annual Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade, the day-after ritual of early-bird shopping and an assortment of concerts, performances and tree-lighting ceremonies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANAYA, CALIXTO JR., ''CHARLIE,''
description: ANAYA-Calixto Jr., ''Charlie,'' was a firefighter with Engine 4 in Manhattan whose life was taken tragically while in the line of duty at the September 11, 2001, World Trade Center attack. Born June 19, 1966, in Manhattan, NY, to Calixto & Lydia Anaya Sr., Calixto enlisted in The United States Marine Corps in 1984 until 1988, and then reenlisted himself in 1991 to serve in Desert Storm and was honorably discharged in 1992. He married Marie Laure Maurin on April 27, 1990, in Kew Gardens, Queens. Calixto was a member of the Suffern Volunteer Hose Company #

title: Grace Notes
description: It started with Christmas. Every year, I'd face the same decision: to card or not to card. I wanted to mark the holiday, and I'd search specialty shops and museum stores for just the right beautiful, nondenominational card to illustrate my Christmas cheer. There wasn't one. Invariably, I'd choose something boringly acceptable -- a Monet waterlily or a collection of sepia-toned botanical prints. And then, without fail, I'd receive the same tasteful (but dull) cards in the mail. I was so uncompelled by my Christmas card options that I gave up. For years, the holiday would slip by without my addressing a single envelope.

title: Film Festivals and Series
description: Film Series

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARNOLD, NED
description: ARNOLD-Ned. Of Lake Success, NY. The Board of Trustees and staff of New York Hospital Queens join his family in mourning the loss of Ned Arnold. Appointed an honorary member of the Board in 1989 and a Life Trustee in 1992, Ned was a major benefactor of the hospital and had a clear vision of this institution's role in maintaining the health of the people of Queens. Through his generous donation in 1995, The Julia and Ned R. Arnold Center for Radiation Oncology was established. Today, that facility and the other components of the Cancer Center treat more Queens patients than any other institution. Businessman, philanthropist, and community leader, Ned's influence was felt beyond the Queens community in the State House and in the White House, where he served as a member of President Eisenhower's Conference on Highway Safety. He will be remembered always for his commitment and dedication to New York Hospital Queens and the people it serves. Stephen S. Mills, President and Chief Executive Officer George F. Heinrich, M.D., Chairman, Board of Trustees

title: QUICK BITE/Freehold; Round-Trip Ribs
description: Every few weeks, John Grigo drives from his home in Jamesburg to buy and take home baby back pork ribs from LaRosa Chicken & Grill in the Raintree Shopping Center in Freehold. It's about a 20-mile drive each way, but worth it, he'll tell you. It's an assessment with which Enzo Pugliese agrees. Of course, Mr. Pugliese owns the place, one of three such grills (the others are in Marlboro and Madison), which he describes as ''upscale fast-food restaurants.'' And when he says fast, he means fast. That's because there are no waiters or waitresses. The only wait involved is the 8 or 10 minutes it takes to be served freshly cooked ribs, or the time it takes to prepare roasted or grilled chicken, hamburgers and salads, plus sandwiches, pitas and finger foods, plus desserts like tiramis or baklava. The tab ranges from $6 to $7 for an average meal, up to $48.99 for a LaRosa Feast No. 5: ''4 whole chickens, 8 large side dishes and 10 corn bread.'' Eat-in customers -- ''a lot of locals,'' Mr. Pugliese says -- can sit in any of 15 booths in the 2,000-square-foot restaurant. Among the diners are employees and patrons from elsewhere in the shopping center. And there are those like Mr. Grigo, who think nothing of clocking 40 miles for some LaRosa ribs.

title: The Sex-Worker Literati
description: TRACY QUAN, the 30-something author of ''Diary of a Manhattan Call Girl,'' sat in the generic chill of an Upper East Side Starbucks and talked about how one goes about having sex with strangers for money.

title: Better Order It to Go At Montclair State
description: The Red Hawk diner, all shiny stainless steel outside, red Formica and chrome inside, is open for business at Montclair State University. This prefab 50's-style diner opened Oct. 23. What could be more convenient: breakfast, burgers and club sandwiches (plus wraps and stir-fries and much more) served 24 hours a day?

title: The End of the Road?
description: COMING SOON!!!

title: A World War II Romance And Its Narrative Minefield
description: FANS of Sebastian Faulks's best-selling novel, ''Charlotte Gray,'' can understand why the director Gillian Armstrong was so keen to turn it into a movie. A romantic World War II adventure set in London and in a cobblestone village in occupied France, it has the makings of a cinematic banquet, mingling star-crossed lovers, resistance fighters, Nazi collaborators and two little orphaned boys, all caught up in the maelstrom of war. The linchpin for everything is the heroine, whose resilience and daring in Vichy France earn her a place beside Lucinda, Sybylla and the other strong, spirited women in Ms. Armstrong's celluloid pantheon.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-4-01; What They Were Thinking
description: Summer 1987, Camp Buckner, West Point, N.Y.

title: Ever More Familiar, but Still Hard to Get to Know
description: WHEN Jennifer Connelly was hired to play opposite Russell Crowe in ''A Beautiful Mind,'' the producer, Brian Grazer, worried that the formidable Mr. Crowe might intimidate Ms. Connelly once they started filming, to the detriment of her performance.

title: Rising to the Occasion
description: I have tangible proof of Cake Doctor's existence, and I have seen the power of Cake Doctor's works. The first time Cake Doctor came into my life, it was in our garden in Santa Monica, Calif. The candles had burned low, lights were twinkling in the trees, stomachs were full, and one guest brought out a fancy dessert torte. Looking at the downcast faces, my friend Elizabeth Stewart said, ''Never fear, Cake Doctor's here.''

title: The View From/Waterbury; A Hilltop Landmark Undergoes a Revival
description: ANYONE who has driven through Waterbury has seen it. Perhaps they caught a glimpse of the 56-foot neon cross, or read the large lighted letters that glare: ''Holy Land.''

title: Liberties; Bay of Mules
description: The only place where tribal feuds are more rampant than Afghanistan is Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDAU, JEAN
description: LANDAU-Jean. Devoted wife and mother, beloved grandmother, artist and philanthropist, died from natural causes early Friday, November 2, at home in Teaneck, NJ. In 1991 she was honored for her charitable vision by the Faculty of Arts and Sciences of Harvard University. She is survived by her daughter Jacqueline and son-inlaw Stuart Kaffee of River Vale, NJ; by her grandchildren Joshua, Brian and Michelle; by her son David and daughter-in-law, the former Kaori Tominaga of Albany, California. Donations to the American Committee for the Weitzmann Institute of Science, Attention Tina Begleiter, 130 East 59th St., 10th floor, New York, NY 10022.

title: The Long Goodbye
description: While reading Carolyn See's beautiful tribute to her dying partner, I realized he was John Espey, my professor at U.C.L.A. in the 1960's. I studied the second half of English poetry with him, as well as Ezra Pound in a private tutorial. Espey had known Pound and T. S. Eliot. He hilariously described working on Eliot's papers, which in those days were guarded more fiercely than the recipe for the neutron bomb. In a new world of new criticism, what a richly civilized man he was, never taking himself or us too seriously, but reserving that seriousness for the love of literature.

title: Lodgings To Linger At: Some Traditional, Some Hip
description: Here is a selection of Manhattan hotels in the middle price range, four traditional and four less so. All rates are for double rooms.

title: New Frontier
description: I HAD been craving scallion dumplings in yogurt sauce and sauted sweet pumpkin with meat sauce and yogurt for months, debating the merits of a trip to suburban Virginia for dinner when Sept. 11 changed our world.

title: Political Briefing; Neighborly Repartee Takes On an Edge
description: Minnesota and South Dakota share a border, and their governors, like good neighbors, talk to each other a lot. The exchanges have been mostly good-natured, but lately they have taken on an edge -- which was probably inevitable, given that few governors are more outspoken than Jesse Ventura of Minnesota, an independent, and William J. Janklow of South Dakota, a Republican.

description: Approximate running times are given at end of Broadway and Off Broadway listings.)

title: Microsoft Explores A New Territory: Fun
description: DEEP in the wine cellar of the Hotel de Paris in Monte Carlo one evening last month, two dozen of Europe's top video game publishers, along with some American rivals, gathered to toast the Xbox, the newest machine that will run their games. Surrounded by Napoleonic vintages, they dined at the invitation of the game's creator, the Microsoft Corporation, which stands little chance of succeeding in the $20 billion market without their games to propel sales.

description: Paula Michele Collins, a daughter of Carol Hutton Collins of Old Greenwich, Conn., and Gerald E. Collins of Long Valley, N.J., was married yesterday in a nondenominational ceremony to Robert Emmett McGlarry, the son of Aurora Day of Albany and John J. McGlarry of Boston, N.Y. The Rev. Phillip A. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, AUGUSTA L.
description: GOLDSTEIN-Augusta L. Passed away on October 28, 2001. Born October 18, 1916 in New York City, where she lived for all but several years during WW II when her work with the Federal government took her to Washington, DC. Augusta had a long and proud career as Executive Secretary to the Hon. D. N. Edelstein. Augusta loved to do crosswords, play Scrabble, visit with friends and pursued interests in art and interior decoration. Augusta traveled extensively, both vacationing abroad and visiting family around the U.S. She was also active in HIAS. August was predeceased by her parents Sam and Sadie as well as her brothers Sidney, David and Phillip. Survivors include her sister-in-law Selma Goldstein of Reno, NV, and many cousins, nieces, nephews, grand nieces and grand nephews. A graveside service will be held at 1 PM Friday, November 2, at Beth El Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. Please call 800-522-0588 for directions.

title: In Neckties or Fire Helmets, Victims Shared a Work Ethic
description: They were men in their 30's and 40's, in the prime of their lives, many of them Irish- and Italian-Americans, neighborhood guys made good -- college athletes who followed friends to Wall Street, flourished, married, and became soccer-coaching, weekend-golfing, suburban family men.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENDER, GERTRUDE
description: BENDER-Gertrude. Beloved wife of the late Meyer. Devoted mother of Stephen and Maxine, and Alice & Bernard Klausner. Adoring grandmother of Lee and Jane, Dr. Evan, Sharon, and Jay Ira and Jodi Klausner. Cherished great grandmother of Justin and Noah. Services at ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1895 Flatbush Avenue (at Ave. L), Brooklyn, NY, Sunday at 1 PM.

title: BackTalk; Hate the Yankees? This Harangue Is for You
description: For as long as I can remember, the Yankees have been America's Team and for as long as I can remember people have tried to deny it. This has become a complicated issue now that some people have allowed themselves to temporarily root for the Yankees. They claim they are rooting for New York as a symbol of their nation under attack. They are really giving themselves permission to get in touch with their feelings briefly. In nature, all fans are Yankee fans. There is only one true team.

title: Oct. 28-Nov.3
description: Energy Giant Suddenly Flailing

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCCA, RONALD
description: BUCCA-Ronald, 47. FDNY, Fire Marshal. He responded to the call of duty at the World Trade Center, September 11, 2001. Best friend and husband to Eve, proud father of Jessica and Ronald, beloved son of Astrid and Joseph, devoted brother of Alfred and Robert. Ron was a 23-year veteran of the FDNY and had served with Engine 95, Ladder 2, the Fitness Unit, Rescue 1, the FDNY Terrorist Task Force, and was promoted to Fire Marshal in 1992. While a member of Rescue 1, in an attempt to rescue a brother firefighter, he fell five stories, severely injuring himself. Although many believed his career was over, he returned to full duty within a year. The men at Rescue 1 nicknamed him ''The Flying Fireman.'' He had served in the military for 29 years and was recently promoted to Warrant Officer in the US Army Reserve. He spent two years active duty with the 101st Airborne Division. Most of his career was with the 11th Special Forces Group and the Defense Intelligence Agency as a Military Intelligence Analyst. He was a past President of Chapter 66 Special Forces Association and a member of the American Legion. He was a Licensed Practical Nurse and held an Associate Degree in OSHA and Fire Science from John Jay College and a Bachelor of Science in Public Safety from Mercy College. His hobbies included archaeology, travel, history, and physical fitness. He was a man of many accomplishments and interests. He was an avid historian and was assisting the Fire Museum in a Zoave exhibit. He had lifelong interests in Boy Scouting and woodsmanship, but what he truly enjoyed was spending time with his family and friends. We will miss his insatiable curiosity, mischievous humor, adventurous spirit, and commitment to doing the right thing. He touched many lives and hearts and led by example. When facing the ultimate challenge, he stood fast & did his duty. He will be greatly missed and loved. The family will receive friends at Westchester Funeral Home, Inc., Eastchester, NY, Thursday and Friday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Service will be held Saturday, November 10, 2001 at Concordia College Student Chapel at 11 AM. Interment to follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate Memorial Donations to the Fire Marshal Ron Bucca Memorial Fund C/O the law office of Carro, Velez, Carro, & Mitchell, LLP, 475 Park Avenue South, New York, New York 10016.

title: Combining Apartments in a Co-op
description: Q A shareholder at our eight-unit co-op wants to combine his two adjacent one-bedroom apartments, which are separated only by a lath-and-plaster partition, into one apartment. Does the co-op have to get a new certificate of occupancy and change the original offering plan? Does the co-op have to reissue the shares for this new apartment? Can the co-op force the shareholder to buy additional shares because of the enhanced value of the new two-bedroom apartment? . . . Roy Caporale, Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYERS, MORRIS A. ''KUTCH''
description: MAYERS-Morris A. ''Kutch''. Princeton 1927. On October 31, 2001. Husband of the late Roslyn Elsas Mayers. Survived by sons Alan and Kenneth. Memorial contributions may be made to Princeton University Rowing Association, care of Princeton University, Princeton, NJ 08544.

title: Officials Fear Reactors Are Vulnerable to Attacks by Terrorists
description: As they survey the industrial landscape for objects that terrorists could turn into weapons, members of Congress, governors and others are showing growing anxiety about the vulnerability of nuclear reactors, and especially their spent fuel.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Page 36 of The Times Magazine today about the prospects for New York City under its next mayor includes an outdated reference to pre-election polls. In a survey completed by The Times on Thursday, after the magazine had gone to press, Michael Bloomberg, who trailed Mark Green considerably in previous polls, closed the gap to five percentage points.

title: When Getting There Isn't Half the Fun
description: LONG before the rush hour train leaves Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan, commuters are inching toward the favored track. The experienced ones have learned to place bets early, and they cluster at the top of the stairways.

title: Lucy Hunt, Martin Fenton III
description: Lucy St. John Hunt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Pratt Hunt of Washington, was married yesterday to Martin Fenton III, a son of Susan B. Sheridan of Denver and Mr. Fenton Jr. of San Diego. The Rev. John A. Gumbs, a Methodist minister, officiated at Cap Juluca, a resort on Anguilla, in the British West Indies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISNER, JEFFREY MICHAEL, M.D.
description: ISNER-Jeffrey Michael, M.D. The physicians, nurses, researchers, caregivers, patients and friends of St. Elizabeth's Medical Center of Boston mourn the loss of our colleague, Jeffrey M. Isner, M.D., Chief of Cardiovascular Research & Vascular Medicine at St. Elizabeth's Medical Center. Dr. Isner was a revered physician, a brilliant researcher and close colleague to all who had the privilege to know him. His passion for excellence and his compassion for his friends and family will forever be an inspiration to us all.

title: Oct. 28-Nov. 3; OPEC to Lower Output
description: After nearly three months of sinking oil prices, the members of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries indicated that they would probably cut daily production at their next meeting, on Nov. 14, and that the reduction would go into effect on Jan. 1. Oil ministers did not specify how large the decrease would be, but most industry experts expect it to be 700,000 to 1 million barrels a day. The cartel, which accounts for about 35 percent of the world's oil supplies, has already pared output this year three times, by 3.5 million barrels a day, or 13 percent. Neela Banerjee

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACNIVEN, THOMAS E.
description: MacNIVEN-Thomas E., 74. Retired investment banker, of East Hampton, NY, formerly of Larchmont, NY. Attended Pace College and served in US Navy in WW II. Avid sailor. Survived by wife of 49 years, Margot (Gotte) MacNiven and three children, Thomas E. MacNiven Jr. of East Hampton, NY, Hugh MacNiven of White Bear Lake, MN, and Katharine E. MacNiven of Holyoke, MA. Memorial Mass to celebrate his life on Saturday, November 17th at 10AM at Most Holy Trinity Church, Buell Lane, East Hampton. Memorial contributions are suggested to Town of East Hampton Adult Day Care, 128 Fireplace Rd., East Hampton, NY 11937, or VNSHospice of Suffolk, 505 Main Street, Northport, New York 11768.

title: Footlights; Foreign Policy Series
description: Purchase College may be best known for the performing arts, but this time the spotlight is on the social sciences division.

title: Habitats/Manhattan; The Roving Adventures of a Serial Subletter
description: THERE have been times when Bud Ghegan, on his way home after a very late night with friends, has to pause for a moment. Where exactly, he has to ask himself, does he live?

title: Ideas & Trends; The Ripples From a Life Lost
description: OLD ideas of family and connection die hard these are the deepest kinds of preconception. For a decade and more, however, the culture has been telling us that family in America is no longer a matter of blood. Tony Kushner's drama ''Angels in America'' explored the interconnections of the ungenetically connected. That chatty paradigm of our age, ''Friends,'' also laid out the design of the new human web. But nothing has brought the highly extended, extenuated, yet enduring family into bolder relief than the atrocity at the World Trade Center and the stories of all the bereft people left behind.

title: Move Over, Goblins
description: Halloween is about identifying with someone or something by donning a costume. Last week, many masqueraders, 3 to 8, chose to be New York firefighters rather than the usual spooky crowd. The parents of the small fry in slickers at celebrations and parades around town confirmed that it was the trick-or-treaters themselves who decided to identify with heroes.

title: Pass the Stuffing, Please. Or Is That a Problem?
description: WITH all the chilling effect of Sept. 11 on flying and travel, no one has mentioned the upside of travelphobia. Those of you who regard Thanksgiving and Christmas family reunions as a trial and a torment of Dante-esque proportions now have an excuse not to go Home for the Holidays: not to find yourself in the bosom of your dysfunctional family, apprehension gnawing away at your duodenum as a drunken Uncle Fred carves the turkey and Mom criticizes your hair and the kids look surly because they'd rather be anywhere but here.

title: A Renaissance Bronze With a Story to Tell
description: TOCCA, tocca! Touch it!'' urged Giovanni Morigi, one of the world's authorities on the conservation of Renaissance bronzes. A bronze head, almost double life size, lay on a worktable at the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum here. Even with such an enthusiastic invitation, I hesitated. The head is by Benvenuto Cellini (1500-71), the Renaissance sculptor and goldsmith, and it's one of a handful of autograph bronzes, documented pieces that are certainly the work of his hand. Although it is among the rarest and most beautiful objects in the Gardner collection, it is not very well known.

title: Many Flee From War To Cities, Not Camps
description: His three small children wailed at night, terrified by the sound of the American bombs. He was afraid of being conscripted by the Taliban, the rulers he couldn't stand. All around his home, neighbors were leaving their village to seeking safety and shelter elsewhere.

title: Your Home; Cleaning Dust From Air Ducts
description: RESPONSIBLE homeowners are generally diligent about cleaning their homes and apartments to eliminate dust and dirt from floors and furniture. And good property managers are equally attuned to similar conditions in lobbies and hallways of buildings they manage.

title: Bush Urges Calm Amid Anthrax Fears
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3  President Bush urged the nation today to remain calm about the emergence of anthrax as a weapon of terror, and warned that the government would deal harshly with whoever was found to be responsible for it.

title: The Candidates on Major Issues in the Mayoral Race: An Overview; Security and Policing
description: MR. GREEN -- He would create a new position, a deputy police commissioner for counterterrorism, to coordinate antiterrorism efforts with other law enforcement agencies and to oversee the investigation of money laundering and cyber crimes. He has called for stepping up security at public venues, with more random bag searches and electronic surveillance, and supports asking people to present identification when they want to enter government and historic buildings. He rarely speaks about security without noting that he is being advised and supported by Jerome M. Hauer, who led the Office of Emergency Management under Mayor Giuliani.

title: STYLE & ENTERTAINING
description: ON THE COVER

title: PATERSON MURDER CASE
description: A dozen teenagers charged with murder in the June 20 beating death of a homeless man in Paterson are waiting to learn whether they will face 10 to 20 years in prison if tried and convicted as juveniles, or at least 30 years behind bars if tried in adult court. A family court judge, Nestor F. Guzman of State Superior Court in Paterson, held hearings last week for seven of the teenagers, ages 16 and 17, and for five others, all 15. He plans to announce his decisions for the older group on Wednesday, although he did not say when he will decide on the younger group's fate. A 13th defendant, Freddy Rivera, 17, will be tried as an adult. Lawyers for some of the older defendants said they would appeal a decision to try their clients as adults, on grounds that the state law unconstitutionally differentiates between juveniles who are 16 or 17 years old, and those age 14 or 15. Steve Strunsky

title: A Seldom-Seen Holocaust Image: The Resister
description: IN April 1943, hundreds of young Jews many of them teenagers -- barricaded themselves in the Warsaw ghetto and began lobbing homemade bombs and firing stolen weapons at German troops. The Germans soon responded with tanks and artillery fire.

title: Corrections
description: An annotated listing today on Page 4 of the Holiday Films supplement of Arts & Leisure includes four outdated references to openings. After the section had gone to press, ''A.B.C.D.'' was rescheduled to open on Nov. 30 (not Nov. 16); ''Behind Enemy Lines'' on Nov. 30 (not Jan. 18); ''Black Hawk Down'' on Dec. 24 (not Jan. 18); and ''The Royal Tenenbaums'' on Dec. 14 (not Dec. 21).

title: Can-Do Architects
description: The publicity material is full of puns, for example, calling the event ''The Uncanniest Show On Earth.'' But the proceedings are no joke; organizers expect that the so-called Canstruction competition will raise 20,000 pounds of food for the Community Food Bank of New Jersey in Hillside, a group especially in need because of its participation in World Trade Center relief efforts.

title: A Patriotic Plea: Sideline S.U.V.'s
description: To the Editor:

title: Lauren Saul, Michael Safran
description: Lauren Rachel Saul, the daughter of Denise Saul and Dr. Michael Saul of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married there last evening to Michael Edward Safran, a son of Anita and Charles Safran of Great Neck, N.Y. Rabbi Alan Fuchs performed the ceremony at Temple Beth El of Northern Westchester.

title: A New Battleground for an Old War: The Internet
description: Old opponents -- tenants and landlords -- appear to have found new turf to dispute: cyberspace.

title: Tax Breaks for New Yorkers
description: To the Editor:

title: Benching Himself
description: HOOP ROOTS

title: Residence for the Elderly Is Refurbished and Renamed
description: The Bethel Springvale Inn, a residence for older people in Croton-on-Hudson, is undergoing a $5.5 million renovation and is being renamed the Springvale Inn. The project is expected to be completed in May 2002. During the renovation, the 105 current residents have been given the use of temporary apartments.

title: Jeanette Edwards, Ricardo Chavira
description: Jeanette Bertrand Edwards and Ricardo Chavira were married yesterday. The Rev. Jean R. Smith performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church in Princeton, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COURTIS, THOMAS
description: COURTIS-Thomas. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Thomas Courtis, associated with The Times from 1981 to 1992.

title: Meredith Kotler, Daniel Gitner
description: Meredith Eve Kotler, a daughter of Sheila B. Kotler and Dr. Stuart M. Kotler of Holmdel, N.J., was married yesterday to Daniel Mark Gitner, a son of Deanne G. Gitner and Gerald L. Gitner of Short Hills, N.J. Rabbi Jay M. Stein officiated at Liberty House, a restaurant in Jersey City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPTON, HILDA
description: LIPTON-Hilda. Her place in our lives was immeasurable, her loss unimaginable. The Spiegel Family Sherry, Ed, Auriell, Brennan and Tracy

title: What to Tell a Child Raising a New Generation in the `Center of the Universe'
description: To the Editor:

title: SOAPBOX; Tax Factor
description: LAST June someone from AT&T; testified at a legislative hearing in Trenton in favor of a change in how New Jersey calculates what corporations owe in taxes. The very same day, an AT&T; representative in Oregon released a statement strongly opposing a proposed corporate tax law change in that state.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Seven Arts of Japan

title: Gauging the Use of Ground Troops and the Scale of the Afghan War
description: Four weeks after the United States began its military campaign to unseat the Taliban in Afghanistan and to destroy Osama bin Laden's terrorist network, there is an increasingly vigorous debate about whether substantial numbers of American combat troops will be needed to seal the victory in Afghanistan.

title: Against Love
