description: All marriages are business arrangements (for sharing resources and raising children), whether they are negotiated by two families or two people madly in love. To think otherwise is to ignore our evolutionary past and the history of long-term pair bonding in our species.

title: Corrections
description: An entry on Oct. 14 in the New & Noteworthy Paperbacks column about a book by David Rosenberg on Jewish mysticism omitted a word from the title. It is ''Dreams of Being Eaten Alive: The Literary Core of the Kabbalah,'' not ''Dreams of Being Alive.''

title: Prayers Sustain Pakistani Church In Hard Times
description: Christians in Pakistan are a tiny minority in a Muslim nation, and have not been spared from religious tensions.

title: Ancien Rgime
description: THE CULT OF THE NATION OF FRANCE

title: Sports of The Times; Give This Yankee Team a Long Last Look
description: JOE TORRE cannot afford to feel nostalgia for the players still in his clubhouse, but Torre knows that win or lose tonight, this Yankee team will not remain.

title: For a Hardened Lawyer, a Tender Personal Moment
description: David Boies, the master litigator who helped the government battle Microsoft ( news/quote ) and seems to be a fixture in every big legal battle these days, is rarely at a loss for words. But he choked up twice and was forced to pause during an emotional acceptance speech last week in Manhattan.

title: U.S. SETS UP PLAN TO FIGHT SMALLPOX IN CASE OF ATTACK
description: The government has begun taking steps to cope with the possibility of a terrorist attack involving smallpox by training doctors to recognize the disease and by vaccinating small teams of experts who would rush to any part of the country to contain and treat a suspected outbreak.

title: More and More, Other Countries See the War as Solely America's
description: Whatever doubts the world's intellectuals and politicians may raise about America's war on terror, the world's people do not seem to be voting with raised fists -- yet.

title: It's Up to Schilling to End a Dynasty
description: Curt Schilling turned around his career 10 years ago when Roger Clemens provided a blunt critique of his work habits. Clemens, whose regimented preparation between starts is legendary, shared that attitude with Schilling, who has become one of baseball's most prepared pitchers. Master and student meet Sunday to decide the World Series.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLASSON, SYLVIA (SHERRY)
description: KLASSON-Sylvia (Sherry). On October 27, 2001. Dear wife of the late Jack Klasson. Beloved mother of Janet, Ilene and Walter. Service private. Contributions to the Alzheimer's Association, 360 Lexington Ave., NY, NY 10017.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, MARCIA KUYPER
description: SCHNEIDER-Marcia Kuyper. Age 74 of Clearwater Beach, FL formerly of New York City died October 17, 2001 at her residence. Born in Chicago, she grew up in Pella, Iowa. She worked as a television director for NBC Television Network for over 40 years, and retired to Florida. She had many achievements including directing ''Sing Along with Mitch'', ''Christmas in Rockefeller Center'', public service shows such as ''The First Estate'', and news for WNBC-TV. She was the recipient of 4 Emmy Awards, one of which was as the Associate Director for ''S' Wounderful, S'Marvelous, S'Gershwin with Jack Lemmon''. She also received an ''Angel Award'' for Religion in Media. She was also Associate Director of ''Your Show of Shows'', ''Perry Como'', ''Hallmark Hall of Fame Specials'', and ''The Bell Telephone Hour''. Later, she worked as a Producer, Director, & Associate Director for numerous NBC News events. She is survived by her husband of 45 years Francis Schneider a retired art director for NBC for 25 years, a daughter Pamela Schneider Butler of HoHo-kus, NJ and 3 grandchildren, Matthew, Laura, & Kristin Butler.

title: 'Remade in America': A Label to Avoid
description: WHEN we last encountered Csar (Eduardo Noriega) -- the handsome, then nightmarishly disfigured, then surgically restored protagonist of the sexy 1997 Spanish psychological puzzler ''Open Your Eyes'' (''Abre los Ojos'') -- he was either dead, dreaming or about to awaken from a virtual-reality coma in which his true love, played by that sultry toothpick Penlope Cruz, might or might not have been a figment of his imagination. ''Abre los ojos,'' commands a woman's voice. What will Csar look like when he next opens his eyes?

title: One Who Listens to Ruins That Speak of Mortality
description: PRESIDENTS should see these photographs. Members of Congress should see them. Military strategists and merchants of weapons, sowers of land mines and brewers of lethal chemicals should meditate on them. They are pictures of a global array of once-noble cultural monuments reduced by time, natural erosion and human misadventure to the barest of ruins. Like Shelley's poem ''Ozymandias,'' Kenro Izu's photographs can be read as an ominous warning to partisans of ideology and empire. The artist, however, does not read them that way. For him, the photographs are full of hopeful humanity. Yet both themes are in this work. How could the value of the arts for an age of ideological confrontation be better shown?

title: Alternatives to Indian Point Should Be Considered
description: To the Editor:

title: Alternatives to War
description: To the Editor:

title: From Here to There
description: ARTHUR IMPERATORE JR. stared at the black cloud pouring from the World Trade Center as the ferry crossed New York Harbor at top speed. Heading for Lower Manhattan, Mr. Imperatore guided the vessel straight into the hellish swirl.

title: Verplank Has Company Atop the Leader Board
description: Scott Verplank kept his one-stroke lead at the Tour Championship, but he will need more birdies to win it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, ISADORE L.
description: NEWMAN-Isadore L. 90 years old, February 18, 1911 to November 2, 2001. Survived by his loving wife Regina Delit and four married sons Eliott, William, Jeffrey and Philip and ten devoted grandchildren. For further information please call Hellman Memorial Chapels at 845-356-8600.

title: The Smiles Say It All
Paid Notice: Memorials  DENSEN, PAUL
description: DENSEN-Paul. Two years have passed. Always in our hearts and thoughts. We love you. Sarah, Mark and Robert

title: The Nation; The Boom Is Over. What's Next?
description: DON'T count on going back to the days when the Nasdaq was a one-way bet, Alan Greenspan was omniscient and all-powerful, Bill Gates could be portrayed as the worst predator on the horizon and the biggest challenge for the unemployed was sorting out the job offers.

title: Abscess Doesn't Slow Horse at the Garden
description: With her horse recovering from an abscess in one of his hind feet, 16-year-old Sarah Thordsen of Waukesha, Wis., won the National Horse Show Assn. Good Hands Saddle Seat Equitation Championship at yesterday's matinee session of the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden.

title: Ruler of the Ridge Where the West Commences
description: In 1995, while filming the nomadic society of wild stallions that live on the slopes of Montana, Ginger Kathrens witnessed the birth of a fiesty colt with a distinctive pale coat and the air of a remarkable destiny. In ''Cloud: Wild Stallion of the Rockies,'' which has its premiere tonight at 8 on Channel 13, Ms. Kathrens chronicles the colt's progress as play fights with other colts evolve into serious competition during his brutal ascent to becoming a stallion.

title: Rachel Barber, Daniel Schwartz
description: Rachel Elizabeth Barber, a daughter of Lynda A. Barber of Akron, N.Y., and the late Joseph J. Barber, is to be married today to Daniel Jacob Schwartz, a son of Ellen Schwartz and Dr. Malcolm Schwartz of Wyckoff, N.J. Rabbi Anthony Glickman is to perform the ceremony at Temple Emanuel in Paterson, N.J.

title: Marijuana Misjudgment
description: To the Editor:

title: At Diners, And Delis, Talk Turns To Rabbi
description: BARSON'S has been a place for the Jewish community in this sprawling suburban township to nosh since it opened in the 1960's -- long before Fred Neulander took his first local job as the assistant rabbi at Temple Emanuel.

title: The Glorious, the Gaudy: 5 Decades of T-Birds
description: THE lights dim, the curtain rises and glamorous fashion models pull the wraps off the retro-styled, nostalgia-inducing 2002 Ford Beaver.

title: World Series Audio: Game 6
description: Postgame audio from Game 6 of the World Series between the Yankees and the Arizona Diamondbacks provided by SportsAudio.net.

title: What's Doing In Williamsburg
description: Always festive during the holidays, Williamsburg is bound to resonate as Americans grapple with the aftermath of Sept. 11. Seeing the minutiae of day-to-day Colonial life and the seismic shifts toward revolution offers a reminder of how the ideas of independence and freedom were forged.

title: Electricity Rationing in Brazil Inflames Regional Animosities
description: A few months ago the Brazilian government imposed mandatory rationing of electricity. Violators, it said, would be punished. People scoffed, but more than a quarter of the country's 170 million residents are now having to adjust to a four-day work week, and they do not like it.

title: Redemption Is Such a Guy Thing
description: THE template underlying all Christmas movies is hardly obscure. Someone a little too focused on the things of this world undergoes a change of heart, the better to realize what is really important in life: family, friends and love.

title: 'Where the Stress Falls'
description: IWHO WOULD BE nothing without the Russian nineteenth century ...," Camus declared, in 1958, in a letter of homage to Pasternakone of the constellation of magnificent writers whose work, along with the annals of their tragic destinies, preserved, recovered, discovered in translation over the past twenty-five years, has made the Russian twentieth century an event that is (or will prove to be) equally formative and, it being our century as well, far more importunate, impinging.

title: The Candidates on Major Issues in the Mayoral Race: An Overview; Education
description: Teachers' Salaries

title: Uneasy Smokers Conjure Up Old Europe
description: ASIF CHEEMA had been a social smoker for a long time, lighting up at bars and clubs on Friday and Saturday nights, always throwing away his unfinished packs of Camel Lights when he left. But after Sept. 11, Mr. Cheema began smoking during the week, too. He started taking two and three smoking breaks a day at his Wall Street office. He craved cigarettes when he got home.

title: Introduction
description: Many readers said that the diversity of the couples featured in ''Love in the 21st Century'' is what made the issue particularly appealing. Others argued that celebrating unconventional lifestyles in the press is one reason that some cultures despise the United States.

title: Pills Will Keep Us Together
description: The article by Lauren Slater tells the tale of a typical addicted and deluded couple in dire need of a reality neither wants to accept. Instead, they are on drugs and are enabled by a legal drug pusher. There is real and healthy recovery available for these people irrespective of what may become of their relationship. But they are unaware of this because the current psychological paradigm won't allow it. Better to be addicted and sick together than in recovery alone? This is love?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AVERY, ROGER E.
description: AVERY-Roger E. An IEEE member, of Mount Gretna, PA, died Wednesday, October 31, 2001. He was 88. Roger was born in New Hampshire and educated at Harvard. He retired as President of Avery Laboratories in 1985. Prior to that he was an employee at Airborne Instruments Laboratories (AIL) in Mineola, NY. He was a technical observer and scientific consultant to the U.S. Army and Navy in the European Theater in 1943-44. He wrote many articles on biomedical and implantable devices for pain management and contributed to books on the use of radar in counter measures. He was instrumental in development of the heart pacemaker and biomedical devices such as the TENS Unit. He was a Boy Scout leader for over 25 years. His wife Vivian, his son Devin and daughter Diana Lessel, survive him. Predeceased by his son Tom, he has 6 grandchildren and six great grandchildren.

title: Close Indian Point And Conserve Energy
description: To the Editor:

title: Good Thing He Got His Licks In
description: Michael Capuzzo of Wenonah had a tremendous run this summer with his book, ''Close to Shore: A True Story of Terror in an Age of Innocence,'' (Broadway, $24.95) a detailed account of shark attacks at the Jersey shore in 1916. It remained on best-seller lists for months, and Mr. Capuzzo became a certified expert and talking head on television and radio whenever a shark attack occurred as an expert.

title: Scarsdale Told to Ensure Students Take State Tests
description: SAYING that Scarsdale school officials contributed to their students' boycott of the statewide eighth-grade tests in May, the state education commissioner this week called for Scarsdale administrators to submit a plan describing how the district will ensure that all students take this year's test.

title: No-Fun City
description: In August, a poll appeared in this newspaper indicating that New Yorkers, a perennially discontented lot, had reached a possibly unprecedented level of contentment under Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. Barely a third of the respondents said that they would move out of the city if they could, down from 60 percent 10 years earlier. Only a quarter expected life in the city to worsen over the next 10 to 15 years, which was the lowest such figure the pollsters ever recorded. Though few respondents knew much about the six major candidates then vying to succeed Giuliani, who is barred by law from seeking a third term, the outcome scarcely seemed to matter; nearly two-thirds said they felt that New York would be as good a place to live, or better, under any of them. The city appeared to be running on rails.

title: Bikini Waxes For the Shy Set
description: Do-it-yourself is finding converts in very personal territory, as more and more women choose to administer their own bikini waxes. For those who would rather suffer this sort of indignity and pain at their own hands, new waxing kits designed expressly for bikini lines offer an alternative to primitive drugstore brands.

title: Initial Offerings Make a Comeback of Sorts
description: After a miserable summer, the market for initial public offerings enjoyed something of a rebound in October.

title: The Candidates on Major Issues in the Mayoral Race: An Overview; Taxes and Budgeting
description: MR. BLOOMBERG -- He has ruled out any tax increases, even in the face of steeply declining city revenues. It is too easy for citizens and companies, faced with higher taxes, to leave New York, he says.

title: The Meal Must Go On...
description: It feels like a century ago. On Sept. 10, we were still organizing a mix of scenarios for this issue. With our standard volubility, we were debating which stories might interest and amuse. Then the world changed -- and not with a whimper, Mr. Eliot, not with a whimper at all.

title: The Novelist in Spite of Herself
description: FANNY BURNEY

title: What Would John Philips Sousa Have Done?
description: WHEN the Frank Scott Bunnell High School Marching Band and Guard of Stratford was chosen last year as one of a dozen high school bands to play at the 2002 Tournament of Roses Parade in Pasadena, Calif., on New Year's Day, it was a dream come true for the band leader, James Miller, and many of the 120 band members.

title: Stagnant Wages
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLLANDER, BERTRAM
description: HOLLANDER-Bertram. Attorney, 93. Native of New York. Died October 24, 2001. Beloved husband of Edith for 62 years. Loving father of Michael and father-in-law of Clare. Brother of the late Helen Fink and his twin brother Edward who died at the age of three days. Also survived by numerous nieces and nephews. Graduate of the University of Pennsylvania. Forever in our hearts.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-4-01: The Ethicist; Get a Leash
description: My 80-pound unneutered (male) dog and I frequent a park where we often see a 90-pound unspayed female. The two basically ignore each other except when the female is in heat. At those times, I do my utmost to keep my dog away from the female, but her owner gives her total freedom, off-leash and running around. It drives my dog crazy! Who is acting irresponsibly? Can you suggest a solution? A.L. H., New York City

title: Disaster Gives a Boost to Island Tourism
description: EVERY October for the last 11 years, Pamela Ross and her husband, Maurice, of Baldwin have headed north to upstate New York or to Massachusetts to take in the fall foliage. But this year the couple made a two-hour trip east to Montauk instead.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FITZGERALD, THOMAS MAURICE JR.
description: FITZGERALD-Thomas Maurice Jr. Born April 23, 1928 to Dr. and Mrs. Thomas M. Fitzgerald of Brooklyn, NY, he was a graduate of Brooklyn Preparatory School and the College fo Arts and Sciences of Georgetown University. Following combat service as an artillery officer with the 2nd U.S. Infantry Division in the Korean War and marriage to the former Katharine H. Bigelow of La Canada, CA on January 9, 1954, he joined The First National Bank of Boston. Mr. Fitzgerald played a leading role in the formation and development of the 25 nation International Factors Group, the world's first network of bank sponsored companies dedicated to international trade credit management. He served as the Group's first President from 1967-72 and as a director of member companies in Canada, England, Ireland, Italy and Switzerland. In 1975, he joined Citicorp Business Credit as Senior Vice President and subsequently served as worldwide International Factoring Product Manager for Citibank, NA. In 1981, he joined Manufacturer's Hanover Commercial Corporation (later merged into the CIT Group) to establish an international factoring department with offices in Hong Kong, Milan and New York. He retired from CIT in 1992 as Senior Vice President International. The Fitzgerald's raised their family in Wellesley Hills, MA and Larchmont, NY. Mrs. Fitzgerald predeceased her husband in July 1996. Mr. Fitzgerald was decorated for service as banking advisor to the Controller of the Army and retired from the Army Reserve with the rank of Colonel. He was a past President of the Georgetown Club of New York, Fund Agent for the Class of 1950 and a member of the Board of Governors of the Georgetown Alumni Association. In 1992 he received the John Carroll medal, Georgetown's highest alumni award. He was a past Director of the University Club of Larchmont; a member of the Finance Committee of St. Augustine's Church and a member of the Larchmont Yale Club. He is survived by his sons: Thomas M. Fitzgerald, III, James B. Fitzgerald and Geoffrey B. Fitzgerald, all of Manhattan, a daughter, Katharine D. Fitzgerald of Oakland, CA, a sister Elizabeth F. Mohan of Rockville MD, a brother Richard V. Fitzgerald of Washington, DC and six grandchildren. Reposing Fox Funeral Home, 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont, Tuesday 7-9PM. Funeral Mass: St. Augustine's Church, Larchmont, NY, Wednesday 10AM. Burial: Arlington National Cemetery.

title: Miss Rafferty Wore Taffeta
description: And the meal was pure poetry.Who better to portray an evening excess of meat and sweets and libations galore than a troupe of talented young dancers who treat their bodies like a temple? Besides their talented imaginings, they also recover faster. We don't advise that you try this feat at home, but we do recommend ''The Pocket Book of Ogden Nash'' (Washington Square Press) -- read aloud -- and these recipes, perfect for the preholiday season, prepared by the private caterer Hank Tomashevski. Jarret McNeill

title: Standing Tall as a Cheerleader for Judaism
description: RUNNING a synagogue is like a multiplex cinema, said Rabbi Charles Klein, spiritual leader of the Merrick Jewish Center, Instead of movies, he said, a ''synaplex'' needs to offer more than a main prayer service.

title: The War on Civilians
description: To the Editor:

title: The Next Front: Our Driveways?
description: To the Editor:

title: Among Voters' Ballot Choices, Balancing the 'Hes' With 'Shes'
description: On Tuesday, when voters finally confront what elections officials have called a ''busy'' ballot, they will find among the many candidates a group of five City Charter revision proposals, and a proposal to make the language of the State Constitution gender-neutral.

title: Set for Life
description: In the last few years, Russel Wright's sleek, curvaceous midcentury dinnerware has gone from your mother's white elephant to an eBay must-have. But few Wright fanatics born after the 1950's realize that he wasn't just about plates and pitchers. Six decades before Martha Stewart sold towels at Kmart, Wright was this country's first lifestyle guru. He campaigned for modern design as an expression of the new, informal American way of life ''derived from democratic ideals''; railed against European cultural snobbery and ruffled bed skirts; and not only designed furniture and tabletop lines, but also told consumers exactly how to use them. And in the process, he turned himself into a brand name.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-26

title: Homer's Odyssey
description: There's a scene from ''The Simpsons'' that has been looping inside my brain since Sept. 11. It comes from ''The City of New York vs. Homer Simpson,'' a four-year-old episode of the Fox show. During a family trip to Manhattan, Homer finds himself on a cartoon version of the plaza between the twin towers of the World Trade Center. There, waiting for a traffic officer to remove the boot from his pink family sedan (while his family is taking in a Broadway musical about the Betty Ford Center), Homer meets a vendor selling an exotic delicacy called Khlav Kalash. He buys some, washing it down with many cans of crab juice. When all that crab juice takes its inevitable toll, Homer runs up 107 flights of stairs, only to discover that the men's room in Tower 2 is out of order. But that's not the only surprise: Tenement-style clotheslines are strung between the two skyscrapers, and the windows open to reveal surly New Yorkers yelling at each other to shut up.

title: Catching the Retreating Sun for Fresh Greens
description: ALIGHT frost has turned most of my vegetable garden to brown vines, but the collards and mustard greens love the cool weather. It's satisfying work, pulling up the old tomato and bean vines, and raking in winter rye seed, so that this green manure, or cover crop, will enrich and lighten the soil.

title: The Man Who Mainstreamed Mahler
description: MUSICOLOGISTS of the future may well term the 1960's the decade of the Beatles and Gustav Mahler: the remarkable, unexpected flowering of Liverpudlian lyricism and the re-emergence, at the centenary of his birth, of a composer many critics saw only as a relic of a vanished Vienna. No one understood this historical moment more fully, more passionately and, some might say, more opportunistically than Leonard Bernstein. Sony Classical's new remastered, repackaged bargain-price edition of Bernstein's first recordings of the complete Mahler symphonies, originally made for Columbia, takes listeners back to those days, when the release of the ''White Album'' and that of Mahler's Seventh Symphony were equally revelatory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLACKMAN, MURRAY, RABBI
description: BLACKMAN-Murray, Rabbi. Rabbi Emeritus of Temple Sinai, New Orleans, LA on October 30, 2001. Loving husband of Martha Mecklenburger, dear father of Michael S. Blackman, Peggy Blackman and Barbara Blackman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRANZ, ANNA
description: KRANZ-Anna. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Anna Kranz, associated with The Times from 1955 until retiring in 1976.

title: Corrections
description: The review on Page 24 of the Book Review today misstates a word in the book title. It is ''The Cult of the Nation in France,'' not ''of France.''

title: After a Fire, Young and Cashless Can Still Store Their Stuff
description: Jessica Weinstein, a 26-year-old office worker for a labor union, does not own furniture from any one of the 46 Gothic Cabinet Craft stores in and around the city. But that doesn't mean she doesn't come across it all the time. ''You can't escape it,'' she said. ''All of my friends own it.''

title: Postings: 526 Rental Apartments Come on the Market; Hoboken Riverfront Project
description: Tenants are moving into the latest, and largest, residential building in Hoboken, a project with 526 rental units on the southern waterfront, across the Hudson River from Manhattan.

title: Two Bishops, More Space And a Matter of Technique
description: The sixth Governor's Cup, held Sept. 21-23 in Sioux Falls, S.D., ended in a tie between the grandmasters Yuri Shulman of Belarus and Alexander Wojtkiewicz of Poland. Each scored 4 1/2- 1/2 in the 244-entrant Swiss-system tournament sponsored by the Sioux Empire Chess Foundation.

title: In Fairfield County, The Play's the Thing
description: To the Editor:

title: Business; Lloyd's Says It Can Pay, But Officials Seek Proof
description: FOR centuries, Lloyd's of London, which began doing business insuring ship cargo in a dockside coffee house in 1688, has been the very symbol of insurance. It has expanded exponentially to insure the most dangerous and most precious of things, from North Sea oil rigs to Betty Grable's legs to Mick Jagger's voice. And it has always paid its claims.

title: Gretchen Rorick, Vergel Cervantes
description: Gretchen Adams Rorick, the daughter of Ann Adams Rorick of Old Lyme, Conn., and Richard Packard Rorick of Litchfield, Conn., was married yesterday to Vergel Hao Cervantes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Virgilio Cervantes of Manila. The Rev. William T. Pickering performed the ceremony at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in New Canaan, Conn., with the Rev. Vicente Magdaraog, a Roman Catholic priest, taking part.

title: Giuliani Is the Leader of a Special Fan Club
description: PHOENIX, Nov. 3  Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani led a group of 25 family members of victims of the Sept. 11 attacks to see the end of the World Series. Giuliani and the families flew a donated Continental charter flight from La Guardia Airport to Phoenix. Giuliani sat in a field box at Bank One Ballpark and the families were guests of Major League Baseball in its hospitality suite.

title: 'Uncle Tungsten: Memories of a Chemical Boyhood'
description: Many of my childhood memories are of metals: these seemed to exert a power on me from the start. They stood out, conspicuous against the heterogeneousness of the world, by their shining, gleaming quality, their silveriness, their smoothness and weight. They seemed cool to the touch, and they rang when they were struck.

title: Fox Bringing Back First-Down Line
description: Fox Sports, which cited the need to cut costs when it eliminated the electronic first-down line on its football broadcasts in late September, will bring it back today.

title: Commercial Property/Retail Leasing; At a Rockefeller Store, It's All Pokmon, All the Time
description: BUGS BUNNY is leaving town and Mickey Mouse has retreated from Times Square. But that's O.K.; Pikachu is moving into Rockefeller Center.

title: For a Perfectionist, a Posthumous Promotion
description: Having arrived at Skidmore, Owings & Merrill only last year, Arkady Zaltsman was heading quickly toward a promotion.

title: An Even Merrier Season Next Year
description: FEW of this year's holiday films are actually holiday films. But for those who can wait, 2002 promises a sackful of seasonal delights.

title: Devils Don't Make Most of Power Plays, but Bruins Do
description: The Devils had two glorious opportunities to extend their six-game winning streak today but they were denied by their power-play ineptitude.

title: Moving Back With Parents
description: To the Editor:

title: And Bear In Mind
description: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

title: Post-Victoriana
description: FALLING ANGELS

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: EVERYONE in Curtis Hanson's WONDER BOYS (2000) is at least a little quirky. Grady Tripp (Michael Douglas), a pot-smoking college writing teacher, is on page 2,611 of a novel he'll never finish. He has a pregnant mistress (Frances McDormand), whose husband (Richard Thomas) owns the fur-collared jacket that Marilyn Monroe wore at her wedding to Joe DiMaggio. He has a gloomy best student (Tobey Maguire) who feels compelled to steal the jacket. And he has an agent (Robert Downey Jr.) who picks up transvestites on airplanes. Not everyone likes this film, based on Michael Chabon's novel about one intense, snowy weekend in academia. Paramount released it twice, stunned that it hadn't done better the first time. But it has a real charm, and it's fun to see Mr. Douglas playing low-key. Very low-key -- Saturday at 8 p.m. on Showtime.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORNREICH, JOANNE
description: KORNREICH-JoAnne. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University records with profound sorrow the passing of the beloved wife of Morton Kornreich, the cherished mother of Thomas and Barbara Kornreich, loving sister-in-law of Susanne & Matthew Kornreich, and adored aunt of Kathy and Samuel Weinberg. The Kornreich family has participated greatly in the growth and development of our institution as members of our Board of Overseers and Society of Founders, and as leaders in our National Women's Division and our Men's Division. To the entire family, we offer our heartfelt condolences. Yeshiva University Dr. Norman Lamm, President Albert Einstein College of Medicine Robert A. Belfer, Chairperson Board of Overseers Dominick P. Purpura, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean

title: Half Empty and Half Full
description: KEVIN ZRALY faced the 150 people who filled the room.

title: Paying the Price For Active Duty
description: To the Editor:

title: Nicaragua to Decide Fate of Ortega's New-Age Candidacy
description: Throughout Daniel Ortega's third campaign to return to the Nicaraguan presidency, the slogan ''love is stronger than hate'' has been his New Age mantra. The question for Nicaraguans going to the polls on Sunday, however, is whether it is stronger than their memories.

title: O'Neill Ovations Still Echo
description: Two days after Paul O'Neill played his final game at Yankee Stadium, Manager Joe Torre was still impressed with the ovations the fans gave O'Neill. O'Neill heard chants throughout the game as fans thanked him for nine years of loyal service in right field with the Yankees.

title: Flash in the Pan
description: THE GODFATHER

title: The Next Front: Our Driveways?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUMNER, JANET
description: SUMNER-Janet. The Directors and members of the Washington Square Outdoor Art Exhibit note the passing of its firm supporter and Executive Director, 1968-82.

title: What to Tell a Child; Taking Account Of a 'Hidden Life'
description: To the Editor:

title: A Long Shot vs. the Machine in Suffolk Sheriff Race
description: AT a recent meet-the-candidates night for the local AARP in Northport, Felicia Collins emerged from behind a table lined with office-seekers, shunned the microphone that was being passed around and marched confidently in front of the audience.

title: . . . and Students Go on Assignment, Dollars in Hand
description: Gay Snodgrass, a professor at New York University, wanted to help the local economy recover after the Sept. 11 attacks, but she thought that spending the money herself would be overindulgent. So when her husband suggested that she turn her psychology students into designated shoppers, she fell in love with the idea, and so did her N.Y.U. colleague Ted Coons.

title: The Defectors
description: As the light fades and shadows lengthen, a half-dozen fighters from the Northern Alliance scurry along a shallow trench in their forward post, at the farthest reaches of their forces' territory. A Taliban machine gun spits fire at Northern Alliance positions to the west; a lone tank fires back. Ahead, abutting the no-man's-land between enemy lines, lies the six men's destination, a ruined farmhouse.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FEIRSTEIN, ABRAHAM
description: FEIRSTEIN - Abraham. Gone eighteen years, but never forgotten. Love from the whole family. Edna

title: An Eames Math Exhibition; The Concorde Flies Again
description: Math Exhibition Finds Common Denominators

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEDERSEN, CHARLES RICHARD
description: PEDERSEN-Charles Richard, 78. On October 26, 2001. Husband, father, grandfather. Born and raised in Havre, Montana, Dick was a Captain in the U.S. Army, serving in Europe in WWII. He later attended Harvard Law School on an academic scholarship. A member of the law firm Dewey, Ballantine, Bushby, Palmer and Wood, he was the Senior Vice President & General Counsel at American Can Company/Primerica until his retirement in 1988. He is survived by his wife Muriel, his children Richard, Kirk, Lloyd, Suni and Kari, and his eleven grandchildren. An avid traveler and dedicated supporter of animal conservation efforts, he loved a good martini, a good cigar, and good jazz. His humor, wisdom and guidance will be sorely missed. Services will be held at St. Stephen's Church in Ridgefield, Connecticut on Saturday, November 10, at 4 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his name to the Wildlife Conservation Society, C/O Mary Beth Gaffney, The Bronx Zoo, Bronx, New York 10460.

title: Stephanie Bransfield, Sanford Keys
description: Stephanie Christina Bransfield, a daughter of Christina and John R. Bransfield of East Williston, N.Y., was married yesterday to Sanford Hardeman Keys, a son of Martha and Ben Geer Keys of Greenville, S.C. Msgr. Thomas Hartman performed the ceremony at St. Aidan's Roman Catholic Church in Williston Park, N.Y.

title: Marked Bills for Patriotic Purchases
description: A New York-based artist is putting the tools of capitalism to double use -- combating fear as well as recession -- by putting his mouth where his money is. The artist, David Greg Harth, has been stamping United States paper currency with one of two phrases, ''I am not afraid'' or ''I am not terrorized.'' The bills are then put back into circulation in the time-honored way with the goal of providing subliminal comfort to skittish consumers.

title: Is That a Welcome Mat?
description: BRENDEN P. LEYDON, the lawyer who sued Greenwich over its beach rules and won in the Connecticut Supreme Court in July, considered and discarded an idea to hold a party at Greenwich Point after the ruling to allow outsiders there took effect on Sept. 13.

title: Martinez Helps His School
description: Even though Tino Martinez graduated from Jefferson High School in Tampa, Fla., in 1985, he has remained in close contact with the school. The field is named after Tino's father, Rene, and the clubhouse is named after Tino.

title: Against Love
description: Brava to Laura Kipnis for her intelligent examination of modern society's infatuation with the delusional notion of ''happily ever after.'' The demise of my 28-year marriage forced me to examine the institution itself. The conclusion I arrived at is that 50 percent of marriages fail because there is something inherently wrong with our notion of wedded union.

title: Ideas & Trends: Under the Tent; The Coalition Is Broad. But Can It Hold?
description: YOU could almost see Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld squirm. Someone had asked him whether the United States would consider halting the bombing of Afghanistan during the Ramadan holiday out of concern for Islamic religious sensitivities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REINSCHREIBER, SYLVIA ELIAS
description: REINSCHREIBER-Sylvia Elias. On Friday, November 2, of Riverdale, NY. Beloved wife of the late Seymour. Devoted mother of Amy (Jerel) Zoltick and Laurie (Ron) Weinreich. Also survived by two cherished sisters and one brother. Loving nanna of seven grandchildren. Services Sunday, November 4, 12:30 PM at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: A Corporation to Rebuild Ground Zero
description: Gov. George Pataki and Mayor Rudolph Giuliani yesterday announced a welcome agreement to create a city-state authority to begin rebuilding Lower Manhattan. The Lower Manhattan Redevelopment Corporation, as it will be called, is desperately needed and the structure the two men settled on is smart. It gives the governor control and the city a significant voice. It is also similar to entities the state has used successfully on earlier projects like the revitalization of Times Square.

title: Cole Porter With Joy And Glee
description: TRUE believers dream on, wishing for a renaissance of the American musical, our theater's indigenous art form. At the least, they look forward to revivals.

title: Walsh Sees Dark Side Of Salary Cap's Impact
description: The Hall of Famer Bill Walsh was asked if he had seen an N.F.L. season like this one, which is so topsy-turvy that the Super Bowl champions are struggling and the Cleveland Browns are hot.

title: A Fantastical Plot Made Real Over Time
description: EVEN before the premiere of the new Fox action series ''24,'' the advance word had been so promising that the show's creators were swept up in the hype. Would the show live up to expectations? A nervous Joel Surnow, co-creator of ''24,'' said, ''Well, I'd rather people say good things about the show than the alternative.''

title: Islanders Hold Off Aggressive Flyers
description: The Philadelphia Flyers were not merely beating the Islanders tonight. The Flyers were also beating them up. The Islanders were being pounded, punched and punished, and this looked like the night they would finally crumble.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-4-01; United Nations
description: In crises, some things clarify. I grew up for 20 years in Britain, and I'm now closing in on 20 years of adulthood in the United States. It's funny how feelings of identity arc in such a life. I remember the first time I got a lump in my throat singing ''The Star-Spangled Banner,'' on July 4 about 10 years ago. It took me completely by surprise. My attachment to my new country had taken shape and form without my even knowing it, until I found myself tearing up in a routine ritual of patriotism. It wasn't that I had left my love of homeland behind. But it was now refracted through the prism of my new love -- a love that is foolish to inspect because it belongs somewhere in the heart where reason doesn't follow.

title: Finding Shelter After the Storm
description: ON the nascent downtown architectural scene, Mancini Duffy were literally veterans. Not only had they been among the first to settle in Lower Manhattan, but with offices in the World Trade Center, they survived the 1993 attack and learned several lessons.

title: The Next Front: Our Driveways?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISBERG, ZIPPORAH
description: WEISBERG-Zipporah. We mourn the passing of the mother of our esteemed member, Dr. Joseph Weisberg, & pray that the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Young Israel of Great Neck Yaacov Lerner, Rabbi Michael Frank, President

title: Incredible, But True: Rangers Rally Late
description: Facing the prospect of defeat with time running out, the Rangers put one of their most stirring touches to a thus-far-forgettable early season.

title: Elizabeth Arden Red Door Salon To Open in White Plains
description: In time for the holiday season, Elizabeth Arden's Red Door Salon and Spa will open at the Westchester mall in White Plains on Nov. 12.

title: International Datebook: Dec. 6 to 23
description: DEC. 6, DEMRE (NEAR ANTALYA), TURKEY

title: Airport to Get Financing
description: THE Federal Aviation Administration signed an agreement last week giving Westchester $10 million for safety and security improvements at the county airport. The grant was contingent upon the county's agreement to place fees collected from airlines that break a voluntary overnight curfew in an escrow account.

title: Aliza Brooks, Joshua Bloomstein
description: Aliza Raquelle Brooks and Joshua Michael Bloomstein were married last evening by Rabbi Jerry Cutler at the Beverly Hills Hotel in California.

title: The World; Allure Must Be Covered. Individuality Peeks Through.
description: WHETHER they call it ''observing purdah'' or ''hijab,'' the meaning is the same: a traditional Muslim woman's obligation to hide her physical beauty from men to whom she is not related. But there are many interpretations of what is required among the Afghan refugees now living in Pakistan.

title: Ideas & Trends: High vs. Low; Seizing the Literary Middle
description: JONATHAN Franzen, whose new novel, ''The Corrections,'' is a best seller, recently got into some trouble for being less than overjoyed at his book's selection by Oprah Winfrey for her on-air book club. ''I feel like I'm solidly in the high-art literary tradition,'' he asserted in one of a series of interviews that resulted in his disinvitation from Ms. Winfrey's talk show and inspired an orgy of populist finger-wagging.

title: The Close Reader; Barbarians Inside the Gates
description: Now is not the moment to glorify violence. On the other hand, when Martin Scorsese puts off the release of a long-awaited new movie, you can't help dwelling for a moment on the forbidden spectacle implied by such self-censorship. A clue to ''Gangs of New York,'' a film Scorsese has been working on intermittently since the mid-1970's, is the book it's based on -- Herbert Asbury's 1927 cult classic, ''The Gangs of New York: An Informal History of the Underworld,'' which has just been reissued in paperback with a foreword adapted from a story by Jorge Luis Borges.

title: Art Listings
description: Museums/Institutions

title: Tourism Industry Pins Hopes on Heritage and Culture
description: Joan and Allan Stanford considered lying on the beach or relaxing in the mountains, but with a war going on, a self-indulgent pleasure just seemed inappropriate. They wanted to travel, did not want to fly.

title: Travel Advisory
description: The designing couple Charles and Ray Eames brought a sense of play to everything they did.

title: Oct. 28-Nov. 3; Candidates Debate in Spanish
description: A mayoral debate in New York left little doubt how much the voting population is changing: for the first time ever, it was conducted in Spanish. For 90 minutes, Mark Green, the Democrat, and Michael Bloomberg, the Republican, donned ear pieces and fielded questions. The event, sponsored by El Diario, the Spanish-language New York newspaper, was broadcast over Spanish-language radio and television. But both candidates, as well as most of their immediate audience, were English-speakers, so the questions as well as the answers had to be translated into Spanish. Polls now show the candidates to be neck and neck. Adam Nagourney

title: A Hug for the Mayor
description: Tom Pettitte, whose son, Andy, started Game 6 tonight, said Andy was not the only one in the family to realize a dream when he was named the most valuable player of the American League Championship Series. Tom visited his son in the clubhouse after the game and then brought his wife, Joann, into the dugout for the first time. That is where Tom ran into Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Militancy; Living in a World Without Women
description: IN the war of militant Islam against the infidel West, there is a chilling paradox. Nowhere not on protesters' banners, pre-suicide videos or posters of the most wanted is there a woman's face. These martyrs and radicals call themselves the purifiers of society and the saviors of the poor, yet everything the world has learned in the last decade about why some countries develop and others stay mired in poverty shows that women can make all the difference.

title: As Grief Sets In, More Seek Help
description: PATRICIA DONOVAN-DUFF was preparing for work on Sept. 11 when, on television, she saw the planes hit the World Trade Center.

title: Have the Terrorist Attacks Made America More Conformist?
description: Almost all readers agreed that America had become more unified/conformist since September 11 but whether or not that is a good thing was the main point of contention.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEGELYS, NICHOLAS
description: GEGELYS-Nicholas. Of Fort Lee, NJ. Sales manager for Wood America, Miami, FL, suddenly on November 2, 2001. Beloved son of Elsie Gegelys. Loving brother of Anthony Gegelys and Mary Gegelys. Dear brother-in-law of Helen Gegelys. A close companion of Marin Rosato. Fond nephew and Godson of Alex Pappas. Cherished uncle of Chris and Ann Gegelys and Sofia and Anthony Scola. Reposing Basis Funeral Home, 27-12 23rd Avenue, Astoria, NY, Monday and Tuesday 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. Funeral Liturgy, Wednesday, St. Demetrios G.O. Cathedral, Astoria, NY, 12 noon.

title: Footlights; From Temple to Coffeehouse
description: It's a temple. It's a coffeehouse. It's the Woodlands Coffee House of the Woodlands Community Temple in White Plains. Cantor Jonathan Gordon, who oversees the building's transformation six times a year, said the temple becomes ''the Greenwich Village coffeehouse you always wished for -- not smoky but really intimate.''

title: Love in the 21st Century
description: I love that you chose to photograph Debbie, a lesbian, and Chris, who is transgendered, for the cover, with the headline ''How the American Couple Has Changed.'' I hope that you'll receive many letters commending the possibilities, the complexities, the freedom, inherent in those changes. After Sept. 11, there may no longer be any Americans who can claim never to have felt hated. Perhaps now we will all be more tolerant about love.

title: The Rugby Mystique
description: IN a sweet-as-you-please breeze, candy-colored leaves kissed gently on their way to the ground. With that as a backdrop, 48 women got ready to grapple, wrestle, rip, tear and tackle one another.

title: Catching the Retreating Sun for Fresh Greens
description: A LIGHT frost has turned most of my vegetable garden to brown vines, but the collards and mustard greens love the cool weather. It's satisfying work, pulling up the old tomato and bean vines, and raking in winter rye seed, so that this green manure, or cover crop, will enrich and lighten the soil.

title: A Festival of Sights and Sounds
description: THE Stamford Center of the Arts is in the midst of a six-month arts festival called ''Revealed.'' It is designed, according to the center's executive director, George Moredock, ''to feature music, dance, theater, visual arts, film and more as a means of exploring the artistic, political and sociological implications of a single theme.''

title: Love in the 21st Century
description: The interviews of couples in your issue included four photos of each couple, the last showing them kissing. Except for one: the gay couple. You showed the interracial couples kissing. Why not the gay couple?

title: Program Aims to Promote Food Allergy Awareness
description: WHEN Brenda Resnick Spano, the county executive's wife, made a trip to the Westchester Medical Center emergency room recently after she ate something that set off a serious allergic response, she personified the plight of some four million Americans whose life-threatening food allergies can make dining out a risky venture.

title: East Villagers Pull Out Their Magenta Hair Over Cooper Union's Expansion Plans
description: East Village residents say they might as well live in Midtown if Cooper Union has its way and develops a bigger campus.

title: How Time Goes By on West 43d Street
description: JAAWANI ABDU was once a handsome man. His face was wholesome and his gait vigorous until he began working at the parking garage.

title: What to Tell a Child; Reappearance of Grocery Should Be an Inspiration
description: To the Editor,

title: Taking on Another War, Against Mixed Messages
description: At the end of his roughest week so far in the war at home and abroad, President Bush had some sharp words for those who complain that the Pentagon's best-case scenarios for Afghanistan have evaporated, and that the war at home has descended into muddled, often contradictory messages about anthrax and other new terrors.

title: Name Your Favorite 'Simpsons' Character
description: Homer ran away with the balloting in this week's survey. Many identified with his personality traits while others just felt that everything he said was funny. Homer's daughter Lisa came in second. Readers identified with her because of perceived similar academic and familial experiences in childhood.

title: Harvard Defeats Columbia And Keeps Pace With Penn
description: The Harvard Crimson scored on all six of its first-half possessions, intercepted three passes and held on to defeat Columbia, 45-33, yesterday at Wien Stadium.

title: Against Love
description: Just because Laura Kipnis is against long-term couplehood, I would not presume to call her ''immature'' or ''unable to settle down.'' She suffers, instead, from the intellectual pathology of Foucaultism: the inability, having deconstructed social arrangements into power structures, to come up with practical alternatives.

title: Hoping That Children Won't Feel Her Pain
description: ANNE HAINSWORTH, on a mission to help the state's schoolchildren use computers safely, operates the old-fashioned way. Her desk is a coffee table in the living room. She keeps paper files in an antique bureau, does research at the library and makes contact by phone calls or visits.

title: Voices From a Place on the Verge
description: ONLY yesterday, or so it seems, the meatpacking district on the far West Side of Manhattan was the hottest place in the city. Restaurants, nightspots and expensive retailers were sprouting with a vengeance among the wholesale meat houses. By late summer, even as the economy sagged, the cluster of blocks south of 14th Street and west of Ninth Avenue seemed destined to become a second SoHo.

title: In a Suffering City, Charity Endures; The Times Neediest Cases Fund Helps a Man Who Has No Home
description: Robert Tucker hunched forward, his cheek resting on the side of a nearly deserted subway car. His body bumped up and down with the movements of a Manhattan-bound E train as it thundered through the tunnel under Queens Boulevard at 3 a.m.

title: 'The Godfather of Silicon Valley'
description: The Nasdaq was far from the top of its historic ascent the first time I heard Ron Conway's name. The locale was San Francisco, inside a Mission District cafe whose purveyor had only recently shared with me a stock tip. The particular Internet stock he mentioned didn't seem nearly as significant as the fact that he was whispering a stock at all. The moment called to mind Joe Kennedy's famous quip that he knew it was time to get out of the market when his shoeshine boy started giving him investment advice. In today's San Francisco the equivalent is the barista in a coffee bar sharing intelligence he overhears while jerking lattes.

title: What to Tell a Child
description: To the Editor:

title: A NATION CHALLENGED
description: C.I.A. Office Was Destroyed

title: Comfort Shopping, Premium Pricing
description: FASHION-CONSCIOUS shoppers, distracted more by economic and political concerns than by the latest Prada tote, are shunning luxury goods. Purveyors of opulent wares are bracing for a lean Christmas. In Susie Hilfiger's opinion, that means it's a perfect time to sell $540 cashmere bunting bags for babies.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption Oct. 7 with an article about astronomy groups misidentified the speaker at a meeting of the Westport Astronomical Society. He was Carl Lancaster, not Bob Meadows, the society's vice president.

title: Suddenly, Love in a Hurry
description: DAIL METZGER, who runs a Connecticut and Westchester matchmaking service, says that in a post-Sept. 11 world, people are looking for love. Not only did calls from her clients double after the terrorist attacks, but also Ms. Metzger herself is re-examining a longtime platonic friendship for romantic possibilities.

title: A Way to Catch Up On Retirement Savings
description: You may not feel so nifty at 50, and beyond, if you have not been making regular contributions to a retirement savings plan. There may still be time to build up the account, even though retirement is just a few years away.

title: Fighting the Suits
description: To the Editor:

title: Seeing the Causes Of Resentment
description: To the Editor:

title: Marathon Winners Set Records
description: Tesfaye Jifar, a 25-year-old Ethiopian, had never won a marathon. Margaret Okayo, a 25-year-old Kenyan, had won only two: this year and last in the Rock 'n' Roll Marathon in San Diego.

title: Guns Won't Win the Afghan War
description: Neither the current bombing campaign nor the deployment of American ground forces to Afghanistan offers good military options for dealing with the Taliban and Al Qaeda. A better approach would emphasize ground-level diplomacy, with open wallets, among Pashtun leaders in central and southern Afghanistan, the fullest use of Pakistani intelligence and influence, and selective military actions. The moment for dramatic demonstration of American military power has passed. Our resolve must now be expressed through many careful steps, or we will never achieve the victory we seek against Al Qaeda.

title: MANNERS; Engine Company
description: On Sept. 19, my husband, John, and I had several remarkable house guests: seven firefighters from Gary, Ind. A few days earlier, these men had pooled their money, rented a van and driven halfway across the country to help out in a city they had seen only in the movies. Within 20 minutes of arriving in New York, they were on the bucket brigade at ground zero at the site of the World Trade Center attacks. Gary's Rescue Squad 2, known as the Dogs of War, are experts at rescues in confined spaces. They are firemen's firemen. After their first 12-hour shift, they ate cheeseburgers at Bar Odeon (which, like many restaurants in the neighborhood, was feeding rescue workers for free) and, using their helmets as pillows, stretched out and fell asleep on the West Broadway sidewalk.

title: A Woman's Reconstruction
description: Isabel Allende makes it look easy. Her new novel, PORTRAIT IN SEPIA (HarperCollins, $26), which has been elegantly translated by Margaret Sayers Peden, smoothly transports readers from opulently appointed mansions to a back-alley opium den in San Francisco's Chinatown to a squalid field hospital during Chile's invasion of Peru in the War of the Pacific. Our tour guide is a photographer named Aurora del Valle, who tells the story of her life as she reconstructs it with the help of old pictures and family gossip. She learns that her mother died during childbirth and that she was only 5 when sent to live with her paternal grandmother, one of many bigger-than-life women who would instill a sense of independence in her despite the inchoate feminism of 19th-century South America. (Her maternal grandmother figured prominently in Allende's previous novel ''Daughter of Fortune.'') As Aurora slowly uncovers the tales of her family's sordid past, we witness her own unhappy marriage and eventual self-discovery. Allende doesn't probe the inner life of every character to its deepest layer, but she musters enough grace and poise to give us complex histories in the simplest lines. It adds up to a book about transformation -- of people and nations and of the rights of women. Andrew Ervin

title: Here a Bid, There a Bid
description: Those looking to go back to the soil -- or to get there for the first time -- can bid on eight moderately priced ''preserved'' farms at an auction next month and in December. The State Agriculture Development Committee, part of the Agriculture Department, is holding the auctions. The committee works to preserve farms by buying some that are on the market and reselling them with a deed permanently preserving the land for agriculture. The farms that will be auctioned off are in Burlington, Monmouth, Mercer, Hunterdon and Warren Counties. The first, to be auctioned Friday, will be the 43-acre former Hunt farm in Hamilton, Mercer County, with bidding starting at $150,000. The former Fisher farm, 82 acres in Delaware Township, goes on the block Dec. 7, with bidding starting at $540,000. Potential buyers will be given a tour of the farms. Information: (800) 474-5314. Margo Nash

title: Gaining New Fans . . .
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Radical Imagination
description: WHERE THE STRESS FALLS

title: York, Me., Tackles Commercial Demand
description: Year-round residents of bucolic New England towns have a well-founded fear that vacation homes and weekend visitors will slowly change their local economy and culture. They worry that restaurants will force out supermarkets and antiques dealers will displace hardware stores or other shops that offer staple items.

title: What's to Love?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRANBAUGH, ROBERT F., SR.
description: TRANBAUGH-Robert F., Sr. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family joins with the leadership of the hospital's parent company, Continuum Health Partners in acknowledging with sadness the passing of Robert F. Tranbaugh, Sr., beloved father of our dear friend and devoted colleague, Robert F. Tranbaugh, Jr., M.D., Chief of the Division of Cardiac Surgery at Beth Israel. To Bob, his family and all his father's loved ones we extend heartfelt condolences. Morton P. Hyman, Chairman, Boards of Trustees, Continuum and Beth Israel Peter A. Kelly, President and CEO, Continuum Matthew E. Fink. M.D., President and CEO, Beth Israel Sidney K. Stein, M.D. President, Medical Board Thomas Killip, M.D. Director Continuum Heart Institute Richard H. Gemming, Executive Director, Continuum Heart Institute

title: Down Mexico Way
description: The filming of the wedding -- Scene 54 from ''Frida,'' a biopic produced by Miramax Films and Salma Hayek, who also is starring as the artist Frida Kahlo -- may last longer than the marriage.

title: Desperate Trip To Lobby For Grants, Not Loans
description: As pupils returned from their summer break, enrollment at Park Preschool in Lower Manhattan was at its highest in its 12-year history. The neighborhood was growing so fast that Kevin Artale, who owns the private school, was considering opening another one.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORST, BEATRICE (NEE STEIN)
description: FORST-Beatrice (nee Stein). Suddenly on September 29th, 2001. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother and sister. She was as beautiful inside as out.

title: The Next Front: Our Driveways?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Past Is Another Small Town
description: ESTHER STORIES

title: What Do Airlines Deserve?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOLDE, MORRIS
description: GOLDE-Morris. Share happy memories of Morris. Tuesday, November 13th, 6:00 PM, NY Society for Ethical Culture. 2 W 64 St.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, ROSALIND (FRIED)
description: FISHER-Rosalind (Fried) of Delray Beach, FL, died peacefully on November 3, 2001. beloved wife of the late Herbert. Devoted mother of Nancy Englander of New York City and Suzanne Bloomberg of Chestnut Hill, MA. Dear mother in law of Robert Englander and Jeffrey Bloomberg. Adoring grandmother of Adam, Alex, Ben, Drew and Heather. Private graveside service. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the charity of one's choice.

title: Private Sector; The Art of Answering Carefully
description: Robert E. Rubin and Felix G. Rohatyn no longer hold government office, but they cannot comfortably answer every question in public. At a breakfast sponsored by The New Yorker at the 21 Club last week, David Remnick, the magazine's editor, brought together Mr. Rohatyn, who helped rescue New York from its last fiscal crisis, and Mr. Rubin, who, as an adviser to Mark Green, the Democratic candidate for mayor, could help lead a future rescue.

title: Travel Advisory; Bucking the Trend, Concordes Fly Again
description: Amid the disruptions and cancellations in airline service over the last several weeks, one familiar face (more the nose, actually) is coming back: the Concorde. Beginning Wednesday, Air France is scheduled to offer five round trips a week between Kennedy Airport and Charles de Gaulle in Paris on the supersonic craft, and British Airways will have six weekly round trips between New York and Heathrow in London.

title: Dance Listings
description: AILEY II  "How Anansi Learned His Greatest Lesson" and "Revelations." Carnegie Hall, 154 W. 57th St. (212-247-7800) Sat., 2.

title: Ethics Becomes Dominant Theme In Nonpartisan Contest in Atlanta
description: Mayor Bill Campbell cannot seek a third term because of term limits, but he is as much a factor in this year's mayoral race as the three leading candidates.

title: FOOTNOTES
description: Resources, references and the back story behind the story.

title: An Uphill Struggle For an Injured Olympian
description: Drive into the valley that is home to the world's greatest skier. Drive past the dairy cows and the still-closed hotels and the morning mist that clings to the wooded hillsides like cotton candy to a moist finger. Before long, you are at the entrance to the resort town of Flachau and staring at a larger-than-life photograph of a grinning Hermann Maier with his two Olympic gold medals, his two world championship gold medals and his enviable collection of crystal globe trophies from the World Cup circuit.

title: Singled Out
description: To the Editor:

title: Ready for Winter: Planting a Cold Frame
description: A LIGHT frost has turned most of my vegetable garden to brown vines, but the collards and mustard greens love the cool weather. It's satisfying work, pulling up the old tomato and bean vines, and raking in winter rye seed, so that this green manure, or cover crop, will enrich and lighten the soil.

title: New Setting in Scarsdale for Italian Fare
description: MOSCATO can be noisy, especially when the place is full. The buzz bouncing off the high ceiling and gleaming windows is from customers pleased to dine in this pretty new restaurant, one of several run by the Lusardi family, veterans in the business.

title: Building on Success
description: ''One man's success is built on another man's shoulders,'' said Neal Brunson, director of the Afro-American Historical Society Museum, in Jersey City, adding that the museum's new show, ''Blacks in Politics: 1900 to 2000, Hudson County,'' will prove that point.

title: Suffolk Is at Odds Over Tobacco Money
description: A PROPOSAL by Robert J. Gaffney, the Suffolk County executive, to sell the rights to the county's share of the national tobacco settlement -- using the money to pay off debt, hold down property taxes and stave off a $37.7 million budget shortfall next year -- is facing opposition from county legislators who say it all sounds too much like a Nassau County-style scheme.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUGANO, SEAN T.
description: LUGANO-Sean T. Age 28, of Manhattan. Lost in the tragedy of the World Trade Center where he was a trader for Keefe Bruyette and Woods. Loving son of Eileen (nee Duffell) and the late John A. Lugano. Best brother of John, Stephanie, Kristen and Michael. Devoted grandson of Anne M. Duffell and Francis Lugano Haller. Cherished nephew, cousin and friend. Graduate of Xavier High School, '91, Loyola College, Maryland, '95. Outstanding athlete and avid rugby player who played on many national, collegiate and men's teams. Rugby coach for Fairfield University and a leading force on the NYAC rugby team. An entrepreneur, Sean was a partner in Rathbones and Opal, Manhattan east side establishments. A memorial service will be held Friday, November 9, 6 PM, at St. Francis Xavier R.C. Church, 30 W. 16th St, NYC. Donations can be made to the Sean Lugano Scholarship Fund at Xavier High School.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUNIN, GEORGE H.
description: LUNIN-George H. On Tuesday, October 30. Adored husband of Sylvia (Altshuler), and children Barbara-Jane (B-J) & Dov Frishberg of New York City, Dr. Mitchel & Susan Lunin of Newton, MA and Scott & Halli Lunin of New Jersey, and grandchildren Jesse, Sam, Justin, Zachary, Noam, Russell, Avner, Eric, Adam, Sloane and Sabrina. Services were held in Massachusetts on Friday, November 2. The family will be at 600 W. 115th St., Apt. 93 Sunday through Tues. evenings, 6:30PM-10PM, and in Livingston, New Jersey Sun. & Mon. evenings, 6:30PM-10PM. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be made to Habitat for Humanity or a charity of one's choice.

title: D. B. Blanchard, 58, Investment Adviser
description: David B. Blanchard, the chairman of the Clifford Management Group, a financial advisory concern that he founded, and president of Clifford Asset Management, another investment advisory concern, died on Monday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 58 and lived on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.

title: Time for Giving
description: To the Editor:

title: Northwestern Alumni to End Donations if Ex-Radical Stays
description: It was old news. Bernardine Dohrn, formerly head of the radical Weather Underground group and once among the F.B.I.'s most wanted fugitives, is a faculty member at Northwestern University Law School. But her husband's recently released memoir about their days as Weathermen has apparently opened new wounds.

title: Hoping to Preserve the Idyllic Nature of a Place Like Home
description: Harding Park is not quite as pristine as it was half a century ago when Bill Pajer hunted pheasant in nearby fields. But the area, a 231-home neighborhood of winding private ways and converted summer bungalows still reminds many of its Puerto Rican residents of a small town back home, just as former Irish residents used to say it reminded them of their homeland. Other New Yorkers might see a resemblance to the Rockaways or Fire Island. The bottom line is that it reminds everyone of anywhere but the Bronx.

title: Geeks Win
description: GO TO

title: An Unabashed Kisser, a Human Bulldozer and a Steely-Nerved Mother
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: As Election Day Nears, Mayoral Candidates Fire Final Barrages of a Bitter Campaign
description: In an acrid final burst of weekend campaigning to become New York's mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg and Mark Green battled over the support of black and female voters yesterday, reflecting the calculation of both sides that Mr. Green is having trouble nailing down blocks of voters that Democratic candidates normally rely on to win elections in the city.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CAPALDO, LOUIS A.
description: CAPALDO-Louis A. 31 years ago, November 8, 1970 Louis passed away. Memories of love and devotion never die. Always alive in my heart. Susan

title: Oct. 28-Nov. 3; A Ford Heads Ford
description: The last time a Ford ruled the Ford Motor Company, Jimmy Carter was president and ''The Deer Hunter'' was winning Oscars. But last week, William Clay Ford Jr., Ford's chairman, replaced Jacques A. Nasser as chief executive, becoming the first Ford family member to assume operational control of the company in 22 years. Mr. Ford, 44, said his first priority was to refocus on Ford's core business, but also said he was open to mending the bitter rift between Ford and Firestone. Mr. Ford is a great-grandson of the founders of both companies. Danny Hakim

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOGEL, SYLVIA
description: VOGEL-Sylvia. November 1, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Moe Vogel. Loving mother of Howard and Laurence, and mother-in-law to Judith and Anna Lise. Adoring grandmother to Peter, Michael and Carsten. Cherished greatgrandmother to Edward, Charles and Emma. Devoted aunt of Naomi Leeds and Alan Steinberg. Sylvia was a special, caring person who loved and was loved by her husband and all of her family, and she will be missed by everyone who knew her. Service 11:30 AM, Monday, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Initial Offerings Make A Comeback of Sorts
description: After a miserable summer, the market for initial public offerings enjoyed something of a rebound in October.

title: FASHION PLATES; The China Monologue
description: When I was about to be married and was having one of those greedy, frustrated afternoons making the list at the china-and-glass shop, my exasperated mother finally said, ''Darling, you're not marrying an ambassador; you're marrying a journalist.'' I was clutching a salad crescent in the Herend fruit-and-flower pattern -- the version without the bugs, thank you -- and would not let it go.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-4-01: On Language; Eviscerate
description: A word with a fearsome and odious primary meaning has been adopted by our military to describe the effect of our air power on the enemy in Afghanistan.

title: Already Gone
description: To the Editor:

title: Arizona Whips Yanks to Force Game 7
description: There was no dramatic ending tonight. There was no ninth-inning home run, no extra-inning victory and no chance. Instead, a dreary start by the Yankees led to a dreadful finish as the Arizona Diamondbacks won Game 6 of the World Series, 15-2. The Series will be decided in Game 7 here on Sunday night.

title: Oct. 28-Nov. 3; Target-Spotting Technology, Off-the-Shelf
description: Last week, the first scouts of the American special forces finally joined Afghan resistance fighters on the front lines facing the Taliban's army. The Pentagon said that explained the suddenly increased intensity and precision of the strikes by its heavy bombers and fighter jets. But how can a few soldiers have such a strong effect?

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-4-01: Questions for Ryan Adams; America Rocks
description: Q: Your new CD, ''Gold,'' came out just two weeks after the terrorists first attacked, and on the cover you're standing in front of an American flag. What made you pick a flag?

title: The New Hitless Wonders
description: The lasting images of the World Series, with one game to play, are of Derek Jeter and Chuck Knoblauch crossing home plate at the ends of Games 4 and 5, respectively, their faces overwhelmed by joy. Or perhaps Tino Martinez stomping around the bases after hitting his game-tying home run Wednesday, or Scott Brosius with his arms raised after his homer tied Game 5. Or perhaps 15 Arizona Diamondbacks crossing the plate in Game 6.

title: Andra Reeve, Jonathan Rabb
description: Andra Elizabeth Reeve, a casting director, and Jonathan Richard Rabb, a novelist, are to be married today. Rabbi Andrew N. Bachman officiated at Gedney Farm, an inn in New Marlborough, Mass.

title: Alexandra Benis, James Molloy
description: Alexandra Gaynor Benis, the daughter of Michele Claire Lucas of Port Chester, N.Y., and Arthur J. Benis of London, was married yesterday to James Francis Molloy, a son of Dr. John C. Molloy of Brighton, Mass., and the late Mary McCourt Molloy. The Rev. Daniel Chesney Kanter, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at King's Chapel in Boston.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the International Datebook listing on Page 15 of the Travel section today for Art Basel Miami Beach, an art fair on Dec. 13 to 16 in Florida, has become outdated. After the section had gone to press, the event was postponed for a year, to Dec. 5 to 8, 2002.

title: French Have Competition in Trans-Atlantic Race
description: In France, the definition of ''ocean racing'' is far different from the one employed almost everywhere else. For example, in the United States, Australia and Britain -- bastions of offshore sailing -- the three most prominent ocean races are decidedly similar.

title: The Next Front: Our Driveways?
description: To the Editor:

title: Vegan Family Values
description: When you live in a one-room apartment in the farther reaches of the Lower East Side, the secret of entertaining becomes quickly clear.

title: Hold Your Horses
description: AS a horse lover, I thought riding was the only way to go, until I discovered another dimension to my favorite animal. On my first trip to Amsterdam in the 1980's, I saw a parade of enormous black Friesian horses pulling carriages with flickering coach lamps. At a fair in Maine, I saw my first pulling contest. Then one morning I left my Manhattan apartment and bumped into a mule (''Ragtime'' was being filmed around the corner). Draft animals became my next big thing.

title: A Computer Screen For Your Eyes Only
description: IF you use a laptop computer while traveling, other people may be looking over your shoulder. But eShades, which look like a pair of oversized sunglasses, let you switch off the laptop monitor and view sensitive material privately. And to the outside world, you might just look like Joe Cool.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHANZER, BENJAMIN
description: SCHANZER-Benjamin. November 2, 1984. In loving memory of our husband and father. Always remembered and always loved

title: GLOVES FOR TOLL TAKERS
description: New Jersey Turnpike toll collectors are now required to wear rubber gloves to protect against anthrax spores. Edward Gross, executive director of the New Jersey Turnpike Authority said recent infections in the state and false anthrax threats involving money at turnpike toll booths led the agency last week to hand out gloves to 1,300 full- and part-time workers. Gloves are available to Garden State Parkway workers, but are not required. John Holl

title: A Changed New York Is Still Grand
World Series: Game 6
The Floating World
Slide Show: Loving Hands
Scenes From Race Day
Coghlan Leads the Pack in a Different Manner
description: Of all the celebrated runners here for yesterday's New York City Marathon, perhaps the most popular was not even running. Eamonn Coghlan jogs four or five times a week, but the former world indoor record-holder in the mile will turn 49 in two weeks, and his racing career faded soon after he became the first masters runner (40 and older) to run a sub-four-minute mile.

title: Links to the Global Struggle
description: WHAT Sept. 11 destroyed cannot be wholly reconstructed, but the World Wide Web has proved to be useful in providing informational building blocks to help people understand the scope of the tragedy and all that has come after.

title: The Elusive Search for Efficiency
description: IT wasn't so long ago when Delta Air Lines was abuzz with dozens of projects to take advantage of the Internet revolution. It was in a consortium of airlines building an online exchange to buy aircraft parts. It was building a Web site that would allow frequent fliers to book their reward flights and was creating a system to beam flight schedules to Internet-ready cellphones.

title: Settling the Microsoft Case
description: Though sensible, the terms of the settlement agreement put forth by the Justice Department and Microsoft to end their epic antitrust battle will disappoint many. The deal would modify Microsoft's behavior to a lesser degree than its competitors would like. It is a triumph for the company, a violator of the nation's antitrust laws, when compared with the structural remedy, long favored by this page and ordered last year by Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson. That would have broken the company in two, with one entity focused on the Windows operating system and the other on software applications.

title: U.S. MAY GAIN USE OF MORE AIR BASES TO STRIKE TALIBAN
description: Tajikistan and the United States are moving toward an agreement that could lead to American military strikes against the Taliban forces from the territory of that Central Asian republic.

title: Extremists at Home
description: To the Editor:

title: Carrying On Family Name With a Message
description: ''Everybody talks about my father, my father,'' Femi Kuti joshed at Irving Plaza on Saturday night. His father was Fela Anikulapo Kuti, the Nigerian bandleader whose Afro-Beat, a hybrid of funk, jazz and West African rhythms, wielded dance music as a political force and who suffered beatings and imprisonment from the regimes he defied. Like any dutiful son inheriting the family business, Femi Kuti has made his way carefully through a maze of expectations.

title: Hough, Run Over by Her Horse on Friday, Is Champion Two Days Later
description: On Friday night, as Lauren Hough guided Windy City through the final strides of the Welcome Stakes at the National Horse Show, the horse caught a back leg awkwardly, flipping her onto the dirt floor at Madison Square Garden and running over her.

title: Credit Offerings This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and a four-week bill on Tuesday.

title: Reebok Builds Ties To Arnell Agency
description: Reebok International has expanded its relationship with the Arnell Group in New York, part of the Omnicom Group, by naming the agency to handle assignments that had been handled by two other agencies. Spending for 2002 was estimated at as much as $40 million to $60 million.

title: Subdued Patriotism Replaces Glitter as Television Finally Presents Its Emmys
description: A tone of patriotism marked the twice-delayed 53rd Emmy Awards tonight as the NBC series ''The West Wing'' won the best drama award, defeating its main rival, the HBO hit ''The Sopranos,'' for the second year in a row.

title: Team of American Military Personnel Arrives in Rebel Territory in Afghanistan
description: A small team of American military personnel landed in Northern Alliance territory just north of Kabul this afternoon, as thousands of alliance troops mobilized for military exercises here, a senior alliance official said tonight.

title: Mourning Their Loss
description: To the Editor:

title: Last Refuge for an Ego Whose Luck Had Run Out
description: THE DIARIES OF KENNETH TYNAN

title: Machine-Made Links Change the Way Minds Can Work Together
description: MODERN science is accustomed to bigness. In five years, the world's most powerful particle accelerator will be in operation at the CERN physics laboratory outside Geneva. The $4 billion accelerator will give physicists the tools they need to search for scientific prizes like the elusive Higgs boson, a particle believed to be the origin of mass and weight in the universe.

title: Time Finds a New Role for Life In Special Issues and Hardcovers
description: Born in 1936, Life has already died twice: as a weekly in 1972, and as a monthly in May 2000. But although a picture-driven magazine would seem like an anachronism in the Internet age, Time Inc. appears to believe that Life's heart is still beating.

title: Publishers Joust Over Merit Of Terrorist Leader's Words
description: A series of proposals to publish the words and ideas of Osama bin Laden are testing the willingness of book publishers to handle indisputably important but highly objectionable material, reviving a debate that has simmered since Houghton Mifflin published an English-language edition of ''Mein Kampf'' in 1933.
