title: Afghan Exile Turned Reluctant Star
description: Nelofer Pazira was wearing the same embroidered Afghan dress in which she walked the red carpet at the Cannes Film Festival last May. At a strip-mall Starbucks last month near her parents' house in suburban Ottawa, she spoke urgently in accented English, declaring, ''I'm a journalist, not an actress.''

title: A Nation Challenged
description: Securing a Base

title: Rumsfeld Tells India That U.S. Wants to Extend Military Ties
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 5  The United States is committed to building closer military ties with India, an ally in the global campaign against terrorism, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld told India's Defense Minister, George Fernandes, today. The secretary also discussed possible sales of American military equipment to India.

title: From 24 Countries, They Compete for Their Team
description: The thought of not coming to New York never entered their minds.

title: Torture Seeps Into Discussion By News Media
description: In many quarters, the Newsweek columnist Jonathan Alter is considered a liberal. Yet there he was last week, raising this question:

title: New London Journal; A Sculpture Light in Weight, Heavy in Effort
description: John DeNardis had to produce a truck and a rider that would go where they were supposed to, always look spiffy and be ready for holiday crowds. So he and his assistants set to work in their usual way. They cut up slabs of polystyrene, sprayed them with adhesives, stuck them together and began carving away.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the election campaign for mayor in Seattle misstated the title of a candidate, Greg Nickels. He is a King County councilman, not a city councilman.

title: Leaf Gets a Spin on Dallas's Carousel
description: It sounded out of joint, when Dave Campo, the coach of the Dallas Cowboys, talked today of his players needing to ''learn how to win.'' It was as if there were no glorious history.

title: Compressed Data; May the Force/Boss Be With You, in 3-D
description: In an early scene in ''Star Wars,'' the robot R2-D2 projects into the room a holographic image of Princess Leia, who implores Obi-Wan Kenobi to help defeat the Empire. Her image was lifelike and three-dimensional, but it was a cinematic gimmick reserved for the movies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, ABRAHAM
description: WEISS-Abraham. The members, officers, and staff of the former District 1115/SEIU deeply regret the passing of our friend and mentor, Abraham Weiss. ''Abe'' served our Union for five decades. He opened our minds through education, inspiration and humor so that we could imagine who we could be. We will never forget him. Our condolences to Abe's beloved wife Ruth and their family. Jay Sackman Executive Vice President 1199SEIU

title: Even Rowdy Bunch Was Quieter
description: It took John TenBroeck two words to describe how yesterday's New York City Marathon was different from the 15 others he attended: ''More subdued,'' he said. TenBroeck, from Jacksonville, Fla., was one of about two dozen race directors from the United States and other countries who had come to to learn more about how a 26.2-mile race is done, New York-style. But as their bus made its way from the Sheraton Hotel, at Seventh Avenue and 53rd Street in Manhattan, to the starting line at Fort Wadsworth on Staten Island, they felt they were absorbing lessons on the effects of terrorism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZWEIFLER, DR. LEONARD J.
description: ZWEIFLER-Dr. Leonard J. On November 2, 2001. Beloved husband of Perri. Loving father of Jordan. Dear brother of Irving and Lorraine. Devoted uncle, cousin and friend. Service Monday, 1 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Stocks Close Higher on Hopes of an Interest-Rate Cut by the Fed
description: Stocks rose today in a broad rally led by technology issues, as investors followed a familiar pattern of becoming optimistic just before the Federal Reserve's regular meeting on interest rates.

title: A Spokesman's Job
description: To the Editor:

title: Coghlan Leads the Pack in a Different Manner
description: Of all the celebrated runners here for yesterday's New York City Marathon, perhaps the most popular was not even running. Eamonn Coghlan jogs four or five times a week, but the former world indoor record-holder in the mile will turn 49 in two weeks, and his racing career faded soon after he became the first masters runner (40 and older) to run a sub-four-minute mile.

title: The F.B.I. Can't Do It Alone
description: Americans are counting on the Federal Bureau of Investigation to find terrorists and their supporters in this country. But to live up to those expectations, the F.B.I. needs to change its internal culture and learn to work closely with local police. Police know their communities better than F.B.I. agents ever will. And there are a lot more of them: 650,000 police officers, compared with about 12,000 F.B.I. agents. Only the local forces can provide the insight and texture that is so crucial to good detective work.

title: Little Tokyo Journal; Charting Revival Through Basketball
description: The bathhouses and historic houses are distant memories, swallowed by parking lots and city buildings. The Far East Cafe has yet to disappear, but only because no one else has moved into an empty storefront with its forlorn red neon sign.

title: Lull in Tension, Traveling Diplomacy and New Help in the War Zone
description: It felt almost like a normal Sunday. The skies were clear, the day was delightfully balmy, the Marathon went smoothly, with new records for men and women, the historic Trinity Church in Lower Manhattan reopened for normal Sunday worship, and the talk over brunches in packed sidewalk cafes was not anthrax, for a change, but whether the Yankees could recover from the previous night's drubbing.

title: Israeli Sets Mark in Men's Hand-Cycle Competition
description: Saul Mendoza of Wimberley, Tex., raised his hands in victory yesterday as he crossed the finish line at the New York City Marathon. But even though he was one of the first competitors to start the marathon at 10:20 a.m. as an elite competitor in the push-rim wheelchair division, he was not the first to cross the finish line. That honor went to Ziv Bar-Shira of Israel, who won the hand-cycle division. He finished almost seven minutes before Mendoza despite starting the race almost six minutes after him.

title: Battle of the Undefeated Coming Saturday
description: The Penn-Harvard game on Saturday will be the first game since 1993 and just the fourth since 1935 in which Ivy League teams with 7-0 records will meet. At least a share of the Ivy championship is at stake with both teams 5-0 in league play.

title: Ill-Fated Path to America, Jail and Death
description: They found him around 10:30 on the morning of Oct. 23, lying face up on his cot, inside a first-floor cell in the Hudson County Correctional Center in New Jersey. Muhammad Rafiq Butt, a native of Pakistan, had been arrested for being in the country illegally, one of hundreds who had been picked up on the basis of tips from an anxious public in the days after the Sept. 11 attack on the trade center.

title: Making Better Toys and Jumbo Jets by Sharing the Rough Draft
description: FOR Mike Barbato, making changes to three-dimensional objects and beaming them to colleagues around the world has become as easy as altering a sentence in a shared word-processing document.

title: Steinbrenner Vows Yanks Will Return
description: PHOENIX, Nov. 4  When the Yankees lost to the Indians in the 1997 division series, George Steinbrenner walked around a solemn clubhouse, patted players on the back and vowed to reporters: "We'll win it next year. Mark that down." The Yankees not only won the World Series in 1998, they also won it in 1999 and last year, too.

title: Zones Give The Knicks Troubles On Offense
description: Since Jeff Van Gundy became the Knicks' head coach in 1996, his preparedness has been beyond reproach. A tireless worker, Van Gundy has always had the Knicks ready for whatever the opposition threw at them.

title: Our Nuclear Plants
description: To the Editor:

title: Race for Comptroller, Minus One Rival
description: ALBANY, Nov. 4  Gov. George E. Pataki today cleared the way for John J. Faso, the Assembly minority leader, to become the Republican nominee for state comptroller when he appointed Mr. Faso's rival to lead a new Olympic committee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRUSS, SOL
description: DRUSS-Sol. On November 3, 2001. Loving father of Nancy, Vicki (Bracha) and adored grandfather of Andy, Robby, Gavriel, Sara, Rochel, Dina, Shira & Binyamin. Services were held on Sunday.

title: Florida Keys Are Evacuated As Hurricane Approaches
description: As the Florida Keys were ordered evacuated, residents of the chain of islands and South Florida braced today for Hurricane Michelle, which landed on Cuba and could threaten Florida by dawn.

title: A Smooth Early Start
description: The early start portion of the marathon, which had been a cause for great hand-wringing last year, went remarkably smoother in its second year.

title: To-Do List for Christmas: This Year, the Little Things
description: IN the 1999 holiday e-tailing season, marketing was in, as merchants like eToys and Amazon engaged in what amounted to an arms race fought with advertising dollars. Last year, the watchword was fulfillment, the industry term for shipping and handling, which so many e-tailers ignored the year before in their quest to simply attract holiday customers.

title: U.S. Jets Pound Taliban Positions in Heaviest Bombing Yet
description: American jets pounded Taliban positions today in their heaviest bombing yet along the country's far northern front, as rebel troops appeared to take their first steps toward mounting an attack on the ground.

title: A Modest Martin Soars
description: The Jets' Curtis Martin gets little attention, especially considering he was the N.F.L.'s leading rusher entering this weekend's games. His statistics -- leader in rushing yards (738) and total yards from scrimmage (871) and tied for the league lead in rushing touchdowns (7) -- speak loudly, but Martin never has.

title: States Weigh Going It Alone In Legal Battle With Microsoft
description: As they neared a deadline to accept or reject the proposed antitrust agreement between Microsoft and the Bush administration, a group of state prosecutors spent the weekend fielding growing complaints about the deal from scores of industry executives, technology experts and consumer groups.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the election campaign for mayor in Seattle misstated the title of a candidate, Greg Nickels. He is a King County councilman, not a city councilman.

title: Shades of Blue
description: The runners usually catch his eye first, but the sports artist LeRoy Neiman saw something different at yesterday's New York City Marathon. The presence of the police was so apparent that most of his sketches were of them.

title: Old Rivalries Provide the Thrills
description: For a change, the weekend in major college football saw few significant changes. The three undefeated teams -- Nebraska, Miami and Brigham Young -- remained that way. Except for defeats of Michigan and Stanford, the race to the Bowl Championship Series stayed pretty much on track, even as conference races became more intriguing.

title: Firefighter Runs for Charity
description: ''I'm on your left, running for charity,'' Larry Parker barked for the entire 26.2 miles. When he was done, Parker, a New York City firefighter, had raised $118,705 for the families of firefighters who died in the Sept. 11 attacks. That was $5 for each of the 23,741 runners he passed.

title: Helicopters Heard in Kabul Raid, Marking Possible Shift in Tactics
description: New American attacks were reported today in the Afghan capital, Kabul, and on Taliban front lines to the north, and near the border with Tajikistan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINER, HELENE S.
description: WEINER-Helene S. Of Fort Lee, on November 4. Beloved wife of the late Louis. Devoted mother of Grace Wolf and David Weiner. Loving grandmother of Nicole, Justine, Danielle, Sarah-Anne and Dara. Loving great-grandmother of Ezra, Ethan, Carmen, Noa and Eliza. Services will be held ''Gutterman-Musicant,'' Hackensack, NJ, on Tuesday, November 6, at 9:30 AM. Should friends desire contributions to Temple Emanuel, Closter, NJ, would be appreciated.

title: Now, Hitting 'Save' Is Not Enough
description: IN the aftermath of Sept. 11, job No. 1 for most information technology managers outside the World Trade Center neighborhood was to make sure their operations were functioning normally. But it did not take long before they began to assess the business lessons of that horrific day. In most cases, their analyses included a re-examination of which data should be stored, how it should be kept and whether plans for retrieving it were adequate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALABAN, ELMER
description: BALABAN-Elmer. Age 92. The last remaining sibling of the Balaban family. Beloved husband of the late Elenore. Dear father of Nancy Magidson, Robert (Lynn) Balaban and the late Susan Flaxman. Loving grandfather of Jim Magidson, Deborah (Steve Curley) Magidson, Mariah Hazel and the late John Flaxman. Services Monday, November 5, 2001, 11 AM, at the Piser Chapel, 5206 N. Broadway, Chicago. Entombment family mausoleum, Waldheim Cemetery. In lieu of flowers memorials in his name may be made to American Cancer Society, 820 Davis St, Suite 206A, Evanston, IL 60201. Information: 773-561-4740.

title: Cotovelo do Xingu Journal; A Collector's Item Costs Brazilian Divers Dearly
description: The tiny fish, among the most exotic and coveted in the world, are hardly larger than a thumb. But they are worth their weight in gold on a clandestine international market.

title: Compressed Data; Access to Documents From Afar, Securely
description: From the time he missed out on riches by turning down the chance to join Netscape Communications, Krishna Kolluri knew that Jim Clark, a Netscape founder, was worth following. So he left Silicon Graphics in 1995 to become one of the first engineers at Mr. Clark's next start-up, Healtheon.

title: McGreevey Cancels Events as Pregnancy Keeps Wife in the Hospital
description: James E. McGreevey canceled campaign events today for the second day in a row to be with his wife, Dina, who remained hospitalized with pregnancy complications, campaign aides and local hospital officials said. Mrs. McGreevey's condition, which was described as stable, raised the possibility that her husband would not be seen in public in the final days of his campaign for New Jersey governor.

title: After Two Decades, Returning to the Character Who Started It All
description: A petite madeleine dipped in a lime-blossom tisane got Proust's narrator started. Sensing that the analogous experience for the protagonist of my as-yet-unwritten first novel would be an encounter with a Hebrew National hot dog, I set aside the notion of an exquisitely observed seven volumes and wrote a whodunit.

title: U.S. May Gain Use of More Air Bases to Strike Taliban
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4  Tajikistan and the United States are moving toward an agreement that could lead to American military strikes against the Taliban forces from the territory of that Central Asian republic.

title: Rumsfeld Tells India That U.S. Want to Extend Military Ties
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 5  The United States is committed to building closer military ties with India, an ally in the global campaign against terrorism, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld told India's Defense Minister, George Fernandes, today. The secretary also discussed possible sales of American military equipment to India.

title: A Clutch Conclusion To a Very Trying Season
description: Tony Womack's season halted in April after his father suddenly died. He took a week off, his world spinning. When he rejoined the Diamondbacks, Womack took months to regain his form as the feisty leadoff hitter who had once scared so many opponents.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Schumer Urges Terror Penalties
description: Senator Charles E. Schumer proposed legislation yesterday that would make terrorist hoaxes a federal crime punishable by up to five years in prison, fines of at least $10,000 and reimbursement of all expenses, such as police overtime. Senator Schumer said no federal law outlaws false alarms and pranks, such as falsely writing that a letter contains anthrax spores. In the first three months of October, Senator Schumer said, the F.B.I. alone responded to 2,500 anthrax reports.

title: Going Against Doctor's Advice
description: Senator Bill Frist ran his second marathon in eight days yesterday against the advice of his doctor -- himself.

title: The Online Holiday Outlook; No Longer a Novelty, Web Is Now Vulnerable To the Weak Economy
description: Could this be the first ''normal'' e-Christmas?

title: Oil Industry Seeks Federal Help Against Terror
description: It was not a terrorist act, just a drunken hunter with a rifle who shot a hole in the Alaska pipeline last month. Nonetheless, he disrupted the flow of 286,000 gallons of oil for three days and raised doubts about the ability to both protect the 800-mile pipeline from attack and maintain its flow of oil.

title: U.S. May Gain Use of More Air Bases to Strike Taliban
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4  Tajikistan and the United States are moving toward an agreement that could lead to American military strikes against the Taliban forces from the territory of that Central Asian republic.

title: Compressed Data; Put Off by Disco Dancing, Sony Tightens Leash on Its Robotic Dog
description: The Sony Corporation, invoking a controversial copyright law, has cracked down on disco dancing by Aibo, the company's robotic dog.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, ANNETTE PALTIN
description: BERMAN-Annette Paltin. October 24, 1914, to November 2, 2001. Beloved mother of Myron J. Berman and Arnold T. Berman. Grandmother of Jainee L. Berman, Corey M. Berman and Abigail T. Berman. She was a great gift, an exemplary life and an inspiration to all. Shiva will be at the home of Myron J. Berman in Staten Island, Monday through Wednesday.

title: Afghan Trying to Do 'Big Things' at Big Risk
description: In a mountainous southern region of Afghanistan, far from the round-the-clock pounding by the United States in the north, an Afghan politician-cum-commander, Hamid Karzai, is working to topple the Taliban without the luxury of much backing and with his enemy in hot pursuit.

title: THE FIGHT AGAINST TERRORISM / According to Plan: Rumsfeld Shrugs Off Doubts About the War
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld shrugged off doubts about the U.S. campaign in Afghanistan on Sunday, saying that the ruling Taliban militia were no longer functioning as a government and that their effective power and control had been reduced to enclaves.

title: Harnessing the Spirit of Sept. 11
description: New York's chief judge, Judith Kaye, got a taste of the city's new civic spirit when she told about 100 people who showed up for jury duty one day recently that they would not be needed. Instead of the customary cheering, New Yorkers who not long ago viewed jury duty as a civic form of root canal voiced disappointment at being excused. Indeed, so many New Yorkers have been showing up for jury duty lately that Judge Kaye decided to institute a new system that allows prospective jurors throughout the city to call in the night before to find out if they are needed the next day.

title: U.S. Inquiry Into Trading Of Long Bond
description: The Treasury Department is investigating suspicious trading in the 30-year bond on Wednesday after an investment consultant said he told clients the Treasury was about to announce that it would no longer issue the security.

title: World Series Audio: Game 7
description: Postgame audio from Game 7 of the World Series between the Yankees and the Arizona Diamondbacks provided by SportsAudio.net.

title: Helping Software Companies Be as Open as They Want to Be
description: THE standard picture of the software industry in recent years has been big, secretive companies like Microsoft at one extreme and the collaborative approach of the open source movement at the other. But now open source is actually changing how many software companies do their work -- up to a point.

title: Islam and the Response to Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: Equity Offerings Planned
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook article on Tuesday about James Levine's appointment as music director of the Boston Symphony Orchestra misstated the date that Serge Koussevitzky, a legendary occupant of that post, stepped down. It was 1949, not 1929.

title: Americans Rescue Soldier Who Fell Ill
description: In a risky mission across the rugged, rain-swept terrain of northern Afghanistan, United States personnel late Saturday night rescued an Army Special Operations soldier who had fallen ill while assisting front-line rebel troops opposed to the Taliban, American officials said today.

title: Rewarded For Putting Stages in the Right Light
description: Maybe now she can slow down. Maybe now that Jennifer Tipton has won the 2001 Dorothy and Lillian Gish Prize of $250,000 for work in lighting design she can rest on her laurels. But it doesn't seem likely.

title: Sideswiped by Chaos and Costly Errors, the Jets Hold On
description: They would not return their victories, the Jets muttered last week. It was a way to deflect criticism that they had not looked like winners in spite of their winning record. But the Jets will clutch their 16-9 defeat of the Saints tonight tightly because this was an opponent they and everyone else believed to be among the elite of the league.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Atlanta Journal-Constitution, owned by Cox Communications, to Austin Kelley Advertising, Atlanta, to handle the introduction in February of a revamped version of its employment Web site, ajcjobs.com. Billings were estimated at $3.3 million. Austin Kelley is part of the McCann-Erickson World Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies. --> Kathy Kayse, publisher at Fortune Small Business magazine, New York, part of the Time Inc. division of AOL Time Warner, was named publisher at a sibling, Money magazine, succeeding Don Fries, who will take a senior post in the Time Inc. corporate sales and marketing group. <!--

title: Yankees Face Off-Season Changes
description: It was as if the Yankees rationed their runs and hits this year, producing enough to win but rarely enough to take pressure off their starting pitching -- a problem underscored by the Yankees' woeful offensive performance in the World Series. Their largest investment last year was pitcher Mike Mussina, but the Yankees will undoubtedly concentrate on restocking their lineup for 2002.

title: Musician Takes His Familiar Stand
description: On a barren stretch of Long Island City, Queens, with few spectators and a view no more glorious than faded warehouses, Stanley Rygor stood playing his button accordion, as he has for the past 12 years.

title: 'Harry Potter' Film Has a Ready Audience
description: It may be an apt fantasy for these terror-laden times. The hero is a child whose parents have been killed by a shadowy malevolent figure intent on imposing his dark view of the world. The young hero prevails through a combination of bravery, virtue and magic.

title: It's the Place to Be For a Sassy Volunteer
description: After the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, Allison Hope volunteered to help the relief effort and was assigned to a West Village soup kitchen. Far from ground zero, Hope, a 35-year-old comedian and actress from Midtown Manhattan, wanted to have a more immediate effect.

title: Pack With a Leader
description: Mikulas Dzurinda can run not only for a country. He can flat-out run. The prime minister of Slovakia ran a respectable 3:42:30 yesterday, leading some noteworthy competitors in the marathon. Ron Dicker

title: Rivera Fails To Make Good On His Promise
description: Mariano Rivera is a quiet man, content to read his Bible before games, watch stoically from the bullpen for the beginning of games, then dash to the mound in the eighth or ninth inning with no expression on his face. Rivera breathes, blinks and spits. Other than that, it is usually impossible to detect any emotions emanating from the best closer in baseball.

title: New Economy; A writer chronicling the Internet revolution recalls living the experience he covered.
description: FOR a journalist, it was another dreary moment in the dot-com death spiral. On a recent morning, I found myself in a bankruptcy courtroom in San Francisco, reporting on the demise of yet another former highflier. In 2000, the company had surpassed $140 million in revenue, with well over 400 employees spread across four continents. And yet, when the hearing ended, the assets of this once-proud company had been sold for just $1.4 million.

title: Larson and Drossin Win National Crowns
description: Clint Verran of Rochester, Mich., increased his training to 20 miles a day and took a $10-an-hour job in a running store. Milena Glusac of Fallbrook, Calif., made a painful return to running after debilitating illness and injury almost ended her career.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVACK, A. PAUL
description: LEVACK-A. Paul. Of Yonkers on November 4, 2001. Beloved husband of Helen. Father of Ann and Brian and his wife Nancy. Grandfather of Christopher and Andrew. Calling hours at The Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 PM, Tuesday. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Barnabas Church, Bronx, on Wednesday, November 7, 2001, at 10:30 AM.

title: Staving Off a Recession When Only Old Scripts Are at Hand in a New Age
description: With daily doses of bad economic news pointing to the first recession in more than a decade, government policy makers face increasing questions about whether they have the resolve and the proper tools to bring about a quick recovery.

title: Islam and the Response to Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: This Week
description: New Adventures

title: Seeking a United Voice on Capitol Hill
description: Representative Nita M. Lowey of Westchester was sounding exasperated the other day as she tried to get a point across at a gathering of her New York colleagues on Capitol Hill. But they simply would not let her get a word in edgewise.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GETTENBERG, GUSTAVE
description: GETTENBERG-Gustave. He left us November 5, 2000. Always in our hearts and thoughts. Deeply missed. Everlasting love and cherished memories remain. His Family

title: Sports of The Times; Arizona Makes Some New History
description: Even before the Diamondbacks ever played their first game, their managing general partner, Jerry Colangelo, speculated about a neutral-site World Series, a Super Bowl-style party that could be planned in advance.

title: A Suddenly Timely Afghan Journey; New Resonance for a Little-Noticed Iranian Film
description: Mohsen Makhmalbaf is a central figure in Iran's current movie wave, a prolific novelist, screenwriter and director whose films frequently earn him the wrath of Iranian censors. Outside festival and art-house circles, however, he is still little known in the West. Even at this year's Cannes film festival, his latest movie, ''Kandahar,'' went largely unnoticed by critics on the prowl for future hits.

title: Economic Calendar
description: MONDAY: None

title: A Dancer Casts a Spell And Becomes a Cloud
description: Movements slowly took shape and dissolved in ''108 Days of Clouds,'' the hypnotic 50-minute solo Kei Takei danced on Thursday night at St. Mark's Church. One soon could imagine that Ms. Takei had become a human cloud.

title: Celebrating Continuity, Mourning The Absent
description: As police officers and firefighters linked arms to lead the field of 30,000 onto the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge yesterday, they wore race bibs, but they also wore photographs of their fallen colleagues and relatives. They wore the names of the dead on their arms and they scribbled badge numbers on their headbands.

title: Colangelo Watches His Team Grow Up
description: PHOENIX, Nov. 4  The owner asked Major League Baseball for help with his bills, then requested that players defer part of their salaries. The offense is built around aging National League veterans and one home run threat. The team has basically been carried by two pitchers.

title: A Bazaar Erupts in Fury On a Tour of Everyday Life
description: Twenty six foreign journalists went to the main bazaar in Kandahar, the Taliban's spiritual center, to see how much ordinary life still went on in the face of American bombing. This may well have been a fool's errand. With 26 journalists around, nothing was normal.

title: A Brutal Final Weekend in the Race for City Hall
description: The contest between Mark Green and Michael R. Bloomberg hurtled through a brutal and expensive final weekend yesterday. Mr. Green took to the pulpits of black churches in Brooklyn to accuse Mr. Bloomberg of insensitivity toward black and female New Yorkers. Mr. Bloomberg filled the airwaves with television advertisements warning that Mr. Green would ''tear apart City Hall'' if elected.

title: Second Union Leader Is Charged With Trespassing in Demonstration at Ground Zero
description: The president of the union representing New York City's fire officers was charged with criminal trespass yesterday, a day after the leader of the city firefighters' union was arrested on the same charge. The police said both allegations stemmed from their roles in a firefighters' protest rally at the World Trade Center disaster site on Friday.

title: Rookie Knoblauch Played Key Role in Another Game 7
description: PHOENIX  Chuck Knoblauch was a chubby-faced 23-year-old for the Minnesota Twins when he trotted to second base at the Metrodome on Oct. 27, 1991. He was about to play in Game 7 of the World Series, the culmination to an excellent rookie year. He could not have known that he was about to participate in one of the most memorable World Series finales ever.

title: A Woman Makes History At the Championships in Paris
description: The world championships ended here on Saturday, and for the first time in history a woman has won a major world title in an open field. Rose Meltzer of Los Gatos, Calif., broke the barrier after an exciting final that kept 300 spectators glued to their seats in the Vugraph theater.

title: Helicopters Heard in Kabul Raid, Marking Possible Shift in Tactics
description: New American attacks were reported today in the Afghan capital, Kabul, and on Taliban front lines to the north of the city, and near the border with Tajikistan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, J. LESTER
description: KLEIN-J. Lester. On November 4, 2001, in Green Acres, FL, formerly of Queens, NY. Loving husband of Annette. Devoted father of Matthew, step-father of Michael, father-in-law of Robin and Fran. Cherished grandfather of Samantha, Jordan, Matthew and Stephanie. Beloved brother of William ''Bill'' Klein. Services on Wednesday, November 7, at noon, Schwartz Bros, 114-08 Queens Blvd. In lieu of flowers a donation to the American Parkinson's Disease Association, 1250 Hylan Blvd, Ste 4B, SI, NY 10305-1946, would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BOARDMAN, ARTHUR G. JR.
description: BOARDMAN-Arthur G. Jr. August 20, 1910-November 5, 1991. Gone ten years, but with us every day. Your loving family

title: Did Pettitte Tip Pitches?
description: Rick Sutcliffe, the former Cy Young award winner, said during a Game 6 international broadcast that the Yankees' Andy Pettitte was tipping the identity of his pitches, and to demonstrate, Sutcliffe proceeded to predict Pettitte's forthcoming pitches -- correctly.

title: Steinbrenner Vows Yanks Will Return to Series
description: When the Yankees lost to the Indians in the 1997 division series, George Steinbrenner walked around a solemn clubhouse, patted players on the back and vowed to reporters: ''We'll win it next year. Mark that down.'' The Yankees not only won the World Series in 1998, they also won it in 1999 and last year, too.

title: Networks See Threat in New Video Recorder
description: Three years ago, television executives watched as so-called personal video recorders allowed viewers, for the first time, to pause and replay programming even as it was being broadcast.

title: Essay; The Turkey Card
description: Reached by cell phone in purgatory, where he is expiating his sin of imposing wage and price controls, Richard Nixon agreed to an interview with his former speechwriter.

title: Green Navigates Brooklyn Bearing Swipes at Bloomberg
description: Mark Green campaigned across Brooklyn yesterday, strolling through Sunset Park and Borough Park and visiting four predominantly black churches, where he fiercely and repeatedly criticized his opponent, Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: After 70 Years, A Family Sells Its Stake in a Dapper Elephant
description: The French family that owns partial rights to Babar, the urbane picture-book elephant who has endeared himself to children worldwide, is selling its stake in the brand 70 years after the character was created.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIESEN, IRVING
description: WIESEN-Irving. The Officers, Trustees, Clergy and Members of Park Avenue Synagogue mourn the passing of a devoted congregant. We extend to his wife Tobie and the entire family our heartfelt sympathy. David H. Lincoln, Senior Rabbi Geoffrey J. Colvin, Ch. of the Bd. Paul S. Schreiber, President

title: Israeli Pullout Resumes, Despite Gunman's Attack on Bus
description: Israeli forces began pulling out early this morning from a Palestinian-controlled city in the West Bank, despite an attack on Sunday by a Palestinian gunman who emptied a semiautomatic rifle into a city bus here, killing two teenagers and wounding dozens of other Israelis.

title: Too Tall? Not at All, Tenants Say; Mass Exodus Is Absent at Skyscrapers as Anxiety Drops
description: New Yorkers have long been willing to pay a stiff premium to live and work in tall buildings that provide panoramic views of New York Harbor, Central Park, the Brooklyn Bridge or the thicket of Midtown skyscrapers.

title: Kenyan Uses the 26.2 Miles as a Skiing Warm-Up
description: In Kenya, the Rono family name has long been associated with distance running.

title: Giants Refuse to Panic, Then Win in Overtime
description: There was no yelling in the locker room at halftime, no soapbox motivational speech and no novel scheme sketched on a blackboard. The Giants, trailing Dallas by 17 points, knew exactly where they stood without oratory and artifice.

title: Into Afghanistan
description: To the Editor:

title: Thurmonds Forever
description: COLUMBIA, S.C. -- Faulkner once wrote that the past is never dead  it's not even past. And sure enough, there was something oddly familiar about President Bush's announcement this summer that he had agreed to Senator Strom Thurmond's request to nominate the senator's 28-year-old son, Strom Thurmond Jr., as the next United States attorney for South Carolina. To understand why, you have to go back a little way.

title: Prospects Dim for Medicare Drug Benefit
description: This was supposed to be the year when a long-sought, long-promised prescription drug benefit was finally delivered to the nation's elderly. Now, crucial lawmakers and health policy experts say, those benefits seem almost certain to be deferred again, like so much else on the domestic policy agenda.

title: Election Day Tomorrow
description: NEW YORK

title: Finding Excitement in the Big City, on a Harley and on the Golf Green
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Musharraf, the Indispensable Ally, Grows More Confident
description: For a man ruling a nation of 140 million Muslims, who is torn between a reluctant military alliance with the United States and Islamic militants who almost daily urge his overthrow for siding with ''infidels,'' Pakistan's president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, is radiating an impressive calm.

title: Judah Seeks an Answer After Defeat
description: Flashing an impressive blend of speed and power, Zab Judah dominated the first round of the 140-pound unification bout against Kostya Tszyu on Saturday night at the MGM Grand Hotel. The unlimited future many had anticipated for Judah, a Brooklyn native, seemed only moments away.

title: Let the Debate Begin Over Use of Schilling
description: The element of this World Series that will very likely be remembered and debated as the years pass is Bob Brenly's use, or overuse, of Curt Schilling. Any time a manager drifts away from the expected, or the routine, at this time of year he subjects himself to greater scrutiny than he would normally receive.

title: Arizona's Two Aces: Got 'Em, Need 'Em
description: PHOENIX, Nov. 4  Now that the Diamondbacks ran through the playoffs and pushed the Yankees to Game 7 of the World Series on the arms of Curt Schilling and Randy Johnson, will other team build around two aces in anticipation of the postseason?

title: INSIDE
description: Winners in a Patriotic Marathon

title: Some I.B.M. Software Tools To Be Put in Public Domain
description: I.B.M. plans to announce today that it is placing $40 million of its software tools in the public domain as the first step toward founding an open-source organization for developers.

title: Tin Pan Alley Revisited, With Hooves
description: One of the jazz pianist Uri Caine's roles, in the happy story of his association with the German record label Winter & Winter, has been to prepare projects that reinvent older music -- so far, mostly canonic classical works by Bach, Wagner, Schumann and Mahler. Typically he turns the music on its head, stuffing in turntablists, contemporary poets reading their work, hiccuping vocalists. It's akin to having a dream about a piece of music, then trying to replicate the dream compositionally, laying in all the dreamer's warps and wrinkles.

title: Islam and the Response to Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: An Energized Brokaw Is in the Middle of the Story
description: Tom Brokaw walked into his office on the third floor of NBC's headquarters in the General Electric Building on Thursday, knowing he would find it empty, stripped of all his personal and professional mementos, the photographs of his daughter's wedding, his baseballs autographed by Jackie Robinson, Ted Williams and Joe DiMaggio, the wooden rocking chair his father had made with his own hands.

title: On the Trail, Stop and Smell the Fir Trees
description: To the Editor:

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of Thursday, 4,651 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEGER, THOMAS G., M.D.
description: STEGER-Thomas G., M.D., 32. Died suddenly on October 23 in Durham, North Carolina. Dr. Steger attended elementary and middle school in Scarsdale and graduated from the Scarsdale High School in 1987. He graduated with honors from Northwestern University in 1991 and with honors from the NYU School of Medicine in 1995. He completed a residency in Orthopaedics at the Barnes Hospital in St. Louis, in June, 2001, where he served as Chief Orthopaedic Resident. At the time of his death, Dr. Steger was a Fellow at the Duke University Hospital Medical Center where he held the first Fellowship in Trauma Orthopaedics. Dr. Steger is survived by his parents Nancy and John Steger of Scarsdale, his sister Katherine of Montreal and by his grandmothers Mrs. Wilma Steger of the Bronx, NY and Mrs. J.D. Gunther of Bloomfield, CT. A memorial service will be held at 10:30 AM on November 17 at The Church of St. Pius X in Scarsdale. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Dr. Thomas G. Steger Orthopaedic Trauma Fund, Dept. of Surgery, DUMC, Box 3704, Durham, N.C. 27710.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, KENNETH
description: RUBIN-Kenneth. Of Ardsley, Professer of Physics at CUNY for 35 years. Husband, father, grandfather, ardent Researcher, Skiier, Skater, Trekker, International Traveler, Food afficinado and Blues enthusiast died November 3, after nine months of wordlessness and paralysis. He is soaring now. He will missed by Teel, David and Adrian, Josh, Robyn and Nisha and Judy. A future memorial service is planned.

title: U.S. MAKES INROADS IN ISOLATING FUNDS OF TERROR GROUPS
description: For years American officials have suspected that Osama bin Laden and his terrorist network were taking advantage of the free-wheeling financial system of the United Arab Emirates, a tiny Persian Gulf nation that boasts of 47 banks and 105 money changers for its three million people.

title: Study Finds Genetic Link Between Intelligence and Size of Some Regions of the Brain
description: Plunging into the roiled waters of human intelligence and its heritability, brain scientists say they have found that the size of certain regions of the brain is under tight genetic control and that the larger these regions are the higher is intelligence.

title: Market Place; Skepticism about EchoStar's proposed purchase of G.M.'s Hughes abounds among investors.
description: INVESTORS are deeply skeptical about EchoStar's deal for DirecTV.

title: U.S. Interrupts Cambodian Adoptions
description: It was, of course, love at first sight. Still jet-lagged from their long flight across the Pacific, the American families embraced their adopted babies and pronounced them, in one voice, adorable.

title: J. P. Miller, 81, Dies; Writer of Teleplays
description: J. P. Miller, an Emmy Award-winning writer from television's golden age of live drama, who was best known for the teleplays ''The Days of Wine and Roses'' and ''The People Next Door,'' died on Thursday at the Hunterdon Medical Center in Flemington, N.J. He was 81.

title: Minding Our New E-Manners
description: A POWERFUL collaborative software that was developed at the Max Planck Institute for Gravitational Physics in Germany allows scientists around the world to cooperatively design, simulate and visualize cosmic events like the collision of black holes. The most provocative feature of the software, known as Cactus, is that it allows any of these scientists at any point to ''steer'' or change the direction of the simulation in midstream, while it is computed.

title: Whistling as a Weapon
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing
description: CONNECTICUT

title: Cartoonists Find Issues For Humor
description: The first week after the terrorist attacks, The New Yorker's cartoonists, like so many people, wondered if anything would ever be funny again. The thought of laughing seemed inappropriate, said Bob Mankoff, the magazine's cartoon editor. And the idea of creating the witty, biting topical jokes The New Yorker is known for seemed impossible.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLANER, LUELLA B.
description: SLANER-Luella B. Died peacefully November 3, 2001, at home. Beloved mother of Eugenia Ames, Barbara Winslow and Deborah Larkin. Sister to Pauline Burgo. Grandmother to Alexander, Juliet, Jessie, Samantha, Margaret. Memorial service Thursday, November 8, 10 AM, Scarsdale Congregational Church, 1 Heathcote Rd, Scarsdale. Donations in her memory in lieu of flowers to Scarsdale Public Library.

title: Half a Commander in Chief
description: America seems to be governed by two presidents. The George W. Bush who is commander in chief has been keeping the country united at a time when the war in Afghanistan has run into problems. But the George W. Bush running domestic policy is an entirely different person, less a leader than a narrowly focused politician. If America is to fight terrorism within its own borders and conquer the economic recession, the commander in chief is going to have to take control at home, too.

title: Islam and the Response to Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: On a Zigzag Day, Bloomberg Sticks to Nonpolitician Label
description: It was 10:45 a.m. on the final Sunday before Michael R. Bloomberg's first bid for political office, and the candidate, on his way from one black church in Manhattan to another in Queens, was calling into a radio talk show for an interview that followed one with his opponent.

title: Patents or Poverty? New Debate Over Lack of AIDS Care in Africa
description: A new debate has erupted over the epidemic of AIDS in Africa, about whether it is patents or poverty that is primarily responsible for the widespread lack of treatment. The issue has become a major bone of contention as the World Trade Organization prepares to discuss new rules on patents at its summit mmeting in Qatar this week.

title: Travel Agents At Convention Tackle Drop In Tourism
description: As the nation's major trade group of travel agents opened its annual convention in New York City yesterday morning, it seemed reasonable to ask Richard M. Copland how things had been going.

title: Nicaragua Awaits Results in Ortega's Appeal for a Comeback
description: Nicaraguans voted today on whether to return the Sandinista leader, Daniel Ortega, to the presidency he lost in 1990 or to elect a Liberal Party stalwart and businessman, Enrique Bolaos. The vote pitted the fears and failures of a Socialist past against the corruption and economic hardship of the present.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: 2 Charged In Case Of Injured Baby
description: The mother and grandmother of an infant with bruises and a fractured rib were arrested late Saturday after taking the child to a hospital, the police said yesterday. The 17-month-old girl was in serious condition last night at Staten Island University Hospital. The mother, Dawn Hathaway, 22, and the grandmother, Evelyn McHone, 40, were charged with endangering the welfare of a child, the police said. Ms. Hathaway was also charged with assault. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: In Final Twist, New York Falls in Ninth
description: The Yankees' dynasty was about to be passed down intact, and all that was needed was three outs from Mariano Rivera, who had not failed in the postseason in 1,479 days.

title: Addiction, Depression, And Now, Job Skills
description: When he was in his prime in the early 1990's, Manny Rodriguez, inspecting the underside of a car at his auto-repair shop, looked just like another hard-working guy, earning a living in a rough part of town.

title: Defensive Showdown Is Decided By Kicker
description: When Jerome Bettis runs, no love handles are jiggling underneath that black-and-gold uniform. If there is such a thing as being a svelte 255 pounds, he is it. His bulk, energized by powerful muscles, not an abundance of fat cells, is the reason that tackling Bettis, the Steelers running back, is like trying to stop a tornado. Few defenders can, and most refuse to hit him straight up and above the waist.

title: Telling a Tale, But Not Loudly
description: IT has been a year since our Web site, www.iwasbornablackwoman .com, hit cyberspace. I ask myself: has it been worth it?

title: For Shaky Shopping Season, Fresh Ideas and Aged Whiskey
description: Bergdorf Goodman is preparing for the holidays by trying to soothe men who might be jittery about spending during a recession. Bergdorf's will be installing a television set in its men's store so that customers can catch up on sports events while they shop, sometimes while sipping 25-year-old whiskey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEXNER, BELLA
description: WEXNER - Bella. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun mourns the passing of our Senior Member the beloved mother of our devoted member Susan Wexner and extends heartfelt sympathy to all the members of the bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Rabbi Joshua Lookstein Chaim Edelstein, President

title: SportBrain: The Transplant
description: When the online fitness Web site SportBrain.com was shut down in late July, it seemed the site had suffered the same fate as many other bankrupt dot-coms. The company, which sold $99 belt-clip pedometers that let fitness enthusiasts log their workouts online and provided a free Web community for its customers, had no bailout in sight.

title: McCarver Doubles As a Seer
description: If you keep Fox's Tim McCarver talking, he is liable to divine what a player will do before he does it. I wrote almost the same sentence after the final game of last year's World Series. But it remains true. McCarver is the best announcer/ manager around.

title: After tiptoeing into many messages in recent years, death makes a hasty exit.
description: DURING the summer, a print advertisement for Supersmile tooth-whitening products presented a funeral where the sun shone brightly off the teeth of a young, good-looking pallbearer.

title: Local Candidates Everywhere Focus on Terrorism
description: In Pennsylvania, David Wecht, a candidate for State Supreme Court judge, laments in a television commercial that his baby son's ''world changed forever'' on Sept. 11.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROCHETEAU, RALPH C. JR.
description: ROCHETEAU-Ralph C. Jr. April 1, 1924-November 1, 2001. Died at home in Hyannis, Massachusetts. Survived by his wife of 54 years, June, and children, Ralph, Joseph, Diane, Michael, and Joanne, and by brother, Albert. Served in the U.S. 3rd Army during W.W. II. Awarded Silver Star and Bronze Star for bravery. Grandson of Provincetown (MA) pioneer, Capt. Joseph W. Rocheteau (d. 1931). Son of Ralph C. Rocheteau, Sr. (d. 1955), and Clara Rocheteau (d. 1952) of Provincetown.

title: Patriotism Is the Running Theme
description: This year's New York City Marathon was about personal records and partying. But it was more about patriotism, and for some it was very personal.

title: Of Household Cleaners And Recreational Sex
description: It is a safe bet that no sane person, having sat through Alice Tuan's ''Ajax (por nobody),'' will go off to try this at home. The title refers not to the crazed suicide of the Sophoclean hero, but to a household cleanser, and this play about sex as recreation may leave you feeling scoured from the inside out.

title: Editors' Note; A Nation Challenged
description: News of the terrorist attacks and their aftermath appears today in Section B; index, Page B2.

title: Davenport Limps Away No. 1
description: As has become the rule in women's tennis, there was no shortage of story lines on the final day of the WTA Tour's 2001 season. But there was a definite shortage of women's tennis today at the final of the Sanex Championships.

title: Spores Found On a Package Sent by NBC To City Hall
description: Trace amounts of anthrax spores have been found on a package sent at least a month ago to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's chief of staff by NBC News, city officials announced yesterday, in a discovery that illustrates how easily the toxic substance can apparently be spread to unintended targets.

title: Barbara Tropp, 53, a Scholar Who Became an Innovative Chef
description: Barbara Tropp, an innovative San Francisco chef, restaurateur and author of books about cooking, died on Oct. 26 at her apartment in San Francisco. She was 53 and had a second home in the Napa Valley.

title: Taking Messianic Imagery And Going Halfway With It
description: The climactic scene of the film ''Jesus Christ Superstar'' may be when Ted Neeley, playing the man from Galilee, is sucked into a crowd of groping, writhing acolytes. In the movie, the followers are lepers, and Jesus is doubting his capacity to help them. Sonny Sandoval of the Southern California band Payable on Death must have seen that movie once or twice, since he repeatedly restaged that scene Friday at Roseland. Mr. Sandoval, however, flipped the script: stepping offstage and putting himself in the path of his feverish fans, he let them support him, not overwhelm him.

title: Islam and the Response to Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: A Playoff Puts Weir Up on Cloud Nineteen
description: After going the entire year without a victory, and surviving today's improbable four-man playoff, Mike Weir earned a triumph worth waiting for.

title: Sports of The Times; At 41, Andersen's Message: Go for It
description: HE would kick the winning 42-yard field goal to complete the Giants' 27-24 comeback over the Dallas Cowboys yesterday, but what has made the 41-year-old Morten Andersen tick for 20 seasons was trying the 59-yard field goal he didn't make as time expired before the overtime.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LAWLOR, DAVID
description: LAWLOR-David. Memorial service at St. Xavier's, 30 W. 16th St., Friday, November 9th at 4:30 PM. Contributions to Homeless Tails, 1056 Valley Rd., Wayne, NJ 07470.

title: A Cartoonist's Venture Into the World of E-Books
description: MY e-book, ''God's Debris,'' is the No. 1 best-selling e-book in the world this year. That's the good news. The bad news is that it sold only 4,500 copies. If any e-book sold more this year, let me know. There's no reliable data on e-book sales, but when I share my figures with people in the e-book industry there's a lot of head-nodding, and no one has doubted my claim yet. I have been making the same boast since I hit the 2,000 mark. It's rare for any e-book to crack a thousand.

title: Rumsfeld Says Ramadan Won't Halt U.S. Attacks
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld, after flying over Afghanistan to meet here with Pakistan's president, said on Sunday that American attacks had not dislodged the Taliban's power and must continue through the Muslim holy month of Ramadan.

title: The Jets Won This One With Stifling Defense
description: The last time the Jets played here in the Superdome, Coach Joe Walton was about to be booted. Ken O'Brien, Al Toon and Johnny Hector were the offense and Erik McMillan, James Hasty and Jeff Lageman were the defense. The Jets lost the game, 29-14, fell to 1-5 and were crashing toward a 4-12 season.

title: Corrections
description: Three pictures on Saturday with an article about relations between ethnic groups in Afghanistan carried erroneous captions in some editions, and two were also credited incorrectly. The close-up of a boy showed Ahmed Massoud at a memorial for his assassinated father, and was taken by Yannis Behrakis of Reuters. The picture of a man in a field with a hoe showed Muhammad Yusef, an Uzbek refugee, and was taken by James Hill for The New York Times. The picture of men around a table showed Pashtun, Uzbek, Tajik and Hazara villagers celebrating a wedding engagement; it was also by James Hill.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASKETBALL

title: Connecticut Getaways
description: For a closer-to-home escape, Connecticut offers packages at a number of inns and hotels throughout the state. In Woodstock, in the northeast corner, the B & B at Taylor's Corner, an 18th-century farmhouse with a fireplace in each bedroom, has a Friday-Saturday Fireside Weekend in November, January and March for $395 a couple. It includes breakfast, a hearth-cooked dinner, fresh flowers in the room and a natural wreath to take home. Call (888) 503-9057. A fall getaway in Mystic includes a room starting at $59 a night or a room at one of the Foxwoods casino's lodgings for $49 to $89 a person (and a $15 food coupon). Valid Sunday through Thursday this month. Taxes are extra. There are savings on admission to Mystic Seaport and Mystic Aquarium; (800) 863-6569. Packages are also available at Silvermine Tavern in Norwalk and at the Inn at Chester; (800) 282-6863 or www.ctbound.org .

title: Anthrax Contamination Found in Pentagon Mail Boxes
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5  Officials said today that anthrax spores had been found in two mail boxes at a post office on a commercial concourse inside the Pentagon.

title: Thurmonds Forever
description: Faulkner once wrote that the past is never dead it's not even past. And sure enough, there was something oddly familiar about President Bush's announcement this summer that he had agreed to Senator Strom Thurmond's request to nominate the senator's 28-year-old son, Strom Thurmond Jr., as the next United States attorney for South Carolina. To understand why, you have to go back a little way.

title: Struggling to Reach a Consensus On Preparations for Bioterrorism
description: In his five years as president of Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore, Ronald R. Peterson has spent much of his time trying to make ends meet. But now that the anthrax scare has made bioterrorism a reality, Mr. Peterson is planning to spend money, not save it.

title: E-Commerce Report; Selling made-to-order clothing online without sending the customer to a tailor.
description: BUYING a computer or airline ticket online is mainly a matter of convenience and price. But a pair of pants?

title: Sports of The Times; It's a Metaphor For New York: United We Run
description: ALLAN STEINFELD sat tall on the back of a smart canary-yellow sports car yesterday morning. Waved, smiled. ''Thank you, folks. Thank you.''

title: Neil Tillotson, 102, First Presidential Voter
description: Neil Tillotson, an industrialist and resort owner who became a celebrity every four years as the first person to vote in the presidential primaries and the election of the president, died Oct. 17 at a hospital in Colebrook, N.H. He was 102.

title: Accounting Firm Sues Its Trade Association
description: It is rare that a lawsuit is filed against a trade association by a company in its own industry.

title: For a President at War, Refuge at Camp David
description: The plan had been to spend nearly every weekend at the Texas ranch, with the White House serving as a kind of Monday-to-midday-Friday pied--terre away from what was really home. But then came Sept. 11, when George W. Bush was transformed into a wartime president who could no longer be seen fishing for long weekends in Crawford while sending Americans to fight in Afghanistan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUNEBAUM, ANNELIESE E.
description: GRUNEBAUM - Anneliese E. Peacefully on November 3, 2001, in her 96th year. Beloved widow of Kurt H. Grunebaum. Loving mother of Peter. Proud grandmother of George, Nicole and Danielle. Devoted great-grandmother of Marcus, Sebastian, Annabel, Solene and Charlotte. Services will be private. A memorial service will be held on November 13, 2001, at 2 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to The Neue Gallerie, 1048 5th Ave, New York, NY 10028.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: EchoStar Deal for Hughes Draws Investor Skepticism

title: As Debate On Privacy Heats Up, Sales Don't
description: SOFTWARE that helps Internet users protect their privacy has received a great deal of attention since Sept. 11. Some say the government's new powers to snoop on the Web could lead to a boom for such services. Others say regulators will crack down on these tools, which can help terrorists hide.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NATION, DOUGLAS P.C.
description: NATION-Douglas P.C. Age 59. Died Sept. 2nd, 2001 in Switzerland. He was a Senior Managing Director at Bear Stearns, NYC. He is survived by his wife Caroline, his two daughters, Tanya & Charlotte, and his aunt, Mary Wallace. A memorial service will be held at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, 921 Madison Avenue, at 11:00 AM, Nov. 8th. Donations to US Court Tennis Preservation Fund/Douglas Nation Fund. Mail to USCT Preservation Fund, in care of The Racquet Club of Philadelphia, 215 South 16th Street, Philadelphia, PA. 19102.

title: U.S. Looks for More Vaccine Sources
description: The United States has begun looking for scarce anthrax vaccine overseas as a precaution in case lingering production problems cannot be resolved at an American vaccine factory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCNICHOL, SAMUEL
description: McNICHOL-Samuel. Lieutenant Colonel, U.S. Army, Retired. On November 4, 2001, of Great Neck, NY. Husband of the late Constance P. McNichol. Father of James G., William M., Samuel J., Margaret M. McNichol, Patricia A. Hugo, Joan McNichol-Coffman, Jane E. McNally, Clare M. Curinga and Mary A. DelPonte. Brother of Lorraine Muller and William H. McNichol. Also survived by 11 grandchildren. Visiting in the Doyle B. Shaffer, Inc. Funeral Home, Little Neck Parkway and Northern Blvd, Little Neck, NY, on Monday and Tuesday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass will be held on Wednesday at 10:45 AM, at St. Anastasia R.C. Church. Interment in All Saints Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to Great Neck Community Fund would be appreciated.

title: Spike Robinson; Jazz Saxophonist, 71
description: Spike Robinson, a lyrical jazz saxophonist who had careers in both music and engineering, died last Monday at his home in his adopted hometown of Writtle in central Essex, England. He was 71.

title: U.S. Makes Amends to Japan for Sinking of Ship
description: When United States Navy divers recovered the body of Yusuke Terata aboard a sunken Japanese fishing school boat here the other day, they bowed in its presence and joined their hands together in front of them solemnly in the manner of the 17-year-old student's countrymen.

title: Stocks Rise on Hopes of an Interest-Rate Cut by the Fed
description: Stocks rose today in a broad rally led by technology issues, as investors followed a familiar pattern of being optimistic ahead of the Federal Reserve's regular meeting on interest rates.

title: Georgia Fugitive Arrested in Brooklyn
description: A man sought by Georgia authorities in connection with the killing of a sheriff-elect in December was arrested on Saturday in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Pakistan and Kashmir
description: To the Editor:

title: A Safety Net For New York
description: To the Editor:

title: High School Winners
description: They were all from Bronxville High School and all were winners. Michelle Rorke and the twins Caroline and Cathy Mullen crossed the finish line together in the New York City Marathon's 2.6-mile preliminary girls race for high school runners. Their time was 18 minutes 54 seconds.

title: Americans Rescue Soldier Who Fell Ill
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4  In a risky mission across the rugged, rain-swept terrain of northern Afghanistan, United States personnel late Saturday night rescued an Army Special Operations soldier who had fallen ill while assisting front-line rebel troops opposed to the Taliban, American officials said today.

title: 4 Women in the Spotlight, With Strauss the Token Male
description: The organization of concert programs around premises that are essentially extra-musical can shift the emphasis from what is best to hear to what has a right to be heard. Susanne Mentzer's recital at the Morgan Library on Friday night, called ''Women in Love,'' had as its subtexts posthumous emancipation, early death and current success among female composers.

title: Punter Has Broken Wrist
description: Giants punter Rodney Williams broke his right wrist making a tackle in the third quarter of the Giants' 27-24 overtime victory against Dallas. Williams returned with his wrist wrapped in a temporary cast, and punted once for 39 yards. But Williams seemed to think he would have trouble punting for a few weeks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMS, LYNN
description: ABRAMS-Lynn. 70, of Great Neck, on November 2, 2001. Cherished mother of Danal and Seth. Treasured ''Grammy'' of Madeline. Loving mother-in-law of Wendy. Gardener and craftsperson par excellence, computer whiz, animal lover and avid gem collector. Sage in advice and unlimited in knowledge. Former owner of New City Packing & Provision Co., Chicago, Illinois. For all this and more she will be greatly missed and loved always. Services today, 12:45 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers donations in her memory may be made to North Shore Animal League, Port Washington, New York.

title: When It Comes to Poker, Working Together Is Against the Rules
description: FOR years, pundits have debated the relative merits of interaction in the real world versus interaction online. They appear to have missed a more pressing issue: where is it easier to cheat in poker?

title: Colangelo Watches His Team Grow Up
description: PHOENIX, Nov. 4  The owner asked Major League Baseball for help with his bills, then requested that players defer part of their salaries. The offense is built around aging National League veterans and one home run threat. The team has basically been carried by two pitchers.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The mood was so positive; people were so proud to be out there. To see the firemen and policemen out there cheering for us for something that seems so inconsequential, it was just beautiful.''

title: No Major Emergencies
description: The worst medical emergency by late afternoon was of some foreign runners mistaking Vaseline for nutritional goo at Mile 15. High spirits and temperatures in the low to mid 50's made for an uneventful injury report yesterday, said Lewis Maharam, the marathon's medical director. By 4:30 p.m., no competitors had been admitted to a hospital.

title: Metro Matters; Choosing A Stranger For Mayor
description: A POP quiz. Quick now, and no fair cheating:

title: Off the Grid in Idaho, Life Is Unchanged by Crisis
description: Unconnected to any utility lines, without a telephone or mail delivery, drawing water from a nearby spring, living in a cabin that is seven miles of dirt roads from the state highway, Rocky Richards and his wife, Deby, have been here in the backwoods of northern Idaho for eight years. The winters are brutal, and the muddy spring known as ''breakup'' is often even more trying.

title: Swissair Will Sell Its Ticketing Unit
description: The Swissair Group said today that it would announce the sale of its Atraxis ticketing unit on Monday. The statement came after a Swiss newspaper reported today that Electronic Data Systems and Galileo International were negotiating to buy the business.

title: High-Scoring B.Y.U. Reaches Top 10
description: LaVell Edwards, who was known as an offense-minded coach, relinquished his 29-year hold on the Brigham Young job after last season. Enter Gary Crowton, who is making Edwards look as if he had run the single wing.

title: Islam and the Response to Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: In America; 3 Nights In the Bronx
description: All over the city last Friday morning alarm clocks had been set to ring a little later than usual.

title: Never the Favorites, Jifar and Okayo Wear the Laurels
description: Tesfaye Jifar, a 25-year-old Ethiopian, had never won a marathon. Margaret Okayo, a 25-year-old Kenyan, had won only two: this year and last in the Rock 'n' Roll Marathon in San Diego.

title: A NATION CHALLENGED
description: Vaccine Sought Overseas

title: Diamondbacks Win 2001 World Series
Theres No Place Like Home
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: The 53rd Emmy Awards
European Union Brings Peres and Arafat Together Again
description: The Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, and the Israeli foreign minister, Shimon Peres, met this evening for the second time in three days, joining European Union officials for an informal gathering in Brussels.

title: Islamic Science, Language and Limits
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters Wait for Examination
description: The government says it is still too risky to examine mail impounded in Washington's investigation of anthrax contamination. Page B6.

title: Jack Manning, 80, Photographer With a Long Career at The Times
description: Jack Manning, a veteran photographer for The New York Times whose subjects ranged from gritty city streets to high culture, died on Friday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 80, had been retired for one year and lived in Pearl River, N.Y.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: New Shares For Bank
description: Southeast Asia's biggest bank, DBS Group Holdings of Singapore, said yesterday that it had raised $2.1 billion through a private placement of new shares to offset the more than $5.5 billion cost of buying the Dao Heng Bank of Hong Kong earlier this year. The new shares represent 18 percent of DBS's enlarged capital and reduce the Singapore government's stake in the bank to less than one-third. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Pioneer in the Battle to Avert Needless Pain and Suffering
description: In June, a panel of medical experts issued a stunning indictment of the care offered to cancer patients in America at the end of life. Many of the 550,000 patients who die of cancer each year spend their last days in distress, suffering from pain, nausea, fatigue and depression.

title: Ziff Davis to Cut 11% of Its Staff
description: Ziff Davis Media, the publisher of PC Magazine and Yahoo Internet Life, said yesterday that it would cut 11 percent of its staff after it closes Smart Partner magazine and combines Interactive Week with eWeek.

title: Rivera's Final Pitch: Gone, Never Forgotten
description: Mariano Rivera answered questions in English, then in Spanish and then in English again. Every answer was thoughtful yet short. Rivera was polite, unfailingly polite, in a quiet and humid clubhouse as he discussed the ninth inning that turned awry, the inning that terminated a dynasty.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISNER, JEFFREY MICHAEL, M.D.
description: ISNER-Jeffrey Michael, M.D. Our heartfelt condolences to Dr. Isner's loving wife, Linda Isner, and their children, Joshua, Jessica and Matthew; to Dr. Isner's courageous and devoted mother, Lilli Isner; and to Dr. Isner's beloved and caring sister, Betsy Robinson and her family. Ethel and Herman Steinberg

title: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: Somalia Border Reopened
description: President Daniel arap Moi of Kenya agreed to reopen the country's 420-mile border with Somalia in recognition of progress in talks between the Somali government and opposition warlords. Mr. Moi ordered the border closed in July, saying illegal arms were entering his country. Four days of talks ended yesterday in Nairobi, Kenya's capital, with the president of Somalia's transitional government agreeing to meet again with well-armed opposition leaders. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Roads to Victory in This War
description: To the Editor:

title: First Art Auction of Season Indicates a Healthy Market
description: Retail sales may have suffered since Sept. 11, but in the small, rarefied world of art, buyers are feeling no inhibitions if the price is right. Last night, the sleek new 57th Street salesrooms of Phillips, de Pury & Luxembourg were jammed with 500 or so collectors, dealers and curiosity-seekers. The occasion was the first big sale of the fall -- 72 works, mostly early 20th-century French and German art that had belonged to the Los Angeles collectors Nathan and Marion Smooke.

title: Sharon Cites Possible Surge In Attacks for Delaying Trip
description: Explaining the postponement of his planned trip to the United States this week, Prime Minister Ariel Sharon said today that he had to stay in Israel to cope with a possible surge in attacks as a result of new army tactics in the confrontation with the Palestinians.

title: Longtime Equity Strategist Is Resigning at Prudential
description: Greg A. Smith, a longtime investment strategist and one of the least bullish on Wall Street, has resigned from Prudential Securities.

title: Medic, Out of the Rubble, Finds an Identity Restored
description: When he finally woke up that morning, all the e-mail messages told him something awful had happened: We can't believe it, Hope you're O.K., Our hearts are with you. On the answering machine, he found a message from his sister. She loved him and figured he was down there, helping.

title: Now Jets Have to Guard Against Letdown
description: There were probably a few moments earlier this season when a Jet wanted to pull a Kyle Turley and fling a green-and-white helmet across the field in frustration.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nortel Clinches $1 Billion Contract
description: The Sprint Corporation awarded a $1.1 billion, four-year equipment contract yesterday to upgrade its telecommunications network to Nortel Networks of Canada. The contract will permit Sprint to transform its telephone network into a new system that permits multiple phone calls and Internet connections to share the same telephone line. The contract will not affect the services Sprint now provides to its 8 million customers, but the company hopes the new technology will permit it to provide services like video caller ID and desktop video conferencing. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, FRED
description: BERNSTEIN-Fred. Beloved husband of Marilyn. Devoted father of Richard, Linda and Steven. Dear brother of Seymour. Services were held at Sinai Chapels, Fresh Meadows, N.Y.

title: The Neediest Cases; A Mother and Son Struggle to Cope With the Burdens of Her Illness and Job Loss
description: Ismael Martinez has been jogging around the reservoir in Central Park for more than a year now, but for every mile he runs, he remains in the same place mentally, trapped between the beginning of his mother's nightmare and the end of his own dreams.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Corrections
description: A headline in the Company News column of Business Day on Thursday about an acquisition announced by Thor Industries, a maker of recreational vehicles, misidentified the business being bought. It is the Keystone RV Company. (Airstream is a line of recreational vehicles made by Thor.)

title: Signs Our Pastime Might Not Be Pass
description: Before the World Series, Ed Goren, the president of Fox Sports, predicted that ratings for the World Series would surpass last year's record low. And he guaranteed that with a six- or seven-game World Series, the rating for the Yankees-Diamondbacks matchup would exceed the ones for the past few Series.

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: States Split on Microsoft

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILBERMAN, CHARLES L.
description: SILBERMAN-Charles L. Died November 1, 2001, at age 87, in New Rochelle, NY. Formerly of New Milford, NJ, and New York City. Loving husband of the late Lenore (Guth). Father of Shoshana and Julie; father-in-law of Dianne; grandfather of Sonya, Alex, Rachel & Dan. Also survived by brothers, Paul & David, extended family and friends. Union organizer and longtime editor of the American Communications Association newspaper. Throughout his life he was committed to creating a world of peace, justice & equality.

title: On the Home Front, A Winnable War
description: Perhaps a simple distinction can help resolve many of the perplexities of life in our brave new world. Despite the panic of the moment, our domestic problems are manageable, if not completely solvable. But our international problems are utterly intractable, and the sooner we recognize this, the better.

title: Insurance Companies Favor a Plan to Limit Terrorism Losses
description: With time running short for Congress to adopt a plan that would help the insurance industry deal with losses from future terrorist attacks, the insurers say they strongly favor a Senate plan that would require them to pay for the first $10 billion in damage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEXNER, BELLA
description: WEXNER-Bella. The Israel Education Fund of UJC and the Jewish Agency mourns the death of Bella Wexner. A Jewish leader and philanthropist who helped build projects in Jerusalem and Israel. A true leader in philanthropy. We send our condolences to her daughter, Susan Wexner, and to the family. Terry Rubenstein, President-IEF Yitzchak Shavit, Vice Pres.-IEF

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, JEAN
description: DAVIS-Jean. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family joins the staff and volunteers of the Jeanette and Morris Kessel Volunteer Services Department in acknowledging with sadness the passing of Jean Davis, a devoted member of the Volunteer Service Board for over 10 years. To her family, and to all who loved her, we offer our heartfelt condolences. Matthew E. Fink. M.D., President and CEO, Beth Israel Theresa Rizzo-Williams, Director, Jeanette and Morris Kessel Volunteer Services Gladys Messenger, President, Volunteer Service Board

title: Nicaragua Voters Reject Ortega's Bid for the Presidency
description: Enrique Bolaos, a businessman who was arrested and stripped of property in the 1980's for his outspoken opposition to Sandinista rule, was elected president of Nicaragua today, defeating his nemesis, Daniel Ortega, by a surprisingly wide margin.

title: Yankees and Arizona Fail to Close the Deal
description: This was the first World Series in which the home team won every one of the seven games and one of the teams was not the Minnesota Twins. This was the first World Series in which a pitcher (Randy Johnson) was the winning pitcher on consecutive days as a starter in Game 6 and as a reliever in Game 7. This was the first World Series in which the winning team scored more runs in one game than the losing team scored in all seven games.

title: Central Banks Poised for a New Round of Rate Cuts
description: LONDON  As the world's largest economies appear headed into a simultaneous recession, central bankers stand poised this week to deliver a new round of interest-rate relief. But economists are divided on the size of the cuts and on whether they will stimulate a rebound.

title: Islamic Science, Language and Limits
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HACKETT, ANN R.
description: HACKETT-Ann R. On November 4, 2001. Wife of the late David P. Mother of the late Adam C. Beloved mother of Allyson and Mitchell. Devoted daughter of Lawrence and Cynthia Rozett. Adored grandmother of Brooke. Cherished sister of Robert Rozett. Loved by Phyllis, Daysie & Sadie. Will be tremendously missed by all those who loved and knew her. Funeral services today, 11:30AM Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Facing Up to the Helplessness Factor
description: The way stressful events affect the body may depend on whether those subjected to the stress can do anything to change the situation, a new study suggests.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Cyprus: Concern Over Turkish Threat
description: A United Nations envoy visiting Turkey, Alvaro de Soto, said he hoped that a settlement could be reached over the fate of Cyprus before the divided island's Greek Cypriot government joins the European Union. Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit of Turkey said over the weekend that Turkey could annex the northern third of the Mediterranean island if plans for union membership proceed. Cyprus was partitioned in 1974 after an invasion by Turkish troops to stop a coup attempt by people who wanted unification with Greece. Douglas Frantz (NYT)

title: NYC 2012 Picks Agency
