description: NYC 2012, an organization dedicated to bringing the 2012 Summer Olympics to New York, is naming the Kirshenbaum Bond Creative Network in New York to handle a marketing campaign to garner support for its goal. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, ALLIS BEAUMONT
description: MARTIN-Allis Beaumont. I mourn the loss of my spiritual mother, Allis Beaumont Martin, once wife of American-born tenor Riccardo Martin, who debuted as Faust in Boito's Mefistofele and continued at the Metropolitan Opera for nine seasons, sang also at La Scala, and shared with Allis composition lessons with Nadia Boulanger in Paris. I mourn never knowing the son they had together and lost together before the age of 10. I am blessed by knowing Allis' offspring from a later time in her life, when she was known as Allis Beaumont Reid, and settled in Vermont where Memorial Services will be held November 8th in Burlington, & November 12th in Lyndonville. Allis Beaumont Reid's life story can be read at the www.squeakyfiddle.com/allis/ Sturmella de Ville

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, BARBARA (NEE KLEINMAN)
description: BERGER-Barbara (nee Kleinman). Aug. 23, 1941 to November 5, 2001. Beloved wife of Leonard Berger. Loving mother of Lauren Berger, Dina & Dave Bortnichak. Stepmother to Amy and Lee Certilman, Betsy and Michael Moreno. Sister to Dennis and Ken Kleinman. Beloved daughter-inlaw of Frances Berger. Sister-inlaw to Joel & Hinda Berger, Jerri Sue and Geri-Mae Kleinman. Cherished Nana to Andrew, Reid, Alex and Henry. Caring aunt to Jana, David, Stephen, Scott and Jennifer Kleinman. Fought a heroic battle against cancer. Died Monday, November 5, 2001 at Lenox Hill Hospital, NYC. At long lastpeace. Interment Knollwood Park Cemetery beside her loving parents Jerry & Sylvia Kleinman. Funeral services on Wednesday, November 7, 2001 at 11:45 A.M. at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th and Amsterdam. In lieu of flowers donations in her memory may be made to the Susan G. Komen Breast Cancer Foundation. Nana and Pop-pop, she is coming home.

title: U.S. Escalating Efforts to Bomb Taliban Caves
description: A combination of heavy-duty bombs and more precise target information from Russia and from American Special Operations forces on the ground have helped the United States escalate attacks on caves and tunnels in Afghanistan that have been identified as Taliban arms depots and command centers, military officials said today.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: 'Mein Kampf' Conviction
description: The publisher of a Czech language edition of ''Mein Kampf,'' Hitler's political autobiography, has been convicted in a retrial on charges of ''supporting propaganda aimed at suppressing civil rights and freedoms.'' Michal Zitko was given a three-year suspended sentence and fined after his first conviction was thrown out on appeal because of ''serious mistakes'' by the court. About 15,000 copies were printed and more than 4,000 sold before the police seized 12,500 copies of the book. Mr. Zitko's lawyers said he would appeal the sentence. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNEDY, PETER J.
description: KENNEDY-Peter J. Died on November 3, 2001. Born March 8, 1912, Brooklyn, New York. Son of Cornelius Kennedy & Mary Reilly of Ireland and New York. A 1929 graduate of Regis HS, Manhattan, New York. Served in the U.S. Army's 77th Division in Guam, Okinawa and elsewhere in the Pacific. Awarded two Bronze Stars and a Purple Heart. Retired from J.C. Penney Company in 1969 after 40 years. Continued to work in the toy industry as a manaufacturer's representative until 1988. Married for 51 years to former Geraldine Murphy, who died in 1994. Survived by a sister, Florence Kennedy, of Fairfield, CT and children Mary Jane Bikowski of Sewickley, PA, Geraldine Biederman of Cromwell, CT, Gail Van Buren of Lunenburg, MA, Hope R. Kennedy of Port Washington, NY, Peter J. Kennedy, Jr., of Glastonbury, CT, James X. Kennedy of Geneva, NY, John P. Kennedy of Port Washington, NY and 15 grandchildren. Reposing at Austin F. Knowles, Inc. Funeral Home, 128 Main St., Port Washington. Visiting hours Tuesday 7-9 PM. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated Wednesday 10:30 AM at St. Peter of Alcantara Church. Interment will follow at Nassau Knolls Cemetery. A memorial gift in his name may be sent to the Regis High School Scholarship Fund, Alumni Office, 55 E. 84th Street, New York, New York 10028.

title: No Second Term for Surgeon General
description: Dr. David Satcher, the surgeon general of the United States, says he plans to leave office when his term expires, on Feb. 13.

title: When Bioterror First Struck The U.S. Capital
description: The nation's capital was struck by a plague so terrible that 10 percent of the population died in a matter of months. People panicked. Everyone who could fled the city. Politicians seized the moment to try to gain advantages over their opponents.

title: DEBATE OVER RULES FOR VICTIMS FUND
description: Six weeks after Congress created an unlimited fund to compensate the victims of the Sept. 11 terror attacks, the federal government is still wrestling with an emotionally charged question that could reduce payments to victims' families by hundreds of thousands of dollars and affect how more than $1 billion in charitable donations is spent.

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Ryanair Posts Profit
description: The low-budget Irish airline Ryanair announced a 39 percent increase in its half-year profit after taxes, to 88 million euros ($79 million). Revenue rose 29 percent, to 344.2 million euros. Over the six months ending Sept. 30 -- in which terrorist attacks and the foot-and-mouth crisis both damaged the travel industry -- passenger numbers grew 37 percent from the same period last year, to 5.3 million, while the company's Web site reduced marketing and distribution costs 30 percent. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Global Slump Is Blurring Line At Bank Units for Junk Bonds
description: To cope better with an increasing number of companies whose investment-grade debts have been reduced to junk status, J. P. Morgan Chase said today that it would combine certain parts of its European corporate bond operations.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Guilty Verdict In 1989 Murder
description: A Queens man who was charged last year with a murder that was unsolved for more than a decade was found guilty yesterday, said the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown. A jury convicted the man, Ralph Romano Jr., 38, the owner of a company that paints bridges, of second-degree murder in the 1989 killing of John Spensieri, 51. The authorities found clues to the murder during a separate investigation into the garbage-hauling industry and organized crime. Mr. Romano faces up to 25 years to life in prison. Mr. Spensieri had run a trash-hauling company with Mr. Romano and was romantically involved with Mr. Romano's mother, officials said.

title: SL INDUSTRIES SAYS IT MAY NOT SELL ENTIRE COMPANY
description: SL Industries Inc., the maker of power-surge protectors and other electrical equipment which put itself up for sale in March, said yesterday that it might only sell two subsidiaries and not the entire company. Preliminary bids for SL, and also its power motion and power electronics groups, were too low. Negotiations for the sale of two unidentified units are continuing, the company, based in Mount Laurel, N.J., said in a newsrelease distributed by Business Wire. SL rescheduled an election of directors for Jan. 22 after postponing its last meeting, until it reviewed the offers. Credit Suisse First Boston was hired in March to help find a buyer after semiconductor, telecommunications and aerospace customers canceled orders. SL shares fell 20 cents, to $6.60. They have fallen 41 percent this year.

title: When Laughter Is the Best Medicine
description: In ''The Mooncalf'' by Elisabeth Karlin, when a sulking 16-year-old blames her confusion and habitual rudeness on negligent upbringing, her dying mother replies, ''You have a nature on which nurture will never stick.'' That remark encapsulates the underlying message of the play: the mysteries of family relationships elude culture and the only way to endure them is to laugh about them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZEFF, GERALDINE
description: ZEFF-Geraldine. Loving wife of the late Dr. Seymour Zeff. Devoted mother of Richard and Monica. Adored grandmother of Rachel and Zachary. Beloved sister of Joyce Swartz. Dear aunt and cherished friend of many. Services were held Monday, November 5. For Shiva information please call Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ITKIN, EDYTHE
description: ITKIN-Edythe. Beloved wife of Sam; mother of Larry and David; sister of Rosalind, Mary and Marian; grandmother of Nicole Itkin & Benjamin Sawyer and Stephanie Itkin; and mother-in-law to Cheryl and Valerie; passed away on Sunday, November 4th. A service will be held at Riverside Memorial on West 76th Street on Thursday, November 7th at 11:15 AM. The family will sit at the home of Larry and Cheryl Itkin, 53 Saldo Circle, New Rochelle, New York on Thursday night.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Grants For Retail Businesses
description: Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday announced a $20 million program to provide grants of up to $10,000 for small and medium-size businesses hurt by the Sept. 11 terror attack. Owners of retail businesses with fewer than 50 employees and who intend to remain in New York will be eligible. The Empire State Development Corporation will review applications and disburse grants within 10 days at a center at 199 Church Street.

title: 2 More Firefighters Arrested In Dispute on Search for Bodies
description: Two more officials of the firefighters' union were charged with criminal trespass yesterday in connection with a scuffle on Friday in which firefighters pushed through barricades and police lines during a protest march to ground zero and tangled with police officers.

title: In Hartford and Waterbury, Voters Are to Choose New Mayors
description: Voters in two of Connecticut's largest cities Hartford and Waterbury -- will choose new mayors on Tuesday to help lead them out of their financial and political troubles.

title: Racing in Real Time to Track Down an Assassin and a Daughter
description: Over the summer a new Fox drama called ''24'' was being touted as the hot new show to watch this season. Its gimmick: this thriller about a C.I.A. officer trying to thwart an assassination plot would play out in real time. Each weekly episode would cover one hour of the officer's day, which would be completed in a 24-episode season. Asked by a reporter what would happen in the second season, Joel Surnow, one of the show's creators, said in June, ''There could be a nuclear bomb about to go off in New York City.''

title: Budget Cuts May Foul Sidewalks Of Paris
description: It is one of the stranger aspects of Parisian life.

title: The Big City; If You Fool Us Once, Jail for You
description: SENATOR CHARLES E. SCHUMER wants to make it a federal crime to threaten or falsely report a terrorist attack. If his bill passes, a hoaxer would face penalties of up to five years in prison, fines of at least $10,000 and reimbursement of the costs due to the hoax, such as police overtime.

title: Father-and-Son Firefighters, an Avid Dancer and a Love Sealed in Paris
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: The Plate He Already Knew

title: Islamic Science, Language and Limits
description: To the Editor:

title: EchoStar to Receive Loan
description: EchoStar Communications said today that Credit Suisse First Boston would provide a $2.75 billion short-term loan to help finance the planned purchase of its satellite-television rival, Hughes Electronics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELTZER, HAROLD G.
description: SELTZER-Harold G. Riverdale Jewish Center extends condolences to our member Susan Seltzer, upon the loss of her father. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi David Sable, President

title: Schundler Puts Bioterror Plan Atop Agenda
description: On the final day of campaigning in the New Jersey governor's race, Bret D. Schundler said today that his first priority in office would be to ready the state for a major bioterrorism attack, perhaps involving smallpox or plague. His opponent, James E. McGreevey, spent a third day sequestered with his wife, who was hospitalized over the weekend with pregnancy complications.

title: The Heartland Hunkers Down; Cincinnati Area Is Taking Job Losses in Stride, for Now
description: Even as the economy worsens, the giant Procter & Gamble, the most prominent corporation with headquarters here, is still relying on a softer approach to shrinking its work force, offering early retirement packages and other incentives instead of handing out pink slips.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Dell Offers Storage Servers
description: Dell Computer, the biggest maker of personal computers, will sell three network-attached storage server computers that it designed. The machines, PowerVault 755N, 750N and 715N, are based on Microsoft's Windows 2000 Advanced Server operating system. Prices start at $1,999 to $8,700. The 750N and 755N servers are available and the 715N will be sold later this month. A network-attached storage device permits file-sharing among different operating systems. Dell had total storage sales of about $1.4 billion for the four quarters ended in August.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUSER, HELEN
description: MUSER-Helen. On November 5, 2001 in her 88th year. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Robert Muser. Loving mother of Judith Brook and Howard Muser. Mother-in-law of David and Francine. Devoted grandmother of Adam, Jonathan and Nicole, Ilyse, Andrew and Marc. Sister of David Zimmerman. Services Tuesday, 10 AM, Bernheim Apter Goldsticker Funeral Home, Maplewood, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRAWFORD, ROBERT J.
description: CRAWFORD-Robert J. On September 11, 2001 during the performance of his duties as a New York City firefighter (Safety Batallion). He was lost in The World Trade Center disaster while in the process of evacuating civilians. Beloved husband of Dorothea (Mallon), dearest father of Christine, Mark R., Jennifer Eppolito, Rachel V. Connor and Matthew J. Loving father-in-law of Georgia, Stacy, Anthony Eppolito and Billy Connor. Cherished grandfather of Alexandra and Justin Eppolito and Andrew Scott Crawford. Devoted brother of Patricia Crawford and Kathleen Rothaug. Cherished brother-in-law of John and Louise Mallon, Lois Duffy, Carole and Jim McCann, Peter and Ann Mallon and Madelyn and Ben Grisafe. Friends may call Thursday and Friday between the hours of 2-5 and 7-9 PM at The McManus Funeral Home, 2001 Flatbush Avenue, corner of Avenue M, Brooklyn. Memorial Mass Saturday 1 PM, St. Thomas Aquinas Church (Flatlands).

title: New Tapes Indicate Johnson Doubted Attack in Tonkin Gulf
description: A new book examining secret tapes President Lyndon B. Johnson made in the early days of the Vietnam War show that only weeks after Congress gave him the authority to pursue the war in 1964, he privately acknowledged that the incident that inspired the resolution probably never happened.

title: Keiko Makes It Clear: His 'Free Willy' Was Just a Role
description: The sad fact is, it looks as if the world's mostly closely watched experiment in returning a cetacean to the wild is a bust.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Benefits Bill For Soldiers
description: A bill that would give state employees called to military service in Operation Enduring Freedom partial pay and other benefits is expected to be introduced at the special legislative session next Tuesday. Representative Linda Orange, Democrat of Colchester, is sponsoring the bill that would grant military personnel paid leave for 30 days plus partial pay for the duration of service; a state income tax waiver; and continued family health benefits. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELIGSOHN, SELMA
description: SELIGSOHN-Selma. Migdal Ohr Institutions in Israel and the Board of Directors of the American Friends of Migdal Ohr deeply mourn the passing of Selma Seligsohn, mother of our dear friend & Board member, Jerry Seligsohn. We join all who knew her in remembrance of a loving mother to Jerry and his wife Sandy, grandmother to Lisa and Danny and wife to her departed husband, Max Seligsohn, o'bm. May the Almighty console the entire Seligsohn family among the other mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Yitzchok Dovid Grossman, Founder and Dean, Migdal Ohr Chief Rabbi, Migdal Ha'Emek Rabbi Eliezer Rosner, Migdal Ohr Institutions, Jerusalem Max Thurm, President Ronni Amster, National Director American Friends of Migdal Ohr

title: Sonics Outlast Magic in Two Overtimes
description: Rashard Lewis had career highs of 36 points and 19 rebounds, and Gary Payton scored 32 points as the Seattle SuperSonics defeated the host Orlando Magic, 123-119, in double overtime last night.

title: Sports of The Times; The Mayor Was There For the Yanks
description: HE has had worse duties. The smile on the face of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani told everybody he knew the difference between a funeral and a losing clubhouse.

title: The Heartbreak In Yankee Land
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Bronx, A Farewell To a Victim
description: She lived alone, without a family, but every pew in the church was filled.

title: Islamic Science, Language and Limits
description: To the Editor:

title: Combining Offices In San Francisco
description: J. Walter Thompson in New York, part of the WPP Group, said yesterday that it would merge its San Francisco office with Tonic 360, a digital branding agency in San Francisco that Thompson acquired in October 2000

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the world's changing perceptions of the United States since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks misstated the nationality of Eduardo Galeano, a journalist who wrote of Guatemalan victims ''sacrificed not by Muslim fanatics but by terrorist militias supported by the successive American governments.'' He is from Uruguay, not Mexico.

title: Clifton Brown's Scorecard
description: Every two weeks, Clifton Brown ranks the 10 best men and women in professional golf. These rankings are from Nov. 6.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Water-Hoarding Beetle

title: Ever-Tighter Mayoral Race Draws to a Bitter End
description: Mark Green and Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday completed the final day of a contest for mayor that both sides said had turned unexpectedly whisker-close. Mr. Bloomberg campaigned at the side of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, whose support has proved critical to his candidacy, while Mr. Green released a harsh advertisement that recounted charges made against Mr. Bloomberg in a sexual harassment suit.

title: Principessa, Don't Be Cruel to a Heart That's True
description: The New York City Opera is at its best when it presents unusual repertory, especially 20th-century and Baroque works, or when it revisits operatic staples in innovative productions with young singers who act well and look like the characters they portray. Puccini's ''Turandot,'' which major opera companies routinely present in spectacular stagings with high-powered, high-priced singers, would seem ill suited to the City Opera's current mission and resources.

title: Trade Towers Leaseholder Sues Insurers
description: The battle over insurance coverage of the World Trade Center took another twist yesterday when Larry A. Silverstein, the developer who won the lease of the trade center in July, sued Ace Bermuda Insurance Ltd. and XL Insurance Ltd., two Bermuda companies that covered the complex. The suit seeks to compel them to litigate any dispute over payments in federal court in Manhattan.

title: Outscalping the Scalpers
description: If theatergoers had to decide whether scalpers or producers should reap the profits for selling hard-to-get theater tickets at outrageous prices, most would opt for the producers. At least they might use the money to put on another show. So the announcement that the musical ''The Producers'' had jacked up the price on prime tickets to $480 stirred more interest than outrage on Broadway. However, when the producers of ''The Producers'' describe their decision as a ''war'' on scalpers, their battle cry has to be taken with a grain of salt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STARK, CECELIA SHIER
description: STARK-Cecelia Shier. Age 89, on November 5, 2001, in Boca Raton, Florida. Born November 28, 1911. Beloved wife of the late Wilfred, devoted mother of Emily Danson, and the late Winifred Stark, cherished grandmother of Christopher and Melissa Danson, dear sister of Esther Stein, Dr. Julius M. Shier, and the late Helen Provisor. Gone from our sight, forever in our hearts.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: LOUISIANA-PACIFIC CORP., Portland, Ore., a maker of building products, said it had suspended its quarterly dividend of 5 cents a share and rescinded its stock repurchase program, pending an improvement in the overall market and the company's financial condition.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zambia: Kaunda's Son To Run
description: Entering a crowded field, Tilyenji Kaunda, a son of former President Kenneth Kaunda, will run for president in an election planned for later this year, his party announced. Mr. Kaunda will be the candidate of the United National Independence Party, which governed for 27 years under the firm hand of the elder Kaunda before being turned out in 1991. With Mr. Kaunda's entry, at least half a dozen candidates are now in the race. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: Weak Bats Take Rap for the Yankees' Downfall
description: Jorge Posada seemed to be fighting tears every time he mentioned Mariano Rivera's name after Game 7, maybe out of sympathy for a teammate and friend who has been reliable and accountable, or maybe from the ache of knowing what could have been. If the Yankees and Rivera could have held a 2-1 lead in the bottom of the ninth inning Sunday night, they would have won a fourth consecutive World Series title and the veteran Yankees who may not be back for 2002 would have departed with a championship.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Vizzavi Gains Subscribers
description: Vizzavi, an Internet portal owned by Vivendi Universal of France and Vodafone of Britain, the world's biggest wireless operator, said its subscriber base grew 30 percent in October after the acquisition of a Spanish portal called Navegalia with roughly one million subscribers. Vizzavi, created in early 2000, said it now has 5.3 million customers using its services to reach the Internet from computers, mobile phones and handheld digital devices. Vizzavi has also been promoting its services with sponsorships of events, including a concert by the singer Sting.

title: In Defense of Fallaci
description: To the Editor:

title: Rich and Poor: Same Ills, Different Clock
description: Poor people who live into middle age tend to die of the same causes as their more affluent peers, but to die earlier, according to a new study in The British Medical Journal.

title: Technology Briefing
description: HANDHELDS

title: Offering French Opulence, Even if Some of It Is Swiss
description: The program that the Netherlands Chamber Choir performed at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University on Saturday evening was called ''French Opulence,'' and for the most part, the title described it accurately. The exception was the first work, the ''Songs of Ariel,'' a group of Shakespeare settings in English by the Swiss composer Frank Martin.

title: Bay Area's Bridge-Wary Jam Ferries and Trains
description: This morning, Julie Hodapp took a ferry from Marin County to her workplace in San Francisco rather than her usual bus across the Golden Gate Bridge. And to avoid the new crowds, she skipped rush hour and went in late.

title: Election Day Choices
description: This list summarizes The Times's recommendations for some races and ballot proposals throughout the New York region today. Poll hours are 6 a.m. to 9 p.m. in New York and 6 a.m. to 8 p.m. in New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, WILLIAM JOSEPH
description: MOORE-William Joseph. Of Rye Brook, died November 4, 2001, after a brief illness. He was born September 18, 1918 in New York City. He married Justine Collins in 1945 who predeceased him. He graduated Fordham Prep 1935 and from Fordham University 1939. Mr. Moore graduated from New York University School of Law after he had completed his military service. Mr. Moore served as Dean of Admissions at Fordham Law School and retired in June of 2001 after more than thirty years of service. He previously served as General Counsel for a major life insurance company in Washington, D.C. He was a captain in the Army Corps of Engineers during W.W. II and took part in the DDay Invasion of Normandy. Thereafter he was reassigned to a select group of volunteers who were sent to the Far East for the planned invasion of Japan. He was a member of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick and the New York State Bar Association. Mr. Moore was a recipient of the initial Gov. Malcolm Wilson Distinguished Alumnus Award in 2001 and was awarded the Fordham University Bene Merenti Award in 1990. He is survived by 5 children, Sheila Moore-McSpedon, William Moore Jr., Patricia Andersen, Michael Moore & Eileen Wooden. His brother George, and two sisters, Mary Carpenter and Regina Boyle, and eleven grandchildren also survive him. Visitation will be Tuesday, 2-4 PM and 7-9PM at McMahon, Lyon & Hartnett Funeral Home, 491 Mamaroneck Avenue, White Plains, New York. A Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday at 10 AM, Our Lady of Mercy Catholic Church in Portchester, NY. Interment will follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Valhalla. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the American Cancer Society, 2 Lyon Place, White Plains, New York 10605.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Brookfield Reports Earnings
description: Brookfield Properties, which owns several buildings close to the World Trade Center site, yesterday reported a 36 percent increase in third-quarter net earnings and a 16 percent rise in operating cash flow. Net income for the period was $53 million (Canadian), or 30 cents a share. Earlier this year, the company, based in Toronto, raised its annual dividend 50 percent. Brookfield said rental income from buildings in Lower Manhattan that were evacuated on Sept. 11 was assured through business interruption insurance. But new insurance policies, effective Oct. 31, carry increased premiums and exclude terrorism.

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press yesterday about the crash of a Greyhound bus in Phoenix referred incorrectly to charges against Charles George, a passenger who the police say caused it by struggling with the driver. The Pinal County Attorney's office said it had authorized the future filing of 10 charges of aggravated assault against him; he has not already been charged with 37 counts.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Do I think Afghanistan will take years? No, I don't.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PASACHOFF, MILDRED BARNETT
description: PASACHOFF-Mildred Barnett. On Monday, November 5, 2001, of New York City. Devoted wife of the late Harry. Beloved mother of Alice Wegman of Bethesda, MD. and Jane Schlaifer of Rockville, MD. Loving grandmother of Laura, David, Jonathan and Elizabeth. Dear sister of Sylvia Gahan. Funeral service at The Riverside, 76 St and Amsterdam Ave, Wednesday, November 7, 11:30AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, ANNETTE
description: BERMAN-Annette. The Officers, Directors and Staff of the USO of Metropolitan New York extend deepest sympathy to the family and friends on the passing of Annette Berman, mother of USO's Chairman Myron J. Berman. R.J. Lobb, President Stephen J. Scheffer, Vice Chairman

title: Anthrax Danger Delays Inspection of Millions of Letters
description: Three weeks after an envelope filled with anthrax spores was opened in Senator Tom Daschle's office, government officials say they have been unable to examine millions of other letters to determine whether any of them also contain anthrax.

title: Groups at Odds Over Postcard On Proposed Charter Changes
description: Included in the flurry of campaign literature mailed to voters over the last several days was a postcard from the city's Charter Revision Commission.

title: Afghan Opposition Says It Takes Areas Near Major Northern City
description: Northern Alliance officials claimed today to have captured three districts near the strategic northern city of Mazar-i-Sharif after what they said was extensive involvement by United States military advisers in the attacks.

title: Back in Their Locker Room, Some Quiet Perspective
description: Twenty-two bats with the branded signature of Paul A. O'Neill still cluttered one locker. A base imprinted with the World Series logo leaned against Derek Jeter's chair. There was a World Series program atop a pile in Roger Clemens's locker.

title: Edward P. Boland, 90, Dies; A Longtime Representative
description: Former Representative Edward P. Boland, a steady, self-effacing lawmaker whose name became central to the debates over the Reagan administration's policies in Central America, died on Sunday. He was 90.

title: General Musharraf's Visit
description: Less than two months have passed since Pakistan's ruler, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, shocked his country's military establishment and infuriated radical Islamic groups by disowning the Taliban and allying with the United States. Now he feels confident enough to travel to New York this week to speak at the United Nations, visit the World Trade Center site and meet with President Bush.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHOTTENFELD, MARVIN
description: SCHOTTENFELD-Marvin. The Jewish Community Center of Harrison announces with profound sorrow the loss of its esteemed member. We extend deepest sympathy to his wife Barbara, his children Richard and Beth, and to the entire family. Alfredo F. Borodowski, Rabbi Sarah A. Zemel, Hazzan Norton D. Shargel, Rabbi Emeritus Bernard Dienstag, Cantor Emeritus Katherine Teich, President Steven Chill, Chairman

title: Asian-American Vignettes Spread Across 120 Years
description: ''The Square,'' a well-executed anthology of short new works at the Joseph Papp Public Theater through Nov. 18, brings an impressive concentration of theater talent to a single subject, the Asian-American experience, and a single place, a fictional public square in the Chinatown of some imagined American city.

title: Concert Brought in $30 Million
description: A rock concert held last month that featured legends like Mick Jagger and Paul McCartney has raised $30 million for victims of the World Trade Center attacks, said Charles Schueler, a senior vice president at Cablevision, one of the concert's sponsors.

title: Justices Weigh Lawyers' Ethical Obligations
description: A lawyer who was appointed to represent a murder defendant in a 1992 trial in Virginia had represented the murder victim in an unrelated case just a week earlier, an unusual situation that led to a wide-ranging Supreme Court argument today about lawyers' ethical obligations to clients.

title: Roads to Victory in This War
description: To the Editor:

title: Tunnel Vision; In a Simple Memo, F.Y.I., A Tense Tale of Survival
description: New York City Transit puts a lot of faith in paperwork. At times, it seems to have missed the whole computer revolution, or at least mistrusted it. In fact, in a dusty file room in downtown Brooklyn, there are boxes containing minute-by-minute records of the daily movements of your subway line, going several back years -- all handwritten, on paper.

title: Accounts
description: * Ralston Purina, St. Louis, which is being acquired by Nestl, expanded its relationship with the Minneapolis office of Fallon Worldwide by naming the agency to handle its Purina One dog and cat food account, which had been handled by Lowe Lintas & Partners Worldwide, New York, part of the Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Billings were estimated at $25 million to $30 million. Fallon, part of the Publicis Groupe, already handles Purina pet-food brands like Dog Chow and Puppy Chow.

title: Helping Teenage Drivers
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COREA, DAVID S.
description: COREA-David S. On November 3, 2001. Of Weehawken and Ortley Beach NJ, formerly of Hoboken. Commodities broker, Global Executions, Inc., NY, NY. Beloved husband of Brenda Valentino Corea. Loving son of Camille (nee Palmieri) and the late Anthony Charles (Bob) Corea. Cherished brother of Cara, Robert, Kim, Marc, John & Christopher Corea. Cherished uncle of six. Funeral from Failla Memorial Home, 533 Willow Ave, Hoboken, Thursday, November 8, 2001. A Mass of Christian Burial will be offered at St. Ann's R.C. Church, Hoboken at 10AM. Entombment will follow at Holy Cross Mausoleum, North Arlington, NJ. Visiting hours will be held on Wednesday, continuously between the hours of 2 and 9 PM.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Sally Andrews was named to the new post of vice president and direct marketing director at Cole & Weber/Red Cell, Seattle, part of the Red Cell unit of the WPP Group. She had most recently been a consultant. Also, Daymon Bruck was named creative director for the interactive department; he had been creative director at Mullen, Wenham, Mass., part of the Partnership unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Islamic Science, Language and Limits
description: To the Editor:

title: Moscow Journal; The Worker's State Is History, and Fashion Reigns
description: Giorgio Armani just opened a salon a few blocks from the Kremlin, which might prompt a student of economic statistics (Russian per capita income, $1,660) to ask whether the House of Armani has any lights on in its attic.

title: U.S. and India Map Path To Military Cooperation; More Arms Sales Are Seen
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld told India's defense minister, George Fernandes, today that the United States is committed to building closer military ties between their two countries, and the two men discussed possible sales of American military equipment to India.

title: Roads to Victory in This War
description: To the Editor:

title: Main Offices Up for Grabs In 3 Counties In the Suburbs
description: With control of Nassau County government at stake and the Legislatures in Suffolk and Westchester also up for grabs, local candidates in New York suburbs made their final appeals to voters yesterday.

title: McCAW CANCELS ICO-TELEDESIC MERGER
description: The billionaire Craig O. McCaw called off plans to merge his satellite communications companies ICO Global Ltd. and the Teledesic Corporation, blaming a weak United States economy. Mr. McCaw had planned to merge the two companies by the end of last year. The combination was delayed as the economy weakened. Mr. McCaw, who owned 60 percent of ICO Global last year, also owns Teledesic and would have been chairman of the combined company. A merger of ICO and Teledesic may be re-evaluated in the future, the company said in a statement.

title: Top Team To Play For Arena
description: The United States has clinched a spot in the 2002 World Cup finals, but Sunday's final qualifying game at Trinidad and Tobago is still of significance to Coach BRUCE ARENA. For this game, he has all the players he is counting on for the Cup finals in Japan and South Korea except for CLAUDIO REYNA, who was given permission to stay with the Glasgow Rangers.

title: Trivia Question
description: Here are the question and answer from last week's Baseball Report. Subscribe to The Baseball Report and get a new question each week.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the final weekend of campaigning for the New Jersey governorship misstated the percentage of respondents to a Star-Ledger/Eagleton-Rutgers Poll who were supporting or leaning toward Bret D. Schundler, the Republican. It was 36 percent, not 46 -- compared with 53 percent for James E. McGreevey, the Democrat.

title: Tigers Select Executive
description: Dave Dombrowski, who helped build the Florida Marlins into World Series champions in just five years, was hired yesterday as president of the Detroit Tigers.

title: Sometimes, The Doctor Is Blind
description: The woman's hair was gone, her bare scalp hidden beneath a stretchy pink turban. Her head drooped; to converse, we crouched to meet her gaze. Her breasts had been removed some time ago. Her arms were swollen, hands almost useless. Peeking out from the neck of her gown were patches where her cancer had returned, a thick layer encasing her in a red leather corset.

title: Kuerten Increases Lead in Ranking
description: Gustavo Kuerten, seeking to win the Champions Race a second straight year, increased his lead in the tennis ranking with only next week's Master Cup left. Only Lleyton Hewitt and Andre Agassi can overtake him.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Oct. 21 about the Pashtun, the ethnic group that straddles the border of Pakistan and Afghanistan, referred incorrectly to the border, which many in the tribe consider simply a line on paper. It is based on a boundary negotiated in 1893 by Sir Henry Mortimer Durand, foreign secretary to India's colonial government, not one drawn by a British general.

title: Stretching a Jewish Vigil for the Sept. 11 Dead
description: In the darkest hours of the night, Judith Kaplan, dressed in her Sabbath finery, sat in a tent outside the New York City Medical Examiner's office, singing the haunting repertoire from the Book of Psalms. From midnight until 5 a.m., within sight of trucks full of body parts from the World Trade Center, she fulfilled the most selfless of Jewish commandments: to keep watch over the dead, who must not be left alone from the moment of passing until burial.

title: Attacks Hit Low-Pay Jobs The Hardest
description: The terrorists who attacked the World Trade Center may have been trying to crush American capitalism and its masters of the universe on Wall Street. But the economic impact of the attack is felling a very different group of people: cooks, cabdrivers, sales clerks and seamstresses.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Falling Profits At Amadeus
description: The travel distribution company Amadeus, hit by the collapse in business affecting the travel industry after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, has reported a 33 percent drop in third-quarter net profits and warned of a possible loss in the fourth quarter if bookings do not recover. The company, whose major shareholders include the European airlines Iberia, Air France and Lufthansa, said it was considering financial incentives to get passengers flying again. Emma Daly (NYT)

title: Big Easy Savings
description: More than 60 hotels in New Orleans are adding a third night free to two-night stays under the New Orleans for a Song promotion, through Dec. 31. Among them are the Bourbon Orleans, the Doubletree downtown, the Fairmont, the Embassy Suites and the Windsor Court. A complete listing can be found at www.neworleansonline.com . Reservations can also be made at that site. For a free guide with discounts on shopping, dining and sightseeing, call (800) 474-8167.

title: Evicting an Unwelcome Tenant: Anthrax
description: The anthrax assaults have set off a scramble to decontaminate places where bacterial spores were found and to prevent more infections by sterilizing the mail -- the prime source of the initial anthrax exposures and also apparently a means by which stray spores dispersed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHREIER, LEONARD J.
description: SCHREIER-Leonard J. The Partners and Staff of Sterling Equities, with deep sorrow and sadness, mourn the death of our partner and friend Lenny Schreier. He will be remembered for his wisdom, generosity of spirit and his devotion to humanity. We will miss him very much, yet he will always be with us. Our sympathies are with his children Deyva and Michael, grandson Julian and brothers Arthur and Herb. Friends may join in remembering Lenny at a Memorial Service on Sunday, November 11, 2001, 11 AM at the Harlem Yacht Club, City Island, Bronx, NY.

title: Q & A
description: Snowbirds in the City

title: Winning the Hard Way Gives the Giants a Lift
description: Maybe it was the way the Giants won Sunday, with the son of a Staten Island stuntman doing sack dances and a former nighttime telemarketing operator blocking a punt, but something had them feeling especially good about themselves today.

title: Wines of the Week
description: With the holidays fast approaching, here are four stash-your-cash wines that will allow you to have a nightly glass with dinner and enjoy the shopping season.

title: U.S. and Some States Split on Microsoft, Risking New Delay
description: The 18 states involved in the Microsoft antitrust case appeared headed for a sharp split today, with one group of attorneys general planning to sign onto the proposed settlement between the software giant and the Bush administration and another group preparing to challenge it, saying it leaves loopholes that would undermine provisions intended to promote competition.

title: Woods Is One Player Knicks Let Get Away
description: Kevin McHale, the Minnesota Timberwolves executive who is one of the most-respected men in basketball, foresees a solid professional career for Loren Woods. Terrell Brandon, the two-time All-Star point guard, calls Woods another Marcus Camby.

title: COURT APPROVES $50 MILLION CREDIT LINE FOR POLAROID
description: The Polaroid Corporation, the largest instant-photography company, received final bankruptcy court approval for a $50 million credit line to finance the company while it restructures debt. Judge Peter Walsh gave interim approval last month for the company to draw $40 million on the credit line, which is being financed by a group of banks led by J. P. Morgan Chase & Company. Polaroid sought bankruptcy protection last month after instant film sales declined against the rising popularity of digital cameras. In August, Polaroid reported a second-quarter loss of $109.9 million, compared with net income of $26.6 million a year earlier.

title: Gannon Recovers To Punish Broncos
description: When Raiders quarterback Rich Gannon broke loose from a collapsing pocket, scrambling right to avoid the rush, he was able to dash 6 yards along the far sideline before being hit hard in the head at the Broncos' 1-yard line. A raucous crowd was suddenly hushed.

title: People Get Hungry, Even at Ground Zero, Restaurateur Says of Plans
description: The way Yun Oc Nam sees it, ''everybody has to eat,'' even people in Lower Manhattan. Further, he says, the show must go on.

title: A Sudden Breakout Moment, And Kate Burton Is Loving It
description: When Kate Burton makes her entrance as Hedda Gabler -- when the audience applauds before she even opens her mouth and laughs appreciatively as soon as she delivers her first zinger -- there is the unmistakable sense that a star has swept onto the stage of the Ambassador Theater.

title: Solace in Sports
description: Two sporting events on Sunday gave New York an emotional lift that made this heavy-hearted autumn seem lighter. The New York City Marathon, where Tesfaye Jifar of Ethiopia and Margaret Okayo of Kenya were declared winners shortly after 2 p.m., and the World Series, where the Arizona Diamondbacks became world champions approximately nine hours later, provided timely diversions from Afghanistan and anthrax. Beyond that, however, they served an important therapeutic function -- showcasing competitive sports at their very best, full of astonishing grit and resilience, and giving a battered city positive and nourishing memories to take away from a season of sorrow and suffering.

title: Van Gundy Dismisses Complaints As Excuses
description: It is only three games into the season, early for predictions of doom, but also early for excuses. Knicks Coach Jeff Van Gundy has heard both, the predictions from outsiders who see struggles ahead for his team, and excuses from his players, and he accepts neither.

title: Front Row
description: The Case of the Killer Heels

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: Focal Figure

title: Islamic Science, Language and Limits
description: To the Editor:

title: Dialysis Study Cites Chemical In 53 Deaths
description: Baxter International said yesterday that a chemical that it used to manufacture filters for dialysis patients might have played a role in dozens of deaths around the world.

title: Students Recreate the Towers' Basement
description: Architectural models are usually visions of the future, but last month Jiri Boudnik, a structural engineer who is working at the site of the World Trade Center, realized that a scale model of its ruined basement could be an invaluable aid to New York City's engineers as they planned to excavate debris from the 7-story, 16-acre underground complex. Mr. Boudnik took his idea to his alma mater, Cooper Union, and on Friday students at its Irwin S. Chanin School of Architecture presented their model to engineers from the city, the Port Authority and its contractors.

title: New York Olympics Bid For 2012 Picks Agency
description: NYC 2012, an organization dedicated to bringing the 2012 Summer Olympics to New York, is naming the Kirshenbaum Bond Creative Network in New York to handle a marketing campaign to garner support for its goal. Billings were not disclosed.

title: U.S. TRIES TO SWAY WORLDWIDE OPINION IN FAVOR OF WAR
description: The Bush administration, worried that public opinion abroad has turned against the American military campaign in Afghanistan, is making a major effort to take its case to the foreign -- and especially the Islamic -- news media.

title: Rebels' General Came, Saw, and Said Nothing
description: Two thousand Northern Alliance troops and two dozen tank crews gathered expectantly on a treeless, dirt-covered hillside here early this morning and waited for their visitor.

title: At Ground Zero, Questions About the Air
description: To the Editor:

title: Rate Reduction Expected, but How Big?
description: After nine interest rate cuts this year, the Federal Reserve may be preparing to temper its campaign to revive the economy, analysts said today.

title: Swissair Makes Deal With E.D.S.
description: The beleaguered Swissair Group said today that it had agreed to sell its ticketing and reservations unit, Atraxis, to Electronic Data Systems as it begins shedding its profitable subsidiaries.

title: F.B.I. Says Man Carried Knives Past Screeners
description: A Nepalese man was indicted today on a federal charge of trying to carry weapons onto an airplane, after the authorities said airline workers caught him boarding a flight to Omaha this weekend with several knives, a stun gun and a can of pepper spray.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOLTZFUS, MARY LESLIE
description: STOLTZFUS-Mary Leslie. On November 2, 2001 at age 94. Loving sister of the late John C. Stoltzfus. Dear sister-in-law of Bertha Stoltzfus. Devoted aunt of John A. Stoltzfus and his wife, Daly. Adoring great aunt to Charlotte E. Stoltzfus. Interment private. Memorial service at St. Thomas Episcopal Church, 5th Ave. at 53rd St., Thursday, Nov. 8th, 11 AM.

title: Traumatic Moments End, But the Reminders Linger
description: Elizabeth Bakalar and Zoe Risutto both ran for their lives on the morning of Sept. 11, fleeing their office a few blocks from the World Trade Center.

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article on Oct. 21 about the Pashtun, the ethnic group that straddles the border of Pakistan and Afghanistan, referred incorrectly to the border, which many in the tribe consider simply a line on paper. It is based on a boundary negotiated in 1893 by Sir Henry Mortimer Durand, foreign secretary to India's colonial government, not one drawn by a British general.

title: Roads to Victory in This War
description: To the Editor:

title: Focus on Health, One Problem at a Time
description: If Air Force personnel are any indication, work rules about weight can act as a powerful force to keep smokers smoking, a new study suggests.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO FALLS. The dollar rose as expectations increased for a half-percentage-point cut in interest rates by the Federal Reserve today. In New York, the euro settled at 89.71 cents, down from 90.25 cents on Friday.

title: Where Mexico (Not Salsa) Is King; It May Not Have the Hype But a Regional Music Rules
description: At the bullring-shaped Pico Rivera Sports Arena, the show kicked off on a recent Sunday with a jaripeo or rodeo. But the 5,000 fans filling up the $40 bleacher seats -- the women holding children on their laps, the men in cowboy attire -- were there not for horses but for music.

title: H.I.V. Practices Face Grim Financial Times
description: Let's say you're a primary care physician with a large number of H.I.V.-infected patients. Until a few years ago, almost all your patients died; now, with new medications, many are doing great, and you know you're making a difference. There's just one small problem: your practice is going bankrupt.

title: A Nation Challenged
description: International Opinion

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKEL, NAFTALI
description: FRANKEL-Naftali. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun mourns the passing of the beloved brother of our devoted member Esther Davis. We extend our condolences to the entire bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Rabbi Joshua Lookstein Chaim Edelstein, President

title: Company Plans to Test Cleaner Cigarettes
description: The Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation, the third-largest tobacco company in the United States, will test Advance Lights cigarettes, which the company says emit fewer toxic substances, in Indianapolis.

title: Concert Brought in $30 Million
description: Arock concert held last month that featured legends like Mick Jagger and Paul McCartney has raised $30 million for victims of the World Trade Center attacks, said Charles Schueler, a senior vice president at Cablevision, one of the concert's sponsors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSENSTEIN, HERBERT
description: WEISSENSTEIN - Herbert. The staff and Board of Aaron Davis Hall mourn the loss of Herb Weissenstein. He will be truly missed. Our condolences to his family.

title: Voting Information
description: New York City voters going to the polls today will have the opportunity to vote not only for mayor, but also for the other citywide positions on the ballot: public advocate and comptroller. In addition, there will be races in all 51 City Council districts.

title: Bethlehem Steel Financing
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation won a judge's final approval yesterday of a $450 million bankruptcy credit line to finance operations while the company restructures its debts.

title: Market Place; Despite a downturn and the terror attacks, Cisco manages a quarter-to-quarter sales increase.
description: THE steep year-long slide of Cisco Systems has apparently ended. For the first time this calendar year, Cisco's revenue increased from one quarter to the next, surpassing its own projections of flat-to-slightly-weaker sales.

title: Roads to Victory in This War
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Utility Transfer Notice
description: Dabhol Power, the Indian unit of the Enron Corporation, served an asset transfer notice yesterday to the utility of the western Indian state of Maharashtra. This takes Dabhol a step closer to terminating its agreement to sell power to the state utility, its only customer. Dabhol and Maharashtra have been involved in a payment dispute. Dabhol said the notice was necessary to protect the interests of its sponsors, lenders and other stakeholders. The company will probably serve the final termination notice soon to continue the legal process against the state utility, a company statement said. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Hearing A Revival Of the Past In a Garage
description: ''Imagine 1966,'' the vocalist Bob Garner scrawled in spray paint on a blank white canvas Sunday night at Warsaw in Brooklyn, as the Creation closed the annual Cavestomp festival of garage rock.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: FURIOUS LOBBYING IS SET OFF BY BILL ON MENTAL HEALTH
description: A plan newly passed by the Senate to broaden health insurance coverage for mental illness has touched off an intense lobbying campaign on Capitol Hill as advocates for the mentally ill try to eliminate restrictions on care.

title: Executives' Purchases Help Conseco
description: Shares of Conseco, an insurance and finance firm, surged as much as 22 percent after its chairman and other executives bought stock in the company on Friday near an all-time low.

title: Letters: Islamic Science, Language and Limits
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Another Slap In the Face
description: Foreign Minister Makiko Tanaka, who has complained that she has become sidelined as a figurehead after a series of battles with ministry officials, was rebuffed yesterday in a second attempt to go to New York this week to represent Japan at the United Nations General Assembly. Tadamori Oshima, chairman of the parliamentary affairs committee of the governing Liberal Democratic Party -- Ms. Tanaka's party -- refused to schedule a new vote to authorize her trip. Upholding Friday's rejection of Ms. Tanaka, Mr. Oshima said passing a supplementary budget promptly should take priority. James Brooke (NYT)

title: Contrasting Tudor and, at Season's End, Balanchine
description: American Ballet Theater ended its season on Sunday with a packed house at City Center amid a storm of applause that fit the cascade of happy debuts in the company's new productions. An expanded version of ''Reverie,'' a cameo for veteran dancers seen on opening night, was included.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in the special New York City Marathon section yesterday about winners in the wheelchair competition misidentified the woman shown. She was Francesca Porcellato, winner in the push-rim division, not Helene Hines, who won the hand-cycle division.

title: Shifting Stance, Taliban Demand U.N. Help to Avert an Afghan 'Catastrophe'
description: Afghanistan's ruling Taliban reversed course today and demanded that United Nations relief agencies that have faced extensive harassment from Taliban and Al Qaeda fighters ''help the people of Afghanistan'' cope with American bombing and the severe Afghan winter.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Revision Of Zero Tolerance
description: In a settlement covering more than 100 housing developments in Western states, the CBM Group has agreed to change its zero-tolerance policy of evicting the entire household after any incident of domestic violence. CBM, a property management group based in California, agreed to retrain its employees and to compensate Tiffani Ann Alvera, who was evicted from her apartment in Seaside, Ore., in 1999 two days after her husband assaulted her. The groups representing Ms. Alvera said the settlement put all landlords on notice that it was illegal to evict women who were victims of domestic violence. Tamar Lewin (NYT)

title: Islamic Science, Language and Limits
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUGENTI, MARION WALLACE
description: AUGENTI-Marion Wallace. Died at the Methodist Church Home in Riverdale, NY on November 5, 2001 at age 104. A graduate of Oberlin Conservatory of Music, she had resided in New York City since 1924. Her husband, Anthony, died in 1971. She is survived by a daughter, Martha Kershaw, a son, Thomas, four grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: Epitaph for the Twin Towers
description: The glossy pictures of the World Trade Center were ready to go. So was an accompanying letter about a four-part lecture series on the planning, construction and management of the twin towers. The meeting was to have begun on Oct. 23 -- at Windows on the World.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEMARTINI, FREDERICK C.
description: DEMARTINI-Frederick C. On Nov. 5, 2001 of Bayside. Beloved husband of Rose. Loving father of Gerri Gallo and Gina Cifichiello. Cherished grandfather of Kristine Myhre, Jason & Paul Gallo, Peter and Matthew Cifichiello. Great grandfather of Justin and Jamie Myhre. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, Tuesday 79PM, Wednesday 3-5 & 7-9PM. Funeral Mass Thursday 10AM, St. Mary's R.C. Church, Manhasset. Interment Calvary Cemetery, Woodside.

title: Editors' Note; Today's Sections
description: News of the Sept. 11 attacks and their aftermath continues to appear in Section B; index, Page B2.

title: $5 Million Settlement on Vacation Clubs
description: Med Resorts International and other providers of vacation accommodations have agreed to pay about $5 million to settle United States claims that the companies used deceptive practices to sell vacation travel club memberships.

title: Foreign Affairs; Fighting bin Ladenism
description: If you want to know why the U.S. is hated in the Arab street, read the recent editorial in the semi-official Egyptian daily, Al Ahram, written by its editor, Ibrahim Nafie. After saying that the U.S. was deliberately making humanitarian food drops in areas of Afghanistan full of land mines, Mr. Nafie added: ''Similarly, there were several reports that the [U.S.] humanitarian materials have been genetically treated, with the aim of affecting the health of the Afghan people. If this is true, the U.S. is committing a crime against humanity by giving the Afghan people hazardous humanitarian products.''

title: Farms as Business in Russia
description: Change is afoot at the Rogovatoye farm, 27,700 acres of fertile fields and cow pastures in this southwestern corner of Russia.

title: Islamic Science, Language and Limits
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: * Jean-Michel Carlo, chairman and chief executive at the Diversified Agencies Group unit of Havas Advertising, Paris, is leaving, the agency company said, to ''move to a new challenge outside the group.'' His departure comes after a decision to dissolve the unit and divide its agencies among the three main divisions of Havas: Arnold Worldwide Partners, Euro RSCG Worldwide and the Media Planning Group.

title: Putin Grows in Job, Raising the Question: For Good or Ill?
description: Now that the rush of praise for President Vladimir V. Putin's recent bold turn toward the West has begun to subside, it may be useful to examine the case of the Kremlin and Nikolai Yemelyanovich Aksyonenko.

title: POLYMER GROUP SAYS IT WILL ELIMINATE 600 JOBS
description: Polymer Group Inc. plans to cut about 600 jobs, or 14 percent of its work force, and said costs to trim its overhead and improve manufacturing will affect results in the fourth quarter. The maker of fabrics used in diapers and surgical gauze expects costs this quarter for restructuring to be less than $150 million before taxes, a spokesman, Robert Johnston, said. Polymer Group shares had plunged 76 percent this year. The plan to cut expenses will be completed by the end of next year, the company said in a statement. By trimming overhead and payroll costs and improving manufacturing operations, Polymer Group expects to save $55 million to $60 million a year. Polymer Group, based in North Charleston, S.C., said last week that its third-quarter loss widened to $11.5 million, or 36 cents a share, from $5.6 million, or 18 cents, a year ago. Sales dropped to $202.4 million from $214.4 million. The company's shares fell 11 cents, to $1.16 yesterday.

title: Arbitration Is Sought in Lumber Dispute
description: The Canfor Corporation is seeking $250 million in compensation from the United States government, which last week increased duties on most Canadian softwood imports by 67 percent.

title: Roads to Victory in This War
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVACK, A. PAUL
description: LEVACK-A. Paul. Of Yonkers on November 4, 2001. Beloved husband of Helen. Father of Ann and Brian and his wife Nancy. Grandfather of Christopher and Andrew. Calling hours at The Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 2 to 4 and 7 to 9PM Tuesday. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Barnabas Church, Bronx on Wednesday, November 7, 2001 at 10:30 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his name may be made to Fordham University Library.

title: Its All Good
description: Two bedrooms. A big living room with four windows. A kitchen with a pantry. A real dining room and a clawfoot tub. 1000 square feet. May I add "affordable" to the list? How about West Village?

title: World Economic Forum Shifts Site From Switzerland to New York
description: The World Economic Forum, the annual gathering in Davos, Switzerland, of chief executives, political leaders, academics, writers, artists and scientists from around the world, is being shifted to New York this winter, people involved in arranging the move said yesterday.

title: U.S. Takes Steps to Bolster Bloc Fighting Terror
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6  The Bush administration is taking its first steps to expand the coalition fighting the Taliban and the Qaeda terrorist network after weeks of deflecting offers from several European allies of forces to support the American war in Afghanistan.

title: Bin Laden's Wildfire Threatens Might of Saudi Rulers
description: Prince Mamdouh bin Abdel Aziz is holding court in a glass tent with wall-to-wall beige carpeting erected in the garden behind his low-slung mansion, recalling the night a decade ago when Osama bin Laden attended an evening salon to describe his exploits fighting in Afghanistan.

title: New Work May Provide Stem Cells While Taking Baby From Equation
description: In a development that may sidestep some of the ethical issues surrounding stem cell research, a scientist here says he has created stem cells that can turn into nerve cells using a kind of embryo that cannot develop into a baby.

title: Ohio Chapter Head Named United Way President
description: More than 13 months after its president resigned in a struggle over standards for effectiveness, United Way of America selected a new president yesterday.

title: Buyout Firm May Bid for Telekom Austria
description: Providence Equity Partners, the U.S. buyout firm that led the takeover of Ireland's biggest phone company in August, may bid for Telekom Austria, a consultant to the group said today.

title: Baseball's Labor Talks Are Going Nowhere
description: The collective bargaining agreement between baseball club owners and players expires at midnight tomorrow, and no negotiations for a new agreement are in sight. With each passing day, the two sides also move farther away from talks last spring that people on both sides said could have produced a new labor contract.

title: MERCER CONSULTING IS CLOSING TWO OFFICES
description: Mercer Management Consulting, an advisory firm based in New York, yesterday announced that it is in the process closing its offices in Washington and in Geneva, Switzerland. The moves, which are part of a larger restructuring that the firm said it is undertaking as a result of a slowdown in the consulting business after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, will affect about 70 employees in Washington and seven in Geneva. The firm will attempt to find jobs for those employees in other Mercer offices, a spokesman said. Jonathan D. Glater (NYT)

title: The Old and New Blended In a Valedictory Season
description: This is the final season for Gerard Schwarz as music director of the New York Chamber Symphony, the orchestra he founded in 1976. Now that he has also given up the Mostly Mozart festival, the orchestra is his last link with musical life in New York. No doubt he will turn up again, perhaps as a guest conductor and almost certainly on tour with the orchestras he directs in Seattle and Liverpool, England.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Coal Mine To Close
description: Hurt by high labor costs and cheap imports, Japan's last coal mine will close in January, Kyodo News has reported, citing company sources. Taiheiyo Coal Mine, which operates the mine in Kushiro, on Japan's northernmost island of Hokkaido, plans to transfer half of the 1,000 workers there to a subsidiary that sells mining technology. The decision came one week after the labor union at the Ikeshima Mine in the prefecture of Nagasaki accepted the Matsushima Coal Mining Company's proposal to shut its mine. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: A War on Two Fronts, and in the Anthrax Laboratories
description: Modern military campaigns are fought on two fronts -- military and public relations -- and from the outset, the Bush administration has faced severe challenges on both. On the former, the problem has been to strike arsenals and command centers secreted in the mountains of Afghanistan -- literally to ''smoke them out of their caves,'' in President Bush's words. On the latter, the challenge has been to sustain the worldwide support that poured forth on Sept. 11 against the erosion inevitable as the bombing continues, with the inescapable ''collateral damage'' and no sign of ending soon.

title: SKYWAY AIRLINES ORDERS 4 JETS FROM FAIRCHILD DORNIER
description: Astral Aviation Inc., operator of commuter airline Skyway Airlines, has placed an order valued at $177 million for four 328JET aircraft from Fairchild Dornier. Skyway, a unit of Midwest Express Holdings Inc., will get the first of these new aircraft in January 2002, with the other three coming by December 2002, Midwest Express said. Fairchild Dornier is a unit of the closely held Fairchild Aerospace Corporation. The order also calls for 10 options, which, together with the new orders, could increase Skyway's 328JET fleet to 22 by December of 2002. Company officials were not immediately available for comment. Shares of Midwest Express fell 4 cents, to $10.96.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Sex Sites Will Pay $30 Million
description: The owners and operators of playgirl.com and highsociety.com and a group of other sexually explicit Web sites have agreed to pay $30 million to settle accusations that they illegally billed thousands of consumers for services that had been advertised as free, and billed others who never visited the sites at all, the Federal Trade Commission said yesterday. The F.T.C. and Eliot L. Spitzer, the attorney general of New York State, said the Crescent Publishing Group of New York and 64 related corporations said they required credit card numbers ''to prove that the consumers were of legal age to view the adult material.'' But many visitors to the sites were charged recurring monthly membership fees ranging from $20 to $90, the commission said. John Files (NYT)

title: Northwest Reduces Fares as Much as 25%
description: Northwest Airlines today reduced some of its advance-purchase fares aimed at leisure travelers by 25 percent as the carrier, the fourth-largest in the United States, tried to revive passenger demand.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about movement by the United States and Tajikistan toward agreement on the use of military bases to support the war in Afghanistan referred incorrectly in some copies to the broadcast network on which Gen. Richard B. Myers, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, discussed sending supplies to the anti-Taliban fighters of the Northern Alliance. It was NBC, on ''Meet the Press,'' not ABC.

title: Some New Talents Gain as Stores Buy American
description: A few days after the attack on Pearl Harbor in December 1941, Hattie Carnegie, the shopkeeper, dress manufacturer and employer of personages as varied as Norman Norell and Lucille Ball, received a frantic phone call in her Manhattan workroom. It came from a friend in San Francisco, one of the Magnin brothers, proprietors of the department store that bore the family name.

title: Islamic Science, Language and Limits
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: BellSouth Brightens Forecast
description: BellSouth, the largest local telephone company in the Southeastern United States, surprised analysts yesterday with sales and earnings estimates for the coming year that were more optimistic than forecasts. BellSouth said yesterday that it expected revenue to grow 5 percent to 7 percent next year, compared with sales growth of 8 percent to 9 percent this year. The company, which is based in Atlanta, also said it expected earnings per share to increase 7 percent to 9 percent in 2002. BellSouth's estimates were a surprise after more pessimistic outlooks were provided by other large local telephone companies like SBC Communications and Qwest Communications. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Roads to Victory in This War
description: To the Editor:

title: Red Cross and Sept. 11
description: To the Editor:

title: If the Guinea Pig Dies, Beware
description: One of the most dangerous bioterrorist acts against the United States would be an aerosol attack of anthrax. Not only is anthrax resilient and highly toxic, but because a cloud of it would be colorless, odorless and invisible, no one would know it had been released. And because the spores are so small and can seep through tiny spaces, an outdoor attack could expose people both indoors and outdoors to anthrax.

title: Needed in Tehran: A Plaque to Mark 444 Days
description: To the Editor:

title: A growing list of airlines resume image advertising in the aftermath of Sept. 11.
description: THE advertisers perhaps most directly affected by the wrenching changes in the marketing landscape after Sept. 11 -- the nation's airlines -- are continuing efforts to lure customers back despite few initial signs of success.

title: Corrections
description: A report by Bloomberg News in Business Day on Friday about third-quarter earnings for MBIA Inc., a bond insurer, misstated its profit. Excluding realized gains and losses and the effect of refinancings, the figure was $1.01 a share, not 95 cents. On that basis, the results beat Wall Street expectations of 98 cents a share; they did not miss estimates.

title: The Art of Afghanistan
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Denies Taliban Claim That Dead Man Was American
description: The American Embassy in Islamabad said today that a man who the Taliban announced had died in a hospital in Afghanistan was not an American citizen, as the Taliban had asserted.

title: Finding Short-Lived Relief in Pregnancy
description: Some women with diseases related to immune system malfunctions find that their symptoms subside during pregnancy, then rebound after childbirth.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Second Look At Severance
description: Acting Gov. Jane M. Swift, left, has asked the Massachusetts Port Authority to renegotiate its severance agreement with its departing director, calling the $175,000 deal unacceptable. The director, Virginia Buckingham, agreed to the package, which consists of $112,500 in severance pay and a two-year consulting contract worth $62,500, before resigning last month. The chairman of the Massport board, Mark Robinson, said it would work with Ms. Buckingham's lawyers to assemble a ''less controversial'' package. The authority oversees Logan International Airport, where the two airplanes that hit the World Trade Center took off.

title: South Florida Spared as Storm Hits Bahamas, Losing Punch
description: Hurricane Michelle spared South Florida today, hitting the Bahamas instead with winds weakened by its deadly encounter with Cuba on Sunday.

title: Airborne Dangers
description: To the Editor:

title: Albany Bill Strengthens Buyer's Hand In Home Sales
description: Hundreds of thousands of times a year, when a house is sold in New York State, the rule is let the buyer beware. Sellers have little duty to reveal problems, and buyers have little legal recourse.

title: Wife of Canadian Slain in Kuwait Confesses
description: KUWAIT -- The wife of a Canadian man who was fatally shot last month has confessed to police that she and three accomplices were behind the attack, the interior minister said Tuesday.

title: In Pulpits, a Grateful Christian Testifies to Deliverance
description: The 9:30 service at the First Family Church here on Sunday morning began in familiar ways. The pastor's daughter led the youth choir in ''You're Worthy of My Praise.'' Ushers handed out carnations to first-time visitors. A church member testified that tithing had fulfilled her spiritual life.

title: Ever-Tighter Mayoral Race Draws to a Bitter End
description: Eight weeks after hijackers committed the worst terrorist attacks to ever take place on American soil, New Yorkers headed to the polls today to choose a successor for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: A Simple Procedure for Extending Life
description: Giving blood transfusions to elderly heart attack patients who are anemic appears to reduce their death rates within the next month, according to a study published on Oct. 25 in The New England Journal of Medicine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, LAZARUS I.
description: LEVINE-Lazarus I. A longtime resident of Sullivan County, New York, died on Saturday at age 96 in Boca Raton, Florida. Husband of the late Blanche E. Natelson, he graduated from Brooklyn Law School in 1926, was admitted to the New York Bar in 1927 & practiced law in Hurleyville, New York, until 1960 and thereafter in Liberty, New York, until 1994, retiring at the age of 89. He was elected Special County Judge and Surrogate of Sullivan County in 1932, and served as a member & Chairman of the Committee on Character and Fitness of the Third Judicial Department of the New York Bar, and was apppointed a member of the New York Bar's Committee on Professional Standards for three terms. Mr. Levine was also a member of the Sullivan County Bar Association, serving as its President in 1934, and member of the American Bar Association. He was a director of the Sullivan County National Bank for thirtyfive years & served as a member and Vice Chairman of the Board of Education of Fallsburgh Central Schools for 25 years. He is survived by two daughters, Dolores Seiler and Ellen R. Brown, and by his son, Leslie J. Levine; by seven grandchildren and seven greatgrandchildren. Services 1 PM, Tuesday, Cong. Ahavath Israel, Liberty, New York.

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of Monday, 4,591 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUROVY, WALTER
description: SUROVY-Walter. On November 4, 2001 at age 91. Beloved husband of Rise Stevens Surovy, father of Nicholas Surovy, grandather of Marisa Z. Surovy, brother of Hilda Csoka. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Rise Stevens Scholarship Fund, Juilliard School of Music, C/O Lincoln Center, NY, NY 10023, or The Lindemann Young Artist Development Program, c/o The Metropolitan Opera, Lincoln Center, New York, New York 10023.

title: Europeans Unmoved by U.S. Proposal
description: Microsoft is no nearer to resolving its antitrust problems in Europe than it was before Friday's proposed settlement with the United States Justice Department, a spokeswoman at the European Commission here said today.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Putin Responds To Racial Violence
description: Angered by a skinhead attack on an ethnic open-air market last week that left three people dead, President Vladimir V. Putin ordered his interior minister to find new ways to curb political violence, a persistent problem in Russia since the collapse of Communism. The attack last week, on Afghan, Caucasian and Asian merchants in southern Moscow, followed a similar brawl last April on the anniversary of Hitler's birthday. People from the Caucasus are frequently targets of police roundups as well. Mr. Putin also asked his justice minister to speed up work on a new law to punish acts of political violence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EATON, ELIZABETH WITSELL
description: EATON-Elizabeth Witsell, 75, of Manhattan, on November 4, 2001. Loving mother of Carolyn, Alexander, Sarah and Lisa. Treasured grandmother of Eliza, Lily, Jay, Nina and William. Sister of Frederick C. Witsell, Jr. Avid tennis player and golfer, lifelong traveler and cherished friend to many. Service Friday at 11AM at the Church of Heavenly Rest, 90th & 5th Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory and in honor of Manhattan and New Hampshire may be made to the Central Park Conservancy, 14 East 60 Street, New York, NY 10022.

title: Comics, Muslim and Jewish, Sharing a Toronto Stage
description: Enis Esmer paused to let the laughter wash over him and then dove into his next joke.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Said To Know Hijacker
description: A Jordanian student who attended an American college pleaded not guilty yesterday in federal court in Manhattan to two counts of lying before a grand jury about knowing a man suspected of crashing a jetliner into the Pentagon. Prosecutors have accused the student, Osama Awadallah, who attended college in San Diego at the time of his arrest, of lying about his associations with Khalid al-Midhar, above, one of the people suspected in the hijacking of the jetliner that crashed into the Pentagon on Sept. 11. Mr. Awadallah's lawyer, Jesse Berman, said he would seek his client's release in a bail hearing. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLAUBER, LUCILLE A.
description: KLAUBER-Lucille A. Devoted mother of Andrea Spilka and Jan (Alan) Romm. Cherished sister of Doris Levine and the late Ethel Mann. Services today, at 11 AM, at the Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Ridgewood, Queens.

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Tomorrow: Hearing On Charities For Terror Victims
description: The New York State Assembly has scheduled a hearing on the management of charities for victims of the Sept. 11 terror attack. Assembly hearing room, Room 1923, 19th floor, 250 Broadway, Manhattan, noon. Information: (518) 455-3888.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Threat To Ex-President's Trial
description: The trial of Joseph Estrada, the deposed president, threatened to veer into chaos as the presiding judge said one of his senior colleagues was trying to oust him. Judge Anacleto Badoy said he would not step down despite being accused of having an ''inflated ego'' by the chief judge of his judicial division. The prosecutor said the bickering could affect Mr. Estrada's case, which he described as a symbol of ''how we apply justice in this country.'' Mark Landler (NYT)

title: Local Elections to Test the Nation's Mood
description: In the first broad test of the nation's political mood since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, voters will go to the polls today to elect governors and legislatures in New Jersey and Virginia and mayors in a dozen or so major cities, including New York, Detroit, Houston, Seattle and Miami.
