title: Election Day
description: NEW YORK

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, ROSE
description: SHAPIRO-Rose. A former president of the NYC Board of Education, at her retirement home, Lauderhill, FL, November 3, three days short of her 98th birthday. Beloved wife of the late Morris Shapiro, mother of James Shapiro & Nina Agel, grandmother of four, great-grandmother of six. Memorial contributions to the A & F LaGuardia High School Scholarship Endowment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PACKARD, JOYCE T.
description: PACKARD-Joyce T. On November 5, 2001. Beloved daughter of Leon and Roz Cohen; mother of Sean; sister of David and Joel; sister-in-law of Abbe and Joanne, and aunt of Michael, Caroline and Nicole. Joyce made everyone around her smile, and her own smile will not be forgotten. In lieu of flowers, contributions in memory of Joyce Packard may be sent to the Ovarian Cancer Research Fund, MSKCC, 1275 York Avenue, Box E, New York, NY 10021.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Challenge Rejected
description: The High Court in Belfast threw out a challenge by hard-line Protestants to a vote to re-elect the moderate Protestant David Trimble to the first minister post, and the Northern Ireland Assembly scheduled the election for today. Mr. Trimble gained the support of 70 percent of the assembly in the original contest on Friday but lost when he failed to get the necessary majority of the Protestant ''unionist'' vote. The centrist Alliance Party then said it would let enough of its members join the unionist bloc temporarily to put Mr. Trimble over the top in new balloting. Mr. Trimble's re-election would signal a resumption of power-sharing government in return for the Irish Republican Army's decision last month to start disarming. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: A NATION CHALLENGED
description: Security Lapse at O'Hare

title: Rebels to Get American Envoy
description: Showing impatience over efforts to replace the Taliban in Afghanistan, the Bush administration today selected a veteran diplomat, James F. Dobbins, as ambassador to the Afghan opposition.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Arizona: Help For Border Traffic Congestion
description: To help speed border crossings from Mexico that slowed after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, Gov. Jane Hull has ordered the Arizona National Guard to assist customs agents at border checkpoints. Ms. Hull said 45 soldiers would be stationed at six points of entry where the heavy traffic contributes to the economy of towns on both sides of the border. Lately, she said, businesses have been complaining about the length of time it takes for commercial vehicles to pass through the checkpoints. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCNICHOL, SAMUEL
description: McNICHOL-Samuel. Lieutenant Colonel, U.S. Army, Retired. On November 4, 2001, of Great Neck, NY. Husband of the late Constance P. McNichol. Father of James G., William M., Samuel J., Margaret M. McNichol, Patricia A. Hugo, Joan McNichol-Coffman, Jane E. McNally, Clare M. Curinga and Mary A. DelPonte. Brother of Lorraine Muller and William H. McNichol. Also survived by 11 grandchildren. Visiting in the Doyle B. Shaffer, Inc. Funeral Home, Little Neck Parkway and Northern Blvd, Little Neck, NY, on Monday and Tuesday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass will be held on Wednesday at 10:45 AM, at St. Anastasia R.C. Church. Interment in All Saints Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to Great Neck Community Fund would be appreciated.

title: National Briefing | West: Alaska: Finding Ice with Radar
description: Workers began installing a radar tower that will be used to monitor icebergs in the shipping channels of Prince William Sound, where the Exxon Valdez spilled 11 million gallons of oil in 1989 after striking a reef while avoiding reported ice. The system will replace the helicopters and tugs now used to spot ice that drifts into the path of tankers hauling oil from Alaska's North Slope. It is expected to be operating by early 2002. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Anthrax Investigators Are Hoping Bronx Case Leads Them to Source
description: Investigators are intensifying efforts to trace the last encounters and daily routines of a New York hospital worker before she died of anthrax last week, hoping to unravel the mystery of who is behind the attacks that killed her and three other people and sickened a dozen more.

title: Terror Witness Withheld Theft Plot, Prosecutors Say
description: Prosecutors have told a federal judge in Manhattan that the government's chief witness in a recent terrorism trial failed to disclose, as he was required to, that he had tried to rob a currency exchange in Montreal to raise money for terrorist operations, a document shows.

title: Nets Are Winning Games but Not Fans
description: At 3-1, the Nets find themselves in a most unfamiliar place: on top of the Atlantic Division standing. But judging from the stands at Continental Arena, it is a lonely place.

title: Saudis to Sign Agreement On Assets of Terror Groups
description: Saudi Arabia announced today that it would sign an international accord adopted nearly two years ago that calls for choking off the money used by international terrorist organizations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLANER, LUELLA B.
description: SLANER-Luella B. Died peacefully November 3, 2001, at home. Beloved mother of Eugenia Ames, Barbara Winslow and Deborah Larkin. Sister to Pauline Burgo. Grandmother to Alexander, Juliet, Jessie, Samantha, Margaret. Memorial service Thursday, November 8, 10 AM, Scarsdale Congregational Church, 1 Heathcote Rd, Scarsdale. Donations in her memory in lieu of flowers to Scarsdale Public Library.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Production Level Drops
description: After decades of slow decline, production levels in British industry recorded their sharpest drop in four years in September, falling 1.2 percent from August. Around 80 percent of industrial output comes from manufacturing, which slipped 1.6 percent in September from August, its worst retreat since 1992. The numbers were much worse than economists had forecast. They reinforced speculation that the Bank of England might cut its benchmark interest rate by a quarter-point, to 4.25 percent, this week to bolster flagging growth.

title: CLASS-ACTION STATUS IS GRANTED IN U.P.S. BIAS SUIT
description: A federal judge, Thelton E. Henderson, granted class-action status to a discrimination lawsuit filed against United Parcel Service Inc. by five hearing-impaired workers who use sign language as their main form of communication. The federal lawsuit, filed in San Francisco, charged that U.P.S. did not provide hearing-impaired workers with interpreters or other communication aids, forced employees to meet federal hearing standards on non-regulated vehicles, and created an ''illegal glass ceiling for deaf workers'' in violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act. A spokesman for U.P.S. could not immediately be reached for comment.

title: For Jacob Lawrence, a Subway Showcase
description: All but unnoticed by the half-million subway riders who pass through the Times Square station each day, the last public work by a major American artist has been visible for more than a week not far from the shuttle line.

title: No Room at the Dog Shelter; With 'No Kill' Policy, Searching for Space for Strays
description: A motley pack of seven dogs slept near two gigantic heaters on Sunday in the cavernous boiler room of a blocklong blue building. Night was falling on the West New York dog pound, better known as the Department of Public Works garage.

title: Miscellany
description: * The Burger King Corporation, Miami, part of Diageo, formed a strategic alliance with AOL Time Warner, New York, to offer interactive programs and features to Burger King customers through the various media properties of AOL Time Warner, including publishing, broadcast, music, film and online. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Fairchild Shareholder Fights Pay Plan
description: The Fairchild Corporation's biggest outside investor, Gabelli Asset Management, plans to vote against the company's board in a protest over executive pay at the business, a maker of aircraft parts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEXLER, JOHN P., M.D., PH.D.
description: WEXLER-John P., M.D., Ph.D. Albert Einstein College of Medicine is profoundly shocked & saddened by the untimely death of our valued colleague and friend, Dr. John Wexler, Professor of Nuclear Medicine and of Radiology. A member of our faculty since 1973, John played an active and expansive role in the life of our community as physician, teacher and administrator. In 1996 he was named Assistant Dean for Information Technology assuming overall responsibility for coordinating the development of the medical school's Internet site. We will miss his presence and his vitality. We extend our deepest condolences to his entire family. Dominick P. Purpura, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUNEBAUM, ANNELIESE E.
description: GRUNEBAUM - Anneliese E. Peacefully on November 3, 2001, in her 96th year. Beloved widow of Kurt H. Grunebaum. Loving mother of Peter. Proud grandmother of George, Nicole and Danielle. Devoted great-grandmother of Marcus, Sebastian, Annabel, Solene and Charlotte. Services will be private. A memorial service will be held on November 13, 2001, at 2 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to The Neue Gallerie, 1048 5th Ave, New York, NY 10028.

title: Triton Reports Bigger Loss
description: Triton PCS, the wireless telephone company, said today that its third-quarter loss widened from the similar quarter last year and it added fewer subscribers than expected but revenue rose 50 percent as customer turnover remained low.

title: Anthrax Doesn't Faze Him, but Cipro? Scary
description: THE doctor's white lab coat is flung across the office sofa, sleeves drooping, as if in despair at being left behind by its wearer again. A novel teaching tool, the baseball cap with the fake hippopotamus head grafted on top, is gathering dust on its assigned hook, goofy ears askew.

title: Tips for Staying a Step Ahead of Scoliosis
description: As a teenager growing up in Belmont, Mass., Erin Mahony was, in her mother's words, ''tilted like a teapot.'' Because of a curvature of the spine called scoliosis, Erin's right shoulder was several inches higher than the left, she limped and her left arm hung down so low that her hand could touch her foot.

title: After the Race, Some Minor Disappointments and a Major Relief
description: It took Tesfaye Jifar of Ethiopia and Margaret Okayo of Kenya not much more than two hours to win the New York City Marathon on Sunday. Yesterday, it took them from dawn to dark for their victory lap around Manhattan, with appearances on the morning network news shows, a City Hall ceremony to receive the keys to the city and a champions' reception.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: VA Linux Introducing Software
description: VA Linux Systems is to introduce today its first products since it shifted course in August away from marketing computers that run Linux, an operating system distributed free. The company's new SourceForge software is a programming tool kit intended to help companies build and manage cooperative software projects. Such projects use the open-source development model behind Linux, in which programmers around the world cooperate to develop and debug software. But VA Linux, once a hot startup company, discovered that it could not make money selling Linux machines, especially after its dot-com market withered. ''In some sense, what we're selling now is the open-source development model,'' said Larry Augustin, chief executive of VA Linux, which plans to change its name to VA Software.

title: Anthrax Version of the Canary in the Coal Mine Is Suggested
description: Is waiting for people to fall ill the only way to detect the presence of anthrax spores? Or might small animals like guinea pigs be used as ''sentinels'' to provide an earlier warning?

title: A New Start for National Service
description: Since Sept. 11, Americans have found a new spirit of national unity and purpose. Forty years ago, at the height of the cold war, President John F. Kennedy challenged Americans to enter into public service. Today, confronted with a challenge no less daunting than the cold war, Americans again are eager for ways to serve at home and abroad. Government should make it easier for them to do so.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Fed Is Facing a Challenge In Rate-Cutting Campaign

title: How Osama bin Laden Became a Global Celebrity
description: HOLY WAR, INC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCREVANE, PAUL R.
description: SCREVANE-Paul R. On November 4, 2001. Formerly of Douglaston, NY. Former President of New York City Council, Commissioner of Sanitation, New York City. Husband of the late Bridie Screvane. Father of Paul Owen, Sara-Ann Steber, Christopher J. and Brian Screvane. Also survived by nine grandchildren and three greatgrandchildren. Visiting in the Doyle B. Shaffer, Inc. Funeral Home, Little Neck Parkway and Northern Blvd, Little Neck, NY, Wednesday 7-9 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial will be offered in St. Anastasia RC Church on Thursday at 9:45 A.M. Interment in Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to Metropolitan New York U.S.O., 625 8th Avenue, New York, New York, would be appreciated.

title: The Heartbreak In Yankee Land
description: To the Editor:

title: Voting Information
description: New York City voters going to the polls today will have the opportunity to vote not only for mayor, but also for the other citywide positions on the ballot: public advocate and comptroller. In addition, there will be races in all 51 City Council districts.

title: Save a Hip Bone, Save a Tooth
description: Calcium supplements can help older people hang on to their teeth as well as keep their hips strong, according to a study published late last month in The American Journal of Medicine.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Plum Island: Tighter Security Urged For Lab
description: Senator Charles E. Schumer called yesterday for a prompt ''top to bottom'' review of security at a federal research laboratory specializing in animal diseases. The Plum Island Animal Disease Center, off Long Island's North Fork, studies and handles animal pathogens like the virus that causes foot-and-mouth disease, which has devastated British beef. Noting that security has been enhanced at nuclear power plants, Senator Schumer said, ''We've got to do the same for Plum Island.'' A spokeswoman for the Department of Agriculture said a review was already under way and was expected to be released by year's end. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: Lebanon to Resist U.S. Sanctions on Hezbollah
description: The Lebanese government is indignant over American pressure to freeze the assets of Hezbollah, the Shiite Muslim organization bitterly opposed to Israel.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of Election Day arrangements in The Metro Section yesterday referred incorrectly to some government offices. All federal offices will be open today, including those in New York and New Jersey. New York State offices will also be open; only city offices will close. A corrected listing appears today, on Page D6.

title: Treasuries Increase as Nonmanufacturing Business Slumps
description: Treasury bond prices rose yesterday after a survey showed that nonmanufacturing business slumped in October more than forecast, bolstering expectations that the Federal Reserve will cut the benchmark lending rate half a percentage point at its policy meeting today.

title: Arizona's Next Aim: To Better the Marlins
description: Craig Counsell was here once before. A World Series hero with the Florida Marlins in 1997, Counsell watched that championship team disintegrate the following winter, with marquee players traded off so that the payroll could be slashed.

title: Mailing Stirs Partisan Suspicions in Passaic
description: On the eve of elections here in Passaic County, where past allegations of voter harassment have led to the appointment of a federal monitor, new complaints have surfaced about a mailing sternly warning minority voters about the penalties for vote fraud.

title: Mrs. Clinton Calls for Health Spokesman
description: SYRACUSE, Nov. 5 (AP)  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton said today that the nation needed a single person designated to notify the public on health matters.

title: Hospitals' Bigger Loss
description: To the Editor:

title: Shares Rise on Expectations That Fed Will Cut a Rate
description: Stocks rose yesterday in a broad rally led by technology issues as investors followed a familiar pattern of showing optimism just before a regular meeting of Federal Reserve policy makers.

title: OPEC Says Oil Quotas Could Drop Up to 6.5%
description: The secretary general of OPEC said yesterday that it might reduce oil production as much as 1.5 million barrels a day, or 6.5 percent, since prices have fallen to a two-year low.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Mashantucket: Casino Advocate Keeps Seat
description: A leading advocate of Foxwoods Casino who was ousted as chairman of the Mashantucket Pequot tribal council two years ago has been re-elected vice chairman of the council. The former chairman, Richard Hayward, won re-election Sunday as vice chairman of the seven-member council, a spokesman for the tribe said yesterday. Mr. Hayward, first elected in the late 1970's, worked to get Foxwoods Casino opened on the reservation in 1992. He lost his seat as head of the council to Kenneth Reels, who is up for re-election next year, the spokesman said.

title: Trivia Question
description: Here are the question and answer from the final Baseball Report of the 2001 season. Subscribe to The Baseball Report and get a new question each week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRACKEN, KEVIN H.
description: BRACKEN-Kevin H., 37. Of Manhattan (formerly of Central Islip). Kevin was a firefighter with Engine Company 40 on the Upper West Side. He lost his life heroically in the line of duty at the World Trade Center on September 11, 2001. An eight year veteran of the FDNY and former member of Engine Company 23, Kevin always had a joke & a smile for everyone he met. Cherished husband and best friend of Jennifer Liang, the two shared their passion for NYC, sports, sushi and travel. Devoted son of Hugh and Mary Bracken of Sandwich, MA (formerly of Central Islip). Loving brother of Billy Bracken & sisters Chickie Carlson, Kathy Brown and Patty Sample. Known by teammates as ''Coach Pugsley,'' Kevin coached and played on a co-ed softball team with Jen and also played on a team for his firehouse. An allaround athlete, he was an avid golfer and hockey player. Friends coined the term ''The Bracken Bounce'' to describe Kevin's uncanny luck and ability to get a shot into the woods back out onto the middle of the fairway. Along with many close friends, Kevin is also survived by a large & loving family including sister-in-law Nancy Bracken and brothers-in-law Ritch Carlson, Jim Brown and Chuck Sample, nieces Kerin, Keara and Mallory, nephew Joel, and uncle and Godfather Michael Norton. Kevin's quick wit, warm smile and companionship will be deeply missed by his family and friends. We love you very much and we will never be the same again. A memorial mass will be held at 9:30 AM, Wednesday, November 7, 2001 at St. Patrick's Cathedral in Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, contributions to aid the families of missing members of Kevin's firehouse may be made in his name to the ''E-40/L-35'', 131 Amsterdam Avenue, NYC 10023.

title: Labor of Love
New York City Elects a New Mayor
Hirschfeld Through the Years
Long-Lasting Impressions
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: The Raiders' Gannon Plays a Heady Game
description: When he was the quarterback at the University of Delaware in the mid-1980's, Rich Gannon was often the topic of conversation in the locker room among his teammates after the game. The talk was of some great touch pass he made deep that left them breathless, a cornerback he would outrun, a last-minute winning drive he led with seeming great ease.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, PHYLLIS M.
description: SIEGEL-Phyllis M. On November 5, 2001, at Lenox Hill Hospital, in her 86th year following a long illness. Beloved wife of the late Sigmund A. Siegel, M.D. Cherished daughter of the late David and Helen Moskowitz. Devoted mother of Mark and Stephen. Caring mother-in-law of Susan Bandes. Loving grandmother of David, Jonathan, Jessica, Daniel and Andrew. Phyllis was a graduate of Vassar College and Columbia Teachers College. For more than 50 years she devoted herself to the Jewish community. She served the Women's Division of the Greater New York United Jewish Appeal as chairman and executive director and as a longtime member of the Campaign Cabinet. She served the Park Avenue Synagogue as trustee, vice president, member of the school board, and president of the Sisterhood. Phyllis was among the first women called to the Torah at Park Avenue Synagogue. We will miss and love her forever. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the UJA-Federation of New York, 130 E. 59 St., New York, NY 10022. Services Thursday, November 8, 11 AM, at Park Avenue Synagogue, 50 East 87th Street.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Mud Flies Before Election
description: In a bizarre dispute between two former allies, President Chandrika Kumaratunga has accused her former parliamentary affairs minister, S. B. Dissanayake, of having offered to kill two critical journalists, the state-run newspaper reported. Mr. Dissanayake responded that Mrs. Kumaratunga was aware of murders committed by a presidential bodyguard who was himself gunned down on Friday. Mr. Dissanayake's recent defection from Mrs. Kumaratunga's coalition helped reduce it to a minority in Parliament. Elections are scheduled for Dec. 5. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: Cookies to Boost Downtown Morale
description: Cookie Island is a store that offers a bit of bright and shiny relief on a street struggling to return to normal just blocks away from ground zero. Formerly a mail-order-only business in Brooklyn, Cookie Island was to open the week of Sept. 11; it still has no working phone. But that has not stopped Billy Baldwin, the owner, above, from turning out more than a dozen kinds of nubbly, chewy cookies, like chocolate chip-oatmeal with macadamia nuts, white and dark chocolate chip, and raisin-oats-pecan. Peanut butter is freshly ground for peanut butter crunch cookies. The cookies come in sizes: small, at 60 cents ($10 a pound); medium, at $1.25; and large, at $2.50. Cookie Island, at 189 Broadway (Cortlandt Street), also sells cookie mix in a couple of flavors for $8 (just add butter and an egg; makes 25) and ice cream. For mail order: (888) 266-5434 or www.cookieisland.com.

title: Europeans Urge Israelis and Palestinians to Resume Talks
description: The European Union urged Israelis and Palestinians today to resume talks, without preconditions, to establish a lasting cease-fire, ensure security and move quickly to peace talks on a settlement that would establish an independent Palestinian state.

title: Politics and Curriculum: How History Is Taught
description: IN 1954, my eighth-grade history teacher in Queens said we could not use the term ''Civil War'' but must adopt a textbook phrase, ''War Between the States.''

title: Write What You Know? Why, No
description: For his first novel, ''The Ash Garden,'' Dennis Bock took the adage ''write about what you know'' and, in his words, ''threw it out the window.'' As he said in a recent interview, ''I wanted to stick my neck out as far as it went -- to test myself, to see if I could write about something I had absolutely no first-hand knowledge about.'' He decided to pursue a subject he was ''passionately interested in: World War II and moral ambiguity.''

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Yahoo Revises Auction Fees
description: Continuing its effort to squeeze revenue out of customers who once used its services free, Yahoo said it intended to change the way it charges sellers on its auction site. In January, to discourage frivolous postings on its auction site, Yahoo imposed fees of 20 cents to $2.25 for each item listed. Starting Nov. 20, sellers will pay only 5 to 75 cents to list their goods, but Yahoo will add a transaction fee. The company will charge sliding fees ranging from 2 percent for items selling for less than $25, plus 1 percent of the next $975, and 0.5 percent of the amount above $1,000. The pricing model, which Yahoo said customers had requested, more closely resembles that of the company's larger auctions rival, eBay. Yahoo said its changes had improved the percentage of auctions that close, to 31 percent from less than 10 percent.

title: Afghan Rebels Assert Gains, Saying U.S. Troops Helped
description: Northern Alliance officials said today that they had captured three districts near the strategic city of Mazar-i-Sharif, after what they said was the extensive involvement of American military advisers in the assaults.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Glen Cove: Transmission Line Delayed
description: Northeast Utilities is postponing plans to lay 30 miles of electric transmission lines from Norwalk, Conn., to Hempstead Harbor. Northeast Utilities, which is based in Berlin, Conn., cited a lack of response by power suppliers who would use the lines. The company called for bids from suppliers in August. But it will now wait until next year to reopen the bidding and ask for permission from the state authorities to lay the cables. Frank J. Poirot, a Northeast Utilities spokesman, said that suppliers appeared to be waiting for details of new federal regulations on trading between regional power grids. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

title: A Message to the Saudis
description: To the Editor:

title: An Election In a Shadow
description: It was a mayoral election unlike any other, following a mayoralty unlike any other. Rising above the campaign's many extraordinary developments, from the race-tinted schism within the Democratic Party to the voters' acceptance of an expensive candidacy by a wealthy political neophyte, was the specter of the man who went before.

title: Postal Service Is Expected To Ask U.S. For Bailout
description: So many Americans have shied away from mailboxes and post offices since anthrax appeared that the volume of mail handled by the United States Postal Service has dropped about 10 percent, costing at least $500 million in lost revenues and pushing the battered postal system to the brink of financial crisis, officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLANER, LUELLA B.
description: SLANER-Luella B. Died peacefully November 3, 2001, at home. Beloved mother of Eugenia Ames, Barbara Winslow and Deborah Larkin. Sister to Pauline Burgo. Grandmother to Alexander, Juliet, Jessie, Samantha, Margaret. Memorial service Thursday, November 8, 10 AM, Scarsdale Congregational Church, 1 Heathcote Rd, Scarsdale. Donations in her memory in lieu of flowers to Scarsdale Public Library.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRAWFORD, ROBERT J.
description: CRAWFORD-Robert J. On September 11, 2001 during the performance of his duties as a New York City firefighter (Safety Batallion). He was lost in The World Trade Center disaster while in the process of evacuating civilians. Beloved husband of Dorothea (Mallon), dearest father of Christine, Mark R., Jennifer Eppolito, Rachel V. Connor and Matthew J. Loving father-in-law of Georgia, Stacy, Anthony Eppolito and Billy Connor. Cherished grandfather of Alexandra and Justin Eppolito and Andrew Scott Crawford. Devoted brother of Patricia Crawford and Kathleen Rothaug. Cherished brother-in-law of John and Louise Mallon, Lois Duffy, Carole and Jim McCann, Peter and Ann Mallon and Madelyn and Ben Grisafe. Friends may call Thursday and Friday between the hours of 2-5 and 7-9 PM at The McManus Funeral Home, 2001 Flatbush Avenue, corner of Avenue M, Brooklyn. Memorial Mass Saturday 1 PM, St. Thomas Aquinas Church (Flatlands).

title: World Briefing | Americas: Nicaragua: Carter Wary On Vote Count
description: Former President Jimmy Carter, leading an observer mission, urged ''vigilance'' as election officials resumed counting votes from Sunday's presidential and legislative elections. The count has been slowed by a two-step data entry process that relies on untrained party loyalists chosen before the election, and voters have worried that the results of legislative races could be manipulated. Mr. Carter said he was deeply disappointed by the slow tally and urged officials to release more detailed local counts. Enrique Bolaos defeated the Sandinista leader, Daniel Ortega, in the presidential vote. David Gonzalez (NYT)

title: Charms of Bittersweet Solidarity
description: THERE'S a new ID badge hanging around my neck. I picked it up last week, in a tiny room equipped with a digital camera, in an out-of-the-way corner of The Times.

title: Recipe: Raspberry Coulis
description: Time: 15 minutes plus cooling 2 tablespoons sugar

title: Mets Are Planning to Be Active in the Off-Season on the Trade Market
description: For the Mets, there is a fundamental difference between this winter and last. A year ago, the Mets were coming off a World Series appearance and wanted to keep the players who made it happen. After this season's disappointment, the team is more willing to deal players who may be part of the problem.

title: Poets' Group Ousts Chief, Igniting Ire Of Members
description: The board of the Academy of American Poets has ousted its popular executive director, William Wadsworth, setting off an uproar among some of the country's most prominent poets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, ROSALIND
description: FISHER-Rosalind. The officers, Board of Directors, & staff of UJAFederation of New York mourn the passing of Rosalind Fisher, beloved mother of Nancy Englander, our generous, longtime friend, and loyal supporter of our women's campaign. We send our deepest sympathies to Nancy and her husband, Robert; to Nancy's sister and brother-in-law, Suzanne and Jeffrey Bloomberg; to their children; and to her entire family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board Joan Ginsburg, Chair, Women's Campaign John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO

title: A World Away, Just Down The Road
description: ONE of the fundamental differences between dining in Europe and dining in the United States has been that many of the finest restaurants in Europe are in the countryside. People travel for hours to have dinner at them, often making day trips out of the experience. They might take a long, meandering drive, visit family or go sightseeing, with the reward of a good meal at the end of the day.

title: Mayor-Elect Michael Bloomberg
description: In electing Michael Bloomberg mayor yesterday, New Yorkers were clearly hoping the man whom Rudolph Giuliani endorsed would turn out to be the kind of leader Mr. Giuliani has been during the weeks since Sept. 11. The choice of Mr. Bloomberg, a political novice, over Public Advocate Mark Green is in many ways a gamble, a leap into the unknown. But every resident of New York and every American who cares about the city will root for him to succeed.

title: Consolidation Is Continuing At Lucent
description: Lucent Technologies, continuing to consolidate, said yesterday that it planned to sell a unit that provides corporate consulting services and network design advice.

title: TRIBUNE CO. SEEKING A SALE OR TRADE ON RADIO STATIONS
description: The Tribune Company, the owner of The Chicago Tribune, said that it was seeking a sale or trade of its Denver radio stations to expand its television broadcasting operations. Tribune's Denver radio stations are KOSI-FM, KKHK-FM and KEZW-AM, a statement said. Tribune said in June that it was in the market for more television acquisitions as a decline in stock prices at many small broadcasters made some purchases attractive. Shares of Tribune rose 30 cents, to $33. The stock has declined 13 percent in the last year.

title: U.S. Moves to Cut 2 Financial Links for Terror Group
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- President Bush announced an international effort today to destroy two financial networks that American officials said had long been suspected of having ties to the Al Qaeda terrorist organization.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSS, AUBREY LIONEL
description: MOSS-Aubrey Lionel. On November 6, 2001, of Hackensack, NJ. Beloved husband of Harriet. Devoted father of Paula Moss and William Moss. Loving grandfather of Michael Moss, Lauren Giglio and Jessica Giglio. Memorial service Thursday, November 8, 11:00 AM at the ''Wien & Wien'' Memorial Chapel, Hackensack, NJ.

title: Footlights
description: Coming of Age

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Mortgage Lender Formed
description: Three of Germany's biggest banks, which have struggled unsuccessfully to merge with one another, announced plans yesterday to combine their mortgage banking subsidiaries into a new company that would be the biggest mortgage lender in Europe. The deal would merge the mortgage banks of Deutsche Bank, Dresdner Bank and Commerzbank and be called Eurohypo. It would start out with a combined loan portfolio of 138.3 billion euros, or $123 billion, and the three banks would have roughly equal stakes. Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)

title: People
description: * David Copithorne, president at Porter Novelli International, New York, part of the Omnicom Group, was named chief executive, succeeding Bob Druckenmiller, who was named to the new post of chairman. Mr. Copithorne is being succeeded as president by Helen Ostrowski, who had been senior partner for the Eastern region and general manager at the Porter Novelli New York office.

title: America's Resolve, Then and Now
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We will do everything we can to make sure he does not acquire the means to deliver weapons of mass destruction.''

title: Letters on the Edge, E-Mail From Beyond
description: ''At last, our long national nightmare is over,'' writes Hugh Geenen of Seattle. ''I'm not talking about Sept. 11, bioterrorism, the Taliban, Bush versus Gore, Islamic fundamentalism, the mayoralty of Rudolph W. Giuliani, Bill Buckner or anthrax. I'm talking about the incessant arrogance of the New York press (uh, that would be you) as fifth columnists for a professional sports fan base that is so parochial in its self-absorption as to make Madonna look like Mother Teresa. Thank god the better team finally won.''

title: Losing Isn't a Loss
description: Sure it hurts. How can't it? The World Series can be real nerve-wracking, very emotional. It's unlike anything else you feel as a player, coach or manager. When you're so close to winning, to see victory slip away -- it's a terrible emptiness. Some guys dwell on it longer than others. Some careers even get ruined over tough World Series losses. But I'll tell you this: The Yankees will get over their loss to the Arizona Diamondbacks. I just wish some fans would do the same.

title: The Other Jersey Shore
description: THERE are two Jersey Shores. The first is a keg party that starts on Memorial Day and continues, at top volume, through Labor Day. The second is a little cluster of old-fashioned, even genteel beach resorts, where the Victorian houses all have spacious front porches, brightly striped canvas awnings on the windows and impossibly green lawns. On long summer evenings, when dusk seems to linger forever, a dreamy kind of peace settles over the quiet streets of towns like Deal, Spring Lake and Ocean Grove that, to me, feels like happiness distilled to its purest essence.

title: Network Coverage a Target Of Fire From Conservatives
description: As television news networks cover the war, they are increasingly coming under criticism from conservatives who say they exhibit a lack of patriotism or are overly negative toward the government.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHREIER, LEONARD J.
description: SCHREIER-Leonard J. The Partners and Staff of Sterling Equities, with deep sorrow and sadness, mourn the death of our partner and friend Lenny Schreier. He will be remembered for his wisdom, generosity of spirit and his devotion to humanity. We will miss him very much, yet he will always be with us. Our sympathies are with his children Deyva and Michael, grandson Julian and brothers Arthur and Herb. Friends may join in remembering Lenny at a Memorial Service on Sunday, November 11, 2001, 11 AM at the Harlem Yacht Club, City Island, Bronx, NY.

title: Contraction's Attractions: Players
description: If two major league franchises are folded, many players could become available, ranging from All-Stars like Montreal's Vladimir Guerrero and Jose Vidro to expensive veterans like Tampa Bay's Greg Vaughn. The effort to address the lack of parity, however, could ultimately benefit big-market teams like the Yankees and the Mets.

title: U.S. TAKES STEPS TO BOLSTER BLOC FIGHTING TERROR
description: The Bush administration is taking its first steps to expand the coalition fighting the Taliban and the Qaeda terrorist network after weeks of deflecting offers from several European allies of forces to support the American war in Afghanistan.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WALT DISNEY CO., Burbank, Calif., the theme park and multimedia company, acquired the closely held Baby Einstein Company, Lone Tree, Colo., a maker of learning products for small children, to sell more toys and books for babies and toddlers.

title: America's Resolve, Then and Now
description: To the Editor:

title: Decades Of Growth Coming To an End
description: For 60 years, 16 teams dotted baseball's landscape.

title: The Front Is Here, and You're Drafted
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush and Blair Trade Praise at White House Love Fest
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- No one ever said they would be soulmates, and they aren't. But today President Bush and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain stood side by side at the White House as unwavering allies joined by war, national self-interest and what their aides say is a growing personal chemistry.

title: New Look Shaped by the Primary Comes Into Focus
description: New Yorkers who went to the polls yesterday to vote in City Council races were participating in an election that, because of new term limit laws, brought about the most sweeping changes in the Council since the five boroughs came together more than 100 years ago to form modern New York City.

title: List of Organizations
description: Here is a list of organizations and individuals with suspected terrorist ties that were designated by the Bush administration today to have their assets frozen. Spellings of names may vary.

title: Metro Matters; No Doubt: Money Wins Elections
description: HOW do you beat a man who can overwhelmingly outspend you with his own money and has the backing of a politician as universally admired as Franklin Delano Roosevelt was in his day? How do you overcome ethnic and racial tensions, a reputation for being less than lovable, the advantage that the tragedy of Sept. 11 gave to a first-time candidate claiming his business background as his strength?

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Scotland: Chickens Infected With Disease
description: About 16,000 chickens infected with avian influenza, a potentially fatal disease, were destroyed yesterday, state officials said. Tests at neighboring farms indicated that the disease had not spread, officials said. The flock belongs to one poultry owner near the town of Scotland. Avian influenza hurts the respiratory, digestive and nervous systems of birds but poses no threat to humans, said Bruce H. Gresczyk, the deputy commissioner of the State Department of Agriculture. The flock was quarantined on Oct. 12, and all Connecticut poultry owners were advised of how to protect their birds, Mr. Gresczyk said.

title: Knicks Find No Way to Stop Szczerbiak
description: Wally Szczerbiak said it did not motivate him. Perhaps he did not want to start a personal feud. But if his play tonight was any indication, the taunting that Latrell Sprewell gave him last season inspired Szczerbiak.

title: Fewer Students Suspended
description: The number of public school students suspended for bad behavior has dropped by almost 80 percent this school year, a change the Board of Education attributes to the somber mood in classrooms since Sept. 11. Schools have reported 1,455 suspensions from early September to mid-October, down from 6,910 for the same period last year. Some of the steepest declines were in Manhattan, where schools were more directly affected by the terrorist attack. FRANCINE GOLDSTEIN, the board's director of student support services, said that students were more subdued this fall and teachers more reluctant to suspend those who misbehave. But some teachers theorized that principals were afraid to suspend students because Chancellor HAROLD O. LEVY had ordered districts to try to cut suspension rates. Although a new state law allows teachers to remove disruptive students from the classroom temporarily without formally suspending them, only 110 such removals were reported.

title: Text: Mark Green's Speech
description: The following is text of the speech by Public Advocate Mark Green conceding the New York City mayoral race to Michael Bloomberg, as recorded by The New York Times .

title: Detectives Ask for Help In Tracing Victim's Steps
description: Investigators said yesterday that they believed Kathy T. Nguyen did not leave New York City in the weeks before her puzzling death from anthrax on Oct. 31, slightly constricting their quest for the infection's source.

title: All 5 Proposals Approved For Revision of City Charter
description: Voters approved all five of the City Charter revision proposals on the ballot yesterday by wide margins and passed a proposal to make the language of the State Constitution gender-neutral.

title: Suozzi Wins Easily in Rebuke of Nassau's G.O.P. Machine
description: In a sweeping victory, Thomas R. Suozzi today was elected the new chief executive of Nassau County's financially troubled government, piloting the rest of his Democratic slate to a strong showing in a fabled Republican bastion that had not elected a Democrat to the top job in more than 30 years.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Shiseido Posts Loss
description: Japan's largest cosmetics maker, the Shiseido Company, said it lost 1.48 billion yen ($12.2 million) in the first half of the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, harmed by weakening consumer spending and new regulations that require manufacturers to list a product's ingredients on the package. The company will write off $226 million as it pulls old inventory off store shelves and prepares new labels. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERMAN, FREDERICK, M.D.
description: SILVERMAN-Frederick, M.D. The Lenox Hill Hospital family expresses its profound sorrow at the passing of Frederick Silverman, M.D., a distinguished member of the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology for over 30 years. Throughout his career, his deep commitment to his patients was unwavering. Dr. Silverman earned the respect and admiration of all who knew him with his knowledge, compassion and integrity. He was a devoted and gifted educator who trained several generations of obstetricians, enthusiastically sharing with them his knowledge and love of medicine. Lenox Hill Hospital honors the memory of this truly remarkable physician who exemplified the highest standards of his profession. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife Marilyn and his three daughters. James S. Marcus, Chairman Board of Trustees Gladys George, President & CEO Allen H. Collins, M.D., MPH President, Medical Board Michael Divon, M.D., Director Dept. of Obstetrics & Gynecology

title: A Firm's Revival Comes in Crisis
description: Struggling to do business in a nation at war, unnerved by anthrax threats and at times hesitant even to open the mail, America's business leaders are looking for answers.

title: Hewletts Vow to Oppose Hewlett-Packard Merger With Compaq
description: Casting increasing doubt on the already unpopular plan by Hewlett-Packard to acquire Compaq Computer, the Hewlett family said yesterday that it would vote against the proposed takeover.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Insurer Moves To New Building
description: XL Capital Assurance, an insurance company, is moving its operations from Park Avenue to a larger space at 1221 Avenue of the Americas, a 50-story tower at 48th Street. The company signed a 20-year lease late last week for 92,600 square feet of space, according to Barry Zeller, a broker with Cushman & Wakefield, which represented XL Capital. Charles V. Bagli (NYT)

title: Torre May Be Needed to Recruit Giambi
description: Joe Torre helped the Yankees secure the free agent Mike Mussina last year by simply picking up the telephone and assuring the small town pitcher that not every inch of the metropolitan area is as bustling as Manhattan. Mussina mentioned the importance of Torre's call to him in the opening moments of his introductory news conference with the Yankees.

title: BLOOMBERG EDGES GREEN IN RACE FOR MAYOR; McGREEVEY IS AN EASY WINNER IN NEW JERSEY
description: Michael Rubens Bloomberg, a self-made billionaire who set out at the age of 59 to finance a new career in politics, was elected the 108th mayor of New York City yesterday, as voters turned to him to lead a city apprehensive about the loss of a popular mayor and anxious about a future clouded by threats of terrorism and economic turmoil.

title: Polo Ralph Lauren Profit
description: Polo Ralph Lauren, maker of Polo Sport and Club Monaco clothing, said yesterday that it had a fiscal second-quarter profit even as consumers slowed purchases after the terrorist attacks.

title: E. H. Gombrich, Author and Theorist Who Redefined Art History, Is Dead at 92
description: Ernst Gombrich, an author of panoramic erudition and probably the world's best-known art historian thanks to his best-selling "Story of Art," died on Saturday in London, where he had lived since moving from his native Vienna in 1936.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Direct Election For President?
description: A majority of parliamentary factions endorsed a plan to shift from a complex two-step electoral formula to a new system of direct presidential elections. Lawmakers said they expected the plan to be adopted in time for the next election, in 2004. Under the current system, the winner of a plurality in the 1999 election, Megawati Sukarnoputri, was outmaneuvered for the presidency by Abdurrahman Wahid in the subsequent parliamentary vote. Parliament removed Mr. Wahid in July and replaced him with Mrs. Megawati. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Kitchen-Wise Conversions, Tacked Right Onto the Fridge
description: In that dream kitchen we will all have some day, there will be every shape and size of pan, from 6-inch round to 12-inch square. But for now, there is a little cheat sheet to help out. And it can hang right on your refrigerator. It is a mock-tart magnet by Amco, 2 1/2 inches across, and it lists five common pan equivalents. Two 9-inch cake layers, for instance, equal 24 cupcakes or a 13-by-9-inch sheet cake. The equivalents are approximate, but they certainly beat guessing when the recipe is for brownies and your pans are all pie plates. An even more useful feature is a hidden measuring tape, which comes in handy for measuring unmarked pans. The magnet costs $4.98 at Zabar's, 2245 Broadway (80th Street), (212) 787-2000; and $6.50 at Broadway Panhandler, 477 Broome Street (Wooster Street), (212) 966-3434. Another magnet has measurement equivalents (1 cup equals 8 fluid ounces equals 16 tablespoons), a third has common baking substitutes and a fourth gives cooking times for meat. AMANDA HESSER

title: Homer's Odyssey
description: Each episode of The Simpsons takes nine months to complete.

title: Orlando Getaways
description: There's no magic to turning two nights into three. The Magical Orlando Getaways program, for example, lets you pay for two nights gets the third one at no extra charge at over 65 hotels. The offer is good through Dec. 20, and restrictions apply based on the hotel. Rates per night start at $32 (Days Inn Lakeside in Orlando) and go up to $240 (Universal's Portofino Bay), but most are well below $100 a night. Refer to the program by name when reserving. For a listing of the hotels, call up www.orlandoinfo.com/getaways . Call (800) 551-0181.

title: Not the Grand Vin, but Still Grand
description: Poking around wine shops here and in Bordeaux last week, I was surprised to see how many second wines are to be found on shelves. Second wines are those that chateaus have rejected for their principal offerings, often known as ''grands vins,'' or first wines. But this doesn't mean they are mediocre -- far from it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCREVANE, PAUL R.
description: SCREVANE-Paul R. On November 4, 2001. Formerly of Douglaston, NY. Former President of New York City Council, Commissioner of Sanitation, New York City. Husband of the late Bridie Screvane. Father of Paul Owen, Sara-Ann Steber, Christopher J. and Brian Screvane. Also survived by nine grandchildren and three greatgrandchildren. Visiting in the Doyle B. Shaffer, Inc. Funeral Home, Little Neck Parkway and Northern Blvd, Little Neck, NY, Wednesday 7-9 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial will be offered in St. Anastasia RC Church on Thursday at 9:45 A.M. Interment in Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to Metropolitan New York U.S.O., 625 8th Avenue, New York, New York, would be appreciated.

title: 'The Fat Lady' Has a Few More Songs
description: EVERY Sunday afternoon, aficionados of eccentricity and nutritional incorrectness can still get a fix of ''Two Fat Ladies,'' its dotty duo zooming through the impossibly lush English countryside on a motorbike to yet another quaint kitchen where the cream will flow.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about property of the C.I.A. and the Secret Service buried at the World Trade Center site misstated the nearby location of the two agencies' former offices. While the agencies stored vehicles beneath the Custom House, at 6 World Trade Center, their offices were in No. 7.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KINNALLY, HOWARD G., JR.
description: KINNALLY-Howard G., Jr. Of Bronxville on November 5, 2001. Husband of the late Anne Power Kinnally, father of Timothy and Robert, son of Gertrude and the late Howard Kinnally, brother of Richard, Robert and the late Timothy. Grandfather of Meaghan and Sean. Calling hours at The Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 PM Thursday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville on Friday November 9, at 10 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, FLORENCE
description: SINGER-Florence. The Officers, Board of Governors and members of Metropolis Country Club mourn the passing of our esteemed member, and extend our heartfelt condolences to her husband, Eugene and her family. Corey B. Rabin, President Joyce Baumgarten, Secretary

title: Sports of The Times; Owners Pitch High and Inside to Players
description: Here, finally, baseball's band of merry multimillionaires, its A-Rods and other assorted lightning rods, have been confronted with the flip side of unencumbered financial freedom. The owners have said, well, we can't seem to convince you at the bargaining table that we are suffering from a dire competition gap so we'll have to deal with the problem in the only way we probably don't need the consent of the union. We'll lop off the weakest of the weak, and possibly even two at a time.

title: A Cozy Spot in Cutchogue
description: FOR a spirit-lifting weekend getaway, it's difficult to beat the old towns of Mattituck, Cutchogue, Southold and Greenport on the North Fork of Long Island, with their white clapboard houses and quiet tree-lined streets surrounded by working farms and miles of vineyards.

title: Philadelphia Inquirer Editor Is Forced Out
description: Robert J. Rosenthal, the editor of The Philadelphia Inquirer, was forced out of his job yesterday in an abrupt culmination of months of tensions brought on by disagreements with executives of its corporate parent, Knight Ridder, over the newspaper's journalistic and strategic ambitions.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Horse Betting Surges
description: Despite global economic uncertainty, bets flowed into gambling companies nationwide for the 2001 Melbourne Cup horse race, which is celebrated with a state holiday in Victoria and afternoons off by many Australians in the rest of the country. TAB Ltd. took in record bets worth 43 million Australian dollars, or $21.9 million, an increase of 4.6 percent from last year, according to a spokesman, Peter Fletcher. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: More Troops, More Accusations, More Economic Stimulus
description: Naturally, the Bush administration has wanted international support for its war on terrorism, but only up to a point. British troops aside, the idea of foreign armies joining the actual fighting in Afghanistan has hardly thrilled the Pentagon, where the feeling is that more players mean more back-seat drivers. So Washington has for the most part ignored offers of help. Until now.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POPS, JOSEPH L.
description: POPS-Joseph L. On Nov. 5, 2001 at 81 years. Beloved husband of Marion. Devoted father of Susan Pops and Vicki and Herb London. Cherished grandfather of Jaclyn. Dear brother of Paul. Service today, 11:30 AM ''Parkside'' Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Ave., B'klyn, NY (opposite Kings Plaza).

title: JetBlue, Exception Among Airlines, Is Likely to Post a Profit
description: Less than two years after it began flying, JetBlue Airways is making money at a time when nearly all major airlines are posting record losses. The fast-growing low-fare airline, based at Kennedy Airport in New York, is expected to announce a profit today of $10.5 million in its third quarter on $82.6 million in revenue.

title: Pirro Is Victorious a Year After Her Husband's Conviction
description: A year after her husband was sentenced to federal prison on tax fraud charges, Jeanine F. Pirro, the Westchester district attorney, emerged victorious in her bid for a third term tonight, beating an unknown rival who sought to link Mrs. Pirro to her husband's case.

title: An Evening of Lieder to Hear and Behold
description: If Merchant-Ivory were to make a period film about Franz Schubert, Christoph Genz would be ideally cast as a Schubertiade singer. Not because this young tenor, in his American recital debut in an all-Schubert program on Monday night, showed himself a master of period style, but rather because he was able to make this song literature so compelling to a 21st-century audience.

title: A Portrait of an Architect Who Was Drunk on Form
description: GAUD

title: Traveling the Seas From Home
description: When the Makulu II sets out on its second voyage around the world on Nov. 16, students from 11 New York City public schools will accompany the 43-foot sailboat on its educational mission. The students will not actually be on board, but will watch the action over the Internet. During the boat's first voyage, students at the Salk School of Science in Manhattan chatted with children in the Cook Islands, using the ship's crew as intermediaries. Reach the World, a nonprofit group, links the classrooms to the boat, and the Institute for Learning Technologies at Teachers College of Columbia University provides technical support. The two-year voyage can be followed on this Web site: www.reachtheworld.org.

title: A True Taste of Vietnam, but With a Parisian Feel
description: I COULDN'T help feeling bittersweet on my first visit to Nam, a handsome new Vietnamese restaurant in TriBeCa not so far from the World Trade Center site. Whenever I go to a restaurant for the first time, I feel a mixture of anticipation, hope and sometimes a little dread. But this was different.

title: E-mail won't soon replace regular mail in the direct marketer's reach for new customers.
description: PITY the poor direct marketer.

title: Fed Cuts Rate Again
description: The Federal Reserve cut its key short-term interest rate for the 10th time this year, pushing it down to a level not seen since the presidency of John F. Kennedy. The rate was cut by a half a percentage point.

title: Moderate Re-elected in Ulster; Vote Advances Peace Accord
description: The moderate Protestant leader David Trimble overcame the blocking tactics of hard-line Protestant opponents today and was re-elected first minister of the Northern Ireland Assembly.

title: Respite on the River
description: EVER since I spent a summer -- and a small fortune -- exploring the Hudson Valley, the Hudson House in Cold Spring has been my preferred antidote to major stress. The town itself is the most charming spot on the river, picturesque but completely real, and the inn, built in 1832, is the best place I know for an overnight respite. Getting there is also half the healing: Cold Spring is a world away from Manhattan intensity but easy to reach in a little over an hour if I leave the driving to Metro-North, whose tracks hug the river with dazzling views all the way.

title: Federal Plan for an Aid Formula Is Criticized
description: The Justice Department has provoked a sharp debate among lawyers by asking whether it should use formulas to help determine awards from the federal fund for victims of the Sept. 11 terror attacks.

title: How the Polls Were Conducted
description: The Election Day polls were based on questionnaires completed by voters as they left voting stations throughout New York City and New Jersey yesterday. Questionnaires in New York City were available in English or Spanish.

title: Fewer Students Suspended
description: The number of public school students suspended for bad behavior has dropped by almost 80 percent this school year, a change the Board of Education attributes to the somber mood in classrooms since Sept. 11. Schools have reported 1,455 suspensions from early September to mid-October, down from 6,910 for the same period last year. Some of the steepest declines were in Manhattan, where schools were more directly affected by the terrorist attack. FRANCINE GOLDSTEIN, the board's director of student support services, said that students were more subdued this fall and teachers more reluctant to suspend those who misbehave. But some teachers theorized that principals were afraid to suspend students because Chancellor HAROLD O. LEVY had ordered districts to try to cut suspension rates. Although a new state law allows teachers to remove disruptive students from the classroom temporarily without formally suspending them, only 110 such removals were reported. Abby Goodnough

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EATON, ELIZABETH WITSELL
description: EATON-Elizabeth Witsell, 75, of Manhattan, on November 4, 2001. Devoted wife of the late William Mellon Eaton. Loving mother of Carolyn, Alexander, Sarah and Lisa. Treasured grandmother of Eliza, Lily, Jay, Nina and William. Sister of Frederick C. Witsell, Jr. Avid tennis player and golfer, lifelong traveler and cherished friend to many. Service Friday at 11AM at the Church of Heavenly Rest, 90th & 5th Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory and in honor of Manhattan and New Hampshire may be made to the Central Park Conservancy, 14 East 60 Street, New York, NY 10022.

title: Onetime A.I.G. Heir Apparent To Be Chief of Small Insurer
description: Evan Greenberg, who walked away from a chance to run one of the world's biggest insurance companies, has agreed to become the chief executive of a relatively small insurer based in Bermuda.

title: China's Upbeat Governor in Tibet Promises Investment
description: China's top official here said today that a determined influx of investment from Beijing over the next decade would bring prosperity and social harmony to Tibet, and he dismissed any notion that the money was intended to dilute the culture of a region occupied by Chinese Communist troops more than 50 years ago.

title: Big Hits And Misses In Auction At Christie's
description: For an hour and a half last night, the world stopped at Christie's as a group of voracious collectors grabbed and fought over 25 paintings and sculptures collected in the 1920's and 30's, as soon as artists like Picasso and Mir, Lger and and Magritte had finished them. The rarity of many of the works, coupled with the fact that the proceeds would go to charity, spurred buyers to heights that surprised even the auction house.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAKOVER, SYLVIA
description: MAKOVER-Sylvia. Beloved wife of the late Abraham. Devoted mother of David and Sharon. Grandmother to Jeremy, Daniel, Judah, Ilana, Avishag, Netta, Hillel and Mishael. Services today, November 7, 2001, 2pm, at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, L.I.

title: Man in the News; Flexibility in Victory; James Edward McGreevey
description: He has been introducing himself to the New Jersey public for six straight years, but James Edward McGreevey has never really gotten past hello.

title: Confusion, but It Was No Florida
description: There had been predictions of mayhem: broken machines, overwhelming lines, Florida-like chaos. But when voters finally made it to the polls yesterday for the city's general election, they found only a few sporadic glitches. The most serious seemed to be the ballot itself, which left many voters struggling, behind the curtains, to locate levers corresponding to a group of City Charter proposals.

title: A Black Immigrant's Dead-End Struggle
description: The German social melodrama ''Otomo'' has a fascinating weight. Spare and taut, it follows the story of Frederic Otomo, a Cameroon immigrant living in Stuttgart. He's played by Isaach de Bankol, whose fine bone structure and faraway gaze make him seem even further apart from the pale, suspicious Germans he lives among. He seems to be staring into the distance when he's in the same room with someone, an aloofness that plays as a kind of distracted royalty.

title: The Best-Kept Secret of Irish Theater: Tom Murphy
description: Many people who attended the Abbey Theater's Tom Murphy season in October have been mulling over how to consider his emotional and enduring body of work, so Declan Hughes tried to help.

title: Year After Florida Vote Fiasco, Congress Is Acting on Changes
description: Bipartisan bills to help fix the election system are taking shape in both the House and the Senate, with lawmakers saying that if they do not act quickly, they will fail to make meaningful improvements in time for next year's elections.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Inside Art column on Oct. 26 about the Norman Rockwell exhibition that opened Saturday at the Guggenheim Museum misstated the order of the show's tour. It opened at the High Museum of Art in Atlanta -- not at the Norman Rockwell Museum in Stockbridge, Mass., where it arrived after stops in Chicago, Washington, San Diego and Phoenix.

title: Reckonings; A Cross of Dollars
description: When Franklin Roosevelt took the United States off the gold standard in 1933, his budget director was aghast. ''This is the end of Western civilization!'' he declared. In fact, the real threat to civilization was the Depression and its political consequences, and one shudders to think what might have happened if Roosevelt hadn't defied monetary orthodoxy.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Stuyvesant Air-Quality Dispute
description: Parents and Board of Education officials clashed over air quality at Stuyvesant High School, which is four blocks north of the still-smoldering World Trade Center site. An environmental consultant hired by the parents has advised them that the school's dust levels are ''a potential health concern.'' Marilena Christodoulou, the parent association president, said they want special filters, known as HEPA filters, installed. But David Klasfeld, the deputy chancellor for operations, who met with the parents yesterday, said such filters were incompatible with Stuyvesant's ventilation system. Ms. Christodoulou said the parents would await further air tests and explore ways of overhauling the ventilation system before deciding what to do next. Abby Goodnough (NYT)

title: Omnicom Unit Gets Adobe Systems Job
description: Adobe Systems in San Jose, Calif., has named Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco, part of the Omnicom Group ( news/quote ), to handle its American advertising assignment. Billings were estimated at $20 million.

title: America's Resolve, Then and Now
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Drug Traffickers Seized
description: Federal officials announced the arrest of two important drug traffickers, one of whom may have information on the whereabouts of Joaqun Guzmn, a cocaine smuggler who escaped prison earlier this year. Jess Castro Pantoja and Adn Segundo Prez, who were arrested over the weekend, are former federal police officers and leaders of two of Mexico's largest cartels. Graham Gori (NYT)

title: Comings, but Mostly Goings, at the Stadium
description: A harmonic convergence pulled together Joe Torre, Paul O'Neill and Tino Martinez one last time at Yankee Stadium yesterday. Martinez went to clean out his locker for perhaps the last time and bumped into Torre as the manager arrived. As Torre and Martinez entered Yankee Stadium, O'Neill happened to be leaving with his 8-year-old son, Aaron, on the way to O'Neill's life after baseball.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: Changes at Heineken
description: Heineken Holding, which controls the Dutch brewer of the same name, said today that Alfred Heineken would step down as head of the management board in April and be replaced by a board member, Maarten Das. Mr. Das will also join the supervisory board of Heineken N.V., the maker of Heineken and Amstel beers. Heineken's supervisory board will also replace its chairman, with Jan Maarten de Jong of ABN Amro Holding.

title: Profit Falls 2.9% at Oxford
description: Oxford Health Plans Inc., one of the biggest health insurers in the New York area, said today that third-quarter profit fell 2.9 percent as medical costs rose and the company added customers.

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of Monday, 4,591 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR SLIPS. The dollar was little changed after the Federal Reserve cut interest rates. In New York, the euro settled at 89.73 cents, up from 89.71 cents on Monday. The dollar traded at 121.06 yen, down from 121.80 yen.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a chart yesterday with an article about Osama bin Laden's challenge to the ruling family of Saudi Arabia misstated the name and title of the leader who serves below the ailing King Fahd. The official is Crown Prince Abdullah Abdel Aziz al-Saud (not simply Abdel Aziz); he is the first deputy prime minister; the title of prime minister, though rarely used, belongs to the king.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: 10 Executions In Beijing
description: Two migrant workers accused of killing a dozen people during robberies and eight other ''thieves and murderers'' were executed in Beijing yesterday, The Beijing Evening News reported. China is conducting an anti-crime drive in which thousands of people are being executed in an effort to cow criminals and reassure people worried about a rising crime rate. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: NPR's Story Project Proves Truth Is Stranger; Listeners' Tales Filled With O. Henry Twists
description: There were 5,000 stories. In one, six teenagers and their father go to the beach after their mother has been murdered and spend several days in a drunken stupor. In another, a man sits down opposite a woman in a restaurant. She gives him her phone number. He puts it away in his coat, only to have the coat stolen. He searches in vain for the woman. A few months later in a restaurant in Paris, he is by chance seated opposite her again, and this time their hearts are joined.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Partying For Money, But Quietly
description: The National Republican Senatorial Committee is holding its seventh annual fund-raising bash tonight in Washington. It is the first to be held while Republicans control the White House, but it will not have the benefit of a White House headliner. Republicans say it would be inappropriate for either President Bush or Vice President Dick Cheney to make partisan fund-raising appeals in person while the nation is at war. Katharine Q. Seelye (NYT)

title: Long Wait for Democrats, but It's Glee at Last
description: The Democrats finally won the right to cry victory tonight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, LAWRENCE D., M.D.
description: JACOBS-Lawrence D., M.D. The passing of Larry Jacobs, a preeminent neurologist who personified the ideal of the compassionate physician, saddens all of us at Biogen. Larry was among the first to see the potential of interferon beta in the treatment of multiple sclerosis. Today, as a result of his research and determination, more than 114,000 patients throughout the world use AVONEX (Interferon beta-1a) therapy to slow the progression of disability and minimize the number and severity of the exacerbations associated with MS. Larry was a close colleague and friend to all of us at Biogen. We established the Irvin and Rosemary Smith Chair in Neurology at the University of Buffalo School of Medicine in his honor in 1998. In his memory, we will continue to work toward finding improved treatments and the ultimate cure for this devastating disease. Our deepest condolences to Pam and their family. Burt A. Adelman, M.D. Executive Vice President Research and Development James C. Mullen President and CEO James L. Vincent Chairman of the Board Biogen, Inc.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Montana: Expecting A Bush Posting
description: Rebecca A. Watson, who was assistant general counsel in the Energy Department under President Bush's father, said she expected the president to appoint her as assistant secretary of the interior for land and minerals management, a position that would put her at the helm of the nation's biggest land management agency. Ms. Watson, a Helena layer, is a former law school classmate of Interior Secretary Gale A. Norton. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: Adviser in Tawana Brawley Case Pays Off Defamation Award
description: More than two years after he was found to have defamed a former prosecutor in the Tawana Brawley case, Alton H. Maddox Jr. has finished paying off a $95,000 damage award against him.

title: Terror Follows Immigrants to America
description: Immigrants who came to America to escape strife-torn nations and start businesses in the homeland of entrepreneurship are suddenly facing some of the same fears they had fled. They came here from the Middle East, from the former Soviet bloc, from Africa, from Latin America. They left so they would never again have to worry about governments regulating their every move or bombs exploding in the streets or mustard missiles slamming into their homes.

title: On the Dock, Holes in the Security Net Are Gaping
description: The big cargo ships and ships with truck-size containers pull up to docks where no one inspects their contents. Brown tankers from the Middle East steam into the bay, slide under a drawbridge that bisects the Fore River and tie up by terminals, tanks and a pipeline that carries the oil that heats Montreal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALLORAN, VINCENT GERARD
description: HALLORAN-Vincent Gerard. Of North Salem NY, was lost in the line of duty while serving as a Lieutenant for the New York City Fire Department at the World Trade Center on September 11, 2001. He was 43. Beloved husband of Marie and a devoted and loving father to his sons Jake 15, Conor 13, Aidan 12, Kieran 9, and Declan 2. Another child is due in May. As a Lieutenant, he was deployed to lead his men in the evacuation of the North Tower. As a true hero, he placed his men's lives, and those of countless others, before his own. He began his career as a firefighter at Engine 262 in Astoria, Queens and later served at Engine 43 in the Bronx prior to being assigned to Ladder 8 in NYC, as a Lieutenant. He celebrated his twentieth year with the FDNY on September 5, 2001. He was born in Flushing, NY to Joseph and M. Alice Halloran in 1958. Vincent attended St. Kevin's Parochial School, St. Francis Prepartory School and took various courses at the City College of New York, the New York Institute of Technology and the Empire State College. In addition to his wife and children, Vincent is survived by his mother, M. Alice of Flushing and his siblings, Maureen, Terence, Patricia and James, their spouses and children. He will also be greatly missed by his father-in-law and mother-in-law Ernest and Theresa Parkanzky of Van Wert Ohio, his brothers and sisters-in-law, Dan, Karen, Connie, Paul and John, their spouses and children. He is predeceased by his father Joseph who passed away in 1991. Vincent will be remembered by those who knew him and loved him as a man who showed his care and concern for all he met, who graced others with his overwhelming generosity, who proudly displayed his love for children and as a man who always shared his brilliant smile and love of life. If we follow his example, we too can make a difference. In lieu of flowers, your contribution to the UFA Widows' and Children's Fund or the Northern Ireland Children's Enterprise (Mount Kisco) in Vincent's name would be greatly appreciated. A Memorial Mass will be held on November 9, 2001 at 9:30AM at the Cathedral of St. Patrick, NY NY. Gone but not forgotten.

title: Recipe: Mint Ice
description: Time: 20 minutes plus 4 1/2 hours' cooling and freezing 2 cups sugar

title: The Front Is Here, and You're Drafted; Bioterror Dangers
description: To the Editor:

title: Louis Armstrong Centenary
description: Louis Armstrong may be well known, but he is not well understood, said DAVID LALAMA, professor of music at Hofstra University, which is host of a symposium on the great jazz trumpeter Nov. 15 to 17 to mark the 100th anniversary of his birth. ''We have to do a better job fleshing his life out,'' Professor Lalama said. The symposium will feature the jazz producers GEORGE AVAKIAN and GEORGE WEIN as well as performances by Johnny Blowers and the Louis Armstrong Legends, both Armstrong contemporaries, and the Armstrong Legacy Band featuring the trumpeter Randy Sandke and other influenced by Armstrong.

title: Beyond Our Shores, A Battle for Opinion
description: To the Editor:

title: Liberties; Talkin' Ain't Fightin'
description: It's not easy to demonize a demon. But President Bush is trying.

title: Back to Business: Baseball Votes to Drop 2 Teams
description: In a move that Commissioner Allan H. (Bud) Selig said was necessary for economic reasons, Major League Baseball owners voted overwhelmingly today to eliminate two of their 30 teams before next season. The two teams are to be determined, Selig said, but the strong feeling among team executives was that they would be the Montreal Expos and the Minnesota Twins.

title: Colorful Miami Mayor Ousted; Race to Be Decided in Runoff
description: Joe Carollo's colorful and controversial time as mayor of Miami ended tonight as voters passed him over for two candidates who will now compete in a runoff election to replace him.

title: Text: Michael Bloomberg's Speech
description: The following is the speech by Michael Bloomberg declaring victory in the New York City mayoral race, as recorded by The New York Times .

title: Seeking City Money, Lincoln Center Submits Its Renovation Plans
description: After months of argument, Lincoln Center's powerful performing arts organizations agreed this week to send City Hall a redevelopment plan of nearly $1.2 billion, which does not include a proposed separate on-campus home for the New York City Opera but sets aside $240 million for a new opera house elsewhere if a site can be found.

title: CALENDAR
description: Act I, With Lunch

title: Fordham Law Dean Retiring
description: After 20 years as dean of the Fordham University School of Law, JOHN D. FEERICK, 65, will step down in June. ''It has always seemed to me that I should pass the baton when the school was strong and the challenges ahead were exciting,'' said Mr. Feerick, who has held his post longer than any other law school dean in New York State. Mr. Feerick graduated from Fordham and Fordham Law and, before becoming dean, developed the labor and employment law practice at Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom. Along with his role as an administrator, Mr. Feerick served on a number of commissions. He also acted as an arbitrator; it was he who ruled in 1998 that the Golden State Warriors had to reinstate LATRELL SPREWELL, the All-Star shooting guard who choked his coach, and that the National Basketball Association had to shorten Mr. Sprewell's one-year suspension. Mr. Feerick said he hoped to write about the Constitution, teach, continue in public service and play with his grandchildren. Karen W. Arenson

title: The Neediest Cases; Lifetime Caring for Father Leaves 2 Brothers Little for Themselves
description: Bill and Jeff Collins have just a little more than nothing in their four-room apartment in Rego Park, Queens.

title: British Chain Reports 20% Profit Surge
description: Radical changes at Marks & Spencer, once a stalwart of British retailing, seemed to be paying off today when the company announced a 20 percent surge in six-month profit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALSH, ROSEMARIE A.
description: WALSH-Rosemarie A. On Nov. 5th. Survived by Ann Wazeter, Michael M. Walsh, Esq., four nieces and nephews, many aunts, uncles, cousins, a brother and sister-inlaw. She was preceded by her parents. Harmon Funeral Home, Staten Island, NY on Wed. 2-4PM & 7-9PM. Mass on Thursday at St. Clare's on Nelson Ave., S.I. Interment Resurrection Cemetery, S.I.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EFROS, JUDITH (JUDY) B. (NEE BREITMAN)
description: EFROS-Judith (Judy) B. (nee Breitman). Beloved, darling wife and best friend of Edwin Efros. Loving, caring mother of Ellen Anne Efros-Kahn and Paul Steven Efros. She fought a long and heroic battle against disease. She had been a fine pianist, and almost to the end, was an avid gardener whose works were a delight to the eye. Judy loved to travel and had exceptional ability to make friends everywhere. She had a great flair for interior design and apparel but never was ostentatious. A graduate of New York University and recipient of a Master's Degree from C.W. Post College, she volunteered professional family counseling services to Nassau County and New York State agencies, in particular those overseeing the operation of nursing homes.
