There will be a memorial service on Sunday, November 18, 2001 at 12:30PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. No flowers please. Instead, a gift to your favorite charity or to the Jewish Guild for the Blind, 15 West 65th Street, New York, New York 10023, in her memory, will be deeply appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERT, FRIEDA MOSKALIK, PH.D.
description: SILVERT-Frieda Moskalik, Ph.D. Age 80. Sociologist and author, died on November 3. She was a noted educator who taught sociology at the Institute of Sociology, Buenos Aires, Argentina, Dartmouth College, City College of New York, Brooklyn College and Sarah Lawrence University. As an activist in the struggles against oppression at home and abroad, she co-authored ''Dissent Denied: The Technocratic Response to Protest,'' and many articles including ''Fate, Chance and Faith,'' about the Cuban revolution. She was active in the peace, civil rights and student movements. She was the wife of the late Kalman H. Silvert, mother of Henry, Benjamin and Alexander; mother-in-law of Morrie, Andrea and Diana; grandmother of Lea, Eli, Kal and Che; and sister of Nora Sterling. For information about the Commemoration of Frieda's life, please contact her son Henry, NYC.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Norwich: Candle Cited As Fire Cause
description: Fire officials have determined that an overturned candle caused a fire that killed four children on Saturday, Fire Chief James Walsh said. Investigators do not know know how the candle, encased in a glass jar, ignited combustible materials around it. Clark Whitfield, 13, Dexter Whitfield, 10, Isaiah Whitfield, 5, and Daniel Leon, 5, died in the fire. The boys died of smoke inhalation in a second-floor bedroom. Nicholas Whitfield, 14, brother of three of the boys and their baby sitter, was at a nearby apartment when the fire broke out. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBLATT, LEE (NEE FIRESTONE)
description: GREENBLATT-Lee (nee Firestone). Beloved wife of the late Samuel, gently passed away in her 90th year in Boca Raton, FL, on November 6, 2001. Loving mother of Sheila and Marvin Shenfeld, Judith and R. Paul Kashden and Joan and Michael Nelson. Adored grandmother of Steven & Wendy Shenfeld, Robert Shenfeld, David Shenfeld, Jody and Dr. Steven Bloomfield, Ronald Kashden and Kelly Franklin, Mark Kashden, Christopher Nelson and Laura Cordes, Emily Nelson and Jennifer Nelson. Great-grandmother of Kyle, Ricki and Michael Shenfeld and Zoe and Orion Bloomfield. Services Private.

title: In Congress, Harsh Words For Red Cross
description: The American Red Cross came under scathing criticism today from members of Congress who expressed outrage and astonishment over the agency's recent decision to withhold more than $200 million in charitable donations intended for the families of the victims of the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Leftovers From an Old War
description: After a recent meeting with Russia's foreign minister, Igor Ivanov, Secretary of State Colin Powell proclaimed a new era: ''Not only is the cold war over, the post-cold war period is also over.'' When President Vladimir Putin visits President Bush at his ranch in Crawford, Tex., next week, they will have an extraordinary opportunity to turn Secretary Powell's encouraging words into reality. Unfortunately, they will have their work cut out for them -- the nuclear arsenals of the two nations are still stuck in the cold war.

title: Fireside and Candlelight
description: MY fondest memories of going out to dinner in the Connecticut countryside as a young girl came flooding back Sunday night when I walked into the Elms in Ridgefield with my daughter, son-in-law and two grandchildren. Past stately clapboard houses and equally stately trees, some still with golden and red leaves, the inn, built in 1799, looked familiar and welcoming. Inside, the warmth of the fireplaces took the chill off the evening air. Charming primitive murals cover the walls of the wide center hall, depicting the Revolutionary War Battle of Ridgefield. Both the tavern room and the dining room are softly lighted with candles.

title: Business Travel; The nation's airline security system continues to come up short in its basic responsibility.
description: ANYONE gathering evidence to support growing suspicions that the airport security system is pretty much out of control has to be looking this week at Subash Bahadur Gurung as Exhibit A.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Fishery Groups Sue Over Dams
description: A coalition of environmental and fishery organizations is suing the Bonneville Power Administration for its decision to limit the amount of water it diverts from turbines in its hydroelectric dams this spring and summer, saying the administration, a federal agency, violated the Northwest Power Planning and Conservation Act by not balancing financial and power needs with those of migrating salmon. Plaintiffs in the suit, filed on Monday in District Court in San Francisco, include the Sierra Club and the Pacific Coast Federation of Fishermen's Associations. The administration provides 45 percent of the Northwest's power. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: America's Resolve, Then and Now
description: To the Editor:

title: It's a Free Country
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TISHMAN, FRANK
description: TISHMAN-Frank. On November 6, 2001. Beloved husband of Elaine. Loving and proud father of Jamie and Pamela. Dear father-in-law of Matthew and Marc. Adored grandfather of David, Rachel, Isabel, Jacob and Joshva. Caring brother of Henry and William. Interment private.

title: Sports of The Times; O'Neill Moves On Gracefully
description: THE tall man with the familiar gentle face, his 8-year-old son at his side, entered Yankee Stadium for the last time yesterday morning as a member of the Yankees. He happened to glance ahead, and through the tunnel he noticed a piecemeal view of the park. How bright the green grass looked in the sunshine, he thought, how beautiful.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a chart yesterday with an article about Osama bin Laden's challenge to the ruling family of Saudi Arabia misstated the name and title of the leader who serves below the ailing King Fahd. The official is Crown Prince Abdullah Abdel Aziz al-Saud (not simply Abdel Aziz); he is the first deputy prime minister; the title of prime minister, though rarely used, belongs to the king.

title: FORD REDUCES PAYMENTS TO CONTRACT WORKERS
description: The Ford Motor Company will reduce payments to contract workers by 7 percent as it cuts costs to stem losses. The reduction takes effect Nov. 19, and the contractors were notified last month, a spokeswoman said. The automaker uses about 6,000 contract workers for tasks like computer programming, parts design and clerical work. Ford lost a total of $1.44 billion in the second and third quarters as it paid for replacing 13 million Firestone tires, spent more on marketing and reduced production because of lower demand. Ford shares rose 20 cents, to $16.38. The stock has declined 30 percent this year.

title: Understated and a Bit Underground
description: BID almost asks to be overlooked. It's half a floor below street level in Sotheby's forbidding Lubyanka of a building, which is itself in an isolated pocket of the Upper East Side, where streets come to a dead end and the neighborhood tone is defined by two enormous hospital complexes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDNER, CHARLES K.
description: GOLDNER-Charles K. On November 6, 2001. Beloved husband of Pearl (Piri). Loving father of Naomi (Abe) Colton, Debbie (Elliot) Gibber. Dear brother of Edith Steinlauf. Adoring grandfather of Daniel & Amy, Aryeah and Tzippi, Jacob and Jennifer, Leah, Marc, Miriam, Michael, Mindy & David. Great-grandfather of Jonathan, Nama, Chana. Shiva will be observed through Monday, November 12 at the home of Charles Goldner.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUROVY, WALTER
description: SUROVY-Walter. The Metropolitan Opera mourns with profound sadness the death of our very dear friend, Walter Surovy, the beloved husband of Managing Director, Rise Stevens. An elegant gentleman, he was a friend to many at The Metropolitan Opera. Deeply committed to the company, both Mr. Surovy and Miss Stevens were founding members of The Encore Society. Born in 1910 in Vienna, Walter was a renowned actor with The Neues Deutsches Theater in Prague when he met Miss Stevens, then a fledgling singer. He gave up acting professionally to manage Miss Stevens' opera career, including 23 seasons as one of The Metropolitan Opera's leading artists. His irreverent wit and friendship will be missed by many members of the Board and Met management. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Rise, their son, Nicolas, daughterin-law, Marguerite, and granddaughter, Marisa. Bruce Crawford, Honorary Chairman James Kinnear, Chairman of the Board Paul Montrone, President Joseph Volpe, General Mgr. James Levine, Artistic Dir.

title: Israel Begins Withdrawal of Its Troops From Ramallah
description: Israel started withdrawing its forces early today from another Palestinian-controlled city, Ramallah, after occupying positions there for almost three weeks, Israeli officials said.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELLNER, MARVIN
description: FELLNER-Marvin, 73, on November 5, 2001. Husband of the late Naomi Kramer Fellner. Beloved father of David M. and his wife Mary; Gary M. and his wife Ada. Adored grandfather of Franco and Joyce. Cherished loved one to Ede Berelson & her son and daughterin-law George and Suely Berelson. Funeral services Thursday 1:30PM at Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Friends may call this evening from 5-9 PM. Memorial contributions in his memory may be made to Calvary Hospital in Brooklyn, New York.

title: Democrats Win Assembly In New Jersey
description: Propelled by James E. McGreevey's solid victory in the governor's race, New Jersey Democrats on Tuesday recaptured a majority in the State Assembly for the first time in a decade and battled to at least a tie with the Republicans in the State Senate.

title: With Medicine, It's Personal
description: When I was president of Mount Sinai Medical Center, at least one month a year I'd serve as attending physician and go on early morning rounds with the house staff. I got to see how the institution really worked, how the patients were treated, how the doctors treated the nurses and how clean the place was.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: The Prevailing Wind

title: Judge to Hear From 9 States On Microsoft
description: A federal district judge said today that she would hold a pair of separate but related proceedings early next year to consider the proposed antitrust settlement between the Bush administration and Microsoft and to hear arguments by a group of states that officially broke ranks with the federal government in search of tougher penalties.

title: Heading Toward a Runoff
description: In Houston, the nation's fourth-largest city, Mayor Lee Brown seemed almost certain to wind up in a runoff. Mr. Brown, who campaigned on a theme of experience and stability in his race to win a third two-year term, had 42 percent with 93 percent of the ballots counted, local election officials said. To avoid a runoff, Mr. Brown would need 50 percent of the votes.

title: INSIDE
description: Israel Continues Withdrawal

title: After an Easy Start, Osgood Stops Lightning
description: Chris Osgood does not like to think of himself as some kind of hockey phenomenon. That would be too brazen for Osgood, whose voice does not carry much farther than a stage whisper. It would also be incorrect, in his humble opinion.

title: The Front Is Here, and You're Drafted
description: To the Editor:

title: Edward Padula, 85; Staged 'Bye Bye Birdie' on Broadway
description: Edward Padula, a Broadway producer with a keen eye for talent, who won a Tony Award in 1961 for ''Bye Bye Birdie,'' died on Thursday at Southampton Hospital, near his home in Bridgehampton, N.Y. He was 85.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: AOL Deal Lifts Aether
description: A developer of software and services for wireless Internet access, Aether Systems, said it would sell a minority stake to AOL Time Warner and that the two companies would work together to develop and market Web and wireless services. Shares in Aether jumped on news of the deal, closing the day at $8.33, up $1.72, or 26 percent. Under the agreement, America Online will integrate its e-mail, instant messaging and other content into the Aether wireless products and services for small and medium-sized businesses. Aether will also create a wireless version of Netscape's Netbusiness service, which provides information and resources for small-business owners. Netscape is owned by AOL Time Warner. AOL Time Warner stock rose $1.66, or 5 percent, to $35.15.

title: F. A. O. SCHWARZ POSTS 22% DROP IN QUARTERLY SALES
description: F. A. O. Schwarz, the toy store chain owned by Royal Vendex of the Netherlands, posted a 22 percent drop in third-quarter sales yesterday. The terrorist attacks caused its Fifth Avenue store in New York to close for a week. Sales at F. A. O. Schwarz fell to 36 million euros in the quarter from 46 million euros in the period a year earlier. That contributed to a 1.9 percent drop in Vendex's total third-quarter sales. Demand for toys has picked up in recent weeks, Vendex said, and talks to sell F. A. O. Schwarz continue with potential bidders.

title: Angelo Ippolito, 79, an Artist and Professor
description: Angelo Ippolito, a painter and one of the founders of the Tanager Gallery, an artist-run space that was part of the New York School of Abstract Expressionists in the 1950's, died on Oct. 29 in Johnson City, N.Y., near Binghamton, where he was a professor emeritus of art at the State University. He was 79.

title: Relief Effort Races Winter To Save Millions
description: Sixty Afghan refugees worked in a dusty warehouse this morning, bent under backbreaking sacks of wheat, toiling like men building a levee against a flood, racing to keep two million fellow Afghans alive.

title: Panel Recommends Ending Satellite Plan
description: At the urging of its Republican leadership, the House Appropriations Committee is recommending canceling an expensive infrared satellite system that the Pentagon considers vital to missile defense.

title: Hospital in Manhattan Reopens After Anthrax Case
description: Seeking to reassure jittery employees and attract patients to surgical beds and examining rooms that had been empty for seven days, administrators reopened Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital yesterday morning and declared it free of the anthrax spores that killed one of its employees a week ago today.

title: Bloomberg Edges Green in Race for Mayor
description: Michael Rubens Bloomberg, a self- made billionaire who set out at the age of 59 to finance a new career in politics, was elected the 108th mayor of New York City yesterday, as voters turned to him to lead a city apprehensive about the loss of a popular mayor and anxious about a future clouded by threats of terrorism and economic turmoil.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Profit Leaps At Phone Concern
description: Telefnica Mviles, the dominant Spanish mobile phone operator with interests in Latin America, reported a 37.6 percent rise in nine-month net profit to 670.2 million euros, or $602.18 million, thanks to a strong performance at home. Nine-month earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization, or Ebitda, rose to 2.53 billion euros, or $2.27 billion, above analysts' estimates, while operating revenues were up 2.7 percent, to 6.17 billion euros, or $5.54 billion, despite a fall in average revenue per user and the depreciation of Latin American currencies. Shares rose 1.8 percent in Madrid. Emma Daly (NYT)

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: AUTO RACING

title: World Briefing | Asia: Australia: Candidate Flaunts Wart
description: A candidate for Parliament from Australia's Northern Territory who has been charged with drunken driving is using some unique campaign material, dropping into bars and passing out coasters that say ''Have a drink on Dave Tollner.'' ''It doesn't encourage irresponsible drinking,'' Mr. Tollner said. ''This is just a way of getting a message out there that I'm the man.'' The election is on Saturday. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: Warnings by 2 OPEC Nations Send Oil Price to a 2-Year Low
description: Oil prices fell to a two-year low after ministers from two members of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries warned today that a price war could break out if non-OPEC nations did not cooperate with the group in reducing oil output.

title: Plan to Gas Offices Is Abandoned
description: The Senate and the Environmental Protection Agency have abandoned a plan to fumigate the entire Hart Senate Office Building with a powerful gas to kill anthrax germs, Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota said today.

title: Japanese Drug Makers' Profits Are Strong
description: Japanese pharmaceutical companies, long derided overseas as copycat drug makers, are booking better-than-expected profits this fiscal year, providing one of the few highlights in an otherwise bleak earnings landscape.

title: Miscellany
description: * The Eastman Kodak Company, Rochester, renewed a marketing agreement for five years with Universal Studios, Universal City, Calif., part of Vivendi Universal. Terms were not disclosed. Under the agreement, Kodak will provide products like film and cameras exclusively to the Universal theme parks in the United States.

title: Anthrax Is Familiar Threat At Nation's Abortion Clinics
description: For John Nugent, like many others who run abortion clinics, anthrax threats are old hat. Two years ago, when he headed the Planned Parenthood affiliate in Spokane, Wash., a letter arrived one day with a brown stain, a picture of a skull and crossbones, and the words ''Anthrax. Have a nice death.''

title: Green Calm As Victory Slips Away At the End
description: Mark Green sat, for the third time this election season, on a yellow sofa in the Sheraton New York last night watching the election returns on television with his family. Weeks ago, on the nights of the primary and the runoff, he had said he was ''serene'' and ''confident.''

title: Dreams Interrupted or Not Yet Lived, Great Photos Never to Be Taken
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: 70's Radical Reaffirms Guilty Plea
description: In a high-pressure drama in which her future turned on her willingness to utter a single word, the onetime radical Sara Jane Olson jousted verbally with a judge today but finally, if reluctantly, said in court that she stood by her guilty plea to charges that she had plotted to bomb two police cruisers here 26 years ago.

title: A Charter School Plan Is Not Enough
description: For three years, a grass-roots team of educators -- friends from their days as teachers in troubled schools and as students at Ivy League universities -- have been trying to start a charter school for the arts in the South Bronx.

title: What a Short, Strange Icelandic Trip It's Been
description: It was a crazy idea that began, as many crazy ideas do, at the end of a long night of drinking. Sitting in the home of Aron Arnarsson, a studio engineer for the Icelandic record label Thule, and polishing off the last of his beer and whiskey, the members of a Reykjavik band called the Funerals decided to embark on an October tour of Iceland.

title: A Tour of Paris Restaurants, Recipe by Recipe
description: A WISCONSONITE by birth, Patricia Wells moved to Paris in 1980 and immersed herself in French cuisine with a fearlessness that conjures up a latter-day Jean Seberg, dashing across a boulevard to charm a brooding chef out of his recipe for turnip gratin. She frequented cheesemongers and pastry shops, asking all the tough questions, and in cookbooks like ''Bistro Cooking'' and ''Simply French'' offered recipes that demystified the French kitchen, in a voice that was encouraging and always attentive to the next discovery.

title: He's Still the Big Fella But No Longer the Man
description: Grant Hill watched those Georgetown teams in the early 1980's, standing and applauding his favorite player. ''When I was younger, in elementary school and junior high, Pat was the man,'' Hill said.

title: America's Resolve, Then and Now
description: To the Editor:

title: In President's Words: 'Lift This Dark Threat'
description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's speech by satellite to Central and Eastern European leaders meeting in Warsaw, as transcribed by the Federal News Service Inc.:

title: S.I. Couple Charged With Murder of Daughter, 3
description: The police charged a Staten Island couple with second-degree murder yesterday in the death of their 3-year-old daughter who, the medical examiner's office said, had been beaten repeatedly and forced to eat soap.

title: Man in the News; Finding a New Mission; Michael Rubens Bloomberg
description: Michael Rubens Bloomberg, among the wealthiest people in New York City, has been a man in search of a mission beyond making money. With yesterday's come-from-behind victory in the mayoral race, he seems to have found it.

title: A Close Race in Detroit
description: Kwame Kilpatrick appeared to have won one of the closest races in this city in decades, becoming the city's youngest mayor since 1933.

title: Fed Reduces Short-Term Rates to Lowest Level Since 1961
description: Struggling to reverse the slide in the American economy, the Federal Reserve cut its key short-term interest rate today for the 10th time this year, aggressively pushing it down to a level not seen since early in the presidency of John F. Kennedy.

title: A Fraying of Nerves at 2 Parties Late at Night
description: Mark Green sat, for the third time this election season, on a yellow sofa in the Sheraton New York last night watching the election returns on television with his family. Weeks ago, on the nights of the primary and the runoff, he had said he was "serene" and "confident."

title: A 'Traviata' About Soul, Not Scenery
description: Franco Zeffirelli's 1998 production of ''La Traviata'' is likely to have a long life at the Metropolitan Opera, not only because this Verdi classic has a permanent berth in the company repertory, but also because however vehemently critics denounce the extravagance of Mr. Zeffirelli's staging, audiences love its dizzying abundance of detail. Or so one has assumed. In a house where the scenery is routinely greeted with more vigorous applause than conductors and singers are, the audience took in its first glimpse of the dcor in silence on Monday evening, when ''La Traviata'' returned to the Met stage for the first time this season. It was a heartening nondisplay.

title: Latino Mayor for Hartford; New Haven Incumbent Wins
description: Hartford voters made history today by electing the city's first Latino mayor, while New Haven's longtime mayor, a fellow Democrat, won his race for a fifth term.

title: Arizona   New York
description: To the Editor:

title: York and Richter Make a Case for the Olympics
description: With just six weeks until Olympic rosters must be submitted, neither Mike Richter nor Mike York hurt their chances of being named to the United States team last night.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GENOVESE, STEVEN
description: GENOVESE-Steven. During our time of sorrow we learn how much our friends mean to us. Your kindness and sympathy will always be remembered by the family of Steven G. Genovese.

title: F.A.A. Adds to O'Hare Security
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said today that undercover agents had increased monitoring of checkpoints at O'Hare International Airport after a security lapse in which a man carrying knives and a stun gun passed through a United Airlines security station on Saturday.

title: Germany Ready to Send Force of 3,900; Not Clear if They Would Be Combat Soldiers
description: Despite nervousness among Europeans about the length and tactics of the American-led war against Afghanistan, European governments have not wavered in their support for Washington. The Europeans have had their own experience with terrorists, regard themselves as vulnerable to terrorist attacks, and understand that to oppose Washington now would put them on the side of Osama bin Laden and Al Qaeda.

title: The Next Governor of New Jersey
description: James McGreevey, who came close to pulling off an upset victory in the New Jersey governor's race four years ago, won the job easily last night. The state reconfirmed its reputation as a place that likes its Republicans moderate, something Mr. McGreevey's opponent, Bret Schundler, was not.

title: The Mystique Of Miso
description: MISO, the traditional Japanese soybean paste, is one of those convenience foods whose complexity belies its ingredients: it contains only soybeans, salt and grain (usually rice or barley, though others are used too), inoculated with the Aspergillus orzyae bacteria and aged for up to three years. The production process is not unlike that for good hard cheese, and miso is frequently compared with Parmesan. Obviously, much of its character is different, but it is equally complex, and both are known for the strong presence of umami, the Japanese word for the fifth taste (after salt, sour, sweet and bitter), roughly translated as ''deliciousness.''

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Deal Costs Weigh Qualcomm Results
description: Qualcomm, which licenses patents for mobile phones used by 96 million people, had a fiscal fourth-quarter loss of $44.5 million, in contrast to a year-earlier profit, because of acquisition-related costs. After a change in accounting rules for license fees, the loss was 6 cents a share, in contrast to net income of $126.3 million, or 16 cents, a year earlier, the company said. Revenue in the three months ended Sept. 30 increased 5.9 percent to $650.8 million from $614.7 million. Excluding acquisition costs, investment losses and other items, Qualcomm said, profit would have been $162.8 million, or 20 cents a share, compared with $186.1 million, or 23 cents, a year earlier.

title: Trenton Democrats Are Out of Doghouse
description: Nearly a decade after they were cast into exile for foisting a politically disastrous tax increase on an unsuspecting public, New Jersey Democrats finally completed their escape from the doghouse of state politics today.

title: Pound Cake With a French Squeeze
description: WHEN I began training as a pastry chef in France, I tended to dismiss simple American desserts -- they just didn't seem as exciting as the French. But when I discovered sweets I grew up with in the Paris temples of pastry, I started to pay attention. On display in the windows of Mulot and La Maison du Chocolat, even something as plain as poundcake commanded respect. It really opened my eyes.

title: Scarsdale Standards
description: To the Editor:

title: Jets Struggle to Pass Go With Veteran in Charge
description: Vinny Testaverde had cuts on his nose, a bandage on his right hand and a smile. The cuts were courtesy of the New Orleans Saints, the smile was a reflection of the Jets' best victory of the season. Testaverde, as always, gets an A for effort but his results have been less than stellar.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Talks On Refugee Dispute
description: The foreign secretaries of Nepal and Bhutan are holding talks on a long-festering dispute over the status of 100,000 Hindu refugees who fled Buddhist Bhutan on grounds of religious persecution and who now live in United Nations refugee camps in Nepal. Bhutan does not want to take back most of the refugees, who it says left voluntarily, while Nepal says all should be allowed to return. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, BARBARA
description: BERGER-Barbara. To my one and only. You were always there for advice, a pep talk, a shoulder to cry on. We shared secrets. You understood my fears. We shared life's joys and sorrows and ordinary moments. You believed in me even when I gave up on myself. That's the kind of friend you were to me. You were the wind beneath my wings. Love Always, Your One and Only

title: AT&T Is Sticking to Timetable on Cable Unit
description: C. Michael Armstrong, the chairman of AT&T, reiterated yesterday that he hoped to decide on a plan to either spin off or sell the company's cable television unit by the end of the year.

title: NEWPORT NEWS RECEIVES REVISED OFFER FROM NORTHROP
description: Newport News Shipbuilding said yesterday that it had received a revised buyout offer from a rival military contractor, Northrop Grumman, that would lock the purchase price at $2.6 billion. Under the proposal, a new stock-price range would be set to determine how much of the payment of $67.50 a share would come in stock, with the balance paid in cash, Newport News said in a statement. Northrop's stock cannot trade below $80 or above $100. Northrop is also assuming $500 million in debt. Shares of Northrop, based in Los Angeles, had risen almost 30 percent in the weeks after Sept. 11, leading some investors to speculate it would raise the offer for Newport. Shares of Newport News fell $1.49, or 2.1 percent, to $68.51.

title: Tips for the Pastry Chef, From the Professionals
description: The United States Pastry Alliance, a professional association of pastry chefs, has a new Web site, which is also useful for amateur bakers. Its best feature is step-by-step recipe demonstrations, which change almost weekly. For example, Nancy Kershner, the pastry chef at Town Restaurant in Manhattan, shows how to prepare sourdough chocolate cake, chocolate-covered pretzels, organic malt ice cream, a caf brlot bombe and chocolate-filled beignets. The beignets are made with a pasta machine, like ravioli, then fried.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUGANO, SEAN T.
description: LUGANO-Sean T. Age 28, of Manhattan. Lost in the tragedy of the World Trade Center where he was a trader for Keefe Bruyette and Woods. Loving son of Eileen (nee Duffell) and the late John A. Lugano. Best brother of John, Stephanie, Kristen and Michael. Devoted grandson of Anne M. Duffell and Francis Lugano Haller. Cherished nephew, cousin and friend. Graduate of Xavier High School, '91, Loyola College, Maryland, '95. Outstanding athlete and avid rugby player who played on many national, collegiate and men's teams. Rugby coach for Fairfield University and a leading force on the NYAC rugby team. An entrepreneur, Sean was a partner in Rathbones and Opal, Manhattan east side establishments. A memorial service will be held Friday, November 9, 6 PM, at St. Francis Xavier R.C. Church, 30 W. 16th St, NYC. Donations can be made to the Sean Lugano Scholarship Fund at Xavier High School.

title: A Stew of Choreographic Styles, Seasoned With Ingenuity
description: Because ballet and jazz are arts always capable of renewing themselves, no one needs to worry about how neatly the offerings of Les Ballets Jazz de Montral fit into either category.

title: It's Three-and-Out Early, and Too Often
description: It may seem as though the Giants' offense has been anything but consistent. But that is not true. It is amazing how consistently poor the offense has been at the beginning of practically every game this season.

title: Spain Considering Suing Baxter On Kidney Filters, Official Says
description: The Spanish health minister, Celia Villalobos, said today that her government was weighing legal action against Baxter International in connection with the deaths in Spain of 11 kidney dialysis patients who had been treated with filters, known as dialyzers, made by a Baxter unit.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column in Business Day on Monday, about depictions of death in advertising, misstated a title of Alex Bogusky, partner and creative director at Crispin Porter & Bogusky in Miami, who said the agency did not plan to alter its anti-

title: Omnicom Unit Gets Adobe Systems Job
description: Adobe Systems in San Jose, Calif., has named Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco, part of the Omnicom Group, to handle its American advertising assignment. Billings were estimated at $20 million.

title: Our Towns; In Suburbia, Vouchers Sink Schundler's Campaign
description: IT almost seemed that in his run for New Jersey governor, Bret D. Schundler forgot he needed the suburban vote. New Jersey, the most suburban state, with the nation's highest annual income, $54,226 per household. In no other major industrial state do cities count so little, says James Hughes, a Rutgers public policy expert. Only 10 percent of New Jersey people live in its six biggest cities (compared to New York State, where 60 percent do.)

title: A Nation Challenged
description: On the Front Lines

title: Beyond Our Shores, A Battle for Opinion
description: To the Editor:

title: The Front Is Here, and You're Drafted
description: To the Editor:

title: Women's Studies Center Is 30
description: When Barnard College created its Center for Research on Women 30 years ago -- one of the first in higher education -- women's colleges were struggling for survival, and many academics viewed the idea of women's studies with suspicion. But a task force led by CATHARINE STIMPSON, then a Barnard professor and now dean of graduate studies at New York University, recommended that Barnard establish the center to focus self-consciously on feminist issues. As more than 400 people gather on Nov. 9 for the anniversary, women's studies are more firmly established in academe. But JANET JAKOBSEN, the center's current director, said the center was still playing an important role as a place where departments come together around issues of women and sexuality. ''If the center weren't here, it would be much harder,'' she said. ''There is still not gender parity in the regular curriculum.'' Karen W. Arenson

title: The Bears Are Human; The Camels Are Camel
description: In a scarred and shaken city in a time of terror, the touchstones of tradition work their comforting magic -- as they did at the opening of the 2001 Christmas Spectacular at Radio City Music Hall.

title: Cincinnati Mayor Re-elected
description: Cincinnati Mayor Charles Luken, who finished second in the Sept. 11 primary, won re-election today in a race against Courtis Fuller, a political neophyte. With 98 percent of precincts reporting, Mr. Luken won 55 percent of the vote in a city that has seen racial tensions over the fatal shooting of an unarmed black man by a white officer who was acquitted of all charges in September.

title: Enron Looks for Investors, But Finds Them Skittish
description: Enron's attempt to quietly line up a big-name investor to demonstrate its financial strength seems to have backfired.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Free-Trade Area Discussed
description: The 10 members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, or Asean, agreed yesterday to begin planning the creation of a free-trade area with China within the next decade. China, which proposed the idea last year, has been luring an increasing amount of foreign trade and investment away from Southeast Asia as it prepares to join the World Trade Organization. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NORWICK, DOUGLAS J.
description: NORWICK-Douglas J. Your star shines brightly and your spirit dances on. Always love. Herbert J. Bake

title: Editors' Note; Today's Sections
description: News of the Sept. 11 attacks and their aftermath continues to appear in Section B; index, Page B2.

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Tomorrow: Hearing On Mental Health
description: The City Council has scheduled a public hearing on the status of mental health programs after the Sept. 11 terror attacks. Committee Room, City Hall, Manhattan, 10 a.m. Information: (718) 287-8762.

title: SONIC SHARES DROP 19 PERCENT ON PROFIT WARNING
description: Shares of the Sonic Corporation, which owns the largest chain of drive-restaurants in the United States, fell as much as 19 percent yesterday after it said its fiscal first-quarter earnings would be at the lower end of analysts' estimates. Sonic shares fell $5.52, to $29.73, in early afternoon trading of 1.49 million, seven times the three-month daily average. The stock, which traded as low as $28.45, reached a 52-week high yesterday of $35.25. It ended the day down $4.28, to $30.97. Profit in the quarter ending Nov. 30 will be at the lower end of the range of 33 to 36 cents a share because of worsening consumer confidence and economic conditions, the Oklahoma City-based company said. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call was 35 cents.

title: The Firefighters' Grief
description: To the Editor:

title: Nyon Journal; Sky Falls In on the Swiss: Tranquillity Is a Victim
description: Switzerland's image is that of an orderly country, smooth as its fabled chocolate, whose trains run as precisely as its watches and where crime does not exist, companies are profitable, and even the president takes public transport to work.

title: National Briefing | New England: Vermont: Not Running For Governor
description: Representative Bernard Sanders, left, said he would seek re-election instead of running for governor. Mr. Sanders, an independent who usually votes Democratic, said he would be most effective in Congress, where he has served for 11 years. Gov. Howard Dean said in September that he would not run again. Lt. Gov. Douglas Racine, a Democrat, has declared his candidacy. So have three Republicans: James Douglas, the state treasurer; Cornelius Hogan, a former human services secretary; and Brian Pearl, an opponent of civil unions for gays. Pam Belluck (NYT)

title: Basque Suspects Held in Bombing in Madrid
description: The Spanish police arrested two people associated with the Basque guerrilla group E.T.A. as suspects in a car-bombing at rush hour this morning on a busy Madrid street. The bomb wounded almost 100 people but missed its apparent target, a government official.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: World Briefing
description: AMERICAS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NACHWALTER, ANNA
description: NACHWALTER-Anna. Age 94. On November 6, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Morris. Loving mother of the late Renee and Neil, and mother-in-law of Ruby. Devoted grandmother of Elaine and Alfred Fields, Susan Traub, Eric Traub, Ricky, Wendi and Steven Nachwalter. Adoring great-grandmother of Randy, Adrienne, Ryan, Jordan, Jaimee, Melissa and Jarred. She was loving and loved by all who knew her. Service Wednesday 9:45AM ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in her memory to the Kittay House, 2550 Webb Avenue, Bronx, NY 10468.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Software Damages Hard Drives
description: Some Macintosh computer users lost data from their hard drives as a result of a bug in a program that Apple Computer made available over the weekend, the company said yesterday. The bug was part of a program used to install the latest version of Apple's new music software, iTunes 2.0. Apple made the software available for download on its Web site on Friday night. The company said it quickly heard from several people who said their hard drives had been damaged when they installed the program. Apple said it had identified the problem and replaced the problem program by Saturday morning. The problem had not affected everyone who downloaded the program, Apple said, but only a subset who, among other particulars, were using Apple's Mac OS X operating system and had partitioned their hard disks into two or more drives. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: Federal Agents Are Directed to Stop Physicians Who Assist Suicides
description: Taking square aim at a measure approved twice by voters in Oregon, Attorney General John Ashcroft authorized federal agents yesterday to take action against doctors who prescribe lethal drugs for terminally ill patients.

title: Accounts
description: * The Boeing Company to the Chicago office of Foote, Cone & Belding, part of the FCB Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, to handle its account, with billings estimated at $70 million. The account had been handled by the Foote, Cone Seattle office since January 2000. After Boeing, which moved its headquarters to Chicago from Seattle, placed the account in review, Foote, Cone competed to keep the assignment with work from the Chicago office rather than the Seattle office.

title: If It's Champagne, It Can't Be in Plastic, Even at Homecoming
description: The once-a-year tailgate picnics of college football homecoming weekends deserve better than supermarket six-packs. Indeed, Champagne might be in order (with smoked salmon sandwiches, of course). And to avoid your having to pour it into plastic, Piper-Heidsieck has 187-milliliter splits that come with their own straws. They are popular in bars, come in Jeep Wagoneer red and are now sold in handy four-packs for about $40.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARBER, MIMI
description: FARBER-Mimi. Age 90. Died peacefully at home November 5, 2001. Wife of the late Irving Farber. Beloved mother of Howard (Pat). Adored grandmother of Lori and Abbey. Great grandmother of Leah. A great lady of humor and kindness, she will be greatly missed. Donations to Cancer Care, 275 7th Av, NY, NY 10021.

title: Mutual Fund Manager at Merrill Plans to Accept Buyout Offer
description: James D. McCall's short, strange tenure at Merrill Lynch ended suddenly yesterday when he resigned as the manager of two of the firm's worst-performing mutual funds.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Less Patrician Patroon

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, JORDAN S., M.D.
description: BROWN-Jordan S., M.D. Husband of Joan. Father of Melissa, Mark, Jim and Jessica. Grandfather of Lily, Laura and Maya. Brother of Ruthel. Uncle of John and Peter and their families. His great passions were his family and medicine. Until two weeks ago he practiced Urology at NYU School of Medicine. We shall all miss him. Memorial services Thursday, 11:30 AM, at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Acquisition By WPP Continues
description: Faced with intractable opposition from British regulators, the WPP Group said it would proceed with its $637 million acquisition of the Tempus Group. Martin Sorrell, left, WPP's chief executive, argued that the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks had a material adverse change on Tempus's business of buying advertising space for clients. He tried to invoke an escape hatch that would have allowed WPP to abandon the deal. But regulators ruled against him and last week dismissed his appeal. At that time, Mr. Sorrell said he would appeal a second time, but yesterday WPP notified regulators that it would drop its case. In published remarks yesterday, members of the regulatory body, known as the Takeover Panel, agreed with Mr. Sorrell that the events of Sept. 11, ''were exceptional and unforeseeable.'' But they said WPP had failed to show what effect those events had on Tempus's business, beyond the general slowdown in the advertising industry. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Riordan Enters Race for California Governor
description: After months of testing the waters, Richard J. Riordan, the former mayor of Los Angeles, formally announced his plans today to run for governor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERRY, JOHN W.
description: PERRY-John W., 38. NYPD lawyer, died a hero September 11 volunteering to rescue victims of the WTC attack. Civil libertarian and cop, down-to-earth free spirit, actor, linguist, with his restless mind, he questioned authority but played by the rules, housed the homeless, sought challenges of mind and body, packing a wallop in his time on earth. As board member of NYCLU Nassau Chapter, and son of former chapter president, Patricia Perry, he carried on his family's dedication to liberty and justice for all. He leaves also his father, Dr. James Perry, brother Joel, sister Janice and nephew Jimmy. Service are on Saturday, November 10, 11 AM, First Presbyterian Church, 12 West 12th Street, New York City. In lieu of flowers, family asks donation to favorite charity or to NYCLU Nassau Foundation (John W. Perry Memorial Fund), 210 Old Country Road, Mineola, New York 11501. Board of Directors NYCLU Nassau

title: A Big Purchase Of Saks Shares
description: An affiliate of Carlos Slim Hel, the wealthiest investor in Mexico, bought 578,000 shares of Saks Inc. last month. The share price of Saks has fallen as much as 52 percent since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: BP Stays With Output Goal Despite Profit Drop
description: Hurt by lower prices for oil and gas, BP reported a 20 percent drop in third-quarter earnings today but said it would continue to meet production targets set this year.

title: Sumptuous Victorian
description: IN November, Cape May's rows of colorful and shambling Victorian houses are silent, the rocking chairs on porches in repose. By early evening the streets are deserted. Nonetheless, a few lights still burned, and our destination, the Union Park Dining Room, was a glowing beacon, drawing a couple of dozen other off-season souls.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: The Association of National Advertisers, New York, presented its first multicultural excellence awards recognizing campaigns aimed at consumers from a variety of ethnic backgrounds. The four advertisers, along with their agencies, that received awards at a multicultural marketing conference in Key Biscayne, Fla., are: PepsiCo, Purchase, N.Y., for campaigns created by Dieste & Partners, Dallas, an affiliate of the Omnicom Group; the AT&T Corporation, Basking Ridge, N.J., for a campaign created by the UniWorld Group, New York; State Farm Insurance, Bloomington, Ill., for a brand image campaign created by Intertrend Communications, Torrance, Calif.; and Verizon Communications, New York, for a campaign created by the Burrell Communications Group, Chicago, 49 percent owned by the Publicis Groupe.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Finland: Fortum Buys Stake In Birka
description: Seeking to strengthen its position, the Finnish energy company Fortum Oyi will acquire the City of Stockholm's 50 percent stake in Birka Energi A.B. for 1.5 billion euros, or $1.3 billion, the company said. Fortum already owns the remaining stake in Birka, which is Sweden's third-largest energy producer and has annual sales of 1.36 billion euros, or $1.22 billion. The deal was widely expected as it fits in Fortum's strategy to expand in its home markets in response to acquisitions of its bigger European rivals in the Nordic region.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Results: The Races for New Jersey
description: Two Assembly members per district

title: U.S. Plucks Rebel Figure From Afghan Redoubt for 'Consultations,' Then Returns Him
description: Hamid Karzai, the Afghan exile who has emerged as the Bush administration's main hope for forging a southern alliance against the Taliban, was plucked from Afghanistan by American forces early Monday, brought to Pakistan and then ferried back across the border, senior Pentagon officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about former Representative Edward P. Boland, a Massachusetts Democrat, misspelled the name of the hometown of Jim McGovern, another Massachusetts Democrat, who commented on Mr. Boland's low-key style. It is Worcester, not Worchester.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Trying Again On Budget
description: Gov. Jeb Bush called state legislators to a 10-day special session for late November to take care of the state's $1.3 billion budget deficit. The move comes a week after the first special session to balance the budget dissolved in bickering among Republican legislative leaders over whether to delay a tax cut for wealthy investors that is set to take effect in January. At Mr. Bush's urging, legislative leaders have agreed to delay the tax cut for 18 months, but they also plan to cut spending by more than $1 billion. Gary Fineout (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 28 about divisions in the Indian nations of New York over gambling misstated the location of the reservation of the Onondagas, who oppose gambling. It is near Syracuse, not Buffalo.

title: Democrat Vows to Alter Way 'Business Is Done in Trenton'
description: James E. McGreevey, the Democratic mayor of Woodbridge, easily won election Tuesday as New Jersey's 51st governor, defeating a fiery conservative Republican, Bret D. Schundler, who never gained the support of his party's moderate establishment.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Whale Fleet Goes Hunting
description: Five ships left the western port of Shimonoseki for a voyage to the Antarctic Ocean where whalers are to kill 440 minke whales for what the government says is research. The vessels, belonging to the government's Institute of Cetacean Research, are to catch the whales from an estimated population of 760,000 minkes in the Antarctic. Protesters picketed Japanese diplomatic missions in the United States and a dozen other countries, charging that the research is a cover for commercial whaling. James Brooke (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZEFF, GERALDINE GELFOND
description: ZEFF-Geraldine Gelfond. Our adored Cherney. She touched the lives of all who met her. To know her was to truly love her. We will sorely miss the head of our family. Joycie and Arnold Swartz Ronald and Jill Swartz Steven Swartz and Jill Gross Lisa and Alan Adler Zachary, Rochelle, Courtney, Solomon, Sol, Robert, Ethan, Erma, and Ava

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  IUSHEWITZ, MORRIS
description: IUSHEWITZ-Morris, born November 7, 1901. In memory of a scholarly man of great character and accomplishment. His extraordinary life was dedicated to improving the lives of workers everywhere.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a decision by Sara Jane Olson (formerly known as Kathleen Soliah) to plead guilty in a 1975 bomb plot by radicals referred incorrectly to her residence as a fugitive. It was in St. Paul, not a Minnesota suburb.

title: Court Reverses U.S. Approval Of a Generic
description: A federal appeals court in Washington yesterday overturned the government's approval of a generic version of Taxol, a widely used cancer drug made by Bristol-Myers Squibb.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EINHORN, GERALDINE
description: EINHORN-Geraldine. On November 5, 2001, beloved wife of the late Sheldon, devoted sister of Steven & Rae Jaffe, loving aunt to Aaron, Claudia, and Lauren. Services Wednesday 1 P.M. at Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, Queens Boulevard and 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Wee Tomato, Big Wallop And Fit to Be Stuffed
description: Organic tomatoes from the Molino ranch in the desert near Palm Springs, Calif., pack a wonderfully concentrated flavor, partly because they are grown without water. Their skins are relatively thick, so for a salad they are best peeled or diced. But their sturdy skin and rounded shape make them excellent for stuffing and baking. Select a dozen of the smallest, remove the stems and turn them on the stem end, then slice off the top half-inch. Scoop out, drain and mince the flesh and tops, and mix the pulp with a cup of chopped onion and two cloves of minced garlic sauted in olive oil. Add half a cup of bread crumbs, capers, minced chives, parsley and salt and pepper. Fill and bake in an oiled pan at 400 degrees for about 25 minutes. The tomatoes, $4.99 a pound, will be available for about two more weeks at Eli's Manhattan, 1411 Third Avenue (80th Street) and at the Vinegar Factory, 431 East 91st Street.

title: National Briefing | West: California: A Medical Marijuana Defender
description: The San Francisco district attorney, Terence Hallinan, asked the federal Drug Enforcement Administration to stop cracking down on dispensers of marijuana for medical use. Mr. Hallinan, the only district attorney in California who actively campaigned for the voter initiative that legalized such marijuana, said that in recent weeks, two San Francisco dispensaries had been under surveillance by unidentified agents and patients' records had been seized from a doctor's office in El Dorado County and from the largest cannabis dispensary in Los Angeles, which was forced to close. Evelyn Nieves (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: 'Bloody Sunday' Challenge
description: Former British soldiers who served in Londonderry in 1972 began a legal challenge in London's High Court against a tribunal investigating ''Bloody Sunday,'' when soldiers shot and killed 14 unarmed civilians during a Roman Catholic civil rights march. In August, the tribunal, based in Londonderry, ordered the 36 soldiers to return to the city to testify but the soldiers say their lives could be threatened by republican guerrillas if they do so. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: U.S. Arrests 7 in Mafia Use of a Bank on L.I.
description: At first glance, the European American Bank on Broad Hollow Road in Melville, on Long Island, seemed like a typical suburban retail branch. There were teller windows and safe deposit boxes. Customers filed in and out, withdrawing and depositing their money.

title: The New York Times's N.F.L. Computer Ranking
description: The New York Times's computer football ranking is based on an analysis of each team's scores with emphasis on three factors: who won, by what margin and against what quality of opposition. The quality of an opponent is determined by examining its record against other teams

title: Idling on Airport Security
description: Subash Gurung certainly made a mockery of Tom DeLay's airport security plan. Over the weekend Mr. Gurung easily made it through security at O'Hare Airport in Chicago with several knives, a stun gun and a can of pepper spray in his carry-on luggage. The private contractors hired by United Airlines to work at the checkpoint missed these weapons, even though they found two pocket knives on his person. It is hard to believe that Mr. DeLay, the House Republican whip, is still trying to sell the idea that passenger and baggage screening should be left in private hands.

title: The Trouble With Harry
description: To the Editor:

title: F.B.I. Lifts the Warning About West Coast Bridges
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation today lifted a warning issued last week that terrorists might be planning to destroy bridges on the West Coast and said its investigation showed that the threat was ''not credible.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Enron Fails in Effort to Find A High-Profile Investor

title: Smallpox Vaccine Costlier Than Expected
description: Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services, warned tonight that procuring 246 million doses of smallpox vaccine would cost more than the $509 million he had previously predicted.

title: In a Turnaround, Virginia Elects a Democratic Governor
description: Mark R. Warner, a Democrat who campaigned like a Republican, easily won the Virginia governor's race today, loosening the grip that Republicans have had on most top offices in the state for almost a decade.

title: F.B.I. Admits Little Progress On Bioterrorism
description: In a blunt exchange with members of the Senate, a senior counterterrorism official at the Federal Bureau of Investigation acknowledged today that one month into its bioterrorism investigation, his agency still could not answer such basic questions as how many laboratories in the United States handle the anthrax bacteria.

title: MEDICA TO ELIMINATE 20 PERCENT OF ITS WORK FORCE
description: Medica, a nonprofit health insurer, plans to eliminate about 20 percent of its work force, or more than 230 jobs, to reduce expenses. The insurer, based in Minnetonka, Minn., said the job cuts would save $30 million annually. Most of the reductions will be completed by the end of this month, a spokesman, Rob Longendyke, said. Medica sells health plans to consumers and offers Medicaid and Medicare services. Medica had $1.5 billion in sales last year.

title: A Texan in New York, Silver Tongue in Cheek
description: ANN RICHARDS has one of those hairstyles you have to call a coif: styled, curled, wouldn't move in a Texas windstorm. What's got her attention right now is the hairstyle of a photographer's assistant. It's stiffer than Ann's, spiky, punk, and now, in a borrowed office, she hits him with the honey.

title: While Congress Argues, the Fed Acts
description: Yesterday the Federal Reserve cut interest rates for the 10th time this year in its campaign to revive the sluggish economy. The federal funds rate now stands at 2 percent, a 40-year low. The Fed offered no sign that it had reached the end of the rate cuts, yet there are powerful arguments against too many further reductions. Congress can save Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, some much-needed maneuvering room by taking over the job of supplying economic stimulus as soon as possible.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORDICE, ROBERT J.
description: CORDICE-Robert J. Heroically on September 11, 2001, firefighter from Squad 1. Loving son of Caroline (nee Calicchio). Loving nephew of Jo Ann Amelio and Alphonse Calicchio. A memorial mass will be held Friday, November 9, 10 AM at Our Lady of the Holy Angels Church, 65 Main Street, Little Falls, New Jersey. For further information: BedellPizzo Funeral Home, Staten Island (718) 984-0913.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article in Money & Business on Oct. 7 headlined ''Companies' Big Debts Now Carry Big Risks'' discussed the falloff in consumer spending since Sept. 11. The article cited a cruise operator that had filed for bankruptcy protection, and then said that even companies that were not close to the edge were imperiled by consumers' cutback in spending. That passage gave several examples, including Ethan Allen Interiors.

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: A Delivery Of Holiday Bests
description: AFTER 19 years of writing the mail-order gift guide, nothing has dimmed my enthusiasm for finding secret sources for the new and the exotic. I never tire of the chase in the search for holiday gifts that actually taste as good as they look in the glossy brochures, not to mention arrive on time and intact.

title: Filing for Bankruptcy, Sabena Shuts Down
description: Sabena, Belgium's long-suffering national airline, filed for bankruptcy today, ending 78 years of service.

title: Technology Briefing
description: SOFTWARE

title: ALCOA TO BUY 8 PERCENT OF ALUMINUM CORP. OF CHINA
description: Alcoa, the world's biggest aluminum maker, said yesterday that it would buy 8 percent of the Aluminum Corporation of China, the country's largest producer of the metal, to expand in China's growing economy while the United States economy slumps. The Chinese state-controlled company plans to offer a total of a 30 percent stake and raise about $350 million, the International Financing Review said yesterday, citing an unidentified banker. The shares, which will be sold starting Nov. 19, will trade in London and New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, CHAIM
description: STERN-Chaim. The clergy, staff and members of Temple Beth El of Northern Westchester are profoundly saddened by the untimely death of our Rabbi Emeritus, Chaim Stern. As our Senior Rabbi for thirty-three years, he will be remembered with great fondness for his wisdom, humor, and influence on our Reform Movement as its foremost poet and liturgist. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his beloved wife, Lea, his sons, David, Philip, and Michael, and his stepsons, Rand and Cary Lane. A Memorial Service will be held at Temple Beth El, 220 South Bedford Road, Chappaqua, NY, on Sunday November 11, 2001 at 2 P.M. May his memory be for a blessing. Alan D. Fuchs, Rabbi Dana S. Anesi, Cantor Stephen Adler, President

title: RAILAMERICA TO BUY PARKSIERRA FOR $48 MILLION
description: RailAmerica, the owner of 39 railroads in four countries, agreed yesterday to buy the ParkSierra Corporation for $48 million to expand in the Western United States, in its second purchase in the last month. The price includes $23 million in cash and assumed debt and $25 million in RailAmerica stock, the company said. The closely held ParkSierra owns three railroads with 751 miles of track in California and three other Western states and had sales of $24 million last year. RailAmerica said on Oct. 15 that it would buy the Dallas-based StatesRail for $90 million. StatesRail operates eight railroads. RailAmerica was expected to earn $1 a share this year and $1.30 in 2002, according to Thomson Financial/First Call surveys of four analysts.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Search Engine Expands
description: The top-ranked Internet search engine Google has expanded its index to include material in Microsoft Word, Excel and PowerPoint documents and other business and academic file formats linked from Web pages. The move augments Google's February 2001 addition of Adobe Portable Document Format, or P.D.F., files and brings the search engine's non-Web document total to 35 million. A Google spokesman, David Krane, said P.D.F.'s now account for 22 million of those documents, up from 10 million in February. Google converts these indexed documents to Web pages that can be viewed with standard browsers via a link on its search results pages. Google also now indexes the text of files formatted as PostScript, Rich Text Format, Lotus 1-2-3 and WordPro, and MacWrite, as well as the WordStar 2000 format.

title: Rayovac Profit Is Off 49%
description: The Rayovac Corporation, the third-largest United States battery maker, said fiscal fourth-quarter profit fell 49 percent and it eliminated an additional 60 jobs in the last six months. The company also lowered its 2002 forecast. Profit fell to $6.5 million, or 20 cents a share, from $12.7 million, or 44 cents, a year earlier. Sales dropped 2 percent, to $187.6 million, in the period ended Sept. 30 from $191.5 million, the company said.

title: Paul R. Screvane Dies at 87; Held Many Political Offices
description: Paul R. Screvane, who began serving New York City by driving a garbage truck and progressed to one of its loftiest political positions, president of the City Council, died on Sunday at his home in Wyomissing, Pa. He was 87.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUNEBAUM, ANNELIESE E.
description: GRUNEBAUM - Anneliese E. Peacefully on November 3, 2001, in her 96th year. Beloved widow of Kurt H. Grunebaum. Loving mother of Peter. Proud grandmother of George, Nicole and Danielle. Devoted great-grandmother of Marcus, Sebastian, Annabel, Solene and Charlotte. Services will be private. A memorial service will be held on November 13, 2001, at 2 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to The Neue Gallerie, 1048 5th Ave, New York, NY 10028.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, WILLIAM J.
description: MOORE-William J. The Fordham Law School community records with great sorrow the passing of William J. Moore, our Dean of Admissions for over 30 years. He brought great warmth, dignity, wise judgement and compassion to his work. His legacy is found in the lives of over 10,000 Fordham Law graduates who were admitted during his tenure. We extend our deep sympathy to his family. John D. Feerick, Dean

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BYRNE, ELEANOR (NEE CASEY)
description: O'BYRNE-Eleanor (nee Casey). On November 5, 2001. Beloved wife of Frank M. (retired Lt NYPD). Loving mother of Brian, Barbara Gogan, Michael and Ellen Mauser. Adored grandmother of Patrick and Casey Gogan, Erin & Michael O'Byrne and Christian Mauser. Fond mother-in-law of Patrick Gogan, Donna O'Byrne and John Mauser. Reposing at Romano Family Funeral Home, 24 Depot Square, Tuckahoe, NY. Mass of Christian Burial Friday 9:45AM, St. Barnabas R.C. Church. Interment in Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Visiting Wednesday and Thursday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 10th Fed Rate Cut This Year Raises Hopes for a Recovery
description: The Federal Reserve cut interest rates again yesterday, pushing down short-term rates as far this year as it has usually done before the economy comes out of a recession. Stock market investors now seem to believe a recovery will begin by the middle of next year.

title: President Named At G. P. Putnam
description: Carole Baron, a longtime publisher of commercial fiction and president of the Dutton division of Penguin Putnam, was named president of its G. P. Putnam & Sons division as well yesterday.

title: Amid Stimulus Wrangling, a Call for the President to Step In
description: Congressional Republicans stepped up attacks on Senate Democrats over economic stimulus legislation today, while Democrats argued that it was time for President Bush to get directly involved to avoid a partisan breakdown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEXNER, BELLA
description: WEXNER-Bella. The Officers, Board of Trustees and staff of United Jewish Communities mourn the passing of Bella Wexner, mother of Susan Wexner and Leslie Wexner, a true philanthropic leader whose lifelong devotion to the Jewish people was deeply felt from her own community of Columbus, Ohio, to the people and institutions of Israel. She was a generous supporter of the Columbus Jewish Federation and Columbus Jewish Foundation, and she took particular pride in the establishment of Wexner Heritage Village, one of the nation's premier elder care facilities. Her dedication to Israel included philanthropic support of projects through the Israel Education Fund of UJC and the Jewish Agency. Her deep and abiding commitment to the Jewish community is carried on by her son, Leslie, one of the country's most prominent Jewish philanthropists, who continues to be a major influence on Jewish life around the world. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire Wexner family. Charles R. Bronfman, Chairman of the Board Joel D. Tauber, Chairman, Executive Committee Stephen H. Hoffman, Chief Executive Officer

title: Console Shootout: New Video Games for New Systems
Local Motives
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Welcome to the Room
Editors' Note; Today's Sections
description: News of the Sept. 11 attacks and their aftermath continues to appear in Section B; index, Page B2.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a Man in the News article yesterday about James E. McGreevey, the New Jersey governor-elect, used an erroneous given name in some copies for a state senator who said Mr. McGreevey was a consensus builder. He is John Lynch, not Robert.

title: Hernndez Wants to Be a Yankee Next Season
description: Orlando Hernndez waved his hands and spoke quickly in Spanish to inform two reporters that he would not answer any questions about his uncertain future yesterday. Hernndez playfully added that they should not try to trick him with end- around inquiries, should not ask whether the Yankees might trade him before the 2002 season.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COPPER DROPS. Copper fell as weakening economies reduce industrial demand for wires and pipes. In New York, copper for December delivery fell a penny, or 1.6 percent, to 60.6 cents a pound.

title: Drug Policy Forum: Special Panel
description: On Monday, November 5, the NYTimes.coms Drug Policy forum hosted a special panel with 4 national drug reform activists. This panel was part of a series organized by the forum participants. Special Panelists:

title: A Programmable Dog That Will Bite Back
description: When Sony came out with its first four-legged Aibo robot in 1999, a lot of people thought that it was awfully cute. The latest Aibo, officially called ERS-220, is designed to look a little more menacing. Its eyes flash and it growls like an engine. The design is based on a revving race car, said Jon Piazza, a Sony spokesman, who described the new Aibo as ''a Terminator type of guy'' (minus the salty vocabulary).

title: Corrections
description: A sports column about the Yankees yesterday, discussing readers' e-mailed comments, misspelled the address of the columnist, Robert Lipsyte. It is thelipsite@aol.com.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in the sports pages on Monday showing the Yankees' rec ord in seventh games of the World Series referred incorrectly in some copies to the Milwaukee team that was their opponent in 1957 and 1958. It was the Braves, not the Brewers.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Taiwan Lifts Restrictions On Investment in China

title: Florida Hotel Savings
description: Through Dec. 15, hotels in the Fort Lauderdale area are offering Fort Lauder Deals, with rates starting at $39 a night (the Green Island Inn, a block from the beach) and going up to $207 for a suite at the Wyndham Bonaventure. Marriott's Harbor Beach and Spa is $149 a night. And through Dec. 31, travelers who present a hotel room key will receive two-for-one admission to the Broward Center for the Performing Arts, the Florida Grand Opera, the Florida Philharmonic and the Miami City Ballet, among other institutions. Hotel discounts are based on availability. For information and reservations, www.sunny.org/deals .

title: News Corporation Reports 44% Drop in Quarterly Profit
description: The profit of the News Corporation, which is owned by Rupert Murdoch, fell 44 percent in the first quarter of the company's fiscal year as the Fox television network, which is owned by the company, and British newspaper units of the company were hurt by a global slowdown in advertising.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Cambodia: 4th Opposition Candidate Killed
description: An opposition candidate for local elections set for February was beaten to death, the fourth such killing, said a spokesman for the party, the Sam Rainsy party. ''This is completely a political killing,'' he said. The local police said the killing had occurred during a robbery and was not political. The police have also said the previous killings were not political. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Green Air Purifiers Vs. Ground Zero
description: ON Tuesday, a tractor-trailer loaded with 1,000 houseplants rumbled to a stop at Stuyvesant High School, a few blocks from ground zero. That was after Howard Bader, an environmental engineer hired by the school's parents association, had reported high levels of airborne particles.

title: A Tour Guide That Heeds Your Prompts and Preferences
description: Tourists with cellphones -- and soon that may mean most tourists -- can now use them as personal city guides when taking in the sights in Washington or, with a service that started last week, Manhattan. By calling a toll-free number, users of a new service called BeyondGuide can listen to short narratives about 21 major New York sites, including the Brooklyn Bridge, Fifth Avenue and, of course, the World Trade Center.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: MP3.Com Settles Copyright Suit
description: MP3.com, the online music-sharing site owned by Vivendi Universal, settled a lawsuit brought by the record label TVT Records. The settlement ends a suit that had seen a mistrial declared in June after an arithmetic error by the jury resulted in an award one-tenth what jurors had intended. The trial was to have decided how much MP3.com owed for posting online 145 copyright-protected compact discs controlled by Tee Vee Toons, known in the industry as TVT Records. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: In Desperate Times, Talking of Torture
description: To the Editor:

title: Out of the Pantry and Partying On
description: THE guests at the Upper West Side apartment last Friday were caught up in the plastic gadgets, including a colander shaped like a lunar lander and ventilated containers that are intended to extend the life spans of corn ears.

title: New Tools Emerging to Speed Anthrax Detection
description: An ideal test for anthrax -- fast, sensitive, infallible and cheap -- does not yet exist. But drug companies say they have developed new tools that will greatly speed detection and diagnosis.

title: The Sleek Concorde Is Once More Carrying Passengers
description: With stronger tires, armor-plated wiring and redesigned fuel tanks, the Concorde, the world's only supersonic jetliner, resumed passenger service today for the first time since an Air France Concorde crashed in a ball of flames on the outskirts of this city 15 months ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PENTEL, SALLY
description: PENTEL-Sally, 95 years. Beloved wife of the late William, loving mother of Harvey & Eileen (Don Wade), cherished grandmother of Willie Wade-Pentel. Services on Friday 12:45PM ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, New York.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Not Happy With U.S.
description: Justice Minister Jos Gregori complained that a letter President Bush sent to Congress including Brazil among countries used as drug trafficking routes should have noted that the world's biggest consumer of illegal drugs is the United States. He also took issue with the interim American ambassador to Brazil, Cristobal Orozco, who recently said there are members of terrorist organizations in southern Brazil. The justice minister said there was no proof of that. Mery Galanternick (NYT)

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of Wednesday, 4,583 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about elections in Westchester County referred incorrectly in some copies to the spread by which Andrew J. Spano, the county executive, defeated Larry I. Horowitz, his Republican challenger. It was 71 percent to 27, not 55 to 42.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bad Loans Reportedly Rising
description: A report that the world's biggest bank, Mizuho Holdings, would write off twice as much in bad loans as it had planned earlier this year sent its shares tumbling 8.2 percent. The sell-off in Mizuho led Japan's Topix index of banking issues to sink to a 17-year low. Mizuho has lost nearly 60 percent of its market value since April 1. A bank spokesman, Yoshinori Ide, declined comment on a Mainichi newspaper report that Mizuho would write off 1.8 trillion yen ($14.8 billion) of bad loans for the year that began April 1, terming it speculation.

title: Coalition Maintenance
description: By welcoming French, German, Italian and Turkish troops to the war against terrorism, the United States is shoring up international support for its campaign against Osama bin Laden and the Taliban. The addition of these forces, some of which may be involved in combat operations, will render military decision-making more cumbersome. That is an acceptable price for ensuring the diplomatic solidarity needed to sustain an extended and difficult armed campaign.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Steve Cotten and Todd Nonken were named group account director and director for client services, respectively, at the Chicago office of the Sales Machine, part of the Euro RSCG Worldwide unit of Havas Advertising. Mr. Cotten had been director for brand marketing at Alamo Rent-A-Car, Ft. Lauderdale, Fla., part of the ANC Rental Corporation. Mr. Nonken had been a vice president at Upshot Marketing, Chicago, part of Ha-lo Industries.

title: Man Indicted In Fake Threat Of Anthrax
description: Nixon B. Saldanha of Bombay had had enough of New York and wanted to return to India. But he could not afford the plane fare, prosecutors said yesterday, so he tried to get himself deported.

title: McGreevey Warns of Tough Fiscal Future in New Jersey
description: Governor-elect James E. McGreevey exulted today in his victory over Bret D. Schundler and thanked voters for their support at his first post-election news conference. But he also issued a stark warning about the tough fiscal situation that he and the newly elected state legislators will face when they take office.

title: Ridge Offers Hope of End To the Anthrax Attacks, But Inquiry Is Still Stalled
description: As President Bush prepared to make a major address on the domestic wartime effort, his director of homeland security tried to reassure the public today while acknowledging that a monthlong government investigation into anthrax attacks had yet to provide any satisfactory answers.

title: New York Races
description: Results as of 9 p.m.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOHLER, JAMES E. SR.
description: KOHLER-James E. Sr. On November 7, 2001, of Breezy Point, NY, formerly of Brooklyn, NY. Deputy District Attorney, Kings County, NY. Former Deputy Commissioner, NYFD. Beloved husband of Jeanne. Loving father of Patricia and Thomas McVeigh, James Jr. and Patricia, Theresa and William Estes, Michael, Andrew and Margaret, and Jeanne. Cherished grandfather of T.J., Kaitlin, Sean, William and Christopher. Friends may visit Thursday and Friday, 2-5 and 7-10, Marine Park Funeral Home, 3024 Quentin Road, Brooklyn, NY. Mass of Christian Burial, Saturday 10AM at St. Thomas Moore R.C. Church, Breezy Point, NY. Interment to follow at St. Charles Cemetery, East Farmingdale, NY.

title: Making the Airport and the Plane Secure
description: To the Editor:

title: Proven Politician's Day 1: Getting Plenty of Advice and Keeping a Promise
description: Describing himself as elated, humbled and a bit tired, Mayor-elect Michael R. Bloomberg moved quickly yesterday to set a tone of accountability and inclusiveness in the next administration while also exhibiting some ease and humor with his newfound celebrity.

title: At the End, Labor Made Little Effort For Green
description: With polls showing the mayoral race neck-and-neck in the final days, Mark Green could have used a huge get-out-the-vote push from labor, but unfortunately for him, the campaign efforts by several major unions were half-hearted.

title: Police and the Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: The Role Of a Lifetime: Elaine Stritch As Herself
description: The firm-fleshed girls who bare it in bars can gyrate all they want, but the prize is taken. The honors for the most exciting striptease of the season go to a woman who is currently doing a little number called ''Zip'' in a downtown theater. She is tall and blonde, with skyscraper legs and klieg-light eyes, and she has the approximate energy quotient of a supernova in midexplosion. And -- oh, did I mention? -- she is 76.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JESSE, MARY JANE, M.D.
description: JESSE-Mary Jane, M.D., November 7, 2001 in Cincinnati, OH. Born January 8th, 1918 in Owensboro, Kentucky; daughter of Ethel May and Joseph Preston Jesse. After graduation from Nazareth College and a successful career with Young and Rubicam, she began to study medicine and graduated from the College of Physicians & Surgeons, Columbia University at the age of 41. Board certified in both pediatrics and cardiology, she served as Director of the Pediatric Medical Intensive Care Unit, Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center.
