After she became a member of the University of Miami Medical School, she assumed the position of Director of the Division of Heart and Vascular Disease at the National Institutes of Health. She returned to Miami as Professor of Pediatrics and ultimately became Professor Emeritus. At age 67, she moved to Cincinnati and became both the Associate Senior Vice President and Associate Provost for Health Affairs. At the same time, she became President-Elect and President of the American Heart Association. After her term of office, she became the Senior Vice President for Scientific Affairs of the American Heart Association. She was active in national and international health affairs. Dr. Jesse retired again in 1992 and lived with her sister, Martha Radike, Ph.D who predeceased her. She is survived by six nieces and nephews, twelve great-nieces and nephews. Funeral Mass, November 9th, 7PM, St. James of the Valley, Wyoming, OH. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be sent to: Habitat for Humanity, 420 West Wyoming Avenue, Cincinnati, OH 45215.

title: Footlights
description: Downtime for Bialystock

title: Proven Politician's Day 1: Getting Plenty of Advice And Keeping a Promise
description: Describing himself as elated, humbled and a bit tired, Mayor-elect Michael R. Bloomberg moved quickly yesterday to set a tone of accountability and inclusiveness in the next administration while also exhibiting some ease and humor with his newfound celebrity.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Factory Orders Fall
description: Manufacturing orders fell 4.1 percent in Germany in September from August, the biggest decline in six years, the Finance Ministry said. The September decrease was led by a drop in demand from overseas customers, and the report increased pressure on the European Central Bank to trim interest rates to avert a recession. Economists had expected German factory orders to fall 2 percent. In August, orders rose a revised 0.8 percent.

title: Firestone Said to Reach Tire Settlement
description: The Bridgestone/Firestone Corporation will pay $41.5 million to avert state lawsuits over millions of tires recalled last year, a person close to the settlement talks said today. The announcement is expected to be made on Thursday.

title: West Paterson to Stay That Way
description: For the third time in 12 years, voters here have turned back an attempt to change their community's name. But don't count out a fourth try.

title: Economic Scene; The decline of the Muslim Middle East, and the roots of resentment, can be traced to Islamic inheritance law.
description: UNTIL the late Middle Ages, the Muslim Middle East was at least as economically developed as Europe. Then, beginning with the rise of the great Italian traders in the 14th century, Europeans pulled ahead, while the Islamic world gradually declined. By the 19th century, European economic influence had translated into political domination of the Middle East. The Islamic world has never fully recovered, and that disparity feeds resentment today.

title: A House in the Round Comes Full Circle
description: THE HENRY FORD MUSEUM is a treasury of Americana from plows to presidential limousines, but its latest acquisition looks as if it flew in from outer space. A sleek silver dome, it is the only example of Buckminster Fuller's Dymaxion house ever built, trucked from Kansas in pieces to be reassembled here. It opened to the public on Oct. 24.

title: Worker Who Died Suspected Anthrax Was Root of Illness
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7  Hours before he died here last month from inhalation anthrax, a postal worker called 911 for an ambulance and, clearly afraid, told the emergency operator he suspected he had anthrax because he remembered that colleagues working near him the week before had handled a letter with powder in it.

title: Lower Profit Is Reported At DoCoMo
description: NTT DoCoMo, Japan's largest wireless operator, said today that its profit fell in the six months ended Sept. 30 as growth in the country's cellphone market slowed and plunging stock prices forced the company to write off equity losses.

title: Corrections
description: A drawing with the Q & A column in Science Times on Tuesday about birds' ability to survive New York winters was published in error. It was intended for a column scheduled for next week, about weather conditions that favor a bumper crop of apples.

title: A Rich Palette On the Floor Says, 'Welcome to the Room'
description: WHAT better way to warm up a house and feel snug in cold weather than to roll out lively, boldly colored carpets?

title: Ashcroft Orders Justice Dept. Into New Wartime Structure
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8  Attorney General John Ashcroft announced today that he has ordered the Justice Department to take a wartime posture and has begun to restructure the agency's priorities under a plan that will send thousands of agents from Washington out to offices around the country, where they are to work to prevent further terror attacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEXLER, JOHN P.
description: WEXLER-John P. We are saddened by the loss of our cousin, who will be sorely missed. Judy, Jane, Robert, Marilyn, David and families

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Arab Lawmaker Faces Charges
description: Israeli lawmakers voted to lift the parliamentary immunity of Azmi Bishara, an Israeli Arab legislator, so he can be prosecuted for remarks urging resistance to Israel and for arranging visits by Israeli Arabs to Syria, with which Israel is technically at war. It was the first time a lawmaker had been stripped of his immunity for political statements. At a memorial gathering in Damascus last June after the death of President Hafez al-Assad, Mr. Bishara called for broadening ''the path of resistance'' to Israel. He denies that he incited violence and says he supports the right of Palestinians to struggle against Israeli occupation. Joel Greenberg (NYT)

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I refused to help Green, and by anyone's estimation it hurt him. But there's nothing the party can do to me. What can they do to me?''

title: White House Sets Meeting With Film Executives to Discuss War on Terrorism
description: Several dozen top executives in the film and television industry plan to meet on Sunday morning with Karl Rove, a senior White House adviser, to discuss what Hollywood can do to aid the war effort.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEXNER, BELLA
description: WEXNER-Bella. The President, Chancellor Emeritus, Boards of Governors & Overseers, Faculty, Administration and Students of Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion, record with profound sorrow the death of Bella Wexner, beloved mother of Leslie, Abigail and Susan Wexner. Her philanthropy & devotion to Jewish continuity was evident in her generosity to her own community of Columbus, throughout America and in Israel. May the family find comfort together with all those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi David Ellenson, President Rabbi Alfred Gottschalk, Chancellor Emeritis Mr. Burton Lehman, Chair, Board of Governors

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUSSMAN, MURRAY
description: SUSSMAN-Murray. On November 7, 2001. Beloved husband of Harriet, devoted father of Samuel, Eleanor and Bernard. Cherished grandfather of 7 and great-grandfather of 1. Services on Thursday 1 PM at Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, Queens Blvd and 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUROVY, WALTER
description: SUROVY-Walter. The Officers, Board of Directors and staff of the Metropolitan Opera Guild mourn the passing of Walter Surovy, the husband of our beloved longtime Board member, Rise Stevens. Walter was a great friend of the Guild and a valuable supporter of our work, and we will miss his warm and subtle humor at Guild events. Our deepest condolences go to his wife, Rise, and their family. Thomas J. Hubbard, Chairman of the Board Susan S. Braddock, President Rudolph S. Rauch, Managing Director

title: In Desperate Times, Talking of Torture
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article last Thursday about Maira Kalman, an artist who painted a mural in the temporary quarters of Public School 234, which had to move from its building in TriBeCa after Sept. 11, misspelled the breed of her dog, which accompanied her to work. It is a wheaten terrier, not Wheaton.

title: 'Max Bickford' Struggles To Earn Television Tenure
description: ''The Education of Max Bickford,'' a new CBS dramatic series about a college professor facing a midlife crisis, seemed to have everything going for it. It stars the Academy Award-winning actor Richard Dreyfuss. The network has placed it in a choice time slot, Sunday night at 8, following the venerable and still popular ''60 Minutes.'' Its creators are Nicole Yorkin and Dawn Prestwich, a respected writing team who had been co-executive producers of the successful CBS series ''Judging Amy.''

title: Levy Tells Berlin School Leaders Of New York Bilingual Program
description: As a guest of the American Academy here this week, the New York City schools chancellor, Harold O. Levy, joins the ranks of people like Arthur Miller and Susan Sontag who have also been lecturers at the academy. The academy, in a stately residence on the shore of the Wannsee in Berlin, was founded in 1998 to promote German-American ties in the arts, humanities and public affairs.

title: NBC Enterprises Plans A National Campaign
description: The NBC Enterprises division of NBC will introduce a national licensing and consumer merchandising program centered on shows that appear on the network in prime-time, daytime, late-night and Saturday morning slots.

title: Suozzi Quickly Focuses on Nassau's Woes
description: Now comes the really hard part.

title: Torre Talks Leadership, And Executives Listen
description: A baseball observer can easily detect Joe Torre's people skills. He handles his players deftly while dealing with an exceedingly demanding boss. Through six seasons as the Yankees' manager and four World Series titles, there have been few clubhouse blowups, no Bronx Zoo-like eruptions. He easily expresses love for his players and respect for his opponents.

title: UTILICORP OFFERS TO BUY BACK STOCK IT SPUN OFF
description: A large utility owner, UtiliCorp United, said yesterday that it had offered to buy the 20 percent of its trading arm, Aquila, that it did not own for $362.1 million, seven months after it spun off part of the unit to raise $420 million. Aquila shareholders are being offered 0.6896 share of UtiliCorp, or $20.69 based on Tuesday's closing price. That represents a 15 percent premium based on Aquila's close yesterday. But that is 14 percent below the initial stock sale price of $24. UtiliCorp sold 17.5 million Aquila shares in April. Before yesterday, Aquila's stock had fallen 25 percent to $17.99 as gas and power prices declined.

title: Adjustment To Lines Lifts Holik And Devils
description: The Devils have lost once in their last eight games, but Coach Larry Robinson continues to change lines to produce more scoring.

title: Sports of The Times; Regaining A Rivalry, And Respect
description: THERE was a subdued air of excitement at Nassau Coliseum Tuesday night. The resurgent Islanders had defeated the Tampa Bay Lightning, 3-0, for their 11th victory of the season.

title: Excerpts From Postal Worker's 911 Call
description: Following are excerpts from a 911 call on Oct. 21 by Thomas Morris Jr., a postal worker who died hours after the call, as recorded by The New York Times from CNN:

title: Not Just an Office Romance
description: TRADITIONALLY, contract textiles were not something you would want to snuggle up to. A byproduct of the postwar building boom, these commercial fabrics were created to withstand heavy traffic -- waiting room upholstery, elevator walls, hospital privacy curtains. Their reputation: indestructible and unglamorous.

title: The Vote, and the Post-Mortems
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, RABBI CHAIM
description: STERN-Rabbi Chaim. On November 5, 2001. Beloved husband of Lea. Father of David, Philip and Michael. Stepfather of Rand and Cary. Private, graveside service Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, N.Y. Memorial service on Sunday, November 11th, 2PM at Temple Beth El, Chappaqua, N.Y. Donations to Chaim Stern Caring Community Fund, C/O Temple Beth El, 220 South Bedford Road., Chappaqua, NY 10514.

title: Part of First Four: Donovan's Gators Ring In New Season
description: Billy Donovan stepped out of a cab yesterday and walked three blocks to the New York Stock Exchange. There, Donovan was confronted with metal barricades, police officers and security guards in gas masks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EATON, ELIZABETH WITSELL
description: EATON-Elizabeth Witsell, 75, of Manhattan, on November 4, 2001. Devoted wife of the late William Mellon Eaton. Loving mother of Carolyn, Alexander, Sarah and Lisa. Treasured grandmother of Eliza, Lily, Jay, Nina and William. Sister of Frederick C. Witsell, Jr. Avid tennis player and golfer, lifelong traveler and cherished friend to many. Service Friday at 11AM at the Church of Heavenly Rest, 90th & 5th Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory and in honor of Manhattan and New Hampshire may be made to the Central Park Conservancy, 14 East 60 Street, New York, NY 10022.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WICHMANN, HILDEGARD C.
description: WICHMANN-Hildegard C. On November 5, 2001. Former Executive Secretary with Niagara Alkali. Graveside prayer service at 1 PM Friday, November 9th, 2001, Lutheran-All Faiths Cemetery, Middle Village, New York.

title: Colleen Dewhurst Mementos Are Sold in Low-Key Auction
description: When the bidding concluded at the William Doyle Galleries in Manhattan yesterday, it wasn't oil paintings or duck prints that had been snatched up by the bidders. The prizes were items as mundane and minute as an open package of emery boards and a smeared makeup towel that once belonged to the actress Colleen Dewhurst and a copy of the script of ''Dr. Strangelove: Or How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Bomb'' that had belonged to George C. Scott, whom Dewhurst married and divorced twice.

title: Sailor Is Feared To Be Lost at Sea From Kitty Hawk
description: An American sailor aboard the aircraft carrier Kitty Hawk was feared lost at sea today after a helicopter crew tried unsuccessfully to save him, Pentagon officials said.

title: The Vote, and the Post-Mortems
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, SAM
description: ROSENBERG-Sam. On November 6, 2001. Beloved husband of Elaine, loving father of Lance. Former President of The Town Club Foundation. He will be missed. Private service. Contributions in his memory to The Town Club Foundation, 9 East 86th Street, New York, New York 10028.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUNEBAUM, ANNELIESE E.
description: GRUNEBAUM - Anneliese E. Peacefully on November 3, 2001, in her 96th year. Beloved widow of Kurt H. Grunebaum. Loving mother of Peter. Proud grandmother of George, Nicole and Danielle. Devoted great-grandmother of Marcus, Sebastian, Annabel, Solene and Charlotte. A memorial service will be held on November 13, 2001, at 2 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to The Neue Gallerie, 1048 5th Ave, New York, NY 10028.

title: As Democrats Bicker, Bloomberg Era Begins
description: Mayor-elect Michael R. Bloomberg indicated yesterday that he would form his own team for a new administration, and not necessarily by retaining Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's top aides.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDNER, CHARLES
description: GOLDNER-Charles. On November 6, 2001. The Manhattan Day School-Yeshiva Ohr Torah family mourns the passing of Mr. Charles Goldner, beloved father of our past PTA Presidents Debbie Gibber and Naomi Colton and beloved father-in-law of our devoted Chairman of the Board, Elliot Gibber. May the family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Mordechai Besser, Principal Eli Salig, President

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Arizona: Immigrant's Killing May Bring Death Penalty
description: The Maricopa County attorney, Richard Romley, is seeking the death penalty for the man accused of killing a Sikh immigrant from India outside his gas station in Mesa four days after the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11. Prosecutors said Frank Roque shot Balbir Singh Sodhi, then fired shots into a convenience store owned by a Lebanese man and a house that Mr. Roque had sold to a family from Afghanistan. Mr. Roque was quoted in police reports saying, ''all Arabs had to be shot.'' Laurie Goodstein (NYT)

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Sued Over Suicide Law

title: Giuliani Officials Aren't Promised Automatic Jobs
description: Mayor-elect Michael R. Bloomberg indicated yesterday that he would form his own team for a new administration, and not necessarily by retaining Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's top aides.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORODOVKO, IDA
description: BORODOVKO-Ida. On November 6, resident of Greenwood House, Ewing, NJ. Beloved wife of the late Isidore Borodovko. Mother of Judith Walzer and Naomi Lager; survived also by five granddaughters, six great-grandsons and two great-granddaughters. Services at Gleason Funeral Home, Somerset, NJ at 11:30AM today. Contributions may be made to Greenwood House.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Arizona: Guilty Plea In Fires
description: A Phoenix man pleaded guilty to eight counts of extortion and one count of using fire to commit a federal felony. The man, Mark Warren Sands, 50, said he set fire to seven luxury homes near protected desert areas in Phoenix and Scottsdale starting last year to stop development in environmentally fragile places. Mr. Sands was scheduled to be sentenced in February; he faces 15 to 20 years in prison and restitution payments to the homeowners of about $3.1 million. He had faced 23 counts in the arson case. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: People
description: * Steve Farella, chief executive at Media Planning, New York, part of the Media Planning Group division of Havas Advertising, resigned, he said, because the agency ''brought in new management and we have disagreed on the direction of the company.''

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: McDonald's Cuts Profit Forecast
description: McDonald's (Japan) Ltd., the country's largest restaurant chain, lowered its profit forecast for the year ending Dec. 31 as consumers shunned beef after the discovery in September of a cow that had bovine spongiform encephalopathy, or mad cow disease. The company said that it expected to earn a net 10.7 billion yen ($88.3 million) this year, 27 percent less than forecasts released in August. Sales slid 17.6 percent in October from a year earlier even though the company said all the beef it used was imported from Australia, where no infected cows have been found. Shares in the company, a subsidiary of the McDonald's Corporation of the United States, have fallen 36 percent since they were listed on Japan's over-the-counter market in July. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Sun, Surf and Sexuality In a Pina Bausch Romp
description: Few artistic personalities have the international renown of Pina Bausch, the German choreographer whose latest dance-theater piece in the Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music is unsurprisingly the hot ticket in town.

title: 3 Worldwide Agencies Form Strategic Alliance
description: Three worldwide financial communications agencies are forming a strategic alliance under one name, AMO International Financial Communications. Terms were not disclosed.

title: From 2 Brothers, Bolts of Lightning
description: WHILE the plot thickeners are all in the mix -- two ambitious brothers, a multimillion-dollar family business that began with the proverbial pushcart, an indomitable father -- the Maharam story is no made-for-television melodrama.

title: As Democrats Bicker, Bloomberg Era Begins
description: In a day of recriminations, New York Democrats battled yesterday over who was to blame for Mark Green's loss to Michael R. Bloomberg, the novice candidate who was elected New York's 108th mayor on Tuesday.

title: Palm Beach Is Selling Its Voting Machines
description: An infamous bit of political Americana went on the block today, with an online auction site offering to the public 3,055 of Palm Beach County's Votomatic voting machines and the ''butterfly ballots'' that prompted accusations of misdirected voting in last year's presidential election.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: Trade Center Leaseholder Sues a Big Reinsurer
description: The real estate developer who holds the World Trade Center lease fired back at one of the complex's biggest insurers yesterday, filing a lawsuit demanding that the insurer promptly pay its share of the coverage -- even while litigation continues to determine how much the insurers are liable for.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLANER, LUELLA B.
description: SLANER-Luella B. Died peacefully November 3, 2001, at home. Beloved mother of Eugenia Ames, Barbara Winslow and Deborah Larkin. Sister to Pauline Burgo. Grandmother to Alexander, Juliet, Jessie, Samantha, Margaret. Memorial service Thursday, November 8, 10 AM, Scarsdale Congregational Church, 1 Heathcote Rd, Scarsdale. Donations in her memory in lieu of flowers to Scarsdale Public Library.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERMAN, FRED, MD.
description: SILVERMAN-Fred, MD. Our dear friend and colleague. We are saddened at the loss. Sincere condolences to Marilyn and family. Claire and Sherwin Kaufman

title: A Paternity Dispute Divides Net Pioneers
description: FEW inventions are immune from claims and counterclaims of precedence. Thomas Edison was embroiled in a number of patent disputes. It took years for the Wright brothers to secure their rightful claim to aircraft-powered flight.

title: U.S. Figures Show Rate of Productivity Gained in Third Quarter
description: Productivity in the third quarter rose at the fastest pace in more than a year as companies relied on fewer workers to produce goods and services, government figures showed today.

title: Know Thy Retailer: Help for Mail Phobia
description: NO one loved the surprise of mail more than I did. I have even been known to start humming the tune to ''Wells Fargo Wagon'' when I spied a package waiting on the stoop.

title: Defectors Cite Iraqi Training For Terrorism
description: Two defectors from Iraqi intelligence said yesterday that they had worked for several years at a secret Iraqi government camp that had trained Islamic terrorists in rotations of five or six months since 1995.

title: From a Room With a View, Going to Bat for Parks
description: HOW often is it that a New Yorker gets a chance to work in a charming old building that looks like a medieval fortress, and from an office window, can hear sea lions barking for their chow three times a day?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERT, FRIEDA MOSKALIK, PH.D.
description: SILVERT-Frieda Moskalik, Ph.D. Age 80. Sociologist and author, died on November 3. She was a noted educator who taught sociology at the Institute of Sociology, Buenos Aires, Argentina, Dartmouth College, City College of New York, Brooklyn College and Sarah Lawrence University. As an activist in the struggles against oppression at home and abroad, she co-authored ''Dissent Denied: The Technocratic Response to Protest,'' and many articles including ''Fate, Chance and Faith,'' about the Cuban revolution. She was active in the peace, civil rights and student movements. She was the wife of the late Kalman H. Silvert, mother of Henry, Benjamin and Alexander; mother-in-law of Morrie, Andrea and Diana; grandmother of Lea, Eli, Kal and Che; and sister of Nora Sterling. For information about the Commemoration of Frieda's life, please contact her son Henry, NYC.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Domain Name Goes Live
description: The company that manages the new .biz Internet addresses, NeuLevel, yesterday began accepting registrations for .biz names first come first served. NeuLevel also officially activated 169,000 .biz names that had been preregistered over the summer. The company, based in Sterling, Va., received applications for 289,000 .biz addresses during preregistration, some of which remain inactive pending the outcome of a lawsuit over how the names were distributed. The .biz suffix is one of seven new top-level domains to be added to the Internet's address system.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Merchants Prepare For Euro
description: As the Jan. 1 deadline for the introduction of euro notes and coins approaches, Britain as a noneuro nation remains aloof -- but not its shopkeepers. Chains like Marks & Spencer and Harrods say that while Britain's leaders wrangle over whether to accept the euro or not, the stores will. The pound, though, will continue to dominate. The euro will be treated in much the same way as dollars, francs or German marks, a spokeswoman at Marks & Spencer said: The store will take euros for purchases and give change in pounds. Harrods said that while it would accept euros, it would price its goods in sterling. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: A Tale of 2 Engines: How Hybrid Cars Tame Emissions
description: DRIVERS are creatures of habit. They expect a vehicle to start with the turn of a key, respond to the accelerator and brake pedals, and depend on gasoline in the tank to move. What they do not expect is to get more than 50 miles to the gallon in city driving, or a quiet start after stopping at a light. To get those features you need a new class of car called a hybrid electric vehicle, or H.E.V.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Utility To Sell Bonds
description: Scottish Power, Britain's biggest electric utility, said that it no longer planned to sell Southern Water, its water utility in southern England. Instead, Scottish Power said it would try to raise $2.6 billion by selling Southern Water bonds to restructure Scottish Power's $8.5 billion debt. The announcement sent Scottish Power shares soaring to the biggest increase in three years, despite a report of a first-half loss attributed to miscalculations of American energy prices. Scottish Power owns PacifiCorp, which serves eight Western states. Scottish Power said its loss in the six months ended Sept. 30 was 126.7 million ($185 million), compared with a profit of 76.4 million a year earlier. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Ashcroft Orders Justice Dept. Into New Wartime Structure
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8  Attorney General John Ashcroft announced today that he has ordered the Justice Department to take a wartime posture and has begun to restructure the agency's priorities under a plan that will send thousands of agents from Washington out to offices around the country, where they are to work to prevent further terror attacks.

title: Another Entry in the 'DVCR' Race
description: In last week's State of the Art column, I reviewed Panasonic's new DMR-E20, a video recorder that uses DVD's instead of tape. I wrote that the discs last longer than tape, never require rewinding, and never open you to the risk of recording over something by accident.

title: WASTE MANAGEMENT SETTLES LAWSUIT FOR $457 MILLION
description: North America's largest trash hauler, Waste Management, said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $457 million to settle a class-action lawsuit. The lawsuit, filed in July 1999, accused Waste Management executives of misleading investors about the company's financial health after a merger. USA Waste Services bought Waste Management for $25.6 billion in 1998 and took the company's name. The company also said that Arthur Andersen, the accounting firm, had agreed to pay $20 million to settle accusations of professional malpractice. Shares of Waste Management, which is based in Houston, rose $1.63, to $26.98. The settlement is subject to court approval.

title: 2 Companies Choose Agencies for Accounts
description: Reckitt Benckiser Inc. in Wayne, N.J., named Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer Euro RSCG in New York as the new agency for its food division, which sells brands like French's Mustard, French's Potato Sticks, French's Taste Toppers french-fried onions and Frank's Original Red Hot sauce. Billings were estimated at $15 million.

title: Throngs at Art Institute of Chicago Say Go van Gogh
description: The crowds these days at the Art Institute of Chicago are not as overwhelming as curators had expected before the Sept. 11 attacks, but they are big enough to be the envy of most museums.

title: Leonardo, if You Could Only Have Lived to See This Day
description: In 1502, Leonardo da Vinci designed a sweeping stone bridge (drawing, right) to span the Golden Horn inlet in Istanbul. It would have connected the last bit of Europe to the first bit of Asia, but the design was rejected by the Turkish sultan, who thought it technologically impossible. Five hundred years later, the bridge has finally opened -- in a small town in Norway. The Norwegian artist Vebjorn Sand saw Leonardo's tiny drawing of the bridge in 1995. ''I just fell in love with the design,'' he said, ''and was amazed that it had never been built.'' Mr. Sand persuaded the Norwegian Public Roads Administration to build a 190-foot timber version of the bridge so pedestrians could cross a highway in the town of As. The bridge (above, before teak and stainless steel railings were added) was built by the architect Knut Selberg of Trondheim and the Moelven Group structural engineers at a cost of $1.47 million. ''I am very proud of the result -- taking a sketch from Leonardo da Vinci and translating it into a modern laminated wood-arch construction,'' Mr. Selberg said. He called it ''an interpretation of the original.'' Queen Sonja opened it officially last week. Mr. Sand said that the bridge was the first civil engineering scheme by Leonardo to be realized. Its elegant, pressed-bow form is based on an engineering principle that was not generally accepted until the 1800's. Mr. Sand now wants to put a Leonardo bridge on every continent. The bridge, he said, ''has a Renaissance man's dual way of thinking and at the same time touches on something eternal.'' PETER HALL

title: Changing of Guard at U.A.W.
description: Ron Gettelfinger, the union executive who negotiated a spinoff of Ford's auto supply business on exceedingly generous terms for its workers, is expected to be nominated as the next president of the United Automobile Workers on Thursday, several people close to the deliberations said today.

title: U.N. Says Four Billion Will Be Living in Hunger by 2050
description: The world population stands at 6.1 billion, double what it was in 1960, and is projected to reach 9.3 billion by 2050, the United Nations Population Fund reported today in its annual report. All the growth will be in developing countries; industrialized countries will remain stable in population.

title: WNYC, Damaged on Sept. 11, Sets a Fund-Raising Record
description: WNYC Radio, which lost two of its three transmitters in the attack on the World Trade Center and was forced to evacuate its offices in the Municipal Building in Lower Manhattan for three weeks, has completed one of the most successful pledge drives in public radio history, raising at least $3.1 million, the station announced on Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, MURRAY
description: SINGER-Murray. On Nov. 7, of Clark, NJ; beloved husband of Blanche (nee Bigel), devoted father of Amy & Robert Singer, fatherin-law of Mark Hahlbeck & Stacy Goldstein, dear brother of Pearl Wellin and the late Marley Lefkowitz, loving grandfather of Max, Emily and Jonah. Funeral services Fri., Nov. 9 at Temple Beth O'r/Beth Torah, 111 Valley Rd., Clark, NJ at 10:00 AM. Interment Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Iselin, NJ. For further information, Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Union, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADAMSON, PENNY
description: ADAMSON-Penny. Peacefully on November 5. Beloved wife of Iain Adamson. Loving sister of Edward and sister-in-law Ann. A celebration of Penny's life will take place in the Lion's Sensory Garden of Snug Harbor Botanical Gardens, Staten Island on November 10, 1 PM. Donations may be made to SHARE, 1501 Broadway, Suite 1720, New York, New York 10036.

title: Squeezed by a Renovation, the Modern Finds Space Online
description: It sounds like a bad pickup line, but the Museum of Modern Art really does want you to see its etchings. With more than half of its Midtown galleries closed for renovation, the Modern has turned to the Internet and mounted its first Web-only exhibition, ''Artists of Brcke.'' The show, which opened last week at moma.org/brucke, includes more than 110 etchings, woodcuts

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Oct. 18 about anthrax found in the office of the Senate majority leader misspelled the given name of the commander of the Army's Medical Research and Materiel Command at Fort Detrick, Md., which tested it. He is Maj. Gen. John S. Parker, not Jon.

title: Procter & Gamble Gets Approval for Clairol Deal
description: Procter & Gamble announced yesterday that it had won the Justice Department's approval for its $4.95 billion purchase of Clairol from Bristol-Myers Squibb.

title: Worker Who Died Suspected Anthrax Was Root of Illness
description: Hours before he died here last month from inhalation anthrax, a postal worker called 911 for an ambulance and, clearly afraid, told the emergency operator he suspected he had anthrax because he remembered that colleagues working near him the week before had handled a letter with powder in it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AHERN, JOHN J.
description: AHERN-John J. (1932-2001) in Paris, France, of a rare form of cancer. A native New Yorker, Mr. Ahern was a pharmaceutical business executive who lived and worked in Colombia, Australia, and throughout Europe. Survived by his loving wife, Marianne, his daughters Florence and Teresa, and son William. Also survived by his sister Anne Mulloy and brother William Ahern. Services Friday, November 9th in Paris at Church of St. Honre Eylau followed by Burial at the cemetery of Montparnasse.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Indictment Over Sarajevo
description: The prosecutor of the United Nations war crimes tribunal said that a former Bosnian Serb commander, Dragomir Milosevic, had been charged with war crimes for his troops' attacks against civilians during the 1992-95 siege of Sarajevo. The indictment was kept secret since it was issued in April 1998 in the hope that NATO troops would arrest him, the prosecutor's spokesman said, but he has not been detained. General Milosevic, whose whereabouts are unknown, is not related to the former Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic, who is awaiting trial on war crimes charges. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEUTSCH, ALFRED L.
description: DEUTSCH-Alfred L. The membership and Board of Governors of the Boca Rio Golf Club, Boca Raton, Florida, announce with deep regret and sorrow the passing of our dear friend and esteemed member, Alfred L. Deutsch, and extend our sincerest condolences to his wife, Bernice, and their family. Robert P. Adler, President Boca Rio Golf Club, Inc.

title: Head of Troubled New York Academy of Sciences Is Resigning in Policy Rift
description: The New York Academy of Sciences announced yesterday that its president and chief executive, Rodney W. Nichols, would leave at the end of the year. Mr. Nichols's efforts to reshape the academy, including closing its award-winning magazine The Sciences and putting its elegant headquarters on East 63rd Street up for sale, roiled the institution in recent months.

title: Black Woman Elected Mayor Of Atlanta In Close Vote
description: After a long night of vote counting, Shirley Clarke Franklin appeared today to be the first woman to be elected mayor of Atlanta and the first black woman to lead a major Southern city.

title: The C.E.O. of N.Y.C.
description: On Day 1 as mayor-elect, Michael Bloomberg was busy yesterday sending out comforting signals to New Yorkers who might have been worried about thrusting a non-politician into what has often been described as the second most difficult political job in the country.

title: Focusing on the Losers
description: In a burst of candor and finger-pointing, a senior Republican official here departed from his colleagues' spin that they had frittered away the governorships in Virginia and New Jersey on Tuesday to Democrats who had more money and did not have to contend with divisive primaries.

title: It's Morning for the Democrats In the Suburbs of the Northeast
description: In New Jersey, Democrats claimed control of state government for the first time in nearly a decade. In Nassau County, Democrats wrested control of the county government for the first time since World War I. Even in Greenwich, Conn., a bastion of Republican politics, Democrats managed, in a stunning upset, to take control of local government for what the new top elected official believed was the first time ever.

title: F.C.C. Is Expected to Lift Airwave Spectrum Cap
description: The Federal Communications Commission is expected to vote today to gradually eliminate the cap on the amount of airwave spectrum that mobile phone companies can acquire in a single market, people close to the commission said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a Staten Island couple charged with second-degree murder in the death of their 3-year-old daughter referred incorrectly to the availability of Nicholas Scoppetta, the commissioner of children's services, for comment. He was not unavailable, having returned to New York from Washington. His comment and other new developments are reported today on Page A1.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the At the Movies column on Friday about the Pixar computer-animated film ''Monsters, Inc.'' misspelled the surname of its executive producer, who directed the previous Pixar films. He is John Lasseter, not Lassiter.

title: The Big City; An Outsider Comes Inside To Run Things
description: ONCE again we have elected a mayor who proudly claims not to be a politician. This is a wonderful formula for lively news conferences, as we learned during Rudolph W. Giuliani's performances, and the city's political journalists are understandably ecstatic.

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article on Oct. 18 about anthrax found in the office of the Senate majority leader misspelled the given name of the commander of the Army's Medical Research and Materiel Command at Fort Detrick, Md., which tested it. He is Maj. Gen. John S. Parker, not Jon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOLLMERHAUSEN, JOSEPH WILLIAM, M.D.
description: VOLLMERHAUSEN-Joseph William, M.D. Of Summit, NJ died November 6, 2001 after a long illness. Born in Barmen, Germany, May 10, 1917, son of Maria and Joseph. The family emigrated in 1925. He graduated valedictorian of Brooklyn Prep School 1935, Fordham University 1939, and Long Island College of Medicine 1943. Dr. Vollmerhausen interned at University of Pennsylvania Hospital, Philadelphia. From there, he served as Captain in the US Army. He completed his residency at Pilgrim State Hospital. For more than 40 years, he practiced psychoanalysis in Manhattan. Part of that time, he also practiced in Summit. He served as Associate Dean of Karen Horney Institute of Psychoanalysis, where he was a training and supervising analyst. Subsequently, he joined the Postgraduate Center for Mental Health. He was a member of the Academy of Psychoanalysis, life member of American Psychoanalytic Association, and member of the New York Medical Society. Cherished husband of Claire Murphy Ruotolo whom he married in 1973. Together they enjoyed many years of world travel, playing tennis wherever they went. Proud father of John, M.D. of CA, Robert of NC, and Ruth Carey of FL. Loved by stepchildren Denise Ruotolo of Plainfield, the late Andrew Ruotolo, Jr. of Westfield, Cynthia Sherwin of CT and Diane Webber of PA. Adored grandfather of Todd, Jamie, Jessica, Jill, Lyndsay, Andrew, Jayne, Ryan and Chelsea. Brother to John, Gertrude Gehringer, and the late Elizabeth Metesch. Memorial service will be held on Saturday, November 10, noon at Dangler Funeral Home, 309 Springfield Ave, Summit. Contributions in lieu of flowers, to Community Food Bank of New Jersey, 31 Evans Terminal Road, Hillside, New Jersey 07205.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: A Nation Challenged
description: The Financial Front

title: Console Shootout: The Sequel
description: THIS month two new game consoles make their debut, and their differences are apparent before you even take them out of the box. When I received Microsoft's Xbox in the mail, I looked at the package and thought, can it really be this big? A few days later, when the mailman dropped off Nintendo's GameCube, I wondered, can it really fit inside this little box?

title: When Is a Television Really a Lamp?
description: The Infinite Light from Snowcrash, a Stockholm-based company, is like a high concept televised yule log. The bulb ''burns'' on your television screen, thanks to a 45-minute videotape. Want to dim it? Adjust your set's brightness control. ''It's not an object,'' said Arik Levy, its designer. ''It is technology.'' The Infinite Light is at www.snowcrash.se for about $40 (including tax, shipping and duty), or at the Apartment, 101 Crosby Street (Prince Street), (212) 219-3661. (Television not included.) STEPHEN TREFFINGER

title: Pursuit of Terror Funds, Anthrax Victim on Tape, Partisan Sniping
description: ''Follow the money'' is a tried and true maxim for investigators, and it works for President Bush, too. Repeatedly, he has made clear that one way to strike at Al Qaeda, Osama bin Laden's terrorist network, is to cut off its cash flow. Now that effort has taken a new course.

title: Slow Lane to Kmart's Recovery; Consumers Turn Frugal and Many Suppliers Discontent
description: When Charles C. Conaway strode into Troy, Mich., 18 months ago to take over the sagging Kmart Corporation, he had big plans. Not only did he intend to revive Kmart, the nation's No. 2 discount chain, by attracting new customers with a wide array of useful, low-price goods, but he would also do it by September 2002.

title: Incredibly Shrinking AT&T And the Armstrong Agenda
description: C. Michael Armstrong, the chairman of AT&T, has sympathizers in high places these days.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: No Agreement In Refugee Talks
description: Nepal and Bhutan, two Himalayan nations that are among the world's poorest, did not manage to settle a longstanding dispute over refugees in two days of talks but the Nepalese Foreign Ministry said that the countries had agreed to continue discussions. About 100,000 Hindus fled mostly Bhuddist Bhutan about a decade ago and settled in United Nations-sponsored camps in Nepal.

title: In the Bookstore With Care
description: The Grisham that stole Christmas.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FISHER COMMUNICATIONS, Seattle, the operator of 12 television stations, said it would sell most of its real estate to focus on broadcasting and media and to cut business expenses in 2002.

title: National Briefing
description: SOUTHWEST

title: No Joy in Mudville, as Twins Are Near Striking Out
description: There is no epitaph for baseball here yet. But if there was any handwriting on the wall for Minnesota Twins fans on the day after Major League Baseball owners voted to cut the 30 professional teams by two, it read: Baseball is dead.

title: A Living Link To Roots Music
description: A little over a year ago, I sat in a trailer home in Gravel Springs with a 93-year-old Mississippi gentleman by the name of Otha Turner, one of the last living links to one of the roots of American music. Slouched in a chair in overalls and a cap, Mr. Turner recalled the time in the 1950's when a musicologist named Alan Lomax drove up. He greeted Mr. Turner, a sharecropper then, and said he was from the Library of Congress and wondered if there were any blues musicians in the area he could record.

title: Giuliani's Possibilities Multiply as His Days Left in Office Dwindle
description: So what now for Rudy?

title: In America; Mark Green's Problem
description: It was a humiliating defeat. And if Mark Green is at all interested in understanding the real reason he is not the mayor-elect of New York at this critical moment in the city's history, he should do the thing he has always done best -- look in a mirror.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Utica: Child Shot To Death
description: A man shot and killed his 9-year-old neighbor Tuesday night and then died after he sped from the scene and his sport utility vehicle crashed into a utility pole, the police said. The man, Nkrumah Jack, 24, shot Jorge Escedero with an assault rifle inside the boy's apartment at 11:50 p.m., the police said. Mr. Jack then drove two miles into downtown Utica, exceeding 70 miles an hour before crashing. Mr. Jack knew the boy and his mother, though the police said they had not determined the motive for the shooting.

title: In Desperate Times, Talking of Torture
description: To the Editor:

title: To Promote Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: One Way to Put an Annex on a Fairy Tale Castle
description: In 1997, when Aaron Parker, an architect in Minneapolis, was hired to design an addition to the American-Swedish Institute there, he flew to Stockholm to look at how things were built. He saw curvy, sloped roofs ''of wood, cedar shakes and thatch,'' he said. Mr. Parker designed a 65,000-square-foot addition (the left part of the model, right) emulating those rooftops. Some see the roofs of Swedish public buildings in it, others the thatched roofs of Swedish barns. The institute's turreted and spired building, finished in 1908, was originally the home of Swan Turnblad, the publisher of the Svenska Amerikanska Posten, a newspaper in Swedish. In 1929, Turnblad transformed it into an institute for Swedish arts and science. ''It's an extraordinarily well-ordered Palladian plan, disguised as a fairy castle,'' said Mr. Parker, who teaches architecture and urban design at the University of Minnesota. The addition, which will include a rooftop garden planted with grass, is estimated to cost $18 million. Half of the money has been raised, the architect said. He hopes the institute, at 2600 Park Avenue, will break ground next year. ELAINE LOUIE

title: Spanish Judge Shot to Death; Basque Rebels Are Suspected
description: A Spanish judge was shot dead today as he left his home in northern Spain in the first fatal attack linked to the Basque separatist group E.T.A. since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States.

title: The To-Do List That Knows Where You Are
description: IN the wired world of the 21st century, it seems impossible to forget anything. A cartoon pops up on your computer screen reminding you that it's a friend's birthday. An exclamation mark surfaces on your palmtop alerting you to a looming project deadline. Every once in a while your cellphone breaks into spasms of music to signal your next appointment.

title: Move by U.S. on Suicide Law Draws Suit in Oregon
description: Richard L. Holmes does not want to die.

title: For Antiquers, An Anxious Season
description: THE Winter Antiques Show in January, the most prestigious annual antiques event in the country, has been locked out of the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue at 67th Street -- its home for 48 years -- by National Guard operations there. The show will be staged instead at the Hilton New York on the Avenue of the Americas at 53rd Street.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Girl Killed In House Fire
description: A 13-year-old girl was killed and her sister and another family member were injured when a fire broke out in the girl's bedroom, apparently trapping her inside, the authorities said yesterday. Flawed electrical wiring may have led to the one-alarm fire at 155 Jerome Street in Highland Park shortly before 11:30 p.m. Tuesday, the police said. The girl, Sake Dentin, suffered third-degree burns and was pronounced dead at the scene. Her 10-year-old sister, whose name was not immediately released, was taken to Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center with head and neck injuries and was listed in stable condition, the officials said. Another family member, whose name was not released, was treated for smoke inhalation, the police said. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: Court Overturns Jury Award In '89 Exxon Valdez Spill
description: A federal appeals court ruled today that the $5.3 billion in punitive damages the Exxon Corporation was ordered to pay for the 1989 Exxon Valdez oil spill, the worst in the nation's history, was excessive, and told a judge to set a lower amount.

title: A Game to Remember for All the Wrong Reasons
description: Still angry, frustrated and humiliated, Greg Schiano wanted to find a place to hide for a few days, but the situation demanded otherwise. Schiano, the head coach at Rutgers, had just experienced nothing less than one of the most embarrassing losses in the history of the program, an unimaginable 80-7 thrashing doled out by West Virginia, a middle-of-the-pack Big East team.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MADDEN, JOSEPH MICHAEL
description: MADDEN-Joseph Michael, 65. Of Katy, Texas, born in New York City, passed away in a Houston, Texas hospital on Monday, November 5, 2001. Survived by wife, Catherine; children, Catherine Shkolnik, Joseph, Jr., Patrick, Jeanne, John & Robert Madden; eight grandchildren; siblings, Jane, George, Vincent, Peter, Nancy, John, and Kathy. A mass will be celebrated 10 A.M. Saturday at Epiphany of the Lord Catholic Church, Katy, Texas, Rev. Msgr. Jack M. Dinkins, Celebrant. Schmidt Funeral Home, 1508 East Ave., Katy, TX 77493, (281) 391-2424

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHELAN, KENNETH J.
description: PHELAN-Kenneth J. Lieutenant FDNY, Engine 217, Brooklyn, New York, and former firefighter in Ladder 7 & Engine 16 Manhattan. He died bravely in the line of duty on September 11, 2001 at the World Trade Center. Beloved husband of Patty. Loving father of Kimberly, Erin, Danny and Kenny, Jr. Cherished son of Helene and Daniel (Retired FDNY). Dear sonin-law of Bud and Di Horan. Devoted brother of Marian Owens, Jean Diaz, Mary Cox, Lenny (Lt. FDNY) and Fran Krische. Dear grandson of John Phelan & Helen Obremski. Loving godfather, godson, brother-in-law, uncle, nephew, cousin and friend. The family will receive friends at Papavero Funeral Home, 72-27 Grand Ave, Maspeth, Friday 2-5 and 7-9PM. Memorial Mass Sunday, November 11, 2001 at Our Lady of Hope Church, 2:30PM. In lieu of flowers, donations to E-16/L-7 Fallen Firefighter Fund, 234 East 29th Street, NY, NY 10016, would appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERNER, ROSALIND
description: WERNER-Rosalind. On Tuesday, November 6, 2001, Rosalind Werner passed away after a heroic 4-1/2 year battle with pancreatic cancer. She is survived by her loving husband, Jules, sisters Gertrude Entin and Anne Zucker, children Toby Kaulkin, Linda Diaz, Roger Werner, Matthew Schneider and Kenneth Werner, 10 grandchildren and 3 great grandchildren. Rosalind loved her life, her family, her many good friends and the many causes and social events through which she shined. She died surrounded by family at her daughter's home, content with all the wonderful years with which she was blessed. Funeral services on Friday, November 9th, 10 AM at Temple Beth El of Great Neck, Old Mill Road, Great Neck, N.Y. Interment will follow at Beth Moses Cemetery, Farmingdale, L.I.

title: Bush and Blair Trade Praise At White House Love Fest
description: No one ever said they would be soulmates, and they aren't. But today President Bush and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain stood side by side at the White House as unwavering allies joined by war, national self-interest and what their aides say is a growing personal chemistry.

title: Essay; To the Crawford Summit
description: George Bush told Vladimir Putin last month that the 1972 ABM treaty was ''outdated, antiquated and useless.'' Putin countered by telling Barbara Walters, in an interview ABC broadcast last night, that the treaty, which keeps the U.S. and Russia defenseless against nuclear attack, was ''essential, effective and useful.''

title: Eight Centuries of Afghan Conflict
description: The 13TH CENTURY

title: From a Clash of Titans, A Window on a Century
description: WITTGENSTEIN'S POKER

title: Before Child's Death, a History of Abuse and Efforts to Help
description: The confession is brutal in its details and deadly in its ending.

title: A Trivia Expert, Some Music Lovers, Along With Expectant Fathers
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Dynegy Is Said to Be Near to Acquiring Enron for $8 Billion
description: The board of Dynegy Inc. tentatively approved a deal last night to acquire the Enron Corporation, the once-mighty energy-trading company laid low by a financial crisis and government investigation, executives close to the transaction said.

title: Musharraf Urges Bombing Halt for Ramadan
description: The president of Pakistan, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, made another plea today for a stop to the American-led military strikes in Afghanistan during the Muslim holy month of Ramadan as he made his way to Europe and the United States.

title: A Virginia Victory Offers A Lesson for Democrats
description: In becoming the first Democrat to capture the Virginia governor's office in 12 years, Mark R. Warner shook up a Republican establishment that had become complacent.

title: Bloomberg's Support...
description: Results of the 2001 mayoral election, in each of the city's election districts.

title: A Former U.S. Envoy Links Greek Politicians to Assassin Group
description: Tensions between Greece and the United States increased this week after a former American ambassador to Athens asserted that there were links between the country's ruling political elite and the Revolutionary Organization 17 November, a terrorist group held responsible for a series of assassinations of Americans and others in recent years.

title: Trial Beginning For Ex-Chairman In Sotheby's Case
description: Four years after federal prosecutors began peeling back layers of secrecy in the global art market, eventually exposing a huge price-fixing scheme at the world's two dominant auction houses, a final phase begins today in a Manhattan federal courtroom, where one of the most powerful figures in the art world goes on trial on charges of antitrust conspiracy.

title: Northern Army Says It's Near Key Crossroad
description: Forces opposed to the Taliban claimed another victory today on a road to Mazar-i-Sharif, a city regarded as a linchpin in the battle to control northern Afghanistan.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Profit Up At Mining Company
description: BHP Billiton, the world's biggest mining company, said profit rose 3.2 percent in the first quarter of its fiscal year because of higher prices for iron ore and coal in Asia. Net income rose to $608 million, or 10 cents a share, in the quarter ended Sept. 30, from $589 million, or 10 cents a year earlier. The result beat most analysts' expectations for the period, the first full quarter since BHP's $11.6 billion takeover of Billiton. The deputy chief executive, Brian Gilbertson, said a protracted slowdown might hurt future earnings.

title: City's Hispanics Shift, Moving Toward G.O.P.
description: In an election year in which the city's mayoral candidates reached out to Hispanic New Yorkers as never before, voter surveys showed that Hispanic voters have responded in kind.

title: Fears of New Company at Ground Zero
description: Four of the city's largest contractors have labored around the clock downtown, removing rubble from the site of the World Trade Center while dodging falling debris, smoke and fires.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Product Selected By Charter
description: A St. Louis-based cable television company, Charter Communications, said it would use Microsoft software to deliver interactive programming and Internet services to up to a million cable customers the next seven years. The deployment will start next year in St. Louis. Financial terms were not announced. Microsoft has invested billions of dollars in a drive to replicate in digital TV software the success it has achieved with its Windows operating system in personal computers. The software is already in use in Portugal and, under the Ultimate TV name, by customers of DirecTV, a satellite TV company. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: In Waterbury, Mayor-Elect Inherits Crisis
description: While the mayor of this tough but fraying city sits in jail on charges that he raped two girls, his newly elected successor said this morning over tea and eggs that he still regrets that he never attained the rank of Eagle Scout. Frank Capra could not have scripted a better line for his Mr. Smith.

title: Jets Safety Fined by N.F.L. And Warned by Edwards
description: Jets safety Damien Robinson was fined $20,000 by the National Football League today for pulling and twisting Saints quarterback Aaron Brooks's face mask Sunday. But if Robinson does not stop placing himself at the center of bad news, he may have a bigger problem than a depleted bank account.

title: Technology That Aims To Do Good
description: SILICON VALLEY is not generally known for a pervasive sense of charity. Last year Paulina Borsook, a longtime technology journalist, found a large and sympathetic audience with her book ''Cyberselfish: A Critical Romp Through the Terribly Libertarian Culture of High Tech,'' which attacked the technology world for showing ''a lack of human connection and a discomfort with the core of what many of us consider it means to be human.''

title: For Congress, an Abrupt Introduction to the Mobile Office
description: When the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks prompted the evacuation of the Capitol and many other government buildings, members of Congress and their staffs found themselves scattered, dazed and largely cut off from reliable sources of information and from one another.

title: The Chair That Grows Up At the Same Rate as the Child
description: Now appearing in America is an award-winning Norwegian child's seat designed by Peter Opsvik and known in Europe as the Stokke Tripp Trapp Chair or ''the chair after the highchair.'' Here it is called the Stokke KinderZeat and is sold with a strap to meet American highchair standards. With its adjustable seat and footrest, the chair grows with the child. Children can sit up straight in it, even if they do not always sit still. The KinderZeat, of sturdy European beechwood, costs $199; a washable velour cushion in blue, green or salmon is $29. At Planet Kids, 247 East 86th Street, (212) 426-2040; other stores: (877) 978-6553 or www.stokkeusa.com. N. C. MAISAK

title: An Awkward Transition for Trenton: From One-Party to Bipartisan Rule
description: When James E. McGreevey promised to change the way business was done in New Jersey's capital city, he probably didn't have this in mind.

title: Suit Contends Lost Millions Weren't 'Lost'
description: Ten days after the World Trade Center collapsed, as firefighters and rescue workers dug through the rubble looking for victims, three executives of a currency firm with offices in the twin towers plotted in Brooklyn to cover up $105 million that was missing from the firm, according to a lawsuit filed yesterday.

title: Technology Briefing
description: INTERNET

title: A Month in a Difficult Battlefield: Assessing U.S. War Strategy
description: There is a saying at the Pentagon that no plan survives contact with the enemy. With the war in Afghanistan now a month old, the United States military has been forced to adjust its strategy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, JORDAN S., M.D.
description: BROWN-Jordan S., M.D. Husband of Joan. Father of Melissa, Mark, Jim and Jessica. Grandfather of Lily, Laura and Maya. Brother of Ruthel. Uncle of John and Peter and their families. His great passions were his family and medicine. Until two weeks ago he practiced Urology at NYU School of Medicine. We shall all miss him. Memorial services Thursday, 11:30 AM, at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Law Would Ban Election Monitors
description: With an election for president planned for early next year, a proposed law banning international election monitors has provoked an outcry among civic groups. President Robert Mugabe's government says the law is needed to curb foreign interference in the country's politics but critics say it is an effort to continue the political intimidation and violence that have roiled the country for nearly two years. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Skill Leading a Tourney And at the Playing Table
description: The world championships, which ended on Saturday in Paris, were a triumph for the teams that captured the major titles in exciting final matches: the United States over Norway in the Bermuda Bowl, and Germany over France in the Venice Cup for women's teams.

title: The Vote, and the Post-Mortems
description: To the Editor:

title: Justices Try to Determine The Meaning of Disability
description: The Americans With Disabilities Act defines disability as an impairment that ''substantially limits'' someone from engaging in one or more ''major life activities,'' phrases that the courts have struggled to understand and apply since the law took effect 11 years ago.

title: Swedish Unmodern In Country Style
description: We tend to think of Swedish furniture as modern, but there is also the sunny, whitewashed 18th-century Gustavian country style. Now Ethan Allen has created a collection of moderate-price Swedish country pieces: dining chairs are $399 to $499; china cabinets, $1,199 to $1,499; armoires, $2,999; and bed frames, $799 to $1,599. The furniture, made of maple and other hardwoods, has classic rosettes and fluted or reeded legs. In antique white or a bisque wash, it is an alternative to French country furniture. At Ethan Allen, or www.ethanallen.com or (800) 228-9229. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR FALLS. The dollar dropped as investors worried that the Federal Reserve's 10 interest-rate cuts this year will not prevent a recession. In New York, the dollar settled at 120.90 yen, down from 121.06 yen on Tuesday.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Dissidents To Be Tried
description: Twenty dissidents accused by hard-liners of trying to overthrow the Islamic government are to go on trial on Sunday. The men are affiliated with a movement that separated from the religious establishment after the takeover of the American Embassy by militant students in 1979 and that supported President Mohammad Khatami's reform efforts. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: Kidd Similar in Style to Payton, but Quieter
description: Jason Kidd has not just been watching Gary Payton since growing up in his shadow in Oakland, Calif. Kidd has also been listening to Payton, first on the playground, now on the professional courts where Payton's highlight-film game comes with his own nonstop soundtrack.

title: Spending War With White House Focuses on Countering Terrorism
description: Democrats in Congress headed today toward a major confrontation with President Bush over tax and spending policy, vowing to defy his threat to veto legislation that provides additional money to counter terrorism in the United States.

title: Bloomberg Turns Down Tax Break For Business
description: In one of his first acts as mayor-elect, Michael R. Bloomberg refused tax breaks from the city that his company worked hard to gain, according to campaign and company officials.

title: Taiwan Lifts Restrictions on Investment in China
description: Yielding to the reality of life next door to the world's fastest rising political and economic power, Taiwan today lifted longtime restrictions on direct investment in China.

title: A Sometime Punter Wins a Job As Giants Hold an Amateur Day
description: Football coaches rarely dwell on particulars when it comes to kickers. Last Sunday, when Giants punter Rodney Williams shattered his right wrist, Coach Jim Fassel was asked what he planned to do about the team's punting.

title: Nuremberg Journal; The Architect Who Speared His Own Nazi Demon
description: Gnther Domenig has designed a museum here to pierce the pompous building Hitler ordered up for his mass rallies of the Nazi faithful. In a sense, Mr. Domenig's museum is also a biopsy of his own corroded heart.

title: The Knicks Are Advised To Cut It Out
description: Magic Johnson, sitting at midcourt in Madison Square Garden last night before the Knicks-Cavaliers game, took the occasion to express a dim view of the Knick players' bickering.

title: Holiday Air Travel Is Expected to Be Off Sharply
description: Air travel this holiday season is expected to be off sharply, deepening the gloom for airlines that have been desperately cutting fares to try to put more people into airplane seats during what is traditionally the busiest travel period of the year.

title: 2 Companies Choose Agencies for Accounts
description: Two advertisers are making decisions on accounts.

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIA

title: ONLINE DIARY
description: Middling Earth

title: Baseball Is Now Waiting for the Sale of Two Teams
description: As intriguing as Major League Baseball's decision to eliminate two teams is, so are the ongoing negotiations for the sale of two other teams, one of them to an owner whose team is No. 1 on the contraction list.

title: The Vote, and the Post-Mortems
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDLANDER, EDITH
description: FRIEDLANDER-Edith. Of New York City on November 7, 2001 at age 94. Edith was born in NYC on March 15, 1907. Wife of the late Irving Friedlander who died in 1974. Edith was a legal secretary in NYC and is the mother of Martin of Los Angeles, who practices law in New York and L.A. and Carolyn Levy of New Rochelle, NY. Edith is the sister of Mary Goldman and Elsie Hertzberg, both of Scarsdale. Dearest grandmother to Jonathan (wife Dana) Levy, Scott Levy, Andrew Levy & great-grandmother to Jordan Levy & Samantha Levy. Service on Friday at 11 A.M. at Zion Memorial Chapel, 785 East Boston Post Road, Mamaroneck. For directions please see www.zionmemorialchapel.com, 1800-381-1809. Interment follows at Mount Ararat Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WHITE, WILLIAM E.
description: WHITE-William E. November 5, 1956 to November 8, 1995. Bill's zest for life sustains me in the difficult times and our 18 years together were the best years of this life. Larry Lingl

title: How to Mate Your Laptop With a Wireless Network
description: Q. What do I need to make my laptop connect to a wireless network?

title: National Briefing | Science and Health: Release Of Stem Cell List
description: The National Institutes of Health posted its list of human embryonic stem cell lines approved for use by government-supported researchers. The registry embodies the compromise struck by President Bush on Aug. 9 when he ordered that research on the cells could proceed, but only with cell lines established before that date. The registry lists 72 cultures of embryonic stem cells prepared by universities and companies. Many of the cultures are not ready for distribution. But enough are available, an institutes official said, for research to begin. Nicholas Wade (NYT)

title: Networks Pause, Then Some Show bin Laden Tape of Children
description: On a day that the Pakistani government cracked down on the daily anti-American news conferences given by the Taliban's ambassador in Islamabad, Osama bin Laden appeared to find a new avenue of propaganda: children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYBLUM, RAE
description: MAYBLUM-Rae. Loving wife of Samuel. Devoted mother of Burton and Marilyn. Cherished grandmother of Jaymie and Scott. Doting great-grandmother of Gabrielle and Joshua. Graveside service today, 1PM, at Mount Zion Cemetery, Maspeth, Queens.

title: In a Tight Blue Costume, A Bird, a Plane or a Guy?
description: Who says all sitcoms look alike? One that makes its debut tonight on Fox has, for starters, a hero who's blue. And that doesn't mean melancholy.

title: Pakistanis Urge U.S. to Suspend Textile Tariffs
description: A two-thirds decline in business from United States companies is forcing apparel and textile concerns in Pakistan to lay off thousands of people and could soon close numerous factories, according to a report released yesterday by a Pakistani trade group. The Pakistani government had previously estimated the decline in orders at closer to 40 percent.

title: Accounts
description: * Miller Brewing Company, Milwaukee, part of the Philip Morris Companies, to LatinWorks, Austin, Tex., to create campaigns for Miller Lite beer aimed at Spanish-speaking consumers, a project that had been handled by Uno Communicaciones, Dallas. Billings were estimated at $20 million to $25 million. LatinWorks will become a member of the Syndicate, a consortium of smaller creative agencies that works with Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, New York, part of the WPP Group; Ogilvy creates the general-market campaigns for Miller Lite.

title: Record Spending by Bloomberg Raises Questions About City's Acclaimed Law
description: Michael R. Bloomberg spent at least $50 million of his own fortune running to become the mayor of New York, setting a record that raises new questions about how well the city's nationally recognized campaign finance law can limit the influence of money in politics when one candidate chooses to ignore it.

title: 3 Smaller Companies Say Their Vaccines Are Cheaper
description: Three small vaccine manufacturers that lost out in the first round of bidding for a government contract for smallpox vaccines complained today that they could supply the vaccines for a price that large drug makers still in the running say they cannot meet.

title: In Desperate Times, Talking of Torture
description: To the Editor:

title: We Put a Man on the Moon, But Try Finding Orion's Belt
description: The aurora borealis made an unusual appearance this week, lighting the sky as far south as Texas. While a new device called the Star Navigator can't explain that, it can help sort out some other celestial mysteries.

title: Novartis Plans Drug Discount For Elderly
description: Novartis A.G. of Switzerland said yesterday that it would offer cards to low-income elderly Americans to provide discounts of 25 percent or more on the company's brand-name drugs.

title: Former French Finance Minister Is Acquitted in Forgery Trial
description: France's new breed of hard-driving, corruption-busting investigating magistrates suffered an embarrassing setback today when a court acquitted a former finance minister, Dominique Strauss-Kahn, in his forgery trial.

title: The Vote, and the Post-Mortems
description: To the Editor:

title: Searching for the Intersection of a Woman and a Germ
description: Investigators pursuing clues to the anthrax death of Kathy T. Nguyen have begun using posters with her picture and tips discreetly gleaned from friends and acquaintances who attended her funeral on Tuesday to determine where and how she might have been exposed to the germ.

title: Editorial Observer; The Private Life of Kathy Nguyen
description: The authorities want three weeks of Kathy Nguyen's life. What they want from those three weeks is everything, every step, every breath, every contact with the material world, no matter how slight. It would be trouble enough for anyone to rebuild three weeks in that kind of detail, to remember, for instance, the almost unnoticeable variations in a workday commute so familiar that it feels entirely automatic. But in Kathy Nguyen's case, there is no one to help with the reconstruction, no one to look back over the narrative of her life. She died on Oct. 31 of inhalation anthrax at the age of 61. By the time the superintendent of her apartment building brought her to Lenox Hill Hospital, she was too sick to do anything but perish.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAFUOCO, ANNA
description: CAFUOCO-Anna. Wife of Antonio, adored mother of Lina and Rosemarie, cherished grandma to Caroline, Anna, Amelia, and Isabelle, beloved sister and aunt. You fought a courageous battle. Our hearts are broken. Not a day will pass where we won't think of you. Family will receive friends Thursday and Friday 2-4 and 7-9 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Mass of Christian Burial, Saturday 9:45 AM, Holy Trinity R.C. Church. Interment St. Theresa Cemetery.

title: Johnnie Cochran to Head Business Zone
description: Johnnie L. Cochran Jr., the lawyer who gained national prominence by successfully defending O. J. Simpson against murder charges, has been named chairman of the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone, the economic development organization that has been administering $250 million in federal, state and city funds in Harlem, Washington Heights and Inwood.

title: German Cabinet Supports New Immigration Laws
description: Germany's cabinet today adopted plans for important changes in security and immigration laws in response to the Sept. 11 attacks, which were carried out in part by immigrants who had been living in Germany.

title: Italian Arab Is Perplexed By Swiss Raid
description: As he left his office here the night before the Swiss and Italian police raided it, Youssef M. Nada, 71, shook his head, saying: ''To come to the end of my life, a good life, and be accused of helping terrorists -- it is too much.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCRACKEN, JOHN EDWARD
description: McCRACKEN-John Edward. July 28, 1914-November 3, 2001. Beloved husband of Jeanne M.S. McCracken. Devoted father of David J.B. McCracken. Princeton University '36, Yale Law School '39, The Union Club. Memorial service Fifth Ave. Presbyterian Church, 7 West 55 St. Thursday, November 15, 2001 at 11AM. Contributions in his memory may be made to his Church or Princeton UniversityClass of '36 Endowment Fund.

title: Yankees Fire Batting Coach
description: Gary Denbo became the first casualty of the Yankees' failure to win a fourth consecutive World Series title yesterday when the team said that he would not be retained as the batting coach. Denbo, who lasted only one season, was in a precarious position before the postseason started. Once the Yankees batted .183 against Arizona, it became obvious that they would replace the 40-year-old coach who has been with the organization for 12 years.

title: Stock Fraud Settlement Opens Path For Hartford to Regain Pension Loss
description: A Texas-based waste management company has agreed to settle a securities fraud case for $457 million, opening a path for the Connecticut pension fund and other investors to recoup millions in losses, state officials announced today.

title: Central Banks in Europe and Britain Cut Rates as Economy Fears Grow
description: FRANKFURT, Nov. 8  With Europe slipping closer to a recession, both the European Central Bank and the Bank of England reduced their benchmark interest rates by half a percentage point today, following the Federal Reserve by 48 hours.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, PHYLLIS M.
description: SIEGEL-Phyllis M. On November 5, 2001, at Lenox Hill Hospital, in her 86th year following a long illness. Beloved wife of the late Sigmund A. Siegel, M.D. Cherished daughter of the late David and Helen Moskowitz. Devoted mother of Mark and Stephen. Caring mother-in-law of Susan Bandes. Loving grandmother of David, Jonathan, Jessica, Daniel and Andrew. Phyllis was a graduate of Vassar College and Columbia Teachers College. For more than 50 years she devoted herself to the Jewish community. She served the Women's Division of the Greater New York United Jewish Appeal as chairman and executive director and as a longtime member of the Campaign Cabinet. She served the Park Avenue Synagogue as trustee, vice president, member of the school board, and president of the Sisterhood. Phyllis was among the first women called to the Torah at Park Avenue Synagogue. We will miss and love her forever. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the UJA-Federation of New York, 130 E. 59 St., New York, NY 10022. Services Thursday, November 8, 11 AM, at Park Avenue Synagogue, 50 East 87th Street.

title: Pirro's Victory Is Rated, for Future Reference
description: Jeanine F. Pirro, the Westchester County district attorney, emerged from Tuesday's election as either a consummate politician who overcame her husband's legal and financial troubles, or a fading Republican star who was barely able to keep her office.

title: The Neediest Cases; Fearful in Sierra Leone, and Grateful in East Harlem
description: She is the cashier in Aisle 1 who earns $7.61 an hour.

title: Bush to Open a U.N. Meeting Expected to Focus on Terrorism
description: The United Nations will take its place in the global spotlight this weekend when President Bush leads off an intense round of speeches and diplomacy, most of it now focused on the war on terrorism and what to do with Afghanistan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCONNELL, NORMAN
description: McCONNELL-Norman. On November 4, 2001. Reposing at the Gannon Funeral Home, 152 E. 28 St, NYC on Friday 3-8PM. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday 10AM Our Lady of the Scapular-St. Stephen's Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: York Is Put in Position To Flourish for Rangers
description: The atmosphere inside Nassau Coliseum on Thursday night figures to be supercharged. That is, of course, the norm when the Rangers meet the Islanders.

title: Text of President Bush's Speech
description: Following is a transcript of President Bush's speech in Atlanta on Thursday night, as recorded by The New York Times :

title: Safety Becomes Prime Concern at Ground Zero
description: Ground zero at the World Trade Center is a landscape like no other. It is jagged and angular on the surface, with shards of steel piled upon steel. It is caustic beneath from the smoke of subterranean fires. And it is emotional always and everywhere, from the reminders of the lives that were lost.

title: The Vote, and the Post-Mortems
description: To the Editor:

title: Meet the Anna Sofa, Which Gives Flexible Seating New Meaning
description: When the Swedish consul general's mansion in New York needed refurbishing, Inger Claesson Wastberg, the consul's wife, called on a group of women who are design students and teachers in Sweden to present ideas for the residence's living room. One result was the Anna sofa, like a one-armed chaise longue, which can be easily moved to create seating areas or placed end to end to form a couch (far left). Designed by Anna Kraitz, 28, a design teacher in Stockholm (left), they fit any scale room. The sofas come in green, black or white wool upholstery; a 45-inch sofa is $1,550, and a 64-inch model is $1,600. They can be ordered from the maker, Kallemo in Stockholm, at (011) 46-8665-1989; for more information: www.kallemo.se. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: After Terrorist Attacks, Army Rethinks Priorities On Fighting and Spending
