description: During a long, hot summer of Pentagon budget battles, whispers in the corridors said 2 of the Army's 10 active divisions were headed to the chopping block to free money for the military's future weapons.

title: TECHNOLOGY: Market Place; A growing group of disgruntled relatives may seal the fate of Hewlett-Packard and Compaq.
description: WITH David W. Packard joining the opposition to the proposed merger of Hewlett-Packard with Compaq Computer, executives and directors of both companies were scrambling yesterday to rescue the deal.

title: Mets Plan to Ignore Rocker
description: One of the areas the Mets must address this winter is left-handed relief pitching. But while many of their plans hinge on larger industry issues, the Mets have already decided against pursuing one available left-hander: John Rocker.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERBST, DANIEL
description: HERBST-Daniel. Of Yorktown Heights, New York, died on November 6, 2001 at Mt. Sinai Hospital in New York City. He was 48. He is survived by his wife Sandra, son Colin, son Larry Antinozzi of Yorktown; father Joseph, stepmother Lois Herbst; sister Diana of Seattle, WA. Calling hours are Thursday, November 8, 7-9PM at Clark Funeral Home in Yorktown Heights. The funeral is Friday, November 9, at 12PM, also at Clark Funeral Home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUGANO, SEAN T.
description: LUGANO-Sean T. Age 28, of Manhattan. Lost in the tragedy of the World Trade Center where he was a trader for Keefe Bruyette and Woods. Loving son of Eileen (nee Duffell) and the late John A. Lugano. Best brother of John, Stephanie, Kristen and Michael. Devoted grandson of Anne M. Duffell and Francis Lugano Haller. Cherished nephew, cousin and friend. Graduate of Xavier High School, '91, Loyola College, Maryland, '95. Outstanding athlete and avid rugby player who played on many national, collegiate and men's teams. Rugby coach for Fairfield University and a leading force on the NYAC rugby team. An entrepreneur, Sean was a partner in Rathbones and Opal, Manhattan east side establishments. A memorial service will be held Friday, November 9, 6 PM, at St. Francis Xavier R.C. Church, 30 W. 16th St, NYC. Donations can be made to the Sean Lugano Scholarship Fund at Xavier High School.

title: Bush Plan Would Revise Bill to Aid Charities
description: President Bush asked the Senate leadership today to pass a slimmed-down version of his plan to give federal money to religious charities, saying all charities were hard-pressed to provide disaster relief for the victims of the Sept. 11 attacks while helping the needy.

title: Transcript of Scott Imler's Visit to the Drug Policy Forum
description: On Wednesday, Nov. 7, the NYTimes.com's Drug Policy forum Scott Imler , Director, Los Angeles Cannabis Resource CoOperative . This discussion was part of the speaker series organized by forum participants. Scott Imler Ground Zero: West Hollywood

title: A Reading List for a Troubled Land
description: Afghanistan, for centuries a country of brutal wars between local tribes and foreign armies, has inspired a substantial literature, fiction and nonfiction, military history and semicomic fantasy.

title: Making the Airport and the Plane Secure
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Software: THQ Buys Rainbow Studios In Stock Deal
description: The videogame maker THQ Inc. said it had acquired Rainbow Studios in a bid to bolster its internal development skills. THQ, based in Calabasas, Calif., will exchange about $58 million of its shares for Rainbow, which is based in Phoenix and is considered the largest animation and game studio in the Southwest. THQ publishes many of the game industry's most successful titles, both for personal computers and game consoles like Playstation 2, Nintendo's GameCube and the new Xbox from Microsoft. Its titles include Rugrats, WWF Smack Down and a new game, Jimmy Neutron: Boy Genius. Rainbow publishes ATV Offroad Fury and the popular Tiger Woods PGA Tour 2000. THQ shares slipped $1.35, to $57.45. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Making the Airport and the Plane Secure
description: To the Editor:

title: For Knicks, Even Victory Over Cavs Feels Good
description: It did not matter last night that the Cleveland Cavaliers might be the worst team in the National Basketball Association, that they lose by an average of more than 13 points a game. The Knicks, reeling from three straight defeats, needed a victory, and one over any N.B.A. team would do.

title: School Board Keeping Broadcast Stations
description: Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy has withdrawn a plan to turn over the management of the Board of Education's radio and television stations to New York City's public television and radio stations.

title: Focusing on Small Victories After Day of Larger Defeats
description: As New Jersey Republicans surveyed the wreckage of their worst electoral defeat in more than a decade, party leaders had to search far and wide today to find a bright side.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, MILDRED RUBENSTEIN
description: NEWMAN-Mildred Rubenstein, psychologist-psychoanalyst. Born April 8, 1920 in New York City's Upper East Side, grew up on East 97th St. walking distance from where she died of pulmonary embolism on East 68th St., November 6, 2001. Survived by her husband, co-author and colleague, Dr. Bernard Berkowitz; daughter Sandy Newman, a researcher, Labor Market Information, state of Ohio; son Dr. Neal Newman, Ohio State University, Student Health Services and stepson Bob Berkowitz, former TV host of ''Real Personal'', now private consulting practice, and five grandchildren. Funeral services Sunday, November 11th, 11:30AM, Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made to Equality Now or charity of donor's choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAIER, MARY RICHMOND
description: MAIER-Mary Richmond. Wife of the late John Maier, M.D., died on November 7th in Ithaca, NY, age 85. She is survived by two sons, Hugh P. of Portland, OR., and John R. of West Hartford, CT, one daughter, Jan of Manhattan, and three granddaughters. Contributions in her memory may be made to Cornell Medical College, C/O Director of Operations, Office of Development, Cornell Medical College, 1300 York Avenue, Box 123, New York, NY 10021.

title: Hospital Worker's Infection Poses Troubling Possibilities
description: Investigators assigned to the case of Kathy T. Nguyen, the Manhattan hospital worker who died of inhalation anthrax last week, are confronting some disquieting possibilities as to how she might have become infected.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about disputes in the Senate over economic legislation referred incorrectly in some copies to the home state of the majority leader, Tom Daschle. It is South Dakota, not Iowa.

title: Ready for Battle, Wielding a Stylus
description: IMAGINE this: Lieutenant Smith, a United States Army platoon leader at a base camp in Uzbekistan, is preparing for a three-day mission in Afghanistan. For four hours, he and his fellow officers have been going over maps and hundreds of details that must be nailed down. They retrieve the information they need from a new addition to their battle packs: hand-held computers.

title: Transcript of Eric Sterling's Visit to the Drug Policy Forum
description: On Thursday, Nov. 1, the NYTimes.com's Drug Policy forum hosted Eric Sterling, a medical marijuana activist. This discussion was part of the speaker series organized by forum participants.

title: Girl, 4, Dies in a Brooklyn Apartment Fire
description: A 4-year-old Brooklyn girl was killed yesterday in a fire that broke out at a six-story apartment building in Flatbush.

title: Excerpts From Postal Worker's 911 Call
description: Following are excerpts from a 911 call on Oct. 21 by Thomas Morris Jr., a postal worker who died hours after the call, as recorded by The New York Times from CNN:

title: LOCKHEED TO CUT 360 JOBS FROM ITS SPACE SYSTEMS UNIT
description: The nation's largest military contractor, the Lockheed Martin Corporation, said yesterday that it would eliminate about 360 jobs at its Space Systems business, which was supposed to build four satellites and provide services for the company's unsuccessful Internet telecommunications venture. The job cuts, which represent about 1.4 percent of the unit's work force, will reduce expenses about $30 million a year, Lockheed said. The job reduction will affect employees in Denver and Sunnyvale, Calif. Lockheed has said it expects to write down the value of its $400 million investment in the Internet satellite communications venture, Astrolink International, a sign that the $3.7 billion project may fold.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNIFFIN, JEAN NOLAN
description: KNIFFIN-Jean Nolan. Died on Monday, November 5, 2001 at her home in Nissequogue, New York. She was 90 years old. After graduating from Rosemary Hall, she entered the Foreign Service and for 23 years she worked in various United States Embassies-Tokyo, Costa Rica, Mexico City and Paris. In 1959, at the United States Embassy in Paris, she married Edgar Aldrich Kniffin, the former president of Peerless Photo Products, Inc. Mr. Kniffin was a former commanding officer of Squadron A, New York National Guard and a past president of its Association of Ex-Members. Mrs. Kniffin is survived by a son, Timothy B. Kniffin, nine grandchildren and five great grandchildren. There will be a memorial service held for Mrs. Kniffin on Saturday, December 1, 2001 at 1:00PM at the St. James Episcopal Church, 490 North Country Road, St. James, Long Island, NY.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: MAKER OF AIRCRAFT MATERIALS TO CUT 25% OF WORK FORCE
description: The Hexcel Corporation, a maker of aircraft materials, said yesterday that it would cut 1,500 jobs, or 25 percent of its work force, by the end of 2002 as demand for commercial aircraft wanes. The company expects to have fewer than 4,500 employees worldwide at the end of next year, down from about 6,000 today, its chairman and chief executive, David Berges, said. The company, based in Stamford, Conn., expects sales to fall in 2002 because of reduced production of commercial aircraft in 2002 and 2003 and a slump in the electronics market, a company spokesman said. The company's fourth-quarter earnings will be hurt by costs of $35 million to $40 million related to the restructuring, the company said.

title: AES ENDS ITS HOSTILE TAKEOVER ATTEMPT IN VENEZUELA
description: The AES Corporation withdrew its bid for control of one of Venezuela's largest telecommunications companies yesterday. AES, a power company with businesses in 30 countries, terminated its $1.4 billion tender offer for C.A. Nacional Telfonos de Venezuela, or CANTV, after the Venezuelan company's shareholders approved a share buyback and dividend last month. AES owns a minority stake in CANTV. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Top Pentagon Officials Urge Patience in Afghan Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8  The Pentagon said today that fierce fighting is going on near the crucial crossroads town of Mazar-i-Sharif in northern Afghanistan. But officials warned Americans not to count on a quick victory, either at the town or in the wider struggle against terrorism.

title: Justices to Decide on Drug Tests for Public School Groups Beyond Athletes
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8  The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether public schools may require students to pass drug tests as a condition of participating in extracurricular activities.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Plymouth: 2 Dead After Standoff
description: A man and the toddler he apparently took hostage were dead after a standoff with the police yesterday, state authorities said. Troopers shot the man, whose name was not released but who had a criminal record, after he refused to drop a sword and advanced toward the officers, the police said. The 23-month-old girl, whose name was also not released, was found dead inside a house here. She suffered extensive neck wounds and died before the police entered the home, they said. The Associated Press reported that the man was the girl's uncle, but the police did not confirm the relationship. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: More Firefighters Added to Crew To Calm Dispute at Trade Center
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday doubled the number of firefighters -- to 50 -- assigned to dig for their colleagues' remains in the World Trade Center rubble, in an apparent effort to calm a rancorous dispute that has pitted firefighters against the police and the city.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Metromedia Fiber Reports A Loss
description: Metromedia Fiber Network, a provider of high-speed Internet infrastructure, said yesterday that losses in the third quarter ballooned to $242.1 million, or 39 cents a share, compared with a shortfall of $95.3 million, or 17 cents, in the comparable period a year earlier. Metromedia, which is based in White Plains, N.Y., attributed the loss to costs stemming from network expansion and expenses related to its acquisition of SiteSmith, a company that provides advice on the design of fast Internet systems. Metromedia avoided filing for bankruptcy last month after securing $611 million in financing and overhauling its management. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NIGHTINGALE, BERTHA
description: NIGHTINGALE-Bertha. November 8, 2000. 11:45AM-11:54AM. Remembering the nine minutes it took for ''allegations'' made by the Visiting Nurse Service of New York to change our family forever. Safe from indignity, injustice and abuse. Heaven has no home health care. Ever remembered.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRINCIOTTA, VINCENT A.
description: PRINCIOTTA-Vincent A. Age 39, heroically responded to the call of duty at the World Trade Center on September 11, 2001. Beloved husband of Karen and loving father of Christina, 16 months. Devoted son of Anita and the late Vincent, loving brother of Michele and Bernadette. He will be greatly missed by his aunts, uncles, nieces, nephews, cousins, in-laws & friends. Vinny was with Ladder Company 7 on East 29th Street in New York City for 16 years. He was known to all his brothers in the firehouse as a ''Happy Go Lucky Guy''. It was a job he loved with all his heart. He was a man who enjoyed life to the fullest. He was an avid fisherman and enjoyed many outdoor sports including surfing, skiing and snowboarding. We will miss his sense of humor and adventurous spirit. He touched the lives and hearts of all who knew him. Memorial Mass will be held Saturday, November 10, 2001 at 11:00 AM at St. Catherine's Church, Blauvelt, New York. In lieu of flowers, a Trust Fund has been established for Vincent's daughter, Christina. Contributions can be made payable to the Christina M. Princiotta Trust and mailed to: UBS Paine Webber, Attention Carmela Montella, 1251 Sixth Avenue, 2nd floor, New York, New York 10020.

title: Nonprofit groups are trimming their sails to match the winds of public sentiment.
description: CAMPAIGNS from People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals have been notable for their shock value, featuring, for instance, pictures of dismembered chickens and cows. (''Do you want fries with that?'' asks one of their more gruesome efforts.) But that has changed in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks as PETA and other nonprofit groups have adjusted their strategies.

title: Field Trip to the City
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Struggling to Adjust to Fighting Both Crime and Terrorism
description: Not far from the sad, punched-out gap in the Lower Manhattan skyline, there is a new, permanent fixture outside 1 Police Plaza: the police.

title: In Bush's Words: Attack on '2 Terrorist-Supporting Financial Networks'
description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's announcement today of a crackdown on international financial organizations, as transcribed by the Federal News Service Inc.:

title: RESULTS -- The Races for New Jersey
description: Results as of 3:42 p.m.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: The Voice Is Bond. James Bond.

title: Gunman Is Killed at Base In Qatar Used by the U.S.
description: A gunman was shot and killed today after he opened fire at American and Qatari troops guarding an air base in the Persian Gulf nation of Qatar that was being used by American military aircraft. The attack added to concerns in a region made uneasy by the war in Afghanistan.

title: Cave Redoubts Are Formidable, Rebel Leader Says
description: Talking about the tunnels and caves that line the walls of the Panjshir Valley, Gen. Abdul Hafiz of the Northern Alliance sounds like a proud father. ''They are resistant to bomb attack,'' he said today. ''No bomb or missile can destroy these caves.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHREIER, LEONARD J.
description: SCHREIER-Leonard J. The Partners and Staff of Sterling Equities, with deep sorrow and sadness, mourn the death of our partner and friend Lenny Schreier. He will be remembered for his wisdom, generosity of spirit and his devotion to humanity. We will miss him very much, yet he will always be with us. Our sympathies are with his children Deyva and Michael, grandson Julian and brothers Arthur and Herb. Friends may join in remembering Lenny at a Memorial Service on Sunday, November 11, 2001, 11 AM at the Harlem Yacht Club, City Island, Bronx, NY.

title: AMERICAN MEN TO FACE TRINIDAD AND TOBAGO
description: With the United States' spot in next summer's World Cup secured, Sunday's final qualifying game in Trinidad and Tobago is a good time for Coach Bruce Arena to test players with the potential of making the roster for the final stages.

title: Seeking Ancient Life? Ask the Robot Where to Trowel
description: THE ancient settlement of Amheida lies deep beneath windblown layers of sand in the Western Desert of Egypt. Dr. Lynn Meskell, an archaeologist at Columbia University, is keenly interested in the buried remains, but she doesn't plan on relying solely on trowels to reveal them.

title: DOMINION RESOURCES TO CUT 24% OF SENIOR MANAGERS
description: Dominion Resources, a utility company, said yesterday that it would reduce its 79-person senior management team by 19 officers by the end of the year to cut costs. The group of senior officers was formed last year when Dominion completed its $8.5 billion acquisition of the Consolidated Natural Gas Company. The chief executives of the company's business operating units will keep their jobs. The executives who will leave are from offices in Virginia, West Virginia, Pennsylvania and Ohio, a spokesman, Mark Lazenby, said. The company, based in Richmond, Va., said it still expected to earn at least $4.15 a share this year, $4.90 to $4.95 a share next year, and achieve 10 percent annual growth in per-share earnings after 2002. Shares of Dominion fell $1.17, to $60.70.

title: The Caprice of Coffee
description: For generations, coffee paid for everything here: the paving of roads, the electrification of remote hamlets, the building of schools. Growers, flush with cash from producing beans that were widely considered the best in the world, built elegant haciendas and sent their children to top universities.

title: Surging Islanders Find Little Things Do Add Up
description: Peter Laviolette, the Islanders' new coach, has a wife and two kids, and he dresses so immaculately for games and sweats so little that he looks as if he could go out for a power lunch afterward. That is his suburban dad side. His other side is much more visceral. Ben Hur lurks within him.

title: No Strings, No Loyalists
description: The New York City electorate has realigned itself once again. This time Latinos held the winning hand, and they played it for Michael Bloomberg. In an extraordinary swing that has implications for the future, nearly half the Latino voters pulled the lever for the winner in the mayor's race. This bloc was not necessarily pro-Bloomberg, but it expressed anger about Mark Green's failure to make sufficient amends with Latinos after his attacks on Fernando Ferrer in the Democratic primary runoff.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BYRNE, ELEANOR (NEE CASEY)
description: O'BYRNE-Eleanor (nee Casey). On November 5, 2001. Beloved wife of Frank M. (retired Lt NYPD). Loving mother of Brian, Barbara Gogan, Michael and Ellen Mauser. Adored grandmother of Patrick and Casey Gogan, Erin & Michael O'Byrne and Christian Mauser. Fond mother-in-law of Patrick Gogan, Donna O'Byrne and John Mauser. Reposing at Romano Family Funeral Home, 24 Depot Square, Tuckahoe, NY. Mass of Christian Burial Friday 9:45AM, St. Barnabas R.C. Church. Interment in Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Visiting Wednesday and Thursday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

title: E. H. Gombrich, Author and Theorist Who Redefined the History of Art, Is Dead at 92
description: Ernst Gombrich, an author of panoramic erudition and probably the world's best-known art historian thanks to his best-selling ''Story of Art,'' died on Saturday in London, where he had lived since moving from his native Vienna in 1936.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: OWNER OF GRAND OLE OPRY TO SELL CHRISTIAN MUSIC LABEL
description: The Gaylord Entertainment Company, the owner of Nashville's Grand Ole Opry, said yesterday that it was looking to sell its Word Entertainment unit, a Christian music label. Gaylord also reported that its loss widened to $45.2 million, or $1.35 a share, in the third quarter, from $19.1 million, or 57 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue fell 9.5 percent, to $75.1 million from $83 million. Gaylord also said it would sell GET Management, its artist-management business.

title: U.S. MOVES TO CUT 2 FINANCIAL LINKS FOR TERROR GROUP
description: President Bush announced an international effort today to destroy two financial networks that American officials said had long been suspected of having ties to the Qaeda terrorist organization.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOX, DAVID JOSEPH
description: FOX-David Joseph, 74. Of Haworth, N.J. Devoted husband of the late Louise. Died yesterday at Englewood Hospital. He is survived by his brother, Allen Fox, his four adoring daughters, Amy, Michal, Heather and Erica, and the grandchildren he loved, Zachariah, Jonah and Sarah. Dr. Fox was a Professor of Educational Psychology at the City College of New York serving students and the community in Harlem for 40 years. Services will be held at Gutterman-Musicant, 402 Park St., Hackensack, N.J. on Thursday, November 8 at 1 PM and will be officiated by Rabbi Daniel Cohen of Young Israel Synagogue in West Hartford. Visitors will be welcomed at the family house on Thursday, Saturday and Sunday evenings from 6 to 8 PM. Contributions can be made to Englewood Hospital Foundation and should be earmarked for the Intensive Care Unit Family Support Room. Mail to: Englewood Hospital, 350 Engle Street, Englewood, N.J. 07631.

title: Mayor Vows Immediate Aid
description: Amid growing concern over how more than $1.2 billion in Sept. 11 charity is being spent, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday that the city's own Twin Towers Fund would immediately begin to distribute about $40 million to the families of the uniformed service personnel who died responding to the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11.

title: Join the War Effort
description: To the Editor:

title: Envoy Is Told Not to Assail U.S. Bombing
description: Under pressure from the United States, Pakistan has told the Taliban ambassador here to stop using news conferences at the Afghan embassy to attack the United States for its bombing of Afghanistan, Pakistani officials said today.

title: Finding a True Humanity Along With the Doodles
description: Garth Fagan Dance offered an evening of pleasurable listening, dynamic performing and provocative choreography on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater. But the two recent pieces on the program may not have provoked quite the line of thought that Mr. Fagan intended.

title: Supreme Court Search
description: Browsing

title: 1,400 Layoffs Are Planned At Waterford Wedgwood
description: Waterford Wedgwood, the Irish luxury goods conglomerate, will cut 1,400 of its 10,000 jobs worldwide in response to slumping sales, which started falling from record highs in July and are now down 4.5 percent from last year.

title: Miami Beach Buyers Chill Out
description: AT the north end of Ocean Drive, the Art Deco axis of South Florida's night life, the Breez restaurant sits empty. It's a bar without drinkers, a restaurant without diners. It laid off its star chef five weeks ago. ''We do a lot of cleaning,'' said Gabriel Fernandez, the 25-year-old bartender, wiping the sinuous aluminum bar.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: She Just Can't Win
description: Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi reprimanded his blunt-speaking foreign minister, Makiko Tanaka, saying, ''I told her to think well before she speaks.'' Ms. Tanaka, who was refused permission from Parliament to travel to New York to take part in the United Nations General Assembly, had her hopes dashed again after leaders of the governing Liberal Democratic Party turned down her latest appeal. Annoyed that Ms. Tanaka had told the leaders that he had encouraged her to go to them, Mr. Koizumi complained, ''One shouldn't blab about what people said.'' James Brooke (NYT)

title: Unit of Enron Is Challenged
description: A consortium of Indian lenders to the Enron Corporation's power company in India asked the Bombay High Court today to prevent the unit, the Dabhol Power Company, from pulling out of a distressed energy project.

title: Election Of Mayor Will Affect Speaker Vote
description: Within hours after the results of the mayoral election became clear yesterday, several members of the City Council and others elected to join their ranks were on the phones, conferring with one another and assessing the next election that is likely to consume their attention.

title: 'We Regret We Are Unable To Open Unsolicited Mail'
description: Unpublished authors are used to rejection, but these days they can blame anthrax. Anthrax has not only cost lives and caused panic, but also emerged as one more excuse for all but a handful of publishing houses not to read unsolicited manuscripts.

title: U.S. Explores Indicting a Possible Member of the Hijackers' Squad
description: Federal prosecutors are weighing whether to seek a conspiracy indictment against a man in custody in New York who the authorities suspect was the 20th suicide hijacker in the Sept. 11 terror attacks, senior law enforcement officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOWBA, ALBERT
description: TOWBA-Albert. On November 6, 2001. Devoted husband of Evelyn. Loving father of Eugene Towba and Janet Winter. Dear brother of Cecile Fried. Adored grandfather of Jordan, Jesse, Catherine and Natalie. Services 1 PM, today, Nieberg Midwood Chapel, 1625 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, corner of Avenue M.

title: J.F.K. Terminal Evacuated
description: The Federal Aviation Administration ordered Terminal 6 at Kennedy International Airport evacuated for more than an hour yesterday after federal agents found that airport security officers were not making random hand-held metal detector sweeps of passengers.

title: House Committee Approves Measure to Aid Insurance Industry in Terrorist Attacks
description: Congress edged closer to aiding the insurance industry tonight when a House committee voted to promise insurers billions of dollars in loans in the event of any large terrorist attacks next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, NANI
description: MEYER-Nani. On November 7, 2001. Beloved mother of Peter and Mark and mother-in-law of Esther and Lisa. Dear sister of George Stein and sister-in-law of Carol. Loving grandmother of Michael, Lisa, Lucy and Molly. Services Friday 11:15 at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: 3 Bodies Found In Field
description: Mexican authorities found the bodies of three women in a cotton field in Ciudad Jurez, the border city of 1.2 million where hundreds of women have been murdered, and often raped, over the past 10 years. The number of serial homicides of women has declined sharply in recent years, but local officials are nervous that the trend may begin anew. Two of the bodies were badly decomposed, making it difficult for authorities to immediately determine if the victims had been sexually assaulted.

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Today: Suffolk Lawmakers To Meet
description: The Suffolk County Legislature has scheduled a special session to consider taxes and other budget matters. William H. Rogers Legislature Building, 725 Veterans Memorial Highway, Hauppauge, 11 a.m. Information: (631) 853-4074.

title: Small Sale At Sotheby's Cools Fever Of Bidders
description: After overheated auctions at Phillips and Christie's this week, reality bit last night at Sotheby's sale of Impressionist and modern art.

title: Longest-Serving Woman in Congress Announces Retirement
description: Representative Marge Roukema, the dean of the New Jersey congressional delegation and the longest-serving woman in Congress, announced today that she would retire after her current term.

title: Trade Group Predicts Turnaround in Chip Sales Next Year
description: The trade association for the semiconductor industry predicted today that the sharpest ever decline in chip sales would turn around next year with 6 percent growth, followed by a full-blown recovery in 2003.

title: Good Inventions
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, JOHN S., PHD.
description: WHITE-John S., PhD., age 91, Nov. 6, 2001 after a short illness in Sarasota, FL. Retired Managing Director of N.Y.C. Opera. Beloved godfather of Cristina. We as his family, friends and former colleagues mourn his death with deep sorrow and sadness. Lisa, Hans and Cristina Gegenschatz, David Kinkela and Maximillan.

title: Voting System Overhaul Plan Moves Ahead
description: House Republicans and Democrats have reached agreement on a bill to overhaul the nation's election system, providing $2.25 billion to the states over three years for new equipment and registration systems and an extra $400 million to buy out old punch-card voting machines.

title: Indian Novelist's Fury
description: To the Editor:

title: New Video Releases
description: Shrek

title: Court Blocks Evangelist's Effort to Reopen a Refinery
description: Browning with age, its spires slowly rusting, the old Powerine oil refinery sits dormant after decades of bellowing smoke so thick that residents complained it took the paint off their cars.

title: Opponents of the War Are Scarce on Television
description: It is not true that antiwar speakers are unwelcome on television news and talk shows.

title: A Nation Challenged
description: The Buildup

title: Black Photographers Who Are Trying to Get Blackness Right
description: ''Reflections in Black: Smithsonian African-American Photography'' at the Studio Museum in Harlem, organized by Deborah Willis, is a mind-bendingly big show with a big thesis: that African-Americans used photography to define themselves. The exhibition, divided into two sections, ''The First Hundred Years,'' which runs from 1842 to 1942, and ''Art and Activism,'' which runs from the 1950's to the present, includes hundreds of photographs by and mostly of African-Americans.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Immigration Accord With Greece
description: In an attempt to improve ties and protect their borders, Turkey and Greece agreed that Greece will be able to return illegal immigrants to Turkey. The long-sought deal comes as Greece fears a new wave of illegal immigrants from the American bombing campaign in Afghanistan. Along with easing the immediate refugee problem, the agreement reached between the countries' foreign ministers in Athens marked a renewal of progress in repairing their relations. Douglas Frantz (NYT)

title: To the Stranger, a Wild Land, Strangely Awesome
description: The first things you notice are the stars. The night sky forms a dome of light over the mud-brick Afghan village, a glittering veil that begins where the land ends and sweeps overhead to the far horizon.

title: How Bloomberg Swayed Democrats
description: To the Editor:

title: Reporter's Notebook; No Jerry Lewis, but Saudi Telethon Reaches Goal
description: The midnight deadline ending Saudi Arabia's recent national telethon for the Afghan people was fast approaching, with the tally well short of the goal, when a $5 million pledge phoned in from King Fahd pushed it over the top.

title: Advertising Declines In Magazines and Radio
description: Two media organizations have reported declines in advertising sales.

title: A campaign promotes noble behavior and the adoption of better values by everyone.
description: AN unconventional campaign that starts with more than $10 million worth of donated outdoor advertising space, promoting values like determination, perseverance and selflessness, is beginning today after a postponement.

title: SALOMON SMITH BARNEY EXPECTED TO CUT 300 JOBS
description: Salomon Smith Barney plans to eliminate as many as 300 investment banking jobs, or 10 percent of the division, as soon as next week and reassign some senior bankers, according to people close to the company. The cutbacks were among the topics of discussion yesterday at a quarterly management meeting for the 3,000-person division, the people said. Salomon Smith Barney, a unit of Citigroup, is the latest Wall Street firm to plan job reductions and shuffling of bankers as the securities industry suffers its most prolonged profit decline since 1994. Securities firms have cut more than 26,000 jobs this year.

title: B. K. Nehru, 92, Indian Envoy And Cousin of Prime Minister
description: B. K. Nehru, an Indian diplomat who nearly succeeded Dag Hammarskjold as United Nations secretary general and quarreled with his cousin Prime Minister Indira Gandhi over Kashmir, died on Oct. 31 in Kasauli in northern India. He was 92.

title: Experts See F.B.I. Missteps Hampering Anthrax Inquiry
description: The federal inquiry into the anthrax attacks has stumbled in several areas and may have missed opportunities to gather valuable evidence as criminal investigators have been unable to fully grasp the scientific complexities of the case.

title: G.O.P. Leader Is Criticized Over Party's Election Losses
description: James S. Gilmore III is governor of Virginia. He is also chairman of the Republican National Committee. So how could it be that the voters of his state on Tuesday surrendered the governorship to a Democrat for the first time in eight years?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUHN, LOUIS
description: KUHN-Louis. Loving husband of Lee (61 years); father of Robert (Pasadena, CA & NYC) & Karen (Paradise Valley, AZ); father-inlaw of Dora Kuhn & Stuart Troyan; adoring grandfather of Aaron, Adam, Daniella, Ross & Michael. Born: May 18, 1912 in New York; died: November 7, 2001, in his 90th year, in Phoenix. Founder & president, Chief Apparel, Inc. and affiliated manufacturing companies. W.W. II service in Europe. A good and decent man; strong, handsome, vital and radiant; wonderful sense of humor, always with a smile, often with a twinkle. Devoted family man; very charitable; enjoyed reading, math, chocolate. An inventor late in life. An athlete all his life: punchball on the city streets (Lower East Side); baseball (All-City); basketball (college center); handball (playing doubles into his 70s, the combined ages of the three other players on the handball court-added up!-would often be less than his). Funeral service 11:30 AM, Sunday, Nov. 11, at Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI, NY.

title: 'Shackleton's Antarctic Adventure'
description: Directed by George Butler

title: Jordan Stands By To Spell Martin
description: For several years, when Curtis Martin heard coaches talk about giving him a rest, he laughed and said he would believe it when he saw it. For several years, Jets coaches said that to get Martin to take a play off required nothing short of handcuffing him to the bench.

title: Poets' Academy to Cut Its Staff
description: The board of the Academy of American Poets, the 65-year-old organization best known for making April poetry month and for its popular Web site, has decided to lay off nearly half its staff to forestall an impending financial crisis.

title: Excerpts From President's Speech: 'We Will Prevail' in War on Terrorism
description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's speech last night in Atlanta, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Martin Wants Quicker Turnaround This Time
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 8 — Kenyon Martin is the silent, suffering type. Last season at this time, Martin, the Nets' No. 1 overall draft pick from 2000, was still recovering from the broken leg and torn ankle ligaments that abruptly ended his college career. But he did not tell anyone that the leg was still bothering him.

title: 'I Remember Me'
description: Directed by Kim A. Snyder

title: One Month Into the Afghan War
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Washington: Gain For Green Party
description: The Federal Election Commission has recognized the Green Party as a national committee, a step that will allow it to collect larger campaign contributions -- up to $20,000 a year per donor -- and send money to state and local party committees. But party rules cap such donations at $10,000 a year, officials said, and the party's candidates refuse contributions from corporations. The Green Party has about 200,000 members, with chapters in 33 states.

title: Book and Disk Drives Seen as Evidence in Rebel's Slaying
description: Part of the inquiry into the assassination of Ahmed Shah Massoud, the commander of the rebel Northern Alliance in Afghanistan, centers on two hard disk drives, with 63,000 files and 1 million e-mail addresses, and a 300-page book in Arabic, a prosecutor here said this week.

title: Gun Found in Garment Bag
description: An investment broker from Syracuse who is charged with trying to board an airplane with a loaded gun is expected to surrender to the authorities in White Plains today, according to the United States attorney's office. A security officer detained the broker, Barbara Mongelluzzo, 52, at the Westchester County Airport, in Harrison, N.Y., after noticing a dark object in her carry-on garment bag as it passed through an X-ray machine, according to court papers. Westchester County police officers searched the garment bag and found a .22-caliber revolver loaded with five rounds, court papers said.

title: Ready for W.T.O. Talks, and Ready to Deal
description: As trade ministers converge on Doha, Qatar, for a World Trade Organization meeting that begins on Friday, Japan, long the world's staunchest multilateralist, is quietly hedging its bets, pursuing a parallel policy of negotiating bilateral free trade agreements.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: More Aid For Welfare Families
description: Gov. Gary Locke announced extensions of the state's welfare-to-work program for the 3,200 families who will reach the five-year limit for assistance in August. Federal law allows for ''hardship extensions'' for up to 20 percent of state welfare caseloads. Under the new rules, benefits equal to 60 percent of a family's discontinued grant will continue for the children through a trustee. Assistance will also be extended to those who are unable to work and those who, despite following state guidelines for moving off public assistance, have been unable to find work. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the art collector Elaine Dannheisser on Oct. 30 misstated her maiden name. It was Hanfling, not Fansling.

title: Corrections
description: An Arts in America article yesterday about the popularity of van Gogh exhibitions, particularly the current blockbuster at the Art Institute of Chicago, misidentified the New York museum that presented ''Van Gogh's Postman: The Portraits of Joseph Roulin'' this year. It was the Museum of Modern Art, not the Metropolitan.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Philip Morris Loses Appeal
description: A state appeals court in San Francisco upheld a $26.5 million judgment against Philip Morris, dismissing the company's claim that it was ''grossly excessive.'' Jurors ordered Philip Morris in 1999 to pay Patricia Henley, who had smoked for 35 years and suffered from inoperable lung cancer, $1.5 million in compensatory damages and $50 million in punitive damages, a judgment that was then the largest ever in a smoking-related case. A judge halved the punitive damages later that year, finding them excessive. Greg Winter (NYT)

title: FORD MOTOR NAMES SEVERAL EXECUTIVES TO NEW JOBS
description: The Ford Motor Company named three group vice presidents yesterday, as the new chief executive, William Clay Ford Jr., began installing his own team. Roman Krygier, 58, was named group vice president to oversee production and standards, a spokesman said. David Thursfield, 56, will also become a group vice president, but will remain chairman, president and chief executive of Ford of Europe. Martin Zimmerman, 55, was named group vice president for corporate affairs. He had been vice president for governmental affairs. Ford also named seven vice presidents, including one in charge of human resources, and appointed a product chief for its most profitable luxury models.

title: The Neediest Cases; For Mexican Immigrants, Help in Bronx
description: In a bustling room on Willis Avenue in the South Bronx, a boy was enjoying his first day in pottery class. He smiled as he rounded the edges of a coiled snake.

title: Colorado State Holds Off Air Force
description: Pete Rebstock's 73-yard kickoff return helped set up Henri Childs's 1-yard scoring run with 6 minutes 46 seconds left as Colorado State defeated host Air Force, 28-21, last night.

title: Only ABC Broadcasts Bush Talk
description: President Bush's speech threw the broadcast networks into a quandary last night, separating them, at least for a time, between those committed to getting the president on the air and those committed to their hit shows.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: I.B.M. Expands Supercomputing Project
description: I.B.M.'s Blue Gene supercomputer project, a $100 million research initiative announced in 1999, is taking a step toward commercialization today as the company announces a partnership with the government's Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory. The partnership is intended to use a variant of the Blue Gene architecture that will enable a supercomputer to handle tasks beyond the biological simulations of protein folding. The supercomputer at the lab, expected to be completed by 2004, will use its 130,000 processors to simulate physical phenomena like the aging of materials, fires and explosions, potentially useful in safety and security planning. ''We're expanding the project to handle a much broader range of applications than we originally expected,'' said Dr. Bill Pulleyblank, who heads the project. I.B.M. is also looking for a big customer to become a partner in commercial applications. Steve Lohr (NYT)

title: One Month Into the Afghan War
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERMAN, FREDERICK
description: SILVERMAN-Frederick, M.D. The faculty of the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology of the NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital, Weill Medical College of Cornell University, express their deep sorrow on the death of their esteemed colleague Dr. Frederick Silverman. Dr. Silverman did his residency training in Obstetrics and Gynecology at this hospital and was a member of the attending staff and the teaching staff from 1962 until his retirement in 1998. As Clinical Professor of Obstetrics and Gynecology, he was a respected and valued teacher of medical students and residents because of his enthusiasm and the depth of his clinical knowledge. His presence will be sorely missed. Frank A. Chervenak, M.D., Chairman and Given Foundation Professor, Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology William J. Ledger, M.D. Professor and Chairman Emeritus, Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital, Weill Medical College of Cornell University

title: The Outlook for Saks Is Weak as Its Sales Tumble
description: With shoppers skittish about the economy and worried about terrorism, many retailers have experienced drops in business this year. But the pinch is sharp at Saks Inc.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Past Lessons Guide Transit Planning for Attack
description: Yesterday morning was the kind that has come to be considered normal in the subway.

title: Foreign Affairs; Beware Of Icebergs
description: As I was boarding my Emirates Air flight from Dubai to Pakistan the other day, I noticed a young Pakistani in front of me wearing a brown corduroy jacket, on the back of which was written in big white letters: ''Titanic.''

title: Diverse Styles At the Birth Of Porcelain
description: In the 18th century, the English Channel was as much a cultural chasm as a body of water between England and the rest of Europe is particularly well illustrated by the different attitudes toward porcelain production.

title: Mark Bradford
description: Lombard-Freid Fine Arts

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: New Airline Names Chief
description: The former head of the Dutch national carrier KLM Royal Dutch has been named president of the new Swiss airline. The selection of Pieter Bouw to head the airline, a merger of Swissair and its former regional subsidiary, Crossair, pushed aside Crossair's founder, Moritz Suter. Mr. Bouw must integrate the two operations, a task that is expected to be difficult because of different corporate cultures and the downturn in international air travel. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Ow! Watch Those Claws
description: Girl fight! Girl fight! Watch 'em ladder their stockings, chip their nail polish, smear their makeup and tear each other's eyelashes out! And if we're really lucky, one of 'em will lose her dress!

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: How Bloomberg Swayed Democrats
description: To the Editor:

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Julia Brady was named a senior client strategist at the Via Group, Portland, Me. She had been an associate at the Stamford, Conn., office of McKinsey & Company.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: One Month Into the Afghan War
description: To the Editor:

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Sparkling Webs Of Dance

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: One Month Into the Afghan War
description: To the Editor:

title: Sad Search By Kerik To Find His Mother; Family Secret Is Revealed In Autobiography
description: For years, Bernard B. Kerik, the New York City police commissioner, was haunted by the same dream. He said he would wake up drenched in sweat, feeling like a frightened child waiting for his mother to come home.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: No Ban On Hitting Children
description: The government said it would not introduce legislation making it illegal for parents to hit children in England and Wales even though Scotland has already announced plans to propose such a law. ''I am not convinced that banning smacking actually helps us to be better parents,'' said Health Minister Jacqui Smith. Mary Marsh, director of the National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, said that the government was ignoring the views of child welfare advocates and that ''children should enjoy the same legal protection from being hit as that afforded to adults.'' Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: Family Life, Without the Meditations
description: THE EVIDENCE AGAINST HER

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about a Staten Island couple charged with second-degree murder in the death of their 3-year-old daughter misstated the surname of the father before he assumed his wife's name. Now known as Matthew Herrnkind, he was Matthew Poppe, not Poppa. The article also misstated the number of Herrnkind children who were taken into custody in 1998 by the Administration for Children's Services. It was three, including the girl who later died, not four.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: E.ON In Talks To Sell Unit
description: E.on, the German conglomerate that has been shedding industrial companies to focus on its core business of power generation, said yesterday that it was in negotiations to sell its aluminum-making subsidiary to Norsk Hydro of Norway. The deal could be worth more than $3 billion, but E.on and Norsk Hydro said negotiations were likely to last several months. Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)

title: A Homeland Pep Talk
description: President Bush sought last night to bolster the confidence of Americans in his administration's efforts to protect their safety at home. It was a rather muted performance, less inspiring than his address to Congress in September. But his call on the nation to ''live in a spirit of courage and optimism'' was well taken.

title: Toughen Up, Little Guy, But Not Too Tough
description: It's almost never a good sign when a movie character is named Seymour -- he's either the butt of a joke, or an object of pity. In ''King of the Jungle,'' a violent but gooey urban fairy tale, the Seymour played by John Leguizamo runs perilously close to the latter. He's a mentally challenged man who has the emotional development of a 5-year-old.

title: Nanowires May Lead to Superfast Computer Chips
description: In the race to make computer chips that are ever faster and ever smaller, scientists at Harvard University have grown tiny crystal rods of silicon and other semiconductors, then sluiced them onto chips to form rudimentary circuits that perform basic logic operations.

title: More to Satisfy 'Matrix' Mania
description: Joel Silver, producer of ''The Matrix'' and two new ''Matrix'' movies now being filmed simultaneously in Australia, has some time on his hands.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Jury Says It's Deadlocked in Rabbi's Murder Trial
description: The jury deliberating the fate of a prominent Cherry Hill rabbi accused of arranging his wife's murder in 1994 reported today that it was deadlocked on all three charges against him.

title: Fewer Choices For Workers On Benefits
description: Tens of thousands of employees are being forced to drop their health plans and choose a different one this month as companies across the country sharply reduce their rosters of H.M.O.'s and other managed care insurers.

title: Northern Alliance Claims It Has Captured Mazar-i-Sharif
description: KHOJA BAWAHUDDIN, Afghanistan, Nov. 9  Forces opposed to the Taliban said tonight they had captured the key northern city of Mazar-i-Sharif after a brief firefight that sent Taliban forces fleeing. Control of the town would give the rebels an important airfield and the route north to Uzbekistan, where American soldiers are stationed 100 miles over the border.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EHLERS, ELAINE M.
description: EHLERS-Elaine M. Age 48, of Morristown, NJ died on November 8, 2001 of metastatic melanoma. Wife of Richard Eger, daughter of Theresa & the late Francis Ehlers, sister of Frank Ehlers, Mary Ehlers Vaccarelli, and Cathie Ehlers Sayre, and aunt of Lisa, Michael, Philip and Kim, daughter-in-law of Edith Eger. She was a shimmering star in an otherwise dull sky. Generous, elegant, and fun-loving with her family and friends, she added life to life. There was simply nobody like her. In lieu of flowers, tax-deductible contributions may be sent to (The Arts Council of the Morris Area) ACMA/Elaine Ehlers' Scholarship Fund, P.O. Box 370, Madison, New Jersey 07940. A Memorial Service at 2:00 PM, on Saturday, November 17, 2001 at The Morris Museum (Bickford Theatre), 6 Normandy Heights Road, Morristown, New Jersey.

title: Panel Picks Candidate For U.A.W.
description: A United Automobile Workers panel nominated Ron Gettelfinger today to succeed Stephen Yokich as president, a move that virtually assures he will take over as the union's leader next year.

title: Patricia Locke, 73, Champion of American Indians
description: Patricia A. Locke, who worked for decades to preserve American Indian languages and became a pioneer in an effort to grant the tribes greater authority in the education of their children, died on Oct. 20 at a hospital in Phoenix. She was 73 and lived in Wakpala, S.D., on the Standing Rock Indian Reservation.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Ideas on Saturday about the rise and fall of public trust in government misstated the name of a historian at Texas A&M University who is the author of a recent book, ''The Strange Death of American Liberalism.'' He is H. W. Brands, not C. W. Brands.

title: Of Old-Time Treachery With Modern Precepts
description: Fred Ho's ''Once Upon a Time in Chinese America,'' performed on Wednesday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music Harvey Theater, unspooled to one of the best dance scores to be heard in these parts in recent times. Composed by Mr. Ho and performed live by his Afro-Asian Music Ensemble, the music was brash yet densely textured and full of witty musical asides. It required -- and repaid -- close listening. There was no imbalance of attention, however, given the mostly enjoyable silliness of the drama and dance component of the piece.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIMMET, WALTER
description: FRIMMET-Walter. Age 68, of Teaneck, NJ. Beloved husband to Sandra. Devoted father to Tobi Edwards and her husband Darryl, Douglas Frimmet, Marci, Scherl & her husband Jonathan. Loving grandfather to Jackie and Matt Klein, Cameron Edwards & Dani, Jared and Jesse Scherl. He lived his life with loyalty, dedication, love, hope and determination. He will be sorely missed! Services will be held at Temple Emeth in Teaneck, Friday, November 9th, 11 AM. For further info call ''Gutterman-Musicant'', 1-800-522-0588.

title: A Clash of Experts
description: To the Editor:

title: Pending Appeal, Paterson Teenagers Are to Be Tried as Adults
description: A state judge ruled today that 12 teenagers should be tried as adults on murder charges in the beating death of a homeless man here last June, although today's decision does not necessarily mean the boys will end up in adult court.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: AT&T Broadband To Offer Tivo
description: AT&T Broadband, the largest United States cable provider, said it planned to offer the TiVo personal digital video recorder and service to its cable customers in selected areas. Beginning Nov. 15, AT&T Broadband will offer TiVo to customers in New England, Denver and in six cities in Silicon Valley in California for roughly the same price TiVo charges its retail customers -- $299 for the device, plus a service contract for $8.95 a month or $249 for the life of the device. AT&T Broadband, of Englewood, Colo., sees TiVo, which allows viewers to easily record and replay programming, as a way to bolster its offerings and drive revenue growth. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Class Action By Inmates
description: A federal judge granted class-action status to a lawsuit filed on behalf of scores of patients at the Arkansas state hospital for the criminally insane at Little Rock. The Arkansas affiliate of the American Civil Liberties Union maintains in the suit that state and county jail inmates held at the hospital under court order have not received prompt evaluation or treatment and therefore are being subjected to cruel and unusual punishment.

title: History of a 3-Year-Old: A Life Supervised, but Not Saved
description: From the day she was born almost to the day the authorities say she was beaten to death, Sylena Herrnkind was under the protection of New York City's child welfare system -- a system that had been overhauled and granted new resources in the aftermath of another little girl's death from abuse.

title: No Quick Victory, U.N. on Alert, Stepping Up Counterterror Effort
description: With the war in Afghanistan a month old, the American commander of combat operations gave notice that a bigger buildup of United States forces was likely. How many troops would be deployed, and when, Gen. Tommy R. Franks did not say. Nothing big seemed likely in the next few days. The point, General Franks said, was, ''We want to keep all the options open.''

title: Which Australian Candidate Has the Harder Heart?
description: Three sweet little girls, Eman, Zahra and Fatimah, stared earnestly from the front pages, party ribbons in their hair, their dark eyes shining -- three of the nearly 400 refugees who drowned last month on a refugee boat heading through a stormy sea to an Australia that would not have them.

title: Shackles Off, Russia's Muslims Are Still Chafing
description: Summoned by a familiar, plaintive call, young men dazed from studying stumble from their dorm rooms with slippers on their feet and prayer on their minds.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Just Grazing With the Stars

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Hauppauge: Suffolk Adopts Budget
description: Under a $2.1 billion budget adopted last night by the Suffolk County Legislature, property taxes will rise 14.5 percent, or $90 a year, for the average homeowner in 2002, officials said. The amount differs geographically, with $106 being the average in the five western towns and $11 in the five eastern towns, which are served by local police instead of county police. The legislature cut $26 million in spending and also adjusted for a $20 million drop in sales tax revenue after the terrorist attacks. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

title: Laura Bush's View of Life After 9-11
description: Laura Bush spoke today about some of the fears she had experienced at the White House since Sept. 11, but she also made an audience roar with laughter at a sly reference to Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Climate Talks Come Down To Haggling Over Details
description: Talks in Morocco aimed at finishing a pioneering climate treaty headed into a final sprint last night, with negotiators from more than 160 countries haggling over a few important details.

title: A Yale Player the Pros Can Love
description: As a wide receiver at Yale University, Eric Johnson was so far off professional football's radar screen that few of the major scouting services bothered to list him among National Football League prospects. Johnson had an outstanding college career, breaking 11 receiving records, but to the N.F.L., frankly, he was a nobody.

title: European Central Bank Cuts Key Interest Rate 0.5%
description: With European nations slipping closer to recession, both the European Central Bank and the Bank of England reduced their benchmark interest rates by half a percentage point today, following the Federal Reserve's action by 48 hours.

title: Hamilton Improving, To Giants' Relief
description: For Keith Hamilton, the last two Sundays have been nightmares, and not only because his Giants blew one game to the struggling Washington Redskins and almost another to the lowly Dallas Cowboys. Hamilton, a 10th-year defensive tackle, who had started 76 consecutive games for the Giants, could not play because of a dislocated right shoulder, and he watched from the sideline wearing street clothes and a perpetual frown.

title: Exchanging Her Halo For a Cloak of Darkness
description: If the shock-rocker Alice Cooper hadn't claimed the title before she was born, Britney Spears could have called her latest tour ''Welcome to My Nightmare.'' The show she took to Nassau Coliseum on Wednesday night, which was actually titled ''Dream Within a Dream,'' is dazzling. But its concept is darker than you'd expect -- or perhaps just dark enough to illuminate the commotion America's latest sweetheart generates.

title: Editorial Observer; The Meaning of That Star-Spangled Hard Hat
description: The trade center disaster came to my neighborhood as a dark thunderhead of smoke that boiled over the river into Brooklyn, showering the streets with burning papers from the desks of the dead. Charred documents were still falling when the first American flag went up along our street. Within 48 hours this tree-lined block of 19th-century brownstones was flying more flags than it ever has. The flags have already created a new subset of petty crime. Like bicycles, they get stolen, leaving their owners to rustle up new ones in the midst of a flag shortage.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday with an article about turnaround efforts at Kmart misstated the date of the appearance of Charles C. Conaway, the chief executive, with Martha Stewart at the introduction of a line of housewares. It was October 2000, not last month.

title: Jenny Holzer -- 'Oh'
description: Cheim & Read

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nextwave Settles License Dispute
description: NextWave Telecom settled a dispute with the United States government over wireless spectrum licenses that the company controlled, lawyers told a bankruptcy judge yesterday. The settlement is worth about $16 billion, people close to the situation have said. While settlement terms were not disclosed at the hearing, Deborah Schrier-Rape, a NextWave lawyer, said outside the court that the company's share would be $6 billion. The settlement ends years of wrangling over licenses that NextWave bought in 1996 for $4.7 billion. NextWave sought bankruptcy protection in 1998 after defaulting on payments for the licenses. The government seized the licenses last year and resold them for $15.9 billion. An appeals court overturned that sale.

title: Dynegy to Acquire Fast-Sinking Rival Enron
description: With its finances in doubt, the Enron Corporation ( news/quote ), the world's largest energy trading company, agreed today to be acquired by a rival, Dynegy Inc. ( news/quote ), for stock valued at more than $9 billion and the assumption of $13 billion in debt.

title: Tighter Fuel Standards?
description: To the Editor:

title: F.B.I. Releases Profile of Person Behind Anthrax Attacks
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9  He usually keeps to himself, both at work and at home. He avoids confrontation, not because he is good-natured but because he simply lacks the personal skills to say what he wants.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Julia Brady was named a senior client strategist at the Via Group, Portland, Me. She had been an associate at the Stamford, Conn., office of McKinsey & Company.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ZELDIN, BENJAMIN
description: ZELDIN-Benjamin. Gone two years. We lost our treasure. Your place can never be filled. Our cherished memories remain. Sweatheart, protect our children in these perilous times. Loved and deeply missed. Beverly and Childre

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIELBERGER, LAWRENCE, MD.
description: SPIELBERGER-Lawrence, MD. On November 7, 2001. A devoted anesthesiologist at NYU Medical Center for over thirty years. He was a physician of unmatched talent and integrity. His intellectual curiosity and knowledge covered many human endeavors, among them art, music and literature. After his retirement he became a full-time artist endowing the world with beauty and inspiration. He is mourned by his beloved wife, Dr. Greta, his sister, nieces, nephews, grand-nieces, grand-nephews and cousins in America, Hungary and Austria. Services on Sunday, November 11, 2001, at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th St. For more information contact ''The Riverside'', 212-362-6600.

title: Wall Street Lawyers Being Laid Off as Deals Drop
description: From her apartment in Forest Hills, Queens, M. Catherine LaTorre made her regular call to the unemployment office Monday morning, her 59th day as a lawyer without a job. Ms. LaTorre has been able to find one, and only one, headhunter to talk to her, but after the World Trade Center attacks the headhunter was laid off herself for lack of work.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Graphics Chip Maker Says Profit Rose
description: Nvidia, the best performer in the Nasdaq 100 index this year, said fiscal third-quarter profit rose 59 percent as the company, a maker of chips that enhance computer graphics, took market share from ATI Technologies. Net income rose to $44.7 million, or 26 cents a share, from $28.1 million, or 17 cents, a year earlier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CINISOMO, EDMUND
description: CINISOMO-Edmund. We all live on borrowed time! How Daytop's Vice President for Texas's and California's Youth life-saving efforts, Ed Cinisomo, reflected that reality. Armed with more than two decades of inspired leadership, captaining treatment Staff in major Daytop treatment centers across New York State, he relished the assignment to offer the branch of safety to legions of troubled youth being swept downstream from raging family crises across the Lone Star and Golden Gate States. Thousands of the young today lay claim upon his legacy. We return to his God a Soul who bore lasting impact during his 'borrowed time'! Heaven favor his journey! (Msgr.) William B. O'Brien President, Daytop Village, Inc.

title: Tormented by a Syndrome, But Tickled in New Love
description: It's tough to not admire an actor with the strength to walk away from a successful television series. Which is just what Rob Morrow did in 1994 when he departed the relentlessly quirky vistas of Cicely, Alaska, the setting of ''Northern Exposure.'' In the years since, Mr. Morrow has pursued work to show that he's as little like the smug Dr. Joel Fleischman as possible. He tries his biggest vault from his past yet with the romantic triangle melodrama ''Maze,'' in which he plays Lyle Maze, a sculptor afflicted with Tourette's syndrome.

title: CLOROX SAYS IT MAY SELL ITS TRASH-CAN LINER BUSINESS
description: The Clorox Company said yesterday that it might sell its trash-can liner business and that it had hired J. P. Morgan Chase to help find a buyer. Clorox is seeking offers for the business, Himolene, though it said it might keep the business if it did not receive an acceptable offer. The company was not more specific. The chief executive, G. Craig Sullivan, has been closing plants and laying off workers, using the savings to lower prices and spend more on marketing and new products to lift sales. Himolene has four plants in the United States and sells liners to hotels, hospitals, airports, restaurants and the military.

title: Profit at Walt Disney Decreased 82% in Fiscal Fourth Quarter
description: The Walt Disney Company said today that its fiscal fourth-quarter profit fell 82 percent because it sold less advertising on its ABC television network and fewer people visited its theme parks.

title: 'Mir2'
description: Smack Mellon Studios

title: World Briefing | Europe: Scotland: Parliament Leader Forced To Resign
description: The first minister of the Scottish Parliament, Henry McLeish, resigned after admitting that he had received $52,000 in rent payments for subletting part of his district office in Fife during the 14 years he represented the area in the British Parliament. ''I recognize the mistakes I have made,'' Mr. McLeish, a Labor Party leader, said. The Scottish Parliament was created in 1999 along with the Welsh National Assembly and the Northern Ireland Assembly in Prime Minister Tony Blair's program to cede the British Parliament's power over local matters to regions of the United Kingdom. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: 12 Port Authority Workers Charged With Stealing Disaster Money
description: Twelve employees of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey were charged yesterday with stealing disaster relief money from the American Red Cross by falsely claiming that they lost their jobs after the collapse of the trade center.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Discounters Give Lift to Retail Sales
description: Retailers' sales in October rose a better-than-forecast 0.9 percent as consumers sought low prices at chains like Wal-Mart Stores and Kohl's and avoided clothing retailers like the Gap, industry figures showed yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, IRWIN
description: CLARK-Irwin, pioneer in the study of calcium and phosphoros metabolism in bone growth and regeneration, died on November 6 at his home in Plainfield, NJ after a lengthy illness. He was born on April 28, 1918, received his Bachelor's degree from Harvard University, and was awarded a Doctorate in Biochemistry from Columbia University. After working at Merck for many years he became a professor at the College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia Medical School. In 1971 he relocated to the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill for four years, after which he returned to the metropolitan area to conduct research at Rutgers University until retirement at the age of 71. He is survived by four children and nine grandchildren. Donations may be made to the Center for Hope, 176 Hussa Street, Linden, NJ 07036.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Old-Timers and Dinosaurs

title: Up From Seattle
description: Trade ministers from 142 nations will meet in Doha, Qatar, today for a conference of the World Trade Organization. Their agenda is much the same as the ill-fated ministerial meeting in Seattle in 1999, when attempts to bridge the gap between poor and wealthy countries' priorities blew up in a cloud of tear gas. The whole world has an interest in seeing this gathering turn out better. With the world's terrorized economy stuck at a standstill, the time is ripe for a cooperative, international push for growth through trade.

title: Stage Manager-Slash-Director Finds Christmas
description: THE camels are sleeping in their darkened room in the basement of Radio City Music Hall, and Howard Kolins, the executive producer of the Radio City Christmas Spectacular, is reluctant to wake them up.

title: Poets' Academy To Cut Its Staff
description: The board of the Academy of American Poets, the 65-year-old organization best known for making April poetry month and for its popular Web site, has decided to lay off nearly half its staff to forestall an impending financial crisis.

title: Surest Steps, Not the Swiftest, Are Propelling Dynegy Past Enron
description: The tortoise appears ready to overtake the hare.

title: Brazil Gives Priority to Reaching Accords
description: A Brazilian delegation to the World Trade Organization talks landed in Qatar today, hoping to lay the groundwork for new accords even as trade liberalization was losing momentum around the world.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: Stars Hooked On Highfalutin

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHREIBER, MURIEL N.
description: SCHREIBER-Muriel N. On November 8, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Danny. Loving mother of Les and Karen, Ron and Helaine. Cherished grandmother of Justin, Dara, David, Ira & Brian. Services are on Sunday at 11:30 A.M. at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARRETT, BETTY
description: BARRETT-Betty. Of NYC. A sculptor who received training at the New School for Social Research and whose works were displayed at the Library for Performing Arts, Lincoln Center, and the White House. In addition, her sculptures are represented in private collections in both the U.S. and England. Betty is survived by her husband Herbert, President and founder of Herbert Barrett Management. She is also survived by daughters Nancy & Katherine and a son-in-law Richard. Grandchildren include Wendy, Andrew, Sarah, Benjamin, and Sandy. Services are private.

title: Arnold J. Kemp
description: Debs & Company

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: More Women's Remains Found
description: One day after officials discovered the bodies of three women in a cotton field in Ciudad Jurez, the skeletal remains of another five were found nearby. A police spokesman would not say if the deaths were connected to the 57 young women who were raped and murdered in the city during the 1990's. Human rights groups planned demonstrations to demand more rigorous investigations into the crimes, which have largely gone unsolved. Graham Gori (NYT)

title: Celebrities in Spoof To Promote Tourism
description: New York City does not normally have to advertise its virtues to visitors, but these are not ordinary times. So it was that the Giuliani administration, with the help of the advertising agency BBDO New York, persuaded some celebrities to send themselves up in a new campaign promoting tourism during the holidays.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Volkswagen To Lay Off 3,000
description: Facing sluggish sales caused by high local interest rates and a slowing economy, the Brazilian unit of said that it would lay off 3,000 of its 28,000 workers starting on Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PADULA, ED
description: PADULA-Ed. My friend and first mentor. You left too soon for me though clearly the right time and place for you. I will miss you so much. I promise to follow your advice. Emily says you'll see every performance at Bay Street, contagiously inventive, persistent and inspiring. Love, Lisa

title: Taking Time for Children, Boston Sports and a Poconos Dream House
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Rangers Relish Bringing the Islanders Back to Earth
description: Earlier this week, Theo Fleury was asked if tonight's meeting between the Rangers and the Islanders, the first of five this season for the longtime rivals, was a measuring stick.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDNER, CHARLES
description: GOLDNER-Charles. The board and staff of NJCD/Yachad mourn the passing of Mr. Charles Goldner, beloved father of Debbie Gibber, and father-in-law of Elliot, our immediate past national chairman. We also extend our deepest condolences to Amy and Daniel Gibber, Yachad committee members, upon the passing of their beloved grandfather. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Jeffrey Lichtman,, Nat'l. Dir. Steven Spira, Nat'l Chairman

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Let me just say this, they really are so off base that it's a sin. And I mean that in a moral sense. What they're doing is sinful. The effort here is to try to recover as many human remains as possible. They have absolutely no monopoly on caring about the people there.''

title: Pakistani Warns of Image Problem
Pakistan Orders the Taliban To Close Karachi Consulate
description: In a continuing effort to muffle the Taliban and restrain Islamic militancy, Pakistan has ordered the Taliban consulate in Karachi to close, and has placed a prominent militant Muslim cleric under detention, the Pakistani Foreign Ministry said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANGER, VANESSA
description: LANGER-Vanessa. Of Yonkers, N.Y., an office manager for Regus on the 93rd floor of Tower 2, missing and presumed dead since September 11, 2001 in the tragedy at the World Trade Center. She was the loving wife of Timothy Joseph Langer and mother-to-be of their unborn child. She was the cherished daughter of Donna Marsh and Walter Lang. Vanessa was born on October 31, 1971 at Einstein Hospital, Bronx, N.Y. She attended Liverpool High School and Syracuse University. Vanessa is survived by her mother and stepfather, Donna Marsh O'Conner and Robert O'Conner; two brothers, James and Jackson of Syracuse, N.Y.; father and stepmother Walter and Debbie Lang. Also three brothers, Dustin, David and Bobby Lang, all of Denver, CO. In addition to her husband, parents and siblings, Vanessa is survived by her grandmother, Betty Meister of Yonkers, N.Y., grandmother Marie O'Brien of New Jersey, aunt Nadine Knoll of Yonkers, aunt Robin and uncle Nicky Della Rocca, nieces Laura, Stephanie and nephew Nicholas Della Rocca of Yonkers. Also, uncle Michael Marsh and aunt Denise Marsh; nephews Christopher and Eric Marsh of Clifton, N.J., mother-in-law Elaine M. Langer of Congers, N.Y.; father-in-law Thomas G. Langer and his wife Susan of Scarsdale; brothers-in law Thomas M. Langer and wife Karen of Lakewood, N.J., Theodore F. Langer of Congers, N.Y. and Todd G. Langer and wife Rebecca of Denver, CO. Vanessa was a beautiful, beautiful person in appearance and spirit. Her smile was captivating and her whole attitude toward life was remarkable. She was kind, thoughtful, intelligent and very motivated; the ultimate woman and true friend. Although she relished the water, boating, the New York Yankees and Giants, her desire to have children with Tim was paramount. She enjoyed her pregnancy and could not wait to be a mother. She had given books to Tim titled, ''How to Pamper Your Pregnant Wife,'' ''What to Expect When Your Wife is Expanding,'' and ''She's Having A Baby and I'm Having a Breakdown.'' A celebration of her life will be held at the Kensico Cemetery, Lakeview, Valhalla, N.Y. on Sunday, November 11 at 12 noon. Vanessa, we will never forget you. For information call Lincoln Park Funeral Home, 914-963-1550.

title: One Month Into the Afghan War
description: To the Editor:

title: Helping Mozart Along
description: Mozart's five violin concertos do not fit very well into today's concert life. Big soloists with big orchestras want to do big concertos, while chamber organizations tend to avoid pieces that easily sound modest without a supreme musician in the central role. Written when Mozart was in his teens, the concertos do not quite have the musical strength to force a place for themselves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEXNER, BELLA C.
description: WEXNER-Bella C. The Officers and Board of the Columbus Jewish Foundation mourn the passing of Bella Wexner, one of its first philanthropic fund holders. The Bella Wexner Founders Fund generously supported the Foundation's general operations and community-wide grants program. She took special pride in Wexner Heritage Village, a Jewish elder care facility, where she regularly visited the residents and tended to their personal needs. Among the beneficiaries of her Foundation funds were Columbus Hebrew and Jewish day school educators, and Statewide naturalization programs.
