A devout member of Agudas Achim Synagogue, children regularly stopped by her seat for sweets and kind words. Her interest in Jewish Family Services, Columbus Torah Academy, Israel Bonds, Hadassah, Chabad, and Columbus Jewish Federation, where she was a major donor for many years, were hallmarks of a beloved community matriarch who honored the Foundation and its partner agencies with her support. May the Wexner family be comforted among the mourners of Zion. Gary B. Robins, President Jackie Jacobs, Executive Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOHLER, JAMES E.
description: KOHLER-James E. The Kings County District Attorney and his staff mourn with deep sorrow the passing of James E. Kohler, beloved husband of Jeanne, wife of more than 40 years. Loving father of Patricia, James, Michael, Teresa, Andrew and Jeanne and beloved grandfather of T.J., Kaitlin, Sean, Christopher and William. James was a man of honor, goodness and decency, who served the people of Kings County with distinction as a Deputy District Attorney for 12 years. He was a cherished and loyal friend, fierce and fair litigator and mentor to many in his personal and professional life. His brilliant mind, twinkling eyes, and indomitable spirit will be missed but remembered by all those whose lives he touched. Charles J. Hynes, District Attorney and the Staff of the Kings County District Attorney's Office

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JESSE, DR. MARY JANE
description: JESSE-Dr. Mary Jane, 83. Died peacefully in Cincinnati on November 7, surrounded by loving family. Former president of the American Heart Association, she led major divisions at Columbia Presbyterian, NIH, University of Miami & University of Cincinnati. Thousands of patients, students, colleagues and friends whose lives she brightened will remember her always with love and admiration. Contributions can be sent to Habitat for Humanity, 420 W. Wyoming Avenue, Cincinnati, OH. 54215.

title: Corrections
description: The Making Books column in the arts pages yesterday, about John Grisham's ''Skipping Christmas'' and other seasonal books that are being shipped in large numbers, misspelled the surname of Mr. Grisham's editor and agent. He is David Gernert, not Gernet.

title: Court to Rule on Drug Tests for School Groups
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether public schools may require students to pass drug tests as a condition of participating in extracurricular activities.

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: It's Still a Safe World for Microsoft
description: Four years almost to the day after the government first sued Microsoft for violating the terms of its antitrust settlement, the United States ended its prosecution of Microsoft with another proposed settlement. This consent decree is weaker than the one Microsoft had apparently agreed to before a United States Court of Appeals unanimously affirmed the finding of liability against the company last summer. Some may wonder how you get a better deal after being found guilty than you did before.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLANER, LUELLA B.
description: SLANER-Luella B. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff of Mount Sinai School of Medicine mourn the passing of Luella B. Slaner, generous benefactress. Her outstanding philanthropy to Mount Sinai included the establishment of the Alfred P. Slaner Professorship in Psychiatry, and other important research support for Alzheimer's Disease. Mrs. Slaner will be remembered with gratitude for her thoughtful generosity. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her entire family. Stephen M. Peck, Chairman The Mount Sinai Medical Center Nathan Kase, Interim President and CEO, The Mount Sinai Medical Center and Interim Dean, Mount Sinai School of Medicine Barry R. Freedman, President and CEO, The Mount Sinai Hospital

title: Somalis in Minneapolis Worry About Effect of Money-Transfer Raids
description: In recent years, thousands of refugees from Somalia have made a home here near Cedar Avenue, where the scent of grilled onions, lamb and spices rises on the wind and where storefront shops and restaurants stand as symbols of their success.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOLLMERHAUSEN, JOSEPH WILLIAM, M.D.
description: VOLLMERHAUSEN-Joseph William, M.D. Of Summit, NJ died November 6, 2001 after a long illness. Born in Barmen, Germany, May 10, 1917, son of Maria and Joseph. The family emigrated in 1925. He graduated valedictorian of Brooklyn Prep School 1935, Fordham University 1939, and Long Island College of Medicine 1943. Dr. Vollmerhausen interned at University of Pennsylvania Hospital, Philadelphia. From there, he served as Captain in the US Army. He completed his residency at Pilgrim State Hospital. For more than 40 years, he practiced psychoanalysis in Manhattan. Part of that time, he also practiced in Summit. He served as Associate Dean of Karen Horney Institute of Psychoanalysis, where he was a training and supervising analyst. Subsequently, he joined the Postgraduate Center for Mental Health. He was a member of the Academy of Psychoanalysis, life member of American Psychoanalytic Association, and member of the New York Medical Society. Cherished husband of Claire Murphy Ruotolo whom he married in 1973. Together they enjoyed many years of world travel, playing tennis wherever they went. Proud father of John, M.D. of CA, Robert of NC, and Ruth Carey of FL. Loved by stepchildren Denise Ruotolo of Plainfield, the late Andrew Ruotolo, Jr. of Westfield, Cynthia Sherwin of CT and Diane Webber of PA. Adored grandfather of Todd, Jamie, Jessica, Jill, Lyndsay, Andrew, Jayne, Ryan and Chelsea. Brother to John, Gertrude Gehringer, and the late Elizabeth Metesch. Memorial service will be held on Saturday, November 10, noon at Dangler Funeral Home, 309 Springfield Ave, Summit. Contributions in lieu of flowers, to Community Food Bank of New Jersey, 31 Evans Terminal Road, Hillside, New Jersey 07205.

title: SUNY Deal Is Questioned By McCall
description: State Comptroller H. Carl McCall released an audit today charging several improprieties in a State University of New York contract with an architect who has close personal ties to Gov. George E. Pataki.

title: On the Sly, Iran Weighs Closer Ties With U.S.
description: No issue is more central in Iran these days than the officially nonexistent relations with the United States.

title: Fed Panel Saw a Need to Buoy Confidence
description: The need to support a stumbling economy by bolstering consumer and business confidence led Federal Reserve policy makers to lower the overnight bank lending rate by half a percentage point on Oct. 2, minutes of their meeting showed today.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about conservatives' criticism of networks' coverage of the war in Afghanistan gave an erroneous name in some copies for an organization that hires monitors to watch newscasts. It is the Media Research Center, not Council.

title: Fishermen Express Dismay Over Exxon Valdez Ruling
description: Before the 1989 Exxon Valdez oil spill in Prince William Sound, Herb Jensen grossed up to $400,000 a year fishing for herring, salmon and crab. Since the spill, his average has dropped under $100,000.

title: Fighters for the Forests Are Released From Mexican Jail
description: Faced with mounting pressure from international human rights groups, President Vicente Fox ordered the release of two ecologists today after they had been tortured by soldiers and jailed for leading a campaign to stop the destruction of forests in the Pacific Coast state of Guerrero.

title: McGreevey Asks for Freeze On Spending In New Jersey
description: With their common nemesis, Bret D. Schundler, finally out of the picture, Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco and Governor-elect James E. McGreevey met for lunch today at Drumthwacket, the executive mansion in Princeton, where both men promised a smooth transfer of power and pledged to work together to tackle New Jersey's looming budget deficit.

title: NOVARTIS TO CREATE A CENTER ON TROPICAL DISEASES
description: Novartis, the European drug maker, plans to spend $122 million in Singapore to create a center dedicated to finding treatments for infectious diseases like dengue fever and tuberculosis. The center, the Novartis Institute for Tropical Diseases, will focus on diseases that affect people in developing countries, the company said. The center plans to employ about 60 scientists and technicians. Separately, the European Commission approved Novartis's Glivec leukemia treatment yesterday. The approval means the drug can be sold in the 15 countries of the European Union.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCRACKEN, JOHN EDWARD
description: McCRACKEN-John Edward. July 28, 1914-November 3, 2001. Beloved husband of Jeanne M.S. McCracken. Devoted father of David J.B. McCracken. Princeton University '36, Yale Law School '39, The Union Club. Memorial service Fifth Ave. Presbyterian Church, 7 West 55 St. Thursday, November 15, 2001 at 11AM. Contributions in his memory may be made to his Church or Princeton UniversityClass of '36 Endowment Fund.

title: King of Shores (and Parking Lots)
description: When I was in college, I knew someone who did field biology observations in his dorm room late at night. He would set out some crumbs near a couch and wait. First the ants would come. Then a spider would emerge from under the couch to go after the ants. And finally a centipede would come to try to eat everybody.

title: GRAHAM PACKAGING SAYS IT WILL CLOSE A PLANT IN ONTARIO
description: Graham Packaging, a maker of plastic containers, said yesterday that it would cut 140 jobs and close a manufacturing plant in Burlington, Ontario, because of the slowing economy. The plant's operations will be moved either to a plant in Mississauga, Ontario, or to the United States, the company said. Graham, a closely held company based in York, Pa., employs 4,000 people at plants in North America, Europe and Latin America. The company makes about six billion containers a year for food, personal care and household products, and automotive lubricants. It had $825 million in annual sales in 2000.

title: Americans Skeptical About Bioterrorism Risk
description: Americans do not think it very likely that they will become victims of bioterrorism in the next year, but many are still taking precautions, like opening mail more carefully and stocking up on food and water, according to a new poll by the Harvard School of Public Health and the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation.

title: NATIONAL SERVICE APPROVES SPINOFF OF TWO OF ITS UNITS
description: National Service Industries, North America's leading maker of light fixtures, said yesterday that its board had approved a spinoff of the company's lighting equipment and chemicals units into a separately traded business. The new company is temporarily called L&C Spinco. National Service shareholders will get one share of the new company for each share owned. Lithonia Lighting and the NSI Chemicals Group, National's two largest units, will form the new company, which is expected to be renamed soon. The post-spinoff National Service will consist of the textile rental and envelope units.

title: A Onetime War Maker Now Makes Peace
description: To our eyes, Fort Tilden is the most beautiful place in New York City. The first time we visited eight years ago, after driving to the end of Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn, crossing the Marine Parkway Bridge into the Rockaways and taking an inconspicuous turn into the Queens park, it was as if we had been transported to a remote section of Cape Cod. On the park's 317 acres, we found an unspoiled beach scattered with the thick white shells of surf clams. Behind the beach were dunes covered with clumps of beach grass and wind-sculptured bayberry bushes. Trails led behind the dunes into a maritime forest of gnarled black pines, holly bushes and cottonwood trees.

title: How Bloomberg Swayed Democrats
description: To the Editor:

title: Pakistan Tries To Split Army From Mullahs
description: It was called the mullah-military nexus, Pakistan's alliance of Muslim clerics and soldiers born out of the war that began next door, in Afghanistan, in 1979.

title: Sinclair Reports Loss in Third Quarter and Reduces Estimates
description: The Sinclair Broadcast Group, the owner of 63 United States television stations, reported a third-quarter loss today and reduced fourth-quarter estimates because the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks worsened an advertising slump.

title: Anthrax Scare Hits Groups Backing Right To Abortion
description: In the second wave of anthrax threats against abortion clinics in the last month, about 200 clinics and abortion rights groups were sent Federal Express packages containing a powdery substance and, in some cases, a letter signed by the Army of God indicating that the substance was anthrax.

title: The Poets at the Front
description: Ordinary Americans who were on the front lines from the Revolution to the Persian Gulf war show themselves to be poets of troubled times in ''War Letters,'' Sunday on PBS. Several shows this weekend have a Veterans Day theme.

title: A New, Experienced Protector For the Navy in Home Waters
description: The Firebolt, one of the Navy's newest, fastest ships, built to insert and extract commandos in exotic places around the globe, zipped through the Chesapeake Bay this morning on a new mission: homeland defense. And in place of Navy Seals, it had a new strike team: a boarding party from the United States Coast Guard.

title: Mayor Criticizes Firefighters Over Stand on Staffing at Trade Center Site
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani lashed out yesterday at the firefighters who have been battling the city over how to recover human remains at ground zero, a day after his administration acquiesced to one of their main demands at the site.

title: The Troops at the Front as Poets for Future Readers
description: Not long ago my stockbroker, whom I've never met face to face, called me on business but instead kept me riveted with his first-person account of the Sept. 11 attack. He told me of his escape from the Merrill Lynch offices in the World Financial Center, across the street from the twin towers, and of his single-minded desire to speak to his wife. He couldn't get through. As the towers crumbled and the sky turned black, he crouched by the Hudson River embankment, certain he was going to die without reaching her.

title: Kidd's Unlikely Shot Provides a Big Lift For Amazing Nets
description: This was not a shot Jason Kidd could have called, either tonight or back in the gyms in Oakland, Calif., playing against his mentor, Gary Payton. Few can do what Kidd does with two shoes on, let alone with the right shoe off.

title: Bush and India's Leader Pledge Cooperation in War on Terror
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9  President Bush and Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee of India stood side by side today and vowed cooperation in fighting terrorism and working toward a stable Afghanistan once the Taliban is gone.

title: Suffering After Attack, Guggenheim Announces Plans for Layoffs
description: Just one month after it toasted the opening of two museums in Las Vegas, the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum confirmed yesterday that it was planning layoffs at its main museum on Fifth Avenue, which had been particularly hard hit by a drop in out-of-town tourism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDBERG, SEYMOUR, M.D.
description: SANDBERG-Seymour, M.D., 70. In White Plains. Survived by wife Saroj Devi, children David, Stephen, Michael and Shana and brother Lawrence. Memorial service on Sunday, November 11, 12:30PM at Edwin Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale Avenue, Scarsdale.

title: Losing Her Child to a Mysterious Killer
description: Marc Foster's shivery domestic drama ''Everything Put Together'' is a tease of a film that up until its final moments leads you to believe it's something it's not. The story of Angie (Radha Mitchell), a glowing, young suburban mother who loses her baby boy to sudden infant death syndrome, is drenched in eerie sound effects that lend the movie a varnish of supernatural horror. The soundtrack is regularly punctuated by ominous heartbeats. Those pulses are often accompanied by the distant, muffled sounds of crying infants.

title: David Wells, the Sequel, Might Be Worth Seeing
description: It was time for a group photograph yesterday, so David Wells shuffled into the pack of young women whose bikini-clad bodies adorned the 2002 Hooters calendar and, in typically goofy fashion, warned them, ''No pinching now.'' Wells obviously wanted to ensure that his 280-pound temple of a body would be safe.

title: Formula To Finance Counseling Is Criticized
description: The New York City Board of Education is providing about $2,100 per student in federal mental health aid for those who lost neighbors or family members in the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center, but only a small fraction of that for thousands of students who were forced to flee their schools as debris and bodies fell from the twin towers.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. The ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on

title: Officials Miss Decisive Goal
description: Apotentially embarrassing situation during the Devils-Thrashers game Wednesday night was avoided when Bobby Holik scored the winning goal with 1 minute 44 seconds left. But Holik appeared to score a goal three minutes earlier to break the 2-2 tie. The on-ice officials, though, and the videotape judge, Murray Seltzer, missed the goal.

title: F.B.I. Releases Profile of Person Behind Anthrax Attacks
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9  He usually keeps to himself, both at work and at home. He avoids confrontation, not because he is good-natured but because he simply lacks the personal skills to say what he wants.

title: Chrysler Names Manufacturing Executive
description: Chrysler today named Thomas W. LaSorda executive vice president for manufacturing, as the automaker cuts production costs in a plan to end losses.

title: Shadowy U.S. Military Presence in an Afghan Town
description: Just after 7 this morning, two seemingly ordinary vehicles drove quietly through the center of this bustling market town and headed south. A green, four-seat Russian jeep followed a silver Nissan pickup truck loaded with backpacks, dark plastic containers and a box labeled ''battery charger'' in English.

title: Court Says France Can't Censor Yahoo Site
description: In a decision that is being applauded by Internet companies and civil liberties groups, a federal judge ruled on Wednesday that the United States Constitution's protections of free speech trumped a French order requiring Yahoo to remove Nazi materials from its Web site.

title: Inner Beauty Counts, And She's a Perfect 10
description: Peter and Bobby Farrelly have made a name (and a lot of money) for themselves as champions of tasteless, puerile humor. But their high-grossing gross-out movies -- ''Dumb and Dumber,'' ''Kingpin,'' ''There's Something About Mary'' and ''Me, Myself and Irene'' -- have all had an undercurrent of sweet humanism. Their naughtiness allows them to voice sentiments that in other hands might be unbearably preachy and mawkish.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: 'Lilith' Is Made Flesh
description: A GORGEOUS, raven-haired woman prowls through the ranks of sleeping couples. Silently, she moves from one man to the next, rolling them over with a foot, raising them to their feet, taking them in their sleep in a reversed pantomime, female-male rape.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Ex-President Denies Arms Crime
description: Former President Carlos Menem, who has been under house arrest for six months, testified before a criminal judge for four hours and denied having anything to do with illegal shipments of weapons to Croatia and Ecuador between 1991 and 1995. Mr. Menem acknowledged that he had signed decrees enabling the sales but said that the arms were supposed to be shipped to other countries. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: BLOOMBERG VISITS HEADS OF 2 UNIONS OVER FISCAL FEARS
description: Mayor-elect Michael R. Bloomberg paid visits to the leaders of two of New York's most powerful municipal unions yesterday, moving quickly to build ties with officials who will be key players in dealing with the city's mounting budget problems and offering an early and sharp stylistic difference with the man he is succeeding.

title: N.F.L. Matchups Week 9
description: SUNDAY 1 P.M.

title: Editors' Note; Today's Sections
description: News of the Sept. 11 attacks and their aftermath continues to appear in Section B; index, Page B2.

title: 12 Port Authority Workers Charged With Stealing Disaster Money
description: Twelve employees of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey were charged yesterday with stealing disaster relief money from the American Red Cross by falsely claiming that they lost their jobs after the collapse of the trade center.

title: Exchange Considers Move to Trade Center Site
description: Four days before the city was to vote on $920 million in bond financing for a trading complex and office tower on Wall Street, Richard A. Grasso, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, cast a cloud of doubt over the project yesterday when he said he would instead consider building a new home blocks away on the former site of the World Trade Center.

title: Saudi Charges Bush With Failure to Broker Mideast Peace
description: Saudi Arabia's foreign minister, Saud al-Faisal, said tonight that his government was ''angrily frustrated'' that the Bush administration has failed to begin a promised new peace initiative in the Middle East.

title: After Slower Sales and Missteps, Chief Resigns From Palm Inc.
description: Mired in a sales slump, Palm Inc., the hand-held computer maker, said today that its chief executive, Carl J. Yankowski, had resigned.

title: Federal Judge Stops Effort To Overturn Suicide Law
description: Siding with the State of Oregon, the only state to legalize assisted suicide, a federal judge issued an order here today that would temporarily block Attorney General John Ashcroft's move earlier this week to overturn the law.

title: 'Keeping It Real' -- 'The Adventures of Greg Walloch'
description: Directed by Eli Kabillio

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  INY, DAISY
description: INY-Daisy. Congregation Shearith Israel, the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue, mourns the loss of its devoted member and extends its deepest sympathy to her family. Alvin Deutsch, Parnas

title: Girl, 6, Is Abducted From Her Front Yard
description: A 6-year-old girl was abducted from the front yard of her family's home in Spring Lake, N.J., just before noon yesterday, the Monmouth County prosecutor's office said.

title: Ashcroft Plan Would Recast Justice Dept. In a War Mode
description: Attorney General John Ashcroft announced today that he had ordered the Justice Department to assume a wartime footing and had begun to revamp the agency's priorities under a plan that would send thousands of employees from Washington to offices around the country where they would work to prevent terror attacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JUDGE, CURTIS HERBERT JR.
description: JUDGE-Curtis Herbert Jr. Formerly of White Plains, recently of Charleston, SC on November 7, 2001 at age 77. He joined R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company in 1965 as Vice President of Marketing and resided in Winston-Salem, NC until he joined Lorillard in 1970 where he was Chairman and Chief Executive Officer until his retirement in 1985. He served on the Board of Directors for Loews Corporation. Following service in World War II as a pilot in the Air Force, Mr. Judge received his Doctor of Jurisprudence from the University of Texas in 1947. Following a year practicing law, Mr. Judge joined Colgate-Palmolive Company. Mr. Judge received numerous honors and awards from his peers. In 1981 he was inducted into the N.A.T.D. Tobacco Hall of Fame. He served two terms as Chairman of the Executive Committee of the Tobacco Institute, the trade association of the U.S. Cigarette Manufacturers. He was married for 52 years to the late Rosemary Tom Judge. Mr. Judge is survived by two children, Curtis H. Judge III of Harrisonburg, VA., and Kate Longo of White Plains. Also survived by three grandchildren. Services will be private. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be sent to: Habitat for Humanity, Attn: Gifts from the Heart, 121 Habitat St., Americus, GA 31709-3498. For information, contact Coxe & Graziano Funeral Home, Mamaroneck 914-698-5968.

title: Deals and Steelers
description: Pittsburgh has a range of cultural attractions, like the Andy Warhol Museum, the Carnegie Science Center and the Frick Art and History Center. And through Dec. 31, admission to these and 13 other regional attractions is half price with a Getaway Hotel Package from the Greater Pittsburgh Convention and Visitors Bureau. The hotel rates, normally from $80 to $140 a night, are being discounted by $30. Participating hotels include the Hilton Pittsburgh and Towers, the Omni William Penn and the Renaissance. Call (800) 927-8376.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAFFAELE, FRANCIS
description: RAFFAELE-Francis. On November 8, 2001 of Manhasset, NY. Beloved husband of Lorraine. Dear father of Donna, Brian, & Jessica. Beloved son-in-law of Mary Lessa and brother-in-law of Dan Lessa. In repose at The Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset on Friday, 3-5 & 7-9PM. Funeral Mass, Saturday, 9:15AM, Notre Dame R.C. Church, New Hyde Park. Interment St. Charles Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

title: Panel Approves Plan of $5 Billion for New York
description: Efforts to help Lower Manhattan rebuild from the recent terror attack moved forward today when the Senate Finance Committee approved a $5 billion economic stimulus package for the area.

title: Arizona Forgets It's Supposed to Be a Down Year
description: Didn't the N.B.A. draft sap Arizona's roster? Aren't the starters from last season's national runner-up scattered among pro teams? Who are these guys?

title: Democrats' Recovery Plan Moves Forward in Senate
description: Democrats pushed their economic recovery plan through the Senate Finance Committee tonight, setting out their negotiating position on an issue that has left the two parties bitterly divided and at risk of deadlock even as unemployment surges and business activity slows.

title: Random House Is Dropping E-Book Imprint, but Not E-Books
description: The Random House Trade Group, one of the first publishers to announce the creation of a line of purely digital books last year, became the first to cancel that idea yesterday, quietly scuttling its AtRandom imprint in recognition of the scant consumer demand for books that can be read on screens. But the company will continue to publish electronic versions of books.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEE, ESSIE E.
description: LEE-Essie E. The Board of Trustees, officers, staff and residents of Odyssey House mourn the passing of Essie E. Lee, a devoted and loved member of the Odyssey House Board of Trustees for more than 15 years. Her dedication to serving the men, women, and children in treatment at Odyssey House for substance abuse & mental health problems was a source of inspiration to our community. We extend our deepest sympathies to her loved ones. Services Tuesday, November 13, 11:30 AM, at Christ Chapel, Riverside Church, 490 Riverside Drive.

title: Mildred R. Newman, 81, Psychologist and Popular Author
description: Mildred Rubenstein Newman, a New York psychologist whose vastly popular books helped meet an American yearning for emotional self-help and self-betterment in the 1970's, died Tuesday at her home on the Upper East Side. She was 81.

title: Bronx Man Charged With Murder in Death of Girlfriend's Boy, 2
description: A Bronx man was charged yesterday with murdering his girlfriend's 2-year-old son after smacking the toddler on the head as the child tried to rouse him from an afternoon nap, prosecutors said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRALL, LOUIS VICTOR
description: KRALL-Louis Victor. On November 7, 2001. Husband of Joan Spooner. Father of Michael and his wife Shelley and Valerie and her husband Ralph Lieberman. Grandfather of Jordan, Abigail & Jacob Krall and Peter Lieberman. Retired president of GotaasLarsen, Inc. Reposing at Moore Funeral Home, 54 West Jamaica Avenue, Valley Stream, Friday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral services St. Boniface Church, Elmont Road, Elmont, on Saturday at 11:30. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory made to Hospice would be appreciated.

title: Elmer Balaban, Cinema Magnate, Dies at 92
description: Elmer Balaban, the last surviving brother of seven in a family that dominated the movie theater business in Chicago and the Midwest, died on Nov. 2 in Chicago, where he lived. He was 92.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Machinery Orders Fall
description: With profits shrinking and the recession deepening, Japanese companies scaled back the amount of machinery they ordered in September. Machinery orders -- an important indicator of capital spending plans -- hit a two-year low, falling a worse-than-expected 13.2 percent compared with the level in August. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SIMMONS, HELEN ELIZABETH
description: SIMMONS-Helen Elizabeth. We will miss you and love you always. Deirdre, Maud and Charles

title: Realizing That Modern Is Something Antique
description: What was Modernism? A historical era? A period style? An ideology? A religion? A state of mind? It was all that, and more. The age that extended (depending on whom you ask) from sometime after the Civil War to sometime after World War II was one of scientific and technological optimism, of expanding personal and social freedoms and accelerating material abundance. It was a time when a future of unparalleled prosperity and unlimited possibility seemed at hand.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIDRO, FRANK, VIRGINIA (NEE MAINELLA)
description: GIDRO - FRANK - Virginia (nee Mainella). Of Tenafly, NJ on November 7, 2001. Devoted mother of Michael Gidro. Friends may call at the Barrett Funeral Home, 148 Dean Dr., Tenafly, NJ on Monday, 9 to 11 AM. Funeral Mass Monday, 11 AM, Mount Carmel Church, Tenafly, New Jersey. Interment in Valleau Cemetery, Ridgewood, NJ. Donations to the World Wildlife Fund, 1250 24th Street, N.W. Washington, D.C. 20037-1132, or online at www.worldwildlife.org would be appreciated.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Terra Lycos Posts Loss
description: Terra Lycos, the Internet arm of the giant Spanish telecommunications company Telefnica S.A., reported better-than-expected results for the third-quarter. The company said it narrowed its core loss to 49 million euros ($44 million), 16 million euros less than its loss in the second quarter. The company's net loss was 82.9 million euros; Terra Lycos did not provide a figure for a year ago. Revenue for the third quarter was 170 million euros, a 24 percent increase from the similar period in 2000, meeting Terra's forecast despite a negative impact of 7 million euros because of exchange rate differences. ''These results again show we are on the right path,'' said Joaquim Agut, the executive chairman. Emma Daly (NYT)

title: 2 New York Agencies Merge as Blum Ellenson
description: Two agencies in New York, the Blum Network and the Ellenson Group, are merging to form Blum Ellenson. The combined agency has 16 employees and billings estimated at $27 million from clients like Palm Bay Imports, for wine brands like Cavit's Pinot Grigio, and Pokmon USA, a unit of Nintendo, for the introduction of a retail store.

title: INSIDE
description: Trade Talks Are Called Test of U.S. Leadership

title: Arabs Reject Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: The Union Puts Up a Stop Sign As the Owners Plan Contraction
description: In an attempt to speed up the road to contraction, management lawyers yesterday presented the union with their ideas for the distribution of players from the two teams Major League Baseball wants to eliminate. The union, however, is trying to set up a roadblock, filing a grievance to halt contraction.

title: A Free Mitsubishi? No, Not Quite
description: THE hard-edged radio voice proclaims that Mitsubishi is offering ''triple zero'': zero money down, zero percent interest and zero payments until 2003. It sounds as though the company is giving away its cars.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCMAHON, ROBERT D. (BOBBY)
description: McMAHON-Robert D. (Bobby). Member of Ladder 20, FDNY, who lost his life while heroically saving others in the World Trade Center Disaster of September 11, 2001. Beloved husband of Julie (nee Siard). Devoted father of Matthew Clifford, with Julie expecting their second child. He will be remembered as a loving son to Irene Siroka, Robert McMahon and his stepmother Nancy. Cherished brother of Andrew, Irene, Tony, Damon, Michael, Peter McMahon, Michele Pomara and Gina Giammarino (nee Ingrisano). As a member of a very large family, he will be missed by his 4 nephews and one niece, many cousins and his inlaws. Bobby was also a true friend to many, he will be deeply missed & forever remembered. Reposing at the Kennedy-Roth Funeral Homes, Inc. 41-45 58th Street Woodside, NY Sunday 2-5, 7-9 P.M. His mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at the St. Sebastian R.C. Church Woodside, Monday 10:30 A.M. Interment to follow at Calvary Cemetery.

title: Once Busy, An Airport Is Awaiting A Revival
description: Staring down the runway, John Ruplenas had to wait awhile in the autumn breeze. But finally a jetliner gunned its way forward, the plane gleaming upward as it ascended from what is arguably now the nation's safest yet most forlorn airport.

title: British Telecom Announces A Resignation And a Big Loss
description: British Telecommunications today announced a huge quarterly loss and its second top-level resignation in a week.

title: Front and Center, a Commander Faces the Media
description: For more than five weeks, Gen. Tommy R. Franks has led the war on terrorism in Afghanistan. Today, the lanky artilleryman with a chestful of medals faced a new challenge: taking the public stage to rally the country behind the campaign.

title: Sports of The Times; Chambliss Still Wonders About Firing
description: NO, Don Mattingly was saying last night, he is not yet ready to return full time to the Yankees as hitting instructor. His growing boys still need him at home and he isn't willing to commit to the position Gary Denbo no longer holds and Chris Chambliss still doesn't know why he had taken away.

title: The Leader in Airport Security, and in Lapses
description: It seemed impossible, at a time when fingernail clippers are being confiscated by the hundreds at American airports, that a man could slip past a checkpoint at O'Hare International Airport in Chicago with a bag of knives, Mace and other weapons.

title: COMBAT CHIEF SAYS BUILDUP OF FORCES GOES ON IN REGION
description: In his first Pentagon briefing since the war began, the American commander of combat operations in Afghanistan said today that the United States was continuing to build its war-fighting ability in the region, and hinted that larger deployments were still to come.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHOMATE, JAMES P.
description: SHOMATE-James P. On October 13, 2001. Renowned accompanist, vocal coach, and humanitarian. A service commemorating his life will be held at The Weill Art Gallery, 92nd Street YM/YWHA, 1395 Lexington Avenue, NY, from 4-6 P.M., Wednesday, November 28, 2001. Memorial contributions in his name may be made to: The Curtis Institute of Music, Development Office, 1726 Locust Street, Philadelphia, PA. 19103.

title: Art in Review
description: Alex Katz

title: A NATION CHALLENGED
description: Crackdown in Pakistan

title: Judge Orders Rare Lineup Of Suspects One at a Time
description: A judge in Brooklyn ordered investigators in a homicide case yesterday to conduct an identity lineup by showing a suspect and stand-ins to witnesses one after the other instead of all together, a method that scientific studies have shown to be far less likely to result in false identifications.

title: Rose Shapiro, 97, Is Dead; Led School Board in 1960's
description: Rose Shapiro, the president of the New York City Board of Education during one of its stormiest times, died last Saturday at a retirement home in Lauderville, Fla. She was 97 and a former resident of Manhattan and Westport, Conn.

title: British Take Blunter Approach to War Reporting
description: After taking a Taliban-guided tour into southern Afghanistan last week, along with other Western journalists, Simon Ingram wrapped up his four-day experience for ''BBC World News.'' The cameras showed a crowd of village men in turbans, their fists raised in anger as soldiers looked on.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Synagogue In Dresden
description: The first new synagogue to be built on the territory of the former East Germany since the Nazi era will be dedicated in Dresden today, the anniversary of the Kristallnacht rampage against Jews in 1938. The cube-shaped building cost about $9.5 million, provided by the city of Dresden, the regional government of Saxony and donations. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Alex Katz
description: Whitney Museum of American Art

title: Groups Warn Of Calamity If A-Plants Are Attacked
description: Environmentalists and public officials, including three members of Congress and nine members of the State Legislature, presented a petition to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission yesterday, warning that the Indian Point nuclear plants, 35 miles north of Midtown Manhattan on the Hudson River, are vulnerable to terrorist attack and should be shut down until they can be made safe.

title: Does Enron Trust Its New Numbers? It Doesn't Act Like It
description: YOU'D be better informed if, instead of listening to what we say, you watch what we do.''

title: How Bloomberg Swayed Democrats
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: Police Chief Will Run For Mayor
description: Richard Pennington, the highly regarded police chief of New Orleans, has decided to run for mayor next year and plans to announce his candidacy in two weeks. Mr. Pennington was hired by Mayor Marc Morial to clean up corruption in the Police Department and lower the city's homicide rate. He will join two City Council members and a state senator in seeking to succeed Mr. Morial, who is prohibited from running for a third term. Kevin Sack (NYT)

title: SUN HEALTHCARE WANTS TO ISSUE STOCK AS IT REORGANIZES
description: The Sun Healthcare Group, a nursing home and hospital chain, filed a reorganization plan yesterday that would provide newly issued stock to some creditors. The company, based in Albuquerque, filed for bankruptcy protection in Delaware in 1999 amid large losses and a crushing debt load. If the plan is approved by a bankruptcy judge, the company would issue 25 million shares of new stock. Senior lenders would receive about nine million of those shares and $6.65 million in cash, court papers show. About one million shares would go to unsecured creditors. Holders of Sun's senior subordinated debt would receive warrants to buy up to 500,000 shares.

title: Earle K. Moore, 79, Advocate Of Public Voice in TV License
description: Earle K. Moore, an American communications lawyer who secured a landmark civil rights court ruling that obliged broadcasting stations to serve the interests of their audiences, died of cancer Saturday in Manhattan. He was 79.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VANDER POEL, DOROTHY MARLATT
description: VANDER POEL-Dorothy Marlatt. On Tuesday, November 6, 2001 at her residence in Washington, DC. Beloved wife of Halsted Billings Vander Poel; devoted mother of Jane Stuart Lenzetti, Virginia Stuart Muse, Deborah Billings Jorgensen and Halsted Billings Vander Poel II; sister of Constance Huested of California. Memorial service will be held at Christ Church Georgetown, 31st and O Streets, NW, Washington, DC on Monday, November 12 at 11 A.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Hospice of Washington, 3720 Upton Street, NW, Washington, DC 20016, Attn: Development Department. Please reference ''in memory of Dorothy Vander Poel.''

title: Toyota Bucks the Economy And Posts Record Earnings
description: It's a good time to be a company that sells cars for dollars and counts its profits in yen. While American carmakers struggle with losses, Toyota's profits are booming.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Closing A City To Foreigners
description: Russia plans to return the arctic mining capital of Norilsk to its Soviet status as a closed city on Nov. 25, Gov. Aleksandr Lebed of Krasnoyarsk Province said. There was no immediate confirmation from the Kremlin of what would be the first such closing since Russia became independent a decade ago. Mr. Lebed said national security was not behind the closing, as in Soviet times; rather, he said, the city of 200,000 has become a center of drug abuse and H.I.V. infection because of an invasion of foreigners -- now 10 percent of the population. The regional airline KrasAir has already stopped selling tickets to Norilsk to foreigners and the government plans to deport noncitizens once the decree becomes effective, Mr. Lebed said. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Zero Percent: The Fine Print Counts
description: BY promising to shave hundreds or thousands of dollars in interest over the span of a car loan, zero percent financing deals have made auto sales one of the economy's few bright spots since Sept. 11. Cars and trucks sold at an annual rate of 21.3 million in October, the industry's strongest month ever. But many of those buyers ended up with loans that charged interest, and some may have agreed to higher prices than they would have under other buyer-incentive plans.

title: Russian Oil Cutbacks Appear Unlikely, Despite Market's Belief
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 9 — On the surface, it looked like big news: The Russian news service Interfax quoted Prime Minister Mikhail Kasyanov saying that a group of Russian oil companies may agree next week to reduce oil exports in support of the efforts by the Organization of Petroleul Exporting Countries to raise oil prices.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RIGG, TREVOR MARK ANTHONY, ESQ.
description: RIGG-Trevor Mark Anthony, Esq. In loving memory of our dear ''Bunney'' who passed away on November 9, 1990. Sadly missed by mother, brothers and sisters, nephews, nieces, in-laws and friends.

title: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: Effort To Escape Terror List
description: North Korea, which has been eager to lose its designation by the United States that it is a state that sponsors terrorism, has indicated that it will sign a United Nations convention against terrorism tomorrow. The United States welcomed the news but did not indicate whether it would remove North Korea from the list, a move that could help North Korea gain greater international acceptance and more international aid. Howard W. French (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: President Quits As Party Leader
description: President Kim Dae Jung resigned as leader of the Millennium Democratic Party, saying he wanted to take responsibility for the party's loss in an election last month. Mr. Kim, whose term as president ends in February 2003, has been kept on the defensive in recent months by the opposition, which won all three of the parliamentary seats contested in a special by-election. Mr. Kim said the losses had ''diminished confidence in our party an d disappointed party members and supporters.'' Howard W. French (NYT)

title: Reviews of Current Releases
description: For all New York Times film reviews since 1996, go to the Film Archive .

title: Knitting Images and Words Into a Deft, Knowing Style
description: Joe Brainard (1942-94) was a word-and-image man the way other people are song-and-dance men or women. In his art, language and pictures flowed together effortlessly, almost musically. The retrospective of his short, productive career at P.S. 1 in Long Island City feels a little too precious in spots, but there is not a note off or a step missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGEE, JOHN GERARD
description: McGEE-John Gerard. Of Middle Village at the age of 44. Beloved son of Florence. Loving brother of Robert McGee, Jr., Dr. Judith McGee, Kathleen Daniels, Reverend Michael McGee, Janice McAuliffe, Patricia Nulty, Margaret McGee, Nancy Dockstader, William McGee and the late Richard McGee. Devoted uncle of Lt. J.G. Daniel McAuliffe, Richard McAuliffe, Christine McAuliffe, Timothy McGee, Brendan Daniels, Emily Daniels, Alexandra Dockstader, Brian Dockstader, Nicholas McGee and Sean Nulty. Graduate of Xavier High School, decorated Veteran of The United States Army, including two tours with the Berlin Brigade; Crew Coordinator for Tanqueray's N.E. AIDS Ride and Avon Breast Cancer Walk. Long time and devoted coordinator of Hugh Volunteers for American Red Cross. He was awarded New York Red Cross Volunteer of the year in 1999. John delighted in portraying Santa Claus to entertain children in hospitals and shelters at Christmas time. Mass Friday 9:45AM at Resurrection Ascension Church. Interment in Calverton National Cemetery.

title: Technology Briefing
description: TELECOMMUNICATIONS

title: Patterns of a Can-Do Idealist
description: AT the very end of ''Over the Line: The Art and Life of Jacob Lawrence,'' at the Whitney Museum of American Art, are paintings from the ''Builders'' series, which the artist, who died last year, worked on through the last 30 years of his life. The pictures show men and women, black and white, perched on scaffolds, shouldering boards and hammering nails as they erect what is probably a skyscraper, given Lawrence's urbanite disposition. The figures don't relax or talk; they just work away side by side, their forms and those of the rising architecture locked together in big bright puzzles of color and line.

title: Zimbabwe Arrests Editor, Raising Fears of Wider Crackdown
description: The editor of Zimbabwe's only privately owned daily newspaper, The Daily News, was arrested today, for the second time in less than three months, raising fears of a widening crackdown by the government against its opposition ahead of next year's elections.

title: As Camby Heals, Questions of His Resolve Linger
description: A large part of the relationship between Latrell Sprewell and Marcus Camby involves good-natured ribbing. Whenever the two Knicks kid each other, Sprewell has a sure-fire way to quiet his friend: bring up the soft label.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Man Admits Hanging Dogs
description: A man who admitted hanging six dogs from a bicycle rack in his garage to avoid transporting them to his new home in Colorado pleaded guilty this week in Westchester County Court to six counts of aggravated animal cruelty, District Attorney Jeanine Pirro said yesterday. The man, Leonard Ammaturo, 51, a dog breeder who formerly lived in Goldens Bridge, said he killed the Akita dogs in March because he was moving and a veterinarian refused to kill the dogs because they were healthy. Under a plea deal, Mr. Ammaturo is to receive five years' probation and a $12,000 fine. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: John Berger -- 'Bodies-Places: Drawings'
description: Denise Cad Gallery

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARONSON, MICHAEL M.
description: ARONSON-Michael M., 28. November 5, 2001, Daytona Beach, FL. Beloved son of Alan and Barbara Aronson of Katonah, NY, and Ellen and Jan Stern of Ormond Beach, FL. Also survived by his three brothers, grandparents, aunts, uncles and cousins. Contributions may be made to Musicians on Call (hospital programs), 216 W. 18 St, #

title: Enron Admits to Overstating Profits by About $600 Million
description: The Enron Corporation yesterday sliced more than half a billion dollars from its reported profits over the last five years, but its crosstown rival, Dynegy Inc., still appeared to be willing to acquire Enron, executives close to the merger talks said.

title: Terror War Offers Russia New Hope For Membership
description: With China's membership in the World Trade Organization set to be sealed at the group's summit meeting in Qatar over the next few days, Russia remains the only big world power outside the global trade club.

title: Bush Seeks New Volunteer Force for Civil Defense
description: President Bush called tonight for the creation of a volunteer civil defense service and told the American people that the specter of a long war against terrorism within the United States would force the country to confront ''new responsibilities, both for the government and for our people.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 7 Jurors Picked For Sotheby's Case
description: Five men and two women were chosen yesterday as the first seven jurors in the criminal antitrust trial of A. Alfred Taubman, the former chairman and largest stockholder of Sotheby's, the auction house. The jurors include a health care aide, a transit worker, a restaurateur and a former prison guard in Puerto Rico. Judge George B. Daniels of United States District Court said he expected to seat the remaining five jurors and at least three alternates today. The judge said the trial, which involves charges that Sotheby's conspired to fix prices with a rival auction house, Christie's, to fix art prices, might take a month. Ralph Blumenthal (NYT)

title: One Month Into the Afghan War
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GACH, LILLY (BRUST)
description: GACH-Lilly (Brust). Died at home on November 8, 2001. She was 89 years old. She is survived by her loving daughter Eva Cooper and son-in-law Leslie. Adored grandmother of Lisa Friedland and her husband Ed Friedland. Devoted great grandmother to Adam, Peter, and Andy. Dear sister-in-law of Eleanor Shaw. We will all miss her. Services Friday, 12:45 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Battle on Broadway
description: To the Editor:

title: Longtime Congresswoman Will Step Down
description: Representative Marge Roukema, a moderate Republican and the elder stateswoman of New Jersey's Congressional delegation, announced today that she would not seek re-election next year, leaving open a seat that could hold promise for the Democrats.

title: Forget the Girl and Gold; Look for the Chemistry
description: In ''Heist,'' David Mamet applies himself to a creaky subgenre: the last-big-score picture, in which an aging master thief is paired with a cocky, not entirely reliable youngster. The formula has been worked over so many times in the past -- so many times this year, for that matter -- that even as shrewd an operator as Mr. Mamet may not have much to add. This director, whose film-making career has been a series of self-subverting genre exercises, plays it straight this time, and what ''Heist'' lacks in novelty it makes up for in solid entertainment.

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of Thursday, 4,559 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONNOR, MARY (NEE COSTELLO)
description: CONNOR-Mary (nee Costello). On November 6, 2001 in Coconut Creek, Florida. Beloved wife of the late Vincent. Devoted mother of Thomas, Catherine Morrell, Michael and the late Maureen Fitzgerald. Cherished by seven grandchildren and one greatgrandchild. Sister of John Costello and the late Donald Costello and Julia Satterlee. Visiting Friday 2-5 and 7-9PM McLaughlin & Sons FH, Third Avenue & 97th St. Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, 10 AM, St. Anselm's Church.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in the arts pages yesterday with a report about an auction of Colleen Dewhurst memorabilia at William Doyle Galleries referred incorrectly to a photograph among items for sale. It showed Ms. Dewhurst as Martha in ''Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?''; ''Martha'' was not the name of the play.

title: Republicans and Democrats Face New Reality in Nassau
description: Not long ago, a Democratic takeover of Nassau County government would have been more than a disappointment for Republicans. It would have been unthinkable.

title: Joseph Santore; Shawn Spencer
description: Edward Thorp Gallery

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GLOBAL CROSSING, Hamilton, Bermuda, owner of a telecommunications network, won a 12-year $700 million contract to provide service to Computer Sciences, El Segundo, Calif., a computer services company. Computer Sciences won a $400 million order from Global Crossing to run its personal and mainframe computers for 10 years.

title: Argentina's Leader Comes Begging, Burdened by More Bad News
description: President Fernando de la Ra's critical negotiations with opposition governors to curtail spending fell apart tonight, dealing him a severe setback just before he left for New York to seek emergency international help to avert a complete financial collapse.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, MILDRED R.
description: NEWMAN-Mildred R. We mourn the loss of our dear friend and extend heartfelt sympathy to her darling Bernie, and all of their family. It is impossible to think of Mildred except in superlatives: Extraordinary presence, gifted psychotherapist, brilliant in friendship, the compleat role model, courageous and victorious in life and work-much beloved. We will miss her. The Cowen-Scott FamilyDiane, Henry, Scotty and Will

description: European Central Bank And Britain Lower Rates

title: Advertising Declines in Magazines and Radio
description: Two media organizations have reported declines in advertising sales.

title: French Reporter Tells of Days Held in Jail by the Taliban
description: During the 25 days he was imprisoned by Afghanistan's Taliban authorities, Michel Peyrard, a French journalist, watched the makeshift jail where he was held fill with other prisoners.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STENGEL, KENNETH
description: STENGEL-Kenneth. The Board of Governors and we of North Shore Country Club record with deep sorrow the passing of our former employee and friend, Kenny Stengel. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. Peter J. Baum, President Dan Klonsky, Secretary

title: Exploring a Seaside Sentinel
description: Fort Tilden in Queens, a place of beauty and, in troubled times past, security.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Ex-Legislator Sentenced
description: A former Passaic County freeholder was sentenced yesterday to six months' house arrest and fined $25,000 for his involvement in awarding building contracts in exchange for bribes. The former freeholder, Charles J. Delahanty, pleaded guilty in Federal District Court to accepting $9,600 in bribes from 1994 to 1996. Mr. Delahanty was given a lesser sentence because he cooperated with prosecutors and testified against Nicola R. DiDonna, the former Passaic County administrator. Mr. DiDonna was sentenced in October to four months in prison.

title: A Trade Agenda Tempts Murphy's Law; U.S. Sees Talks as a Test of Leadership, But the Road to Qatar Was Rocky
description: Just about everything that could go wrong has gone wrong in the prelude to the global trade talks that begin on Friday in this Persian Gulf nation.

title: Why the Chicanery in Connecticut?
description: This has been exactly the kind of perfect autumn that can be so easily used to shore up the image of Connecticut on postcards, in movies, in the American mind. Parti-colored leaves tumble down from refulgent skies pierced by white Congregationalist steeples.

title: New Unemployment Claims Drop Sharply
description: The number of workers filing new claims for state unemployment benefits plunged last week to the lowest level in one-and-a-half months, suggesting that the pace of layoffs may be slowing, a government report showed today.

title: JoAnne Carson
description: Plus Ultra

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Swedesboro: Striking Workers To Return
description: Sixty-five truck drivers and other workers on strike at a Dunkin' Donuts distribution center plan to return to work Monday without a contract, labor and management officials said yesterday. The workers struck at a franchise-owned distribution center that supplies 1,400 franchises in eight states. They walked out in June after talks failed to produce their first contract as a new union bargaining unit. The management had hired replacement workers, but the strikers wanted to return while talks continued, said Rose Kelly, organizing director for Local 1360 of the United Food and Commercial Workers. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLATZER, ADELE
description: PLATZER-Adele. Of Lido Beach, NY. On November 7, 2001. Beloved wife of Philip. Devoted mother of Bruce and Francine Fox, Lauren Fox, and Sam and Hillary Fox. Adoring grandmother of Shelley, Jamie, Jonah, and Elijah Fox. Dear sister of Morton and Shirley Sloan, and Sydele and the late Harold Sloan. She was our golden girl who touched the lives of so many. She will live on in our hearts forever. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Light of Life Foundation, C/O Platzer, 2 Richmond Rd., Lido Beach, NY 11561.

title: Fire Commissioner to Leave, Proud, if Sad and Bewildered
description: A double funeral had just let out from St. Patrick's Cathedral on Monday afternoon when a group of California firefighters stopped Thomas Von Essen, the New York City fire commissioner.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in Business Day on Wednesday about Polo Ralph Lauren's financial results for its second quarter omitted a credit. The source was Bloomberg News.

title: More to Satisfy 'Matrix' Mania
description: Joel Silver, producer of "The Matrix" and two new "Matrix" movies now being filmed simultaneously in Australia, has some time on his hands.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Condit's Son Joins Race
description: Chad Condit, who abandoned all thoughts of running for the State Assembly next year after his father, United States Representative Gary A. Condit, came under fire for the Chandra Levy matter, is now planning to run for the State Senate. On Wednesday, the younger Mr. Condit, left, like his father a Democrat, filed a notice of intent to seek the seat held by State Senator Dick Monteith, a Republican. Mr. Monteith in turn is running for the seat of Congressman Condit, who appears ready to seek an eighth term. Barbara Whitaker (NYT)

title: As U.N. Meets, Bin Laden Tape Sets Off Alarms
description: As scores of world leaders converge on New York this week for the United Nations General Assembly, Osama bin Laden's latest message to the world has provoked profound new security concerns for the United Nations and its global work force.

title: One Month Into the Afghan War
description: To the Editor:

title: Legacy Passed From Legend To Legend at Grambling
description: Slivers of sunlight stream through half-closed blinds as Doug Williams sits in his office at Grambling State University. Williams is in an athletic building named after the former coach Eddie Robinson, adjacent to the school's stadium, also named after Robinson.

title: Separating Death From Agony
description: Not long ago, a cancer specialist I know faced a situation that chilled those of us who care for people with terminal illness. A young woman close to death lay suffering in a hospital bed, her husband at her side. Her leukemia had defied bone marrow transplant and experimental drugs. She had begun to bleed into her lungs and was gasping for air.

title: Major Clients Award Big Accounts to 2 Shops
description: Major advertisers are making decisions on large accounts.

title: U.S. Red Cross to Keep Withholding World Dues Over Israel Issue
description: The top American Red Cross official told the national societies at a meeting here today that the United States chapter would continue to withhold its dues until a way was found to admit the Israeli counterpart, Magen David Adom.

title: Blizzard of Goals Cools Isles
description: It was impossible to tell, but Peter Laviolette had just absorbed the worst loss of his brief career as an N.H.L. coach.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about conservatives' criticism of networks' coverage of the war in Afghanistan gave an erroneous name in some copies for an organization that hires monitors to watch newscasts. It is the Media Research Center, not Council.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELIGSOHN, SARA
description: SELIGSOHN-Sara. The board and staff of NJCD/Yachad mourn the passing of Mrs. Sara Seligsohn, beloved mother of our esteemed board member Jerry (Sandra) Seligsohn. May the family know of no further sorrow and be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Jeffrey Lichtman, Nat'l. Dir. Steven Spira, Nat'l Chairman

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: The Minnow, as the name might suggest, is small, and it specializes in fish. The chef and owner, Aaron Bashy, grew up in New England, spent several years cooking at Le Bernardin and for a time was the executive chef at Alva, so the cod, the clam and the calamari have been his constant companions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIEDEKE, DONALD KURZ
description: FIEDEKE-Donald Kurz. Died October 19, 2001 at the age of 70. Donald started his working history with J. Walter Thompson. He then travelled to Spain and owned and operated three restaurants. Finally returning to the U.S. to become executive chef at Saks Fifth Avenue, Batus & Triangle Industries. He then opened a successful B & B in Brooklyn. For anyone wishing to pay their final respects you can make contributions to the American Cancer Society. Burial was at the Goshen Indiana Cemetery in the Fiedeke family plot.

title: Capture of City Would Provide First Victory in U.S. Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9  The capture of Mazar-i-Shaif would deliver the first tangible victory for the American-led military campaign against the Taliban after more than a month of war.

title: Van Gogh-Getters
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Slide Show: High-Flying Flags at the N.Y. C. Marathon
An Easy Bargain With Russia
description: When President Bush and Vladimir Putin meet next week, one aim will be to resolve differences about the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty. With much at stake in the war against terror and in Russia's hopes to be seen as a part of the West, no one wants the developing closeness of the United States and Russia to be held back by the old argument about an American missile shield.

title: Editors' Note; Today's Sections
description: News of the Sept. 11 attacks and their aftermath continues to appear in Section B; index, Page B2.

title: Racing Daylight
description: For some reason, every stage in this advancing season has brought with it a feeling of incredulity. A few weeks ago it seemed unbelievable that the leaves should be turning so soon and then that they should have dropped so promptly. Now, just this week, it seems incredible that snow should have fallen out of a goose-gray sky, skidding eastward toward the missing sun. I wake up, like everyone else, thinking ''November already'' and realize that ''already'' is a word that's been with me all autumn long, always measuring how far behind the season I feel.

title: Office Vacancy Rate Climbs in New York
description: New York's office vacancy rate rose to 9.9 percent in October, the highest since 1998, as Merrill Lynch, Salomon Smith Barney and other financial firms shed workers and excess space.

title: All Signs Indicate the Nets Are Headed the Right Way
description: Invigorated by a sunny morning after the best game of his professional career, a gleeful Todd MacCulloch put the top down on his Porsche going to work this morning, hoping for a joy ride, if not more room for his 7-foot frame.

title: SHARES OF KETCHUP MAKER FALL ON EARNINGS OUTLOOK
description: Shares of the H. J. Heinz Company fell yesterday after the company, the biggest ketchup maker, said that its fiscal second-quarter earnings would miss forecasts and that its profit projections for the year would be lowered. Heinz said late Thursday that lower sales to restaurants and hotels and higher costs in Australia, New Zealand and Japan had reduced earnings in its second quarter, ended Oct. 31. Food service sales were $25 million to $30 million less than a year earlier because fewer people are eating out or traveling, Heinz said. Heinz, based in Pittsburgh, now expects second-quarter earnings of 59 cents to 60 cents a share, compared with an earlier forecast of 64 cents to 66 cents.

title: CRITICAL PATH, E-MAIL PROVIDER, SETS SUIT SETTLEMENT
description: Critical Path, a corporate e-mail provider plagued by financial troubles, said earlier this week that it would pay $17.5 million and issue warrants on 850,000 shares to settle a class-action shareholder lawsuit. The company also announced yesterday a deal for $95 million in financing, led by General Atlantic Partners. Earlier this year, the company, based in San Francisco, restated earnings for two quarters because of financial irregularities, dismissed top executives and laid off half its work force. The company said it had since reduced its debt to $35 million, from $300 million. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Ex-Starter a Symbol of Bears' New Status
description: Three weeks ago, with a victory at Cincinnati, the Chicago Bears won their fourth straight game. The Bears have won six straight now, lead the National Football Conference Central division with a 6-1 record and will reach for midseason glory against the Green Bay Packers (5-2) tomorrow at Soldier Field.

title: Initial Steps by Bloomberg Show Contrast With Giuliani
description: In the 72 hours since he was elected to lead New York City, Michael R. Bloomberg has made numerous gestures -- both symbolic and substantive -- that appear to demonstrate he is not the man whose coattails he rode into office.

title: INSIDE
description: Progress on Climate Treaty

title: PAKISTANI LEADER SEEKS  'GESTURES' FOR  BACKING  U.S.
description: President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan said yesterday that he has come to the United States in search of major gestures from the Bush administration, including the release of American F-16 fighters sold to Pakistan when it was an ally against the Soviet Union and then withheld because of the country's development of nuclear weapons.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Poll Shows Incumbent Slipping
description: A Democratic poll shows Senator Gordon Smith's lead over his Democratic challenger falling to 7 percentage points from 12 points in February. Mr. Smith, a Republican, was chosen by 44 percent of likely voters, with Secretary of State Bill Bradbury getting 37 percent. Mr. Bradbury became the probable Democratic nominee after Gov. John Kitzhaber and Representative Peter DeFazio declined to run. The Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee poll, by Grove Quirk Insight, Ltd., tested 500 likely voters and had a margin of error of plus or minus 4.4 percentage points. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Rebel With Long Career of Picking Fights (and Sides)
description: Gen. Abdul Rashid Dostum, whose forces were apparently taking control of Mazar-i-Sharif, an important crossroads in northern Afghanistan, last night, is the very model of a modern Uzbek warlord.

title: A Western Front: Is Iraq Next?
description: To the Editor:

title: IRAN CHIEF REJECTS BIN LADEN MESSAGE
description: President Mohammad Khatami of Iran yesterday branded as extremist Osama bin Laden's version of Islam and said it did not represent the majority of the world's 1.2 billion Muslims.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, DAVID W.
description: LEWIS-David W. On November 7, 2001. Died peacefully in his 97th year following a short illness. Beloved husband of Muriel. Devoted father of Stephen, Daniel, and Robert, and daughters-in-law Suzanna, Claudia, and Stacey. Adored grandfather of Rachel, Aaron, Matthew, Ethan, Jennifer and Samuel. Loving brother of the late Charles Lewis, the late Alice Berman and the late Florence Shafran. He was the former President and CEO of Certified Moving & Storage Company, a founder of the Riverdale Temple, a Trustee of the Riverdale YM/YWHA, and a former Federation of Jewish Charities Chairman for the Moving and Storage Industy. Services at the Riverdale Temple, Monday, November 12, 2001 at 11:30 A.M.; interment is at Mount Lebanon Cemetery. Donations may be made to the Riverdale Temple and Riverdale YM/YWHA.

title: The Battle for Mazar-i-Sharif
description: The first important military victory of the war against terrorism seemed close at hand yesterday, with reports by Northern Alliance forces that they had taken the northern Afghanistan stronghold of Mazar-i-Sharif. Capture of the city, which has been under Taliban rule, would provide an important military, psychological and political boost to the American-led campaign to drive the Taliban from power and bring Osama bin Laden to justice. But because the city is separated from the southern population centers of Afghanistan by nearly impassable mountains, the fall of Mazar-i-Sharif is not likely to lead to the Taliban's rapid collapse.

title: 'Hit to Kill'
description: In the autumn of 1944, the terror and destruction of German V-2 rockets, traveling faster than the speed of sound and slamming one-ton-explosive loads into British neighborhoods, marked the dawn of the missile age. At the end of the war, the Allies learned of Nazi plans to build a larger, two-stage rocket that might have been able to span the Atlantic Ocean, enabling Germany to make good on its intention of striking the United States. This revelation prompted Americans to question whether they could ever feel secure from missile attack.

title: U. of Georgia Won't Contest Ruling on Admissions Policy
description: The University of Georgia said today that it would not fight a federal appeals court ruling that an admissions policy that gave a slight edge to minority applicants was unconstitutional.

title: China's Record in Tibet
description: To the Editor:

title: Rival to Buy Enron, Top Energy Trader, After Financial Fall
description: With its stock plunging and its finances in doubt, the world's largest energy trader, the Enron Corporation, agreed to be acquired yesterday by the rival Dynegy Inc. for about $9 billion in stock and the assumption of $13 billion in debt.

title: Rise in a Pay-Phone Rate
description: By Bloomberg News

title: Bush Chides Some Members of Coalition for Inaction in War Against Terrorism
description: President Bush expressed impatience today with nations that he said had done little in the war against terrorism beyond offering condolences, and said he would use an address to the United Nations General Assembly on Saturday to make the case that ''the time for sympathy is over.''

title: To Rebuild a Place That Lost So Much
description: To the Editor:

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of Friday, 4,547 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11.

title: To Rebuild a Place That Lost So Much
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Churchill'
description: Churchill's provenance was aristocratic, indeed ducal, and some have seen this as the most important key to his whole career. That is unconvincing. Churchill was far too many faceted, idiosyncratic and unpredictable a character to allow himself to be imprisoned by the circumstances of his birth. His devotion to his career and his conviction that he was a man of destiny were far stronger than any class or tribal loyalty. There have been politicians of high duty and honour — Edward Halifax and Alec Douglas-Home immediately spring to mind — who did see life through spectacles much bounded by their landed background. But Churchill was emphatically not among them. Apart from anything else, he never had any land beyond his shaky ownership (and later only occupation) of the 300 acres surrounding Chartwell, the West Kent house only twenty-four miles from London which he bought in 1922 and just managed, with financial subventions from friends, to cling on to for the remaining four decades of his life.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Airline Loan Shift
description: Sabena, Belgium's bankrupt national airline, can pass an unused $111.6 million bridge loan from the Belgian government to its subsidiary, Delta Air Transport, the European Commission said. The loan, the commission said, is short-term rescue aid and is open to any part of Sabena as long as it is not used to finance a restructuring. The Belgian prime minister, Guy Verhofstadt, said yesterday that his government had commitments for $178.6 million in financing from 12 lenders to help the Delta unit establish itself. The Brussels bankruptcy court, however, has yet to rule on whether the subsidiary can take over Sabena's operations. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Women and Prosperity
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan's Revised Forecast Sees Deepest Slump in 2 Decades
description: The Japanese government, acknowledging what investors figured out months ago, lowered its economic forecasts for this fiscal year and now expects its economy, the second largest in the world, to contract at its fastest pace in more than two decades.

title: Europe Moving Toward Ban On Internet Hate Speech
description: The 43-nation Council of Europe is trying to ban racist and hate speech from the Internet by adding a protocol, or side agreement, to its cybercrime convention, which was stamped for ratification on Thursday. The convention is scheduled to be formally ratified at a meeting in Budapest Nov. 23.

title: After a Disappointing Year, a Difficult Off-Season Is Looming for the Mets
description: Mike Piazza has made a career of proving people wrong, so he could always do it again. Piazza might really be as different as the Mets say he is, as close to indestructible as a catcher has ever been.

title: 'The Age of Homespun'
description: The basket is four and a half inches high and four inches in diameter, about the size of a large tomato can, though smaller at the top than the bottom. When new it could have held a generous pound of meal or beans or twenty-four fathoms of wampum. Now light leaks through a weft ravaged by time and insects. The basket holds it shape through hundreds of invisible mends, the unseen art of a conservation lab. Tiny twists of rice paper bonded with unpronounceable adhesives like polyvinal acetate and polymethyl methacrylate fill gaps in a fragile fabric strengthened by multiple infusions of soluble nylon in ethyl alcohol. Would the basket be as precious without its story?

title: Chief Democrat To Resign Dec. 3
description: Three days after the Democratic Party suffered a stunning defeat in the New York City mayoral election, Judith Hope, the state party chairwoman, announced she would resign Dec. 3.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DESATNICK, RUTH
description: DESATNICK-Ruth. On November 9, 2001. Beloved daughter of the late Keva and Etta. Dear sister of Belle and Julius Meiman and the late Esther Desatnick. Devoted aunt of Kevie and Martin Michael. Loving great aunt of Evan Michael. Service Sunday 11:00AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dynegy Plans to Acquire Enron for $9 Billion in Stock

title: Kidnapped New Jersey Girl Reunited With Parents
description: A 6-year-old girl whose family had fled their apartment in Lower Manhattan after the Sept. 11 terror attack was found this morning, safe and apparently unharmed, a day after she was abducted from her front yard here.

title: Corrections
description: A chart with the Economic Scene column in Business Day on Nov. 1 showing the percentage of economic output spent by nations on development aid to poor countries mislabeled the dollar figures. They were billions, not millions.

title: Early Test for Bloomberg: Shaping Police Strategy
description: After months of tailoring himself as the seamless heir to the Giuliani era, Michael R. Bloomberg faces his first big decision, one that is likely to be shaped, in large part, by a man who came to prominence under Mayor David N. Dinkins.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Nomura Investor To Open Fund
description: Guy Hands, a wealthy British private-equity specialist, is negotiating his departure from Nomura Holdings of Japan to establish a separate fund called Terra Firma Capital Partners, people close to the discussions said. Mr. Hands will take 70 members of his team with him, and the deal is expected to be completed by March of next year. Mr. Hands, 41, has invested some $16 billion since 1995 when he joined Nomura, Japan's biggest securities company, after working for Goldman Sachs. In that period he made Nomura, Europe's leading private-equity investor, into Britain's biggest pub landlord and bought luxury hotels and German real estate. Nomura will invest in the new fund, for which Mr. Hands wants to raise $2.7 billion, the people close to the discussions said, adding that the details of the arrangement were still being negotiated. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Fledgling Punter Steps Forward After Six-Year Layoff to Do the Kicking for the Giants
description: Owen Pochman remembers the last time he stood behind the line of scrimmage waiting for the ball to be snapped to him for a punt. It was at Mercer Island High School in Washington, where, a proud Pochman says, he never had a punt blocked. But that was six years ago, and the punting he did there did not do much to prepare him for what he will face Sunday in Arizona against the Cardinals.

title: GRANDDAUGHTER OF FOUNDING FAMILY GETS CRUCIAL JOB
description: Another member of the founding family has landed a new job at the Ford Motor Company. Elena Ford, 35, a granddaughter of the former chief executive Henry Ford II, was named group brand manager of Mercury, a spokeswoman, Nancy Carollo, said yesterday. The appointment was one of four that Ford, the No. 2 automaker, has made in its Lincoln Mercury division, based in Irvine, Calif. Ms. Ford had been director of e-solutions in Ford's marketing department, a position related to Internet ventures. William Clay Ford Jr., a nephew of Mr. Ford, was named chief executive last week.

title: Editors' Note; COMING ON SUNDAY
description: THE NEXT NEW YORK

title: Giovanni Leone, Italy's Ex-President, Dies at 93
description: Giovanni Leone, a former president of Italy noted for his cheerful bonhomie and successful negotiations as a senator to bring about his country's first divorce law, died yesterday at his home outside Rome. He was 93.

title: Afghan Rebels Report Capture Of Major City From the Taliban
description: Forces opposed to the Taliban have captured the key northern city of Mazar-i-Sharif after a days of bombing and a firefight that sent Taliban forces fleeing, both rebel and Taliban officials said today.
