Control of the town will give the rebels an important airfield and the route north to Uzbekistan, where American soldiers are stationed 100 miles over the border.

title: Ski Savings
description: This time of year makes some travelers think of the Caribbean, while others think about snow. For the latter, Maxxim Vacations, a Canadian tour operator, offers a ski package to Mont-Tremblant, Quebec, starting at $899 a person, based on double occupancy. It includes round-trip air fare from New York to Montreal, a five-day car rental, a four-day lift ticket and four nights' accommodations. From Boston or Philadelphia, prices start at $929 a person, double; Chicago or Detroit, $939; Atlanta, $999; and Los Angeles, $1,099. Information: (800) 567-6666 or www.maxximvacations.com .

title: BERKSHIRE HATHAWAY POSTS LOSS ON ATTACK CLAIMS
description: Berkshire Hathaway Inc., the investment vehicle of Warren E. Buffett, had a third-quarter loss, reflecting $2.2 billion in insurance claims from the attacks that destroyed the World Trade Center. The company -- which owns General Re, the car insurer Geico and a range of other companies and investments -- posted a third-quarter net loss of $679 million, or $4.45 a share, in contrast to a profit of $797 million, or $5.23, a year earlier. Under Mr. Buffett, Berkshire has been raising prices in its flagship insurance operations to improve profits after several years of bigger-than-expected losses. General Re's top credit ratings and ample capital may allow it to benefit more than most insurers from the ability to raise rates since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, which caused an estimated $70 billion in insured losses, analysts said. Together, Geico, General Re and Berkshire's other insurance interests account for 60 percent of the company's revenue.

title: Little Airplay for Al Qaeda Rebuttal to Bush
description: Establishing what could become a pattern of direct response by videotape to statements by President Bush, Osama bin Laden's chief lieutenant said yesterday that the president had lied in a speech on Thursday night when he said the United States was destroying Al Qaeda and the Taliban forces.

title: Financial Officer Named
description: Coach Inc., a maker of leather accessories whose shares have almost doubled since shares were first sold to the public in October 2000, yesterday named Michael F. Devine III its chief financial officer. Mr. Devine, 43, joins Coach from the maternity-clothing retailer, Mothers Work Inc., replacing Richard Randall, who left to pursue other opportunities, Coach said. Mothers Work said that Mr. Devine will stay on as its chief financial officer until Nov. 30. It has already begun the search for a replacement.

title: Abroad at Home; Ideology As Usual
description: George W. Bush has focused effectively on the need for an international alliance against terrorism. But he has not yet understood what a wartime president has to do at home: Put aside ideological politics so he can be president of all the people.

title: Straight Talk and Uplift
description: Angie Stone means it when she calls her music soul. Not funk, not R&B, not hip-hop, not urban, but soul, the secular pop with gospel fervor behind it. At the Supper Club on Tuesday night, introducing her new album ''Mahogany Soul'' (J Records), her songs were churchy testimony to the power of love when things get tough.

title: Loss Leaves Schundler In Search of Political Role
description: In a race full of difficult moments, Bret D. Schundler left his party pondering one final awkward note after he was trounced by James E. McGreevey on Tuesday night.

title: ADELPHIA COMMUNICATIONS TO SPIN OFF UNIT AND CUT DEBT
description: The Adelphia Communications Corporation, a heavily indebted cable television operator, said yesterday that it would sell assets and securities and spin off a telephone business as it reported a wider third-quarter loss. Analysts expect it to cut debt by as much as $5.7 billion, or 42 percent, to $7.8 billion under the plan. Adelphia, based in Coudersport, Pa., will sell $950 million in shares and bonds convertible into stock to raise money to pay down debt, its chief financial officer, Tim Rigas, said on a conference call with analysts and investors. The company will pare debt by another $1.7 billion by spinning off its 79 percent stake in the business-phone provider Adelphia Business Solutions Inc.

title: Iris Murdoch
description: REVIEWS

title: National Briefing | Washington: Advocates Unhappy With Voting Bill
description: Civil rights advocates said they were disappointed with draft language in a House bill to overhaul the nation's voting system. Hilary O. Shelton, director of the Washington bureau of the N.A.A.C.P., said the bill, proposed by Representatives Bob Ney, Republican of Ohio, and Steny H. Hoyer, Democrat of Maryland, gave states too much discretion on civil rights provisions. Jim Dickson, vice president of the American Association of People with Disabilities, said the bill gave too much leeway to state legislatures over accessibility issues. The groups plan to meet with Mr. Hoyer next week before the bill is introduced. Katharine Q. Seelye (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article last Saturday about research at St. Louis University on the effectiveness of diluted smallpox vaccine misstated results of a similar study by the same researchers last year. It showed effective immunization of 70 percent of subjects who were given vaccine diluted to one-tenth its original strength, not one-fifth. The study also produced what the researchers described as disappointing results with vaccine diluted to one-hundredth its original strength, not one-tenth.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about changes in American military strategy as the war in Afghanistan develops misspelled the given name of a scholar who spoke about the poor chances of forming anti-Taliban resistance in southern Afghanistan. She is Rosanne Klass, not Roseanne.

title: A Banker Leaving Seoul Warns Against Bailouts
description: Wilfred Horie, lured to Korea nearly two years ago to run a troubled bank, has a word of advice for investors who are thinking about bankrolling large companies on the brink of failure: follow his example and do not do it.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN FALLS. The yen dropped after a Ministry of Finance official stoked concerns that the Bank of Japan will sell yen to increase exporters' earnings. In New York, the dollar settled at 120.20 yen, up from 120.04.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Ericsson To Invest $5 Billion
description: Ericsson, the biggest maker of wireless telephone networks, said yesterday that it planned to double its investment in China to $5 billion in five years to expand its share there. ''Asia is the fastest-growing market for Ericsson,'' Kurt Hellstrom, the chief executive, said at a Hong Kong conference. Ericsson's move comes as Beijing prepares to play host to the 2008 Olympics, and some of Ericsson's rivals have also announced expanded investments there. Motorola, the second-largest mobile-phone maker, said on Thursday that it would triple its investment in China in the next five years, to $10 billion from $3.4 billion. China accounts for half of Ericsson's business in Asia.

title: U.N. Will Send Food to Zimbabwe's Hungry
description: The World Food Program has announced that it will begin providing emergency food aid to more than half a million Zimbabweans, a stark indication of a deepening hunger crisis in a country that has traditionally been one of Africa's most self-sufficient.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: TODAY'S KEY GAMES

title: Opening With Audacious Haydn, Continuing With Grittiness
description: Petersen Quartet

title: Israeli Arabs' Role Raised By Legislator Facing Trial
description: Savoring a cup of coffee and a cigarette begged from a waiter, Azmi Bishara sat in a hotel lobby this morning and contemplated the legal battle awaiting him. In a matter of weeks, he said, maybe in two or three months, his trial will begin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULLIVAN, MARK A.
description: SULLIVAN-Mark A., Honorable. 90. Of Spring Lake, NJ on Friday, November 9, 2001. Judge Sullivan was appointed to the Second District Court of Jersey City in 1945, the Superior Court of NJ in 1953, and the Supreme Court of NJ in 1973. During his tenure on the Supreme Court, he served as Acting Chief Justice on several occasions. Husband of the late Josephine Hamill, father of the Honorable Mark A. Sullivan, Superior Court New Jersey, brother of Joseph M. Sullivan, Winifred Sullivan, and grandfather of Mary Beth Sullivan. Mass of Christian Burial Monday November 12th, 9 AM, St. Catharine's R.C. Church, Spring Lake, NJ. Burial St. Anne's Cemetery, Wall, NJ. Visitation Sunday 2-4, 7-9 PM, at Meehan Funeral Home, 555 Warren Avenue, Spring Lake Heights, N.J., (732)449-4000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENBERG, VIVIANE
description: EISENBERG - Viviane. Died peacefully in her sleep on November 7 at her home in Delray Beach, FL. Survived by Everett, her loving husband of many years. She was 88 years old. Viviane was a Parisienne for the first half of her life. She was a diva, as Viviane Toubiana, singing to great acclaim the lyric roles Butterfly, Boheme, Traviata, etc, etc, for l'Opera de Paris, l'Opera Comique and in opera houses throughout Europe and North Africa. Then she became a New Yorker, living in Manhattan until recently. Gatherings of remembrance will be convened in Delray Beach, New York and Paris.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEE, ESSIE E., ED.D.
description: LEE-Essie E., Ed.D. The Board of Trustees, officers, staff and residents of Odyssey House mourn the passing of Dr. Essie E. Lee, a devoted and beloved member of the Odyssey House Board of Trustees for more than 15 years. Her dedication to serving the men, women, and children in treatment at Odyssey House for substance abuse and mental health problems was a source of inspiration to our community. We extend our deepest sympathies to her loved ones. Services Tuesday, November 13th, 11:30 AM, at Christ Chapel, Riverside Church, 490 Riverside Drive. Dana Meltzer, Chairperson Peter Provet, President

title: U.N. Official Fears China Uses Terror War as Front for Abuses
description: The top United Nations human rights official expressed concern here today that the American-led campaign against terrorism had given license to the Chinese government to intensify a crackdown against its Muslim minority and members of the banned Falun Gong spiritual sect.

title: Rangers Show Potential In Victory Against Isles
description: During the franchise's dark days in the 1950's, Rangers goaltender Gump Worsley was asked which team was toughest for him. ''The Rangers,'' Worsley, a Hall of Famer, replied.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADELHARDT, ANDREW J.
description: ADELHARDT-Andrew J. Of Massapequa on November 8, 2001. Retired president of Adelhardt Construction Corporation N.Y.C. Graduate of Syracuse University School of Architecture. Former chairman, board of trustees Old Westbury School of The Holy Child. Former president of Mechanics Institute. Former trustee Portsmouth Abbey School. Former president American Lung Association of Queens. Beloved husband of Barbara. Devoted father of Andrew J. III and wife Catherine, Susan Adelhardt & husband David Whitney, Mary and husband Scott Thompson, David and wife Suzanne. Dear brother of Anita Zimmon and Helen Hammond. Cherished grandfather of Andrew J. IV and Anna. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Ronald McDonald House, 405 East 73rd St., N.Y.C. 10021, would be appreciated.

title: Cheers to the Jets, Longtime Tenants at the Meadowlands
description: There is an old story about the Jets and the home-field advantage and it goes like this: The Jets do not have a home, so they do not have an advantage.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Practicing For Nuclear Disaster
description: The government said it would conduct mock exercises next week to test how its civil defense system would cope with a simulated nuclear accident that contaminated a wide area of the country and forced millions of people into bomb shelters. Although the drill has been in preparation for a year, it coincides with new concerns about how the country would respond if confronted with biological, chemical or nuclear terrorism or accidents. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Stockbroker Is Arrested
description: India's top law enforcement agency, the Central Bureau of Investigation, arrested Harshad Mehta, a stockbroker accused in a $1.3 billion stock market scandal almost a decade ago. The 1992 scandal rocked the Indian stock markets and left thousands of small investors poorer and shaken. Along with Mr. Mehta, the bureau arrested his two brothers, Ashwini and Sudhir, also in Bombay, and charged them with misappropriating millions of shares of 90 different companies. Harshad Mehta, popularly known as Big Bull, caused a huge stock market boom in the early 1990's by manipulating prices. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Agency Looks Into Claim Doctor Had Skin Anthrax
description: A cardiologist in New Jersey said yesterday that he thought he might have contracted skin anthrax in the first week of September.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JEFFREY, MICHAEL
description: JEFFREY-Michael. Age 65. Of Cornelius, N.C. died Thursday, November 8, 2001 at his residence. He was born May 4, 1936 in Jamaica, New York to Paul and Miriam Jeffrey. Funeral services will be held 1:00 Saturday, November 10, 2001 at Harry & Bryant Chapel in the Oaks, 500 Providence Road, with Mr. Gene Smith officiating. Interment will follow in Forest Lawn East Cemetery, Matthews, N.C. Mr. Jeffrey is survived by his mother, Miriam Jeffrey; his wife Lynn Jeffrey; daughters, Judith Rojas and Catherine Ilson both of Matthews, N.C, and son, Steve Jeffrey; brother, Andrew Jeffrey and eight grandchildren. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be sent to Hospice at Charlotte, 1420 East Seventh Street, Cahrlotte, N.C. 28204.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: More Women Seek Abortions
description: More than 1,700 Irish women traveled to England to have abortions in the second quarter of this year, the highest quarterly figure recorded. The actual figure could be much higher since many Irish women give false addresses in England. The Irish Family Planning Association estimates that more than 7,000 Irish women will have abortions in England in 2001, compared with more than 6,000 in 1999 and more than 5,000 in 1997. The government plans a referendum next year to tighten the ban on abortion. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLMAN, BENJAMIN
description: ELLMAN-Benjamin, 86. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, great grandfather, patriarch and source of strength and guidance to all who knew him. Survived by his loving wife Pearl, son Mark and his wife Nancy, daughter Lois, grandchildren Jeff and his wife Sonya, Diana and Eric and great grandson Colin. Funeral services will be held Sunday, November 11 at 10AM, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 W Broad St, Mt Vernon, NY.

title: Disappearing in America
description: Thousands of detainees being held in secret by the government; wiretaps on prisoners' conversations with their lawyers; public debate about the advisability of using torture to make suspects talk. Two months into the war against terrorism, the nation is sliding toward the trap that we entered this conflict vowing to avoid. Civil liberties are eroding, and there is no evidence that the reason is anything more profound than fear and frustration.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Tool Maker Will Lay Off 2,000
description: Sandvik will cut as many as 2,000 more jobs by the end of next year, as the company, the biggest maker of metal-cutting tools, faces waning demand from manufacturers in the United States and Europe, the company said. Sandvik will trim 6.7 percent of its staff by the end of next year, including 300 job losses already announced. It is cutting 1,000 workers at its tools division and will probably shed as many in steel and mining, the chief executive, Clas Aake Hedstroem, said in an interview.

title: U.S. Strengthens Security at Borrowed Uzbek Air Base
description: All day long the trucks come and go, ferrying gravel to the Khanabad air base.

title: A Bright, Soaring Delivery For Wild Romantic Fantasies
description: Jimmy Webb and Paul Williams

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUHN, LOUIS
description: KUHN-Louis. Loving husband of Lee (61 years); father of Robert (Pasadena, CA & NYC) & Karen (Paradise Valley, AZ); father-inlaw of Dora Kuhn & Stuart Troyan; adoring grandfather of Aaron, Adam, Daniella, Ross & Michael. Born: May 18, 1912 in New York; died: November 7, 2001, in his 90th year, in Phoenix. Founder & president, Chief Apparel, Inc. and affiliated manufacturing companies. W.W. II service in Europe. A good and decent man; strong, handsome, vital and radiant; wonderful sense of humor, always with a smile, often with a twinkle. Devoted family man; very charitable; enjoyed reading, math, chocolate. An inventor late in life. An athlete all his life: punchball on the city streets (Lower East Side); baseball (All-City); basketball (college center); handball (playing doubles into his 70s, the combined ages of the three other players on the handball court-added up!-would often be less than his). Funeral service 11:30 AM, Sunday, Nov. 11, at Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI, NY.

title: Compensating Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: In Covenant Marriage, Forging Ties That Bind
description: By the time Dewaldon and Rita Frazier found each other at Gloryland Baptist Church, they had both learned a thing or two about the heart's capacity to falter and rise again. He had left the Army in disgrace, living with a prostitute and mainlining heroin. She had had a daughter out of wedlock and divorced a faithless husband.

title: Anthrax Report Fixes on Victims' Stories
description: It took just four to six days after exposure for the first symptoms to appear, usually a mild to moderate fever, drenching sweats and overwhelming fatigue. And once the disease took hold, death, if it occurred, came a day or two later.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCMAHON, ROBERT D. (BOBBY)
description: McMAHON-Robert D. (Bobby). Member of Ladder 20, FDNY, who lost his life while heroically saving others in the World Trade Center Disaster of September 11, 2001. Beloved husband of Julie (nee Siard). Devoted father of Matthew Clifford, with Julie expecting their second child. He will be remembered as a loving son to Irene Siroka, Robert McMahon and his stepmother Nancy. Cherished brother of Andrew, Irene, Tony, Damon, Michael, Peter McMahon, Michele Pomara and Gina Giammarino (nee Ingrisano). As a member of a very large family, he will be missed by his 4 nephews and one niece, many cousins and his inlaws. Bobby was also a true friend to many, he will be deeply missed & forever remembered. Reposing at the Kennedy-Roth Funeral Homes, Inc. 41-45 58th Street Woodside, NY Sunday 2-5, 7-9 P.M. His mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at the St. Sebastian R.C. Church Woodside, Monday 10:30 A.M. Interment to follow at Calvary Cemetery.

title: Fresh Pain at Plaza Downtown; Refurbished Vietnam Memorial Is Dedicated, 11/9/01
description: In the end, the World Trade Center tragedy never stopped intruding.

title: 2 Boys, 6 and 9, Die in Newark Crash
description: Two boys, ages 6 and 9, were killed last night in a car crash in Newark, and the police were investigating the incident as a possible case of assault, murder and carjacking.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, RUTH PORTER
description: KLEIN-Ruth Porter. A lifelong teacher who designed pioneering courses in reading for both remedial and advanced students, died on October 27, 2001 at the age of 88 at her home in Sarasota, Florida. Ms. Klein taught at Hewlett High School in Long Island, New York, from 1954 through 1973, and was named a New York State Teacher of the Year. She was also an artist, and her portrait of Supreme Court Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes hangs in the Brooklyn Law School. She was married for 48 years to Solomon Asa Klein, a lawyer and professor of law. She is survived by her daughters, Susan Klein of Bainbridge Island, Washington and Laura Feldbaum of Bethesda, Maryland, and by two grandchildren, Harley Feldbaum and Mia Feldbaum.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Protest At School Lifted
description: In what they said was a goodwill gesture, Protestants in the Ardoyne neighborhood of north Belfast suspended their protest outside the Holy Cross Girls' Primary School yesterday morning for the first time since Sept. 3 to avoid upsetting the girls before they took the secondary school admissions exam. In a significant scaling down of their security presence, the police no longer wear riot gear while guarding the route to the school. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: After Asking for Volunteers, Government Tries to Determine What They Will Do
description: A day after President Bush asked Americans to respond to the war on terror with an outpouring of volunteerism, his administration began trying to figure out how to mobilize a vast force of Americans for a still sketchy role on the home front battlefield.

title: American Sikhs Contend They Have Become a Focus of Profiling at Airports
description: Dr. Jasjit S. Ahluwalia had just attended a research conference about carcinogens in tobacco and was racing to catch a plane at the Minneapolis airport when he was stopped by a member of the National Guard.

title: Edgemont Seeking Another Championship
description: At first glance, Edgemont High School does not appear to have the typical trappings of a strong football program. The school is located next to Scarsdale in Westchester County, N.Y., and does not even field a junior varsity squad. No one is cut from the team at tryouts, and this is the first season the team has had more than 24 players. But appearances, in this case, are deceiving.

title: Board Sees $45 Million Gap In Nassau's Budget for 2002
description: Edging closer than ever to a fiscal takeover of Nassau County government, a state oversight board rejected the county's 2002 budget plan today, declaring it to be in the red by up to $45 million.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the approval of five City Charter revision proposals misattributed the creation of the Organized Crime Control Bureau, the Commission on Human Rights and the Office of Immigrant Affairs and Language Services. An article on Sunday, about the coming vote, made the same the error. The agencies were created during various administrations, not by the Giuliani administration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POST, BLANCHE SIMON
description: POST-Blanche Simon, 78. Of West Hartford, CT and Boca Raton, died Thursday, November 8, 2001. She is survived by her husband, Herman; Robin Post and Jim Tait, Ernest Post and Luisa Lehrer, Amy & Dana Wiseman, and Laura Post and Mark Pazniokas. She is also survived by seven grandchildren & two sisters, Klari Tufe & Alice Charlton. Blanche grew up in Bronx, NY and raised her family in Great Neck, NY. A memorial service will be held Monday, November 12, 2001 at 2PM in the Chapel of Weinstein Mortuary, 640 Farmington Ave., Hartford, CT. The family will receive relatives and friends one-half hour prior to the service at the mortuary. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to Camp Vacamas, 250 W. 57 St., Suite 2202, NY NY 10019

title: On High Wire at a 5-Ring Circus
description: In the first pew of a tidy brick church, Lloyd Ward, his mother and four siblings would sit as tight as piano keys while Rubert Ward soothed the 40 or so souls seated in front of him each Sunday.

title: Bella C. Wexner, 93, Matriarch of a Retail Chain
description: Bella Cabakoff Wexner, a philanthropist and the matriarch of the Limited Inc., a multibillion-dollar retail chain that specializes in women's clothing, died last Sunday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. She was 93 and lived on the Upper East Side, where she moved from Columbus, Ohio, in 1992.

title: New Jersey Security Idea Would Use Ex-Officers
description: Seeking to rein in ballooning overtime costs since Sept. 11, New Jersey's attorney general wants to hire retired police officers instead of using state police and National Guard personnel to provide increased security at Newark International Airport and other potential targets of terrorism.

title: Sports of The Times; Just How Are The 5-3 Jets Doing It?
description: HERMAN EDWARDS was in a philosophic mood yesterday. Practice was over and on a beautiful, bright autumn afternoon, the Jets' first-year coach offered snapshots on a wide range of subjects. He talked about tomorrow's matchup against Kansas City and Dick Vermeil, his former coach at Philadelphia. He talked about missing those days but enjoying the game in an entirely new dimension as a head coach.

title: One Center Staying Open; Anthrax Found at 4 Others
description: A federal judge yesterday refused a request by the New York Metro Area Postal Union to shut down the Morgan Processing and Distribution Center. In late October, anthrax was found in four high-speed mail-sorting machines at the station, at 29th Street and Ninth Avenue.

title: Before '67: What Peace?
description: To the Editor:

title: Civil Liberties vs. Threats to Society Through U.S. History
description: Here are some of the most significant actions by Congress or the president that have restricted civil liberties or have led to disputes about those rights. Most of the actions have come in times of war, anticipated conflict or threats of terrorism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMPSON, PERRY ANTHONY
description: THOMPSON-Perry Anthony. Age 36, of Williamstown, NJ. Died on September 11, 2001 at the World Trade Center in NY. Survived by his wife Charlette (nee Payne), two daughters Ashley & Chelsea; his mother Lula Thompson of Lumberton, NC, one sister Lisa Fenner of Charlotte, NC, and one brother Mike Thompson of Burlington, NJ. Memorial service will be held on Monday, November 12, 2001 at 2PM at the Cathedral at 277 Madison Ave., Perth Amboy, NJ.

title: Fred J. Maroon, 77; Was Asked To Photograph Nixon in Office
description: Fred J. Maroon, a meticulous photographer whose work caught the eye of Richard M. Nixon, who invited him into the White House where he wound up photographing the decline and fall of a president, died Monday at his home in Washington. He was 77.

title: A Knicks Lead, No Surprise, Doesn't Last
description: It happens so often, it barely qualifies as a news flash. Still, the Knicks fell apart on the road again. They have not won in an opponent's arena since beating the Los Angeles Lakers last April, and nothing they did tonight in the second half of an abysmal 103-95 loss to the Indiana Pacers made you believe they were a decent professional basketball team.

title: Against an Intense Rival, Elias Lifts the Devils
description: The Devils' rivalry against Toronto is growing more intense each season. The Devils, using a physical style, have eliminated the Maple Leafs from the playoffs the last two years. This summer, the Maple Leafs signed the free agent Alexander Mogilny, the Devils' leading goal scorer last season, adding to this fiery situation.

title: Guardsmen At Airports To Increase By 1,800
description: The government will call out an additional 1,800 members of the National Guard to patrol airports for the next 60 days, administration officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about an oil refinery in Santa Fe Springs, Calif., controlled by the television evangelist Pat Robertson referred incorrectly to a lawsuit that David G. Hawkins, a director at the Natural Resources Defense Council, said ''has the potential to greatly increase air pollution.'' It was a federal lawsuit brought by Mr. Robertson's oil company to ease environmental requirements for reopening refineries and power plants, not a suit by environmentalists to block the operation of the Sante Fe Springs refinery.

title: Iraqi Opposition Says U.S. Denied Money for Intelligence Effort
description: An Iraqi opposition group that has tempestuous relations with the State Department said today that its request to use American money to gather intelligence inside Iraq had been turned down.

title: Hollywood's Newest Star Is a Mall, And More
description: Hollywood today greeted what it hopes will be its newest star: a $615 million development that includes stores, a hotel, restaurants, cinemas and a new home for the Academy Awards.

title: Company Vows Better Screening In U.S. Airports
description: Under fire for a lengthy series of lapses at airport checkpoints, Argenbright Security, the nation's largest airport security company, appointed a new chief executive today to replace its founder and overhaul its management and policies. It plans to improve training and weed out employees with criminal records.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEIN, MILTON
description: WEIN-Milton. Of Boca Raton, FL. Beloved husband of Norma (nee Schwartz). Devoted father of Susan Bernstein, Howard Wein and Rita Bernstein. Dear brother of Freda Horowitz. Loving grandfather of Jeremy and Doreen Bernstein, Emily Bernstein, Jason and Anne Wein, Courtney and Christopher Wein, Samantha, Chelsea and Haylee Bernstein. Services on Sunday 11:30 A.M. at Gutterman-Musicant, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ.

title: Upstate Republicans in House Join Democrats in Fight for More Money for New York
description: New York Republicans appear headed toward a showdown with the Bush administration and Republican leaders in the House, demanding billions of dollars in additional federal aid to help New York rebuild from the terrorist attack.

title: A Western Front: Is Iraq Next?
description: To the Editor:

title: Gains Among Hispanic, Black and Liberal Voters Helped Push Bloomberg to Victory
description: A significant defection of Hispanic voters from the Democratic Party, coupled with stronger-than-expected showings among black voters and white liberals, helped propel Michael R. Bloomberg to victory in the mayoral election over Mark Green, according to a statistical analysis of the voting patterns in Tuesday's election.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDERMAN, MYRON C. (MIKE)
description: RUDERMAN-Myron C. (Mike). At his home in Plainview, after a long bout with Lou Gehrig's Disease. Beloved husband of Judy. Doting father of Josh, Lisa and David Ruderman, and father-in-law of Sasha Nyary. Delighted grandfather of Sarah Wheeler, Brian & Lily. He was a 35-year employee of Aeroflex Labs. Graveside services 1 P.M., at Montefiore Cemetery, Queens, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERRY, JOHN W.
description: PERRY-John W. The staff and Boards of Directors of the New York Civil Liberties Union and the American Civil Liberties Union are deeply saddened by the death of former Nassau Chapter Board Member, John W. Perry. John was both a deeply committed civil libertarian and police officer who died in the rescue effort at the World Trade Center. Our deepest sympathies to his parents Pat and Jim and siblings Janice and Joel. The NYCLU and its Nassau Chapter have established the John W. Perry Memorial Fund in his memory to support the civil liberties work in which he believed. NYCLU, John W. Perry Memorial Fund, 125 Broad Street, 17 Floor, New York, New York 10004. Steven J. Hyman, President Donna Lieberman, Interim Director NYCLU Nadine Strossen, President Anthony Romero, Executive Director ACLU

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Spare Times for Children column of Weekend yesterday about the musical ''Really Rosie,'' playing through Nov. 17 at the Atlantic Theater in Manhattan, misstated the address. It is 336 West 20th Street, not 36.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLATNICK, SAMUEL
description: POLATNICK-Samuel. Compassionate, learned, dedicated educator spent almost 40 years in the New York City Public School System. Executive Director of the division of high schools. First principal of Springfield Gardens, High School. Assistant Superintendent of Curriculum and Instruction in Great Neck. Served for eight years as member and President of The Board of Education in Plainview, L.I. He believed that every child must be empowered by the best possible public education to participate in modern society. Above all, beloved husband of Florence Tambor, devoted father to Steve & Rosa, Margaret Rivka and Michael. Doting grandfather of Esta, Inbar, Itai and Sandy. A Memorial service is on Sunday, November 11, 2001 at 10:45AM at Riverside Gordon, Del Ray Beach, Florida.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTH, RHEA
description: ROTH-Rhea. A wonderful and loving mother, grandmother and great-grandmother passed away November 7, 2001. Through her sense of humor, unique outlook on life and meaningful words of wisdom, Rhea touched the life of every person that knew her. She was a mentor and role model to all of us. Ivy and Michael Berke Amy and Corey Shanus Scott Wagner Stacy and Larry Hirsch Andrew Roth

title: Suspicious of Clippers
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Tunnel To Reopen For Cars
description: Officials said they planned to reopen the St. Gotthard Tunnel to cars as early as next month, but trucks will have to wait until May to use the north-south artery. The tunnel was closed on Oct. 24 after a truck collision caused a fire that killed 11 people and damaged the tunnel's roof. The ban on trucks is to allow time for improvements in the tunnel's ventilation system. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Longer Visa Waits for Arabs; Stir Over U.S. Eavesdropping
description: The State Department said today that it would slow the process for granting visas to young men from Arab and Muslim nations in an effort to prevent terrorist attacks.

title: Noriega's 'Extradition'
description: To the Editor:

title: Sylena Herrnkind, A Child Abused
description: To the Editor:

title: A bin Laden Threat
description: In an interview with a Pakistani newspaper, Osama bin Laden said he had chemical and nuclear weapons and ''if America used them against us, we reserve the right to use them.''

title: World Briefing | Asia: Koreas: New Talks, Old Words
description: North and South Korea opened talks on reconciliation but remained far apart on the main issues, including security and family reunifications. The North blamed the South for setbacks in attempts to ease relations, saying a security alert in the South after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on the United States disqualified South Korea from playing host to more visits between families separated by the Korean War. The South said the alert was meant to protect lives, including those of foreigners. The talks are being held at a resort in North Korea. Howard W. French (NYT)

title: Awards' Rewards Are Financial, Too
description: At the last minute, the headliner for the Rhythm and Blues Foundation's 12th annual Pioneer Awards ceremony on Thursday night, the Rev. Al Green, didn't show up because he was ministering to a parishioner. But Fontella Bass, Dee Dee Sharp, Big Jay McNeely, the Emotions, Brian and Eddie Holland (who with Lamont Dozier wrote six dozen Top 10 hits, primarily for Motown) and the widow of Louis Jordan were on hand to receive awards, with Isaac Hayes and Dionne Warwick as hosts and Prince applauding from the audience.

title: A Modest Man With a Drumming History
description: Charlie Watts, the 60-year-old drummer for the Rolling Stones an organization with long off-seasons and unending profits -- could be in the sitting-room of his Devon farmhouse right now, taking tea and cogitating on names for the foals of his Arabian horses. Instead, he has been getting his hands dirty as a jazz drummer, leading a 10-piece band through nightclub gigs.

title: A Western Front: Is Iraq Next?
description: To the Editor:

title: Trade Center Attack Delays Publication of Putin Book
description: Compared with the loss of life, the loss of a book publishing event is an infinitesimally minor thing, but for the president of Russia, Vladimir V. Putin, the collapse of the World Trade Center towers had a direct impact on his first state visit to America, which begins next week.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Lawrence Jacobs, 63, Pioneer In Treating Multiple Sclerosis
description: Dr. Lawrence D. Jacobs, a neurologist who helped harness the power of a human protein to fight multiple sclerosis, died on Nov. 2 at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York. He was 63.

title: Where New Music Gets Lasting Love and Respect
description: Something special is happening here: European Music Month, a grand celebration of new music with 30 nights of concerts and other events and works by over a hundred living composers.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Fearing A Nuclear Disaster
description: Environmentalist groups said they would stage large protests next week to block a trainload of nuclear waste on its way to a storage center near the northern town of Gorleben. The 370-mile journey of the six containers from a treatment center in western France is expected to begin on Monday. A similar trainload in March drew thousands of protesters and prompted the mobilization of 30,000 police officers, the largest single security operation in post-war German history. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Verizon Charges Many Customers Without Service Since Sept. 11
description: Verizon has continued to charge a number of residential and commercial telephone customers whose phone service still has not been restored in the wake of the World Trade Center attack on Sept. 11, customers and company officials say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREIBERG, JANET
description: FREIBERG-Janet. On November 8, 2001. Loving mother of Jill and Edward. Her goodness, warmth and humor will be greatly missed by her many friends and family. Visiting Saturday 7-9 P.M. Service Sunday, 11:45 A.M. at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEINSIER, JOAN TUBY
description: WEINSIER-Joan Tuby. Two years too many. We love and miss you beautiful Joannie. Love Evelyn, Michael, Wendy and Phili

title: A Yogi-ism That Parses
description: To the Editor:

title: Reports of a Tangible Gain, Tougher Visa Rules, an Anthrax Theory
description: Under the heading of ''Important If True'' was a claim by the main anti-Taliban force that it had captured Mazar-i-Sharif, a city vital to controlling northern Afghanistan. Leaders of the Northern Alliance said their soldiers had moved into the city with little resistance and sent the Taliban fleeing. Two questions arose, however: Were the the reports accurate? And if so, could this success endure?

title: E.P.A. Chief Tries to Calm Water Fears
description: Christie Whitman, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, said today that the nation's water supply appeared relatively safe from terrorist attack, in part because it would take ''a truckload'' of poison, not just a few drops, to threaten public health.

title: La Spezia Journal; Are There Crosses in Schools? Is Italy Catholic?
description: When Cattaneo Middle School's sixth-grade history teacher, Ornella Orlandini, removed a crucifix from her public school classroom recently, she hoped the gesture would make a new Muslim student feel more comfortable.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's too slow, but it's safe. Well, it's a little bit safer.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the approval of five City Charter revision proposals misattributed the creation of the Organized Crime Control Bureau, the Commission on Human Rights and the Office of Immigrant Affairs and Language Services. An article on Sunday, about the coming vote, made the same the error. The agencies were created during various administrations, not by the Giuliani administration.

title: New Jersey Security Idea Would Use Ex-Officers
description: Seeking to rein in ballooning overtime costs since Sept. 11, New Jersey's attorney general wants to hire retired police officers instead of using state police and National Guard personnel to provide increased security at Newark International Airport and other potential targets of terrorism.

title: Sending Warm Thoughts
description: Amid the flood of donations, now comes something soft and fluffy from Oklahoma City.

title: Hispanics and Blacks Helped Bloomberg Win
description: Michael R. Bloomberg's victory in the mayoral election was helped by a significant defection of Hispanic voters from the Democratic Party and stronger-than-expected showings among black voters and white liberals, according to a statistical analysis of the voting patterns in Tuesday's election.

title: Change Ahead As Taiwan Enters W.T.O.
description: The lines started forming all over Taiwan on Thursday. People mobbed supermarkets and corner stores to buy bottles of rice wine, a potent brew essential to Taiwanese cooking.

title: Bulls Fine Oakley For His Remarks
description: The Chicago Bulls fined forward Charles Oakley $50,000 for criticizing Coach Tim Floyd after Thursday night's 127-74 loss to the Minnesota Timberwolves, the worst defeat in franchise history.

title: Demonstrations But No Strike By Pakistanis
description: Thousands of supporters of Pakistan's Islamic parties marched in several cities today, blocking roads, burning tires and clashing with police officers who lobbed tear gas canisters and, in one case, killed at least three protesters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIERER, SIDNEY
description: SPIERER-Sidney. 89. November 9, 2001, Madison, WI. Loving father of Michael Spierer, Larry Spierer and Jamye Spierer Bannon. He is survived by brothers Charles Spierer and Morris Spierer. Graveside service Sunday November 11, 1pm Beth-El Cemetery, Emerson, NJ.

title: Bin Laden Asserts He Has Nuclear Arms
description: A leading Pakistani newspaper published an interview with Osama bin Laden today in which he said, ''We have chemical and nuclear weapons as a deterrent and if America used them against us, we reserve the right to use them.''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: S.A.S. Grounds Aircraft
description: Scandinavian Airlines System, the Nordic region's biggest carrier, grounded 43 of its Boeing MD-80 passenger aircraft and canceled 150 flights after it discovered a crack in a plane's landing gear. The airline found a fracture in a cylinder in one of the three legs of the landing gear on a plane in Oslo during a check of its MD-80 fleet, it said. S.A.S. has a fleet of 200 aircraft, including 63 MD-80's. The move comes as the carrier struggles to attract passengers after the Sept. 11 hijackings scared travelers away from flying. Earlier this week S.A.S. reported a third-quarter loss of 208 million kronor ($19.7 million).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ONASCH, CHARLES
description: ONASCH-Charles. Francestown, NH, formerly of Cold Spring and Pound Ridge, NY. Retired 37 year employee of McGraw-Hill Co. Survived by wife, two children, three step-children, 11 grandchildren, two great-grandchildren. Services Saturday, November 10 in Peterborough, NH. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Francestown Meeting House, Francestown, NH 03043. For info contact Jellison Funeral Home, NH.

title: 'No Saints or Angels'
description: Ikilled my husband last night. I used a dental drill to bore a hole in his skull. I waited to see if a dove would fly out but out came a big black crow instead.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALDRICH, LARRY
description: ALDRICH-Larry. A man of great artistic taste, intelligence, wit and charm. He encouraged artists to create and all of us to see. He was a dear friend to Henry and Erna Leir, and enlisted them in his charitable causes. We will remember. The Leir Foundations

title: Blood and Anne Rice, Yes. Vampires, No.
description: Don't let the first scene of ''Anne Rice's The Feast of All Saints,'' set in early-19th-century Haiti, confuse you: the piercing screams, the people running in terror, the circle of dead and dying in white garments drenched with blood. ''The Feast of All Saints,'' published in 1979, is a strictly historical, nonsupernatural novel, written before it was clear (at least to the author herself) that Ms. Rice had a lifelong future in horror fiction. Viewers should not spend the first hour, as I did, waiting for James Earl Jones or Jennifer Beals or somebody to turn into a vampire.

title: 'Death and the Penguin'
description: First, a stone landed a metre from Viktor's foot. He glanced back. Two louts stood grinning, one of whom stooped, picked up another from a section of broken cobble, and bowled it at him skittler-fashion. Viktor made off at something approaching a racing walk and rounded the corner, telling himself the main thing was not to run. He paused outside his block, glancing up at the hanging clock: 9.00. Not a sound. No one about. He went in, now no longer afraid. They found life dull, ordinary people, now that entertainment was beyond their means. So they bowled cobbles.

title: GENERAL MILLS EXPECTS EARNINGS DECLINE
description: General Mills Inc., the maker of Cheerios and Wheaties cereals, said yesterday that its earnings this quarter would fall and it would cut about 1,000 jobs in connection with the acquisition of the Pillsbury operations of Diageo P.L.C. Those layoffs are in addition to the 459 people General Mills let go when it sold a plant in Toledo, Ohio, pant and the nearly 1,000 positions lost as a result of a hiring freeze while it completed the acquisition, a spokesman, Tom Forsythe, said. Food retailers have been reducing inventories, and General Mills expects sales volume to rise only slightly in the last three quarters of the year. Excluding certain expenses, General Mills expects to earn 61 cents to 64 cents a share in the quarter that ends Nov. 25.

title: War is Heck
description: I was also at Chicago's O'Hare Airport last Saturday when Subash Gurung, an illegal immigrant with no fixed address, slipped seven knives, a can of Mace and a stun gun through the X-ray machine at a ''security'' checkpoint. Eager to honor our toughened airport protocols, I had my ticket and ID ready for examination, but at the penultimate juncture, a smile and a wave were enough. The ''guard'' smiled back, never bothering to read or match the ticket with the ID. It was all so convivial you'd never guess this is a nation at war.

title: 'Fire in Beulah'
description: Ahigh, hot wind had been blowing from the south for seven days. It blew morning and evening and did not lay at night as it should but cried and fingered at the windows till the sun rose, and then it went on blowing. A constant wind, an unremitting wind, it did not gust or fall but blew one monotonous gritty speed. Water could not be kept in the troughs for the animals but evaporated almost as quickly as it was pumped and had to be pumped anew each time the cattle started bawling. Washing on the line did not flap and dance but held a steady northward angle and dried bone-dry in less than twenty minutes. The older Whiteside girls complained their lips and cheeks were cracking. Their mother stayed indoors, though it was more miserably hot inside than out, because she feared the wind would suck the life from her unborn child.

title: On the Greyhound Bus, Too, Life Changed After Attacks
description: There are many rules aboard Greyhound bus No. 6235 as it rumbles through the cornfields along Interstate 80 from Omaha. No drinking, smoking or drugs. No singing, whistling, gum-cracking or cursing. Music must not spill from earphones. Spray your perfume somewhere else.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about changes in American military strategy as the war in Afghanistan develops misspelled the given name of a scholar who spoke about the poor chances of forming anti-Taliban resistance in southern Afghanistan. She is Rosanne Klass, not Roseanne.

title: Islam Experts Off On a Wild Ride, Willing or Not
description: ''It's been a roller coaster,'' said Okbar S. Ahmed, a Pakistani scholar who had just started a new teaching job at American University in Washington this fall when the terrorist attacks hit the Pentagon and the World Trade Center.

title: A Nation Challenged
description: Shaping the Coalition

title: A Perfect Record Makes Harvard A Hot Ticket
description: On Halloween, Bob Glatz surprised trick-or-treaters by handing out tickets to Saturday's Harvard-Penn game. Word got around his neighborhood. Children began running down the street, banging on his door: Are you the ticket guy?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EHLERS, ELAINE
description: EHLERS-Elaine. With respect, admiration and love, we extend our deepest sympathies to Dick Eger, her beloved husband and devoted companion, and to her family and friends. Forever reflecting upon her warmth & humor, her joyous and vital life, we will be renewed each day by her memory. Linda, Carlos, Anders Urmacher, Dale Mann and the Mann-Urmacher Family

title: Threat to Close Faces Schools In Roosevelt
description: The New York State education commissioner moved yesterday to dissolve the academically and financially troubled Roosevelt school district by next fall and disperse its 3,000 students to surrounding school districts in Nassau County.

title: 'Afghan Arabs' Said to Lead Taliban's Fight
description: Foreign fighters allied with Osama bin Laden and trained in Afghan camps are spearheading the Taliban's resistance to American and allied attacks, according to military and intelligence officials in Pakistan and the United States.

title: Single Letter With Anthrax Is Discounted
description: Postal investigators said today for the first time that other mail containing anthrax bacteria was probably sent here last month in addition to the one letter that has been found, the one sent to the office of Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota.

title: Despite Mail Tumult, Pitney Bowes's Long-Term Outlook Is Strong
description: Logically speaking, this should be a perilous time for Pitney Bowes. The combination of a recessionary economy and bioterrorism has caused mail volume to plummet. Postal rates are almost certain to rise, which will probably prod many businesses to switch even more of their mailings to the Internet or to private deliverers like Federal Express. Since Pitney makes most of its money from renting out postage meters and running mailrooms, Michael J. Critelli, Pitney's chief executive, should be sweating badly.

title: Regulators Struggle With a Marketplace Created by Enron
description: For years, the Enron Corporation used its political muscle to build the markets in which it thrived, pushing relentlessly on Capitol Hill and in bureaucratic backwaters to deregulate the nation's natural gas and electricity businesses.

title: People in Need Criticize Plans to Close a Center of Help
description: The Family Assistance Center on Pier 94, set up by the city for people left jobless, homeless, bereaved or injured by the attack on the World Trade Center, is being dismantled, and the system replacing it is already generating complaints from volunteers and those seeking help.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Jailed Editor Is Released
description: After spending the night in police custody, Geoff Nyarota, the editor in chief of the country's only privately owned daily newspaper, was released on bail. Mr. Nyarota and his former partner, Wilf Mbanga, were charged with improperly obtaining an operating license to start the newspaper, The Daily News, in 1998. Prosecutors said the men were granted a certificate to run weekly provincial newspapers, not a daily newspaper. Mr. Nyarota has acknowledged clerical errors in their filing papers but denied criminal wrongdoing. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: World Briefing
description: AFRICA

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Guidelines To List Foreign Concerns
description: China has issued broad guidelines allowing foreign firms to list shares in their Chinese operations on the country's domestic stock exchanges. Under the new rules, foreign-owned companies must have at least three years of operation in China before listing and must retain at least a 10 percent foreign stake afterward. Unilever, which recently restructured its China operations, is widely expected to be one of the first foreign companies to list shares in the country. Craig Smith (NYT)

title: Oil Prices Soar on Confusing Report About Russia's Output
description: On the surface, it looked like big news: the Russian news service Interfax quoted Prime Minister Mikhail Kasyanov today as saying that a group of Russian oil companies might agree next week to reduce oil exports in support of the efforts by the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries to raise oil prices.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Clinton Wants To Resign From Supreme Court Bar
description: Former President Bill Clinton wants to resign from the Supreme Court bar, a lawyer for Mr. Clinton said in a letter to the court. Under an agreement in January to settle complaints that he gave false testimony in the Paula Jones case, Mr. Clinton accepted a five-year suspension from the Arkansas bar and was assessed a $25,000 fine. Under Supreme Court rules, such an action automatically leads to suspension from the Supreme Court bar. On Oct. 2, the court suspended Mr. Clinton from the bar, giving him 40 days to explain why he should not be disbarred.

title: Doing the Lawn-Mower Dance, and Bringing a Yard Into Full Bloom
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Rosenkranz's Dual Passions Fuel a Mind Vigorous at 85
description: This planet has more than a million bridge players, but only one can claim to have changed it in a material way. His name is Dr. George Rosenkranz, and 50 years ago, working with steroids in a small Mexico City laboratory, he and a colleague synthesized the birth control pill. The results, directly for women and indirectly for population control, have been extraordinary.

title: Sotheby's Chief Said to Have Met Secretly With Rival
description: Declaring that ''the price fix was in, for hundreds of millions of dollars,'' federal prosecctors yesterday opened their criminal antitrust case against A. Alfred Taubman, the former chairman and largest stockholder of Sotheby's auction house, charging for the first time that he and his counterpart at Christie's held a series of secret face-to-face meetings in New York and London to stifle their customers' ability to bargain between them.

title: Pay Phone Rates To Increase 15 cents
description: Verizon increased rates for its 62,000 pay phones in New Jersey to 50 cents for a local call of unlimited time, up from 35 cents for a timed call, company officials said yesterday.

title: Security Tight for Start of United Nations Meeting in New York
description: Keenly aware that the United Nations General Assembly is a potential terrorist target, federal and New York City law enforcement officials are on the highest security alert for a week of meetings among world leaders scheduled to begin today.

title: Promised Land No Longer; Dot-Commers Who Once Flocked to San Francisco Are Turning Elsewhere
description: Michelle A. Lemire, 28, moved here from Denver 18 months ago to join the dot-com revolution. She remained enthusiastic when her first employer went bankrupt. She was undeterred when she was laid off from a second job, and even when told by her third company that she could stay -- though it had gone broke -- if she agreed not to be paid.

title: Reflections on the Famous, As Both a Target and a Goal
description: John Buffalo Mailer, a 23-year-old playwright, seems to have inherited the family hubris; that's a good thing, more or less. When not much older, his father yes, Norman published ''The Naked and the Dead'' and began his career as a self-appointed American mentor. And whether or not you think Mailer pre was up to the task, he never shied from it. Now his son, a recent graduate of Wesleyan University and very possibly the smartest kid in theater class, has written a play that is a chip off the old block -- at least in terms of authorial bravado.

title: Innocent but Odd Letters, Many Millions of Them, Occupy Anthrax Patrols
description: In late October, Bill Burch had his fourth graders at Skyway Elementary in Coeur d'Alene, Idaho, make ''Just Say No'' antidrug posters. The students then mailed one poster to a random school in a random town in each of the 50 states, along with a letter asking for a poster in return.

title: Reconstructed Arizona Stuns And Surprises
description: Arizona played on the final night of the season last April, proving it was the second-best team in college basketball. The Wildcats played on opening night of this season, and their upset of Maryland on Thursday was a testament to how they have overcome the departures from last season's team.

title: The Neediest Cases; Single Father Gets New Start for 7 Children After a Fire in Harlem
description: Dorian Hardin thought he smelled something burning.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Foot-And-Mouth Controls Lifted
description: The government lifted livestock movement controls on large swaths of Northern England, leaving fewer than 5 percent of affected farms still under the restrictions imposed eight months ago to combat foot-and-mouth disease. Nearly four million animals have been slaughtered in the campaign to rid Britain of the disease, and there have been no new cases confirmed since Sept. 30. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Suit Says Homes Were Built on Bomb Range
description: KB Home, one of the largest home builders in the nation, was sued this week by 64 homeowners who say that the company knowingly built their dwellings on a former military target range that contains unexploded bombs.

title: Negotiators Push to Settle World Treaty On Warming
description: With momentum building for a treaty curbing global warming, delegates from 164 countries, cloistered in a convention center in Morocco, negotiated late into the night yesterday to resolve several lingering disputes.

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook article on Nov. 1 about the composer Arnold Schoenberg and his years in Southern California misidentified the university where he taught privately. It was the University of Southern California, not the University of California.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Airline Stops Flying
description: Canada 3000, the nation's second-biggest airline, has ceased operations after failing to agree with unions on a restructuring required to get government aid. The carrier, with 38 aircraft, more than doubled in size over the last year, adding a domestic network to charter operations that served Europe and resort destinations in the United States and the Caribbean. Compounding a slump in traffic since Sept. 11, Canada 3000 was hurt by competition from Air Canada's new discount airline, Tango, which started operating on Nov. 1. Unions turned down management's proposal to shrink the airline by about 30 percent, including 1,500 layoffs. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: No Bail for Friend of Man Suspected of Preparing for Sept. 11 Hijackings
description: An Oklahoma friend of Zacarias Moussaoui, the man the authorities suspect was meant to be the 20th suicide hijacker in the Sept. 11 attacks, has been ordered held without bail on weapons charges by a federal magistrate in Oklahoma City.

title: Warren E. Henry, 92, Physicist and Educator
description: Dr. Warren Elliott Henry, a scientist who in a long career in government and academia made significant contributions to the fields of radar technology, physical properties of materials and physics education, died on Oct. 31 in Washington.

title: Crossroads Conquest Would Give Alliance First Major Victory
description: The capture of Mazar-i-Sharif delivers the first tangible victory for the American-led campaign after more than a month of war.

title: Beliefs; A military campaign, the calls for caution and some complex roots in Christian thought.
description: The American government is understandably concerned about convincing Muslims around the world that the war against Al Qaeda and the Taliban is justified. Washington officials might do well also to worry about another religious group: Christians.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Corrections
description: An opening passage was scrambled in some copies yesterday in the American Journal article, about the sparseness of air traffic at Reagan National Airport since Sept. 11. The affected paragraph, about a father who took his young daugther to see planes take off, should have read: ''Staring down the runway, John Ruplenas had to wait awhile in the autumn breeze. But finally a jetliner gunned its way forward, the plane gleaming upward as it ascended from what is arguably now the nation's safest yet most forlorn airport.''

title: Why Are Deep Thinkers Shallow About Tyranny?
description: Is there a special gene among intellectuals that lends itself to the embrace of tyranny? Are they less sensible than the general populace?

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Nov. 2 about Juan Bosch, the first freely elected president of the Dominican Republic, misstated the family names of the man who succeeded him after a coup in 1963. The successor was Donald Reid Cabral, not Cabal Reid. The article also referred incorrectly to the 22,000 United States troops who were sent to the Dominican Republic in 1965 to occupy the capital for several months while a provisional government was formed and elections were arranged. They were a mixed force of marines and Army soldiers, not just marines.

title: Dissecting the Era of Virgins and Satyrs
description: ''All generalizations are wrong,'' said Peter Gay. ''That's why I find being an historian so interesting.'' Mr. Gay, 78 now, emeritus professor of history at Yale, author of 25 books, was having a cup of morning coffee and some little chocolates in his apartment on the Upper West Side. The sun burst in from the Hudson River, lighting up a pair of dark red Victorian slipper chairs, a large Victorian secretary and a silver sugar caster on the coffee table, relics of the period that has absorbed Mr. Gay for the last 30 years.

title: Benefits Panel Plans Array Of Choices For Solvency
description: The co-chairmen of President Bush's Social Security commission said today that they intended to set out a number of alternative plans for achieving the administration's goal of creating personal investment accounts within the retirement system rather than present a single proposal.

title: A Western Front: Is Iraq Next?
description: To the Editor:

title: Israeli Minister Vacates Home After Assassination Warning
description: An Israeli cabinet minister and his family moved out of their home in an Israeli town near the West Bank several days ago after warnings from security officials that he might be the target of an assassination attempt by Palestinians.

title: On the Trail of the Anthrax Killers
description: My best friend is an F.B.I. agent. We have a little joke: I ask him what he had for lunch. He tells me he's sorry, that's classified.

title: Holiday on Monday -- Veterans Day
description: The holiday, actually Nov. 11, is observed on Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPEIZER, THELMA
description: SPEIZER-Thelma. On November 8, 2001. Beloved wife of Morris, loving mother of the late Ronnie and mother-in-law of Irving Dobbs. Cherished grandmother of Stephanie, Scott, Kimberley and Erica. Services Sunday in Florida.

title: CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER IS QUITTING AFTER 6 MONTHS
description: The Kmart Corporation, which has reported a drop in profit for six consecutive quarters, said yesterday that Jeffrey Boyer quit as chief financial officer after six months and would be succeeded by John T. McDonald Jr. Kmart, the second-largest discount chain, said Mr. Boyer resigned to spend more time with his family. Mr. McDonald has been treasurer since September 2000 and previously worked at the CVS Corporation, where Kmart's chief executive, Chuck Conaway, was president until moving 18 months ago to Kmart, which is based in Troy, Mich.

title: To Rebuild a Place That Lost So Much
description: To the Editor:

title: Trade Talks Hinge on Finesse of U.S.
description: With one of his first decisions as President Bush's chief trade negotiator, Robert B. Zoellick last spring quickly set himself apart from colleagues in the Bush cabinet who were eagerly overturning Clinton administration policies on everything from arsenic levels in drinking water to mining on public lands.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ROYAL BANK OF SCOTLAND, Edinburgh, Britain's second-largest bank, was given Federal Reserve approval to purchase 345 bank branches from Mellon Financial Corp., Pittsburgh, a provider of global investment services. The deal was valued at $2.1 billion when it was announced in July.

title: Lloyd David Ward
description: AGE: 52, grew up outside of Detroit in Romulus, Mich.

title: 'The Last Canyon'
description: May 23-June 15, 1869

title: A Yogi-ism That Parses
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. 'Dialogue' Focuses on Sept. 11 Terror Attacks and U.S. Bombing of Afghanistan
description: From the sand-filled trucks on First Avenue to most every speech in a warm-up debate on ''Dialogue Among Civilizations,'' the General Assembly has left no doubt of the centrality of the terror attacks on Sept. 11 in its delayed annual gathering.

title: A Western Front: Is Iraq Next?
description: To the Editor:

title: Saluting a Star With a Galaxy of Her Own Making
description: There is some very good dancing onstage at City Center this weekend from Alicia Alonso's Ballet Nacional de Cuba, and a sense of style is not the least of the pleasures.

title: VERIZON WIRELESS NEAR TO COMPLETING PUBLIC OFFERING
description: Verizon Wireless Inc., the biggest American mobile-phone company, said yesterday that it hoped to complete an initial public offering to raise as much as $5 billion by the middle of next year. The sale was postponed a year ago. Verizon will use part of the money to pay for wireless licenses obtained in a proposed $16 billion settlement with the bankrupt NextWave Telecom and the government. Verizon's share is $8.8 billion, the company said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The company is based in Bedminster, N.J.

title: Kerik Says He Won't Stay On as Police Commissioner
description: Police Commissioner Bernard B. Kerik, who supervised the New York Police Department as historic crime reductions continued and coordinated the city's response to a frightening new era of terrorism, had twice before said that he would not continue in the job past New Year's Day.

title: [RETHINK]: Manifestoes For the Next New York; [Traffic]: Price the Drivers out of Manhattan
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani was never accused of being a transportation visionary before Sept. 11. But when he banned single-occupant cars from entering Lower Manhattan a couple of weeks later, he not only averted a colossal traffic jam. He also showed what New York could become if we take back our streets from the invaders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURNSIDE, JOHN PATRICK
description: BURNSIDE-John Patrick. FDNY. Heroically died in the line of duty on September 11, 2001, in the World Trade Center attack. John was a three year veteran of the NYPD at Central Park Precinct. The last seven years he served as one of New York's bravest amongst his friends and comrades of Ladder 20. John was actively pursuing a promotion by preparing for the FDNY Lieutenant's exam while also representing his fellow fire fighters as the Union delegate at Ladder 20. John Burnside is survived by his forever loving wife Sandra, his parents William and Elizabeth Burnside, brother Robert and sister Ann Marie, and his adoring niece and nephews who thought there was no greater man in the world, Stephen, Mikey, Billy, Amanda, Jenna, Nicolette and Alexis. John will always be rememberd for his musical talent as he was an avid guitar player/musician/writer who strived for creativity and perfection. For his fanatical love of the Minnesota Vikings for which he took much abuse from his friends and fellow fire fighters at Ladder 20. For his dedication and commitment, studying every day to make Lieutenant so he could further make a difference in this city, for this I hope you knew how proud we were. John is and will always be dearly missed by all who were fortunate to have known him. He gave willingly every day to the City of New York as an upstanding citizen and proud fire fighter who was just realizing his potential. John, you were a hero to me everyday at home, now you're a hero to the world and we'll all be forever proud. You will forever be in all our hearts and prayers till we meet again. Memorial visitation, Thursday 2-5 and 7-9 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Memorial Mass Friday, November 16, 11 AM, at Good Shepard Church, Broadway at 207th St., SCJ.

title: Security and Warmth In Needle and Thread
description: WOMEN with determination, needle and thread are an enduring image of American history, from Betsy Ross and her flag to pioneer women sitting at looms or bent over a darning egg in the light of an oil lamp. But that is not the image that comes to mind when Sister Ann Marie slides scissors through the security check at the Federal Correctional Institution for women in Danbury.

title: November 4-10; E.T.A. Attacks
description: The Basque separatist group E.T.A. detonated a car-bomb in Madrid during the morning rush hour , injuring almost 100 people, and, 24 hours later, shot dead a judge in the Basque city of Bilbao. The car-bomb missed by three seconds its intended target, a government official. The police arrested two people leaving the scene, and said they believe they have broken up a cell responsible for planting as many as five bombs in the capital this year and killing two people. Emma Daly

title: Consumers Look At Corporate Conduct
description: In the wake of the terrorist attacks, consumers are paying much closer attention to whether they think a company is socially responsible, a new poll suggests.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORGANSTERN, MILDRED
description: MORGANSTERN - Mildred. Be loved wife of the late Jack. Loving mother of Gerald and Karen, and Andy and Carol. Cherished grandmother of Jeffrey, Bradley, Rachel and Jaime. Dear aunt. Adored sister-in-law of Murry Morgenstern and Seymour Klass. Contributions to The Bridge, Inc. 248 West 108 St., NYC in her memory would be appreciated.

title: Firefighters Who Granted Wishes, and Sporting Dads
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: More Financial Aid, Maybe
description: A few years ago, the pleas for financial aid by a few students who wanted to take college courses over the Internet barely elicited a yawn on Capitol Hill.

title: Hell's Belles
description: STRANGER THINGS HAPPEN

title: Charting the Outer Limits of Inner Beauty
description: California, land of the bodacious babe and the physically impossible body. Yet, overweight actors in the movie ''Shallow Hal'' -- those who do not fall into the category customarily thought of as West Coast perfect -- watched as Gwyneth Paltrow eased her slender frame into a director's chair on the set of ''Live With Regis and Kelly'' on Tuesday and spoke about the despair of being morbidly obese.

title: Weeks of Grief, Then Joy
description: ON Tuesday, Oct. 27, Mariana Aguilar arrived in New York from the outskirts of Cuenca, Ecuador, to mourn three of her eight sons and daughters, undocumented immigrants who were killed in the attack on the World Trade Center.

title: The Nation: It Ain't Over . . .; Baseball in a Minor Key
description: ALL anyone really needs to know about Major League Baseball's announcement last week that it plans to eliminate two so-called small-market teams is that they can't do it without a bitter and probably unwinnable fight with the Players Association. That means, almost certainly, that it's not going to happen.

title: Anthony Shaffer, 75, Playwright With a Flair for the Whodunit, Dies
description: Anthony Shaffer, the British playwright whose jokey but chilling thriller "Sleuth" ran for more than 2,300 performances in London's West End and more than 2,000 on Broadway, died in London on Tuesday. He was 75.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: HIDDEN POWER

title: [RETHINK]: Manifestoes For the Next New York; [Economy]: Bring Back the MAC
description: There is no question that New York City and New York State are facing not only a serious financial crisis, but an economic crisis as well. The crisis of 1975 was essentially financial: with a $1.5 billion deficit on a budget of about $15 billion and $6 billion of short-term debt coming due, the city was unable to finance itself in the marketplace. However, the city's economy was turning around, and once the debt was refinanced and the budget was brought under control, the economy recovered strongly.

title: Furry Creatures: Sentinels for Anthrax?
description: To the Editor:

title: THE GUIDE
description: Understanding the Mideast

title: Insurance Check
description: To the Editor: The article ''Trip Insurance: Refunds Vary,'' (Oct. 7) was of particular interest to my wife and me. We had been booked to sail on an 18-day Renaissance cruise from Singapore to Hong Kong in November. The article mentioned Access America as one of the large travel insurance companies. As most cruise travelers know, Renaissance Cruises filed for bankruptcy in September and is no longer operating.

title: They'd Rather Beat Yankees, But They're Still Proud
description: Mary Kangas, 70, heard the news from her friend Natalie McKeon, 71, as they drank coffee at the Dunkin' Donuts in the square.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: November 11, 2001
description: Weeks

title: Take This Advice, or Don't
description: Faculty advising is like a blind date: given differences of character, temperament and values, it does not often blossom into love, or even like. What's more, as students oscillate between adolescence and adulthood, they are often ambivalent about the kind of relationship they want with an adviser. Should advisers be surrogate parents, friends, mentors or skilled professionals? Some students are looking for Mr. Chips. Some chafe at any decisive, directive adult. Some cling to anyone who throws them a lifeline.

title: Liberties; Doubt of a Shadow
description: Everybody thinks Michael Bloomberg is going to languish in Rudy's shadow.

title: Dance; Song, Dance and Talk, but Without the Social Criticism
description: FOR the last 30 years, German Tanztheater, with its collages of vignettes, its performers who sing, dance and talk, and its sociocritical discourse, has both dazzled and confounded audiences around the world. With the American premiere this week of ''La Guerra d'Amore'' by Joachim Schlmer at CalPerformances Zellerbach Hall here, Tanztheater in the United States will get a new face.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOLDE, MORRIS
description: GOLDE-Morris. Share happy memories of Morris. Tuesday, November 13th, 6:00 PM, NY Society for Ethical Culture. 2 W 64 St.

title: Not Your Corner Drugstore
description: CALVIN G. WASDYKE is no corner druggist.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALSHON, CAREN. (NEE GREENBERG)
description: WALSHON-Caren. (nee Greenberg). Beloved daughter of Gloria and the late Paul. She fought valiantly for two years to win the battle of breast cancer and lost. Loving sister of Jay and Arthur. Her life were her children Megan and Zak. Funeral Tuesday November 13, 11 AM at Temple Israel in Westport, CT. Burial to follow at Maimonides Cemetery, Elmont, NY. Shiva in Westport.

title: Alyssa Cohen and Marco Tablada
description: Alyssa Robin Cohen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Cohen of New York, is to be married today to Marco Aurelio Tablada, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Tablada Jr. of San Antonio. Judge Harold Baer Jr. of the Federal District Court in Manhattan will officiate at the Essex House.

title: Bloomberg's Recipe: Luck, Cash, Control
description: Thirty-six hours before the polls opened on Election Day, Michael R. Bloomberg's campaign staff felt the race was slipping away. Mr. Bloomberg prevailed with a combination of luck, money, high-priced strategy and hands-on management.

title: Harvard Foils Penn Defense in Duel of Unbeatens
description: The song ''Dancing in the Moonlight'' blasted through Harvard's locker room today, and pockets of players danced. The moon was not out quite yet, but the Crimson players could have convinced themselves that it was. Anything seemed possible after their victory over Pennsylvania in a duel of unbeaten Ivy League teams this afternoon at Harvard Stadium.

title: Feeding the Psyche
description: ''IS there somewhere I can smoke? Can I smoke in the bathroom?''

title: The Return Of New York
description: Dealing with what happened to our city on Sept. 11 has involved a kind of progression, and for many of us, the initial phase included some level of incomprehension. One of the stranger images left in my head from that terrible morning is of a woman standing on my corner in TriBeCa, laughing into her cellphone. Survivors, many of them coated head to foot with ash, were processing mutely up Church Street. My wife and I had run outside to determine whether we should evacuate the children from our apartment. And this nicely dressed woman was chatting with a friend as if New York were the same city it had been an hour earlier. Perhaps this was simply some kind of hysterical reaction. But I think that on that day, and for days afterward, all of us faced in varying degrees the difficulty of wrapping our minds around the magnitude of the murderous destruction visited on the place we live.

title: Television/Radio; Public Radio's Private Guru
description: DURING the final days of October, as the public radio station WAMU-FM in Washington launched an on-air fund drive, one particular group of former listeners began calling in to donate only their complaints. They were fans of a bluegrass show that had been dropped without warning four months earlier from its coveted slot during drive-time on weekday afternoons. Refusing to contribute money, demanding refunds of previous gifts, the protesters meant to deny WAMU its goal of raising $1 million. And this was only their latest piece of political theater.

title: His Finest Hour
description: CHURCHILL

title: Ideas & Trends; Reading Italy's Signs of the Cross
description: AFTER a sixth-grade public school teacher in this Northern port town removed a crucifix from her classroom recently, in an effort to make a new Muslim student feel more at home, the community rose up in an angry embrace of Italy's long-neglected Catholic roots.

title: Owens Joins the List Of Outspoken Players
description: After an emotional loss to Chicago two weeks ago, 49ers wide receiver Terrell Owens made a controversial statement that rocked the San Francisco franchise. His inflammatory words raised an interesting question.
