title: The Way We Live Now: 11-11-01: On Language; Ground Zero
description: Three days after the World Trade Center's twin towers were brought down, Peter Jennings told ABC-TV viewers of the emotional impact on those who had the chance ''to go down to what we all call ground zero and see the work effort that is there and see the destruction up close.'' A few days later, Bill Hemmer of CNN reviewed the alternative names of the site: ''We're going to take you now to the area known as the zone. Some people are calling it the pile, others ground zero.''

title: Jennifer Kirstein, Howard Klar
description: Jennifer Susan Kirstein and Howard Paul Klar were married last evening by Rabbi Ruth Zlotnick at the Angel Orensanz Foundation on the Lower East Side.

title: Rutgers Struggles To Remain Optimistic
description: Greg Schiano, the eternally optimistic coach at Rutgers, says he sees the glass as half full, not half empty. But what if the glass is just empty? A week after an embarrassing 80-7 loss to West Virginia, the Scarlet Knights suffered another thrashing, losing, 42-0, to Pittsburgh today at Rutgers Stadium.

title: Travel Advisory; In Baltimore, a Museum's Renaissance
description: In the latest chapter in the transformation of old Baltimore, the Walters Art Museum, which dates to 1931, has been largely reborn. The museum, on elegant Mount Vernon Place about 10 blocks north of the rejuvenated Inner Harbor and Camden Yards area, reopened the largest and newest of its three buildings on Oct. 20 after a three-year renovation, with four new exhibitions.

title: In the 'Idea Wars,' a Fight to Control a New Currency
description: AS OFFICIALS from around the world gather to discuss global trade in Doha, Qatar, this weekend, many are challenging one of the towering achievements of American industry during its economic boom years: an unprecedented expansion of intellectual property rights.

title: Bein' Green
description: Most college campuses make an effort to recycle, at the least separating plastic and glass. Some even compost. Middlebury, the Vermont liberal arts college, has raised the bar.

title: Stacey Sotirhos, Petros Goneos
description: Stacey Katharine Sotirhos, the daughter of Estelle and Michael Sotirhos of Lauderdale-by-the-Sea, Fla., was married on Friday evening to Petros D. Goneos, a son of Dora and Dimitrios Goneos of Athens and New York.

title: Staying Power In Wineglasses
description: Riedel stemware, leading its field, is too fragile and costly for high-style holiday entertaining in low-budget times. Spiegelau's Vino Grande crystal from Germany, which is nearly as good, seems more durable and hence economical. Spiegelau Bordeaux and chardonnay glasses, $10 each at New York Wine Exchange, 9 Beaver Street (Broadway), make $20 wines smell and taste like $35 purchases. HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

title: Elizabeth Frederick, Brian Peldunas
description: Elizabeth Anne Frederick and Brian Paul Peldunas were married yesterday by the Rev. Joseph O'Meara at Our Lady of the Rosary Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: Streetscapes/The Federal Reserve Bank of New York; Mix of Limestone and Sandstone, in Florentine Style
description: BUILT in 1924, the Florentine-style Federal Reserve Bank at 33 Liberty Street had long ago acquired an ancient-looking patina of black crust on its noble stones. When a yearlong facade cleaning was completed late this summer, it revealed a fascinating variety of coloration and pattern in the huge blocks of stone. In the last few weeks, after the attack of Sept. 11, the stones have had to be dusted off again.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  READ, G. STEPHEN
description: READ-G. Stephen. Jan. 30, 1942 to Nov. 8, 1981. In Loving Memory Bo

title: World Trade Organization Admits China, Amid Doubts
description: China joined the World Trade Organization this evening, completing a quest that required 15 years of haggling over whether the nation's fitful embrace of a market economy entitled it to the full trading rights of capitalist countries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, REBECCA
description: SOLOMON-Rebecca. The Western New England Psychoanalytic Society and Institute mourn the death of our beloved colleague, teacher and friend, Dr. Rebecca Solomon, on October 25, 2001. Lawrence Levenson, M.D., President, WNEPS Lynn Reiser, M.D., Pres., WNEIP

title: MILLBURN SECESSION
description: Millburn residents voted 3,872 to 538 to instruct its town council to seek the town's secession from Essex County. Proponents cited rising property taxes and diminishing county services. The nonbinding referendum must be approved by the State Legislature. The town shares borders with both Union and Morris Counties and could become part of either. John Holl

title: White House Takes Steps To Renew Tie To Hollywood
description: Several dozen top Hollywood executives are to meet for two hours on Sunday morning with Karl Rove, President Bush's senior adviser, to try to find common ground on how the entertainment industry can contribute to the war effort, replicating in spirit if not in scope the partnership formed between filmmakers and war planners in the 1940's.

title: WORTH NOTING; Intellectual Curiosity Born of Necessity
description: Not surprisingly, people want to know more about Islam these days. At the Princeton University Press, the hot sellers include a translation of Middle Eastern poetry and tomes on Muslim culture.

title: GOING OUT
description: An guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Her Queens Days Will Become Moscow Nights
description: LUDMILA, a 55-year-old widow, set the supper table. There was bread and butter smeared with red caviar, pickled herring, eggplant, beef, potatoes, chocolate sweets, good teacups and bottles of beer.

title: Laundry, Explained
description: New Yorkers with nesting instincts no longer have to forgo fashion when they head to the laundromat.

title: Rosemary Maggiore, Adam Brightman
description: Rosemary Maggiore, a financial executive, and Adam Brightman, an independent film producer, are to be married today in New York. Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman is to officiate at the Conservatory Garden in Central Park.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWENHERZ, ESTELLE
description: LOWENHERZ-Estelle. Died November 6 at age 99. She leaves her loving son Jack, daughter-in-law Lila, sister-in-law Lisel, grandchildren Mark, Jennifer, Geraldine, and many devoted friends. There will be no public service.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: DREAMERS OF DREAMS

title: Al Qaeda Sites Point to Tests Of Chemicals
description: The United States has identified sites in Afghanistan that are suspected of involvement in Osama bin Laden's efforts to acquire and produce chemical and biological weapons, but none have been bombed since the military campaign began, according to American military and intelligence officials.

title: November 4-10; Try, Try Again
description: For the 10th time this year, the Federal Reserve cut interest rates in an effort to revive the economy. The latest cut, by half a percentage point, reduced the rate at which banks lend to one another to 2 percent, down from 6.5 percent at the beginning of the year. The move went over well on Wall Street, where the stock market advanced amid hopes that the economic downturn will end in the first half of next year. Floyd Norris

title: Breaking the Laws in New York City
description: UNTIL very recently, virtually the entire community of political handicappers in New York viewed the mayoral candidacy of Michael R. Bloomberg as a self-indulgent lark. Just two weeks ago, even one of his close advisers was arguing that if Mr. Bloomberg did better than Ruth W. Messinger, a Democrat who won 42 percent of the vote in 1997, that should be deemed a moral victory. This was so not only because of Mr. Bloomberg's obvious limitations as a first-time candidate, but because of the immutable laws of New York politics. Here is how several of those laws were articulated by political experts this summer:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLACK, JAMES G.
description: BLACK-James G. The officers and members of the New England Society in the City of New York are saddened by the recent death of James G. Black, longtime Director and Secretary of the Society. His wise counsel, organizational skills and the pleasure of his company will be sorely missed. C. Harvey Kelley, President Arnold Hayward Neis, First V.P.

title: Know Your Homeland Defense Agency
description: 1. The principal functions of Homeland Defense are:

title: In the Region/Long Island; Office Leasing: No Influx From Manhattan Reported
description: SPECIALISTS in the Long Island real estate market, including a big developer, say they are still optimistic about prospects for office space despite the lack of response to offers of free space to companies displaced in the World Trade Center attack. In the long term, they say, they expect large Manhattan companies seeking to open branch offices and smaller companies relocating from New York City will turn to the Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, GRACE
description: SOLOMON-Grace. Age 94. Passed away November 2, 2001. Born and lived in New York City. Her home for the past five years: The Jewish Home and Hospital Nursing Facility, Bronx, New York. Survived by her loving son Richard and her sister Helen.

title: Theater; London Theater And the Cloud of War
description: IN times of public anxiety in Britain, it has fallen to the royal family to stand up, be counted, show the flag and do the other things expected of national symbols. The obvious case is George VI, who refused to escape the blitz by fleeing to Canada with his wife and daughters. And in the anxious London of late 2001 it seems to have fallen to ''The Royal Family'' to perform a similar if smaller function.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, Pages 110 and 111 in some copies of The Times Magazine today omit Entries 20 to 23 of "Let Us Count the Ways," a series of accounts of famous New Yorkers' favorite places in the city, and Entries 17 to 19 are duplicated. The missing entries are printed in this section, on Page A47, and the full series is on the Web, at www.nytimes.com/magazine.

title: Let Us Count the Ways [10-16]
description: 10. Madeleine Rumely, former chorister at St. John the Divine

title: F.Y.I.
description: Windup, Pitch, Splinter

title: Peter C. Martin: He Still Speaks to Her
description: Lt. Peter C. Martin had plenty of interests. He liked to watch Nascar races, "glued to the TV," said his friend, Lt. Peter Lund. He also kept track of how many fires he had been to, perhaps inspired by a book, "20,000 Alarms," that was lying around the Rescue 2 firehouse in Brooklyn.

title: Downtown Journal; Inside a Store Window, A Moment Is Frozen
description: Most restaurants and small shops on Broadway near Fulton Street, just one block east of ground zero, have struggled back to business since the Sept. 11 terrorist attack, but Chelsea Jeans has not.

title: [RETHINK]: Manifestoes For the Next New York; [Times Square]: Bring Back New Yorkers -- and Sex
description: Labor Day brought the romance it always does to Broadway: the whiff of a new season. In the Times Square that Disney helped build in the late 1990's, you could squint your eyes and imagine that the crossroads of the world was as vital as ever. The blazing lights, after all, seemed even brighter than those of ''42nd Street'' lore, and foot traffic had become so dense that Broadway sidewalks had just been widened to accommodate it.

title: November 4-10
description: The Voters Speak

title: A Nation Challenged
description: The Enemy and the Ally

title: Giants' No. 5 Eludes a Blitz Of Criticism
description: He does not look for them, but Kerry Collins confesses that he has seen his No. 5 Giants jersey this season in places he never expected. At malls and gas stations and throughout the parking lot when he arrives for games at Giants Stadium, Collins has noticed that fans have made the emotional attachment, a symbolic leap of faith.

title: On the Other Hand, You Can Swim Across
description: On Sept. 11, New York Waterway was transformed from a commercial ferry operation carrying 16,000 commuters a day across the Hudson to an evacuation fleet that let 160,000 injured, homeless and terrified people flee Lower Manhattan. Despite its heroics that infamous Tuesday, the company has suffered at least one public relations black eye since then. On Oct. 15, New York Waterway raised its one-way fare by a dollar for trips between its Hoboken North terminal to 38th Street in Manhattan. The timing, particularly in light of a doubling in ridership since Sept. 11, led some to grumble.

title: Memorial for Peter Maas
description: A memorial service for Peter Maas, the reporter and author of true-crime books including ''Serpico'' and ''The Valachi Papers'', will be held tomorrow at 5 p.m. at the Promenade Theater, 2162 Broadway. Mr. Maas died on Aug. 23. Peter Jennings, Frank Serpico, former governor Hugh L. Carey and Senator Fred Thompson will be among the speakers.

title: In Flowerless Seasons, the Charm of Foliage
description: When we moved to our house 25 years ago, I envisioned borders filled with flowers from spring through fall. Lack of time and money squashed that dream. It takes time to plant swaths of long-blooming annuals in spring, and it takes money to have a continuous panorama of perennials in flower. By default, my borders often had long green, flowerless periods.

title: Practical Traveler; Putting the Kids On the Slopes
description: IS this the year you're going to get your kids on skis? Or snowboards? Skiing as a family can be great fun, or a tearful, frustrating, exhausting experience. To help make it the former, there's a lot of support available.

title: Charles Joseph Houston: A Mush Around Children
description: Charles Joseph Houston was 6-foot-1, weighed 225 pounds and had a thick mustache. "He had a rough exterior, but inside, he was such a mush, especially around children." said Linda Houston, his wife.

title: OPEN-SPACE TAXES
description: Almost all the questions on ballots last week to increase property taxes to buy open spaces were approved, according to a planner for the state Green Acres Program. Voters in 2 counties and 52 municipalities voted on such questions. Middlesex County and Morris County voters approved increases in their open space tax rates of 2 cents per $100 of assessed value of property. Voters in Ocean City in Cape May County and in Oakland in Bergen County rejected the funds. Karen DeMasters

title: As Crowds Dwindle, San Franciscans Become Nostalgic for the Missing Tourists
description: The seals were barking up a riot on their favorite pier this afternoon, barking and clapping and all but doing cartwheels as they waited and waited for the tourists and their famous Boudin Bakery sourdough bread.

title: Awaiting Arbitrator, Teams Are Cautious
description: At the first meeting on contraction between representatives of major league players and owners last Thursday, management lawyers said they ideally would like to have plans in place by Nov. 20. The lawyers acknowledged, however, that they might not be able to achieve the ideal. There's the matter of a union challenge to the owners' plans to eliminate two teams that an arbitrator has to hear and decide.

title: Hospitals That Whisper 'Resort'
description: WHEN looking for deluxe overnight lodging, the first clue that a place might pamper you is valet parking. Another sign of status is a lavish lobby, perhaps a sunlit atrium with marble floors and a bubbling fountain.

title: Beyond the Black Diamonds
description: UP to 20 skiers a day are allowed to descend the Big Couloir, a vertical slash down the eastern face of the 11,166-foot-high peak of Lone Mountain, which dominates Big Sky resort in Montana. But they must be checked out by the ski patrol first, descend with a partner and carry shovels and transceivers (radio beepers) in case they get buried by an avalanche.

title: [RETHINK]: Manifestoes For the Next New York; [The Financial District]: Make a Playground for the Rich
description: By the time the World Trade Center buildings were completed, market forces had rendered them obsolete. Every day there was less reason for big financial firms to be near each other, and so, increasingly, they weren't. The world's biggest trading floor is now in Stamford, Conn., and the world's biggest financial shots work in Midtown or the suburbs. The destruction of the twin towers didn't kill any of them because they were nowhere near the place.

title: The Future That Stopped Working
description: If what you seek is something polished, pleasant and acceptably provocative, ''SOVIETS: Pictures From the End of the USSR'' (Yale University, $45) is not the coffee-table book for you. Its hundreds of grainy black-and-white images by Shepard Sherbell depict a land that was always raw, uncomfortable and so full of powerful contrasts -- the best and worst of the world -- that few would assume it could offer solace. Sherbell set out to portray the end of the Soviet Union. He offers ample evidence of the detritus that attests to the failure of the Soviet empire: the rusting hulks of ships or factories; the urban developments thrown up to house millions, littered with discarded pipes or even the carcasses of nuclear missiles; the vast factories whose architecture screams ''Planned!'' and whose workers struggle to keep production going; the fallen statues of Soviet heroes like Lenin or Feliks Dzerzhinsky, founder of the organization that became the K.G.B. Yet Sherbell's keen eye has also discovered why this most enduring of authoritarian systems did not, after all, prevail. Even the most ruined faces that gaze out from these vistas of destruction glisten with unvarnished human emotion, hinting at the vast cultural achievement that will always be Russia's, though it is merely glimpsed here. Alison Smale

description: CABBY NO. 1, SEPT. 13

title: Rift Grows Among Anti-Taliban Leadership
description: As Northern Alliance commanders relish their success at Mazar-i-Sharif and prepare to mount an offensive against the capital, Kabul, signs of division are emerging in the group's political leadership.

title: QUIZ ANSWERS
description: Questions are on page 38.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLATNICK, SAMUEL
description: POLATNICK-Samuel. Compassionate, learned, dedicated educator spent almost 40 years in the New York City Public School System. Executive Director of the division of high schools. First principal of Springfield Gardens, High School. Assistant Superintendent of Curriculum and Instruction in Great Neck. Served for eight years as member and President of The Board of Education in Plainview, L.I. He believed that every child must be empowered by the best possible public education to participate in modern society. Above all, cherished husband of Florence Tambor, beloved brother of Dr. Jerome Polatnick, devoted father to Steve & Rosa, Margaret Rivka and Michael. Doting grandfather of Esta, Inbar, Itai and Sandy. Dear brother-in-law to Selma A. Polatnick, Carolyn and Herb Sax, Frieda Miller, and to their families. A Memorial service is on Sunday, November 11, 2001 at 10:45AM at Riverside Gordon, Del Ray Beach, Florida.

title: Chocolate by Hand, Backed Up by Taste
description: CHOCOLATE is a simple sweet, basically nothing more than cocoa powder, cocoa butter and sugar, and perhaps a dash of flavoring or powdered milk. But for those who love it, the whole is much greater than the sum of its parts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VASATKA, PETER EMMONS
description: VASATKA-Peter Emmons. ''Artist at Large'', died unexpectedly on October 19th. He was 36. Survived by his parents Hugh and Roberta; siblings Laura (Robert), Gregory, Maren (Rick), Tria (Bradley) and nieces Lera, Jamie, Jessie and nephew Aaron. A celebration of Peter's life will be held on November 17, 10 A.M. at The Plaza Hotel, Versailles room. In lieu of flowers contributions preferred for a living memorial endowed to Peter in Central Park. Make checks payable to Central Park Conservancy and mail to Maren Vasatka, 2342 Monkton Road, N. Ferrisburg, VT. 05473.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DICLEMENTI, BEVERLY SHEPPARD
description: DiCLEMENTI-Beverly Sheppard. November 9, 2000. Four seasons have passed since you left us. We expected the earth to stand still when you closed your eyes for good but your gardens continue to grow, Saks stays in business despite your absence and love doesn't end with death, it just finds another way. Daddy and I picture you dancing along the stars each night with Fred Astaire and miss you more every day. All Our Love Forever, Frank and Debbie, Aunt Ginny, Kelly, Sheppie, Ryan, Laura and your friends.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 28 about spiritual retreats misidentified the site in Costa Rica at which the Omega Institute for Holistic Studies conducts winter programs. It is the Sueo Azul Resort, not Pura Vida.

title: The Very Good Apprentice

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the luxury home market described train service from New Canaan incompletely. Not all Metro-North commuters to New York have to change at Stamford; several trains a day in each direction are direct. A picture caption with the article misstated the price and ownership of a new house in Greenwich. It was built for its owner at a price of $8 million; it is not on the market for more than $7 million.

title: A Y.M.C.A. Changes Its Tune by Offering Office Space
description: The Vanderbilt Y.M.C.A. at 224 East 47th Street near Second Avenue is many things: a fitness center, a juice bar, a cafe and a child care center. Mostly, though, it's a budget hotel. For 70 years, the Vanderbilt has offered 400 rooms with bunk beds and shared baths at rates far below other city hotels. Last week, a room for two was $60 a night.

title: Designers Who Inspire One to Be Seated
description: INSPIRED by nature, Laura Spector of Fairfield climbs trees, cutting down gnarled branches and tangled vines that she sculpts into chairs, benches, arbors, archways and follies.

title: Last-Play Victory Shocks Roxbury Coach
description: Even Coach John Quinn of Roxbury was not sure his team had a shot against Elizabeth on Friday night. His team was without three key offensive starters, and its star running back, Sean Szarka, was hampered by a hand injury. Quinn expected to spend yesterday with his wife and their 15-month-old baby.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEVENS, PETER NORTON
description: STEVENS-Peter Norton. Died on October 17th, 2001 at age 73. His education includes a BS degree in economics from the University of Virginia and an MS Degree from MIT. He spent five years in the US Marine Corps. Peter was a Peace Corps Country Director for six Latin American countries. He is survived by two sons, Kendall Edward Stevens of Zurich, Switzerland, Peter Jerome Stevens of Lansing, MI, and Noel Elizabeth Samra of Miami, Florida and five grandchildren. He also leaves a brother Don Edward Stevens of La Jolla, CA., and a sister Hope Thayer Iaccaci of NYC. A memorial service was held in Miami, FL.

title: Army Takes Turn as Favorite, but Shows It's Not Up to the Part
description: Army found itself in a rare favorite's role when it encountered Buffalo today in the Black Knights' home finale at Michie Stadium. Army had won only two of eight games, but Buffalo, a fledging Division I-A team, had also won only two games, and against lesser competition. Buffalo came back in the fourth quarter, however, for a 26-19 victory.

title: The Sound of Recordings
description: In the early years of the 20th century, Camden was a center for the American recording industry, attracting musicians, including the opera legend Enrico Caruso, right, who made their recordings at the old Victor Talking Machine company. Now developers of the Delaware River waterfront not far from the old Victor studios have proposed a new museum, SoundWave, that will house collections of historic recorded sound as well as other artifacts of the industry.

Pope Jr. of Manhattan, and by five step grandchildren. No services are planned. Contributions: The Freer Gallery of Art, Washington D.C.

description: BROWN-Jordan S., M.D. Jordan our charming chauffeur, our compassionate doctor, our dear friend, our warm neighbor who laughed at our not so funny jokes. We will miss him. Emile and Diane

description: THE Museum of Television and Radio's current screening series, ''Disruptive Directors of British Television,'' will soon be focusing on a form of English drama that rarely gets optioned by PBS: the original teleplay.

description: KAREN WERFELMAN was teaching a ninth-grade algebra class at Hicksville High School when the principal announced over the public-address system that there had been a disaster at the World Trade Center.

description: GARSON-Eugene. May 8, 1926Nov. 12, 1998. An everlasting bond of love and devotion can never be broken. Gloria

title: Street Brawl; The New Power of Arab Public Opinion
description: THE Arab street: the well-worn phrase evokes men clustered around dusty coffeehouse tables, discussing the events of the day with well-earned cynicism between puffs on a hookah -- yet suddenly able to turn into a mob, powerful enough to sweep away governments.

title: [RETHINK]: Manifestoes For the Next New York; [Style]: Forget Fashion, Think Product Design
description: Never has the glazed gaze that models habitually wear on the runway seemed more appropriate than it did during the shows in New York, Milan and Paris, which ended mid-October. If the nihilistic glare of the models this time spoke to the surreal nature of the shows, occurring as they did while bombs were falling on Afghanistan, usually it can be read as a mirror of the audience. That audience, which could conceivably witness up to 250 shows a season, does its best every six months to bead and feather the dull routine of it all. But as editors lined up in their front-row seats this time, many turned to the left or turned to the right and asked, Is this the only way for fashion to register change? Like the closing of the stock market and the grounding of the nation's airlines, the halt to the runway shows in New York on Sept. 11 was a historic first. But before fashion picks up exactly where it left off, is there some way to rethink New York's industry and its role in this new world?

title: Newspapers and TV Paint U.S. Action as a Kind of Terrorism
description: Osama bin Laden is not being portrayed as a hero in the Arab media. But neither is the American war in Afghanistan being portrayed as anything heroic, or even wise or necessary.

title: Rahman Works His Way Up to Anonymity
description: Virtually in the clouds, on a mountaintop resort that is making the transition from the rust color of fall leaves to the rainbow raiment of skiers, the heavyweight boxing champion of the world is in training for his first defense of the title.

title: Lindros Lifts the Rangers and Raises His Olympic Profile
description: Just a couple of weeks ago, there were rumblings that Eric Lindros might be passed over by the Canadian Olympic team if he did not shake off some of the rust caused by a 16-month layoff.

title: The Knicks Are a Shadow Of Their Past
description: It is worse than anyone imagined. The Knicks, a legitimate conference contender for many years, have degenerated into an N.B.A. weakling in just seven months.

title: Mary Magsamen, Stephan Hillerbrand
description: Mary Elizabeth Magsamen, a video artist based in Brooklyn, and Stephan Christopher Hillerbrand, a television manager and instructor, are to be married today. The Rev. William Lutz, a United Church of Christ minister, will officiate at the New York Aquarium in Brooklyn.

title: November 4-10; Power-Sharing Prospects
description: For the moderate Protestant leader David Trimble and his effort to be elected first minister of the Northern Ireland Assembly, it was three strikes and you're in. Hard-line Protestants opposed to Mr. Trimble's willingness to share power in government with Sinn Fein, the party of the Irish Republican Army, denied him the support he needed in a first vote, brought legal action to stop a second vote and filed motions to forestall the third -- which ended up giving him victory. The long-awaited I.R.A. decision last month to start disarming and Mr. Trimble's hard-fought return to office held out the promise that the power-sharing assembly could function without interruption for the first time since its creation in 1999. Warren Hoge

title: The Defense Rests
description: THE WRONG MAN

title: John R. Fisher: Guiding Force From Below
description: It looked like the flight deck of the starship Enterprise. The operations control center in the World Trade Center basement was hooked up to every surveillance camera and intercom in the twin towers. Only 15 people were authorized to enter. John R. Fisher, a Port Authority security consultant, was one of them.

title: In Litchfield, A Restaurant Seasons the State
description: SINCE the West Street Grill opened on the historic Litchfield green in 1990, it has been hailed by critics and patrons for its creative new American cuisine and has been credited with starting the town's transformation from simple to chic.

title: Vietnam Ghosts
description: As Americans fight the war against terrorism, we assure ourselves that this conflict is completely different from the one we carried out a generation ago in Southeast Asia. Yet Vietnam's ghosts are still here. They do not tell us that our current fight is less than just or necessary. But they steal away the old certainty that the end will inevitably be triumphant. And Americans of a certain age will always shiver when the debate turns to the use of ground troops in far-away, inhospitable lands.

title: David Garcia: An Unexpected Present
description: David Garcia was a man who could make things work, albeit in the most unusual ways. Once, he patched up a pair of run- down work boots by gluing pieces of tire to the soles. And when the floor on his future wife's Chevy Malibu rusted out, he retrieved his tin sandbox and welded it to the bottom.

title: Christopher Stewart Gray: His Big Moment Came to Be
description: Just for a moment, Christopher Stewart Gray lived his greatest dream. He became a professional football player -- a strong-armed quarterback no less -- for the Miami Dolphins, the team he rooted and raved for while growing up in New Jersey. His big moment came in 1992, when the team offered him, a former University of West Virginia quarterback, a free agent contract.

title: Tribute to Maria Karnilova
description: A memorial tribute to Maria Karnilova, a charter member of American Ballet Theater who became a became a Tony-award winner as an actress, will be held tomorrow at 12 noon at the Lucille Lortel Theater,121 Christopher St. Ms. Karnilova died on May 20. George Irving, John Kander, Sheldon Harnick, Jerry Bock and, Donald Saddler will be among the speakers.

title: Lydia Peelle and Ketch Secor
description: EVERYONE who knows Lydia Child Peelle and Jay Ketcham Miller Secor agrees that their romance could come right from an episode of ''Dawson's Creek,'' the high school television drama.

title: Jeanine Famiglietti, John Chronakos
description: Dr. Jeanine Stephanie Famiglietti, the daughter of Josephine and Anthony Famiglietti of East Northport, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. John Chronakos, the son of Anna and John A. Chronakos of Whitestone, Queens. The Rev. James Kissane performed the ceremony at St. Anthony of Padua Roman Catholic Church in East Northport. Later in the day, a Greek Orthodox ceremony was performed by the Very Rev. Archimandrite John A. Heropoulos at the St. Paraskevi Greek Orthodox Shrine Church in Greenlawn, N.Y.

title: Letters: Rebuilding
description: REBUILDING

title: Old-Style Barroom Brawl At the Hoogeveen Corral
description: When my brother and I were children, we loved to go to the movies of a Saturday afternoon to see a horse opera. We particularly favored the saloon fights, which ended in the destruction of chairs, tables, balustrades and other friable pieces. Not to mention the damage to the wearers of hats, both white and black.

title: Art/Architecture; The Commemorative Beauty of Tragic Wreckage
description: A PIECE of architecture was created in Lower Manhattan last week, and architects had nothing to do with it. This major new work materialized during the scuffle that broke out between police officers and firefighters over access to ground zero. The firefighters believed, with the emotional logic that has helped prevent the terrorist attack from unraveling the soul of New York, that removal of the wreckage should not proceed without their participation. Their objective, which should be everyone's, is that all efforts should be made to retrieve and identify the remains of their fallen brethren before the wreckage is carted off to the dump.

title: Editors' Note; A Nation Challenged
description: News of the terrorist attacks and their aftermath appears today in Section B; index, Page B2.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCMAHON, GAVIN
description: McMAHON-Gavin. On September 11, 2001, World Trade Center at age 35. Loving son of Terence and Linda McMahon. Also survived by John and Maureen Sproha, Bertha Stirling, Maurice and Geraldine McMahon, Bridget Fitzpatrick and numerous cousins. Funeral Mass at St. Henry's Church, Avenue C between 28th and 29th St., Bayonne, NJ, Wednesday, November 14, 2001 at 9:30A.M. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to The ASPCA Memorial Program, 424 East 92nd St., New York, New York 10128.

description: Weeks

title: Sports of The Times; Forget the World; Fight Contraction
description: THE United States is at war and Major League Baseball says it will eliminate two sickly teams and politicians around the country have begun to cry out against the owners' proposed euthanasia. It is so heartening to know that our nation has grasped the lessons of Sept. 11 and has all its priorities in working order.

title: A Season Of Salutes
Editors' Note
description: An article last Sunday about the effects the Sept. 11 attacks have had on television news and entertainment cited the shortage of reliable firsthand reporting from the Afghan war zone. It said American reporters were ''forced to rely on video from the Defense Department and bits of unverifiable secondhand film sent out by a range of sources: the Taliban, the Arab television channel Al Jazeera, Reuters.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JESSE, DR. MARY JANE
description: JESSE-Dr. Mary Jane, 83. Died peacefully in Cincinnati on November 7, surrounded by loving family. Former president of the American Heart Association, she led major divisions at Columbia Presbyterian, NIH, University of Miami & University of Cincinnati. Thousands of patients, students, colleagues and friends whose lives she brightened will remember her always with love and admiration. Contributions can be sent to Habitat for Humanity, 420 W. Wyoming Avenue, Cincinnati, OH. 54215.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-11-01: Gallery
Kenneth J. Tarantino: The Christmas Connection
description: Kenneth J. Tarantino was known around Bayonne High School in New Jersey as "the cute sub." He worked there as a substitute teacher while going to college, and among his students in English class was the woman who would later become his wife.

title: New Year's Partygoers Consider A New Spot: The Hinterlands
description: Like many New Yorkers, Jay Emmanuel, a pop singer who lives in the Manhattan Plaza towers on 42nd Street and Ninth Avenue, recently had an unsettling dream. But his dream had one distinctive image: The New Year's Eve ball above Times Square exploded like a bomb, causing mayhem among the throngs below that resembled the scene at ground zero.

Beloved husband of the late Florence Druss, loving father of Nancy (Marty) Peckerar, Vicki ''Bracha'' (Aryeh) Goetz, adored grandfather of Andrew, Robby (Nomi) Peckerar, Sara Penina (Binyamin Zev) Yankelove, Gavriel, Rochel, Dina, Shira Leah, Binyamin Goetz. Donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Foundation, the American Heart Association, or Bais Yaakov School for Girls, Owings Mill, MD.

title: Around Alone to Add Leg And Return to Newport
description: For the long-distance sailor Richard Konkolski, Aug. 28, 1982, was a day to remember. That morning, Konkolski announced his defection from Czechoslovakia. That afternoon, he led a fleet of 17 solo sailors past Castle Hill off Newport, R.I., to begin the inaugural BOC Challenge, the first singlehanded around-the-world race to set out from the United States.

title: Corrections
