The missing entries are printed in this section, on Page A47, and the full series is on the Web, at www.nytimes.com/magazine.

title: Jane McNamara, John Oddy
description: Jane Brooks McNamara and John James Oddy were married yesterday in New York. The Rev. Stephen S. Garmey, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Century Association.

title: Oregon's Suicide Law, Under Siege
description: To the Editor:

title: Global Warming Impasse Is Broken
description: After four grinding years of negotiations, the final details of a pioneering treaty aimed at fighting global warming emerged from talks in Morocco yesterday, and many large industrial countries, excepting the United States, said they were likely to ratify the agreement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCVEIGH, JOSEPH EDWARD
description: McVEIGH-Joseph Edward. On November 9, 2001. Dear husband of Denise Finn McVeigh and beloved father of Brendan. Reposing Monday 2-5 and 7-9 pm Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Ave., NYC. Mass of Christian Burial Epiphany R.C. Church Tuesday 10 am. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Epiphany School Foundation, 234 East 22 St., NY, NY 10010, 212-473-6158

title: Oregon's Suicide Law, Under Siege
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHOMATE, JAMES P.
description: SHOMATE-James P. On October 13, 2001. Renowned accompanist, vocal coach, and humanitarian. A service commemorating his life will be held at The Weill Art Gallery, 92nd Street YM/YWHA, 1395 Lexington Avenue, NY, from 4-6 P.M., Wednesday, November 28, 2001. Memorial contributions in his name may be made to: The Curtis Institute of Music, Development Office, 1726 Locust Street, Philadelphia, PA. 19103.

title: Dance; Talking and Dancing, Reconcilable Differences
description: IN 1973, the fledgling choreographer Douglas Dunn wrote a poem, ''Talking Dancing,'' that borrows for its opening lines the dance-world aphorism, ''Talking is talking, and dancing is dancing,'' which means just what you'd think: talking and dancing don't mix. The poem proceeds by a rigorous and seemingly mindless process,  la Gertrude Stein, to rearrange the terms ''talking,'' ''dancing,'' ''and'' and ''is,'' and to undercut its opening truism. But Mr. Dunn's own long career has mainly respected the saying's sentiment.

title: Republican Redoubt No Longer
description: WITH Democrats winning landslide victories in key offices in both Nassau and Suffolk Counties in last week's elections, Democratic leaders locally and beyond heralded a new day for Long Island politics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAER, NORMAN
description: BAER-Norman. Husband, best friend of Josephine. Devoted father of Ellen, loving brother of Herbert Fensterheim. On November 8 in Los Angeles. Beloved sportswriter, producer, agent what will we do without you? Donations to Jackie Robinson Foundation, 3 West 35 Street, NY, NY 10001.

title: The Old School
description: By the time I reached my grandmother's house on the eastern shore of the Chesapeake Bay, I was dizzy with hunger. I had firmly resisted a Snickers bar at a rest stop, knowing I would regret it if I showed up even partly full. And so I sped down the highway, and then the single-lane roads that dart through cornfields, hurrying to get there.

title: Susan Alexander, John Kraus
description: Susan Alexander and John Kaufman Kraus are to be married this afternoon by Rabbi Dorothy A. Richman at the Golden Gate Club in San Francisco.

title: Alexandra Kirby, Dennis Taylor Jr.
description: Alexandra Pauline Kirby, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas C. Kirby of Garden City, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Dennis John Taylor Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Taylor Sr. of New Canaan, Conn. The Very Rev. James J. Cardone performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Cathedral of the Incarnation, where he is the dean.

title: Braided, Coiffed, Dreadlocked
description: The tress-obsessed who, after cutting, coloring, fussing over and just plain talking about their hair, still want more, can now read all about it. Several new books shed all sorts of light on the surprisingly inexhaustible topic of hair styles and styling.

title: Quandary in U.S. Over Use of Organs Of Chinese Inmates
description: Three years ago, in New York, one of Dr. Thomas Diflo's patients on a long waiting list for a kidney transplant showed up with a new problem: she no longer needed a kidney, but suddenly needed after-transplant care.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLATZER, ADELE
description: PLATZER-Adele. Of Lido Beach, NY. On November 7, 2001. Beloved wife of Philip. Devoted mother of Bruce and Francine Fox, Lauren Fox, and Sam and Hillary Fox. Adoring grandmother of Shelley, Jamie, Jonah, and Elijah Fox. Dear sister of Morton and Shirley Sloan, and Sydele and the late Harold Sloan. She was our golden girl who touched the lives of so many. She will live on in our hearts forever. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Light of Life Foundation, C/O Platzer, 2 Richmond Rd., Lido Beach, NY 11561.

title: Following Threads To Find Their Art
description: THE designation ''fabric artist'' leaves much to be clarified. What type of fabric? What texture? Is it cut? Sewn? Woven? Made into something else?Then there's the word ''artist.'' Just what kind of art is being made?

title: Radical Animal Rights Groups Step Up Protests
description: The incidents have not tailed off, even since Sept. 11: a firebombing at a federal corral for wild horses in northeastern California; a fire at a primate research center in New Mexico, and back-to-back break-ins in Iowa, one at a fur farm to release more than 1,000 mink, the other to free pigeons raised for research.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-11-01: Sightlines; The View From Out Here
description: We have a tendency to measure the life of New York by the habits and welfare of the upper-middle classes, which is rather like taking all your weather reports from 25,000 feet in the air. The vast majority of New Yorkers make less than $40,000 per year. This is their city too, though that version of New York doesn't have a series yet on HBO.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREIBERG, JANET
description: FREIBERG-Janet. On November 8, 2001. Loving mother of Jill and Edward. Her goodness, warmth and humor will be greatly missed by her many friends and family. Visiting Saturday 7-9 P.M. Service Sunday, 11:45 A.M. at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Life Without Father
description: Hockey equipment spills off the side porch of the stately but welcoming brick house in Pelham Manor, N.Y. There are a football by the kitchen door, soccer cleats in the hallway and a basketball migrating about. In the mudroom, near the perpetually running washer and dryer, a meticulous carpenter has built cubicles to control the chaos. Danny's cleats. Casey's shin guards. Peter's gloves and pads. Patrick's hard hat -- the bright yellow kind grieving families are given when they visit ground zero.

title: Post-9/11: The Series: 'The Nationals'
description: ''The Nationals'' is a one-hour drama with lots of good comedy, set behind the scenes with New York's other National League team.

title: November 4-10; The Voters Speak
description: The election winners all campaigned so much as centrists that it was sometimes hard to see who was the Democrat and who was the Republican. Democrats snatched the Virginia and New Jersey governorships from Republicans. But the platforms of Governors-elect Mark R. Warner of Virginia and James E. McGreevey of New Jersey often seemed more conservative than liberal. While Michael R. Bloomberg, the next mayor of New York, ran as a Republican, he had actually been a Democrat until he decided to run.

title: Bloomberg Recipe: Luck, Lots of Cash and a Hands-On Role
description: Thirty-six hours before the polls opened on Election Day, a wave of gloom swept through the Republican mayoral campaign of Michael R. Bloomberg. After a steady climb in the opinion polls, the race was suddenly threatening to slip away.

title: Girls With Goals Give Grown-Ups a Lesson
description: THE jerseys this year have a flame motif licking the shiny polyester sleeves. They come in all colors of the rainbow and are for the most part far too large for the kids who wear them, the miniature soccer players who stream out of their apartment buildings beginning in the quiet early hours of these improbably gorgeous fall weekends. Shinguards thickening their skinny legs, they nudge soccer balls on sidewalks that lead to a pristine field in Central Park or a dusty patch in Riverside. Sleepy parents with coffee in a go-cup walk along with their kids.

title: Spiritual Guidance
description: To the Editor:

title: Wearing It On Your Belt
description: The proliferation of I N.Y. logos has been a harbinger: the fashion graphic of the moment is the heart. No longer the sole domain of Moschino, this beguiling shape can be found this winter in a variety of accessories and sportswear.

title: Hands in the Dirt, Face Toward the Sun: Hope in the Garden
description: FOR six weeks every summer, campers at Camp Quinebaug, run by the Connecticut Department of Mental Retardation in Killingly, Conn., spend the warm days doing what generations of campers have done: swimming, boating and arts and crafts. But the 80 developmentally disabled children, teenagers and young adults also participate in something less familiar: horticultural therapy.

title: Facing the Problems Of Coffee Growers
description: To the Editor:

title: International Datebook: Dec. 17 to 31
description: DEC. 17 TO JAN. 1, MARAMURES, ROMANIA

title: Music; After Valhalla, a Home in Nuremberg
description: AFTER Wotan and the Dutchman, everybody kept asking for years, 'When will you do Hans Sachs?' I glanced at the score a couple of times, and it didn't speak to me. Finally I decided to do it, not because I wanted to but because it's what people were expecting.''

title: Homeless, Not Scandal, Shakes Up Atlantic City
description: An aggressive campaign by a challenger to recruit support from absentee voters has apparently ended the three-term career of Mayor James Whelan, who distinguished himself from most predecessors by running a scandal-free administration.

title: The Nation; A Last Gasp of Radical Cheek
description: THE slyly insightful writer Jorge Luis Borges once wrote a story in which an author replicates whole sections of ''Don Quixote'' as part of a novel. Nevertheless, the narrator, a critic, praises the fictional author for his originality, since even a word-for-word copy had a different, contemporary ring in the changed historical context.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-11-01: The Ethicist; Case Study Study
description: Browsing at a bookstore, I came across a book written by my old psychotherapist. To my surprise, I was an (unnamed) case study. Was it ethical to publish that without notifying me or verifying the details? Anonymous, New York

title: OUT THERE: Paris; Glittering Aromas From a Low-Key Star
description: ONE of the pleasures of going into JAR's, the jewelry shop in Paris owned by Joel A. Rosenthal, is that you have to wait for something to happen. There are no jewels in glass cases for you to pore over; no exultant pen-tapping on the counters to announce a sale, the way they do at Tiffany. There is just a Chesterfield sofa, a low table stacked with books and a Parsons desk set with a bouquet of flowers and some rocks -- not significant rocks, but the kind you might pick up and stroke. For luck.

title: Voter Portraits: New York City
description: After a campaign marked by the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center and record-breaking campaign spending, Michael R. Bloomberg was elected the 108th mayor of New York City last week, defeating his Democratic opponent, Mark Green. Pre-election polls showed Mr. Green leading by about 15 percentage points until the week before Election Day. After Mayor Giuliani endorsed him, Mr. Bloomberg began to close the gap and the last polls before the election showed the candidates tied.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEXNER, BELLA
description: WEXNER-Bella. Yeshiva University Women's Organization mourns the passing of Bella Wexner, a generous patron with her daughter Susan, of YUWO and its mission of assisting the students of Yeshiva. Mrs. Wexner was known far and wide for her lifelong dedication to the advancement of the Jewish people and steadfast support for Jewish education. Our heartfelt condolences to Susan and to her brother Leslie and to all members of the bereaved family. Dinah Pinczower National Chairman Harriet Muss Maguy Naparstek Gabrielle Propp Presidium

title: Q and A
description: Traveling as a Courier

title: Singed From the Attack, Trees Find a Safer Home
description: Just south of the onramp to the Brooklyn Bridge, on a patch of green, there is a small cluster of trees. Among them are six new transplants, easily spotted because they are singed at the tops. One also has flecks of fiberglass in its branches, and a string of videotape is threaded through its few leaves.

title: INVESTING WITH/James W. Stratton; Stratton Growth Fund
description: INSURANCE companies remain compelling investments despite the attacks on Sept. 11, says James W. Stratton, who manages the $45 million Stratton Growth fund.

title: S.E.C. Moves to Allow Exchange-Traded Funds
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has taken the first step toward allowing the introduction of actively managed exchange-traded funds.

title: History Up Close
description: To the Editor:

title: Ralph Licciardi: 'Handsome Son of a Gun'
description: Ralph Licciardi could stuff his ear lobe into his ear and then wiggle the ear until the ear lobe fell out. Few people can do that. Mr. Licciardi was pretty funny, but not in looks. He was "a handsome son of a gun," his father, Sebastiano, said, and a very much a family oriented person.

title: 1,000 Songs In Your Pocket
description: Apple's new MP3 player, the iPod, is the ultimate fashion accessory for the chic and famous. Introduced yesterday, the high-design white and chrome iPod is the size of a cassette tape and weighs about six ounces: small enough to tuck into an inside pocket or evening bag.

title: In Flowerless Seasons, the Charm of Foliage
description: WHEN we moved to our house 25 years ago, I envisioned borders filled with flowers from spring through fall. Lack of time and money squashed that dream. It takes time to plant swaths of long-blooming annuals in spring, and it takes money to have a continuous panorama of perennials in flower. By default, my borders often had long green, flowerless periods.

title: A Time Out for Bioterrorists
description: ON ''The Daily Show'' on Comedy Central, Jon Stewart, a New Jersey native, has a new segment titled ''America Freaks Out.'' I am here to tell you that New Jersey, particularly South Jersey, is setting the gold standard. We are freaking out with a vengance.

title: Beginnings
description: Since Sept. 11, New Yorkers have found themselves unable to escape the stunning reality of what the city has lost: thousands of lives, tens of thousands of jobs, billions of dollars in capital and seven buildings, including two that only now, in their absence, seem to have stood as twin symbols of the city's ambition and pride. In the immediate aftermath of the attacks, the magazine published ''Remains of the Day,'' a special issue that focused on that loss. Today, exactly two months after the attack on New York, the magazine looks away from the towers' destruction and ahead to the city's future. This issue's subject is rebuilding -- and not just of physical structures but also of psyches, families, institutions and communities. In a series of manifestoes, writers lay out their blueprints for a better New York. In ''Let Us Count the Ways,'' New Yorkers remind us why the city inspires such love. And some of the city's musical stars contribute original songs, commissioned by the magazine and inspired by this moment: a soundtrack for a city full, even now, of possibilities.

title: Florio Sees a Budget Mess, But Not as Bad as His Was
description: Jim from Metuchen was on the line again. He'd called in to a radio station after the first gubernatorial debate last month with a scathing analysis of Bret D. Schundler's performance: ''stunningly uninformed, and embarrassingly superficial,'' he'd said in that distinctive acid tone.

title: Matriculation Fixation
description: Two years ago, I was languishing in the waiting room of a Philadelphia hospital when a complete stranger unexpectedly began telling me about his daughter's college plans. As my 79-year-old mother was recovering from major surgery that afternoon, I could not give him my complete and undivided attention. But as the briefing session wore on, I did manage to garner most of the relevant details.

title: Where to Get a Train
description: Taking a cue from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority store at Grand Central Terminal, New Jersey Transit will open its own shop tomorrow at Newark Penn Station, full of items emblazoned with the agency's orange, fuscia and purple logo. The store is stocked with clothing, commemorative items and scale-model trains and buses produced in the striking detail demanded by serious collectors. Jeff Warsh, the agency's executive director -- a professed ''railroadiana'' collector -- said the 500-square-foot space failed to attract a commercial tenant. But as a transit store, he said, it will boost employee pride, spread the New Jersey Transit name, and give the station a fun place to shop. One commuting dad who stopped to stare, Richard Latrell, 38, of Atlantic Highlands, said his son, Ricky, 7, would love the store. ''Maybe I'll get him a train set for Christmas,'' he said. Steve Strunsky

title: Back Issues
description: THE AGE OF SCIENCE

title: Anna S. Allison: From Wine, a Beginning
description: Love blossomed over crushed grapes.

title: Riva Atlas, David Atik
description: Riva Debra Atlas and David Charles Atik are to be married today by Rabbi Jonathan I. Rosenblatt at the Sands, a caterer in Atlantic Beach, N.Y.

title: Appreciation, Size XXL
description: In a motif of bloopers, corrections from various newspapers have been stenciled along the restroom walls of the Newseum, the museum of news in Arlington, Va.

title: Consolation
description: To the Editor:

title: Private Sector; In This Particular Tire Test, Failure Was Not an Option
description: To hear Edouard Michelin tell it, there was almost a ''religious silence'' when the Air France Concorde took off from Charles de Gaulle airport at 10:30 a.m. on Wednesday. With the plane safely airborne, the passengers broke into the kind of applause that travel sophisticates usually eschew. Small wonder: the supersonic jets were grounded after July 25, 2000, when a blown tire on takeoff caused a fatal crash, so even road warriors could be forgiven a small frisson. Mr. Michelin, though, insists that the applause came less from relief than delight. ''Everyone was just so happy that this big white magic bird was back in the air,'' he said.

title: 15 Minutes Of Fame Has Lasted 35 Years
description: LONG ago-go, in 1964, when Baby Jane Holzer, Edie Sedgwick and Jean Shrimpton, some of New York's first postmodern glamour girls, were giving uptown society a run for its old money, Holly Solomon, an actress-in-training with a Sarah Lawrence degree, an ocelot coat, a wealthy husband, two sons, a love of the avant-garde and a fear of boredom, settled into a photo booth on 42nd Street with $25 in quarters.

title: How Green Was His Valley
description: LANDOR'S TOWER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENBERG, VIVIANE
description: EISENBERG - Viviane. Died peacefully in her sleep on November 7 at her home in Delray Beach, FL. Survived by Everett, her loving husband of many years. She was 88 years old. Viviane was a Parisienne for the first half of her life. She was a diva, as Viviane Toubiana, singing to great acclaim the lyric roles Butterfly, Boheme, Traviata, etc, etc, for l'Opera de Paris, l'Opera Comique and in opera houses throughout Europe and North Africa. Then she became a New Yorker, living in Manhattan until recently. Gatherings of remembrance will be convened in Delray Beach, New York and Paris.

title: Bioterror Role An Uneasy Fit For the C.D.C.
description: On the morning of Sept. 11, not long after terrorists crashed planes into the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta received a worrisome tip from the F.B.I.: Another hijacked aircraft appeared headed for Atlanta and possibly the C.D.C., whose laboratories house some of the world's deadliest germs, including the only official repository of smallpox outside Russia.

title: Private Sector; An Oklahoman From Up North
description: For many American consumers who fear that the United States is overly dependent on OPEC, it may be a revelation to learn that Canada is a leading source of natural gas and crude oil. What is more, most of the natural gas and crude imported from Canada comes from one province, Alberta. Murray Smith, Alberta's energy minister, visited the United States last week to assure his biggest customer that Alberta was a steady and loyal supplier.

title: Why Republicans Lost: Ideology or Circumstance?
description: JUST before Bret D. Schundler walked on stage to give his concession speech, the Republican chairman, Joseph M. Kyrillos -- trying almost anything to rev up supporters -- mentioned how proud he was of the party. His comments drew a chorus of boos from the conservative Schundler crowd, which in turn elicited tight smiles from the moderates on the dais.

title: QUICK BITE/Princeton; A Bowl and a Bite at the Y
description: Ruth Alegria used to be the owner of the two Mexican Village restaurants in Princeton and Lambertville. Now she's running a more modest operation, a lunch spot called the Garden Caf, in the Y.M.C.A.-Y.M.H.A. in Princeton. She says she can make a good soup out of almost anything, and that is what she does. ''I research a lot of soup recipe books, but I swear some of my best soups come out of the blue,'' she said, citing one of her more popular creations as a mixture of some leftover carrot-ginger, split pea and lentil soups. Customers have been asking her for the unnamed soup ever since. She prepares two soups each day, making the unassuming one-room cafe across from the Y's day care center a popular stop for lunch. The menu depends largely on how Ms. Alegria and her son Blake Varr feel that morning, but a few items like chicken, egg and tuna salads, are almost always on the menu. The chicken salad, served on white, wheat or a croissant, consists entirely of breast meat, poached then shredded and prepared with fresh onions, celery, carrots and spices, many of which have traveled with Ms. Alegria from the Union Square market in Manhattan.A $5.25 combination price buys half a sandwich and bowl of soup. A smaller platter, the $2.95 quiche du jour, always light and airy, may be the traditional potato-bacon-onion variety or made with spinach, red pepper and Brie. The huge brownies ($2), also made by Ms. Alegria, offer a decadent conclusion.

title: 'Roosevelt's Secret War'
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Islam Meets 'Brave New World'
description: Life is short, pray on time!'' warns a sign in a stairwell. Below it, a flier reads ''Eighth-grade girls bake sale! Wednesday.'' A sticker on an office file cabinet announces in stylized Arabic that there is no God but Allah, and Mohammad is his prophet; beside it, an American flag waves on a computer screen.

title: Oregon's Suicide Law, Under Siege
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the influence of women in Islamic cultures misstated the affiliation of Rounaq Jahan, an expert on women in developing countries. It is Columbia University's School of International and Public Affairs, not Public and International Affairs.

title: All Must Join Fight Against Terror, Bush Tells U.N.
description: President Bush tried to cast the war against Osama bin Laden and the Taliban in the broadest global context today as he told the United Nations that every member country was a potential target of terrorism and that responsibility for fighting it was ''binding on every nation with a place in this chamber.''

title: Iris Murdoch
description: REVIEWS

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Fleetwood, Mount Vernon; Diverse, Convenient, Leafy and Friendly
description: JUST north of the city streets of the Bronx and south of suburban Bronxville, the leafy Fleetwood section of Mount Vernon offers a spectrum of housing alternatives -- co-ops, rentals, multifamily residences and single-family houses -- for a diverse population.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELSTEIN, ALICE L.
description: ELSTEIN-Alice L. Never without a smile, she died peacefully on October 28th. She collected friends and kept them for life. One of the funniest people we ever met, she wrote colorful, witty work. Honest, generous, accepting, she looked for the best in people. Graduated with honors from Queens College at age 80. Husband Bernard, sons Paul and Kenneth, grandsons Robert, David, and Daniel, and other family and friends will always miss her.

title: The World; Running Terrorism as a New Economy Business
description: AT the embassy bombings trial earlier this year, Osama bin Laden's Al Qaeda network looked nothing like the far-reaching and sophisticated terror organization that most Americans have feared and loathed since Sept. 11. Instead, Al Qaeda Inc. resembled a start-up company struggling to adapt to the ever-changing rules of the new economy.

title: Finding Duty and Privilege in 24 Notes
description: WHEN Frank Calistro puts his glinting silver trumpet to his lips and plays ''Taps'' at a military funeral, the mournful vibrato at the end makes grown men cry, especially if they are old soldiers who know the words.

title: Steven Strobert: Knew When She Met Him
description: The woman was pregnant and frightened. It was during the 1993 World Trade Center bombing. Steven Strobert, a hefty six-foot bond broker for Cantor Fitzgerald, put one big arm around her and guided her down a hundred flights of stairs. "He was so modest, he never really told me much," recalled his wife Tara. "I didn't know about it till later. His mother brought it up. He just said, `Yeah.' "

title: U.S. May Air C.I.A. Ties to Peru Spy Chief
description: The Bush administration may soon disclose secret details of the relationship between the Central Intelligence Agency and Peru's powerful former spy chief, Vladimiro L. Montesinos, Peru's president said in an interview yesterday in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOK, FREDERICK H.
description: COOK-Frederick H. Age 86 of Liberty Corner, N.J. formerly of New Vernon, N.J. on November 7, 2001. Retired CEO of Purolator, Inc., Dillon, Read and Co., Inc. and Congoleum Nairn. Beloved husband of Beryl (Anderson) Cook, devoted father of Susan C. Murray and Nancy C. O'Brasky, brother of Robert A. Cook and grandfather of Christopher B. and Stephen F. Murray. A Memorial service will be held Sunday November 11, 2001 at 11:00 A.M. in the Church of St. John on the Mountain, Mt. Harmony Road, Bernardsville, N.J. Interment private. Those planning an expression of sympathy are asked to consider contributions in his memory to the Arthritis Foundation, 200 Middlesex Turnpike, Iselin, N.J. 08830 would be appreciated. For information, contact Gallaway & Crane Funeral Home, Basking Ridge.

title: Somalia Winces as Its Chaos Attracts U.S. Attention
description: In many ways Somalia is like another collapsed country across the Arabian Sea, one that is under American bombardment.

title: Paperback Advice
description: This

title: Seeking Privacy Online, Even as Security Tightens
description: CONSUMER privacy is getting a squeeze on all sides these days.

title: Music; At the End, Fiddling His Way Back To His Beginnings
description: IN the weeks before the singer, songwriter and multi-instrumentalist John Hartford died of non-Hodgkins lymphoma in June at age 63, a procession of old friends and associates visited him at his Nashville home to say goodbye and play music for him. On his veranda overlooking the Cumberland River, Hartford, no longer able to play an instrument himself, called out the names of tunes he wanted to hear, and his friends obliged, serenading him for hours.

title: Scratch and Pass
description: Answering those mundane multiple-choice test questions can now have all the tactile thrill of an instant lottery ticket.

title: Investor Expectations Slip
description: Investors have begun to scale down their expectations for the stock market, although most are counting on much better returns next year, according to a new survey by the Securities Industry Association.

title: Indian Woman Is Episcopal Bishop
description: Across from the Rev. Carol J. Gallagher's office at St. Anne's Episcopal Church here is a room hung with small portraits of the priests who have served the 297-year-old parish. All were men -- except, of course, for her.

title: Film; From Afar, '2001' Looks Like 1968
description: THE year was 1970, the hour was late, and the dark-bearded young man in the college bookstore had fixed his pupils, the size and color of two double espressos, on a new paperback, ''The Making of Kubrick's '2001.' '' Everything about its pictures -- the text was beyond him for the moment -- seemed both wondrous and reasonable to my fellow youth-culturist, whose voice had caught my attention from four aisles away. ''Yes,'' he was saying, ''right,'' he said, ''a space station, right, of course, they'll have a space station, they'll have a space station by 2001.'' His tone was admirably calm for someone who was raving.

title: Terrence P. Farrell: Giving His Very Self
description: Terrence P. Farrell lived close to the flame, said his brother Dennis. As a transit police officer, Terrence Farrell's specialty had been disasters. In the Fire Department, he joined Rescue Company 4, an elite unit specially trained to do things like extricate people from collapsed buildings.

title: Art/Architecture; Making Art of Masochism and Tests of Endurance
description: ZHANG HUAN began his career in art by sitting still. A performance artist with a provocative edge, Mr. Zhang has managed, from humble beginnings in poorest China, to make himself an international contemporary art success by enduring punishments of his own devising.

title: Imagining Together
description: To the Editor:

title: Your Home; Tenant Law Can Vary By Borough
description: MOST people know that different courts occasionally reach different conclusions when faced with the same basic facts. A person walking beside the road with a shotgun during hunting season would be treated quite differently in some rural parts of the state than he would be in New York City. In some cases, however, disparate judicial decisions result neither from differences in the facts nor the law, but from the way a particular court interprets a law at a given moment.

title: Post-9/11: The Series: 'Stayin' Alive'
description: These days there are enough smart-talking kids on television to warrant outlawing parenthood altogether. And they have little to tell us about life after Sept. 11. If I were pitching a sitcom based in New York today, I'd want to deal with the other end of life -- three elderly couples and a host of widows and widowers who spend their days at a recreational center for seniors, a few miles from ground zero.

title: Phones Abroad
description: To the Editor: In response to ''Cellphone Users: Options Abroad,'' (Practical Traveler, Oct. 14): I wish to add my very positive experience with my cellphone that works easily both here and abroad.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: THE first time the world saw the devastating 23-minute D-Day scene at the beginning of SAVING PRIVATE RYAN (1998), its impact wa about the horror of war. But now that we know battlefield-horrible deaths can come on sunny Tuesday mornings over coffee at our desks, the scene plays differently. Now it's about the loss. And the film's plot is a microcosm of the ultimate question about waging war. Is it worth risking the lives of eight men (led by Tom Hanks) to find and save one (Matt Damon as Pvt. James Ryan of Iowa, whose three brothers have all just died in combat)? The film won five Oscars, including Steven Spielberg's as best director - Sunday at 8 p.m. on Channel 7.

title: Perspective; Reader Responses Continue to Pour Through the Yankee Floodgate
description: We have surely moved on. Or have we? The First Fan, by staging a late-inning rally in the New York mayor's race, managed to keep a hated opponent from winning the championship. Yankee management, avoiding the sentimentality it demands only of fans, began the human pruning, weeding and replanting process that will transform the greatest team of our time into the greatest team of some other time. Baseball itself will abandon its traditional premise of being a pastime with a civic subtext by closing down money-losing teams.

title: Sports of The Times; Call It What It Is: Subtraction
description: THE new buzzword in baseball is contraction, as in the folding of two franchises. But what the owners want to do is really subtraction. In any math class, 2 from 30 has always been subtraction, not contraction.

title: Afghan War Divides Rome Into Two Rallies
description: A huge ''U.S.A. Day'' pageant starring Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi brought tens of thousands of people into the Piazza del Popolo tonight without provoking the violence that many had feared.

title: In This Particular Tire Test, Failure Was Not an Option
description: To hear Edouard Michelin tell it, there was almost a "religious silence" when the Air France Concorde took off from Charles de Gaulle airport at 10:30 a.m. on Wednesday. With the plane safely airborne, the passengers broke into the kind of applause that travel sophisticates usually eschew. Small wonder: the supersonic jets were grounded after July 25, 2000, when a blown tire on takeoff caused a fatal crash, so even road warriors could be forgiven a small frisson. Mr. Michelin, though, insists that the applause came less from relief than delight. "Everyone was just so happy that this big white magic bird was back in the air," he said.

title: Peter C. Fry: A Big-Handed Fisherman
description: Big hands were an asset to Peter C. Fry, even when he was using them to tie flies onto hooks to use as bait when fly-fishing. It was an activity on a rainy day, when fishing might be out of the question, for him and his 6-year-old daughter, Taylor. She had a natural advantage with her smaller fingers, but Mr. Fry's hands taught hers, said his wife, Meredith. Mr. Fry's friends say they will take Taylor fishing now.

title: Children's Books
description: This

title: Private Sector; Bringing Up Baby Einstein
description: Five years ago, Julie Aigner-Clark, a former high school English and art teacher, created the Baby Einstein company to fill a need she did not see others supplying: books, videos and compact discs for babies that expose them to poetry, language, music and art. She began by shooting a video for her newborn daughter in the basement of the family home in Lone Tree, Colo.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-11-01; Lost and Found
description: I'm here because I was born here and thus ruined for anywhere else, but I don't know about you. Maybe you're from here, too, and sooner or later it will come out that we used to live a block away from each other and didn't even know it. Or maybe you moved here a couple years ago for a job; maybe you came here for school. Maybe you saw the brochure. The city has spent a considerable amount of time and money putting the brochure together, what with all the movies, TV shows and songs -- the whole ''if you can make it there'' business. The city also puts a lot of effort into making your hometown look really drab and tiny, just in case you were wondering why it's such a drag to go back sometimes.

title: November 4-10; Israeli Withdrawal Continues
description: The odd couple leading the Israeli government -- the hawkish prime minister, Ariel Sharon, and the dovish foreign minister, Shimon Peres -- said that they were collaborating on a peace proposal. The two did not immediately come to terms, and Palestinian leaders rejected the few leaked details. Israeli forces withdrew from two more Palestinian-controlled cities but continued to hold positions in two others. Israelis said that to stop attacks, troops would continue blockading several Palestinian cities.

title: Smithtown Sets Up Library Tax District
description: Town of Smithtown residents voted overwhelmingly on Tuesday to turn their library system into an independent taxing district, allowing them to vote for library trustees and a library budget. Since 1952, the library has been controlled by the town.

title: On Long-Lost Pages, a Female Slave's Voice
description: In the spring of 1857, one of John Hill Wheeler's slaves slipped away from his North Carolina plantation and made her way north to New Jersey. There she promptly picked up a quill pen and began to write a novel, combining the story of her own life with elements of the many sentimental sagas she had evidently borrowed from Mr. Wheeler's shelf.

title: It's a Volatile, Complex World...
description: A mere semester ago, in a country that has spent much of the last decade refashioning the world in its own image, the guiding assumption among most educators was that students, like the rest of America, were growing less and less interested in foreign policy and international affairs. Since the end of the cold war, course descriptions have shifted to address issues relevant to a seemingly safe world, and federal spending on international education has dropped in real dollars. Since the 1960's, foreign language study has declined sharply. And despite the fact that there are 1.3 billion Muslims in the world, the majority of undergraduates at American universities have been exposed to only a limited range of courses about Islamic history, politics and culture, with the number of academics in these fields relatively small.

title: Lost in Cyberspace
description: To the Editor: Regarding ''Fewer Passengers, Fewer Flights,'' and the box on ''Airlines' Policies on Refunds and Changes'' (Sept. 30), in which a Web site for United Air Lines was provided:

title: Divas, Dwarfs and Dogs
description: MOLTO AGITATO

title: Paperback Business Best Sellers
description: This

title: With One Prize in Hand, Afghan Rebels Press On
description: Fresh from their first tangible victory of the war, rebel troops attacked Taliban positions today in the far northeast, consolidating their gains and claiming to have secured a string of provincial capitals as their opponents retreated.

title: An Open Door
description: To the Editor:

title: Music; A Big Girl Now? Or Just Posing?
description: GO ahead and leer. Britney Spears wouldn't have it any other way. In fact, if the world isn't riveted by the sexual brinkswomanship of a cleavage-baring, avowedly virginal, heavy-breathing, lightly clad 19-year-old, then Ms. Spears and her handlers have seriously miscalculated. Her third album, ''Britney'' (Jive 1241-41776-2) seeks, like most pop, to invite a mass audience to share a particular feeling. For the just under 40 minutes that the album lasts, people of all ages and genders can feel like a dirty old man.

title: November 4-10; Assault on Assisted Suicide
description: One week after moving to crack down on a California law allowing the distribution of marijuana for medical purposes, Attorney General John Ashcroft took on the Oregon law that allows physicians to prescribe lethal medication for terminally ill patients. Mr. Ashcroft directed federal drug agents to revoke the licenses of any doctor who does so, even though Oregonians upheld the law by 60 percent to 40 percent when a challenge to it arose on their ballot four years ago. A federal judge in Portland temporarily blocked Mr. Ashcroft, but many Oregonians remained enraged that a state's rights administration had sought to thwart the voters' will. Sam Howe Verhovek

title: Jude Moussa: Family, and a Simple Life
description: Jude Moussa did not keep a lot of clutter in his apartment in Battery Park City. It was clean and sparse and uncomplicated, and that's the way he liked it.

title: Sitting With Memories in a London Park
description: THE first order of the day as soon as I arrive in London is to head for Berkeley Square, that perfect oval of greenery in the midst of Mayfair's haughty shops and men's clubs. My destination is a wooden bench in the northwest corner of the garden; in my fantasy life, this is my very own parcel of London real estate.

title: A Society Page With Her Name on It
description: THE voice on the answering machine is as lilting and aristocratic as Daisy Buchanan's, only with a hint of urgency.

title: A Historic Delaware Mill Is Transformed
description: Several years ago, when producers came looking for suitable sites to film a television documentary on the Civil War, Roy H. Lopata, this city's planning director, took them to a vacant mill at the northern edge of this classic college town.

title: A Fall Festival of Game
description: The fall harvest season is also the season for game, and many restaurants, including these, are featuring game dishes.

title: Carry-On Rules
description: To the Editor: Hope Reeves describes the myriad items that airport personnel will confiscate in ''Carry-On Rules: List Grows Long,'' (Practical Traveler, Oct. 21). My recent experience at the Greenville, S.C., airport shows concern for the individual.

title: Name Your Favorite 'Simpsons' Character
description: Homer ran away with the balloting in this week's survey. Many identified with his personality traits while others just felt that everything he said was funny. Homer's daughter Lisa came in second. Readers enjoyed watching her because of perceived similar academic and familial experiences in childhood.

title: A Paradise of Loss
description: THE LAST CANYON

title: American Spirit
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: 'The Girls in the Van'
description: November 6, 2000. We are somewhere in the air between Rochester and La Guardia, in a twelve-seat turboprop plane, playing a Frank Buckley Travel Game that is slowly restoring my sanity.

title: Television/Radio; A Bit Older and Sadder, but Still Fabulous, Darling
description: I DID it because I wanted to work with all those people again, and because it was such fun,'' said Jennifer Saunders, trying with limited success to explain how it was that she came to write six new episodes of ''Absolutely Fabulous'' long after the show was supposed to be dead and gone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARNELL, WILLIAM
description: GARNELL-William, 77. Of Florham Park, NJ and New Marlborough, MA., on November 3, 2001. Loving husband of Natalie. Devoted father of Joni and David. Caring grandfather of Matthew, Noah, Evan, Dana, Jeremy, Benjamin & Daniel. A member of Actor's Equity, SAG and AFTRA, he was a professional actor before and after his career with AT&T Technologies. An avid tennis player, fisherman and painter, he lived his life to the fullest.

title: And Bear In Mind
description: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADELHARDT, ANDREW J.
description: ADELHARDT-Andrew J. Of Massapequa on November 8, 2001. Retired president of Adelhardt Construction Corporation N.Y.C. Graduate of Syracuse University School of Architecture. Former chairman, board of trustees Old Westbury School of The Holy Child. Former president of Mechanics Institute. Former trustee Portsmouth Abbey School. Former president American Lung Association of Queens. Beloved husband of Barbara. Devoted father of Andrew J. III and wife Catherine, Susan Adelhardt & husband David Whitney, Mary and husband Scott Thompson, David and wife Suzanne. Dear brother of Anita Zimmon and Helen Hammond. Cherished grandfather of Andrew J. IV and Anna. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Ronald McDonald House, 405 East 73rd St., N.Y.C. 10021, would be appreciated.

title: Threading Needles for Good Causes
description: MEMBERS of the Comfort Quilters say their group's name has a double meaning: the quilts they make and donate to needy people in Westchester and Putnam bring comfort to the recipients; the process of making them is relaxing and gratifying -- comforting -- to the quilters themselves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZELMAN, ROBERT
description: ZELMAN-Robert. On October 28. Loving husband of Rose. Father of Lois and Eric S. Weiss. Grandfather of Gabe, Mona, Bradley. Brother of Rose Davis & Sidney.

title: Voices Over the Din
description: Why quiet the students when you can amplify the teachers? With studies showing a correlation between classroom amplification and student achievement, more and more teachers are using wireless microphones and transmitters to make themselves heard.

title: For Latin Dancing, Follow the Beat and the Crowd
description: FIVE years ago, Eddie Perez moved from the Bronx to Stamford and was surprised to find such a pronounced Hispanic presence in his new neighborhood.

title: Peace Corps Is Vital
description: To the Editor:

title: DataBank; Dow Breaks Through Pre-Attack Level
description: Stocks posted big gains this past week, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average to its highest close since the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHORE, ETHELEE (LEAH)
description: SHORE-Ethelee (Leah). On Nov. 2, 2001 (nee Finifter) age 67, mother of Tevy Shore, Shirah Shore, & Ariel Shore, daughter of Esther, & the late Morris Finifter. Jewish and Hebrew educator for 50 years. Contributions can be made to the Twin Towers Fund, GPO, P.O. Box 26999 New York, New York 10087-6999 or Israel Bonds, 2 Reservoir Circle, Suite 203, Baltimore, MD. 21208.

title: Egypt, Our Friend?
description: To the Editor:

title: Islam and Intellectuals
description: To the Editor:

title: Judy Nathan, Andrew Fusco
description: Judy Ellen Nathan, a lawyer, and Andrew Lambert Fusco, a jazz saxophonist and music teacher, were married last evening in New York. Rabbi Robert A. Raab officiated at the Yale Club.

title: Five-Alarm Firefighting Chic
description: NEW YORK police and firefighter chic is clearly in, to judge from all the politicians, celebs and other assorted boosters and trend lemmings sporting F.D.N.Y. and N.Y.P.D. caps and apparel since Sept. 11.

title: Dr. Marian Fischman, 62; Studied the Effects of Cocaine
description: Marian Fischman, a scientist who explored narcotics addiction by paying addicts to take heroin, cocaine and other drugs, died on Oct. 23 at New York Presbyterian Hospital. She was 62 and lived in Manhattan.

title: American Spirit
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Destruction Casts a Spotlight
description: ANGUS KRESS GILLESPIE'S throat catches and a tear wells up in his eye as he brings up the name Frank DeMartini, a friend.

title: Laurie Sadly Listening
description: Laurie if you're sadly listening

title: November 4-10; Linking Size and Smarts
description: Just as body size is in part inheritable, so too is the anatomy of the human brain. The volume of gray matter in the frontal lobes is under particularly tight genetic control, according to a study by Dr. Paul Thompson of the University of California at Los Angeles. He found that the larger the volume of gray matter -- a measure of the number of brain cells -- the higher a person's intelligence was likely to be. The connection is on average; an individual's I.Q. cannot be gauged this way. The degree to which intelligence is inherited has long been disputed; Dr. Thompson's physical measures of gray matter may help narrow the argument. Nicholas Wade

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: Q

title: Alyssa Cohen, Marco Tablada
description: Alyssa Robin Cohen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Cohen of New York, is to be married today to Marco Aurelio Tablada, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Tablada Jr. of San Antonio. Judge Harold Baer Jr. of the Federal District Court in Manhattan will officiate at the Essex House.

title: Small Country, Big Day, One Ecstatic Moment
description: THE SETTING -- More than 100 people are crammed into two rooms at Mammalinda restaurant on West 52nd Street in Manhattan, and they are waiting anxiously for the broadcast of the World Cup qualifying match between Ecuador and Uruguay. A victory or a tie would send Ecuador, population 13 million, to its first World Cup finals. This is a big, big deal.

title: Che in Africa
description: THE AFRICAN DREAM

title: November 4-10; Enron, a Giant Bargain
description: With its principal business in peril, Enron agreed to be acquired by Dynegy for $9 billion -- one-ninth what it was worth last year. Enron, of Houston, used political muscle and trading-floor savvy to create new markets for electricity and gas and become the nation's dominant energy trader. Yet its refusal to explain its finances caught up to it last month, when investors fled after disclosure of an S.E.C. probe and an unusual $1.2 billion reduction in shareholder equity. After it admitted overstating profits by $600 million, other energy companies began to shun Enron, putting its trading business in jeopardy. Finally, a humbled Enron, out of options, threw itself into the arms of Dynegy, its much smaller crosstown rival. Richard A. Oppel Jr.

title: Two New Plays: A Comedy And a Suburban Esther
description: PEGGY is a junior associate on the move in a big-deal law firm. She needs a paralegal. Tim, dressing casually for such starchy surroundings, wants the job, though he loathes everything it represents. If anything, he's overqualified.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, DAVID W.
description: LEWIS-David W. On November 7, 2001. Died peacefully in his 97th year following a short illness. Beloved husband of Muriel. Devoted father of Stephen, Daniel, and Robert, and daughters-in-law Suzanna, Claudia, and Stacey. Adored grandfather of Rachel, Aaron, Matthew, Ethan, Jennifer and Samuel. Loving brother of the late Charles Lewis, the late Alice Berman and the late Florence Shafran. He was the former President and CEO of Certified Moving & Storage Company, a founder of the Riverdale Temple, a Trustee of the Riverdale YM/YWHA, and a former Federation of Jewish Charities Chairman for the Moving and Storage Industy. Services at the Riverdale Temple, Monday, November 12, 2001 at 11:30 A.M.; interment is at Mount Lebanon Cemetery. Donations may be made to the Riverdale Temple and Riverdale YM/YWHA.

title: New Yorkers Lose Their Inner Rand McNally; Sept. 11 Rips Up Mental Maps That Guide City Dwellers' Lives
description: Early human ancestors on the African savanna had to find food, avoid being eaten by predators, and on top of all that remember how to get home again across a complex, dangerous terrain. It was too much, development experts say, and the mind's solution, arrived at over thousands of years, was to divide up the tasks. Thinking about paths and landscapes was shifted mostly into the subconscious, leaving the rest of the brain free for the hard work of earning a living.

title: Post-9/11: The Series: 'Ground Zero'
description: ''Ground Zero,'' the ultimate reality show, would follow every movement and moment in the lives of a cross-section of New Yorkers who live or work in or near the site of the World Trade Center. Subjects would include: the mayor, a fireman, a stockbroker, a cabdriver, a prostitute, an illegal-immigrant janitor, a child who lost a parent. I would get the widest possible ethnic, generational and gender mix. At least two of the participants should be Arab or Arab-American.

title: The Perfect House From (Go Ahead, Say It) the Perfect Broker
description: IT is 10:20 on a Tuesday morning in early autumn, and Carolyn Klemm is whizzing through Washington Depot in her immaculate, black Range Rover, one hand gesturing as fast as she is talking, spieling stories about which major person bought which major property through her Litchfield County real-estate agency.

title: Abused Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Private Sector; Banker's Novel Late-Career Move
description: AT an age when most people think about retiring and at a time when many younger investment bankers are doing so, A. Robert Towbin made an unexpected career move after Sept. 11.

title: Postings: A Civil Court Guide on Sept. 11 Issues; For Owners And Tenants
description: ''Legal Information and Resource Guide for Owners and Tenants Affected by the World Trade Center Disaster,'' a 47-page booklet that addresses issues connected with the Sept. 11 attacks, has recently been issued by Justice Fern Fisher-Brandveen, the administrative judge of Civil Court in New York City. The booklet, written by Justice Fisher-Brandveen's staff and other court lawyers, was sent on Oct. 31 to Civil Court resource centers, legal services offices and social service agencies throughout the city. It is also being made available to the public free of charge.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-11-01; What They Were Thinking: Starting Over
description: Fred Alger, president, Fred Alger Management:

title: November 4-10; Our Feathered and Furry Shield
description: It may not have been foremost on President Bush's mind when he called for the creation of a volunteer civil defense service, but it's a fair question: why should America's pets get a free ride in the war on terror? Actually, the idea of a furred-and-feathered brigade has been gaining ground on two fronts.

description: SACRED GEOGRAPHY

title: Paul F. Beatini: Barbie's Best Customer
description: Paul F. Beatini told his 3- year-old daughter Daria that Tuesday wasn't her first real day of preschool. It was only orientation. There was no way Daddy would miss Daria's first day of school, so he would bring her on the first real day, Thursday. That rationalization made sense for both of them and it made Paul, who worked with FM Global, an insurance company, feel better about keeping his morning meeting at Aon.

title: Facing the Problems Of Coffee Growers
description: To the Editor:

title: Delivery of the Mail Is Almost Back to Normal
description: Not even anthrax can stop the mail for long, postal officials say.

title: Our Towns; Hard Times at Yale, Where the Peace Corps Has a Waiting List
description: YALE students are the best and brightest, they go full throttle at whatever they do, and lately, seniors have excelled at worrying. ''Everyone's gossiping in the dining halls,'' says Bethany Lacina. ''You hear stuff like Salomon Smith Barney hired hundreds last year, but they're only taking 40 in the whole country this time. Who knows if it's true. But it's preying on everyone's mind.''

title: Health Care As Main Engine: Is That So Bad?
description: WHENEVER the economy begins growing again -- be it early next year, if the recession is an average one, or many months later, if not -- the next expansion will probably have a character starkly different from those of the recent past.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SYKES, LOIS (FARNSWORTH)
description: SYKES-Lois (Farnsworth). 59, of Bronxville, New York, and formerly of New Canaan, CT, and Dallas, TX, died on November 9 at Hammond Pointe Nursing Home in Chestnut Hill, MA, from complications of Lupus. Daughter of the late Kenneth C. Farnsworth, MD, and Marguerite (Pelksy) Farnsworth. Loving mother of Benjamin F. Sykes of Dallas, TX. Dear sister of Barbara F. Fairburn of Greenwich, CT, and Susan F. Spooner of Boston, MA. Cherished aunt of Hilary F. Sullivan of Delray Beach, FL, Lisa F. Clark of Moraga, CA, Scott S. Fabyan of Manchester, MA, Nicholas M. Spooner of New York City, and Amanda S. Frank of Brighton, MA. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, December 8, at 12 noon at the Reformed Church in Bronxville, NY. Memorial contributions in her name may be sent to the Lupus Foundation of America, Inc., 1300 Piccard Drive, Suite 200, Rockville, MD 20850-4303 or to the Reformed Church, PO Box 397, Bronxville, NY 10708.

title: Before the Unveiling, A Peek at the Crafts
description: IT was inventory week at the Brookfield Craft Center. The countdown had begun: it was two and a half weeks before the opening of the 26th annual holiday exhibition and sale.

title: Rally Caps Williams's 8-0 Season
description: In a thrilling ending to one of college football's oldest rivalries, Tyler Shea scored on a 1-yard run in overtime today to lift Williams College to a 23-20 come-from-behind victory over Amherst College.

title: Thomas Galvin: After Hours, Soaring Drives
description: When it came to soaring drives, pinpoint irons, mental toughness, Thomas Galvin had the whole package. He played a mean game of golf. Fortunately for his opponents, he worked a lot, and that limited the number of tournaments he entered.

title: Telling a Story, 'One Tiny Line' at a Time
description: MARILYN NELSON, Connecticut's new poet laureate, has not made a practice of writing anything that cries out Connecticut, she said. Rather, her verse speaks of motherhood, African-American identity, theology and history.

title: Bitter Rivalry Endures in Cozy Setting
description: The conversation was silenced now that the 116th meeting of Williams and Amherst was in overtime with the Ephs and the Lord Jeffs knotted, 17-17. They were deadly serious in the corner of this East Side bar. Kevin Kelly, a psychiatrist and 1972 Williams graduate, studied the big screen with practiced concentration.

title: William Fallon: To the Shoreline of Kauai
description: When Kayla turned 6 in 1999, William and Laura Fallon decided it was all right to start taking long trips. The resulting trip to the Grand Canyon was Kayla's first long airplane ride and the first of a series of trips to national parks for the Fallons.

title: Fireman's Spirit Is the Wind Beneath a Bird's Wings
description: Each morning, Richard Haugland of Bay Ridge goes to his gardening job at City Hall Park and looks for Liberty, a peregrine falcon he named after seeing it perched atop a park flagpole on Oct. 15. The footlong bird is cream and cinnamon brown, and it prefers a meal of pigeon to anything else.

title: Miami Takes Detour To Avoid First Loss
description: On a brisk, gray and ominous day, the Miami Hurricanes needed four field goals and a fluky touchdown by the defense to escape New England with their undefeated record. Their high rankings, their national championship aspirations and Ken Dorsey's Heisman Trophy hopes are subject to further review.

title: Harsh Civics Lesson for Immigrants
description: The startling new lesson about this country for the immigrant owner, accountant, matre d' and busboy at the Crazy Tomato restaurant was forced upon them a month ago in a incident known as the perp walk.

title: Furry Creatures: Sentinels for Anthrax?
description: To the Editor:

title: Recalling the 70's, Warily
description: The words have an eerily familiar ring to them. Deficits. Budget gaps. Hiring freezes. Cuts. Early retirement. Attrition. Sacrifice.

title: Sonuvagun, if It Isn't Dominion
description: For much of the 20th century, a Manhattan neighborhood called Inwood reigned as the unofficial capital of the Irish diaspora, and in its later years, an elderly Jewish man and a young Irish kid from the Good Shepherd school had their own daily ritual.

title: A Stranger's Surprise Gift, And a Woman's Life Shines
description: When Crystal Vazquez ate a banana on Nov. 1, it was Angel Candelaria's kidney that made it possible.

title: Business; Marketing Bonanzas, and Pitfalls, in a Disaster
description: SUNDAY LEWIS has had plenty of experience with fast-changing markets.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  OCHS, LOUIS W. JR.
description: OCHS-Louis W. Jr. Princeton '45. November 10, 2000. Life is not the same without you. Missed and loved by Audrey, Philip, Philip Jr., Suzanne, Brooke and Philip III Kiendl

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARRETT, BETTY
description: BARRETT-Betty. The staff of Herbert Barrett Management mourns the passing of Betty Barrett, beloved wife of our President Herbert Barrett. We extend heartfelt condolences to him and the family.

title: Postings: 1920's Building Between 43rd and 44th to Be Filled In; Facelift for Madison Ave. Block
description: The owner of a mostly vacant beige brick 1920's office building on Madison Avenue near Grand Central Terminal is planning a renovation that will give it a blocklong glass facade and add 50,000 square feet to the 650,000-square-foot E-shaped structure.

title: Smithtown Newcomer for Seafood Lovers
description: H2O says seafood much like those other straightforward, one-word names like Coolfish, Waves and Clearwater. The Smithtown newcomer, situated in a building that once housed the Beachtree Cafe, has a common ownership with Tellers, the posh Islip steakhouse.

title: On Road, Knicks Are Still Dismal
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 10 — There was a time when Reggie Miller was supposedly too old and unproductive, and Allan Houston was supposedly too young and talented, a time when the Indiana Pacers were losing their edge at the exact moment the Knicks had developed a serrated one on their way to the 1999 Eastern Conference finals.

title: Business; The Yin and Yang of Harvard M.B.A.'s
description: Harvard M.B.A.'s have long occupied executive suites throughout corporate America, but George W. Bush, '75, was the first to make it to the top box of the nation's organizational chart. Now, Michael R. Bloomberg, '66, has won what has been called ''the second-toughest job in America.'' That doesn't mean they will manage alike, however. Here is a head-to-head comparison of the two, as consultants might see them.

title: Christine Bitner, Henry Baer Jr.
description: Christine Dawn Bitner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter E. Bitner Jr. of Ringoes, N.J., was married yesterday to Henry Philip Baer Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Baer of North Palm Beach, Fla. Msgr. Walter E. Nolan performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church in Princeton, N.J.

title: A U.S. Town Reached Via Canada Is Suddenly Boxed In at the Border
description: As a cartographic curiosity, Point Roberts is perhaps the most isolated community in the United States outside Alaska. A fingertip of American land that can be reached by road only after passing through 26 miles of Canada, the town sits in edge-of-the-world splendor just below the 49th parallel.

title: Peaceable Playgrounds
description: Teachers at Public School 217, a large, diverse elementary school in the Ditmas Park section of Brooklyn, were searching for ways to explain to their students the attack on the World Trade Center. So they turned to a simple lesson that is part of their continuing conflict resolution program.

title: Albany Lawmakers Raise Their Allowance
description: When legislators returned here last month to amend the state budget, the talk was of austerity, shrinking resources and painful program cuts. But when it came to the lawmakers themselves, state spending was headed up, not down.

title: Robinson Calls Play By Leafs 'Gutless'
description: Devils Coach Larry Robinson played 23 seasons in the N.H.L. and logged 793 penalty minutes along the way. As a coach he also appreciates tough teams.

title: INSIDE
description: Ken Kesey Dies

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an essay on Aug. 19 about the charm of a trip to Morocco misstated the year of the author's visit. The trip, during which the author traveled around the country with a young man named Rashid and came to know members of his family in Fez, took place in 1988, not 1998.

title: Nassau Police Seek $23.5 Million
description: AFTER spending most of the last two months on heightened alert after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, local law enforcement agencies on Long Island are tallying higher costs for overtime and have begun to clamor for extra money to pay for it, along with extra equipment and training.

title: Theater Listings
description: Approximate running times are given at end of Broadway and Off Broadway listings.)

title: Buying a New Car for New Times
description: WE needed a new car in a hurry. We had put it off as long as possible, and perhaps longer. Chuck, the owner of the local repair shop, was planning to retire to Florida on the strength of our constant visits to his greasy emporium. After our second and last vehicle had been towed into his shop, leaving us with an empty driveway and a stark choice between staying at home or taking the bus, we accepted our fate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LESAUVAGE, GEORGE R. JR.
description: LeSAUVAGE-George R. Jr. The Officers, Trustees and members of The Church Club of New York mourn the passing of our beloved Trustee and Vice President George R. LeSauvage Jr. on November 5. Stuart E. Prall, President

description: To the Editor:

title: From the Catalog to the Table, A Nibble of the Local Fare
description: FOOD catalogs featuring yummy-looking goodies appear regularly at this time of year, but those with a Connecticut return address are rare.

title: The Nation: Wayne's World; A Military Disaster Waiting to Happen
description: I KNOW we all should be supporting our president 110 percent these days, but I feel compelled to take issue with what seems to be his first major misstep in prosecuting the war on terrorism. I speak, of course, of his decision to immediately deploy Wayne Newton to entertain our troops.

title: Buy Stuff, Pay for College
description: Start with the premise that any money saved for college is better than none. From that vantage point, several new programs that help families put away small amounts of money for college -- and potentially large ones -- make a lot of sense.

title: Elizabeth Schneider, Peter Weimersheimer
description: Dr. Elizabeth S. Schneider and Dr. Peter Martin Edward Weimersheimer were married on Monday in Shelburne, Vt. Judge Michael Kupersmith of the Vermont District Court officiated at the coach barn at Shelburne Farms, an agricultural museum.

title: Paperback Fiction
description: This

title: Article 2001111191851073834 -- No Title
description: Christine Bitner and Henry Baer Jr. .menubig {font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;color:#ffffcc;font-weight:bold;letter-spacing: 0 pt;} .menusmall {font-family:Times;font-size:10pt;color:#ffffcc;font-weight:normal;letter-spacing: 0 pt;} Back to Main Student Connections News Summaries Daily News Quiz Word of the Day Test Prep Question of the Day Web Explorer Science Q & A Letters to the Editor Ask a Reporter On This Day in History Weekly News Quiz Resources on the Web Facts About the Times Specials

title: It's a Business
description: On Saturday, the Museum of Early Trades & Crafts in Madison and the Arts Council of the Morris Area will sponsor a workshop on business skills for artists. The event, to be held at the museum, in Madison, includes a panel discussion with Pat Kettenring, director of the business and the arts program at Rutgers University, Newark; Paul Joseph Stankard, a glass artist from Mantua, whose work is featured in a show at the museum; and Ulysses Grant Dietz, curator of decorative arts at the Newark Museum.

title: Junior R.O.T.C. Cadets Face Hard Choices
description: WEEKDAY mornings at 6:15, 15-year-old Christina DeLeon arrives at Hempstead High School in her green camouflage uniform to begin 45 minutes of calisthenics and marching drill.

title: When Adventure Racing Becomes Less Adventurous
description: Just a few years ago, adventure racing was an obscure sport with a cult-like following. But as more sponsorship and television deals are signed and the sport attracts better athletes, adventure racing has become a more professional and mainstream sport. Unfortunately, it is also losing some of its originality and its edge.

title: WEST PATERSON KEEPS NAME
description: Residents of West Paterson rejected a proposal to change the borough's name, 2,317 to 1,707. Attempts to change the name had failed in 1989 and 1995. Some residents said a new name would increase property values by separating the town in public perception from Paterson, which is much poorer. Woodland Park and Garret Mountain were considered as possible new names. John Holl

title: DUNKIN DONUTS STRIKE
description: Truck drivers and other workers who went on strike in June at the Dunkin Donuts distribution center in Sweedesboro, which supplies 1,400 franchises in eight states, will begin returning to work Monday, labor and management officials said. The 65 returning workers struck at the company's Mid-Atlantic Distribution Center, a cooperative owned by the franchises, not by Dunkin Donuts Inc., after negotiations failed to produce their first contract as a new bargaining unit. The N.L.R.B. gave the workers the right to return, though no agreement has yet been reached. Steve Strunsky

title: The Barber of Pound Ridge
description: WHEN barbers set up shop in Pound Ridge, they usually stick around for a while. When Philip Canonaco (pronounced ka-NON-a-ko) set up up his barber shop, he took over a space that had been owned and operated for 18 years by a guy named Vincent Penna. Before Vinny, there was another barber in that space for a long time, but Mr. Canonaco doesn't know what his name was. It was before his time, he says.

title: WHAT THEY'RE READING
description: James Grant, 55

title: Lawyers' Math in Sept. 11 Deaths Shows Varying Values for Life
description: The salesman was running late that morning. He called his wife to say he was probably going to miss his meeting at Windows on the World. But at the last minute, at 8:47, he called his office to say he had made it to the restaurant.

title: Race Strains a Mexican Campaign
description: To run a political campaign against Lzaro Crdenas, the son and grandson of two of Mexico's most beloved leaders, is to run uphill against a legend.

title: Security
description: To the Editor: On Sept. 25, we flew from San Francisco to Cleveland via Chicago. We had to show our ID's at the check-in counter. We were not requested, however, to show them when we boarded the plane, as is customary in Europe, for instance. We left Cleveland on the 28th for Chicago. Two policewomen stood at the airport entrance, but they were involved in a private conversation.

title: Kristen Palma, Paul Poth
description: Kristen Lyn Palma and Paul Patrick Poth were married yesterday on Martha's Vineyard. The Rev. John Ardis performed the ceremony at St. Elizabeth's Roman Catholic Church in Edgartown, Mass.

title: Home Movies for the Self-Absorbed
description: FOR months now, the designers Mark Badgley and James Mischka have known precisely where they would be tomorrow night: in front of a television set tuned to Comedy Central, awaiting the first strains of ''Wheels on Fire,'' the theme song of the British comedy series ''Absolutely Fabulous.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAZAN, DANIEL
description: GAZAN-Daniel. Beloved friend. You fought hard ''Big Guy''. Your smile, spirit & hugs will be forever missed. Carol, Jeff, Samantha and Justin

title: Travel Advisory; Four Seasons Returns To San Francisco
description: Four Seasons is back in San Francisco for the first time since 1994 with the opening last month of its hotel at the edge of the burgeoning Yerba Buena Gardens district near the convention center. The company previously managed the Clift, now an Ian Schrager hotel and the subject of an extensive makeover.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Gambling Law May Mean Salvation for Yonkers Track
description: Just two months ago, it seemed that nothing could save Yonkers Raceway. The dilapidated harness racing track, once a gambler's Mecca, had been losing money for years, and the 100-acre property just off the Major Deegan Expressway was for sale.

title: A New Strategy for Saving Streams: Rip Them Up
description: Within the perfect green bowl ringed by the Windham High Peak, Black Dome and Thomas Cole Mountains, bulldozers tore up Vincent Charbonneau's upper field, the one where his daughters were wed. Mr. Charbonneau praised their efficiency.

title: Cyberclasses in Session
description: A HALF-DOZEN years ago, when a handful of educational institutions began what was seen as a perilous process of teaching classes over the Internet, the notion of thousands of students graduating with full degrees earned online seemed, well, technically impossible. But that is what will happen this coming spring, as the first big crop of students completes three- and four-year programs delivered through the ether.

title: Hands in the Dirt, Face to the Sun: Hope in the Garden
description: FOR six weeks every summer, campers at Camp Quinebaug, run by the Connecticut Department of Mental Retardation in Killingly, Conn., spend the warm days doing what generations of campers have done: swimming, boating and arts and crafts. But the 80 developmentally disabled children, teenagers and young adults also participate in something less familiar: horticultural therapy.

title: Women and Health
description: To the Editor:

title: Ken Kesey, Author of 'Cuckoo's Nest,' Who Defined the Psychedelic Era, Dies at 66
description: Ken Kesey, the Pied Piper of the psychedelic era, who was best known as the author of the novel ''One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest,'' died yesterday in a hospital in Eugene, Ore., said his wife, Faye. He was 66 and lived in Pleasant Hill, Ore.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAZARUS, NORMAN (BUD)
description: LAZARUS-Norman (Bud). Age 82, of Great Neck, NY, on November 1, 2001. Beloved husband of Phoebe Lazarus. Devoted father of Diane and Fern. Dear brother of Shirley Toran. Survived by loving nieces and nephews. The family feels truly blessed to have had Buddy in our lives.

title: Reckonings; Another Useful Crisis
description: Remember California's energy crisis? It illustrated, in particularly stark form, the political strategy of the Bush administration before Sept. 11. The basic principle of this strategy -- which was also used to sell that $2 trillion tax cut -- was that crises weren't problems to be solved. Instead, they were opportunities to advance an agenda that had nothing to do with the crisis at hand.

title: Film Series Listings
description: AMERICAN MUSEUM OF THE MOVING IMAGE — Shadow Play: Avant-Garde Views of Early Cinema. Today, 2: Wenders's "Trick of the Light" (1996); at 4: Moon's "Lumiere and Company" (1995) with Brand's "Demolition of a Wall" (1973). Sat., 2: Nekes's "Film Before Film" (1986) with short films by Laitala and Morrison; at 4:30: Beloff's "Shadow Land or Light From the Other Side" (2000) with live performance by Ms. Beloff and Ken Montgomery. Repertory Nights. Today, 6:30: Reed's "Third Man" (1949). Sat.-next Sun., 6:30: Sirk's "Written on the Wind" (1956). 35th Ave. at 36th St., Astoria, Queens. (718-784- 0077)

title: Adept in Politics and Advertising, 4 Women Shape a Campaign
description: Twenty-four hours after the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, President Bush summoned his close aide Karen P. Hughes, telling her that the job of coordinating wartime public relations for the government would be hers.

title: Tested
description: ADRIAN BRIDGES was frowning.

title: The Neediest Cases; Getting Old and Getting By, With a Little Help From Some Friends
description: The knuckles on Rose Ann's hands have vanished. So, too, for all practical purposes, have the spaces between her fingers. What during her 30's and 40's were the busy hands of an executive secretary and loving mother are, at 73, gnarled, immovable lumps of skin and bones.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTS, JOHN
description: ROBERTS-John. The Trustees, Advisors and staff of Outward Bound USA mourn the loss of John Roberts, a trustee and friend whose intelligence, humor and grace set him apart, and at the same time connected him to us and to everyone. We offer our sympathy and support to his wife Rona, his daughter Jennifer and his son Douglas. Frances Rubacha, Chair Richard Bangs, President Outward Bound USA, Garrison, NY

title: Private Sector; Hitting the Pause Button
description: Norio Ohga's first love is music. So it perhaps came as little surprise that when Mr. Ohga, chairman of the Sony Corporation, fell ill last Thursday, it was in front of an orchestra.

title: Singing the Jersey Sound Still Makes Him Happy
description: TWENTY years ago, John Eddie wanted to be a famous rock 'n' roll star. Now he just wants to write and perform his own music -- an ambition he has achieved.

title: With Osgood Stumbling, Canadiens Beat Islanders
description: Michael Peca sat alone in a corner of the losers' dressing room late tonight and somberly scanned a statistics sheet from the Islanders' uninspired 3-2 loss to the Montreal Canadiens.

title: The Ballad of Mary O'Connor
description: By the midafternoon of September eleventh,

title: November 4-10; Sticks, Stones and Kalashnikovs
description: Last week, the leader of the Taliban, Mullah Mohammad Omar, apparently fed up with dodging bombs and being called an ''evildoer,'' challenged President Bush and Tony Blair, the British prime minister -- to a duel. With machine guns. Kalashnikovs.

title: On the Road Again, Bound for a State of Mind
description: IT was not exactly ''Easy Rider,'' that classic of the American road trip as a journey by outlaws with scruffy sideburns on chopper bikes. Instead, when Philip Greenspun and Kyle Nich olls decided to drop out of their daily lives for a month and take to the highway, they drove a pristine Winnebago stocked with laptop computers, cases of Perrier and Kiehl's beauty products.

title: The Stuff of Legend
description: THE AGE OF HOMESPUN

title: Bruce Simmons: Chef of the Wee Hours
description: Kathy Simmons awoke to the smell of onions cooking.

title: Lynn Desenberg, Daniel Heumann
description: Lynn Ruth Desenberg and Daniel Andr Heumann were married last evening by Rabbi Daniel Friedman at the Ritz-Carlton in Chicago.

title: Oregon's Suicide Law, Under Siege
description: To the Editor:

title: Haute Cuisine in the Burbs
description: ANYONE living outside Manhattan knows how difficult it can be to tempt city dwellers north for a visit. Double that when the invitation is for dinner out -- the assumption being that no restaurant past the city limits is worth it.

title: Film; A New Wave Auteur Without the Rough Edges
description: YOU have charm, you have grace, you have beauty,'' says an awestruck American sailor to the title character (played by Anouk Aime) of Jacques Demy's 1961 film ''Lola,'' and those words are as true of the movie itself as they are of its heroine. If Demy's first feature isn't as well known as the debuts of others in what we call the French New Wave -- as say, Franois Truffaut's ''400 Blows'' or Alain Resnais's ''Hiroshima Mon Amour'' or Jean-Luc Godard's ''Breathless'' (all 1959) -- it's perhaps because ''Lola'' is too charming, graceful and beautiful for its own good. This auteur's sensibility obviously lacks the invigorating rough edges we associate with the New Wave.

title: A Second Rail Tunnel Should Be Re-evaluated
description: To the Editor:

title: Teachers Worth Remembering
description: THERE is much talk about heroes these days.

title: Music; Always Making Jazz Seem New
description: THERE are great jazz musicians whose contributions to the art derive from the conceptual brilliance of their playing.
