Others go deeper and engage jazz's most fundamental elements to achieve a singular musical vision. The pianist Ahmad Jamal, who will appear this week at Iridium, epitomizes the latter. For 50 years he has exhibited his profound understanding of the formal aspects of jazz, turning his piano trio into an orchestra of American sound in motion. His music has not only had an inestimable effect on small-group jazz; at a time when innovation is confused with iconoclasm, it has also exemplified how originality can be achieved by examining and reworking what is often overlooked in jazz.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DESATNICK, RUTH
description: DESATNICK-Ruth. On November 9, 2001. Beloved daughter of the late Keva and Etta. Dear sister of Belle and Julius Meiman and the late Esther Desatnick. Devoted aunt of Kevie and Martin Michael. Loving great aunt of Evan Michael. Service Sunday 11:00AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Finding a Criminal In a Crowd of Faces
description: NORMALLY, Viisage Technology of Littleton, Mass., catalogs drivers' licenses and other forms of identification for government offices. But nowadays, its technology, which converts video images, photographs or police composites of faces into strings of numbers, is being considered for airport security.

title: Islam and Intellectuals
description: To the Editor:

title: Suburban Abbondanza
description: THE Suriano brothers grew up in Abruzzo, the region of mountains, seacoast and small farms on the calf of Italy's boot. Their father grew apples and tomatoes, and grapes for wine, which he continued to make even after the family emigrated to New Jersey in the early 1970's. There were sheep, goats, a milk cow -- and, in the hills, wild boar for hunting. After their chores, the boys would wander into town, where the main avenue was called the corso.

title: Anxiety Spreads, Not Anthrax
description: BEING afraid isn't something we get to practice a lot. That much was evident a few nights ago in New Brunswick, where the Robert Wood Johnson Medical School plunked three doctors in front of about 100 people to answer questions about anthrax.

title: Art/Architecture; An Ancient Garden Youthfully Abloom: Chinese Art Today
description: AT an exhibition of early Picasso last year at the National Gallery in Washington, a woman in a red dress stood in front of a beautifully drawn nude and said with surprise: ''Glory be! He was perfectly capable of painting people the way they look.''

title: In Collapsing Towers, a Cascade of Failures
description: For a span of time that lasted thousands of heartbeats and spared thousands of lives, the World Trade Center towers withstood the crashes of two jetliners and the flames stoked by their fuel. But eventually, the fires softened the steel structures, and the twin towers collapsed in a terrifying avalanche.

title: November 4-10; Ecstasy in the Lab, Legally
description: The Food and Drug Administration has approved the first study of the illegal party drug Ecstasy as a treatment for post-traumatic stress disorder. Conscious of the need for drugs to treat the disorder after the Sept. 11 attacks, the Multidisciplinary Association for Psychedelic Studies, a nonprofit group working to have psychedelic drugs approved as medicines, applied in October for government approval of a study in which 20 people will take Ecstasy during therapy sessions. The theory is that the drug will reduce fear so patients can talk about the trauma. Melody Petersen

title: Sheridan's Fork in the Road: Either Fix It or Kill It
description: The Sheridan Expressway, the 1.25-mile roadway that links the Bruckner and Cross Bronx Expressways, is the ugly duckling of Bronx highways. Drivers tend to avoid the Sheridan because it is hard to get to from other roads. South Bronx residents say it cuts them off from the gradually greening banks of the Bronx River.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PESTYNER, MIRIAM
description: PESTYNER - Miriam. Beloved wife of the late Philip. Loving mother of Bernard (Carole) and Arlene (Richard Stein). Cherished grandmother of Jamie, Lee, Scott, Jill, Tama and Kevin, and nine beloved great grandchildren. Graveside services on Sunday 12:30 P.M. at Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

title: Music Listings
description: Opera

title: Consumers Look at Corporate Conduct
description: In the wake of the terrorist attacks, consumers are paying much closer attention to whether they think a company is socially responsible, a new poll suggests.

title: Not Just Puppy Love
description: Ten-year-old Missy Alsworth hugs Judson, a golden retriever puppy her family is training to be a guide dog for the blind, in ''Dogs: The Early Years,'' a ''Nature'' episode that has its premiere tonight at 8 on Channel 13. Created to help people choose a compatible puppy, the show focuses on the characteristics of different breeds and the importance of proper training.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 21 about the film ''Night of the Hunter'' misstated the name of the character played by Billy Chapin. It was John, not Billy. The article also included an erroneous version of a line from a hymn sung by the preacher played by Robert Mitchum. He sang, ''Leaning on the everlasting arms,'' not ''Leaning on the arm of the Lord.''

title: Bush's Exhortation at the U.N., and Firing Up the Hollywood Canteen
description: George W. Bush, born-again nation builder and multilateralist, gave his first speech to the United Nations General Assembly, where he warned that all countries were potential targets of terrorism. So they would do themselves a favor, the president said, by standing side by side with the United States in this war.

title: The New Arrivals
description: In sorrow's wake, they still chose to make the city their home.

title: A Time for Giving
description: To the Editor:

title: Nets' Start Is Unheard Of And Unseen
description: As a phenomenon is growing virtually undercover in the swamplands, last-second drama is becoming more like ritual for the Nets, and even a lackluster game can become cause for celebration.

title: Yin Ping Wong: Hong Kong on Canal Street
description: The crooning ballads by Cantonese pop stars reminded Yin Ping Wong of his childhood in Hong Kong. Mr. Wong, known to his friends as Steven, immigrated with his family in the late 1970's to Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, from Hong Kong. He was 12 years old, the sixth of seven children and spoke only a little English. It was a difficult transition for a boy with a gentle soul.

title: Edwards and Vermeil Share a Three-Decade Bond
description: Before the start of today's game between the Jets and the Kansas City Chiefs, Herman Edwards and Dick Vermeil will meet on the field. They will forgo the handshakes and go straight for the hugs and probably the tears.

title: Closed-End Country Funds Show Some Unexpected Life
description: CLOSED-END mutual funds that invest in foreign countries are not dead yet. In fact, they have offered bargain-hunting investors some appealing opportunities in recent weeks.

title: Canadian Rockies
description: To the Editor: We have just returned from the journey described by Adam Clymer in ''Travel Like a Magnate,'' (Sept. 23) on the Royal Canadian Pacific Railway, called the Golden/Crowsnest Excursion.

title: Post-9/11: The Series: 'You Want What?'
description: A constant barrage of unprecedented horrors around the world causes misery, sure, but it also provides hilarious new predicaments for the staffers of a network's news-graphics department as they scramble to produce the little visuals that appear over their anchorperson's shoulder, dizzily trying to keep up with nightmarish scenarios no one could have imagined the day before. (Think ''Taxi'' as written by Samuel Beckett and Tom Clancy, with frenzied newsroom shouting like: ''Roosevelt's mustache doesn't make sense by itself! Circle it on Rushmore and add the words HELD FOR RANSOM!'')

title: For Some Companies, a Post-Sept. 11 Surge
description: THE terrorist attacks of Sept. 11 took thousands of American lives and helped push the economy toward a recession, bringing a number of companies to the brink of bankruptcy. At the same time, the attacks have provided an economic opportunity for others by creating a sense of urgency for products and services that could reassure a public suddenly preoccupied with bioterrorism, information security and personal safety.

title: Margaret Eng, Albert Yeh
description: Margaret Shao-Fong Eng, a daughter of Kathleen and Sidney Eng of Garden City, N.Y., was married yesterday to Albert Alan Yeh, a son of Susanna Ting and George Yeh, both of San Diego. The Rev. Joseph M. Schlafer performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Garden City.

title: Corrections
description: The Practical Traveler column on Oct. 28, about car rentals, misstated the telephone number for Alamo. It is (800) 462-5266.

title: Pressure of War Splinters Israel's Left
description: For more than 20 years, a name with a plain message has animated the broadest Israeli movement to end the conflict with Palestinians: Peace Now.

title: Ideas & Trends; Numbers Games: Go Figure
description: NUMBERS seem so solid. As taught in elementary school, they are as reliable as cold milk at lunch: 2 + 2 = 4, immutable and comforting in their certainty.

title: November 4-10; Ortega Redefeated
description: In a settling of old scores, Enrique Bolaos was elected president of Nicaragua, defeating Daniel Ortega, the Sandinista leader who had confiscated his businesses and imprisoned him in the 1980's. Mr. Bolaos, a former vice president who staunchly opposed the Sandinista regime, will confront a battered economy and a population weary of corruption. Mr. Ortega, who lost his third bid to regain the presidency since 1990, will continue to have a seat in the National Assembly. David Gonzalez

title: Dance Listings
description: BALLET NACIONAL de CUBA — "Magic of Alonso." New Jersey Performing Arts Center, Prudential Hall (888-466-5722) Wed., 7:30.

title: Running Game
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The View From Inside the Gas Mask
description: TWO weeks ago, Armand Tomo, a medical equipment dealer, bought a Geiger counter. It sits on his desk keeping tabs on a possible nuclear strike. Should radioactive material be indicated, he'll then know to reach for the potassium iodate capsules he recently stored in his desk drawer at work and bedside table at home. Just two a day should ward off the thyroid cancer such an attack would induce, Mr. Tomo said, certainly a more palatable alternative than consuming 300 pounds of salt.

title: Oregon's Suicide Law, Under Siege
description: To the Editor:

title: In Two Shows, Abstraction and Exuberance
description: 'James Brooks'

title: Science Fiction
description: ''Past performance is no guarantee of future results.'' This warning, familiar from mutual-fund ads, might be inserted as a disclaimer in all history books. History, as history itself teaches, is not a science. But what if it were? What if studying the past allowed you not only to avoid past mistakes but also to create the future of your choice? This is the premise of IN THE COUNTRY OF THE BLIND, by Michael Flynn (Tor/Tom Doherty, $27.95).

title: Half-Life
description: NO SAINTS OR ANGELS

title: Forecast: An Uncertain Climate
description: IN recent years, the Gruskin family of Ossining, N.Y., has headed west each December. This year, they had Utah in mind. But while Stuart Gruskin is still ready to go, his wife, Adrienne, has been considering a car trip to Vermont, or perhaps not traveling at all.

title: Todd Ouida: The Strength in That Smile
description: Whether he was mischievously finagling another stroke at golf or beaming over his infant niece, Todd Ouida's smile touched people. "A great smile that could light up a room," said his mother, Andrea.

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of Friday, 4,547 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11.

title: November 4-10; The Concorde Is Back
description: Making a comeback during one of the worst slumps in aviation history, the world's only supersonic jetliners returned to the skies with paying passengers. Both Air France and British Airways had grounded their SST's after the fiery crash of an Air France plane shortly after takeoff in July 2000. Since then the planes have been revamped to address safety concerns -- equipped with stronger tires, armor- plated wiring and redesigned fuel tanks. Suzanne Daley

title: Erin Zyko, Samir Hussein
description: Erin Elizabeth Zyko, a daughter of Paulette C. Zyko and Eddi Z. Zyko Sr. of Middlebury, Conn., was married yesterday to Samir Hassan Hussein, a son of Jean Hussein of Clarence Center, N.Y., and the late Dr. Gamal-Eddin Hussein. The Rev. John Tarrant, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. George's Episcopal Church in Middlebury.

title: Something Tulsa Forgot
description: THE BURNING

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEIL, JOAN S. (SINGER)
description: WEIL-Joan S. (Singer). Died November 6. Age 95. Beloved cousin of Mary Jacoby & Sue Nirenberg. Widow of Charles A. Weil. Remembrance charity of your choice.

title: [RETHINK]: Manifestoes For the Next New York; [Development]: And Why Not Bulldoze Lincoln Center?
description: As landmarks, they were unmistakable. As symbols, they were tragically alluring. And in the aftermath of their destruction, the towers of the World Trade Center have become justifiably sanctified, holy stations along the line of American memory that runs past Valley Forge and Gettysburg, Normandy and Iwo Jima.

title: These Guys Got Game: An Empire in the Making
description: HOLLYWOOD deal makers were snubbed not to mention stunned. Last year, when the pop diva Celine Dion was seeking a long-running engagement so she could spend more time with her newborn son, she ignored the courtship of a handful of prominent promoters and signed with Timothy Leiweke, chief executive of the Anschutz Entertainment Group. Fans can expect to see Ms. Dion nightly when her three-year show opens at Caesars Palace in Las Vegas in March 2003.

title: Not Dead Yet
description: To the Editor:

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2002 Kia Sedona; A Blue-Light Special in the Minivan Department
description: MINIVANS are not stylish or exciting, but they remain the most practical transportation for families with small children. Still, many parents have found that their family finances, after covering tennis shoes, school supplies and macaroni-and-cheese dinners, can't handle the $26,000 cost of a typical new minivan.

title: A Recent Influx of Syrian Jews Alters a Neighborhood Yet Again
description: For decades, residents of Gravesend knew the building at the southeast corner of East Second Street and Avenue U as a place to gas up their cars. For six months, it was a place to eat. For the last three years, the one-story structure, whose large glass-paned bays still recall its automotive past, has been Mikdash Eliyahu, an Orthodox synagogue that serves the area's fast-growing Syrian Jewish community.

title: MORTAGE FRAUD
description: The state has filed suit against several companies that said they would help people save their homes from foreclosure but instead pocketed their money. HRS Holding Corporation and Homeowner's Rescue Service, both based in Ocean Township, several related companies, and Francis C. Pullano of Ocean Township and Michael Klebanoff of Long Branch, the principals, have been charged with defrauding 26 homeowners, 9 of whom lost their homes to foreclosure. The homeowners were told to sign over their homes to the companies, and then required to lease back the property, with the promise that the company would buy the property back from the bank or mortgage-holder for the homeowner. Karen DeMasters

title: Russia's Germ Warfare Secrets
description: A top Russian scientist issued a little-noticed warning last week that impoverished experts from Russia's former biological weapons programs may be up for sale to any terrorist organization willing to pay the price. As the United States mobilizes to develop defenses against bioterrorism, it urgently needs reliable intelligence on just what has happened to the people and materials that gave the Soviet Union the most frightening arsenal of biological weapons ever developed. A more vigorous effort to bring Russian expertise, weapons formulas and biological materials under better control should be on the agenda this week when President Bush meets with Vladimir Putin, the Russian president.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-11-01: Prescription; In Defense of Folly
description: On the 43rd day after the attacks on the World Trade Center, the Garren New York hair salon, on the third floor of Henri Bendel, was operating at about Defcon 2. The weapons of choice, plied in the glow of flattering lighting and blond-wood walls, were afternoon tea, dish and beauty.

title: The Warranty War Heats Up
description: THE fortunes of Kia and Hyundai markedly improved after those Korean companies, now part of the same corporate family, began offering extra-long warranties. In recent weeks, as the incentive wars have escalated, other automakers have beefed up their warranties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCRACKEN, JOHN EDWARD
description: McCRACKEN-John Edward. July 28, 1914-November 3, 2001. Beloved husband of Jeanne M.S. McCracken. Devoted father of David J.B. McCracken. Princeton University '36, Yale Law School '39, The Union Club. Memorial service Fifth Ave. Presbyterian Church, 7 West 55 St. Thursday, November 15, 2001 at 11AM. Contributions in his memory may be made to his Church or Princeton UniversityClass of '36 Endowment Fund.

title: Half a Century of Student Protest
description: Organized labor and students come together.

title: Greed Speaks
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, VINCENT J., MD.
description: FISHER-Vincent J., MD. It is with deep sadness that we send condolences to the family of Dr. Vincent (Vince) Fisher. We extend our deepest sympathy to Natalie as she has lost her husband of 50 years, to his children Barbara, Maureen, Kevin, Brian, Theresa and Clairemarie they have lost their father and his many grandchildren, they have lost their grandfather. We the Members of the Department of Physiology and Neuroscience have lost a wonderful colleague and a gentle friend. As course director for the Physiology Course for many years, Vince injected humor and enthusiasm to a course that can be quite challenging for a first year medical student. He was an inspiring teacher, and a draconian defender of the role of physiological studies in the forging of physicians. We will miss him immensely. Dr. Rodolfo Llinas, Chairman All Faculty and Staff Members Department of Physiology / Neuroscience New York University School of Medicine

title: An Unchanging Need
description: Few of us have ever seen anything like the outpouring of charity that has occurred since Sept. 11. There is simply no way to overstate the warmth behind that effusion of aid, which includes more than $45 million given to The New York Times 9/11 Neediest Fund, established in the days just after the World Trade Center attack.

title: Heroes of the Past, Fighting for a Future
description: ''It's the superteam of superteams,'' said Bruce Timm, the creator and producer of ''Justice League,'' which has its premiere on Cartoon Network Saturday at 7 p.m. before settling into its regular 9:30 slot on Monday nights. ''I kept saying I would never do a 'Justice League' show because I knew how difficult it was going to be, but on a purely emotional level I just couldn't resist.''

title: Craft Store Chic
description: SO you're suddenly overwhelmed by an urge to quilt, even though you haven't put needle to thread in more than 20 years. Or maybe your fifth grader comes home from school announcing that she needs a costume for next week's school pageant. Perhaps you're thinking of creating special holiday gifts.

title: What to Build
description: RILEY: The collapse of the twin towers has left us with 16 acres of land downtown, which someone told me comes out to about 15 football fields. Before we talk about what we should do there, let's think first about what we should not do.

title: Meet Me Around the Corner In a Half an Hour
description: Atlantic City Police didn't have to go far to raid a restaurant where they claimed liquor was being sold without a license and patrons were being treated to what was described as ''sexually explicit physical floor show performances.''

title: Michael James Stewart: His Favorite Talent
description: When Michael James Stewart came to New York 20 years ago, he joined the Old Blue rugby club, one of the best clubs on the East Coast. He was an immediate star, but some of the other players did not know what to make of him. "He looked like a skinny, little guy with crazy sideburns and a goatee, and he wore all black," recalled Greg Finn, a good friend and former teammate. "He looked like a punk rocker; he didn't look athletic. People looked at him and wondered, `Who is this guy?' I think Michael enjoyed that. He believed you couldn't judge a book by its cover."

title: What's Doing In Salt Lake City
description: With less than three months to go before the opening of the Olympic Winter Games in February, work crews are hustling to resurface roads and complete a light-rail commuter line and a new downtown shopping entertainment district. Temporary sites, like the medals plaza, are under construction.

title: Good at Her Job, She Walked Away
description: HELLO?'' A tentative voice answered the phone.

title: Mending a Psyche
description: Early in the morning on Sept. 18, a woman waited anxiously in a small counseling center at the Port Authority's Journal Square branch, her head in her lap, her arms crossing her chest. Catching sight of her, a therapist assumed the woman was a stranger, one of the hundreds of Port Authority employees who had shown up for one-on-one help since they'd fled Tower 1 on Sept. 11. But when the woman looked up, the therapist was shocked. ''Our eyes locked,'' she says. ''I recognized her and she recognized me.'' The patient -- I'll call her by her middle name, Elizabeth -- was a co-worker she knew well, a nurse in her 50's from the Port Authority Medical Department. Elizabeth had always seemed invincible, the sort of person who inspired bravery in her patients. Now she was hunched over in distress, trembling. ''To see her, of all people, that way -- it reinforced for me the magnitude of the event,'' the therapist says.

title: Writing History In Class
description: PETER KRAFT had intended to teach his ninth-grade students at the Peddie School about China this year. They were going to study its geography, its culture, its history.

title: Carry-On Rules; Lost in Cyberspace; Canadian Rockies
description: Carry-On Rules

title: Alison Heller, Glen Roberts II
description: Lori Alison Heller, a daughter of Sue Ann Heller and Dr. Charles Heller of Fairfield, Conn., was married yesterday evening to Glen Wallace Roberts II, the son of Edith Roberts of Durham, N.C., and the late George W. Roberts. Rabbi Marcia Rappaport officiated at Le Parker Meridien Hotel in New York.

title: Post-9/11: The Series
description: LYNN HIRSCHBERG: Television shows from ''N.Y.P.D. Blue'' to ''Seinfeld'' and ''Sex and the City'' have projected an image of New York City to the world. Now that we've entered into a new moment in the city's history, is it up to television to help re-establish that image. And how do you, as television producers, go about doing that?

title: Ruth E. Ketler: Heard on the Street -- Ruth
description: Ruth E. Ketler once said she thought it was possible to be an executive who was liked and admired, instead of respected and feared. At Fiduciary Trust, where she was director of research, and in her daily life around the city, she tried to make that come true.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACKLIN, GOLDIE
description: MACKLIN-Goldie, 83. Of Deerfield Beach, FL on Nov. 8, 2001. Now in heaven with beloved husband Al. Devoted mother of Dennis and Michael, daughters-in-law, Julie and Larissa. Dear grandmother to Keith, Karen, Shayna, Alex, Alan and Lisa. Survived by sister Florence Spiro and dear friend Selma Silberburg.

title: Letters
description: Source Material

title: William R. Godshalk: For Love of Wild Bill
description: James Bond Godshalk had five children and William R. Godshalk was the wildest. When Bill Godshalk was 10 and playing shortstop in Little League, he caught a ball only to drop it when the base runner hit his glove. Bill attacked the other player. James Godshalk walked on to the field and pulled his son back. "He needed me," Mr. Godshalk said. "And I needed him, I did so much."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLIPSTEIN, JULISKA (HIRSCHLER), NEE SCHMIDT
description: KLIPSTEIN-Juliska (Hirschler), nee Schmidt. On November 6, 2001, of Teaneck, NJ, formerly of the Bronx, NY. Beloved wife of the late Leo Klipstein and David Hirschler. Devoted mother of Alex (Teaneck, NJ) and Fred (Toronto, CA) Hirschler. Dear sister of Clara Papo (Milan). Loving grandmother of four grandchildren and three great grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at a later date. For information, contact Gutterman-Musicant, Hackensack, NJ.

title: Bronze Survivor of Sept. 11 Dusts Himself Off
description: The downtown business executive has changed forever. And that's an apt physical and metaphorical truth for the sculpture ''Double Check.''

title: Hardcover Advice
description: This

title: Borghese Imprints Style
description: The new style at Castello di Borghese/Hargrave Vineyard has become distinct, and it is distinctly favorable.

title: Islip Puts Huge Fee on Late-Night Flights
description: AS air travel boomed in recent years, Islip's Town Board welcomed increased jet service at the town-owned Long Island MacArthur Airport as an economic boon and a convenience for most residents. When Southwest Airlines arrived in 1998 and steadily expanded service, neighbors who complained about all the noise got something close to a cold shoulder in Town Hall.

title: Mrs. Glasser's Biggest Fan: Avery Levine
description: This pair of letters can speak for themselves, but there's another part of the story, provided by Avery's mother, Lauren Levine of Bedford:

title: Asking Aid, Colombians Cite Terror; U.S. Demurs
description: As he made the rounds in Washington this week, President Andrs Pastrana of Colombia was greeted with hearty handshakes from the friends he has cultivated in his three years in office.

title: Give Me That Old Time Religion
description: Oy. Who knew?

title: Jets Audio
description: Postgame audio from the Jets vs. the Kansas City Chiefs provided by SportsAudio.net.

title: Theater; Chicken Soup for the Soul Inspires a Play
description: IF I had my way and the technology to carry it off, I would live for six months of days in L.A. and every night of the year in New York -- without actually making the flights. Los Angeles, where I reside now, relaxes me. New York reminds me that I'm alive. (But no Los Angeles jokes here. In its way, it's been good to me.)

title: The Law on Co-ops in New Jersey
description: Q I am a resident of New Jersey and live in a co-op apartment that I own. Can you tell me where I can get the New Jersey law pertaining to co-op ownership? . . . Matthew S. Oleks, West New York, N.J.

title: The Nation; Troubled Times for the Whole World
description: FROM Washington to London to Frankfurt, the world's economic policy makers spoke with one voice last week, and their tone was not reassuring.

title: David Tengelin: All That the City Offered
description: Shakespeare in the Park? David Tengelin was the one who would wait in Central Park to get the tickets.

title: Terror, Not Election Losses, Worries a Governors Group
description: When the nation's Republican governors gathered here this weekend for their annual meeting, they put the best face they could on last Tuesday's elections in which Democrats reclaimed the governor's offices in Virginia and New Jersey. And they mostly glossed over the possibility that Democrats might lengthen their victory string next year when 36 more governor's races are held, races in which more Republican than Democratic seats will be at risk.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: ICE TIME

title: With Sagging Economy as Ally, Democrats in Congress Go on the Attack
description: The halls of Congress will reverberate with shouts of ''big corporations,'' ''class warfare,'' and ''bioterrorism'' next week, unless the phrase ''point of order'' drowns them out.

title: Jennifer Weld, Eric Scheuermann
description: Jennifer Hesburgh Weld, a daughter of Carol and William Weld of Bedford, N.Y., was married yesterday to Eric Franz Scheuermann, a son of Anne Marie and Franz P. Scheuermann of Ruckersville, Va. Msgr. Thomas Bergin, the vicar for education of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, performed the ceremony in the Lady Chapel at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: Music; Persecuted, Schoenberg Rallies
description: ARNOLD SCHOENBERG was not much of a pianist. Yet he wrote what is arguably the most important body of piano music in the 20th century. Played complete, these five works -- each a set of shorter pieces -- take roughly 60 minutes. The music used to fit easily onto a single LP, like the one by Glenn Gould that I wore out during college.

title: Next Step: To Establish A Just Rule For the City
description: The first victory for the Northern Alliance at Mazar-i-Sharif after a month of fighting brings both opportunity and potential risk for the Bush administration in Afghanistan.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MARCOVE, RALPH C., M.D.
description: MARCOVE-Ralph C., M.D. Happy Birthday. Loved and remembered each day. Christina & Laura

title: Casual Reigns at Turkish Restaurant
description: THE modest storefront Middle Eastern restaurants keep coming. Much like the Chinese spots in strip shopping centers that preceded them, they serve satisfying, inexpensive, filling food. The casual Tarkan Cafe, a Mediterranean Turkish restaurant that opened in Westbury about eight months ago, possesses many of the attributes that account for their proliferation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFE, RUTH C.
description: WOLFE-Ruth C. Died on October 29, in Boca Raton, FL. Devoted wife of the late Dr. Samuel A. Wolfe, and devoted mother of Rosemay Wallach of Delray Beach, FL, and Helene Guttman of Indianapolis, IN. Mother-in-law of Sidney Wallach. Grandmother of Steven and Gina Wallach, Jeff Wallach, Ilene and Robert Senoff, and great-grandmother of Scott and Adam Wallach.

title: Pantsuit Detail
description: THE GIRLS IN THE VAN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PESHKIN, DANIEL
description: PESHKIN-Daniel. A longtime resident of Weston, Connecticut, died Wednesday, November 7, 2001 at the age of 72 after a brief illness. He was a ''world class'' husband and father, and is survived by his wife, Westport attorney Joy Kony Peshkin; their two children, Wendy Ann Forkner of Darien, Connecticut, John Robert Peshkin of Osprey Florida; four adored grandchildren; and his brother, Richard A. Peshkin of Killen, Alabama

title: Travel Advisory; Disney World Trims Some Hours and Shows
description: It may be home to the Magic Kingdom, but Walt Disney World in Orlando isn't immune from the rest of the world's troubles. Because of the slump in tourism following the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, it has reduced operating hours of some attractions and made other cutbacks.

title: Flings Fall Apart
description: OCTOBER SUITE

title: Innovation Is Back, With Attitude
description: THE economy is in a downturn. Venture capital spending has plunged. Disillusioned dot-com entrepreneurs have packed up their business plans and gone off to dental school. So it is inevitable that innovation will drop off, right?

title: Word for Word/Weights and Measures; In the Aftermath of Terror, Grab a Calculator and Tally Forth
description: MEASURING the impact of the Sept. 11 attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon has become a relentless exercise among economists, politicians, journalists, historians and everyday people. In its simplest terms, taking numeric stock of damages and changes is the necessary stuff of recovery --the basis for making decisions on the allocation of funds, the adjustment of interest rates, or at a more mundane level, whether to take that holiday trip to the Big Apple. But the counting ritual is also therapeutic -- a means for getting a handle on events that may still feel wildly out of control.

title: [RETHINK]: Manifestoes For the Next New York; [Mass Transit]: Connect the Connectors
description: When the World Trade Center fell to the ground, it knocked out train and subway lines and in doing so made the public aware of the incredible machinery that pumps people into our streets and buildings. We saw one thing very clearly: this machinery is ancient. The subway line that ran directly under the fallen towers, for example, began service in 1918.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, ESTHER PFEFFER
description: ROSEN-Esther Pfeffer. Age 89, on October 27, 2001, in Boynton Beach, FL. Beloved wife of Fred M. Rosen. Devoted mother of Daniel Rosen, Alice Rosen and Louise Fuchs. Grandmother of Mara, Dallin, Luke, Leia, Jed and Natalie. Dear sister of Charlotte Gerstel and Fred Pfeffer. Cherished sisterin-law of Ruth and Joseph Mennen and Judith Pfeffer.

title: A Class Act
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRUDDEN, HORTON RORICK
description: PRUDDEN-Horton Rorick. Age 82, retired Chairman of the First Southeast Corporation. He was a Veteran in the U.S. Army in the Pacific Theater. He is survived by his wife Shirley Davidson Prudden, three children Horton R., Jr., James D., Jeffrey P.; sister Gloria Prudden Lange; daughter-in-law Marsha Linzy Prudden; grandson Sean D. Prudden; granddaughter Linzy J. Prudden. Graduated from Yale University in 1942, from Yale University Law in 1947 with a JD degree, member of Delta Kappa Epsilon Fraternity, member of the Yale Club, belonged to the Madison Beach Club and a member of the Connecticut Society of Genealogists. Memorial donations to St. Raphael Foundation, Hospital of St. Raphael, 1450 Chapel Street, New Haven, CT. 06511-9839. Call 203-789-3242/1-866-699-4647.

title: A Dip in Attendance And a Rise in Angst
description: Gary Payton tried to keep up with Jason Kidd on Thursday night in the Meadowlands, a hoop-junkie matchup between two Oakland playground legends acknowledged as the game's two elite point guards. The listed attendance was 5,277 -- for a building holding 20,049 seats.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-22

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAWLEY, CAPTAIN MARK TANEY, SR.
description: HAWLEY-Captain Mark Taney, Sr. A resident of Covington, LA, and a former shipping executive with International Shipholding Corporation and community activist, died Sunday, November 4, 2001 in Houston of a massive heart attack. He was 50. Born in Great Neck, NY, he graduated from Maria Regina High School, attended St. Michael's College and graduated from the United States Merchant Marine Academy. He was the first in his class to achieve master's license (unlimited tonnage) for ocean-going vessels. In addition to his marinetime consulting, he was a board member of Tchefuncta Club Estates and the USMMA. He was also a member of the Bienville Club, the Azalea Club and several Carnival organizations in New Orleans and was active with the Boy Scouts of America. Survivors include his wife, Colleen Dienes Hawley; two sons, Mark T. Hawley, Jr., and Jack Dienes Hawley; his mother, Mrs. Janice Hawley-Kopf of Great Neck, NY; three brothers-Rollin James Hawley, Jr., of Dublin, VA, George S. Hawley of Harrison, NJ and Joseph S. Hawley of Westport, CT; two sisters-Joy Hawley of Lexington, KY, and Mary Eddy of Amherst, MA; and numerous friends and family. In lieu of flowers the family asks for donations to be sent to The St. Anselm Building Fund, PO Box 40, Madisonville, LA 70447.

title: Music; Retaking the Measure of American Song
description: LAST spring, the New York Festival of Song presented an exemplary concert of 19 newly commissioned songs that demonstrated the energy and diversity of contemporary musical language in collision and collusion with contemporary poetry. This was far from the good old art-song recital with its predictable order, most often compared to a well-balanced banquet. Rather than a carefully chosen appetizer followed by a substantive entre and (usually frothy) dessert, the concert was an eclectic tasting event, featuring 19 wildly divergent styles, influences and texts, which gave a listener the dizzying sense of newly discovered marvels -- and future possibilities -- in the art of song.

title: The First R
description: The National Assessment of Educational Progress, aka the Nation's Report Card, is about to become more familiar to American children. The test is now given every two years to a sampling of 4th, 8th and 12th graders for use by the National Center for Education Statistics. Under President Bush's accountability push, it is the test of choice to independently confirm the results of each state's own reading and math tests. If, for example, New York reports that scores have risen but the sampling shows the opposite, a red flag goes up. Here are recently released reading questions.

title: Changed Plans
description: Until Sept. 11, the Camden County Board of Chosen Freeholders had planned to create a memorial at Cooper River Park in Pennsauken honoring residents of New Jersey who perished in the explosion of Pan American Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, in 1988. John Giannotti, above, a sculptor and professor emeritus at Rutgers University, had already designed the memorial.

title: A NATION CHALLENGED: HEARTS AND MINDS
description: A history of how the government has presented images of war and controlled information, and of how the message got out.

title: A Second Rail Tunnel Should Be Re-evaluated
description: To the Editor:

title: BENEFITS
description: Dinner for Design

title: Acquiring A Taste For Skiing
description: STANDING by a ski lift one day, I heard a woman say, quite apologetically, that she had simply never developed a taste for skiing. I wanted to run over and hug her. I loved the way she put it, comparing it to butterscotch pudding, or grapefruit.

title: Demolition Begins On Northport Building
description: Ending a preservation dispute by bringing in a wrecking crew, officials in the Village of Northport have proceeded with the demolition of the Art Deco building at 188 Main Street that a group of residents had campaigned to save.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: QUARREL & QUANDARY: Essays, by Cynthia Ozick. (Vintage International, $13.) In her latest collection of essays, which won a National Book Critics Circle Award, the author recalls her public school education in New York City in the 1930's and 40's and her formative encounters with New Criticism during its heyday in the 1950's. She also offers striking reflections on such topics as the Unabomber and the commodification of Anne Frank. Ozick is ''the most accomplished and graceful literary stylist of our time,'' John Sutherland said here last year.

title: In Flowerless Seasons, the Charm of Foliage
description: When we moved to our house 25 years ago, I envisioned borders filled with flowers from spring through fall. Lack of time and money squashed that dream. It takes time to plant swaths of long-blooming annuals in spring, and it takes money to have a continuous panorama of perennials in flower. By default, my borders often had long green, flowerless periods.

title: Billionaire Next Door Is a Regular Kind of Guy
description: They live amid a crowded constellation of stars and celebrities, of the famous and the infamous.

title: Let Us Count the Ways [1-9]
description: 1. Lena Dunham, St. Ann's student

title: Art Listings
description: Museums/Institutions

title: 5 Touchdowns Later, Westbrook Proves to Be Too Much for Hofstra
description: In a game that at times more closely resembled a track meet than a football game, Villanova's Brian Westbrook rushed for 287 yards and accounted for 5 touchdowns as the Wildcats outlasted Hofstra,

title: Carry-On Rules
description: To the Editor: The list is not long enough. I recently flew from Philadelphia to Burlington, Vt., and back. I got to Burlington with my corkscrew, but on the return it was confiscated. Not confiscated were a bottle of gin and a bottle of wine. No one questioned the liquids, and apparently glass bottles are not considered as potentially dangerous as corkscrews and safety pins. Seems to me we need some logic to all this.

title: November 4-10; Microsoft Settlement Near
description: The antitrust odyssey of Microsoft moved much closer to conclusion when the company reached a settlement with the Bush administration and 9 of the 18 states left in the case. The proposal restricts some of the software giant's business practices and requires it to make more disclosures of its software code to promote competition. Competing companies and the nine dissenting states see too many loopholes and are preparing to ask a federal judge to impose tougher penalties. Stephen Labaton

title: All Night Long, Swinging to a Latin Beat
description: JUST as the disc jockey Edgar Ramirez had predicted, the crunching guitar chords of the song ''Puto'' by the band Molotov energized the 100 dancers who clogged the small floor at September's in Elmsford. As soon as the dancers recognized the tune, they sang along and waved their arms.

title: Hea Kyung Chung, Ken Mak
description: Hea Kyung Kaitlyn Chung, a daughter of Kyung Ran Chung and Key Young Chung of Commack, N.Y., was married yesterday to Ken Ping Mak, the son of Susan Pui-San Mak and Ty Tse-Fai Mak of Stamford, Conn. The Rev. Hung-Cheon Rim, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Evangelical Lutheran Church in Huntington Station, N.Y.

title: New City Council a Portrait Composed by Term Limits
description: One incoming Council member is a former deputy superintendent of banking for the state. Another is a former member of the Black Panther Party who now runs a leadership-training consulting group. One is a podiatrist, two have served as police officers and still another made a name for himself by organizing an international student exchange program.

title: A NATION CHALLENGED: HEARTS AND MINDS -- A special report.; In the War on Terrorism, A Battle to Shape Opinion
description: Late last month, Karen P. Hughes, the White House communications director, met with her British counterpart to join forces in what may be the most ambitious wartime communications effort since World War II.

title: One View Of Fallout Over Ending Long Bonds
description: THANKS to the Federal Reserve, since January, the cost of servicing short-term debt has been dropping.

title: How All Charities Can Benefit in Changed City
description: To the Editor:

title: Gently Preparing For Deer Bowhunt
description: The adage maintains that those who rise before the sun on a daily basis are invariably optimists. But I've never known the jollity to kick in until the said optimist has consumed enough strong, scalding coffee to break a sweat. That's what I was thinking as I fumbled around in the dimly lit kitchen before dawn -- the fabled ''grumpy'' hour -- on a recent, chilly morning, as I prepared to go bowhunting.

title: A Valet, of Course
description: To the Editor:

title: Let Us Count the Ways: [17-23]
description: 17. Dolores D'Ambrosio, bait-shop owner

title: William F. Burke Jr.: Rendered by the Flame
description: Calling Capt. William F. Burke Jr. a firefighter is a little like referring to Elvis as an entertainer. Captain Burke took the job description and set it over the high flame of his personality, rendering something else entirely. "He always made everything better," said his brother Michael, "and in Manhattan, it's nice to be around somebody like that."

title: Hain Celestial Acquisition
description: The Hain Celestial Group (Nasdaq: HAIN) of Uniondale said last week that it had signed a letter of intent to acquire Lima NV, a Belgian manufacturer and marketer of natural and organic foods, and the owner of Biomarch, an organic produce distributor.

title: Investing; Those Who Did, Shopped Discount
description: OLD-LINE department stores suffered a sucker punch on Sept. 11. Shoppers stayed home in droves, and those who have made purchases since then have mainly bought household goods, not the fashionable clothes that department stores sell. Shoppers and investors alike have been turning toward discount stores and wholesale clubs.

title: No Sanctions for Gentiva
description: Gentiva Health Services (Nasdaq: GTIV) of Melville said last week that the federal Department of Health and Human Services had concluded its two-year investigation into the company's dealings with various government programs and had issued no sanctions.

title: A Night Spot That's Cozy and Live
description: TWO years ago Richard Franzino decided to do something to bring live music to people his own age who did not feel at ease in bars, clubs and loud arenas. So he opened the Acoustic Cafe in Bridgeport.

title: Five Hollywood Producers Pitch Their Post-Attack Fall Season
description: 'The Nationals'

title: Franklin Pershep: Like a Kid, With Bagels
description: To his co-workers at the Aon Corporation on the 93rd floor of 2 World Trade Center, Franklin Pershep was the Bagel Man. First he would bring in two or three dozen to celebrate someone's wedding, promotion or new baby, said his daughter, Stacy, then later, for no reason. He bought them at a shop near his home in Bensonhurst that Stacy also visited. "They'd say, `Oh Stacy, your dad was here, he paid for your bagel and coffee this morning,' " she recalled.

title: In Flowerless Times, the Charm of Foliage
description: WHEN we moved to our house 25 years ago, I envisioned borders filled with flowers from spring through fall. Lack of time and money squashed that dream. It takes time to plant swaths of long-blooming annuals in spring, and it takes money to have a continuous panorama of perennials in flower. By default, my borders often had long green, flowerless periods.

title: Habitats/89th Street Between First and Second Avenues; Fireman and His Family Find an East Side Condo
description: MANY firefighters who work in New York City live in the suburbs, in houses with several bedrooms and grassy yards for their children. The suburbs are very practical for firefighters because they work two shifts a week of 24 hours each, making commuting far less frequent and onerous.

title: Princess Cruises
description: To the Editor: We hope that the four-day Alaska samplers that were described in the Travel Advisory (''Shorter Cruises to Alaska on Princess,'' Aug. 12) are correcting some of the problems we encountered on the Dawn Princess earlier this year.

title: Second Home Market Reviving After Lull
description: FOR two weeks after the Sept. 11 attacks, the offices of real-estate firms specializing in second homes fell silent. Phones stopped ringing, inquiries came to a halt, prospective buyers stayed away. The desire to purchase a home for leisure use seemed somehow frivolous.

title: Teachers Worth Remembering
description: THERE is much talk about heroes these days.

title: 'Fog of War' Marks Campaign as Australia Re-elects Leadership
description: Prime Minister John Howard and his conservative government won a third term today in national elections that focused on security and immigration issues.

title: OPINION; Introducing Billy Crystal's Father
description: THERE was a time when the best-known member of Long Beach's Crystal family was not Billy, the actor and comedian, or his brother Joel, the City Council president, but their father, Jack. The elder Crystal was one of the most loved and respected figures of the jazz world, having promoted years of performances and run a classic jazz record label.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BRYER, RICHARD
description: BRYER-Richard. 36 years without you, my precious Richie. You live forever in my heart. Mom

title: No Headline
description: Chaim Stern, one of Reform Judaism's most prolific liturgists -- whose influence extended even to President Bill Clinton, who quoted a passage on contrition from one of Rabbi Stern's books during the president's sex scandal -- died of a malignant brain tumor at a Miami hospital on Monday. He was 71 and lived in Miami.

title: Putin Urges A 'New Level' Of the Trust With America
description: Days before a much-anticipated meeting with President Bush, President Vladimir V. Putin called tonight for Russia and the United States to bury the vestiges of their cold war suspicions and form an alliance with ''a qualitatively new level'' of trust.

title: SELF-CLEANING HUDSON
description: The lower portion of the Hudson River may be slowly cleaning itself, according to a study released last week by Rutgers University scientists. The study found that metal pollutants in the portion of the river from the Tappan Zee Bridge to the river's mouth, about 40 miles downstream, do not lie immobile on the river bottom but are occasionally stirred up. Though the pollutants return to the river's floor, the repetitive process releases contaminants and moves them out to sea, the study said. The scientists said their research raised the question of whether the river should be allowed to clean itself rather than undergo dredging. Sarah Rubenstein

title: When Day Gets Hectic, Just Remember to Sing
description: LARA HERSCOVITCH does not remember exactly what sparked the rant. It was either her being turned down for a booking she really wanted, or maybe it was something that happened during a recording session.

title: Commercial Property/Manhattan; Amid Uncertainty, Few Office Buildings Are for Sale
description: OWNERS of office buildings think their properties are still worth what they were before the attack on the World Trade Center, many real estate executives say. But prospective buyers think that a slowing economy and the aftereffects of Sept. 11 have reduced those values. The resulting disconnect means that few properties in New York are changing hands or are even for sale.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUDWIG, WILLIAM FRANK
description: LUDWIG-William Frank. Died November 8, 2001 in Vero Beach, Florida from complications of lung cancer. Loving husband of Gaye, devoted father of Bill, Amelia, Jack and Julia, beloved grandfather of Stacey, Lydia, Anna and Zachary and brother of Judy and Donald. Friend and colleague to many as Vice President at JP Morgan and partner at Morgan Lewis G&A. Born February 2, 1930 in Sanford, Florida, Bill graduated from the University of Pennsylvania in 1951, and Columbia Law School in 1958, after military service as an officer in the US Naval Reserve. Bill began a 26-year career at JP Morgan & Co. in 1958, first as legal counsel, then as Vice President serving the banking needs of many of America's largest companies. Bill interrupted his career at Morgan in the mid 1960s, heeding the call of John F. Kennedy for public service. He led the Latin American Lending Division of the US Agency for International Development. Bill was the first head of the workout department of Morgan in the 1970s and was named a director of Penn Central when that company emerged from bankruptcy. In the mid-1980s he created and led the bank's leveraged buyout activities. Bill's vigorous independence of mind, pragmatic approach to business and ability to find humor in almost any situation impressed all with whom he came in contact. From long standing business relationships grew many fast friendships. At the suggestion of a bank colleague, Bill met his second wife, Gaye McIntosh, just over 20 years ago. In 1986, Bill left JP Morgan to become partner in the leveraged buyout firm of Morgan Lewis G&A. After 7 years of creative and successful deal making, Bill and his family moved to Vero Beach, Florida to be close to his Florida roots. A memorial service was held Saturday, November 10th at his home in Vero Beach. Contributions in Bill's memory can be sent to the University of Pennsylvania's Penn Fund.

title: Travel Advisory: Correspondent's Report; Far From the Worry, Rio Just Rolls On
description: WERE it not for the headlines in the paper, it would be hard to tell from Brazil that the world is grappling with perhaps its greatest crisis since World War II. Fewer Americans may be traveling here, but with summer approaching, the beaches are packed and restaurants and clubs are still open until the wee hours as Brazilians continue to demonstrate a talent for living to the fullest.

title: Pictures That Make The Artist The Subject
description: WHAT artists look like and how they live can be as fascinating, or sometimes more so, than what they create. This point is illustrated by an exhibition of photographs of artists, which opened late last month at the Ben Shahn Galleries at William Paterson University.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTWELL, BETTY HAWK
description: HARTWELL-Betty Hawk. 83, a resident of Greenwich, CT, passed away on November 6. A memorial service is planned for December 1 at 2 PM at the First Church of Round Hill, 464 Round Hill Road, Greenwich, CT.

title: E-Commerce Degrees: Fight or Flight?
description: IN the final hours of the 20th century, universities jumped on the online money wagon, and for some, not without regrets. Many master's programs in e-commerce are now facing an enrollment free fall, yet another side effect of the failed dot.com economy.

title: Below the Jet Stream
description: If the weeks following Sept. 11 literally took the air out of many travelers' plans, it didn't stop them altogether. Amtrak, for one, had a ''spike in overall sales'' through September and October, according to Kathleen Gordon, the company's assistant vice president for e-commerce. That reflected an inability among would-be air travelers to find flights -- to Washington, for example, while Reagan National Airport was closed -- or a reluctance to return to the skies, or both.

title: A Plan for Traffic
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation: Double Bind; Acting Normal When Nothing Is Normal
description: A POPULAR technique called cognitive-behavioral therapy can be summed up in a phrase: ''Fake it till you make it.'' Instead of endlessly analyzing the deep-seated patterns that erupt in neurotic behavior, just try to get the patient to pretend he is O.K. Coax an agoraphobic to venture out to the mailbox, then the bus stop, then the mall, and after a while the fear of open spaces will subside. What begins as feigned bravery solidifies and becomes real.

title: Christine Maloy, Nicholas Jacobs
description: Christine Marie Maloy, a daughter of Catherine and Paul Maloy of Roslyn Harbor, N.Y., was married yesterday at the Cosmos Club in Washington to Nicholas Charles Jacobs, the son of Lenore Jacobs of Washington and the late Theodore Jacobs. Rabbi Harold S. White, the head Jewish chaplain of Georgetown University, officiated, and the Rev. Scott Pilarz, a Roman Catholic priest and a Georgetown English professor, took part in the ceremony.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, ETHEL D.
description: JACOBS-Ethel D. 91, passed away in the loving arms of her family in Miami Beach, Florida, at Mount Sinai Medical Center on November 9, 2001, after a brief illness. Born March 18, 1910, in Yonkers, New York, she was a longtime resident of Forest Hills, New York, and Bal Harbour, Florida. Predeceased by her beloved husband, Hirsch Jacobs, breeder and trainer of such Hall of Fame thoroughbreds as Stymie, Searching and Affectionately which raced in her salmon pink and emerald green colors. She also raced classic winner and Horse of the Year, Personality and classic winner, High Echelon, trained by her son, John. She is survived by her children Thomas E.W. Jacobs, Patrice (Louis) Wolfson and John Wm. (Barbara) Jacobs; her grandchildren John W. Jacobs, Jr., and Jennifer Dahl Jacobs. There will be a private memorial mass at St. Patrick's Catholic Church, Miami Beach, on Monday and a private interment at the Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Valhalla, New York. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the charity of your choice. For information, Riverside-Gordon Memorial Chapel 305-531-1151 www.dignitymemorial

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUHN, LOUIS
description: KUHN-Louis. Loving husband of Lee (61 years); father of Robert (Pasadena, CA & NYC) & Karen (Paradise Valley, AZ); father-inlaw of Dora Kuhn & Stuart Troyan; adoring grandfather of Aaron, Adam, Daniella, Ross & Michael. Born: May 18, 1912 in New York; died: November 7, 2001, in his 90th year, in Phoenix. Founder & president, Chief Apparel, Inc. and affiliated manufacturing companies. W.W. II service in Europe. A good and decent man; strong, handsome, vital and radiant; wonderful sense of humor, always with a smile, often with a twinkle. Devoted family man; very charitable; enjoyed reading, math, chocolate. An inventor late in life. An athlete all his life: punchball on the city streets (Lower East Side); baseball (All-City); basketball (college center); handball (playing doubles into his 70s, the combined ages of the three other players on the handball court-added up!-would often be less than his). Funeral service 11:30 AM, Sunday, Nov. 11, at Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI, NY.

title: The World: The Untold Story; Why They Don't Know Us
description: IN the 1980's, when Pakistan was considered a cold war battleground, American cultural centers were a focus of intellectual and social life in Islamabad, Karachi, Lahore, Hyderabad and Peshawar. Each offered well-stocked libraries, discussion groups led by visiting Americans and a stream of cultural programs. In Lahore, the country's most sophisticated city, singers from the Metropolitan Opera created a sensation, and there were long lines for a show of posters of American paintings.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASKETBALL

title: [SONGS FOR THE CITY]; N.Y. City Pretty
description: New York City AOK. . . .One of the greatest cites in the USA. . . .Still got it good in the neighborhood. . . .We all come together like you know we should. . . .They try to knock us down. . . .We get back up. . . .New York City unified. . . .They tried to keep us down, yeah,they tried. . . .We won't stand down, we will stand tall. . . .New York City, the greatest city of all. . . .

title: Moises Rivas: 'Some Kind of Moves'
description: When Moises Rivas first laid eyes on Elizabeth, it was at a local beauty pageant in Queens, and he was the lead singer of the band. He was smitten, and made a $50 bet with another band member that he would get her to go out with him.

title: HOLIDAY TOMORROW -- Veterans Day
description: The holiday, actually Nov. 11, is observed on Monday.

title: In the Tracks of Olympians
description: THEY say it is healthy to keep some fantasies alive in a fertile corner of the brain -- a half-dozen or so active daydreams to prevent dry rot of the imagination. I'd like to hit a Roger Clemens fastball, do stand-up comedy for a night, swap tequila shots with Cameron Diaz, and ski the Olympic downhill. Not long ago, one of them came true. Not the Clemens, comedy or Cameron dreams. But for a brief time, I was an Olympian.

title: A Highflier's Last Gasp as the Bubble Runs Out of Air
description: THE last of the Internet imposters -- overheated stocks posing as growth companies -- has at last been unmasked. Now perhaps we can get chief executives back to the business of running their companies rather than running their stocks.

title: [RETHINK]: Manifestoes For the Next New York; [Boroughs]: Put a Piece of Downtown in Flushing
description: The radical act of the terrorists opens a space for us to think radically as well. While many of the billions that will be available for rebuilding -- from insurance, from federal aid, from city coffers, from developers -- are surely needed to restore the health and character of Lower Manhattan, it seems reasonable to question whether such massive expenditure should be focused exclusively downtown rather than throughout the city at sites of need and opportunity.

title: The Banner Yet Waves
description: There was flag-wearing and flag-waving everywhere at last Sunday's marathon. Both runners and spectators were caught up in the current display of patriotism. Many of the nearly 10,000 international runners carried both their own flags and the American flag.

title: The Lessons of Terrorism For a School in Jersey City
description: FROM their windows, students at the Golden Door Charter School used to be able to see the World Trade Center rising just over the Newport Mall. But on that awful day, many of them saw it come down.

title: The Un-Jefferson
description: ALEXANDER HAMILTON

title: Leah Ramirez, William Lie
description: Leah Holmes Ramirez and Gerard William Lie were married on Friday at the Lotos Club in New York by Judge Carol R. Edmead of the New York City Civil Court.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, JOHN S.
description: WHITE-John S. New York City Opera mourns the passing of one of its most esteemed and cherished company members, John White. Born in Vienna, he joined the company in 1946 as its first language coach and went on to serve the City Opera as a stage director, administrator and, from 1970 until his retirement in 1980, managing director. He continued to serve as a consultant until his death. With general director Julius Rudel, he established the City Opera as a true operatic repertory company that continued to grow in stature over the years. Many of the young American singers who joined the company during his tenure went on to establish major careers throughout the world. For 55 years, the City Opera has benefited from his knowledge and his wise counsel. He leaves an indelible mark on our company, as well as in our lives, and we will miss him greatly. Paul Kellogg General Director

title: Why Are We Hiding bin Laden?
description: Why can't we watch Osama bin Laden on American television? White House officials called on network executives last month, after a videotaped statement by Mr. bin Laden was widely broadcast on Oct. 7. The administration persuaded the networks that self-censorship was necessary to the war effort. The tapes of Mr. bin Laden were merely propaganda, it was suggested. Besides, he might be using the tapes to send hidden messages to terrorists, although no evidence was offered to support this notion. Network officials agreed to treat future broadcasts with care.

title: Westfield, A Brief History
description: IN several instances, the underwear was too tight. In another, there was no top at all. Who knew what would happen during a half-off sale?

title: Exploring the Darker Side of Dr. Spock
description: THERE is a time-honored tradition in family-oriented situation comedy that requires the vast majority of children to crack wise beyond their years, to the point that they sound more like editors at The Harvard Lampoon than fifth graders. Lately, though, another trend has emerged that seems to be taking television families in the opposite direction: sitcom parents, particularly fathers, are becoming more childish.

title: A Different Road Home
description: Nearly one in four Americans planning to travel over the holidays will use a different mode of transportation than in years past, according to a survey of 1,000 people released last week by Maritz Research. For those making a change from their normal routines, 51 percent now plan to drive, while 46 percent plan to fly. The poll was conducted in late September and early October.

title: Laura Gilly: The Joy in Her Voice
description: For nine years, Laura Gilly traveled the world, all expenses paid; a perk from her life as a flight attendant. She saw Paris, she saw Rome, indulged in the exotic sights and sounds of Egypt, Jakarta and Kuwait.

title: Travel Advisory; London Ticket Booth Adds to Its Offerings
description: The official theater-ticket stand in Leicester Square in London has changed its name and expanded its offerings.

title: [RETHINK]: Manifestoes For the Next New York; [Labor]: Capitalize on Blue-Collar Heroism
description: For the first time in decades, America's heroes are everyday working people: firemen, postal workers, E.M.S. technicians, police officers, soldiers. In celebrity magazines, iron welders appear, in their beefy union T-shirts, like movie stars, and outside the city's firehouses, crowds continue to linger -- the buckets of flowers still fresh, the candles still lighted. As David Letterman said, summing up the nation's sense of gratitude: ''I hope we never, ever take these people for granted.''

title: For Catterson, Some Old Scores Got Settled
description: DURING nearly 12 years as Suffolk County district attorney, James M. Catterson Jr. gained a reputation as a vigorous prosecutor, but also as a quick-tempered bully who used the powers of his office to batter enemies and others who got in his way.

title: A Correction: Today's Magazine
description: Because of a production error, Pages 110 and 111 in some copies of The Times Magazine today omit Entries 20 to 23 of ''Let Us Count the Ways,'' a series of accounts of famous New Yorkers' favorite places in the city, and Entries 17 to 19 are duplicated. The missing entries follow, and a corrected version of the full series appears on the Web, at www.nytimes.com/ magazine.

title: The Journalist's Role
description: To the Editor:

title: In Chamber Music, Significant Others
description: NONE of the eight descriptions of ''chamber'' in Webster's dictionary has just one word about chamber music, even though instrumentalists regard it as their art's highest form. There is no mention of the deep, intimate thrill of playing inspired works in a small ensemble.

title: Red Kettles, Good Deeds and Business Advice
description: DOROTHY McBRIDE earned a master's and Ph.D. in business administration while in the Air Force. She reached the rank of lieutenant colonel. Then at age 42, she decided to discard her career to answer this job posting: Invest two years of training, at your own expense, to earn low pay for long hours dealing with desperate people. Uniform required.

title: The New York Times Top 50
description: The New York Times's computer football ranking is based on an analysis of each team's scores with emphasis on three factors: who won, by what margin and against what quality of opposition. The quality of an opponent is determined by examining the opponent's record against other teams.

title: Holding the Keys
description: MACONOCHIE'S GENTLEMEN

title: Getty Realty Offering Raises $131.5 Million
description: The Getty Realty Corporation (NYSE: GTY) of Jericho said on Monday that its public offering, completed during the third quarter as the company became a real estate investment trust, had raised $131.5 million. Getty paid out nearly half of that to stockholders and $37.4 million to eliminate its debt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JURGENS, THOMAS E.
description: JURGENS-Thomas E. 26 year old Senior Court Officer at Manhattan Supreme Court, heroically on September 11, 2001. Tommy was also a Captain of Engine 332 of the Meadowmere Park Volunteer Fire Department and was honorably discharged from the United States Army, Army Reserves, and the National Guard where he was a combat medic. Tommy is survived by his proud and loving family which includes his wife Joan, father Joseph, stepmom Barbara, mother Linda, stepfather Alan, two brothers Joseph and Bradley, a sister Jessica, a grandmother Margaret Dracker, a grandfather Robert Blakeman, mother and father-in-law Joan and Andy Schmitt, a God daughter Kayla Schmitt as well as many relatives and friends. Tommy will be deeply missed and will always be remembered for his loyalty, generosity, sincerity, sense of humor, and most of all his heroism and great love. A memorial wake will be held on Whitting Funeral Home, 300 Glen Cove Ave, Glen Head, NY, on Thursday, November 15, from 2 PM to 5 PM, and 7 PM to 9 PM. There will be a Fire Department Service held at 8 PM, at the funeral home. A memorial Mass will be held at St. Raymond's Roman Catholic Church, 263 Atlantic Ave, East Rockaway, NY, on Friday, November 16, at noon. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the American Cancer Society, 839 Stewart Ave, Garden City, NY 11530 (1-800-227-2345), or the Nassau County Burn Center, PO Box 246, Levittown, NY 11756 (516572-3208).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEAVEY, JOSEPH G.
description: LEAVEY-Joseph G., Lieutenant, NYFD, 45 of Ladder 15, NYFD gave his life in the line of duty at the WTC on September 11, 2001. Joe, a resident of Pelham, was born and raised in the Inwood Section of NYC on November 13, 1955 to Mary S. (Giannotti) & Joseph P. Leavey, retired NYC Transit Police. He married Carole J. Raffio on May 12, 1984 in St. Catharine's Church. He was the devoted father of Brian Michael & Caitlin Alexandra and stepfather and fatherin-law to Kerri & Chris Kelly of NYC. In addition to his wife and children of Pelham and his parents of Yonkers, Joe is survived by his mother-in-law Renee Raffio of Palm Coast, FL, his sisters and brothers-in-law Maureen & Jim McGillicuddy of Yonkers, Nora & Steve Coco of Rochester, Patty & Tim Sumner of Martinsburg, PA and brothers-in-laws Alex Raffio of Palm Coast and Walter Bagley of Bronxville. He was a wonderful uncle to his nephews, John & Timmy McGillicuddy, Mark Fitzgerald and his niece Christine Coco. He was the beloved nephew of Edward & Anna M. Leavey of Middle Village and the dear Godson of Mary Furlong of the Bronx. He is also survived by several cousins. He was predeceased by his father-in-law, Alex Raffio and his sister-in-law, Marilyn (Muffy) Bagley. Joe graduated from Good Shephard Grammar School, the former Power Memorial Academy and Manhattan College School of Engineering in 1977. He worked for the W.J. Barney Co. and HRH Co. in the Civil Engineering field. As a young boy, Joe always wanted to become a NYC Firefighter. He was appointed to the FDNY in 1982. He served at Engine 23, Ladder 4 and most recently as a Lieutenant at Ladder 15 on South Street all in Manhattan. He considered the WTC to be an ''Engineering Marvel''. How ironic that the building he loved so much would become his final resting place. Joe was active in his Parish of St. Catharine's where he served as an Eucharistic Minister and Lector. He also was the Treasurer for the Hutchinson School PTA, his daughter's school. He will be greatly missed by his family and friends. Visitation with the family will be held on Sunday, November 11, and Monday November 12, 2001 at the Pelham Funeral Home, 64 Lincoln Avenue, Pelham from 2-4 and 7-9 PM. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at 10:30 AM on November 13, 2001 at Saint Catharine's Church, 25 Second Avenue, Pelham. Interment to follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Valhalla.

title: S.E.C. Moves to Allow Exchange-Traded Funds
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has taken the first step toward allowing the introduction of actively managed exchange-traded funds.

title: Elizabeth Sitnick, David Balfour
description: Elizabeth Ann Sitnick, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Sitnick of New York, was married yesterday to David Mayo Balfour, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Donald C. Balfour III of San Diego. Rabbi Ari Fridkis officiated at Bridgewaters in New York, where the Rev. Jeffrey V. O'Grady, a Presbyterian minister, took part in the ceremony.

title: To Add to Wall Street's Woes, Riders Must Wait for Limousines
description: If corporate belt-tightening weren't enough, many Wall Street executives must now wait a little longer for their chauffeured rides home.

description: Missouri's Justin Gage and Texas Tech's Kliff Kingsbury were among those who had big games on Saturday.

description: ALDRICH-Larry. A man of great artistic taste, intelligence, wit and charm. He encouraged artists to create and all of us to see. He was a dear friend to Henry and Erna Leir, and enlisted them in his charitable causes. We will remember. The Leir Foundations

description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: The Making of a Student Activist
description: In many ways, Ryan Nuckel is a typical student activist: he doesn't take drugs, he rarely drinks, and he is fueled by a nagging anger over the fact that there are haves and have-nots, oppressors and the oppressed. He and his fellow insurgents would never consider themselves a counterculture: Hippies turned on and dropped out. He doesn't want to drop out. He just wants change.

title: Theater; In Honor Of Wildness And Wit
description: WITOLD GOMBROWICZ, the Polish-born playwright, novelist, diarist and iconoclast, earned a reputation as a scandalous genius in Poland, though he lived in self-imposed exile in Argentina for 24 years after being stranded there when Hitler invaded his country.

title: Gary Haag: Following His Lead
description: Gary Haag was the Pied Piper of the neighborhood. Children would flock to his house when they saw him drive home from work. He would lead the children off to games of baseball, soccer or hockey. Bicycles and scooters would be left scattered in the Haag driveway, their owners off playing with Mr. Haag and his kids.

description: In a sun-soaked homecoming as triumphant as anything seen here since the Persian Gulf war, nearly 10,000 people cheered, carried balloons and waved patriotic banners today as one of the first aircraft carriers to strike at Afghanistan, the Enterprise, returned to her home port.

title: Olympic Champion Tripped Up by Steroids
description: Once a slightly suspect but essentially solid symbol of human resilience, Ludmila Engquist took a sledgehammer to her image last week by admitting that she had purchased, smuggled and used anabolic steroids in an attempt to become better at her new sport of bobsledding.

title: Heavy Reinforcements For Security
description: The F.B.I., Secret Service, the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms and police from neighboring states will join local law enforcement, emergency medical personnel, public health workers and the Utah National Guard for a security force of over 8,000 at the Olympic Games Feb. 8 to 24.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Heather Matarazzo; She Loves a Cabaret
description: FOR decades, certain New Yorkers who have stumbled upon Marie's Crisis, the stamp-size piano bar on Grove Street in the Village, have been smitten by its Broadway show-tune singalong format. The latest victim of its cheesy charm is Heather Matarazzo, the once geeky teenager who memorably starred in ''Welcome to the Dollhouse,'' Todd Solondz's 1996 film.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARBER, MIMI
description: FARBER-Mimi. Age 90. Died peacefully at home November 5, 2001. Wife of the late Irving Farber. Beloved mother of Howard (Pat). Adored grandmother of Lori and Abbey. Great grandmother of Leah. A great lady of humor and kindness, she will be greatly missed. Donations to Cancer Care, 275 7th Av, NY, NY 10021.

title: City to Drop Charges Against 17 of 18 Firefighters Arrested Over Protest
description: Charges against all but one of the firefighters arrested during a raucous demonstration at ground zero on Nov. 2 will be dropped, city officials said yesterday, in a gesture to help restore the close relationship forged between police officers and firefighters in the wake of the Sept. 11 terrorist attack.

title: Where Graduate Students Seldom Go-Grade School
description: Wasmannia auropunctata -- little red fire ants -- most likely arrived in Hawaii as stowaways in a horticultural shipment. With no natural enemies or competitors, these reddish-brown invaders carry a huge potential for destruction, and at barely a millimeter long are difficult to spot. Hawaii's best hope of eradicating them may be an army of 7th through 10th graders.

description: I RECENTLY asked a couple of connoisseurs how the movie version of ''Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone'' might be better than the book.

A Second Look

title: Orders in a Slump For Machine Tools
description: Orders by companies for machine tools fell in September, returning to levels last seen in the recession in 1980 and 1981, two trade groups said today.

description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week included tomorrow's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and a four-week bill on Wednesday.

title: A Shaky Economy May Threaten Future Giving
description: IN the four weeks after Sept. 11, more than half of American adults gave money to disaster relief efforts, and 7 in 10 donated money, blood or time, according to a survey released by the Independent Sector, a Washington nonprofit group dedicated to strengthening the efforts of other nonprofit groups.

title: With Time, Favre Dissects The Bears
description: There were early passing sequences in the Green Bay-Chicago game today when Packers quarterback Brett Favre would cradle the snap, drop back and look left. Then look right. Roll left. Roll right. Look left again. Look right again.

title: The New York Skyline
description: The New York skyline was dramatically changed on September 11, and it will change again as the city rebuilds. Here is a collection of articles about architecture and New York.
