description: The following is a transcript of spokesman Ari Fleischer's press briefing as provided by the White House.

title: Accounts
description: * Equiva Services, Houston, the marketing services arm for the Shell and Texaco brands in the United States, to the Houston office of J. Walter Thompson, part of the WPP Group, to handle Texaco, which had been at the Houston office of BBDO Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group. Billings were estimated at $20 million. Thompson is the worldwide agency of record for Shell, part of Royal Dutch/Shell; the American Texaco stations are to eventually be rebranded as Shell.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''When something like that happens, you feel helpless. I had to fix that.''

title: Random House President to Lead New Asian Push
description: Responding in part to a steep downturn in book sales in the United States, Random House, the largest book publisher, appointed its president, Youngsuk Chi, to the new position of chairman of Random House Asia. He will open an Asian office and seek new areas of growth, possibly through acquisitions.

title: Taliban Begin to Pull Out of Kabul as Rebels Move In
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 - After a string of successes by the Northern Alliance in Afghanistan, the forces of the Taliban appeared to be retreating from Kabul, the capital, a senior Bush administration official said tonight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MIDDENDORF, GEORGE A.
description: MIDDENDORF-George A. Of Melville, NY, on November 8. Born July 8, 1919, in New York. Graduate Dartmouth College 1941. Married July 6, 1946, to Barbara Lloyd. Served as Lt. in US Army 1941-1945, stationed in New Guinea and Australia. Executive Editor Harper and Row for 39 years. Predeceased by his wife Barbara and survived by his children George III, Lloyd, Louise Stokes and Julia Stehlik, six grandchildren, and two brothers, John and Robert. Memorial visitation Wednesday, 6-9 PM, at A.L. Jacobsen Funeral Home, Inc, 1380 New York Ave, Huntington Station, NY. Donations to Half Hollow Hill Community Library or Lustgarden Foundation would be appreciated.

title: Corrections
description: A table in the Automobiles section on Friday showing the costs of financing new cars misstated the amount a buyer with the best credit rating would pay on a 48-month loan for a $30,000 vehicle. Based on an interest rate of 6.53 percent (the going rate for Manhattan), the payments would be $688.13 a month, not $604.17; the total cost would be $34,030.24, not $30,000.16.

description: High-Technology Exports From China Create Tension

title: Two Months After the Attack, a Veterans Day Parade During Wartime
description: In recent years, the march up Fifth Avenue for New York's annual Veterans Day Parade was often a lonely one, but yesterday the men and women who dusted off their old uniforms, donned Veterans of Foreign Wars hats and pinned on decades-old medals found their reception transformed by the attack that shook the city two months ago.

title: Windows XP Seems to Have Solid Start
description: The early sales for Windows XP, given the economic climate, appear to be good -- not a runaway hit perhaps, but very solid.

title: Oil Diplomacy Muddled U.S. Pursuit of bin Laden, New Book Contends
description: A former F.B.I. antiterror official who was killed at the World Trade Center on Sept. 11 complained bitterly last summer that the United States was unwilling to confront Saudi Arabia over Osama bin Laden and that oil ruled American foreign policy, according to a new book published in France.

title: Afghan Phone Links Are an American Legacy
description: While the Soviet-built conventional telephone network in Afghanistan has suffered significant damage in recent bombing raids, a more sophisticated telecommunications system built by a United States company in the late 1990's remains in service and is an important link to the outside world, according to a report expected to be released today.

title: From Back of Pack, a Team Gallops to Championship
description: For more than 30 years New York's best players have competed in the Von Zedtwitz Double Knockout Team Championship, an event named for one of the game's all-time great performers, long a resident of the city. It has regularly been won by players of national or international reputation playing for a high-ranked team.

title: The Toy War for Holiday Movies Is a Battle Among 3 Heavyweights
description: Let the product tie-in wars begin.

title: Shaky Marriages Sunk By Emotional Baggage
description: This is none of my business, but I'll bet John Patrick Shanley has gone through a divorce. His new play about marriage, ''Where's My Money?,'' has a sardonic, wicked tone that sounds personal, the kind that results when a talented writer tears into his own rage and frustration with exorcising zeal.

title: Critical News Coverage
description: To the Editor:

title: Helping After Terror: Oklahoma City's Lessons
description: AT 9:02 a.m. on April 19, 1995, a bomb killed 168 people at the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building in Oklahoma City. The country's grief was both palpable and tangible. Americans responded by sending more than $40 million, trying to provide what succor they could to the families of the victims. None of the local charities had ever administered such sums before, so they learned as they went along. The Oklahoma City Community Foundation, which usually manages money donated for improving the city, quickly took the lead in coordinating the relief efforts.

title: Equality at Trade Talks: No Country Gets a Vote
description: World trade ministers say they fear that they will deliver a shock to the world economy unless they agree to liberalize trade at their meeting here. But the only shocking thing may be if they manage to agree on anything at all.

title: Pro Bono Accounts
description: * Twin Towers Fund, New York, to the interactive unit of Merkley Newman Harty & Partners, New York, part of the Omnicom Group, to handle an assignment including online brand identity and graphic design. The fund helps support the families of firefighters, police and others who died in the attacks on the World Trade Center.

title: Thornton Played Well, Even if U.S. Didn't
description: Goalkeeper ZACH THORNTON was the only United States player to distinguish himself during Sunday's scoreless tie with Trinidad and Tobago in the last World Cup qualifying game for both teams.

title: Publisher to Sell Digital Books Online
description: Simon & Schuster announced last week that it would open its own online store to sell digital editions of its books directly to consumers, moving ahead with the plan despite scant demand to read such books.

title: Hollywood Discusses Role in War Effort
description: Top executives from Hollywood's movie studios, television networks, cinema operators and labor unions met for 90 minutes this morning with Karl Rove, senior adviser to President Bush, to discuss how the entertainment industry could cooperate in the war on terrorism and to begin setting up a structure to make it happen.

title: White House Letter; Multilateralist From Midland Takes the Stage
description: When President Bush strode into a splashy news conference in New York City on Saturday night with the man whose name he once couldn't remember, General Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan, it was yet another eye-popping display of a presidency turned upside down. Suddenly the military president of Pakistan, who seized power in a coup two years ago, was Mr. Bush's best new friend in the subcontinent.

title: Iraqi Defectors Tell of Kuwaitis in Secret Jail in Baghdad
description: Two Iraqi defectors, veterans of the country's intelligence service, say they worked in a secret site outside of Baghdad where 80 Kuwaitis captured during the 1991 war were detained in an underground prison.

title: On One Afghan Front Line, the Rebel Tide Surges, Then Flows Back
description: On the first day of the Northern Alliance's long-awaited offensive along the front lines here, the men ran forward.

title: Air Crash Probably Not Caused by Terrorists, Officials Say
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 - Early indicators suggest that American Airlines Flight 587 was not brought down by terrorists, senior law enforcement and intelligence officials said today.

title: For the New Mayor, a City's Advice on Challenges That Must Be Faced; Healing Ethnic Rifts
description: Memo to: Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: Online Privacy Expert Shifts Focus to Security
description: As perhaps the nation's most vocal authority on data privacy, Richard M. Smith spent the last two years trying to keep Americans' personal information private from corporate intrusions. But seeing bigger threats, he is now turning his attention to studying whether the public is sufficiently secure.

title: The Neediest Cases; Reasons to Give Are as Varied as Donors
description: Donors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund often cite personal encounters with the city's needy as inspiration for their gifts -- whether it's the disabled panhandler on 42nd Street they pass every day or someone down on his luck whom they've read about in the articles that appear in The Times each winter.

title: CBS News Asks '60 Minutes' To Cut Back On Producers
description: In what many CBS News staff members described as the first time in memory that television's pre-eminent newsmagazine has been asked to reduce its production staff, ''60 Minutes'' is cutting back its corps of producers as part of a plan by CBS News to pare its budget in reaction to the rising costs of covering the war in Afghanistan.

title: Honoring Lost Lives From Some 80 Nations
description: The names were read aloud one by one, more than 80 in all, each a nation or region of the world that had lost a soul, and more, when the planes flew into the buildings that morning. President Bush, Secretary General Kofi A. Annan, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, the governor, the two senators, the mayor, the mayor-elect and the ambassador, among many others, paid witness.

title: Knicks Have No Spirit, No Size and Little Shot
description: Allan Houston and Latrell Sprewell have been in losing situations before. Houston made the playoffs only once in three seasons with Detroit, and Sprewell's Golden State Warriors failed to qualify for the playoffs in five of the six seasons he was there.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PENCHINA, HAROLD
description: PENCHINA-Harold. On November 10, 2001. Beloved husband for 57 years of Sylvia. Father of Norman, Cheryl and Paul Horowitz and Jeffrey and Sharon. Loving grandfather of Carrie and Hal. Brother of Pauline, Thelma and George and the late Max, Bernard, Ray, Mollie and Bella. Services Monday, November 12, 2001, at 11:30 AM, Parkside Chapels, 9860 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, NY.

title: The Cool Granddad, the Francophile, the Laundry-Room Romantic
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: REBEL FORCES SAY THEY HAVE TAKEN A 2ND AFGHAN CITY
description: Forces opposed to the Taliban said Sunday that they had captured the northeastern city of Taliqan, in their second apparent victory in three days. Early this morning, the anti-Taliban Northern Alliance opened a major assault on Taliban positions north of Kabul, backed by American airpower.

title: Rats on Anthrax Detail
description: To the Editor:

title: Calculating Loss
description: To the Editor:

title: Broken Lives and Healing at the Coffee Shop
description: They're such thoughtful folks, the old couple who run the coffee shop in the sentimental new comedy ''45 Seconds From Broadway,'' that you would have expected them to put one of those signs in their window. You know, the kind that help visitors from foreign places orient themselves when they're feeling lost in big cities. The sign, in this instance, would declare the following useful information: ''Neil Simon spoken here.''

title: Work and Home Clear, Anthrax Search Widens
description: Investigators searching for the source of the anthrax bacteria that killed Kathy T. Nguyen have tested her Manhattan workplace and her Bronx home so thoroughly for any traces of the germ over the last two weeks that they are now all but certain that the exposure happened elsewhere in the city.

title: Miscellany
description: * Taylor Nelson Sofres, London, which owns companies like CMR, the ad-spending tracking service, agreed to acquire TES, Los Angeles, composed of Theatrical Entertainment Services and RapidCheck Reporting, for an initial cash payment of $37.9 million and a maximum final price of $76 million.

title: Mental Health, on Equal Terms
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHWEITZER, DR. NANCY J. (RUBENFELD)
description: SCHWEITZER-Dr. Nancy J. (Rubenfeld). 11/10/49 to 11/12/86. I loved you so much and I still do. Your Mo

title: Transporting Delta Tunes From the Farm To the City
description: It's more than improbable that the music of poor, untutored farmhands in the Mississippi Delta could reverberate around the world. It's simply true. But even as Delta blues became a core component of rock worldwide, other Mississippi musicians kept playing local juke joints and parties, maintaining music that faces down hard times or calls on the Lord with stony determination.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERMAN, IDA M.
description: SHERMAN-Ida M. On November 10, 2001. Beloved wife of Dr. Harry Sherman. Dear mother of Ellen Samuel (Sandy) Luger, Alice Sherman (Robert) Quine and Laura Sherman. Adored grandmother of Mimi and Joanne, and greatgrandmother of Jesse, Mollie and Sherman. Dear sister of Joseph (Lillian) Miller and Sally Greene. Services Tuesday, November 13, 12:45 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., NYC.

title: As a Booster of the Arts, One City Proves a Model
description: ABOUT 15 years ago, a tightly knit group of the city's most powerful corporate executives decided to get serious about fund-raising for cultural institutions here. Since then, they have built one of the country's most effective systems for financing museums, dance companies, musical groups and historical and educational projects.

title: Reporter's Notebook; At Auction Trial, a Cameo for a Johns Painting
description: It did not take long at the price-fixing trial of A. Alfred Taubman, the former chairman of Sotheby's auction house, for the first important painting to get a mention. The painting was Jasper Johns's seminal ''Highway,'' a bright red, blue and yellow abstract work from 1959.

title: Goldman Unit to Buy Bad Japanese Loans
description: The Goldman Sachs Group plans to establish a subsidiary to buy bad loans from Asahi Bank, which intends to write off up to 300 billion yen ($2.49 billion) of its shakiest lending in two years, Asahi Bank officials said today.

title: Making Sure Your Money Goes Where It's Intended
description: HOW do you know whether your gift to a charity will be used as you intended?

title: CNBC Struggles To Stay Relevant; With Stocks No Longer the Big Story, News Viewers Are Looking Elsewhere
description: Think back to the distant past: last year.

title: A Nation Challenged
description: Taking Towns

title: Compressed Data; Software Helps Workers Start -- and Finish
description: Smart security experts often say they do not worry as much about hackers as about disgruntled insiders who might commit acts of sabotage against their company's computers. One of the quickest and easiest ways to upset employees is to give them pink slips -- and there are plenty of those going around lately.

title: A Few Among the Thousands Who Offered Time and Expertise; Their Donation: An Oasis Amid Chaos
description: Money flowed plentifully after the attack of Sept. 11, but a quieter kind of charity was going on as well: in-kind giving. From the earliest moments, people were donating time, expertise and supplies to the relief effort, or offering to do so. It was overwhelming, in good ways and bad. Here are some people who handled in-kind donations, and what they make of the experience, two months later.

title: Effort to Discover Terrorists Among Illegal Aliens Makes Glacial Progress, Critics Say
description: In placing the Justice Department on a wartime footing, Attorney General John Ashcroft has ordered the Immigration and Naturalization Service to lead the charge in ferreting out potential terrorists among the nation's illegal immigrants.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief pop review on Saturday about a song program at Feinstein's at the Regency misspelled the surname of a guest singer. She is Liz Callaway, not Calloway.

title: Mental Health, on Equal Terms
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUCORE, JACK S.
description: DUCORE-Jack S. 47, of Edison, NJ, formerly of Howard Beach, Queens, NY, on November 10, 2001. Husband of Jill M. James-Ducore. Father of Gregory D. and Blair E. Ducore. Son of Robert L. and Thelma (Levin) Ducore. Brother of Michael A. Ducore. Service was held at Mount Sinai Memorial Chapels, East Brunswick, NJ. Memorial gifts to a cancer charity of your choice.

title: Assisted Suicide
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Roads Taken After Sept. 11
description: America's two oldest monthly magazines, Harper's and The Atlantic Monthly, often go head to head in reporting and criticism. Each reacted differently to the events of Sept. 11.

title: Teaching Kids: Who Knows Best?
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Players Confer at U.N. On a Post-Taliban Regime
description: As fighters from the Northern Alliance sweep across northern Afghanistan, the Bush administration is struggling to answer a critical question: Who will govern Kabul if the Taliban abandon the capital?

title: For the New Mayor, a City's Advice on Challenges That Must Be Faced
description: Memo to: Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Health Care Program To Expand
description: The United Hospital Fund of New York, a Manhattan-based charity, plans to expand a program that provides medical and social services to the elderly. Instead of serving only people in nursing homes, the fund will also help elderly people living in mainstream housing, like apartment buildings and individual homes. The fund plans to spend $1 million over two years. City government agencies committed $12 million last year to provide similar services.

title: Like Other Monthlies, Esquire Dances to a New Rhythm
description: On Sept. 11, David Granger, the editor in chief of Esquire, was about to ship the last few pages of his November issue when terrorists attacked America. Staring at a mockup of the cover -- a photo of the actress Cameron Diaz -- Mr. Granger knew that three weeks later, when the issue reached newsstands and mailboxes, it would seem ''wrong,'' he said, ''that Esquire would be represented to the world by that cover.''

title: It's Duke and 63 Other Teams
description: Rafael Hermoso of The Times analyzes the nation's best teams and forecasts which ones have the best chance to make it to the final 16 in March.

title: Lost Jobs, Ragged Safety Net
description: The economic fallout from terrorism is hitting some Americans much harder than others, and we need to respond. Last year, when the slowdown began, layoffs and pay cuts hit hardest at manufacturing workers, white-collar managers and professionals. But since the terrorist attacks, consumers have cut their spending, and now a different group is experiencing the heaviest job losses: the mostly low-paid workers in America's vast personal-service sector.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCVEIGH, JOSEPH EDWARD
description: McVEIGH-Joseph Edward. On November 9, 2001. Dear husband of Denise Finn McVeigh and beloved father of Brendan. Reposing Monday 2-5 and 7-9 pm Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Ave., NYC. Mass of Christian Burial Epiphany R.C. Church Tuesday 10 am. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Epiphany School Foundation, 234 East 22 St., NY, NY 10010, 212-473-6158

title: Looking for Mr. Dickens in the 'In' Pile
description: To the Editor:

title: Northern Alliance Says Its Forces May Enter Kabul
description: With their soldiers rolling across northern Afghanistan and American jets continuing to pound Taliban forces, confident senior officials of the Northern Alliance said tonight that an advance toward Kabul was imminent and hinted that their forces might enter the capital.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Woman Dies From Fall
description: A 60-year-old woman fell from a window of her second-story apartment while removing an air-conditioner and died, the police said yesterday. The woman, Rosalie Pascale of Morris Park, had apparently been standing on a chair when she and the air-conditioner slipped through the window about 6 p.m. Saturday, the police said.

title: Giants Do Just Enough To Hold Off Cardinals
description: The Giants came to Arizona's Valley of the Sun seeking redemption for an uneven start this year and for the momentum a victory might yield as they begin the second half of their season. So often in recent years, the Cardinals and their half-filled, unthreatening stadium could be counted on for an assist when a confidence-building victory was required.

title: Sept. 11 Influenced Move Of Director to Hirshhorn
description: Ned Rifkin, who is leaving as director of the Menil Collection in Houston to become director of the Hirshhorn Museum in Washington in February, said that his decision to move was influenced by the terror attacks of Sept. 11.

title: 6,000 Busy Elbows, One Long Party; In Midtown, Dances of Decades Past Still Come Out to Play
description: On a Saturday night in New York City, on a dance floor packed with a dressed-up crowd of thousands, Jacqueline Saunders was dancing like a chicken.

title: Health Care's Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Pilots Could Do Little if Engine Fell Off
description: The Airbus A-300 that crashed shortly after takeoff from Kennedy International Airport shed part of one of its two engines, raising the possibility that the jetliner suffered a catastrophic breakup of the engine or that the engine itself detached from the plane — an event so severe that pilots do not even train for it.

title: Local Officials Accuse F.B.I. of Not Cooperating
description: The police chief of Portland, Me., says the F.B.I. threatened to charge him with obstruction of justice if his officers continued to chase a terrorism suspect after Sept. 11.

title: Historic Boston
description: The Lenox and the Copley Square, two hotels in Boston that are each over 100 years old, are offering a Celebrate Historic America package through Dec. 29. It includes a room and a meal for two at the Union Oyster House in Fanueil Hall, among other things. Rates are $201 a night at the Lenox and $179 at the Copley Square, plus taxes and tips. Reservations are required; (800) 225-7676, www.lenoxhotel.com , or (800) 225-7062, www.copleysquarehotel.com .

title: Hate Boils In Family Torn Apart By Taliban
description: It was the kind of news that made a few Afghan mothers, displaced and impoverished, tousle their children's hair and talk briefly of the better times that might lie ahead.

title: On the Border, a Relief Effort Loaded With Hope and Frustration
description: Forty miles south of the banks of the Amu Darya River, at the edge of an arid stretch of steppe and the wide and gently sloping road traversing it, lies Mazar-i-Sharif, the first Afghan city to be liberated from Taliban control since the American-led bombing campaign began more than a month ago.

title: Who Won Florida? The Answer Emerges, but Surely Not the Final Word
description: The comprehensive review of the uncounted Florida ballots solidifies George W. Bush's legal claim on the White House because it concludes that he would have won under the ground rules prescribed by the Democrats.

title: Patents; Two new systems try to protect office buildings from chemical or biological attack.
description: IN this new era of unconventional war, many Americans -- especially those working in the government and the media -- are preoccupied with the safety of their workplaces. But is it possible to make modifications to an ordinary office building to protect against a biological or chemical attack?

title: Players to Watch
description: Dajuan Wagner, guard, Memphis Wagner passed up a chance at the N.B.A. lottery and maybe he will be a tad more into the college game than the Seton Hall freshman Eddie Griffin last season. Wagner will not score 100 points in a college game, as he did in high school, and college defenses should provide some challenge, but Wagner will still be looking to be the go-to guy on Coach John Calipari's trip back to the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Sports of The Times; Breakout and a Bruise For the Jets' Chrebet
description: ABOUT 30 minutes after the Jets' 27-7 victory over Kansas City yesterday, Wayne Chrebet finally entered the locker room: pads off, jersey off, walking rapidly toward the trainer's room, his left shoulder tilting at a nasty angle. Chrebet said he would answer questions later. ''I just want to go in here and see how bad this thing is,'' he said, referring to the shoulder. ''The ground's even harder this time of year.''

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Wednesday about Paul R. Screvane, a former New York City Council president, misspelled the given name of his wife, who died in 1989. She was Bridey McKessy Screvane, not Birdy. Her nickname was the Bird.

title: Giving
description: Charities are facing the toughest times, and toughest choices, in decades. Also: A reporter's perspective on the relief effort for families of the World Trade Center

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUGGARD, STEPHEN F.
description: HUGGARD-Stephen F., 86, of Bayside, NY, formerly of Malba (Whitestone), NY, died at home on November 10. Mr. Huggard is mourned by Anne Shanley Huggard, his wife of 62 years, his children Stephen F. and Bonnie Huggard of San Diego, CA, David and Jane Huggard of Honesdale, PA, and his daughter Sarah and her husband Michael Nerad of San Francisco, CA. Mr. Huggard is also survived by three grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. Mr. Huggard retired as a lieutenant from the New York City Fire Department in 1958. He was a 1937 graduate of Manhattan College of Riverdale, NY. A requiem mass will be celebrated at a later date.

title: AIDS Patients in China Lack Effective Treatment
description: Zhang Jianqi remembers the doctor's advice at the rural Sui Xian County hospital in central China when they told him this summer that his 8-year-old daughter, plagued by constant fevers, had tested positive for H.I.V.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Saturday about comments by President Mohammad Khatami of Iran rejecting the version of Islam professed by Osama bin Laden referred incorrectly to an additional statement of his, about Israel. The assertion that Iran might be prepared to recognize Israel if the Palestinians did so first was the plainest expression yet of an Iranian policy that had earlier been expressed less specifically. But it was not a break with past Iranian statements.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Accounts

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, BENNIE
description: SCHWARTZ-Bennie. Loving husband of Miriam. Adored father of Sheldon, and Judy Melnick. Beloved grandfather of Lori Fishtenbaum, Barbara Gold, Gregg Scheuing and Michael Schwartz. Adored grandfather of six. Services were held privately.

title: A Company Scrambles to Keep Its 'Strategic Philanthropy' Going
description: IN 1984, American Express revolutionized corporate philanthropy when it introduced a highly successful campaign to restore the Statue of Liberty. The company offered to donate 1 cent from every charge made on its cards over a three-month period to help rebuild and restore the statue. The campaign raised $1.7 million and encouraged customers to pull out their cards to make purchases. During the campaign, card use rose 28 percent compared with the same period a year before.

title: San Francisco Prevails In a Battle of Offenses
description: The defenses of the San Francisco 49ers and the New Orleans Saints were being solved, making defense an endangered species in this game. Could someone get a stop, any stop, please?

title: Help for Careers That Require Heavy Lifting
description: Name: Hard Hatted Women

title: Lax Nuclear Security in Russia Is Cited as Way for bin Laden to Get Arms
description: In the last year, there have been dozens of violations of nuclear security rules in Russia and at least one loss of fissile material; Taliban emissaries have tried to recruit Russian scientists, and terrorists have tried to stake out a Russian nuclear storage site at least twice, say senior officials of the International Atomic Energy Agency and Western governments.

title: A Few Among the Thousands Who Offered Time and Expertise; Special Delivery From a Leader Whose Workers Know How to Collect Food
description: Money flowed plentifully after the attack of Sept. 11, but a quieter kind of charity was going on as well: in-kind giving. From the earliest moments, people were donating time, expertise and supplies to the relief effort, or offering to do so. It was overwhelming, in good ways and bad. Here are some people who handled in-kind donations, and what they make of the experience, two months later.

title: U.S. Is Expecting to Spend $1 Billion a Month on War
description: The United States expects to spend more than $1 billion a month on the early phases of the war in Afghanistan, and the cost is likely to rise rapidly above that level as the Pentagon builds its forces in the region, Congressional and administration officials say.

title: A Few Among the Thousands Who Offered Time and Expertise; Providing Care to Stranded Animals
description: Money flowed plentifully after the attack of Sept. 11, but a quieter kind of charity was going on as well: in-kind giving. From the earliest moments, people were donating time, expertise and supplies to the relief effort, or offering to do so. It was overwhelming, in good ways and bad. Here are some people who handled in-kind donations, and what they make of the experience, two months later.

title: Equity Offerings Planned This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: U.S. Officials Complain That Chinese Companies Supply Rogue Nations
description: China's high technology industry finds itself treading on geopolitical fault lines these days, as Chinese companies have become suppliers of advanced communications equipment to nations that Western companies avoid, or are barred from doing business with.

title: 255 People Said to Be Aboard; Homes in Queens on Fire
description: An American Airlines commercial airliner departing from Kennedy International Airport in New York City crashed into a Queens neighborhood this morning just minutes after it took off.

title: Giants Audio
description: Postgame audio from the Giants vs. the Arizona Cardinals provided by SportsAudio.net.

title: Punter Stays Out of Trouble
description: Owen Pochman, the Giants' rookie place-kicker, who was pressed into service as the team's punter, averaged 29.2 yards on 5 punts in today's 17-10 victory over Arizona.

title: ARAFAT THANKFUL FOR BUSH REMARK ABOUT 'PALESTINE'
description: As the United States moved to resume an active role in mediating an end to Israeli-Palestinian violence, Yasir Arafat expressed his ''deepest appreciation'' today for President Bush's public endorsement of Palestine as a state, choosing to make no mention of the fact that the president had declined to meet him.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Snapshots Of Confusion, Heartbreak, Compassion And Spirit
description: 5 P.M., SEPT. 13 -- In a deserted oval salon at the Pierre Hotel in Manhattan: Just met with Howard W. Lutnick, the chairman of Cantor Fitzgerald, the bond trading firm that lost more than 675 people in the terrorist attacks two days ago. He marched into the room, stared at me from red-rimmed eyes and offered me a deal.

title: Veterans Day
description: NEW YORK

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORKMANHATTAN: POLICE KILL ROBBERY SUSPECT Police officers shot and killed a robbery suspect on the Upper West Side last night after he shot at them, the police said. Just before 9 p.m., two officers confronted a man in his 40's at Amsterdam Avenue and 103rd Street. According to a police spokesman, the man matched a description of robber wanted for a string of holdups. When the man, who was not identified, began firing at the officers, they returned fire and killed him, the police said. He was dead on arrival at the St. Luke's unit of St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. Corey Kilgannon  (NYT)

title: Benefits Are Toned Down, or Called Off
description: NOT surprisingly, this fall's benefit season in New York has been unlike any other in recent memory. The shock of the World Trade Center attack, coupled with the troubled economy, affected almost every event scheduled for September or October. Some were canceled outright; others postponed. Almost every one that went on was toned down.

title: International Agencies Give Aid, While Trying to Avoid the War
description: WHEN the huge American transport planes dropped their first cargo of 37,000 ready-to-eat meals over Afghanistan last month, crew members were said to have cheered wildly as the yellow packages labeled ''Food gift from the people of the United States of America'' fell earthward. No doubt famished Afghans devoured the beans and rice, lentil stew, biscuits, peanut butter, jam and pastries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HURWITZ, ANN ISSERLIS
description: HURWITZ-Ann Isserlis. Died on November 8, 2001, in Boynton Beach, FL. Loving wife of Herbert Hurwitz. Beloved mother of Martin Isserlis (Judythe), Joan Isserlis and Robin Isserlis. She had a full and wonderful life truncated by Alzheimers disease. Shiva at Martin's residence in Manhattan.

title: Charities Get a Big Helping of Uncertainty
description: AFTER an extraordinary string of fat years and rapid growth, the nation's charities are facing the toughest times and toughest choices in decades.

title: Savoring Strength in the North, U.S. Worries About Weakness in the South
description: Even as the United States savors a first victory in Afghanistan in the north of the country, senior American officials say the key to defeating the enemy has shifted to the south.

title: Demand, Public and Private, Booms for Dogs to Sniff Out Security Threats
description: Panting, his tail whipping and nose bobbing, Angus, a black Labrador retriever, scampers along the aisles of a food warehouse near here. Abruptly, he stops, excited, and sniffs into the crevices of boxes holding jars of Super Dolce pizza sauce. Then he sits, immobile as a sphinx.

title: The Game Looms in Harvard's Title Drive
description: Letdown? What letdown?

title: Andy Grove's Tale of His Boyhood in Wartime
description: While the leading chip maker Intel was building itself as a Silicon Valley institution, Andrew S. Grove was known for many things: his attention to minute details, his secrecy, his acute paranoia of competitors, his often cantankerous leadership. Underlings recall his proclivity for cursing at unprepared executives and, before surgery repaired his ears damaged by childhood scarlet fever, rapping his bulky hearing aid on conference tables to shush long-winded presenters.

title: Northern Alliance Breaks Taliban Lines North of Kabul
description: KALAI NASRO, Afghanistan, Nov. 12  Northern Alliance forces easily pierced Taliban lines north of Kabul today and advanced to within 10 miles of the Afghan capital, setting the stage for a possibly bloody entry into the city.

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of yesterday, 4,547 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11.

title: Dreams of a Summer Camp Take the Form of Reality
description: THERE is a quiet confidence about Amy Callahan of Hoboken, N.J. She is 30 and petite, and she measures her words in a way that befits her profession as a special-education teacher in nearby Springfield. She occasionally stumbles, though, when speaking of Scott Hazelcorn.

title: Metro Matters; The Race Card And Knowing When to Fold
description: WE'VE come to this. The head of New York's Democratic Party suggested last week that one of the two Democratic rivals for governor drop out to avoid another round of the racial antagonism that infected the mayoral campaign.

title: Market Place; Dynegy's Rushed Gamble on Enron Carries Some Big Risks
description: Call it a $9 billion shotgun wedding.

title: London Journal; Recipe for Roasting the Sacred Cow, Tastelessly
description: In its first post-Sept. 11 issue, the satirical magazine Private Eye included a clip-out cancellation form for infuriated readers. This was a wise move.

title: Jets' Martin Speaks Volumes In Rout of Chiefs
description: The Jets' coaches closed the door behind them at the team meeting Saturday night and left the players to themselves. Coach Herman Edwards had decided that his speeches preceding home games must not have been that good, because the Jets had won just once at home before today. So Curtis Martin and a few others spoke instead.

title: Waking to Writing While Watching a Writer Write
description: ''Show, don't tell'' is the first rule of creative writing. Or so its teachers tell us. Robert Olen Butler has his own commandments for good writing. But rather than recite the maxims in a classroom, he has ventured onto the Internet to show them in action.

title: Ravenous Defense Stays Hungry
description: Never mind that the Jets' defenders were quick, relentless, tenacious, clever and more in today's 27-7 drubbing of the Kansas City Chiefs. Maybe their most impressive accomplishment was that none of them seemed satisfied. They said they were still learning, still getting comfortable with their new coaches and new schemes, still expecting improvement.

title: Martin Adds To His Feats
description: Running back Curtis Martin moved up to 16th on the N.F.L.'s career rushing list with 8,671 yards. He passed Green Bay's Jim Taylor late in the first half and finished with 113 yards. His 10 rushing touchdowns this season are one short of the Jets' record.

title: Compressed Data; In Anxious Times, Faster, Safer Snail-Mail
description: Even as Americans, newly wary of paper mail, are embracing e-mail with greater gusto, people in places like India are turning e-mail into paper.

title: Store Sales of 'Shrek' Illustrate the Arrival of DVD's
description: Toys are not the only products tied to children's movies. There is also the lucrative home-video market, where DVD's are beginning to catch on in a market long dominated by the VHS videocassette.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Police Kill Robbery Suspect
description: Police officers shot and killed a robbery suspect on the Upper West Side last night after he shot at them, the police said. Just before 9 p.m., two officers confronted a man in his 40's at Amsterdam Avenue and 103rd Street. According to a police spokesman, the man matched a description of robber wanted for a string of holdups. When the man, who was not identified, began firing at the officers, they returned fire and killed him, the police said. He was dead on arrival at the St. Luke's unit of St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. Corey Kilgannon (NYT)

title: A Song in His Head (if Not in His Heart)
description: SOMEWHERE FOR ME

title: Northern Alliance Breaks Taliban Lines North of Kabul
description: KALAI NASRO, Afghanistan, Nov. 12  Northern Alliance forces easily pierced Taliban lines north of Kabul today and advanced to within 10 miles of the Afghan capital, setting the stage for a possibly bloody entry into the city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBMAN, JOSEPH AND CAROLYN
description: LIEBMAN-Joseph and Carolyn. With deep remorse, the family of Joseph and Carolyn Liebman report their passing and hope that their friends will remember them with the love, laughter and optimism they shared.

title: INSIDE
description: Memo to: Mr. Bloomberg

title: Under Bloomberg, Kelly Will Guide Police Again
description: Raymond W. Kelly, who was New York City's 37th police commissioner, under Mayor David N. Dinkins, has accepted Mayor-elect Michael R. Bloomberg's offer to return to 1 Police Plaza as the city's 41st police commissioner, two people familiar with the transition plan said yesterday.

title: The I.R.S. Moves Rapidly To Process New Charities
description: LIKE clockwork -- very slow clockwork -- a charitable group's request to the Internal Revenue Service for tax-exempt status usually sets in motion an arduous process of dealing with a bureaucracy seemingly bent on making life difficult.

title: Oil Drilling in Arctic Called Departure From Past Policy
description: If Congress approves drilling for oil and gas in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, it will be breaking with government practice of the last 35 years, which has limited when drilling may occur in refuges, the General Accounting Office has concluded.

title: Mental Health, on Equal Terms
description: To the Editor:

title: In America; The Sadness Within
description: If you stay away from Ground Zero, which remains a landscape out of Dante, the city can seem pretty normal. The pre-Thanksgiving throngs in Midtown over the weekend were impressive. A gorgeous eight-ton, 81-foot Norway spruce is up and waiting for its Christmas decorations at Rockefeller Center.

title: For a Youngster Who Needs It, an Adult With Attention to Spare
description: THE 10-year-old boy picked at the crust on his chicken nuggets. He twirled a straw in his mouth, roiling a milkshake. The murmur of conversation filled the background at Mike's Diner in Astoria, Queens, as the boy, Solomon Fisher, sat across from his Big Brother, Joel Sanchez.

title: McGwire Retires To Help the Cards
description: Mark McGwire, who was the first major league baseball player to hit 70 home runs, then lost the record only three years later, announced his retirement last night.

title: Anthony Shaffer, 75, Author Of Long-Running 'Sleuth,' Dies
description: Anthony Shaffer, the British playwright whose jokey but chilling thriller ''Sleuth'' ran for more than 2,300 performances in London's West End and more than 2,000 on Broadway, died in London on Tuesday. He was 75.

title: The Battle Is Joined in the Big East
description: Neither Miami nor Syracuse was particularly impressive while winning on Saturday. But win they did to set up a Big East showdown Saturday in South Florida. The result could have a big impact on not only the conference championship race but also participation in the national title game.

title: A Baby Behind Bars, Where Its Job Is to Soothe the Youngsters
description: I VISITED my baby in jail last month. My baby grand. In 1999, I donated it to Materials for the Arts, an organization I knew nothing about, which handed it off to the Crossroads Juvenile Center, a secure detention facility in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn. The Department of Juvenile Justice wrote me a letter of thanks.

title: Local Arm of the Law
description: To the Editor:

title: New Economy; A rush to appropriate symbols of the day terror punctured New York's skyline.
description: HOPING to find a dark cloud's silver lining, and mine it, more than two dozen enterprising types have applied for trademarks related to the events of Sept. 11.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Car Crashes Into Firehouse
description: A 29-year-old man was charged with driving while intoxicated yesterday after he drove a car through the closed garage door of a fire station, causing minor injuries to a firefighter inside, the police said. The driver, Timothy Winn, of Richmond Hill, Queens, was arrested about 3 a.m. at the Engine Company 236 station, at 998 Liberty Avenue in East New York. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: Daschle Seeks Compromise On Aid Plan For Insurers
description: Striving to break a political logjam before the Senate adjourns, Senator Tom Daschle, the majority leader, will try this week to forge a compromise to offer financial assistance to insurers for any more large terrorist attacks, his colleagues say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNABLE, ANNA
description: SCHNABLE-Anna. Devoted wife of the late Alexander. Loving mother of Audrey and Buddy Magid. Adored and beloved grandmother of Douglas, Lauren and Stewart, and great-grandmother of Alexis. Graveside service today at 2 PM at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY.

title: For the New Mayor, a City's Advice on Challenges That Must Be Faced; Saving Public Schools
description: Memo to: Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: The Eggplant Rebellion
description: There is a cell of political subversives in the Senate so obscure that its existence is little known beyond the members themselves and several hundred farm lobbyists who fear them as they would the boll weevil. It is known as the Eggplant Caucus, after a leading New Jersey farm product, and it consists of about 20 Eastern senators from West Virginia and Maryland all the way up to Maine. They are the last best hope this year for a meaningful revision of the country's antiquated, ineffective and manifestly unfair farm programs. If they fail, the country may be stuck for five more years with a wildly expensive program that has long ceased to be useful to anyone except the biggest and most powerful farmers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHULMAN, MAX L.
description: SHULMAN-Max L. Of Manhattan, died on Friday, November 10, 2001, at his home. He was 93. Mr. Shulman was President and Chairman of J.W. Mays Department Stores. Mr. Shulman was born October 18, 1908, in New York City to Jacob and Dora Silberman Shulman. He was educated in Brooklyn, NY, and graduated from Boys High School. He earned his law degree from George Washington Law School in Washington, DC, and graduated with honors. Mr. Shulman served in the Army during World War 2 in the Transportation Corps and retired attaining the rank of Major. On June 25, 1939, he married Sylvia Weinstein. Mr. Shulman lived in New York City since 1946. Before that he lived in Washington, DC. Mr. Shulman was a member of the Bar Association in Maryland and New York, was on the Board of Directors for the Boy Scouts of America, The Weissman Institute and the Israel Museum. He was also on the Board for Brookdale Hospital, and a member of the Board for Brooklyn Community College. Mr. Shulman is survived by his wife Sylvia Shulman, a son Lloyd Shulman of Carmel, NY, a daughter Gail Koster of Manhattan, a sister Ethel Weiss of Maryland and two grandchildren Melinda Koster and Jonathan Koster. A funeral service will be officiated by Rabbi Joseph Potasnik on Tuesday, 10 AM, at the Cargain Funeral Homes, Inc., 418 Rt. 6, Mahopac, NY (845) 628-5655. Interment will take place following the service at Westchester Hills Cemetery, Hasting, NY.

title: After the Day When Time Stopped, How One Cause Went Forward
description: A CELEBRATORY spirit pervaded the Vanderbilt Room of the Roosevelt Hotel on the evening of Sept. 10. Many of the volunteers and staff members of the New York City affiliate of the Susan G. Komen Breast Cancer Foundation had been working night and day since mid-August to organize Race for the Cure, the annual event they hoped would raise $1.5 million for the foundation.

title: Group Gives Shelter to Teenagers in a Storm
description: NAME: Persons Expressing Problems, Challenging Ideas.

title: For the New Mayor, a City's Advice on Challenges That Must Be Faced; Untangling Transportation
description: Memo to: Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: War's Monthly Cost: $1 Billion and Rising
description: Officials in Congress and the Bush administration say that the United States initially expects to spend more than $1 billion a month on the war, and that the cost will probably rise rapidly as the Pentagon builds forces in Afghanistan.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: The board of the Direct Marketing Association, New York, named Michael P. Sherman, president at the Fingerhut Companies, Minnetonka, Minn., as the 2002 chairman. Gordon R. Cooke, president and chief executive, the J. Jill Group, Quincy, Mass., will be the vice chairman. G.M. O'Connell, chairman at Modem Media, Norwalk, Conn., will be treasurer and Jane Brandt, vice chairman and chief marketing officer at AOL Time Warner, New York, will be secretary. Fingerhut is owned by Federated Department Stores.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day last Monday ranking top Web sites by customer spending for the third quarter mislabeled the dollar figures. They were the average size of each transaction, not the monthly spending per customer.

title: Corrections
description: A picture on Oct. 30 with an obituary of Eugene Jackson, the actor who played a character named Pineapple in the ''Our Gang'' movies, was published in error. It showed Mr. Jackson's son, Eugene III, as he appeared in the 1965 movie ''Shenandoah.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEXNER, BELLA
description: WEXNER-Bella. The Officers, Board, Staff and parents of Columbus Torah Academy mourn the passing of Bella Wexner, a true philanthropic leader and a devoted supporter of Jewish education. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire Wexner family. Rabbi Herbert Cohen, Headmaster Jay Schottenstein, Honorary Chairman of the Board Jon Diamond, Chairman of the Board David Portman, President

title: Electric Cars May Lose Push In Northeast
description: Two years after New York, Massachusetts and Vermont announced that they would require the sale of electric cars, they are considering postponing that requirement by four years and promoting the use of other emission-reduction technologies instead.

title: E-Commerce Report; Cosmetics competitors are unlikely bedfellows as they unite behind the Gloss.com site to sell products.
description: NOW would not seem to be a great time to introduce a retail business, much less one devoted to luxury items. And reviving an Internet site devoted to prestige beauty products sounds borderline masochistic, given that investors long ago hung consumer e-commerce companies out to dry.

title: People
description: * Jay Shields, executive vice president and chief operating officer at Austin Kelley Advertising, Atlanta, was promoted to president and chief executive. He succeeds Geoffrey Nixon, who becomes chairman, a new post. Austin Kelley is part of the McCann-Erickson World Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARISH, ROSE
description: BARISH-Rose. 90, on November 10, 2001. Wife of the late Harold Jack. Mother of Muriel Gray and Millie and Bernie Brown. Grandmother of David, Lori and Dougglas. Great-grandmother of Danielle and Michael.

title: Road Trip Is a Measuring Stick for the Islanders
description: Here come the Islanders, lazily floating down to the pile like a leaf off a tree. They have lost two games in a row and three of their last five, and their next four games are on the road, jammed into six days over three time zones.

title: 255 People Said to Be Aboard; Homes in Queens on Fire
description: An American Airlines commercial airliner departing from Kennedy International Airport in New York City crashed into a Queens neighborhood this morning just minutes after it took off.

title: Ways of Saying Thanks On This 'Giving Day'
description: TOD HILL would like Americans to put the ''giving'' back in Thanksgiving. Worried about the effect of the September terrorist attacks and what he called a resulting ''donor burnout,'' the communications consultant, who lives and works in San Francisco, decided it would be nice to recast Thanksgiving Day as Giving Day.

title: This Week
description: On the Map

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Saturday about comments by President Mohammad Khatami of Iran rejecting the version of Islam professed by Osama bin Laden referred incorrectly to an additional statement of his, about Israel. The assertion that Iran might be prepared to recognize Israel if the Palestinians did so first was the plainest expression yet of an Iranian policy that had earlier been expressed less specifically. But it was not a break with past Iranian statements.

title: Online Giving Is Up. Will It Stay There?
description: FOR a number of charities, the immediacy of the Internet was never more apparent than in the days after Sept. 11. Between then and the end of October, more than $100 million was donated online to the relief effort, according to one estimate. That included about $65 million to the American Red Cross alone, which received as many as three donations a second the day after the terrorist attacks, averaging $125 a donation.

title: Israeli Is Slain by Gunman; Palestinian Dies in Explosion
description: A gunman on foot opened fire tonight in the Israeli village of Kfar Hess, killing an Israeli security officer and wounding a passer-by, the Israeli police said.

title: Ruth Limmer, 73, Poetry Editor Who Aided Tenement Museum
description: Ruth Limmer, an authority on the poet Louise Bogan, died on Oct. 31 at her home in Manhattan. She was 73.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: In Silicon Hills, Making Good On Vows of High-Tech Profits
description: DURING the 1990's, Austin's new high-tech millionaires, marching lock step with the city's largely Birkenstock ethos, promised to help their community realize many goals -- a new performing arts center, a new art museum, more money for the local United Way.

title: Victims' Funds May Violate U.S. Tax Law
description: On Friday, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced that the city's Twin Towers Fund had written its first 73 checks to the families of the rescuers who died at the World Trade Center. The checks ranged from $50,000 to $325,000, and are part of $85 million in charity the mayor has promised to some 400 families.

title: Torture Is Un-American
description: To the Editor:

title: Take My Father's Prize, Please
description: IF you carefully read the catalog for Carleton College, in Northfield, Minn., you will find under the list of fellowships and scholarships the Samuel Strauss Prize for Humorous Writing.

title: A High-Mileage Gift That Doesn't Add Up
description: THERE you are, gazing gloomily at that clunker in your driveway and weighing your options. You could sell it to a dealer, but with Susie's gum ground into the seats and that nasty scrape on the outside (it never quite seemed worth fixing), you wouldn't get much. You could sell it yourself, but what a headache: the ads, the calls, the waiting for buyers to show up, the bargaining, the wrestling with rust remover to get the plates off.

title: Seeking Tax Breaks For Giving Overseas
description: FOR 10 years, Mudar Kothari, a software engineer turned venture capitalist, shared the good fortune he earned in Silicon Valley by sending money home to Pakistan. First, he picked up the tab for educating nieces and nephews. Last year, he sent $100,000 to cover school fees for 300 students.

title: For the New Mayor, a City's Advice on Challenges That Must Be Faced; Halting Business Flight
description: Memo to: Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: Bush and Putin Expected to Agree to Reduce Nuclear Arsenals and to Fight Terrorism
description: President Bush will hold a summit meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia this week and will try to close a number of agreements that could profoundly change the post-cold-war trajectory of relations between Washington and Moscow.

title: Study of Disputed Florida Ballots Finds Justices Did Not Cast the Deciding Vote
description: A comprehensive review of the uncounted Florida ballots from last year's presidential election reveals that George W. Bush would have won even if the United States Supreme Court had allowed the statewide manual recount of the votes that the Florida Supreme Court had ordered to go forward.

title: The Only U.S. Laboratory for the Anthrax Vaccine Says Production Will Be Delayed
description: The only laboratory in the country that makes anthrax vaccine will not be ready for a crucial federal inspection until mid-December, later than federal officials had hoped.

title: Making Sure Painful Stories Are Told Just Once
description: NAME: Collin County Children's Advocacy Center.

title: A Seventh Site Is Decontaminated in New Jersey
description: Inconclusive test results for anthrax prompted the Postal Service to order the precautionary decontamination of the Allentown, N.J., post office yesterday. It is the seventh in the state to undergo the cleaning since the first contamination was discovered.

title: Bruised G.O.P. Seeking Kean To Take Back Torricelli's Seat
description: Driven from power at the state level in Tuesday's gubernatorial and legislative elections, New Jersey Republicans are turning to a very well-known figure from the party's past -- Thomas H. Kean, the former governor -- to put the pieces together in time for next year's race for the United States Senate.

title: At Differing Speeds, Foundations Adjust to a World Transformed
description: FOUNDATIONS are used to acting with deliberation, not dispatch. But that, along with just about everything else, changed after Sept. 11. In the aftermath of the terrorist attacks, they showed uncharacteristic speed in pledging millions for disaster relief.

title: For the New Mayor, a City's Advice on Challenges That Must Be Faced; Easing the Housing Crunch
description: Memo to: Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: Sports of The Times; Giants Win Again By a Split Decision
description: THE Giants are like the boxer who has to win on points because he doesn't possess a knockout punch.

title: 260 People Were on Board; No Survivors Found
description: An American Airlines jetliner bound from New York to Santo Domingo with 260 people aboard plunged into a neighborhood in Queens minutes after takeoff yesterday morning, jarring a city still numb from the agony it has already endured.

title: Elliott Triumphs While Gordon Stalls
description: For the longest time, this looked to be the day that Jeff Gordon would capture his fourth Winston Cup Series championship. But the hopes of Gordon, Nascar's hottest driver, were dashed on Lap 152 of the Pennzoil 400 when he ran into the bumper of a competitor leaving pit road.

title: Sagging Economy Threatens Health Coverage
description: Yohannes Gezu is one of the economic casualties of the terrorist attacks. A well-paid waiter at a big Chicago convention hotel before Sept. 11, he is now lucky to get a few days of work a week.

title: The Time for Ballot Reform
description: The results of the 2000 presidential election may never be final in the minds of some Americans, but the comprehensive review of Florida's vote by The Times and other news organizations may put an end to the counting. It appears that Al Gore might have carried Florida if he had successfully pursued a statewide manual recount of all 175,010 rejected ballots -- a strategy he never tried. But the United States Supreme Court's decision to stop a more limited recount ordered by the Florida Supreme Court simply cut off a process that would have wound up confirming George W. Bush's victory.

title: A Few Among the Thousands Who Offered Time and Expertise; He Stored Stuff Everyone Gave
description: Money flowed plentifully after the attack of Sept. 11, but a quieter kind of charity was going on as well: in-kind giving. From the earliest moments, people were donating time, expertise and supplies to the relief effort, or offering to do so. It was overwhelming, in good ways and bad. Here are some people who handled in-kind donations, and what they make of the experience, two months later.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALONEY, WILLIAM L.
description: MALONEY-William L. 1928-2001. Actor, dancer, teacher of speech, died October 4, 2001 having achieved nearly 73 revolutions around the sun. A Mass of Christian Burial was celebrated October 8, at St. John's R.C. Church, Center Moriches. Interment followed at Calverton National Cemetery. He served in the Army during the Korean War. The theater was his first love, and he appeared in hundreds of plays and performances including the Ruth Page Company, the Goodman Theater in Chicago, the New York Metropolitan Opera, HB Studios, Judson Poets. Lamama ETC, and Theatre in Chelsea, where he played the Shakespearean roles of Malvolio, Bottom, Titus, Ariel and Hamlet. He was an innovator of the off-off Broadway movement and a beloved vocal coach to hundreds of students and professionals. The New York theater community will pay their respects at a Memorial to be held at Theater for the New City, 155 First Avenue, NYC, at 7:00 PM, November 19, 2001.

title: Wait a Minute, Mr. Postman; New Yorkers Take Their Mail Cautiously, if at All
description: Sandy Reich is dutifully following the new rules. She is on high alert for any and all lumpy, taped-shut letters with amateurishly scrawled addresses and postmarks from Trenton. But that doesn't mean she can't impose some postal regulations of her own.

title: Ballots Cast by Blacks and Older Voters Were Tossed in Far Greater Numbers
description: Black precincts had more than three times as many rejected ballots as white precincts in last fall's presidential race in Florida, a disparity that persists even after accounting for the effects of income, education and bad ballot design, The New York Times found in a new statistical analysis of the Florida vote.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCMAHON, GAVIN
description: McMAHON-Gavin. On September 11, 2001, World Trade Center at age 35. Loving son of Terence and Linda McMahon. Also survived by John and Maureen Sproha, Bertha Stirling, Maurice and Geraldine McMahon, Bridget Fitzpatrick and numerous cousins. Funeral Mass at St. Henry's Church, Avenue C between 28th and 29th St., Bayonne, NJ, Wednesday, November 14, 2001 at 9:30A.M. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to The ASPCA Memorial Program, 424 East 92nd St., New York, New York 10128.

title: Keepers (and Disbursers) of the Country's Sudden Generosity
description: AMERICANS wanted to do something, anything, after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks -- and more often than not, that involved giving. The more than $1 billion in donations has inspired the country -- and stunned, and sometimes staggered, the charities that received the bounty.

title: Gliding With Ease, Romance And Sorrow
description: The Ice Theater of New York emphasized the varied forms choreography for skaters can take in a fast-paced evening on Wednesday night in the Sky Rink at the Chelsea Piers.

title: Broadway Stars Spread The Gospel at Benefits
description: MICHAEL McELROY'S childhood Baptist church in Shaker Heights, Ohio, was started by his grandfather and carried on by his stepfather. His grandmother played the piano and directed the choir. His mother, aunt, sister, uncle and brother sang in the choir. So did he.

title: Democrats Contend a Pataki Lobbyist Has a Conflict
description: A longtime Republican associate of Gov. George E. Pataki has found himself playing a dual role in recent days, at times lobbying Congress on the governor's behalf, at others representing American Indians in negotiations with Mr. Pataki.

title: For the New Mayor, a City's Advice on Challenges That Must Be Faced; Solving a Labor Paradox
description: Memo to: Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: Ad Declines Force Magazines To Make Cuts
description: In the wake of steep revenue declines, magazines have continued to shrink staffs and pages, cut back on salaries or health care plans, and merge -- or even disappear.

title: Transforming Relations With Russia
description: After a whirlwind of diplomatic meetings over the weekend in New York, President Bush turns his attention this week to one nation and one leader. Mr. Bush and President Vladimir Putin of Russia will spend three days at the White House and Mr. Bush's ranch in Texas trying to strengthen the surprisingly cordial relationship that has developed between the two men and their two nations in recent months. Though obstacles remain, Mr. Bush and Mr. Putin seem within reach of decisions that could open a new era of cooperation.

title: Coca-Cola keeps some brands where they are while PepsiCo battles a former agency in court.
description: IN another wild twist to the most recent skirmish in the cola wars, the Coca-Cola Company froze the planned shifts in the creative accounts of two of its large brands, the Powerade line of sports drinks and Dasani water.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLATZER, ADELE
description: PLATZER-Adele. The Board of Directors of the Light of Life Foundation are deeply saddened by the death of Adele Platzer. Adele was committed to patient support and research for thyroid cancer treatment and cure. Our deepest sympathies to her husband, Phil Platzer, and to her children, Lauren, Sam and Bruce. Joan Shey, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUNEBAUM, ANNELIESE E.
description: GRUNEBAUM - Anneliese E. Peacefully on November 3, 2001, in her 96th year. Beloved widow of Kurt H. Grunebaum. Loving mother of Peter. Proud grandmother of George, Nicole and Danielle. Devoted great-grandmother of Marcus, Sebastian, Annabel, Solene and Charlotte. A memorial service will be held on November 13, 2001, at 2 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to The Neue Gallerie, 1048 5th Ave, New York, NY 10028.

title: Red Cross Offers to Refund Gifts for Sept. 11
description: The American Red Cross, reacting to criticism of its fund-raising for Sept. 11 relief, said yesterday that it would return donations to any contributor who requested a refund.

title: Rebel-Style Advances, Incoming Bills and Fading Anthrax Fears
description: It was a crystalline blue day in New York -- remarkably like Sept. 11 -- ideal for Veterans Day and for taking stock after two months of living with terror. Much of the news was like the parade, solemn but upbeat. Major progress in the war in Afghanistan was reported. There were no new anthrax cases. And at the rubble of the World Trade Center, President Bush and other dignitaries attended a memorial service for all nations that lost citizens in the terrorist attack.

title: Having a Two-Way Learning Experience
description: DR. T. BERRY BRAZELTON, the 83-year-old author of dozens of books on being a parent, is probably the nation's most trusted pediatrician -- and a ubiquitous presence in the world of child-rearing. Even those who have never bought his books have probably seen his television show, read his syndicated columns or heard of his Congressional testimony on child-care policy. Whatever the medium, Dr. Brazelton's pronouncements carry all the prestige of his status as a professor emeritus at Harvard Medical School.

title: The Confusing Ballots
description: Of the 175,000 ballots that were rejected in Florida's county tabulations, more than 113,000 were considered overvotes, in which voters made marks for two or more presidential candidates. The media consortium that examined the rejected ballots did not include the vast majority of the overvotes in its final counts because there could be no clear determination of a voter's intent. However, The New York Times performed a further analysis on ballots where voters made marks for George W. Bush and another candidate or those with marks for Al Gore and another candidate. In 18 counties, particularly Palm Beach and Duval, voters seemed to have been confused by ballot designs that split the listing of candidates. Altogether, those mistakes worked to Mr. Bush's advantage by more than 2 to 1. ARCHIE TSE

title: U.S. Has Covered 200 Campuses To Check Up on Mideast Students
description: In the two months since the attacks of Sept. 11, federal investigators have contacted administrators on more than 200 college campuses to collect information about students from Middle Eastern countries, the most sweeping canvass of the halls of academia since the cold war, the colleges say.

title: Twilight of the Expos
description: Perhaps it will require the intervention of 28 baseball team owners to confirm what many have long thought: Major league baseball in Montreal was never meant to be.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HUBBARD, BRUCE
description: HUBBARD-Bruce. ''I'll get along as long as a song is strong in my soul.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SENTER, JONAS
description: SENTER-Jonas. Suddenly on November 9, 2001. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Life partner of Huguette Glushanok. Devoted and cherished father of Leigh and Jill Senter. Adoring grandfather of Gennifer, Danielle and David. Greatgrandfather of Nathaniel and Gabriel. Dearest brother of Ellen Steiner. Services today, 11:30 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: HOCKEY

title: Richter's Glove Helps Extend Rangers' Streak
description: Eric Lindros scored the winning goal 56 seconds into overtime last night as the Rangers rallied for a 3-2 victory over the Montreal Canadiens to extend their winning streak to five games.

title: Essay; Prague Connection
description: The undisputed fact connecting Iraq's Saddam Hussein to the Sept. 11 attacks is this: Mohamed Atta, who died at the controls of an airliner-missile, flew from Florida to Prague to meet on April 8 of this year with Ahmed al-Ani, the Iraqi consul.

title: Compressed Data; Book Raises Questions of Publishing Rights
description: Who owns the rights to the words people write in public online forums?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SZUMLAK, DAVID
description: SZUMLAK-David. Beloved husband of Estera. Devoted father of Gail Weisbrod, Kenneth and Lana Chudkoski. Loving grandfather of Yehuda, Sabrina, Laura and Christopher. Services Tuesday, 11:15, ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions may be made to The Hampton Synagogue, Westhampton Beach, NY.

title: Vietnam-Era G.I.'s Watch New War Warily
description: With the month-old war in Afghanistan at a crossroads and poised for the introduction of ground troops, Vietnam War veterans say they are looking for indications of a clear military strategy and for signs of a shift in the mood of the nation.

title: How the Consortium of News Organizations Conducted the Ballot Review
description: The ballot review project commissioned by eight media organizations tried to decipher 175,010 Florida ballots that went unexamined in last fall's presidential election and the ensuing recounts.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Meriden
description: A 22-year-old man was killed and two others were injured early yesterday morning when two men fired shots from a car into one parked in a neighborhood known for drug activity, the police said. Derling Mercado of Meriden died from a gunshot to the chest, the police said. The police spotted the assailants' car and chased it by car and helicopter, the police said, but the passengers escaped on foot. Corey Kilgannon (NYT)

title: Editors' Note; A Nation Challenged
description: News of the terrorist attacks and their aftermath appears today in Section B; index, Page B2.

title: Available for Benefits: A Mansion W/Hef (Sometimes) & Playmates
description: THE idea of a celebration at the Playboy Mansion might evoke images of swinging parties, with Hugh Hefner lounging in silk pajamas and Playmates cavorting in the pool.

title: Steps Planned By MobileStar And Intel On Net Access
description: The financially struggling MobileStar Network Corporation said on Friday that it had struck a deal to sell most of its assets to VoiceStream Wireless, which agreed to invest as much as $2.5 million to enable MobileStar's high-speed wireless Internet access network to resume operations until the deal is completed.

title: Multimedia Coverage of the Crash of American Airlines Flight 587
description: Video

title: A Dismal Campaign
