title: A Self-Described Slacker Decides He's Ready to Be a Soldier
description: On Oct. 4, Kirk Evans had his grandmother drive him to the Army recruiting station, a storefront wedged between a tanning salon and a window-blind shop in a strip mall a few miles from his home in Bloomington, Ill. It was one day after his 19th birthday and three days before the United States began bombing Afghanistan.

title: Multimedia Coverage of the Crash of Flight 587
description: November 14, 2001

title: Skyscrapers Are Here To Stay, Says Panel Of Experts
description: An architectural panel here said the race to build the tallest building in the world had become obsolete. But they agreed that skyscrapers, with their bold and powerful presence in cities around the world, were here to stay.

title: Learning To Build A House, As Well as A New Life
description: NAME: Proyecto Azteca, San Juan, in South Texas.

title: Getting Too Much of a Good Thing
description: THE striking surge in blood donations after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks not only helped replenish the nation's dwindling blood supply but also created ample reserves in parts of the country.

title: Voter Portraits: New Jersey
description: In 1997, James E. McGreevey, the Democratic candidate for New Jersey governor, was narrowly defeated by the Republican, Christie Whitman, losing by 1 percentage point. This year, Mr. McGreevey came back to easily defeat the Republican candidate, Bret D. Schundler, by 13 points. Ninety-two percent of those who voted for Mr. McGreevey in 1997 cast their ballots again in his favor last week, and he picked up the support of nearly 30 percent of those who voted for Mrs. Whitman in 1997.

title: Upcoming Economic Events
description: MONDAYNone

title: Mental Health, on Equal Terms
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about Afghanistan's place in literature gave misspelled names in some copies for the main characters in ''The Man Who Would Be King,'' by Rudyard Kipling, and misstated one character's fate. The men are Peachey Carnehan, not Peachy, and Danny Dravot, not Dravott. Only Dravot is killed.

title: Shapes That Lift the Spirit
description: How coverage of styles, fashion and design has changed in The Times over the years.

title: Activism or Terrorism?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Plane Crash in Queens
Taking Time to Recognize a New Age of Heroes
description: HEROES are her business. But first she arranges a straw in her visitor's diet soda can with the deft manners of a hostess who has not only studied her Amy Vanderbilt but has updated the social niceties with an eye to our post-Sept. 11 preoccupation with bioterrorism's lurking residue.

title: Coming Soon: Prime View of a Meteor Shower
description: On Sunday morning, well before sunrise, astronomers expect the skies to be streaked with light in what could be the most impressive Leonid meteor shower in three and a half decades.

title: Front Row
description: Spotting a Trend

title: Fetisov Awed as He Takes His Place Among Elite
description: In the days preceding his induction into the Hockey Hall of Fame today, Vyacheslav Fetisov wandered the halls of the shrine, reading about the select group of members he would soon join.

title: Wounded City Sheds New Tears
description: When the word came yesterday morning, it was almost too much.

title: The Neediest Cases; A Man's Internal Struggle Strains Family Resources
description: Oleg Jaisini fears there is a problem with the water.

title: Miscellany
description: Arnold Worldwide, Boston, part of the Arnold Worldwide Partners division of Havas Advertising, laid off another 20 employees, or 3 percent of its staff, in a move related to the economy.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Leftist Wins Race for Governor
description: Lazaro Crdenas, scion of one of Mexico's most powerful political families, was elected governor of the central state of Michoacn. His election was the most significant victory this year for the left-wing Democratic Revolutionary Party and another stinging defeat for Mexico's once-invincible Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI. With 97 percent of the vote counted, Mr. Crdenas had 41 percent to about 37 percent for Alfredo Anaya of the PRI. Mr. Crdenas will be the fourth member of his family to govern Michoacn, known for its violent politics, its fertile farmland and the millions of migrants it sends to California and Illinois. Ginger Thompson (NYT)

title: Powell Says Muslim Nations Should Be Peacekeepers in Kabul
description: Hours before the first reports that the Taliban appeared to be moving out of the Afghan capital, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said yesterday that it might soon be necessary to send an international "coalition of the willing," led by soldiers from Muslim nations, to secure the capital and prepare the ground for an interim government.

title: Cavity Fighters, Financed by Medicaid
description: Though poor children are known to be at higher risk for dental problems, few of their parents are taking advantage of a widely available anti-cavity procedure in which some teeth are coated with a plastic sealant, researchers say.

title: Bush and Putin Agree to Reduce Stockpile of Nuclear Warheads
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- President Bush and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia pledged today to cut their nuclear stockpiles by roughly two-thirds over the next decade, leaving each side with fewer than 2,200 warheads.

title: Developing a Winning Team Should Be Preferred to Closing the Books
description: Remember when the Cleveland Indians were a major league joke?

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: War Criminals Lose Pensions
description: The Labor Ministry has stopped paying pensions to 72 World War II veterans who have been accused of or prosecuted for crimes against humanity, the Jerusalem office of the Simon Wiesenthal Center said. An additional 11 pensions could be canceled in coming weeks and around 250 other investigations are still going on that could lead to prosecutions for war crimes. Germany pays special disability payments to around 60,000 people living outside the country, and until the law was amended in 1998 accused or convicted war criminals abroad were able to receive payments. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Trade Deal Near for Broad Access to Cut-Rate Drugs
description: Negotiators all but clinched a deal today that would give developing countries greater access to cut-price drugs to fight epidemics, defusing the most inflammatory dispute between rich and poor nations that had threatened to scuttle trade talks here.

title: Britain Moves To Expand Arrest Powers
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair's government asked Parliament today for emergency powers to permit the detention without trial of foreigners suspected of terrorism.

title: LOEWS CINEPLEX FILES BANKRUPTCY RECOVERY PLAN
description: The Loews Cineplex Entertainment Corporation filed a Chapter 11 recovery plan to give the Onex Corporation of Toronto and Oaktree Capital Management L.L.C. of Los Angeles full ownership of the company and allow it to emerge from bankruptcy. Loews filed in February for Chapter 11 protection, citing a glut of multiscreen ''megaplex'' theaters that has forced more than half a dozen cinema chains into bankruptcy court. Under the recovery plan, holders of more than $742 million in bank loans to the company would receive cash and more than $429 million in new notes. The company's unsecured creditors, including bondholders owed about $313 million, would divide $45 million in cash under a settlement with lenders. Shareholders get no distribution under the plan. (Bloomberg News)

title: Russian Oil Industry Agrees To Small Cut in Production
description: The Russian government said today that the country's oil industry had agreed to cut production, as the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries had been pressing it to do. But for all the trumpeting the announcement was given, the size of the cut -- about one-half of 1 percent of Russia's daily output -- was so tiny that it will have virtually no effect on oil prices, analysts said.

title: Taking Off For Points Unknown
description: Simone Forti

title: Letters: Preventing Painful Death
description: To the Editor:

title: Powell Says Muslim Nations Should Be Peacekeepers in Kabul; 3 Offer Troops
description: Hours before the first reports that the Taliban appeared to be moving out of the Afghan capital, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said yesterday that it might soon be necessary to send an international ''coalition of the willing,'' led by soldiers from Muslim nations, to secure the capital and prepare the ground for an interim government.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Koreas: Sign Of Progress
description: North and South Korea extended reconciliation talks until today, one day beyond their scheduled end, amid signs of progress on anti-terrorism measures and family reunification visits. The talks, at an isolated North Korean resort, have repeatedly stumbled over security-related objections by the North over the South's emergency alert against terrorist violence declared after the Sept. 11 attacks on the United States. South Korean officials have called the concerns irrelevant and urged the North to resume family reunification visits, which have been stalled for months.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: A Citizen Challenges the President
description: The last word may not yet have been heard on President Jacques Chirac's immunity from questioning by investigators and possible prosecution arising from corruption inquiries. France's highest court of appeal ruled last month that the president cannot be made to appear before a judge before the end of his term. But a private citizen who wants Mr. Chirac to testify has appealed the case to the European Court of Human Rights, saying the ruling violates articles of the European Convention that guarantee the right to trial within a reasonable period, the right to question witnesses and a ban on discrimination.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Walkout At Volkswagen
description: About 16,000 workers walked off the job at the largest Brazilian factory of Volkswagen A.G. after talks between union officials and management over payroll reductions reached a deadlock over the weekend. Volkswagen announced last week that it would make 3,000 layoffs after the local metalworkers' union refused to accept a 15 percent cut in wages and working hours in the face of a 13 percent drop in car production in October compared with the previous year. The Anchieta factory, one of four that Volkswagen operates in Brazil, produces about 900 cars a day. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: 'J. R. R. Tolkien'
description: The dominant literary mode of the twentieth century has been the fantastic. This may appear a surprising claim, which would not have seemed even remotely conceivable at the start of the century and which is bound to encounter fierce resistance even now. However, when the time comes to look back at the century, it seems very likely that future literary historians, detached from the squabbles of our present, will see as its most representative and distinctive works books like J.R.R. Tolkien's The Lord of the Rings , and also George Orwell's Nineteen Eighty-Four and Animal Farm , William Golding's Lord of the Flies and The Inheritors , Kurt Vonnegut's Slaughterhouse-Five and Cat's Cradle , Ursula Le Guin's The Left Hand of Darkness and The Dispossessed , Thomas Pynchon's The Crying of Lot-49 and Gravity's Rainbow . The list could readily be extended, back to the late nineteenth century with H.G. Wells's The Island of Dr Moreau and The War of the Worlds , and up to writers currently active like Stephen R. Donaldson and George R.R. Martin. It could take in authors as different, not to say opposed, as Kingsley and Martin Amis, Anthony Burgess, Stephen King, Terry Pratchett, Don DeLillo, and Julian Barnes. By the end of the century, even authors deeply committed to the realist novel have often found themselves unable to resist the gravitational pull of the fantastic as a literary mode.

title: The Florida Vote, and the Echoes
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Arab Lawmaker Charged
description: Azmi Bishara, an Israeli Arab member of Parliament, was formally charged with voicing support for the Lebanese guerrilla group Hezbollah, becoming the first Israeli lawmaker to be indicted for remarks made in office. The indictment charges him with encouraging violence and expressing support for a terrorist organization. The offense carries a maximum penalty of three years in jail. Mr. Bishara faces separate charges for organizing visits by Israeli Arabs to Syria, with which Israel is technically at war.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUGHELMAN, SOLOMON (SASHA)
description: KUGHELMAN-Solomon (Sasha). We mourn the loss of our esteemed member and extend heartfelt condolences to his family. Temple Israel of Great Neck Mordecai Waxman, Rabbi Steven Markowitz, President

title: Striving for Equity in Things Like Mountain Climbing
description: It was ''if only'' time on Thursday night at the Duke on 42nd Street when Ellis Wood and Lisa Race presented new and recent works that came frustratingly close to their apparent goals.

title: Connecticut Budget Deficit Brings a Threat of Layoffs
description: One day before the State Legislature was to begin a special session to address a $300 million budget deficit, Republican Gov. John G. Rowland today threatened to lay off state employees if the Democratic leadership failed to resolve the budget gap.

title: Executions And Looting As Alliance Nears Kabul
description: Near an abandoned Taliban bunker, Northern Alliance soldiers dragged a wounded Taliban soldier out of a ditch today. As the terrified man begged for his life, the alliance soldiers pulled him to his feet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAMIGHETTI, JOSEPH P.
description: FAMIGHETTI-Joseph P. The Partners, Attorneys, and Staff of Certilman Balin Adler & Hyman, LLP are deeply saddened by the passing of our dear friend and valued partner, Joseph Famighetti. Joe was a highly-regarded expert in the field of Criminal Law. He brought years of law enforcement experience to his practice, having served as a Long Island Parkway Police Officer, Detective, and Nassau County Assistant District Attorney. Joe served as Counsel to two New York State Senators and was a member of the Nassau County Civil Service Commission and the Long Island Regional Planning Board. We are grateful for his legal guidance and dedication he provided during his service to our firm. He will be truly missed by all of the people whose lives he touched with his compassion, dependability, and friendship. To his beloved wife, Janice, his adoring children, Peter, Christine and sonin-law Joseph Marshiano, and his loving grandchildren, Jenna and Christopher, we offer our heartfelt sympathies.

title: HAYES LEMMERZ TO CLOSE AUTO WHEEL PLANT IN KENTUCKY
description: Hayes Lemmerz International Inc., a leading maker of automobile wheels, said it would close a plant in Kentucky by mid-2002 and eliminate about 235 jobs to reduce costs as vehicle output falls. The company will offer an undetermined number of the workers jobs elsewhere, a spokeswoman, Marika Diamond, said. The factory is in Bowling Green. and makes steel wheels for cars and light trucks. Hayes Lemmerz has about 14,000 employees. (Bloomberg News)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Lawyers' Group Nominates Judge As President
description: The Association of the Bar of the City of New York has nominated a former state appeals court judge as its next president. A former associate justice of the Appellate Division of the state Supreme Court, Leo Milonas, left, is a partner at Pillsbury Winthrop, a national law firm with offices in Manhattan. Judge Milonas, whose election is virtually assured following the nomination, will succeed Evan A. Davis, a partner at Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton, a firm in Manhattan. Mr. Davis's one-year term ends in May. Jonathan D. Glater (NYT)

title: Adding a Touch of Newness To a Cuban Troupe's Evening
description: Ballet Nacional de Cuba caused a fresh sensation with cast changes before closing its City Center season on Sunday. The company moves on tomorrow night to the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark, where it will perform ''The Magic of Alonso,'' the same program that featured major debuts.

title: A Homeland in Search of Security
description: Yesterday's plane crash in Queens may not have been caused by terrorists, but it inevitably adds to the national fear of flying. And it focuses attention on the national need to feel more secure in our everyday lives. We are alarmingly slow in building a homeland defense that can win Americans' confidence.

title: Kabul Braces Again for New Rulers
description: The last time Afghanistan's capital of Kabul fell -- to the Taliban on Sept. 27, 1996 -- shocking brutality ensued.

title: A Hospital's Strange Quiet
description: It was strangely quiet at Jamaica Hospital Medical Center near Kennedy Airport, the closest trauma center to the crash site.

title: Footlights
description: Winds of Change

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NARDELLI, CAMILLO
description: NARDELLI-Camillo. November 13, 1987. Always remembered with love. Ka

title: Bioterror Drugs Stall Over Rules And Logistics
description: Stephen G. Sudovar, the president and chief executive of EluSys, a fledgling biotechnology company in Pine Brook, N.J., has what he thinks is an immensely promising anthrax drug, which might save patients' lives by inactivating deadly bacterial toxins.

title: Gun Foes Use Terror Issue In a Push for Stricter Laws
description: Gun-control organizations have seized on the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks to argue that any crackdown on terrorism should include tightening gun laws, particularly the so-called loophole that allows many people to buy weapons at gun shows without background checks.

title: Market Place; Gas Pipeline Is Prominent As Dynegy Seeks Enron
description: Dynegy has negotiated a great takeover. And it may end up buying Enron, too.

title: Sports of The Times; His Show Of Power Is Over
description: EVEN Barry Bonds stopped to watch, halting his pregame exercises while on his back near the third-base dugout. He propped himself up on an elbow in the grass to gaze at one of the most spectacular sights in sports: Mark McGwire taking batting practice, sending baseballs like little moons into the twilight.

title: Editors' Note; Today's Sections
description: News of the Sept. 11 attacks and their aftermath continues to appear in Section B; index, Page B2.

title: A New Way of Thinking
description: To the Editor:

title: Taliban Troops Abandon Capital Without a Fight
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Tuesday, Nov. 13  Capping their stunning victories in the north, Afghan opposition fighters rolled into Kabul on Tuesday after Taliban troops slipped away under cover of darkness, abandoning the capital without a fight.

title: Grief Echoes From New York to Santo Domingo
description: Several times a day, the flights depart from Kennedy Airport, providing a crucial link between the Dominican Republic and New York City's Dominican neighborhoods. The first flight out, American Airlines Flight 587 to Santo Domingo, is so familiar that some Dominicans talk about it as if it were the morning train. With holidays approaching, Flight 587 was packed.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR IS MIXED. The dollar was little changed against the euro and the yen. In New York, the euro settled at 89.50 cents, up from 89.40 cents on Friday. The dollar traded at 120.43 yen, up from 120.20 yen.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Weak Quarter For Bank
description: ABN Amro Holding said third-quarter profit fell 40 percent, as the bank put aside more money to cover loans that might go bad. Net income dropped to 476 million euros ($426 million), or 30 euro cents a share, from 796 million euros, or 52 euro cents a share, a year earlier. The large Dutch bank doubled its provisions to cover potential losses from bad loans to 308 million euros in the period. Of those provisions, 115 million euros was set aside at ABN Amro's North American commercial bank, which lends to small and medium-size businesses. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLUTSKY, ROSE
description: SLUTSKY-Rose. On November 11, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Meyer. Loving mother of Judith Kowler, and Carol Ziff. Dearest sister of Lillian Joltin. Adoring grandmother of Suzanne, Andrew, and Laura Kowler, and Aaron and Rachel Ziff. Graveside service today 11 A.M. at Montefiore Cemetery, Saint Albans, Queens, NY.

title: No Stranger to Loss
description: At midday at La Guardia Airport's main terminal, Louis Mercado was waiting for a plane to fly home to Orlando. He had come to New York for the weekend to attend a memorial service for his son Steve Mercado, a firefighter who was among those missing from the World Trade Center disaster.

title: Young Love: The Good, the Bad and the Educational
description: When they fell in love, she was barely into her teens, and he wasn't much older. Some saw a star-crossed couple who found understanding, joy and maturity in each other's arms. Others saw impulsive kids whose reckless passion cut them off from family, friends and more appropriate interests, provoked mood swings, delinquent behavior and experimentation with drugs, and ended in tragedy.

title: First Test for a Disaster Response Plan
description: President Bush was starting a meeting of the National Security Council on the war in Afghanistan. Tom Ridge, the new homeland security director, was beginning an on-air chat on Don Imus's radio program. And then, suddenly, the White House was again facing a crisis.

title: Doctors Lacking Humanity
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | West: Hawaii: Plans For Ehime Maru Memorial
description: A $65,000 memorial for nine people who were killed when a Japanese fishing vessel, the Ehime Maru, was struck by a Navy submarine is planned for a hilltop park that overlooks the ship's final resting place. The monument, to be paid for by Japan, is expected to incorporate the ship's anchor. The Hawaii Community Development Authority, which oversees the park, hopes to dedicate the monument on the anniversary of the sinking, next Feb. 9.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHULMAN, MAX
description: SHULMAN-Max. The Board and Staff of The American Friends of The Israel Museum and The Israel Museum, Jerusalem, are deeply saddened by the death of Major Max Schulman, National Committee Member, and original founder of The Israel Museum, and a longtime patron and supporter. The Schulmans helped foster the growth of the Museum's Ruth Youth Wing. Our condolences to his wife, Sylvia, and to the entire family. Maureen Cogan, Chairman, International Council James S. Snyder, Anne & Jerome Fisher Dir, IM Nurit Shilo-Cohen, Chief Curator, Ruth Youth Wing, IM Carolyn Cohen, Exec Dir, AFIM

title: Horror Visits a Haven On a Holiday Morning
description: Into the sleepy rhythms of a holiday morning, human bodies came hurtling from a jet fuselage onto a quiet residential street. In an instant, a half dozen or more homes were wiped out.

title: At Least for the Moment, a Cooling Off in the Culture Wars
description: One of the curious and possibly short-lived consequences of the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11 has been an apparent cease-fire in the cultural skirmishing that had previously pitted right against left and Washington against Hollywood in a struggle over one of the country's most lucrative and influential global industries.

title: Property Lending Up in Some Cases
description: Commercial mortgage lending rose 32 percent in the third quarter, spurred by falling interest rates, the Mortgage Bankers Association of America said yesterday.

title: New Crisis, But This Time In Backyards Of Rescuers
description: They lost hundreds of their fellow firefighters on Sept. 11. Many have worked night and day in the two months since to bring out their brothers' remains from the rubble of the World Trade Center. Yesterday, they responded to another plane disaster, racing yet again toward the flames, this time from their homes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCRACKEN, JOHN E.
description: McCRACKEN-John E. The Amateur Comedy Club records with sorrow the passing on November 4th of its esteemed Retired Member. Elected in 1951, John was a gentleman and loyal member of the Club, and will be missed. Our sincere condolences to his family. There will be a memorial service at Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church on November 15 at 11 AM. George S. Coyne II, President

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Results Improve At Drink Maker
description: Almost two years after Brazil's two leading beverage companies merged to become AmBev, the world's fifth-biggest drink maker, the company is still reaping productivity and revenue gains despite a slowdown in the local economy. Revenue for the third quarter increased 27.5 percent, as the company improved management and distribution channels for both its beer and soft drinks. Revenue from sales abroad jumped 80 percent, aided by a 25 percent devaluation in the Brazilian currency, the real. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOK, FREDERICK H.
description: COOK-Frederick H. Age 86 of Liberty Corner, N.J. formerly of New Vernon, N.J. on November 7, 2001. Retired CEO of Purolator, Inc., Dillon, Read and Co., Inc. and Congoleum Nairn. Beloved husband of Beryl (Anderson) Cook, devoted father of Susan C. Murray and Nancy C. O'Brasky, brother of Robert A. Cook and grandfather of Christopher B. and Stephen F. Murray. A Memorial service will be held Saturday, November 17, 2001 at 11:00 A.M. in the Church of St. John on the Mountain, Mt. Harmony Road, Bernardsville, N.J. Interment private. Those planning an expression of sympathy are asked to consider contributions in his memory to the Arthritis Foundation, 200 Middlesex Turnpike, Iselin, N.J. 08830 would be appreciated. For information, contact Gallaway & Crane Funeral Home, Basking Ridge.

title: Allegiances Fluid and Confusing in Taliban Forces' Collapse
description: BANGI, Afghanistan, Nov. 13  The scene was set for Northern Alliance troops to make another triumphant entrance into a city liberated from the Taliban. And then everything went wrong.

title: Northern Alliance Moves Into Kabul
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Nov. 13  The Northern Alliance said it sent security forces into Kabul today following the unexpected withdrawal of the Taliban only after it received reports that armed groups in the capital were creating security problems for its residents.

title: Stocks Fall, Then Rise as Fears of Terrorism as Crash's Cause Abate
description: Stocks tumbled in the wake of the American Airlines crash near Kennedy International Airport yesterday but rebounded when it appeared that the crash might be an accident rather than a result of a new terrorist attack.

title: Pride in a Friend's Daughter, a Trade Show, Vacuuming, Rescue Work
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Critic's Notebook; Trying To Keep Up With History On the Run
description: Last January two television documentary producers began work on a program for the History Channel's ''Modern Marvels'' series, which celebrates architectural and engineering accomplishments. Their subject was the World Trade Center.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Bomber Killed By Own Device
description: A Protestant teenager was killed when a pipe bomb he was preparing to throw at police and a rival Catholic crowd blew up in his hand, the police said. They said he lived in a North Belfast neighborhood that has been the scene of nightly rioting. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Another Plane Crashes
description: Not again. A jittery New York steeled itself for another day of unimaginable horror yesterday as another airliner rained terror on the city. The crash of American Airlines Flight 587 shortly after takeoff from Kennedy Airport led to an immediate closing of all area airports and major bridges and tunnels, an evacuation of the Empire State Building and a partial lockdown of the United Nations.

title: Suitor for Enron Receives Approval From Wall St.
description: Wall Street found nothing but good news in Dynegy's $9 billion takeover of the Enron Corporation yesterday.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: AOL And Sony In Venture
description: AOL Time Warner and the Sony Corporation of Japan announced yesterday that they had agreed to cooperate to develop advanced digital entertainment technologies and services. The pact joins AOL, a large media company, with Sony, a big maker of electronic devices. The statement included few specifics, but perhaps the most intriguing aspect of yesterday's deal was the announcement that the companies intended to develop an Internet browser, posing a potential challenge to Microsoft's Internet Explorer. AOL controls Netscape, a browser pioneer that has lost ground to Microsoft. Seth Schiesel (NYT)

title: Taliban Troops Abandon Capital Without a Fight
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Tuesday, Nov. 13  Capping their stunning victories in the north, Afghan opposition fighters rolled into Kabul on Tuesday after Taliban troops slipped away under cover of darkness, abandoning the capital without a fight.

title: Two French Radio Journalists and a German Are Killed in Taliban Ambush of a Rebel Force
description: Two French radio journalists and a German magazine writer were killed on Sunday evening when the Northern Alliance forces they were traveling with were ambushed by Taliban forces in northern Afghanistan.

title: Credit Suisse Trims Compensation of More Top Bankers
description: In a continuing effort to bring employee costs at Credit Suisse First Boston in line with those at other Wall Street firms, John J. Mack, the new chief executive, has done away with special, lucrative compensation deals for Frank Quattrone and many other senior investment bankers, people close to Mr. Mack said.

title: Beauty, It Turns Out, Lights the Brain
description: Given the opportunity, many men will gladly spend time gazing at beautiful women's faces.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SUPERIOR INDUSTRIES INTERNATIONAL INC., Van Nuys, Calif., the world's second-largest maker of wheels for cars and light trucks, said it had won a contract with DaimlerChrysler, Stuttgart, Germany, the automaker, to supply aluminum wheels for the 2002 model year Chrysler PT Cruiser. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Officials Find No Clear Signs of Terrorism in Crash, but No Firm Answers, Either
description: An absence of the tell-tale signs of terrorism in the crash of American Airlines Flight 587 led intelligence and law enforcement officials to express doubts today that terrorists had brought the jet down.

title: Johnson Tapes Show a Man Full of Doubt, Even as Victor
description: REACHING FOR GLORY

title: A Summit Topic: Russia's Plutonium
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Juniper Buys Start-Up
description: Juniper Networks, which makes Internet communications gear, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Pacific Broadband Communications for $200 million in stock. Pacific Broadband, a privately held start-up based in San Jose, Calif., makes equipment for Internet traffic on cable television networks. Juniper said it expected to complete the deal in December and take a $10 million charge for the fourth quarter. Scott Kriens, Juniper's chief executive, said Pacific Broadband, whose products are still being tested, would start to contribute revenue near the end of 2002. Until then, he said, the acquisition would trim earnings by a penny a share each quarter. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Another Blow to Airlines and Their Insurers
description: The crash of the American Airlines passenger jet in New York yesterday is expected to further increase the cost of insurance for the airlines, which were already facing steep increases as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11, industry experts said.

title: Tibet's Quiet Protest
description: To the Editor:

title: Man Charged In Kidnapping Of 6-Year-Old
description: A 37-year-old freelance photographer was arrested yesterday and charged with kidnapping a 6-year-old girl last Thursday as she played in her front yard in the upscale New Jersey coastal community of Spring Lake, the authorities said.

title: Poor Start Makes Doubt A Companion for Knicks
description: Shortly before the start of the Knicks' season-opening game, Jeff Van Gundy discussed his team's need for early success, something that would halt the questions about the team's roster and allow the Knicks to believe in themselves.

title: Crash Inflicts Heavy Blow On Prospects Of American
description: Before Flight 587 fell from the sky yesterday, American Airlines was seen as one of the carriers best positioned to weather the drastic downturn that followed September's terrorist attacks. But now American could find itself in much deeper trouble, experts said yesterday.

title: Accident Curbs Japan Research Into Cosmos's Ghostly Particles
description: A huge underground chamber that made historic observations of ghostly particles called neutrinos that stream through the cosmos was crippled over the weekend when thousands of light detectors imploded in a chain reaction.

title: Preventing Painful Death
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAY, LAWRENCE F.
description: FAY-Lawrence F. Of Bedford, NY, died on November 11, 2001, at Rosary Hill Home. He was 72. He was a partner at the law firm of Kent, Hazzard, Jaeger, Wilson, Fay & Conroy, in White Plains, NY, where he worked for 44 years. He was born on July 5, 1929 in the Bronx, to Lawrence R. and Mary (Duffy) Fay. He graduated from All Hallows High School in 1947, and Fordham University in 1951. In 1957 he graduated from Georgetown Law Center with JD and LLM degrees. He served in the U.S. Navy during the Korean conflict, attaining the rank of Lt. JG. He lived in Bedford, NY, for the past 33 years. He was a member and Director of The Thomas and Agnes Carvel Foundation. He is survived by his mother, Mary, of Point Pleasant, NJ, his brother, Robert, of Ft Lauderdale, FL, his sister, Mary Ellen Gentle, of Bethel, CT, his children, Kathleen Tell, of Point Pleasant, NJ, Kevin J., and Brian P., both of Bedford, NY, and Jennifer Rice, of Seattle, WA. He is also survived by six grandchildren. He is predeceased by his wife of 44 years, Marie (McCafferty) Fay, who died in 1998. Calling hours will be at Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, NY, on Tuesday 7-9 P.M. and Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. Funeral Service will be at St. Patrick's R.C. Church, Bedford, NY, on Thursday at 10 A.M. Interment will be at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. Contributions in his memory may be made to: The Rosary Hill Home, 600 Linda Avenue, Hawthorne, NY 10532 or The All Hallows H.S., 111 East 164th Street, Bronx, NY 10452.

title: A Nation Challenged
description: Swift Successes

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STELZER, RUTH SONDRA (NEE MINESS)
description: STELZER-Ruth Sondra (nee Miness). Of Roslyn, New York, died on November 11, 2001. Beloved wife of Edward, treasured mother of Stephen Stelzer, and Barbara Friedman, loving mother-in-law to Lenny Friedman, and Francie Lyshak-Stelzer, adored grandmother of Andrew Stelzer, and Emily and Noah Friedman. A kind, compassionate woman devoted to her family and the arts, who never lost her sense of humor. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be send to Women's American O.R.T. at: 516-487-4575.

title: National Briefing | Science and Health: University Sanctions Researcher
description: Johns Hopkins University has sanctioned a researcher who tested experimental cancer drugs on patients in India without the approval of a university review board. The sanctions were based on the findings of a faculty committee that investigated a study by Ru Chih C. Huang, a biology professor in the Krieger School of Arts and Sciences. It said he had not conducted adequate preliminary tests of the drugs on animals; it did not find evidence that patients had been harmed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARISH, ROSE
description: BARISH-Rose. The National Council of Jewish Women, Brooklyn Section Board of Directors, We mourn the passing of Rose Barish, a past president. Sylvia Ladner, Dolores Measer Co-Presidents

title: More U.S. Campaigns Related to Attacks
description: Additional federal agencies are naming or seeking advertising agencies to handle campaigns related to responses to the terrorist attacks.

title: Giant Roaches Also Roamed the Earth
description: Millions of years ago, giants walked the wilds of North America, in the form of dinosaurs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKER, SHEILA (NEE MOLEFSKY)
description: PARKER-Sheila (nee Molefsky). On November 12, 2001. Cherished daughter of Philip and Beatrice Molefsky. Dear sister of Barry. Services today, November 13th, at 1 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC.

title: Antibiotics Business Is Again Popular
description: Like other pharmaceutical companies, Eli Lilly & Company rushed late last month to offer the government help in fighting bioterrorism. It volunteered to increase production of its antibiotics and even to allow its plants to be used to produce antibiotics made by other manufacturers.

title: Officials Say Voice Recorder Indicates Crash Was Accident
description: Investigators said today that initial analysis of the cockpit voice recorder retrieved from the wreckage of American Airlines Flight 587 showed that Monday's crash appeared to be an accident.

title: Two Wars, Many Fears
description: There are two wars in Afghanistan now, a northern campaign that is rapidly entering its final stages and a southern campaign that is just beginning.

title: Putin, Starting U.S. Trip, Predicts Missile Accord
description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia arrived on his first official visit to the United States tonight hours after predicting that a deal was within reach that would allow President Bush to speed ahead with tests of an antiballistic missile system.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNABLE, ANNA
description: SCHNABLE-Anna. The AntiDefamation League mourns the passing of Anna Schnable, beloved mother of Audrey Magid, an Honorary Chair of the ADL Women's Division and member of the New York Regional Board. We extend our condolences to Audrey and the entire family. Carol Ostrow Hochfelder, Women's Division Chair Joel J. Levy, New York Regional Director

title: Again a Witness to Tragedy
description: ''I thought I saw it all at the World Trade Center,'' said Steve Feldheim, of the Hatzoloh volunteer ambulance service, who helped with the rescue efforts in the aftermath of the Flight 587 crash.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOCHSTADT, ABRAHAM
description: HOCHSTADT - Abraham. We mourn the passing of the father of of our esteemed member, Gail Barnehama and pray that the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Young Israel of Great Neck Yaacov Lerner, Rabbi Michael Frank, President

title: Taliban Withdrawing From Kabul as Rebels Move Toward Capital
description: After a string of successes by the Northern Alliance, the forces of the Taliban retreated early this morning from the Afghan capital, heading southward to their heartland in a move that smacked of tactical withdrawal.

title: Corrections
description: Abiographical sketch on Sunday about Anna S. Allison, a Boston software developer who died on the plane that struck 1 World Trade Center, referred imprecisely to the Beaujolais-producing region she toured with her husband, a wine appreciation instructor. It was the Beaujolais district of southern Burgundy, not the Burgundy wine region.

title: Celebrities Join Bristol-Myers Campaign
description: When offering a free month's supply of medicine is not enough to win over patients, try Hollywood.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Kuwait: A Shot Across the Border
description: A mortar shell believed to have been fired by Iraqi forces landed just across the border in Kuwait. The apparent attack on Sunday morning, called ''a very serious matter'' by United Nations observers, was the first of its kind in more than three years along what remains a tense frontier. A United Nations spokesman, Daljeet Bagga, said the 82-millimeter shell had left a small crater in the ground and that the angle of trajectory ''indicated it could have been fired from Safwan inside Iraq.''

title: After the Funerals, Another Catastrophe
description: Disaster came to the Rockaways yesterday just as its residents seemed ready to draw their first easy breaths after a long march of grief and memorials for the firefighters and Wall Street strivers who perished on Sept. 11.

title: LVMH Sales Dropped 5% In October
description: In its third warning of deteriorating results since the Sept. 11 terror attacks, LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton said today that its sales in October fell 5 percent from the period last year and that its operating profits for the full year might be 15 percent lower than forecast.

title: Auto-Wrecking Teenagers
description: To the Editor:

description: Additional federal agencies are naming or seeking advertising agencies to handle campaigns related to responses to the terrorist attacks.

description: Mark Shore owns the house at 405 Beach 130th Street in Belle Harbor, Queens.

title: U.S. and Partners Quickly Set Sights on a Post-Taliban Kabul
description: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 12  The United States and the countries most closely affected by developments in Afghanistan called today for "broad- based, multiethnic, politically balanced, freely chosen Afghan administration" to take charge once the Taliban is totally driven from Kabul.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDINO, ERNESTO
description: ANDINO-Ernesto. On November 9, 2001. Husband of Hebe CoriaAndino, loving father of Sandra, Fernando, Coral, Olga, and Nydia Kimberly. Dear brother of Elsie, Marina, and Enriqueta, Anibal, Marcus, Teodoro, Ernesto, Milton, Minerva, Nereida, and Nydia Margarita. Former employee of The New York Times. Also survived by eight grandchildren, and one great grandchild. Friends may visit at Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 1439 Unionport Road, Bronx, NY, on Tuesday 2-5 and 7-9 P.M., and Wednesday 2-5 only. Interment in Puerto Rico.

title: VIROPHARMA TO HALT TRIALS OF HEPATITIS TREATMENT
description: ViroPharma Inc. said it would halt human trials for a hepatitis C treatment that the company was developing with the American Home Products Corporation. The companies will end trials on the treatment because the compound did not work as well as expected, said a ViroPharma spokeswoman, Kori Beer. ViroPharma was developing the drug with Wyeth-Ayerst Laboratories, American Home's pharmaceutical arm. ViroPharma's shares fell 28 cents, to $23.54, and American Home rose 41 cents, to $57.38.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: American Airlines Faces Problems From Plane Crash

title: European Union Set to Vote on Data Law
description: European Union lawmakers are expected to ignore a request by the Bush administration to revise a data-protection law they are drafting to allow the authorities greater access to information about telephone calls and Internet messages.

title: Rattling Noises Were Heard Before Jet Crash, Officials Say
description: The cockpit voice recorder from American Airlines Flight 587 revealed two instances of an airframe rattling noise, just seconds before the plane's two pilots made comments indicating that they were losing control of the aircraft, the National Transportation Safety Board said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUMNER, JANET
description: SUMNER-Janet. The Amateur Comedy Club records with sorrow the passing on October 31st of its esteemed Honorary Associate Member and former Administrator. Janet came to the Club in 1993 and for more than five years looked after, befriended and laughed with us. A lover of cabaret, nightlife and fine martinis, she will be missed by all who knew her. There will be a memorial service at Calvary Church on November 18th at 1 PM. George S. Coyne II, President

title: Overwhelming Grief as Relatives Gather
description: Mark Shore owns the house at 405 Beach 130th Street in Belle Harbor, Queens.

title: Pay Dispute Turns Violent in France
description: Employees of Moulinex, the bankrupt French appliance maker, set fire to one building at the company's microwave oven plant in western France and threatened to blow up another unless they are granted extra severance pay when their jobs are eliminated later this month.

title: San Francisco Voters Defeat Two Measures About Energy
description: Despite frustration with high energy costs, voters here have narrowly defeated a ballot measure that would have allowed the city to push the region's largest energy provider, the Pacific Gas and Electric Company, out of the local power market.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Nov. 5 showing the change in visitor traffic for various retail Web sites since the holiday season of 2000 misstated the month for which the figures were collected. It was April, not September.

title: When Everything Changed at the C.D.C.
description: About 3 a.m. on Oct. 12, Dr. Jeffrey P. Koplan, director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, awoke to a call from one of his top epidemiologists, Dr. James M. Hughes, who said, ''We've got something reported from the lab, and we need to look at it.''

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINTZ, ARTHUR A., M.D.
description: MINTZ-Arthur A., M.D. Age 86. Died November 11, 2001 at home in Hollis, Queens. He graduated from Columbia University in 1942, and received his Medical Degree in 1945 from N.Y. Flower Fifth Avenue Medical School. He served in the U.S. Navy from 1942 to 1947, and remained in the Reserves for thirty more years as a Commander. After practicing Internal Medicine for twenty years, he became a psychiatrist and worked at Creedmore State Mental Hospital, Queens Children's Hospital, Rikers Island Prison, and The V.A. Hospital in Valhalla, N.Y. He last worked for the NYPD's Disabilities Board, retiring at 82. He also played piano and organ by ear, and taught his method to adults at Roslyn H.S. Skiing, the beach and dancing were the other joys he shared with family and friends. He leaves his wife Ruth (Obler), daughter Linda Shriberg and her husband Larry of Madison, WI, daughter Kathryn, son Bill and his wife Linda of Manhattan, five grandchildren Elizabeth, Kathryn, Janet, Amanda and Zoe, and great grandson Tate.

title: Pujols and Suzuki Win, But There Is a Surprise
description: One player was an unknown because he had played 133 games in the minor leagues before this season. The other player was a bit of an unknown because his glossy accomplishments had all occurred in the Japanese league. But Albert Pujols of the St. Louis Cardinals and Ichiro Suzuki of the Seattle Mariners immediately became well known, and by the end of the season it was obvious that they were the best rookies in the major leagues.

title: SCIENTIFIC-ATLANTA TO ACQUIRE BARCONET
description: Scientific-Atlanta Inc., a maker of cable television set-top boxes, said yesterday that it would purchase a communications equipment maker, BarcoNet N.V., for about $154 million to add to its presence in Europe and Asia. Scientific-Atlanta will pay $5.12 a share, more than twice BarcoNet's last trading price of $2.17, said the chief financial officer, Wallace Haislip. BarcoNet, which had $98 million in revenue for the 12 months ended June 30, was spun off from a Belgian projection equipment maker, Barco N.V., last year. Its shares had fallen 80 percent in the last year.

title: INSIDE
description: Heart Pump Could Help Save 100,000 a Year, Study Says

title: Traveling Worries Nets More Than Playing Pacers
description: Lucious Harris was distracted this afternoon, wanting to rush home from Nets practice to spend an extra hour with his week-old son, Lucious III, before flying on the team charter.

title: Tiki's Team: Barber Reanimates the Giants' Offense
description: In the off-season, as the playbook was being subtly revised, players began calling the offense Tiki's Team. The Giants' offense had developed more flexibility and skill, but Tiki Barber was the most gifted, versatile player and the plan was to exploit his skills as a running back, receiver and punt returner.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAY, ELIZABETH ''LILLIAN''
description: GAY-Elizabeth ''Lillian''. On November 10, 2001. Beloved wife of the late William ''Bill''. Survived by her sister Katherine Hoban and many nieces & nephews. Visiting today 2-5 and 7-9 PM at the Nagel Funeral Home, 352 East 87 St., NYC. Funeral Mass Wednesday 10 AM at the Holy Name Church, Amsterdam Avenue at 96th Street. In lieu of flowers the family would appreciate memorial donations to the Jacob Perlow Hospice, Beth Israel Medical Center, First Ave. at 16th Street, NY, New York 10003.

title: Growing Old, With the Bones in One Piece
description: Bones, once taken for granted, have become a major health issue now that so many Americans are living well into their 70's, 80's and beyond. For at least half of women and one in eight men, bones are not bearing up as well as they should to sustain an active, independent old age free of debilitating fractures.

title: Divided Senate Takes Up Stimulus Bill Today
description: With prospects for a compromise clouded by politics, ideology and pressure from interest groups, the Senate plans to take up a Democratic economic recovery package on Tuesday that has left the two parties bitterly divided.

title: After Angioplasty, Silent Symptoms
description: It has long been known that many patients who have angioplasty to clear blockages from blood vessels supplying the heart experience a return of the clogging. Angioplasty involves briefly inflating a balloon inside an artery to compress the blockages.

title: VISIONICS SAYS 2 AIRPORTS WILL USE SECURITY SYSTEM
description: The Visionics Corporation, a maker of identification systems, said its face-recognition technology would be installed in two major international airports to increase airline security. Shares in the company rose 10 percent. The two airports will not be identified until the installations are complete around the end of December, the company said. Visionics, which is based in Minnetonka, Minn., has a corporate office in Jersey City. Its shares rose $1.31, to $14.15. The shares have more than tripled since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: John Simon White, 91, City Opera Director
description: John Simon White, a mainstay of the Vienna-born triumvirate that steered the New York City Opera to its berth as an important repertory company and proving ground for young American singers, died last Tuesday in Sarasota, Fla., where he had moved from Manhattan in July. He was 91.

title: Preventing Painful Death
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Sensible Shoppers Set Tone At Sale of Contemporary Art
description: Phillips's sleek salesroom on 57th Street was jammed last night with collectors and dealers from all over the world who had come to New York for the first of four consecutive evenings of contemporary art auctions. There was considerable energy throughout the evening as bidders showed their enthusiasm for the best works in the sale. But more striking was the sensible mood that prevailed: bidders knew what things were worth and, for the most part, stubbornly hunted for a good buy.

title: On Eve of Putin Visit, Red Belt Sees Greenbacks
description: They call this region south of Moscow the Red Belt, because of its fealty to Communist leadership. But these days when talk turns to Russia's newly warm relations with America, dollar signs seem to glow in people's eyes and words like ''credits, investment, joint ventures'' spill off their tongues.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Mazda Sees Severe Conditions
description: The Mazda Motor Corporation posted profit of 1.3 billion yen ($10.7 million) in the six-month period that ended Sept. 30, but expects ''severe conditions'' in Japan and the United States to mar the second half of the fiscal year. The company expects to break even in the October-March 2002 period. Mazda, which is one-third owned by Ford Motor, said its share of Japan's auto market fell one percentage point during the period, to 6.1 percent. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Few Choices for Travelers
description: When flights stopped at the city's airports yesterday, many travelers' first thought was to take a cab to a hotel. But that was not easy, either: taxi drivers were reluctant to leave Manhattan because they feared they would not be able to get back in. So the taxi supply at the airports quickly shrank.

title: Players to Watch
description: Dajuan Wagner, guard, Memphis Wagner passed up a chance at the N.B.A. lottery and maybe he will be a tad more into the college game than the Seton Hall freshman Eddie Griffin last season. Wagner will not score 100 points in a college game, as he did in high school, and college defenses should provide some challenge, but Wagner will still be looking to be the go-to guy on Coach John Calipari's trip back to the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Interviewer Calls bin Laden Aggressively 'Changed Man'
description: ''At that time, his beard was black and he was soft-spoken,'' Hamid Mir said, sitting on the front lawn of his house here. ''This time, his beard was white and he was hard-hitting and aggressive.''

title: It's Duke and 63 Other Teams
description: Rafael Hermoso of The Times analyzes the nation's best teams and forecasts which ones have the best chance to make it to the final 16 in March.

title: U.S. and Partners Quickly Set Sights on a Post-Taliban Kabul
description: The United States and the countries most closely affected by developments in Afghanistan called today for ''broad-based, multiethnic, politically balanced, freely chosen Afghan administration'' to take charge once the Taliban is totally driven from Kabul.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Somalia: New Premier Appointed
description: The president of Somalia's transitional government named a new prime minister to replace the one ousted by the national assembly last month in a no-confidence vote. President Abdulkassim Salat Hassan chose his minister of water and mineral resources, Hassan Abshir Farar, to replace Ali Khalif Galaydh. The former prime minister, who held office for a year, was blamed for not restoring peace and stability to the country, which has been in turmoil for more than a decade. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Can Bush and Putin Control Russia's Arsenal?
description: The events of Sept. 11 shattered any illusion that America is secure from foreign attack. As horrible as that day was, future attacks could be far more deadly. If terrorists had used a nuclear weapon in lower Manhattan, hundreds of thousands might have died.

title: A House Divided Against Its Will; Separation Adds to Firefighters' Sense of Loss and Grief
description: They have lost their rigs. Their firehouse in ground zero is off limits. Worst of all, five of their members are dead.

title: Alumnus's $60 Million Gift to Pay for Gehry Building at Princeton
description: Princeton University is getting a Frank O. Gehry building.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, ARTHUR
description: SCHWARTZ-Arthur. On November 10, 2001 at Albany, NY. Beloved husband of Millie Bernstein Schwartz. Loving father of Steven Schwartz and his wife, Lois, of New City, NY, and Dr. Laura Kagan and her husband, Dr. Richard Kagan of Delmar, NY. Brother of Jerry Schwartz of Victoria, British Columbia. Cherished grandfather of Rachel, Daniel, Jeffrey, Jacob and Robert Schwartz; Joshua, Michelle and Michael Kagan and his wife, Cindy Johnston. Funeral services and interment were held on Monday at Albany, New York. For information: Levine Memorial Chapel, 518-438-1002.

title: 6 Arrested as Suspects in Terrorism in France
description: PARIS, Nov. 12  Six suspected terrorists have been arrested by the French police. The authorities said they believed that the suspects were part of a dormant cell that once had plans to blow up a Christmas market and the cathedral in Strasbourg, reports in the French news media said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANNIZZARO, BRIAN
description: CANNIZZARO-Brian. F.D.N.Y. Of Great Kills, Staten Island on September 11, 2001. Beloved husband of Jacqueline (nee O'Mara). Devoted father of Christopher. Loving son of Sam and Carol Cannizzaro. Dear brother of Charles and Craig Cannizzaro. Funeral from the the Casey McCallumRice South Shore Funeral Home, 30 Nelson Avenue, Great Kills, Staten Island, Thursday, November 15th. Mass of Christian Burial Saint Clare's Church, 11 AM. Interment Resurrection Cemetery. Friends will be received Wednesday 2-5 and 7-9PM. In lieu of flowers donations to the Brian Cannizzaro Memorial Trust, PO Box 090321, Staten Island, New York 10309, would be appreciated.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Alternative Energy Program
description: The Seattle City Council is expected to approve a bill today to give city power customers the option of higher rates to pay for energy sources like wind and geothermal power. Starting in January, residential customers would pay an extra $3, $7 or $10 on their monthly bill, to be divided between buying from and investing in renewable power sources. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Late Commercial Real Estate Loans Fall
description: Delinquent commercial real estate loans held by life insurers fell to a low in the third quarter, in part as companies sold or paid off bad loans, a poll by the American Council of Life Insurers said.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Coffee Shop Ovation

title: Dorothy Dunnett, Novelist Of Scotland, Is Dead at 78
description: Dorothy Dunnett, a Scottish historical novelist whose weighty works about Renaissance life attracted swarms of devoted fans in the United States, died on Friday in Edinburgh. She was 78.

title: SC Johnson patriarch promotes the value of companies that are owned by families.
description: THE maker of Raid, Glade, Pledge, Ziploc bags and Windex, SC Johnson, is rolling out a new brand name: Sam.

title: Yankees Can Pay To Get Giambi
description: If the pursuit of Jason Giambi becomes a two-team race between the Yankees and the St. Louis Cardinals, the early betting among baseball people is that the Yankees will win.

title: On Preparing To Wage War With Germs, Guilt Aplenty
description: If it did not drag on for slightly too long, ''Bioterror'' would be a prime example of that all too rare television commodity, the scientifically accurate horror-thriller.

Allison, a Boston software developer who died on the plane that struck 1 World Trade Center, referred imprecisely to the Beaujolais-producing region she toured with her husband, a wine appreciation instructor. It was the Beaujolais district of southern Burgundy, not the Burgundy wine region.

title: Hearing Pilots' Reassurances, Fliers Continue Their Travels
description: If normal means long lines, desperate cell-phone calls and white-knuckled takeoffs, then the nation's aviation system stayed largely normal today, at least outside New York. Americans continued to fly after the crash of a jetliner in Queens. But more than ever, passengers relied on the comforting, sturdy voices of pilots.

title: An Increase in Households Owning Mutual Funds
description: The number of households holding mutual funds rose amid the steepest decline in stocks since 1974, an industry survey said.

title: Arthritis Patients Embrace the Tiger
description: Elderly people who have osteoarthritis, the most common form of arthritis, may benefit from beginning a martial arts program, a new study suggests.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMILL, NANCY JAYNE
description: AMILL-Nancy Jayne, 68. Of Weston, CT, died on November 11, 2001 at home. Graduate of Brown University, beloved wife for 46 years of Richard, mother of Andrew, Alexander, & Sally. Grandmother of Ryan, Jarrett, Sean, and Kennison. Interment will be private. Contributions in her memory may be made to The Alzheimers Association, Southern Connecticut Chapter, 607 Main Avenue, Norwalk, CT. 06851.

title: Temple Might Meet Its Match Against St. Joseph's
description: Atlantic 10

title: Anxious Fate of Kabul, a Coming Showdown and a Busy U.N.
description: And now, Kabul.

title: Legal Experts Divided on New Antiterror Policy That Scuttles Lawyer-Client Confidentiality
description: Legal experts differ sharply on the new Justice Department policy of monitoring communications between people the government says have been involved in terrorism and their lawyers.

title: Accounts
description: Royal Dutch/Shell Group, London, to the London office of MediaCom Worldwide, part of the Grey Global Group, to handle media planning and buying for European and global corporate assignments, with billings estimated at $100 million. The European duties were handled by the CIA Medianetwork, part of the Tempus Group. Royal Dutch/Shell continues to review media assignments for other markets like North and South America.

title: Thornton Played Well, Even if the U.S. Did Not
description: Goalkeeper ZACH THORNTON was the only United States player to distinguish himself during Sunday's scoreless tie with Trinidad and Tobago in the last World Cup qualifying game for both teams.

title: Sisters, Hear Them Roar
description: Deeply Rooted Dance Theater

title: Tolstoy Nobleman, Trying to Do the Right Thing
description: As a professor of music and media at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, the composer Tod Machover directs several forward-looking projects, notably the Opera of the Future/Hyperinstruments Group. In his fascinating 1987 science-fiction opera, ''Valis,'' Mr. Machover genuinely pushed the boundaries of the genre, especially in the way this brash, strangely alluring score synthesized acoustic and electronic instruments.

title: 260 ON JET DIE IN QUEENS CRASH; 6 TO 9 MISSING AS 12 HOMES BURN; U.S. DOUBTS LINK TO TERRORISM
description: An American Airlines jetliner bound from New York to Santo Domingo with 260 people aboard plunged into a neighborhood in Queens minutes after takeoff yesterday morning, jarring a city still numb from the agony it has already endured.

description: BASEBALL

title: Why the Mystery? It's a Secret
description: LKB Dance

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SICHER, ANN B.
description: SICHER-Ann B. Died peacefully on November 11, 2001. She was a lifelong resident of New York City and was predeceased by her husband, the late William D. Sicher. She is survived by her former husband, Richard Weinreich. She is survived by her sons, David Sicher of New York, and Steven Sicher of Peoria, IL; daughters-in-law Linda and Nancy; adoring grandchildren Karen, Peter, Sarah, David, and the late Mark; and her brother Tony Bernhard. Services will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., at 11:30 AM on Tuesday, November 13th. Friends may call at her home Tuesday 5-7 PM. Contributions in her memory may be made to the New York Police and Fire Widow's and Children's Benefit Fund, PO Box 3713 Grand Central Station, New York, NY 10163 or to the charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LARKIN, EDWARD JOSEPH
description: LARKIN-Edward Joseph. Age 67. Died suddenly November 11, 2001. Devoted husband to Patricia (nee Tarpey). Loving father to his nine children, Eileen, Kathleen, Kevin, Patricia, Mary, Thomas, Maureen, Elizabeth and Colleen. Second father to John, Jill, Billy, Joey, Lisa and John. ''G'' to Edward, Patricia, Matthew, Cari, Andrew, Victoria, Ryan, Morgan, Thomas, Julia and Jack. Beloved son of the late Thomas A. & Margaret M. Larkin. Dearest brother of Maureen L. Watson. The joy of his life was his family, although his love of Wall Street and the markets was great. Voted youngest partner of Goodbody and Company, former member New York and American Stock Exchanges, were among highlights of a long and illustrious career. Visiting on Tuesday and Wednesday, 2-5 and 7-9PM, McLaughlin Funeral Home, Third Avenue at 97 Street, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday, 10 AM, Saint Anselm Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDEN, MINA (SONKIN)
description: GOLDEN-Mina (Sonkin). Formerly of Belle Harbor, New York. On November 11, 2001. Wife of the late Jack Golden. Mother of Rosalie Schiffman & Neil Golden. Sister of Lillian Bloom and the late Annie Sonkin. Grandmother of Jessica and Julia Golden, Andrew and Aimee Goldstein. Graveside services Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, L.I. on Wednesday, Nov. 14 at 11AM. Remembrances to a charity of your choice. For further information the BrezniakRodman Funeral Directors, Newton, MA., 617-969-0800.

title: Bishops Draft Principles to Guide Response to Terrorism
description: The nation's Roman Catholic bishops unveiled a sweeping pastoral message today in response to the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, calling for strict moral principles to guide American military action, international efforts to rebuild Afghanistan after the war and for mitigating problems like human rights violations and poverty that cause widespread resentment and anger.

title: Early Walking for Babies With Down's
description: The simple act of placing a baby with Down syndrome on a treadmill to practice walking early in life can yield a wide range of developmental benefits, both physical and emotional, a new study reports.

title: Scouts Had Used Doomed Flight
description: Omar Minaya is well acquainted with American Airlines Flight 587. Minaya, an assistant general manager for the Mets, travels frequently to the Dominican Republic and last took the flight in February.

title: Japan Airlines and Japan Air System Take Merger Move
description: Stung by a global downturn in travel and growing competition at home and overseas, Japan Airlines and Japan Air System, the country's largest and third-largest airlines, said they would set up a holding company next year, a first step toward merging.

title: Pacific Sunwear Records a Drop
description: Pacific Sunwear of California Inc., a retailer of casual clothes and accessories, said today that its fiscal third-quarter profit fell 29 percent as costs rose.

title: Asperger's: Information And Advice
description: ''The Oasis Guide to Asperger Syndrome: Advice, Support, Insights and Inspiration,'' by Patricia Romanowski Bashe and Barbara L. Kirby. Crown Publishers, $27.50.

title: Some Experts Suspect Engine Failure in Jet's Sudden Destruction
description: The National Transportation Safety Board said tonight that a preliminary play-through here of the cockpit voice recorder from the American Airlines plane that crashed this morning near Kennedy International Airport showed that the crew was apparently unaware of a problem until just before the crash.

title: The War on TV, Here and Over There
description: To the Editor:

title: Weather Forecasters Look Ahead, Far Ahead
description: Competing for companies and consumers seeking reliable weather information, commercial forecasters are sharply expanding the boundaries of their predictions.

title: The Florida Vote, and the Echoes
description: To the Editor:

title: Salfit Journal; In the West Bank, Even Olive Trees Cause Quarrels
description: They are just about done harvesting olives here, along ancient terraces cut like giants' steps into the massive, stony hills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILDIN, LUCILLE
description: GILDIN-Lucille. We mourn the passing of our sister-in-law Lucille on November 12, 2001. She was a lovely, bright mother of three and grandmother of six. She was devoted to the State of Israel, Riverdale Mental Health & caring for the welfare of all. The funeral will be held on Wednesday November 14 at 11:15 AM at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. The Gildin Family.

title: Pump Seen Extending Life Of Heart Failure Patients
description: An implanted mechanical pump that assists a failing heart, but does not replace it, can significantly prolong the lives of people who are dying of heart disease, according to a landmark study reported here today.

title: Grim Giuliani Presides Over Another Tragic Scene, This Time in Queens
description: In a time of trauma and a transition in government, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani found himself in a familiar position yesterday, rushing to the site of another emergency where he comforted families of survivors, took charge of the city's response to the crisis and consoled New Yorkers alarmed that their city might once again be the target of a terrorist attack.

title: DURA, AUTO PARTS MAKER, TO SELL PLASTICS BUSINESS
description: Dura Automotive Systems Inc., which makes parking brakes and other car parts, agreed to sell its plastic products business for about $41 million. The buyer was not disclosed. The sale is subject to the buyer securing financing for the purchase and is expected to close in the first quarter, the company said. Dura Automotive, based in Rochester Hills, Mich., will record $7 million in noncash costs this quarter for the sale, which is part of the company's strategy to focus on its core business.

title: Anchors Use Care to Avoid Speculation On the Cause
description: As soon as the first reports of a plane crash near Kennedy Airport in Queens commandeered television screens yesterday morning, some stations quietly removed the red, white and blue logos and American flags from their broadcasts. Any suggestion -- even a subliminal one -- that this airplane disaster was a continuation of the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11 could seem premature.

title: Citing 'New Day' in U.S.-Russia Relations, Bush Pledges Warhead Cuts
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 — President Bush told President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia today that he had decided to reduce America's nuclear arsenal by roughly two-thirds over the next decade, to a total of 1,700 to 2,200 weapons, after determining that "a new day" in Washington's relations with Moscow had eliminated the need for overwhelming strength.

title: A Suburb Pulls Together For Its Grieving Families
description: A young widow with five children and a yawning mortgage, Isabel Nimbley has a lot on her mind these days. Even before her husband, Paul, perished in the rubble of the World Trade Center, her waking hours were an exhausting whirl of carpools, basketball games, meal making and parent-teacher conferences. ''I'm just taking it one day at a time,'' she said wearily as she fed her 9-month-old son, Michael Paul, moments after her other children, ages 8 to 15, had left for school.

title: Meddling in Managua
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Wars, Many Fears
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12  There are two wars in Afghanistan now, a northern campaign that is rapidly entering its final stages and a southern campaign that is just beginning.

title: Persian Canal Discovery Is Testament to Ancient Engineering Skills
description: In 480 B.C., King Xerxes of Persia ordered his men to build a canal a mile and a quarter long through a peninsula in northern Greece -- conceivably one of the biggest engineering assignments of its time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEAD, ROSEMARY DOOLEY
description: MEAD-Rosemary Dooley. On November 12, 2001 of Garden City. Wife of the late Nicholas. Loving mother of Mary Sinatra Rutman, Michael, David, Nicholas, Rosemary Trompeter and Geraldine Allen. Proud grandmother of 13 grandchildren. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave. at 12th Street, Garden City 2-4 and 6-9 PM Tuesday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, Garden City 10 AM Wednesday. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery. An avid gardener she belonged to the American Hemerocallis Society, Long Island Daylily Society and the North American Rock Garden Society. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to Burke Rehabilitation Hospital, 785 Mamaroneck Ave., White Plains, NY 10605, in care of Karen McCoy, Director of Respiratory Research.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Downsizing the Military
description: Russia plans to trim its 1.2-million-member armed forces by 200,000 servicemen and officers by 2003, the chief of the general staff, Anatoly Kvashnin, said after a meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin and other military officials. The cuts, part of a slow-moving package of military reforms, are aimed in part at freeing up money to better train and equip the remaining forces. General Kvashnin said combat preparedness had fallen so low that some air force regiments were not able to fly nighttime combat missions and a significant portion of the naval command staff no longer had the skills to navigate ships.

title: Returning To Kentucky, Minus One
description: The office overlooking Cardinal Arena, the multimillion-dollar contract, the 14 basketball players waiting a couple of floors below in the gym so he could harangue them about their diets and defensive stances: Billy Minardi gave this all to Rick Pitino. The University of Louisville only paid for it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEE, ESSIE E.
description: LEE-Essie E. The faculty and alumni of the Hunter College Program in Urban Public Health mourn the death and send condolences to the family of our colleague, Essie E. Lee. Professor Lee served as mentor to hundreds of students and contributed to the prevention and treatment of alcoholism. We will miss her. Nicholas Freudenberg, Director Program in Urban Public Health Hunter College, City University of New York

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Economy Shrinks
description: Japan's economy shrank 0.7 percent in the April-June period compared with the previous quarter but the figure was slightly better than had been forecast. The government said exports and corporate capital spending fell at slower rates than first thought, while consumer spending, which makes up 55 percent of the economy, was little changed. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: G.M. Starts to Back Off on Its Price War
description: General Motors has begun a slow retreat from the auto industry's price war that was spurred by the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Memories of Vietnam
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, WILLIAM M.
description: WEISS-William M. November 12, 2001, in Palm Beach, FL, at age 94. Survived by his loving son, Laddie, and daughter-in-law Fraya Karsh, two beloved grandsons, Maxwell and Robert, and two adoring great-grandchildren, Jake and Jessica. Service today, 11:30AM, ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Marshals Restrain Unruly Man
description: A US Airways flight from Pittsburgh to Ronald Reagan National Airport outside Washington was diverted to nearby Dulles International Airport this evening after a passenger became unruly, government officials said.

title: Milosevic to Face New Charges for Bosnian War
description: A sweeping new indictment has been issued against Slobodan Milosevic, the former Yugoslav president, this time charging him with war crimes in Bosnia, an official of the United Nations war crimes tribunal at The Hague said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KESTENBAUM, MYRA
description: KESTENBAUM-Myra, 69. Violist and composer, died November 6, 2001, in Santa Monica, CA, after a long battle with cancer. Beloved sister of Dr. Clarice Kestenbaum, mother of David and Beth Shamrock. Memorial service will be held at Congregation Rodeph Sholom at a date to be announced.

title: The Florida Vote, and the Echoes
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KINDERMANN, JOYCE A. (KRANNAWITTER)
description: KINDERMANN-Joyce A. (Krannawitter), age 85. In New London, New Hampshire on November 10, 2001. Formerly of Riverdale and Chappaqua, NY. Beloved wife of George Kindermann of New London, NH; loving mother of Jan and Ben Acard of New London, NH; step grandmother to Adam and Brian; step great grandmother to four. Service Ferncliff Cemetery Chapel, Hartsdale, NY, Wednesday, November 14, 2001 at 11:00 A.M. Memorial contributions to Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research, Grand Central Station, P.O. Box 4777, NY, NY 10163. For information McGrath & Son, Inc., 914-337-6770.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about anthrax testing and cleanup at post offices in the New York region misstated the number of employees at the four offices in New Jersey where anthrax was found. It is 80 to 90 in total, not apiece.

title: Taking Off for Points Unknown
description: Simone Forti

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLINUS, SEYMOUR M.
description: PLINUS-Seymour M. On November 11, 2001, after a prolonged illness. A wonderful and devoted son. Beloved brother, brother-inlaw, uncle and grand-uncle. Esteemed member of the Harry S. Truman Lodge of the Masonic Order. He was a lovable human being who will be dearly missed.

title: The Florida Vote, and the Echoes
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SZUMLAK, DAVID
description: SZUMLAK-David. Ariel American Friends of Midrasha and United Israel Institutions express sincerest condolences to Gail Weisbrod, wife of our dedicated supporter and Guest of Honor Michael B. Weisbrod on the passing of her dear father, David Szumlak. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Chief Rabbi Shear Yashuv Cohen, Chancellor Natalio S. Fridman, President Michael D. Jaspan, Treasurer

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOENIG, LAWRENCE JEROME
description: KOENIG-Lawrence Jerome, 79. Passed away on November 11, 2001. Loving husband of Hannah for 57 years, adored father of Susan & husband Daniel Dengate, Bruce Koening and cherished grandfather of Raegan Koenig, Craig and Bradley Martin. He was a devoted husband, father, grandfather and friend to all he met. He will be greatly missed by all who knew and loved him. Gone from our sight but never from our hearts, may he rest with all the souls in Zion.

title: Columbia Sets Goal Of Making Tourney
description: For the past 13 years, there has been little suspense when it comes to which Ivy League team will represent the conference in the N.C.A.A. men's basketball tournament.

title: The Road to San Antonio
description: Frank Litsky of The Times rates the teams with the best chance of reaching the final 16 in March, and who could survive to the Final Four March 29 and 31 in San Antonio. (Last season's records in parentheses.)

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Today: Hearing On Boxing Regulator
description: The New York State Assembly has scheduled a public hearing on the effectiveness of the New York State Athletic Commission, which oversees professional boxing. Room 1923, Assembly Hearing Room, 19th Floor, 250 Broadway, Manhattan, 10:30 a.m. Information: (518) 455-3888.

title: Joining the Mingus Legacy, Just Like the Other Fans
description: Romance, rage, art, ancestry, risk, camaraderie and an endless scuffling quest are encompassed in the music of Charles Mingus.
