Elvis Costello is neither the first to cherish those qualities nor the first to put them in lyrics, but he stretched himself to try both when he collaborated with the Charles Mingus Orchestra in a concert on Wednesday night at the Beacon Theater.

title: Rapid Advances by Northern Alliance Deal a Setback to Pakistan's Policy
description: The stunningly swift successes of the Northern Alliance in Afghanistan amount to a huge setback for the longtime policy of Pakistan, which until the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11 had supported the ruling Taliban.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about a plan by Simon & Schuster to open an online store to sell digital editions of its books directly to consumers misidentified the company's parent. It is Viacom; one of the parent's major shareholders is National Amusements.

title: BETHLEHEM STEEL TO LAY OFF 400 NONUNION WORKERS
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection last month, will lay off 400 nonunion employees by the end of January to reduce costs. The reductions will take place at all of the company's operations, including its headquarters, in Bethlehem, Pa. The 13,000-employee company, which eliminated 300 nonunion jobs earlier this year, said that with the cuts its salaried staff will have been reduced by 25 percent since June. Last week, the United Steelworkers of America union said the company wanted to lay off 2,000 union members.

title: Tortured Bodies: Vanity Through The Ages
description: Here, on a workroom table, are the shoes for women with bound feet, tiny objects that look like hoofwear for some endangered breed of miniature deer; here, the cone bra Jean Paul Gaultier made for Madonna, velvet volutes in the form of mortar launchers. Here is the latest in monster boots worn by maniacal fashionistas in Tokyo's Shinjuku. And here is a rare neckpiece from the Padaung people in Myanmar, the kind that turns the neck into an attenuated stalk.

title: Preventing Painful Death
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing
description: TELECOMMUNICATIONS

title: Freeing Keiko
description: To the Editor:

title: On Stage, a Day in the Life of an Idiosyncratic Physicist
description: Richard Feynman, a physicist at the California Institute of Technology, was the scientist as he might have been imagined by Jack Kerouac.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERMAN, IDA M.
description: SHERMAN-Ida M. On November 10, 2001. Beloved wife of Dr. Harry Sherman. Dear mother of Ellen Samuel (Sandy) Luger, Alice Sherman (Robert) Quine and Laura Sherman. Adored grandmother of Mimi and Joanne, and greatgrandmother of Jesse, Mollie and Sherman. Dear sister of Joseph (Lillian) Miller and Sally Greene. Services Tuesday, November 13, 12:45 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., NYC.

title: Once a Farce, the Jets' Defense Is Now a Force
description: There was a time, just a month ago, when it looked as if the Jets' defense was going to single-handedly destroy Ted Cottrell's chances of ever becoming a head coach. When Cottrell came to the Jets this year from Buffalo, he was one of the league's most respected defensive coordinators, after seasons in which his Bills defenses ranked sixth, first and third.

title: U.S. Says Aid To Pakistan Won't Include F-16 Fighters
description: The Bush administration has rejected Pakistan's request to release a fleet of F-16 jet fighters that it bought in the 1980's, American officials said today, adding that the United States wanted to avoid destabilizing relations in South Asia.

title: Less Can Be More for an Ensemble in a Small Space
description: Orpheus is most at home at Carnegie Hall, where the auditorium's acoustical bloom gives this chamber orchestra a velvety patina, much as it has on recordings. But this conductorless ensemble plays elsewhere in Manhattan as well, and on Saturday evening it offered the first of two concerts this season at the 92nd Street Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, BENNIE
description: SCHWARTZ-Bennie. Loving husband of Miriam. Adored father of Sheldon, and Judy Melnick. Beloved grandfather of Lori Fichtenbaum, Barbara Gold, Gregg Scheuing and Michael Schwartz. Adored great-grandfather of six. Services were held privately.

title: People
description: Elizabeth DeMaso was named to the new post of senior vice president and director for business development at the New York office of Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies. She had headed an executive placement company, DeMaso Adelson, New York.

title: Carrie Donovan, One-of-a-Kind Fashion Editor and TV's 'Old Navy Lady,' Dies at 73
description: Carrie Donovan, a fashion editor who could easily have rested on her laurels and leopard skins but came out of semiretirement to find a new and even more enthusiastic audience as ''the lady from Old Navy,'' died yesterday in Manhattan. She was 73.

title: An Overwhelming Grief
description: The grief of the 500 relatives of Flight 587 passengers who gathered yesterday in the ballroom of the Ramada Inn at Kennedy Airport was overwhelming, said a doctor who was there.

title: Small Businesses Slow to Grasp Government's Helping Hand
description: The city and the state are giving money away to small businesses -- but almost no one is taking it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUNEBAUM, ANNELIESE E.
description: GRUNEBAUM - Anneliese E. Peacefully on November 3, 2001, in her 96th year. Beloved widow of Kurt H. Grunebaum. Loving mother of Peter. Proud grandmother of George, Nicole and Danielle. Devoted great-grandmother of Marcus, Sebastian, Annabel, Solene and Charlotte. A memorial service will be held on November 13, 2001, at 2 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to The Neue Gallerie, 1048 5th Ave, New York, NY 10028.

title: Looking Ahead in Kabul
description: Just days after its victory in Mazar-i-Sharif, Afghanistan's Northern Alliance has swiftly expanded its control over northern Afghanistan and has now sent Taliban forces fleeing from Kabul. This creates an urgent need for the United Nations to assemble an international administration that can govern the capital until Afghanistan's people can choose a new government. Secretary of State Colin Powell is rightly pressing for such an arrangement, which can help prevent political and ethnic reprisals and make Kabul a showcase for the kind of international help that would follow the Taliban's ouster nationwide.

title: The Florida Vote, and the Echoes
description: To the Editor:

title: The Prankster's Death
description: Some names come trailing behind them not a sense of the person but an idea of something larger, a time, a possibility, an actual shift in the ways of being. Ken Kesey's is a name like that. The man it belonged to died Saturday at 66, after complications following liver surgery. Mr. Kesey was only 27 when his first novel, ''One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest,'' was published, a book that began the making of his reputation. People will be arguing about the meaning of that reputation for years to come, even as it grows more and more elusive.

title: Williams Is on a Stage All His Own at Duke
description: Who would ever want to leave Duke? The basketball team held an intrasquad scrimmage at Cameron Indoor Stadium late last month, and a near-capacity crowd of 9,314 showed up, including Crazy Towel Man and a fan in an electric-blue fright wig and a T-shirt with a bad wish for the hated North Carolina Tar Heels.

title: The Rust Belt With a Drawl; States of the Interior South Mired in Worst Downturn In Nearly Two Decades
description: In a patch of land that once held pine, spruce and oak trees, an auto-parts maker opened a modern-looking manufacturing plant here five years ago. Over on the east side of town, another company makes computer circuit boards on a former military base. And an hour and a half to the northwest, a telecommunications equipment factory sits in a field that produced cotton a decade ago.

title: Technology Briefing | Investment: Alcatel Executive Joins Venture Capital Firm
description: Morgenthaler Ventures, the Silicon Valley venture capital and investment firm, said yesterday that it had hired Krish Prabhu, the former head of Alcatel's operations in the United States. Mr. Prabhu will be responsible for seeking out investments in the communications and information-technology industries. ''I think there are opportunities in the optical and wireless sectors,'' Mr. Prabhu said in an interview. Mr. Prabhu began his career with Bell Labs in 1980 before joining Alcatel, the French communications equipment company, in 1991. Earlier this year he was involved in Alcatel's ultimately unfruitful effort to acquire Lucent Technologies of Murray Hill, N.J. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Foreign Affairs; In Pakistan, It's Jihad 101
description: You need only spend an afternoon walking through the Storytellers' Bazaar here in Peshawar, a few miles from the Afghan border, to understand that America needs to do its business in Afghanistan -- eliminate Osama bin Laden and his Taliban pro tectors -- as quickly as possible and get out of here. This is not a neighborhood where we should linger. This is not Mr. Rogers's neighborhood.

title: North Platte Journal; Espresso Oasis Halfway Between Yuck! and Foo!
description: Here at Exit 177 on Interstate 80, halfway between New York and San Francisco, halfway between Omaha and Denver, halfway between Cozad, Neb., and Roscoe, Neb., sits a sign that says, ''Friends Don't Let Friends Drink Folger's.''

title: Peter Sellars Quits as Director Of Arts Festival in Australia
description: Less than four months before the beginning of the Adelaide Festival, Australia's premier performing arts event, Peter Sellars has resigned as the festival's artistic director, citing his own mistakes as well as the reaction to his recently announced schedule.

title: Global Kaleidoscope: Powell Notes Shifts After Sept. 11
description: Within 48 hours of September's terrorist strikes, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell telephoned Gen. Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan and said, ''General, you have got to make a choice.''

title: Weighty Group Revives Plan for a Newark Sports Arena
description: Two months after a plan to build a $355 million sports arena in Newark fell apart, New Jersey political and business heavyweights have formed a new organization to revive the project.

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Today: Connecticut Lawmakers To Meet
description: The Connecticut State Legislature meets in special session to consider ways to close a $300 million budget deficit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAVITZ, GERALD., D.P.M.
description: RAVITZ-Gerald., D.P.M. 69. Of Smithtown, Y, on November 11, 2001. Loving husband of Thelma for 44 years. Adored and devoted father of Marjorie, Stephen and Suzanne, and father-in-law of Jeff and Elliot. Beloved grandfather of two grandsons. An all great guy & he will be missed tremendously. Donations can be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: BNP PARIBAS BUYS MAJORITY STAKE IN CAPSTAR PARTNERS
description: BNP Paribas S.A., France's biggest bank by assets, said it bought 60 percent of Capstar Partners L.L.C. of New York for an undisclosed amount to expand its asset-financing business in Europe and the United States. BNP Paribas has been expanding internationally. Capstar, which has about 50 employees worldwide, advises clients on the best way to finance assets like heavy machinery, said a BNP Paribas spokeswoman, Agathe Heinrich.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHILIT, BERNARD (BARRY)
description: SCHILIT-Bernard (Barry). On November 11, 2001 of New York City and Fire Island, NY. Beloved father of Lisa, Rebecca & William. Loving grandfather of Arielle, Leah, Kirk, and Nell. Devoted brother of Claire, Irving, Mildred & the late Charles. Born September 7, 1923 in Poland and came to this country at age 2 where he grew up in Brooklyn. Graduate of City College of NY in 1946. Served in the U.S. Army 1942-1945. Became the youngest weather forecaster in the Army Air Corp at 19 years. Promoted to Technical Sergeant with the 12th Weather Squardon serving in numerous battles and campaigns in Italy, France andGermany. Founder and President of Weather Trends, Inc., a NYC based weather consulting firm, 1954-2000. Weather columnist for Progressive Farmer Magazine, 1955-2000 and author of numerous books and almanacs. Avid bridge player and silver life master. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his memory to the New York Public Library. Service Wednesday, 1 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: The Big City; Able to Adapt To What Fate Throws at Us
description: ''IT could have been far worse,'' Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday. In another time and place, that would have seemed an odd way to describe the plunge of a jetliner into a residential neighborhood.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS DROPS. Natural gas fell as forecasts for mild weather signaled reduced demand for heating fuel. In New York, natural gas for December delivery fell 19.2 cents, or 6.6 percent, to $2.733 per million B.T.U.'s.

title: After Acquiring Beef Producer, Tyson Foods Says Profit Is Up
description: Tyson Foods, the nation's leading poultry producer, said today that profit almost tripled in its most recent quarter as chicken prices rose and the company benefited from the acquisition of IBP Inc., a beef producer.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Long-Shot Asteroids

title: An Elegant Bridge to a World in Upheaval
description: The gulf between serial music and general audiences can offer only a few fragile bridges, but none is more passable than Alban Berg's Violin Concerto. Its most obvious but not its most compelling argument comes in the finale: a literal statement of the old Lutheran hymn ''Es Ist Genug,'' which in both tone and harmonic underpinning mediates the arguments of an old world and a new one.

title: Two Wars, Many Fears
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12  There are two wars in Afghanistan now, a northern campaign that is rapidly entering its final stages and a southern campaign that is just beginning.

title: State Department Finds Traces of Anthrax at a Mail Center
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 — The State Department said today that more traces of anthrax were detected in its Virginia mail center. While not startling, the finding bolsters the theory that at least one more tainted letter, so far undiscovered, has moved through the Washington mail.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DOBKIN, SOLOMON (SOL)
description: DOBKIN-Solomon (Sol). In fond and loving memory-20 years. Lillian K. Dobkin

title: In a Fallen Taliban City, a Busy, Busy Barber
description: In this town just taken from the Taliban by Northern Alliance troops, the busiest spot was Amon's Barbershop, where men lined up to have their beards shaved off.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: American Business Media, New York, gave its Grand CEBA award, for creative excellence in business advertising, to Carmichael Lynch, Minneapolis for a campaign created for the American Advertising Federation. The campaign seeks to demonstrate the value of advertising by using familiar brands as examples. Carmichael Lynch is part of the Partnership unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It could not have happened at a worse place. This is like the aftershock of an earthquake. Just when you're getting comfortable, another plane falls out of the sky.''

title: McGwire Gives ESPN News First
description: Mark McGwire chose to announce his retirement to ESPN's Rich Eisen because of a professional relationship that began two years ago.

title: F.B.I.'s Anthrax Inquiry
description: To the Editor:

title: Death of a Child: How Israel's Army Responds
description: There is little doubt now about the facts.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Loss Widens At WEBMD
description: The WebMD Corporation, which makes medical practice management software, said yesterday that its third-quarter loss widened after it wrote down the value of acquisitions by $3.83 billion. The company, based in Elmwood, N.J., had a loss of $4.62 billion, or $12.86 a share, compared with a loss of $786.9 million, or $3.17, a year earlier. Revenue rose 10 percent, to $167 million, from $151.2 million. The company also canceled a technology agreement with Microsoft. Under the pact, WebMD would have used Microsoft software in its systems that help doctors run their offices. WebMD expects 2002 revenue of $730 million to $750 million. Shares rose 36 cents, to $4.90.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Exodus Says Its Stock May Be Worthless
description: The Web site operating company, Exodus Communications, said yesterday that it was likely ''that the company's common stock will have no value'' even if it finds new investors or is acquired. Exodus, based in Santa Clara, Calif., sought bankruptcy protection in September even after receiving $200 million from GE Capital. Shares in Exodus, which are traded over-the-counter, fell 9 cents, to 19 cents. The company said it might seek a buyer or new investors, but that neither course of action was likely to give its stock value. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Maryland Spa Savings
description: Winter weather can require some rejuvenation, and the Five Gables Inn and Spa on the Chesapeake Bay in St. Michaels, Md., makes it easier to afford. From Nov. 12 to March 31, 2002, it is taking 30 percent off its winter retreat package. Rates start at $475 a couple on weekends ($325 weekdays), and include two nights' accommodations with a whirlpool and fireplace, a facial or hydrotherapy bath followed by a 45-minute massage and daily Continental breakfast. The inn also has a heated indoor pool. The rooms are in three 19th century homes. Other packages are also available. Information: (877) 466-0100 or www.fivegables.com .

title: For McGwire, The End Came Prematurely
description: No one hit home runs that were more majestic than the balls Mark McGwire sent soaring into the sky, headed for distant points beyond outfield fences. No one hit more home runs in a four-year period than McGwire slugged from 1996 through 1999.

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of yesterday, 4,432 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11.

title: New York Was Bioterrorism Target, in 1864
description: Bioterrorists want a horrible disease that is easy to spread and that has a high fatality rate. So, thought terrorists during the Civil War, what better disease than yellow fever? It kills within days, causing a hemorrhagic fever that makes victims bleed from the mouth and nose and vomit a black substance that resembles coffee grounds but consists largely of dried blood.

title: From 70's Relic, a Possible PATH Station
description: The old Hudson and Manhattan Railroad station on the eastern edge of the World Trade Center site, closed since the early 1970's, could be restored and reopened as a permanent replacement for the PATH station that was partly crushed in the collapse of the trade towers, an official at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday.

title: Q & A
description: The Thinking Apple Tree

title: Lessons From Sept. 11 Are Followed in Quick Transportation Shutdowns and Restarts
description: New York's major airports shut down, bridges and tunnels were closed, some buses and trains were halted and the Empire State Building was evacuated. The United Nations was locked down, security at government buildings and nuclear plants was tightened and a city traumatized by terrorism suffered a bad case of the jitters yesterday after the American Airlines jetliner crashed in Queens.

title: Metro Briefing
description: CONNECTICUT

title: Losing Control
description: In his first days as mayor-elect, Michael Bloomberg has started to talk about the budget crisis facing New York City. That is important, since many experts think the situation is so dire that there will have to be a takeover of city finances next year by Gov. George Pataki.

title: Very First Feminist's Eerie Revenge On Men
description: The house was nearly full for the premiere of Deborah Drattell's ''Lilith'' at the New York City Opera on Sunday afternoon. As the company's former composer in residence who inaugurated its valuable Composers Showcase project, Ms. Drattell has earned much good will among artists, staff and, it would appear, audiences.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIN, HERMAN
description: LEWIN-Herman. Beloved husband of Hortense for 55 years, on November 11. Devoted brother of Eva Gruenberg & the late Hanna Linn. Cherished brother-in-law of Lisa and Ralph Mariam. Adored by his six nieces and nephews. Services will be held 12:00 noon today at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, Queens Blvd. at 76th Road, Forest Hills, NY.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: A Bid For At Home's Internet Portal
description: The At Home Corporation said yesterday that InfoSpace had bid $10 million for its Excite.com Internet portal. At Home, which does business as Excite@Home, had paid $6.7 billion for Excite in 1999. At Home is under bankruptcy protection and has agreed to sell its high-speed Internet access to AT&T, its controlling shareholder. InfoSpace, which provides search and directory services, would keep Excite's search technology and would sell the portal to Iwon.com, a portal company based in Irvington, N.Y., that is backed by Viacom. At Home said the deal would need approval by the bankruptcy court and that other bidders could emerge. While Excite's audience has been shrinking, it is still the ninth most visited site, with 24 million users a month in the United States, according to Jupiter Media Metrix. Saul Hansell (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Friday about Mildred Newman, a New York psychotherapist and author, misstated the title of a best-selling book of which she was co-author. It was ''How to Be Your Own Best Friend,'' not ''How to Be Your Best Friend.''

title: Wines of the Week
description: Thanksgiving dinner is the ultimate roundup of comfort foods from succulent roast turkey to mashed potatoes smothered with gravy and savory cornbread stuffing. Even the traditional desserts -- pumpkin and apple pie -- soothe with sweetness.

title: Problems at the Pound
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Studies Aim to Preserve Fertility of Women in Chemotherapy
description: Two years ago, the day after she completed a marathon, Lindsey Nohr learned that a lesion on her tongue was cancerous. She could cope with cancer, she thought, but at age 22, she found one potential consequence of chemotherapy unbearable: infertility. Drugs that kill cancer cells can also destroy a woman's eggs.

title: Images From an Enlisted Man
Weathering the Odds
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: A New Day in Kabul
description: As the Taliban retreats, the people of the Afghan capital celebrate amid an uneasy mood.

title: U.S. Troops Must Go In
description: We are at a critical moment not only for Afghanistan, but for the United States. The Northern Alliance has proved itself a good proxy force, working in conjunction with American air power to drive the Taliban and Al Qaeda forces into disarray. But in a country whose recent history is one of warring factions and hostile ethnic divisions, America cannot allow Northern Alliance occupation of Afghan cities to become the order of the day. Before the alliance can become entrenched, we must send in our own soldiers -- in large numbers -- to enforce human rights and keep the peace.

title: Taubman Datebooks Cited In Sotheby's Collusion Trial
description: He was listed as an unnamed ''gentleman.'' He was also listed as ''Sir A,'' ''Anthony,'' and ''Tony.'' Once he was mentioned by no name or word at all, just four asterisks. And other times he was named in full: Sir Anthony Tennant.

title: Corrections
description: A picture credit was omitted yesterday for a portrait with the obituary of Carrie Donovan, fashion editor and later spokeswoman for the Old Navy stores. The photographer was Jesse Frohman. In some editions a credit was also missing for a caricature of Ms. Donovan used in the stores' advertising. It was copyrighted in 1997 by Al Hirschfeld and appeared courtesy of the Margo Feiden Galleries Ltd., New York.

title: Technology Briefing | Research: Heart Drug Shows Promise
description: Alexion Pharmaceuticals said a drug it is developing prevented serious heart attacks and cognitive impairment in patients who had coronary bypass surgery. The results, reported at the American Heart Association meeting in Anaheim, Calif., were from a Phase 2 trial. The company, based in Cheshire, Conn., is planning a larger Phase 3 trial. The drug, pexelizumab, is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits inflammation that can occur when the blood is passed through the heart-lung machines often used in bypass surgery, said Dr. Jane C. K. Fitch, chairwoman of the anesthesiology department at the University of Oklahoma and an author of the studies. ''This is one of the first things available that may be able to prevent this,'' she said. In a study involving 914 bypass surgery patients, 3 percent treated with the drug had heart attacks or died in the 30 days after the operation, compared with 9.3 percent for those receiving a placebo. However, when smaller heart attacks were included, the drug did not show a statistically significant improvement over the placebo, something the company had previously reported. Andrew Pollack (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAVALLARO, ANTHONY
description: CAVALLARO-Anthony, 77. Retired from EBCBS, World War II veteran 82nd Airborne. Survived by wife Hannah (Gilmartin) Cavallaro, sister Ann Orsi, two nephews and four nieces. For further information, Westchester Funeral Home, (914)-337-4585.

title: Bush and Putin Agree to Reduce Stockpile of Nuclear Warheads
description: President Bush and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia pledged today to cut their nuclear stockpiles by roughly two-thirds over the next decade, leaving each side with fewer than 2,200 warheads.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOLLEY, REV. WILLIAM G.
description: TOLLEY-Rev. William G., 75. Of Cape May, NJ, formerly of Brooklyn. He was retired Presbyterian minister of Union Church of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. Rev. Tolley is survived by wife of 55 years, Rev. Jo Tolley; four daughters, Joyce Tolley Weiskopf, Kim E. Gibbons, Carol Hastings, and Cindy Tolley. Funeral service today 2 PM in First Presbyterian Church, Cape May. View Today 11 AM to 1 PM in Sudak-Danaher Funeral Home, Cape May. Donations: First Presbyterian Church, 500 Hughes St., Cape May, New Jersey 08204.

title: People
description: * Penny Baldwin was named president and chief executive at the San Francisco office of Young & Rubicam Advertising, part of the Young & Rubicam unit of the WPP Group, succeeding Austin McGhie, who left last month to return to the client side of the business. Ms. Baldwin had been president at the San Francisco office of Arnold Worldwide, part of the Arnold Worldwide Partners division of Havas Advertising.

title: After Terror at His Doorstep, Kelly Returns to Public Stage
description: Hours after Raymond W. Kelly was officially introduced by Mayor-elect Michael R. Bloomberg as the next police commissioner of New York, Mr. Kelly sat in a plush executive conference room at Bear Stearns, where he serves as director of global security, to explain his return to the government-issue chair he left in January 1994.

title: America West Is First to Seek a U.S. Loan
description: America West Airlines applied for a federally guaranteed loan of $400 million yesterday, becoming the first airline to seek some of the $10 billion in guarantees approved by Congress in September as part of an emergency rescue package for the airline industry.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the special Giving section on Monday about Proyecto Azteca, a program in South Texas that provides low-cost housing, misstated the average size of the homes. They are 910 square feet, not 9,100.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Chechnya Withdrawal Planned, AGain
description: Most Russian troops in the separatist province of Chechnya will probably be withdrawn by next spring, leaving only a rifle division and a brigade of Interior Ministry forces, the commander of Russian operations there said. Gen. Gennadi Troshev spoke to the Interfax news agency as President Vladimir V. Putin told top military officials that a return to peace in Chechnya was ''irreversible'' and that the Russian campaign there had been successful. Commanders said last winter that they were starting to remove most Russian troops from Chechnya but the withdrawal was suspended after only a relative handful had left. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Student Kills Himself After Taking Hostages
description: A 17-year-old student smuggled guns into his school outside a small town north of here on Monday, took two hostages and then killed himself, law enforcement officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUMBAUGH, DAVID W.
description: BRUMBAUGH-David W., 93. Formerly of Scarsdale, NY and Pinehurst, NC, died November 10. Husband of the late Dorothy (Seay) and Juanita (Johnson); father of Ann of Manhattan and David Jr. of Rye, NY; step-grandfather of Nelson, Christopher, and Juanita Bell and Peter Bedini. Memorial Service Nov. 20, 11 AM, Scarsdale Community Baptist Church.

title: Reducing the Fear That Arrives by Mail
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Farmers Stage Protest Over W.T.O. Rice Deal
description: Thousands of farmers swarmed through the streets around the National Assembly in Seoul demanding that the government pull out of an agreement with the World Trade Organization under which it will cut subsidies for home-grown rice and reduce quotas on imports. Some of the farmers battled with police officers while burning W.T.O. officials in effigy and overturning cars. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Governor Cuts $55 Million
description: Gov. Ronnie Musgrove cut $55 million out of the state's $3.5 billion general fund budget, saying he had warned lawmakers that they had been too optimistic in drafting the spending plan. Tax collections for the first quarter of the new fiscal year are about 5.5 percent below projections.

title: Buenos Aires Journal; Home From Cuba, Soccer Star Kicks Some Shins
description: The news in Buenos Aires could hardly be worse, with the nation's finances nearing collapse and unemployment soaring. But Argentines are transfixed by something more beguiling and only somewhat less painful: the bittersweet return of Diego Armando Maradona.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHOATE, ELOISE WELD
description: CHOATE-Eloise Weld. On November 12, 2001. Wife of the late Arthur O. Choate. She is survived by her son, Dr. William L. Elkins, Jr. of Coatesville, PA., daughter Carol Elkins of New York City, seven grandchildren, twelve great grandchildren, and her sisters Priscilla W. Grosjean of Haverford, PA. and Sylvia W. Bigelow of Cambridge, MA. A memorial service will be held 3 PM Friday, November 16th in the Church of the Good Shepherd, Wareham, MA. and also at 10 AM Saturday, November 24th in the Church of the Advent, Kennett Square, PA. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in memory of Eloise Choate to Children of Bellevue, 462 1st Ave, Mezz. #

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOJCAK, RANDY
description: WOJCAK-Randy. The Board of Directors, staff & volunteers of God's Love We Deliver are deeply saddened by the loss of our friend & former Board member, Randy Wojcak. Randy was always an active Board member & committee participant, & we are grateful to have known his dedication & loyal support. His enthusiasm for our efforts, coupled with his willingness to assist us with our services, enriched the lives of thousands of New Yorkers living with HIV/AIDS. We extend our sincere condolences to his family & his many friends & associates.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Big Board Leases Space
description: The New York Stock Exchange has agreed to lease 65,000 square feet of space at 14 Wall Street, a tower across from the exchange. The offices will house the 140 people in the exchange's enforcement division who were displaced from the World Trade Center, said Ray Pellecchia, a spokesman for the exchange. The exchange signed the lease late last month. Charles V. Bagli (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; It's Too Soon To Write Off The Knicks
description: I AM all for foresight, but are things really hopeless for the Knicks? The headlines and the story lines have this team roasted and done.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Telecom Concern Expects Loss
description: The Japan Telecom Company, the country's third-largest phone company, said it expected to lose two billion yen ($16.6 million) in the fiscal year ending March 2002, lowering its previous forecast for a small profit, because of competition among local service providers. The company also wrote off about $107 million in outdated cellular phones. Through several share purchases, the Vodafone Group of Britain has built a two-thirds stake in Japan Telecom, leading to talk it will sell the company's fixed-line operations to focus on the more profitable wireless provider, J-Phone Company Ltd. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Assembly's Vote Could Settle Democrats' Battle for Speaker
description: Representative Robert Menendez, the influential Hudson County Democrat, led a rally yesterday at City Hall in Jersey City, urging Governor-elect James E. McGreevey to support Assemblyman Joseph V. Doria Jr. of Bayonne in the increasingly fractious fight for leadership of the New Jersey General Assembly.

title: A 3rd Front: War's Spoils
description: The United States military created the conditions for the sudden and dramatic fall of Kabul to the Northern Alliance, with American advisers calling in punishing air strikes against Taliban forces.

title: Many Travelers Delay Flying, Holding Out for Cheaper Fares
description: A day after the American Airlines crash in Queens, travel agents reported scattered cancellations of airline bookings yesterday and signs of procrastination as leisure travelers held out hope that desperate carriers would slash fares to lure holiday business.

title: Footlights
description: Between Two Worlds

title: In 2 Presidents' Words: The 'New Relationship' Moves to Antiterrorism
description: Following are excerpts from a news conference by President Bush and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia today at the White House, as transcribed by the Federal News Service Inc. Mr. Putin's remarks were interpreted by a translator.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAVITZ, GERALD
description: RAVITZ-Gerald., D.P.M. 69. Of Smithtown, N.Y. on November 11, 2001. Loving husband of Thelma for 44 years. Adored and devoted father of Marjorie, Stephen and Suzanne, and father-in-law of Jeff and Elliot. Beloved grandfather of two grandsons. An all-around, great guy and he will be missed tremendously. Donations can be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: A Democrat's Mandate: No More Racial Division
description: Having just witnessed a bitter, racially divisive primary for mayor, the man who is poised to be the new leader of the state Democratic Party said yesterday that his mandate would be to avoid a bitter, racially divisive primary for governor next year.

title: Cablevision Says Its Loss Grew Wider In 3rd Quarter
description: The Cablevision Systems Corporation, the cable operator that owns Madison Square Garden and the New York Knicks, posted a wider third-quarter loss today after writing off some player contracts.

title: 150th Anniversary: 1851-2001; The Facts That Got Away
description: EINSTEIN once said, ''Whoever undertakes to set himself up as judge in the field of truth and knowledge is shipwrecked by the laughter of the Gods.''

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Tomorrow: Hearing On Board Of Education
description: The City Council has scheduled a public hearing on the Board of Education's performance after the Sept. 11 terror attack, including how it reassigned students following the attack and how it assessed air quality in Lower Manhattan schools. Committee Room, City Hall, Manhattan, 10 a.m. Information: 718-272-3050.

title: Ray Kelly, 83, Babe Ruth's Little Pal, Dies
description: Ray Kelly, who fulfilled the fantasy of every American boy when he became Babe Ruth's mascot and sat in the Yankees' dugout in a pinstripe uniform when Murderers' Row ruled the baseball world, died Sunday at his home in Valley Cottage, N.Y. He was 83.

title: Reducing the Fear That Arrives by Mail
description: To the Editor:

title: Arts Groups Helping Schools Deal With Disaster
description: In the anguished days after Sept. 11, as New York City schools offered counseling to children scarred by the terrorist attack, arts groups around the city were quietly planning their own forms of therapy.

title: China Seems Uncertain About Dealing Openly With AIDS
description: At the opening ceremony of China's much celebrated first conference about H.I.V. and AIDS, an anonymous H.I.V.-positive person delivered brief remarks -- from the corner of a darkened stage, lit by green glow sticks, so that his face could not be seen.

title: P.O.W.'s Were Shot; Question Is How Many?
description: Did Northern Alliance troops massacre 100, 200 or even 600 Taliban fighters after the alliance took control of the northern Afghan city of Mazar-i-Sharif last week?

title: Looking for bin Laden, Staving Off Chaos, Domestic Disquiet
description: Where's Osama? It is a somewhat crude way to frame the question. But among the many ''now what'' issues raised by the startlingly fast-paced events in Afghanistan, it remains the central American concern. Since Sept. 11, the main objective has been to track down Mr. bin Laden and destroy his terrorist network, Al Qaeda. Ridding Afghanistan of his Taliban protectors was a secondary goal, though obviously a big one. So Washington was delighted -- not to mention stunned -- to see the Taliban in full retreat from the capital, Kabul, as nearly half the country fell to the Northern Alliance.

title: Survey Finds Tougher Lending Practices by Banks
description: Banks imposed tougher standards on business and consumer loans over the last three months because of the slowing economy, a Federal Reserve survey of bank loan officers showed today. Loan demand also fell.

title: Resilient Nets Show Their Grit To Beat Pacers
description: Two weeks ago, the Nets opened their season with a flash of grit against the Indiana Pacers, storming to a surprising comeback victory.

title: House G.O.P. Rejects Stimulus-Bill 'Summit'
description: Senate leaders and the Bush administration agreed today to bipartisan high-level negotiations by Congress and the White House on an economic stimulus package, but House Republicans blocked any talks, at least for the moment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIES, NORMAN
description: DAVIES-Norman. On November 13, 2001. Beloved husband of Inez A. (nee Darin). Loving father of Ann McPherson, Penny Whipp and Elaina Hyde-Mills. Fond grandfather of six grandchildren & three great-grandchildren. Family receiving friends at the Leo F. Kearns Funeral Home, 85-66 115 Street, Richmond Hill, NY, on Thursday, 10AM-12PM. Religious service 11:30AM. Cremation Fresh Pond Crematory. As per family no flowers.

title: WASHINGTON TRUST BANCORP BUYING FIRST FINANCIAL
description: Washington Trust Bancorp, which has branches in Rhode Island and Connecticut, agreed to buy the First Financial Corporation for about $39 million in cash and stock. First Financial stockholders will get a combination of $16 in cash and 0.889 share of Washington Trust for each share. Based on an $18 price for Washington Trust, that would value First Financial at about $32 a share, Washington Trust's chairman, John Warren, said. First Financial is based in Rhode Island.

title: Citing Sept. 11, 2 Sides Avert Janitors' Strike
description: New York's largest janitors' union signed a tentative three-year agreement with the real estate industry yesterday, seven weeks before the contract deadline. Both sides said the surprise move was intended to minimize uncertainty during an anxious time for the city's businesses.

title: A Dash of Single Malt, and Voil
description: IN France, chestnuts and chocolate are often combined in cakes, particularly in the autumn, when chestnuts come into season. Sometimes a bit of alcohol, usually an Armagnac or Cognac, is included to accent the flavors. In this recipe, I do something different: I add single-malt Scotch whiskey. The woodsy, earthy flavors of the chestnuts marry really well with the smoky aroma of the Scotch. To me it seems a natural cold-weather combination.

title: David Hopkins, 79, Authority On Land Bridge of First Ice Age
description: Dr. David Moody Hopkins, an arctic geologist and leading authority on the land link that allowed ice age hunters to pursue their mammoth and mastodon prey from Siberia to Alaska nearly 12,000 years ago, died on Nov. 2 at his home in Menlo Park, Calif. He was 79.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCSHANE, TERENCE A.
description: McSHANE-Terence A. Of West Islip, L.I. Died heroically in the line of duty at the World Trade Center on September 11, 2001. Devoted husband of Cathy. Adored father of Aidan, Sean and Colin. Cherished son of Jeanne and the late John P. McShane. Beloved brother of Kieran M. McShane, Brian McShane, John McShane and Maribeth Eccleston. Dear sonin-law of Robert and Pauline Watt. Special uncle of John, Daniel and Kieran A. McShane. Cherished friend to all that knew him. Beloved brother Firefighter at Ladder 101 and Engine 202, Brooklyn, N.Y. and Engine 308 Queens, N.Y. Visitation Friday, November 16, 2001 2-5 PM and 7-9PM at Overlook Beach, Ocean Pkwy, Babylon, Long Island (4 miles west of Robert Moses Cswy. and 9 miles East of Wantagh Parkway). Celebration of the Liturgy of Christian Burial, Saturday November 17, 2001 at 10:15 AM Sts. Cyril and Methodius R.C. Church, Deer Park, L.I. Cremation private. In lieu of flowers, donations would be appreciated by his family to the Terence A. McShane Memorial Fund, C/O Merrill Lynch & Company, 125 High Street Tower, 19th Floor, Boston, MA. 02110, Attention: FA1260. For information The Fredrick J. Chapey & Sons West Islip Funeral Home.

title: Cruel 'New Normal' For Sept. 11 Widow
description: To the Editor:

title: Institute at Polytechnic to Promote Research
description: Polytechnic University has earmarked $25 million for an institute of interdisciplinary studies that will serve as an incubator for research in fields like photonics, biotechnology, signal processing and information management. The institute will provide seed money for faculty research at Polytechnic laboratories -- for example, in how to use fiber optics to detect impurities in groundwater, which requires work in biochemistry, physics and civil engineering. IVAN T. FRISCH, above, executive vice president and provost of the university, is acting director; a new director will be elected from among the institute's senior fellows in the next month. The $25 million is part of a $176 million bequest to the university by DONALD F. and MILDRED TOPP OTHMER in 1998.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLAVOTSKY, SONIA
description: SLAVOTSKY - Sonia. Beloved wife, daughter, mother and grandmother, friend and free spirit. Services held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam and 76th Street Wednesday, at 11:30AM.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday about a flag made of flowers in honor of Capt. Patrick Brown, a firefighter who died in the World Trade Center attack, misstated the location of his funeral on Friday. Although the family received visitors at the Frank E. Campbell funeral home in Manhattan, the Mass took place at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: A Nation Challenged
description: Change in Afghanistan

title: The Pied Piper
description: Ken Kesey conceived of the final scene of "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest," while on peyote working the night shift as an attendant in the psychiatric ward of a hospital.

title: A Direct Descendant Of the Plymouth Feast
description: NEXT Thursday, as they do every year, American families will sit down to a misapprehension. They will celebrate Thanksgiving in the belief that they are feasting on much the same dishes that were served at the first Thanksgiving in Plymouth, Mass., in 1621.

title: New Allies: One Trusts, The Other's Not So Sure
description: Ronald Reagan used to say about arms control agreements with the Soviet Union: ''Trust but verify.''

title: Channeling Ginger Rogers in a Seriocomic Dating History
description: There is hardly a cabaret performer in New York who couldn't learn something from Sally Mayes. The plucky platinum-haired singer and actress embodies a hard-shelled professionalism that is too often missing from the nightclub stage. Alternately sparkly and brassy, and exuding a determined can-do energy, Ms. Mayes, who is appearing at Arci's Place through Nov. 24, often suggests a contemporary cabaret descendant of Ginger Rogers.

title: Article 2001111491239511887 -- No Title
description: function pop_me_up(pURL, features) { new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features); new_window.focus(); } Tools for Staying in Touch By Voice, Touch or Even Sight, Plenty of Ways Not to Make Yourself Scarce

title: Start of Recession Thought to Be in March
description: The six economists who determine when recessions officially begin and end have publicly mentioned March for the first time as the month in which the longest economic expansion in American history ''possibly'' ended and the current recession ''possibly'' began.

title: The New York Times's N.F.L. Computer Ranking
description: The New York Times's computer football ranking is based on an analysis of each team's scores with emphasis on three factors: who won, by what margin and against what quality of opposition. The quality of an opponent is determined by examining the opponent's record against other teams.

title: Postwar Art Fails to Meet Expectations At Christie's
description: It may have been a good day for the stock market, but the rising Dow Jones industrial average did nothing to bolster the mood last night at Christie's. Its auction of postwar art was an anemic affair, bogged down in large part by too much German art.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Hynix To Raise Funds
description: Hynix Semiconductor has come up with another way to raise the funds it needs for survival. Hynix said on Monday that its shareholders had agreed to increase the number of shares from 1.5 billion to 9 billion and to double the ceiling for convertible bonds from three trillion won to six trillion won ($4.7 billion). Don Kirk (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Pushing Ahead With Land Reform
description: Moving to quicken the pace of land redistribution, the government has amended the law to allow officials to resettle blacks on white-owned farms before the farmers exhaust their legal appeals. Officials said farmers were flooding the courts with frivolous appeals in an effort to stymie the land reform program. Critics say the government hopes to speed the pace of land reform to win support before the presidential election, expected early next year. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RASKAS, ANNETTE
description: RASKAS-Annette. The Yeshiva University family and its affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary (RIETS) are saddened by the passing of a highly respected leader of the St. Louis Jewish community, matriarch of the Raskas family, wife of the late Ralph Raskas, of blessed memory, beloved mother of Yeshiva College and RIETS alumnus and Yeshiva College Board member, Stanley Raskas, who together with his wife, Sheri, are YU Guardians, Dr. Hershel (and Adina) Raskas, & Judy (and Dr. Robert) Hellman. Heartfelt condolences are also extended to her brothers Rabbi Samuel Geffen and Abraham Geffen; sisters Bessie Wilensky and Helen Ziff; 13 grandchildren, many of whom are YU alumni; 19 great grandchildren; and the entire Raskas family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Robert M. Beren, Chairman YU Board of Trustees Julius Berman, Chairman RIETS Board of Trustees

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DIMSTON, BLANCHE K.
description: DIMSTON-Blanche K. Happy Birthday Mom We will be at Pietro's.

title: Heart Patient In Experiment With Implant Suffers Stroke
description: Robert Tools, the first recipient of a self-contained artificial heart, has suffered a stroke, one of his doctors at Jewish Hospital in Louisville, Ky., said last night.

title: 150th Anniversary: 1851-2001; The Reporter's Reporter
description: NOTHING changed the nature of print journalism quite like the force of television. In the 1960's and 70's, the encyclopedic, omniscient style that had defined The Times was no longer enough. There had to be room for a subtler style of reporting, one that greatly enhanced the influence and judgment of the reporter on the ground. Reporters had to be able to go places that television's bulky cameras couldn't go, and produce stories that television, with its inherent limits of time and space, could not match.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Coalition Protests Bombing
description: A coalition of Seattle church groups and peace advocates are beginning a campaign to protest the bombing in Afghanistan. The Church Council of Seattle, joined by the Washington Association of Churches and 911 Peace Coalition, will sponsor four days of food drives and a 72-hour fast to protest the bombing's effect on the country. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: INSIDE
description: Cholesterol Drugs May Help In Heart-Attack Prevention

title: Top Teams Find Winning Keys on Ground
description: Turning the corner in the season means that you have played half the schedule and that you should have more answers than questions about what your team is and where it is going.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE ROTHSCHILD, DEBRA
description: de ROTHSCHILD-Debra. Our hearts are weeping over the loss of our good friend, Debra de Rothschild, dear departed wife of our Executive Committee Member and Founders Society Co-Chairman, Robert de Rothschild, and mother of sweet little Jacob Alain. Debra brightened any room she entered, and was always a good friend. Our hearts are broken for Robert & the Rothchild and Cohen families. A beautiful person, a beautiful life, cut far too short. May her memory be for a blessing. Irving M. Rosenbaum, National Chairman A. Arthur Sherman, Founders Society, Co-Chairman Eric G. Heffler, Executive Vice President American Friends of The Open University of Israel

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: America West Seeks Loan In First Application to U.S.

title: 3 Ex-Guards at Bosnia Camp Are Sentenced by Hague Panel
description: In its second trial focusing on a group of notorious Serbian prison camps in Bosnia, the United Nations tribunal in The Hague sent three former guards to prison today for the brutalities they committed at Keraterm, a crowded camp in a former ceramics factory.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 4 Accused In BB Attack On Joggers
description: Four teenage boys were charged with robbery and assault after they fired BB guns at the legs of two joggers in separate incidents in Central Park and demanded money from one of them, the police said yesterday. The two joggers, a 28-year-old man and a 26-year-old woman, were attacked on Monday night along the reservoir's running path, the police said. The four boys, whose names were not immediately released, were arrested around 7:40 p.m. and two BB guns were recovered, the police said. Both joggers, who were hit several times in the legs, were treated at area hospitals and released from area hospitals. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: Central Bank Cuts Rate in New Zealand
description: The central bank of New Zealand cut its key overnight lending rate to 4.75 percent from 5.25 percent yesterday, citing a weak economy that will probably stay sluggish in the near term. The cut was the fifth this year by the central bank.

title: N.B.A. and AOL Discuss Network
description: The N.B.A.'s television negotiations with AOL Time Warner are focused on creating a jointly owned network that could show the majority of the league's cable TV games, two industry officials said yesterday.

title: Earnings Rise At Wal-Mart, Home Depot And Penney
description: Wal-Mart Stores Inc. and Home Depot Inc. posted gains in third-quarter profits yesterday, while the J. C. Penney Company rebounded from a loss.

title: 150th Anniversary: 1851-2001; So Here's What's Happening to Language
description: WRITTEN English, which reigned as America's national language for most of The New York Times's 150 years, has been dethroned. The spoken word now rules, in all its informality and occasional vulgarity. The effects are felt in politics, public taste and even in our writing.

title: Italy Wrapped Up
description: Italiatour, the tour division of Alitalia, has off-season packages to Rome, Florence or Naples starting at $599 a person, double occupancy, and Venice for $699. That includes round-trip flights from Kennedy Airport, Newark, Boston, Chicago or Miami (from Los Angeles, add $100), five nights' accommodations, Continental breakfast, a half-day city tour and hotel service charges and V.A.T. For Rome, airport transfers are also included. Departures run from Nov. 16 through Dec. 15 and Jan. 4 to March 10 (Venice dates vary). The hotels include the Portamaggiore in Rome, the Garden in Naples, the Martelli and San Giorgio in Florence and the Olimpias in Venice. Information, (800) 845-3365 or www.italiatour.com .

title: Jet's Cockpit Voice Recorder Reveals Rattle Before Crash
description: Investigators said yesterday that the cockpit voice recorder of American Airlines Flight 587 picked up sounds of the jet's frame rattling shortly before the pilots lost control of the plane, but no noises that they characterized as an explosion.

title: Bush Orders Oil Reserve Filled to Maximum
description: President Bush ordered the Energy Department today to increase the United States' emergency supply of oil, the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, to its capacity over the next few years, the first time it will be full.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: INVESTCORP, Manama, Bahrain, an investment and holding company, bought Neptune Technology Group, the water meter business of Schlumberger Ltd., New York, the world's second-largest provider of oil field services. Terms were not disclosed.

title: 150th Anniversary: 1851-2001; Sports and The Times: At Last, a Full Embrace
description: THE Times has always had an idiosyncratic relationship with sports. It's not that we don't love them. It's just that we're not always sure we should love them well, so we tend to love them wisely.

title: Agents Raid Residences After Tip On Anthrax
description: Acting on a tip related to the anthrax investigation, more than 30 federal agents, backed up by hazardous material crews, raided two residences here today, carrying off plastic bags of belongings, questioning some of the occupants and sealing the property with yellow tape.

title: Reducing the Fear That Arrives by Mail; The Electronic Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: 150th Anniversary: 1851-2001; The Addiction Begins
description: By modern standards, the first daily crossword puzzle in The Times was not particularly memorable. Its theme, New York City's water supply, was . . . well, a bit dry. The key names were scattered around the grid, not symmetrical as they would be now. The grid included an abbreviation that was almost unheard of (52-Across), numerous obscurities (38-Across, for example) and a clue too vague to pass muster today (21-Across). Not a single humorous, punning or misleading element could be found.

title: As a Last Resort, Eisley Is the Knicks' Best Option
description: The last resort strolled stoically to the scorer's table with less than four minutes left in the third quarter last night, his new team in the midst of another collapse. It had been more than six months since he last played in an N.B.A. game, but Howard Eisley refused to let fear or the thought of being unprepared creep into his mind.

title: Business Travel; After Monday's crash, CNN Airport Network gave travelers a singing cowboy instead of news.
description: USUALLY, those televisions hanging overhead in airport passenger-waiting areas drive me to distraction with their announcers constantly braying about some company's stock price or some windstorm in the Caribbean.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Nov. 3 about Hellmut Alexander Lehmann-Haupt, known as Sandy, who was one of the Merry Pranksters on the novelist Ken Kesey's psychedelic bus in the 1960's, misstated the cause of his death and omitted the names of his mother and some survivors. Mr. Lehmann-Haupt died of a pulmonary embolism, not a heart attack, his family said. He was the son of Hellmut Lehmann-Haupt and Letitia Grierson. Survivors include a half sister, Roxana Lehmann-Haupt, and a half brother, John Lehmann-Haupt, both of Manhattan.

title: 150th Anniversary: 1851-2001; When Newspapers Were Newsmakers
description: I MAKE news,'' boasted James Gordon Bennett Jr. He was full of himself, as usual. But make news he did, with deep pockets and commanding zeal. As owner of The New York Herald after the Civil War, Bennett would not wait for news to just happen. He dispatched reporters far and wide with orders to send back sensational copy of adventure and discovery, anything to capture the essence of a time of expanding horizons and, not incidentally, to win readers away from the competition.

title: Bob Eckhardt, 88; Served 14 Years in U.S. House
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14  Bob Eckhardt, who survived for 14 years in Congress as a liberal Democrat from Houston despite a constituency that was considerably to his right politically, died on Tuesday in his hometown of Austin, Tex. He was 88.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Lisa Balshan was named to the new post of senior vice president for national promotions at the New York office of New Line Cinema. She had been vice president for strategic marketing at Loews Cineplex Entertainment, New York. New Line is a subsidiary of AOL Time Warner. Also at New Line, David Sporn, executive director for business affairs administration, was named vice president.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Blue Martini In Sprint Deal
description: Blue Martini Software Inc., a maker of customer relationship applications, said Sprint would use Blue Martini software to help manage and expand the SprintPCS.com e-commerce Web site, adding to a customer list that also includes Levi Strauss, Harley-Davidson and Stanford University. Currently, SprintPCS customers can log onto the SprintPCS.com site to buy service plans and merchandise, manage their accounts and get technical support. Blue Martini's software will extend those capabilities by adding personalization and advanced commerce features, as well as improved customer service. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: After Hitler, Bin Laden Isn't So Scary; In Response to Terror, A New Generation Gap
description: Jess Biblowitz remains calm in the face of menace, uneasy about the stock market and the possibility of a military draft but not given to apocalyptic visions. Roy Kean feels swells of patriotism that send him browsing the ''help wanted'' page on the C.I.A. Web site. David Diggs plans to leave New York City, join his girlfriend in the Middle West and find a secure job in what has become an insecure economy.

title: 150th Anniversary: 1851-2001; Turning Away From the Holocaust
description: AND then there was failure: none greater than the staggering, staining failure of The New York Times to depict Hitler's methodical extermination of the Jews of Europe as a horror beyond all other horrors in World War II -- a Nazi war within the war crying out for illumination.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices Uphold 2-Year Deadline on Suing Credit Raters
description: Federal law gives people whose credit ratings have been damaged by a credit reporting company's mistake only two years from the date of the mistake to file a lawsuit, the Supreme Court ruled today, even if the mistake does not come to light until later. The vote was 9 to 0.

title: 150th Anniversary: 1851-2001; Six Buildings That Share One Story
description: MID-MANHATTAN has one of America's great newspaper buildings. White as a web of fresh newsprint, terse as a punchy bulletin, it celebrates the masses and proclaims journalism's global reach. Clark Kent and Lois Lane would feel right at home. In fact, it was where they worked in the movie ''Superman.''

title: Guarding Our Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Anxiety in the Air
description: To soar 30,000 feet above the earth is an inherently anxious experience. It seems to violate the laws of nature -- of human nature, at least. At some primitive level, we've always known this, but over the last few decades, and particularly in the last few years, the airline industry has dedicated itself to masking this ancient suspicion.

title: To Help the Elderly
description: To the Editor:

title: Devils' Turnovers Add Up to Defeat
description: Avoid turnovers. That was the message on the board in the Devils' dressing room before tonight's game, and Coach Larry Robinson reminded his players orally in case someone missed reading the board.

title: It's On With the Show, for Those Who Need It
description: NOT long after Sept. 11, the full vision came to the director Jeff Cohen -- in a dream. No, really. His reverie was all about Queen Esther, a downtown cabaret diva, who was the M.C. for a U.S.O.-style variety show for World Trade Center disaster workers. ''I usually never even remember my dreams,'' Mr. Cohen said. ''This one I remembered. Two weeks later, the dream was reality.''

title: Specialists Set Up Shop With Long List of Possible Causes to Pursue or Cross Out
description: At the charred crash site in the Rockaways, in hangars at Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn, and in laboratories in Washington, an enormous investigative army settled in yesterday to seek the cause of the crash of American Airlines Flight 587.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Koreas: Warming Trend Continues
description: North and South Korea agreed to hold a new round of family reunification visits in December and extended their talks, originally scheduled for three days, to a fifth day to discuss economic issues. In a major concession by South Korea, the family meetings will take place at the isolated North Korean resort where the current talks are being held; three previous rounds of family meetings were held in both countries. The Koreas also agreed to hold the next round of talks in Seoul at a date to be set later. Howard W. French (NYT)

title: 'Klinghoffer' Composer Fights His Cancellation
description: Boston Symphony officials are sympathetic but unapologetic. The composer is still angry.

title: Afghan Warfare: Taliban Trick Throws Rebels Into Retreat
description: The scene was set today for Northern Alliance troops to make another triumphant entrance into a city taken from the Taliban. Then everything went wrong.

title: A Polish Provocateur Trashes Decorum
description: Nose-thumbing outrageousness is the leading spirit of ''Ferdydurke,'' the 1937 satirical novel by the Polish writer Witold Gombrowicz. And it is a quality that is more than preserved in the stage adaptation of that book being presented at La MaMa through Nov. 25.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Yahoo To Feature Paid Search Results
description: Yahoo, by far the biggest search engine on the Internet, said it would display listings from sites that pay money ahead of sites that were chosen by its editors. The paid listings will be provided by Overture Services, formerly GoTo.com, which has similar arrangements with America Online, Lycos and parts of Microsoft's MSN. Overture runs an auction among advertising sites, which bid how much they will pay each time users click on the link to their site; those that offer the largest payments are listed first. On Yahoo, the five top-paying sites will be listed first, in a section called ''sponsored matches'' above its other listings. The deal will last for six months, after which Yahoo will decide if it will sell its own paid listings or continue using those from Overture. Neither company would discuss the financial terms of the deal. In Overture's deal with AOL, it agreed to share the revenue from the listings with a minimum of $50 million over 18 months. Yahoo is under enormous pressure to find new sources of revenue to replace advertising from Internet companies. It is holding an analyst meeting Thursday to detail its plans for investors. Saul Hansell (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Recount Confirms Mayoral Result
description: A recount in Atlanta's mayor's race has confirmed that Shirley Clarke Franklin became the first woman to be elected mayor last week. The recount, requested by Ms. Franklin's primary challenger, Robb Pitts, the City Council president, gave Ms. Franklin a victory with 50.23 percent of the vote in a multicandidate field or 188 votes more than a majority. The original tally gave her 191 votes more than a majority. The results are expected to be certified today. Kevin Sack (NYT)

title: Boldface Names
description: Two Michaels in the Datebook

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORNREICH, DORIS J. (NEE GREENBERG)
description: KORNREICH-Doris J. (nee Greenberg) aka Doris Schwarz and Doris Deutsch. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin Kornreich, loving mother of Ronald and Richard Deutsch, devoted sister of Sissy Greenberg, adored aunt, cousin and wonderful friend to many. Services Wednesday, 11:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Contributions in her memory may be made to Israel Humanitarian Foundation for the Doris Kornreich Art and Music Project, 276 Fifth Avenue, Suite 901, New York, New York 10001.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKEON, GEORGE P.
description: McKEON-George P. Of Mt. Pleasant, SC. Died on November 11. Mass of Christian Burial will be Thursday morning in Christ Our King Catholic Church. Contact: J. Henry Stuhr, Inc., MT. Pleasant Chapel. (843)881-9293. Born in New York City. Was a member of the Lions Club International and Alumni Federation of New York University. Survived by wife, Kathleen McGuire McKeon, son, George P. McKeon, Jr. Daughters, Mary Beth Dacey, Kathleen Graham, Bernadette Hohenadel and six grandchildren. Memorials may be made to Christ Our King Catholic Church, Building Fund, 1122 Russell Dr, MT. Pleasant, SC 29464.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOW, ARTHUR J.
description: LOW-Arthur J. On November 12, 2001. Beloved husband of Marjorie. Loving father of Peter and Peggy Low, and Babette R. Low, C.S.W., and Alan Lintz. Adoring grandfather of Amy and David Chasen and John Low. Retired long-time member of the New York Stock Exchange and pasthistorian of its Buttonwood Club. Services are today 12:45 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. You will be in our hearts forever.

title: 10 Nations Look Like Prospects For Joining the European Union
description: The European Union announced today that as many as 10 countries from Southern and Central Europe may be allowed to join by 2004.

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: For the Holidays, Cocktail Party in a Box
description: Instead of serving onion dip with cocktails, how about surprising the guests? They can nibble molasses-tequila-cured salmon on corn pancakes with lime cilantro cream (ingredients above in box); sun-dried tomato polenta with wild mushroom ragout and truffle oil (on tray); steamed dumplings with roasted peanut sauce (in steamer); and sugar-cane skewered shrimp with spicy mango glaze.

title: President Bush's Order on the Trial of Terrorists by Military Commission
description: Following is the military order signed by President Bush yesterday on the detention, treatment and trial of noncitizens in the war on terrorism:

title: The Jets Salute an Ogre: It's Shrek, Not Thomas
description: Only a team with a finely honed sense of self-deprecation, a team willing to proclaim Shrek, the big green movie monster, as its mascot, can truly appreciate the words that will be posted in its locker room this week.

title: More Loss: Disaster on Rockaway
description: To the Editor:

title: 150th Anniversary: 1851-2001; Fool or Prophet? No, Just a Critic
description: WHAT do they mean?'' asked The New York Times, eyebrow arched and mouth agape, in 1911. ''Have those responsible for them taken leave of their senses? Is this art or madness? Who knows?''

title: Pashtuns in Exile Seem Determined to Fight for Power, if Not for Land
description: The news that Kabul had fallen to the Northern Alliance at dawn today did not sit well with Hajji Zaman Khan Ghum Shariq. As the blitzkrieg from the north raced through Afghanistan, far ahead of the world's diplomacy, it did not sit very well at all.

title: AXCELIS PURSUING PLAN TO REDUCE ITS WORK FORCE BY 20%
description: Axcelis Technologies, a semiconductor equipment maker, will reduce its work force by 20 percent of December 2000 levels and consolidate equipment production to lower costs. The company will begin eliminating about 180 jobs immediately, a spokeswoman said. It has already cut about 16 percent of its work force from the December 2000 level of 2,200, she said. The changes are to be completed by the third quarter of 2002.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We just need the one who wants peace and stability in the country. We just want that one.''

title: Burger King Names McCaffery Ratner
description: The Burger King Corporation in Miami, part of Diageo ( news/quote ), has named McCaffery Ratner Gottlieb & Lane in New York to handle several project assignments including product advertising and the development of local and national promotions centered on music and radio. Billings were not disclosed.

title: A Plane Crash Deeply Wounds a City's Dominican Heart
description: Washington Heights had a facade of normalcy about it yesterday. Traffic was bumper-to-bumper on Broadway. Schools and bodegas were open. Beauty salons and lunch counters were full.

title: New Findings Point to Anthrax Letter to State Dept.
description: New evidence has been found that mail containing anthrax spores was sent last month to the State Department, which has begun to examine stacks of impounded mail in search of one or more contaminated letters, the department spokesman said today.

title: Miscellany
description: * Fleishman-Hillard, St. Louis, the public relations agency owned by the Omnicom Group, and Fuld & Company, Cambridge, Mass., a business intelligence consulting company, formed a partnership enabling them to offer clients access to each other's services. Terms were not disclosed.

title: FORD PERSUADES JUDGE TO REDUCE JURY AWARD TO VICTIMS
description: The Ford Motor Company persuaded a Florida judge to cut a $30.7 million jury award to the family of a child who was injured when the Ford van in which she was riding rolled over. The judge said that he cut the award to about $13 million after reviewing a recent Florida appeals court ruling on damages and jurors' finding that the girl was 50 percent responsible for her injuries by not wearing a seat belt. ''This is a reminder from the court that seat belts can help protect passengers only when they are worn,'' said Kathleen Vokes, a Ford spokeswoman. Mary Phyllis Jimenez, 12, was hurt in May 1999 after her family's Ford Econoline van rolled over after a tire blew out. One person died in the wreck. Ms. Jimenez suffered brain damage.

title: Teachers' Union Wins Court Ruling on Pensions
description: The United Federation of Teachers has won an appellate court ruling allowing teachers to count hourly wages, in addition to regular school time, as part of their pensionable income. The issue of so-called per-session pay had become more pressing in the last two years as the Board of Education made summer-school and after-school programs regular features of the school year. Teachers earned $232 million in per-session pay last year, up from about $95 million two years earlier, court papers say. Under the teachers' contract, the per-session rate is about $33 an hour. In the ruling on Thursday, the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Manhattan found that the additional hours worked amount to ''vital components of the education experience'' and should be rewarded as such. Anemona Hartocollis

title: Liberties; Go Fly A Kite, Taliban
description: Our new friends in Afghanistan celebrated taking Kabul. They played some music. They flew a kite. They put a woman newscaster on the radio. They killed some people just because it felt good.

title: 150th Anniversary: 1851-2001; Beyond (and Behind) the Stock Tables
description: WHEN the New-York Daily Times made its debut on Sept. 18, 1851, it provided what was deemed to be a requirement of a serious newspaper, even then: stock tables and an article on what had moved the market.

title: Russia Seeks Belated Peace Dividend
description: The people who run Russia's companies and oversee its economy did not draft a formal wish list of economic measures for President Vladimir V. Putin to raise with George Bush as they meet this week. That is because what they want from the United States can be boiled down to one point: stop treating Russia like an enemy economy.

title: Civility and Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBINSON, HUBERT S. (ROBBIE)
description: ROBINSON-Hubert S. (Robbie) 1919-2001. In loving memory of a cherished friend and colleague. Robbie will be remembered by the former production staff of Dell-Publishing Co. for his wisdom, patience and humanity. Our deepest sympathy to his loving family, wife Evelyn, daughters, Karen, Donna, Margi and Colleen, their partners and children. Memorial donations may be made to the Ralph T. Waterman Bird Club C/O Allan Michelin, 23 High View Road, Wappingers Falls, NY 12590.

title: Strong New York Ties Bind Families in Grief
description: The 15 years that Diego Lugo owned several bodegas in Brooklyn left him scarred with bullet holes in his arm, his leg and his head from three violent robberies. It was the price he paid for a better life, working 12-hour days alongside his wife, Ramona Pimentel, as they saved money to return in 1997 to this town, which they had fled after Hurricane David devastated the island and its economy.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Infineon Posts Wider Loss
description: Hammered by collapsing prices for computer chips, Infineon said today that its loss had widened to 523 million euros ($468 million) in the quarter ended Sept. 30. Sales were down 54 percent from the period last year. The results were not as bad as analysts had feared, and Infineon shares gained slightly. But company executives warned that losses would continue until there was a recovery in the market for D-RAM memory chips, where prices have dropped from $15 to about $1 in the last year. Memory chips were Infineon's biggest business a year ago, but its sales in that segment have been down 81 percent since then. Infineon was also hurt by cutbacks in the telecommunications industry. The good news was that Infineon's sales declined less than the market as a whole, and the company still has about $500 million in cash as a result of a capital increase last July and the sale of its infrared products business.

title: 150th Anniversary: 1851-2001; Investigative Reporting Was Young Then
description: IN the late 1800's, William Marcy Tweed loomed singular. Grand sachem of the powerful Tammany Hall organization that reigned over New York politics, Boss Tweed had a stranglehold on the Democratic Party and much of city and state government in New York. By 1868, he controlled thousands of patronage jobs and various million-dollar public works contracts. A bankrupt chair maker only a few years before, Tweed occupied a stunning Manhattan mansion. He owned a yacht. Diamonds sparkled on his shirt and fingers.

title: Restoring the Heart of Ford
description: In 1992, when Nicholas V. Scheele took the reins of the Ford Motor Company's recently acquired Jaguar luxury division, J. D. Power ranked the Jaguar's quality one notch above that of a Yugo.

title: Students Discuss Foreign Policy at West Point
description: About 180 American students and 45 international students and Fulbright scholars will gather today at the United States Military Academy at West Point for the 53rd annual Student Conference on United States Affairs. The students will participate in round-table discussions to determine what United States foreign policy should be in particular regions, said Capt. MARTHA VANDRIEL, executive secretary of the conference. ''At the end of the conference, each round table produces a policy memo. In the process, the students discover how hard it is to create a policy and come up with a consensus.'' After the conference, students' reports will be posted for a year on West Point's Web site, at www.dean.usma.edu/sosh. The conference, to continue through Saturday, happens to fall this year during International Education Week, a week designated by the Education and State Departments to promote foreign affairs studies and exchanges.

title: Editors' Note; SPECIAL TODAY
description: 150, and Counting

title: An Update of Genesis, Leaning Toward Yiddish
description: Imagine a Book of Genesis in which Adam sits in a beach chair in the Garden of Eden, wearing sunglasses and a florid sport shirt and holding a reflector under his chin, the better to tan. Imagine Cain as an ax-wielding child in a cowboy suit. Or three angels as the Three Stooges in the story of Abraham. Imagine Esau as a biker like Marlon Brando in ''The Wild One.'' Imagine the wily Laban, who tricks Jacob into marrying his daughter Leah rather than Rachel, as a top-hatted, slouching Groucho Marx, complete with rubber duck.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINBERG, ABNER W.
description: FEINBERG-Abner W. On 8 November 2001 our Dad died in Scottsdale, Arizona of pneumonia at age 96 after seventy years of ardent involvement with the legal profession, 50 in active practice and 20 more as a special student at Arizona State University College of Law. Dad graduated from Columbia College in 1924 and from New York University School of Law in 1928. He then specialized in corporate, banking and life insurance law in Jersey City while living in South Orange, New Jersey. He was active in the Village of South Orange affairs.
