Temple Israel and Jewish Community groups. New Jersey Bar Association committees and numerous charitable organizations. He had two very happy relationships: first with our mother Jeanette who died in 1984 and later with Mrs. Ruth Einhorn. Besides his children Ellen and Jack, he leaves many friends and relatives who thought he was a very special person. Dad requested that any contributions be made to the American Red Cross, the American Jewish Committee or Arizona State University College of Law.

title: THE BOSS; An Emblem for a Career
description: Thirty years ago, when I was working for the Scripps-Howard Broadcasting Company in Cleveland, I suggested that the company buy a lighthouse to use as an employees' retreat. After all, the company's corporate logo was a lighthouse, and I couldn't imagine a more serene or inviting getaway. These structures represent a safe harbor, good deeds and selfless service to humanity. My boss didn't like the idea. He told me I was a crazy romantic. So I started looking for another job.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILDIN, LUCILLE
description: GILDIN-Lucille. Beloved wife of David. Mother of Beth, Marsha and Janis. Grandmother and great grandmother. Sister of Ira Miller and aunt of many nieces and nephews. Passed away peacefully at home. Funeral services Wednesday, November 14, at 11:15 AM at Riverside Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Fashioning a Real Life Amid Slogans and Archetypes.
description: ''Man, who the hell is Willie Horton?'' a character erupts toward the end of the multimedia jazz opera ''Three Willies.'' He, in his living room -- and the audience, at the Kitchen -- have now seen the infamous 1988 pro-George Bush television commercial for the fourth time. ''They put that picture up there like we're supposed to -- know -- him!''

title: Chekhov Transposed in Sex and Tempo
description: Chekhov was not the winner in Monday night's ''Three Sisters'' at the Thtre du Chtelet, but perhaps he was not meant to be. Peter Eotvos's opera advertises not only Russian soul but Zen art; and doing so, it poses a question. Are the two elements to mingle, or will one lead to the other? Does an original setting survive its new and exotic climate, or does the new replace the old?

title: Moist Brined Turkey Ready to Go
description: As if there was not enough to do to prepare for Thanksgiving, now the experts are saying that to get a wonderfully moist and flavorful turkey, brining is a must. But is there really enough room in the refrigerator for a turkey submerged in gallons of liquid for two days? This year, Matthew Lanes (below), the chef at Gourmet Garage in SoHo, will do it for you. Turkeys for brining must be ordered no later than Sunday. There's an extra charge of $1 a pound for the brining. Gourmet Garage sells Murray's and Bell & Evans turkeys for $1.99 a pound and D'Artagnan organic turkeys for $4.99 a pound. Brined turkeys can be picked up next Wednesday at the SoHo store, 453 Broome Street (Mercer Street) or can be delivered for a $10 fee. Orders are taken by the catering department, (212) 941-5850.

title: National Briefing | South: Fraternity Members In Blackface
description: Fraternities at two Southern universities have been seriously disciplined because members in blackface attended Halloween parties. At Auburn University in Alabama, Beta Theta Pi was disbanded and banished from campus after an Oct. 25 party at which some members painted their faces and wore Afro wigs. Another Auburn fraternity, Delta Sigma Phi, has been suspended by the university because of an Oct. 27 party at which one member was photographed in a Ku Klux Klan costume pretending to hang another member in blackface. At the University of Mississippi, officials have suspended Alpha Tau Omega for at least one year because a member costumed as a police officer pointed a gun at a man in blackface. Kevin Sack (NYT)

title: Immigrant Muslim Workers: Few Drive Taxis, Many Are Managers
description: Ask someone living in New York City what most Arab and Muslim immigrants do for a living and the first reply is likely to be: Taxi driver.

title: Canada's Top Book Prize Spotlights the Provincial
description: In recent years Canadian literary critics have been asking why so many Canadian fiction writers confine themselves to provincial, even small-town themes. The answer may lie in the rewards. Last week Canada's biggest literary prize went to ''Clara Callan,'' a slow-moving, low-key novel couched mostly in the form of letters between two sisters from small-town Ontario traveling sharply divergent paths to maturity.

title: Community Service 101
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Move to Extend Scope of Payroll Tax
description: The Internal Revenue Service issued regulations today requiring companies and employees to pay the 15.3 percent payroll tax on the exercise of incentive stock options and proceeds from employee stock purchase plans.

title: More Loss: Disaster on Rockaway
description: To the Editor:

title: 150th Anniversary: 1851-2001; Banner Headlines and Comic Strips
description: IF you live to 150 and are open to change, slow though it may occasionally be, you will do a great many things for the first time. So it has been with The New York Times since it began publication a century and a half ago.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOLDBERG, FANNY
description: GOLDBERG-Fanny. November 14, 1971. Loved and remembered forever. Rachel, Jay, Edward, and Grandchildre

title: CUTS WILL COST KODAK AT LEAST $200 MILLION
description: The Eastman Kodak Company will have at least $200 million in fourth-quarter expenses for severance packages and costs related to the elimination of as many as 4,000 jobs. The amount may increase because of nonpersonnel-related expenses, Kodak said in a filing Friday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The company, based in Rochester, announced the job cuts on Oct. 24. Kodak expects to save as much as $450 million next year through the cuts. The cuts will bring Kodak's work force cuts to 7,500 this year.

title: From 'The Joy of Cooking' to Frida Kahlo
description: LAURA BUSH has a large collection of cookbooks that she dips into just for the pleasure of reading them. But when it's time to cook, she reaches for the tried and true. ''These are the ones I refer to most over the years,'' she said. ''The common theme is that these are regionals, and they have recipes for the kind of food we like, Southwestern.''

title: Shift From Food Stamps To Private Aid Widens
description: Five years after the government scaled back its responsibility for the poor, more people get food from private charities over the course of the year than participate in the federal government's food stamp program, according to a yearlong survey to be released on Wednesday.

title: Rivals Are Best of Friends
description: Geno Auriemma and Jim Foster grew up as basketball fans and buddies in the Philadelphia suburbs. They became two of the most successful coaches of college women. They are still the best of friends and have long phone conversations maybe twice a week. But they have never scheduled games against each other's teams, because friends don't play basketball games against friends if they don't have to.

title: The Essence of Home Cooking, Puerto Rican-Style
description: DECADES ago, restaurants liked to boast, paradoxically, of their ''home cooking.'' This was particularly true of roadside diners and cafes, where travelers in the years before interstates, jet planes and conference centers sought refuge from the hard, dusty miles. But it was also true in the urban hangouts and neighborhood joints that were homes-away-from-homes for new city dwellers, many of whom had left their families in rural America.

title: U.S. Rescues 8 Aid Workers South of Kabul
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Thursday, Nov. 15 -- More than three months after being detained in Afghanistan by the Taliban on charges of preaching Christianity, eight Western aid workers, including two Americans, were rescued today by United States military helicopters and flown to Pakistan, United States officials said tonight.

title: 150th Anniversary: 1851-2001; The Assignment Is to Get the Story, but the Image Can Rise to Art
description: ON the days just after, we paused, many of us, to look at the photographs of the events that had seemed to rush by on the streets and on our televisions. We woke up, hoping it wasn't true, to check with the newspapers whose still images of the smoking towers and fleeing people confirmed what had happened. They gave us a chance, which we reluctantly needed, to grasp the unimaginable by stopping time, as still images do. Instead of the same endless video loop of jets going into the World Trade Center towers that we had watched on Sept. 11, until it had almost become a blur, we saw details:

title: 150th Anniversary: 1851-2001; If It's So Light, Why Is It So Serious? Shapes That Lift the Spirit
description: THE conventional wisdom is that there are good restaurants that the critics favor, and then there are stylish restaurants; good clothes, and stylish ones. And most of the time, it's the stylish ones that make the news. That is true today, and it was true 150 years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEXNER, BELLA
description: WEXNER-Bella. The officers, Board of Trustees and staff of the Leo Yassenoff Jewish Community Center of Greater Columbus mourn the passing of Bella Wexner, mother of Leslie Wexner and Susan Wexner, a true philanthropist, a leader whose lifelong devotion to the Jewish Community throughout the United States and Israel was deeply felt. She was a generous supporter of the Jewish Community in Columbus, in particular, the Wexner Heritage Village. Her dedication to Israel included many philanthropic projects. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to Leslie, Abigail and to the entire Wexner family. She will be sorely missed. Jeff Coopersmith, President Joel Dinkin, Executive Director

title: Catholic Bishops Elect First Black President
description: Bishop Wilton D. Gregory was elected president of the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops today, the first African-American named to the office.

title: Where Warheads Are Made, and Where a Good Pair of Pliers Can Put Them to Rest
description: Experts on nuclear arms are uncertain how many weapons would actually be dismantled under President Bush's proposal and how many simply placed in some kind of storage, where they would no longer be ''operationally deployed,'' in his words.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Teaching Kids History
description: To the Editor:

title: Mother Drowned Daughter, 4, In Exorcism Rite, Police Say
description: A Washington Heights woman was charged yesterday in the drowning death of her 4-year-old daughter, and officials said the woman told investigators that she had been trying to exorcise the child of demons.

title: An Agency's New Role
description: To the Editor:

title: Cuomo Says Pataki's Plan Imperils Aid To New York
description: Andrew M. Cuomo, one of the Democrats seeking to challenge Gov. George E. Pataki in next year's gubernatorial race, today accused him of jeopardizing New York's chances of getting aid from Washington to help the state recover from the recent terrorist attack.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Standards Put Compaq In No. 1 Spot
description: A Compaq supercomputer made up of more than 3,000 processors is currently the world's most powerful computing system, according to new measurement standards released yesterday by IDC. A 256-processor Hewlett-Packard Superdome led in the category of business computers costing more than $1 million. A Silicon Graphics Origin computer led the $250,000-to-$1 million-category and another Hewlett-Packard unit topped the under-$250,000 rankings. The new supercomputing performance standards, developed with industry help, are intended to replace former speed ratings that often departed so radically from computer performance on real-world problems that potential customers came to ignore them. The new standards include processor speed, memory capacity, and scalability tests. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: BUSH SETS OPTION OF MILITARY TRIALS IN TERRORIST CASES
description: President Bush signed an order today allowing special military tribunals to try foreigners charged with terrorism. A senior administration official said that any such trials would ''not necessarily'' be public and that the American tribunals might operate in Pakistan and Afghanistan.

title: 150th Anniversary: 1851-2001; Reported From Afar, Yet Close to Home
description: The Slaveowner's Fear

title: U.S. Arsenal: Treaties vs. Nontreaties
description: President Bush did not mention it, but the arms control approach he presented today would undo one of the signal accomplishments of his father's administration: the ban on multiple-warhead missiles based on land.

title: Spanish Police Arrest 11 Accused of Working for bin Laden
description: The Spanish police arrested 11 people today, mostly Islamic warriors with experience in Afghanistan or Bosnia, and accused them of recruiting volunteers to carry out attacks on behalf of Osama bin Laden's terrorist network, Al Qaeda. It was the second time in two months that Spain had dismantled a cell connected to Mr. bin Laden.

title: Stuffing, With Crunch
description: WHEN it comes to Thanksgiving dinner, most people want what they've always had; it is a holiday of traditions that aren't messed with much. I'm no exception to that rule.

title: The Taliban Fade Away, But Remain A Threat
description: In the end, the Taliban left Kabul as they arrived five years ago, fading away in ghostly fashion at the dead of night, in their pickup trucks, with all the weapons they could carry.

title: Our Towns; Hail the Mayor (Whose Name Isn't Giuliani)
description: GLEN GILMORE, the Anthrax Mayor, became a national hero for his quick response in mid-October after it was discovered that all three anthrax letters had passed through the regional postal facility here. Often the mayor was a step ahead of federal, state and postal officials in looking out for the more than 1,000 Hamilton postal workers. On Friday, Oct. 19, he made a decision -- when state leaders would not -- that helped avert a panic and should be a case study for any public health official trying to learn from the anthrax crisis.

title: Everything for the Feast, Except the Food
description: All the equipment necessary for roasting and carving a turkey, making gravy, mashing potatoes and baking pies is on hand at an engaging new shop, the Art of Cooking, 555 Hudson Street (11th Street). The owner, Kate Humphrey (right), has given the place a warm, almost colonial look with rustic cabinets (all for sale) alongside shelves filled with the latest in pots, pans and professional baking tins. Worth noting is a novel nonstick roasting rack (above), which slants toward a container, to catch the drippings ($22.50). The container is skimpy, so juices must be siphoned off during roasting. Ms. Humphrey also sells candles, simple white dinnerware and, for those who still iron, pastel linen cocktail napkins ($1.50 each).

title: More Loss: Disaster on Rockaway
description: To the Editor:

title: His Season's Dream Fulfilled, Johnson Wins 4th Cy Young
description: Almost 20 years ago, Joe McIlvaine, then the Mets' scouting director, took note of a gangly, absurdly tall 18-year-old left-handed pitcher for Livermore High School in California. This kid will be boom or bust, McIlvaine wrote in his report. A real gamble. McIlvaine could tell that with his long arms, the kid might one day dominate left-handed hitters. But, he wrote, he has a long way to go.

title: New Rules for Weapons Cuts
description: The last time American and Russian leaders stepped into the East Room of the White House to initiate a new round of nuclear arms reductions, in 1987, they signed an elaborate, painstakingly negotiated treaty. Yesterday George W. Bush and Vladimir Putin used the same setting to unveil a very different approach. President Bush announced steep cuts in America's nuclear arsenal, which President Putin later in the day said he would match. No legally binding treaties were presented or signed. This new method has its advantages. Legislative action in Washington and Moscow, for example, is not needed. It also has some disadvantages. These include the possibility that either party will simply change its mind.

title: Parrish: For Team, Maybe for Country
description: Mark Parrish's life has suddenly become much more complicated, but in a good way. He was an underachieving player on a terrible team a year ago. Now he is the top goal-scorer for the Islanders, the story of the year so far in the N.H.L., and one challenge has been split into two.

title: Looking Back Is Not Moving the Giants Forward
description: There are two words holding the Giants back, two words that are spoken by someone at Giants Stadium every day, two words that the Giants have to forget if they want to make something of the rest of this season. The words are: last year.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Man Loses Foot In Fall Onto Tracks
description: A 64-year-old man lost his right foot after he fell onto the subway tracks and was hit by an D train, the police said yesterday. The man, Juan Diaz, was taken to Montefiore Medical Center shortly after 1:30 p.m. on Monday and listed in stable condition, the police said. Mr. Diaz apparently lost his balance and fell from the platform at East 174th Street and the Grand Concourse, the police said. He was trying to climb back onto the platform when the southbound train entered the station and severed his foot, they said. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: A Good-Food Fan, a Would-Be Fisherman, a Guy With a Taste for Fun
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Suit Over Diana Crash Dismissed
description: A Paris court has dismissed a lawsuit by Mohammed al-Fayed, who was seeking damages from the French government stemming from the death of his son Dodi in the car crash that killed Diana, the Princess of Wales, in 1997. Mr. Fayed, the flamboyant owner of the London department store Harrods, had brought a suit for negligence, saying investigators had been slow to act against eight photographers who trailed the speeding car through Paris. In rejecting the suit the court noted that earlier this year the photographers were placed under investigation for invasion of privacy -- a step short of formal charges -- and thus there was no ''denial of justice.'' Suzanne Daley (NYT)

title: Lawyer for Cuban Boy's Relatives Is Elected Miami Mayor
description: Manny Diaz, a political no-name who became a central figure in the Elin Gonzlez episode, shook up the local political establishment today by easily winning the race for mayor of Miami in his first campaign for elected office.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNNE, GERALD A.
description: DUNNE-Gerald A. Of Falmouth, MA, formerly of Muttontown, NY, November 12. Beloved husband of Patricia (Dennen). Father of Anne Hourihan, Barbara Paulsen, Mary, Kathleen and Robert Dunne. Also survived by five grandchildren. Brother of the late Desmond. A funeral mass will be held on Thursday, November 15 at 11:30 A.M. at Christ the King Church, Mashpee, MA. Interment V.A. Mass. National Cemetery in Bourne. Visiting hours at the Chapman, Cole & Gleason Funeral Home, 475 Main St., Falmouth Center on Wednesday 5-7 PM. For directions or online guest book visit www.ccgfuneralhome.com.

title: Reclaiming Kabul
description: The chaotic retreat by Taliban forces from Kabul, and indeed from most of northern Afghanistan, is a dramatic development that did not seem conceivable even a week ago. But the Northern Alliance's triumph does not, by itself, achieve the basic American objective of defeating the Taliban and destroying the terrorist organization Al Qaeda. That may require more difficult military operations against the Taliban in their southern stronghold, where the United States lacks a combined Afghan force like the Northern Alliance.

title: Use of Military Court Divides Legal Experts
description: Though there is clear legal authority for the government to use military tribunals to try people accused of crimes during war, legal experts were divided yesterday on the merits of allowing such proceedings against foreign terrorists.

title: Restructuring Will Make I.N.S. Dual Focus Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14  Attorney General John D. Ashcroft said today that the Immigration and Naturalization Service was being restructured to better serve law-abiding immigrants and keep out terrorists and troublemakers.

title: The Pilgrimage to Lower Manhattan
description: Mourners pour into Lower Manhattan from all over the world, seeking a glimpse of the disaster site and a place to leave tokens of sympathy and support. Cut off from the ruins of the World Trade Center by temporary walls and closed streets, people congregate in front of St. Paul's Chapel of Trinity Parish, a block from the trade center site on Lower Broadway. The church has responded to a pressing emotional need by inviting visitors to write their names and messages of support on large canvas dropcloths hung from the church's fence. The dropcloths fill up quickly and are placed in storage, with the hope that they will one day be put on display.

title: More Loss: Disaster on Rockaway
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Bank's Profit Falls
description: UBS, Switzerland's largest bank and an international banking power, said its third-quarter profit fell 44 percent as transaction fees and investment earnings declined. UBS's net income fell to 903 million Swiss francs ($552 million), or 65 centimes a share, from 2.08 billion francs, or 1.7 francs, in the period a year earlier. According to the bank's executive board president, Luqman Arnold, the bank favors reducing compensation rather than adopting the practice of large-scale layoffs that some rival banks, also suffering similar losses from the economic downturn, have followed. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Everything for the Feast, Except the Food
description: All the equipment necessary for roasting and carving a turkey, making gravy, mashing potatoes and baking pies is on hand at an engaging new shop, the Art of Cooking, 555 Hudson Street (11th Street). The owner, Kate Humphrey (right), has given the place a warm, almost colonial look with rustic cabinets (all for sale) alongside shelves filled with the latest in pots, pans and professional baking tins. Worth noting is a novel nonstick roasting rack (above), which slants toward a container, to catch the drippings ($22.50). The container is skimpy, so juices must be siphoned off during roasting. Ms. Humphrey also sells candles, simple white dinnerware and, for those who still iron, pastel linen cocktail napkins ($1.50 each).

title: Bin Laden Has Less Room to Hide, U.S. Says
description: Osama bin Laden is on the move, forced by the Taliban's military setbacks to find a safe haven in a rapidly shrinking area of southern Afghanistan, American intelligence officials said today.

title: 150th Anniversary: 1851-2001; Dept. of Conscience: The Editorial 'We'
description: THE editorial ''we'' was an institution when Henry Jarvis Raymond introduced the New-York Daily Times in 1851 -- though even then some thought that newspaper editorial pages were doomed. Noting the rise of neutral, fact-based reporting, an essayist in 1866 wrote that the time was at hand ''for the abolition of editorials, and the concentration of the whole force of journalism upon presenting to the public the history and picture of the day.''

title: 2001 World Series Slide Shows
description: Acollection of slide shows from the 2001 World Series between the Yankees and the Arizona Diamondbacks.

title: A Splendid Year On Long Island
description: AS autumns go, this hasn't been a pleasant one for New Yorkers. Perhaps that's why it is so satisfying to discover a group of them who have something to cheer about: Long Island's winegrowers. They appear to have had what may be their best harvest ever.

title: 150th Anniversary: 1851-2001; 1951: Big Stories and the Cry of 'Copy!'
description: BEING a backward-looking person, I was curious to know what The Times was like in its centenary year, 1951. I happen to have handy an original bound run of the newspaper from that era, in all its wood-pulp bulk and glory -- a set of issues that once looped and cavorted through the groaning machines that dwelled in the basement of 43rd Street, in an atmosphere heavy with ink mist and paper dust. So I pulled out some of the old volumes, set them on a long table and began turning my way through them.

title: All of Sept. 11 Fund Will Go to Victims, Red Cross Says
description: The American Red Cross said today that it will devote all of the money raised in a special fund created after the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11 to the victims, including at least the injured, the displaced and families of the dead, and perhaps others.

title: Ensemble Turns to Vivaldi To Herald Changing Seasons
description: Following two all-Mozart programs with the Camerata Salzburg at Carnegie Hall last week, the violinist Anne-Sophie Mutter was back on Friday night, this time with the Trondheim Soloists, a Norwegian ensemble making its Carnegie Hall debut. The concert was to be the start of an important joint American tour for the ensemble and Ms. Mutter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SZUMLAK, DAVID
description: SZUMLAK-David. The Jerusalem Fellowships and Aish HaTorah wish to extend heartfelt condolences to Gail Weisbrod on the loss of her father David Szumlak. May she and her husband Michael and their children Yehuda and Sabrina be comforted among the other mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

title: Fallon Worldwide Plans More Layoffs
description: Fallon Worldwide, part of the Publicis Groupe, said yesterday that it would make additional layoffs, dismissing 60 employees or 11 percent of its staff of 550. The layoffs, attributed to the economy and reduced client spending, will be made at the Minneapolis headquarters office and will affect employees working on advertising and interactive assignments. Fallon made its first layoffs ever in late June, dismissing about 30 employees.

title: The Neediest Cases; Unable to Work and No Husband to Help, but With Young Children to Raise
description: Julia Reyes leaned forward, as if the weight of all her problems would not allow her to sit back comfortably.

title: Cholesterol Fighters Lower Heart Attack Risk, Study Finds
description: Cholesterol-lowering drugs safely reduced the risk of a heart attack or stroke by one-third in the world's largest study of people at high risk for these conditions, including some who had seemingly normal cholesterol levels.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Enron Chief Will Give Up Severance
description: Trying to quell a furious reaction from employees outraged that he stood to profit from a merger with Dynegy Inc., Kenneth L. Lay, the chairman and chief executive of the Enron Corporation, decided late yesterday to give up a severance package worth more than $60 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPECTOR, SHIRLEY ALBERT
description: SPECTOR-Shirley Albert. Piano teacher, of Jamaica, New York, formerly of Lawrence, MA, died at her home on November 11th. Survived by daughter Maria, son Nicholas, grandchildren Jessica and Sonja, and sister Marilyn. Services in Lawrence, MA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHIPPS, WILLIAM HAMILTON
description: PHIPPS-William Hamilton, 84. Of Seaford, NY & Honolulu, HI. on November 10, 2001. Retired President of Muller & Phipps International Corp. Survived by wife: Judith, two sons, William & Christopher, four daughters, Suzanne, Alma, Jay & Robyn; Grandchildren & Great grandchildren. Funeral Services Thursday 11:30 AM First Presbyterian Church of Englewood. Interment Brookside Cemetery, Englewood, New Jersey. Memorials to Rehabilitation Center of the Pacific, Honolulu, HI.

title: An Agile Partner
description: YOU would hardly expect California's canny winemakers to ignore a grape that is turned into world-class wines in Spain and France. Yet here is grenache, the key component in the blend that makes up Chteauneuf-du-Pape, the great wine of the southern Rhone, and the primary grape in Priorat in Spain, where it is called garnacha. It is one of the most widely planted red wine grapes in the world, but in California it is generally used as a filler in cheap blends.

title: Technology Briefing
description: SOFTWARE

title: With a Festival in 3 Rooms, A Third Is All You Can Hear
description: As in previous seasons, Sonic Boom had several of New York's foremost ensembles and soloists playing programs of new music, but this year the entire festival was crammed into a single long evening, Sunday's, and put for some reason into three crowded, ill lighted, visually offensive, acoustically unpleasant and noisy spaces at the Knitting Factory in TriBeCa.

title: 150th Anniversary: 1851-2001; Some Struggles Never Seem to End
description: HISTORY is most often described in terms of its signal events: a bloody battle in a small town in Pennsylvania, the murder of an archduke, a day that will live in infamy. Social history is different. It is best understood as the changing by inches of the ways in which Americans live and work and, above all, think of themselves and others. Nowhere in the nation's history is this clearer than in the struggles for civil rights over the last 150 years. Here there is no war between nations, to be settled with signatures on a treaty, but a conflict of hearts and minds that flares up and eases, then flares again.

title: Accounts
description: * M&M/Mars, part of Mars Inc., to offices of Grey Worldwide, part of the Grey Global Group, to handle creative duties for the Mars brand candy bar in Europe as well as the equivalent American product, sold under the brand name Milky Way. Billings were not disclosed; Adweek estimated them at $50 million. The assignments had been handled by offices of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, part of the Bcom3 Group, which continues handling Mars in other markets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANOFSKY, HARRY. ''POPPA''
description: KANOFSKY-Harry. ''Poppa'' to Roy, Marvin, Arie, Deenie, Marni, Dov, Molly, Bobbi and Valerie; husband of Sarah; brother of George. Services on Wednesday, 12:15 P.M., at ''Gutterman's,'' Woodbury, Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHULMAN, MAJOR MAX L.
description: SHULMAN-Major Max L. The Yeshiva University family is saddened by the passing of a former member of the Benjamin N. Cardozo of Law Board of Directors and a dear and distinguished friend. He was chairman of J.W. Mays Department Stores who, with his beloved wife, Sylvia, was a YU Guardian. We express our heartfelt condolences to Sylvia, to son Lloyd, daughter Gail Koster, sister Ethel Weiss, and grandchildren Melinda and Jonathan Koster. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Robert M. Beren, Chairman YU Board of Trustees

title: Corrections
description: An editorial last Saturday on the government's terrorism investigation misstated the number of people who have been arrested and detained since Sept. 11. It is about 1,100, not 11,000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAPPEL, HYMIE
description: GRAPPEL-Hymie. Of Secaucus, NJ on November 13. Beloved husband, devoted father, loving grandfather & great-grandfather. Services will be held at ''Gutterman-Musicant'', Hackensack, New Jersey on Wednesday, November 14 at noon. Should friends desire, contributions to Sloan-Kettering Cancer Research or the American Heart Association.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEMARCO, MICHAEL
description: DeMARCO-Michael. New York State Supreme Court Justice and former New York City Councilman. Beloved husband of Dorothy J. (nee Genadio). Loving father of Michelle Paci, Christine Gentile and Joseph DeMarco. Devoted grandfather of Michael and Alexandra Paci, Samuel and Matthew Gentile. Fond brother and brotherin-law of Joan and Clifford Ricci. Reposing at Schuyler Hill Funeral Home, 3535 E. Tremont Avenue, Bronx, until Thursday 10 AM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Theresa's Church, 10:30 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Visiting hours are Tuesday 7-9:30 PM & Wednesday 2-5 & 7-9:30 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations to Friends of Karen, a charity helping children with terminal and lifethreatening illnesses, 118 Titicus Road, P.O. Box 190, Purdys, NY 10578, would be appreciated.

title: Loss Reported By Interpublic
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies said yesterday that it had lost $478 million in the third quarter as sales fell 7.4 percent after businesses cut back spending on marketing campaigns and rivals snatched away some accounts.

title: A Temp's Life: I'm Not Really Here
description: I'm an actor, but to pay the bills I've worked as a temporary administrative assistant in several big Wall Street firms. At my first job, my new boss strode past me anxiously, stopped, turned and demanded, ''How good are you at Word?''

title: 150th Anniversary: 1851-2001; 150 and Counting: The Story So Far
description: BEGINNINGS are apt to be inauspicious, and so they were in 1851 with Henry Jarvis Raymond's little newspaper. But over the last 150 years, as the nation endured wars, depressions and often painful political, economic and cultural growth, that paper survived competitive challenges, even brushes with death, and prospered beyond its founders' wildest dreams.

title: The Right Stuffing Comes in Cubes
description: Preservative-free packaged croutons can be a great stuffing shortcut. Balthazar Bakery, 80 Spring Street (Crosby Street), sells a mix with dried mushrooms, pine nuts, currants and herbs, $13 a pound. Eli's Manhattan, 1411 Third Avenue (80th Street), and the Vinegar Factory, 431 East 91st Street, have one-pound sacks of mixed bread cubes, $4.95; seasoned, $5.95. Blue Ribbon Bakery, 33 Downing Street (Bedford Street), offers 12-ounce bags of white, rye or whole wheat croutons, $2.75 each. Whole Foods Market, 250 Seventh Avenue (27th Street), sells Chatham Village stuffing mix, in herb flavor, $1.99 for 12 ounces.

title: Documenting a Death Camp in Nazi Croatia
description: Officials of the United States Holocaust Museum said today that they had discovered and preserved a cache of decaying documents and artifacts from one of the lesser-known but most brutal concentration camps of World War II. The camp, known as Jasenovac, was operated in Croatia by the Ustasha, the Nazi puppet government.

title: Golden Oldies, With a Spin
description: AS much as I may be a kitchen adventurer, this spirit is put on hold at Thanksgiving, when tradition takes over. Chocolate cake at the family feast? Not a chance. Cheesecake? It would have to be pumpkin-flavored.

title: LOUISIANA PACIFIC TO CUT OUTPUT OF BUILDING PRODUCT
description: The Louisiana-Pacific Corporation, a lumber maker, plans to curtail production for the rest of the year at most of its North American plants because of less demand. Production will be halted for a week on a rolling schedule at plants that make oriented strand board, a plywood substitute used in home building. Plywood mills in Texas and Louisiana will halt production for as much as two weeks beginning Dec. 20, the company said. Louisiana-Pacific has had losses in the last five quarters because of declines in demand and price for oriented strand board, which is made of wood wafers that are glued together. The company, which is based in Portland, Ore., is a leading maker of oriented strand board and has 16 such mills and 5 plywood mills.

title: More Loss: Disaster on Rockaway
description: To the Editor:

title: Editors' Note; Today's Sections
description: News of the Sept. 11 attacks and their aftermath continues to appear in Section B; index, Page B2.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LARKIN, EDWARD JOSEPH
description: LARKIN-Edward Joseph. Age 67. Died suddenly November 11, 2001. Devoted husband to Patricia (nee Tarpey). Loving father to his nine children, Eileen, Kathleen, Kevin, Patricia, Mary, Thomas, Maureen, Elizabeth and Colleen. Second father to John, Jill, Billy, Joey, Lisa and John. ''G'' to Edward, Patricia, Matthew, Cari, Andrew, Victoria, Ryan, Morgan, Thomas, Julia and Jack. Beloved son of the late Thomas A. & Margaret M. Larkin. Dearest brother of Maureen L. Watson. The joy of his life was his family, although his love of Wall Street and the markets was great. Voted youngest partner of Goodbody and Company, former member New York and American Stock Exchanges, were among highlights of a long and illustrious career. Visiting on Tuesday and Wednesday, 2-5 and 7-9PM, McLaughlin Funeral Home, Third Avenue at 97 Street, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday, 10 AM, Saint Anselm Church.

title: Loan Activity at Fannie Mae Sets Record
description: Fannie Mae, the No. 1 buyer of home loans, said today that it had made commitments to buy a record $33.6 billion in mortgage loans in October, as home loan refinancing surged to a record.

title: 5 Neighbors Gone, and a Jet Engine Where a Child's Bike Might Have Been
description: A boy dribbled a basketball past imagined defenders. A woman took her dust mop of a dog for a walk. A white sanitation truck inched along, grinding the garbage in its hold.

title: Corrections
description: An editorial last Saturday on the government's terrorism investigation misstated the number of people who have been arrested and detained since Sept. 11. It is about 1,100, not 11,000.

title: A Lincoln Center Gala With a Lively Latin Beat
description: Jazz at Lincoln Center doesn't have to present new programming at its gala fund-raisers; it could sail by on what's now a decade-deep catalog of repertory and original work. But it chooses to, and the concerts themselves -- swift, celebrity filled, ending early to leave time for the party afterward -- can surprisingly be among the best of the season. ''The Spirit of Tito Puente,'' Monday night's show, put forward a subject that deserves elaboration beyond a gala, with its award-acceptance speeches and benign fripperies; it's too tempting, musically exciting and culturally deep an idea to ignore.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Cable Acquisition
description: The Liberty Media Corporation, the cable television company run by John C. Malone, has agreed to buy part of TeleColumbus, a cable service provider that is owned by Deutsche Bank and has about 1.4 million customers. As part of the deal, Deutsche Bank will retain a 12 percent stake in Liberty's German cable networks, including six systems bought from Deutsche Telekom earlier this year, the companies said. DB Investor, a unit of Deutsche Bank charged with managing the bank's industrial holdings, said it was looking for partners for cable networks in Baden-Wrttemberg and North Rhine-Westphalia, serving about 800,000 customers. Those regions were not part of the Liberty transaction. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Stabbing the Heart and Soul With the Savagery of Truth
description: THE COMPLETE WORKS OF ISAAC BABEL

title: Executive Who Promoted Interest-Free Car Loans Is Leaving G.M.
description: Ronald L. Zarrella, the architect of the General Motors strategy to offer interest-free financing after Sept. 11, resigned from G.M. today to take the top job at his former employer, Bausch & Lomb.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Judge Bars AIDS Activists
description: A San Francisco judge has barred two AIDS activists suspected of making threatening telephone calls to several Chronicle staff members from having any contact with the newspaper's employees. Court papers said the two, Michael Petrelis and David Pasquarelli, were angered by articles in the paper about the rise of unsafe sexual practices among gay men in San Francisco and the rate of syphilis among the city's gay and bisexual men. Both are members of Act Up San Francisco, a protest group concerned with AIDS issues. Evelyn Nieves (NYT)

title: Tapenade and Wafers From the Vineyard
description: A dab of lush tart-sweet fig and shallot tapenade on buttery Parmesan wafers makes a nibble that will not spoil appetites. And it seems just right with a glass of wine. The crackers and spread are part of a new food line called the Winemaker's Table, from the venerable Beaulieu Vineyard in Napa Valley, which also includes sauces and condiments laced with wine. The tapenade is $9 for 8 ounces, and the wafers are $5.75 for 4.5 ounces (plus shipping) from (800) 264-6918, extension 5232, or www.bvwine.com.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Oracle Chief Warns On Outlook
description: The Oracle Corporation has lowered its financial projections for its fiscal second quarter, which ends in two weeks. Lawrence J. Ellison, Oracle's chief executive, said at the Comdex industry conference that he expected earnings of 9 or 10 cents a share. The company had forecast earnings of 11 cents a share, which would have matched the results of the period last year. On Sept. 17, Oracle said it expected revenue from software licenses to fall as much as 15 percent but that it would match last year's results by cutting costs and improving software license renewals. Oracle's shares slid 88 cents, or 5.7 percent, to $14.52. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Jobs That Recession May Never Touch
description: Two and a half years ago, as seniors at St. Peter's College in Jersey City were flocking to the glamorous dot-com world across the river in Manhattan, Krzysztof Augustynowicz turned passionate about accounting.

title: Restructuring Will Make I.N.S. Dual Focus Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14  Attorney General John D. Ashcroft said today that the Immigration and Naturalization Service was being restructured to better serve law-abiding immigrants and keep out terrorists and troublemakers.

title: Small Towns Find Their Ingenuity Tested By Terrorist Threat
description: In a newly required class on anthrax, Detective Craig H. Long of the Suffern police held up a full-face respirator, a white jumpsuit and latex gloves to prepare his officers in this rural village in Rockland County for the worst case.

title: A New Set of Widows and Widowers, Now Focused in Northern Manhattan
description: For more than two months they have mourned for the city, as has everyone. Yesterday, they mourned for sons, parents, spouses, friends. Grief, once general in its embrace, is now excruciatingly specific.

title: REBELS IN CONTROL IN KABUL AS TALIBAN TROOPS RETREAT; BIN LADEN HUNT INTENSIFIES
description: Nearly half of Afghanistan tumbled out of the hands of the Taliban today in a dramatic turn in the five-week-old war that shifted the focus of military operations to the south, intensified the hunt for Osama bin Laden and left unanswered the overarching political question of who will govern Afghanistan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, BENJAMIN (BEN)
description: ROSS-Benjamin (Ben). Of Boca Raton, FL formerly of Great Neck, NY. Died peacefully on November 12. Husband of the late Ruth, loving father of Barbara Block and Kathy Adams, father-in-law of Seymour Block and Eric Adams, grandfather of Robert, Stacy, Alexandra, Todd and Joseph, and great grandfather of Samantha, Rachel and Evan. He was president of Ross Watch Case Company, a consultant to the jewelry industry, member of the Manufacturing Jewelers Association and the 24-Karat Club. Contributions to the charity of your choice.

title: Columbia Brings Together Its Online Offerings
description: With the aim of providing outsiders with better access to its online digital material, Columbia University today will unveil Columbia Interactive, a Web site of everything from conferences to faculty interviews to graduate student dissertations. Much of the material is free. But some, like short noncredit e-seminars by the history professors KENNETH T. JACKSON and SIMON SCHAMA, will carry a charge. (Their three- to five-hour seminars will cost $45.) The site will also offer lectures, discussions and other material on the World Trade Center attack. ``We wanted to provide one place where you can see everything online at Columbia in an organized, collective way,'' said G. TODD HARDY, executive director of Columbia Digital Knowledge Ventures, a nonprofit unit of the university. ``Before, it was there, but it was buried.'' The Web address is ci.columbia.edu.

title: SCHOOL SPECIALTY TO ACQUIRE FRANKLIN COVEY SUBSIDIARY
description: School Specialty Inc., a direct marketer of educational products to schools, agreed to buy the Franklin Covey Company's Premier School Agendas unit for $152.5 million to become the largest provider of academic planners in North America. The planners allow parents and teachers to track a student's progress by recording assignments and test results, said Dan Spalding, chief executive of School Specialty, which is based in Greenville, Wis.

title: Fine China, and Tears Through the Glass
description: Brian K. Fisher, an accounts representative for a paint and wall covering company in Lititz, Pa., stood transfixed, looking through the north glass wall of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center.

title: Several agencies are trying a variety of methods to reflect the world after Sept. 11.
description: SEVERAL agencies are becoming known as specialists in a new kind of advertising, producing a variety of work seeking to reflect the changed national reality after Sept. 11.

title: Giving Thanks, at the President's Table
description: AT a time when there are so many uncertainties, one thing is immutable: President Bush and his family will share a Thanksgiving dinner of the traditional dishes they've always loved, complete with a few Texas touches and one new grace note from the White House pastry chef, Roland Mesnier.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Boldface Names column yesterday about the Center for Science in the Public Interest, which protested a marketing link between the film ''Harry Potter and the Sorceror's Stone'' and Coca-Cola misstated the given name of the group's executive director. He is Michael F. Jacobson, not Mark.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANLEY, GEORGE P.
description: HANLEY-George P. Of Millwood, NY, on November 3, 2001. Beloved husband of Mary Jane (nee Opris). Devoted father of Matthew, Mark, Luke, John, Michael and Mary. Also survived by eight grandchildren. George received a B.S. in Economics from Mt. St. Mary's College, served in the US Army as a telecommunications instructor, then completed 32 graduate credits in Economics at Fordham Univ. During his 40 years in banking and finance, he was VP of Central Federal Savings Bank, VP at Chase Manhattan Bank, President of Lincoln First Commercial Corp., Partner Omega Financial Corp. He retired in 1996. A Mass of Christian Burial was on November 5, 2001 at St. John and St. Mary Church in Chappaqua. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Reckonings; Other People's Money
description: You may have seen the story about the businessman who allegedly used the attack on the World Trade Center to make off with other people's money. According to his accusers, Andrei Koudachev stole $105 million that had been invested with his firm, falsely asserting that the sum had been lost in the collapse of the towers. It's not entirely clear whether he is accused of stealing the money before Sept. 11, then using the disaster to cover his tracks, or of taking the money after the fact; maybe both.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Tastes of Vienna

title: Van Gundy Downsizes Starting Lineup
description: The Knicks' already small starting lineup shrank five inches yesterday. But in this case, less is more.

title: The Art of Aftermath, Distilled in Memory; Work Inspired by Sept. 11 May Take Time
description: How do artists respond to momentous acts of violence? Some are stunned into silence, others rush forward to express their feelings with a poem or a painting. But many allow for a time of reflection until they can begin to grasp the meaning and approach it within a creative context.

title: Burger King Names McCaffery Ratner
description: The Burger King Corporation in Miami, part of Diageo, has named McCaffery Ratner Gottlieb & Lane in New York to handle several project assignments including product advertising and the development of local and national promotions centered on music and radio. Billings were not disclosed.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Convictions In Killing Of Indian
description: In a case seen as a test of the fairness of the criminal justice system, four young men accused of killing an Indian by dousing him with gasoline and setting him on fire have been convicted and sentenced by a jury in Braslia to 14 years in prison. The victim, Galdino Jesus do Santos, of the Patax tribe in southern Bahia, was killed in April 1997 after traveling to Braslia to join a demonstration. The defendants, including the son of a federal judge, belong to the upper middle class and there was widespread outrage when the charges against them were initially dismissed. Mery Galanternick (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAY, LAWRENCE F.
description: FAY-Lawrence F. Of Bedford, NY, died on November 11, 2001, at Rosary Hill Home. He was 72. He was a partner at the law firm of Kent, Hazzard, Jaeger, Wilson, Fay & Conroy, in White Plains, NY, where he worked for 44 years. He was born on July 5, 1929 in the Bronx, to Lawrence R. and Mary (Duffy) Fay. He graduated from All Hallows High School in 1947, and Fordham University in 1951. In 1957 he graduated from Georgetown Law Center with JD and LLM degrees. He served in the U.S. Navy during the Korean conflict, attaining the rank of Lt. JG. He lived in Bedford, NY, for the past 33 years. He was a member and Director of The Thomas and Agnes Carvel Foundation. He is survived by his mother, Mary, of Point Pleasant, NJ, his brother, Robert, of Ft Lauderdale, FL, his sister, Mary Ellen Gentle, of Bethel, CT, his children, Kathleen Tell, of Point Pleasant, NJ, Kevin J., and Brian P., both of Bedford, NY, and Jennifer Rice, of Seattle, WA. He is also survived by six grandchildren. He is predeceased by his wife of 44 years, Marie (McCafferty) Fay, who died in 1998. Calling hours will be at Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, NY, on Tuesday 7-9 P.M. and Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. Funeral Service will be at St. Patrick's R.C. Church, Bedford, NY, on Thursday at 10 A.M. Interment will be at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. Contributions in his memory may be made to: The Rosary Hill Home, 600 Linda Avenue, Hawthorne, NY 10532 or The All Hallows H.S., 111 East 164th Street, Bronx, NY 10452.

title: Morgan Stanley Ends Small-Investor Push in Japan
description: Beating a hasty retreat in a sagging market, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company said today that it would close its only retail brokerage outlet in Japan, less than a year after opening it, because there was little chance the venture would turn a profit.

title: A Revolutionary Idea: Trading Grape for Apple
description: A THOUGHTFUL host may have the best intentions, beginning the evening with a splash of Champagne, perhaps, and then pausing with a crisp Alsatian white, before settling into earthy reds for the main course. But Thanksgiving dinner is a meal that, even in the best hands, stretches the definition of hearty. By the end, it is a triumph if you are not stuffed, tired and tipsy.

title: Putting the Nuevo Back Into Nuevo Latino
description: WHEN Andrew DiCataldo succeeded the hugely popular Douglas Rodriguez as executive chef at Patria, he must have felt like a mayoral candidate running in the shadow of Rudolph W. Giuliani. Mr. Rodriguez, now at Chicama and Pipa, made a big noise when he zoomed in from Miami and showed New York what Nuevo Latino was about. He cooked with flash and panache. Like an infectious salsa tune, Patria immediately had the whole city dancing.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Princeton: Town To Cull Deer
description: For the second year in a row, Princeton Township has been given permission to have as many as 500 wild deer shot by professional sharp shooters or culled by drop nets, state Fish and Wildlife officials said. The Fish and Game Council voted yesterday to allow the township to hire a wildlife management firm to kill the animals, said Larry Herrighty, chief of the Bureau of Wildlife Management. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Mellon Foundation Makes Humanities Awards
description: Move over, Nobel Prize. The Andrew W. Mellon Foundation's new award in the humanities far surpasses the $950,000 Nobel grant, not to mention the $500,000 that the MacArthur Foundation gives to ''geniuses.'' The Mellon award, given for the first time this year, grants up to $1.5 million for each recipient, depending on the cost of a scholar's research project. Winners announced last week include two professors from Princeton University: ALEXANDER NEHAMAS, a professor in the humanities, philosophy and comparative literature, and PETER BROWN, a professor of history. Other winners are STEPHEN GREENBLATT, a professor of the humanities at Harvard; SABINE MacCORMACK, professor for the study of human understanding, and a professor of history and classical studies, at the University of Michigan at Ann Arbor; and ROBERT PIPPIN, a professor of philosophy at the University of Chicago and chairman of the university's Committee on Social Thought.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Washington: New York Produces Less Smog
description: A study released yesterday by the Sierra Club showed that New York City produces less smog per person than any other major city in the United States. A principle reason: New York is the only state that spends more money on mass transit systems than on new roads, the report found. Oklahoma, where the budget for roads is 17 times the budget for public transportation, received the worst score and had the highest rate of smog per person. Increasing levels of smog nationwide in the past decade have been linked to numerous respiratory problems, including pneumonia and asthma, the group said.

title: Tom Dardis, 78, Literary Biographer Fascinated by Film
description: Tom Dardis, a biographer whose work was enriched by his own experiences, died on Nov. 2 at New York-Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan. He was 78 and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: 150th Anniversary: 1851-2001; Where the Gray Lady Got Its Steel
description: IT was cold and windy that day and she was somewhat irritated, she later recalled, because her parents had made her wear long underwear. The date was Jan. 18, 1904, and Iphigene Ochs, then 11, was laying the cornerstone for Times Tower, on Broadway near 42nd Street. Her father, Adolph S. Ochs, the publisher of The New York Times, had decided that his daughter should give the speech commemorating the event and he had written his words out carefully, and she in turn had dutifully memorized them.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO FALLS. The dollar climbed after United States-backed forces entered Kabul, the Afghan capital, and the Taliban militia fled. In New York, the euro settled at 88.13 cents, down from 89.50 cents on Monday.

title: Legislators Are Seeking to Limit Antitrust Exemption for Majors
description: Major League Baseball's contraction problems are expanding.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Outdated Buildings
description: To the Editor:

title: German Leader Calls Vote of Confidence on Role in Afghanistan
description: Putting severe pressure on his junior coalition partner, the Greens, Chancellor Gerhard Schrder today called a parliamentary vote of confidence over his decision to deploy up to 3,900 troops to support the war in Afghanistan.

title: Senator's Compromise Measure Would Use Federal Screeners Only at Busiest Airports
description: House and Senate negotiators tried to break a deadlock today over legislation to beef up aviation security, taking up a proposal that called for federal employees to do all screening of passengers and baggage at the nation's 31 busiest airports.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary by The Associated Press on Friday about Roy Boulting, who produced some of postwar Britain's hardest-hitting films with his twin brother, John, misspelled the surname of a German pastor who inspired their film ''Pastor Hall.'' He was Martin Niemller, not Neimuller. The article also misstated Pastor Niemller's fate at the hands of the Nazis. He was imprisoned in a concentration camp, not killed; he died in 1984.

title: 4 Guilty in Fatal 1986 Berlin Disco Bombing Linked to Libya
description: After a four-year trial involving a 15-year-old terrorist act, four people were convicted today of bombing a disco in West Berlin at the behest of Libya, killing two American soldiers and a Turkish woman and wounding 229 others.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the Navy's need for aircraft carriers misidentified the one that is scheduled to be retired in 2003. It is the Constellation -- not the Constitution, which was launched in 1797 and is popularly known as Old Ironsides.

title: Despite Flowers and Festivities, Alliance Finds an Uneasy Capital
description: On trucks, tanks and armored troop carriers, Northern Alliance forces poured into this battered capital today, greeted initially by flowers and festivities but confronting a situation of explosive uncertainty.

title: U.S.-Backed Leader Says He's Talking to Taliban
description: Hamid Karzai, the man the United States has embraced as the best alternative to the Taliban in their stronghold, southern Afghanistan, said this evening that he was in touch with Taliban leaders and was working with them to find a peaceful solution for a new government.

title: Serendipity Comes Calling
description: For as long as he can remember, Ramn Bonilla, an immigrant from the Dominican Republic who has lived in New York for 16 years, would take only one flight to go home: American Airlines Flight 587.

title: Trade Officials, Feeling Pressure to Avert a Damaging Setback, Extend Talks in Qatar
description: Representatives of 142 nations wrangled into the early morning today, past their deadline to reach agreement on a comprehensive plan to liberalize world trade.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Doubleclick Sells European Unit
description: Adlink Internet Media A.G., a German online advertising company, agreed to buy the money-losing European business of DoubleClick, the Manhattan Internet advertising agency, for $27 million. Adlink sells ads on European Web sites and said the DoubleClick business would help it reach a larger share of European Internet users. For DoubleClick, the deal means getting rid of a unit that generated a large percentage of its operating losses, Kevin Ryan, DoubleClick's chief executive, said in an interview with Bloomberg Television. Shares of Adlink traded on the Neuer Market in Germany rose 15 percent, to 2.60 euros. Shares of the DoubleClick rose 34 cents, to $9.55, in New York. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: Investment Chief at Calpers Quits After Ruling on Pay
description: The California Public Employees' Retirement System, the nation's largest public pension fund, said today that its chief investment officer had resigned after a court ruling that could force it to cut salaries for its investment staff.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Disputed Dam Loses Builder
description: Plans for a major dam in southeastern Turkey were thrown into doubt when a British engineering company, Balfour Beatty, said it was pulling out of the project. Opponents had said the Ilisu dam on the Tigris River would displace 30,000 people and flood towns and the historic Hasenkeyf monument. The company said its decision followed an evaluation of the commercial, environmental and social issues in the project, part of a huge power-generating plan sponsored by the Turkish government. Douglas Frantz (NYT)

title: Despite Profit From Cellphones, Vodafone Reports a Loss
description: The Vodafone Group said today that though its mobile phone business was operating profitably, write-downs of overvalued assets and other charges resulted in a net loss of 9.7 billion ($14.1 billion), or 14.41 pence a share, for the six months that ended Sept. 30.

title: 150th Anniversary: 1851-2001; The First Issue: Imagining How a Paper Was Born
description: HENRY JARVIS RAYMOND was an ambitious but a prudent man. It had been rash of him, deplorably reckless, to announce, three months beforehand, the exact date -- Sept. 16, 1851 -- on which his new paper would commence publication, and he soon regretted having made such an uncharacteristic boast. But his rivals -- Bennett of The Herald, Beach of The Sun and Greeley, that spewing, treacherous old dragon Horace Greeley of The Tribune -- were powerful men, ruthless competitors, eager and ready to watch him fail (Greeley most of all), and like many prudent but ambitious men, Henry Raymond could be bold, even intemperate, in the face of personal attack. At this time, rival editors regularly debated the strategy and tactics of news gathering in the streets, with horsewhips, a form of discourse that actually represented something of a falling off from the previous era, in which newspapermen settled their disagreements on the cliffs of Weehawken, with pistols at 20 paces. Henry Raymond owned a secret audacity, a hot temper that from time to time he flashed briefly as a gun concealed under the coat.

title: U.S. Bombs Taliban Troops as They Make a Speedy Retreat to the South
description: The United States military sought to capitalize on the disarray of Taliban forces in Afghanistan today, bombing them as they retreated and moving to expand American forces in the region and open new airfields closer to the rapidly shifting front.

title: With Jury Split, Trial of Rabbi Ends in Mistrial
description: A mistrial was declared today in the murder trial of a South Jersey rabbi, after the jury said it was unable to reach a unanimous verdict on charges that he ordered the killing of his wife in 1994.

title: 150th Anniversary: 1851-2001; A Gallery of Hirschfelds
description: In 1931, while walking in Bali - where the brilliant sun seemed to bleach out all color - Al Hirschfeld became ''enchanted with line.'' The effect of that sunlight on the young artist's style soon became evident in his acutely evocative drawings of entertainers for The Times. And readers have been enchanted by Hirschfeld - a caricaturist without malice - ever since.

title: A Comedian Wrestles With Instant Fatherhood
description: ''The Bernie Mac Show'' is determined not to be just another family sitcom. In pursuit of that objective, it sabotages itself, flirting with offensiveness in a way that is likely to overshadow its good points.

title: Assessing Money's Role In Making Schools Better
description: MANY school reforms today are intended to narrow the achievement gap between middle-class and poor children. Holding all pupils to the same high academic standard is one approach. Increasing school funds is another.

title: It's Not Just Another Game
description: The timing almost seems scripted. Just as Eric Lindros is re-emerging in full force after a 16-month absence from hockey, just as he is putting a long-lost Rangers team on a roll, here comes Lindros's old team -- the Philadelphia Flyers -- skating into Madison Square Garden for their first meeting with their old captain.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Hyundai's Profit Rises
description: Hyundai Motor posted a net profit of $712 million in the first three quarters of this year, slightly more than double Hyundai's income in the period last year. The rise in profit reflected the sale of 1,202,358 vehicles from January through September, 8.3 percent more than were sold from January through September a year earlier. The company also began construction of a $30 million design and technical center in Irvine, Calif., as part of a plan for developing cars specifically for the United States market. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Taliban Flee Kandahar; bin Laden Is at Large
description: The rout of the Taliban from Afghan cities continued apace yesterday, and there were reports that Pashtun tribes in the south, the ethnic base of the Taliban, were rising up and challenging the Taliban even in its stronghold of Kandahar.

title: 'Too Many People'
description: Firefighter Sean Cummins lives with four ground zeros.

title: Environmental Activism
description: To the Editor:

title: 150th Anniversary: 1851-2001; Go Ahead, Laugh
description: For decades, not far from The Times in midtown Manhattan, another institution - one know for a few amusing idiosyncrasies, too - cast its glance over here and found that this was a funny sort of place.

title: U.N. Seeks Meeting of Afghans to Fill Vacuum in Kabul
description: Rushing to fill the void in Kabul created by the unexpected flight of the Taliban, the United Nations proposed today to convene a meeting of Afghan representatives quickly to start work on a provisional administration, and to deploy an ''international security presence'' in the Afghan capital until a national force can be readied.

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of yesterday, 4,432 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11.

title: 150th Anniversary: 1851-2001; After the Birthday Party: NYT@150 Online, and in Bookstores
description: This section will remain available online, with links to special multimedia features -- including audio interviews with many of the writers, a video tour of New York City in 1851 and archival material about the history of The Times: www.nytimes.com/150

title: South Carolina Students Repay A 134-Year-Old Act of Kindness
description: Students at White Knoll Middle School said today that they had raised more than $447,000 to buy a fire truck to replace one of those destroyed in the World Trade Center disaster on Sept. 11.

title: On This Anniversary: Who We Are
description: This special section was originally scheduled for publication on Sept. 20, the week of the 150th anniversary of our first issue in 1851. The deaths of thousands of New Yorkers on Sept. 11 made that the wrong time for even the most solemn anniversary celebration. We offer this issue now as a symbol of the continuity of our home city and our nation and as a token of the continuity of this newspaper, created to address, from its first day, the information needs of a society based on the highest civic, political and humanitarian principles.

title: Columbia Brings Together Its Online Offerings
description: With the aim of providing outsiders with better access to its online digital material, Columbia University today will unveil Columbia Interactive, a Web site of everything from conferences to faculty interviews to graduate student dissertations. Much of the material is free. But some, like short noncredit e-seminars by the history professors KENNETH T. JACKSON and SIMON SCHAMA, will carry a charge. (Their three- to five-hour seminars will cost $45.) The site will also offer lectures, discussions and other material on the World Trade Center attack. ''We wanted to provide one place where you can see everything online at Columbia in an organized, collective way,'' said G. TODD HARDY, executive director of Columbia Digital Knowledge Ventures, a nonprofit unit of the university. ''Before, it was there, but it was buried.'' The Web address is ci.columbia.edu. Karen W. Arenson

title: More Loss: Disaster on Rockaway
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: British Prime Minister Has 'No Doubt' of bin Laden's Guilt
description: LONDON, Nov. 14  Prime Minister Tony Blair made public new findings today that he said left no doubt about the guilt of Osama bin Laden in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: KANEB TO BUY TERMINALS FROM STATIA FOR $193 MILLION
description: Kaneb Pipe Line Partners, a fuel transporter, agreed to buy terminals in Canada and the Netherlands Antilles from the Statia Terminals Group for $193 million. Kaneb will also assume $107 million in debt for the terminals, which make up almost all of Statia's assets, the company said. The transaction is expected to close in the first quarter. The company will get a terminal in St. Eustatius, east of Puerto Rico, and one in Point Tupper, Nova Scotia. The deal will increase terminal capacity by about 42 percent, to 63.1 million barrels.

title: Sweet Potatoes With Nary a Marshmallow in Sight
description: EVEN a salt abuser like me would never think of getting out the shaker for salted peanuts. So I'm mystified that so many cooks reflexively reach for the sugar when they contemplate sweet potatoes. In both cases, the adjective should be the signal to put on the brakes.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the Navy's need for aircraft carriers misidentified the one that is scheduled to be retired in 2003. It is the Constellation  not the Constitution, which was launched in 1797 and is popularly known as Old Ironsides.

title: More Tax Sought From Drug Maker
description: The Schering-Plough Corporation said the Internal Revenue Service has asked it to pay an additional $195 million in taxes for 1990 through 1992, according to a federal regulatory filing.

title: 150th Anniversary: 1851-2001; The News Today: One Hard Slap
description: WHEN the news first hit on the morning of Sept. 11, our initial inclination was to disbelieve it, such was the unfathomable magnitude of the horror. Once the reality set in, we had to ask ourselves if we could trust the messengers -- the news media -- who would tell us the rest of the story.

title: The Road to San Antonio
description: Frank Litsky of The Times rates the teams with the best chance of reaching the final 16 in March, and who could survive to the Final Four March 29 and 31 in San Antonio. (Last season's records in parentheses.)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: President Signs Land Reform Law
description: President Leonid Kuchma signed into law a long-awaited measure that will allow land to be bought and sold starting in 2005. The law overturns Soviet-era restrictions that have hobbled agricultural reform in what was known as the breadbasket of the Soviet Union. The government hopes the new land code will draw investment, although foreigners will not be allowed to buy farmland. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: Design, Cubed
Kabul Throws Off Taliban Yoke
Times Headlines Through the Years
description: From the Titanic to Nixon, Times headlines have announced and contextualized important events.

title: Kabuls Troubles
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: City Braces For Gridlock, Holding Line On Road Jobs
description: New street construction projects will be suspended from Monday until the new year as part of the city's plan to ward off traffic congestion during the holidays, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: $150 Million Gift For Johns Hopkins
description: Sidney Kimmel, a clothing company executive, has donated $150 million for cancer research and patient care to Johns Hopkins University, the largest single gift to the university, administrators said. The Hopkins Cancer Center in Baltimore will be renamed the Sidney Kimmel Comprehensive Cancer Center. The gift from Mr. Kimmel, founder and chairman of the Jones Apparel Group, will also provide money for a residence to serve patients and families undergoing prolonged cancer treatments. Mr. Kimmel recently gave $25 million to finance research and develop a new prostate and urological cancer center at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York.

title: 2 Pilots Praise Passengers Who Fought Hijackers
description: Two Air National Guard fighter pilots paid tribute today to the passengers on United Airlines Flight 93 who by thwarting the plane's hijackers may have saved the pilots from having to shoot down a commercial airliner in defense of Washington.

title: PC Vintage: Full-Bodied, Mellow Price
description: YEAR in, year out, we tech writers are fond of wrapping up our year-end PC buying-guide articles with the same safe statement: ''There's never been a better time to buy a new PC.'' And why not? For years, prices have steadily come down and features have steadily improved.

title: A Nation Challenged
description: Advance and Retreat

title: Technology Briefing
description: HARDWARE

title: Waffling Again, 70's Radical Asks to Change Guilty Plea
description: In court sessions over the past two weeks, Sara Jane Olson hemmed, dodged and protested. But she said yes, on three occasions, when asked if she was certain she wanted to plead guilty to charges of plotting to bomb two police cruisers in 1975.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: AUTO RACING

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Currents column last Thursday about a bridge designed by Leonardo da Vinci to be built in Istanbul referred incorrectly to the Golden Horn, the body of water the bridge was intended to span. The Golden Horn is an inlet of the Bosporus whose shores lie entirely in Europe. It is the Bosporus itself that separates Europe and Asia.

title: AMES STORES, IN CHAPTER 11, PLANS TO CLOSE 16 STORES
description: Ames Department Stores, the fourth-largest discount retailer, said yesterday that it would close 16 stores in Illinois, Indiana, Kentucky, Ohio and Tennessee and lay off about 1,000 workers while emerging from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. Ames, which is based in Rocky Hill, Conn., expects to close the stores by early next year, the company said. About 25 percent of the company's 25,000 employees will be affected. In September, Ames won a bankruptcy judge's final approval of a $755 million credit line to finance the company's Chapter 11 reorganization. Ames sought protection in August after competition from Wal-Mart Stores and other large rivals left the company struggling to pay its debts.

title: U.S. Flies Aid Workers to Safety in Pakistan
description: More than three months after being detained in Afghanistan by the Taliban on charges of preaching Christianity, eight Western aid workers, including two Americans, were plucked out of the country by United States military helicopters Wednesday and flown to Pakistan, United States officials said.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bankruptcies Rise
description: Corporate bankruptcies rose 11.7 percent in October from the month a year earlier, as the sagging economy and banks' efforts to deal with huge portfolios of bad loans combined to push companies out of business. With no sign of economic recovery in sight, analysts expect the pace to accelerate and total bankruptcies for 2001 to reach 20,000. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Washington: Thurmond Moves To Hospital
description: Senator Strom Thurmond, the oldest and longest-serving member of the Senate, has moved to Walter Reed Medical Center from his home in Virginia so doctors can better monitor his medication. Mr. Thurmond, a South Carolina Republican, will turn 99 next month. The move is temporary, his family said. Mr. Thurmond will continue to work in the Senate, a spokeswoman said. Mr. Thurmond has been in the hospital repeatedly this year, mostly after fainting spells. The senator has said he will not seek re-election next year.

title: Cheating History
description: The records a president amasses during his tenure do not become his personal property when he leaves office. As the Presidential Records Act of 1978 makes clear, this treasure trove of historical material belongs to the American people. Unfortunately, neither that law, nor the public's right to be informed about the workings of its government, dissuaded President Bush from signing an executive order earlier this month creating new barriers to obtaining a former president's papers.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about disarray among Israeli leftists because of the continuing conflict with Palestinians referred incorrectly to the ''right of return'' demanded by Yasir Arafat. It is for refugees from the 1948 Arab-Israeli war, not from later Arab-Israeli wars.

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Today: Public Meeting On Security
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and James K. Kallstrom, director of the state's Office of Public Security, will answer questions about security at a televised town hall meeting on Long Island. Monroe Lecture Hall, Hofstra University, 1000 Fulton Avenue, Hempstead, 7 p.m. Information: (518) 474-8418.

title: Phones Out of Place: Funny, You Don't Sound Like 212
description: MIRANDA SIELAFF, a Minneapolis native, graduated from college last spring, spent the summer with friends in Boston and moved to New York in the early fall. Throughout those transient months, she had a cellphone number starting with her hometown area code, 612.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVENSON, MARIAN
description: LEVENSON-Marian. On November 10, 2001. Beloved wife of Robert. Mother of Gabriel. Sisters Phyllis and Joan. Donation may be sent to your favorite charity.

title: Bodies in Motion, and at Rest; Ergonomic Equipment Can Take Away the Strain in Everyday Tasks
description: TIGHT FIT -- Laptop computers can end up in the most awkward places. The Balt LapMaster ($216) is a well-constructed, adjustable table that can lift, lower, slide, swivel, tilt, roll and turn a laptop into a movable feast. With its swiveling laptop surface, paper holder, adjustable copy-stand and printer platform, it can turn a kitchen corner into a full home office.

title: Recharging (Batteries Included); How to Leave Everything Behind and Nothing to Chance
description: IN FOCUS -- Like all image stabilization binoculars, the Canon 10X30 ($640) tracks the movements of the user's hands and then uses microprocessors and moving internal optical elements to offset any shakes or jerks. By restricting the model to a 10-times magnification, Canon has been able to produce a relatively compact pair. Higher-magnification models carry higher price tags.

title: And Something On the Side; You May Have Chip Speed to Spare, but Peripherals Make the PC
description: TO THE INTERNET -- The Logitech Cordless Optical Freedom keyboard ($100) answers the question ''Which way to the Web?'' The low-rise keyboard has keys to take you automatically to e-mail, Web search and shopping, and for various multimedia controls.

title: Corner Office to Kitchen Table; Households Pull Double Duty: Are a Few More Outlets Too Much to Ask?
description: NAILED DOWN -- Emulating the iMac may be a computer-world clich, but it's still a novel concept in the tool market. The transparent Zircon iSensor ($12) comes in six colors and can find wood or metal studs through three-quarters of an inch of drywall. The fancy plastic casing can withstand six-foot drops. For traditionalists, Zircon offers the iSensor Pro in a solid, stolid yellow.

title: Rapid Changes on the Ground Lead the Pentagon to Focus on Counterguerrilla Tactics
