description: The pell-mell advances of rebel forces in Afghanistan have so outpaced expectations that American commanders are considering a new war plan that would scale back bombing raids and intensify counterguerrilla operations, senior officials said today.

title: Wall Street's Internet-Stock Star Calls It Quits
description: Henry Blodget, the fair-haired stock analyst who became a symbol of the Internet mania that enriched some investors but ultimately cost many others dearly, is giving up the business of publicly rating stocks.

title: Albert Hague, 81, a Composer and Actor
description: Albert Hague, a popular composer whose work included his Tony award-winning score for the 1959 musical ''Redhead,'' the much-recorded standard ''Young and Foolish'' and the soundtrack for last year's film ''How the Grinch Stole Christmas,'' died on Monday at a hospital in Marina del Rey, Calif., where he lived. He was 81.

title: The Battle for Afghanistan: The Tide Is Turned
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAIES, MIRIAM
description: HAIES - Miriam. Congregation Sons of Israel, Woodmere, records with sorrow the passing of its member and extends its condolences to the bereaved family. Bruce Ginsburg, Rabbi Dr. Saul I. Teplitz, Rabbi Emeritus Stephen A. Kreiss, President

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: 2 Instances of Wake Turbulence Before Crash, Investigators Say
description: Investigators said today that information from the flight data recorder of American Airlines Flight 587 revealed that the plane encountered two instances of wake turbulence, or air disturbance from another aircraft, before it broke apart and crashed on Monday.

title: The Battle for Afghanistan: The Tide Is Turned
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRYOR, ROBERTA B.
description: PRYOR-Roberta B. On Nov. 12, 2001, in New York City. Former literary agent who represented many authors, including Peter Benchley, Roger Caras, Paul Fussel, David Halberstam, P.D. James. Born June 7, 1924 in Claremont, CA. Viewing November 15, 2:30-5:00 P.M. and 7:00-9:30 PM at Simonson Funeral Home, Hillside Avenue at Lefferts Boulevard, Richmond Hill, Queens. Service 9 A.M., November 16, at Holy Child Jesus Church, 111th Street at 86th Avenue, Richmond Hill.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: In Belle Harbor, Strength Walks With Grief
description: To the Editor:

title: SAT's Lost, Perhaps Trapped In Contaminated Post Offices
description: Nearly 8,000 students from around the world are being advised to retake the SAT for college admissions because their answer sheets are missing -- apparently trapped in two New Jersey post offices that had been contaminated by anthrax spores.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Crackdown In Muslim Region
description: Chinese officials in the largely Muslim western province of Xinjiang are extending the country's anticrime campaign to religious groups that do not have official approval, according to state media. An article in Xinjiang Legal Daily reported that the police in Kashgar had shut down 13 illegal religious centers and arrested more than 50 people worshiping there. The government fears that gatherings other than those monitored by state-sanctioned mosques could fuel simmering separatist sentiments among the Uighur ethnic group. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NETTLETON, JIM
description: NETTLETON-Jim. July 8, 1947 to November 15, 1990. Loved, missed and always remembered

title: Complexities in a Battle of the Sexes
description: A splendid gala studded with rare revivals from the 1940's, guest artists, a premiere with an emotional wallop by Doug Varone and promising excerpts from novelties to come opened the Limn Dance Company's season at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday night.

title: Bush Names Budget Expert As Administrator of NASA
description: President Bush nominated Sean O'Keefe, a White House budget expert, today to be the new head of NASA, signaling a desire for tighter management and fiscal control for the space agency.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Shipbuilding Merger
description: Under pressure from low-cost rivals in South Korea and China, Ishikawajima-Harima Heavy Industries and Sumitomo Heavy Industries said that they would combine their tanker and warship divisions into a 50-50 joint venture, to be called Marine United, in October 2002. The deal creates Japan's third-largest shipbuilder, after Mitsubishi Heavy Industries and another new joint venture created by Hitachi Zosen and NKK; it is expected to employ 2,000 workers and have first-year sales of about $1.1 billion. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Demand at Food Pantries Rises, but Donations Drop
description: The slow economy and the loss of thousands of jobs after the World Trade Center attack have heightened demand at food pantries, but the supply of donations is decreasing, according to a study released yesterday by the city's largest food bank.

title: U.S. Companies Largely Back Trade Decisions; Textile Regulations
description: As a low-cost, labor-intensive process, textile manufacturing is one of the few industries in which developing countries are equipped to excel. Their regular aim is to reduce steep tariffs and quotas imposed by the United States on their goods, but their ambitions are often frustrated by the American textile lobby.

title: Court Thwarts G.O.P. Hopes For Big Gains In Texas Seats
description: A panel of three federal judges issued a new political map for Texas Congressional districts today, and Democrats say it will help their efforts in 2002 to regain control of the United States House of Representatives.

title: In Belle Harbor, Strength Walks With Grief
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZEITLIN, FERRIN
description: ZEITLIN-Ferrin. The Parkway Hospital is deeply saddened for the Zeitlin family on the loss of Ferrin Randall Zeitlin who lost his brave battle with cancer. He was 24 years old. Ferrin was the beloved son of Dr. and Mrs. Alan Zeitlin, adored brother of Brigitte, treasured grandson of Herbert and Ruth Schwartz and Paul and Mildred Zeitlin. Ferrin graduated from Boston University with a degree in Economics in 2000. Funeral service, Thursday, November 15, 2001 at Schwartz-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, New York at 11:30 AM.

title: Public Theater Cuts Staff To Offset Losses in Funds
description: The Joseph Papp Public Theater has laid off about 20 percent of its staff to balance its budget, citing a downturn in the economy, cuts in city funds and an expected drop in donations. The action follows the resignation of the theater's two largest donors and the departure of its executive director, Fran Reiter, the former deputy mayor of New York who was brought in for her administrative skills less than a year ago.

title: Food Shipment May Be Start of Something Big
description: A cargo barge carrying relief supplies shuttled across the Amu Darya today from Uzbekistan to a long-idled port in Afghanistan, the beginning of what the United Nations hopes will be a sizable aid pipeline into the nation's northern provinces.

title: University of California Moves To Widen Admissions Criteria
description: Six years after it eliminated affirmative action based on race and sex in its admissions process, the University of California Board of Regents moved today toward adopting a new policy that would broaden the factors considered in selecting students.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trade Surplus Turns Up
description: Japan's current account surplus rose in September for the first time in 10 months, as companies repatriated profits at the end of the fiscal half-year and fewer Japanese traveled overseas. The surplus jumped 10.8 percent; analysts had expected a decline because of continuing weakness in exports. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Wartime Bomb Near Reichstag
description: The dome and observation deck of the Reichstag in Berlin were closed when a Russian bomb from World War II was exposed during construction at a nearby site. Visitors were barred from the popular tourist destination while explosive experts detonated the 50-pound bomb.

title: Security Firms Ever Mindful To Cut Costs
description: International Total Services Inc. had been faltering for years. The company, which screens passengers at major airports nationwide, was running out of money.

title: Taliban Troops Move Across Border Into Pakistan
description: About 3,000 Taliban and Al Qaeda fighters have crossed into Pakistan along its western frontier since Sunday, when Taliban troops began retreating in strength from some of Afghanistan's major cities, Pakistani intelligence officials said today.

title: Campbell Profit Falls
description: The Campbell Soup Company said today that its fiscal first-quarter profit fell 16 percent as the company spent more to gain market share and make its products tastier and easier to open. Net income declined to $171 million, or 42 cents a share, compared with $204 million, or 47 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Sales rose 9.4 percent, to $1.73 billion. Analysts had expected the company to earn 41 cents a share, according to Thomson Financial/First Call. Campbell increased marketing spending by 20 percent, excluding certain items, as part of a plan to revive United States soup sales.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Motorola Licenses A Technology
description: Motorola, which said in September that it had discovered a method to deposit gallium arsenide and other high-performance semiconductor compounds on silicon substrates, said yesterday that it had licensed the technology to IQE, a supplier of wafers to microchip manufacturers. To help finance IQE's development work, Motorola will invest $10 million for 4.4 million shares of IQE, which is based in Cardiff, Wales. IQE expects to provide chip designers with sample wafers next spring. Motorola also said it was creating a subsidiary, Thoughtbeam Inc., to develop the technology further. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: First, Consider This
description: MICHAEL LOVE, an interior designer in Manhattan, has a rule of thumb for kitchen appliances. ''Pick the brand that you can afford and like best, but buy the least complicated model of that line,'' she said. ''You do not need a special wok ring, you don't need a top-of-the-stove griddle, and you don't need an automatic timer, unless you don't pay attention to what you're cooking.'' Nonetheless, there are some basic decisions buyers will have to make.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE ROTHSCHILD, DEBRA ELISA
description: de ROTHSCHILD-Debra Elisa, 42 years old, on November 13, 2001. Debra, beloved wife of Robert de Rothschild, mother of Jacob Alain de Rothschild, daughter of Leonard and Ileen Cohen, sister of Joel M. Cohen, aunt, niece, cousin and sister-in-law to many, loved and revered by all. Debra graduated from Miss Hall's School, Brandeis University and Emory University School of Law. A brilliant and dedicated attorney both in public and private practice, Debra pioneered the defense of battered women and was universally respected by colleagues, adversaries and jurists. Debra was an adjunct professor of law at Emory, Pace, and Cardozo law schools and was a Trustee of Miss Hall's School. Debra's immense charm and gentle strength transformed and touched so many lives and she was loved by all who knew her. She leaves an immense void and will be deeply missed by all of her friends and family. The funeral will occur at Park Avenue Synagogue, 50 E. 87 St, November 15, 2001, 11AM.

title: Agency Drops Out Of Kinko's Review
description: Kinko's, the chain of business-services stores, and its agency since July 1998, the TBWA/Chiat/Day office in Playa del Rey, Calif., are parting ways as a review continues for the company's creative and media account, with spending estimated at $30 million.

title: U.N. Sends Envoy to Calm Arafat's Pique Over Snub by Bush
description: Yasir Arafat was so incensed at snubs he received from President Bush at the United Nations on Saturday that the special United Nations coordinator for the Middle East, Terje Larsen, was urgently sent back to Gaza to calm the Palestinian leader, officials at the United Nations said today.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Hanaro Loss Narrows
description: Hanaro Telecom reported a third-quarter loss of $48.17 million, far less than its loss of $65.4 million in the period last year. The company attributed the improvement to both its broadband Internet services and the basic telephone operations that it provides in major Korean cities in competition with Korea Telecom, the dominant communications company in Korea. Revenue for the quarter totaled $166 million, more than double the revenue in the period last year. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, GERALD S., ESQ.
description: LEVINE-Gerald S., Esq. November 13, 2001 at 63 years. Beloved husband of Suzanne, devoted father of Michael of Phoenix, AZ and Marshall of Brooklyn, NY. Cherished son of Belle Levine of Sunrise, FL. Dear brother of Roberta Srebnik of Sunrise, FL and Marsha Levine, Esq. of Irvine, CA. Service Friday 11:30am ''Parkside'' Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn New York (opposite Kings Plaza).

title: The Battle for Afghanistan: The Tide Is Turned
description: To the Editor:

title: Toys 'R' Us Thinks Big in Less Playful Time
description: With the economic downturn, the decline in tourism and forecasts of a dismal holiday season for retailers, it may be a risky moment to open a $35 million store, especially in a neighborhood that depends on out-of-towners for much of its foot traffic. But this Saturday, the giant retailer Toys ''R'' Us is planning to open what it calls the largest toy store in the world in Times Square.

title: Searching for Gifts When the Spirit Is Weak
description: ONE Christmas during World War II, shortages got so bad that there were hardly any places left in eastern Kentucky to shop and no gifts worth buying if you did. My mother, who was a little girl, briefly gave up her favorite pastime of going down to Grigsby's Five and Dime to smell the pretty bottles of cheap perfume, because most had sold out.

title: At One School, All the City's a Playground
description: Public School 40 on East 19th Street now has a rooftop playground with a mini-Manhattan skyline, left, by Macrae-Gibson architects. ''I wanted it to be both educational and recreational,'' Gavin Macrae-Gibson said of the project, which cost the School Construction Authority $160,000. The challenge, he said, was to take the standard decks, bridges, slides and ladders that the school allowed for kindergarteners through fifth-graders and adapt them unconventionally. Here, the Woolworth, Chrysler and Empire State buildings were depicted in steel, painted with metallic-flake auto-body paint. The Empire State, at 21 feet, is the tallest. When you are only 3 feet tall that's pretty high. DONNA PAUL

title: WHITE HOUSE PUSH ON SECURITY STEPS BYPASSES CONGRESS
description: The Bush administration has moved swiftly in the last few weeks to expand its national security authority and law enforcement powers in ways that are intended to bypass Congress and the courts, officials and outside analysts say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANTALA, TIMO
description: SANTALA-Timo. The principals, employees, and friends of Jacmel Jewelry and Soloro Manufacturing are deeply saddened by the loss of our friend Timo Santala. We were fortunate enough to have Timo join Jacmel as the Director of Manufacturing in June 1996. He brought many years of experience in manufacturing and metallurgy to the job, and was immediately respected and admired by his employees and peers. After several years at Jacmel, Timo agreed to take on a new challenge and was appointed President of Soloro Manufacturing, a Jacmel owned manufacturing facility in the Dominican Republic. Timo brought great enthusiasm and energy to Soloro, developing an extremely well run factory and an exceptional staff who will miss him deeply. We will miss our morning conference calls with him, the daily weather update, his quick wit, and being entertained by his stories about life in the Dominican Republic. His vast experience, knowledge and passion contributed mightily to the growth and communities of these two organizations. We know that we are joined by countless people whom Timo touched in his 20+ years in the jewelry industry. In mourning his passing we send our deepest sympathies to his wife Laura, his four children-Leo, Timo Jr., Annikki, Kaarina and the rest of his family & friends.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Bank Profit Falls
description: France's biggest bank, BNP Paribas, said that third-quarter profit declined 7.6 percent from the equivalent figure last year. The Paris-based bank fared better than its European rivals Deutsche Bank, ABN Amro, UBS, and the French bank Socit Gnrale, which is expected to post a 14 percent slide in earnings today. The chairman at BNP Paribas, Michel Pebereau, above, attributed the decline to ''reduced capital gains'' and said that ''it is naturally difficult to predict business trends for the coming months.'' Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: The Yearnings of the Pashtuns
description: As the Taliban's position in Afghanistan continues to crumble, the political future of the Pashtuns -- a plurality of Afghans and a majority within the Taliban -- has become a crucial issue. All sides recognize that it must be resolved if reconstruction of Afghanistan is to begin. To develop an effective strategy, the United States will need to understand some of the Pashtuns' past and aspirations, and in particular how these have affected Afghan-Pakistani relations.

title: Sports of The Times; 49,000 Hugs Should Heal Kim's Psyche
description: IN the noonday sun, a middle-aged husband clicked a snapshot of his wife and two kids against the backdrop of Bank One Ballpark, then handed the camera to his wife.

title: The Battle for Afghanistan: The Tide Is Turned
description: To the Editor:

title: The Family That Slays Demons Together
description: HERE'S the difficult issue my son and I were discussing the other day: Should I sell my Leather Gloves of Nova Shield? You see, their defense rating was only 2, but they did give the wearer a 10 percent chance to cast a Level 3 nova when struck by an attacker.

title: Saving Lives, Satisfying a Hunger for Marmite, Fiddling With Gadgets
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: McGreevey Backs Early Deal on Newark Arena
description: In a conversation with Mayor Sharpe James of Newark, Governor-elect James E. McGreevey said yesterday that he would support an effort by the New Jersey Legislature to reach a deal for a new $355 million sports arena in Newark even before he is inaugurated on Jan. 15.

title: Sales Tax, Key to Budget, Plunges in Nassau
description: As Nassau County's top officials prepare to meet Thursday to try to patch together a budget that could avoid a state takeover, they are facing a major hurdle: the county's biggest revenue source is its sales tax, and no one is sure how badly it has eroded or when it might recover.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAWLER, CHRISTOPHER
description: LAWLER-Christopher. Tragically on November 12, 2001 at age 24 years. Second year law student at St. John's University. Devoted son of Thomas and the late Kathleen C. (nee Blum). Beloved brother of Brendan, Caitlan, and Jennifer. Loving grandson of Anne K. Blum. Reposing at Denis S. O'Connor Funeral Home, 91-05 Beach Channel Drive, Rockaway Beach, NY. Mass of Christian burial on Friday 10 AM at St. Francis De Sales Church, Belle Harbor, NY. Interment St. John's Cemetery. Visiting Thursday 2-5 and 7-10PM. In lieu of flowers donations to The KathieChris Lawler Scholarship Fund for Bishop Kearney High School.

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of yesterday, 4,386 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11.

title: Lincoln's Words and Other Treasures
description: ''I do order and declare that all persons held as slaves within said designated States, and parts of States, are, and henceforward shall be free; and that the Executive government of the United States, including the military and naval authorities thereof, will recognize and maintain the freedom of said persons.'' This statement, signed by Abraham Lincoln on Sept. 22, 1862, is at the core of the Emancipation Proclamation.

title: Additional Budget Cuts As States and Cities Address Safety Issues
description: The Sept. 11 terrorist attacks are leaving a hefty financial bill with state and local governments, forcing them to pay for immediate security needs that were once only vaguely contemplated.

title: Tokyo Journal; Red Light 'Scouts' and Their Gullible Discoveries
description: By dusk, the scouts are as thick on the pavements in Kabukicho as bugs outside a brightly lit room on a summer night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, RUTH
description: GREENBERG-Ruth. Died Nov. 13. Wife of the late Ted Greenberg. Beloved mother of Ellen Hertz and Howard Greenberg. Adoring mother-in-law of Martin Hertz and Ellen Greenberg. Grandmother of Brian and Adam Hertz, and Kate, Corey and Gabrielle Greenberg. Adoring great-grandmother (GiGi) of Sarah, Stephanie & Morgan. Mommy Ruchel, Grandma, Gi-Gi, we will love you forever. We will always miss you and never forget you. Services are at 10 AM, Thursday, November 15, at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Meredith Aman and Jill Duffy were named senior account executive and senior art director, respectively, at S3, Boonton, N.J. Both had worked at Ritta & Associates, Englewood, N.J., Ms. Aman as an account executive and Ms. Duffy as an art director.

title: High Energy and Prices At Contemporary-Art Sale
description: Tried and true American artists like Roy Lichtenstein and Andy Warhol, Jasper Johns and Ellsworth Kelly are exactly what collectors want right now. And that's exactly what Sotheby's was offering last night at its sale of contemporary art.

title: Notes From Underground On Lounge Furnishing
description: ''It's the ultimate basement rec room,'' said Jeffrey Goodman, a partner, with Steven Charlton, in GoodmanCharlton interior designers. It is, of course, if your rec room is built under East 24th Street and contains three coal vaults that have been turned into private rooms in a cocktail lounge. That's fake grass ''growing'' out of the old coal chute at the top of the picture. And if you are looking for the women's room, it's in another vault.

title: Gifts From the East: CD's and Tapes, Teapots And Jewelry Boxes
description: The expanded AsiaStore gift shop, left, is on the main floor of the refurbished Asia Society and Museum, which opens on Saturday. The shop sells books, CD's and videotapes on Asia, as well as home products by Asian designers. One wall is devoted to teapots and tea accouterments. The round lacquered necklace box from China (above) is $98; the red bean-shaped box next to it is $175. The 66-foot-long undulating shoji-like screened wall, left, is by Yoshiki Waterhouse, a designer at Vignelli Associates. Vignelli also designed the museum signs and the gift shop entrance. The New York architect Bartholomew Voorsanger redid the interiors of the Asia Society and Museum, which were designed in 1980 by the architect Edward Larrabee Barnes. The Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue (70th Street); www.asiasociety.org.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Equipment Maker Reports A Loss
description: Applied Materials, the world's largest supplier of chip-making equipment, posted a fourth-quarter loss and warned that it might do so again this quarter, as chip companies delayed orders for new tools. Applied Materials lost $82 million, or 10 cents a share, on sales of $1.26 billion, and said it expected revenue to decline to about $1 billion this quarter. Excluding a $149 million restructuring charge, the company earned 3 cents a share, a penny less than analysts had expected. Adopting an accounting rule that revises the timing of the recognition of revenue, the company restated its sales and earnings for the entire year, making comparisons with the 2000 results difficult. During the fourth quarter last year, the company earned 77 cents a share on sales of $2.92 billion. James C. Morgan, above, the chief executive, said the economic downturn had led to delays in the introduction of new chip-making technologies just as the industry needs them most. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: In Belle Harbor, Strength Walks With Grief
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Companies Largely Back Trade Decisions; Agreement on Medicines
description: The agreement on medicines brokered in Qatar makes it clear that poor countries can make generic versions of expensive brand name drugs for the treatment of AIDS and other serious epidemics -- a situation that the big drug companies have long sought to avoid.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; As he tries to generate revenue, Yahoo's chief moves the company away from its old culture.
description: FOR Terry Semel of Yahoo, this is where the hard part begins.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Pokeweed Warnings

title: Crash Inquiry Focuses on Tail Fin That Broke Off
description: Investigators are focusing on how the tail fin of American Airlines Flight 587 was ripped away from the spine of the aircraft in the moments after takeoff Monday, and what role that played in the deadly crash.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: More Layoffs At Global Crossing
description: Global Crossing, an operator of transoceanic communications networks, said it was cutting another 1,200 jobs in an effort to reduce costs. The move by Global Crossing, which is based in Hamilton, Bermuda, comes after it eliminated 2,000 jobs earlier this year. Global Crossing reported a third-quarter loss of $3.35 billion, compared with a shortfall of $544.1 million a year earlier. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: The Battle for Afghanistan: The Tide Is Turned
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAWLER, KATHLEEN C.
description: LAWLER-Kathleen C. Tragically on November 12, 2001 at age 48 years. Executive secretary with the Diocese of Brooklyn. Beloved wife of Thomas, devoted mother of Brendan, Caitlan, Jennifer and the late Christopher. Loving daughter of Anne K. Blum, dear sister of William J., Francis X., G. Kevin, Anne Marie Greene, Maureen DelVecchio and Mary Ellen Olsen. Reposing at Denis S. O'Connor Funeral Home, 91-05 Beach Channel Dr, Rockaway Beach, New York. A Mass of Christian burial Friday 10AM at St. Francis De Sales Church, Belle Harbor, New York. Interment St. John's Cemetery. Visiting Thursday 2-5 and 7-10 P.M. In lieu of flowers donations to The Kathie-Chris Lawler Scholarship Fund for Bishop Kearney High School.

title: Another Bend In the River For Naipaul; He Tests the Water For Nobel Prize Speech
description: V. S. Naipaul's new novel, ''Half a Life,'' is about the journey -- geographical and emotional -- of Willie Chandran, a man from India who emigrates to England and later Africa. He lives largely through others: his father, his friends, his wife. It is ''about being half a person, of living a borrowed life,'' Mr. Naipaul said during a recent visit to New York.

title: A Verdict on Gatekeepers
description: An article published this month in The New England Journal of Medicine reports a startling discovery: The ''gatekeeper'' physicians who are thought to be so essential to health maintenance organizations may actually do little to reduce costs or block patients' access to specialists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRALEY, DONALD SYMONS, JR., M.D.
description: FRALEY-Donald Symons, Jr., M.D. The Renal-Electrolyte Division and the Department of Medicine of the University of Pittsburgh mourn the passing of Dr. Donald S. Fraley, a cherished friend and exemplary physician. He was a faculty member for 26 years who served as a medical ICU director and was a nationally recognized leader in the academic & medical community. Dr. Fraley served as a role model & mentor for generations of medical students and residents. He was a nationally recognized collector of miniature railroads and served as the editor of the primary reference cataloging the history of Lionel trains. We extend our deepest sympathies to Don's wife, Dr. Zella R. Zeigler his son Donald S. Fraley, III, his mother, Christine Fraley, his sister, Christine Lambert, and his brother Douglas Fraley. We will miss him.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: For Musicians, Microsoft's Xbox Is No Jackpot
description: Tomorrow the Xbox, the new video-game console from Microsoft, arrives in stores on the heels of a $500 million marketing blitz. But it doesn't seem as if much of that money is going to the thousands of musicians who have provided the company with songs to use in the games that will be played on it.

title: What Evil Lurks in the Hearts (and Hard Drives) of Men?
description: DOC SAVAGE had ultraviolet goggles. The Shadow had ''the power to cloud men's minds.'' Chris and David Kalb had a Recoton CD-to-cassette converter.

title: The Battle for Afghanistan: The Tide Is Turned
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Washington: City Council Plans Tax-Free Shopping Days
description: In an effort to reverse declining tourism since the terror attacks, City Council members approved tax-free shopping days for the holiday season. Councilwoman Carol Schwartz said sales taxes on clothing, shoes and accessories priced less than $100 would be dropped from Nov. 23 to Dec. 2. Officials said they did not foresee a loss in revenue from the temporary tax cut, but instead expected to gain thousands of dollars by drawing customers who might buy taxed items over $100.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORN, EDITH
description: KORN-Edith. On Nov. 12, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Robert Korn, dear mother of William (Adrian), Robert and Edward. Cherished grandmother of Rebecca & Emily. Dear sister of Malcolm Lieberman. In her life a painter, sculptor, dancer and teacher. She was a graduate of Hunter College Class of 1938. You can meet with the family at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, Friday, November 16, 2001 at 11AM. Interment is to follow at Bayside Cemetery, Ozone Park Queens, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAMBAUGH, RANDOLPH U.
description: STAMBAUGH-Randolph U. On October 26, 2001 at age 90. Former president of B. Altman & Co., New York City. Survived by his wife, Mary Clark Stambaugh; his two daughters, Anne Satterthwaite (Henry), and Dana Semeraro (Richard); three grandchildren, Dana Amy Jonson, Randolph Jonson, and Kenneth Semeraro. Also survived by his sister, Mary Shafer. He was predeceased by his wife of 50 years, Virginia Wiggins Stambaugh in 1987.

title: Below Rubble, a Tour of a Still-Burning Hell
description: A descent beneath the World Trade Center is a passage into a grotesque landscape of stalagmites formed by dripping metal, entire office floors compressed into a space of six inches, and train cars smashed all the way down to the tracks by collapsed concrete ceilings.

title: Don't Call for Philip Morris; Company to Change Its Name
description: The Philip Morris Companies, the owner of one of the world's best-known corporate names, plans to change that name next year to Altria Group Inc., the company said today.

title: Michael DeMarco, 65, a Judge And a Councilman in New York
description: Michael DeMarco, who was the longest-serving city councilman in New York when he resigned in 1997 to become a New York State Supreme Court judge, died on Sunday at a hospital in the Bronx. He was 65.

title: 'Corrections' Is Winner Of Top Prize For Fiction
description: ''The Corrections,'' Jonathan Franzen's modernist epic of a dysfunctional family and a mother's efforts to get her grown children to come home for one last Christmas, won the National Book Award for Fiction tonight.

title: Panel Defeats Effort to Give Billions More To New York
description: A measure that would have provided billions of dollars to help New York recover from the Sept. 11 terrorist attack was narrowly defeated tonight by a House committee after the White House applied pressure on lawmakers to oppose it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHULMAN, MAX L.
description: SHULMAN-Max L. The American Committee for the Weizmann Institute of Science mourns the passing of Major Max L. Shulman, dedicated ACWIS board member; President's Circle member; benefactor of the Joe and Celia Weinstein Scholarship; & avid supporter of the Weizmann Institute. We extend heartfelt condolences to his wife Sylvia Weinstein Shulman, son Lloyd Shulman, daughter Gail Koster, and the entire family. Robert H. Asher, Chairman, American Committee Albert Willner, M.D., President Martin Kraar, Exec. V.P. Gershon Kekst, Chairman Weizmann Institute of Science Prof. Haim Harari, President

title: Kesey's Words Resonate At the End of a Long Trip
description: The message was simply said to be from ''Kesey'' and posted on the author's Web site, IntrepidTrips.com, shortly after his death here last Saturday.

title: Clarke Talks About Lindros
description: No matter how hard Philadelphia Flyers General Manager Bob Clarke tries to keep calm when the subject is Eric Lindros, he cannot help himself. Clarke's long-running dispute with Lindros and his parents led to Lindros's trade to the Rangers on Aug. 20. Lindros has gone out of his way not to say anything that might rekindle the feud.

title: George A. Kiersch, 83, Field Geologist and Professor
description: Dr. George Alfred Kiersch, a geologist who used his expertise to find the proper sites for large-scale projects like dams and power plants and then built them, died on Oct. 19 in Tucson, Ariz., where he lived in retirement. He was 83.

title: Nathan Pusey, Harvard President Through Growth and Turmoil Alike, Dies at 94
description: Nathan M. Pusey, who led Harvard University through tremendous growth and liberalization only to be swept away in a storm over Vietnam-era protests, died yesterday at New York Weill Cornell Center in Manhattan. He was 94 and lived on the East Side.

title: Ex-Executive of Christie's Tells of Collusion Scheme
description: A onetime printer who aspired to the heights of London society as chief executive of Christie's auction house testified yesterday that the former chairmen of Christie's and Sotheby's masterminded a scheme to squelch competition and boost profits and deployed him and a high-level Sotheby's deputy to carry it out.

title: PRIMEDIA WILL SELL ITS BACON'S INFORMATION UNIT
description: Primedia Inc., the publisher of Seventeen, New York and more than 250 other magazines, agreed yesterday to sell its Bacon's Information unit to Observer A.B., a Swedish media company, for $90 million. Primedia acquired Bacon's, which sells media directories and press information to public relations agencies, in 1995 for $50 million. It would be Observer's first acquisition in the United States. Primedia, based in New York, has said it plans to sell more than $250 million in assets to pare roughly $2 billion in debt the company incurred after it bought the United States magazine unit of Emap in August. Primedia's credit ratings were reduced earlier this month by Moody's Investors Service after the company's third-quarter loss widened.

title: Salazar and Lewis Among 4 Entering Hall
description: Alberto Salazar reminisced yesterday about two races that defined his running career. One was predictable: his world-best time of 2 hours 8 minutes 13 seconds in 1982 for his third consecutive victory in the New York City Marathon. The other race was almost obscure.

title: Hewlett Profit, Off 89%, Stirs New Optimism For Merger
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company reported yesterday that its quarterly earnings fell sharply, down 89 percent from a year ago as revenue declined 18 percent. Yet because its financial results exceeded Wall Street's lowered expectations, Hewlett-Packard executives and some analysts pointed to the figures as a positive sign for its planned merger with Compaq Computer.

title: National Briefing | Labor: Hoffa Takes Lead In Teamsters Race
description: James P. Hoffa, who is seeking re-election to the presidency of the Teamsters union, surged into the lead with about one-quarter of the 330,000 votes counted. Federal officials counting the votes in Alexandria, Va., said Mr. Hoffa had 53,549 votes to 24,325 for his opponent, Tom Leedham, a union official from Oregon. Those votes were from the Eastern region, with votes still to be counted from Canada and the South, West and Central regions. The Hoffa forces were forecasting victory, while the Leedham campaign said it was not ready to concede.

title: Red Cross Pledges Entire Terror Fund To Sept. 11 Victims
description: The American Red Cross, humbled by weeks of scathing criticism, announced today that it would use its $543 million Liberty Disaster Fund only to assist the people affected by the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, a decision that guarantees families hundreds of millions of dollars in additional charitable aid.

title: To Play Emperor or God, or Grunt in a Tennis Skirt
description: Here are a reviewer's choices of the year's best videogames:

title: Brothers Plead Guilty in Mob Payoffs for Construction Businesses
description: A pair of brothers prominent in the construction industry pleaded guilty today to charges that they paid off organized crime figures in exchange for labor peace.

title: Toys That Teach, and Learn; They May Even Help You With Your Homework or Your Taxes
description: CHECKMATE -- Saitek says some of the 500-level combinations in its portable Kasparov Cosmos chess computer ($120) will ''beat 99 percent of all chess players.'' But the Cosmos isn't entirely ruthless. A coaching program warns players when a tactical error is about to be made.

title: The Battle for Afghanistan: The Tide Is Turned
description: To the Editor:

title: Growth in Albany Spending Is Double Rate of Inflation
description: State spending will grow by more than twice the rate of inflation this fiscal year, at a time when the government already faces a shortfall of at least $1.6 billion after the Sept. 11 attacks, budget officials said today.

title: INSIDE
description: OPEC Delays Cut in Output

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Unemployment Rises
description: For the first time since last year, British joblessness rose last month as companies reduced their work forces in a slowing economy. Unemployment measured as the number of people out of work and claiming benefits, rose to 3.2 percent in October compared with 3.1 percent in September, still the lowest in major industrialized nations, according to government figures. Most of the cuts were in the shrinking manufacturing sector. But the Bank of England said it did not believe that Britain was heading for recession, easing pressure for further interest rate cuts. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Standoff in Macedonia Threatening NATO-Backed Peace Plan
description: Ethnic Albanian gunmen and Macedonian police forces remained in a tense standoff today around several villages in western Macedonia, once more threatening the tortuous and much delayed peace process just before a final parliamentary vote on Thursday.

title: Corrections
description: A book review on Tuesday about ''Reaching for Glory: Lyndon Johnson's Secret White House Tapes, 1964-1965'' referred imprecisely to the recordings upon which Robert Dallek drew for his 1998 biography of Johnson, ''Flawed Giant.'' They were from an earlier batch of tapes; those in ''Reaching for Glory'' had not been previously released.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Man Guilty In Officer's Death
description: A man who led a police officer on a high-speed chase that ended in the officer's death has pleaded guilty to attempted assault, prosecutors said yesterday. Under a plea entered on Tuesday, the man, Guido Tritto, 44, of Staten Island, will serve six years, longer than the term carried by the most serious charge in his indictment, criminally negligent homicide, prosecutors said. Officer John M. Kelly, 31, was killed on July 17, 2000, when his patrol car crashed into a utility pole in Bloomfield while chasing Mr. Tritto, who had been stopped for speeding. Sentencing is set for Dec. 3. Richard Lezin Jones (NYT)

title: Taliban Negotiating Surrender of Kunduz, Their Last Stronghold in Afghanistan's North
description: A large garrison of Taliban troops trapped in Kunduz, in northern Afghanistan, continued to defy the Northern Alliance on Wednesday as warlords from both sides met for several hours to try to avert a bloodletting.

title: Windows as Mirrors of a City's Mood; After Sept. 11, Department Stores Rethink Holiday Displays
description: Last spring when Simon Doonan, the creative director of Barneys New York, was musing about what to put into the store's holiday windows, he kept thinking of Rudy.

title: To Survive, Ma, Never Look Back
description: History pulls a disappearing act in ''Everett Beekin,'' Richard Greenberg's haunted, restless meditation on American rootlessness. This tantalizing new play from the author of ''Eastern Standard'' and ''Three Days of Rain'' tells a tale of two families who shed their pasts as instinctively as snakes molt their skins.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: New Bioterrorism Panel
description: Governor-elect James E. McGreevey convened a panel of health experts yesterday to devise strategies for countering bioterrorism. The 21-member panel includes physicians, hospital officials, registered nurses and public health experts, who will recommend measures to the McGreevey administration. There have been five confirmed cases of anthrax in New Jersey, and anthrax spores have been found at seven postal facilities in the state. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Boss on Cover Raises Issues For Magazine
description: When Fortune went searching for ''the smartest people we know'' to poll on the subject of the future, the magazine did not look too far in one case.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Nations Back Freer Trade, Hoping to Aid Global Growth

title: Footlights
description: In Exile

title: Charity on the Web; After Attacks, Selective Shopping Aids the Bereft
description: THIS year's holiday season will unfold in the shadow of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. While many Web sites are selling items with partial proceeds going to funds for victims' families, some sites offer gifts whose full sales price will be donated to charities like the American Red Cross, the New York State World Trade Center Fund, the September 11th Fund and the Twin Towers Fund.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Premier To Take The Stand
description: In a move calculated to emphasize his ''Mr. Clean'' image for the presidential election next year, Prime Minister Lionel Jospin has asked for and gotten permission to appear as a witness in a corruption investigation aimed at his own Socialist Party. The appearance, believed to be the first for a serving prime minister, will be in sharp contrast to President Jacques Chirac, who has consistently refused to take part in a similar investigations into illicit funding for his Rally for the Republic party, citing constitutional immunity. Mr. Jospin, widely expected to challenge Mr. Chirac for the presidency, needed permission from the cabinet to testify. Suzanne Daley (NYT)

title: A Holiday Buying Guide to Technology
description: function pop_me_up(pURL, features) { new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features); new_window.focus(); }

title: Decorators Roam Where the Deer and the Antelope Play
description: MOST of us accept fur-trimmed suede coats and fake animal-skin pillows piled on the sofa. Now, as if from some great collective-unconscious storage closet, have arrived embalmed pets, preserved deer heads and stuffed emus to decorate home and store. While the attitude may be ironic, the taxidermy is real.

title: Just Another Game? That's What Giants Say
description: The Giants convened today to begin their first preparations for Monday night's game in Minnesota against the Vikings. Now if they only knew which Vikings they were preparing to play.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOBIN, CLAIRE
description: TOBIN-Claire. Beloved wife of the late Charles. Devoted mother of Judith & Jay Tobin. Fond motherin-law of Dolores. Cherished grandmother of Todd (Leigh). Graveside services on Friday, 12:30 PM at Wellwood Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

title: Soriano Plans to Help Crash Victims
description: Alfonso Soriano first heard the worried voices of his friends and family after waking up in his New Jersey apartment on Monday. There were 10 or 11 messages on his cellular phone, all from people asking whether he had been on the American Airlines jetliner to the Dominican Republic that had crashed in Queens. His mother, Andrea, had left three of the messages, sobbing into her phone. She was the first person he called back.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Phone Layoffs
description: The second- and third-largest telecommunications companies in Australia both announced layoffs and cost-cutting measures yesterday to stem losses. Cable and Wireless Optus will eliminate 560 jobs, bringing to 10 percent the share of its work force laid off since Singapore Telecommunications took control of it two months ago. Vodafone Australia said it would lay off an unspecified number of workers as it tries to cut operating costs up to 50 percent. Competition and slack demand in the industry forced several smaller companies out of business this year, including One.Tel, which was backed by the News Corporation. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: Kovalev and Penguins Rally to Tie Isles
description: Stadium workers skidded across the ice at Mellon Arena late tonight, collecting caps and souvenir pucks and putting them in white trash bags. How quickly Aleksei Kovalev had injected some electricity into an arena that had been as noisy as the stacks in a library. How quickly he made a stone-cold Islanders lead melt.

title: Retail Sales Increase 7.1%, Mostly From Car Incentives
description: Retail sales surged 7.1 percent in October, almost three times analysts' expectations, as consumers spent money at auto dealers, department and discount stores and building supply outlets.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: No Accord On Deficit Reduction
description: State legislative leaders failed to agree yesterday on budget cuts to close a $300 million deficit, despite Gov. John G. Rowland's statement that workers might face layoffs without an agreement soon. Meetings on the $13 billion budget continued yesterday. Republican leaders seek an across-the-board cut in proposed increases to programs, as Mr. Rowland wishes. The Democrats, who want smaller cuts, the issuance of about $100 million in bonds and delays in paying some expenses until next year, were preparing a bill to address the deficit last night. The special session of the General Assembly is set to end tomorrow, but lawmakers can extend it.

title: In London, One Dollar for One Pound
description: Anyone in London who offers to swap their pounds for your dollars at a one-to-one rate is either weak on currency exchange or is desperate for business. You can be the judge if you take advantage of a deal from the Athenaeum Hotel and Apartments, in the Mayfair district of London. Until Jan. 31, the hotel is taking its regular rates (265 pounds Monday to Thursday, 199 pounds on weekends) and putting a dollar sign in front of them. That works out to a savings of about 40 percent, and the rates include full English breakfast daily and tax. Information: (800) 335-3300 or www.athenaeumhotel.com .

title: ATLANTIC BANK OF NEW YORK BUYS YONKERS FINANCIAL
description: Atlantic Bank of New York, a unit of National Bank of Greece, agreed yesterday to pay $69.6 million for the Yonkers Financial Corporation as the bank shifts its focus from the Greek-American community and moves into the New York City suburbs. Atlantic will pay $29 for each Yonkers share, the companies said in a joint statement. Yonkers shares rose $1.67 to $28.57 in trading yesterday on the Nasdaq. The acquisition adds Yonkers Financial's nine branches in Westchester and Dutchess Counties, north of New York City, to Atlantic's 12 offices in Manhattan, Queens, Brooklyn, Long Island and Boston. The combined bank will have assets of almost $2.6 billion.

title: Ashcroft Says I.N.S. Will Be Split to Refocus Responsibilities
description: Attorney General John Ashcroft said today that the Immigration and Naturalization Service would be split into two bureaus to streamline its border enforcement and service responsibilities.

title: Sorenstam Set to Finish Year to Remember
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 14 — As she prepared to conclude her remarkable season, Annika Sorenstam was asked if she was the player to beat this week. Sorenstam looked directly at her questioner and did not hesitate.

title: Newmont Pursues 2 Buyouts, Aiming to Be No. 1 in Gold
description: Newmont Mining unveiled today a two-pronged plan to become the world's biggest gold company, with agreements to take over Normandy Mining, Australia's leading producer, and Franco-Nevada Mining of Toronto for a total of about $4.4 billion in stock and cash. Newmont would also assume about $750 million in debt.

title: Dutch Warmerdam, Pole-Vaulter, Dies at 86
description: Cornelius (Dutch) Warmerdam, the greatest pole-vaulter in the era before fiberglass poles changed the sport and the first man to clear 15 feet, died Tuesday in Fresno, Calif. He was 86.

title: Gadgets on the Fly; With the Right Hardware, Even a Business Trip Can Feel Like Escape
description: CLICK JUNIOR -- Like its larger brethren, the Atek Electronics Super Mini Optical Mouse ($50) uses a tiny digital camera rather than a rolling ball to track its movements. Roughly the size of a lipstick tube, the tiny mouse can sit on the palm-rest area of most laptop computers, making the tightest airplane seat tray a workstation.

title: The Battle for Afghanistan: The Tide Is Turned
description: To the Editor:

title: N.J. Transit in 'Financial Morass,' Study Says
description: New Jersey Transit is facing a financial crisis caused in part by its use of state and federal funds intended for long-term projects and maintenance to pay its day-to-day operating costs, an independent study warned today.

title: Closer Look At New Plan For Trying Terrorists
description: A day after President Bush signed an order allowing special military tribunals to try foreigners charged with terrorism, a more detailed picture of what government planners envision began to emerge.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: Lindros Scores and Roars, and Richter Is a Rock
description: There was a playoff atmosphere at Madison Square Garden last night that has been missing for more than four seasons, and Eric Lindros and Mike Richter were the stars of the show.

title: Team Is Ready to Publish Full Set of Dead Sea Scrolls
description: Fifty-four years after the discovery of the first of the Dead Sea Scrolls, a sensation in 20th-century archaeology, all the ancient texts have finally been published, or nearly so.

title: Lewis Wants to Make New Knockout Video
description: Up and down the Strip, from the gaudy casino lobbies to the hotel-room television promotions, the five-second video footage of their last fight plays, over and over.

title: Grand Jury Indicts Ex-I.R.S. Employee
description: A federal grand jury in Chicago indicted a former Internal Revenue Service employee yesterday on charges of accepting bribes from 1992 until 1997 to delay tax collections.

title: More Signs Of Downturn For Europe
description: They are not using the word recession yet, but some of Europe's biggest corporations provided new evidence today that a real downturn may come sooner rather than later.

title: Want a Stove Like a Pro's? Ask a Chef
description: THE fantasy is to cook a holiday meal on the kind of appliance that inspires confidence, that gleams with purpose. In other words, a professional-style range, a rugged, boxy implement whose burners torch 15,000 B.T.U.'s under a saut pan, or flutter with a tiny flame to make a perfect beurre blanc. A stove whose oven could handle a Norman Rockwell-size turkey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, ESTHER LAMM
description: MILLER-Esther Lamm. Of Boca Raton, Florida, on November 13. Beloved mother of Marlene Spigner and the late Stephen Lamm. Dear sister of Tessie Soloway. Sweetest Nana & Great Grandma. Graveside service on Thursday, November 15 at 1 PM, Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SOYBEANS RISE. Soybeans climbed on signs of robust overseas demand for oilseed from this year's record United States crop. In Chicago, soybeans for January delivery rose 2 cents, or 0.4 percent, to $4.4725 a bushel.

title: Mets Could Use Bonds But Cannot Afford Him
description: When it comes to Barry Bonds, Mets General Manager Steve Phillips said yesterday, ''The baseball evaluation is the easy part.'' In fact, few evaluations could be more elementary: Bonds is coming off one of the best offensive seasons in history, and the Mets are desperate for hitters.

title: A Ford Report to the S.E.C. Hints At Chief's Rich Severance Deal
description: The Ford Motor Company lifted the veil shrouding the severance agreement with its former chief executive, Jacques A. Nasser, yesterday, but only slightly.

title: Democrats' Stimulus Plan For Economy Dies in Senate
description: Senate Republicans used procedural votes today to kill a $73 billion Democratic economic stimulus plan. After a party line vote failed to advance the measure, talks about alternatives accelerated.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GLEICHER, SUSAN KREVLIN
description: GLEICHER-Susan Krevlin. In loving memory of our beloved daughter and sister who died so tragically in an automobile accident 15 years ago today. Special hugs from sons Jonathan and Adam who hold you always in their hearts. Mom and Dad

title: With Just a Hint of a Plot, Taking It Easy. Very Easy.
description: There are likely to be some people who'll get a laugh out of the loose -- extremely loose -- new comedy ''The Wash'' just by watching Dr. Dre shout ''I'm the L.A.P.D.!'' during a dream sequence. Then again, there are probably others who would guffaw when the credit ''A Film by D.J. Pooh'' rolls across the screen. Mostly, ''Wash'' is a competition to see who can give the most relaxed performance in any recent film: Dr. Dre or his homey and co-star, Snoop Dogg. It's a fierce battle, but Dr. Dre prevails, just barely.

title: Powering Out the Stains On the Most Delicate Linens
description: Laundering fine table linens, especially those with stains after Thanksgiving, can be a challenge. Blanc Plume, a laundry service in Kansas City, Mo., specializes in cleaning delicate table linens and fine and antique bedding, as well as in restoring textiles. Cleaning two sheets and pillow cases is $29; tablecloths are $1 to $2 a square foot; napkins and place mats, $3 each. Shipping to Blanc Plume is free (with a label downloaded from www.blancplume.com). Linens are returned via U.P.S. for $3.95, plus 50 cents a pound. If you are not satisfied, recleaning is free, and so is the next order. The Blanc Plume number is (800) 307-0229. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: A Holiday Buying Guide to Technology
description: function pop_me_up(pURL, features) { new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features); new_window.focus(); }

title: Exemption Legislation Introduced
description: Members of both houses of Congress introduced legislation today that would strip baseball's antitrust exemption on decisions involving the elimination or relocation of major league teams.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO GAINS. The dollar slipped as United States stocks failed to keep the day's best levels, crimping demand for the currency. In New York, the euro settled at 88.28 cents, up from 88.13 cents on Tuesday.

title: Tuberculosis Group Tries to Spur Research for New Antibiotics
description: Trying to entice major drug companies into plunging into the tuberculosis market, the new Global Alliance for TB Drug Development is to release a study on Thursday that estimates that the market will be worth $700 million a year by 2010.

title: Forget Store Windows: Web Wares Beckon
description: IN the past, if holiday shopping brought to mind one thing, it was frustration. Too many shoppers, too few salesclerks, not enough merchandise. Your mouse can provide some relief: shopping online means you need not stand in line. In addition, specialty retailers abound on the Web.

title: In America; Poison Politics
description: Have New York Democrats learned any lessons from the mayoral debacle of 2001? Or are they crazy enough to continue drinking from the poisonous well of ethnic politics?

title: A Little Sorcery, Only for Wizards (And Designers)
description: The staff at Hogwart's boarding school really understand mood lighting. Early in ''Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone,'' first-year students arrive in the main hall, below, for the ''sorting ceremony.'' Among the decorations is a field of levitating candles. Although it was produced by special effects, a similar look was achieved last year during the International Contemporary Furniture Fair with ''Harlem Lights: A Night at the Alhambra,'' right, an installation by the German lighting designer Ingo Maurer. Mr. Maurer is the distributor for Georg Baldele's 1996 Fly Candle Fly candles, which, with a wire attached, are suspended in midair. Unfortunately, you cannot replicate the feat at home (no matter how much the children beg) because the candles are not available here. Mr. Maurer's company said that ''due to 'open fire' manufacturer's liability rules and regulations in the U.S. and Canada, unfortunately insurers refuse to cover the liability risk or the premium is too high.'' STEPHEN TREFFINGER

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Bosnian Serbs File Charges
description: The United Nations war crimes tribunal has received and will examine documents from Bosnian Serb authorities charging the former Bosnian president, Alija Izetbegovic, with war crimes. Mr. Izetbegovic, a Muslim who led the government during the 1992-95 Bosnian war, has not been accused of any crimes by the tribunal. In a separate case, a former vice admiral from Yugoslavia, Miodrag Jokic, pleaded not guilty to charges of war crimes in connection with the 1991 attack on the city of Dubrovnik in Croatia. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Washington: Committee Adds $6 Billion To Food Stamp Proposal
description: The Senate Agriculture Committee voted to add $6 billion to the food stamp program in the committee's proposed farm bill. The vote followed the release of a national study by America's Second Harvest network of food banks showing that the demand for private charities was rising as financing for the food stamp program declined. The bill would also simplify food stamp rules to encourage people to take advantage of the program. Elizabeth Becker (NYT)

title: Filmmakers Send a Message With Lego as the Medium
description: LIKE many filmmakers, Rob Weychert has his ambitions. He used Stravinsky's ''Rite of Spring'' in one film and he makes allusions to ''Brave New World'' in another. He adores the films of Todd Solondz, whom he calls ''the modern master of black comedy.''

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Moving Fast, With Anchor

title: Deaths of Women in Car Crashes Are Rising, Study Finds
description: The number of women killed in car crashes increased 60 percent from the mid-1970's to the late 1990's, according to a study to be released today by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety.

title: Corrections
description: A dance review on Oct. 31 about ''The Book of Love'' by Doug Elkins misidentified the performer with Alexander Excalante in a duet set to the song ''Anyone Who Had a Heart.'' She was Rebecca Chisman, not Sharon Estacio.

title: Oil Prices in Flux as OPEC Decides Against Cut in Output
description: Creating the prospect of a devastating price war, OPEC said today that it would not cut production further unless major producers outside the group also decreased their output sizably by Jan. 1.

title: A Holy Quest in Tibet: Prostrate, and Miles to Go
description: The snows had scarcely melted last June when 24-year-old Joama and her three male cousins, yak herders in the remote mountains of northern Tibet, embarked on the most sublime journey of their lives.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about a memorial service at the site of the World Trade Center for victims from some 80 nations who died in the Sept. 11 attacks misidentified the soprano who sang there two weeks earlier in a contrasting service. (The same error occurred on Oct. 29 and was corrected in this space on the 30th.) The singer was Rene Fleming, not Kathleen Battle.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the National Briefing column on Tuesday about sanctions imposed by Johns Hopkins University for improper research referred incorrectly to a professor who tested cancer drugs on patients without the approval of a review board. The professor, Ru Chih C. Huang, is a woman.

title: Rights of Students
description: To the Editor:

title: Essay; Seizing Dictatorial Power
description: Misadvised by a frustrated and panic-stricken attorney general, a president of the United States has just assumed what amounts to dictatorial power to jail or execute aliens. Intimidated by terrorists and inflamed by a passion for rough justice, we are letting George W. Bush get away with the replacement of the American rule of law with military kangaroo courts.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the European Union's expansion plans misstated the given name of its commissioner for enlargement. He is Gnter Verheugen, not Gnther.

title: U.S. Companies Largely Back Trade Decisions
description: With some notable caveats, many American companies yesterday endorsed the World Trade Organization's new rules for negotiating a trade agreement, arguing that the potential for increased exports outweighs the damage a few industries might suffer.

title: Cubism Finds Itself At Home
description: THE cube, when finished in high-gloss enamel or glove-soft suede, can be more than a simple box. It is a seat, a storage space or a resting place for a lamp or two feet. In short, a cube can be practical in any size home.

title: Nations Move to Send Troops to Keep Order in Afghanistan
description: AUnited Nations resolution has opened the way for multinational military efforts to maintain law and order in Afghanistan and to provide aid in rebuilding the country. Several countries said they were preparing to send troops and diplomats to help establish an Afghan government.

title: Moss Finally Set to Dirty His Uniform
description: Santana Moss grew up about 10 blocks from Pro Player Stadium in Miami. He played in a bowl game there while at the University of Miami and caught 5 passes for 141 yards and a touchdown. Two younger brothers still play at Carol City High School, where Moss was a track star before emerging in football.

title: Hearing for Pakistani Student
description: The president of the Pakistan Student Association at the University of Oklahoma in Norman will face immigration charges today at a hearing in Oklahoma City, according to documents filed for the hearing.

title: Northern Alliance, in Charge, Tries to Ease Fears of Captives
description: Serving alongside Pakistani, Chechen and Arab volunteers, Atiqurahman manned a post on the second line of Taliban forces in the village of Kalai Nasro near the Bagram air base 35 miles north of Kabul.

title: Fight in Philadelphia Over Schools Takeover
description: Kelly Smith-Shepard says she is angry that after eight years as a student in the city's public school system, her son James cannot answer basic questions about books he has just finished and reads at a sixth-grade level at best, even though he is in the seventh grade.

title: Schlopy's Tour May End in Salt Lake City
description: At the end of 13-hour road trips, on the tuckered tires of a used minivan, Erik Schlopy would pull into the parking lot of a motel generally behind a local bowling alley.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the appointment of Raymond W. Kelly as New York police commissioner misspelled the surname of a former aide who is likely to join him at the Police Department. The aide is Paul Browne, not Brown.

title: Don't Call for Philip Morris; Company to Change Its Name
description: The Philip Morris Companies ( news/quote ), the owner of one of the world's best-known corporate names, plans to change that name next year to Altria Group Inc., the company said today.

title: Palestinian Authority Arrests Jihad Leader, Causing a Riot
description: Palestinians rioted against Yasir Arafat's security forces today in the West Bank after officers in Jenin arrested a man accused by Israel of orchestrating suicide attacks against Israelis.

title: Nuclear Plant Plans to Add Gas Power
description: Arguing that gas and nuclear power can co-exist peacefully, Entergy Corporation, the owner of the Indian Point nuclear power plants, has announced its intention to build eight gas-fired power plants at the nuclear site in Westchester County.

title: U.S. Is Reportedly Prepared To Allow Food Sales to Cuba
description: For the first time since the United States imposed trade sanctions against Cuba four decades ago, Havana is negotiating a deal with American producers to buy food and agricultural products to replenish stocks destroyed by a recent hurricane.

title: Cayman Bank Deposits
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Welfare Minister Quits
description: Social Security Minister Patricia Bullrich, an important aide to President Fernando de la Ra, resigned citing a lack of political will to eliminate overlapping welfare programs. Mr. De la Ra appointed Ms. Bullrich to the recently created Social Security Ministry last month to supervise a $3.1 billion program to extend welfare benefits to more Argentine families. She had been Labor Minister until last month, when labor leaders called for her transfer to another post. Susan Gotthelf (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNIPE, ALICE
description: KNIPE-Alice. On November 13, 2001. Beloved wife of Cortland. Mother of George Fearons, Jr. & grandmother of George Fearons. Services Friday, 11AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St. Entombment to follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Prosecutors Begin Effort to Interview 5,000, but Basic Questions Remain
description: The interviews will take place in homes, not police stations. Miranda rights need not be read, though lawyers are welcome to sit in. Interpreters should be provided. Do not ask about religion. Do ask about violence and terrorism. Feel free to mention reward money.

title: First Class, by Bus
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Netherlands: UPC Shares Fall
description: United Pan-Europe Communications N.V.'s shares fell 12 percent after the company said it might be removed from the main Dutch stock index and on investor concern it will convert debt into new shares. The stock of the company, Europe's second-largest cable television concern, fell 7 cents, to 51 cents, valuing UPC at about $199 million. UPC, which is majority-owned by UnitedGlobalCom Inc. of Denver, was valued at about $32 billion in March 2000. UPC shares plunged this year on speculation the company would run out of cash before becoming profitable as it upgrades cable networks it acquired to sell digital TV, faster Internet connections and telephone services. The company said its third-quarter loss widened to $625.8 million from $563.6 million in the period a year earlier.

title: Biotech Drug For Angina Is Promising, Doctors Say
description: A drug developed by a California biotechnology company could become the first new type of treatment for the chest pain of angina in more than two decades, doctors said here today.

title: Nations Back Freer Trade, Hoping to Aid Global Growth
description: Reaching a consensus that they hope will rejuvenate the world's economy, trade ministers from more than 140 nations agreed today on an agenda to topple tariffs and liberalize trade on everything from wheat to insurance policies.

title: U.S. Companies Largely Back Trade Decisions; Agricultural Trade
description: American agriculture officials said they were pleased with the outcome of W.T.O. meetings because it meant members of the group were prepared to move toward reductions of tariffs and other barriers to agricultural trade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENGLISH, REV. RICHARD PAUL, S.J.
description: ENGLISH-Rev. Richard Paul, S.J. Dear brother of Sr. Francis Cecilia, S.S.J. Reposing at the Jesuit Community Chapel at Murray-Weigel Hall, 515 East Fordham Road. Visitation Friday 3-5 & 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday 11:30AM. For information, contact Farenga Brothers, Inc. 718-654-0500.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ALDRICH, LARRY
description: ALDRICH-Larry. A celebration of the life of Larry Aldrich will take place at 2:00 PM on November 18, 2001, at the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art, 258 Main St., Ridgefield, CT. Bus transportation will be available from 40 Central Park South at 12:15. To RSVP or for more information, please contact the Museum at 203-438-4519.

title: Kodak Realigns Operations As Slump in Demand Persists
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, contending with precipitous drops in revenue and profit, said yesterday that it was realigning its businesses along product lines rather than geographic ones.

title: Eisley Is Given Backup Position
description: Practice had been over for 45 minutes, and most of the Knicks were either in the shower, in the training room or heading home. But Howard Eisley, finally satisfied with the number of 3-pointers and free throws he had made, was just leaving the court.

title: Digital Brushes for Creative Drives; It's True That Computers Alone Can't Make Great Art. But They Can Help.
description: TRICORDER -- Flatbed scanners that read negatives and slides as well as prints have generally been very expensive. The Epson Perfection 1250 Photo Scanner ($149) comes with an adapter unit for reading 35-millimeter slides and negatives. It has an optical resolution of 1,200 by 2,400 dots per inch and can generate files with 48-bit color depth. The supplied software can automate some of the work in converting Dad's old Kodachromes into digital files and can even optimize scans for prints or for attachments to e-mail.

title: Spain Is Seeking 3 Militants Linked to bin Laden Network
description: The Spanish police, who dismantled a radical recruitment cell this week after it was linked to Osama bin Laden's Al Qaeda network, said they were searching for another three Islamic militants who appeared in a video seized in police raids on Tuesday.

title: Negotiators Say They're Near Accord on Legislation to Strengthen Security at Airports
description: House and Senate negotiators said tonight that they were close to agreement on legislation that would tighten security at the nation's airports by having federal employees do most screening of passengers and baggage.

title: Airline Management Style Honed by Catastrophe
description: Donald J. Carty, the chief executive of American Airlines, was just settling in at his office in Fort Worth on Monday morning when the call came that an American flight had crashed near Kennedy Airport.

title: Different Results for 2 Stores in 3rd Quarter
description: Federated Department Stores Inc. swung to a profit in the third quarter, and Tiffany & Company's net income fell 34 percent, the companies said yesterday.

title: FORD IS EXTENDING INTEREST-FREE-LOAN INCENTIVES
description: The Ford Motor Company said yesterday that it had extended its interest-free loans on cars and trucks until Jan. 14, following its larger rival, the General Motors Corporation, on incentives that spurred record sales last month. Ford will offer the no-interest loans on all models except the Thunderbird car and Escape sport utility vehicle, said a spokeswoman, Susan Krusel. Even as Ford extended the offer, its chairman and chief executive, William Clay Ford Jr., told a business group in Kansas City, Mo.: ''Maybe the first part of next year isn't going to be great for us. There is going to be a payback. Ultimately, we have to find a way to wean ourselves off this.'' Ford's shares fell 9 cents, to $16.34. The stock has declined 30 percent this year.

title: Xerox And Child: A Story Reproduced
description: WHEN I joined the line outside the office supply store one day a couple of years ago, I felt more than slightly foolish. It was cold and drizzly, and the place wasn't set to open for an hour.

title: Corrections
description: A credit listing on Wednesday with the review of ''Three Willies,'' a jazz opera by Leroy Jenkins, misstated the surname of the librettist. He was Homer Jackson, not Jenkins.

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIA

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Unemployment Rate Climbs
description: The state's unemployment rate climbed seven-tenths of 1 percent, to 6.2 percent in October, state employment officials said, announcing the first figures to show the effects of the Sept. 11 attacks. Economists say the increase in unemployment means the state is in a recession that could last into next year. The service sector was hit hardest, losing 7,800 jobs. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: The Neediest Cases; Fleeing Abuse for a Life of Joy and Independence
description: She's 31 now and living in New York, but Eleanor Bailey's eyes still dart nervously around the room at the mention of her father.

title: Measuring Success: At Least the Talks Didn't Collapse
description: For the Bush administration and other proponents of increasing commerce across borders, the biggest success of the trade talks that ended today in Qatar was that they did not fail.

title: Senior Administration Officials Defend Military Tribunals for Terrorist Suspects
description: Top administration officials today defended a presidential order allowing military tribunals to try foreigners charged with terrorism as the Pentagon prepared for the potential transfer of immigrants detained by the Justice Department into military custody.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: 23 Men Sentenced On Gay Sex Charges
description: In a case widely condemned by human rights organizations, the Emergency State Security Court sentenced 23 men accused of homosexual activity to jail terms ranging from one to five years. The court also acquitted 29 men. Most defendants were seized during a raid on a Nile riverboat disco last May in what critics called an attempt to bolster the government's Islamic credentials by stifling an emerging gay rights movement. A teen-ager tried separately was previously sentenced to three years in jail. Neil MacFarquhar (NYT)

title: The Wireless Future. Maybe.
description: I'm at the Comdex technology trade show in Las Vegas this week, attending one of the grisliest reminders that the new economy is not what it was a few years ago. Perhaps as an antidote to the financial pain the attendees and exhibitors are feeling these days, the keynote speakers seem unusually eager to make predictions about technology's future -- and exclusively rosy ones.

title: A Depression Diner, Brimming With Danger and Dreams
description: Ah, for those carefree Depression days, when bad guys dealt in nice, understandable shoot-'em-ups and strangers could fall hopelessly in love in the time it takes to eat a burger.

title: A Trade Deal in Doha
description: The 144 nations of the World Trade Organization defied expectations and their own protectionist instincts yesterday by approving an agenda that over the next three years could produce an invaluable array of market-opening reforms. The road map endorsed at a meeting in Doha, Qatar, points the way to freer trade in goods and services while promising to protect the interests of poor countries. Though late objections by France and India threatened to scuttle the talks, and perhaps the W.T.O. as well, the meeting ended with an exhausted but deserved sense of success.

title: Gauging Fissures in U.S.-Saudi Solidarity
description: The shah of Iran wrote to King Faisal of Saudi Arabia in the late 1960's, when Teheran's slums and mosques coexisted uneasily with the city's miniskirts and discotheques. Modernize, the shah told the reluctant king, or you may lose your kingdom. I appreciate your advice, but let me remind you, the king wrote back to him, you are not the shah of France.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Sudan: Bush Envoy On Peace Mission
description: President Bush's special envoy for Sudan, former Senator John C. Danforth, said in Khartoum that he would spend the next year trying to end the country's 18-year civil war but would pass the task on to someone else if the government and rebel groups failed to compromise soon. Mr. Danforth toured a refugee camp outside the capital and held meetings with Sudanese leaders and church representatives. Pledging not to ''choose sides,'' he heads to the rebel-held south today. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Unification Talks Between the Two Koreas Break Off Abruptly
description: High-level talks between North and South Korea broke off at dawn today ''without producing final results on anything,'' a South Korean official said.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Heavy Guard For Nuclear Waste
description: A force of 15,000 police officers escorted a train carrying six nuclear waste containers to a storage site in northern Germany in one of the country's largest postwar security operations. Previous shipments had been disrupted by antinuclear protesters but this time the police encountered fewer demonstrators than expected. Some 300 people were detained and minor injuries were reported.

title: The Return of Commissioner Kelly
description: Raymond Kelly has had an action-packed career since he stepped down as head of the New York City Police Department in 1994. He ran an international police operation in Haiti, oversaw the Secret Service for the Treasury Department, served as commissioner of the Customs Service, an official in Interpol and as an executive at a Wall Street securities firm. It's a rsum that should help inspire confidence when he becomes the first person in New York City history to serve as police commissioner twice.

title: Tools for Staying in Touch; By Voice, Touch or Even Sight, Plenty of Ways Not to Make Yourself Scarce
description: WEBFACE -- Dick Tracy technology has been appearing in wristwatches for years, but Timex has the Internet addict's number: the Internet Messenger Watch ($120).
