This talented timepiece can send and receive short e-mail messages, and word-based and numeric pages as well as receive wireless news, sports and stock updates with the help of Motorola and SkyTel.

title: Piniella and Bowa Voted Top Managers
description: In the 2000 season, Seattle Manager Lou Piniella looked at Larry Bowa, his third-base coach, and saw a lot of himself. It turned out he was right, for both wound up with Manager of the Year awards yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AGUADO, CHARLES
description: AGUADO-Charles. On November 13, 2001. Beloved husband of Susan. Devoted father of Steven, Kylene, Kenneth, Joan and Alan. Cherished brother of David and Alice. Loving grandfather of Gaelan, Daniel and Joseph. After fourteen years as a volunteer for the New York State Ombudsman at Treetops Nursing Home, Charles was inducted into the Westchester Hall of Fame. Services Thursday, 1PM at Temple Israel of Northern Westchester. For information, call Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 212-769-4400. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Phelps Memorial Hospital Hospice or the American Cancer Society.

title: For One Family, Grief in the Crash's Wake Is Fivefold
description: For more than a decade, Felipe de la Cruz, a truck driver in the Dominican Republic, had yearned to join his seven brothers in the United States. He was dirt-poor, worn and weathered to the point of looking decades older than he is, 49, and he could have made more money in America. But he refused to sneak into the country illegally.

title: Knicks' Slide a Result Of Never Rebuilding
description: Pat Riley, Alonzo Mourning and the Miami Heat come to town tonight. The blood feud is over, but the coach and his team will take in the usual jeers from Knick fans who remember when New York versus Miami was for everything in the Eastern Conference pot.

title: U.S. Says Noose Is Tightening Around Al Qaeda and Taliban
description: Although up to 60 percent of Afghanistan is now estimated to be in anti-Taliban hands, Defense Department officials stressed today that the initial mission of the campaign remained the same: the destruction of the Qaeda terror network run by Osama bin Laden and the Taliban leadership that shelters him.

title: Scaling the Nation in a Single Bound
description: THEODORE REX

title: The Bridge of Love
description: To the Editor:

title: Taliban Fight On in Kandahar, Shakily
description: Fighting intensified in and around the Taliban stronghold of Kandahar today, and several reports suggested that the southern city and its airport might soon be wrested from Taliban control.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Medical Malpractice Award
description: A pregnant woman who fell into a coma in 1988 at St. Mary's Hospital after the removal of her breathing tube was awarded nearly $115 million by a jury in State Supreme Court last week. A doctor removed a breathing tube from the woman, Michelle McCord, who was eight months pregnant and had been having breathing problems, said her lawyer, Stephen E. Erickson. It took almost 30 minutes before a tube could be re-inserted. Later that day, doctors delivered the baby, a girl. Jane Fritsch (NYT)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: EXXON MOBIL CORP., Houston, the oil company, said it had agreed with state officials on a plan to extract about 75,000 barrels of hydrocarbon liquids a day from natural gas reserves in its Point Thomson gas and condensate field on Alaska's North Slope by 2006.

title: U.S. Companies Largely Back Trade Decisions; Antidumping Rules
description: American business expects the World Trade Organization's pronouncements on antidumping rules to ease the restrictions on steel imports -- a prospect pleasing to companies like Caterpillar, a steel user, and not very pleasing to domestic steel producers like the Sandmeyer Steel Company of Philadelphia.

title: Enron Will Sell Some Assets In Hope of Raising Billions
description: Still working to stabilize its shaky finances, the Enron Corporation said yesterday that it planned to sell assets, with a total book value of more than $8 billion, that executives say have produced dismal returns.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about disarray among Israeli leftists because of the continuing conflict with Palestinians referred incorrectly to the "right of return" demanded by Yasir Arafat. It is for refugees from the 1948 Arab-Israeli war, not from later Arab-Israeli wars.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERMAN, LILLIAN
description: SHERMAN-Lillian. On behalf of the entire birthright israel partnership, we mourn the loss of Lillian Sherman, mother of Jane and Larry Sherman. May the Sherman family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem and Lillian's memory be for a blessing. Charles R. Bronfman, Co-Founding Chairman birthright israel International Michael H. Steinhardt, Co-Founding Chairman birthright israel International Dr. Shimshon Shoshani, CEO birthright israel International Marlene Post, Chairperson birthright israel USA, Inc. Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman Executive Vice President birthright israel USA, Inc.

title: Nets Have Their Health, and a Deep Bench Helps, Too
description: The Nets returned triumphantly from Indiana early yesterday morning, after capturing their sixth victory in seven games this season.

title: A Widening Rout, Civil Liberties Issues, a Red Cross Retreat
description: The war in Afghanistan was going well for the United States and its proxy fighters, so well that American commanders almost felt obliged to point out that things could still go wrong. Maybe, but on this day the rout of the Taliban continued. As they hunkered down in and around Kandahar, their southern stronghold, there were questions about how much longer they would be able to hold on.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOJACK, RANDY
description: WOJACK-Randy. The Board of Directors, Staff and Volunteers of Gay Men's Health Crisis mourn the passing of our esteemed former Board member and volunteer Randy Wojack. A memorial to honor his life and spirit will be held at GMHC on November 19 at 6 P.M. Donations in Randy's name may be made to GMHC, The Tisch Bldg, 119 West 24th St, NYC 10011. Bill McCarthy, Co-Chair Ana Oliveira, Executive Director

title: AT HOME WITH/Lidia Bastianich; A Recipe Kept Warm For 55 Years
description: FROM the commotion in the kitchen, you would have thought it was a wedding day. Pans of eggplant rollatini baked in the oven, turnovers stuffed with salami and mozzarella fried in the pan. Fresh clams were minced, broccoli rape was rinsed. The pears and grapes were already roasted in moscato, and the pignoli cookies were cooling on a sideboard. The chicken hadn't even been started.

title: Dolphins Are Agitated As Jets Come to Town
description: In early May, with baseball in full swing and the N.B.A. playoffs under way, the Miami Dolphins conducted a minicamp. The regular season was still four months away, but the Jets came up regularly in players' conversations, like a sore that would not heal.

title: Brooklyn Jury Awards $115 Million to a Mother With Brain Damage
description: Apregnant woman who fell into a coma in 1988 after a doctor at St. Mary's Hospital in Brooklyn removed her breathing tube has been awarded nearly $115 million in a medical malpractice trial.

title: Bush and Putin Agree on Much, but No ABM Deal Is Reached
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15  President Bush and President Vladimir Putin of Russia said today that after three days of talks, they had not reached an agreement on missiles. But they said they agree on a number of other issues and like each other and each other's countries.

title: The Battle for Afghanistan: The Tide Is Turned
description: To the Editor:

title: The Place Setting As Life's Cure-All
description: IN Russel Wright's hands, even a hostess plate could be didactic. With its indented thumb hold, raised ring for holding a glass and partition ridges for church-and-state segregation of meat and potatoes, the plate, like all of Wright's enormously popular tablewares, linens and furnishings from the 1940's and 50's, had an agenda: to show Americans that life at home could be as easy and efficient as a new washer-dryer.

title: Blair Says New Evidence Ties bin Laden to Attacks
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair made public today new evidence in which he said Osama bin Laden acknowledged for the first time that he was behind the suicide hijackings of Sept. 11.

title: Yankees Executive Resigns
description: Kim Ng resigned as assistant general manager for the Yankees on Monday after four seasons with the team. Ng, 32, was the highest-ranking woman in Major League Baseball involved in player personnel decisions.

title: Something Was Fishy There, And South Suspected West
description: Two of New York's leading bridge personalities have died in the last three weeks. One was Luella B. Slaner of Scarsdale, N.Y., who twice reached the final of a major national team championship. In 1982 she was a runner-up in the Vanderbilt Knockout, and the next year she matched that feat in the Spingold Knockout.

title: New Horizons for CanWest
description: You don't have to go far in Winnipeg to encounter the Aspers.

title: World Briefing
description: Middle East

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Satellite Radio Network Is Delayed
description: The satellite radio company Sirius Satellite Radio said it would begin service on Feb. 14, delaying the start by about six weeks. It had been scheduled to start by Dec. 31. The New York-based company will charge $12.95 a month for 100 channels of music and news, fewer commercials and better sound than traditional radio. The service will be offered first in Denver, Houston and Phoenix, and expand nationwide by September.

title: Developers at the Door, Ranchers Round Up Support
description: LIKE the weather-worn fences traversing the landscape, history holds its ground here. It lies tenderly in waiting whenever Jack and Wanda Redmond sip tea in the kitchen of his family homestead, where until remodeled several years ago, the walls were insulated with pages from a Ladies' Home Journal of 1894.

title: A Proliferation Of Presidents
description: That the books are on the store shelves at this moment is absolutely coincidental, but nonetheless the voracious interest in presidential biographies seems precisely perfect for this moment, when people seem to have a longing to connect to their history. There's no better way than the study of presidents, who are at the center. The writers are McCullough, Beschloss, Reeves and Morris, and the books they have written are not for those who move their lips when they read. And coming is Caro, arguably the best biographer of power of them all.

title: Out at the Ranch, Guests From Russia
description: Vladimir V. Putin may have looked relaxed out here on the Texas prairie this afternoon, riding shotgun as he bounced along in President Bush's gleaming pickup.

title: Powell Poised To Announce New Strategy In Middle East
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell is poised to unveil a new American strategy to end the violence between Israelis and Palestinians and restart talks aimed at creating a Palestinian state, senior administration officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORNREICH, DORIS J.
description: KORNREICH-Doris J. IHF is greatly saddened by her passing. She was an active committee member. Her humanitarism and concerned support for the less fortunate were an inspiration. Israel Humanitarian Foundation Marvin M. Sirota, President Stanley J. Abrams, Exec. V.P. Robert B. Levy, Exec. Dir., Northeast Region

title: Economic Scene; A small dose of common sense would help Congress break the gridlock over airport security.
description: ''WHEREFORE, security being the true design and end of government,'' Thomas Paine advised in 1776, ''it unanswerably follows that whatever form thereof appears most likely to ensure it to us, with the least expense and greatest benefit, is preferable to all others.'' Such common sense is needed in Congress on aviation security.

title: GENEVA STEEL SAYS IT MAY FILE FOR BANKRUPTCY AGAIN
description: The Geneva Steel Company, which emerged from bankruptcy protection in January, closed its Utah steel mill, which had 1,500 employees, yesterday and said it might file for bankruptcy protection again because of low steel prices. Most of the employees will be laid off at the company's only mill, in Vineyard, Utah, Geneva Steel said. The company said it had scheduled a meeting with suppliers, whose cooperation is needed to prevent a bankruptcy filing. More than 15 steel makers, including Bethlehem Steel and LTV, have filed for bankruptcy protection since the beginning of 1998.

title: ABC and CBS Discuss Sharing Of News Costs
description: ABC News and CBS News are discussing a possible cost-sharing arrangement that could forestall their need to ally with CNN, the cable news network that has held talks with both.

title: Tribune Company to Cut Some Executive Salaries
description: Responding to the advertising drought, the Tribune Company announced yesterday that 140 of its top executives would take a 5 percent salary cut effective Jan. 1 and get no bonuses this year. Merit-based raises for a portion of the remaining 18,000 nonunion employees would come in the form of stock options, not cash.

title: A Legal Eagle (His Ad Claims)
description: In an increasingly competitive economic environment, a growing number of law firms are trying to create brand images that will set them apart from their competitors. To do so, they are developing sophisticated marketing campaigns complete with print, radio and television advertisements, even relying at times on kitschy slogans once commonly used to sell consumer goods.

title: Returns Without Remorse
description: RETURNING gifts, like throwing out the Christmas tree, is one of those holiday hangover chores that many people try to put off as long as possible. But if the unwanted gifts were bought online, you may find the process a little more bearable this year. In their frantic quest for customers and repeat business, online retailers have taken steps to make returning items easier. Conveniences like prepaid return labels, the ability to track a return's status by e-mail and the integration of online retailers and their offline counterparts are now for the most part standard.

title: TALIBAN LOSE GRIP ON WIDER REGIONS; FIGHTING IN SOUTH
description: The rout of the Taliban from Afghan cities continued apace yesterday, and there were reports that Pashtun tribes in the south, the ethnic base of the Taliban, were rising up and challenging the Taliban even in its stronghold of Kandahar.

title: Nations Move to Send Troops to Keep Order in Afghanistan
description: AUnited Nations resolution has opened the way for multinational military efforts to maintain law and order in Afghanistan and to provide aid in rebuilding the country. Several countries said they were preparing to send troops and diplomats to help establish an Afghan government.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about a memorial service at the site of the World Trade Center for victims from some 80 nations who died in the Sept. 11 attacks misidentified the soprano who sang there two weeks earlier in a contrasting service. (The same error occurred on Oct. 29 and was corrected in this space on the 30th.) The singer was Rene Fleming, not Kathleen Battle.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Cable And Wireless Dividend
description: After pressure from investors to hand back part of $6.8 billion in cash accrued from asset sales, Cable and Wireless said it would pay a special dividend of 17 cents a share in March and buy back up to 15 percent of its own stock worth around $2 billion. The company has been selling consumer businesses to concentrate on corporate telecommunications and Internet services. Its shares, which have fallen some 60 percent this year, rose by 7.5 percent after the company reported first-half earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization of $736 million, at the top end of analysts' forecasts. Its loss before gains from the sale of assets in the same period was around $2 billion. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Stewart Passed Over by the Blue Jays
description: Something is rotten in the state of baseball, and each off-season announcement makes it worse. Major league clubs are making it clearer than ever: blacks and Latins shouldn't even bother trying to become general managers.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Idaho: Governor Orders Budget Cuts
description: Gov. Dirk Kempthorne, a Republican, ordered more budget cuts for all state agencies, compounding the 2 percent cuts he mandated in August for 2002 budgets. The governor said new projections show state revenues $17 million below expectations, prompting the new 1 percent ''holdbacks.'' Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: The Man Who Put Kissinger in the Dirt, Softly
description: A FEW things you might want to know about those amusing New York City ads that are to make their debut next week:

title: Lindros Still a Sore Subject to Clarke and the Flyers
description: No matter how hard Philadelphia Flyers General Manager Bob Clarke tries to keep calm when the subject is Eric Lindros, he cannot help himself.

title: U.S. Industries Largely Favor Decision on Global Trade
description: With some notable caveats, many American companies yesterday endorsed the World Trade Organization's new rules for negotiating a trade agreement, arguing that the potential for increased exports outweighs the damage a few industries might suffer.

title: Technology Briefing | Research: Arthritis Drug Is Approved
description: Amgen Inc. said it had received government approval for Kineret, its drug for rheumatoid arthritis. The approval opens a new market for Amgen, the nation's biggest biotechnology company, which until now has been built on drugs to treat anemia and ameliorate the side effects of chemotherapy. Analysts, however, have generally said that Kineret sales will be modest at first. Andrew Pollack (NYT)

title: Joy Is Tempered by Fears In California's Little Kabul
description: In the weeks since the United States began bombing Afghanistan, the television has droned nearly constantly in the home of Akhter M. Baigzad. For stretches of eight to nine hours a day, Mr. Baigzad surfs the cable news networks for updates on the anti-Taliban fight in his homeland, which he fled in 1980 after the Soviets invaded.

title: The Battle for Afghanistan: The Tide Is Turned
description: To the Editor:

title: Inquiry in Girl's Death Focuses on Her Return to an Abusive Mother
description: Child welfare officials were trying to determine yesterday how a 4-year-old girl who had been sent to live with an aunt in Hampton, Va., came back into the home of her abusive mother in New York. The girl, Signifagance Oliver, was found drowned this week, and her mother, Sabrina Wright, 29, was charged with murder.

title: World Briefing | Asia: East Timor: More Security Means Fewer Troops
description: The United Nations began a six-month reduction in its peacekeeping force from its current level of 8,000 to 5,000. At a ceremony for the departure of the first group -- 264 Kenyan soldiers -- the force commander, Lt. Gen. Winai Phattiyakul, said, ''This is indicative of the great improvement in the security situation in East Timor.'' The former Portuguese colony, which was annexed by Indonesia in 1976, was ravaged by pro-Indonesia militias after voting for independence in 1999. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the election of Bishop Wilton D. Gregory as president of the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops misstated the given name and middle initial of its new vice president. He is Bishop William S. Skylstad, not Stephen M.

title: Weighing a New Murder Trial for Rabbi
description: A day after a mistrial was declared in the case of Rabbi Fred J. Neulander, prosecutors vowed today to press ahead with the case, although several long-range issues remain unresolved before a new trial begins on charges that the rabbi arranged the murder of his wife.

title: Bringing Hollywood Pizazz to Military Training
description: At the end of a placid, palm-lined street in Marina del Rey, the chants of an angry crowd fill the darkened theater of a nondescript office building. On the movie screen, a realistic drama is being played out: an American sergeant is trying to keep the peace in a Bosnian village while a local boy, hit by an American Jeep, lies wounded on the street. Rioting seems imminent. The sergeant turns to the audience and asks, ''What should we do, Sir?''

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The people of this country have given the Red Cross their hard-earned dollars, their trust and very clear direction for our Sept. 11 relief efforts. Regrettably, it took us too long to hear their message.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERNSTEIN, HOWARD A.
description: BERNSTEIN-Howard A. Lovingly remembering you on your birthday. In our hearts forever. Our Family

title: The Battle for Afghanistan: The Tide Is Turned
description: To the Editor:

title: Special Forces Hunt Al Qaeda On the Ground
description: More than 100 American commandos are in southern Afghanistan, driving around in special vehicles and carrying out covert operations against the Taliban and Al Qaeda leaders, senior American officials said today.

title: Editors' Note; Today's Sections
description: News of the Sept. 11 attacks and their aftermath continues to appear in Section B; index, Page B2.

title: Around Afghanistan, Change Is in the Air
Whats Fit to Print?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Yashin Shines, Despite His Baggage
description: DENVER, Nov. 16 — A rink might as well be a department store sales rack for Aleksei Yashin. He draws crowds of defenders, not just one or even two, and they hold him and hook him and whack at him with their sticks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STATES, EDWARD
description: STATES - Edward. 42 - year - old Plainsboro father of two, was the Captain of the A300 Airbus that crashed in New York Monday, November 12, 2001. Ed was a Captain for 10 of his 16 years with American Airlines. Ed was born in Hackensack, NJ and grew up in Park Ridge, NJ. He and his family have been residents of Plainsboro for 14 years. He was a member of the U.S. Air Force Reserves for 10 years. As an active member of Trinity Episcopal Church, Ed frequently volunteered his carpentry skills to the church and served on the NewComers Committee. He regularly participated in his sons' school activities, coached Little League and was Committee Chairman of the Cub Scouts Pack 759. Son of Marian and the late Frank States, Sr., he is survived by his wife, Mary Alden, sons Bradley and Daniel, a brother and sister, Frank States, Jr. and Kathleen Mangan and her husband, Rick, and two nieces Colleen and Erin Mangan. A service will be celebrated at 1:00 PM Saturday, November 17, at Trinity Episcopal Church, 33 Mercer St., Princeton, NJ. In lieu of flowers the family reuests contributions to the Ed States Children's Educational Fund, C/O Gene Allen, 8 Overlook Road, Hopewell, NJ 08525-1217.

title: Mr. Pusey of Harvard
description: To the Editor:

title: BritRail for Less
description: There is a 25 percent discount through Feb. 28 on BritRail Classic Passes and FlexiPasses. They allow unlimited travel on the National Railways of Britain, which include over 2,400 destinations in England, Scotland and Wales. A four-day FlexiPass, for example, good for unlimited travel on any four days in a two-month span, is $176 for standard-class travel (regularly $235) and $262 in first class (down from $349). By comparison, regular round-trip fares from Heathrow Airport to Edinburgh are $218 standard, $377 first class. An eight-day Classic Pass, for unlimited travel over eight continuous days, costs $199 in standard, $299 in first class. A Family Pass allows one child age 5 to 15 to travel free with one adult. Passes must be bought before departing the United States. Information, (877) 677-1066 or www.britrail.net .

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FALLON, BARBARA A.
description: FALLON-Barbara A. Of Bronxville on November 14, 2001. Sister of John & William Fallon. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxsville, between the hours of 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 PM Friday. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville on Saturday, November 17th at 10 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLANER, LUELLA B.
description: SLANER-Luella B. The Department of Applied Physics and Applied Mathematics and the Fu Foundation School of Engineering and Applied Science of Columbia University mourn the passing of Luella B. Slaner, a special friend and benefactor. Among her many acts of philanthropy, her gifts to Columbia University supported young faculty and research that advanced new techiques to confine high-temperature, ionized matter for fusion energy. Motivated by the 1973 oil embargo, she believed the health of the planet could be improved by developing alternate energy sources. In 1981, she led efforts to raise funds and produce a documentary describing the potential for fusion energy that was televised nationally. Mrs. Slaner will be deeply missed and fondly remembered as a dynamic and constructive person who was devoted to higher education and the realization of practical, clean sources of energy.

title: China's Unwitting Organ Donors
description: To the Editor:

title: Recording Details Takeover of Downed Flight
description: Thirty-five minutes before United Airlines Flight 93 plunged into a Pennsylvania field on Sept. 11, screams filled the plane's cockpit and the pilots shouted, ''Get out of here! Get out of here!''

title: Brazil Welcomes Global Move on Drug Patents
description: The Brazilian government, which has challenged the giant drug companies' patent defenses perhaps more aggressively than any other country, hailed the World Trade Organization's declaration on drug patents as an important victory for the developing world's fight against health scourges like AIDS.

title: Out of the Rajah's Court To Plague-Ridden Streets
description: The documentary ''Bombay Eunuch'' examines with an acute, clear-eyed compassion the sad decline in status of India's eunuchs, also known as hijras. From an honored place in Hindu society, the hijras, who were once thought to possess divine powers, have been increasingly marginalized as Western notions of gender, sexual identity and spirituality have seeped into Indian culture. Even now, especially in the lower classes, a lingering mystique clings to the hijras, who are feared for their supposed power to plant curses.

title: Facing Criticism, the City Again Adds Firefighters to the Search
description: The number of city firefighters assigned to search for bodies at the World Trade Center site has been increased yet again, as the Giuliani administration moves to answer criticism that it was failing to prevent human remains from being disposed of, accidentally, along with debris.

title: Yankees' Off-Season Moves Hinge on Giambi's Decision
description: Jason Giambi is Plan A for the Yankees, just as Mike Mussina was last year, and if they overwhelm all competing offers and sign Giambi -- as many baseball executives expect them to do -- then his presence in the Yankees' lineup would ease an infusion of young players remarkable for a team that has typically relied on veterans. By the middle of next season, the ages of the Yankees' infielders could be 22, 28, 24 and 22, third base to first.

title: Lacking Punch, The Mets Ponder Dealing Benitez
description: The Mets' main objective this winter is to improve their outfield. They may have to sacrifice closer Armando Benitez to do it, and they will almost certainly let go of Benny Agbayani, a mainstay in the outfield for the last few years.

title: N.F.L. Matchups Week 10
description: SUNDAY 1 P.M.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: The museums, gardens and sites are closed on Thanksgiving Day, unless otherwise noted.

title: U.S. Attorney To Step Down In Manhattan
description: Mary Jo White, who oversaw the prosecution of the nation's major terrorist cases for the last eight years, announced yesterday that she will step down as United States attorney for the Southern District of New York by the end of the year.

title: Corrections
description: Articles on Oct. 26 and 27 and a brief report in the Week in Review on Oct. 28 about a fire that closed the St. Gotthard tunnel in Switzerland misidentified a tunnel that is being used as an alternate route. It is the San Bernardino, not the St. Bernhard.

title: Kelly's Job at N.Y.P.D.
description: To the Editor:

title: WARNER BROS. AND SANRIO TO DEVELOP CARTOON PRODUCTS
description: Warner Brothers, a division of AOL Time Warner, and the Sanrio Company, Japan's largest character goods company, will jointly develop and license products that include the Tweety and Hello Kitty cartoon characters. The products will be introduced in March throughout Asia and are expected to generate five billion yen ($41 million) in extra sales for Sanrio. The companies will co-design about 200 products for the Japanese character goods market. Hello Kitty, a mouthless cat popular with both toddlers and teenagers, generates about half of Sanrio's $1.2 billion in worldwide sales. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Heat Plays Down Illness That Has Sidelined Mourning
description: The already diminished rivalry between the Knicks and the Miami Heat lost more luster when the Heat arrived at Madison Square Garden yesterday without center Alonzo Mourning. Last night's game was the first of at least three that Mourning will miss while recovering from an unidentified illness.

title: Muslims See Acceptance and Scrutiny as Holy Month Nears
description: In past years, American Muslims say, they could celebrate Ramadan -- an entire month of fasting from sunup to sundown -- without their non-Muslim colleagues and neighbors ever noticing.

title: Sports of The Times; Knicks Face One Rivalry At a Time
description: IT has come to this. The Miami Heat came to New York last night, and what did people want to talk about before the game? The New Jersey Nets.

title: Was the French Ruling on Yahoo Such a Victory After All?
description: Afederal court decision last week was cheered by Internet companies and civil liberties groups as a victory for free expression, but some legal experts are speculating that, in reality, little has changed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLER, MORRIS
description: KELLER-Morris, 91 years old. On November 15, 2001. Morris, beloved husband of Ann, for 67 years, devoted father of Sylvia (and Dr. Fredric) Brownstein of Longmeadow, MA., and Larry (and Lisa) Keller of Santa Fe, NM. Grandfather of Bryna (and Alan) Klevan, Dr. Ilana Brownstein, Max Beck-Keller and Hannah Wederquist-Keller. Great grandfather of Rachel, Jason and Marcus Klevan. Loved and respected and missed by all who knew him. He graduated from City College in 1931 and received his Master's Degree in 1932. He worked as a hospital administrator for the New York State Dept Mental Hygiene. Funeral, 1 PM, November 16, 2001, Levitt-Weinstein, West Palm Beach, Florida.

title: G.M. to Begin Saturn Review
description: The General Motors Corporation ( news/quote ) said yesterday that it would begin the first review involving its Saturn line since the brand was introduced a dozen years ago, seeking an agency to create campaigns for a new coupe and sedan to be introduced under the Ion model name.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PARADNY, ROBERT, M.D.
description: PARADNY-Robert, M.D. Bob/ Dad/Papa, you are forever in our hearts and homes. Renee looks at your photos and calls you Papa. Your Loving Family.

title: The Big City; A Policeman For Starters, And at the End
description: IF you looked closely at the opening scene of ''NYPD Blue'' Tuesday evening, you could have spotted a tall handsome man named John W. Perry. He was an extra, playing one of the mourners in police uniforms at the funeral of an officer.

title: Hometown Is Jubilant Aid Workers Are Free
description: On a church-sponsored field trip to Austin, Tex., two years ago, Heather Mercer met a homeless teenager who had no shoes. Ms. Mercer promptly removed her own new sneakers and gave them to the girl.

title: A Need for Order, the Smallpox Matter and Oil Prices
description: With the sands of war shifting rapidly in Afghanistan, the United States and its allies chose not to wait for an Islamic security force to be created, not to wait for a post-Taliban government to sort itself out, not to wait for rebels to deliver a knockout blow to Taliban troops holding out in the cities of Kandahar and Kunduz. Instead, some 80 American Special Operations troops, and twice as many British Royal Marines, landed just north of Kabul, the capital, to see that order is preserved and humanitarian aid delivered.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Bank's Earnings Fall
description: France's third-largest bank, Socit Gnrale, posted a 20 percent decline in third-quarter profit from a year earlier, well below the 14 percent predicted by analysts. The bank attributed the drop to declines in the investment banking and asset management sectors. The chairman at Socit Gnrale, Daniel Bouton, said the outlook remained unclear. The bank is trying to cut costs in investment banking, which had a loss of 21 million euros even though the company eliminated 300 jobs. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENDEWALD, MERVIN H.
description: BENDEWALD-Mervin H. November 13, 2001. Born in eastern Montana to a ranching/homesteading family 68 years ago. Merv settled in the West Village after college and two years in the army. For nearly thirty-five years, he has been a mainstay to the Hudson Street community with a variety of enterprises including the current western wear store Whiskey Dust. Abe Beame called him ''the Mayor of Hudson Street.'' He will be deeply missed by his wife Hollie, children Daniel and Andrea, and his four sisters & two brothers. Services will be held Saturday November 17 at The Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker Street at 11:30 AM. Contributions may be made to The Cardiovascular Institute in memory of Mervin Bendewald, The Mt. Sinai Medical Center, Box 1030, One Gustave L. Levy Place, New York, NY 10029.

title: O.K., Just Tell Your Folks It's Artistic Work, in Films
description: Sean McGinnis (Michael Cunio), the title character in ''The Fluffer,'' is a nave young film buff who has gone to Los Angeles to break into the movie industry. One day he rents a videotape that he thinks is ''Citizen Kane'' but that turns out to be a gay pornographic film with a similar title.

title: Allies Building Force to Keep Order in a Vacuum
description: About 160 British marines and American Special Operations troops flew today to Bagram airfield north of Kabul as Western nations rushed to assemble an international force to keep order in Afghan areas wrested from the Taliban.

title: One Clerk Is Murdered, And a New Man Is Born
description: Jeff Goldblum's verbal dexterity -- with its pauses, abrupt downshifts and sudden lurches into full speed -- complements the modest film noir ''Auggie Rose,'' an identity-switching tale by the writer-director Matthew Tabak. Mr. Goldblum's slightly unhinged ruminations as he flamboyantly broadcasts his hesitant thoughts lend themselves to this B-picture that takes off on ''It's a Wonderful Life'' but is soaked with the obsessive guilt of ''Vertigo.''

title: Safekeeping Faith and Tradition; Bronx Mosque Provides a Place for Prayer, and More
description: It is a recent Friday afternoon and tumult fills a former convent in the Bronx, where a center of Islamic life is blossoming.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Broker To Raise Funds
description: The Citic Securities Company, China's second-biggest broker, plans to raise 5 billion yuan, about $604 million, in an initial public offering to domestic investors. The company said it would use the proceeds to acquire rival brokers. Citic and other local brokerage firms are expanding to be competitive with the European and American firms that will eventually get greater access to the China market now that the the country has been admitted to the World Trade Organization. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary yesterday about Albert Hague, a composer and actor, misidentified a film for which he composed the music. It was the 1966 television cartoon version of ''How the Grinch Stole Christmas,'' not last year's movie. The obituary also misspelled the given name of the ''Grinch'' author, whose pen name was Dr. Seuss. He was Theodor Seuss Geisel, not Theodore.

title: No Drought Designation for Region, but No Rain, Either
description: It's dry out there.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROUTH, JOHN S., JR.
description: ROUTH-John S., Jr., 81. Of Boca Raton, FL., and Greenwich, CT, passed away on Wednesday, November 14th, 2001. Mr. Routh ''Jack'' was President of the Pittston Coal Company and Founder and Owner of the Manhattan Coal Company. Mr. Routh is survived by his wife, Dorothy, six children, Rylee Routh, Brenda Whitacre, Lorraine Nelson, Isabel Reddy, John S. Routh, III, and Michael R. Routh, and nine grandchildren. Babione Funeral Home, Boca Raton, FL, 561-395-8787.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOCHMAN, MERVIN, CLU.
description: GOCHMAN-Mervin, CLU. 70, of Sarasota, FL. Died on November 13, 2001. Adored husband of Barbara. Loving father of Carla, Matthew and Enid. Brother of Stanley. Grandfather of Olivia. 1948 graduate of Samuel J. Tilden H.S., Brooklyn, NY. Received BA and MBA from CCNY. Built a distinguished career in financial planning, retiring as Senior V.P. of Washington National Life of New York. Mentor and friend to so many, he will never be forgotten.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Chechen Rebel Goes On Trial
description: The highest-ranking Chechen guerrilla ever captured by Russian forces went on trial with three other rebels in Dagestan, a southwestern province bordering Chechnya. Salman Raduyev is charged with leading an attack on a Dagestani town in 1996 in which 70 people died and 2,000 were taken hostage. Mr. Raduyev fought mostly in the first Chechen war, in the mid-1990's; he has played little role in the second war, which began in 1999 and continues today. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: 2 Inquiries That Involve Politicians Unresolved
description: As Mary Jo White prepares to step down as the chief federal prosecutor in Manhattan, several major criminal investigations being conducted by her office remain unfinished, including two involving allegations of political corruption.

title: Jeremy Blake
description: Feigen Contemporary

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REDDING, ESTHER J.
description: REDDING-Esther J., 94. On November 12, 2001 in La Mesa, California. Devoted wife and mother. She is survived by sons Conway and Lewis.

title: Exposed to the Elements in an Existential No Man's Land
description: The Next Wave Festival of the Brooklyn Academy of Music is the right place for John Jasperse's choreography. ''Giant Empty,'' which had its New York premiere on Wednesday night at the academy's Harvey Theater, is typical of Mr. Jasperse's polished experiments in compelling movement, clear form and emotional provocation.

title: New Video Releases
description: America's Sweethearts

title: Before and After Bush and Putin's Banter, No Agreement on Missile Defense
description: President Bush and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia ended their three-day summit meeting today with warm jokes and a pledge to bring stability to Afghanistan, but no discernible progress on amending the treaty that constrains Washington's plans to test an antimissile system.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Freehold: Arraignment In Kidnapping
description: A man accused of kidnapping a 6-year-old girl did not enter a plea at his arraignment yesterday, but nodded to a judge when asked whether he understood the charges. The man, Barry Sherman, 37, has a medical condition that prevents him from speaking, prosecutors said. He did not enter a plea because he did not have a lawyer. The girl, Anna Cardelfe, was taken from the yard of her Spring Lake home on Nov. 8 and dropped off at a mall the next day. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Art in Review
description: Mark Rothko

title: U.S. Says Top Bin Laden Aide Believed Killed in Airstrike
description: Aleader of Al Qaeda terror network is believed to have been killed in an American airstrike in the last two days, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld and other United States officials said today.

title: A 2nd Night of Protests by Palestinians Angry at Arafat
description: Using stones, guns and small explosives, hundreds of Palestinians vented their disgust this evening with Yasir Arafat's governing Palestinian Authority, clashing with Palestinian security forces who seemed as frightened as they were furious when the mob surged against them.

title: Knicks' Surge Adds Drama to Triumph
description: It was supposed to be dull and boring and ho-hum, evidence that the once gripping rivalry between the Knicks and the Miami Heat was unmistakably dead. Both teams are off to poor starts. Familiar faces are few, and Miami center Alonzo Mourning sat out with an unknown illness.

title: Isbister Reignites His Robust Style
description: Knocking Brad Isbister off the puck is like muscling a truck out of a parking spot. But apparently Isbister forgot that.

title: A Museum Finds Small Is Beautiful
description: The first new art museum to open in New York in the 21st century is little short of superb: the Neue Galerie New York, Museum for German and Austrian Art, housed in an impeccably renovated Beaux-Arts mansion on Fifth Avenue at 86th Street. It is a small institution with only 4,300 square feet of exhibition space -- less than many Chelsea galleries -- and a maximum occupancy of 375 people. Its inaugural exhibition, which opens today, has slightly fewer than 100 paintings, sculptures and works on paper and slightly more than 100 design objects. It has been more than a decade in the planning, but its scale seems right on schedule for the altered cultural landscape that has resulted from Sept. 11.

title: Dentist Meets Femme Fatale With a Toothache
description: Part of the fun of watching the beginning of ''Novocaine'' is wondering how, and when, the movie will catch up with its score. Steve Bartek and Danny Elfman, who composed the soundtrack, throw a blast of noise onto the screen and then keep you jumping with amplified jolts of film noir dread. Their intention seems to be to bring the kind of aural manipulation that Bernard Herrmann supplied to Alfred Hitchcock's American films into the post-rock techno age. They succeed in combining sinister premonitions of bad business to come with an ironic commentary on the banality of what is happening on screen. The setting is the dental office of Dr. Frank Sangster (Steve Martin), where the most trivial of daily exchanges -- a trip to the supply cabinet, a confab with the office manager -- are punctuated by little musical stabs of dread.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Oil Prices Drop Sharply As Russia Rebuffs OPEC

title: Bloomberg Asks for Aid In Washington Pilgrimage
description: In his first visit to Washington as New York's mayor-elect, Michael R. Bloomberg urged the White House today to reconsider its opposition to a measure that would immediately provide billions of dollars to help New York City rebuild from the Sept. 11 attack, a proposal that died on Wednesday in committee amid White House pressure.

title: Steps of Central Asia
description: In Queens, immigrant Bukharan Jews celebrate in big ways, like the dancing at La France restaurant in Forest Hills, above.

title: Miscellany
description: * Captivate Network, Westford, Mass., and Qwest Communications International, Denver, agreed to a deal in which Qwest would advertise on the monitors Captivate operates in elevators and Captivate would use Qwest services like broadband connections, Web site operating and virtual networks. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Loss of 79,000 Jobs Adds to City's Economic Woes
description: A staggering 79,000 jobs disappeared from New York City in October, government officials announced yesterday, signaling that all the dire forecasts of economic fallout from the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks may have been understated.

title: Odili Donald Odita
description: Riva Gallery

title: Defying Wind and Waves, Ahab Composes an Opera
description: ''And God Created Great Whales'' originally opened last year at the Bessie Schnberg Theater in Chelsea. It reopened last night at the 45 Bleecker Theater, 45 Bleecker Street, East Village. Here are excerpts from D. J. R. Bruckner's review, which ran on June 17, 2000.

title: When Men Were Plumed In Silk
description: Sometimes the best exhibitions are staged way out in the country, in historical places like Deerfield, a 332-year-old farming village with 300 residents in western Massachusetts. The museum there, Historic Deerfield, nearly 50 years old, has gained international renown for its meticulous restoration of 14 of the village's 18th- and 19th-century buildings and for the Flynt Center of Early New England Life, which houses collections of important American furniture, silver, ceramics and related artifacts.

title: A NATION CHALLENGED: Letter From Washington; A Shifting Mood, A Haunting Memory
description: What a difference a week makes.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Friday about divisions in the Iranian government over relations with the United States misstated the setting in which Behzad Nabavi, a prominent member of parliament, said his party wanted normal relations with all countries except Israel. It was a speech, not an interview.

title: Luxury for the Rich, Opportunity for Women
description: Men, of course, dominated the interior design field in the late 19th century, a circumstance that made the talented and versatile Candace Wheeler (1827-1923) even more of a standout. Although of rural background and modest education, she became a textile designer of sophisticated taste, joining in partnership with Louis Comfort Tiffany to create luxurious settings for the privileged (including the house of her friend Mark Twain in Hartford).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PUSEY, NATHAN
description: PUSEY-Nathan. The Board and staff of the Neighborhood Coalition for Shelter recall Nathan Pusey with great fondness. His support for providing housing and mental health services helped make it possible for NCS to help thousands of people find a way home. We extend our sincere sympathies to his dear wife Anne, former member of the NCS Board of Directors, and his entire family.

title: U.S. Aid Workers Describe Their Rescue From the Taliban
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 16  Waiting in the predawn cold in western Afghanistan, eight terrified Christian aid workers were not sure who would arrive first, American forces dispatched to rescue them or Taliban soldiers who had held them captive for three months.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AGINSKEE, MAE (NEE KATZEN).
description: AGINSKEE-Mae (nee Katzen). Beloved aunt of Joe and Myra Fisch. Great-aunt of Amy & Terry, and Lauren and Anthony. Service today, 10 AM, Weinstein Garlick Kirschenbaum Chapel, 1153 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Bad Boys, Flee Not: There's a New Cop Car in Town
description: AFTER a 12-year hiatus, Dodge is returning to the police market with its 2002 Dodge Intrepid police car.

title: David W. Brumbaugh, 93; Was 'Mr. Zip' at Time Inc.
description: David W. Brumbaugh, a former Time Inc. executive who played a role in the adoption of ZIP codes, died on Saturday at a hospital in Glen Cove, N.Y.

title: Johannesburg Journal; Unthinkable Attack Jolts a Crime-Weary Country
description: The victim of the unspeakable crime smiles as if nothing had ever happened, gurgling at the steady stream of strangers who hover over her crib at Kimberly Hospital. She is 10 months old, with brown eyes and pudgy legs, and she is one of South Africa's youngest rape victims.

title: Barbecues and Missile Shields
description: Three days of meetings between President Bush and Vladimir Putin, the Russian president, concluded yesterday with evident good will but no agreement on reconciling American missile defense plans with the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty. The remarkably relaxed and friendly atmosphere developing between the two leaders serves both countries and may eventually help resolve the ABM impasse. Meanwhile Washington should continue to defer any missile tests that would violate the treaty in its current form.

title: At Ground Zero, to Remember Forever
description: To the Editor:

title: A Quick Change in Fortune Dulls the Glimmer of Houston
description: On a day when oil prices plunged to two-year lows, when the hometown Enron Corporation continued its ugly free fall and when gloomy projections showed the local economy headed for a decidedly rough patch, George Alcorn lunched on Chilean sea bass at the downtown Petroleum Club and decided that the sky was not falling.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Garden City: No Agreement On Deficit
description: Nassau County officials met yesterday with state overseers but failed to agree on how to balance the county budget. Nassau faces a Nov. 28 deadline to avoid a state takeover of the county's troubled finances. The County Legislature's presiding officer, Judith A. Jacobs, favors more spending cuts and taxes to close a $45 million deficit. But she said ''we need a partner'' to make a deal, either County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta, a Republican, or the Republican legislators. The Republican minority favors layoffs and a reduction in union benefits. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article last Friday about divisions in the Iranian government over relations with the United States misstated the setting in which Behzad Nabavi, a prominent member of parliament, said his party wanted normal relations with all countries except Israel. It was a speech, not an interview.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LITWIN, RICHARD
description: LITWIN-Richard. November 14, 1993. I think of you every day and miss you. Your loving wife, Lynne

title: Legislative Leaders Reach a Deal to Reduce Deficit by $200 Million
description: HARTFORD, Nov. 15  After three days of tense negotiations to reduce a $300 million budget deficit, Gov. John G. Rowland and legislative leaders reached an agreement tonight on a plan that would save $200 million and avoid layoffs of state employees.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: We Killed Judge, Separatists Say
description: The Basque separatist group E.T.A. said it had carried out the killing of a judge last week in the Basque region and a car bombing in Madrid that wounded 95 people. The group said it had shot Judge Jos Maria Lidn as he left his home in Bilbao because ''the judicial system is another instrument of aggression with which to punish Basques and to absolve those who oppress the Basque homeland.'' Emma Daly (NYT)

title: Big Brother Aside, Smart ID Cards Are Making Global Converts
description: The idea of a national ID card is anathema to Big Brother-fearing people around the world, so imagine how these people would feel about a card that contains much of their lives on an electronic chip: holographic photo, fingerprints, iris scan, digital signature, employment history and criminal record, for example.

title: Bidding Charges Dismissed Against 2 in Salt Lake City
description: An already weakened government case collapsed yesterday when a federal judge dismissed all remaining charges in the bribery scandal involving the two chief organizers of Salt Lake City's bid to win the 2002 Winter Olympics.

title: When the Afghans Are Free of War
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: New Ruling On Lead Poisoning
description: The state's highest court yesterday expanded the ability of tenants to sue landlords for lead poisoning. The Court of Appeals, reversing a lower court, ruled that an Albany family could sue their landlord for lead-based paint that resulted in the hospitalization of a 1-year-old girl in 1995, a court spokesman said. The ruling reduced the statewide standard of proof to that already used in New York City, where a tenant need prove only that a landlord knew his property was built before lead-based paint was banned in 1960, that lead paint was peeling and that a young child lived in the building. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Despite Woes, Indonesia Economy Grew in 3rd Quarter
description: Indonesia's currency is sliding, inflation is rising and government finances are a mess. But its economy still managed to grow faster than expected in the third quarter, demonstrating what the World Bank calls the country's ability to muddle through the global slowdown and its own political confusion.

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: CONGRESS AGREES TO U.S. TAKEOVER FOR AIR SECURITY
description: House and Senate negotiators reached agreement today on a major aviation security bill that requires the federal government to hire 28,000 employees to screen travelers and baggage at the nation's airports within one year.

title: U.S. SET TO RETAIN SMALLPOX STOCKS
description: The Bush administration, reversing a course set two decades ago, has decided that the world's remaining stocks of smallpox should be retained until scientists develop new vaccines and treatments for the disease, a process that could take years if not decades.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Angola: President Won't Meet Rebel Leader
description: President Jos Eduardo dos Santos, left, has ruled out direct talks with the rebel leader, Jonas Savimbi, saying that previous negotiations with him were fruitless. Mr. Savimbi's rebel group, Unita, has called for peace talks in recent months and has mounted a series of attacks to prove it remains a force to be reckoned with. Angola celebrates 26 years of independence this month but the country has been racked by civil war, with few breaks for peace, since winning its independence from Portugal in 1975.

title: 'Who Is Sidney Sherman?'
description: Pace/MacGill Gallery

title: Two Promoted By Times Co.
description: The New York Times Company has announced the promotion of two corporate executives.

title: KODAK IS BUYING ENCAD, MAKER OF WIDE-FORMAT PRINTERS
description: Eastman Kodak said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Encad Inc., a maker of wide-format inkjet printers used for advertising displays and architectural plans, for about $25 million in stock and cash. Encad, based in San Diego, lost $13.8 million on sales of $93.6 million last year. The acquisition is expected to add to earnings beginning in 2003, Kodak said. Sales of wide-format printers amount to about $2.4 billion a year and are increasing at a 15 percent annual rate, said Yves Millette, general manager of Kodak's printer business.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Assurances Offered About Military Courts
description: Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld sought today to address growing criticism over plans to try terrorists before military tribunals, saying he would move in a ''very measured and conservative'' way to establish procedures for such trials.

title: Philip Morris To Change Name to Altria
description: Philip Morris, the owner of one of the world's best-known corporate names, plans to change that name next year to the Altria Group, company executives said yesterday.

title: Congress Gives Quick Approval to Aviation Security Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16  A bill to increase aviation security raced through Congress today, on its way to President Bush, as federal officials struggled with the immense challenge of hiring and training 28,000 new federal employees to screen passengers and baggage at all airports within 12 months.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Cost Cuts Help Invensys
description: Invensys, a maker of factory controls, said recent cost cuts helped the company accumulate cash in the first six months of its fiscal year. The company had 68 million ($98 million) of cash as of Sept. 30, in contrast to a shortfall of 194 million a year earlier. Invensys still lost money in the period, 66 million, or 1.9 pence a share, in contrast with a profit of 40 million, or 1.1 pence a share, a year earlier. The chief executive, Rick Haythornthwaite, has moved swiftly to cut jobs and sell divisions to help restore profits. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Writing History to Executive Order
description: With a stroke of the pen on Nov. 1, President Bush stabbed history in the back and blocked Americans' right to know how presidents (and vice presidents) have made decisions. Executive Order 13223 ended more than 30 years of increasing openness in government.

title: Alpine Site Moved For Women's Event
description: Unseasonably warm weather and a lack of snow forced race organizers yesterday to change the site for next week's women's World Cup Alpine event.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Afghans Returning Home, Vindicated and Vengeful
description: In the year he spent in Iran, Aziz Habibi was a construction worker with no family and no history. In Afghanistan, his homeland, he had been a farmer and a mujahedeen member, a father and husband. This weekend, he will return to reclaim those identities.

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Today: Hearing On Building Regulators
description: The City Council has scheduled a hearing today on the performance of the Department of Buildings and the Department of Housing Preservation and Development after Sept. 11. City Hall, 10 a.m.

title: VECTOR AGREES TO BUY MEDALLION, A CIGARETTE MAKER
description: The Vector Group, the holding company for the Liggett Group and Vector Tobacco, agreed to buy Medallion, the discount cigarette maker, for $110 million. Vector will pay $75 million in cash and $35 million in notes for Medallion, which sells USA, Virginian and Marlin cigarettes. Buying Medallion gives Vector added protection to produce cigarettes without being subject to per-pack assessments accepted by the tobacco industry in its settlement with 46 states. Under that accord, Medallion can produce 60 million packs a year, a 0.28 percent share of the United States market, without paying the states. Vector can make about 350 million packs, a 1.67 percent market share.

title: Seeing the Circus Without Peanuts and Cotton Candy
description: If you, like some of us, are a grinch who shuns the circus, no problem. You can always savor the experience in art. From the late 19th century, when painters in Paris like Degas and Seurat discovered the potential of the Big Top, there has been no shortage of satisfying imagery in this country as well as in Europe for those who prefer to avoid the circus live.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Plans For Emergency Bunker
description: Baltimore is converting a cold-war-era fallout shelter into an emergency operations center that can be used in a terrorist attack. Renovation of the shelter, beneath a fire station in the northern part of the city, will cost about $400,000, the city's emergency management agency said. The shelter, with 22-inch-thick walls designed to withstand a nuclear attack, can hold about 50 people. It could be used by the mayor, the police and fire chiefs and other top city officials, as well as the Red Cross, the National Guard and the Baltimore Gas and Electric Company.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: U.S. Halts Peace Corps Work
description: The United States suspended its Peace Corps operations in Zimbabwe after 21 new volunteers who were to teach in the country's schools were not issued work permits by the government. Facing continued criticism from many Western governments over the political turmoil in the country, Zimbabwe has moved to reduce the presence of some foreigners, making it harder for foreign journalists to enter the country and moving to ban international monitors from observing the presidential election planned for next year. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: First Lady to Speak About Afghan Women
description: As part of an unusual international offensive by the Bush administration to publicize the plight of women in Afghanistan, Laura Bush will use her husband's usual Saturday radio address to speak about the oppression of Afghan women under the Taliban, White House officials said today.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Budget Deal Reached
description: After three days of tense negotiations to reduce a $300 million budget deficit, Gov. John G. Rowland and legislative leaders reached an agreement last night on a plan that would save $200 million and avoid layoffs of state employees. The State House of Representatives was set to vote on the plan last night and the Senate today. Lawmakers said the remaining $100 million deficit in the state's $13 billion budget would be addressed when the Legislature convenes in February if deficit projections remain unchanged.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Her Perfection Is Only Part of It

title: Frank Messer, Former Yankees Announcer, Dies at 76
description: Frank Messer, the straight arrow announcer of Yankee games for 18 seasons, died Tuesday at his home in Deerfield Beach, Fla. He was 76.

title: A Mayday System for New York Taxi and Livery Cabs
description: WHILE the events of recent months have overshadowed headlines concerning the dangers faced by drivers of New York taxi and livery cabs, the job continues to be a high-risk occupation.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: 2 Accused In Shooting
description: Two Brooklyn men were accused of shooting a bodega owner in a failed robbery. The men, Marcus Peoples, 20, and Travon Holloman, 19, were charged with assault and criminal possession of a weapon, the police said yesterday. The owner, whose name was not released, had been shot once in the chest and was in stable condition yesterday at Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center, the police said. They said two men went into T&T Deli and Grocery on Sutter Avenue in Brownsville around 5:45 p.m. Wednesday. They left, returned 10 minutes later and began shooting at the owner, who was behind plexiglass. The men fled with no money. Mr. Peoples and Mr. Holloman were soon arrested. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, MINNIE, (NEE KAPLAN)
description: HARRIS-Minnie, (nee Kaplan). Died Greenwich Woods Home November 15, 2001. Wife of the late Aaron Schoenbaum and Sam Harris. Survived by brother William Kalan, and daughters Sue Smith and Rita Gordon. Grandmother of six and great grandmother of nine. Graveside funeral, Sunday November 18th, Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: WEIGHT WATCHERS SHARES RISE 23% AFTER INITIAL OFFERING
description: Shares of Weight Watchers International rose 23 percent yesterday after the company raised $417.6 million in its initial public offering on Wednesday. The shares rose $5.50, to $29.50. Weight Watchers' owner, Artal Luxembourg, sold most of the 17.4 million shares, or 17 percent of the company, at $24 each. Yesterday, the company raised its asking price for the shares to $23 to $25 from $21 to $23. More than seven million shares changed hands in morning trading. Weight Watchers, based in Woodbury, N.Y., says that about 25 million women and men worldwide use its products and services to lose weight.

title: Data Shows Jet Shook After Hitting Wake of 747
description: American Airlines Flight 587 began to shake violently back and forth moments after bumping over the second of two wakes left by a Boeing 747 that had departed Kennedy International Airport just ahead of it. Seconds later, the plane plunged 2,900 feet to the ground, accident investigators said yesterday.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ERICSSON, Stockholm, said it would sell its cable television modems business, which employs about 100 people in the United States, to Aastra Technologies, Concord, Ontario, a maker of telecommunications equipment. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Christie's Ex-Executive Admits Cover-Up of Price-Fixing
description: The former auction house executive who testified this week that the chairman of Sotheby's was behind a giant price-fixing scandal admitted under cross-examination yesterday that he had long helped cover up the scheme by falsely denying its existence to investigators, investors, company directors and lawyers.

title: Knicks' Surge Holds Off the Heat
description: It was supposed to be dull and boring and ho-hum, evidence that the once gripping rivalry between the Knicks and the Miami Heat was unmistakably dead. Both teams are off to poor starts. Familiar faces are few, and Miami center Alonzo Mourning sat out with an unknown illness.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: A NATION CHALLENGED
description: FEAR OVER INTERVIEWS -- Polite and informal though they may be, F.B.I. interviews with young Middle Eastern men have sent a wave of worry through immigrants from the region in Southern California. PAGE B1

title: China's Unwitting Organ Donors
description: To the Editor:

title: At Latest Job Fair, a Warning Not to Take Some Jobs
description: For many people attending the Twin Towers Job Expo yesterday at Madison Square Garden, the hardest part of their day might not have been finding a job.

title: U.S. Suits Contend 3 Men Sold Tax-Evasion Schemes
description: The Justice Department filed lawsuits yesterday against three promoters of what the government contends are tax-evasion schemes that have cost it millions of dollars in taxes, including more than $400,000 of erroneous refunds, and helped others stop paying taxes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STALLMAN, DANIEL J.
description: STALLMAN-Daniel J., 77. Died November 14, 2001. Predeceased by his parents Frieda Kranz & Charles Stallman. and son Adam S. Stallman. Survived by his wife Ada Stallman of Binghamton, NY; son Richard M. Stallman, Cambridge, MA; daughter Claudia E. Stallman, Christine M. Coveney & grandson Benjamin A. Stallman all of Binghamton, New York. Dear husband, father, grandfather and friend. Graveside services Sunday, November 18 at 12:30 PM at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Queens, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations to Simon Wiesenthal Center, Tribute Dept, 1399 South Roxbury, Los Angeles, CA. 90035.

title: A Showdown Featuring Syracuse And Miami
description: At the outset of the season, the University of Miami Hurricanes probably believed they would play in a late-season game in which the Big East Conference title, a berth in a Bowl Championship Series game and perhaps a shot at the national championship would be on the line.

title: Boy, 4, Dies and 4 People Are Hurt In Collision of Ambulance and Van
description: A 4-year-old boy was killed, his younger sister was injured and his mother, who was eight months pregnant, went into labor yesterday after the minivan they were riding in collided with an ambulance at a Queens intersection, the police said.

title: China's Unwitting Organ Donors
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A map on Tuesday with an article about a possible replacement for the PATH transit station at the World Trade Center identified the proposed location imprecisely. A corrected map appears today, on Page B11.

title: Inquiries Put Mideast Men In Spotlight
description: With law enforcement officials set to interview 5,000 Middle Eastern men living in the United States, no part of the country feels itself more in the spotlight than Detroit and Dearborn, a suburb that is home to the nation's largest concentration of Arab-Americans.

title: China's Unwitting Organ Donors
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POCKER, M. PEABODY
description: POCKER-M. Peabody. Passed away November 14, 2001 following a long illness. Beloved by all who knew him. He is survived by his soulmate and life-long companion Lily Pocker and his grieving family, Richard and Beth Pocker of Pound Ridge, N.Y., Audrey and Marvin Pocker of New Rochelle, N.Y., Sam Pocker of Stamford, CT. and a sister, Roxie Azzoni of New Milford, CT. The family wishes to thank Dr. Sean Bell of Greenwich, CT. for his friendship and support during this difficult time. Blessed with every virtue and grace, loving and courageous, he was and shall remain the standard for a champion. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be set to Adopt-aDog Inc. of Greenwich, CT.

title: Vikings' Offense, And Aura, Sagging
description: For years, the Minnesota Vikings have been one of the N.F.L.'s elite teams. This year, they are not, and there are signs of strain in the Twin Cities.

title: Nets Are Ready for Their Early-Season Close-Up
description: Jason Kidd understood the natural hierarchy when he came east this summer and settled across the river from Madison Square Garden -- not that he liked where his Nets fell on the metropolitan area's food chain.

title: If a Guy Acts Like a Goat, He Deserves the Sobriquet
description: THE FEAST OF THE GOAT

title: Corrections
description: Articles on Oct. 26 and 27 and a brief report in the Week in Review on Oct. 28 about a fire that closed the St. Gotthard tunnel in Switzerland misidentified a tunnel that is being used as an alternate route. It is the San Bernardino, not the St. Bernhard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLASCOE, KEITH ALEXANDER
description: GLASCOE-Keith Alexander. A firefighter for three and-a-half years with the Fire Department of New York Ladder Company 21, was tragically lost with that Company's entire squad in the horrific collapse of the World Trade Center on September 11, 2001. He was 38. Born in San Francisco, CA, Mr. Glascoe was known for his 30-year football career beginning as an eight year old child. At Midwood High School in Brooklyn, NY he played offensive tackle, defensive end and kicker. He played football at Springfield College in Springfield, MA for two years, then transferred to Delaware State College in Dover, DE. Mr. Glascoe helped win several championships at Midwood and Delaware State. He graduated from Delaware State with a Bachelor in Business Administration. Following graduation, he participated in the New York Jets football training camp, but was released when he sustained serious shoulder and neck injuries. He then played American football in Northern Italy. Returning from Italy, he worked at the New York City Children's Welfare Agency (CWA) to help improve the plight of inner-city children. Mr. Glascoe also pursued an acting career, appearing in television commercials, print advertisements, television programs (''America's Most Wanted'', ''One Life to Live'', ''100 Centre Street''), and the made-for-TV movie, ''Assault on Devil's Island''. The highlight of his acting career was his role as ''Benny'' in the Luc Bessondirected film, ''The Professional'', which also starred Gary Oldman. Mr. Glascoe was married in 1996 to Veronica Squef and moved briefly to live in South Beach, FL. Mr. Glascoe is survived by his wife Veronica who is expecting their third child in April 2002; two young sons, Nolan Sebastian and Owen Alexander; his parents Benjamin Alexander and Gloria Glascoe; sister and brother-in-law Lee and Calvert Wright; grandmother Addie Oliver; uncles Victor M. Oliver and Sinclair Acey; great uncles Stanford Lawson, Woodrow Guill and great-aunt Jerusha Bennet; a nephew, four nieces and a host of cousins & other relatives. Mother & father-in-law Regina & Jacinto Squef; brother-in-law Gustavo Adrian Squef; sisters-in-law Kristen and Marcela, and a large circle of friends including Pedro Barry, Patrick Fahey, Chris Jones and his FDNY colleagues also survive him. Memorial Mass Saturday, 12 Noon on November 17, 2001 at Transfiguration Roman Catholic Church, 29 Mott Street, New York, New York 10013.

title: Florida Employers Will Offer Incentives to Doctors
description: A group of large Florida employers, including Lockheed Martin, Walt Disney World and Universal Studios, has decided to give financial rewards to doctors who meet certain quality standards and are highly rated by their patients.

title: U.S. Says Top Bin Laden Aide Believed Killed in Airstrike
description: Aleader of the Qaeda terror network is believed to have been killed in an American airstrike in the last two days, United States officials in Washington said today.

title: China's Unwitting Organ Donors
description: China's Unwitting Organ Donors

title: New Theory on a 20th Hijacker Is Offered
description: Federal investigators say that they now believe a Yemeni citizen may have been meant to be the 20th hijacker on Sept. 11 but that he failed to get into the United States.

title: Days of War And Wonder
description: When Saira Shah and her film crew sneaked across the border from Pakistan to Afghanistan last month, they kept the cameras rolling. In haunting black-and-white night vision, they are seen driving along a smugglers' road while Afghan men herd goats the other way, illegally heading to market. The journalists spot a Pakistani border patrol and abandon their truck, traipsing on foot for hours after their guide gets lost, wading across a river in 14-degree weather.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: After opening Canteen and Commune, Matthew Kenney is on to his third C, Commissary. As Matthew's, its previous incarnation, the restaurant was Mr. Kenney's flagship. Now, after getting a minimalist makeover, it feels lighter and breezier, like a communal canteen.

title: When Afghanistan Is Free of War
description: When the Afghans

title: Deal Brings Indian Casino in the Catskills Closer to Reality
description: Gambling in the Catskills moved a step closer to reality yesterday, as the St. Regis Mohawk Indian tribe signed an agreement with the world's largest gambling company to build and run a casino at the venerable Kutsher's Country Club in Monticello.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PENN, BLANCHE (NEE MALTZ)
description: PENN-Blanche (nee Maltz). Beloved wife of the late Jack. Devoted mother of Dr. Dean, Mark and Ronald. Dear sister of Rose Kurian and Mildred Sigler. Loving grandmother. Services ''Wien & Wien'', Englewood, NJ, Friday 1:00 PM (1-800-322-0533).

title: 15 Minutes and Then Some
description: conceptual thinker from a good family," Andy Warhol says about one of his most important acolytes and sounding boards in "Pie in the Sky: The Brigid Berlin Story." To be released on videocassette and DVD by Docurama on Tuesday, Vincent Fremont and Shelly Dunn Fremont's film about one of the more spectacularly unusual denizens of the Factory, Warhol's studio, stands out in a month packed with notable titles.

title: Inmate Education Is Found To Lower Risk of New Arrest
description: Inmates who receive schooling -- through vocational training or classes at the high school or college level -- are far less likely to return to prison within three years of their release, according to a study for the Department of Education.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Telecom Expansion
description: The Telstra Corporation, Australia's largest telecommunications company, has cemented plans to expand in New Zealand through the purchase of Clear Communications from British Telecommunications. After buying Clear for 143 million New Zealand dollars ($60 million), Telstra would take control of its joint venture TelstraSaturn, which will be blended with Clear to become the second-largest carrier in the country, behind Telecom New Zealand. Telstra will assume debt of $270 million New Zealand dollars ($113 million). TelstraSaturn is currently an equal joint venture between Telstra and the Australian regional pay television company Austar United Communications Ltd. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: Defense Creates Turnovers For the Jets
description: In Aaron Glenn's locker, there are three footballs wrapped in tape, with a time and quarter written in magic marker. They are the mementos of three of Glenn's four interceptions this year.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Nursing Home Labor Shortage
description: A new survey found that more than 9 out of 10 nursing homes in the state have severe employee shortages. The survey, by the New York Association of Homes and Services for the Aging, found high turnover rates and strained budgets among nursing homes, despite efforts to attract nurses and aides. Competition with other providers, low government reimbursement rates and low salaries were among the factors, the association said. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

title: Dividing Gifts to Firefighters, By Grief and by Spreadsheet
description: Thousands of free tickets to concerts and sporting events: the Jets, the Giants, the Big Apple Circus. Hundreds of free cabins on a weekend cruise to nowhere. Free two-week holidays for 50 to Germany, courtesy of the German government. Free trips to California, Hawaii, the Caribbean. Even the volunteer fire department of Skaneateles has offered to cover an all-expenses-paid weekend for 20 at a county inn in its small town in upstate New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, RUTH
description: GREENBERG-Ruth. Sutton Place Synagogue extends deep sympathy to our devoted members and Patrons Ellen and Martin Hertz on the passing of Ellen's beloved mother. Condolences to grandchildren Tracy and Adam Hertz and the entire bereaved family. Allan Schranz, Rabbi Robert W. Berend, President

title: Immigrants Refuse Meals to Protest Treatment
description: Seven immigrants detained at a county jail in New Jersey since the Sept. 11 terror attacks are staging a hunger strike to protest their treatment by federal immigration officials, county officials said yesterday.

title: INSIDE
description: No Deal on Missiles

title: Foreign Affairs; Breaking the Circle
description: Although it was never his intention, Osama bin Laden has triggered the most serious debate in years, among Muslims, about Islam's ability to adapt to modernity. In Arab states this debate is still muted. But in Pakistan and other Muslim countries with a relatively free press, writers are raising it openly and bluntly. Nothing could be more important.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRIS, MORTON G., D.D.S.
description: MORRIS - Morton G., D.D.S. Passed away November 14, 2001. Beloved husband of Eleanor. Proud father of Steven & Andrew. Loving grandfather of Alexandra. Uncle of Robert Gewirtz. Practiced as a dentist in Williamsburg, Jackson Heights and Roslyn, N.Y. Ended his long dental career as a devoted teacher at NYU College of Dentistry in Manhattan. WWII veteran who served in the Pacific and retired as a Commander in the U.S. Navy. He will be greatly missed by those who knew him throughout his life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POSTER, MURIEL
description: POSTER-Muriel. We mourn the loss of our dear friend of many years and so many fond memories. Muriel was a true lady and the life of the party. It will never be the same without her. ''Table number 7''..Serko-Feldman Todrys-Davis-Bagley

title: Action at Last on Airport Safety
