description: Under Capitol Hill etiquette, the aviation security bill that is now apparently on its way to passage by the House and Senate is supposed to be praised as a sensible compromise. In truth, it is a victory for the bipartisan Senate plan and a defeat for obstructionist House Republican leaders. Congress is scheduled to vote on the legislation today, allowing President Bush to sign it before Thanksgiving. It's about time.

title: Art Listings
description: Aselective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: Clemens Adds 6th Cy Young to Case
description: Kacy Clemens, 7, pushed a chair to the kitchen sink last summer and held a baseball under a running faucet. His father, a Yankee pitcher of some note, asked the boy what he was doing, and Kacy explained that he had hit this particular ball for a home run in tee ball and it needed cleaning before being added to the family's trophy case.

title: Competition From the Girl Next Door
description: In ''The Simian Line'' Lynn Redgrave gives her all to the role of Katharine, an insecure middle-aged real estate agent desperately possessive of her much younger lover, Rick (Harry Connick Jr.), an easygoing stained-glass artist from the South. The two live together in Weehawken, N.J., just across the Hudson River from Manhattan. Their relationship is running smoothly until Rick strikes up a friendship with Sandra (Cindy Crawford), a beautiful young professional party planner who lives next door with her husband, Paul (Jamey Sheridan), and Katharine plunges into a maelstrom of irrational jealousy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLATTERFEIN, IDA
description: BLATTERFEIN-Ida. On November 15, 2001. Beloved companion of Joseph J. Ferrara. Loving daughter of the late Morris and Rose Blatterfein. Cherished sister of the late Frances Hamilton, the late Rae Ferrara, the late Sydney Blatterfein and the late Gertrude Blatterfein. Adored aunt of Linda, Diane, Joan, Barbara, Larry and great aunt. Services on Monday, November 19, 10AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St & Amsterdam Ave. The family will be receiving at the chapel Sunday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Interment to follow at Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY.

title: Westchester Proposes Raising Property Tax Rates
description: The Westchester County executive, Andrew J. Spano, today proposed raising the county property tax levy by 9.5 percent -- the largest increase in 12 years and the first since Mr. Spano took office in 1998.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Guilty Plea For Murder
description: A 24-year-old man will spend the rest of his life in prison, after pleading guilty yesterday to the kidnapping and murder of a British computer consultant who was dating the man's former girlfriend, federal prosecutors said. The man, Gregory Marcinski of Brick Township, admitted in court that he drove from his home to Kentucky, where, posing as an F.B.I. agent, he abducted Paul J. Gale, 28, and then strangled him with a nylon cord.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the National Briefing column on Wednesday about a judge's order barring two AIDS protesters from contact with employees of The San Francisco Chronicle whom they were suspected of having threatened by telephone referred incorrectly to one protester, Michael Petrelis. He is not a member of the protest group Act Up San Francisco.

title: Johnson and Longley Hurting Bottom Line
description: Larry Johnson and Luc Longley are gone from the Knicks' roster, but clearly not forgotten by their former employers at Cablevision.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a 5 percent cut in the salaries of executives at the Tribune Company of Chicago referred imprecisely to the compensation of its chief executive, John Madigan, and misstated the amount of the cut. In 2000, Mr. Madigan's salary was $846,000 and he received a $3 million bonus. His salary was not $4 million. For 2002 his salary will be lowered by 5 percent from its current level, which has not yet been disclosed, and his bonus will be eliminated this year. His salary will not be cut by $200,000.

title: Maria Friberg
description: Team

title: Technology Briefing
description: HARDWARE

title: A Nation Challenged
description: Safety in the Skies

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JESSE, MARY JANE
description: JESSE-Mary Jane. The Physicians and Staff of the Department of Pediatrics, Columbia University, College of Physicians & Surgeons and the Babies Hospital Alumni Association wish to express our heartfelt sorrow and condolences to the family of Mary Jane Jesse, MD. Following a successful career on Madison Avenue, Dr. Jesse graduated from College of Physicians & Surgeons and completed her residency and a fellowship in cardiology from Babies Hospital. She was awarded the Babies Hospital Distinguished Alumnus Award in 1992. Mary Jane's brilliance has stimulated and brought pleasure to those of her friends from Babies Hospital who had the pleasure of being her friend and colleague. John M. Driscoll, Jr., MD Reuben S. Carpentier Professor Chairman, Dept. of Pediatrics Dorothy Levine, MD President Babies Hospital Alumni Assoc.

title: G.M. to Begin Saturn Review
description: The General Motors Corporation said yesterday that it would begin the first review involving its Saturn line since the brand was introduced a dozen years ago, seeking an agency to create campaigns for a new coupe and sedan to be introduced under the Ion model name.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about immigration charges against Mohammad Yaseen Haider, president of the Pakistan Student Association at the University of Oklahoma, misspelled the surname of the university president, whose press secretary provided details about an assault on Mr. Haider. He is David L. Boren, not Boron.

title: Ex-Rep. Bob Eckhardt, 88, Liberal Democrat of Texas
description: Bob Eckhardt, who survived for 14 years in Congress as a liberal Democrat from Houston despite a constituency that was considerably to his right politically, died on Tuesday in Austin, Tex., his hometown. He was 88.

title: Meeting With Bloomberg May Signal Levy's Future
description: Mayor-elect Michael R. Bloomberg has invited Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy for a lunchtime chat today in what could be the first step toward deciding Mr. Levy's future as the head of what is by far the city's largest agency.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COYLE, DORIS DOW.
description: COYLE-Doris Dow. On November 14, 2001 at age 91. Aunt of Jean Schiller. Cousin of Thelma Beattie, Donna Beattie, Inez and Linwood Hayden, Herbert Dow and Walter Dow of Maine. A close friend of Marguerite Sheridan, Delphine Keathly and Lucille Harkless. A graveside service will be held on Monday, November 19, at Valleau Cemetery, Ridgewood, NJ. Contributions in her memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Wisconsin: Race For Governor
description: The brother of Secretary Tommy G. Thompson of health and human services, Ed Thompson, said he would run for governor in 2002. Mr. Thompson, the mayor of Tomah, a small city in western Wisconsin, said he would run as a Libertarian. The owner of a popular supper club, Mr. Thompson joins Gov. Scott McCallum, a Republican, and two Democrats, Representative Thomas M. Barrett and Attorney General Jim Doyle, in the race.

title: A Correction
description: A map on Tuesday with an article about a possible replacement of the PATH station at the World Trade Center identified the area of the proposed location imprecisely. It is in the area designated below, not the area below the label.

title: Ridge Agrees Taliban Losses May Lead to New Terrorism
description: Taliban defeats in Afghanistan could lead Al Qaeda to strike back with another terrorist attack, Tom Ridge, the director of homeland security, suggested today.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: For Some Kuwaitis, the Ardor for America Cools
description: Eight years ago, the al-Munaif family slaughtered sheep in tribute to one President Bush, as that leader was hailed as the liberator of Kuwait during a 1993 visit in which he basked in adulation.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I saw a family on the way, a husband, a pregnant wife, carrying two small children and their belongings. They could carry them no longer. They kissed their children and left them in the mountains.''

title: At Ground Zero, to Remember Forever
description: To the Editor:

title: Bruins' Might Unravels the Devils
description: It is out of character for the Devils to allow 44 shots on goal in a game and somewhat surprising for them to blow a two-goal lead that they had established early in the second period. But that is what they did against the Boston Bruins tonight at the Fleet Center, and even though they scrambled back to send the game into overtime, they still lost, 5-4. The Devils (8-5-1-2) are without a victory in their last three games after having lost once in the previous nine.

title: National Briefing | West: Hawaii: Tourism Decline Dents Revenues
description: Hit by a 20 percent decline in tourism since the Sept. 11 attacks, Hawaii will collect $150 million less in tax revenue this fiscal year than previously expected. The anticipated 0.7 percent drop in collections for the year that began July 1 will be the first decline since 1995. Just days before the attacks on New York and the Pentagon, state forecasters had predicted 4.1 percent revenue growth for the 2002 fiscal year. The reversal will force the government to trim its $3.5 billion budget or dip into its $600 million cash reserves.

title: Normal She's Not
description: Jeffrey Donovan, Anna Paquin and Brittany Slattery in ''The Glory of Living'' at MCC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONOVAN, CARRIE
description: DONOVAN - Carrie. Parsons School of Design and New School University mourn the passing of our esteemed alumna and fashion leader, Carrie Donovan. We send deepest sympathies to her sister, Joan Donovan. President Bob Kerrey, New School University Chairman Arnold Aronson, Parsons Board of Governors Dean H. Randolph Swearer, Parsons School of Design

title: F.B.I. Visits Provoke Waves of Worry in Middle Eastern Men
description: Ghaith Aljazzar recognized them immediately. Seated at a picnic table in a sea of college students chatting between classes today, the two men in suits and dark glasses were plainly Federal Bureau of Investigation agents, even before they flashed their badges.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHN, SAMUEL
description: COHN-Samuel. Of Newton, MA. Formerly of New York City, died peacefully at home November 14, 2001, 18 days short of his 104 birthday. Devoted husband of the late Dora (Goldman), father of Geraldine Morse of Newton and Marilyn Schwartz of Boston. Grandfather of Ruth Morse Collini of Cambridge, England, Julia Morse of Denver, Steven Schwartz and his wife Joy (Harris) of Los Angeles, Jeffrey Schwartz of Watertown and the late William Schwartz. Great grandfather of William, Jonah, Rebecca and Zachary Schwartz. Graveside service leaving from ''The Riverside'', 76th Street & Amsterdam Avenue on Sunday, November 18 at 10AM. Donations in his memory may be made to Dorot, 171 West 85th Street, New York, NY 10024.

title: For Rahman, Part Rock and Part Rocky, the Carnival Ride Goes On
description: The Rock's entourage marched into the weigh-in ceremony today as if it were on parade. The managers, trainers, sparring partners and family members fell in behind Hasim Rahman, the heavyweight champion, pumped their fists, traded words with jeering Lennox Lewis fans and frolicked in the pageantry of the first title fight for their guy on United States soil.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Menem Cleared On One Charge
description: A federal judge ordered that one charge be dropped in the investigation of former President Carlos Sal Menem's connections to arms smuggling to Croatia and Ecuador between 1991 and 1995. Judge Julio Speroni said there was insufficient evidence that Mr. Menem had been involved in smuggling gunpowder. But Mr. Menem, who has been under house arrest since June, will remain in custody as investigators continue to look into whether he led an ''illicit organization'' set up to traffic in arms.

title: Global Forecast Of Growth Is Cut
description: The International Monetary Fund cut its forecasts for United States, Japanese, European and world growth for 2001 and next year, after the terrorist strikes on Sept. 11 deepened a world economic slowdown.

title: Workers Shore Up Wall Keeping Hudson's Waters Out
description: Workers have begun anchoring a crucial underground retaining wall to the bedrock beneath the World Trade Center site, a reprise of its original construction in the 1960's and an important step in ensuring that the waters of the Hudson River do not come rushing in.

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of yesterday, 4,386 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Airline Posts Loss
description: Hurt by a slumping economy and fears about safety, the Japan Airlines Company said its profit fell 61 percent, to 16.4 billion yen ($136 million) in the six-month period that ended Sept. 30. For the full year, though, the airline, the largest in Japan, expects to lose 40 billion yen ($331 million) as travelers stay home because of concerns about safety. Nearly three-quarters of Japan Airlines' sales come from international flights, and the sagging market has forced the carrier to cut a quarter of its trans-Pacific flights. In a bid to diversify, the company said Tuesday that it would form a holding company with the Japan Air Systems Company, the country's third-largest airline. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Missile Impasse: The Shape of the Deal
description: In the end, neither President Bush, nor President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia wanted to pull the plug on the relationship they have built in the short season of summitry they started only last June.

title: Security Bill Is Criticized By Those It Would Displace
description: Having failed in last-minute lobbying to save its multimillion-dollar contracts with the airlines, the airport security industry reacted with bitterness and skepticism to today's Congressional compromise that essentially puts private companies out of the passenger-screening business for at least three years.

title: The Neediest Cases; In Search of Well-Being, Needing a Home
description: Walking down the long corridor to her office in a Charlotte, N.C., hospital two years ago, Marie Santiago began to notice that she could not walk in a straight line. It seemed to her that the world was spinning.

title: Editors' Note; Today's Sections
description: News of the Sept. 11 attacks and their aftermath continues to appear in Section B; index, Page B2.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Profit Up At Telefnica
description: The Spanish telecommunications company Telefnica reported nine-month net profit up 7.2 percent, to 1.59 billion euros ($1.4 billion), helped by growth in mobile phones and strong fixed-line performance at home. Earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization rose 8.5 percent, to 9.64 billion euros, slightly below analysts' forecasts. The company said a strong showing at Telefnica Mviles and a sharp fall in financial costs helped offset currency effects in Latin America. Telefnica shares rose 2.8 percent, to 15.94 euros. Emma Daly (NYT)

title: Egan Speaks to Dominicans at Mass for Crash Victims
description: There were hundreds of them who did not know a soul who died when the jumbo jet crashed earlier this week. It hardly mattered. All Dominicans are family, they said.

title: Bush by 537; Gore by 537,179
description: Now that a group of major news organizations has concluded that it was not the Supreme Court that imposed President Bush upon the nation, it's important to note that the voters didn't decide it that way, either. It does not take eight months of research with the University of Chicago to know that the current leader of the free (or at least the antiterrorist) world got half a million fewer votes last year than his opponent.

title: Dell Rebounds After a 2nd-Quarter Loss
description: Rebounding from a loss in the July quarter, the Dell Computer Corporation reported a third-quarter profit of $429 million yesterday. Its earnings fell by a third from the period a year ago but edged past Wall Street's estimates.

title: A Catch-22 on Drugs for the World's Poor
description: The good news for the world's poorest countries is that they emerged from this week's global trade talks in Doha, Qatar, with the right to make low-cost generic knock-offs of medicines patented by multinational pharmaceutical corporations.

title: QandA / A chat with an insider : 'A Paradigm Shift in How People Interact With Data'
description: Shai Agassi is chief executive of SAP Portals Inc., a Silicon Valley-based subsidiary of the German business-software giant SAP AG. The company, started in April when SAP spent $400 million to buy TopTier Software Inc., an Israeli company that Mr. Agassi co-founded, sells enterprise portals  basically, software that offers companies customized computer desktops that filter information. These single points of access can also link corporate partners and suppliers as well as a company's financial statistics and other databases.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Novell To Lay Off 1,400
description: Novell, a maker of networking software, said it would eliminate 19 percent of its work force, or 1,400 jobs, and take a charge of $55 million in an effort to become profitable again despite the slowing information-technology market. Novell, based in Provo, Utah, said preliminary financial results from the fiscal fourth quarter, ended Oct. 31, showed that it beat analysts' estimates and its own forecasts by a penny a share. Excluding the restructuring charge, largely related its acquisition of the consulting firm Cambridge Technology Partners, Novell said it would report earnings of 1 cent a share, compared with break-even during the year-earlier period. Quarterly revenue is expected to be $306 million. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Ireland Wins Spot In the World Cup
description: Ireland, which had qualified only twice before, clinched a spot in next year's World Cup soccer tournament yesterday. Even though Iran was a 1-0 winner in the match in Tehran, it was unable to overcome a two-goal deficit from the first game of the home-and-home series.

title: 15 Minutes And Then Some
description: ''A conceptual thinker from a good family,'' Andy Warhol says about one of his most important acolytes and sounding boards in ''Pie in the Sky: The Brigid Berlin Story.'' To be released on videocassette and DVD by Docurama on Tuesday, Vincent Fremont and Shelly Dunn Fremont's film about one of the more spectacularly unusual denizens of the Factory, Warhol's studio, stands out in a month packed with notable titles.

title: A Time of Mourning, and a Rare Time in the Sun
description: LOOKING for Moiss Prez, that mama's-boy-made-good as a tireless community service whiz for the city's Dominicans? Everybody is. Just get in line and follow the tears to 180th Street, and Alianza Dominicana. There Mr. Prez, the harried guy with the office full of clementines -- he postulates they provide an adrenaline rush -- and mournful under-eye circles dark as his mustache, holds a phone aloft as if expecting it to bite.

title: The Sorcerer's Apprentice
description: THE world may not be ready yet for the film equivalent of books on tape, but this peculiar phenomenon has arrived in the form of the film adaptation of J. K. Rowling's ''Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone.'' The most highly awaited movie of the year has a dreary, literal-minded competence, following the letter of the law as laid down by the author. But it's all muted flourish, with momentary pleasures, like Gringott's, the bank staffed by trolls that looks like a Gaud throwaway. The picture is so careful that even the tape wrapped around the bridge of Harry's glasses seems to have come out of the set design. (It never occurred to anyone to show him taping the frame together.)

title: Microsoft and the Courts
description: To the Editor:

title: Senators Seek $3.2 Billion to Fight Germ Threats, Doubling Bush Plan
description: A bipartisan group of senators introduced legislation today calling for $3.2 billion to fight bioterrorism and said it believed President Bush, who has proposed spending half that much, would support the bill. But the White House said its support was not assured.

title: Reading Magic
description: Some years ago, I began the practice of asking students taking my course on the culture of childhood to tell me about the books they bring with them from home to college. With a nod in the direction of those sacred stuffed animals that the child psychologist D. W. Winnicott called ''transitional objects,'' we call these books their transitional stories, narratives that form a part of their childhood identity and help build a bridge to a new one.

title: Peggy Mount, 85, British Actress Who Made Grown Men Tremble
description: Peggy Mount, for many years the fearsome battle-ax of British stage and screen with a voice to make henpecked husbands tremble, died on Tuesday at a London nursing home for actors. She was 85.

title: Stimulus Bill Prompts Insults But No Action
description: After swapping insults, Congressional leaders announced today that they would leave for a Thanksgiving vacation without action, or even talks, on economic stimulus legislation.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: For 'Angels,' A Juggling Act

title: Talks Fail With Taliban Besieged In Kunduz
description: Talks to secure a peaceful handover of the besieged Taliban-held city of Kunduz collapsed today, setting the stage for a possible battle involving thousands of foreign Taliban troops believed to be trapped in the northern Afghan city.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Walking On Air

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. The ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in some copies on Tuesday about a man whose house in Belle Harbor, Queens, was destroyed by the crash of Flight 587 misspelled his surname. He is Mark Shorr, not Shore.

title: In Her World, Normalcy Includes the Grotesque
description: She's still got the glow, all right.

title: $88 Billion Farm Subsidy Bill Is Approved by Senate Panel
description: The Senate Agriculture Committee approved an $88 billion farm bill today that places no limits on subsidies to America's wealthiest farmers and increases spending for conservation and food stamps.

title: Cosmopolitan Trove On the Road to China
description: THE eyes of the world are zeroed in on a battered patch of Central Asia right now, scrutinizing its every move. At the same time, global events in recent years have prompted an increasingly wide-angle view of Asia itself, revealing it to be an array of disparate and dynamic cultures rather than a one-color shape on the map.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SICHER, ANN B.
description: SICHER-Ann B. The Lenox Hill Hospital Auxiliary mourns the loss of its longtime member and past chairman, Ann B. Sicher. Ann was a devoted friend of Lenox Hill Hospital and will be deeply missed by all who knew her. Katherine T. McEnroe Chairman Lenox Hill Hospital Auxiliary

title: How to Submit an Announcement
description: TO submit news of your wedding or celebration to The New York Times, please pay careful attention to the information that follows:

title: National Briefing | Washington: Veto Threat On Base Closings
description: Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld threatened a presidential veto of the defense authorization bill if House negotiators on a conference report continued to resist new base-closing authority for the department. In a letter to Senator Carl Levin, the Michigan Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, Mr. Rumsfeld wrote that keeping unneeded bases ''is unfair to the taxpayer and diverts resources that would be better applied to our war fighters.'' The Senate voted to include in its bill a provision for a new round of base closings. The House bill had no such measure. Adam Clymer (NYT)

title: AOL-AT&T Cable Talks Said to Be Advancing
description: AOL Time Warner's tentative discussions about acquiring the cable television business of AT&T have edged forward, with AOL Time Warner signing a confidentiality agreement that could allow the talks to move to a new stage, people close to the negotiations said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEARCEY, VIOLET HALL
description: PEARCEY-Violet Hall. On September 26, 2001, of New York City, passed away at the age of 89. She is survived by her sister, Rose Hall of New York; cousin, Cameron (Maggie) Moseley & niece, Peggy of Connecticut; stepdaughters, Joan (Eric) Cooke of Edmonton, Alberta; Lynn (George) Allen of Mossyrock, WA, and Gail (Roger) August of Winnipeg, Manitoba; seven grandchildren, nine greatgrandchildren and close friend, Nell (Rod) Kempton and family.

title: Boon for U.S. in Cheaper Energy; OPEC Disunity May Prop Up Hard-Pressed Businesses
description: OPEC's problems could translate into substantial benefits for American business and consumers.

title: Switching to the Euro:The Art of Rounding Up
description: FRANKFURT  COUNTDOWN TO THE EURO 2002 SERIES

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Funny Faces, Sad Topic

title: Jobless Claims Drop for Third Consecutive Week
description: The number of workers filing initial claims for state unemployment benefits dropped to the lowest level since mid-September, the government reported today, signaling that the job cuts after the terrorist attacks are abating.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEXNER, BELLA
description: WEXNER-Bella. Thank you. It is with great sadness that HIAS, the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society, notes the passing of Bella Wexner, a dear friend and generous contributor in support of HIAS' mission of rescue, reunion & resettlement. Her warmth and compassion will be sorely missed. Our heartfelt sympathy goes out to her entire family. Neil Greenbaum Chair of the Board Leonard Glickman President & CEO

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Vital Signs column of Science Times on Tuesday about the brain's perception of beauty identified the authors of the study incompletely. Besides Dr. Hans C. Breiter, they were Dr. Itzhak Aha ron, Dr. Nancy Etcoff, Dr. Dan Ari ely, Dr. Christopher F. Chabris and Ethan O'Conor.

title: Sorenstam And Webb Renew Rivalry
description: Even though it was only the first round, the play of Karrie Webb and Annika Sorenstam helped make today compelling.

title: A Wedding Planner, a Computer Pro, an Animal Lover, a Stargazer
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: A High-Powered Deal Maker Is Named to Lead Lazard
description: Bruce Wasserstein, a Wall Street deal maker who rose to prominence in the 1980's, is taking the top job at Lazard L.L.C., an investment bank adrift after a string of defections.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE GREECE: AMERICAN EXPRESS BANK BOMBED

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Ferrets In The Wild
description: Black-footed ferrets were released in northwestern Colorado as part of a recovery effort for one of the rarest mammals in North America. The ferrets were listed as endangered in 1967. Since 1991, hundreds of ferrets bred in captivity have been released at eight sites in five states and in Mexico. The 38 ferrets released this week will be the first in the wild in Colorado in more than five decades.

title: Solid Contemporary Sale Ends 2 Weeks of Auctions
description: In the quirky world of contemporary art, taste comes in many forms. At Christie's last night, more than four bidders each would have happily taken home a partially used bar of soap inlaid with an artist's pubic hair, or 325 pounds of hard candy wrapped in blue cellophane, or even a stark hanging light bulb. Lots of people were also willing to pay many thousands of dollars for photographs that exist in multiple editions.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: New Woes For Pigs And Farmers
description: Britain's pig population, already diminished by outbreaks of swine fever and foot-and-mouth disease, is facing an epidemic from a new virus that thrives on dirty or mismanaged farms and can be carried by birds. Almost 250,000 pigs were slaughtered in the earlier culls, and veterinarians predict that another 300,000 could die from the new illness, called Postweaning Multisystematic Wasting Syndrome. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Sale Of Comdisco Unit Is Cleared
description: A federal appeals court yesterday rejected the Justice Department's effort to stop SunGard Data Systems Inc. from buying a unit of Comdisco, which filed for bankruptcy protection in July. In late October, federal antitrust officials moved to block the $825 million acquisition of Comdisco's Availability Solutions, a computer disaster-recovery concern, arguing that it would reduce competition. Interest in the future of the unit of Comdisco, short for the Computer Discount Corporation, has increased in the wake of the Sept. 11 attacks. SunGard said it expected the Justice Department to appeal the latest decision, but said it would ask the court to resolve the appeal before Dec. 5, the termination date for the deal. SunGard shares rose $1.08, or 4 percent, to $28.05. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Veterans of Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: Now, the Battle to Feed the Afghan Nation
description: The retreat of the Taliban has opened the next critical phase of the American campaign in Afghanistan: joining the effort to deliver relief for millions of hungry, cold, sick, war-weary Afghans, thousands of them at death's door. In the end, the war against famine, disease and misery may prove as important as the military campaign in ending a generation of misrule and chaos.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KREINCES, ARTHUR D.
description: KREINCES-Arthur D., 96 years old, on November 14, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Mollie. Father of Howard and Leonard. Fatherin-law of Sheila and Loraine. Grandfather of Brad and Amy, Robin, Henry and Lisa, Jeffrey and Melissa, Beth and Jeffrey and Edward and Heather. Great grandfather of Alexander, Jason, Evan, Taylor, Ethan, Harly, Jamie, Max, Alex and Hannah. Brother of Henrietta Goldsmith. A pioneer and founder in the New York and national produce industry. Through his own efforts he transformed the industry as to its credit information and was a friend and supporter to so many entering the produce industry for over 60 years. There will be none like him in the produce industry, much less in this world. Funeral Friday, 12 noon at Sinai Chapels, Flushing, Queens.

title: Corrections
description: Articles on Oct. 26 and 27 and a brief report in the Week in Review on Oct. 28 about a fire that closed the St. Gotthard tunnel in Switzerland misidentified a tunnel that is being used as an alternate route. It is the San Bernardino, not the St. Bernhard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENARDETE, SETH
description: BENARDETE-Seth. On November 14, 2001. Beloved husband of Jane. Loving father of Ethan and Alexandra Emma. Dear brother of Jose and Diego. Professor of Classics at NYU and Philosophy at the Graduate Faculty of the New School for Social Research. He was the author of many articles, translations, and books, among them ''The Being of the Beautiful'', 1984, ''Socrates' Second Sailing'', 1989, and ''Plato's Laws: the Discovery of Being'', 2000. Memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: Rangers Counting on 2 Big Names
description: The Rangers awoke yesterday with a share of first place with the Islanders in the Eastern Conference, a significant turnaround for a team that has not qualified for the playoffs the past four seasons.

title: OIL PRICES TUMBLE TO A 2-YEAR LOW
description: Oil prices went into free fall today as Russia, the world's biggest oil exporter after Saudi Arabia, rejected a challenge from the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries to stabilize prices by sharply cutting production.

title: Two Employees File Bias Suit Against Johnson & Johnson
description: Two employees of Johnson & Johnson sued the giant health care company yesterday, contending it had discriminated against them and hundreds of other minority employees in both pay and promotions.

title: Hofstra Baseball Player Dies in a Touch Football Game With Teammates During Practice
description: A Hofstra University baseball player died Wednesday after collapsing during a touch football game with teammates, the authorities said today.

title: When the Screams Dry Up, The Monsters Get Tough
description: Monsters, Inc.

title: Insurance Battle Escalates
description: The World Trade Center's largest insurer said yesterday that a demand for an immediate payment by the developer who holds the lease to the complex was signaling his decision not to rebuild.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELSNER, ALLAN S.
description: ELSNER-Allan S. 85. Died Sunday November 11, 2001. Allan attended Williams College and was the owner and operator of a bookshop in New York City until his retirement several years ago. He leaves his brothers Morton, James and Robert, several nieces and nephews. Graveside services will be held Sunday, November 18, at 2 P.M. at Beth Israel Cemetery, Ward Street, Hartford, CT.

title: INSIDE ART
description: A Homegrown Biennial

title: French Move To Control Secret Fund Of Leaders
description: Parliament has voted to overhaul a decades-old system of giving the prime minister's office millions of dollars in cash without asking for a public accounting of how the money is spent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE ROTHSCHILD, DEBRA
description: de ROTHSCHILD-Debra. The Staff and Friends of the Ghetto Fighters' Museum extend deepest sympathies to our dear friend Robert de Rothschild on the untimely passing of his beloved wife Debra. May Debra's loving legacy and little Jacob bring comfort to Robert and the family at this tragic time. Simcha Stein, Director, The Ghetto Fighters' Museum Mark Sarna, Chairman, American Friends of the Ghetto Fighters' Museum Debbie Nahshon, Exec. Director, American Friends Raya Kalisman, Director Center for Humanistic Education Michal Gans, Overseas Dept.

title: At Ground Zero, to Remember Forever
description: To the Editor:

title: Knicks' Surge Holds Off the Heat
description: It was supposed to be dull and boring and ho-hum, evidence that the once gripping rivalry between the Knicks and the Miami Heat was unmistakably dead. Both teams are off to poor starts. Familiar faces are few, and Miami center Alonzo Mourning sat out with an unknown illness.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Election Bill Advances
description: In the first concrete sign of progress in the House on changes in election procedures, the Committee on House Administration unanimously passed a bill that would give states $2.6 billion to overhaul their election systems and buy new equipment. Speaker J. Dennis Hastert, Republican of Illinois, said he wanted to move the bill ''as quickly as possible.'' But civil rights organizations oppose the measure, saying it will do little to guarantee that everyone's vote counts. The Senate is working on its own bill.

title: At City Hall, Union Leader Offers Criticism Of the Schools
description: The City Council hearing was called to sing the praises of the teachers and principals who guided thousands of children to safety after the World Trade Center attack.

title: A Woman Is Pushed Into the Path Of No. 6 Train
description: A woman was seriously injured after being pushed into the path of a subway train at Grand Central Terminal last night by an emotionally disturbed man, the police said.

title: When the Afghans Are Free of War
description: To the Editor:

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: After Sept. 11, value and price become the themes for promoting holiday shopping.
description: AS retailers face their most challenging holiday shopping season in decades, they are striving to entice consumers into stores with campaigns playing up value without hurting their brand images by running schlocky ads that scream ''Sale!''

title: 8 Aid Workers' Ordeal Ends Happily in Pakistan
description: A day after their rescue from Afghanistan by American military helicopters, eight Western aid workers, including two American women, exulted today in their first full day of freedom.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: 4 Accused Of Money-Laundering
description: Federal prosecutors yesterday charged four New York City residents with defrauding Medicaid of more than $2.5 million, then laundering the money through bank accounts in New Jersey and using it to buy Mercedes automobiles and property in Staten Island. Immigration officials plan to deport one of the defendants, Mohammad Razzaque Pal, 55, of Queens, to his native Pakistan, prosecutors said. The other defendants are Azam Hayat Khan, 39, of Manhattan, Shahid Khawaja, 43, of Staten Island, and Anita Saeed Khawaja, 39, who is Mr. Khawaja's wife.

title: Executive Bonuses Included In the Hewlett-Compaq Deal
description: Senior executives of Hewlett-Packard and Compaq Computer will receive bonus payments totaling more than $55 million if the companies' merger succeeds and they stay on until September 2003, according to a document filed with the government yesterday.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Gates Sells First XBox
description: More than 1,000 people lined up in Times Square late Wednesday to be among the first to purchase the Xbox, Microsoft's first game console, which went on sale at midnight. Bill Gates was on hand to autograph the box of the first buyer, 20-year-old Edward Glucksman, above, who had waited in line for 16 hours to be the first consumer to buy one of the $299 Xbox game machines. Mr. Gates played and lost some games with some of the first customers. ''I need to find more average gamers,'' he said after one loss, ''not like the ones that are here tonight.'' Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Central Asian Jews Create 'Queensistan'
description: Ilyas Malayev slips out of his suit jacket into a gold brocade silk caftan, adds a matching raised skullcap and begins to tune his handmade tar. Renowned in his native Uzbekistan and now a resident of Queens, he plays his 11-stringed instrument with studied precision, the gold tassel of his hat brushing against his temple. Along with the members of Maqam, the Bukharan musical ensemble he founded, he sings in Bukhari, a Jewish dialect of Persian. The group performs a suite, mostly of love songs, for visitors in a Forest Hills restaurant. But he looks sad.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: The Brownstein Group, Philadelphia, hired two employees. Chris Reif becomes interactive art director at WebFingerprint, the online marketing division of Brownstein; he had been a Web designer at Bucknell University. Also, Jamie Victor, an intern at Brownstein, becomes a graphic designer.

title: U.S. Testing Goes Ahead; Could Violate ABM Treaty
description: With the failure of President Bush and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia to reach an agreement on replacing or amending the Antiballistic Missile Treaty, the Pentagon is moving ahead with plans for missile defense testing and construction work that could violate the treaty sometime next year, officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, RICHARD HOWARD
description: BROWN-Richard Howard. On November 8. A pioneer of credit card electronic reservations for the hospitality industry as co-founder of Telemax in the 1950's. Later turned his marketing skills to the performing arts with an innovative concept of cluster management for small to medium-sized performing groups with Directional Concepts. Survived by his son Zhu Min, his sister Cynthia Cowan and remembered as a good friend and manager by all those who worked with him.

title: Starbucks Profit Soars, but Forecast Is Cut
description: SEATTLE, Nov. 15 (Bloomberg News)  The Starbucks Corporation ( news/quote ), the specialty-coffee retailer, said fiscal fourth-quarter profit soared, but the company lowered its revenue and profit forecasts for next year, citing the economy.

title: Mark Rothko
description: Pace Wildenstein

title: China's Unwitting Organ Donors
description: To the Editor:

title: A Travesty of Justice
description: President Bush's plan to use secret military tribunals to try terrorists is a dangerous idea, made even worse by the fact that it is so superficially attractive. In his effort to defend America from terrorists, Mr. Bush is eroding the very values and principles he seeks to protect, including the rule of law.

title: Small Vote for Universal Care Is Seen as Carrying a Lot of Weight
description: It was the kind of Election Day enterprise that usually slips under the radar, a local nonbinding resolution about health insurance at a time when the nation is consumed by matters of war and terrorism. Most people expected a low-budget campaign and low-static vote with little teeth to it.

title: Did Ken Lay Understand What Was Happening at Enron?
description: WHAT a tangled web was weaved by Enron. Both investors and managers seem to have been misled.

title: 'The Triumph of Beatrice Mandelman (1912-1998)'
description: Gary Snyder

title: QANTAS AIRWAYS TO CUT UP TO 2,000 JOBS BY END OF YEAR
description: Blaming the slump in the international aviation market, Qantas Airways said yesterday that it would cut up to 2,000 jobs by the end of the year. Qantas, Australia's largest airline, also plans to stop all flights to New York as of Nov. 25 and to reduce flights to some other cities abroad. The airline has taken control of almost 90 percent of the domestic market after its rival, Ansett Australia, collapsed in September. But last year, Qantas earned almost 80 percent of its profit from international operations. ''The events of Sept. 11 have affected services far beyond the United States,'' said the chief executive, Geoff Dixon. Since Sept. 11, business from Japan and Britain has dropped by one-quarter and overall traffic levels have declined 10 to 20 percent, he said. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: With Smoke and Mirrors, Love of Sorts
description: The first act of ''Speaking in Tongues,'' a play by Andrew Bovell that opened at the Gramercy Theater last night, is clever, provocative, elliptically resonant and writerly. It is also complete enough in itself and distinct enough from the second act, which is merely clever (and not clever enough), that anyone who leaves at intermission should be satisfied.

title: Peres Calls Palestinian State Israel's 'Best Bet' for Peace
description: Echoing President Bush's call for a separate state of Palestine, the Israeli foreign minister, Shimon Peres, told the General Assembly today that there was ''broad agreement'' that the creation of an independent Palestinian state ''is the best bet.''

title: 'It's All Dust': A Family That Withstood Weeks of War Finally Leaves Kabul
description: A mule crossed the mountains from Afghanistan to the east on Sunday evening. Nadia, seven months pregnant, a schoolteacher who could not work under the rule of the Taliban, rode sidesaddle. Her husband, Dr. Mohammed Azim, walked alongside. Their 18-month-old daughter was in his arms. A saddlebag held their worldly possessions.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: American Express Bank Bombed
description: A bomb exploded outside an American Express bank branch at a shopping center in a northern Athens suburb, blowing out windows but causing no injuries. No one took responsibility for the attack, which came two days before the anniversary of a 1973 student revolt against the military junta that gave rise to the terrorist group November 17.

title: Taliban Under Heavy Attack In Their Last 2 Strongholds : Bombs Said to Kill Some Qaida Chiefs
description: WASHINGTON  U.S. air strikes killed several leaders of the Taliban militia and the Qaida militant network at two Afghan locations, the Pentagon said Thursday, and a top American officer said that the United States and its allies were "tightening the noose" on the followers of Osama bin Laden.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Gap Reports Third-Quarter Loss
description: Gap Inc. had a fiscal third-quarter loss, its first quarterly loss in more than a decade, as the clothing chain slashed prices to get rid of slow-selling fall clothing.

title: Environmentalists Concerned About State Plan for Borrowing
description: The Pataki administration is considering borrowing money to pay for some environmental programs that are usually financed through a special $150 million fund, stirring fears among environmentalists that the governor intends to raid the fund to help balance next year's budget.

title: Security Breach Disrupts Atlanta's Airport
description: More than 5,000 people were told to evacuate the William B. Hartsfield Atlanta International Airport around noon today after an unidentified man entered a secure area of the airport without being searched, airport and federal aviation officials said.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Mitsubishi's Profit Falls
description: The Mitsubishi Corporation, Japan's largest trading company, said its profit fell 45 percent, to 41.9 billion yen ($346 million), in the six months to Sept. 30, as losses on stockholdings offset higher sales of food and oil. However, Mitsubishi, which brokers commodities and other bulk goods, kept its full-year profit target at 80 billion yen ($661 million) because it expects to benefit from higher dividends from its affiliates and low interest rates, which cut its borrowing costs. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSTROW, BARNEY
description: OSTROW-Barney. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Barney Ostrow, beloved father of our devoted members Dr. Gary & Pamela Ostrow, grandfather of Briana, former student of our religious school, and Rebecca, our early childhood student. Deepest sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: In 2 Leaders' Words: Cordial Discord
description: Following are excerpts from a news conference by President Bush and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia today with students at Crawford High School, as transcribed by the Federal News Service Inc. Mr. Putin's remarks were interpreted by a translator.

title: Facing Criticism, the City Again Adds Firefighters to the Search
description: The number of city firefighters assigned to search for bodies at the World Trade Center site has been increased yet again, as the Giuliani administration moves to answer criticism that it was failing to prevent human remains from being disposed of, accidentally, along with debris.

title: Alliance Commander Near Kandahar Says Taliban's Leader Refused a Peace Offer
description: The American backed anti-Taliban commander, Hamid Karzai, said today that a formal peace offer he made to the Taliban leader Mullah Muhammad Omar, had been swiftly rebuffed as Kandahar, the only major city that has not fallen, remained in the tenuous hold of Taliban forces.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Warlord Rule Is Re-emerging In Some Towns
description: In a 10-minute span this afternoon, three different cars arrived here from towns ruled by three different Afghan warlords. The first car arrived from Jalalabad, where a local political leader named Mawlawi Yunis Khalis has declared himself ruler, rejecting the Northern Alliance and the Taliban's authority.

title: Black Employees, in Lawsuit, Accuse Cargill of Discrimination
description: A group of 25 black employees of Cargill Inc., the agricultural business that is one of the world's largest private companies, filed a federal lawsuit yesterday accusing the company of widespread racial discrimination.

title: A Possible Whydunit Turns Into a Whodunit
description: One enters the Jos Quintero Theater for ''The Suicide Bomber'' hoping to learn something that will help explain recent events and the cancerous enmity that now seems to dominate the world. One leaves having learned only that an intriguing premise does not guarantee an enlightening evening of theater.

title: Hoffa Claims Victory in Bid To Stay Head Of Teamsters
description: With about half the votes counted, James P. Hoffa claimed victory yesterday in his bid for re-election as Teamsters union president.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENFIELD, HELEN
description: GREENFIELD-Helen. American Friends of The Hebrew University mourn the passing of Helen Greenfield, beloved mother of Billy Crystal, a long standing contributor to American Friends and distinguished recipient of the 1999 Scopus Award. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Billy, Richard and Joel, their wives and Mrs. Greenfield's three grandchildren, Jonathan, Faithe and Jackie.

title: Admiring (Yes, Really) Rocks Along the Road
description: Here are a few things to do on a highway trip: Play 20 Questions, plug your kids into some sort of electronic anodyne, lose your mind.

title: When the Afghans Are Free of War
description: To the Editor:

title: British News Organizations Aided by a Cooperative Government and Afghan Fans
description: The Sunday Telegraph of London was the only news organization to report that Osama bin Laden had justified the Sept. 11 attacks in a recent video circulating among his supporters. Four days later, Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain cited that video as evidence of Mr. bin Laden's complicity.

title: Reviews of Current Releases
description: For all New York Times film reviews since 1996, go to the Film Archive .

title: When the Afghans Are Free of War
description: To the Editor:

title: Argentina's Tottering Economy Is Steadied a Bit by Agreement
description: President Fernando de la Ra's effort to avert a financial meltdown gained some ground Wednesday night when the governors of Argentina's three largest provinces signed an agreement that cuts public spending and introduces a large amount of scrip of questionable value into the economy.

title: Psion Gets a Painful Lesson in the Economies of Scale
description: LONDON  If everything had gone according to plan, right about now Psion PLC would be unveiling the product that would make it a household name across the world: a phone-cum-personal-organizer jointly developed with Motorola Inc.

title: 'The Worst of Gordon Pym Continued'
description: Printed Matter

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Nets Are Ready for Their Close-Up
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 15 — Jason Kidd understood the natural hierarchy when he came east this summer and settled across the river from Madison Square Garden — not that he liked where his Nets fell on the metropolitan area's food chain.

title: Steering the Driver To Preferred Pit Stops
description: IN-CAR information services like the OnStar system from General Motors are starting to duplicate some of the Web's most useful offerings: driving directions, stock quotes, customized news and weather reports. Now, some of the companies behind these services are adding advertising and ''mobile commerce'' to the mix.

title: Two Roles for Military: Supplying Guns and Butter
description: The Pentagon plans to continue airdropping packets of food into Afghanistan, military officials said this week, even though the United States plans to rebuild Afghan airbases and open roads that would allow much larger deliveries into needy areas.

title: China to Divert Waters, at People-Moving Cost
description: Construction will begin soon on a gigantic project to divert river waters from southern China to the north, where a growing scarcity of water is limiting development around cities like Beijing and Tianjin, officials said this week.

title: Evening Hours: A Splash of Red
Making Magic
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: A New Afghanistan
Corrections
description: A front-page article on Thursday about the rescue of eight Christian aid workers in Afghanistan, including two Americans, misstated the day they were picked up by American military helicopters and taken to Pakistan. In some copies yesterday an article about a news conference held by some of the workers repeated the error. And because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the reaction in Waco, Tex., hometown of the two Americans, also misstated the day. The pickup occurred before dawn on Thursday in Afghanistan (Wednesday afternoon, Eastern time), not on Wednesday.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Euro Zone: Inflation Slows
description: Inflation in the 12-country euro zone fell to 2.4 percent in October from 2.5 percent a month earlier, the European statistical office Eurostat said yesterday. Inflation across the 15-member Union fell to 2.2 percent from 2.4 percent during the same period. The highest inflation levels were recorded in the Netherlands at 5 percent and Portugal at 4.2 percent. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Schools to Allow Ramadan Prayer
description: Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy directed New York City schools yesterday to accommodate individual students who wish to pray for the Muslim holy month of Ramadan, but he barred schools from setting aside special areas for prayer that could violate the constitutional separation of church and state.

title: National Briefing | West: California: 1,100 Nurses Join Union
description: In a vote among more than 1,100 registered nurses, those at Long Beach Memorial Medical Center have chosen, 630 to 523, to join the California Nurses Association. The union said the organizing drive was the largest successful one among nurses at a single hospital in California in nearly two decades. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Aluminum Merger Deal Starting to Look Later Than Sooner
description: Merger talks between Alcoa, the world's largest aluminum company, and WMC Limited, a major miner of nickel and other minerals in Australia, have become knotted over a series of issues and may not produce a deal for some time, according to executives involved with the talks.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEITNER, SYLVIA. (TZIPPY)
description: LEITNER-Sylvia. (Tzippy). In 1940, I was blessed with a beautiful bride. Children and grandchildren made us thrive. In 1989 came the accident and you did not survive. Today, only precious memories remain, like an antidote for the loss and pain. With Love, Nat

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STAR, LEON D., M.D.
description: STAR-Leon D., M.D. In everlasting memory of a loving husband, father and grandfather on his birthday.

title: An Even Closer-Knit Belle Harbor Mourns Anew
description: ''Every funeral is bigger than the last,'' the gray-haired woman in the black jacket said to her neighbor on the packed sidewalk across the street from St. Francis de Sales Roman Catholic Church. ''It's scary.''

title: Wall St. Jobs Are Migrating To New Jersey After Attack
description: Many of the jobs lost in Lower Manhattan after the Sept. 11 attacks have migrated across the river to New Jersey, where employment suddenly spurted in October after falling for most of the year, a new survey confirmed yesterday.

title: BRISTOL-MYERS PLANS JOB CUTS; SELLS CLAIROL
description: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company is cutting about 1,000 jobs, including 350 in New Jersey, and may announce more reductions as part of a drive to cut costs and eliminate overlapping operations. The cuts were from functions like the corporate staff and global business that recently went through a ''redesign process,'' Peggy Ballman, a spokeswoman, said yesterday. Bristol-Myers, the fifth-largest drug maker, employed about 44,000 in its continuing operations as of Dec. 31, according to a regulatory filing. Bristol-Myers is focusing more on pharmaceuticals under Peter Dolan, who became chief executive in May. Separately, the Procter & Gamble Company completed its $4.95 billion purchase of the Clairol hair-care business from Bristol-Myers. Procter & Gamble, maker of Pantene and Head & Shoulders shampoos, said it would decide how many jobs to eliminate and which factories to close in the next 90 days as it combines operations. Clairol, based in Stamford, Conn., has 4,000 employees. The acquisition adds $1.6 billion in annual sales through brands like such as Nice 'n Easy and Miss Clairol hair color and Herbal Essences shampoos. (Bloomberg News)

title: Staying Safe on the Bus
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Post Editor Picks an Englishman for a Top Job in the Newsroom
description: The New York Post, which has undergone sweeping changes in its newsroom staff and style in the past year, announced yesterday that it would once again tap the editor of a foreign tabloid to take over a senior newsroom position.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KONECKY, LEWIS M.
description: KONECKY-Lewis M. On November 16, 2001. Beloved husband of Cyrena. Loving father of Dr. Priscilla Konecky (Tepper), Dr. Elizabeth Konecky (Kronfeld), & Dr. Margaret Konecky (Osher), sons-in-law Dr. Mark Tepper, Mr. Yaakov Kronfeld & Dr. Lawrence Osher, and proud grandfather of Jaron and Julia Tepper, and Matan Kronfeld. Services are at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st and Amsterdam Avenue, on Sunday, November 18, 2001, at 1:30 PM.

title: Usefulness of SAT Test Is Debated in California
description: The battle for the SAT's future in California and perhaps other parts of the nation was joined here today when the leading educator opposed to the influential college entrance exam debated its usefulness with the head of the company that oversees it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLYOM, EDNA (LAZAR)
description: SOLYOM-Edna (Lazar). Age 95, widow of the late Richard Solyom and the late Maurice Cashman, passed away on November 14, 2001. Devoted mother of Joan Cashman and the late Mary Faith Lang, grandmother of Richard and Georgiana Lang, great-grandmother of Melissa Lang & Caitlin and Sarah Lang. Mrs. Solyom was a partner and senior vice president of Stewart Stamping Corp., Yonkers, NY for over 35 years and president of Nike, Division of Toastmistress (New Jersey) for many years. She always had great interest in fancy stitchery and her lacemaking won many awards. Friends may call at the Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale Avenue, Scarsdale, NY on Saturday and Sunday from 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian burial will be held at Sacred Heart Church, Hartsdale, NY on Monday 11 AM. Entombment to follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Arrest In Brotherly Deal
description: The police arrested Shabir Shaik, the brother of the Defense Department's chief acquisitions officer, on charges of improperly obtaining classified documents that helped him win a lucrative defense contract. The chief acquisitions officer was also found to have had a conflict of interest in awarding the contract to his brother. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Al Qaeda Should Be Tried Before the World
description: On Tuesday President Bush signed an executive order allowing the government to try accused terrorists before military commissions rather than in federal court. No matter how tempting or expedient, trials by military commission will prove disastrous -- to the war against terrorism, to the Constitution and to the rule of law.

title: I.M.F. Stance on Terrorism and Lending
description: The International Monetary Fund said today that it would not make rooting out terrorist financing a condition for loans to developing nations, a position that drew criticism from a former State Department official.

title: Budget Gap Is Closing
description: After three days of bitter partisan debate, the General Assembly today approved a $200 million compromise plan to reduce a projected $300 million state budget deficit.

title: Editorial Observer; Abraham Lincoln Speaks to Us of Slavery -- and Freedom -- in 2001
description: The first years of the 21st century will be remembered as a high point in the scholarship of slavery, a time when publishers rained down books on the subject as never before. The causes of this burst of interest have yet to become clear. It may be that Americans needed a century and a half's worth of distance from slavery before they could speak and think about the issue without rage and recrimination.

title: Bogot Journal; Corruption's Her Story; Colombia Doesn't Like It
description: Her book, a stinging indictment of drug-tainted political corruption in Colombia, was a sensation this year in France, where she became known as Madame Colombia. The magazine Nouvel Observateur called Ingrid Betancourt the warrior of the Andes while the newspaper Libration described her as a heroine at war with cocaine kingpins.

title: Abroad at Home; Waiting For America
description: In the bitterness and violence of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict today, can there be any hope of peace? Two longtime negotiators, Yasir Abed Rabbo of the Palestinian Authority and Yossi Beilin, former justice minister of Israel, insist that there can. But they both say it will require U.S. intervention.

title: H.M.O.'s Open the Gate
description: To the Editor:

title: New Game, New Rules
description: There is nothing particularly remarkable about Amway's newest store, which opened six weeks ago in the lobby of a cookie-cutter apartment block in this southern Chinese city. Except that it exists at all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JELLIFFE, GEORGE C.
description: JELLIFFE-George C. Of Manchester-By-the-Sea, MA., died in his sleep November 14th in the Oakwood Retirement Home. He was 93. Born in Jersey City, N.J., Mr. Jelliffe attended Stevens Prep and graduated from Stevens Institute of Technology with an advanced degree in Mechanical Engineering. He was a member of the U.S. Cavalry and volunteered for the Navy during World War II, where he was a member of the U.S. Calvary and volunteered for the Navy during World War II, where he was a Lietenant Commander aboard the U.S.S. Anderson, helping to rescue survivors of the South Pacific death marches. After the war, Mr. Jelliffe was an engineer for United Technologies and was elected President of the Stevens Alumni Association and member of its Board of Directors. Mr. Jelliffe also served as a steward in the Tenafly, N.J. Presbyterian Church and a member of the Tenafly Zoning Board of Appeals. He was a lifelong tennis player and an accomplished musician, both building and playing the tub-afone. He also designed and built squirrel-proof birdfeeders from recycled material and donated them to bird sancutaries. Mr. Jelliffe was married for 63 years to the late Abbie English Jelliffe, whom he adored. He was brother to the late Anna Jelliffe Ogdin of Narberth, PA, and Margaret Jelliffe of Jersey City, loving and doting father to Andrew Clark Jelliffe of Morrison, CO and Nancy Jelliffe Bruette of Marblehead, MA. He is also survived by four grandchildren, Melissa J. Rees of Littleton, CO, Philip A. Jelliffe of St. Helen, Oregon, David C. Bruettof South Boston, MA, Abbie E. Bruett of Marblehead, MA, and one greatgrandchild, Logan C. Jelliffe. Mr. Jelliffe always had a kind word, never let his family down and left everyone happier for seeing him. For further information contact the Murphy Funeral Home, 85 Federal Street, Salem, Mass. His funeral and burial will be private in Lebanon, NJ. In Lieu of flowers, please send donations to Stevens Institute of Technology, Castle Poin-on-Hudson, Hoboken, New Jersey 07030.

title: Cells That Save Lives Are a Mother's Legacy
description: Deborah Lacks closed her eyes as a young cancer researcher opened the door of his floor-to-ceiling freezer. She stood clutching the ragged dictionary she uses to look up words like ''DNA,'' ''cell'' and ''immortality.'' When the icy breeze hit her face, she opened her eyes slowly, and stared into a freezer filled with tiny vials of red liquid. ''O God,'' she gasped, ''I can't believe all this is my mother.''

title: A Visit to Ground Zero
description: Tom Ridge, the director of homeland security, became the latest official yesterday to visit ground zero with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani in the months since the terrorist attack.

title: Roberta Pryor, 77, Literary Agent for 'Jaws'
description: Roberta Pryor, a literary agent who acquired the best-selling author Peter Benchley as a client when he was 16 and was still his agent two decades later, when he became famous as the author of ''Jaws,'' died on Monday in a hospital in Brooklyn. She was 77 and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Revisiting the Electoral College
description: Revisiting the Electoral College

title: Webb Leads Sorenstam And Doolan by 4 Shots
description: The best of the Ladies Professional Golf Association has been introduced to the challenge of Trump International Golf Club, and the confrontation has taken its toll.

title: Revisiting the Electoral College
description: To the Editor:

title: After 15 Years, Executive's Short Goodbye
description: Linda J. Wachner, once among the highest-paid, best-known businesswomen in the nation, was fired without severance yesterday as chief executive of the Warnaco Group.

title: Correspondent; In a State of Denial
description: California cynics offer a variety of ulterior motives for Gov. Gray Davis's announcement early this month, on flimsy evidence, that terrorists might have put the state's bridges on a target list. ''Giuliani envy'' is one explanation I heard during a few days roaming the state where I grew up; a hapless-seeming Democrat facing re-election might relish the chance to step forward in a crisis, especially with a backdrop as majestic as the Golden Gate. Or perhaps it was just political inoculation. Our leaders may not know what to do about the vague fears that beset us, but next time they sure intend to say ''We told you so.''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: New Steel Terms
description: With shares that it planned to use as currency in a $5.43 billion plan to create the largest steel maker now worth considerably less, Usinor S.A. is facing pressure from the companies it hopes to acquire to renegotiate the deal. Usinor is talking to Aceralia Corporacin Siderrgica S.A. and Arbed S.A., the two companies with which it hopes to merge, about revising the terms, the company said yesterday. Usinor said two weeks ago that it would cut steel production in the second half of the year as demand from carmakers and other customers falters. Its shares are down 13 percent since the deal was announced in February. Under the terms of the agreement, Arbed investors would get 10 new shares in the combined company for each share they currently own. Aceralia shareholders would get eight new shares for every seven they own. Usinor would assume about 3 billion euros ($2.65 billion) in debt. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Labor: Gunman Kills Teamster Leader
description: Noel Coln Gonzlez, a Teamster leader in San Juan, P.R., was shot to death by a union organizer he had just fired, the police said. Mr. Coln, 51, was the president of a Teamster local representing 3,900 workers, a candidate for international vice president of the union and the brother of Carlitos Coln, a well-known Puerto Rican independence advocate. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: A Group Made Up Of Other Bands' Stars
description: Oysterhead

title: 3 Asian Exporting Countries Show More Signs of Trouble
description: The difficulties that Asia faces in pulling out of an accelerating economic slump were thrown in stark relief by developments in three of its most important economies today.

title: Wariness On Paying Extra Costs
description: Some airline executives expressed dismay yesterday at the financing provisions in a Congressional plan for improving aviation security, saying that the already suffering carriers might be forced to absorb the cost.

title: Airport Workers See Bill as Ticket to a Better Life
description: While airport security companies are in an uproar about the Congressional bill that would put them out of business, many of the 28,000 workers in the industry think the bill is not a bad idea at all -- if it means they can get rehired as better-compensated federal employees.

title: Reward Offered to Help Find A Girl Missing in Bridgeport
description: This city offered a $10,000 reward today for information on a 10-year-old girl who disappeared more than a week ago from her schoolyard with a man in a brown van.

title: Rebels Pause for Ramadan, but Vow Swift Attack on Kunduz
description: Northern Alliance fighters who have encircled the besieged city of Kunduz paused briefly today to celebrate the start of the Muslim holy month of Ramadan, but their commanders said they would be moving ahead -- perhaps within 24 hours -- to attack the city where they have as many as 20,000 Taliban fighters surrounded.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCNALLY, ANDREW, III
description: McNALLY-Andrew, III, 92. Of Chicago, IL. Husband of the late Margaret Clark (nee MacMillin); father of Betsy Ravenel, Sandy (Jeanine), Teddy (Peggy); grandfather of William, Eleanor, Drew, Carrie, Ward, Heather, Gray; five great - grandchildren. Memorial service at 11 AM, Monday, November 19th, St. Chrysostom's Episcopal Church, 1424 North Dearborn Parkway, Chicago, IL 60610. Memorials may be made to the Antique Boat Museum, 750 Mary Street, Clayton, NY 13624.

title: Chirac to Visit Algeria in North Africa Tour
description: President Jacques Chirac will make the first visit to Algeria by a French head of state in 12 years as part of a North African tour next month that will also take him to Tunisia and Morocco, his spokeswoman said today.

title: Judge Rules That Twins Must Play Next Season
description: The first legal challenge to Major League Baseball's plan to eliminate two teams brought the first roadblock to that plan yesterday.

title: Taliban Leader Said to Be Yielding Grip on Stronghold to 2 Once-Powerful Supporters
description: The Taliban leader, Mullah Muhammad Omar, a main target of the American war in Afghanistan, has decided to cede control of his political stronghold in Kandahar to two commanders from the Pashtun ethnic group, the Afghan Islamic Press reported tonight.

title: Inquiry Into Anthrax 'Cures'
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has accused three publicly traded companies of fraudulently promoting products they said would kill anthrax spores and warn people of biological and chemical attacks.

title: 'Holy War, Inc.'
description: When you go looking for Osama bin Laden, you don't find him: he finds you. It was March 1997 when the phone rang.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: 'Bloody Sunday' Ruling
description: London's High Court ruled that 36 British soldiers did not have to go to Londonderry to testify in the inquiry into the 1972 ''Bloody Sunday'' clash in which troops killed 14 unarmed protesters. The court said the soldiers' fears that their lives could be in danger was reasonable. The decision overturned the investigating panel's decision that the soldiers faced no security risk and must return to the province as witnesses. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Suspect in Subway Attack Has a History of Violence
description: There was the time in 1987 that he fired a shotgun at the tracks of the No. 7 train in Midtown. Afterward, doctors said he had schizophrenia. Then there was the time last year, when he groped a passenger on a subway car. He ended up in a mental hospital again. It seemed to have become a sad pattern of Jackson Roman's life: brushes with the law, followed by short hospitalizations to treat his debilitating mental illness.

title: Timely Turnaround by the Red Cross
description: The fair and efficient distribution of more than $1.3 billion in private charity collected since Sept. 11 has turned out to be more complicated and controversial than anyone imagined. Victims have complained about red tape, Congress about mismanagement and the charities about each other. It was thus an enormous relief to everyone this week when the Red Cross -- the biggest recipient of charitable dollars and the cause of much of the criticism -- announced a dramatic change in policy. This unusual act of institutional humility will help bring coherence to an overall relief effort that has been plagued by poor coordination.

title: Knight Enjoys the Old West
description: The university president who hired him 30 years ago at Indiana was here, as was the retired Army general who treated him like a son for 40 years. They journeyed to West Texas, along with dozens of friends and former players from Bloomington, Ind., and from West Point, to celebrate the beginning of what Bob Knight said would be the end of a coaching career -- an accomplished one that has come to be abhorred by some.

title: In 2 Abandoned Kabul Houses, Some Hints of Al Qaeda Presence
description: A flight-simulator computer program, a list of flight schools in the United States and documents describing chemical, biological and nuclear warfare and referring to the Qaeda organization were found here today in two houses littered with paper.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SARLI, R. STEPHEN
description: SARLI-R. Stephen, 49. Of Paradise Valley, AZ, passed away on Nov. 13, 2001. He was born in Kansas City, MO. Steve was CEO President of Emerald Coast Financial and also the managing member of Lighthouse Financial Group, LLC. Steve has been a prominent member of the Scottsdale and Paradise Valley Community for over 15 years. He was an integral part of and supported many local charities including Scottsdale Boys & Girls Club, ASU Presidents Club and he was passionately involved in numerous chartitable non-profit organizations. Beloved husband, father, son and friend. He will best be remembered as a loving, strong and generous person. He is survived by his wife, Susan; children, Stevie and Sarah. Also parents, Ralph and Mary Helen Sarli; sister, Melinda Wehrle; niece, Lisa; all of Mission Hills, KS. Memorial Service will be held on Sat., Nov. 17, 2001, at 11AM at Ascension Lutheran Church, 7100 N. Mockingbird Lane, Paradise Valley, AZ 85253. Memorial contributions may be made to the Ascension Lutheran Church Foundation, c/o the church. For information contact Messinger Indian School Mortuary 480-945-9521.

title: Exploring the Flaws in the Notion of the 'Root Causes' of Terror
description: Since Sept. 11, few phrases have become as familiar as ''root causes.'' Forthright condemnations of the attacks have often been accompanied by assertions that, ultimately, the ''root causes'' of terror must also be addressed. And the implication is that if those causes are not eliminated, terrorism can be expected to continue.

title: 3.9% OF MERRILL LYNCH WORK FORCE ACCEPTS BUYOUTS
description: Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that more than 2,600 employees, or 3.9 percent of its work force, took the buyouts offered as part of the efforts of Stanley O'Neal, its president, to trim expenses and improve profitability at the company. Merrill, with 65,900 employees as of Sept. 30, earned $6,403 per employee in the third quarter, making it the least profitable of the five biggest Wall Street firms. This year Merrill is the top-ranked arranger of United States bond sales, the top seller of convertible bonds, the No. 2 underwriter of global stock sales and the No. 2 mergers adviser, according to Bloomberg data. Merrill will not say how many employees it hopes to cut. Most employees had until Nov. 9 to decide whether to accept the buyout offer. Departures were subject to approval by managers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHN, SAMUEL
description: COHN-Samuel. Of Newton, MA. Formerly of New York City, died peacefully at home November 14, 2001, 18 days short of his 104 birthday. Devoted husband of the late Dora (Goldman), father of Geraldine Morse of Newton and Marilyn Schwartz of Boston. Grandfather of Ruth Morse Collini of Cambridge, England, Julia Morse of Denver, Steven Schwartz and his wife Joy (Harris) of Los Angeles, Jeffrey Schwartz of Watertown and the late William Schwartz. Great grandfather of William, Jonah, Rebecca and Zachary Schwartz. Graveside service leaving from ''The Riverside'', 76th Street & Amsterdam Avenue on Sunday, November 18 at 10AM. Donations in his memory may be made to Dorot, 171 West 85th Street, New York, NY 10024.

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article on Thursday about the rescue of eight Christian aid workers in Afghanistan, including two Americans, misstated the day they were picked up by American military helicopters and taken to Pakistan. In some copies yesterday an article about a news conference held by some of the workers repeated the error. And because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the reaction in Waco, Tex., hometown of the two Americans, also misstated the day. The pickup occurred before dawn on Thursday in Afghanistan (Wednesday afternoon, Eastern time), not on Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEIANT, MONROE ALDEN
description: WEIANT-Monroe Alden, 97. Of Red Bank, formerly of Westfield and Metuchen, NJ. Mr. Weiant's wife Lois, of 66 years, predeceased him in 1997. He is survived by two sons, Monroe Alden Weiant, Jr. of Trumbull, CT and William Weiant of Red Bank, NJ., four grandchildren, Bruce Weiant, Susan Smith, Clarissa Weiant Holleman and Pamela Weiant and four great grandchildren. No Visitation. Funeral services are private. The family requests that memorial donations be made in his memory to the Seeing Eye, PO Box 375, Morristown, N.J. 07963-0375. For information John E. Day Funeral Home, Red Bank, N.J., 1-888-747-0332.

title: 'Confessions of Zeno' As a Musical Excerpt
description: Duke Quartet

title: The Limn Company Stretches and Steps Into the Jazz Age
