description: ''Cross Roads,'' choreographed by Donald McKayle, and ''If Winter,'' by Billy Siegenfeld, were the two lively and somewhat surprising new works presented by the Limn Dance Company on Thursday night at the Joyce Theater.

title: A Nation Challenged
description: Closing In

title: Foundation Celebrates Singers, Who in Turn Celebrate With Song
description: One distinguishing feature of the 26th Richard Tucker Music Foundation Gala at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday night was that only one of the singers had ever actually won a Richard Tucker Award. Deborah Voigt, who sang selections from ''Tosca,'' got it in 1992. Even this year's winner, Christine Goerke, was absent, because of a previous commitment, and was represented only by a video in which she talked about the award but didn't sing.

title: Rates on Treasuries Climb Back to Pre-Sept. 11 Levels
description: Interest rates on Treasury securities shot sharply higher this week, in one of their biggest weekly moves in recent history.

title: Moving Through Moods, Swiftly
description: Winning exposure in jazz is hard. So Jazz at Lincoln Center's continuous encouragement of younger players in education and performance is a good idea against the odds.

title: Some Hard Decisions Lie Ahead
description: As the Knicks took the floor for the start of the second half tonight, Allan Houston and Mark Jackson took seats on the bench, with the newcomers Shandon Anderson and Howard Eisley starting in their place.

title: After Knockout, Can Lewis Rise Up Against Rahman?
description: As prefight hyperbole goes, no mystery needs unearthing, no catch slogan will oversell the promotion. Simply, two questions need answering: Is Lennox Lewis done? And if so, is Hasim Rahman for real?

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Saudi Arabia: Punishment From God?
description: When even sparse rains fail to show up by late October, King Fahd habitually asks his subjects to pray for it. This year's appeal evidently hasn't worked, and Saudi newspapers quoted Sheik Omar bin Mohammed al-Sabeel, a preacher at the Grand Mosque in Mecca as saying, ''What the nation is experiencing today of aridness and drought is due to disobeying the will of God and excessive sins, taboos and crimes.'' He suggested that worshipers repent as they began fasting for the holy month of Ramadan. Neil MacFarquhar (NYT)

title: New Udalls Rising in West Could Clash for Congress
description: For generations, the Udall name has permeated Western politics, to the point that the family was compared to the Kennedys on the East Coast. Whether the comparison is valid hardly matters. But two more Udalls are emerging to keep the debate going.

title: Reformist Premier Finds Japan Difficult to Change
description: When Jun ichiro Koizumi overturned conventional wisdom to win the prime minister's job in April, he did so by bowling Japan over with his newness: from his reformist policies to his blunt language to his hip hairstyle, everything seemed to suggest a break with the past.

title: Senators Urge Bush Not to Hamper Israel
description: In a letter to President Bush today, 89 senators urged him not to restrain Israel from retaliating fully against Palestinian violence and to express his solidarity publicly with Israel soon.

title: Death Toll Climbs to 3 After Fire In Brooklyn
description: Two more boys, ages 6 and 9, died yesterday from a Brooklyn apartment fire that had claimed the life of their foster brother and had apparently started when the boys were playing with matches, the police said.

title: From Airy Beatles Hits To a Prayer for the Dead
description: The principal attraction presented by the Purchase Dance Corps in a concert to be repeated this weekend is ''The Long and Winding Road'' by Stanton Welch, the Australian choreographer who created ''Clear'' for American Ballet Theater's recent engagement at City Center. Mr. Welch choreographed ''Road'' for the Purchase Dance Corps, made up of students from the Conservatory of Dance at Purchase College of the State University of New York, and six members of the ABT Studio Company, established by Ballet Theater to develop promising dancers.

title: LEADER DESCRIBED AS READY TO FLEE TALIBAN'S BASTION
description: The Taliban's top leader, Mullah Muhammad Omar, was reported today to be ready to abandon his stronghold of Kandahar, as American commandos in southern Afghanistan were engaging in their most intensive ground combat to date.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEXNER, BELLA
description: WEXNER - Bella. Schottenstein Chabad House mourns the passing of Bella Wexner, a visionary both in the business world and in philanthropic causes. She was an extremely kind and gracious lady who was passionate about helping others. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire Wexner family. Mr. Jay Schottenstein, Chairman of the Board, Mr. Mike Schiff, President, Rabbi Areyah Kaltmann, Executive Director

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: New Ethical Standards Set for Museums
description: Concerned about public perceptions that museums and other nonprofit organizations are not operating under the highest ethical standards in their relations with the businesses on which they increasingly rely, the American Association of Museums issued a set of guidelines today and asked its members to follow them.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Revisiting the Electoral College
description: To the Editor:

title: Revisiting the Electoral College
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOWDELL, NORMA
description: DOWDELL-Norma. Beloved wife of John. Devoted aunt and grand aunt. Services Sunday, 12 noon, ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SKLOVER, RICHARD TUCK
description: SKLOVER-Richard Tuck. November 15, 2001. Deeply loved husband of Maxine. Worshipped father of Leesa & Andy. Adoring father-inlaw of Michael & Lauren. Beloved Papa to Emma & Marley. The kindest, most contented man anyone ever knew. He wanted to be or envied no one else. A gentleman, intelligent, soft and fulfilled of a too short good life. He will always be in our hearts. Rest in Peace. We love you so. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street Sunday, November 18, from 7-9 PM, with a service to follow on Monday, 11:30 A.M. at Frank E. Campbell. Contributions in his memory may be made to the American Heart Association Research Division.

title: 30,000 Feet Above the Earth, and Unhappy
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Third Airport For Paris
description: The government has announced a plan to build a third Paris airport in Chaulnes, in the Somme Valley about 80 miles north of the capital. The issue has caused a serious rift in the governing Socialist-led coalition because many Green Party members believe a new airport is unnecessary, particularly in light of the current decline in air travel. Some war veterans' groups are concerned that the airport may force the relocation of thousands of World War I graves. Suzanne Daley (NYT)

title: 30,000 Feet Above the Earth, and Unhappy
description: To the Editor:

title: Near Unity At the U.N. On Opposing Terrorism
description: The annual round of speeches in the General Assembly, delayed and dominated this year by the attacks of Sept. 11, drew to a close today with almost every nation joining to condemn terrorism.

title: National Briefing | Labor: Hoffa's Rival Concedes
description: Tom Leedham, a Teamster leader from Oregon, conceded defeat in his race against the union's president, James P. Hoffa, who won re-election with about 65 percent of the vote. ''Outspent 10 to 1 by an incumbent with a famous name, we have lost,'' said Mr. Leedham, left, maintaining that he had helped make democracy a reality in the union. At a news conference, Mr. Hoffa said his victory was ''a mandate for unity.'' Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Dusting Off the Search Engine
description: In 1913, The New York Times published the first quarterly issue of The Times Index, a painstakingly assembled and cross-referenced guide to virtually every article, name and item that had appeared in the newspaper in the previous three months. The index has long been superseded by computerized databases. As The Times celebrates its 150th anniversary this year, the index is an artifact known mostly to librarians who dust the scores of volumes that still survive on shelves across America.

title: F.B.I. Chief Says Failed Sept. 11 Hijackers May Remain at Large
description: Confirming that a Yemeni fugitive may have planned to be among the Sept. 11 hijackers, Director Robert S. Mueller III of the F.B.I. said today that there might be others still alive who intended to commandeer airplanes that day and join in the suicide attacks in New York and Washington.

title: Corrections
description: A listing and a picture caption in the Classical Music Guide in Weekend yesterday misstated the day for a recital at Carnegie Hall by the soprano Rene Fleming and the pianist Jean-Ives Thibaudet. It is tonight at 7:30; it was not last night.

title: Neither Side Blinks as Ideological Rift Stalls Progress on Stimulus Package
description: Unemployment is surging. Industrial production is tumbling. Business and consumer confidence are faltering. And for the last two months Democrats and Republicans in Congress have been deadlocked over what to do about it, their differing views so deeply held as to transcend partisanship or even ideology and enter the realm of religion.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the struggle in the New Jersey Assembly over the choice of a speaker misspelled the surname of a spokeswoman for Governor-elect James E. McGreevey, who said he believed the lawmakers need to reach a consensus. The same error occurred on Thursday in an article about a proposed deal for a sports arena in Newark. The spokeswoman is Jo Astrid Glading, not Gladding.

title: Devils Extend Stevens's Deal
description: Scott Stevens, who has been the captain of the Devils for the last 10 years, signed a three-year contract extension yesterday that guarantees he will finish his career in New Jersey, something he always wanted to do.

title: Effervescing From Song To Song
description: When Christine Ebersole sashays onto the stage at Arci's Place, the atmosphere begins to fizz as if the cork from a giant Champagne bottle had been popped, and the whole room levitates in the sweet, bubbly mist of her comic energy.

title: Political Violence Strikes Zimbabwe's Second Largest City
description: Violence swept across Bulawayo, Zimbabwe's second largest city, today as supporters of President Robert Mugabe stoned and burned the headquarters of the opposition party to protest the killing of a colleague who the government said was strangled by members of the opposition.

title: McCall Criticizes Cuomo For a 'Divisive' Comment
description: Andrew M. Cuomo said earlier this month that the campaign for governor of his rival, H. Carl McCall, is part of a ''racial contract'' between blacks and Hispanics that should not prevail. The campaign of Mr. McCall, who is black, called the comment ''divisive.''

title: Alors! How German Women Defeated the French in Paris
description: The most remarkable come-from-behind victory in world championship history occurred two weeks ago in Paris. With 16 deals remaining in the final of the Venice Cup for women's teams, Germany trailed France by 47 imps. French supporters in the Vugraph theater were looking for opportunities to cheer their heroines, but found none.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAUSS, EDGAR MARCEL
description: STRAUSS-Edgar Marcel. Beloved husband of Bernice. Devoted father of Michael Strauss, Terry Glick, Ellen Strauss and Kenneth Levinsohn. Loving grandfather of Laurel. Stepbrother of Martin and Rudolph Appel. Services Sunday 9:30AM at ''Wien & Wien'', 402 Park St., Hackensack, New Jersey. Memorial donations in Edgar's memory can be made to the Closter Public Library, 280 High Street, Closter, New Jersey 07624.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Investor Law Revoked
description: The Czech Parliament has revoked a measure that would have required privatization investors to make buyout offers to minority shareholders. In an unprecedented move, Parliament convened in a special session Wednesday night to revoke the passage in a bill it had approved only two weeks earlier. Electric, telecommunications and gas utilities, and the petrochemical industry are scheduled for privatization. Some investors said obligatory buyout offers would have eliminated the few remaining active shares from the moribund Prague Stock Exchange. Other investors said it was a blow to foreign equity investment. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDERS, BYRON REGINALD
description: SANDERS-Byron Reginald. Died on November 12, 2001. He was deeply cherished by his companion, Renee Fisherman, and her daughters and sons-inlaw, Jennifer and Michael Ruff and Jean Bass and Josh Konecky. Beloved uncle of Betsy & Manny Canari. He will be deeply missed by those whose lives he profoundly touched. A memorial service will be planned in New York City at a later date.

title: Hatten Set to Fill Cook's Role as St. John's Point Guard
description: Marcus Hatten realized what he was getting into when he chose to attend St. John's in April. He knew that Omar Cook was likely to enter the N.B.A. draft, creating a void at point guard. Hatten begins filling that role tonight when St. John's opens its basketball season against Stony Brook at Alumni Hall, but he warns fans not to expect him to be like Cook.

title: Price Haggling Is Intense Among Insurers This Year
description: At marble-topped bistro tables and velveteen couches in the sprawling lobby of the Sheraton Hotel here in early November, the dark suits of the insurance industry were talking price. Their murmured conversations rose like the hum of an ancient bazaar.

title: Measure Sets Liability Caps For New York And Landlord
description: The aviation security compromise bill approved today by Congress limits the liability of certain entities that might be sued for damages arising from the terrorist attacks.

title: Waldman Leaves WFAN
description: Suzyn Waldman resigned from WFAN Radio yesterday after 14 years at the station. She had been a co-host of the 10 a.m. to 1 p.m. program with Jody McDonald. She had less than a year to go on her contract.

title: World Business Briefing
description: MIDDLE EAST

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: University Appeals Judgment
description: Oregon Health Sciences University has appealed a $500,000 award that a federal jury in Portland ordered it to pay Dr. John M. Rabkin. Dr. Rabkin was demoted from his post as the university's liver-transplant director in April, after he maintained that a colleague was endangering patients. With that demotion, the jury found on Nov. 5, the hospital violated a whistle-blower protection law. Dr. Rabkin also seeks reinstatement, a request that awaits a decision by the federal judge in the case, Owen M. Panner. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Perseverance, Not Vindictiveness, In a Family Bereaved by Terrorism
description: At the heart of Dorothy Vauk's grief over the last-born of her nine children is a question that has haunted the nation since Sept. 11: How can someone ever manage to hate strangers?

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, a photograph of Gustav Klimt's ''Dancer'' in Weekend yesterday, with an art review of ''New Worlds,'' the inaugural exhibition at the Neue Galerie New York, was reproduced in mirror image. The subject looks to the left, not the right.

title: Glaxo Sues Endo Over Generic Drug
description: Endo Pharmaceuticals Holdings Inc. said today that GlaxoSmithKline P.L.C. filed a suit seeking to block Endo's plan to sell a generic form of the anti-depression drug Paxil, which had $2.4 billion in sales for Glaxo last year.

title: Disputed Phone Licenses Transferred to Big Carriers
description: The Federal Communications Commission reached a deal yesterday to transfer ownership of $16 billion worth of disputed mobile phone licenses to some of the nation's biggest wireless carriers, while providing a windfall for the bankrupt NextWave Telecom.

title: St. John the Divine Chooses A Dean From Connecticut
description: The Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine has reached into a suburban parish for its next dean, a low-profile, fiscally astute churchman who will take over one of the nation's most socially conscious pulpits at a time of war.

title: 30,000 Feet Above the Earth, and Unhappy
description: To the Editor:

title: STARBUCKS SHARES FALL AFTER SALES FORECAST IS LOWERED
description: Shares of the Starbucks Corporation dropped after the company, the largest specialty-coffee retailer in the United States, lowered its annual revenue and profit estimates and reported slower sales to grocery stores and airlines. The shares fell $1.67, to $17.50. They had fallen 13 percent this year. Starbucks cut its fiscal 2002 sales-growth forecast to 20 percent and said earnings would be 54 cents to 55 cents a share, including a 2-cent gain related to the share sale by Starbucks Coffee Japan Ltd. last month.

title: The Taliban Retreat
description: With reports that the Taliban's supreme leader, Mullah Muhammad Omar, is preparing to surrender his remaining stronghold of Kandahar and retreat to the mountains, the Taliban's grip over Afghanistan appears nearly at an end. America's strategy of relentless bombing and logistical support for local opposition groups has proved devastatingly effective. While continued guerrilla warfare in the rugged countryside is a real possibility, the Taliban's national hold on power has been broken faster than anyone expected.

title: Revisiting the Electoral College
description: To the Editor:

title: Champions of the Elk Plan for Its Comeback; Group Wants to Establish Catskill Herd
description: In his red pickup truck, Dave Messics navigated the dark, bumpy road in a remote part of the Allegheny Mountains in Pennsylvania to a hillside shrouded in mist. Before cutting the engine, he cautioned his out-of-town guests that there might not be anything to see at daybreak.

title: A 'Staining Failure' On the Holocaust
description: To the Editor:

title: SUSPICIOUS LETTER TO A 2ND SENATOR
description: Investigators searching through unopened mail sent to Capitol Hill discovered another letter today that contained anthrax. The letter was addressed to Senator Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

title: U.S. Now Faces Big Task to Fill Air-Safety Jobs
description: Federal officials began struggling today with the immense challenge of hiring and training 28,000 new federal employees to screen passengers and baggage at all airports within 12 months.

title: The Warlord, in Charge Again, Thanks the West but Wants It Gone
description: It seems as if things are returning to normal in Herat, especially if you are Ismail Khan, a legendary and highly independent warlord here, whose forces chased away the Taliban.

title: Michigan Officers Fear Pressure of U.S. Plan
description: Daniel Saab is dreading the recently announced national canvass of 5,000 young men from the Middle East in this country on temporary visas. American-born, Mr. Saab is not worried that his name is on the list. He is afraid he will have to ask the hard questions.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: I.R.S. Makes An Exception On Terror Aid
description: The Internal Revenue Service said yesterday that it would allow charities responding to the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks to distribute money and benefits without first proving that families are in financial need.

title: Australia for $99 a Day
description: Australia for $99 a day: that's the price for three 14-day itineraries in eastern Australia being sold by Inta-Aussie. Each package costs $1,386 a person, based on double occupancy, and includes round-trip air fare from Los Angeles on Air New Zealand, 12 nights in standard-class hotels and rail or air connections in Australia. Depending on the package chosen, the stay is divided among Sydney and Brisbane or those two cities and a Gold Coast resort. Information: (800) 531-9222 or www.inta-aussie.com .

title: Sports of The Times; The Hype Is Legit This Time
description: THEY don't like each other. That's a boxing promoter's oldest hype. The fighters go along with it, staring or snarling for the cameras. But sometimes it's real. And when Hasim Rahman defends two-thirds of the world heavyweight title tonight in his rematch with Lennox Lewis, that dislike will be more grudge than fudge.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Sometimes if I go to a household and they're all Americans, I'll cover my name, I don't want them to think of me as Arab, I want them to think of me as police.''

title: I.R.S. Breaking Charity Logjam
description: Breaking a logjam, the Internal Revenue Service has decided to allow charities responding to the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks to hand out money and benefits without first proving that families are in financial need.

title: Pakistanis Unperturbed By U.S. Raid On Residence
description: Dr. Irshad Shaikh, this city's health commissioner, who is from Pakistan, says he loves America. He says he understands that the Federal Bureau of Investigation was just doing its job when its agents broke down his door on Tuesday and entered his house with guns drawn, followed by members of a hazardous materials team in moon suits and gas masks.

title: Revisiting the Electoral College
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, LEONARD V. SR.
description: MURPHY-Leonard V. Sr. On Nov. 15, 2001. Beloved husband of Catherine (nee Johnson). Devoted father of Leonard Jr, Regina Murphy Pfeifer, Katherine Murphy, Gregory W., and Christopher. Dear brother of Eleanor M. Blair. Also survived by nine loving grandchildren and four great grandchildren. Family will receive friends and relatives at the Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, 149-20 Northern Blvd, Flushing, NY. Visiting: Saturday and Sunday 2:00-5:00 and 7:00-10:00PM. Funeral Mass Monday 10:15AM St. Andrew Avellino Roman Catholic Church. Interment: Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery.

title: Hewlett Son Goes to S.E.C. In Fight Against Compaq Deal
description: Walter Hewlett, the son of the co-founder of the Hewlett-Packard Company, has made a regulatory filing that will permit him to lobby shareholders to fight the planned acquisition of the Compaq Computer Corporation.

title: New Chief Inherits a Bausch & Lomb That Is Listing Badly
description: The puns keep popping up when analysts talk about Bausch & Lomb. The venerable eye care company has lost its focus. It must see its present problems clearly and sharpen its vision of the future.

title: Mexico Seen Trying to Halt Oil Price War
description: Mexico, a nation with divided sympathies about how much oil should cost, is setting out on a round of shuttle diplomacy that analysts here said seemed intended to head off an oil price war.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Los Angeles Bond Referendum
description: The Los Angeles City Council is placing a public-safety bond issue worth $600 million on the March 2002 ballot. If approved, the bonds will pay for the construction of a downtown emergency response center, four new police stations, a jail, two bomb squad facilities, a traffic bureau and renovations on existing stations. Los Angeles voters approved a $378 million issue for firehouses and animal shelters in 2000 but, amid an investigation into police misconduct, narrowly rejected a $744 million proposal for police stations in 1999. Greg Winter (NYT)

title: Ex-Firefighter's Quiet Plea Ends Conflict Over Staffing
description: It started with anger over a policy change at ground zero and culminated in an ugly protest with punches and barricades thrown. Yesterday, the sad story of the Fire Department at war with the mayor who loves it appeared to come to an end.

title: Mitzi Myers, 62, Writer, Editor And Scholar of Children's Books
description: Mitzi Myers, an internationally recognized authority on children's literature and a longtime lecturer at the University of California at Los Angeles, died on Nov. 5 at her temporary residence in Anaheim Hills, Calif. She was 62.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: State To Cut Spending
description: Gov. Mike Huckabee has ordered state agencies to cut almost $150 million from the $3.4 budget for the fiscal year that began on July 1. Mr. Huckabee, a Republican, said the impact of the Sept. 11 attacks had aggravated an already anemic state economy. The bulk of the cuts will come from the state's Medicaid program, public education and the prison budget.

title: The Costs of Enduring Freedom
description: The New York Times

title: Death on West Side Tracks
description: A man was killed yesterday after he was apparently struck by an Amtrak train in a Manhattan railroad underpass at 53rd Street, between 10th Avenue and 11th Avenue, the police said.

title: Tinkling Melodies, Shoring Up The Chords
description: There's an amount of bandleader control in Ahmad Jamal's performances that you seldom see in any jazz trio. At Iridium on Tuesday evening he sat at the piano with his back to his drummer, James Johnson, and at an 8 o'clock angle to his bassist, James Cammack; without looking at them directly he ordered them through the set.

title: A NATION CHALLENGED
description: An Arab American's Conflict

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Warnaco Executive Is Fired Without Severance Pay

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO GAINS. The dollar fell after a report that industrial production declined last month and Chancellor Gerhard Schrder won a confidence vote in Germany. In New York, the euro settled at 88.43 cents, up from 88.19 cents.

title: Campbell Reminds Giants: Tight End Is Receiver, Too
description: Dan Campbell has dreamed about having one of those days, the kind when passes rain down in his direction and every one of them sticks to his hands.

title: Democrats Back McGreevey's Choice to Lead Assembly, Ending Feud
description: New Jersey Democrats said today that they had settled their vicious feud over leadership of the General Assembly and that Albio Sires, a freshman lawmaker who is also the mayor of West New York, N.J., will be speaker when the new Legislature takes office in January.

title: Sunday Hours Are Reduced At Libraries In Queens
description: The Queens Borough Public Library will scale back its Sunday service at all but three branches as a result of city budget cuts in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 attack, library officials said yesterday.

title: Man Runs. Airport Empties. Flights Stop. Travelers Stew.
description: At 11:45 this morning, a man in a light T-shirt ran past two security guards and down an up escalator, then disappeared into a secure area of Hartsfield International Airport, the nation's busiest. The startled airport staff wondered briefly if they were being tested by the government.

title: Get Comfortable and Revel In Nostalgic Nightclub Nights
description: Nightclub. The very word conjures images of swanky places where the smart set went to drink too much and laugh too hard. Such images fill ''The Nightclub Years,'' a fizzy cocktail of a documentary that A&E is serving up tomorrow night.

title: Setback for Al Qaeda, Vote for Air Safety, Money for New York
description: Their bombing may not have hit the big prey, but American officials say it will have to do for now. They said airstrikes in Kabul were believed to have killed Muhammad Atef, one of Osama bin Laden's most trusted aides and a man believed to have helped plan the Sept. 11 attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. In short, the Americans say the bin Laden terror network, Al Qaeda, is hurting, though it remains a decided threat.

title: Bin Laden Aide Reported Killed By U.S. Bombs
description: One of Osama bin Laden's most trusted lieutenants has reportedly been killed in a bombing raid, American officials said today. His death, the officials said, would be an important success in a global campaign that has curtailed Al Qaeda's ability to mount large-scale terrorist operations.

title: Retaining Smallpox Stocks
description: The threat of bioterrorism has apparently convinced the Bush administration that it should retain the nation's stock of smallpox virus -- one of only two official repositories for smallpox samples in the world. The administration argued that the samples may be needed to help develop new drug treatments and vaccines against the disease. The decision, disclosed by senior officials to The Times's Judith Miller, is a sensible response to the small but frightening risk that a rogue nation or terrorist group might obtain the virus and unleash it.

title: Franz Hoskins, 86, Dies; Aided in Surgery on Sub
description: Dr. Franz P. Hoskins, a Navy officer in World War II who took part in a storied appendectomy aboard a submarine years before he went to medical school, died on Nov. 8 in Kingsport, Tenn. He was 86.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: RED HERRING COMMUNICATIONS, San Francisco, a provider of news and analysis on innovation in business and investing, reduced its staff by 27 percent, or 38 workers, most of whom worked in the slumping corporate conferences unit.

title: Algerian Man Faces Charges In a Millennium Terror Plot
description: Federal prosecutors and the F.B.I. in Manhattan said yesterday that an Algerian man in Vancouver, British Columbia, has been charged with assisting in a terrorist plot that was tied to the 2000 millennium celebrations.

title: Pride, but Little Drama, in Kosovo Election
description: The fact that most people here think they already know who will win Saturday's long-awaited election has drained none of the drama from Kosovo's first real chance to have a say in selecting its own government.

title: Jets' Burton Sees Success In Quarterback's Eyes
description: On a Jets defense that includes several noted linebackers, a quarterback-sacking defensive end and a highly regarded secondary, only one player leads the league in any category. And only a football buff would know who it is and what it is.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Porsche Net Income Rises
description: Porsche A.G. said that its net income rose 29 percent in the fiscal year ended July 31 as sales of its 911 Turbo and Boxster sports cars increased. Net income rose to 270.5 million euros ($239 million) in the year from 210 million euros a year earlier. Sales rose 22 percent to 4.44 billion euros ($3.92 billion). Porsche is increasing profit and sales, as are its competitors, Bayerische Motoren Werke A.G. and DaimlerChrysler A.G.'s Mercedes-Benz unit, even amid economic slowdowns in their biggest markets, the United States and Germany. The company's pretax profit margin was 12 percent in fiscal 2001, about the same as the year earlier. Porsche said it would pay a dividend of 2.54 euros a common share and 2.6 euros for each preferred share. Its shares closed up 0.8 percent at 393.30 euros.

title: Gloves Are Off When Florida Plays Florida St.
description: When he was a freshman at Florida, Marquand Manuel tried for an interception at a pivotal point in the third quarter of a game against Florida State. He missed, though, and the ball bounced off his hands and landed in the grasp of Peter Warrick of the Seminoles. Instead of Manuel running back an interception for a touchdown to increase the Gators' lead, Warrick scored a touchdown that sparked Florida State to a 23-12 victory.

title: To Forestall a 'Digital Pearl Harbor,' U.S. Looks to System Separate From Internet
description: The Bush administration is considering the creation of a secure new government communications network separate from the Internet that would be less vulnerable to attack and efforts to disrupt critical federal activities.

title: Colombia Resuming Talks
description: A major rebel group and President Andrs Pastrana's administration said today that they would resume peace talks this weekend in Cuba, three months after the government broke off negotiations, citing a lack of will on the part of the guerrillas.

title: Corrections
description: A dance review last Saturday about a performance at City Center by Alicia Alonso's Ballet Nacional de Cuba misstated the given name of a ballet star from Cuba who now dances mainly in the United States and Europe. He is Jos Manuel Ca rreo, not Juan.

title: Was Paper On Bomb A Parody?
description: ''For whatever other dark business may have occurred in the Al Qaeda safe houses in Kabul, a lot of time and effort had been devoted within them to researching the creation of an atomic device,'' The Times of London reported on Thursday.

title: With Sequins and Spunk, Going Back to Nashville
description: Shelby Lynne

title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Pre-Election Cabinet Shuffle
description: With the race to succeed him next year rapidly heating up, President Fernando Henrique Cardoso, left, has reshuffled his cabinet, naming a trusted ally, Aloysio Nunes Ferreira, minister of justice and repaying political favors to a party allied with his government by appointing Senator Ney Suassuna minister of national integration. To be his new chief of staff during the succession battle Mr. Cardoso chose Arthur Virglio, a congressman from his own party. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Panama Francis, 82, Jazz Drummer of Swing Era
description: Panama Francis, a drummer who played for dancers through the glory years of swing in high-profile bands like Lucky Millinder's, Cab Calloway's and Slim Gaillard's, played on countless rhythm-and-blues and rock 'n' roll sessions and became a standard-bearing swing-nostalgia musician, died on Sunday at a hospital in Orlando, Fla. He was 82 and lived in Altamont, Fla.

title: Harvard's Prize Catch, a Delphic Postcolonialist
description: At Harvard University, the acquisition of Homi K. Bhabha from the University of Chicago this fall is regarded as a major coup, as if Sammy Sosa had defected to the Boston Red Sox.

title: After 2-Hour Talk, Bloomberg And Levy Don't Say Much
description: They allowed cameras to briefly record their lunch of deli sandwiches and fruit salad, but Mayor-elect Michael R. Bloomberg and Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy revealed little else about their nearly two-hour discussion yesterday.

title: A Prize Winner Ventures A Bit Outside the Mold
description: Roberto Plano, Pianist

title: World Briefing | Europe: Court To Hear Papon Appeal
description: The European Court of Human Rights has agreed to hear an appeal from Maurice Papon, who was convicted in 1998 of helping to deport more than 1,500 French Jews during World War II. Mr. Papon, who is 91 and serving a 10-year sentence, lost his right to appeal in France because he failed to turn himself in and fled to Switzerland. In accepting the case, the court noted that the European Convention on Human Rights requires that individuals be given the right to appeal a conviction. Suzanne Daley (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLBERT, PETER O.A.
description: SOLBERT-Peter O.A. Age 82, on November 15, 2001 at his home in LLoyd Harbor, New York. Senior Counsel to the law firm of Davis, Polk & Wardwell. He is survived by his loving wife, Deborah (nee Kirk), and his children Leslie K. Fogg, Alan G.K. Solbert, Elizabeth A. Solbert-Sheldon, Alison C.S. Paine, & Christopher O.N. Solbert. He is also survived by twelve grandchildren and his sister Ronni Solbert. Funeral Service Monday 12:00 PM at St. John's Episcopal Church, Cold Spring Harbor, NY.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about Prime Minister Tony Blair's description of a videotape that he said showed Osama bin Laden acknowledging for the first time that he was behind the terror attacks of Sept. 11 referred to the tape imprecisely. While it had not been shown on television, The Sunday Telegraph of London published an article about it last Sunday. It was not unpublicized.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: WPP Buys Polling Firm
description: The WPP Group said yesterday that it had acquired Penn, Schoen & Berland Associates, a strategic research and political polling consulting company. Terms were not disclosed. It is believed to be the first acquisition by a publicly traded company of such a political polling specialist. Penn, Schoen has 81 employees at its Washington headquarters and offices in four other cities. The company has revenue estimated at $31.4 million, and worked for Michael R. Bloomberg in his successful campaign for mayor of New York City. Penn, Schoen will operate as a stand-alone public affairs unit of WPP and remain managed by its three principals, Michael Berland, Mark Penn and Doug Schoen. Allison Fass (NYT)

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of yesterday, 4,343 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAUSS, HERB
description: TAUSS-Herb. The officers and members of the Society of Illustrators deeply mourn the passing of beloved Hall of Fame member Herb Tauss. He will be missed by all who knew him.

title: Religion Journal; Iran's President Speaks On Faith and Civilization
description: One widely praised development since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks is an upsurge in formal discussions between people of different faiths, with Muslims very much involved.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEINSIER, JOAN TUBY
description: WEINSIER-Joan Tuby. On your birthday, November 17th, and everyday beautiful angel, we love and miss you more than the sky! Evelyn, Michael, Wendy and Phili

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONOHUE, BARBARA SANFORD
description: DONOHUE-Barbara Sanford. Of Bronxville and Germantown, NY, died at home on November 15, 2001. She was 59 years old. Barbara attended Scarsdale schools, The Shipley School in Bryn Mawr, PA, and received a Bachelor of Arts from Smith College and a Master's degree from the Hunter School of Social Work. She was married for 23 years to A. James Donohue, an investment banker, who died in 1995. Barbara worked as a social worker for various organizations, including ColumbiaPresbyterian Hospital. In 1983, she and her family moved from New York City to Bronxville, where she was involved in a host of community affairs. She was a vice president and natural resources advocate for the League of Women Voters of Bronxville and, in conjunction with the Bronxville Junior League, she was directly responsible for implementing the Bronxville Village recycling program. For the past six years she was a member of the New York Botanical Garden Council and a volunteer in its horticulture department. She was a member of the Board of Governors of the Bronxville Field Club, chairing the buildings and grounds committee. She was an active member of the Edgewood Club of Tivoli, NY, an avid tennis and paddle tennis player, and a fearless skier, who was nationally ranked as a NASTAR racer. Barbara will be best remembered for her unassailable good nature and positive attitude, her creativity and spontaneity, her thoughtfulness and her song-writing and artistic abilities. She is survived by her three children, Benjamin, Claire and Michael, and her father, Gordon Sanford, all of Bronxville; and a brother, James Sanford, of Warren, VT. A funeral service will be held Monday, November 19, at 3PM at the Reformed Church of Bronxville. Contributions in her memory may be made to: The New York Botanical Garden, 200th St. and Kazimiroff Blvd., Bronx, NY 10458.

title: Winner Emerges in Seattle Mayor's Race
description: Councilman Greg Nickels of King County was able to declare formal victory today in his bid to become the next mayor of Seattle, but only after days of suspense in which the count of mail-in ballots seemed to be slowly whittling away the large lead he held on election night 10 days ago.

title: Hue and Murmur Over Curbed Rights
description: In the days since the Bush administration said it would try suspected terrorists by secret tribunal and interview thousands of recently arrived foreigners, many liberals and civil libertarians have argued that the steps are an affront to long-established freedoms and rights. But other liberal voices have said that the measures can be justified, or at least tolerated, under the special circumstances of war.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the struggle in the New Jersey Assembly over the choice of a speaker misspelled the surname of a spokeswoman for Governor-elect James E. McGreevey, who said he believed the lawmakers need to reach a consensus. The same error occurred on Thursday in an article about a proposed deal for a sports arena in Newark. The spokeswoman is Jo Astrid Glading, not Gladding.

title: Ex-Sixer Wants to Show and Tell
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 16 — The last time Todd MacCulloch went to work out with the Philadelphia 76ers this summer, the Sixers' Allen Iverson greeted his soon-to-be ex-teammate with these words:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERNANDES, RICHARD L.
description: FERNANDES-Richard L. On November 16th. Loving husband of Adele, four children several grand children, brother Eugene and sister Dorothy Amodea. Funeral from Virginia Funeral Chapel, 718987-2828 Tuesday 9:30 AM. Mass at St. Sylvesters Church, SI. Visiting Monday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Retired Vice President of Doremus & Co. (Financial Ad Agency).

title: Children's Books
description: November 18, 2001

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Ulster Terror Suspects Arrested
description: Antiterrorist police officers arrested six men in London and Liverpool and detonated bombs found on an unused pig farm in West Yorkshire in what they said involved the campaign of violence by dissident Irish republicans opposed to the Northern Ireland peace plan. Eight terror attacks over an 18-month period have been attributed to the Real I.R.A., the renegade group responsible for the 1998 bombing of Omagh in Northern Ireland, which killed 29 people. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Sheepshead Bay Seeks Date in Final
description: Last season Sheepshead Bay was just happy to have made it as far as the Public Schools Athletic League semifinals. But this year, the Sharks, with a regular-season record of 8-0, expect to contend for the league championship.

title: Miles of Remembrance
Editors' Note; COMING ON SUNDAY
description: THE TV BATTLEFRONT

title: New Jersey Doctor Doesn't Have Skin Anthrax
description: ANew Jersey doctor who thought he had contracted skin anthrax in the first week of September has tested negative for the disease, state health officials said yesterday.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Charged With Anti-Jewish Remark
description: A nightclub owner in Munich was charged with inciting racial hatred with a remark he made in canceling an Israeli charity's fund-raiser. According to witnesses, Rudolf Fischer said, ''I am not going to open the place for you Jews'' after hearing that the granddaughter of the Yitzhak Rabin, the assassinated Israeli prime minister, was to speak. He has denied the charge. Desmond Butler (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSTROW, BARNEY
description: OSTROW-Barney. It is with deepest sorrow that we announce the passing on November 14, 2001 of our beloved husband, father, father-in-law, poppie, brother, uncle, cousin and friend and all around inspiration. Barney was born on the Lower Eastside of New York City of Russian, Jewish immigrant parents. From these humble roots, he grew a long-lived, successful physical therapy practice that touched many patients' lives. His amazing gifts of healing heart and hands transformed all those who knew him. He is survived by his wife Ida, children Jane Lazere, Flora and Gary, their partners Richard, Betsy and Pam, grandchildren Briana & Rebecca, sister Sarah Music and their many extended family members and friends. We will hold him in our hearts forever. Services 12:00 PM November 16 at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: PROFITS INCREASE BY 68% FOR KRISPY KREME DOUGHNUTS
description: Profits in Krispy Kreme Doughnuts's fiscal third-quarter rose 68 percent as the company opened stores and consumers ate more doughnuts. Net income rose to $6.48 million, or 11 cents a share, in the quarter ended Oct. 28, from $3.85 million, or 7 cents, in the year-earlier period. Revenue rose 28 percent, to $99.8 million, the company said yesterday. Krispy Kreme added 10 stores in California, Pennsylvania and other states, bringing the total number of stores to 198 at the end of the quarter. Krispy Kreme's sales were not hurt by a decline in consumer spending as much as other retailers' were because comfort foods like doughnuts are appealing when the economy slows, analysts said. Krispy Kreme is based in Winston-Salem, N.C.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ALDRICH, LARRY
description: ALDRICH-Larry. A celebration of the life of Larry Aldrich will take place at 2:00 PM on November 18, 2001, at the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art, 258 Main St., Ridgefield, CT. Bus transportation will be available from 40 Central Park South at 12:15. To RSVP or for more information, please contact the Museum at 203-438-4519.

title: Peaceful Power Transfer: Nets Win Without Fight
description: What started as a turf rumble tonight turned into a backyard barbecue, a party the Nets threw to announce their arrival.

title: Judge Denies Bail for Rabbi After Mistrial in Murder Case
description: The judge who declared a mistrial in the case of a South Jersey rabbi accused of arranging his wife's murder refused to grant him bail today, and the rabbi was returned to jail to await a second trial on the charges.

title: Nets Put on a Show, And More Witness It
description: If it were truly about basketball, the Knicks would be the team playing in front of prep-sized crowds and the Nets would be sprinting, dishing and dunking before star-studded audiences of nearly 20,000.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the appointment of Bruce Wasserstein, the Wall Street deal maker, as chief executive of Lazard L.L.C., misstated the year in which he and Joseph Perella formed the firm of Wasserstein Perella. It was 1988, not 1998.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, OGDEN NORTHROP, JR.
description: LEWIS-Ogden Northrop, Jr. Suddenly on November 14, 2001, at age 22. Cherished son of Ogden and Susan Lewis, adored nephew of Margaret Patterson High and William Hall Lewis, III. Beloved by countless friends. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory to The Buckley School, 113 East 73 Street, New York, New York 10021, or Groton School, Box 991, Groton, Massachusetts 01450, would be greatly appreciated. Funeral arrangements incomplete.

title: F.A.A. Tells Airlines to Study Type of Plane That Crashed
description: The Federal Aviation Administration yesterday ordered American Airlines and the two domestic cargo airlines that fly the Airbus A300, the type of plane that crashed on Monday, to take a close look at their vertical tail sections in the next 15 days and report back on what they find.

title: Corrections
description: The State of the Art column in Circuits on Thursday, about buying personal computers, misidentified a Dell model offered for $709 including extras. It was the Dimension 2100, a desktop PC, not the Inspiron 2100, a notebook model.

title: Max Hunter, 79, Rocket Engineer With Wealth of Ideas for Space
description: Maxwell White Hunter, a rocket engineer, project manager and visionary of the space age, died on Nov. 10 at Stanford Hospital in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 79 and lived in San Carlos, Calif.

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Wednesday about the Sonic Boom Festival at the Knitting Factory in Manhattan misidentified the clarinetist in a performance of Shulamit Ran's ''Private Game.'' She was Meighan Stoops, not Jo Ann Sternberg. The article also misspelled the name of the cellist. He was Andr Emelianoff, not Andre Emilianoff.

title: Long at bin Laden's Side, And, It Seems, Very Busy
description: Muhammad Atef, an Al Qaeda military commander who was reported killed in the American bombing raids near Kabul, held a unique place in Osama bin Laden's hierarchy, officials say: he was military commander and a member of Al Qaeda's ruling shura council, as well as an in-law of Mr. bin Laden.

title: Carrying 27 Years of Civic Passion to the Mayor's Office
description: YOU can call him Al.

title: A Taste for Fine Wine, a Seeker of Good Deals, and Fun on Halloween
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Islanders' Offense Continues to Wilt
description: The Colorado Avalanche scored an early goal and, for the second straight game, dared an opponent to match it. The Islanders were the foes tonight, and their offense suddenly has all the voltage of a dead battery.

title: Editors' Note; Today's Sections
description: News of the Sept. 11 attacks and their aftermath continues to appear in Section B; index, Page B2.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: U.S. Plans Missile Radar
description: The United States plans to set up a radar site in South Korea to detect ballistic missiles and guide intercepters to destroy them, according to the semi-official Yonhap news agency. The agency, citing military officials, said South Korea was in one of nine regions where the United States would build such bases between 2000 and 2015 as part of a missile defense system. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: AUTOMAKER REACHES SETTLEMENT IN BIAS LAWSUITS
description: The Ford Motor Company agreed to settle two lawsuits that accused the company, the second-largest automaker, of discrimination in employee evaluations and sought class-action status, a lawyer said. The tentative settlement, reached Wednesday night, is contingent upon also resolving individual discrimination lawsuits against Ford, said James Fett, a lawyer in Pinckney, Mich., who represents clients in one of the lawsuits seeking class-action status and seven individual complaints. He declined to disclose terms of the settlement. Ford is based in Dearborn, Mich.

title: Bush Gives New York More, But Lawmakers Demand All
description: The White House said today that it would give New York an additional $2 billion to help it recover from the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Candidate Has Cancer
description: State Attorney General Jim Ryan, a leading Republican hopeful in the 2002 race for governor, is battling lymphoma for the third time in the last five years. His doctors say the latest recurrence is ''eminently treatable,'' however, and should not interfere with the candidacy of the 55-year-old Mr. Ryan or his duties as attorney general. B. Drummond Ayres Jr. (NYT)

title: The New Mail Pouch
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Thursday about the rescue of eight Christian aid workers in Afghanistan, including two Americans, misstated the day they were picked up by American military helicopters and taken to Pakistan. In some copies yesterday an article about a news conference held by some of the workers repeated the error. And because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the reaction in Waco, Tex., hometown of the two Americans, also misstated the day. The pickup occurred before dawn on Thursday in Afghanistan (Wednesday afternoon, Eastern time), not on Wednesday.

title: U.S. Relief Workers Tell of Fear and Faith
description: Waiting Thursday in the predawn cold in eastern Afghanistan, eight terrified Christian aid workers were not sure who would arrive first, American forces dispatched to rescue them or Taliban soldiers who had held them captive for three months.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Wisconsin: Jump In Caseload
description: More than 8,000 people received cash assistance under the state's welfare reform program in September, the highest caseload since May 1999. The Wisconsin Department of Workforce Development attributed the increase to the sluggish economy. The welfare reform program, which requires participants to work in exchange for child-care help, transportation, job training and cash assistance, was started in 1997, when more than 34,000 people participated. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: Pressing Greens, German Leader Wins Historic Vote on Sending Troops to Afghanistan
description: The German chancellor, Gerhard Schrder, won his game of chicken today with his junior coalition partner, the Greens, forcing them to support the government in a confidence vote over German participation in the war in Afghanistan.

title: The Neediest Cases; After Fire, A Long Year Of Looking For a Home
description: The phone call from the Bronx arrived while Doreen Hall was clearing dishes after a Thanksgiving meal in North Carolina.

The pickup occurred before dawn on Thursday in Afghanistan (Wednesday afternoon, Eastern time), not on Wednesday.

title: The Lady Is a Champ
description: From her conception at the hands of the sculptor Auguste Bartholdi to her transformation as a beacon of hope for immigrants to this country, the history of the Statue of Liberty is traced in ''Lady Liberty: Symbol of Dreams,'' which will be shown tonight at 9 on the Travel Channel. At 9 a.m. on Friday, ''The Magic of Central Park'' begins the channel's all-day tribute to America's most famous travel destinations.

title: Alliance Jails Foreign Foes, But Isn't Sure About Origins
description: Of the 75 to 80 prisoners being held at Arg prison here, 5 are from outside Afghanistan. That makes them ''important prisoners,'' said the prison's commander, Haji-Abdul Kareem Qayabatani, adding that ''they are evidence that other countries were involved'' in supporting the Taliban.

title: All Suicide Bombers Are Not Alike
description: Your writer traveled to three countries and talked to Muslims from all walks of life with all levels of education but failed to find a single group that unanimously condemned the murder of 5,000 people. I don't think this is going to strengthen arguments against racial profiling in the current situation.

title: Eugene Clark: From the Terrace
description: In life, Eugene Clark observed the three D's: dance, drama and divas. He started early: Roberta Flack was his music teacher in Washington, D.C., during the 1960's. He could sing like Jennifer Holliday in the musical "Dreamgirls," he could emote like Norma Desmond in "Sunset Boulevard" and he danced "like Tina Turner," said Larry Courtney, Mr. Clark's partner for the last 13 years. "And he had legs almost as good."

description: The stigma of nearly losing to Boston College the week before put Miami in an aggressive mood today.

description: The neo-preppie pattern -- is holding fast through winter, with the whales and lobsters of August giving way to November argyles -- in a variety of sweaters for day and night.

title: Robert J. Fangman: A Job That Fit
description: Money is little comfort when you hate your job. As a salesman for Verizon Wireless, the only part Robert J. Fangman liked about his job was the travel, said his mother, Ruth. So he kept the travel, threw out the selling, and took a 50 percent pay cut to become a flight attendant with United Airlines last November.

title: The Fun, and Rewards, Of Toying With Tradition

title: It's 'Handsome' One Among a 50 cents Series
description: THE Bridgeport Centennial Half Dollar is not the only commemorative coin to honor Connecticut or its cities. In 1935, the United States minted the Connecticut Tercentenary Half Dollar.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2001 Chevrolet TrailBlazer and GMC Envoy; G.M. Makes Up Ground With New Midsize Sport Utilities
description: FROM the moment the first Ford Explorer went on sale, the Chevrolet Blazer and its near-twin, the GMC Jimmy, were left eating its dust. Ford has dominated the market for midrange sport utility vehicles, and General Motors could never catch it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTMANN, WAYNE J.
description: HARTMANN-Wayne J. Of Bedford, NY died November 14, 2001. He was 85 years old. Beloved husband of Ruth, loving father of Ann Miller, Elizabeth Hartmann, D.V.M. and Wayne Hartmann, Jr. ''Jud''. Services were held at St. Matthew's Church in Bedford.

title: Sports of The Times; King Still Chasing Wild Geese
description: WEARING one of his dozen tuxedos and with his gray hair as stiffly straight as a paintbrush, Don King was waiting to chase ''the wild goose'' that emerged from last night's heavyweight title bout when Lennox Lewis knocked out Hasim Rahman in the fourth round.

title: Luxuries Are Looking Like Durable Goods
description: EVEN in a tough economy, cachet counts.

title: All Suicide Bombers Are Not Alike
description: During the climax of the sci-fi movie ''Independence Day,'' a former fighter pilot in the Vietnam War, desperately recruited to fight again, flies his jet, kamikaze-style, into the belly of an invading alien space ship. No one in the audience wonders about his motivation or whether he was brainwashed with the promise of nirvana. Fiction, perhaps, but American history is replete with such selfless heroics. Did not Nathan Hale regret that he had but one life to give for his country? Have not our armed forces charged into battle with the cry ''Remember the Alamo,'' in the spirit of the brave Texans who willingly met certain death in the cause of independence?

title: White Offers Up a Knight But Gets Too Little in Return
description: The Smartchess.com International Tournament II, which was held at the Manhattan Chess Club, New Yorker Hotel, 481 Eighth Avenue, Oct. 7-15, ended in a victory for the Ukraine grandmaster Igor Novikov, who tallied 6-3. Second prize in this round-robin invitational competition dotted with grandmasters surprisingly went to the Canadian international master Igor Zugic, who scored 5 1/2-2 1/2.

title: Argentina's Provinces Struggle to Stay Afloat
description: Gov. Alfredo Aveln is an eccentric country doctor known for his homespun philosophy, his poetry and a peculiar habit of playfully slapping the faces of visitors to his office.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WOHL, DAVID L.
description: WOHL-David L. November 18, '94. ''I see you, you fade in and out of the mist. I reach for you but I can't touch you. I feel you just beyond the star. How I wish I could realize my heart but it's only wishful thinking on my part.'' I'll always love you, Mommy

title: Characters Flounder in Tough Love and Denial in 'Country Girl'
description: IN the mid-1930's, the name of Clifford Odets stood for social protest in the American theater.

title: Unexpected Guests Warm Hearts in the Frozen North
description: It could have been a short, sweet story: planes get diverted, local people pitch in to help stranded passengers. Polite thank-you letters and gifts follow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUDISCH, DORIS RICE
description: KUDISCH-Doris Rice. November 16, at the age of 84, died on date of heart failure in San Francisco, CA, where she had lived since 1995. Mrs. Kudisch was the widow of Leonard Kudisch. She was passionately devoted to her family, her brother, sisters, nieces and nephews; to her two daughters, Diane Kudisch, proprietor of the San Francisco Mystery bookstore, and Joanna Weinberg, a professor of health policy at UC San Francisco; to her son-in-law, David Levine; and to her three grandchildren, Paul and Tama Weinberg and Arielle Levine. The family wishes to thank devoted caregivers, Juanita, Rose, the San Francisco Hospice by the Bay, and the Jewish Healing Center, and the staff at Coventry Park Senior Residence in San Francisco. Funeral arrangements are private. No flowers; donations can be made to Hospice by the Bay, 1530 Market St, #350, San Francisco, CA 94102; or to Congregation Netivot Shalom, Berkeley Way, Berkeley, CA 94702.

title: Satguru Subramuniyaswami, Hindu Spiritual Leader, Dies at 74
description: Satguru Sivaya Subramuniya swami, a native Californian who sought spiritual meaning in India as a young man and became the spiritual leader of Sri Lankan Hindus, died on Tuesday at his ashram on the Hawaiian island of Kauai. He was 74.

title: So, Friend, It's Time for That Tax Cut
description: IN recent weeks, a steady parade of executives from industries like airlines and insurance companies, hotels and pharmaceutical companies, has trooped to Washington for handouts. Some have walked away with billions in aid. But those pleas pale when compared with the all-out lobbying push now under way -- a fight for broad and deep corporate tax cuts that are being measured in the hundreds of billions of dollars.

title: Clash Over Legacy Fuels Computer Merger Battle
description: The computer industry's biggest merger, championed by executives involved as giving them the tools to master the challenges of the future, has suddenly found itself held captive by two concepts from the past: family and legacy.

title: Wine-Tasting Apex, If You Can Afford It
description: THE public can periodically sample Long Island wines at their best at public tastings that often raise money for charitable causes.

title: A Rush on Rent-a-Planes
description: THE first time Millie Hernndez-Becker flew, as a 10-year-old on a family trip to Puerto Rico, she was awed by the experience.

title: H. Joseph Heller: A Broker and a Fixer
description: Whenever H. Joseph Heller felt strongly that he should do something, he went out and did it. That's how he ended up owning a yellow turn-of- the-last-century farmhouse on a hilly acre in Ridgefield, Conn., a house that his wife, Mary Jean, calls "a major fixer-upper."

title: A Few Missed Paychecks
description: Debrah Morton and her children, Clifton Moore, 12, and Joshua Elfaki, 3, were evicted from their Bronx apartment when Ms. Morton fell behind on her rent. Ms. Morton is just one among the many thousands of working poor helped by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: From Election Loss, Ashcroft Goes to Top in Antiterror Campaign
description: ''For every crucifixion,'' John Ashcroft likes to say, ''a resurrection is waiting to follow,'' and, more than most people in Washington, he should know.

title: U.S. to Press Afghan Rebels Not to Form Government
description: The Bush administration said today that it would apply intense pressure on the Northern Alliance, newly in control of Kabul and much of Afghanistan, not to create a government on its own but to fulfill its promise to let the United Nations put together a broad coalition to rule the country.

title: Our Values, Overseas
description: To the Editor:

title: Cold Comfort
description: The latest trend in modern design is furniture you can almost cuddle up in.

title: Restoring a Polluted Bay to Its Former Pristine Glory
description: Decades of raw sewage have turned Flushing Bay, once prized for its sweet clams, into a smelly spot that people shun. But after persistent community protest, the area may be on the mend.

title: Home Alone
description: AMBER WAS BRAVE,

title: Survey Finds Bonds Mystify Investors
description: The vast majority of investors don't understand bonds, and the confusion appears to be deepening, a survey shows.

title: South Street Seaport's Vital Fuel, Its Foot Traffic, Slows to a Near Halt
description: Windows were cleaned. Postcards were neatly stacked. Daiquiri machines were filled. But the crowds never arrived.

title: Letters
description: Our article on suicide bombers -- and photo essay on "Jihad's Women" -- prompted mail on the mothers of the "martyrs," who take pride in sons who die like this. And many readers said that nothing is off limits in fighting terrorism -- not racial profiling, not restricting civil liberties.

title: The Pox and Human Progress
description: Earlier this month, doctors at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention convened an urgent meeting to discuss a disease that was eradicated two decades ago. Smallpox, which kills two of every five people it infects, claimed its last victim in September 1978. Its return as a biological weapon would not only be a medical catastrophe; it would be a moral failure every bit as great as the triumph that eliminated it.

title: Corn Bread Stuffing Gives Way to Kippu
description: ON the brink of Thanksgiving Day, as people ransack cookbooks looking for recipes, perhaps it is an opportune time to point out that the world's most ancient cookbooks can be found in Connecticut, on permanent display as part of Yale University's Babylonian Collection housed in the Sterling Memorial Library.

title: 'Hate Cannot Drive Out Hate'
description: MARTIN's BIG WORDS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLBERT, PETER O.A.
description: SOLBERT-Peter O.A. Age 82, on November 15, 2001 at his home in LLoyd Harbor, New York. Senior Counsel to the law firm of Davis, Polk & Wardwell. He is survived by his loving wife, Deborah (nee Kirk), and his children Leslie K. Fogg, Alan G.K. Solbert, Elizabeth A. Solbert-Sheldon, Alison C.S. Paine, & Christopher O.N. Solbert. He is also survived by twelve grandchildren and his sister Ronni Solbert. Funeral Service Monday 12:00 PM at St. John's Episcopal Church, Cold Spring Harbor, NY.

title: An Old-Fashioned Job Hunt
description: EILEEN MORAN, an aspiring fashion designer, thought she had the right formula for success. She would attend a prestigious college, graduate with a degree in marketing and small-business entrepreneurship and then land a job with an independent fashion house or start her own company.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: THE personal and political chill of winter in Russia under Communism pervades Michael Apted's GORKY PARK (1983), adapted by Dennis Potter from the best-selling thriller by Martin Cruz Smith. Beginning with the discovery of faceless murder victims in the Moscow park of the title, the plot follows Arkady Renko, a determined police detective protrayed by William Hurt, on a suspensefully byzantine trail of money and mayhem that leads to high-level corruption and, of course, to romance on the run. Lee Marvin is the conniving capitalist to hiss, and Joanna Pacula provides love in a time of cold war - Saturday at 6 p.m. and Saturday/Early Sunday at 1 a.m. on AMC.

title: Get Happy: Nouveau's Here
description: A city seeking a Thanksgiving lift will find cheer in Georges Duboeuf's charming, light 2001 Beaujolais nouveau, released on Thursday. This red captures Mr. Duboeuf's fruity nouveau style. Perfumed, juicy and cherrylike, it invites gulping. Savor the gamay grape's vivacity at room temperature or slightly chilled. K & D, 1366 Madison Avenue (96th Street), Manhattan, charges $8. HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

description: When Vladimir V. Putin came to Crawford, Tex., population very, very small, he and President Bush spent nearly an hour entertaining high school students with their views on arms control, women's rights and the best time to visit Texas (not August) and Siberia (not winter). Then Mr. Bush announced he would cut America's nuclear arsenal to 1,700 from

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEERMAN, ANN
description: BEERMAN-Ann, 98. Died Wednesday November 7, 2001, in Tulsa, OK. Born February 3, 1903 in Brooklyn, NY to parents, Louis & Dora Lapinsky Secan. Married Abraham on November 27, 1927 in Brooklyn, NY. Abraham preceded her in death December 30, 1968. Ann moved to Tulsa in 1981 and is survived by daughter Estelle Beerman-Finer, Tulsa, OK; son Stuart Beerman and wife Elinor Rosen-Beerman, North Woodmere, NY; brother Joseph Secan, Houston TX, five grandchildren and ten great grandchildren.

description: THE WIG MY FATHER WORE

title: A Landscape in Peril
description: Well before German marks and drachmas began showing up at the City Market in Moab, before Lycra became the second skin of nearly every visitor, even before cell phones became tourists' essential companions, the novelist and wilderness defender Edward Abbey wrote about the enduring paradox of Utah's canyon country: it is ''the least inhabited, least developed, least improved, least civilized, most arid, most hostile, most lonesome, most grim bleak barren desolate and savage quarter of the state of Utah -- the best part by far.''

description: Jessica Gabrielle Safier, a daughter of Sondra Safier and Dr. Stanley Safier of Brooklyn, was married last evening to Tobias McMullen Jackson, a son of Marianne C. Jackson and Dr. Richard Jackson of Manhattan. Rabbi Valerie Lieber officiated in the Beaux-Arts Court of the Brooklyn Museum of Art.

description: ADELSON-Irene. Beloved wife of Edward. Loving mother of Barbara and Larry. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother.

description: SHOOTING FOR THE MOON

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Afghan women know, through hard experience, what the rest of the world is discovering: the brutal oppression of women is a central goal of the terrorists.''

description: Museums/Institutions

title: Wines That Travel Well (and Far)
description: I FIRST developed a taste for the red wines of Australia after a trip there five years ago. Back home in Portland, Me., as my husband, Bob, and I sought out shirazes and cabernets, we noticed that many of our favorites came from the Barossa Valley. On our second visit to Australia, in January, we decided to travel to the source. We wanted to taste and learn without having to buy a bottle of everything we sipped.

title: U.S. Airports Becoming No-Buy Zones
description: TRAVELERS who order a sandwich at Au Bon Pain at Pittsburgh International Airport may find that the bread looks as if it were hacked apart with a blunt instrument. It was. Security officials have taken away all the knives because the restaurant is inside the security perimeter, and workers behind the counter now have nothing sharper than a spreader, a metal disk originally designed for slathering mayonnaise or mustard on bread.

title: In the Region/Connecticut; A Restoration of the Audubon Society's Oldest Center
description: A CONSTRUCTION and restoration program costing $12 million is under way at the Greenwich Audubon Society, whose main 500-acre sanctuary of rolling woodlands offers peaceful precincts for visitors seeking a respite from the madding crowd. The project will transform some of the beloved but outmoded components of the half-century-old preserve into a state-of-the-art environmental education center and nature sanctuary, scheduled to open early in 2003.

title: Through a Labyrinth, for Mind and Soul
description: A WAY to find answers to some of life's deepest questions might be waiting, neatly folded and stored in a large blue box at the Parish Resource Center in Valley Stream. The center, a nondenominational organization, lends out books, tapes and other supplies to subscribing churches. But perhaps the most unusual of its spiritual tools is a portable labyrinth.

title: Business; Champagne Houses Waiting Nervously For the Corks to Pop
description: MARILYN MONROE was rumored to bathe in it and Nol Coward claimed to drink it for breakfast. Napoleon and Churchill sipped it to toast battlefield victories. For generations, bottles have been uncorked to bless marriages, christen ships, honor job promotions and add a bit of seductive decadence to an intimate moment.

title: RETRACING A TRAIL TO SEPT. 11 PLOT
description: Shortly after Sept. 11, when the United States sent out urgent inquiries for leads on the suspected hijackers, German officials quickly traced three of the ringleaders to an apartment in this affluent northern port.

description: Speaking of Democratic White House hopefuls (presumed) Senator Russell D. Feingold of Wisconsin gets the latest award for Most Peripatetic.

description: THE MOUSE

title: Where the Salsa Is on the Floor, Not the Food
description: JUAN CALDERON knows salsa dancing. The founder and director of the Cultural Explosion Dance Company, he has taught Latin dance in New Jersey for the last 10 years and has performed at hundreds of events.

title: Liberty and Security in the Age of Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: The World: Withdrawal Symptons; Defeat's First Steps
description: IF every victory in combat is unique the result of a particular strategy pursued against a particular foe the same is true when armies flee. There are strategic withdrawals, panicked routs, narrow escapes and many other forms of what mud soldiers call ''bugging out.'' Sometimes it happens rapidly and pervasively, as appeared to be the case among many Taliban units across most of Afghanistan last week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHU, WU PING
description: CHU-Wu Ping. Peacefully, at home, on November 16, two months short of 101. Deeply beloved mother of John, Yvonne (Meinwald), Theodore, Joan (Fu); grandmother of Barbara, David, Anne (Chu), Constance, Pamela (Meinwald); great-grandmother of Ethan, Benjamin, Beatrix. Funeral private. Interment at Kensico Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory may be made to Palliative Care Unit, Mt. Sinai Hospital.

title: Mayor Must Now Campaign for Real Power
description: EDDIE PEREZ, the newly elected mayor of Hartford, the first Latino mayor of a capitol city in New England, campaigned for and won an office that hardly exists. By city charter, the office is more ceremonial than substantive, but Mr. Perez, a child of welfare, the first high school graduate in his family, the first college graduate in his universe, has never let what is, determine what will be.

title: Chrysanthemums Hold Delightful Secrets
description: I HAVE never really liked chrysanthemums. Maybe it was all those wrist corsages in high school, where my date and I always wanted to be with someone else. Or those pom-pom flowers, which look like bad party favors.

title: Another Terror Victim: Health Care
description: LONG before the economy started to sink, before terrorists crashed planes into the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, before Cipro became part of the popular trademark lexicon, American health care had major problems. Now there are new twists.

title: Afghans, Elated Yet Wary, Greet New Way of Life
description: Residents of several cities in Afghanistan greeted fighters last week from the opposition Northern Alliance, showering them with flowers and money in some places, and celebrated in a variety of ways.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a review on Nov. 4 about two books dealing with the life of John F. Kennedy referred erroneously to ''The Kennedy Women,'' an earlier book by one author, Laurence Leamer. It has not been made into a television movie.

title: Eulogy for a Little Magazine
description: Lingua Franca was not a magazine to sink your savings into. The initial pitch had the feel of self-parody -- The American Lawyer for academics! -- with the twist that instead of hunting for scandal in courtrooms and law firms, Lingua Franca writers were going to track it down in graduate seminars and faculty lounges. But Lingua Franca's founder, a former professor of French named Jeffrey Kittay, refused to see that his premise was ridiculous. He maintained that university politics and scholarly debate, written about in the right way, could make for good copy, not just for academics but for everybody. His magazine proved his point with such force that after 10 years it had become the standard against which most other intellectual journalism was measured.

title: Nets Head West After Disappointing Loss
description: After sprinting to a 7-1 record, the Nets felt their legs stiffen Saturday night as they stopped playing defense and began resting on their success. As a result, the Philadelphia 76ers snapped the Nets' five-game winning streak and showed they might be on the verge of regaining the momentum that helped them win the Eastern Conference championship last season.

title: Into the Outback
description: I KNEW that at least once during our three-month road trip around Australia I would feel like Clark W. Griswold, America's favorite fish-out-of-water vacationer, and this was it: my girlfriend, Jessica, and I were driving back to our seaside campsite in Cape Range National Park in Western Australia, and I was beginning to consider pulling over on the side of the road and sleeping in the car.

title: Eager for Foreign Students, Universities Persuade Senator to Drop Plan to Limit Visas
description: An effort to impose a federal moratorium on student visas in the wake of September's terrorist attacks has foundered after an intense lobbying campaign by university officials, who feared the pause would deal a crippling blow to advanced research programs and to the bottom lines of colleges and universities.

title: In Kabul, DVD's and TV's Fill the Shopping Bags; Burkas Sit on the Shelves
description: Two teenage boys spent the day savoring one of the rituals of youth the world over. They cruised the city to see and be seen, to pick up a favorite album, perhaps to shed a bit of adolescent awkwardness.

title: Reviving a Hemingway Hero
description: BETWEEN writing great novels, Ernest Hemingway took time to hunt and fish and brawl -- also to drink, fight wars, drive ambulances, fall in love. Guy stuff. He ended his own life like that: fast, tough, a shot to the head. ''For Whom the Bell Tolls,'' ''A Farewell to Arms,'' ''The Old Man and the Sea'' and other favorites, are an American tradition.

title: The Green Revolution: It's Also the Color of Money
description: Advocates for roadless wilderness and similar conservation issues have traditionally emphasized the ethical imperatives and aesthetic rewards of promoting environmentalism. But, perhaps noticing that money is green, too, a growing, hardnosed component in the environmental community, often led by constituents in the outdoor industry, is hammering out a different kind of message: that there are great practical, economic benefits to protecting the environment, and in promoting outdoor recreation.

description: GLEAM AND GLOW

description: Postgame audio from the Jets vs. the Miami Dolphins provided by SportsAudio.net.
