description: To the Editor:

title: All Suicide Bombers Are Not Alike
description: Do these ''martyrs'' ever notice that those exhorting them to suicide are mostly old men? This isn't new: Irenaues of Lyon (circa 130-202) and Tertullian (160-220) did the same thing with Christians. Both lived to be at least 60, and neither chose the path of martyrdom he so vehemently espoused for others.

title: The Spin War
description: To the Editor:

title: 'In the Shadow of Our House'
description: If you had lived long on our street, and drunk late at our parties, you would know that before retiring and moving to Texas, Odie Dodd had been a government physician in Georgetown, Guyana. Squawking through the hole in his throat where his larynx had been before the cancer, Odie would have told how Jim Jones had asked him to the People's Temple to vaccinate the children. How malaria, cholera, bacterial meningitis slept in the jungle underbrush. How his truck had overheated along the rutted jungle road and he'd arrived a half-day late. How he was the first to find the bodies, though. Families. Limbs intertwined. Mothers sprawled over children as if sheltering them from some imminent hardship. Scattered on the dirt around them, dixie cups that had held the grape punch and cyanide. And already, of course, the smell. The uninterrupted whine of insects. At a party, Odie's hand would flatten his silver comb-over, and he'd say he hadn't known where he was for a time. That he'd wandered outside the compound and crouched in the shade of the jungle, the insect whine growing louder. In his daze, he glanced up into the canopy and for a moment it seemed it would descend on him. His scalp prickled. He called out. The feeling, he would say, was as in a dream when you know a terrible thing is about to happen but you are helpless to prevent it. But of course the thing had already happened. And then, if Odie had sipped enough scotch, and his wife Ruth had not yet touched his elbow to leave, he would have pulled you aside and asked the question he always asked of us: why was he spared? Later it would occur to you, as it did to Dennis Lipsy, that Odie had not been spared. And sometimes, when you are at the edge of sleep, witnessing calamities befall your children or your own can't-find-the-brake veering into oncoming traffic, Odie's fleshy hole appears.

title: Mrs. Bush Cites Women's Plight Under Taliban
description: Laura Bush took over her husband's weekly radio address today to urge worldwide condemnation of the treatment of women in Afghanistan, and to ensure that they have rights and can contribute when that country is rebuilt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAYNOR, JUDITH E.
description: GAYNOR-Judith E. On November 13, 2001. Beloved wife of Dr. Edward Gaynor. Devoted mother and Kenneth and Tanya, Beth Gaynor LaPat and Michael. Cherished daughter of Ann Greenberg. Loving sister of Richard Greenberg. Services Sunday, 11 AM, at ''Gutterman's, Inc,'' 175 Long Beach Rd, Rockville Centre, LI.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCRIBNER, HOWARD A.
description: SCRIBNER-Howard A. Beloved husband of Patricia Scribner of Chatham, NJ. Loved father of Mark and his wife, Dawn Scribner of Essex, VT, Susan Mirza and her husband Muzzi of Greenwich, CT, Nancy Ruscheinski and her husband Edward of Chicago, IL. Six grandchildren, Shaylea and Kelsey Scribner, Alexander and Christina Mirza, and Kylie and Keegan Ruscheinski. Brother of the late Beverly Bartuska. Also surviving is a sister, Fay Carberry of Norwood, NJ and many nieces and nephews. A funeral liturgy will be held on Monday, November 19 at 11AM at St. Patrick Church, 85 Washington Ave., Chatham, NJ. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made in his memory to the Howard A. Scribner, Jr. Endowment Scholarship at the University of Notre Dame, 115 Main Building, Notre Dame, IN 46556.

title: From Hair to There: A Business Evolves
description: WHAT does Sy Sperling, founder of the Hair Club for Men, have in common with cancer patients at North Shore Hospital, several rock stars and more than a few local Orthodox Jewish women? A deep affinity for Nelida Ines Barrera, the creative and intentionally discreet force behind some of the best-tressed people around. Ms. Barrera owns N.I.B. Hair Products Inc. in Great Neck, which designs and manufactures synthetic and human hair pieces, and hair integration systems. She helped Mr. Sperling gain his tonsorial fame by turning human hair into integration pieces in the earliest days of the nonsurgical hair blending system he developed, and which made him a household name.

title: Profligate Princes Stir Succession Questions And Threaten Reform
description: Last August, when many Saudis had fled the searing heat, the public telephone company quietly released an unprecedented financial report, and those paying attention believe it revealed an astounding detail about what royal princes can cost the kingdom.

title: Inevitably, Insurance Appetite Increases
description: Wouldn't it be refreshing if sports could be merely about the game and the moment? The tennis player would stretch for the wide volley. The golfer would line up a short putt. They would make it or miss; eventually get the trophy or lose it, and that would be that. Remote control in hand on any given weekend, you can still fool yourself. Push a button. Shot on goal. Push another button. Three- pointer from well behind the arc.

title: Murder in Frenchtown
description: THE RAG

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONOHUE, BARBARA SANFORD
description: DONOHUE-Barbara Sanford. Of Bronxville and Germantown, NY, died at home on November 15, 2001. She was 59 years old. She was married for 23 years to A. James Donohue, an investment banker, who died in 1995. She is survived by her three children, Benjamin, Claire and Michael, and her father, Gordon Sanford, all of Bronxville; and a brother, James Sanford, of Warren, VT. A funeral service will be held on Monday, November 19, at 3PM at the Reformed Church of Bronxville. Contributions in her memory may be made to: The New York Botanical Garden, 200th St. and Kazimiroff Boulevard, Bronx, NY 10458.

title: In Bloomberg Country, Wary Talk
description: WHEN Michael R. Bloomberg plunked down $3.6 million last year for a 20-acre farm on Titicus Road in North Salem, he was just another billionaire from New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHOLEY, MICHAEL
description: WHOLEY-Michael. The family of Port Authority Police Officer Michael T. Wholey would like to extend our heartfelt thanks to all the kind and thoughtful people who gave of their time, love and support to us after the loss of Michael in the World Trade Center attack. The many offerings of food, Mass cards, flowers and financial assistance will never be forgotten. A special thanks to those who attended the Memorial Mass for Michael and especially to Fr. Backes and Fr. Jerry Hahn for participating in the Mass in St. Andrews R.C. Church in Westwood, NJ and to the Port Authority NY/NJ for their wonderful support of his wife and children. May God bless you all for your kindness and concern. The Wholey Family

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS IN BRIEF
description: THE KING'S SECRET

title: Home of The Koala
description: ''When walking under trees in Australia, watch out for the drop bears,'' Ann Sharp, managing director of the nonprofit Australian Koala Foundation in Brisbane, warns visitors. ''They can fall on you.'' She's then quick to point out that this popular bit of Aussie humor is rubbish.

title: A Flurry of Home Building on Capitol Hill
description: Developers who for the last few years have been working full tilt in other parts of the city have recently set their sights on Capitol Hill, just to the east of the Capitol dome. The architecturally rich community, whose residences range from stately town houses to modest brick row houses, has long been considered an affordable alternative to the better-known Georgetown.

title: James Douglas Halvorson: Meticulous in Work and Play
description: As a managing director at Marsh & McLennan, the insurance brokerage company where he worked for 30 years, James Douglas Halvorson was meticulous in structuring complex deals for construction projects in Pakistan, Indonesia and other third world countries. He was similarly methodical in his pleasures.

title: Joseph E. Maloney: We Hardly Knew Ye
description: You probably think you know Firefighter Joseph E. Maloney. Son of a cop; grandson of a fireman; married forever to Kathy, the pretty, tough- talking nurse; father of Joe, 10, and Megan, 7.

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of yesterday, 4,343 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11.

title: The View From/Hartford; The Spitting Image, If Not Attitude, of Twain
description: HOW is it that John Pogson, a mild-mannered (if slightly sardonic) electric utility inspector from Farmington, now spends a lot of his time portraying Samuel Clemens, the prolific (and very sardonic) author who was best known by his pen name, Mark Twain?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANGE, HERMAN W.W. COL. U.S. ARMY (RET)
description: LANGE-Herman W.W. Col. U.S. Army (Ret), October 18, husband of Liliane S. Lange, father of Gusty Lange Ettlinger, Mary Lou Lange, Karl D. Lange, stepfather of Christian Calcinatto, 2 grandchildren. Donations: Pentagon Relief Fund. Info: 703-549-0074.

title: Huskies Roll to Preseason N.I.T. Title
description: Top-ranked Connecticut appeared to be in for an unusually early challenge last night against third-ranked Vanderbilt in the final of the preseason Women's National Invitation Tournament. As it developed, it was anything but that as the Huskies crushed the Commodores, 69-50, before a capacity crowd of 10,027 at the Gampel Pavilion in Storrs, Conn. The game was even more one-sided than the final score indicated because Vanderbilt's starters scored the last 10 points against UConn's reserves.

title: Less Ice Is Nice
description: In the subdued spirit of the times, Hollywood stars are paring down their carats. Departing from the Russian-archduchess-cum-Dallas-socialite look of last season, the glitterati are favoring a more streamlined, architectural design -- jewelry that actually looks as if the wearer might own it. The sparkler of the moment is a semi-discreet necklace of vertically stacked small diamonds, known as the past, present and future necklace. At the Emmy Awards earlier this month, the host, Ellen DeGeneres (right), wore a version by Roberto Coin ($1,200 to $23,000 at Saks Fifth Avenue); so did the actresses Lauren Graham and Amy Brenneman. Uma Thurman donned it at the Venice Film Festival; Drea de Matteo has also been seen with one in New York.

title: The Philosophy of Love
description: UPHEAVALS OF THOUGHT

title: Travel Advisory; Major British Museums Ending Admission Fees
description: The Victoria and Albert Museum, the Imperial War Museum, the National Maritime Museum and the Museum of London, among other British institutions throughout the country, will soon be free to visitors. The new policy, a result of changes in V.A.T. rules, which now allow museums to reclaim V.A.T. charges on their purchases, is to take effect Dec. 1 except at the Victoria and Albert, where it will begin on Thursday to coincide with the opening of 15 galleries covering British design from 1500 to 1900.

title: Herat and Western Afghanistan Bristle With Arms, Raising Fears
description: At night here, there is the occasional sound of weapons firing, although this city has been completely under Northern Alliance control since Monday. There is no fighting, but there are plenty of arms and they are ready to be discharged in celebration or boredom or by accident.

title: Office Cleaners Seek Pact in Slow Economy
description: CISERON CIRIACO calls himself one of ''las personas invisibles'' -- the invisible people. The 62-year-old New Rochelle resident, who speaks only Spanish and has six grown children, leaves his home for work at 7 each morning. He goes to a shoe repair shop in Port Chester, where he works all day. Then, he goes to an office building in Armonk to clean at night. Getting home at midnight, Mr. Ciriaco sleeps for a few hours before returning to the shoe shop and then, again, to the cleaning.

title: November 11-17; Air Crash in New York
description: American Airlines Flight 587 bound for Santo Domingo plunged into a Queens neighborhood after takeoff from Kennedy Airport, killing all 260 on board and 5 on the ground. The crash stoked fears of a new terrorist attack, but investigators said the evidence suggested an accident. One theory: the plane, an Airbus A300, encountered air turbulence from a preceding jetliner, and movement of the rudder subjected it to catastrophic aerodynamic forces. The tail fin, made of a composite, is also being examined for fatigue; the Federal Aviation Administration planned to require inspections of all Airbus A300's. N. R. Kleinfield

title: No Room For Fear
description: IN 1983, at the age of 19, I joined the Army, fulfilling a longtime goal. Growing up, I believed that our country was free only because someone had protected it.

title: DataBank; Economic News Helps Stocks, Not Bonds
description: Stocks rallied and bonds plunged last week as investors digested some positive reports about the economy. Inflation at the consumer level declined last month, retail sales surged after falling in September, and weekly initial unemployment claims slowed.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-18-01: On Language; Fog of War
description: 'The early days of any battle introduce what's called the fog of war,'' said Andrew Card, White House chief of staff, ''and we're still looking through that fog to find the truth.'' Senator Hillary Clinton used the same military metaphor: ''We need to cut through the bureaucratic and turf battles. . . . We need to cut through the fog of war here at home.''

title: The Costs of Enduring Freedom
description: Last week, the Pentagon released its first formal estimates of the cost thus far of waging war in Afghanistan. The biggest expense: $634 million to deploy more than 50,000 American soldiers, sailors and airmen, three carrier battle groups and more than 400 aircraft into the region. As the United States dispatches more ground troops to hunt down Osama bin Laden, secure and rebuild Afghan airports, and help deliver humanitarian aid, the price of the conflict is expected to rise even beyond the estimated $1 billion a month price tag. Following is brief per-item, per-hour look at why Enduring Freedom doesn't come cheap. JAMES DAO

title: Kate Diana, Patrick Glenn
description: Kate Baldwin Diana, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald S. Diana of Mendham, N.J., was married yesterday to Patrick Leslie Glenn, a son of Dr. Lee S. Glenn and the Rev. Dr. Charles L. Glenn, both of Boston. The bridegroom's father, an Episcopal priest, officiated at Christ Church in Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. Dr. Georgiana Glenn Rodiger, a nondenominational minister and the bridegroom's aunt, took part in the ceremony.

title: Spring Captures IC4A Title
description: Matt Spring, a junior at Manhattan College, won the IC4A championships in 25 minutes 4.60 seconds for five miles at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: Islander Captain Drops Gauntlet for His Team
description: PHOENIX, Nov. 17 — Michael Peca has another fresh cut on his face, but he can live with that. He is much more bothered by the fissures of complacency that have begun to appear around the Islanders, and he sounded late Friday as if he planned to do something about it besides just playing harder.

title: Political Briefing; Speeding Up the Pace Of the Primary Race
description: Over the last quarter of a century, the presidential nominating season has grown shorter and shorter as primaries and caucuses have been held earlier and earlier.

title: In the Bronx, Chrysanthemums Revealed
description: IHAVE never really liked chrysanthemums. Maybe it was all those wrist corsages in high school, where my date and I always wanted to be with someone else. Or those pom-pom flowers, which look like bad party favors.

title: Liberty and Security in the Age of Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: Deals and Discounts
description: It's a long way to Australia, and every incentive helps. Here are a few:

title: Footlights; Next Endowment Chairman
description: President Bush intends to nominate Michael Hammond as the next chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, according to the endowment. Mr. Hammond, dean of the Shepherd School of Music at Rice University in Houston, was the founding dean of music at Purchase College, where he was responsible for planning the original music curriculum. Mr. Hammond also served as president of Purchase, where he instituted the Pepsico Summerfare arts festival.

title: Taliban Holdouts, and Support for Civil Liberties and Afghan Women
description: The eminent American philosopher Yogi Berra is probably little known in Afghanistan, but one of his more famous aphorisms seemed to apply there: it ain't over till it's over. Despite earlier reports that the Taliban were about to give up Kandahar and head for the hills, they were holding onto that southern Afghan city. Up north, in Kunduz, foreigners who had fought for the Taliban, mainly Arabs and Pakistanis, took control brutally and vowed to fight to the death.

title: In Kabul, DVD's and TV's Fill the Shopping Bags; Burkas Sit on the Shelves
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Nov. 17  Two teenage boys spent the day savoring one of the rituals of youth the world over. They cruised the city to see and be seen, to pick up a favorite album, perhaps to shed a bit of adolescent awkwardness.

title: November 11-17; U.S. Attorney Resigns
description: Mary Jo White, the nation's pre-eminent prosecutor of terrorists for the last eight years, said she would step down as United States attorney in Manhattan by the end of the year. A Clinton appointee, Ms. White stayed on during the Bush administration to complete work on the trial of four men charged in the 1998 bombing of American embassies in Africa. All were convicted. Over her objections, the Justice Department recently consolidated prosecution of terrorist cases in Washington. She said she had decided to leave before that. Jane Fritsch

title: 'Milking the Moon'
description: You may think you don't know me, but you have probably seen me on late-night television playing either an outlaw or a hanging judge. During those twenty-three years I lived in Rome, I must have been in over a hundred of those crazy Italian films. I've been a crooked cardinal, a lecherous priest, and a female impersonator, just to name a few. I was Velvet Fingers in Lina WertmÃ?ller's Ballad of Belle Starr. If you've ever seen Fellini's 8 1/2, I'm the tacky American journalist who keeps pestering Marcello Mastroianni with obnoxious questions. And if you haven't seen 8 1/2, you need to: it's one of the great films of this century.

title: Sharon Moore: Laughing at Her Stumbles
description: For all of Sharon Moore's beauty and elegance -- a slender 5 feet, 9 inches, she was a sometime model whose photo was featured in an issue of Esquire -- she lacked a certain physical grace. "She was a very clumsy person," said Barbara Bridges, Ms. Moore's mother. "She was always falling."

title: Five Years After Ouster, Ex-President Returns to Uneasy Alliance
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Nov. 17 (Reuters)  White-bearded and white-turbaned, a professor of Islamic law, Burhanuddin Rabbani returned to Kabul today, five years after his ouster as the nation's president.

title: Paperback Nonfiction
description: This

title: Corrections
description: The acrostic solution on Page 76 of The Times Magazine today is printed in error; it is for today's acrostic. The solution for last Sunday's will be found in this section, on Page A34.

title: An Insider Shadow Looms Over a Stock's Party
description: ANYONE nostalgic for the heady days of the tech stock bubble can rest assured: pockets of euphoria do remain. A quick consultation with investing chat rooms shows that speculation is alive and well.

title: Thomas Farino: The Gift of Strength
description: Capt. Thomas Farino was the rock on which his wife, Mary, built her life. He was the baby in a family of six boys, sons of a New York City policeman. He was captain of Engine Company 26 in Manhattan, doing a job he loved. He was posthumously promoted to battalion chief.

title: The Banality of Evil (Cont.)
description: INTERROGATIONS

title: At War With Himself
description: THE COMPLETE WORKS OF ISAAC BABEL

title: Nets Get a Big Crowd and Put on a Show
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 17 — In the eighth game of their improbable season, the Nets took another step into the surreal when they trounced the local favorite Knicks by 26 points Friday night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, VERNON
description: SMITH-Vernon. On November 15, 2001. Born in 1918 on the Island of Trinidad. Beloved husband of Jane. Loving father of Bernadette, Carmen and Vernon Anthony. You will always be remembered with great respect and love. Your family and friends, SGMKJ

title: A Beverage That Tastes Good Till the Last Bite
description: The black pearls of Taiwan pass through United States Customs. Then they are sold on the open market at trendy modern tea bars in Chinatown, where they settle at the bottom of glasses of bubble tea.

title: Streetscapes/Richard Haas; Recalling a Quarter Century of Illusion on City Walls
description: THE CITY IS MY CANVAS,'' proclaims the new monograph of the work of Richard Haas, the illusionistic artist who since the 1970's has produced a virtual city in paint on blank building walls. The book, published by Prestel, inventories the giant trompe l'oeil murals throughout the United States that this innovative artist has created in the last quarter century. Now, where he once had acres of blank urban canvas, Mr. Haas often finds that his art must compete with advertising, but he still walks the streets with even more ambitious ideas.

title: Excerpts from 'How to Be a Domestic Goddess' by Nigella Lawson
description: Pies

title: All in the Family
description: Kathleen Norris begins THE HOLY TWINS: Benedict and Scholastica (Putnam, $16.99; ages 5 to 9), the intertwined history of Benedict and his twin sister, Scholastica, on their noble family's farm in the idyllic hills of fifth-century northern Italy, where the two are the best of friends, save for squabbling when ''Benedict would make up too many rules for their games and Scholastica would laugh and ignore them.''

title: The Mellow, and Undying, Magic of Happy Little Trees
description: A TELLING measure of the success of ''The Joy of Painting,'' the hypnotic half-hour show in which the endearingly goofy Bob Ross unfailingly produced a kitschy canvas, was what happened in Holland in 1997. After all, it's one thing to ask people to watch an artist paint on television -- like ''an invitation to watch someone grow cobwebs,'' as Walt Kowalski, the president of Bob Ross Inc., said recently. It's quite another to ask them to listen to a man paint on the radio.

title: Dana Chipkin, Matthew Hiltzik
description: Dana Meredith Chipkin, a daughter of Wendy and Jan A. Chipkin of Parkland, Fla., is to be married today in Pearl River, N.Y., to Matthew Jonathan Hiltzik, a son of Linda and George J. Hiltzik of Teaneck, N.J. Rabbi Kenneth Hain is to officiate at the Hilton Pearl River.

title: Travel Advisory; Touring San Diego By Land and By Sea
description: Old Town Trolley Tours of San Diego now takes visitors to sights on water as well as land with new 49-passenger Hydra-Terra amphibious vehicles. Its 90-minute Sea and Land Adventures on San Diego Bay and Mission Bay, with about half that time spent on the water, cover Seaport Village, Old Town and Shelter Island, and offer views of the North Island Naval Air Station in Coronado, Point Loma, SeaWorld and the San Diego skyline.

title: The Nation; The Vote Count Omits A Verdict on the Court
description: THEORETICALLY, the Supreme Court had a lot at stake in the report last week, based on a news media consortium's count of all the disputed Florida ballots, that George W. Bush would have won the 2000 presidential election even had the court not cut the final recount short.

title: Correspondence/Inside Afghanistan; In a Wasteland, Casual Brutality And Acts of Startling Kindness
description: A LITTLE more than a year ago, I stood at the Khyber Pass a prisoner, escorted to the Pakistani border by a Taliban guard. His hand gripped my arm, and I was being officially expelled. It had been a nasty little episode, replete with preposterous allegations, and when my escort finally let me go I turned to deliver a parting shot.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 4 about Leonard Bernstein's Columbia recordings of Mahler symphonies referred incorrectly to Wilhelm Furtwngler's relationship with the works. Although Furtwngler did not record any of the symphonies, he indeed performed several, early in his career.

title: The Nation: What Price Security?; Testing the Resilience of American Values
description: WHEN President Bush signed an executive order allowing foreigners suspected of international terrorism to be tried in special military tribunals, many on the right as well as the left complained that he had seized dictatorial power and betrayed basic American values of liberty and equality. But in fact, those values have proved to be both malleable and resilient over the course of American history, and their most reliable defenders have been the American people rather than judges interpreting unalterable principles of law.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, OGDEN NORTHROP, JR.
description: LEWIS-Ogden Northrop, Jr. Suddenly on November 14, 2001, at age 22. Cherished son of Ogden and Susan Lewis, adored nephew of Margaret Patterson High and William Hall Lewis, III. Beloved by countless friends. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory to The Buckley School, 113 East 73 Street, New York, New York 10021, or Groton School, Box 991, Groton, Massachusetts 01450, would be greatly appreciated. Funeral arrangements incomplete.

title: A Lotus-Friendly Clothing Line By an Irvington-Based Designer
description: For Eileen Fisher, the Irvington-based women's clothing designer who has built her nationwide business on the idea that clothes can be beautifully made, stylish and comfortable, the recent decision to develop a relationship with Yoga Journal is a natural extension of her philosophy. This fall she introduced yoga pants suitable for wear outside the gym.

title: Bright Lights, Big City
description: FAIR WEATHER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHULMAN, MAX L.
description: SHULMAN-Max L. Passed away peacefully in his 93rd year on November 10, 2001. Beloved husband and life partner for 63 years of Sylvia (nee Weinstein). Proud father of Lloyd J. & Gail Koster. Loving grandfather of Melinda and Jonathan Koster. Caring brother of Ethel Weiss. He retired as Chairman of the Board of J.W. Mays Department Stores after six decades of loyal and dedicated service. He will be mourned and remembered by those many charitable, philanthropic and educational organizations to which he dedicated much of his time and resources, on his own behalf, on behalf of his wife Sylvia, in the name of his children and his late fatherin-law, Joe Weinstein. He received Distinguished Service Awards and personal recognition from many, many organizations, among them: the Weizmann Institute, the Israel Museum where he was a founder; the Joe Weinstein Center for Medical Research at Shenkar College, the Brookdale Hospital and the Boy Scouts of America. He was a Director of the Menorah Home For The Aged. Contributions in his memory may be made to: NYU Medical Center Department of Medicine, Program for Preventative Cardiology; NYU Medical Center Department of Urology; the American Committee For The Weizmann Institute; and the Menorah Home For The Aged.

title: November 11-17; Setback for Heart Patient
description: For 130 days, Robert Tools's recovery as the first of five recipients of a self-contained artificial heart was faster and less eventful than his doctors at Jewish Hospital in Louisville had hoped. The experimental AbioCor device beat flawlessly more than 22 million times. But Mr. Tools, 59, who had reacted badly to anticoagulents that help prevent blood clots, suffered a stroke from a clot that may have come from the device. His prognosis was uncertain, his doctors said. Lawrence K. Altman

title: Thierry Saada: Bellybutton Melodies
description: When Thierry Saada came to New York in 1999 from Paris, he sublet Delphine Zana's apartment through mutual friends in the Sephardic Jewish community. Both their families were originally from Tunisia, but moved to France after Tunisian independence. Mr. Saada was tall, handsome, and "sportif," she said, and they fell in love.

title: Edward R. Vanacore: A Sunset Hog in the Rain
description: Eddie Vanacore had a smile that made everyone around him happy. He was also the youngest of six, and he learned early to be persistent in getting what he wanted. "He was a pain in the neck," said his brother John, the next oldest in the family.

title: Tools for Brushing Up
description: The first installment of the makeup guru Kevyn Aucoin's first line of cosmetics and cosmetic tools came out last week, along with his Web site, www.kevynaucoin.com. The cornerstones of his collection are mascaras in black and burgundy ($25 each), an eyelash curler ($18.50) and a lacquer kit of 12 brushes ($350). Come December, Mr. Aucoin will offer limited-edition Lucite boxes containing all three products.

title: Seeking Truth And Beauty In a Plastic Frog
description: USING a pressurized spray gun the size of a fountain pen, Miguel Luciano turned the plastic coqui frog from green to brown. This coqui, with its sky-blue saddle and big blue eyes, was part of a children's automated ride, the kind that squats outside barbershops and bodegas, eating quarters and bobbing to a tinny tune.

title: Faith, Tested and Abiding
description: SUSAN BAROSSI of Yonkers came to the Zion Episcopal Church in Dobbs Ferry for her friend Michael Lepore's funeral in late September. Raised in the Roman Catholic church but hardly a regular attendee at services, she has since then found herself in the pews of Zion nearly every Sunday.

title: The World; Leasing, if not Building, an Anti-Taliban Coalition
description: LOGIC might dictate that impoverished Pakistan, perhaps the world's leading supporter of Afghanistan's Taliban regime until Sept. 11, would not rank high in the Washington's eyes these days. Of course, logic would be wrong.

title: Enchanted City
description: TRIESTE AND THE MEANING OF NOWHERE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHAN, MYRA
description: KAHAN-Myra. Of Fire Island Pines, NY, and Edgewater, NJ, on November 12, 2001. A humanitarian, a philanthropist, a spokesperson for the rights of pets and worked to rescue and reunite lost or abandoned animals. Survived by Cappy Hanlan-Proud of her mother and guided by Myra to the many windows of the World. A memorial will be held at The Pines on July 14, 2002. To share happy memories of Myra at her home at 1 Shore Rd, Edgewater, NJ, (Call 201-969-9633 for directions), on November 26 from 5-9 P.M. Donations in Myra's memory should be made to PAWS, Box 894 Sayville, NY 11782.

title: In Belle Harbor, Nightmares Never Seems to End
description: BERNIE HEERAN knew something was going to happen. He just knew it, and had been saying so for the last few weeks.

title: The Genuine Article
description: Authentic Turkish Cuisine, 8011 Centennial Boulevard, Voorhees. (856) 489-1212. Hours: Mondays through Thursdays, 11 a.m. to 9:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 11 p.m.; Sundays, 3 to 9:30 p.m.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION & POETRY
description: ARIA

title: Sorenstam Has Rough Finish; Webb Doesn't
description: When Annika Sorenstam reflects on the greatest moments of her career, she will not include today's 18th hole.

title: Travel Advisory; Wildlife Museum Mixes Conservation, Hunting
description: Conservation of natural resources, the importance of fish and other wildlife, and the country's heritage of hunting and fishing are the focus of the American National Fish and Wildlife Museum, an interactive museum and aquarium that opened in Springfield, Mo., this month. It houses 160 live animal species, including mammals, birds, reptiles, amphibians, fish and insects.

title: All Suicide Bombers Are Not Alike
description: The bottom line, stripped of rationalizations and rhetoric, is that the al-Masawabi family of Gaza traded a son for a brand-new apartment with plastic grapevines. The mother of the suicide bomber says that she hopes her other children will ''do the same.'' Perhaps in the hope of an even bigger apartment? If it is so glorious to be a martyr, why don't the parents blow themselves up instead of allowing their impressionable children to do so?

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-18-01: Questions for Mario Vargas Llosa; Dictating History
description: Q: Your new novel, ''The Feast of the Goat,'' gives us a dictator, the late Gen. Rafael Trujillo of the Dominican Republic, who is all too human -- in some ways sympathetic or pathetic, maybe.

title: Ronnie Lee Henderson: An Abundance of Family
description: He may have been earning a fireman's salary, but Ronnie Lee Henderson planned all along to turn that into more. He pared money from his paycheck and put it into bonds and mutual funds. In the quiet hours at the Engine Company 279 firehouse in Red Hook, he could be found reading books with titles like "How to Make Money Buying and Selling Houses."

title: 2 Deaths Narrow Focus on Child Welfare Agency's Changes and Limits
description: On the surface, the two child abuse cases have a terrible symmetry.

title: Beyond the Khyber Pass
description: REAPING THE WHIRLWIND

title: A Nation Challenged
description: After the Taliban

title: November 11-17; Terrorism's Troubadours
description: The Sept. 11 attacks have filtered into popular culture everywhere, even in corridos, the twangy ballads of northern Mexico. The music of corridos is traditional, but their lyrics tell gripping, contemporary tales: the exploits of borderland drug lords, say, or the travails of migrants to El Norte. Following are translated excerpts of two of the most recent. SIMON ROMERO

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOPKINS, JAMES E. (JAY)
description: HOPKINS-James E. (Jay). Died September 6th, 2001. A gathering to celebrate Mr. Hopkins' life will be held on December 5th at 6:30 PM in the Chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, 7 W. 55th St., NYC 10019. In lieu of flowers, donations can be sent to Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church or Maverick Concerts, attn: Vincent Wagner, Woodstock, NY 12498.

title: Political Briefing; Louisiana Apathy: The Ebb and Flow
description: In Louisiana, there is bad political news and good political news, according to a recent poll.

title: 'Upheavals of Thought'
description: Emotions shape the landscape of our mental and social lives. Like the "geological upheavals" a traveler might discover in a landscape where recently only a flat plane could be seen, they mark our lives as uneven, uncertain, and prone to reversal. Why and how? Is it because emotions are animal energies or impulses that have no connection with our thoughts, imaginings, and appraisals? Proust denies this, calling the emotions "geological upheavals of thought." In other words, what changes the Baron's mind from a flat plane into a mountain range is not some subterranean jolt, but the thoughts he has about Charlie Morel, a person who has suddenly become central to his well-being, and whom he sees as inscrutable, undependable, and utterly beyond his control. It is these thoughts about value and importance that make his mind project outward like a mountain range, rather than sitting inert in self-satisfied ease.

title: Family Tree
description: THE SWEET HELL INSIDE

title: Seconds From a Shutout, Ranger Rookie Is Beaten
description: The rookie goaltender Dan Blackburn provided the Rangers with three periods of shutout hockey tonight for the first time since Feb. 26, 1999. Still, it was not enough for the Rangers to extend their winning streak to seven games.

title: O Pioneers!
description: A VOICE FROM

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSE, JOHN LEWIS
description: GROSE-John Lewis. Of Locust Valley, NY, on October 25, 2001 at age 88. Loving husband of the late Barbara Houston. He is survived by a son, Peter Lewis, a daughter, Judith Grose-Johnson, by nine grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. A second son, John Francis, passed away in October 1999. Service will be held at 11 AM on Saturday, November 24th, at All Saints Episcopal Church in Great Neck.

title: Shops Near Ground Zero Were Insured, but Not Enough
description: Samuel Castro had insurance in case a customer had an accident in his Lower Manhattan hat store. But he did not have insurance to cover damage to his inventory or sales losses inflicted by a disaster. Carrying such insurance, he says, would have cost too much.

title: What Stirred Young Chefs to Excel
description: STARS are born, it is often said. But great chefs are made. It is only after the pressure of performing at a consistent level of excellence for knowledgeable patrons and demanding head chefs that a young chef becomes a star.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOWIE, JANET W.
description: BOWIE-Janet W. Of New Hyde Park, on November 13, 2001 in her 93rd year. Beloved wife of the late John. Loving mother of Bruce and mother-in-law of Carol. Beloved grandmother of John. Loving sister of Jean. Loving friend of Eileen & Jamie. A memorial mass will be held Saturday, November 24, 2001 at 2 PM at The Church of the Transfiguration, 1 East 29th Street, New York, New York. For information please contact the New Hyde Park Funeral Home, New Hyde Park, New York.

title: Elizabeth Durant, Adam Waxer
description: Elizabeth A. Durant, a daughter of Trudy and Cary S. Durant of Edison, N.J., was married last evening to Adam Scott Waxer, a son of Barbara and Philip A. Waxer of East Meadow, N.Y. Cantor Lisa R. Hest, a cousin of the bride, officiated at the Rockleigh Country Club in Rockleigh, N.J.

title: Easing the Pain of Recession
description: Economists have begun to agree that what we are now calling a recession began as long ago as last March. This will not be news to the people likeliest to be hurt by any economic downturn those who work close to the economic bone. They have been feeling the sting of things for a long time now. A paycheck-to-paycheck existence is always a precarious one, and especially when the paycheck is barely sufficient. All across this city, hard-working families have found that hard work just isn't enough. As the economy has soured, even the most basic aspirations of many families -- decent shelter and food, education, medical care -- have become impossibilities.

title: Love and War and Taking the Train
description: In the first year of my life, I made my first journey, carried in the arms of my father on a weeklong wartime cross-country train ride from Charleston, S.C., to San Francisco. It was 1945. He was being transferred by the Coast Guard, with instructions to await further orders. My mother had insisted on going with him, and taking the baby too, because she thought it might be the last she'd see of him. She was 25, he was 30. There was no direct route; they had to travel north to Chicago, change stations and catch a second train westward. Occasionally a dining car was added, but it quickly disappeared, and at every stop passengers streamed from the train in search of food. My mother was scared and exhausted. She got sick and couldn't eat at all, too weak to hold the baby. Every time my father rushed into a depot looking for milk, I lay next to her, propped by luggage.

title: Charles Mathers: In Crisis or Comedy
description: Here is the man you want in a crisis: while everyone squawks, he is listening. A great bear of a fellow, his eyes bright blue and calm, white- haired head nodding, he says, "Hmmmm." Then, "I'll take care of it." And he does.

title: His Worst Critic Proved Wrong
description: IN 1962, Bob Dylan visited John Cohen at his Manhattan loft on lower Third Avenue. As a member (playing banjo and guitar) of the New Lost City Ramblers, a group devoted to performing American music as it sounded before the pervasive influence of radio and the record industry, Mr. Cohen had released several albums on the Folkways label. He was also a photographer with an assignment to take a portrait of Mr. Dylan, who had put out his first record that year. ''Bob didn't think much of the photographs, and his management didn't like them,'' Mr. Cohen recalls. ''I put them away.''

title: Seeking Guideposts to Help in No-Man's Land
description: The questions keep coming: How do you deal with Holocaust flashbacks? Can you hold a memorial Mass for a body part? What do you say to scores of angry widows?

title: BackTalk; Nothing Resolved, Everything Changed
description: Thirty-five years ago, on a windswept Saturday in East Lansing, Mich., a diabetic Notre Dame substitute quarterback named Coley O'Brien fell with the football and ended the most talked about game in college football history, not with a bang but with a whimper.

title: What's Doing in Munich
description: Munich takes special pleasure in the Christmas season, although Oktoberfest may be the Bavarian capital's most famous festival. Many of the holiday traditions familiar to Americans, like decorating Christmas trees and baking fruitcake, originated in this region, and there are few better places to get in the seasonal spirit. Nativity scenes, carolers and stalls selling gingerbread abound.

title: In a World of Water, Finding Pleasure In Many Forms
description: ON the finger of land that is Long Island, 24 miles wide at its widest point, a bay, sound or ocean is never far away. Other bodies of water, the source of different pleasures, can be even closer to home.

title: A Star Point Guard With the 'Intangibles'
description: Ask Iona Prep basketball coach Vic Quirolo about his star point guard Christopher Murphy and he will not talk first about the points the player makes nor the assists he contributes to what is expected to be a standout team in the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association this season.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-18-01; Other Woes
description: I've been wondering lately what multiculturalism was. I remember, of course, that it was a cause clbre of the 80's and 90's, a big deal on campus, a hot ticket at the Modern Language Association. I remember all the talk about overthrowing the ''dead white males'' of the old canon and opening it up to the ''subaltern'' and the ''displaced'' and the ''other.'' And I figure that along the way it got some good writers included on reading lists, where they should have been in the first place, and some good writers dropped too. What it apparently did not do was promote the study of other languages, or indeed of other cultures.

title: Now Boarding, Dreams
description: AS American Airlines Flight 587 to Santo Domingo plunged into a row of well-tended houses on a quiet middle-class street in Belle Harbor, Queens, killing 260 people on board and 5 others on the ground, another American Airlines flight to the Dominican Republic was en route to a much happier ending.

title: 'Who Is This Kafka That People Keep Mentioning?'
description: This is a time of national crisis in which Al Bader al-Hazmi's 13-day detainment, while regrettable, is understandable (Deborah Sontag, Oct. 21). The perpetrators of Sept. 11 were all Arab Muslims from Egypt, Saudi Arabia and elsewhere in the Middle East but residing here. We must do everything in our power to follow the letter of the law and, above all, treat people with respect. But to not make use of ethnic profiling in this investigation would be irresponsible, if not deadly.

title: Things That Go Bump, Growl and Glubita
description: A RUMPUS

title: Hoping That Holiday Trees Will Change a Now Bleak View
description: In Greenwich Village, as in many parts of the city, there are streets whose views were once dominated by the twin towers. Looking south along Seventh Avenue, Robert Rinaolo once saw little else. The towers used to be the postcard backdrop to the cafe he owns, the Garage Restaurant and Cafe on Seventh Avenue South near West Fourth Street.

title: Isles' Osgood and Snow Take Turns Missing Puck
description: Chris Osgood was so bad in goal tonight that Garth Snow replaced him 12 minutes 28 seconds into the first period. Snow was so bad that Osgood replaced him more than seven minutes after that. It was lucky for the Islanders that goaltenders are not like pitchers, banished to the showers after a bad stint.

title: Bush Team Is Reversing Environmental Policies
description: In the last two months, the Bush administration has proceeded with several regulations, legal settlements and legislative measures intended to reverse Clinton-era environmental policies.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION & POETRY
description: THE DEADWOOD BEETLE

title: American Ramadan
description: Less than a year ago, Attorney General John Ashcroft's confirmation was nearly derailed when a videotape surfaced that showed Mr. Ashcroft confidently asserting, ''We have no king but Jesus.'' At the time, some questioned whether he could sufficiently carry out his duties when he seemed to favor Christianity over other religions, a favoritism prohibited by the First Amendment.

title: Prayer Warriors Fight Church-State Division
description: Jason Clark, 17, a junior at Thornton Township High School, stood at the chalkboard in Room 202, thumbing through his Bible as about 30 students stood silently, eyes closed and heads bowed.

title: What the Muslim World Is Watching
description: Al Jazeera is not subtle television. Recently, during a lull in its nonstop coverage of the raids on Kabul and the street battles of Bethlehem, the Arabic-language satellite news station showed an odd but telling episode of its documentary program ''Biography and Secrets.'' The show's subject was Ernesto (Che) Guevara. Presenting Che as a romantic, doomed hero, the documentary recounted the Marxist rebel's last stand in the remote mountains of Bolivia, lingering mournfully over the details of his capture and execution. Even Che's corpse received a lot of airtime; Al Jazeera loves grisly footage and is never shy about presenting graphic imagery.

title: Czech Journalists Face Pressure to Curb Criticism
description: Comic-strip characters do not usually have the power to shake real-life governments, but when Karel Brezina, a 29-year-old-Czech government minister, saw himself depicted in a satirical strip in one of the country's leading weekly magazines earlier this year, he sued.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUELLER, CLAIRE
description: MUELLER-Claire. Devoted wife of the late Herbert Mueller. Loving mother of Julian and the late Gladys. Beloved grandmother of Amy, Andrew, Jeffrey, Joel, Jonathan and Nicole, and greatgrandmother of 6, died November 15, 2001 at 87. Graveside service at 11:00 A.M. Monday, November 19th at the New Mount Carmel Cemetery, Glendale, NY.

title: In Religious Schools, Children Put Faith to Work for Others
description: AT South Presbyterian Church in Dobbs Ferry, the congregation's children recently planted spring flowering bulbs on the front lawn. Fourth graders at Temple Beth Abraham in Tarrytown ran a mitzvah fair to raise money for victims of the World Trade Center attacks. Seventh graders at the Presbyterian Church of Mount Kisco offered a shoe-shine service, which raised $1,000 for a charity for Afghan children and the Bereavement Center of Westchester. Students at the Holy Rosary Church in Hawthorne are raising money for a family in their parish who lost its father on Sept. 11.

title: A New Generation Gap?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STALLMAN, DANIEL J.
description: STALLMAN-Daniel J., 77. Died November 14, 2001. Predeceased by his parents Frieda Kranz & Charles Stallman. and son Adam S. Stallman. Survived by his wife Ada Stallman of Binghamton, NY; son Richard M. Stallman, Cambridge, MA; daughter Claudia E. Stallman, Christine M. Coveney & grandson Benjamin A. Stallman all of Binghamton, New York. Dear husband, father, grandfather and friend. Graveside services Sunday, November 18 at 12:30 PM at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Queens, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations to Simon Wiesenthal Center, Tribute Dept, 1399 South Roxbury, Los Angeles, CA. 90035.

title: Cedar Grove Uses Rare Pass To Advance to Title Game
description: Quarterback Tim Palek struggled for much of the game yesterday, but when Cedar Grove needed a completion the most, he came through.

title: Private Sector; Call Him the Sam Walton Of the Casino Industry
description: They may not mean the economy is improving, but gamblers are returning to Harrah's Entertainment Inc., says Philip G. Satre, the chief executive. Many regular customers at its 21 casinos around the country -- largely middle-class, recreational gamblers in their 50's and 60's -- are using promotional discounts offered since Sept. 11. ''Business is pretty good,'' he said. Unlike some of the fancier casinos dependent on high rollers, Mr. Satre said, Harrah's has even done a bit of recruiting from among thousands of workers laid off by rivals. And for those snobs who call Harrah's the Wal-Mart of casinos, Mr. Satre said, ''I love the comparison. It doesn't bother me one bit.''

title: The Fourth R: Remembering Good Teachers
description: THERE is much talk about heroes these days.

title: Is Youssouf Mal A Slave?
description: Editors' Note Appended

title: More Office Space Going Empty in the County
description: The already weakened office market in Westchester dropped further during the third quarter of the year, according to a report from Insignia/ESG, commercial real estate services providers.

title: For the Man With a 15.95-Inch Neck
description: NOT since Yankee Doodle stuck a feather in his hat 225 years ago and called it macaroni -- a derogatory reference to London's Macaroni Club, decadent young fops who had traveled in Italy and adopted its tastes -- has Italian style held such sway in the wardrobes of American men.

title: Constance Thomas, Douglas Genn
description: Constance Campbell Thomas, a daughter of Susan and Norman Mattoon Thomas III of Annapolis, Md., was married yesterday to Douglas Moore Genn, a son of Therese and John Genn of Plainsboro, N.J. The Rev. Thomas Guthrie Speers III, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Elkridge Club in Baltimore.

title: Tennessee Williams Did Have Some Bad Days
description: ALL the best playwrights have their own hidden stockpile of worst plays. And ''Kingdom of Earth'' is arguably among the worst plays of Tennessee Williams, who is, inarguably, one of the best American playwrights of the last century, if not of all time.

title: Hardcover Advice
description: This

title: Salvatore Gitto: Spirit in the Sky
description: The Gitto family did everything as a unit. They raked leaves together. They painted together. They fixed lights together. And everyone piled into the car for trips to the supermarket.

title: Giving History Some Flesh and Blood
description: AUGUSTA GAYNOR, the grande dame of Deepwells, is accustomed to receiving the world's rich and famous. After all, at one time or another, John Barrymore, Fanny Brice, Coco Chanel, Annie Oakley, Mary Pickford, Harry Houdini, Mae West and Madam C. J. Walker have sat down in her elegant Victorian parlor for a cup of tea.

title: Brooklyn Man Charged in Baby's Death
description: A Brooklyn man has been arrested in connection with the death of his girlfriend's 15-month-old son, the police said yesterday.

title: Civil Liberty vs. Security: Finding a Wartime Balance
description: The recent expansion of executive power in the legal fight against terrorism reflects a powerful conviction in the Bush administration that it is fighting acts of war, not mere crimes, on American soil.

title: How to Spot the Classics in the Crowd of Modern Dance
description: AFTER a day spent rehearsing, Carla Maxwell, the artistic director of the Limn Dance Company, recently took time to show a visitor a videotape of the choreographer Doris Humphrey's radiant dance ''Invention.'' Set to a score by Norman Lloyd and created in 1949, it is receiving its first performance in 40 years during the troupe's current season at the Joyce Theater, ending next Sunday.

title: Take My Queen, Please
description: THE ROYAL PHYSICIAN'S VISIT

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCHBERG, ANNE G.
description: HIRSCHBERG-Anne G. On November 12, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin. Loving aunt of Michael Helioff, Carole Greenberg and Irwin Zuckermendel. Great aunt of Scott Helioff and Don and Diana Greenberg. Past president of the Woodstock Artists Association. Listed in ''Who's Who in American Art''.

title: When a Cyberstar Is Born
description: THANKS to digital technology, movies are no longer the same medium they were a decade ago. The rapid evolution in sound and imaging software has transformed filmed entertainment from the bottom up, removing the assurance that what the camera sees is, was, or is remotely related to something real. Seeing is no longer believing, even to the tiny degree it once was.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORMAN, JOSEPH J.
description: HORMAN-Joseph J. Of Kingwood, TX, formerly of New York, on November 12. Born in East New York, Brooklyn, Mr. Horman chose to leave the relative security of the family business to serve as a member of New York's Finest, the NYPD. His meteoric rise from rookie cop at Manhattan's 14th Precinct during the '60s to Lieutenant Detective in the early '70s, during which he led a massive crackdown upon organized crime involved in pornography, resulted in the William Sherman book entitled Times Square, which chronicled the harsh realities behind the lights and glitter of Broadway during the Koch administration. He is survived by his mother Winifred Jackman Horman of Glen Head, NY, wife Arlene, daughter Katherine and son Joseph Jr. He is also survived by his brothers Nicholas Horman of Oyster Bay, NY, Ronald Horman of Locust Valley, NY, and Douglas Horman of Deerfield Beach, FL.

title: If Only Lawrence Welk Had Gone Electric; Life at an Accordion Shop Is Just a Bit Slow
description: The other day, something unusual happened in Walter Kuehr's shop.

title: To Save a Stream, the Old-Fashioned Way
description: To the Editor:

title: Heather Higgins, Jonathan Daly
description: Heather Higgins and Jonathan Giles Daly were married yesterday by Msgr. Lawrence Connaughton at St. Joseph's Church Yorkville in Manhattan.

title: Cancn Dreaming: Will a Sleepy Town Be Next?
description: GERALD G. BARTON, an American developer of golf courses, received an invitation from Mexico last summer to consider building a few courses along the virgin coasts of Loreto, a sleepy town of 12,000 between the Sierra de la Giganta and the Gulf of California.

title: A Wiser but Still Absurd Kind of Guy
description: STEVE MARTIN has a comic's confidence in his voice. Before he abandoned stand-up to do movies -- he walked away in the late 1970's like a man suddenly bored with an addiction -- he used the velvety drape of that voice as counterpoint to his berserk stage persona. On film, he uses it to project a Chamber of Commerce faith that people will listen to him no matter what he has to say -- which works when he plays characters whose complacent authority makes them slightly insufferable, like the brain surgeon Michael Hfuhruhurr in ''The Man with Two Brains'' (1983) or the dentist Frank Sangster in Mr. Martin's latest movie, ''Novocaine,'' a black farce from what can only be called the James M. Cain school of dental hygiene.

title: A Long-Distance Legend Who's Lapped the Field
description: FRANK SINATRA, who later called him the best singer in the business, pegged Tony Bennett at the start of his career with a phrase too colorful to print here, implying he had a brass neck, nerves of steel, colossal chutzpah -- that kind of thing. Sinatra was probably thinking of Mr. Bennett's dynamic, over-the-top attack and vocal range, but he proved more discerning than he knew.

title: 21st-Century Jihad
description: HOLY WAR, INC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBINSON, HUBERT S. (ROBBIE)
description: ROBINSON-Hubert S. (Robbie) 1919-2001. In loving memory of a cherished friend and colleague. Robbie will be remembered by the former production staff of Dell-Publishing Co. for his wisdom, patience and humanity. Our deepest sympathy to his loving family, wife Evelyn, daughters, Karen, Donna, Margi and Colleen, their partners and children. Memorial donations may be made to the Ralph T. Waterman Bird Club C/O Allan Michelin, 23 High View Road, Wappingers Falls, NY 12590. Diana Papasergiou Giuseppone

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a review on Nov. 4 about two books dealing with the life of John F. Kennedy referred erroneously to ''The Kennedy Women,'' an earlier book by one author, Laurence Leamer. It has not been made into a television movie.

title: Limousine Services Look Beyond Airports
description: The airlines are not alone in facing a decline in business travel since Sept. 11; some limousine companies that shuttle executives to and from the airports have been hurt, too. But at least two car services see a potentially profitable alternative: taking business travelers to their final destinations.

title: Footlights; MusicAmerica Award Winner
description: The Westchester Philharmonic has announced that Harry O. Bright Jr., executive director of the White Plains Commission on Human Rights, will receive the 2002 MusicAmerica Lifetime Achievement Award. The award will be presented at the 10th anniversary MusicAmerica concert, an annual tribute to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. that will be held Jan. 19 at 7:30 p.m. at the Performing Arts Center of Purchase College.

title: Setting the Standard When It Comes to Big Beef
description: REMEMBER cholesterol? Apparently not, if Long Island's steakhouse boom is any indication. It was not that long ago when boors at cocktail parties spent more time boasting about their HDL-LDL ratios than their children's SAT. scores. Local sibyls were announcing the demise of the steakhouse.

title: The Original Tree Hugger
description: JOHNNY APPLESEED

title: Spanish Food by a Fireplace in Mt. Kisco
description: AUTUMN leaves threatened to obscure the serpentine road up to La Camelia here, but workers with leaf blowers cleared the way for guests. It would be a pity if the path to this cozy destination were lost, for what it offers is a welcome snuggle on a cold winter's night. Reserve a table next to the fireplace for toasty toes and cheeks.

title: Albert C. Todd, 74, Professor and Translator
description: Albert C. Todd, a professor of European languages and literatures who edited and translated poetry by his friend the Russian poet Yevgeny Yevtushenko, interpreted for him and once physically defended him from attackers, died on Nov. 9 in a Queens nursing home. He was 74 and lived in Flushing.

title: From the Sublime To the Aerobic
description: YES, they had faces then -- and voices and bodies and personalities that thrilled you. Some even had character, the temperamental complexity that keeps you speculating about a performer long after the curtains have come down. The words ''golden age'' tend to give me a pain; they're an easy way to express our longing for simpler, more familiar things and our wish to punish what confounds or alienates us. Some performers and works are golden, though -- sublime, deluxe, the top.

title: The Last Casualty
description: FOR ROUENNA

title: The Works Curators Covet
description: NEXT time you're feeling fidgety in a museum, try playing a game called If You Could. The rules are simple: after meandering through a gallery, turn to the person you're with and ask, ''If you could have any piece in this room, what would it be?'' The question is guaranteed to jolt you from passive appreciation to active engagement, sparking a lively discussion of style, color and personal taste.

title: November 11-17; Congress Reaches Airport Security Compromise
description: Congress, which began debating how to beef up aviation security shortly after Sept. 11, passed a bill that President Bush said he would sign tomorrow just in time for the busiest travel season of the year. The federal government will have one year to hire 28,000 airport screeners, replacing employees of private security companies, many of whom receive little training and earn low wages. The bill also calls for the inspection of all checked baggage, the reinforcement of cockpit doors and a significant increase in the number of sky marshals. Robert Pear

title: 78 Acres With a Lot of Potential
description: IF there were a county capital for fizzled plans, it would be Davids Island. Situated a half-mile off the New Rochelle coast, the uninhabited 78-acre island, with views of Manhattan, has been the object of numerous redevelopment plans over the last three decades. Each one has failed in the face of fierce opposition from the New Rochelle public, but now, with great hope, officials have announced one more.

title: Peter A. Vega: Always Ready to Help
description: Regan Grice-Vega was pregnant and was on the way to the doctor for a checkup with her husband, Peter Vega, when they spotted a car stalled on the side of the road. In it was a woman who had been rushing to the hospital to see her husband, who had had a heart attack. Mr. Vega pushed her car to a safe spot and then drove her to the hospital.

title: Frugal Traveler; Digesting Guangzhou In Bite-Size Pieces
description: ON the train from Hong Kong to Guangzhou, China, I daydreamed of dumplings. Fat, puffy ones, baseball-size, stuffed with tangy minced pork. Glossy transparent Ping-Pong balls filled with crunchy water chestnuts and peanuts. Bite-size mouthfuls of shrimp, squid and chicken wrapped in thin rice dough.

title: Corrections
description: Arts & Leisure

title: All Suicide Bombers Are Not Alike
description: What is most chilling is not the ease with which young men are indoctrinated to become suicide bombers but the feelings of pride and honor of the parents who want their sons to become martyrs by murdering innocent people -- young and old, men, women and children.

title: A Certain Look The Camera Sold
description: IN the 1920's, technology and business boomed in America. Production, media and advertising all gave new meaning to the word ''mass.'' A complete Model T Ford rolled off the line every 24 seconds. Movie attendance climbed from 60 million in 1927 to 90 million in 1930. Magazines, newspapers and radio reached unprecedented audiences; so did fashion. Both mass and elite publications covered haute couture extensively, while the manufacture of ready-made clothing leaped ahead. Vogue and Harper's Bazaar, locked in a duel, both surged in circulation.

title: Political Briefing; Some Question Run By Katherine Harris
description: Katherine Harris, Florida's secretary of state and a center-stage player in last year's presidential vote dispute, has been the favorite to succeed Representative Dan Miller since the day she said she would seek the Sarasota-area House seat he is vacating.

title: Richard D. Rosenthal: With That Devilish Grin
description: Richard D. Rosenthal was not a daredevil, but he did have a childlike adventurous streak. "My older daughter called him a man-kid," said his sister, Audrey Model. His 40th birthday party had a "Three Stooges" theme. For his 50th birthday party last May, Ms. Model toasted her brother, saying she hoped he would remain a man-kid.

title: Life in a Hotel Room: Home, Cramped Home
description: For the past eight weeks, the Chanin family -- mother, father, two children, four guinea pigs -- has been living in a smallish room at the Tribeca Grand Hotel in downtown Manhattan. Space, to put it mildly, is tight. There is one big bed, which Laura Davis-Chanin shares with Mara, her 7-year-old daughter. Lester Chanin, her husband, sleeps on the floor beside the bathroom. He has to move over to let the others use it at night. Zoe, 9, sleeps on the carpet between the bed and a wall.

title: Eric Steen: Man for All Callings
description: Eric Steen spent his days as a bond trader for Euro Brokers in 2 World Trade Center. But he had a secret desire to make his mark in the arts, and that is why he was working on a screenplay, finishing a novel and launching a film-production company in his spare time. "He didn't want to divulge that until it was all finished," said his friend David Hegarty, who attended Garden City High School with him. "He was a pretty deep thinker, and he was very well read, so that was a whole other area where he could feel fulfilled outside of Wall Street."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSSKOPF, FRANCES M. (BETTY)
description: ROSSKOPF-Frances M. (Betty). Died on October 25, 2001, at her home in Jackson, California. A longtime resident of Manhattan, Hastings-on-Hudson, and Ridgefield, Connecticut, she spent most of her later years in Sarasota, Florida. She was the widow of mathematics educator Myron F. Rosskopf. Born and raised in Fairmont, Minnesota, Betty lived in many places. She taught in oneroom schoolhouses in Montana, Minnesota, and the Dakotas. She moved to Missouri during the Depression, where she and her husband had their first home. During World War II, she served as a park ranger in Texas, where her husband was stationed. After the war, they moved to Cazenovia, New York, and thence to New York City and environs. She lived in Oslo, Norway, and Simla, India for brief periods. For as long as possible, Betty spent summers at her beloved island in Canada. Betty studied bonsai with the late Yuji Yoshimura, eventually becoming an exhibitor and teaching associate. She loved the natural world and worked to preserve it. She loved to travel, garden, fish, go out in the boat, entertain. She loved to read, play the piano, listen to jazz and classical music, attend concerts and parties, to dance. She was an avid tennis player. She was a good friend. Betty leaves behind her daughter Kathy and son Peter, their families, and many friends. Donations in her memory may be made to The Riverside Church, 490 Riverside Drive, New York, NY 10027, where her remains rest.

title: Hanging Out With the Smart Set
description: GERDA GODLY was a struggling cocktail waitress in 1985, a college dropout with an uncertain future, when her boyfriend told her she should get some confidence, that she was as smart as anyone he knew.

title: A War Story That's Not Really About War
description: THE New Yorker ran a cartoon recently showing a couple watching television in their American living room. ''Baseball or anthrax?'' asks the one with the remote control.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS IN BRIEF
description: THE REVENGE OF RANDAL REESE-RAT

title: King Captures Soccer Title
description: Martin Luther King Jr. High School of Manhattan, the defending champion, defeated seventh-seeded George W. Wingate of Brooklyn, 3-0, yesterday at Long Island University's Brooklyn campus to win its fifth Public Schools Athletic League soccer title in six years.

title: Arts Groups Are Reeling in Wake of the Attacks
description: Confronted by the plunge in tourism, a decline in charitable contributions and anticipated cuts in the city's cultural budget that are expected to be announced this week, New York City's 2,000 arts institutions are facing the gravest economic period since the fiscal crisis of the 1970's.

title: Dance Listings
description: DIXON PLACE  Tue.: Performance Mix series with Jane Gabriels, Matt Heyner, Annabelle Chvostek, Alyson Ishnovska, others. Wed.: Under Exposed series with Dana Salisbury, Kate Pagliasotti, Vanessa Adato and Mollie Obrien. Vineyard 26, 309 E. 26th St. (212-532-1546)

title: 'Who Is This Kafka That People Keep Mentioning?'
description: That Hazmi's story reached the public so quickly gives the lie to any larger lesson that might be drawn from this overreaction. The moral of this story? Hazmi is right: ''What I went through was not fun. But in another country, I might be in jail for four years and nobody would know.'' Not only the persecution of an innocent man but also its publication merits our attention and reflection. Along with my indignation at Hazmi's treatment, I'm proud of what stopped it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERT, SAMUEL K.
description: ROBERT-Samuel K. Of Concord and Nantucket, MA. Beloved husband of Rita (Kamins) Robert and the late Mildred (Nathan) Kniznick. Devoted father of Andrea K. Waldstein and her husband Arthur of Boston, MA, Stephen Robert and his wife Pilar of East Hampton and Manhattan, NY, Richard Milgrim and his wife Mari of Concord, MA, Victoria Fitts-Milgrim and her husband Robert Fitts of Durango, CO, and the late Stacey Milgrim. Loving grandfather of Brett Levy, Adam Levy and his wife Nancy, Alison Aronson and her husband Adam, Alexandra Robert Gordon and her husband Steven Gordon, Elisabeth Robert, Toby Milgrim, Frederick Milgrim and Natasha Fitts. Great-grandfather of Talia Levy, Noah Levy and Aaron Levy. Dear brother of the late Betty Reanick. Services at the Levine Chapel, 470 Harvard St, Brookline, MA, on Monday, Novemeber 19, at 1 PM. Interment at the Jewish Section of the Prospect Hill Cemetery, Nantucket, MA, on Tuesday, November 20, at 1 PM. Memorial observance at the family residence following the service Monday, until 8 PM, and continuing Wednesday and Thursday, 1-4 PM, and 7-9 PM. Remembrances may be made to the Stacey Milgrim Scholarship Fund at Cambridge College, 1000 Massachusetts Ave, Cambridge, MA 02138.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATCHER, CASSIE
description: KATCHER-Cassie. A 20-year resident of New Rochelle, NY died Friday November 9, 2001, at the age of 92. Mrs. Katcher was a graduate of Teacher's College, Columbia University and taught for many years in both the New York City and Westchester County School Systems. Mrs. Katcher's husband Monroe I. Katcher, II, a New York City attorney predeceased her by twelve years. She is survived by her son Stephen M. Katcher of White Plains, NY and her daughter, Alice D. Kisch of Emoryville, CA as well as her daughter-in-law, Judith Susan Katcher of White Plains, NY. She is also survived by her granddaughters Elizabeth Anne Katcher of Manhattan (NYC), Amy Yael Kisch Bachelor of Boulder, CO, Suzanne Bonnie Kisch of Concord, CA and great-granddaughter Adriane Sara Kisch Hancock, also of Concord, CA. Other survivors include sisters-in-law Faye Gerstein and Sylvia Gerstein, nephews Stanley Gerstein, Larry Gerstein and Robert Gersten as well as niece Ruth Gordon. Funeral services were held at the Ballard-Durand Funeral Home in White Plains, NY on November 12, 2001.

title: The Seafood Is Fresh, and So Is the Decor
description: WHAT does Running Fish have to do with the restaurant 62 Main Street in New Canaan?

title: A Cast of Hundreds, All in One Shop
description: ''PEOPLE like to think of me as their fairy godmother,'' said Nancy Altman Guzzetta as she put on an elegant feathered ball mask. ''I wave my wand, and I can make them anyone they want to be.''

title: November 11-17; The End of the Embargo?
description: How near is the end of the trade embargo with Cuba? Near, it seems.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-18-01; What They Were Thinking
description: Conrad Tamberino, Hampton Bays, N.Y., Oct. 19, 2001.

title: Comfort Food
description: SUN BREAD

title: Private Sector; A Struggle to Battle Depression . . .
description: Howard Solomon, chairman of Forest Laboratories, had plenty of reasons to feel proud last Wednesday night as his son won a National Book Award for ''The Noonday Demon,'' an essay about depression. The book recounts the pivotal role Mr. Solomon played in nursing his son back from the crippling depths of his own depression.

title: History Is Impatient To Embrace Sept. 11
description: EVAN FAIRBANKS is back under the twin towers as they are being attacked. He has been back at least 30 times.

title: ONE STREET AT A TIME; Positively Third Street
description: Now I realize that by confessing to you my favorite street in Los Angeles, I simultaneously run the risk of ruining it by telling you where it is. Why, then, am I willing to endure less street parking and more waiting in line at the cash registers? Because West Third Street, in West Los Angeles -- or at least the dozen or so blocks between La Cienega and Fairfax -- with its adorable, privately owned custom boutiques, is the only street in the city where you can feel like you left your house with your passport.

title: Oh, What a Miserable Mornin'
description: I came to know Richard and Dorothy Rodgers in the 1970's when I was working on the book for the musical ''Rex,'' for which he was the composer (Frank Rich, Oct. 28). Yes, I do recognize the Richard Rodgers of your article, but I found it a very partial portrait, a psycho-history that tends to diminish the artistry and humanity of its subject by focusing on the troubled parts of the life.

title: Airlines and Antitrust: A New World. Or Not.
description: IT is one of the worst periods in aviation history.

title: Pitching In for Paul Newman and Other American Icons
description: ASK Paul Newman how he managed to get Meryl Streep, Matt Damon, Julia Roberts, Morgan Freeman, Brian Dennehy, Kevin Kline, Alec Baldwin, Joanne Woodward, Gwyneth Paltrow, Philip Seymour Hoffman and James Naughton to appear with him on one stage at one time, and he offers a typically understated explanation: ''I called some people.''

title: The Nation: Gearhead Nation; A Time Out for Technophilia
description: ''THERE was a sense that this could be a turning point like no other, that perhaps technology will never be viewed in quite the same way,'' said Robert C. Post, a senior fellow at the Dibner Institute for the History of Science and Technology.

title: New York Flag Inspires Melbourne-Bound Sailors
description: On Sept. 19, before gliding past the Statue of Liberty and into the Atlantic Ocean, the offshore sailor and educator Rich Wilson hoisted the flag of New York State into the rigging of his 53-foot trimaran Great American II.

title: After Auschwitz
description: To the Editor:

title: Resurrecting Reformers of Opera
description: BY the mid-1990's, the Italian mezzo-soprano Cecilia Bartoli had earned wide critical acclaim and sensational popularity, even though her repertory was fairly restricted. In opera, especially, she seldom ventured beyond Mozart and Rossini. Ms. Bartoli announced her intention to broaden her repertory and took on roles typically sung by sopranos, like Mozart's Susanna. But what would she do next? Since Verdi's weighty mezzo-soprano roles were unsuited to her light lyric voice, would she leap ahead to the turn of the 20th century? There were hints about Debussy's Mlisande. Might she even look at works by living composers?

title: Once and Future Issue: Subtracting Donations From Damage Awards
description: It sounds like a question on a law school exam: Should a construction company involved in a devastating fire at a historic synagogue be allowed to reduce the damages it pays by the amount of charity donated to the synagogue after the blaze?

title: 'The Sweet Hell Inside'
description: William Harleston was born in 1804 at The Hut, a plantation owned by his parents, twenty-five miles north of Charleston, South Carolina. The Hut was one of several assets in a Harleston dynasty of land and slaves. (Other family estates were named Rice Hope and Richmond.) Few records have survived from William Harleston's youth. Even his birth date is in question — the year is known, but there is no record of the day — as though it had been clipped from memory. A genealogy states that he was one of five children, with three older sisters, Hannah, Sarah, and Constantia, and one younger brother, John. As a boy growing up on The Hut, a one-thousand-acre rice plantation with about sixty slaves, William would have passed his youth in ways appropriate to his class and sex: he hunted deer and fished, was schooled in classics and mathematics by private tutors, and attended the glittering society balls held every winter in nearby Charleston. The Harleston family's holdings made his life indolent and luxurious.

title: Travel Advisory; Greyhound Applies Security Measures
description: Temporarily, at least, the seats with the best view on a Greyhound bus are one row farther back. The bus company has instituted safety rules that don't allow passengers to sit in the first row of seats, unless they are children traveling alone or Greyhound employees. The rules are a response to an Oct. 3 knife attack on a Greyhound driver that caused a crash near Manchester, Tenn. The crash killed six passengers, including the assailant. There have also been two more recent threats to drivers.

title: Alison McGonigal, Adam Nelson
description: Alison Marie McGonigal, a daughter of Margaret and Thomas McGonigal of Beach Haven, N.J., was married yesterday to Adam Seth Nelson, a son of Linda Nelson of Katy, Tex. The Rev. David Rider performed a nondenominational ceremony at Grace Episcopal Church in New York. Afterward, Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel led another ceremony at the Angel Orensanz Foundation, an arts center and former synagogue in New York.

title: Come Early, Stay Late
description: Evelyn's, 45 Easton Avenue, New Brunswick. (732) 246-8792. Open daily from 11 a.m. to 2 a.m.

title: The Secret
description: To the Editor:

title: Capturing What Matters in Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Liberty and Security in the Age of Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Somewhere for Me'
description: Here comes Jacob Levy trotting along the street, a tiny little man in a neat black suit and fussy bow tie, carrying a cane and sporting a white panama with a surprisingly rakish brim. It is 1926, and Richard Rodgers's grandfather on his mother's side is spending the summer in Long Beach, New York, walking down an expanse of sidewalk bordered by identical lawns, a single Model T Ford parked behind him on that ramrod-straight, deserted street. Now here is Will, Dick's physician father, in the home movies Richard Rodgers began to take with his fancy new film camera, the one you wound up by hand. Will, too, is spending his summer in Long Beach, and stands on the steps of their cottage, red-haired, handsome, and blue-eyed, a smudge of moustache on his upper lip, in his starched-collar shirt and his suit with matching waistcoat, laughing uproariously at some forgotten joke. And here is Mamie, Dick's mother, with her flat, blunt nose, close-set eyes, pince-nez, and distinct gap between her front teeth. Even in those days of blurry and faded film one somehow knows it is a dusty afternoon in high summer, and only city folk get dressed up in hats and gloves to have their pictures taken.

What the Red Hawks do not have is a running game, the ability to avoid costly mistakes and a defense capable of shutting down a capable opponent. The negatives outweighed the positives today as Montclair State bowed out of the Division III playoffs, losing in the first round to Ithaca, 35-23.
