Barry is survived by his mother, Mollie Simowitz, sisters, Renee Brotman & Laurie Simowitz, brother-in-law Alan Brotman, nieces, Susan & Ellen Brotman, nephew, Daniel Austin, and grand-nieces, Rebecca Steingut and Rachel Austin, and grand-nephew, Samuel Austin. Newmont has been a target of antiglobalization and environmental movements.

Ms. Karan was celebrating Iman, who has made only rare appearances since the birth of a daughter 14 months ago. ''I wanted to see how she looks,'' Ms. Aston confided.

title: Devils' Offense Sputters Again

The result has been three consecutive losses, the latest a 3-1 setback to the Philadelphia Flyers this afternoon at Continental Arena in the teams' first meeting of the season.

title: Our Towns; Never Mind the Inventive Curriculum. One Test Fits All.
description: FOR years, reporters looking for a juicy quote on the dangers of standardized testing called Vermont's education commissioner, Dr. Richard P. Mills. ''This is not a golf game,'' he said in 1989. ''We can't reduce performance to a single numerical score.'' In Vermont, Dr. Mills championed the liberal alternative, statewide portfolio assessment -- a collection of students' class work, including writing and research projects. But Dr. Mills has spent most of his career atop state bureaucracies (he's never taught public school, nor been a principal or superintendent) and you don't survive in that political realm without lightning flexibility. In 1995, when he was hired as New York's education commissioner, the Board of Regents and the new Republican governor wanted an aggressive test program, and overnight, Dr. Portfolio became the Scorekeeper.

I promise an answer before this article is done. First, though, I must ask a question of my own, since ''The Way We Laughed'' is finally opening in New York on Wednesday. Why did it take three years for this wonderful film to get here from Italy?

The two Americans, Heather Mercer, 24, and Dayna Curry, 30, said a fire started with the head scarves taken off by the six women in the group helped guide the choppers. ''I don't think Hollywood would have done it better,'' Ms. Mercer said in Islamabad. Douglas Frantz

title: Isle of Wight
description: Tucked away under the southern belly of England, the Isle of Wight rarely appears on the itinerary of the foreign visitor. Despite occasional yachty gatherings, with their attendant fireworks, and a brief rise to prominence in the 1960's, when it was the setting for a series of rock concerts, the island remains a sedate and modest destination that prefers not to draw attention to itself: a quiet haven in unquiet times. It flourished as a resort both in the Victorian period and in the 20th century, before ordinary Britons could afford to go abroad; but lately it has been outflanked by the exotic (and warmer) attractions of southern Europe. Still popular with a certain kind of domestic tourist, it nonetheless remains, determinedly, a curiously old-fashioned backwater replete with 19th-century houses and quaint tearooms.

title: Liberties; Cleopatra and Osama
description: It is hard to fathom how a part of the world that produced Cleopatra -- who perfumed the sails of her boat so men would know she was coming and ruled with elegant authority, signing one tax decree ''Make it happen'' -- could two millenniums later produce societies where women are swaddled breeders under house arrest.

title: A Long Journey
description: To the Editor:

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-18-01: Process; Symbol Making
description: ''I was working with the Dow Chemical company at the time, in 1966, developing containment systems for the Cancer Institute at the National Institutes of Health. And it became obvious to us that there were a lot of different so-called warning symbols in the various laboratories that we visited, but there was no standardization. We saw a need for this kind of a symbol and proceeded to develop some symbols with the help of the Dow marketing people -- the package-design department, I think it was called. The only parameters that I set down for them to noodle through were, it had to be unique and something that would be striking enough that it would be remembered. We wanted something that was memorable but meaningless, so we could educate people as to what it means.

title: Practical Traveler; More Mileage In Flier Plans
description: MATTHEW CLEMENT is planning to earn nearly 92,000 frequent flier miles on two round trips this month between London and San Francisco. He isn't traveling on business, but to Mr. Clement, a 26-year-old management consultant from London, the trips are just as obligatory. He feels he has to take advantage of the miles promotions nearly every airline is offering in an attempt to get people flying again.

title: LIVES; Streetwise
description: In 1980, the ruling Muslim clerics in Iran signed my father's execution warrant and confiscated everything he owned. It was odd then to watch another cleric administering his funeral in an antiseptic Los Angeles cemetery some months later, after he had died of a heart attack. I was barely 15. The Iranians who came to pay their last respects were all fresh exiles like us who left Iran in a hurry after the triumph of the Islamic revolution the year before.

title: When the Label Says Island Made or Grown
description: THERE are men out there -- you know who you are, guys -- whose wardrobe is not complete without a silk tie adorned with a picture of the Big Duck. These fellows will pay $39.95 for the tie, without blinking, and go on to spend another $16.50 on the Big Duck golf ball package: two golf balls plus 11 tees, all emblazoned with you know what.

description: Further fueling speculation about his next step, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani declined yesterday to say whether or not he was negotiating for positions at the accounting giant Ernst & Young for himself and three administration officials.

title: Commercial Property/Staten Island; New Hilton Hopes to Become Island's Meeting Place
description: THE Hilton Garden Inn on Staten Island has something that its counterparts in Manhattan lack -- outdoor space. The hotel, which opened on Sept. 15, is situated on 23 acres of land, much of it near protected wetlands, in the Bloomfield section of the western part of Staten Island.

title: Slowdown Also Hurts Bonuses
description: The so-called corporate ax, it seems, is cutting more than jobs. Many year-end bonuses are also being slashed.

title: Jaime Goldfeier, Andrew Ceitlin
description: Jaime Lyn Goldfeier, the daughter of Evelyn and Harry Z. Goldfeier of Closter, N.J., was married yesterday evening in Pearl River, N.Y., to Andrew David Ceitlin, a son of Leslie and Jim Ceitlin of Plainview, N.Y. Rabbi Irving Spielman officiated at the Hilton Pearl River.

title: A Little Bit of Puff Goes a Long Way
description: This Thanksgiving, -- it won't be embarrassing if you show up to dinner with a sweet potato pie in your hands and the marshmallows in your hair: beauty products are sweetening up with a new ingredient, marshmallow root. A gummy plant extract, originally used in its namesake confection, it is the latest base for a number of salves and cosmetics. At Aveda, its bonding properties can be found in two hair products, Be Curly and Hang Straight ($16), sprays intended to harness hair into shape. Juvena carries a firming eye cream ($36 at Sephora), and Zirh offers an after-sun cooling gel ($22.50 at Bloomingdale's). L'Occitane adds the fluffy stuff to its Linden Foaming Bath ($24.50) and Neal's Yard makes a Comfrey and Mallow Foot Balm ($19 at www.nyr-usa.com).

title: Financing for Shopping Center Moves Ahead in East Harlem
description: After a long delay, a plan to build a $160 million shopping center in East Harlem that would include Manhattan's first Costco and Home Depot superstores is once again on track. The project, approved by the City Council in September 1999, stalled about 18 months ago after officials refused to subsidize the required $45 million parking garage.

title: November 11-17; The Compleat Scrolls
description: After a half-century of curiosity and bitter controversy, publication of the texts from the Dead Sea Scrolls is virtually complete. ''It did take time,'' Dr. Emanuel Tov, the chief editor, acknowledged as he announced that the final two volumes would soon go to press. The first scrolls were discovered in 1947, but the few scholars in control released only eight volumes in 40 years. A more enterprising team took over in 1991 and has now turned out 30 volumes, a compendium of writing at a critical time in the history of Judaism and early Christianity. John Noble Wilford

title: INVESTING WITH/Steven Romick; UAM FPA Crescent Portfolio
description: STEVEN ROMICK, who runs the $142 million UAM FPA Crescent Portfolio, says the current economic slowdown is different from those he has faced in the past.

title: Corrections
description: The two final words and the writer's signature were omitted on Nov. 4 from the Q & A column, which included a question about a club for people who have traveled to 75 or more regions or countries. The closing passage should have said: ''The chairman of the club, Klaus Billep, said it had 1,500 members. As for evidence that a member had taken a trip, Mr. Billep said that when remote destinations were involved, the club did ask that copies of stamped passports or airline tickets be provided.'' The writer was Paul Freireich.

title: A Coin True to Barnum, Controversy and All
description: IN the United States, there have been only 10 individual cities honored with a circulating coin. Bridgeport is one of them.

title: The Selling of Billy Collins
description: TWO weeks ago, the Poetry Center of Chicago sponsored a reading by Billy Collins at the Chicago Historical Society. The last time the center had invited him to read, in 1993, he had been a relatively obscure poet whose last volume, ''Questions About Angels,'' was on its way out of print. This time, Mr. Collins, who was raised in Jackson Heights, Queens, and teaches in the city university system at Lehman College in the Bronx, caused the literary equivalent of Beatlemania.

title: Barcelona
description: The view from the hotel room on this clear sunny morning belongs to any Impressionist painting. Past the French windows and the fluttering sheers that billow every so often to suggest we'll have yet another temperate late-summer day on the Mediterranean, you step out onto the balcony, lean against the slim banister and there, right before you, is Barcelona's grand Cathedral, La Seu, beaming in the sunlight. It stands at the very heart of the Barri Gtic, the city's old quarter, the way so many large churches stand in the middle of medieval towns that have lived through too many eras, sprawled too far and seen too much to remember who did what to whom, when and how. Paris, Milan, London and Berlin have no longer just grown into megaplex centers of culture, tourism and finance. They are global hypercities. And Barcelona, after nearly four decades under the ruthless dictatorship of Generalissimo Franco, is not just on the rebound. It's on the hypermap and it means to stay there.

title: Reading Informs Their Art
description: CREATIVE people often recharge their energies by reading, and the artists who have studios on Long Island are no exception.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCOOEY, ROBERT H.
description: McCOOEY-Robert H. Of Rye, NY, and Sea Island, GA, on Friday, November 16, 2001. Born Brooklyn, NY, October 14, 1930, to Herbert and Elizabeth (Larney) McCooey. Grandson of the late John H. McCooey, political leader of Brooklyn for 25 years. Beloved husband of Mary Catherine (Joyce), devoted father of Robert H., Jr. (Kristina Grimm McCooey), Mark, Michael, Timothy, Mary Catherine and Kevin, and grandfather of Robert III, Christopher, Elizabeth, Matthew and Thomas McCooey. Also survived by three brothers: his twin, Richard of Washington, DC, Bert of Westhampton Beach, NY, and John of New York City. He attended Brooklyn Prep and graduated form Iona Preparatory School and the College of the Holy Cross ('52). He served as Lieutenant J.G. in the U.S Navy from 1952 to 1954. His business career began on Wall Street as an independent broker and later as a specialist at Henderson Brothers. In 1988 he, with his sons and daughter, founded The Griswold Company, which has become one of the largest independent brokerage firms on the New York Stock Exchange. He has been a member of the NYSE for 46 years. His dedication to faith and family was lived through his service to many charitable organizations. At the time of his death, he was a Board member of Lincoln Hall, Lincolndale, NY; the New York Foundling Hospital, NYC; St. Vincent's Hospital-Westchester; Weston Jesuit School of Theology, Cambridge, MA; Our Lady of Mercy Medical Center, Bronx, NY; Morality in Media, New York City;, and Graymoor, Garrison, NY. He served as Chairman of the Board of Trustees of Iona Preparatory School, New Rochelle, NY; Catholic Big Brothers, New York, NY; Mercy College, Dobbs Ferry, NY; and Our Lady of Mercy Hospital Fund. He was a past Board member of the Boy Scouts of New York, the Cerebral Palsy Association (Westchester), Catholic Youth Organization, St. Agnes Hospital, White Plains, NY, College of New Rochelle and AmeriCares, New Canaan, CT. He was an active meber in Catholic organizations, serving as Chancellor of the Order of Malta. He was a member of the Knights of the Holy Sepulchre and the Cardinal's Committee of the Laity of the Archdiocese of New York. He was also a current Trustee of Resurrection Church, Rye, NY, and Our Lady of Victory Church in the financial district, and served as a member of the Finance Committee for both parishes. The family will receive visitors on Sunday, November 18, from 5 to 8 PM, and Monday, November 19, from 3 to 6 PM, at Resurrection Church, 910 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at Resurrection Church on Monday, November 19, at 6 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Robert H. McCooey Memorial Cancer Research Fund, New York Hospital, 525 East 68th St., NY, NY 10021, attn: Peggy Maher.

title: Going Beyond 'Sit'and 'Roll Over' in Dog Agility Classes
description: HARRY sat in front of the tire. He refused to budge. ''C'mon Harry,'' said Irene Post, his owner, tugging the 9-month-old, 120-pound English mastiff by the leash, urging him to jump through the hoop. ''Tire. C'mon, baby.''

title: All the Right Moves
description: This was a Sunday last spring at a church in Pittsburgh. The pastor was about to collect the tithe when a young man suggested that this should be a special day when the church gave to the people instead of them giving to the church. The parishioners who needed rent money, or a car payment, could ask for it, and if the man could help he would.

title: Malan Leads Brown Past Struggling Columbia
description: Mike Malan rushed for 183 yards and 4 touchdowns in his final college game as Brown coasted to a 45-21 victory over Columbia yesterday at Wien Stadium. The Bears finished the season 6-3 over all and 5-2 in the Ivy League, while the loss denied Columbia (3-6, 3-4) its second winning Ivy League mark in 30 years.

title: Hoping That Yesterday's Tent of Tomorrow Has a Future
description: The Tent of Tomorrow may usher in a new future, if two daydreamers get their wish.

title: Beth Wassarman, Steven Weintraub
description: Beth Susan Wassarman, a daughter of Ellen K. Wassarman of Irvington, N.Y., and Dr. Paul M. Wassarman of New York, was married last evening to Steven David Weintraub, a son of Roberta Zelikow of Tucson and Joseph Weintraub of Keasby, N.J. Cantor Daniel Neiden officiated at the Harold Pratt House in New York.

title: Douglas G. Karpiloff: Security and Sweetness
description: After the World Trade Center was bombed in 1993, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey made Douglas G. Karpiloff the director of security and life safety for the center. He installed an array of protective systems, including huge concrete planters around the towers, a strict set of building passes and an identification and tracking system for vehicles entering the basement. He was also called in to consult about security in Denver before Timothy McVeigh's trial for the Oklahoma City bombing and on how to protect the White House and other federal buildings. Last year, his industry trade group named him security director of the year.

title: Whose Pain Is It, Anyhow?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Kebab Coalition; Middle Eastern Restaurants Offer Comfort and Connection to Those From Far Away and Those Who Savor Their Flavors
description: NEW JERSEY is home to 300,000 Muslims, and it's safe to say that on Sept. 11 their lives changed more than most of their neighbors'. Suddenly they had to live with their non-Muslim neighbors' response to unspeakable acts committed in the name of Islam.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-18-01: The ethicist; Shower Away
description: As a gay teenager who only recently came out, I wonder about showering at the gym with other men. For obvious reasons men and women shower separately, and while I don't suggest segregated gay showers, is it right for me to be surrounded by naked men who have no idea that I may see some of them in a sexual way? Anonymous, New York City

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAPERSTEIN, RABBI HAROLD I.
description: SAPERSTEIN-Rabbi Harold I. 90. Beloved husband of Marcia (nee Rosenblum), devoted father of Marc and Roberta Saperstein, David Saperstein and Ellen Weiss; loving grandfather of Sara and Stephen Frug, Adina, Daniel, and Ari Saperstein. Cherished brother of Rabbi Sanford and Leah Saperstein and of the late Gladys and Bernard Lack. Rabbi of Temple Emanu-El of Lynbrook, 1933-1980. After retirement, served as Rabbi at Central Synagogue and Congregation Rodeph Sholom of NYC, and at the West London Synagogue of British Jews. Past President of NY Board of Rabbis and NY Association of Reform Rabbis. Served in American armed forces, European Theater during WWII, reaching rank of major. Tireless champion in defense of Israel, Soviet Jewry and social justice in America. Funeral services Monday, November 19, 11:30 AM, Temple Emanu-El of Lynbrook (opp Lynbrook LIRR station). Contributions in his memory may be made to Temple Emanu-El of Lynbrook, the Religious Action Center of Reform Judaism, Cornell Univeristy, or the Alzheimer's Association.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBLUM, SYD (NEE KAMERMAN)
description: ROSENBLUM-Syd (nee Kamerman). Died peacefully November 14, 2001 in North Miami, FL. Former Manhattanite. Widow of Mike Rosenblum. Survived by sister, Lillie Retter. Spectacular aunt to many nieces and nephews who adored her and were awed by her. She lived intensely for 95 years.

title: The Next New York
description: What the readers wrote:

title: The New York Times Top 50
description: The New York Times's computer football ranking is based on an analysis of each team's scores with emphasis on three factors: who won, by what margin and against what quality of opposition. The quality of an opponent is determined by examining the opponent's record against other teams.

title: Postings: Heschel School Expanding to West End Avenue and 60th Street; A High School Building for 300
description: Work is about to begin on the transformation of a building at the corner of West End Avenue and 60th Street into the Abraham Joshua Heschel High School. When it opens its doors next September, it will mark the completion of a vision: a Jewish day school that encompasses nursery through secondary school and that draws its students from all the branches of Judaism.

title: Harvard Tops Yale for First Perfect Mark Since 1913
description: Neil Rose threw four touchdown passes today as Harvard defeated Yale, 35-23, to win a season finale that had so much at stake for the Crimson.

title: Do Teams Acquire Veteran Leadership, or Just a Bunch of Old Guys?
description: Jerry Krause spoke of how much Charles Oakley meant to him last month, how much Oakley could still mean to the Chicago Bulls, even in his mid-30's.

title: The Skin Game, With New Wrinkles
description: WHERE the mild-mannered Dr. Nicholas V. Perricone goes, throngs follow. Some 200 swarmed him at a personal appearance at Sephora in Rockefeller Center recently, a record for a visiting beauty guru, the store said.

title: California Schools Fear Proposed Cuts May Halt Overhaul Effort
description: Faced with a proposal by Gov. Gray Davis to trim $843 million from education spending for this fiscal year, school officials expressed fears today that educational reform efforts might fall victim to the cuts.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/East Williston; A Well-Appointed, Convenient Village
description: FOR a community with a finely honed a sense of itself, the compact village of East Williston is surprisingly little known beyond its borders.

title: Group Politics: Breaking Up Is Hard to Do
description: YOU move to Westchester, and someone you admire, maybe want to get to know better, asks you to join her cooking, book or newcomer's club. You go, and despite reservations, have a nice time. Sometimes, you even come back tipsy after meetings. ''Hey!'' you think. ''That was fun!''

title: Ideas & Trends; Hair as a Battlefield for the Soul
description: CELEBRATING their liberation from Taliban rule in Afghanistan last week, men shaved off their beards, while women unveiled their faces and revealed bits of hair. Suddenly, ordinary people needed to show they had regained control over their looks. But why?

title: Star Revival of Copland and Hemingway
description: BETWEEN writing great novels, Ernest Hemingway took time to hunt and fish and brawl -- also to drink, fight wars, drive ambulances, fall in love. Guy stuff. He ended his own life like that: fast, tough, a shot to the head. ''For Whom the Bell Tolls,'' ''A Farewell to Arms,'' ''The Old Man and the Sea'' and other favorites, are an American tradition.

title: Anne Dillenbeck, Robert Berger
description: Anne Gilbert Dillenbeck, a daughter of Suzanne Voth Dillenbeck of Locust Valley, N.Y., and Richard R. Dillenbeck of Old Lyme, Conn., was married yesterday to Robert Calkins Berger, the son of Patricia and Everett Berger of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Paul Gilbert performed the ceremony at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANNING, JACK
description: MANNING-Jack. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Jack Manning associated with The Times from 1964 until retiring in 2000.

title: Look to TV
description: To the Editor:

title: Web Site Offers Postings For Teenagers Seeking Jobs
description: Teenagers searching for work no longer need to canvas the county by foot, car or bus to find job openings. Teenagers can log on to www.WestchesterJobCentral.com, a site which offers continually updated postings for actual part-time, full-time, internship and seasonal jobs for students in middle school, high school and college.

title: On the Menu
description: Los Angeles isn't known -- for its carnivores. (Who can forget Woody Allen ordering the alfalfa sprouts and a plate of mashed yeast at a Hollywood caf in ''Annie Hall''?) But in the last few months, steakhouses including Jar, Balboa, Mastro's, Porterhouse Bistro and the Grill have opened their doors.

title: Editors' Note; A Nation Challenged
description: News of the terrorist attacks and their aftermath appears today in Section B; index, Page B2.

title: A Splash Of Red
description: New Yorkers who attend parties for charity are starting to get back into the mood after a period of great sadness. Many had turned to dressing in black for evening benefits. These events were toned down after Sept. 11, with dancing and ostentatious decorations often eliminated, and invitations decreeing not black tie but business attire, the dress code last Monday at the usually dressy Library Lions dinner. But there has been a welcome change in the last few weeks, noticeably the emergence of women in red. While black continues to dominate, red is lighting up the parties. Why red? That favorite of husbands is a very American color. And it recalls the adage: when you feel blue, wear red.

title: One Too Many?
description: Recidivism runs rampant. Smokers who quit years ago are embracing the weed with renewed fervor. Sippers of white-wine spritzers are suddenly demanding vodka martinis with olives. The well-intentioned head for yoga class and wake up hours later covered with powdered sugar in a back booth at Donut Dive. Stairmasters gather dust; chins multiply; reddened eyes peer from darkened sockets. Pimples are everywhere. ''It doesn't matter,'' we say, but one morning, in the slanting November light, the mirror catches our eyes and we realize that yes, it does matter, and something has to be done about it -- fast.

title: Jihad's Women
description: In this time of fear, I hold on to the universal absolute of a mother's love for her child. But looking at the picture of Rehima kissing her infant boy and reading her words, ''I will sacrifice my son, and I don't care if he is my most beloved thing,'' I am left with almost no hope.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 4 about an increase in smoking in the city since Sept. 11 misidentified the director of the Coalition for a Smoke-Free City, who was quoted as criticizing the distribution of free cigarettes to workers at ground zero. The director is Joanne Kildare, not Donna Shelley. Ms. Shelley, who has expressed concern about the rise in smoking, is director of the Tobacco Control Program of the city's Department of Health.

title: November 11-17; World Trade Pact in Qatar
description: They fought about drug patents, farm subsidies, bananas and tuna. They pulled two all-nighters in six days. But representatives of the 142 member nations of the World Trade Organization finally settled on a framework for free trade in Doha, Qatar. Ministers agreed to begin negotiations aimed at ending European farm export subsidies, opening markets to insurance and environmental services, and reviewing antidumping rules. The United States made some concessions, but American businesses are broadly supportive of a trade agenda that could produce results as soon as 2005. Joseph Kahn

title: 'Trieste and the Meaning of Nowhere'
description: If you come to it by car over the Karst, all the same, Trieste looks perfectly self-explanatory. The road crosses the border out of Slovenia and reaches the village of Opicina, where the plateau abruptly falls away through pine-woods towards the sea. There, a tall obelisk marks the beginning of the city. It was erected in 1830 to commemorate the completion of the first proper highroad across the Karst, connecting Vienna with its seaport on the Adriatic. Now the monument is peeling and neglected, and its setting is suburban, but when it was new, it told the grateful traveller that his journey across the wasteland was over, and he was reaching a haven of imperial order — an up-to-date Mediterranean outpost of the empire of the Habsburgs. The young Austrian Archduke Ferdinand Joseph Maximilian came this way in 1850 and thought the Karst a cursed desert, but he saw the distant appearance of the obelisk as a symbol of hope, and urged his coachman to get a move on.

title: Urgent Efforts to Bar Use Of Stolen Trucks as Bombs
description: Well before Sept. 11, and with great urgency since then, law enforcement and transportation officials have been working to prevent one type of terrorist attack -- the theft of a large truck that could be turned into a rolling bomb.

title: With the Afghan Rebels in a Neverland of Sorrow
description: TIMES have changed since ''Jung: In the Land of the Mujaheddin,'' a documentary made by three Italian filmmakers in Afghanistan, had its United States premiere at the Human Rights Watch Film Festival in New York in June.

title: Tax Cuts and Homeland Safety
description: Despite all the pledges of prompt action from Congressional leaders and President Bush, a bill to stimulate the economy is trapped in a partisan impasse, with no way out in sight. So are proposals to upgrade the nation's ''homeland defenses.'' Over Thanksgiving, members of Congress who ask their constituents how they've been doing should be told to go back to Washington and get busy.

title: He Routed Smallpox, Now Tackles Bioterror
description: In 1980, D. A. Henderson did what no one else in history has ever done. He wiped a disease, smallpox, off the face of the earth. Now, smallpox is back -- not as a naturally occurring killer but as a potential bioterrorist weapon. And D. A. Henderson is back, too.

title: Rachel Zweighaft, Gerald Adamski
description: Rachel Mead Zweighaft, the daughter of Dorothy Zweighaft and Dr. Harold M. Zweighaft of Manhattan, was married last evening to Gerald Michael Adamski, a son of Robin and James Adamski of Mount Sinai, N.Y. Rabbi Matthew D. Gewirtz officiated at the Essex House in Manhattan.

title: Hot Dish
description: ''The interesting thing about food,'' says Nigella Lawson, the British author and star of ''Nigella Bites,'' a cooking show that makes its debut in America this weekend on the heels of her new book, ''is that it's both about reality and escape. After those planes bashed into the World Trade Center, I just wanted to chop something. I find that a mindless, repetitive activity loosens one up, and, then, before you know it, you have made something that can seduce people. Of course, you can also make yourself fat that way. I'm a stress eater, and since the World Trade Center, I'm in that fridge eating bits of cheese all day long. But then that's a form of reality and escape, too.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALSH, PATRICIA ANN
description: WALSH-Patricia Ann. Of Palisades, NY, died at home on November 16, 2001 at the age of 50, after a courageous battle with ovarian cancer. She was the daughter of the late Anne Savino Walsh and William Walsh. Ms. Walsh held a Masters in Social Work from New York University and a Masters in Media Studies from the New School for Social Research. She had been employed as a social worker by Alternative to Domestic Violence in Hackensack, New Jersey. In addition, Ms. Walsh was a long distance runner who successfully completed the New York City Marathon in 1992. She climbed Mount Kilimanjaro and other mountains; was an accomplished costume designer; and enjoyed museums, opera, and travel. Her friends described her as having a wonderful sense of humor and great compassion. She is survived by her 11 year old twin sons, Noah and Aidan Walsh, her partner Cristina Biaggi, many caring friends, and her six dogs, three birds, and cat. A funeral service will be held, Tuesday, 1 pm at the Palisades Presbyterian Church in Palisades, NY. Visiting hours will be Monday, 7-10 pm, at the Moritz Funeral Home, 98 Route 303 South, Tappan, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Alternative to Domestic Violence, 1 Bergen County Plaza, Hackensack, NJ 07601, 201-336-7575 .

title: Louise Leduc, Brendan Kennedy
description: Louise Ann Leduc and Brendan John Kennedy, both lawyers, were married yesterday at St. Patrick-St. Anthony Roman Catholic Church in Hartford. The Rev. John C. Murphy performed the ceremony.

title: The Neediest Cases; For Many, Sliding Into Poverty Takes Only a Few Missed Paychecks
description: On a crisp October morning in the Bronx, the dean of students at Community School 61 walked into Clifton Moore's seventh-grade class and made an announcement. Three people in the class had been selected for applications to a program that sends underprivileged students to top private schools.

title: A Double Tax Break May Not Be Dead Yet
description: Four years ago, Congress gave homeowners a phenomenal tax break, allowing them to pocket tax-free profits of up to $500,000 from the sale of their homes. Philip J. Holthouse, a Los Angeles accountant, then came up with a technique that could double the tax exemption.

title: A NATION CHALLENGED
description: LINKS BETWEEN LETTERS -- An anthrax-tainted letter to Senator Patrick J. Leahy may offer fresh clues to the sender's identity. PAGE B1

title: A New Generation Gap?
description: To the Editor:

title: Alexis Hilton, Philip Mintz
description: Alexis Fox Hilton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Hilton of New York, was married last evening to Philip Adam Mintz, the son of Rayna Ragonetti of New York. Rabbi Geoff Hurst officiated at the Ocean Club on Paradise Island in the Bahamas.

title: The Horse's Tale
description: LEONARDO'S HORSE

title: BENEFITS
description: Protecting Journalists

title: This Land Was His Land
description: WOODY GUTHRIE

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HAYES, LOLA WILSON
description: HAYES-Lola Wilson. Prominent voice teacher passed recently on October 2nd in New York City at the age of 95. Memorial service to be held December 1 at Cami Hall, New York City, at 2 PM.

title: Margaret Seeliger: A Mother's Leanings
description: Margaret Seeliger gave up her place on a crowded elevator leaving the 100th floor of 2 World Trade Center to two colleagues, an act of generosity that surprised neither her husband nor the oldest of her eight siblings. Worrying about others was her way.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TRACT, HAROLD M.
description: TRACT-Harold M. Of Blessed Memory. Passed away November 18, 1991. He was a truly noble man.

title: It Took 60 Years To Get Around a Barrier
description: To the Editor:

title: How a Camp Becomes A City
description: Nusrat motions for me to follow him through the crowd. The situation is hectic, and I hesitate, even though Nusrat was a guerrilla commander in Afghanistan who fought the Red Army for a decade, facing far worse than the assemblage of widows and orphans before us.

title: Travel Advisory; Under the Mistletoe With Twain and Melville
description: Mistletoe, gift displays, festive table settings and, of course, readings will mark the holiday season at two National Historic Landmarks in New England that were once homes of distinguished American writers.

title: Vincent Litto: A Very Large Group of 'Us'
description: When Vincent Litto's sister was stricken with multiple sclerosis in 1979, she was no longer able to care for her daughter. So Mr. Litto and his wife, Linda, took the daughter in and raised her as their own. She was one of four girls Mr. Litto doted on.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDERS, BYRON
description: SANDERS-Byron. In loving memory of a dear friend. Our condolences to Renee, Jennifer, Michael, Jean, Josh. We miss you. Shirley, Franco, Deyna & Serena

title: For Giants and Vikings, The Stakes Grow Larger
description: Whether it's 1986 and the Giants convert an improbable fourth-and-17 to spark their first march to a Super Bowl or 14 days into 2001 when the Giants pull off an equally improbable 41-0 rout to charge to a third Super Bowl, the Minnesota Vikings have frequently been the opponent poised at the pivotal juncture of Giants history.

title: Lewis Grabs His Chance At Payback
description: Lennox Lewis, finding the resolve, poise and finally the power he lost seven months ago, reclaimed his heavyweight titles tonight with a knockout of Hasim Rahman at 1 minute 29 seconds of the fourth round.

title: In the Bronx, Chrysanthemums Revealed
description: IHAVE never really liked chrysanthemums. Maybe it was all those wrist corsages in high school, where my date and I always wanted to be with someone else. Or those pom-pom flowers, which look like bad party favors.

title: Jennifer Cabot, Robert Breslin III
description: Jennifer Felton Cabot, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul C. Cabot Jr. of Needham Mass., was married yesterday to Robert Henry Breslin III, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Breslin Jr. of East Greenwich, R.I. The Rev. Julian Cave performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Boca Grande, Fla.

title: Florida Overruns Archrival Florida St.
description: Coming into the game, everyone knew that Jabar Gaffney of Florida was one of the best receivers in college football. But who figured him for a passing threat? Certainly not Florida State -- at least not until Gaffney took a lateral from quarterback Rex Grossman, set his feet, cocked his arm and completed a long, diagonal throw to the uncovered tailback Earnest Graham for a gain of 40 yards.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEXNER, BELLA
description: WEXNER-Bella. We join with world Jewry in mourning the loss of Bella Wexner, a wonderful friend of the Pardes Institute of Jewish Studies in Jerusalem. Through her special efforts, Jewish educators from Columbus, Ohio have been able to enrich the depth of their experience and learning and that of their students through study at Pardes. Her legacy will continue to be a shining example of dedication to Jewish education and values. Rabbi Daniel Landes, Director and the Board of Trustees of the Pardes Institute of Jewish Studies

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS IN BRIEF
description: FATHER SUN, MOTHER MOON

title: SOAPBOX; When a Name Feels Too Heavy
description: WHEN my nephew was born 12 years ago, I was with my sister and her husband in the delivery room. He arrived quietly, and when I held him I was overwhelmed by his beauty and fragility, this weightless angel with lavender eyelids and tiny lips pursed into a Cheerio shape. I bonded to this boy and swore I would protect him throughout his life like a lioness with her cub. My brother-in-law, Wasek, gently pried the baby from my arms. It was the first time I saw Wasek cry, with joy that he had a child.

title: Psychodelia's Middle-Aged Head Trip
description: WHEN Ken Kesey and the Merry Pranksters made their storied journey across America in 1964, they included a pilgrimage to Millbrook, N.Y., the Hudson Valley town where Timothy Leary had turned a Victorian mansion into a lab for his LSD experiments. The meeting was supposed to join the two wings of the nascent drug culture: Kesey's woolly West Coast hedonists and Leary's League of Spiritual Discovery. But the vibe was all wrong. The Pranksters, spilling from a 1939 bus labeled Furthur, came on like unwashed trouble; the Leary crowd, with their meditation rooms and trip diaries, seemed no fun. Leary, engaged in a three-day trip on an upper floor, never even came down to meet his guests. The diodes of the electric drug culture remained apart.

title: Investing; Some Restaurants Thrive in Slowdown
description: AMERICANS' appetite for restaurants that serve sizzling plates of fajitas and shrimp dinners for less than $10 has yet to show any significant signs of waning.

title: 'For Rouenna'
description: After my first book was published, I received some letters. Most of them were from strangers, people who had read the book and who wanted me to know what they thought of it. They were friendly letters for the most part, though a few were critical. ("I hope you won't mind my saying that I did not like the ending at all," and so on.) I also heard from people I had known in the past. Near strangers: people I had not been in touch with for twenty, thirty years and whom I rarely if ever still thought about. Almost every one of these letters began with an expression of doubt that I would remember the sender, and my letters in reply always began with an assurance that I did remember, which was the truth. Even before I opened one of these letters, I would recognize the name written above the return address on the envelope. (Sometimes I recognized the handwriting.) Almost always unfamiliar, though, was the return address itself. These old acquaintances of mine, these ghosts from my past, had moved away from the places where I had known them, some very far. One of the few letters from the state of New York had been mailed from a men's penitentiary. Sometimes the writer wrote PERSONAL On the envelope, or PERSONAL AND CONFIDENTIAL. "I hope you will remember my sorry ass," the letter from the inmate began, "now that it has landed in jail."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADELHART, ANDREW J.
description: ADELHART-Andrew J. It is with deep sorrow and affection that the General Society of Mechanics and Tradesmen of the City of New York records the passing on November 8, 2001, of our member and Past President (1977), Andrew J. Adelhart. For many years he served the Society in numerous capacities, most notably as Chairman of the Library Committee. Andrew's father was also associated with the Society and graduated from the Mechanics Institute. Sincere condlences are sent to his wife and family. A memorial service was held on Tuesday, November 13, 2001.

title: November 11-17; Getting Enough to Eat
description: Four years after welfare reform reduced the government's role in helping the poor, private charities are feeding more people than the food stamp program, according to a survey by America's Second Harvest, a national network of nonprofit food banks. More than 23 million people rely on food pantries and soup kitchens -- up from 21 million in 1997. During the same time, the use of federal food stamps dropped to 17.7 million people from 21.9 million. Lawmakers decided to restore up to $6 billion of the $26 billion cut from food stamps during welfare reform. Elizabeth Becker

title: Habitats/Manhattan; They Arrived on Sept. 10, And They Plan to Stay
description: LAST fall, knowing that the youngest of their four children would be leaving for college within the year, Richard and Christine Frisbee started talking about selling their five-bedroom house in Connecticut and moving to New York.

title: What Detroit Can Teach Washington
description: THERE is an American city where powerful people have swiftly responded to the nation's first recession in 10 years. About a week after Sept. 11, they announced a new policy -- call it a stimulus package -- that has lifted the economy and probably prevented layoffs of thousands of additional workers.

title: F.Y.I.
description: A Dubious Record

title: Officials Hope For New Clues In Senate Mail
description: Federal investigators held out hope today that their discovery of what appears to be an anthrax-tainted letter addressed to Senator Patrick J. Leahy might offer fresh clues to the identity of the sender.

title: Lars Qualben: The Giving Trees
description: The abandoned lots were originally strewn with rusty cars, decrepit refrigerators and rubble. But over the years, the land became a secret garden, a tree-lined oasis with winding brick paths in the middle of Brooklyn.

title: Footlights; Art That Reflects Identity
description: There is little ephemeral or streamlike about ''Ephemeral Stream,'' a painting by the Irvington artist Steven Deo. White forms surge across the 5-foot-by-7-foot canvas, suggesting wind-whipped waves or voracious fish. Color swirls around a background that hints of bottomless depths. As an American Indian artist originally from Oklahoma, Mr. Deo makes art from the rhythms of his Creek and Euchee Indian heritage.

title: Gold Medals, Delayed, Go to Swim Team
description: It took three and a half months, but the New Rochelle Olympic swimming medalist Cristina Teuscher has been vindicated.

title: Sports of The Times; A Difficult Question to Answer: To Run or to Run No Longer?
description: TWO weeks ago, Jaleh Sedehi stood on the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge. She was part of a breathtaking early morning mosaic: 24,000 runners of all nationalities gathered together for the New York City Marathon whose theme was ''United We Run.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SKLOVER, DICK
description: SKLOVER-Dick. Memories. 22 Street/152/Cut/Stickball/Avenue J/ Punchball and marbles/Midwood and all the little things we shared for 63 years-The Forty Niners-so long dear friend. Friends forever. Love Judy, Les and all the Genatts.

title: Liberty and Security in the Age of Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: As Dig Goes On, Emotions Are Buried Deep
description: The workday for the heavy machine operators at ground zero begins as it ends. In darkness.

title: 'Five Points' Artifacts Outlast Time but Not Terrorism
description: Last spring, the tenements, grog shops and gambling houses of the 19th-century slum known as Five Points returned to life on a movie lot in Rome for Martin Scorsese's forthcoming film, ''Gangs of New York.'' A few months later, a flaming chunk of the World Trade Center buried in the ground forever a collection of 850,000 artifacts uncovered from the real Five Points, just west of Chatham Square.

title: Calling Out the Guard
description: A SINGLE-ENGINE airplane tested air security around the Millstone nuclear power station Nov. 1 when the pilot unwittingly strayed into the new, no-fly zone of 10 nautical miles around the plants. Two F-16 fighters forced the plane to land.

title: Elizabeth Ingis, Sanjay Ramaswamy
description: Elizabeth Ann Ingis, a daughter of Judith Ingis and Dr. Theodore M. Ingis of Longmeadow, Mass., was married yesterday in Springfield, Mass., to Sanjay Ramaswamy, a son of Frieda D. Ramaswamy and Dr. P. J. Ramaswamy of Longmeadow. Rabbi Michael Sternfield officiated at the Springfield Marriott.

title: Harvard Tops Yale to Finish Undefeated
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 17  Neil Rose threw four touchdown passes as Harvard defeated Yale, 35-23, today to win a season finale that had so much at stake for the Crimson:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 4 about a compact disc collection of Boston Symphony performances misspelled the surname of a former trumpeter for the orchestra. He was Roger Voisin, not Voison.

title: She Inspires Others to Be Big Losers
description: IT will come as no surprise to the dozens of people who show up weekly to hear Mary Evans that she has actually walked across hot coals. Well, perhaps just a little surprise; the blond and crisply dressed Weight Watchers leader does look more like a real-estate agent than a yogi.

title: Best Illustrated Books of 2001
description: The illustrations on these pages have been taken from the Book Review's choices of the 10 best illustrated children's books of 2001. Every year since 1952, the Book Review has asked a panel of judges to make a selection from among the several thousand children's books published that year. The judges this year were Karen Breen, children's editor of Kirkus Reviews; Thacher Hurd, an artist whose most recent book is ''Cat's Pajamas''; and Judith Rovinger, youth services consultant to the Westchester County library system. As a matter of note: Chris Raschka was a winner once before, Paul O. Zelinsky three times before.

title: Karl Smith: Boating and Breakfast
description: Karl Smith liked all things active: he got his wife, Joanne, started on running, and when they were first dating, they took karate together.

title: The Hula, From Those Islands to This One
description: THE alluring dancers call themselves Na Wahine O Mokupuni Lo'ihi. The graceful hands of these lei-adorned ladies gyrate and beckon to their spellbound audience as their hips sway like palm trees in the gentle Hawaiian breeze. But you're more likely to see these island beauties on the shores of Great South Bay than on the beach at Waikiki.

title: Castanets in a Snowstorm
description: MILKING THE MOON

title: Twain and Melville; Greyhound's Security Measures
description: Under the Mistletoe With Twain and Melville

title: Scholarships to Yale
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VANESEN, JOHN SICHER
description: VANESEN-John Sicher. Of New York City, age 63, died November 13, 2001. Beloved friend of Susan Lampert. Brother of Penny Kohn Craig, Stephen (Tommy Van Esen). Uncle of Molly, Alex and Jenny. John grew up in White Plains, graduated from NYU, received a masters in bio-psychology from Hunter College. He was an advocate for the rights of the disabled involved with Barrier Free Living and on the board of Disabled in Action. He maintained his kind and gentle spirit, sharp wit, and sense of humor against insurmountable odds. Contributions in his name may be made to Barrier Free Living, 270 East 92nd St, NYC 10009, Attn: Lewis Likits. For URL to future memorial website contact PennyCraig@aol.com. Think of John on Fechner Day, April 19.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Environmentalists Fight Over Historic Estate House
description: TWYFORD, a three-story yellow and white 150-year-old manor house with dark green shutters and graceful entryways, stands in a field of tall grasses in a wildlife refuge in Islip. Although it needs a coat of paint and a new roof, the building, once edged by acres of flower gardens and specimen trees, is still reminiscent of its past grandeur as a country manor.

title: Aisha Harris: Keeper of Confidences
description: Aisha Harris had a plan for her life, and she told her mother, Arvette Harris, that she was on schedule. At 22, she enjoyed her job at General Telecom as a customer services representative, dealing with accounts and troubleshooting. She switched her major at New York Technical College to telecommunications because she saw a future in the field.

title: All Hands on Deck
description: SAILING HOME

title: Pass the Raw Seal
description: THIS COLD HEAVEN

title: Hogging the Spotlight
description: OLIVIA SAVES

title: Getting Away From It All, But Still Staying Close By
description: THERE'S no need to travel far. Getting away from it all, even for just a day or two, is easy on Long Island. Enjoying the indulgences of a quick respite, the pleasures of the waters, the quaint charms of the Island's eastern tip, is the province of innkeepers. They won't let you leave stressed or hungry. Here are three of their stories.

title: And the Balloons March On
description: In a salute to tradition and the American spirit, the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade celebrates its 75th anniversary this Thursday, with live coverage beginning at 9 a.m. on NBC.

title: Effort to Remove Mercury Light Switches
description: BENNA FORD, a dealership in Superior, Wis., is doing its part to remove mercury from car light switches. In the last month, it has replaced seven switches.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: VERTIGO, by W. G. Sebald. (New Directions, $13.95.) A rich stew of history, fiction, reporting, fantasy, travel notes, autobiography, photographs and illustrations, this German-born author's first novel is a spiraling inquiry into the workings of memory, as the narrator reflects on episodes in European history and how they relate to his own origins and inner life. The result is an ''extraordinary, unclassifiable book'' by ''a thrilling, original writer,'' W. S. Di Piero wrote in these pages last year. ''He makes narration a state of investigative bliss.''

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: November 18, 2001
description: Weeks

title: Caution on Stock Claims
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers warned investors last week to be on the alert for fraudulent schemes involving stocks of companies that say they make military, anti-terrorism or biological detection products.

title: Down the Stream, Not So Gently
description: THE dawn was rising with a wonderful mist in the crisp, cool air over Carnegie Lake. Long-legged rowers clomped out of the Princeton University boathouse and into their shells, pumping and stretching before their early morning row.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILDEA, MARY
description: GILDEA-Mary. On November 16. Widow of the late James Gildea. Loving mother of Ann Marie Brooke, Teresa E. Solomos, James J. and John T. Gildea. Calling hours from 4 to 8 PM, Sunday, at the FitzGerald-Sommer Funeral Home, 17 South Delaware Ave, Yardley, PA. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at St. John the Evangelist Church, Morrisville, PA, on Monday, 10 AM. Interment to follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthrone, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENARDETE, SETH
description: BENARDETE-Seth. On November 14, 2001. Beloved husband of Jane. Loving father of Ethan and Alexandra Emma. Dear brother of Jose and Diego. Professor of Classics at NYU and Philosophy at the Graduate Faculty of the New School for Social Research. He was the author of many articles, translations, and books, among them ''The Being of the Beautiful'', 1984, ''Socrates' Second Sailing'', 1989, and ''Plato's Laws: the Discovery of Being'', 2000. Memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: Celebrating Firsts, Bests and Mosts
description: THEY have what it takes to get in the record books.

description: To the Editor:

title: W.N.B.A. Players Decide Not to Reopen Contract
description: The Women's National Basketball Association players' union decided Thursday not to reopen its contract with the league, even though several players are said to be unhappy with certain terms of the agreement, which expires next year.

title: Public and Private Business
description: James D. Oberweis, the president of Oberweis Asset Management, is running for the Republican nomination for United States Senator in Illinois while running the family dairy business and the family mutual funds.

title: Hartford's Latinos Revel In Securing Mayor's Office
description: When Hartford elected Eddie Perez mayor by a landslide two weeks ago, his victory margin was eclipsed by the sense of history being made: he will be the first Latino mayor of a capital city in New England. He opened his celebration at a Hartford bar by addressing the crowd in Spanish as salsa music pulsated and Puerto Rican flags fluttered around him.

title: Royal Baby Is Due Soon, And Apathy Grips Japan
description: When Japan's stuffy and secretive Imperial Household Agency coyly announced at a rare news conference in April that Crown Princess Masako was ''showing signs of pregnancy,'' the news was briefly, but richly, celebrated.

title: Melvin Burkhart, 'Human Blockhead' in Vanishing Sideshow Culture, Dies at 94
description: Melvin Burkhart, a legendary sideshow performer who billed himself as the Human Blockhead and proved it by hammering nails and spikes up his nose in front of millions of Americans in thousands of places -- from the 1939 World's Fair to countless dusty midways to the Coney Island boardwalk to an off-Broadway theater just last month -- died on Nov. 8 in a hospice in Sun City, Fla. He was 94, and always swore that it didn't hurt.

title: The Gift of Charity
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT
description: An guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Peter M. West: Terms of the Deal
description: For Eileen West, there was always "the deal" she had with her husband, Peter M. West. The deal was an agreement that spontaneity had its time and its place, and that Mrs. West was the one to say, gently, when and where. On vacations, Mr. West, a municipal bond broker at Cantor Fitzgerald, could do his latest daredevil thrill, like skydiving or hang-gliding. "But never on the first day of vacation," said Mrs. West, a hospital administrator, "always on the last."

title: November 11-17; Education in Prison
description: Taking classes in prison reduces the chances that inmates will be re-incarcerated, according to two studies. One, for the Education Department, found that 22 percent of inmates in three states who took vocational, high school or college classes in prison were back behind bars three years after their release, compared to 31 percent of those who did not. Another study, by the Open Society Institute, found that classes had an even greater benefit for women at the Bedford Hills Correctional Center. Tamar Lewin

title: All Suicide Bombers Are Not Alike
description: Joseph Lelyveld's article (Oct. 28) yielded answers to many questions but raised new ones. I now have a better understanding of why we are hated and of why what we call suicide is called martyrdom by others. What I still do not understand is how a martyr, who sacrifices his life in a show of devotion to sacred beliefs, can justify the murder of innocent people in the process. Martyrdom and murder -- how do those two concepts intersect? American office workers and airline passengers, Israeli pizza-parlor customers and Pakistani churchgoers -- all murdered. Does their death for the sake of someone else's cause make them martyrs as well or just unfortunate victims?

title: Words Fail Me
description: IN THE SHADOW

title: Albanian Moderate's Party Wins Peaceful Kosovo Election
description: After a decade of violence, Serbs and Albanians here voted peacefully today in elections for a new Kosovo provincial assembly and overwhelmingly favored a party headed by a soft-spoken Albanian moderate, Ibrahim Rugova.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASKETBALL

title: CELEBRATION; Hawaii
description: Vaguely triangular, 90 miles by 70, Hawaii, the Big Island, hems in the world's highest mountain and most active volcano, igneous deserts, rain forests and a giant cattle ranch. Its population (137,000) is one of the most diverse in the world. Hilo, the chief town, is the wettest in the United States; to the west, the Kona coast , with its black lava beaches, is predictably sunny.

title: And Bear In Mind
description: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

title: Footlights; Dance and Spirituality
description: It is dance without choreography, prayer without words, metaphor in motion. JoAnne Tucker, artistic director of the Avodah Dance Ensemble, believes her dance and spirituality workshops speak for themselves.

title: Foreigners Allied With Taliban Cling to a Surrounded Stronghold
description: Refugees fleeing the besieged Taliban stronghold of Kunduz said today that large groups of Arabs and Pakistanis fighting alongside the Taliban had taken control of the city, arresting hundreds of civilians and, in speeches, vowing a fight to the death.

title: Caryn Mermelstein, Jeffrey Weinberg
description: Caryn Robin Mermelstein, a daughter of Anne and Martin Mermelstein of Brooklyn, is to be married today to Dr. Jeffrey Mitchell Weinberg, a son of Leslie Dann Weinberg and Dr. Barry M. Weinberg of Jamaica Estates, Queens. Rabbi David S. Halpern is to perform the ceremony at the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, N.Y.

title: Private Sector; . . . Another to Find a Cure
description: When Heinz C. Prechter, the flamboyant automobile industry executive, committed suicide last summer, his family vowed to devote its efforts to battling the cause of his death. Last week, Mr. Prechter's widow, Waltraud, announced the formation of the Heinz C. Prechter Fund for Manic Depression, a nonprofit organization based in Southgate, Mich. The fund will support depression research across the United States, said Stephan Koller, the fund's executive director.

title: Victoria's Secret on TV: Another First for Women
description: THURSDAY was one strange day on television.

title: Riddle Inside the Metrodome: What's Ailing Moss?
description: Is the troubled right ankle of the star Minnesota wide receiver Randy Moss a far bigger problem than is generally known? Will surgery be needed at the end of the season? Will his career be seriously affected?

title: A Fading Scent of Doughnuts
description: EVERY day, customers at Schultz's Cider Mill ask the same thing: ''Is it true? Are you really closing?''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ALDRICH, LARRY
description: ALDRICH-Larry. A celebration of the life of Larry Aldrich will take place at 2:00 PM on November 18, 2001, at the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art, 258 Main St., Ridgefield, CT. Bus transportation will be available from 40 Central Park South at 12:15 PM.

title: Introduction
description: Our article on suicide bombers -- and photo essay on ''Jihad's Women'' -- prompted mail on the mothers of the ''martyrs,'' who take pride in sons who die like this. And many readers said that nothing is off limits in fighting terrorism -- not racial profiling, not restricting civil liberties.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-18-01: Idea Lab; If You Publish It . . .
description: This week the literary world gathered at the Marriott Marquis for its annual ritual of choosing the year's best books. It's a major event in the publishing industry -- an opportunity to wear black tie, grab a few headlines for writers (especially tough this year) and quarrel about the choices, which are always wrong. For one brief, shining moment, books matter.

title: Taliban's Out-of-the-Box Thinker Practiced Crude Science in Kabul
description: The man who left behind notes, drawings and technical reference books in a two-story private house in Kabul was probably someone with at most an undergraduate education in chemistry and physics who knew how to cook up crude explosives.

title: Backwoods of Appalachia Ablaze After Arsonists Strike
description: Beleaguered by drought and bedeviled by arson, the backwoods of Appalachia are burning with scores of fires that emergency crews from 26 states are battling in tight, smoke-packed hollows.

title: Liberty and Security in the Age of Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: Personal Business; In Refinancing, a Chance to Manage Your Debt
description: WOULD you like to improve your monthly cash flow, wipe out some debts or have more money to invest? For millions of American homeowners in these days of low interest rates, those goals can be easily attained through a mortgage refinancing.

title: Reckonings; The Oil-Hog Cycle
description: The price of crude oil, which was around $30 per barrel earlier this year, plunged last week to as little as $17, with warnings that it could go still lower. Alas, it's all too likely that today's oil price plunge will set the stage for tomorrow's oil price surge, in a repeat of a cycle that has been a major source of world instability these past three decades. Intelligent policies could break this cycle, but our actual policies seem, if anything, likely to make the cycle worse.

title: Sarah Womack, Sean Sullivan
description: Sarah Melanie Womack, a daughter of Nelda and Robert D. Womack of Houston, was married yesterday to Sean Patrick Sullivan, a son of Jean and Patrick W. Sullivan of Lakeville, Minn. The Rev. James P. Bartzan, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Old Glory Ranch in Wimberley, Tex.

title: Passages
description: FOUR IN ALL

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STRUHL, DR. BERNARD
description: STRUHL-Dr. Bernard. One year today. Your family misses you terribly. Judi, Pam, Meri and Larry

title: Tempest Rises in a Cappuccino Cup
description: LAST week you could still see the words ''Sant Ambroeus'' oh-so-faintly written in curly ''Babar'' script on the stainless steel facade of 1000 Madison Avenue, as they have been for the last 18 years. Tomorrow, they will be gone, another little piece of New York erased by time and progress.

title: Boy Detective Gets Wise
description: The pseudonymous Jay Russell's new novel, BROWN HARVEST (Four Walls Eight Windows, paper, $14.95), is crammed with ruses and red herrings, but the biggest mystery is why nobody ever thought of its ingeniously entertaining premise before. That treasured and familiar literary character, the boy detective, has grown up, traded his innocence for cynicism and morphed into the rumpled antihero of a 21st-century noir. The former smartest kid in town -- and more recently, a computer hacker and convict -- has come home for the funeral of his childhood love. But as he careers through streets named Milne and Exupry, he discovers his once sleepy town transformed into a hotbed of high-tech crime, corruption and, most jarring of all, chain stores and biscotti stands. It isn't long before he's locking horns again with his youthful nemesis, Roach Blackwell, only this time in a software war. Russell knows all the tics and twists of his genre, and his delight in playing with them is infectious. His protagonist knows all too well that his old town and its denizens have secrets to hide -- his father, the former chief of police, is a corrupt drunkard, his tomboy best friend was the local bad girl. But as he peels back layer upon layer of awful truth, he finds (as boy detectives and jaded gumshoes alike must) something noble and redemptive mixed in with the grime. Like the director David Lynch, Russell has an affection for both the heartbreakingly pure and the unspeakably seamy -- and a natural talent for mixing the two into a sweet-and-sour cocktail. If he occasionally goes in for cheap potshots at the world of boulangeries and carpal tunnel sufferers, he can be forgiven for the sincerity of his disgust and the sharpness of his wit. In his hands, sex, violence and mayhem aren't a problem -- they're the bracing, all-American antidote to bored consumerism. Mary Elizabeth Williams

title: Pictures Simply There For the Taking
description: YOU can look at John Cohen's ''There Is No Eye'' and see through very familiar eyes: the New York City eyes of Helen Levitt and Walker Evans, Evans's country eyes, the highway eyes of Robert Frank, even Margaret Bourke-White's doubting eyes in Holiness churches. These were photographers who, whatever their claims of artlessness, knew what they were looking for. Emptiness for Evans and Frank, a matter of a place that in some essential way fended off its inhabitants. Pathos for Levitt: the pathos of knowing how to wait for the unlikely event, scene, artifact or happenstance that could give a glimmer of individuality to streets that seemed to make everyone the same. For Bourke-White, the revelation of foreignness, of people not like us, right here in our own country, making the viewer wonder, at best, what the country really is.

title: St. John's Shows Depth, But It's a Quiet Opener
description: There was no upset, the small crowd was sedate and St. John's did not unveil a new offensive force. Instead, it slowly put together a victory last night with a roster that showed more depth than explosiveness.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-18

title: Business; Keeping Up With the Nielsen (Executive) Family
description: JOHN A. DIMLING helped navigate Nielsen Media Research through 16 years of seismic shifts in television while maintaining its dominance in assessing how many people are watching which programs. But Mr. Dimling's challenges in managing this cornerstone of the $60 billion TV advertising industry seem mild compared with what his successor will confront.

title: They've Become the Band That Rocks the Cradle
description: ANTHONY FIELD and Murray Cook were studying to become preschool teachers in Australia in the late 1980's when they stumbled on a gaping hole in the music industry. No one in Australia, they realized, had recorded a pop or rock album with lyrics clear and simple enough for a 3-year-old to follow but with a beat that was so jazzy, it would hook their parents, too.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERWOOD, ARTHUR R., PH.D.
description: SHERWOOD-Arthur R., Ph.D. Age 84, of Stratford, CT. Beloved husband of Marie T. (Tangney) Sherwood, died Friday, November 16, 2001. Dr. Sherwood received his B.S. and M.B.A. and Ph.D. from New York University, and was a professor at the New York University School of Business. He was born in Nutley, NJ, to the late Arthur E. Sherwood and Martha (Fricker) Sherwood, and had been a Stratford resident for 25 years. Dr. Sherwood served as a major in the US Marine Corps during World War II. He was a director at the National Community Bank of New Jersey for 40 years and had also formerly been employed as a vice president at Becton-Dickinson Corporation in New Jersey. In addition to his wife, he is survived by three beloved daughters, Karen Sherwood of Ridgefield, CT, Martha Sherwood Whittemore and her husband William, of Stuart, FL, and Laura Sherwood Rudish and her husband Russ, of Saddle River, NJ; and three grandchildren, Jessica Rudish, Katharine Rudish and Charles Rudish. Friends are invited to attend a funeral service on Sunday, November 18, 2001, at 2 PM, at the Pistey Funeral Home, 2155 Main St, Stratford (203-378-2213). Interment will be private. Friends may call at the funeral home on Sunday, from 1 PM until the time of service. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Arthur's memory to the charity of one's choice.

title: International Datebook: Through Jan. 8
description: THROUGH MARCH 15, PACIFIC GROVE, CALIF.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: No. 6 Harbors Many Germs, Not Anthrax
description: The New York City Department of Health, testing the subway system for anthrax spores, has made a not-so-startling discovery: subway stations are far from sterile environments.

title: Ideas & Trends; Cry for Help: This Industry Doesn't Fly
description: EIGHT years ago, Robert Crandall, at the time chairman of the parent company of American Airlines, famously threatened to allow American to go out of business if he could not get the airline's costs down.

title: November 11-17; Immigration Service to Split
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service, long criticized as poorly managed, will be split into two operating parts to streamline the agency's border enforcement and service duties. The reorganization reflects President Bush's promise to bring efficiencies to the immigration service, which lawmakers have complained is unable to process legal immigrants and incapable of keeping track of people who illegally enter the country. The new plan, which does not require Congress's approval, would eliminate layers of regional offices often run independently from Washington. David Johnston

title: Delicately Dissecting the Quiet Life
description: TODD FIELD still remembers the first time he heard of Andre Dubus. ''I was studying directing at the American Film Institute in 1992 and someone told me that Andre Dubus was a really great writer of short fiction,'' Mr. Field said. ''When I started reading his stories, I was amazed. Andre's stories have a classic American feeling, almost like westerns: they're about people, broken and otherwise, living in communities where everyone knows their neighbors. I immediately felt I knew these people from my childhood in Oregon. They reminded me of my cousins, my uncles, my father.''

title: How to Survive Anthrax
description: Analyses of the 10 cases of inhalation anthrax caused by recent bioterrorism incidents have just been released by two leading scientific journals. They suggest that anthrax progresses somewhat differently than long thought, that there are ways to distinguish it from other diseases and that early diagnosis can most likely save your life.

title: Gotta Dance
description: I DREAMED I WAS

title: Dining When and Where Price Is Right
description: EVERYBODY loves a bargain. And although the word wholesale is never seen on a menu, savvy consumers know the code words for it: early bird, sunset, pre-theater and especially fixed price meals. (Think of a fixed price dinner as an early bird without time restrictions).

title: Painting Emotions, As Well as Places
description: THE Chinese writer and artist Mu Xin, who was born in 1927, emigrated to the United States in 1982, and lives in Forest Hills, Queens. During the Cultural Revolution (1966-76) in China, he was imprisoned, and for 18 months between 1971 and 1972, was in solitary confinement.

title: Sports of The Times; The Twins and the Expos Belong to All of Us
description: LAST season's record book for the Minnesota Twins displayed photos of Rod Carew and Harmon Killebrew flanking Kirby Puckett, the newest member of the Baseball Hall of Fame.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: ANY way you look at it, last Monday was a bustling night on the town.

title: U.S. Envoy Looks for Change in Sudan
description: Nobody ran, as they usually do, when an airplane swept in low over the Nuba Mountains in Sudan the other day. For a change, it was food aid and not government bombs showering down on the people of Nuba, one of the most remote and wretched areas of a vast country at war with itself for 18 years.

title: Liberty and Security in the Age of Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: Science Teacher Left His Mark
description: IT has been more than 30 years since Ann Sewell was a student in Julian Kane's Earth Science class at Garden City High School. Yet when Ms. Sewell, who now lives in Maryland and works two days a week in New York, read that the Long Island Weekly was seeking stories about unforgettable teachers, she was eager to share her vivid memories of Mr. Kane.

title: Contraction to Affect Managers as Well
description: One is a manager who doesn't know if he will have a team to manage next season. The other is a coach who awaits word on whether he will be a manager, but he may never hear because the team may not exist either. That's the kind of havoc contraction is playing with peoples' lives.

title: Private Sector; For OPEC's Captain, U.S. Roots
description: CHEKIB KHELIL, the president of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, will tell you that the only house he owns is in Potomac, Md.

title: A Modern Cinderella, No Prince Needed
description: MOST actresses, when a script requires them to run, look like, well, actresses required to run. But Jennifer Garner, as the C.I.A. agent-grad student Sydney Bristow in ABC's ''Alias,'' moves with the concentrated motion of a sprinter. She digs in when she runs, with her elbows tucked close to her sides, her hands efficiently slicing upward. Best of all, she remembers to take off her high heels.

title: Freedom Rider
description: THE MIDNIGHT RIDE

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BUCCA, RONALD
description: BUCCA-Ronald. The family of Ronald Bucca would like to thank everyone for their kind sympathy and tributes to the memory of Ron. We appreciate your countless thoughful efforts to console our hearts. Your outpouring of love and support gives us strength and lets us know how much Ron touched all our lives. We especially would like to thank those who came together to make Ron's service so meaningful to us. ''Ron Stories'' and pictures may be sent to The Bucca Family P.O. Box 276 Tuckahoe, NY 10707

title: The Envelope, Please: Five Who Have Won Recognition
description: IT is often said that success is its own reward. But how about a little recognition for effort? How about a plaque for diligence? How about a trophy for unflagging friendliness?

title: FOLLOWING UP
description: After Capitol Hill, A Climb Out of the Valley

title: A Metaphor, Powerful And Poetic
description: BEFORE fashion and forgetfulness completely cover over Gerard Mortier and Hans Landesmann's decade at the Salzburg Festival, something should be said about their patronage of new music. To be sure, there had been commissions before: operas by Luciano Berio and Krzysztof Penderecki were staged in the 1980's. But Mr. Landesmann's care and Mr. Mortier's sense of occasion made new works -- and by no means only new operas -- an essential and exciting part of the festival's programming.

title: Something Happened
description: ''NOTHING ever happened there,'' the novelist Jill Eisenstadt said of her childhood in the Rockaways. ''And now I wish nothing ever had.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLYOM, EDNA (LAZAR)
description: SOLYOM-Edna (Lazar). Age 95, widow of the late Richard Solyom and the late Maurice Cashman, passed away on November 14, 2001. Devoted mother of Joan Cashman and the late Mary Faith Lang, grandmother of Richard and Georgiana Lang, great-grandmother of Melissa Lang & Caitlin and Sarah Lang. Mrs. Solyom was a partner and senior vice president of Stewart Stamping Corp., Yonkers, NY for over 35 years and president of Nike, Division of Toastmistress (New Jersey) for many years. She always had great interest in fancy stitchery and her lacemaking won many awards. Friends may call at the Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale Avenue, Scarsdale, NY on Saturday and Sunday from 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian burial will be held at Sacred Heart Church, Hartsdale, NY on Monday 11 AM. Entombment to follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery.
