title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUMENTHAL, PAUL H.
description: BLUMENTHAL-Paul H. 75. Of Las Vegas, formerly of Yonkers, on November 9. Loving husband of Fran. Devoted father of Hillary and Amy, father-in-law of Marc Alpert and Sergei Lobanov-Rostovsky, grandfather of Diane and Leslie Alpert, and Sophie Lobanov-Rostovsky. Caring brother of George. Former book buyer extraordinaire. Services were held in NYC, on November 12.

title: Art to Make a Writer Visible for the Ages
description: People who live in the Beaumont apartment building at Riverside Drive and 150th Street, say Ralph Ellison was a great neighbor as well as an illustrious writer.

title: Liberty and Security in the Age of Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: Difficulties on Defense Frustrate the Knicks
description: Most of his teammates were already gone as Mark Jackson finished dressing on Friday night in the cramped visitors' locker room at Continental Arena. His son sat beside him, happily oblivious to the problems floating through Jackson's head as he kept reporters waiting, thumbing through a small Bible as he sat with one shoe on and one off.

title: Taliban Remain in Kandahar, Their Southern Citadel, and Say They'll Fight to the Last
description: As much of Afghanistan began to cast off the effects of seven years of Taliban rule, the southern city of Kandahar, the Taliban's citadel, remained in the movement's hands today, a stubborn refuge for hard-liners.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RINGEL, LUCILLE
description: RINGEL-Lucille. Professor Emerita Cleveland State University, educator, mathematician, researcher, graduate Douglass, Bank Street and Cornell, teacher and volunteer tutor in NYC, dance enthusiast, beloved sister, cousin and aunt, died at age 83, Oct. 23, Medford Leas, NJ. Contributions in her memory: Eliot Feld, Ballet Tech, NYC.

title: 'The Royal Physician's Visit'
description: On April 5, 1768, Johann Friedrich Struensee was appointed Royal Physician to King Christian VII of Denmark, and four years later he was executed.

title: All Suicide Bombers Are Not Alike
description: Lelyveld's article makes the case for restricting the civil liberties of certain groups hiding in our open society far more eloquently than he himself may find comfortable. The resentment that makes terror possible may be born in repressive, failed societies in the Mideast, but it is only in our free society that it has an easy outlet or, indeed, a target worth striking. If we need to steel ourselves to do what we find repulsive, we should recall that Abraham Lincoln suspended habeas corpus during the Civil War and then give the Mossad a call.

title: Love in the 21st Century
description: In his article, Matthew Klam (Oct. 14) and his friends speculate about whether or not they would call someone they loved to say goodbye if they were trapped in a burning building, as so many were in September. One couple thought they would be too busy trying to escape. Klam said he would hate to have that last panic-stricken conversation running through his head till the day he died. Many of us did receive that phone call from a loved one who realized there was no longer any chance of escape.

title: Jihad's Women
description: Lynsey Addario's interviews and photographs with Islamic fundamentalists (Oct. 21) were frightening -- and frustrating. Rehima, a 35-year-old mother of six sons, is prepared to martyr them all. ''If they get killed, it is nothing,'' she says. She herself is prepared to ''suicide bomb.'' Shafia, 16, says: ''Non-Muslims are our enemy according to the Koran, so America is our enemy. We hate America.'' It's that simple.

title: A Clear Allegory
description: To the Editor:

title: Romanians Struggle To Enact Reforms
description: Adi, 14, is a Romanian street kid with ambition: he wants to be a policeman. ''All the thieves will have to share half of what they steal with me,'' he joked.

title: Correction: Solution To Nov. 11 Acrostic
description: The acrostic solution on Page 76 of The Times Magazine today is printed in error; it is for today's acrostic. The solution for Nov. 11 follows; the objective was to take letters from the answers to form a quotation, the author's name and the work from which it came.

title: Girl Saints
description: LIVING WITH SAINTS

title: The Music Man
description: HANDEL

title: Why Small-Cap Stocks Are So Hot in Cold Weather
description: FOR years, finance professors have predicted that the January effect would soon disappear because so many investors were trying to profit from it. But it hasn't. In fact, the effect this year was more than five times larger than its average size since the late 1970's, when it was first noticed.

title: Peanut Butter And Jammies
description: Isn't it redundant to call anything you put in your mouth voluntarily ''comfort food''? All food is comforting, or we'd be eating nothing but Dr. Atkins Diet Advantage Bars and gravel (not that the two are indistinguishable), with possibly a few vitamins thrown in. Unless you are on some kind of nasty medical diet or undergoing a fraternity initiation, there is no such thing as ''punitive food.'' That said, the current ether does seem to demand pleasing palliatives designed for a sort of refined slothfulness.

title: Old Prejudice Lives On In a Multiracial Ireland
description: As expected, class rolls were small this September at St. Joseph's National School, a yellow, two-room schoolhouse in the countryside near Galway.

title: At Last, Signs of Economic Revival in Russia
description: At last, Russia may be turning the corner.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, ROSE
description: WEISS-Rose. Widow of Jack Weiss, mother of Barbara Goldberg and the late Melvin Weiss, Granma Rose to seven grandchildren, their spouses and seven great-grandchildren, died November 13, 2001. Donations may be made to the Jack Goldberg Memorial Scholarship at Temple Beth Sholom, 400 East Middle Turnpike, Manchester, CT 06040.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Incentives Are Offered to Fill Parsippany Offices
description: AS dozens of companies rushed to find a bivouac in New Jersey immediately after the World Trade Center attack, there was a lot of talk among brokers in the state about the ''second wave'' of relocations that would surely follow.

title: Preserving Stuyvesant Town As a Shrine to the Ordinary
description: Changes are afoot at Stuyvesant Town. So is a movement to stop them. Last week, the Historic Districts Council announced its support for designating Stuyvesant Town a landmark. Now, its tenants must decide if they want to approach the Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: Learning Curve; Surprise. War Works After All.
description: EVER since Sept. 11, Americans have wondered what the war on terrorism will look like.

title: Predecessor To Chrysler Building
description: To the Editor:

title: Eyewitness Accounts
description: To the Editor:

title: Mine Blast in China Kills 33 Workers
description: BEIJING, Nov. 17 (AP)  A pocket of gas exploded in a coal mine in central China this week, killing 33 miners, official news media and a mine bureau employee reported today.

title: Reflections on Another Afghanistan
description: AS I look through the photos from that summer, I keep staring at two from the livestock market in Kabul, the capital of Afghanistan. In one, a grinning, turbaned shepherd straddles a ram -- its horns, whiskers and ruff painted a bright red to mark it as part of his flock -- proudly holding its head steady for my shot. In the other, I am astride a two-humped camel, sharing the space between the humps with a villager who had just made the camel kneel so I could climb on. The man then took me on a ride around the perimeter of the dusty market, where villagers were trading sheep, goats, camels and chickens. The men and boys milling around took little notice; apparently a Western woman riding on a camel was not an unusual sight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE ROTHSCHILD, DEBRA
description: de ROTHSCHILD-Debra. Died the 13th of November, 2001, at Mount Sinai Hospital, New York. Wife of Robert de Rothschild. Mother of Jacob Alain, her two year old son. Daughter of Leonard and Ileen Cohen. Daughter-in-law of Baroness Alain de Rothschild. Sister and sister-in-law to Joel and Karyn Cohen, sister-in-law to Eric and Beatrice de Rothschild, sister-inlaw to Pierre and Beatrice Rosenberg. Aunt to Harry, Samuel, Mariana Cohen, Jim, Saskia, Pietro de Rothschild, Marie and Brandino Brandolini and their three sons, Guido, Marcantonio, Gioacchino. Beloved for her exceptional character, the warmest of hearts, the most endearing charm, she will live in the souls of her family and innumerable friends.

title: Alicia Rangel and Howard Haughton
description: THE bridegroom demurs. He was not, Howard Lee Haughton said, ''a player'' in college. ''People would misconstrue my ability to just know a variety of people and be friendly with my being a player,'' he explained in a voice so smooth he could step in for Barry White.

title: This Year, Maybe They'll Behave Until at Least Dessert
description: I'D be the last one to say a word against having 17 people arrive at your house during the Thanksgiving holiday. I like having a family, I really do. Seeing your kin for those special occasions can lead to moments of glorious awareness, affectionate reverie, and joyful communication.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOUNAROPOULOS, NICHOLAS
description: GOUNAROPOULOS-Nicholas. Beloved husband of Maria, father of Jason and Liza, grandfather of Alexander and Aphrodite, brother of Alkistis & Marika. Died Friday, November 16, 2001 at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 74 and lived in Manhattan with his wife. Born in Cairo, Egypt of Greek parents, Nicholas proudly served the United Nations for over thirty years in posts in Europe, the Far East and Africa. A seafaring aquarian who lived life on his terms, he will be remembered and missed by all who came in contact with him. In lieu of flowers, please donate to your favorite charity. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, November 18th at 152 East 28th Street, between Lexington and 3rd Avenues. Hours 2-5 PM.

title: Staying Rent-Stabilized in a Condo
description: Q I am a rent-stabilized tenant in a condominium building that was converted years ago. My next-door neighbors, who own their unit, want to combine my unit with theirs. In a complex deal they have proposed, they would purchase a slightly larger unit down the hall, and the building would allow me to move there. Will I be able to retain my stabilized status -- with all of its rights -- if I make this move? . . . Kenneth Zrubek, Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSMAN, ELYANE
description: WEISSMAN-Elyane. On Nov. 9, 2001. Survived by her children Amy, Beverly and Lewis. Beloved grandmother of Jacklyn, Jonathan, Cory, Martin, Ashley & Martin. She will be greatly missed.

title: Travel Advisory: Correspondent's Report; Airlines Are Cutting Their Discount Services
description: When the airlines reduced their flight schedules by as much as 25 percent after the Sept. 11 attacks, they also cut discount flight operations and the favorite perk of very frequent fliers, the free upgrade to first class. The first major sign that low fares will be less available came in late September when United and US Airways said they would shut down their discount operations.

title: November 11-17; OPEC May Not Cut Output
description: Oil prices have plummeted to their lowest levels in two years, gasoline is sure to follow, and the unlikely party responsible for what could be a boost to the weak economy is the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries. Don't chalk it up to altruism. OPEC has declared a price war, telling rivals that it will not try to prop up prices by cutting production unless they follow suit. So far, OPEC's competitors, in particular Russia, refuse to cooperate. Neela Banerjee

title: Liberty and Security in the Age of Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: November 11-17
description: Congress Reaches Airport Security Compromise

title: With Fronds Like These . . .
description: ED HILLER and George Vor oscak are wrapping up the summer really wrapping it up, with plastic trash bags and a lot of duct tape. Mr. Hiller, owner of 4 Sons Custom Palm Trees, and his right-hand man, Mr. Voroscak, are the prime tenders of the plastic palm trees in this Jersey Shore summer Valhalla. As the leaves on the living trees start to fall, so do the fronds on the hundreds of plastic palms here.

title: Often Frantic, Traders Find A Pastime: Not Moving
description: Standing for a living in the ear-shattering pit at the New York Mercantile Exchange gave John Orlando, a futures trader, a bad back. Business in the pit is conducted so fast and furiously by its heaving, jostling mass of humanity that buyers looking for the right seller typically end up in a moshlike melee.

title: After Curbs, Korea Tries More Freedom For Business
description: The sprawling conglomerates that dominate South Korea's economy are on the verge of obtaining the freedom to expand their holdings after nearly four years of restraints imposed by the government during the economic crisis of 1997 and 1998.

title: Postings: Under Third Owner at Half Moon Bay; Croton Project Is to Expand
description: Construction has begun on the first of 124 condominium town houses at a riverfront site in Croton-on-Hudson in northern Westchester. The gated community, to be called Discovery Cove at Half Moon Bay, is being developed by Spectrum Skanska and will be adjacent to an existing development that was put up a decade ago.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CONHEIM, SUE
description: CONHEIM-Sue. November 19, 1950. In ever loving memory. Daughter Marilyn

title: Investing; Bullish, and Patient, on Energy Stocks
description: DESPITE last week's plunge in the price of crude oil and in shares of big oil companies, some Wall Street analysts remain upbeat about the long-term prospects for energy stocks.

title: Letters
description: BERNSTEIN'S MAHLER

title: The Sound of His Music
description: SOMEWHERE FOR ME

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHULKIND, JOSEPH
description: SCHULKIND-Joseph. On November 16, 2001. Beloved husband of Sylvia and the late Eleanor. Loving father of Nancy and Marcus. Cherished grandfather of Wendy, Jonathan and Eric. Service Sunday, 1 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. The family will be at the home of Dr. Nancy Rosen, 300 E. 54th St, Sunday evening, beginning at 6 PM. Contributions in his memory may be made to The National Neurofibromatosis Foundation, 95 Pine St, NY, NY 10005.

title: Welcoming A Return To Risk
description: MICHAEL R. BLOOMBERG'S mayoral victory showed that the city is willing to take risks. No one is in love with the idea that a billionaire bought the election. But perhaps it took a billionaire to buy City Hall out of the status quo. That independence, however come by, might work to the advantage of New York architecture.

title: Boston: An Insider's Address Book
description: THE ESSENCE

title: Douglas D. Ketcham: He Just Started Climbing
description: Douglas D. Ketcham climbed the corporate ladder. Literally.

title: 'Better Not Call Me Again. I'm a Monster.'
description: I'M NOT BOBBY!

title: Malan Leads Brown Past Columbia
description: Mike Malan rushed for 183 yards and 4 touchdowns in his final college game as Brown coasted to a 45-21 victory over Columbia yesterday at Wien Stadium. The Bears finished the season 6-3 over all and 5-2 in the Ivy League, while the loss denied Columbia (3-6, 3-4) its second winning Ivy League mark in 30 years.

title: Where Death Fell From Sky, Lives Intersect
description: Long before Sept. 11, at least a house or two on any street in the Belle Harbor section of Rockaway was likely to be flying the United States flag. Even more visible, though, was the unofficial flag of the Rockaways, with its motif of bright red lettering on white, a rigid sign on unbending poles: No Parking, Sat. Sun., Holidays, May 15-Sept. 30.

description: To the Editor:

Best Illustrated Books of 2001
description: The Book Review has asked a panel of judges to choose the 10 best illustrated books from among the several thousand children's books published this year.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RICH, GORDON A.
description: RICH-Gordon A., 11/8/57-11/19/00 There is no death! The stars go down. To rise upon some other shore And bright in heaven's jeweled crown. They shine forever more. Loving you, missing you...now and forever. Mom and Dad

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: German Bank Is in Talks With Enron To Buy a Unit
description: A large German bank is in talks to buy Wessex Water from the Enron Corporation, people close to the discussions said today.

title: Moss Debut Shows Little
description: Receiver Santana Moss finally made his professional debut, but it was probably not what he was hoping for, especially in his hometown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THORBECKE, HOCHWALD, JEA NETTE, M.D., PH.D.
description: THORBECKE - HOCHWALD - Jea nette, M.D., Ph.D. Wife of Gerald Hochwald, M.D. Loving mother of Bertrand, Neal and Steven. Cherished grandmother and friend. Died unexpectedly on Friday, November 16, 2001. Born in the Netherlands and resident of Douglaston, Queens, NY. She was Professor of Pathology at New York University Medical Center for more than 45 years. Closed services will be held on Wednesday, November 21, 2001. Memorial service to honor her life will be announced at a later date.

title: At an Islamic School in Pakistan
description: To the Editor:

title: Sinking Knicks Follow the Horizon West
description: The real sign of the Knicks' demise cannot be found in their record or in their jump shots that continue to carom off the back iron. Or in the agitated coach, who is growing edgier by the loss. Listen to the public-address announcer at any away game when he says, ''And now . . . the New York Knicks.''

title: The Corrupt and Brutal Reclaim Afghan Thrones, Evoking Chaos of Somalia
description: The galaxy of warlords who tore Afghanistan apart in the early 1990's and who were vanquished by the Taliban because of their corruption and perfidy are back on their thrones, poised to exercise power in the ways they always have.

title: More Americans Online
description: The number of Americans logging on to the Internet reached a new high in October, with 115.2 million people going online at least once during the month, according to data from the measurement company Nielsen/NetRatings.

title: Dominant Lindros Dazzles Rangers
description: Rangers fans did not, at first, open their arms to Eric Lindros, but there is little doubt about their affection now after he scored a hat trick and led a 6-2 rout of the Atlanta Thrashers last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: A Dad's Inner Artist, an Irresistible Friend and a Distinctive Vocabulary
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: 'The Hobbit'
description: Chapter I: AN UNEXPECTED PARTY

title: New Paltz Journal; Razzle, Dazzle And Aahs
description: On a rocky ledge near here, the stargazers fixed upon a glittering speck of light flitting across the black sky. It had barely faded away when they swiveled their heads to catch the next one, then the one after that. A chorus of oohs and aahs erupted.

title: Laid Low by Last Recession, California Is Ready for Next
description: When she was called in one day last month and laid off from her $10-an-hour job as a housekeeper at the Loews Santa Monica Beach Hotel, Otilia Toledo said she was hurt and anxious. But she was not desperate.

title: Harvard's Rose Is Seeking an Extra Season
description: As if beating Yale on Saturday to complete a perfect season were not enough, Harvard received good news regarding the defense of its Ivy League title next season. Neil Rose, the most successful passer in school history, will petition the league for an additional year of eligibility, Coach Tim Murphy confirmed yesterday.

title: At Comdex, a Ticketmeister With Bluster
description: ''So how many tickets do I have left?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTH, NATHANIEL
description: ROTH-Nathaniel. Age 89, on November 18, 2001. Adored husband of Sophie and the late Dorothy. Cherished father of Vivian and the late Steven. Beloved brother of Esther and Martin. Devoted grandfather, great-grandfather, father-in-law, uncle, stepfather and brother-in-law. Teacher, photographer, scientist, scholar. Services 11:15 AM, today, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Crohn's & Colitis Foundation of America, 386 Park Avenue South, New York, NY 10016.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ONSLOW, DOROTHY TUCKER
description: ONSLOW-Dorothy Tucker. On November 17, 2001. Beloved mother of Danielle and Carolyn Dyer and the late Bernard Dyer. Wife of the late Bernard Dyer, Harry Stockwell and the late Lord Lewis Onslow. Dancer with Balanchine's Ballet Caravan, Finigan's Rainbow and many shows including Guys and Dolls. Visitation Tuesday 4 to 7 PM, Redden's Funeral Home, 325 West 14th St, NYC.

title: Kosovo Winner Wants Independence
description: Ibrahim Rugova, whose party easily won elections in Kosovo on Saturday and is expected to become its president, announced today that his first priority was to seek the independence of the province, which is still technically part of Serbia.

title: With Love, From Pupils In Heartland; Unlikely Pen Pals Share Grief, Hopes and Banter
description: The package was addressed to Any Third Grade Class, New York City, U.S.A. It was stuffed with letters from children in Yorkville, Ill., who yearned for friends in the city whose suffering had transfixed them. They somehow landed in Julie O'Connor's mail box at Public School 48 in Washington Heights, and a correspondence was born.

title: About Time for Campaign Reform
description: The drive to reform campaign fund-raising has understandably stalled since Sept. 11, and opponents claim that lawmakers are too busy dealing with the national emergency to clean up the political system. That argument is ridiculous, given the fact that Republicans and Democrats have quietly resumed soliciting campaign donations, including unregulated soft money, from all the old special interests. Obviously, if they have time to do fund-raising, they have time to pass a law to clean up fund-raising.

title: A Shabby Defense
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEILBRUNN, ROBERT H.
description: HEILBRUNN-Robert H. On November 18, 2001, at age 93. Loving and devoted husband of Harriet, married for 67 years. Beloved father of Helaine Lerner and Joan Rechnitz. Adored grandfather of Emily, Adam and Joshua Rechnitz. Great-grandfather of Max Paladino. Father-in-law of Sidney Lerner and Robert Rechnitz. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, on Monday, November 19, 6 PM to 7:30 PM. Funeral service on Tuesday, Novemver 20, 11:30 AM, also at Frank E. Campbell. Interment to follow at Mt. Carmel Cemetery.

title: Holiday Sales Outlook Roils Book Business
description: When the profitable life of a new hardcover book comes to an end, its publisher usually consigns it to an inconspicuous office building on Fifth Avenue near 26th Street in Manhattan that is the graveyard of unsold books. It is the headquarters for several companies that sell publishers' leftover copies back to bookstores for an undignified afterlife in the deeply discounted remainder bin.

title: 'QED': Iconoclastic Physicist for All Occasions
description: The lecturer, as lecturers are wont to do, poses a rhetorical question. Is it possible, he asks, indicating himself, that ''this thing walking back and forth in front of you, talking to you,'' is in fact simply ''a great glob'' of atoms?

title: Young Viewers Like Screen Translation
description: The reviews of ''Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone'' from the professional critics last week generally followed similar lines: the film hews slavishly to the book it is based on, and that makes it a mediocre movie.

title: Out of the Woods, Into the Spotlight
description: It was Christmas 1989, and Michael Strahan was home after his first semester at Texas Southern University. Since the age of 9, home for Strahan was Mannheim, West Germany, where his father, Gene, served as a major in the United States Army. The base gym, its drill field and nearby glades and forests had been the training ground for young Michael, the place where Gene Strahan had honed his son into an extraordinary specimen of speed and strength with regimens designed for the elite forces of the 82nd Airborne.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAPADIN, LOTTIE
description: SAPADIN-Lottie. Died on November 15, 2001, of pancreatic cancer. She was the beloved wife of Elmer and the loving mother of Randall, Michael and Janet, and their spouses Phyllis, Rosa and John. She is also survived by five grandchildren, Joshua, Jeremy, Danielle, Anya and Eliza, and her brother Henry Krisch and his wife, June. Services were held on November 16. Contributions in memory of Lottie may be made to: The Lottie Sapadin Endowment Fund at the Heather Garden of Fort Tryon Park (212-408-0267); or the Perlow Hospice at Beth Israel Hospital (212-420-3370); or Beth Am, the People's Temple, 178 Bennett Ave., New York, NY 10040.

title: I.B.M. Joins Kroll to Provide A Package of Security Services
description: I.B.M. plans to announce today that its Global Services arm will jointly market a package of security services with Kroll, a New York company that specializes in the protection of corporate assets.

title: President Is Named At OMD Media Agency
description: Joe Uva was named worldwide president and chief executive at OMD, New York, the media agency unit of the Omnicom Group, effective on Jan. 1. He succeeds Daryl Simm, who was promoted in February 2000 to president and chief executive at the Omnicom Media Group unit of Omnicom.

title: Hemingway's Blessing, Copland's Collaboration
description: In 1957 I received a phone call from the producer John Houseman who said he was planning a new live CBS Sunday afternoon series to be called ''The Seven Lively Arts,'' a compilation of dance, drama, music and the like. ''I saw what you did last year with Hemingway's 'The Battler,' '' he said, ''and I wondered whether there was a Hemingway you could do for us.''

title: Month Without Rain Kindles Forest Fires Across the Region
description: With no significant rain for a month and some streams in New York State and New Jersey flowing the lowest ever recorded, forest fires have begun breaking out in parched woodlands.

title: Satguru Subramuniyaswami, Hindu Spiritual Leader, 74
description: Satguru Sivaya Subramuniya swami, a native Californian who sought spiritual meaning in India as a young man and became the spiritual leader of Sri Lankan Hindus, died on Tuesday at his ashram on the Hawaiian island of Kauai. He was 74.

title: A New Story For 2 Rivals From the 70's
description: Bob Woodward arrived in the newsroom of The Washington Post around noon on Sept. 11, walked up to the executive editor, Leonard Downie Jr., and said ''What do you want me to do?'' Across town, Seymour M. Hersh was on the phone, working intelligence sources he had cultivated for three decades. Even before the trade center towers had collapsed, the editor of The New Yorker, David Remnick, had called to say: You are working on this for the next year.

title: Fees Change Everything
description: For Internet sites already hurt by falling advertising revenue, there is evidence a second shoe has dropped: Web surfers are abandoning sites that ask them to pay for content, a new survey has found.

title: At an Islamic School in Pakistan
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; A Punch, the Intrigue And a Looming Tyson
description: WITH his other champions, the legendary trainer Emanuel Steward always knew what to expect when the bell rang for the first round. They would come out punching. But he's never known what to expect from Lennox Lewis, who too often came out thinking instead of punching. So on Friday night Steward was hoping to get a clue when he visited Lewis's suite.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRANE, ROBERT J., M.D.
description: KRANE-Robert J., M.D. Of West Newton, MA, on November 17, 2001. Beloved husband of Diane (Graff). Devoted father of Jennifer Krane Tarleton and her husband Brett, and Jonathan Krane, both of NYC, Jessica Krane and Justin Krane, both of West Newton. Dear grandfather of Sarah Emma Tarleton. Services at Temple Shalom, West Newton, MA, on Monday, November 19, at 1 PM. Memorial observance at his late residence through Friday, sundown. In lieu of flowers, remembrances to Dr. Robert J. Krane Fund at Mass. General Hospital, 55 Fruit St, Boston, MA 02114; or the Sarcoma Center at the Dana Farber Cancer Institute, 44 Binney St, Boston, MA 02115. To send a note of condolence, www.brezniakrodman.com.

title: Campaign Contribution Is Returned
description: Talk Magazine found itself in a difficult spot last week when it came to light that an employee had made a donation from company funds to the gubernatorial campaign of Lt. Gov. Kathleen Kennedy Townsend of Maryland.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZALK, KAYLA KAZAHN
description: ZALK-Kayla Kazahn. Of Newton, MA, formerly of NYC. 70 years old. Devoted mother of Jason and the late Mara Zalk, beloved sister of Sandra Kazahn Masur and aunt of Josh and Ted Masur. Charismatic teacher. Interment on Friday, November 23, at New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. Donations in her memory to Compassionate Friends, 1791 Main St, Concord, MA 01742.

title: Pakistan Fears 3,000 Pro-Taliban Troops Have Slipped In
description: Pakistani intelligence officials, addressing a subject of mounting concern, estimated today that 3,000 or more Taliban and Al Qaeda fighters have slipped over the border into Pakistan's tribal areas in the week since the fall of Kabul.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'KANE, MARTY (MORTIMER)
description: O'KANE-Marty (Mortimer) on November 17, 2001, of Garden City, NY, and Vero Beach, FL. Beloved husband and best friend of Marion, his wife of 49 years. Devoted and proud father of Dennis and his wife Janis, John and his wife Lucy, Marian Cotter and her husband Jim, Doreen Candon and her husband Steve, Carol O'Connor and her husband Eddie and Brian and his wife Helen. Loving grandfather of 14 grandchildren. Dear brother of Robert O'Kane. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave at 12th St, Garden City, Monday and Tuesday 2-4 and 79 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday 10 AM, St. Joseph's R.C. Church, Garden City. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Marty O'Kane Memorial Scholarship Fund, c/o Xavier High School, 30 W. 16th St., NYC 10011, Attn: Fr. Gatti, appreciated.

title: For Baseball, a Five-Star Menu
description: The 2001 class of free agents is relatively thin, and even some of the star players available are shrouded with question marks.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Board Rejects Apartment Tower Again
description: A proposal for an apartment building on the Upper East Side that has drawn the opposition of Woody Allen and others was rejected for a third time by the local community board last week. Despite a scaled-back design, the building would still be too tall, opponents say. Community Board 8, an advisory body, voted 26 to 10 on Wednesday night to reject the proposal, a plan by the Tamarkin Company for a residential tower at 91st Street and Madison Avenue. The current design calls for a building 127 feet tall, 15 feet shorter than a design rejected by the Landmarks Preservation Commission last June. The commission, which considers community opposition, is to discuss the matter soon. Mr. Allen last year made a short film to protest the project.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, MARVIN
description: GOLDMAN-Marvin. Beloved husband of Renee. Devoted father of Sue and Eric J. Rosenthal, and Anne Goldman. Loving grandfather of Karen and Lisa Rosenthal, David and Danielle Winn. Dear brother of Judi and Jackie Diamond, Maddy and Shelly Diamond. Private graveside services to be held on Tuesday, November 20th.

title: Scientific Relay System: Both Help and Hindrance
description: Thousands of enthusiasts began play here today in the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals, two days behind the usual schedule. The normal Friday start was delayed because hotel and convention space were not available.

title: No Pain, No Gain In Gym of the Future
description: Douglas Dunn

title: A Nation Challenged
description: On the Battlefield

title: Wild Welcome Greets Rivera At Fox News
description: Geraldo Rivera arrived at the Fox News Channel last week. What a welcome he got.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Oct. 20 with an article about the effect of the Sept. 11 terrorism in undercutting support for broader immigration policies in Europe misstated the percentage of Austria's population that is Muslim. Most estimates place Muslims at 2 to 4 percent of the population; 17 was the percentage for all who say they are not Catholic.

title: White House Letter; The Politics of Plight And the Gender Gap
description: The American women coming out of the State Department last week were using words like ''amazing'' and ''unbelievable'' to describe what they had heard. The Bush administration, in a worldwide offensive kicked off on Saturday by Laura Bush, was not only publicizing the brutality toward women under the Taliban -- no news there -- but promising that the United States would insist that women have power in a post-Taliban Afghanistan. That, the American women said, is remarkable news.

title: Virgin Blue Seeks Investor and Plans Stock Sale
description: Virgin Blue, the Australian discount air carrier, said today that it was seeking an investor to buy as much as 49 percent of the airline with the remainder to be sold in a public stock offering, possibly late next year.

title: Editorial Observer; Trimming Beards and Ideologies in Modern Afghanistan
description: Americans shocked by the rapid collapse of the Taliban in Afghanistan probably have a lot more surprises in store. At this point even the experts are unable to guess which forces will do what in the power centers the Taliban abandoned or in the enclaves where they are holding on. Top American officials admit that before Sept. 11 they had no clear idea of what the Taliban's power structure was, or how many supporters it had. Even now, they know little or nothing about the identities of the Taliban loyalists, defectors and opponents spread throughout Pashtun-speaking southern Afghanistan.

title: If Philip Morris becomes Altria, its corporate image may lose some of the odor of stale smoke.
description: THE decision by the Philip Morris Companies to call for a new name, the Altria Group, has touched off an intense debate among experts in corporate identity and advertising.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISNER, MARGARET WALLACE
description: EISNER - Margaret Wallace. Greensboro, VT. 80, at her home, November 17. Survived by husband William; sons William Jr., James, Peter; five grandchildren. Services: 10 AM, December 1, des Groseilliers Funeral Home, Hardwick, VT.

title: Torricelli Backed Donor's Bid for a Korean Project, a Letter Shows
description: Despite Senator Robert G. Torricelli's insistence that he did almost nothing for a political donor who claims to have given him expensive gifts and cash, Mr. Torricelli strongly recommended the man for a contract on a sensitive nuclear-reactor project in North Korea.

title: Metro Matters; For the Jobless, The Waiting Stretches On
description: THOUSANDS are out of work in and around New York City. About 79,000 jobs disappeared from the city in October alone in the aftermath of Sept. 11, and the economy was weakening long before then. Matters talked to scores of people at the city's first Twin Towers Job Expo on Oct. 17 and reached some of them again over the weekend to see how they were doing. Most are still unemployed. They don't like to complain. As one said, ''I am alive and healthy.''

title: A Bunker Isn't a Tax Shelter, Greenwich's Golf Clubs Find
description: Gentility, even in Greenwich, often ends at the golf course. But this time, cries of cheating are coming from the clubhouses, not the greens.

title: A Deadly Siege At Last Won Mazar-i-Sharif
description: At least 300 Taliban soldiers died in the fighting when troops of the Northern Alliance laid siege to a Taliban barracks as the alliance seized the city eight days ago, its commander here said today.

title: Harry Potter and the Box Office of Gold; Film Based on Popular Book Sets Record With $93.5 Million Opening Weekend
description: The fledgling wizard with the zigzag scar rode his Quidditch broom to the biggest movie opening of all time this weekend as ''Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone'' earned an estimated $93.5 million in its first three days, making it all but assured of breaking the $100 million mark Monday afternoon.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Hospital Worker Accused Of Assault
description: A medical technician at a hospital has been charged with sexually assaulting a male patient who was heavily medicated, the authorities said yesterday. A spokeswoman for the hospital, St. Clare's Hospital and Health Center, would not comment yesterday on the charges or disclose the technician's duties. The police said the technician, Soe Naing, 42, of Woodside, Queens, was performing oral sex on a 28-year-old patient around 11:15 p.m. Oct. 24 when the patient woke. Mr. Naing was arrested on Saturday. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FONTAKIS, DEBORAH J. (NEE CONATY)
description: FONTAKIS-Deborah J. (nee Conaty). On November 12, 2001, of Floral Park, NY. Flight attendant on American Airlines Flight 587. Survived by devoted husband Steven, loving children Christopher and Stefanie. Cherished daughter of Rose and the late James D. Conaty. Beloved sister of Barbara Cruise, Jim Conaty, Susan Gallagher, Teresa Marler and Terence Conaty. Adoring aunt to Tim, Mallory, Liam, Jake and Ian. Family will receive friends and relatives at the Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, 29 Atlantic Ave, Floral Park, NY, on Monday, November 19, and Tuesday, November 20, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. A funeral Mass will be held at Our Lady of Victory Church in Floral Park, on Wednesday, November 21, at 10:30 AM. Interment Flushing Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Deborah J. Fontakis Memorial Foundation, 1562 Richmond Rd, Staten Island, NY 10304. This foundation was established in Debbie's honor to support the education of her children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHU, WU, PING
description: CHU-Wu-Ping. Peacefully, at home, on November 16, two months short of 101. Deeply beloved mother of John, Yvonne (Meinwald), Theodore, Joan (Fu); grandmother of Barbara, David, Anne (Chu), Constance, Pamela (Meinwald); great-grandmother of Ethan, Benjamin, Beatrix. Funeral private. Interment at Kensico Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory may be made to Palliative Care Unit, Mt. Sinai Hospital.

title: U.S. Publicly Accusing 5 Countries of Violating Germ-Weapons Treaty
description: The United States has concluded that North Korea, Iraq and at least three other countries are developing germ weapons, and has decided to accuse them of violating a treaty they ratified banning such weapons, administration officials said this weekend.

title: Text of Powell's Speech
description: The following full text of Secretary of State Colin Powell's speech was obtained from the State Department's Web Site.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Oct. 21 about the evolving American strategy for the war in Afghanistan misstated the number of Soviet soldiers wounded during the 10-year Soviet occupation of Afghanistan that ended in 1989. It was some 50,000, according to the Russian government, not hundreds of thousands.

title: Kremlin and Rebel Envoys Discuss Peace for Chechnya
description: For the first time since war erupted 27 months ago between Russia and Chechnya, a separatist province, top envoys from the Kremlin and the Chechen rebel government met publicly here today to discuss peace.

title: Four Journalists Kidnapped and Shot, Witnesses Say
description: JALALABAD, Afghanistan, Nov. 19  Four foreign journalists were kidnapped and shot today by armed gunmen on the highway halfway from here to Kabul, three witnesses said. A fifth man, a translator, was reported missing.

title: Foes Claim Taliban Are Killing Soldiers Who Seek to Defect
description: Foreign soldiers fighting for the Taliban have begun killing their Afghan Taliban comrades in a desperate effort to hang on to the encircled city of Kunduz, refugees and Northern Alliance soldiers here say.

title: Of Doctors and Detectives
description: DNA dragnets occur when people who belong to a group that had the opportunity to commit a crime  like workers in a hospital where a patient was raped  are asked to submit DNA samples to be compared with crime scene evidence. There is much debate on how broad a group should be asked for samples. Gale Scott discussed DNA dragnets with a forensic scientist and a professor of medical ethics. These are edited excerpts from those interviews.

title: Five Days in Sydney
description: For those who are not afraid of heights, Downunder Direct has a five-night package in Sydney that includes a climb of the Sydney Harbour Bridge if booked by Nov. 30 for departures no later than Dec. 7. It costs $1,299 a person, double, and includes round-trip air fare from Los Angeles on Air New Zealand, five nights in the Wentworth Hotel and daily breakfast. The three-hour climb, which takes participants 440 feet above the harbor, is led by guides, and climbers are tethered to the bridge at all times. Participants must be reasonably fit but need no climbing experience. From Dec. 8 to Feb. 25, it's $300 more. Information: (800) 642- 6224 or go to www.downunderdirect.com .

title: In America; The Vanishing Act
description: The U.S. unemployment rate rose sharply in October, to 5.4 percent, the biggest jump in five years.

title: Essay; Big Mo
description: Take massive air power. Add to it a substantial local force on the ground guided by special forces of a superpower determined to work its will. Put this military muscle to work on the side of an oppressed population eager for freedom. Result of combining the strong with the just: the overthrow of a tyrannical regime.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARROW, SELMA DAVIS
description: ARROW-Selma Davis. Of Flushing, Queens, on November 17, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Nathan. Loving mother of Eric, Michael, Goldie and Donna, sister to Melvin and Joe Newman. Survived by grandchildren Benjamin, Suzanne, Minda and Sara.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONOHUE, BARBARA SANFORD
description: DONOHUE-Barbara Sanford. Of Bronxville and Germantown, NY, died at home on November 15, 2001. She was 59 years old. She was married for 23 years to A. James Donohue, an investment banker, who died in 1995. She is survived by her three children, Benjamin, Claire and Michael, and her father, Gordon Sanford, all of Bronxville; and a brother, James Sanford, of Warren, VT. A funeral service will be held on Monday, November 19, at 3PM at the Reformed Church of Bronxville. Contributions in her memory may be made to: The New York Botanical Garden, 200th St. and Kazimiroff Boulevard, Bronx, NY 10458.

title: E-Commerce Report; Some big retailers are optimistic about online wish lists, a high-mortality sector.
description: SINCE the earliest days of e-commerce, the big question has been whether the Internet spawns new buying behavior, or whether consumers simply transfer old habits online.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCOOEY, ROBERT H.
description: McCOOEY-Robert H. Of Rye, NY, and Sea Island, GA, on Friday, November 16, 2001. Born Brooklyn, NY, October 14, 1930, to Herbert and Elizabeth (Larney) McCooey. Grandson of the late John H. McCooey, political leader of Brooklyn for 25 years. Beloved husband of Mary Catherine (Joyce), devoted father of Robert H., Jr. (Kristina Grimm McCooey), Mark, Michael, Timothy, Mary Catherine and Kevin, and grandfather of Robert III, Christopher, Elizabeth, Matthew and Thomas McCooey. Also survived by three brothers: his twin, Richard of Washington, DC, Bert of Westhampton Beach, NY, and John of New York City. He attended Brooklyn Prep and graduated form Iona Preparatory School and the College of the Holy Cross ('52). He served as Lieutenant J.G. in the U.S Navy from 1952 to 1954. His business career began on Wall Street as an independent broker and later as a specialist at Henderson Brothers. In 1988 he, with his sons and daughter, founded The Griswold Company, which has become one of the largest independent brokerage firms on the New York Stock Exchange. He has been a member of the NYSE for 46 years. His dedication to faith and family was lived through his service to many charitable organizations. At the time of his death, he was a Board member of Lincoln Hall, Lincolndale, NY; the New York Foundling Hospital, NYC; St. Vincent's Hospital-Westchester; Weston Jesuit School of Theology, Cambridge, MA; Our Lady of Mercy Medical Center, Bronx, NY; Morality in Media, New York City;, and Graymoor, Garrison, NY. He served as Chairman of the Board of Trustees of Iona Preparatory School, New Rochelle, NY; Catholic Big Brothers, New York, NY; Mercy College, Dobbs Ferry, NY; and Our Lady of Mercy Hospital Fund. He was a past Board member of the Boy Scouts of New York, the Cerebral Palsy Association (Westchester), Catholic Youth Organization, St. Agnes Hospital, White Plains, NY, College of New Rochelle and AmeriCares, New Canaan, CT. He was an active meber in Catholic organizations, serving as Chancellor of the Order of Malta. He was a member of the Knights of the Holy Sepulchre and the Cardinal's Committee of the Laity of the Archdiocese of New York. He was also a current Trustee of Resurrection Church, Rye, NY, and Our Lady of Victory Church in the financial district, and served as a member of the Finance Committee for both parishes. The family will receive visitors on Sunday, November 18, from 5 to 8 PM, and Monday, November 19, from 3 to 6 PM, at Resurrection Church, 910 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at Resurrection Church on Monday, November 19, at 6 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Robert H. McCooey Memorial Cancer Research Fund, New York Hospital, 525 East 68th St., NY, NY 10021, attn: Peggy Maher.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, RITA H.
description: BERGER-Rita H. Died at home on November 16, 2001, after a brief illness. Born 1912, in Poland, she grew up and completed medical studies in Vienna. She came to the United States in 1941. In the U.S. she pursued medical research and served for many years as a volunteer woking with metally ill clients of The Bridge, Inc. She was a director of The Bridge, and its first residence, on Amsterdam and 83rd St. in Manhattan, is named Rita Berger House in her honor. Her husband, Jacob Berger, died in 1976, and her brother, Frederick Both, died in 1971. She is survived by her daughter, Vivian O. Berger, who is Nash Professor of Law Emerita at Columbia Law School. Services 11:30 AM, November 20, at The Riverside, 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: A Fireball Too Far
description: Just before Sept. 11 changed storytelling in America forever, my Hollywood agent explained that my new novel was doomed in movieland because it lacked sufficient ''explosive moments.'' It was exactly nine fireballs short of the prevailing formula.

title: Sehorn Is Expected to Play
description: Jason Sehorn, the Giants' star right cornerback, was added to the team's injury list today because of soreness in his right knee. Sehorn, who did not practice Saturday, was listed as probable, and the team said it expected him to play Monday night when the Giants face the Minnesota Vikings.

title: With Water and Sweat, Fighting the Most Stubborn Fire
description: Jose Maldonado has all the basic tools: a ladder truck to lift him up and out toward the fire; a pumper to ensure nearly 800 gallons a minute is poured onto it; and his respirator, boots and other protective gear to guard against the roiling waves of heat and toxic smoke.

title: Attacks Shift Spotlight on Public Figures
description: Before Sept. 11, Senator James M. Jeffords of Vermont was in the political stratosphere for bolting from the Republican Party, becoming an independent and single-handedly delivering Senate control to the Democrats. The night before the terrorist attacks, Katie Couric interviewed Mr. Jeffords for ''Today.'' In August, Mike Wallace interviewed him for ''60 Minutes.'' Those interviews never ran.

title: United in Grief and Prayer, Sharing the Common Language of Tears
description: Dozens of buses, vans and even trolley cars trundled over the Marine Parkway Bridge yesterday to the rib of land in Queens that last week became the city's second disaster site in two months. They bore the families and friends of those who died in the crash of Flight 587 first to a simple prayer service on the edge of the beach and then a short distance farther, to the crash site itself, in Belle Harbor in the Rockaways.

title: INSIDE
description: Plastics Scrutinized Crash

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASKETBALL

title: Mourning and Merriment From Young Irish Visitors
description: The Royal Irish Academy of Music Chamber Orchestra, a student string ensemble that performs standing (except for the cellists) and without a conductor, is visiting the United States this month. At its Tuesday evening performance at Merkin Concert Hall, this 16-player group made a fine case for the state of music education in Dublin.

title: Islanders Searching For Basics
description: Dave Scatchard, the enthusiastic and abrasive Islanders center, said late Saturday that his slumping team would simply have to push a reset button.

title: U.S. Rejects Any Deal for Head of Taliban to Flee Kandahar
description: The United States will not support any effort to allow Mullah Muhammad Omar, the Taliban's supreme leader, to escape from Kandahar, the Taliban's spiritual and political stronghold, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today.

title: Powell Pledges New U.S. Role in Middle East
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 19 -- Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said today that the Bush administration -- after ten months of hesitation -- would send high-level envoys immediately to the Middle East to seek a cease-fire, restart negotiations and help set the terms for the creation of a "viable" Palestinian state and a more secure Israel.

title: As the Taliban Flee, Time to Send In Fido
description: To the Editor:

title: An Old Politician Moves to the Boardroom
description: William M. Daley, the campaign chairman of Al Gore's unsuccessful presidential bid, has decided to move down to what was once enemy territory, Texas, to become president of SBC Communications.

title: Jets Leave Dolphins Dazed and in Second Place
description: The Jets-Dolphins rivalry has been reduced to this: the biggest cheer today at Pro Player Stadium was for a bit of scoreboard trivia -- the Dolphins intercepted Joe Namath six times in a 43-0 victory over the Jets in 1975.

title: Layoffs Are Announced at Several Agencies
description: Several agencies laid off employees last week. The New York office of DDB Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group ( news/quote ), dismissed 20 people, or 6 percent of its staff of 330.

title: Top Democrats Politick Through Rural Mexico
description: Thousands of miles away from their own constituents, the two top Democrats from the United States took a morning ride today through a rural stretch of central Mexico that had all the trappings of a campaign.

title: A Workhorse of the Skies, Perhaps With a Deadly Defect
description: One of an unglamorous fleet, the plane that crashed last Monday morning in Queens was an efficient, anonymous workhorse whose marketers nicknamed the model ''The Regional Profit Machine.'' The ill-fated Airbus A300 was wider than many planes, carried lots of people on the short, packed flights from New York to Miami and the Caribbean, and cost less than other planes to operate.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the News Watch column of Circuits on Nov. 1 about new Samsung computer monitors referred incorrectly to a television tuner available with the SyncMaster 151MP and 171MP models. It snaps into the monitors; it is not built in. The report also included erroneous suggested prices supplied by a company representative. The models are $799 for the 151MP (not $749) and $1,399 for the 171MP (not $1,299).

title: Layoffs Are Announced At Several Agencies
description: Several agencies laid off employees last week. The New York office of DDB Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, dismissed 20 people, or 6 percent of its staff of 330.

title: This Week's Economic Events
description: MONDAYHousing ConstructionSept.

title: Spanish Judge Charges 8 With Terrorism, Citing Likely Links to Al Qaeda
description: A Spanish investigative judge today formally charged eight Arab men living in Spain with participation in terrorism-related crimes, contending in an order that sent the men back to jail that he had seen considerable evidence indicating that they were members of Osama bin Laden's organization, Al Qaeda.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RULNICK, DORIS
description: RULNICK-Doris. November 1, 1992. In loving memory always. Your dear daughter, Joyc

title: Woman Is Found Dead in a Fire
description: A woman was found dead and her husband and two children were injured yesterday morning in an apartment fire in Leonia, N.J., the authorities said.

title: For a Trio at the State Fair, No Grand Nights for Singing
description: GREAT AMERICAN PLAIN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINSON, JO LIST
description: LEVINSON-Jo List. On Saturday, November 17th. Cherished mother of Dinse Israel of Zichron Ya'akov, Israel, the late Michael Israel, Debbie and Chip Weber of Orange, CT, Jo and Daniel Levinson of Westport, CT, and Donna and Jonathan Levinson of New Rochelle, NY. Adored daughter of Vera G. and the late Albert List of Greenwich, CT. Treasured sister of Carol and Eric Schwartz of Denver, CO, Olga and George Mack of NY, NY, and Viki Laura List of Rosemont, PA. Beloved Bubba of 11. She lived as she believed and will be deeply missed. Service Monday, November 19, 9:30 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th and Amsterdam Avenue. Burial at Manhattan Country School Farm, Roxbury, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory to Manhattan Country School, 7 East 96th Street, NYC 10128; or The National Coalition Against Censorship, 275 7th Avenue, NYC, would be greatly appreciated. Shiva 11 AM-5 PM and 7-9 PM, Tuesday and Wednesday, at 263 West End Avenue, Apt 19B, Thursday, 11 AM-5 PM and 79 PM, and Friday, 9:30 AM-12:30 PM, at 75 Dorchester Road, New Rochelle, NY. Directions at ''The Riverside.''

title: Seeking a Kabul Coalition, Killings in Kunduz and Bodies in the Rubble
description: After six weeks, the end of the war in Afghanistan may be glimpsed, with Taliban forces clinging to their last two strongholds. But to win the peace, the United States wants a broad-based government in Kabul, and the Northern Alliance has finally said it will join other anti-Taliban factions in discussing it.

title: Afghan Victors Agree to Talks On Interim Rule
description: Bowing to American pressure, Northern Alliance officials agreed today to attend a meeting of Afghan opposition groups somewhere outside the country, eliminating one of the initial stumbling blocks to the creation of an interim government here.

title: The Series: A Year at Speed
description: Robert Lipsyte delves into the world of auto racing in this series that follows the sport, its safety, stars and popularity.

title: 'The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring'
description: Chapter 1: A Long-Expected Party

title: Redefining 'Normal' In Abnormal Times
description: To the Editor:

title: Challenge Revives SAT Test Debate
description: The challenge being mounted against the main SAT exam by the president of the University of California has given an extraordinary lift to critics who have long considered the test an inappropriate and unfair measure of high school students.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW JERSEYTRENTON: STATE AID FOR MEADOWLANDS TO DROP State financial support for the Meadowlands Sports Complex will drop next year to $31 million, less than half of this year's subsidy, according to figures released on Friday by the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority. Many capital projects, including scoreboards, a new field and a restaurant, have been completed. But attendance has been dropping since the Sept. 11 terror attacks. Income at Giants Stadium is expected to drop next year to $16 million, from $17.5 million this year, and Continental Airlines Arena is expected to post a loss.  (AP)

title: Terror in Beirut, Frustration in Washington
description: Lee Blessing's hostage drama, "Two Rooms," written in 1988, was chosen for production by the Blue Heron Theater before Sept. 11, and it would have been understandable had the theater not followed through. The play, about the kidnapping of an American professor by terrorists in Beirut, might easily have been judged too salty for the national wound. Oddly enough, however, the opposite is true. The attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon and the subsequent education we've all received in the complexities of the terrorist threat make this comparatively simple-minded story too bland to be abrasive.

title: Innovative? For Sure. But What Is It?
description: EVEN at a time when the working definition of opera is extremely loose, the growing body of works that the composer John Moran calls operas  the latest of which, "Book of the Dead (Second Avenue)," opens tomorrow at the Joseph Papp Public Theater  is likely to strain an opera fan's notions of the form.

title: Of Doctors and Detectives
description: DNA dragnets occur when people who belong to a group that had the opportunity to commit a crime  like workers in a hospital where a patient was raped  are asked to submit DNA samples to be compared with crime scene evidence. There is much debate on how broad a group should be asked for samples. Gale Scott discussed DNA dragnets with a forensic scientist and a professor of medical ethics. These are edited excerpts from those interviews.

title: 3 Golds for Benko At World Cup Meet
description: Lindsay Benko of the United States won the 400-meter freestyle yestesrday for her third gold medal at the FINA World Cup in Rio de Janeiro.

title: At an Islamic School in Pakistan
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; The Secondary Ushers In a New Era of Light
description: WITH 4 minutes 33 seconds left in the third quarter, Dolphins fans were beside themselves with rage and frustration. By 9:13 of the fourth quarter, most of them were gone. Large splotches of orange and blue seats were visible as Dolphins fans turned their stadium over to raucous Jets fans. Chants of ''J-E-T-S, Jets! Jets! Jets!'' reverberated inside Pro Player Stadium.

title: Foreigners Who Fought For Taliban Shot in Head
description: Here at a former battlefield outside Kabul, at least half of 30 dead fighters that the the International Committee of the Red Cross found today had been shot in the head, officials close to the investigation of the deaths said.

title: F.D.U. Back in Tourney After Long Absence
description: The long road back to respectability for the Fairleigh Dickinson men's team has taken it back to the N.C.A.A. Division I tournament after 11 years.

title: The Civics Education of Generation 9/11
description: To the Editor:

title: Tommy Flanagan, Elegant Jazz Pianist, Is Dead at 71
description: Tommy Flanagan, a jazz pianist who with a classic trio set a high standard for elegance in mainstream postwar jazz, died Friday night at a hospital in Manhattan. He was 71 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Budget-Cut Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: Change and Fear in Colombia Rights Panel
description: Working under death threats, the prosecutors investigating the massacres and assassinations in Colombia's civil war have never had it easy. Some have been killed or driven from the country, and because of a chronic shortage of money in the national attorney general's office, investigations have sometimes stalled.

title: Behind the Burka: Women Subtly Fought Taliban
description: In the walled garden of her house, Soheila Helal waged a quiet rebellion against the Taliban. On a patio softened by rugs and book-ended by two small blackboards, she ran a school for 120 students, mostly girls. It was a transgression on two counts: as a woman Mrs. Helal was not supposed to work, and her female students were not supposed to learn.

title: Webb Wins As Sorenstam Sets Record
description: While Karrie Webb completed a sensational tournament today, Annika Sorenstam completed an incredible year.

title: Gold Miner Weighs Revising Its Offer For Australian Rival
description: AngloGold, the gold producer, said today that it might raise its bid or restructure its offer for Normandy Mining of Australia in an effort to top a bid by its rival, the Newmont Mining Corporation.

title: Aware of U.S. Pressure, Sharon Insists on Calm Before Talks
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel, concerned about possible new pressure by the Bush administration to accelerate steps toward peace negotiations here, today rejected the idea of easing a requirement that seven days of quiet must precede other formal steps endorsed by both sides.

title: Entrepreneurs' Pride
description: To the Editor:

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of Friday, 4,343 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, OGDEN NORTHROP, JR.
description: LEWIS-Ogden Northrop, Jr. Suddenly on November 14, 2001, at age 22. Cherished son of Ogden and Susan Lewis, adored nephew of Margaret Patterson High and William Hall Lewis, III. Beloved by countless friends. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory to The Buckley School, 113 East 73 Street, New York, New York 10021, or Groton School, Box 991, Groton, Massachusetts 01450, would be greatly appreciated. Funeral arrangements incomplete.

title: Editors' Note; A Nation Challenged
description: News of the terrorist attacks and their aftermath appears today in Section B; index, Page B2.

title: Themes of Gloom and Doom Fill Japanese Bookstores
description: There is no shortage of bad news in Japan these days yet another recession, continued political fumbling and even mad cow disease. But if books are a window into a society, you would think Japan was on the verge of collapse.

title: MORE U.S. TROOPS IN BIN LADEN HUNT; HIDE-OUTS BOMBED
description: With the rapid collapse of the Taliban, the United States has intensified its pursuit of Osama bin Laden and his network, adding more commandos to the chase and aiming more airstrikes at hide-outs near the border with Pakistan, officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKEL, ARTHUR
description: FINKEL-Arthur. Devoted husband of Beverly. Loving father of Barbara Stone and Lynne Petnick. Adoring grandfather of Lee and Laura Petnick and Maggie Stone. A gentle man.

title: One Corner of Afghanistan Peacefully Selects a Governor
description: Peace reigned here today.

title: The Job Nobody Trained For
description: America's diplomatic, military and intelligence strategy came together quickly after Sept. 11. Abroad, we already have the most prominent terrorists on the run. But what about protection at home? The Office of Homeland Defense has accomplished very little so far, and Americans are beginning to wonder if Tom Ridge, its director, is holding an empty title.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, NANCY
description: KAPLAN-Nancy. 56, of Irvington, NY, died Sunday of cancer. At the time of her death, she was an adjunct assistant professor of education at Pace University, an instructor for the Science Leadership Institute at Purchase College, and a docent at the American Museum of Natural History. She is survived by her husband, Lewis A. Kaplan, her daughter, Merrill, her mother, Doris Gelberg, of New York City, and her sister, Wendy Gelberg, of Massachusetts. The funeral will be held at Larchmont Temple, Larchmont, NY, on Tuesday morning, November 20, 2001. Contributions may be made to Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center.

title: Esquire Suspends 'Dubious' Awards
description: When magazines have a signature issue, a regular yearly treat that endures for decades, they customarily celebrate with a big blowout anniversary issue.

title: Phillips and Conoco to Form U.S. Gasoline Giant
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company and Conoco Inc. agreed yesterday to merge, creating an oil company with a market value of $35 billion. It would be the nation's largest gasoline retailer and would combine pump brands like Conoco, Phillips 66, Union 76 and Circle K.

title: Pakistan Demands Alliance Not Assert Control of Kabul
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 19  Pakistan warned the Northern Alliance today that any attempt to turn its military victories into political control would jeopardize the international assistance that is desperately needed to rebuild Afghanistan.

title: Confused Knicks Continue To Struggle
description: The rude blocked shots and fancy breakaway dunks were bad enough. But when the Los Angeles Clippers' backup point guard began making the Knicks look like the Washington Generals, it really got sad.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAUCH, R. STEWART
description: RAUCH-R. Stewart. 87, at his home in Bryn Mawr, PA, November 16, 2001, after a brief illness. Born in Villanova, PA, on July 15, 1914, he attended the Montgomery Country Day School and graduated from St. Paul's School, Concord, NH. A member of the Class of 1936 at Princeton Unversity, he was elected to the Phi Beta Kappa Society and was a member of the Ivy Club. He held a LLB from the University of Pennsylvania and honorary degrees from Swarthmore College and Temple University. He was married to the late Frances Brewster Rauch on June 7, 1941, and is survived by a sister, Paton Rauch Roberts of South Natick, MA, a brother, Thomas M. Rauch of Easton, MD; five children, nine grandchildren and one great-grandchild. He was associated with the law firm of Barnes, Dechert, Price, Myers and Clark from 1941-1949, except for service as lieutenant with the U.S. Navy from 1942-1945. He joined the Philadelphia Saving Fund Society in 1949, and served as President from 1955-1971, and as Chairman from 1971-1979. He was a member of the Board of Directors of many corporate and civic organizations, including Bell Telephone of Pennsylvania, Delaware River Port Authority, General Accident Fire and Life Association, Girard Trust Bank, Penn Central Corp., Pennsylvania Railroad, The Philadelphia Contributionship, The Philadelphia Orchestra Association, the Urban Affairs Partnership. An early and fervent advocate of civil rights, he received the Philadelphia Award for the individual who advances ''the best and largest interest of the communty'' in 1978. Burial will be private; a memorial service will be held Monday, December 17, at 11:30 AM, at St. Christopher's Church, Gladwyne, PA. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to The American Philosophical Society, f/b/o The Rauch Scholars Fund, 104 South Fifth Street, Philadelphia, PA 19106.

title: Companies Compete to Provide Internet Veil for the Saudis
description: Nearly a dozen software companies, most of them American, are competing for a contract to help Saudi Arabia block access to Web sites the Saudi government deems inappropriate for that nation's half-million Internet users.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAMSEY, NINA
description: RAMSEY-Nina. On November 18, 2001, at age 43. Beloved wife of Gregory. Devoted daughter of Si and the late Nancy Friedman and stepdaughter of Margaret Friedman. Dear sister of Mark Friedman and adoring aunt of James Friedman. Interment private. Memorial service to be announced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAJNSOD, ELEANORE
description: FAJNSOD-Eleanore. We mourn her passing on November 13, 2001, after a tenacious battle against pancreatic cancer. Elly was born December 26, 1938, in Brooklyn, daughter of Irving and Rae (Widomlansky) Wilkes, and graduated Thomas Jefferson H.S. While living in the Glenwood Projects, she worked at South Shore H.S., lastly as a paraprofessional. After raising a family, she attended Brooklyn College at nights for 14 years, receiving her B.A. in 1987. This was followed by a Masters Degree and 30 credits above. She then taught 2nd grade at P.S. 251, in the Flatlands area, continuing to teach until the very end. As a master teacher, she enriched the lives of her students with numerous extracurricular projects. Her classroom library of hundreds of books, developed with her own funds, is being donated to P.S. 251. Active in various organizations, Elly enjoyed spending summers with her family in the Hamptons, attending concerts, and traveling; she was a member of Young Israel of Bedford Bay synagogue. Predeceased by her brother Harvey, whom she adored and cared for in his final illness, Elly leaves behind Leon, her husband of 43 years; Robert (and Adeline) Wilkes, brother; Harriet (and Maurice) Wittenberg, sister; Lori (and Aaron) Maslow and Miriam (and Michael) Steinberg, children; Lina (and Michael) Newman, her cousin whom she deemed a sister; nieces and nephews. An outstanding and devoted grandmother, Elly is also survived by her jewels (the term she always used): Rachel (age 10), Simcha (8), and Dov (6) Maslow, and Adina (11) and Benjamin (7) Steinberg. Elly was buried November 15, at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY. The family will be sitting shiva until this Wednesday morning at 2649 E. 65 St., in Mill Basin. A loving biography of Elly was written by Adina earlier this year, and copies will be available upon request to the family. ''An accomplished woman, who can find? Far beyond pearls is her value. ... Her mouth is opened with wisdom, and the teaching of kindness is on her tongue.'' Proverbs 31:10, 26.

title: Uzbekistan Hinders Plan to Aid Afghans, Relief Workers Say
description: The plan to move relief supplies from Uzbekistan into northern Afghanistan, promoted by the United Nations as the best way to assist three million civilians as winter approaches, has left many relief workers frustrated. They say the plan's promise has been bogged down by Uzbek bureaucracy and infighting among relief agencies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SNYDER, HENRY (HANK)
description: SNYDER-Henry (Hank). August 10, 1916-November 17, 2001. Devoted father of Eric, Fran and Ilana. Loving father-in-law of Barbara and grandfather of Robyn, Hila and Alan. Fifty-two year resident of Hewlett and founding member of Congregation Etz Chiam in East Rockaway. WWII veteran, First Lieutenant, U.S. Army, awarded Bronze Star. Outstanding gardener and bird lover. The family will be receiving visitors through Saturday, November 24, at 185 Lakeview Drive, Hewlett. Tax deductible donations can be made to Mary Johnson Children's Center, 81 Water St, Middlebury, VT 05753.

title: The Specter of Nuclear Terror
description: For most Americans there is no more frightening threat than terrorists with nuclear weapons. Assuming Osama bin Laden does not already have them -- the assumption most experts make -- everything possible must be done to prevent him or other terrorists from obtaining them.

title: Gordon Is Right Guy For the Turns Ahead
description: My year at speed, like the gasoline in poor Jerry Nadeau's tank, dwindled away on this lovely southern Sunday as Jeff Gordon took his rightful throne and Bobby Labonte, last year's champion, reached Victory Lane only because the front-runner disregarded the advice you give your children on every road trip -- never pass up a pit stop.

title: Dolphins Can't Find Any Peace Of Mind
description: Defensive end Jason Taylor was the last player out of the Miami Dolphins' locker room today. Disgusted, he threw a towel into his locker and adjusted a bandage on his right ring finger before acknowledging Miami's eighth straight loss to the Jets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NORTON, BROTHER ADELBERT JAMES
description: NORTON - Brother Adelbert James, F.S.C. 83, of Lincroft, NJ, on November 17, 2001. His teaching assignments included Bishop Loughlin High School, Brooklyn, where he was Head of the English Department from 1950 to 1952, and Manhattan College where he was Head of the Education Department and Director of the Division of Teacher Preparation. Surviving are several cousins. Calling hours will be held at De La Salle Hall, Lincroft on Tuesday from 2 to 4 PM, and 7 to 9 PM. The Funeral Liturgy will be celebrated at De La Salle Hall on Wednesday at 10 AM, followed by interment at St. Gabriel's Cemetery, Marlboro, NJ. Memorial donations to De La Salle Nursing Development Fund, 810 Newman Springs Road, Lincroft, NJ 07738, would be appreciated. For information contact Higgins Memorial Home, 20 Center Street, Freehold.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 8 about Youssef M. Nada, an Egyptian-born banker whose office in Switzerland was raided by police officers searching for financial links to terrorists, misstated the reason Egypt banned the Egyptian Muslim Brotherhood, to which he belongs. It was penalized, in 1948, for opposing King Farouk, not Gamal Abdel Nasser, who took power after helping to overthrow the king in 1952.

title: Ravens, Out to Show Browns, Are Shown Up
description: The Baltimore Ravens had heard and seen enough of the Browns' crowing and clowning over Cleveland's victory when these teams met last month, so this afternoon the Ravens set out to clarify a few things. The Ravens wanted the wunderkind Browns to know that the Lombardi Trophy still resided in Baltimore. That the champion Ravens had dominated their division over the last two seasons and had no intention of relinquishing that grip.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALKER, BERNICE R. (NEE ROLF)
description: WALKER-Bernice R. (nee Rolf). In New Haven, CT, on November 12, 2001, of Leeder Hill Drive, Hamden, CT. Beloved wife of the late Charles Allen Walker and loving mother of Allen, John and Larry. Cherished grandmother of Karin, Jessica, Courtney and Meredith. Born in New Sweden, TX, Bernice graduated from Texas College of Arts and Industries in Kingsville, TX, and earned a Master's Degree in Business Administration at Northwestern University. She taught at Texas A & I, where she met Charlie and at Quinnipiac College in Hamden, CT. She was proud of her role as the Master's Wife at Berkeley College. Bernice was an avid and talented artist. Most importantly, she loved people and had innummerable friends. A Service of Remembrance will be held at Whitney Center, 200 Leeder Drive, Hamden, CT, Saturday, December 15th at 2 PM. For information, contact Beecher & Bennett, 2300 Whitney Avenue, Hamden, CT. www.beecherandbennett.com

description: The search-engine service provider Fast Search and Transfer has added constantly updated news stories to the results provided by its flagship site, Alltheweb.com.

title: Muddied Picture For Eclipse Award
description: Lord Zada took the lead two fences and three-eighths of a mile from home, then galloped out to a 15-length victory yesterday in the $100,000 Grade I Colonial Cup at Springdale Race Course in Camden, S.C., throwing the balloting for steeplechasing horse-of-the-year Eclipse Award into uncertainty. He became the seventh different winner of the seven unrestricted Grade I races held by the National Steeplechase Association this season.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies on Thursday about the National Book Awards misstated the sex of the protagonist of Virginia Euwer Wolff's ''True Believer,'' the winner of the Young People's Literature prize. The character is a girl, not a boy.

title: Ford Motor Workers Get on the Job Training in Religious Tolerance
description: The Christians asked about fatwas, divine revelation and the promise of paradise for terrorists, while the Muslims listened. Both groups wore sport coats, work shirts or lab coats, and a few women came with heads covered. But they all carried the same storied emblem on their ID cards, the blue oval encircling the scripted Ford.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAPERSTEIN, RABBI HAROLD I.
description: SAPERSTEIN-Rabbi Harold I. The officers, Board of Directors and congregants of Temple Emanu-El of Lynbrook sorrowfully record the passing of our beloved Rabbi Emeritus who served our congregation with love and dedication for over 47 years. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Marcia, Rabbi Marc, Rabbi David and Rabbi Sanford and their families. Services at Temple Emanu-El 11:30 AM, Monday. Laura Silverman, President Rabbi Paul Joseph Cantor Avery Tracht

title: London Journal; A Storm Swirls Around a Son's Death on Everest
description: At around midday on May 13, 1999, Michael Matthews reached the summit of Mount Everest. At 23, he was the youngest Briton ever known with certainty to have conquered the world's highest mountain. But with that final, supreme triumph, the superlatives ended.

title: Tentative Homecomings in Kosovo, Without the Homes
description: Un der heavy NATO protection past two checkpoints, an armored tank and a roll of barbed wire stretched across the only road into town -- 80 Serbs have just returned to their village here in the Osojane Valley, which they fled in the summer of 1999.

title: Hoping for an Appealing Match
description: Critics say the Bowl Championship Series dilutes the importance of conference races and lessens the prestige of major bowl games except the designated title match, which takes place at the Rose Bowl this season. This week's rankings certainly suggest an appealing championship possibility. Miami, which clobbered Syracuse, 59-0, took over first place for the first time in the New York Times computer ranking, remained first in the Associated Press media poll and returned to first in the coaches' poll by ESPN and USA Today.

title: A Call to Arms and the All the Intricacies of a Triangle
description: Eve Queler, the music director of the Opera Orchestra of New York, rightly prides herself on her good record of introducing singers who then go on to important careers. Her concert performance of Verdi's neglected early opera ''La Battaglia di Legnano'' on Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall had four such singers, all of whom were making return appearances.
