title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEVER, MARTIN J.
description: DEVER-Martin J. Age 85, of Wyckoff, NJ, died Saturday, November 17, 2001. Born in New York City, he lived in Ridgewood and Wyckoff, NJ, for 45 years. He retired in 1986 as the Managing Partner after 39 years with Mendes & Mount, Attorneys, New York, NY. Martin was a member of Downtown Athletic Club, Union League Club and the Mid Ocean Club in Bermuda. Graduate of St. Francis Xavier High School of NY, Fordham College, Class of 1939 and Fordham Law School, Class of 1943. Beloved husband of the late Dorothy (nee Cunniff). He is survived by three children, six grandchildren and two sisters. Funeral from the Vander Plaat Funeral Home, Wyckoff, NJ, on Wednesday, 9:30 AM. Funeral Mass, St. Elizabeth's R.C. Church, 10 AM. Interment Christ the King Cemetery. Visiting, Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Memorial contributions may be made to Alzheimer's Association, 400 Morris Avenue, Suite 251, Denville, NJ 07834-1365; or Christian Health Care Center, 301 Sicomac Avenue, Wyckoff, NJ 07481.

title: For Downtown, Vacant Offices And Lost Vigor
description: The renaissance that began in Lower Manhattan in the late 1990's is now in reverse. Six office towers totaling 13.45 million square feet were destroyed in the World Trade Center attack on Sept. 11, yet the buildings that remain have not filled up with tenants. In fact, there is a lot more empty office space downtown today than before the attack.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I think the most important thing is that he is not able to function any longer, and we're agnostic as to how that happens. I rather doubt -- just given the circumstances here -- I rather doubt we're talking about a long, drawn-out trial.''

title: In Nuremberg With a Renewal of Hope
description: With his uncanny knack for prophesying the dark spots of the future, Wagner set the immense final tableau of ''Die Meistersinger'' on the meadows outside Nuremberg. His musical vision is exhilaratingly realized in the Met revival that opened on Saturday afternoon. The principals endow their characters with a richness that makes the opera a historical novel in sound. The orchestra is full and magnificent but able to skip beautifully into the apprentices' dance. The chorus is powerfully sure. With James Levine at the helm, the pomp, the sweetness, the mockery and the poignancy are all powerfully there, and yet the scene just goes on glowing with humanity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAUCHMAN, ALEXANDER
description: RAUCHMAN-Alexander. On November 17, 2001. Husband of the late Edna. Loving brother Beatrice, Philip, Denis and the late Frances. Longtime member of the Westside Institutional Synagogue. President of the Men's Club and Sponsor of Youth concerts. Service Tuesday, 9:45 AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Colorado's Magical Roy Casts Dry Spell Over the Devils
description: The Devils found out again today how the puck stops at Patrick Roy's crease. They had five shots at Roy during their first manpower advantage, midway through the second period. They had three clear breakaways in the last six minutes of the second period.

title: Nets Head West After Loss to 76ers
description: After sprinting to a 7-1 record, the Nets felt their legs stiffen Saturday night as they stopped playing defense and began resting on their success. As a result, the Philadelphia 76ers snapped the Nets' five-game winning streak and showed they might be on the verge of regaining the momentum that helped them win the Eastern Conference championship last season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, WILLIAM ''BILL.''
description: KLEIN-William ''Bill.'' 84, died Saturday, November 17, 2001. William, known as Bill to everyone, owned and operated William Klein Jewelers, a family business in New York City. He was a prominent jeweler and diamond setter to the trade and his work was of the highest caliber. He was so well known, the industry made him a 60th year celebration for his participation and leadership in the jewelry community. His loving wife, Estelle Reznik Klein, a son, Stephen J. Klein, and daughter Lauri (Raymond) Klein-Stropnicky survive him. Two grandchildren, Emma and Lily Klein-Stropnicky, and sister Shirley Schneider of Delray Beach, FL, also survive. Funeral service will be held today at noon, at the Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Ave. at South Broadway, White Plains, NY. The family will receive friends from 11 AM to noon, at the funeral home. Interment will follow at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ.

title: Siren's Lament: So Many Sailors but So Little Love
description: Beware the siren's call, but pity the siren, too. Invited to create a new work for the Limn Dance Company's current and splendidly danced season at the Joyce Theater, the veteran choreographer Murray Louis has played some witty mischief with ancient myth in ''Isle (From an Ancient Legend).''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOMEISLER, ROBERT EVANS
description: BOMEISLER-Robert Evans, 78, on November 12, 2001, in Santa Monica, CA, of Multiple Myeloma. Born in Santa Monica on December 18, 1922, son of New Yorkers Kathryn and Louis Edwin Bomeisler, Jr., ''Bo'' was a man of many gifts and passions, which he shared freely with family and friends. A WWII veteran, he was a radio technician on the USS Eaton. A UCLA alumnus, he had a career in technology and computers, retiring from Xerox in 1987. Bo, who was young at heart for his entire lifetime, was an all-around athlete par excellence, inveterate genealogist, computer guru, and loyal friend to many. He leaves his loving family: daughter, Anne Bomeisler Farrell (John), Del Mar, CA; son Brian Evans Bomeisler (Roya) and granddaughter Sophie Rose, NYC; former wife, Dr. Betty Edwards, Santa Monica; and brother Donald Bomeisler and family. Contributions to International Myeloma Foundation, (800) 452-2873; or www.myeloma.org.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Nissan's Profit Grows
description: The Nissan Motor Company posted record profits for the third consecutive half-year, benefiting from a weaker yen and cost-cutting. Nissan earned a net 230.3 billion yen ($1.87 billion) in the six months ended Sept. 30, up 34 percent from the period a year earlier. The company said it cut costs by 101 billion yen ($822 million) and was still on track to earn 330 billion yen ($2.68 billion) in the full year despite a 1.4 percent dip in sales. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TULIN, ELYACHAR, ANNA
description: TULIN-ELYACHAR-Anna. On November 18th, at 97, in NYC. Survived by 3 nieces in Germany, where she was born in 1903; by loving relatives of Abraham Tulin, her first husband who died in 1972; and by the family of her second husband, Col. J.R. Elyachar, who died in 1989. Services Wednesday, 11:45AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

We express our deepest sympathies to her husband, our friend and former partner, Judge Lewis A. Kaplan, and their daughter Merrill, and to all other members of the family.

title: Nassau Health System Woes Haunt Shaky County
description: Nassau County split off its public health care system in 1999 in a fiscal maneuver to aid both the county and the health system, but now they are both suffering. The health care system is threatening to lay off 400 workers -- almost a tenth of its work force -- and its problems are haunting the county.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLANAGAN, TOMMY LEE
description: FLANAGAN-Tommy Lee. Jazz great, on November 16, 2001, at 71 years of age. Beloved husband of Diana Flanagan, father of Tommy Flanagan, Jr., Rachel Flanagan Jackson, and Jennifer Flanagan. Brother of Luther Flanagan, Douglas Flanagan, and Ida Flanagan Jones. Grandfather of Jenell, Dominique, Ann, Meighan, Riley Ann, and Tommy III. Family will receive friends at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, on Tuesday November 20th, 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. Funeral services Wednesday 7 P.M. at Saint Peter's Lutheran Church, 619 Lexington Avenue at 54th Street.

title: World Briefing | Australia: Australia: Normandy Still Favors Newmont
description: Pursued by two suitors, Normandy Mining continued to back the takeover bid it received from Newmont Mining, which trumped a bid from AngloGold. A report by Grant Samuel & Associates determined that the bid by AngloGold, which values Normandy at 1.46 Australian dollars a share (76 cents), ''is neither fair nor reasonable,'' Normandy told the Australian Stock Exchange. But Bobby Godsell, AngloGold's chief executive, is asserting that since last week, when Newmont offered 1.70 Australian dollars a share, a drop in its stock price has lowered the value of its offer. The difference between the bids now is marginal, Mr. Godsell said, adding that Normandy's response ''is potentially misleading'' for its shareholders.'' Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: Currency Trader Who Fled Is Indicted in Fraud Case
description: An indictment was unsealed yesterday accusing the owner of a currency trading operation in the World Trade Center of fraud and conspiracy. The owner disappeared after the Sept. 11 attacks, as did $105 million of investors' money.

description: The governing African National Congress hooted with delight when South Africa's leading white party collapsed last month, declaring that the last of its political opponents had been swept away.

description: Kosovo's Serbs turned out in much greater numbers than originally thought in elections on Saturday, showing that they see a future despite the Albanian domination of their province and securing a real level of power in a new provincial assembly, Western officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TARLER, HARRIETTE
description: TARLER-Harriette. Died on November 18, 2001. Born in NYC, she moved to Los Angeles where she became a Hollywood actress. Her most notable credits include ''Joker is Wild'' with Frank Sinatra, many episodes of ''Dragnet'' and over 14 Three Stooges films. She returned to NYC in the 1960's where she was an avid orchid grower and was devoted to her cat, Pharaoh. She leaves behind her daughter Stephanie Queller, granddaughters Jessica and Danielle Queller, and companion Jack Ruth.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Netbank Buys Mortgage Lender
description: Netbank, the country's largest independent Internet bank, said yesterday that it would buy the Resource Bancshares Mortgage Group, a wholesale mortgage banking company based in Columbia, S.C., for about $148.3 million. Shareholders of Resources Bancshares will get 1.1382 Netbank shares for each Resources share. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: State Freezes $350 Million In Spending
description: State treasury officials said yesterday that the state government was deferring spending $350 million, including $15 million to help families heat their homes. Officials said they needed to assess the economic impact of the Sept. 11 terror attacks. In addition to the deferred $15 million for the Lifeline program, which helps poor and elderly residents heat their homes, the government will delay $40 million in advanced debt payments and $20 million in travel and equipment purchases, said Francis Rapa, a spokesman for the State Treasury Department. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: A master deal maker got more than he bargained for when he tried to make an acquisition.
description: SOON after becoming chief executive of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide in 1996, Shelly Lazarus set out to stem losses in its Australian operations. After meeting with top executives, Ms. Lazarus came up with the idea of merging Ogilvy & Mather with John Singleton Advertising, a leading Australian agency.

title: Gore Joining a Financial Services Company
description: Former Vice President Al Gore announced today that after more than two decades in government and politics, he would become the vice chairman of Metropolitan West Financial Inc., a financial services company based in Los Angeles.

title: Russia-Mexico Oil Meeting Seems to Make No Progress
description: The energy ministers of Russia and Mexico met here today to discuss whether to cut oil production to help prop up prices, but the talks made no apparent progress.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORTEZA, ANTHONY S.
description: FORTEZA-Anthony S., born May 24, 1951, died on November 12, 2001 aboard Flight 587. Among the things he loved were fishing, wine, cigars, his family and friends. He was a husband, a father and a friend to many. He will be greatly missed by his friends and co-workers at KPMG, and those he spent his weekend nights with, to share a glass of wine. He loved his family and did whatever was in his power to make them happy and will continue to do so in spirit. He will be greatly missed by them and continue to live on in them. He is survived by his loving wife, Nannette, his son, Anwar, 27, and daughters Natalie, 20, & Adriana, 13. Til we meet again, Dad. Visitation hours are from 11AM-1PM, followed by a Memorial Service at 1PM at Cargain Funeral Homes, 418 Route Six, Mahopac, New York. 845-628-5655.

title: Accounts
description: * Amtrak, Washington, parted ways on its account with Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, New York, part of the WPP Group, after only eight months. Billings were estimated at $35 million. Amtrak will continue working with a select number of agencies that remain on its roster. A spokesman declined to discuss why Amtrak would no longer work with Ogilvy.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Central Bank Darkens Its Outlook
description: A nine-month slump in manufacturing is beginning to impinge on consumer spending as companies eliminate jobs and trim wages, the Bank of Japan said, lowering its assessment of the economy. ''The substantial decline in production is beginning to have an adverse effect on private spending through decreases in employment and income,'' the bank said in its monthly report. Masaru Hayami, above, the governor of the central bank, said there was little more he could do to help turn the economy around, with interest rates already effectively at zero.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, RITA H.
description: BERGER-Rita H. Died at home on November 17, 2001, after a brief illness. Services at 11:30 A.M., November 20, at The Riverside, 76th Street & Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHELPS, ELEANOR
description: PHELPS-Eleanor, 94. September 29, of Gouldsboro, PA, formerly of Manhattan. Mother of Lisa Hebo. She made her Broadway debut in 1929; appeared in 24 Broadway shows, tours, radio, daytime dramas, commercials and films. Memorial mass, at Blessed Sacrament Church, 131 West 71st St, Saturday, Dec. 1, at 1:00PM.

description: Governor-elect James E. McGreevey today outlined his plans to increase literacy among third graders in New Jersey, pledging to spend $45 million on new reading coaches even as other state spending will have to be cut drastically to close a huge looming budget deficit.

description: In the continuing debate over global warming and how to fight it, some scientists and entrepreneurs advocate using the oceans as a sponge to absorb carbon dioxide from the air.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREY, DR. GEORGE F.
description: FREY-Dr. George F. Age 81. A resident of Syosset, NY and a Professor Emeritus of CW Post College in Brookville, NY died on September 22, 2001 at St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, NY. The cause was complications arising from emphysema. After serving four years in the US Army air corp during World War II, he received his degree from New York University in 1950. He went on to earn his MBA in Marketing and his PhD in Economics in 1959. He remained at NYU as a young professor and taught there for several years. He joined the Lionel D. Edie Co. in 1965 as a consultant and went on to become a Vice President and Senior Economist. During this time he traveled extensively as a consultant to many large corporations such as GE, Corning Glass and others. When the company was acquired by Merrill Lynch in 1975 he decided to return to his old love teaching. He joined the faculty of CW Post and served as teacher, researcher, writer and consultant to various businesses and periodicals including Time and Newsweek. His writings included ''Current Heading in Marketing,'' ''Marketing Channels'', ''Vocabulary for Marketing''. Dr. Frey also served as a member of the Board of Directors of Bayside Federal Savings and Loan Association from 1975-1992, when the Bank was acquired by Northfork Savings Bank. Dr. Frey was born and raised in Bayside, NY, but lived most of his life in Syosset, NY. He loved boating, and was an ardent fisherman. He is survived by his wife Valerie, three children George Frey of Westchester, PA., Erica Shields, of Denver, Colorado and Priscilla Incorvaia of Syosset, NY as well as five grandchildren.

title: Arnett to Cover Afghan Fighting
description: Peter Arnett, the former CNN war correspondent, is heading to Afghanistan to report on the fighting there for an independent news production company called BNN. The company, which is based in New York, would not disclose the terms of its deal with Mr. Arnett, but said it had been completed earlier this month. BNN's chief executive, Steve Rosenbaum, said Mr. Arnett would fly to the region in the next couple of weeks.

title: New York Agencies Are Set to Merge
description: Frierson Mee & Partners and Ziccardi & Partners, two New York agencies, are merging to form Ziccardi Partners Frierson Mee. Terms were not disclosed. The combined agency will have 65 employees and billings estimated at $100 million from clients that include Ellen Tracy, Fortunoff and Random House.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRUIN, MARILYN L. (NEE LEFKOWITZ)
description: DRUIN-Marilyn L. (nee Lefkowitz). Of Avon-by-the-Sea, New Jersey, Sunday, November 18, 2001. Beloved wife of Dr. Melvin L. Druin. Devoted mother of Dr. Allison Druin Bederson and her husband Dr. Ben Bederson, Erica Druin and Lauren Druin Griffin and her husband Tom. Cherished grandmother of Chloe and Phoebe Griffin and Dana Druin Bederson. Adored sister of Karen Magenta, Carole Unger, Arlene Mazzuca and Diana Reno. Mrs. Druin was a world renowned enamelist-jeweler. Services 1 PM Tuesday at Louis Suburban Chapel, 13-01 Broadway(Rt 4 West) Fair Lawn, N.J. Memorial donations in memory of Marilyn Druin may be made to International Enamelist Society for the Marilyn Druin Memorial Scholarship C/O Abra Dennis, 6105 Bay Hill Circle, Jamesville, N.Y. 13078, or North East Enamel Guild C/O Sandra Kravitz, 115 Willow Street, Roslyn, New York 11577.

title: National Briefing | West: Criticism On Tobacco
description: Representative Henry A. Waxman, Democrat of California, has accused the Bush administration of adopting 10 out of 11 objections by Philip Morris to a proposed international treaty on tobacco. The accusations come as negotiators for many nations prepare to gather in Geneva this week to set global standards for tobacco sales and marketing. A White House spokesman said President Bush was still committed to reaching an international treaty on tobacco and characterized the negotiations as fluid. Greg Winter (NYT)

description: For Men Only

title: AUTONATION FACES LIABILITY IN ANC BANKRUPTCY
description: AutoNation, the automobile retailer based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., said yesterday that it could face financial obligations of $50 million to $150 million under the bankruptcy filing by the ANC Rental Corporation, parent to Alamo Rent-A-Car and National Car Rental. ANC Rental, which was spun off last year by AutoNation, filed for bankruptcy protection last week as it sought to reorganize. ANC Rental is responsible for monthly lease payments of $4 million to $5 million, according to estimates by AutoNation.

title: Miscellany
description: * Leo Burnett Worldwide, Chicago, part of the Bcom3 Group, is forming a venture with four agency executives in Hamburg, Germany, to open an agency there named Red Rabbit Leo Burnett. Burnett will own an unspecified minority stake.

title: Lyme Ticks May Be Rolling on the River
description: Lyme disease may be headed toward the Midwest as ticks migrate along rivers, according to researchers from the University of Illinois.

title: 4 Foreign Journalists Are Shot And Possibly Killed in Ambush
description: Four foreign journalists were kidnapped and shot today by armed gunmen on the highway halfway from here to Kabul, three witnesses said. A fifth man, a translator, was reported missing.

title: Corrections

title: Budgets Will Be Stretch for Giambi and for Bonds
description: Jason Giambi's great-great-grandchildren will be financially secure after Giambi signs with the Yankees, Oakland or St. Louis in the days to come, and Barry Bonds may be able to afford a small nation after he lands a new deal, perhaps with the San Francisco Giants. But most of the 2001 class of free agents, who can begin signing contracts with new teams today, will find baseball's financial climate to be very cool.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCOOEY, ROBERT H.
description: McCOOEY-Robert H. The Lincoln Hall Board of Managers mourns the passing of our beloved Board member, Robert H. McCooey. Bob faithfully served on the Board for 41 years. He initiated the Scholarship program at the Hall and in his role as Chairman of the Scholarship Committee, Bob was instrumental in granting scholarships to deserving young men after their discharge from Lincoln Hall. He strongly upheld his motto of providing ''the tools in the toolbox'' for our underprivileged youth. He also served on the Finance and Public Relations Committees. The Board and staff extend sincere condolences to Bob's family on their loss. James G. Nugent, President Douglas W. Wyatt, Vice President and the Lincoln Hall Board of Managers

title: Op-Art
Trade Agency Rules On Japanese Steel
description: A United States trade agency ruled today that stainless steel pipe from Japanese manufacturers harmed domestic producers, sending the case back to the United States Court of International Trade.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Security Fears At U.S. Embassy
description: The United States is considering closing its original embassy building on Novinsky Boulevard and moving all operations deeper within the embassy's square-block compound because of security concerns, a senior diplomatic official said. Much of the building was vacated after Sept. 11 and many workers moved to a new embassy building, in the center of the compound, which was recently completed after almost 15 years of construction. The new embassy was completely rebuilt after security experts found in the mid-1980's that its framework was riddled with listening devices. Michael Wines (NYT)

description: StarMedia Network, once the bright light of Latin America's Internet industry, appears to be in serious trouble.

title: Employers Increasingly Face Disability-Based Bias Cases

And from his early days, the rangers Mr. Lanni sent to their jobs made him a target of pranks and ridicule, according to a lawsuit he won against the department in 1999.

description: Following is a list of people named yesterday by Mayor-elect Michael Bloomberg to his transition committee. Nathan Leventhal, the former president of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, will head the committee.

Wise and witty, she was a good and generous friend. Her spirit lives through her son Al (Avy), daughter Elanor Reiter, five grandchildren, many great-grandchildren, who love and will miss her. Her memory is a blessing. Services Tuesday, 10AM at Plaza Chapel, West 91 and Amsterdam, shiva at her West Side home.

description: Merrill Lynch & Company has appointed Japanese executives to run its Japan business for the first time, giving them the task of ending losses at the only foreign-owned brokerage network aimed at individual investors.

description: The words of a poem flashed onto the projection screen at the front of a darkened auditorium of an elementary school here and the teacher, Jiao Feng, asked the more than 40 assembled third graders to identify the author.

title: Fire in Which a Woman Died Is an Arson Case, Officials Say
description: The apartment fire that killed a 43-year-old mother of two here Sunday morning was intentionally set, but the circumstances of the blaze remained a mystery today, the authorities said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELTZ, PAUL L.
description: BELTZ-Paul L. Died September 17, 2001, survived by his loving wife Pat, daughter Ellin and granddaughter Eloise. While in New York, Paul worked with the New York Convention Bureau, Loews Hotels and Hilton Hotels. Also active with Lions Club of N.Y. After moving to Chicago, he continued with the Lions Club and was a founding member of Chris Radio, Chicago Radio Information Service for the blind. He then formed a new company, Resource Base, China Associates. This led to many trips to China, promoting international trade. Memorial services will be held Friday, November 23, 2001, 1 PM at the George H. Wimberg Funeral Home, 7300 Ventnor Ave., Ventnor City, NJ, where friends may call after 12 PM. Paul asked that in lieu of flowers, other forms of remembrance contributions be made to the Paul Beltz Beiging Kungpei Memorial Scholarship Fund, Citibank, Attn. Bob Blazek, V.P., 1900 Spring Road, Oakbrook, IL. 60523.

title: ALLIANCE IN KABUL WILL SHARE POWER, U.S. ENVOY REPORTS
description: The Northern Alliance has agreed to surrender exclusive power in the Afghan capital to a transitional government that will be ''broad-based, multiethnic and fully representative,'' the standard that was set last week by the United Nations Security Council, an American envoy said today.

title: Foreign Affairs; Today's News Quiz
description: So, class, time for a news quiz: Name the second-largest Muslim community in the world. Iran? Wrong. Pakistan? Wrong. Saudi Arabia? Wrong. Time's up -- you lose.

title: For Baseball, a Five-Star Menu
description: The 2001 class of free agents is relatively thin, and even some of the star players available are shrouded with question marks. By BUSTER OLNEY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KONECKY, LEWIS

The National Jewish Outreach Program (NJOP) mourns the passing of Lewis Konecky, devoted husband of Cyrena, and beloved father of Dr. Priscilla (Dr. Marc Tepper), Dr. Elizabeth (Yaakov Kronfeld), and Dr. Margaret (Dr. Larry Osher). Elizabeth, a valued member of NJOP's Board of Directors, and her husband Yaakov, and the entire Konecky family, have played a crucial role in NJOP's effort to assure a bright Jewish future for American Jewry. Yehi Zichro Baruch. Rabbi Ephraim Z. Buchwald, Dir.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Music Company's Loss Widens
description: As economies slow down and music fans turn to downloading free music from the Internet, the EMI Group of Britain, whose artists range from Robbie Williams to Pink Floyd, said its first-half loss widened to $77.6 million while revenues slid 6.7 percent to $1.53 billion. The company, which has shed 500 jobs, said that it might take further measures to cut costs. Its shares rose 4.27 percent in London, to 317.75 pence.

title: Fairleigh Dickinson Returns to Tournament
description: The long road back to respectability for the Fairleigh Dickinson men's team has taken it back to the N.C.A.A. Division I tournament after 11 years.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Police Officers Plead Guilty
description: Four police officers pleaded guilty to unleashing police dogs on three illegal immigrants from Mozambique in an attack that shocked the country when a videotape of the 1998 incident was broadcast on television last year. The officers have said they were training their dogs. Two other officers have denied the accusations and will go to trial. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: Foreign Fighters in Kunduz Left Out of Surrender Talks
description: TALIQAN, Afghanistan, Nov. 20 — Leaders of the Taliban and the Northern Alliance were poised to strike a deal today at the expense of thousands of foreign fighters trapped in Kunduz, in northern Afghanistan.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Evaluations For Nursing Homes
description: The Department of Health and Human Services announced a new system to evaluate nursing homes for Medicare and Medicaid patients in five states using 11 criteria. The findings will be available online at www.medicare.gov in April, Tommy G. Thompson, the department's secretary, said. The system will be expanded to every state late next year to help force nursing homes to improve the quality of care, Mr. Thompson said. ''If you're competing with your peers and you're not measuring up, you're going to find ways to improve,'' he said. The pilot states are Colorado, Maryland, Ohio, Rhode Island and Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AGINSKEE, MAE
description: AGINSKEE-Mae. Young Israel of Flatbush mourns the passing of our beloved member and supporter, Mae Aginskee. Kenneth Auman, Rabbi Elliot Pisem, President

title: The Guggenheim's Scaled-Back Ambition; A Museum Director's Risk-Taking Approach Gets a New Look in Hard Times
description: In a profession known for its caution, Thomas Krens, director of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, has always been something of a high roller, a larger-than-life character who rides around on a BMW motorcycle and challenges conventional notions about art, money and museum management.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR GAINS. The dollar rose as United States stocks gained, reflecting expectations the nation's economy will rebound before the rest of the world. In New York, the euro settled at 87.97 cents, down from 88.43 cents.

title: Bush Renames Justice Building in Honor of Robert F. Kennedy
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20  In a ceremony rich with poignant memories and political twists, President Bush renamed the Justice Department building today in honor of Robert F. Kennedy, who served as attorney general from 1961 to 1964.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CONSUMER PORTFOLIO SERVICES INC., Irvine, Calif., a buyer of auto loans from car dealers, agreed to acquire MFN Financial Corp., Lake Forest, Ill., a maker of short-term loans to customers with bad credit, for $99.9 million in cash.

Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Tuesday November 20th 11:30AM. Interment to follow at Mt. Carmel Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCRIBNER, HOWARD A. JR.
description: SCRIBNER-Howard A. Jr. A wonderful guy! Irrepressible, irreverent, an iconoclast. One never had to resort to guesswork to know where Howard stood on any matter; he told you without circumlocution or embroidery regardless of your station. Howard was our friend and advisor for many years and there will never be a meeting at which he won't be missed. Officers and Directors Herman Goldman Foundation

title: Microsoft Aims to Settle Suits by Equipping 12,500 Schools
description: Microsoft filed a proposal in federal court on Tuesday that could remove another of its legal headaches -- more than 100 class-action antitrust suits alleging that it overcharged consumers. The proposed deal is an innovative approach to settling a class-action case, since the proceeds would not go to the customers claiming they were overcharged, but to more than 12,500 low-income schools around the country.

Cherished grandmother of Jonathan, Stephen, Michael, Amy, Leslie, and Mark. Great grandmother of Samantha. Services today 11:15 AM ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY. title: Braced by Their Ardor, The Vikings Conquer
description: The emotion of the evening was there even before the Minnesota Vikings and Giants began their important football game last night. A group of New York firefighters gently carried a tattered American flag that had stood at the World Trade Center -- and survived the Sept. 11 assaults -- to midfield for a ceremony.

title: A New Generation: Teenagers Living With H.I.V.
description: On the surface, Alora Gale of Boulder, Colo., is an average teenager. A sophomore at Boulder High School, she likes school and for the most part does well. She volunteers as a peer counselor at school, hopes to get her driver's license next month when she turns 16 and is looking for a part-time job to help finance frequent trips to the mall.

title: Havas Outlines Unit's Dissolution
description: Havas Advertising in Paris has outlined an expected dismantling of its Diversified Agencies Group division as most agencies that were part of the division are transferred to the three other divisions: Arnold Worldwide Partners, Euro RSCG Worldwide and MPG.

title: Muslim Group Seeks to Meet Billy Graham's Son
description: A Muslim advocacy organization, the Council on America-Islamic Relations, said yesterday that it had sent a letter to the Rev. Franklin Graham, to discuss remarks that Mr. Graham, an evangelist, made describing Islam as evil.

description: KAY-Hazel. On Nov. 17, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Irving. Loving mother of Sanford, Andrew and Sarah. Daughters-in-law Fran & Julia and son-in-law Eddie. Adoring grandmother of Jason, Amanda and Camilla. Services are today, 2:30 PM at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, W-150 Route 4 East, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: 4 Commanders Seek Staff Role For the F.B.I.
description: The military's four major regional commanders have asked that F.B.I. and Treasury Department agents be assigned to their staffs to improve coordination between the military and civilian agencies in the global war against terrorism, Pentagon and administration officials say.

title: Airline Cutbacks With an Agenda; Preserving Hub Networks Is the Carriers' Motivation
description: Schedule cuts by the major airlines since Sept. 11 have reduced passenger capacity at big airports by as much as a third and increased the biggest carriers' dominance at many of those airports, according to a computer analysis for The New York Times.

title: New Clues and Puzzles in Boston Strangler Case
description: After nearly 40 years, the perplexing case of the Boston Strangler has come back to life -- a result of forensic science and an unlikely alliance between the families of a victim and the man long thought to have killed her.

title: A New Test For Women At High Risk For Cancer
description: For women with a high risk of breast cancer, an experimental procedure that retrieves cells from the milk ducts may help guide difficult decisions about preventive treatment.

title: In New Filing, Enron Reports Debt Squeeze
description: The Enron Corporation told investors yesterday that it faced debt repayments over the next year vastly in excess of its available cash. It said that if any of a number of things went wrong, its ability to continue as a going concern would be called into question.

title: Tunnel Vision; Subway Tunnel Workers At Front Lines of New War
description: It has always been strange, walking back and forth across the bottom of the East River in the middle of the night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, ANITA INDI
description: KAHN-Anita Indi. Of Tenafly, New Jersey. On Nov. 18, 2001. Beloved wife of David Goldstein. Cherished daughter of Francis Kahn. Devoted mother of David and Jason. Services Tuesday, 2:30PM at ''Wien & Wien'', 129 Engle Street, Englewood, New Jersey. Should friends desire, contributions may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Ovarian Cancer Research.

title: Johnnie Cochran in Deep Water
description: Johnnie Cochran will need more than courtroom skill to avoid the political land mines that await him in his new role as chairman of the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone. This publicly funded economic development agency has been hampered by ineffective leadership and political infighting among Albany, City Hall and the Democratic Congressman Charles Rangel, all of whom must approve every project that goes forward. To be effective, Mr. Cochran must dispel widespread suspicion that he was installed in this job to serve as Mr. Rangel's pawn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHREIBER, EVELYN
description: SCHREIBER-Evelyn. AMIT is deeply saddened by the untimely passing of our most beloved, dedicated, devoted and pioneering Honorary President, magnanimous patron of AMIT's needy children in Israel, and cherished mother-inlaw of Elaine Schreiber, AMIT Southwest Regional Vice President. A true woman of valor, with great charm, charisma, superb skills and genuine warmth, Evelyn Schreiber mentored hundreds upon hundreds of AMIT leaders through more that half a century of active and dynamic leadership. Evelyn was very much loved by all, and was profoundly committed to Torah values, religious Zionism, the State of Israel, and all Jewish communal causes. Her life's mission was to help where help was needed, and to make this world a more secure and better place for all mankind. She will be sorely missed. Heartfelt condolences to her children Honey (Herb) Levinson, Dr. Saul (Elaine) Schreiber, Avram (Renee) Schreiber, Simi (Shifi) Schreiber, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Sondra Sokal, President Marvin Leff, Executive Dir

title: Billions at Risk as New York Makes Missteps
description: Only a few days after the World Trade Center attack, President Bush summoned members of New York's Congressional delegation to the White House. There, the Republican president promised to help New York recover -- and then pledged $20 billion to get things started. Even the most partisan Democrat there was moved by the gesture.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EHRENBERG, ABRAHAM
description: EHRENBERG - Abraham. We mourn the passing of the father of our esteemed member Dr. Martin Ehrenberg & pray that the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Young Israel of Great Neck Yaacov Lerner, Rabbi Michael Frank, President
