title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHULMAN, MAX L.
description: SHULMAN-Max L. Women's League for Israel mourns the loss of Maj. Max L. Shulman, a generous benefactor and friend. We extend to his wife, Sylvia and his family, our heartfelt sympathy. Harriet Lainer, President

title: National Briefing | Washington: Directive On Searches
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has issued a directive advising airport security screeners not to single out Sikh and Arab-Americans for additional inspections simply because of their religion, accents or ethnic appearance. ''There appears to have been a rash of improper and insensitive searches,'' the memorandum says. It directs that Sikh men in turbans or Muslim women in veils who set off alarms in the metal detectors should be allowed to remove their head coverings in private. The directive is the result of several meetings between Sikh and Muslim groups and the F.A.A. Laurie Goodstein (NYT)

title: Harry's Big Weekend
description: As everyone knows, except most of the kids who made up the largest share of the audience, ''Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone'' brought in some $90.3 million in its first weekend, the biggest opening weekend for a movie ever. In this case, the number is a cultural artifact as important as the movie itself. It measures the convergence of an enormous and devoted fan base and the synergistic energies of AOL Time Warner, which has made ''Harry Potter'' the common coin in all its realm. The stunning weekend total registers the ability of this product -- a 2-hour-20-minute redaction of the first volume in J. K. Rowling's series -- to pack people into theaters, but not what happens to them when they get there.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Ex-President Called In Graft Case
description: Former President B. J. Habibie has been summoned for questioning in a graft case involving $5.3 billion siphoned from the state food agency. The targets of the inquiry, the former military chief Wiranto and Akbar Tandjung, the parliamentary speaker, said that when Mr. Habibie was president, he instructed them to withdraw the funds for aid programs. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Women in Afghanistan, and Here
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., 81, Dies; Went to Prison Over Abscam Scandal
description: Harrison A. Williams Jr., the Democratic senator from New Jersey who used his considerable power to further the interests of labor and education before being convicted of bribery and conspiracy in the Abscam scandal, died on Saturday. He was 81 and lived in Bedminster.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: The New York office of DDB Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, promoted four creative directors to group creative directors. They are Thom Baginski, Brian Fandetti, Janet Guillet and Kate Murphy.

title: Islam Is Part Of the West, Too
description: The Sept. 11 attack on America has sparked a debate about Islam that has, unfortunately, been framed in terms of us (the civilized, Western world) and them (the dangerous, suspect Muslims). Even well-intentioned statements dismissing the rhetoric of crusades have not softened an implicit skepticism among many people toward Islam. This wariness is of immediate concern to the 12 million Muslims who are citizens of European Union countries, five million of them in the Balkans.

title: Investigators Liken Anthrax in Leahy Letter to That Sent to Daschle
description: A plastic bag holding the sealed letter sent to Senator Patrick J. Leahy was so contaminated that federal investigators strongly suspect that the anthrax is comparable to the highly refined material sent last month to Senator Tom Daschle, law enforcement officials said today.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: New York on an Actor a Day

title: For This 'Merger of Equals,' Little Need for a Wink
description: So is it a merger or an acquisition?

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Company Wins Contract Extension
description: The Computer Sciences Corporation, the third-largest United States seller of computer services, has won a five-year, $1.1 billion contract extension to run networks for the United Technologies Corporation. The contract is now worth $3.7 billion and will expire in December 2014, Computer Sciences said yesterday in a statement. The original 10-year agreement was signed in 1999. Computer Sciences, based in El Segundo, Calif., has lagged its larger rivals, I.B.M. and the Electronic Data Systems Corporation in signing multibillion-dollar contracts to run computer networks.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: 2 Gold Firms Fined
description: Two Manhattan jewelry distributors have been fined for selling charms, earrings and other jewelry as 10 karat when they contained too little gold to meet that standard, the authorities said. Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer, left, said yesterday that after a yearlong investigation, officials found that the two companies -- Alishaev Brothers and J&I Jewelry -- consistently sold items that tested less than 10 karat. The companies agreed to halt shipments of the products. Also, Alishaev Brothers agreed to pay $50,000, and J&I Jewelry, $25,000. The lawyer for Alishaev Brothers, Ivan Fisher, said that the gold was short by ''a small margin'' and that the company was not admitting wrongdoing. J&I Jewelry did not immediately return calls seeking comment. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

title: P & O and Royal Caribbean to Merge Into Largest Cruise Line
description: LONDON, Nov. 20  Two leading cruise lines announced today a $2.89 billion deal to combine as the world's biggest cruise ship company.

title: Military Tribunals Needed In Difficult Time, Bush Says
description: President Bush today vigorously defended his order creating special military tribunals to try foreigners charged with terrorism, saying he needed the option ''should we ever bring one of these Al Qaeda members in alive.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEALY, ROSARIA
description: HEALY-Rosaria. On November 18, 2001 of Brooklyn, NY. Beloved wife of the late Harold. Loving mother of Daniel and Patricia and mother-in-law of Kathryn Healy and Anton J. Hemm. Cherished grandmother of Christine and Robbie Peters, Matthew, Mary, Daniel Jr., Sarah, Angela and Camilla. Dear sister of Louise. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave. at 12th Street, Garden City, 2-4 & 7-9 PM Tuesday. Mass of Christian burial, St. Joseph's Church, at 11 AM on Wednesday. Interment, Pinelawn Memorial Park. In lieu of flowers, donations to The American Cancer Society appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THORBECKE, HOCHWALD, G. JEANETTE
description: THORBECKE - HOCHWALD - G. Jeanette, MD, died November 16, 2001. The trustees, faculty and staff of NYU School of Medicine mourn the tragic loss of our friend and colleague, G. Jeanette Thorbecke-Hochwald, MD, Professor of Pathology. A distinguished member of the Department of Pathology for more than 40 years, Dr. Thorbecke - Hochwald achieved international recognition for her original contributions to immunology, including serving as President of the American Association of Immunologists. She was an outstanding scientist, a prolific author, a committed teacher, and a very active member of the School's academic community. Dr. Thorbecke-Hochwald will be missed by the many people, students and colleagues whose lives she touched. We extend our deepest condolences to her husband Gerald, a senior member of the faculty at the School, and her family. Kenneth G. Langone, Chairman NYU School of Medicine Foundation Board of Trustees Robert M. Glickman, MD, Dean, NYU School of Medicine Vittorio Defendi, MD, Chairman Department of Pathology NYU School of Medicine

title: S.E.C. Chooses Division Director
description: Alan L. Beller, a lawyer who specializes in stock offerings, was named today to be head of the Securities and Exchange Commission's corporation finance division, where he will lead a drive for more frequent company financial reports.

title: Technology Briefing
description: SOFTWARE

title: U.S. Muslims Push Stamp As Symbol of Acceptance
description: For five years, American Muslims tried to persuade the Postal Service to issue a stamp commemorating a Muslim holiday. After all, they reasoned, there were stamps for Christmas and Hanukkah and even for Kwanzaa and Cinco de Mayo. To press the case, Muslim children wrote more than 5,000 letters to the postmaster general, and Muslim groups lobbied Congress.

title: 20th-Century Latin American Art Finally Gets a Home
description: Bogot has a fine museum to display Fernando Botero, while Mexico City has great public palaces to exhibit Diego Rivera, David Alfaro Siqueiros and Jos Clemente Orozco. But for too long Latin America's 20th-century masters of painting have lacked a permanent home in which to be viewed and appreciated together.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about lawsuits filed by the Justice Department against three promoters of what it calls tax evasion schemes referred incorrectly to Operation Enduring Patriotism, part of the ''tax honesty movement,'' which contends that the Internal Revenue Service has no legal authority to collect taxes. Operation Enduring Patriotism, which shares a Web site with the movement, advocates that each state adopt a law to teach the organization's interpretation of the Constitution and civics in schools. Its name does not refer to the tax honesty movement as a whole.

title: 2 Downing Street Neighbors in Need of a Fence
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair has traveled the world keeping the antiterror war coalition united and focused on a common enemy, but at home his powerful second in command, Gordon Brown, the chancellor of the exchequer, has plunged his government into open combat.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: New Leader For Physicians' Group
description: A noted surgeon will take over as head of the American Medical Association on Jan. 15. Dr. Michael D. Maves, 53, who teaches at the St. Louis University School of Medicine and Georgetown University Medical Center, was named executive vice president and chief executive of the A.M.A., the nation's oldest and largest physicians' group. He had previously led the Consumer Healthcare Products Association and the American Academy of Otolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

title: Giants Missing Deep Pass to Dixon
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 19  With 40 receptions in the Giants' first 9 games, Amani Toomer is on a pace to have 70 catches this season, or only 8 fewer than he had last season. With 33 receptions entering tonight's game with the Minnesota Vikings, wide receiver Joe Jurevicius has been a pleasant surprise, having already passed his career high, 24 catches, set last season. After missing two games because of a toe injury, Ike Hilliard has returned to the starting lineup and contributed 25 receptions, including 4 touchdowns. Hilliard appears to be getting stronger.

title: Drop in Housing Construction, At 1.3%, Is Below Expectations
description: Starts of new housing fell less than expected in October, the government said today in a report that suggested the home construction industry continued to buttress the economy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARZ, PRESTON S.
description: SCHWARZ-Preston S., 75. Died Nov. 19, 2001. He grew up and lived in White Plains, NY. So deeply loved by his wife of 52 years Jane, daughters, Nanci Lottner & Barbara Mallaney, son-in-laws, Gene Lottner and William Mallaney, granddaughter Brynn Lottner, and brother Donald. Preston was respected and admired by close friends and business associates. A World War II veteran he served in Europe & the Far East. A pioneer in importing textiles, he started doing business in Shanghai in 1946. Traveled to the Soviet Union, as their guest in 1958 and in 1976 was invited & went to Mainland, China to import textiles to USA. Owner of successful company, Continella Industries, Corp. He acted as a one man market research campaign, and was most emphatic in stating that his success was due to tremendous investigation, hard work, creativity and timing. Active in his private life, he was a long standing member of the Old Guard of White Plains. Funeral service will be held Wednesday, November 21, 2001, at 11 AM, Ferncliff Chapel Secor Road, Hartsdale, New York. Contributions may be made to the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research, Grand Central Station, P.O. Box 4777, New York, New York 10163.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANCIS, PANAMA
description: FRANCIS-Panama. All his greatness, yet a humble man. A wonderful human being. We share in the loss with his lovely wife Alyce, their family and the music world. Susan and Larry Bauman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAMSEY, NINA
description: RAMSEY-Nina. On November 18, 2001, at age 43. Beloved wife of Gregory. Devoted daughter of Si and the late Nancy Friedman and stepdaughter of Margaret Friedman. Dear sister of Mark Friedman and adoring aunt of James Friedman. Interment private. Memorial service to be announced.

title: XEROX OBTAINS $800 MILLION THROUGH GE CAPITAL
description: The Xerox Corporation, which has lost money in four of the last five quarters, has received $800 million in financing through GE Capital, which will take over the company's financing in Canada. GE Capital will provide $350 million, which will be secured by Xerox's Canadian receivables. Xerox, based in Stamford, Conn., will receive $450 million in secured financing in Britain and is in talks for a third party to run the unit. Xerox has already turned over financing in the United States to GE Capital, which had also agreed to lend $1 billion to the American unit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITCHELL, RICHARD
description: MITCHELL-Richard of Sea Island, Georgia passed away November 18. Mr. Mitchell was a former resident of Larchmont, NY. Also a pioneer in the direct mail industry starting his career in 1968. He was president of Qualified Lists a division of the Walter Karl Co. in Armonk, NY. He is survived by his wife Peggy and children Reni and Colleen of Chicago, IL Bill and Tina of St. Simons Island, GA., and Mike and Jill of Alexandria, VA., and two grandchildren. Also by brother Joe of Dallas, TX and a sister Barbara Leahey of Spring Lake, NJ and mother-inlaw Irene Shalloe, of Rye, NY and twenty six nieces and nephews. A memorial mass will be held on Wednesday, November 21, at 10AM at St. Williams Catholic Church, on St. Simons Island. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Oncology unit of Southeast Georgia Regional Medical Center in memory of Richard Mitchell.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Driver's License Restrictions
description: State Motor Vehicle Services is tightening the restrictions for noncitizens to obtain driver's licenses. Officials said the changes were made to curb widespread abuse. The terrorists who carried out the Sept. 11 attacks obtained licenses that allowed them to rent cars and open bank accounts. Now, noncitizens with visas of less than one year cannot obtain a license, while those with visas of more than one year must submit immigration documents. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: U.S. Calls for Global Action To Counter Germ Weapons
description: Countries that have signed the global pact banning biological weapons began their periodic review of the treaty today, promising that the anthrax attacks in the United States would lead to a vigorous and concerted effort to combat germ weapons.

title: Afghans Block Britain's Plan For Big Force
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair's much publicized plan to dispatch thousands of British troops to Afghanistan has been put off as diplomats and Afghan leaders wrangle over the future of the country.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Bank Executive Investigated
description: Henri-Paul Pellegrino, the managing director of the French unit of Barclays P.L.C., has been placed under formal investigation on suspicion of money laundering, the state prosecutor's office said. The allegations relate to a suspected money-laundering network between France and Israel; three other Barclays France employees were placed under formal investigation last week, officials said. A Barclays spokesman in London said the bank was cooperating with the investigation.

title: Connick's Favorite Songs, Some of Which He Wrote
description: Harry Connick Jr.'s performance on Thursday night at City Center was a full-fledged advertisement, expertly paced and designed to show maximum product potential. Now 34, Mr. Connick seems to possess a gift that many less productive artists dream of: the ability to see everything he does as worth sharing.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Party United As Coalition Wobbles
description: Chancellor Gerhard Schrder was re-elected leader of the Social Democratic Party with 88.6 percent of the vote at the party's congress, but his coalition with the Greens may be threatened at their party congress, which opens next weekend. The Green rank-and-file are unhappy with the government's decision to send troops to support the war in Afghanistan. Steven Erlanger (NYT)

title: GLOBAL CROSSING PLANS TO SELL DESKTOP TRADING UNIT
description: Global Crossing, owner of a worldwide phone and data-transmission network, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its IPC Trading Systems units to an investment group for $360 million. The group is led by Goldman Sachs Capital Partners 2000, a unit of the Goldman Sachs Group, Global Crossing said. The deal is expected to close by the end of the year. IPC, which provides desktop trading systems to financial businesses, will operate as an independent company in New York. Global Crossing is based in Hamilton, Bermuda.

title: Australian Honeymoon
description: Aseven-night honeymoon starts at $3,899 a person from Newmans Vacations. Besides air fares from the West Coast, it includes a three-night stay at Silky Oaks, a spa chalet in the Queensland rain forest, that includes a massage, daily breakfast, one dinner and a trip to the Great Barrier Reef or wilderness tour. That's followed by three nights in a private villa on Bedarra Island, off northern Queensland, and then one night at the Sydney Regent Hotel with a harborview room. Information: (888) 592-6224 or on the Web at www.newmansvacations.com .

title: Announcement Of a U.S. Reward
description: Following is a translated text of one of two reward announcements that the American military began broadcasting to Afghanistan from EC-130 Commando Solo aircraft, as provided by the Department of Defense:

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: The New York office of DDB Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, promoted four creative directors to group creative directors. They are Thom Baginski, Brian Fandetti, Janet Guillet and Kate Murphy.

title: CALIFORNIA ENERGY COMPANY LOWERS EARNINGS FORECAST
description: The energy company Edison International said yesterday that it expected 2001 earnings of $1.27 to $1.30 a share, less than analysts had forecast, as the company's Southern California Edison utility struggled to avoid bankruptcy. Edison was expected to earn $1.63 a share, the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call. The estimates ranged from $1.25 to $2.15 a share. Southern California Edison accrued $3.3 billion in losses after buying power for more than it was allowed to charge customers. Last month, Edison and the California Public Utilities Commission reached an agreement for the utility to pay its debts and avoid bankruptcy.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Fatal Stabbing
description: A man was stabbed to death in a Manhattan apartment last night about 9:30, the police said. The 29-year-old man, whose name was not immediately released, was stabbed in the back and chest and was declared dead at the scene, 207 West 20th Street. No suspects were identified. A neighbor said he and others living in the building had been hearing shouting from an apartment on the top floor for several weeks, and that last night around 9 the noises were louder than ever. ''At one point I yelled at them to shut up, but we had no idea what was going on,'' he said. Robert F. Worth (NYT)

title: Bonds Is Voted M.V.P. A Record Fourth Time
description: San Francisco's Barry Bonds was voted the most valuable player in the National League for the fourth time yesterday, distinguishing himself from every other player who has played the game. Seven players -- including Joe DiMaggio, Mickey Mantle and Yogi Berra -- have won three M.V.P. awards, but only Bonds has four.

title: USA Networks' Stock Plan
description: USA Networks Inc., the media and electronic-commerce company, wants to increase the number of preferred shares to 100 million from 15 million for possible use in making acquisitions. The company will have 1.875 million shares of preferred stock remaining after completing its purchase of the Internet travel service Expedia Inc., according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. USA Networks paid $1.5 billion for 75 percent of Expedia.

title: Balanchine's All-American Dedication
description: New York City and the nation are awash in patriotic sentiment. George Balanchine would probably have been one of the most fervent of flag-wavers. Balanchine, who died in 1983, had an unshakeable love for New York and the United States. This Russian migr choreographer, who founded the New York City Ballet with Lincoln Kirstein, delighted in everything from the songs of George Gershwin to the city's ''Don't Walk'' signs.

title: Advocacy Group Says Homeless Are Breaking Shelter Records
description: The number of people sleeping in municipal shelters and welfare hotels exceeds 29,000 nightly -- the highest number in the city's history, according to a report released yesterday by the Coalition for the Homeless, an advocacy group.

title: Laviolette Is Clinical in His Approach
description: DALLAS, Nov. 19  When the Islanders lose, and lately they have been losing far too often to suit him, Coach Peter Laviolette speaks in a mumble, and some of his responses to questions are barely long enough to form a sentence.

title: U.S. Attorney Leaving Legacy Of Prosecutions For Terrorism
description: As Mary Jo White, the United States attorney in Manhattan, was pressing her case with the Justice Department this fall to keep control of terrorism prosecutions stemming from the Sept. 11 terror attacks, there was one person whose opinion she wanted: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Indexes Gain as Prospects Look Rosier for 2002 Rebound
description: United States stocks, led by Citigroup, rose yesterday as investors speculated that profits would rebound next year. Airline stocks, including the AMR Corporation, surged as oil prices languished near two-year lows.

title: Libido Loss? Don't Blame Licorice
description: People may think of licorice as just candy, but real licorice, made from the root of a perennial herb, has some potent medicinal properties. It can raise blood pressure and cause fluid retention, for instance, and people with hypertension are often told to avoid it.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Airline Furloughs, Not Layoffs
description: Korean Air will make all its 17,000 workers take a one-month furlough without pay next year. Korean Air called the plan preferable to laying off any more workers; 1,000 were let go earlier this month. Korean Air's smaller rival, Asiana, said it, too, might have to resort to unpaid leaves and dismissals, but it forecast an operating profit for next year. Both airlines are counting on boosts next June, when the World Cup finals are played in Korea and Japan. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: More Land For Blacks
description: The government said it would cap the size of the country's farms at just under 5,000 acres and turn over the surplus property to landless blacks. The new law will apply only to the relatively small share of large farms not already designated for compulsory acquisition by the government. Government officials have accused white farmers, who control many of the largest farms, of leaving much of their land idle. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Strike At Volkswagen Off, for Now
description: Striking metal workers at Volkswagen's biggest Brazilian factory provisionally returned to work after the company offered to reverse 3,000 layoffs in exchange for a 15 percent reduction in the work week and voluntary buyouts for 700 employees. Union members, who struck last week after the company announced an 11 percent cut in its Brazilian work force, will take a final vote on the offer on Wednesday. Volkswagen, Brazil's top selling automaker, is trying to cut costs and regain competitiveness as sales have slipped from greater competition and an economic slump. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: British Wireless Operation Strikes Out on Its Own
description: While courting investors before today's spinoff of mmO2, British Telecommunications' wireless unit, Peter Erskine, the chief executive of the business, spoke frankly about the company's problems.

title: Women in Afghanistan, and Here
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SNYDER, HENRY
description: SNYDER-Henry. The HewlettEast Rockaway Jewish Centre mourns the loss of its esteemed member, Henry Snyder, and extends heartfelt sympathy to his entire family. Rabbi Stanley Platek Ferne Skiba, President

title: Thefts Using Fake A.T.M. Cards Are Investigated Coast to Coast
description: A ring of computer-savvy thieves has stolen thousands of dollars across New York City by obtaining personal identification numbers and fashioning fake automated teller machine cards, the United States Secret Service said yesterday. Investigators said they expected to make several arrests in the next few weeks.

title: Holiday Travel Volume Looks Steady, but Americans Are Staying Close to the Ground
description: Mike Norwood, a freshman at the College of the Holy Cross in Worcester, Mass., never intended to begin the Thanksgiving holiday with his parents in Washington as early as Tuesday. He had wanted to travel today.

title: Treatment Can Ease Lingering Trauma of Sept. 11
description: On Monday afternoons, Josefina Mendez now does something she has never done before: She goes to see a psychotherapist.

title: Corrections
description: The E-Commerce Report column in Business Day yesterday about retailers that are using online gift registries to attract customers misstated the given name of the general manager at Target.com, who said 30 percent of its sales came from its registry business. She is Kathy David, not Nancy.

title: Yashin Reverses Isles' Fortunes At End of Trip
description: The Islanders finally found a solution to many of their problems tonight. It is Aleksei Yashin's laser-guided and very expensive slap shot.

title: ChevronTexaco Sets 500 More Job Cuts
description: The ChevronTexaco Corporation, the second-largest United States oil company, said yesterday that it would increase the number of job cuts it plans by 500, to 4,500, as part of a plan to save $1.8 billion annually by March 2003.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARREN, PETER B.
description: WARREN-Peter B. October 9, 1922-November 3, 2001. You're walking Tati among the stars. Missing you. Ana Lillian and Alexandra

title: The Mind of Feynman
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IRLANDER, HERMAN
description: IRLANDER-Herman. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Herman Irlander, beloved father of our devoted members Sam and Janet Irlander, grandfather of Max and Ian, students of our Leon and Gina Froemer Religious School. Deepest sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: Judge Will Not Allow Schools To Opt Out of Regents Exams
description: A New York State judge has refused to allow 28 public schools -- most of them alternative schools in New York City -- to continue avoiding the Regents examinations that students at all other public high schools in the state must take to graduate.

title: A Better Chance for Free Trade
description: On some propositions, economists are nearly unanimous: Trade promotes economic growth. Growth reduces poverty. The agreement reached last week among the more than 140 trade ministers gathered in Doha, Qatar, is good for rich countries, perhaps even better for poor countries and surprisingly protective of the environment.

title: Huskies Score Early And Often in Opener
description: Connecticut was sizzling in its season opener tonight, scoring the first 13 points against Vanderbilt and widening its lead to 26 points early in the second half. But then the Commodores, fueled by five 3-pointers by the former Seton Hall guard Chuck Moore, went on a 22-6 run midway through the second half to cut the deficit to 10 points before UConn regrouped and pulled away for an 84-71 victory.

title: Trauma Memories Hold Clues to Coping
description: Dr. Edna B. Foa never set out to study post-traumatic stress disorder. She was interested in other problems, like phobias and obsessive-compulsive disorder.

title: Masur Delivers a Message From Shostakovich, Darkly
description: All Kurt Masur's musical strengths come boiling to the surface when he conducts Shostakovich. The harshness suits him: the sense of music torn into shape, the public violence. Leading the New York Philharmonic with the New York Choral Artists and Sergei Leiferkus in Shostakovich's Symphony No. 13 on Thursday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, he produced a mighty performance, grave, searing and uncomfortable.

title: U.S. BROADCASTING $25 MILLION OFFER TO FIND BIN LADEN
description: The United States stepped up its efforts to persuade the Afghan people to turn over Osama bin Laden, as American military aircraft began broadcasting a radio message into the country announcing a $25 million cash reward for information leading to his location or capture.

title: A Mountain Climber, a Cartoonist, Two Brothers and a Ray of Sunshine
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: F.D.A. APPROVES SALE OF ULCER DRUG MADE BY ANDRX
description: Shares of the Andrx Corporation, the drug maker, rose about 8 percent yesterday after regulators approved its generic version of AstraZeneca's ulcer medicine Prilosec, the world's best-selling drug. Shares of the Andrx Group, which track the performance of the Andrx Corporation, rose $5.04, to $68.49. The chief executive, Elliot Hahn, said Andrx would hold off on marketing the drug until after the outcome of a drug-patent trial, which starts Dec. 6 in Federal District Court in New York. Analysts expect Andrx to introduce its version of Prilosec by mid-2002. The company is based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: Layden's Sugarcoating Turns Van Gundy Sour
description: The Knicks' team president, Scott Layden, thought he was doing the right thing Sunday by trying to put a smiley face on their dreadful start to the season. He heaped praise on Coach Jeff Van Gundy, all but nominating him for coach of the year, and then, referring to the team, said, ''I'm positive about the group in all different areas.''

title: Government Reviving Ties to Scientists
description: A new sense of urgency about terrorism has prompted the Bush administration to try to repair federal relations with the nation's scientific elite -- ties forged during the cold war that shriveled with the demise of the communist threat as advisory panels went out of existence and agencies dropped scientists in droves.

title: INSIDE
description: Bull Market Returns

title: Mets Prefer the Trade Market Over Free-Agent Spending
description: General Manager Steve Phillips said yesterday that the Mets did not expect to make an immediate impact in the free-agent market, which opened last night at midnight. ''I won't wake anybody up,'' he said.

title: Survival of the Arts
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has done a splendid job of rallying prospective theatergoers to come to Broadway. But the rest of New York's cultural world has been watching him nervously, fearful that he is about to cut back their city funding at a time when museums, smaller theaters and art institutions are struggling, some even to survive.

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of yesterday, 4,194 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERMAN, BEULAH
description: SHERMAN-Beulah. Born and lived her entire life of 82 years in Lawrence. Her father was a founder and past President of Shaary Tefila. As well, her active life included the synagogue and she was a long time participant as a volunteer in Peninsula General Hospital. Devoted wife of the late Martin. Adored mother of Michael. Cherished sister of Jenny Finkelstein. Passed away peacefully. She loved to travel, attend theater and always looked very glamorous & elegant as an original Lawrence lady. Graveside services 10:30 AM, Mt. Lebanon Cemetery.

title: Miami Moves Closer to Top B.C.S. Ranking
description: Miami spoke, and even the Bowl Championship Series computer listened.

title: When a Woman Loses Hair: New Insights
description: Some fashion models with beautifully shaped heads may choose baldness as part of their look. But for most women, loss of hair -- or even thinning of it -- is highly upsetting, often much more so than for men.

title: Correction: Bonds and Foreign Stocks
description: Two charts on the Databank page of Money & Business on Sunday showing the weekly change in some bond yields and in some foreign stock indexes were a week out of date. Corrected charts appear below.

title: Women in Afghanistan, and Here
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A roster of World Trade Center victims on Sept. 19 listing deaths confirmed by the New York City medical examiner's office misspelled a surname. The Times learned of the error yesterday during research for a future article. The victim was Gary Albero, not Alberto.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINSON, JO LIST
description: LEVINSON-Jo List. Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, Inc., expresses its sorrow at the passing of Jo List Levinson, beloved daughter of Vera G. List, a Guardian of Tomorrow; cherished sister of Olga List Mack; a member of our National Board; beloved mother of Dinse Israel, the late Michael Israel, Debbie and Chip Weber, Jo and Daniel Levinson, and Donna and Jonathan Levinson; and grandmother of 11. Her legacy will live on in her good name. Bonnie Lipton, National President

title: Just in Time, Grandma Is Out of Retirement
description: O.K., Barry Lubin, it pretty much has to be one or the other: is it absolutely the worst time to be a clown or absolutely the best?

title: Indictment by Spanish Judge Portrays a Secret Terror Cell
description: The suspected leader was a jovial family man who drove his children to school at the mosque and listed himself in the Madrid phone book. The man authorities believe to be his lieutenant seemed a bit moodier to neighbors, wearing dark glasses night and day, but he took part in a tree-planting project at his apartment complex.

title: Harry Potter's Appeal
description: To the Editor:

title: Shootout Between Two Gunmen Kills Man and Child in Bronx
description: A 5-year-old boy and a 24-year-old man were killed in crossfire last night when two unidentified gunmen shot at each other on a street corner in the Olinville section of the Bronx, the police said.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Decisions For Water Systems
description: About 150 of the 4,200 small water systems in unincorporated Washington will have to upgrade or join municipal networks when new federal arsenic standards take effect in 2006. Most of the systems are in the populous Puget Sound region, where arsenic from volcanic rock makes its way into soil and waterways. The new rules, which lower allowable arsenic levels to 10 parts per billion, from 50, will be made final in January. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAPERSTEIN, HAROLD
description: SAPERSTEIN-Harold, Rabbi. Congregation Rodeph Sholom notes with sorrow the passing of a giant in the rabbinate. Harold Sapperstein had a legendary career as Rabbi of Temple Emanuel in Lynbrook. Later, he served as Rabbi of our congregation in the painful transition period following the death of our beloved Rabbi Gunter Hirschberg in 1989. Rabbi Sapperstein did everything with passion, dignity, and class. He spoke with prophetic clarity, but embodied personal gentleness. He He will be profoundly missed. Condolences to his beloved family, his wife Marcia, son Marc, & son David, who served us as Rabbi, and all their dear ones. Robert N. Levine, Senior Rabbi Mark Biderman, President

title: Something Missing in Fragile Cloud Forest: The Clouds
description: Bathed in a curtain of life-giving fog and mist, the Monteverde cloud forest in the mountains of Costa Rica is a profusion of dripping green that stands as an international model of conservation gone right. But despite Monteverde's tens of thousands of protected acres, scientists say this tropical luxuriance, beloved by biologists and eco-tourists alike, may be at risk: the clouds that bathe the mountains seem to be disappearing.

title: After Beating Taliban in Herat, Two Warlords Start Perilous Struggle for Credit
description: It would not seem to augur good things for this city that while everyone agrees that the Taliban has been vanquished here, not everyone agrees who deserves the credit.

title: FACING OFF: Of Doctors and Detectives; Should Physicians Help Law Enforcement Authorities Conduct 'DNA Dragnets'?
description: DNA dragnets occur when people who belong to a group that had the opportunity to commit a crime -- like workers in a hospital where a patient was raped -- are asked to submit DNA samples to be compared with crime scene evidence. There is much debate on how broad a group should be asked for samples. Gale Scott discussed DNA dragnets with a forensic scientist and a professor of medical ethics. These are edited excerpts from those interviews.

title: Gay Teenagers' Travails
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS CLIMBS. Natural gas gained on forecasts for colder weather this week. In New York, natural gas for December delivery rose 15.4 cents, or 5.8 percent, to $2.791 per million B.T.U.'s.

title: Corrections
description: A biographical sketch on Sunday about Salvatore Gitto, a World Trade Center victim who was a risk insurance manager and liked to fly planes, misidentified his employer. It was Marsh & McLennan, not Aon Insurance.

title: The Boy and the Firehouse: A Love Story
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Atlantic City: No Fine For Casino Operator
description: A casino operator whose Fourth of July fireworks barge caught fire off Atlantic City this year, sending rockets careering, will not be cited, fire officials said last week. No one was hurt in the incident. James Foley, the city's fire inspection chief, said yesterday that the operator, Park Place Entertainment, was not cited because it had no direct control over the fireworks. Bay Fireworks of Huntington Station, N.Y., which prepared the fireworks barge, was earlier fined $13,800 for storing fireworks improperly, allowing debris to accumulate and failing to outfit technicians with life jackets.

title: Resurgent Rangers Collide With an Unyielding Roy
description: Two weeks ago, the yardstick was the surprising Islanders. Last week, it was a grudge match with the Philadelphia Flyers. Both times, the Rangers more than measured up.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Mobile Phone Sales Drop
description: Mobile telephone sales throughout the world declined to 94.4 million during the third quarter of this year, a 10 percent decline compared with the period a year earlier, a market research firm said. The firm, Gartner Dataquest, which is based in San Jose, Calif., said the cellular phone industry had been affected by widespread economic downturns in regions where the growth of mobile phone use had been high, including Latin America and Europe. ''Most important of all, has been the astonishingly lackluster performance of the Western European market,'' said Ben Wood, an analyst for mobile communications at Gartner.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A Rebound In Search Of a Reason
description: Stocks are strutting their stuff again, up 20 percent or more from their September lows. By conventional measures then, the bull market is back. But does it have stamina?

title: Exelixis in Deal For Genomica
description: Exelixis said yesterday that it would acquire Genomica, a maker of software for genetic analysis, for about $110 million in stock in a sign of further consolidation in the genomics business.

title: Pressing for a Mideast Cease-Fire
description: Secretary of State Colin Powell launched a timely new initiative yesterday to revive stalled Middle East peace efforts. Greater American activism is justified by the inability of Israelis and Palestinians to move forward on their own and by the changed international conditions created by the war against terrorism. While obstacles to progress are daunting, strong engagement by the Bush administration can help overcome them.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: An Honor For A Dishonorable Deed?
description: French investigators looking into illegal arms sales to Angola want to know whether a national decoration bestowed on a businessman, Arkadi Gaydamak, was genuinely in return for his services in rescuing two French hostages in Bosnia in 1995 or for donations he made to further the interests of former Interior Minister Charles Pasqua. Mr. Pasqua has been under investigation since May in connection with receiving kickbacks from illegal sales of arms to Angola. Suzanne Daley (NYT)

title: CUMULUS BUYS CONNECTICUT AND NEW YORK RADIO STATIONS
description: Cumulus Media said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the closely held Aurora Communications for about $223 million in stock, cash and assumed debt to gain radio stations in Connecticut and New York. Cumulus will pay $10 million in cash and assume $83 million in debt for Aurora, which operates 18 radio stations in places like Danbury and Bridgeport in Connecticut, and Westchester County and Poughkeepsie in New York. The stations put Cumulus, based in Atlanta, in the New York area for the first time.

title: Innocence, Desire and Evil Amid the Sails and Salty Air
description: Back-to-back evenings on Friday and Saturday at the Lyric Opera of Chicago suggest that the company is on an artistic roll. First there was an elegant performance of Bellini's ''Capuleti e i Montecchi'' that offered winning performances by the soprano Andrea Rost as Giulietta and the mezzo-soprano Vesselina Kasarova as Romeo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, JORDAN S., MD
description: BROWN-Jordan S., MD, died November 5, 2001. The trustees, faculty and staff of NYU School of Medicine mourn the passing of our friend and colleague, Jordan S. Brown, MD, Professor of Urology. A 1954 graduate of NYU School of Medicine and member of the Department of Urology for more than 40 years, Dr. Brown's career reflected the highest standards and most enduring values of the medical profession. Dr. Brown was an outstanding urologist, a valued member of the faculty and a mentor to many young physicians & students. We will always remain grateful for his years of service to the School of Medicine. We send our deepest condolences to his wife Joan and his family. Kenneth G. Langone, Chairman NYU School of Medicine Foundation Board of Trustees Robert M. Glickman, MD, Dean, NYU School of Medicine Herbert Lepor, MD, Chairman Department of Urology NYU School of Medicine

title: The Opportunist's Friend (and Foe): States' Rights
description: ''We are all republicans, we are all federalists,'' Thomas Jefferson said in his first inaugural address. What Jefferson didn't add -- since he didn't know it yet -- was that when it comes to states' rights, we are all hypocrites.

title: How to Assist Failing Hearts? New Questions Emerge
description: Two events last week involving mechanical heart implants have raised questions about whether research should focus on devices that replace the heart completely, or on ones that assist the heart by taking over some of its pumping.

title: Selling to the Disabled Can Mean More Than Ads
description: Carmen Jones, the founder of the Solutions Marketing Group here, is a dynamo in a wheelchair. Her mission, which she pursues at conventions and businesses across the country, is to help companies develop and carry out marketing strategies aimed at people with disabilities.

title: Kidd Keeps McDyess at (Long) Arm's Length
description: DENVER, Nov. 19  Jason Kidd was not about to talk to Denver Nuggets forward Antonio McDyess today.

title: 3 People at an Uncertain Stage Making Their Uncertain Way
description: The post-college state of adulthood does not get much attention from playwrights except perhaps from those who are in it and are thus without enough experience or perspective on their generation to shed much valuable light. By the time most writers reach their 30's they have seen enough of the world to want to write about it instead of themselves and their friends.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINCHYTZ, MINDEE
description: LINCHYTZ-Mindee. Our very dear friend and special lady. We will always remember your kind words and caring smile. Condolences to the entire family. Jan & Arthur Leichtung

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Atlantic City: Convention Center Losses Expected
description: Atlantic City's two convention centers are projecting a combined loss of $9.8 million for this year, a third larger than last year's loss of $7.4 million. The New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority said one of the centers, the East Hall, the site of the Miss America pageant, was closed for renovation for much of the year. Dan Emmer, a spokesman for the authority, said that because of maintenance, renovation and other costs, losses were expected to continue next year as well.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: $25 Million Printing Plant Set
description: City officials yesterday announced a developer for a $25 million, 400,000-square-foot printing plant in Queens to be completed in 2003. The center will be built on city-owned land and will be called the Graphic Communications Center at College Point. It will serve graphic artists, printers and related companies. The city is in talks to sell the land. The designated developer is Hudson Development L.L.C., which plans a two-story center with private parking on a seven-acre site in the College Point Corporate Park. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

title: Making the Case for Plain Old Aspirin
description: In people who have had one stroke and hope to ward off another, aspirin works just as well as a commonly used and more expensive blood-thinning drug, warfarin, according to a study published last week in The New England Journal of Medicine. Warfarin is also known as Coumadin.

title: Tale of the 'Fever Fiend'
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZWERDLING, ELI D.
description: ZWERDLING-Eli D. Devoted husband of Florence. Beloved father of Janet (Eli) Jeddah and Paula (Steven) Zirinsky. Dear brother of Minnie Storch. Cherished grandfather of Ayallah and David. Services today, 12:15, at ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Tpke., Woodbury, LI.

title: Tar Heels' Problems Continue
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C. -- Matt Doherty has played on one of the few North Carolina teams to start a season 0-2.

title: A Tool for Coping
description: To the Editor:

title: They Happen to Like Singing to Beat the Band
description: There they were, the girls who made you love them and then disappeared, turning up like the bad-penny dames in private-eye novels. They only stuck around for a couple of nights in their slinky silks and satins. But that was long enough for them to win and break hardened hearts all over again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELYACHAR, ANNA TULIN
description: ELYACHAR-Anna Tulin. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) are deeply saddened by the loss of Anna Tulin Elyachar, an ardent supporter of the ATS, the Technion and Israel for more than half a century. Mrs. Elyachar became a devoted Zionist and ATS supporter along with her first husband, the late Abraham Tulin, in the early years of the State of Israel. A Life Trustee of the Women's Division since 1992, Mrs. Elyachar served as vice president of the ATS, was on the Technion International Board of Governors and received an Honorary Fellowship from the Technion. Her second husband, Col. J.R. Elyachar, a founder and past president of the ATS, established the Elyachar Central Library. As Technion Guardians, the couple demonstrated their devotion to the Technion through numerous additional gifts, including the Elyachar Library Fund. After Col. Elyachar's passing, Mrs. Elyachar established a state-of-the-art information center in the library. Intelligent, modest and an inspiring speaker, Mrs. Elyachar will be sorely missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her stepdaughter Ruth (Elyachar) Turner and the entire Elyachar and Tulin families. American Society for TechnionIsrael Institute of Technology Evelyn Berger, President Lawrence S. Jackier, Chairman, Board of Directors Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President Natalie Lyons, President, Women's Division

title: Powell Says Nations Must Act Quickly to Help Afghanistan
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20  Opening a multination conference on the future of Afghanistan, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said today that countries wishing to help must move quickly, yet be prepared for a long mission.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Search Goes On for 2 U.S. Sailors Missing After Ship Sinks Off Iraq
description: Navy ships and helicopters continued to search today for two American sailors missing in the northern Persian Gulf after an overloaded cargo ship they had boarded for inspection sank in rough seas, the Pentagon said.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary of the jazz pianist Tommy Flanagan yesterday misspelled the given name of his wife, who survives him, and omitted her maiden name. The names of three other survivors were also omitted. His wife is Diana Kershner Flanagan, not Diane. Survivors also include his sister, Ida Flanagan Jones of Detroit, and his brothers -- Luther, of Ann Arbor, Mich., and Douglas, of Detroit.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Chairman Of Bull Departs
description: The French information technology company Bull announced that its chairman had resigned and said that it would receive an advance of 100 million euros, or $88.4 million, from the French government. No replacement was named for Guy de Panafieu, who has been chairman of Bull for the last four years, and he will remain at his post until a successor is chosen. Bull is jointly owned by the French government, Motorola, NEC and France Tlcom. The company is struggling with debt and is expected to post an annual loss of around 100 million euros. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: Powell Speech Draws Praise and Pickiness From 2 Sides
description: Israeli and Palestinian officials welcomed tonight the Bush administration's commitment to the struggle for peace here, a commitment spelled out in a speech today by Secretary of State Colin L. Powell. But as Israelis and Palestinians picked apart the meaning of each phrase, their cavils and bouquets underscored the complexity of the mission the administration has set for itself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENMAN, JAMES A.
description: EISENMAN-James A. Died on November 16, 2001, after a long illness. Survived by wife Jan, three daughters, Jan, June and Nancy and a brother, Alvin. Services Saturday, December 8, at St. John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., at 11:30 A.M. In lieu of flowers donations in his memory may be made to Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory Cancer Research.

title: Wall Street Sees Possibility Of a New Suitor for Conoco
description: A day after Conoco and Phillips Petroleum announced plans to merge, creating an oil company with a market value of $35 billion, the stock markets were abuzz yesterday with speculation that another suitor might emerge to woo Conoco, the fourth-largest oil concern in the United States.

title: Women in Afghanistan, and Here
description: To the Editor:

title: Chief Witness Accuses Former Boss at Sotheby's
description: The central witness in the price-fixing trial of A. Alfred Taubman of Sotheby's -- his former chief executive, Diana D. Brooks -- took the stand for the first time yesterday and testified that Mr. Taubman drafted her for a conspiracy with archrival Christie's that he sought to conceal until the very end.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Investment Cut Back
description: Samsung Electronics said it would cut capital investment by about one-third next year, to $1.4 billion. Most new investment will go into semiconductor operations, a company spokesman said. Samsung, the world's largest producer of memory chips, lost nearly $300 million on operations in the third quarter. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHU, WU, PING
description: CHU-Wu-Ping. Peacefully, at home, on November 16, two months short of 101. Deeply beloved mother of John, Yvonne (Meinwald), Theodore, Joan (Fu); grandmother of Barbara, David, Anne (Chu), Constance, Pamela (Meinwald); great-grandmother of Ethan, Benjamin, Beatrix. Funeral private. Interment at Kensico Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory may be made to Palliative Care Unit, Mt. Sinai Hospital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBLUM, MARIE EVA
description: ROSENBLUM-Marie Eva. Survived by her daughter Roberta Shapiro, three sisters, Dr. Grace Kay, Albertine Reuter, and Rosalie Grabel, three grandchildren and three great-grandchilren. Memorial contributions may be made to Hospital Audiences Inc. (HAI), 548 Broadway, 3rd floor, New York, NY 10012, or Lighthouse, 111 East 59th Street, New York, NY.

title: Toys 'R' Us Posts Narrower Quarterly Loss
description: Toys ''R'' Us, the nation's largest chain of toy stores, said today that its third-quarter loss narrowed as it sold more exclusive toys and attracted customers to remodeled stores.

title: Grbac and the Ravens' Offense Are Missing Their Mark
description: The Baltimore Ravens won the Super Bowl last season with a defense that dominated and with a pooh-pooh offense that often shriveled. The prevailing sentiment across the N.F.L. insisted that that was a rarity, a stroke of great fortune, a one-shot deal.

title: New Jersey Sports Arena Bill Stalls for 2nd Time in Committee
description: For the second time in three months, a plan to build a new sports arena in Newark and an entertainment complex in the Meadowlands stalled in committee today, leading many to conclude that its future had gone from uncertain to bleak in the current lame-duck Legislature.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Net Incubator To Close
description: A business incubator founded by Halsey Minor, who also founded CNET Networks, will shut down as soon as January and return the money that it has not invested to its financial backers. The company, 12 Entrepreneuring, which raised $137 million over the last 18 months, invested about $33 million in Internet services companies like iBuilding Inc. and Oxygen Software. Such so-called Internet incubators have fallen on hard times with the collapse of the Web economy. Based in San Francisco, 12 was started by Mr. Minor and Eric Greenberg, founder of the Net consultant Scient Inc. In early November, 12 laid off half its staff in a move to cut costs. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: The Mind of Feynman
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Two charts on the DataBank page of Money & Business on Sunday showing the weekly change in some bond yields and in some foreign stock indexes were a week out of date. Corrected charts appear today, on Page C9.

title: A Star on the Field, but a Bigger Star Off It
description: Randy Earle gathers his teammates together before and after a game and has them say one word: family. For the other players on the Farmingdale (N.Y.) High School team, maybe the word brotherhood would do.

title: Taiwan at Trade Table
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: 2 Die In Crash
description: Two men were killed when the cars they were riding in collided on a Brighton Beach street, the police said yesterday. The driver of one car, Mark Ferdman, 29, of Sheepshead Bay, has been charged with driving while intoxicated and vehicular manslaughter, the police said. One of Mr. Ferdman's two passengers was his brother, Oleg Ferdman, 30, who was taken to Coney Island Hospital and pronounced dead there, the police said. The driver of the second car, Ruby Monachom, 17, was also pronounced dead at the hospital. The two vehicles collided near 154 Neptune Avenue about 11:45 p.m. on Sunday. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: The Big City; For Air Safety, An E-ZPass Using Retinas
description: IF your Thanksgiving starts with a long line at the airport, you may appreciate the recent proposal by the airline industry for a ''trusted traveler'' card. It would be a bit like Monopoly's Get Out of Jail Free card.

title: Wines of the Week
description: Thursday is turkey day and if you haven't been to the store yet, here are some wine ideas to speed up your Thanksgiving Day shopping.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK ALBANY: 2 GOLD FIRMS FINED Two Manhattan jewelry distributors have been fined for selling charms, earrings and other jewelry as 10 karat when they contained too little gold to meet that standard, the authorities said. Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer, left, said yesterday that after a yearlong investigation, officials found that the two companies — Alishaev Brothers and J&I Jewelry — consistently sold items that tested less than 10 karat. The companies agreed to halt shipments of the products. Also, Alishaev Brothers agreed to pay $50,000, and J&I Jewelry, $25,000. The lawyer for Alishaev Brothers, Ivan Fisher, said that the gold was short by "a small margin" and that the company was not admitting wrongdoing. J&I Jewelry did not immediately return calls seeking comment.   Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRADDY, JAMES J.
description: DRADDY-James J. On Nov. 18, 2001, at home in Washington, D.C. Beloved husband for forty-six years of Patricia Shea Draddy. Loving father of Elizabeth Draddy Vangaever, Anne, James Jr., Vincent De Paul, Neil V., Samuel J., Suzy Jacobs. Father-in-law of seven outstanding spouses. Proud grandfather of 14 grandchildren. Memorial mass at Annunciation Church, Washington, D.C., 11 A.M., Tuesday, November 20. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Hospice of Washington, 3720 Upton Street, N.W., Washington, D.C. 20016.

title: Nasdaq's Message Of Global Thanks
description: As many Americans celebrate Thanksgiving, the Nasdaq stock market is set to thank the world.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WOHL, DAVID L.
description: WOHL-David L. November 18, '94. ''I see you, you fade in and out of the mist. I reach for you but I can't touch you. I feel you just beyond the star. How I wish I could realize my heart but it's only wishful thinking on my part.'' I'll always love you, Mommy

title: Awash in Grief After Attack, Adrift in a Sea of Paperwork
description: Meryl Mayo's to-do list is measurable not in length but in thickness. It is an accordion file, royal blue and encyclopedia-fat -- a gift from a prescient sister-in-law who somehow knew in the first days after Mrs. Mayo's husband was killed that paperwork management would become a spouse's survival skill.

title: Bloomberg Names 56 to Transition Committee
description: Michael R. Bloomberg, New York's mayor-elect, named 56 people to his transition committee yesterday, putting together a group of both prominent campaign supporters and a deliberately diverse assembly of New Yorkers to advise him on forming his administration.

title: Pearson and Chinese Network In Educational TV Venture
description: Pearson P.L.C., the biggest educational publisher, said today that it formed a venture with the biggest television broadcaster in China to provide education and publishing service to the nation's 350 million television households in March of next year.

title: Gift Tally: $1.5 Million In, But $2.5 Million Is Spent
description: America's Fund for Afghan Children, a program President Bush started last month to encourage children and families in the United States to contribute to the relief efforts for the children of Afghanistan, has collected about $1.5 million, officials said.

title: Easing Pain Rooted in Nervous System
description: Pain caused by problems in the nervous system, called neuropathic pain, is often difficult to treat. But a new study published this month in the journal Neurology found that the severity of the pain was reduced significantly among patients taking an antidepressant called bupropion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOINESTER, LOUIS
description: MOINESTER-Louis. (Formerly of New York City.) Beloved husband of Roslyn. Devoted father of June. Brother of Isaac. Brother-in-law of Sterna & David Weisinger. Uncle to Dena Shelley, Nina Moinester, Ron Weisinger and Judy Ziegler. A kind, gentle, unassuming, charitable man who never expected anything in return. He will be in our hearts forever. Services ''The Riverside'', 76 St and Amsterdam Avenue, Wednesday, at 9:45 AM.

title: The Music Makers Return and, Hesitantly, a City Sings Again
description: Radio Nangarhar is on the air, 1,000 watts of poetry beaming out over Afghanistan.

title: Editors' Note; Today's Sections
description: News of the Sept. 11 attacks and their aftermath continues to appear in Section B; index, Page B2.

title: Tommy Flanagan Service
description: The funeral for the jazz pianist Tommy Flanagan, who died on Friday, will be held on Wednesday at 7 p.m. at St. Peter's Lutheran Church in Citicorp Center, Lexington Avenue at 54th Street. Many of his associates, including the Detroit pianist Barry Harris, will play at the service, which is open to the public.

title: Judges Rebuff Skakel Effort To Avoid Trial in Adult Court
description: The Connecticut Supreme Court yesterday dismissed Michael C. Skakel's appeal of a ruling that he be tried as an adult in the slaying of Martha Moxley in 1975, when they were both just 15.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Utility To Buy British Network
description: Pursuing a contentious program of rapid expansion beyond its home base, the state-owned lectricit de France said that it would spend around $2.4 billion to buy a power distribution network and a coal-fired power generator in Britain from the TXU Corporation of Dallas. The French utility's expansion this year in several European countries has drawn criticism from rivals complaining that government ownership prevents them from making similar inroads in France. The latest acquisitions require European regulatory approval. lectricit de France said its British subsidiary, London Electricity, would buy the Eastern Electricity network from TXU for $1.87 billion in cash and assumed debt, and would also acquire the 2,000-megawatt West Burton power station for $523 million. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We will do all we can to help the process along. We will push and prod. We will present ideas.''

title: Footlights
description: Introducing a 'Messiah'

title: California Retailer to Buy F.A.O. Schwarz Toy Stores
description: Just in time for the holiday shopping season, F. A. O. Schwarz and its fantasyland for 5-year-olds on Fifth Avenue are changing hands again.

title: ALCOA PLANS TO LAY OFF 6,500 AND CLOSE PLANTS
description: The aluminum maker Alcoa plans to lay off about 6,500 employees at 40 sites in the Americas and Europe, or 4.6 percent of its work force, and close plants to reduce costs. The company forecast fourth-quarter expenses of as much as $250 million for severance packages and plant closings, which are expected to be completed by the end of next year. Alcoa, based in Pittsburgh, has 140,000 employees. The chief executive, Alain Belda, says he wants to reduce Alcoa's expenses by $1 billion a year by the end of 2004. Earnings fell 7.9 percent in the third quarter as sales dropped 13 percent.

title: U.S. PLEDGES PUSH FOR MIDEAST PEACE
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said today that the Bush administration -- after ten months of hesitation -- would send high-level envoys immediately to the Middle East to seek a cease-fire, restart negotiations and help set the terms for the creation of a ''viable'' Palestinian state and a more secure Israel.

title: Safeguarding Uranium
description: To the Editor:

title: Tokyo Fears China May Put an End to 'Made in Japan'
description: Last spring, Toshiba stopped making televisions in Japan, turning to its factories in China to supply the market here. Soon Minolta announced that it was phasing out camera production in Japan and would import from Shanghai instead.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JANOFSKY, ALBERT
description: JANOFSKY-Albert. Beloved husband of Rachel, loving father of Dr. Elliott and Betty Janofsky and Sally and Michael Hipscher. Devoted grandfather of Steven, Joel and Lorraine, Karen and Jenny. Adored great-grandfather of Emma Rose. Devoted to family, country, religion, community and loved his NY Yankees. Services today 1 PM at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, Ave J.

title: For a Shopping Spree, the Closet's the Place
description: There was, in the language of the H.M.O.'s, a pre-existing condition. Even before the ''in the wake ofs'' and ''in the aftermath ofs,'' in those distant-seeming days when the news media hadn't yet begun diagnosing these as ''uncertain times,'' American retailing was already experiencing plenty of distress. Sales were slumping. Anyone who visited a mall felt the cold winds whistling down empty aisles.

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Jets Learned Their Defensive Lessons Well
description: On the bleak Monday after the Jets lost to St. Louis a month ago, safety Damien Robinson visited the defensive coordinator, Ted Cottrell, in his office. It was, Cottrell said today, one of the best talks he has ever had with a player.

title: 'Kangaroo' Care for Underweight Infants
description: In developing countries, the number of underweight infants needing special care far outstrips the cribs available in neonatal units. To help free resources for the tiniest and most fragile babies, a technique called kangaroo mother care has been developed for newborns who, while underweight, do not require intensive care in the hospital. A new study in the journal Pediatrics found the method to be as effective as more traditional methods.

title: Inquiry Focus: Pilot Training In Emergencies
description: Investigators looking for the cause of the crash in Queens a week ago that left 265 people dead are scrutinizing training for American Airlines pilots that involves unusual emphasis on using the rudder to regain control of an airplane thrown into an unusual angle.

title: Miami Quarterback Hasn't Forgotten Late Hits
description: Still smarting over what he describes as numerous late hits by the University of Washington in last season's game, University of Miami quarterback Ken Dorsey yesterday added fuel to Saturday's showdown by asserting that things would be different this time.

title: Talks About the Future, Pressure on the Taliban, Suspects in the West
description: Decades of war and centuries of ethnic hatred have left Afghanistan broken: a country without a government, a land without an economy, a people torn apart by rivalries. With the Taliban nearly beaten, an effort to put the nation back together has begun, and a crucial step was made by the Northern Alliance, which seized control of the capital, Kabul, last week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KETTLES, GILBERT PARMELE
description: KETTLES-Gilbert Parmele. Of White Plains, NY, formerly of Mamaroneck, NY died November 16, 2001 at the age of 75. Born on April 2, 1926 in New York, he was the son of the late Emilie F. Parmele and Francis Kettles and a predeceased brother, Frank. Mr. Kettles was prominent in the packaging industry. He graduated from the University of PennsyvaniaWharton School of Business. He also served in the United States Air Corps during World War II. He was a member of Westchester Country Club in Rye, NY and a former member of the New York Athletic Club and the Seigniory Club in Ottawa, Canada. He was an accomplished bridge player. Mr. Kettles was the beloved husband of Alanna Macnamara Kettles and devoted father of Pamela K. Keller of Chicago, IL. Debra Busby Kunces of Darien, CT. Gail B. Donovan of New Canaan, CT. Diane Busby of Wilton, CT. and Gilbert P. Kettles Jr. of San Francisco, CA. He is also survived by nine grandchildren. A Memorial Mass is being held at 11AM, Wednesday, Nov. 21st at the Church of the Resurrection 910 Boston Post Road in Rye, NY. For information contact William H. Graham Funeral Home in Rye. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to Rosary Hill Home, 600 Linda Ave., Hawthorne, NY 10532 or Calvary Fund at Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Road Bronx, NY 10461.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Alaska: Payments Decrease
description: Dividends from the state's Permanent Fund are expected to shrink for the second consecutive year. About 590,000 residents -- every man, woman or child who has lived in the state for at least a year -- will receive checks of $1,630 in 2002, down from this year's $1,850, a spokesman for the fund said. Payments were $1,963 in 2000, when the fund's earnings peaked. The $24.5 billion fund was established in 1976 with oil revenues; it was intended to attract people to Alaska. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Coming of Age with H.I.V.
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JELLIFFE, GEORGE CLARK
description: JELLIFFE-George Clark. Of Manchester-By-the-Sea, MA., died in his sleep November 14th in the Oakwood Retirement Home. He was 93. Born in Jersey City, N.J., Mr. Jelliffe attended Stevens Prep and graduated from Stevens Institute of Technology with an advanced degree in Mechanical Engineering. He was a member of the U.S. Cavalry and volunteered for the Navy during World War II, where he was a Lieutenant Commander aboard the U.S.S. Anderson, helping to rescue survivors of the South Pacific death marches. After the war, Mr. Jelliffe was an engineer for United Technologies and was elected President of the Stevens Alumni Association and member of its Board of Directors. Mr. Jelliffe also served as a steward in the Tenafly, N.J. Presbyterian Church and a member of the Tenafly Zoning Board of Appeals. He was a lifelong tennis player and an accomplished musician, both building and playing the tuba-fone. He also designed and built squirrel-proof birdfeeders from recycled material and donated them to bird sanctuaries. Mr. Jelliffe was married for 63 years to the late Abbie English Jelliffe, whom he adored. He was brother to the late Anna Jelliffe Ogdin of Narberth, PA., and Margaret Jelliffe of Jersey City, loving and doting father to Andrew Clark Jelliffe of Morrison, CO. and Nancy Jelliffe Bruett of Marblehead, MA. He is also survived by four grandchildren, Melissa J. Rees of Littleton, Co., Philip A. Jelliffe of St. Helen, Oregon, David C. Bruett of South Boston, MA., Abbie E. Bruett of Marblehead, MA., and one greatgrandchild, Logan C. Jelliffe. Mr. Jelliffe always had a kind word, never let his family down and left everyone happier for seeing him. For further information please contact the Murphy Funeral Home, 85 Federal St., Salem, MA. His funeral and burial will be private in Lebanon, N.J. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Stevens Institute of Technology, Castle Point-on-Hudson, Hoboken, New Jersey, 07030.

title: A Shellfish of His Own
description: Jay Shaffer, left, who owns Shaffer City Oyster Bar & Grill, 5 West 21st Street, serves a variety of oyster that is his exclusively: Shaffer Cove, a plump, lightly briny medium-size bluepoint, above. This oyster has a sweet finish, suggesting artichokes, and a crisp texture. The oysters are bred from Wellfleet spat, transplanted to Great South Bay, near the Long Island town of Blue Point, and then transferred to beds that Mr. Shaffer leases on the North Shore, near Port Jefferson. The oysters are $2 each and can be ordered, freshly opened, to take out. To order: (212) 255-9827.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCOOEY, ROBERT H.
description: McCOOEY-Robert H. The Board of Trustees, Administration and Medical Staff of Our Lady of Mercy Medical Center deeply mourn the passing of our dear friend, trusted leader and colleague, Robert H. McCooey. His integrity, intelligence, vision, compassion, & humanity made him a remarkable and wonderfully rare individual. His dedication to faith and family embodied the mission of Our Lady of Mercy Medical Center. We will greatly miss him, and we extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Mary Catherine (Joyce), his children Robert H. Jr., Kristina Grimm McCooey, Mark, Michael, Timothy, Mary Catherine and Kevin, and grandchildren Robert III, Christopher, Elizabeth, Matthew, Thomas McCooey, and to his brothers Richard, Bert and John. Our Lady of Mercy Medical Center Christopher Conley, Chairman James A. Rutherford, President and CEO

title: Brady Will Start Ahead of Bledsoe
description: New England Patriots Coach Bill Belichick said yesterday that Tom Brady would start at quarterback for the rest of the season, even though Drew Bledsoe has recovered from a chest injury.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Conoco Plays Security Card In Promoting Its Merger
description: As he leads the cheers for his company's planned merger with Phillips Petroleum, the chairman of Conoco, Archie W. Dunham, has added a new rationale for the deal that would probably not have been mentioned before Sept. 11: energy security.

description: Standing ovations are nothing new for Patrick Roy, who someday will be voted into the Hall of Fame. But the one he received last night was one he could well have done without.

title: Bank Street College Gets $7 Million Gift
description: The Bank Street College of Education has received $7 million, the largest private gift in its history, from LYNN STRAUS, a trustee and graduate school alumna (1947), and her husband, PHILIP, to be used at the college's discretion. In addition, the college has announced a $1.1 million grant from the Atlantic Philanthropies of New York City for its Center for Urban Teacher Education and Technology, which opened this fall. The center, headed by MARVIN COHEN, is aimed at fostering the innovative use of new technologies in its teacher preparation courses. Stephanie Rosenbloom

title: LTV ASKS BANKRUPTCY COURT IF IT CAN SELL MILLS
description: The LTV Corporation, the steel maker based in Cleveland, asked a bankruptcy court yesterday for permission to close its mills and put them up for sale because it did not have enough cash to continue operating. LTV, which filed for bankruptcy protection in December, said it had also asked the bankruptcy judge, William T. Bodoh, for permission to reject its labor agreements. The company has 7,800 employees and around 45,000 retirees. LTV said that it planned to continue to operate its tube-making unit, LTV Copperweld. In July, LTV reached a labor agreement with the United Steelworkers of America that allowed the company to lay off 1,300 workers, halt raises and cut benefits. At the time, LTV said the accord would help avert a shutdown and liquidation.

title: World Business Briefing | The Americas: Canada: Trade Surplus Increases
description: A 4.6 percent slump in imports lifted Canada's trade surplus to 4.7 billion Canadian dollars ($2.9 billion) in September, from 3.9 billion Canadian dollars ($2.4 billion) in August, Statistics Canada said. Exports fell 1.7 percent to their lowest level since February 2000. Shipments to the United States, which accounts for more than 85 percent of Canada's exports, slipped 2.1 percent. The decline in exports continued a trend evident in earlier months. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: A Transit Security Overseer
description: Louis R. Anemone, a former city police official whose exacting manner was said to have improved crime fighting while it antagonized colleagues, was appointed yesterday to oversee security for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, a position created to address the threat of terrorism against the transit system.

title: DEERE REPORTS ITS LARGEST QUARTERLY LOSS IN A DECADE
description: Deere & Company, the large maker of farm equipment based in Moline, Ill., had its biggest quarterly loss in a decade and said yesterday that it expected a fiscal first-quarter loss because of low crop prices, production slowdowns and costs related to job cuts. Analysts were expecting a first-quarter profit. First-quarter sales are expected to fall by as much as 7 percent, and Deere is not expecting farm subsidies to help in 2002, a spokeswoman, Marie Ziegler, said. In the fourth quarter, ended Oct. 31, Deere had a loss of $320 million, or $1.36 a share, in contrast to net income of $71.1 million, or 30 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales fell 6.4 percent, to $3.16 billion.
