title: Cablevision Will Increase Rates 5.5%
description: Cablevision Systems Corporation, the New York region's largest cable television provider, said yesterday that it would increase its rates 5.5 percent starting next year. The increase reflects higher programming and operating costs, inflation and improvements in service, said Charles Schueler, a company spokesman. Last year's increase averaged 7 percent, he added. AT&T Corporation, the nation's largest cable television provider, raised its rates by an average of 5.5 percent this month. Cablevision has 3 million customers in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Duty Dancing

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: $81 Million Stock Windfall
description: Connecticut will receive stock valued at nearly $81 million after the conversion of its health insurer, Anthem Blue Cross/ Blue Shield, to a publicly traded company. Gov. John G. Rowland announced yesterday that the state would receive about 1.7 million shares of stock. The state legislature and the governor are attempting to close a $100 million deficit. But it was not immediately clear whether or how much the stock would help with the deficit. The shares will become available in January, but cannot be sold until June.

title: Investment Banking Is Cited For Much of Credit Suisse Loss
description: Losses at its investment banking arm and the general drooping of the global economy combined to push the Credit Suisse Group, Switzerland's second-largest bank, into a loss in the third quarter, along with many of its peers in the banking industry.

title: Knicks Have Issues; Just Count Them Up
description: Road trip, Day 4. The reeling Knickerbockers gained revenge last night against the team that ran them off the floor at Madison Square Garden a couple of weeks ago, the healthy and hungry Golden State Warriors. Latrell Sprewell was asked before the game if he ever imagined his old team in better shape than the Knicks. He feigned a smile and said he was happy to see the Warriors, a perennial lottery club, doing well.

title: Robinson Searches for Right Mix
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20  While the Devils have struggled in recent days, Larry Robinson has not idly watched and waited for the turnaround to come. But after shuffling his lines on Saturday when the Devils played host to the Flyers, Robinson, the Devils' coach, put the team's A line back together by the time the game was over.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINSON, JO LIST
description: LEVINSON-Jo List. The community of West End Synagogue mourns the death of our member Jo Levinson and extends its condolences to her mother, sisters, children and grandchildren. title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Songwriters Sue Music Services
description: A group of 27,000 songwriters and publishers said they had filed a lawsuit contending copyright infringement against three Internet services that permit the free exchange of music. The songwriters and publishers, who own the rights to about 90 percent of the music recorded for distribution in the United States, assert that users of MusicCity, Consumer Empowerment and Grokster exchanged more than one billion song files last month. ''They've effectively replaced Napster,'' said Carey Ramos, above, the lawyer representing the copyright holders. Mr. Ramos said the lawsuit filed this week was similar to the one filed by publishers and song writers against Napster, a free music exchange that has been offline since July. Mr. Ramos said the new suit did not specify an amount of damages, but he said the figure could be as much as $200,000 per work. But, Mr. Ramos said, the suit's main objective was to stop the services from operating. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: An Investigation in Egypt Illustrates Al Qaeda's Web
description: To support their terrorism, they skimmed money from a charity for Muslim orphans in Albania and robbed an Italian diplomat's home in Jordan. They acquired or forged seals from universities, border guards and the Saudi Arabian Interior Ministry.

title: Court Backs Levi Strauss On Pricing
description: In a blow to consumers looking for savings on designer goods, Europe's highest court backed Levi Strauss & Company today in a long-running legal battle to keep cut-price versions of its blue jeans from being sold by Tesco, Britain's biggest supermarket chain.

title: Polish Pair Wins Life Master Bridge Title
description: Many of Europe's best bridge players were in action at the Fall National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League here on Monday, and two of them carried off a major title, their first on this side of the Atlantic.

description: To the Editor:

title: Man Linked to Hijackers Is Granted Bail; San Diego Muslims Put Up Money
description: A Yemeni student who federal officials say provided assistance to three of the hijackers in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks was granted bail today after members of the Muslim community here agreed to put up $500,000 on his behalf.

title: Fearful City Wonders Whether Taliban Will Leave Quietly or Fight
description: An atmosphere of fear and suspense hangs over Kandahar, the birthplace of the Taliban in southern Afghanistan, as the leader of the movement, Mullah Muhammad Omar, appears to be maneuvering toward his exit, travelers from the city said today.

title: The Usual Suspects? Look Again
description: YOU'VE stocked the pantry with all the staples: sweet potatoes, cranberries, maybe chestnuts. It's fall. It's Thanksgiving, and you know how much family and friends expect the comfortable and familiar. But getting stuck in the rut of yesteryear, in the belief that it's absolutely required, may deprive you and everybody else of some culinary excitement.

description: SOFTWARE

title: First Anthrax, Now Mice
description: The United States Postal Service may have done enough to clean up the anthrax in its New York facilities, but a federal judge ruled last week that there is a mouse problem, and it is out of control, at least at the Morgan Processing and Distribution Center in Manhattan.

title: Our Towns; Sometimes, The School Is the Football
description: CHRISTINA ALEXANDER, a Roosevelt High senior, is a dynamo. She's ranked sixth, plays clarinet in the band, made the basketball team and is class vice president. If you ask for her church and civic activities she prints out an impressive rsum on her home computer.

title: Augustus C. Long, 97, Chief Of Texaco in 50's and 60's
description: Augustus C. Long, a former chief executive of Texaco, who guided the company's international expansion in the 1950's and 60's, died last Thursday at his home in North, Va. He was 97.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONDE, ANNE
description: SONDE-Anne. Of New York and Maryland, died peacefully in her Maryland home on November 19, 2001. She was 89 years old and a retired New york City school teacher. She is survived by her beloved sister Lillian Kaufman, her devoted children Ted, Clive, Diane and their spouses, Susan, Vicky and Larry, and her loving grandchildren Darlene, Tina, Rikki, Andi and David and their spouses David, Doug, Andrew and Roland and her 12 great grandchildren. ''We can't imagine the world without you, Nana.'' Funeral Service: Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76 St & Amsterdam Ave on Wednesday, November 21 at 11:15 AM. Contributions in her memory may be made to the New York Diabetes Association or the Floating Hospital, New York.

title: Museum Pieces for the Table (Silverware Not Included)
description: Museum shops, long destinations for gift shoppers, now cater to holiday hosts, too, with distinctive dinnerware being the latest offering. AsiaStore, the shop in the newly refurbished Asia Society (725 Park Avenue at 70th Street), sells Asianera, its exclusive pattern in white bone china with patterned rims. A 10-inch dinner plate is $28.50; the 7-inch salad or dessert plate with an underwater scene, $16.50; a soup bowl, $15; and a mug, $18. The Neue Galerie New York, a museum of German and Austrian Art (1048 Fifth Avenue at 86th Street) has stoneware dishes, center, inspired by the Austrian designer Koloman Moser of the Wiener Werkstatte. The white plates have demure blue-and-white checked rims. The dinner plate is $48; a salad plate, $18; the soup bowl, $24. For more casual entertaining, the Metropolitan Museum Shops sell tin plates that are exact reproductions of blue and white English Staffordshire. A set of four is $30. For store locations: (800) 662-3397.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONESCU, ARTHUR
description: CONESCU-Arthur. Died Tuesday, November 20, 2001. Beloved husband of Marcia. Devoted father of Joshua and Rachel and their spouses Karyl and Francis. Dear brother of Sidney Conescu. Adored grandfather of Reva, Ben, Isabelle, and Lilly. Graveside service today. Memorial service will be held in December, date to be announced. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Port Washington Public Library Music Advisory Council or Art Advisory Council.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMORY, THOMAS CARHART
description: AMORY-Thomas Carhart. Passed away November 18, 2001 from complications from a long battle with Progressive Supranuclear Palsy. He was born in New York City on October 29, 1933. Mr. Amory was the only child of George Sullivan Amory and Marion Renee Carhart Amory. He attended the Buckley School, Exeter Academy and Harvard University (class of '56). Mr. Amory was the former President of William H. Clark Associates. He served on the Boards of the Museum of the City of New York, the Tuxedo Club and was an officer of the Clove Valley Rod and Gun Club. He was also a member of the River Club, the Nantucket Yacht Club, A.D. Club of Harvard University, the Boys and Girls Club of Santa Barbara, the Chamber Orchestra of Santa Barbara, Birnam Wood Golf Club of Santa Barbara, the Santa Barbara Club and a Trustee of the Santa Barbara Museum of Art. Thomas was a devoted husband to Doris Mack Amory. He is survived by his three daughters, Renee Amory Ketcham of Greenwich, CT, Caroline Carhart Amory of Atlanta, GA, Gillian Brookman Amory of Tampa, FL and his two grandchilden Saunders Carhart Ketcham and Elizabeth Amory Ketcham. The family wishes to thank caregivers Willie Rowan and Jerry Lee for their devotion to the care and comfort of Mr. Amory throughout his illness. They would also like to extend special thanks to the physicians and staff who contributed to his excellent medical care. A devout Catholic, Mr. Amory will be remembered for his profound faith that allowed him to endure the extreme physical limitations of PSP. He was an example to us all and we will miss him. Contributions may be made to the Society for Progressive Supranuclear Palsy, Woodhome Medical Bldg, Suite 515, 1838 Green Tree Rd, Baltimore MD 21208.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHU, WU PING
description: CHU-Wu Ping. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff of the Mount Sinai Hospital and Mount Sinai School of Medicine note with sadness the passing of Wu Ping Chu. Her personal generosity and the generosity of her family to The Lillian and Benjamin Hertzberg Palliative Care Institute helped further Mount Sinai's mission of excellence in patient care. Wu Ping Chu will be remembered fondly, with gratitude, for her loyal support. We extend our sincere sympathy to Wu Ping Chu's children, grandchildren, and the entire family. Stephen M. Peck, Chair The Mount Sinai Medical Center Nathan Kase, Interim President and CEO, The Mount Sinai Medical Center and Interim Dean, Mount Sinai School of Medicine Barry R. Freedman, President and CEO, The Mount Sinai Hospital

Elyachar, was a YU Benefactor. Her participation and interest in Yeshiva University over the years will be sorely missed. May her stepdaughter, Ruth Elyachar Turner, and the enire Elyachar/Tulin family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Robert M. Beren, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Fire Chaplain Honored
description: The City Council unanimously passed a bill yesterday that would rename a stretch of West 31st Street in Manhattan after the Rev. Mychal F. Judge, left, one of the first people identified as dying in the collapse of the World Trade Center on Sept. 11. Father Judge had been the fire department's chaplain since 1992 and died as he ministered to victims, many of them firefighters. The bill passed along with similar measures, including one that would name a Lower East Side park after former Mayor John V. Lindsay over the objections of the local community board.

title: Editors' Note; Today's Sections
description: News of the Sept. 11 attacks and their aftermath continues to appear in Section B; index, Page B2.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAMSEY, NINA
description: RAMSEY-Nina. On November 18, 2001, at age 43. Beloved wife of Gregory. Devoted daughter of Si and the late Nancy Friedman and stepdaughter of Margaret Friedman. Dear sister of Mark Friedman and adoring aunt of James Friedman. Interment private. Memorial service to be announced.

description: When Gerald Ford turned down New York City's appeal for financial aid, the front page of The Daily News screamed ''Ford to City: Drop Dead.'' Those were the days.

description: Shares of Enron Plunge On Doubts Over Merger

title: Carmichael Lynch Ends Work for Ikea
description: Carmichael Lynch in Minneapolis is parting ways with Ikea, the home furnishings retailer, after 11 months of working together by declining to take part in an account review the company is starting. Billings were estimated at $40 million.

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday with an On Pro Football article about the decline of the Baltimore Ravens in the season after their Super Bowl victory, tracing the performance of other champions since 1991 in each one's next season, gave records erroneously for several teams. A corrected version appears today, on Page S5.

title: Signing Smoltz to Start Is Tempting for the Mets
description: General Manager Steve Phillips has stressed that the Mets' payroll concerns might make them more active in trades than in free agency this winter. But the free-agent market is intriguing to the Mets, who want to be involved as talks move along with several prominent players.

title: At an Anthrax Lab, the World Changed Quickly
description: The rectangular box arrived via overnight delivery at Dr. Theresa Koehler's laboratory. That box contained a smaller box, which held a canister. Inside the canister was another canister, which safeguarded a glass vial. And at the bottom of the vial were anthrax bacteria.

title: Carmichael Lynch Ends Work for Ikea
description: Carmichael Lynch in Minneapolis is parting ways with Ikea, the home furnishings retailer, after 11 months of working together by declining to take part in an account review the company is starting. Billings were estimated at $40 million.

title: OBITUARY : Gene Fenn, 90, Photographer
description: PARIS  Gene Fenn, 90, a fashion photographer for Harper's Bazaar and other popular women's magazines, died Nov. 14 in Paris.

title: Foreign Militants in Kunduz Seek Safe Passage to Pakistan
description: EMAM SAHEB, Afghanistan, Nov. 21 - Foreign militants, trapped inside the besieged city of Kunduz and desperate to save their lives, have asked to leave the country through a protected corridor and travel overland to Pakistan, a senior Northern Alliance official said here today.

title: A Little Extra Care Elevates a Simple Wine
description: HOW empty life would be if, night after night, one drank nothing but Mouton-Rothschild and the other great wines of the world. I can picture Orson Welles in ''Citizen Kane,'' surrounded by wealth in his Xanadu but longing for simple pleasures like an honest Ctes du Rhne, a Rosebud wine if ever there was one.

title: Business Travel; Some women fliers complain about the treatment they are receiving from male security guards.
description: ANN ZAKOWSKI is still peeved about the way she was treated at an airport more than a month ago.

title: Dodging Bombs and Ghosts in Civil War Spain
description: One of the pleasant surprises of last summer was ''The Others,'' a rigorous and effective ghost story by the Chilean-born Spanish director Alejandro Almenbar. Like Mr. Almenbar, Guillermo del Toro, the director and writer of ''The Devil's Backbone,'' who was born in Mexico and who has worked both in Spain and in Hollywood, is a devoted student of classic horror films. The two filmmakers, both of them relatively young (Mr. Almenbar is 29, Mr. Del Toro, 36), seem to have spent their childhoods studying Alfred Hitchcock's camerawork and the voluptuously scary compositions of the Italian terror-maestro Mario Bava.

title: Top Microsoft Lawyer to Retire After Years of Legal Battles
description: William H. Neukom, general counsel of the Microsoft Corporation ( news/quote ), will retire next summer, the software company announced today.

title: Barak Testifies on Israeli Arab Violence
description: Ehud Barak, the former Israeli prime minister, told a state inquiry commission today that he was caught by surprise by the wave of violent protests by Israeli Arabs that erupted after the outbreak of the Palestinian uprising last year.

title: Panel Suggests More Sharing Of Research
description: The Department of Defense should share more information with civilian engineers on constructing bomb-resistant buildings, a panel of engineering experts said yesterday.

title: What's Doing In New York's Farm Set
description: What has 15 recipes for winter squash, a list of 200 varieties of apple and profiles of New York farmers? It is Farm to Table, the Web site of the Earth Pledge Foundation, a Manhattan nonprofit organization that promotes sustainable agriculture and environmental preservation. The site, www.farmtotable.org, provides information about New York State's produce and other foods, recipes, a listing of events and discussions of food-related issues, and information about producers like Laurie Goodheart, left, who makes goat cheese at Nettle Meadow Organic Farm in Warrenburg, N.Y.

title: Footlights
description: Of Gods and Man

title: A Green Light for Love at the Frazzled Corners of Life
description: Surely, after everything this city has been through, the time is right for a breezy, captivating New York romantic comedy. ''Sidewalks of New York'' is not an especially good movie, but it will do. Edward Burns, who wrote, directed and stars, has an evident and specific fondness for Manhattan: the slightly insecure romanticism of a migrant from the outer boroughs or the near suburbs. This sentiment is most clearly expressed by Mr. Burns's character, a television producer named Tommy, who comes from Queens.

title: Consultants Put Aside Rivalries for New York
description: Kathryn Wylde did not think twice about asking half a dozen consulting firms that have always viewed one another as archcompetitors to work together on a study of the terrorist attack's economic impact.

title: Another Reason to Eat Cranberries
description: GEORGE BUSH, the one known as No. 41 to distinguish him from his son, No. 43, might be pleased to learn that he can get many more antioxidants by eating cranberries than by eating broccoli, which he put on the map by proclaiming his hatred of it. Just in time for Thanksgiving, researchers have discovered that cranberries have five times the antioxidant content of broccoli, which means they may protect against cancer, stroke and heart disease.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILTSHIRE, AMABEL
description: WILTSHIRE-Amabel. Trustees and staff of Brooklyn Public Library and Brooklyn Public Library Foundation mourn the death of Amabel Wiltshire, dear mother of Library President and Foundation Trustee Albert C. Wiltshire. Our prayers and love are with the Wiltshire family. Martin Gomez, Executive Director Trustees, Brooklyn Public Library Brooklyn Public Library Foundation

A memorial service will be held at a time to be announced. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Valerie Fund, 2101 Millburn Avenue, Maplewood, NJ 07040. For information Dangler Funeral Home, 600 Speedwell Avenue, Morris Plains, New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ASCHER, GERARD
description: ASCHER-Gerard. Born July 31, 1917 to November 21, 1999. Remembered by your loving family.

title: McGreevey Says Budget Falls Short by $1.9 Billion
description: After an intensive two-week review of New Jersey's fiscal condition, Governor-elect James E. McGreevey warned today that the state faced a shortfall of $1.9 billion in its current $24 billion budget, far larger than had been anticipated. He also forecast a deficit of $3.7 billion in the next fiscal year.

title: Harry Potter and the Publisher's Dream
description: To the Editor:

title: In Their Heartland, Defiant Taliban Let Refugees Meet the Press
description: A calendar hangs on the office wall of the local Taliban leader here, celebrating the destruction of this country's Buddha statues this year. Before-and-after photographs show the effects of the Taliban's policies, though the biggest picture is of the explosion itself, a brown cloud of dust that the calendar celebrates as a historic image.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Refunds For Handicapped Parking Permits
description: The state's Motor Vehicle Department must refund an estimated $30 million in fees collected from disabled people who were illegally charged for for parking permits for the handicapped, a state court judge ruled, saying the $15 fees violated the Americans with Disabilities Act. More than a million people are eligible for a refund.

title: Yeshiva Names Law School Dean
description: DAVID RUDENSTINE, a professor of constitutional law at Yeshiva University's Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law and expert in First Amendment and cultural property law, has been named Cardozo's dean. Professor Rudenstine, 59, the first dean in the school's 25-year history to be drawn from its faculty, succeeds PAUL R. VERKUIL, who will remain a professor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKENNA, CATHERINE
description: McKENNA-Catherine. November 19, 2001. Native of County Monaghan, Ireland. Beloved sister of the late Mary McEneany. Loving aunt of Sr. Mary Carmel, O.P., Kathleen Singer, Edward J. McEneany and Sr. Barbara McEneany, O.P. Also survived by several nieces and nephews in Ireland and England. Family will receive friends in the Chapel of Frances Schervier Nursing Home, 2975 Independence Ave., Bronx, Wednesday at 11:00 AM where a Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at 12:00 noon. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Donations in her memory may be made to Sisters of St. Dominic Retirement Fund, 496 Western Hwy., Blauvelt, NY 10913.

title: P & O and Royal Caribbean To Merge Into Largest Cruise Line
description: Two leading cruise lines announced a $2.89 billion deal today to combine, becoming the world's largest cruise ship company.

title: TV Advertising Group Will Meet in New York
description: The Television Bureau of Advertising, the trade association of local television broadcasters, plans to hold its 2002 Annual Marketing Conference in New York to show support for the city and to guarantee a high level of participation.

title: As Soliders Cheer, Bush Braces Country for Long Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21  With the Taliban forces in retreat across much of Afghanistan, President Bush sought today to brace the country and its soldiers for a long campaign, one that will be fought in many places.

title: Outback Excursion
description: Contiki has one-week Gold'n Outback tours starting at $509 a person, based on two people to a tent, land only. Stops on the tour, geared for ages 18 to 35, include Purnululu National Park (home of the Bungle Bungle mountain range), Wolfe Creek Meteorite Crater, Alice Springs and a stay in bush camps and a cattle ranch. Information: (888) 266-8454 or on the Internet at www.contiki.com .

title: As Nets Rise, Kidd Seeks Promotion
description: The Nets are 7-3, even after two consecutive losses, and the consensus within the organization and throughout the league is that Jason Kidd is the primary reason for the team's surprisingly strong start.

title: New Doubts on Enron's India Investment
description: The fate of the single largest foreign investment in India, the $2.9 billion Dabhol Power project, has been thrown into new uncertainty by the financial meltdown and pending takeover of its majority owner, the Enron Corporation of the United States.

title: Court Ruling In Arms Case Frees Menem In Argentina
description: Former President Carlos Sal Menem was released from house arrest today after the Supreme Court ruled that prosecutors had failed to prove that he and his former brother-in-law were involved in a conspiracy to smuggle arms to Croatia and Ecuador between 1991 and 1995.

title: Putting Name to Bush Justice Dept.: Kennedy
description: President Bush reached out to the nation's most prominent Democratic political family today in a ceremony to name the Justice Department headquarters in honor of Robert F. Kennedy, who has become an unlikely hero to the current administration.

title: A Collaboration Reveling in Textures
description: Emmanuel Ax and Yefim Bronfman, pianists

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: To Untangle the Mideast Knot
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALKER, LOUIS
description: WALKER-Louis. In Bidderford, ME. On November 17, 2001. Age 89. Of Hobe Sound, FL and Kennebunkport, ME. Graduate of Yale University Class of 1936. WW II veteran. Former investment banker with G.H. Walker & Company, founded by his father, George Herbert Walker, donor of the Walker Cup in golf. He served on the vestries of St. Ann's Church of Kennebunkport and Christ Memorial Chapel of Hobe Sound. Survived by his wife, Grace Walker, a son, James Walker, and daughters Suzanne W. Robinson, Elizabeth W. Field, and Dorothy W. Stapleton, eight grandchildren and two great grandchildren. A private family service was held in Kennebunkport.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Ex-I.N.S. Inspector Charged with Fraud
description: A former immigration inspector, who had already served time in jail for extortion, was arrested in Queens yesterday on charges that he swindled Chinese immigrants out of more than $575,000 by promising work visas for their relatives and friends in China. Federal agents arrested the man, Tin Yat Chin, who had been fired from his job with the Immigration and Naturalization Service in 1993, early yesterday morning at his home in Flushing. He was ordered held without bail at a court appearance before Magistrate Judge Robert M. Levy of Federal District Court. Mr. Chin, 43, was charged with an elaborate ruse in which federal agents said he falsely claimed to be an I.N.S. lawyer with experience on the staff of the United States consulate in China. Operating out of an office in Bay Ridge, he collected cash payments on the promise of visas and jobs for people in China, according to the complaint filed yesterday. Mr. Chin's lawyer did not respond to a phone message yesterday. Thomas J. Lueck(NYT)

title: Outpouring for Sept. 11 Groups Means Less for Food Banks
description: It has become a Thanksgiving tradition among the poor to come to the soup kitchen at Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church here for free turkeys to take home to their families.

title: A Police Force Rebuffs F.B.I. On Querying Mideast Men
description: The Portland, Ore., police will not cooperate with the Federal Bureau of Investigation in its efforts to interview 5,000 young Middle Eastern men nationwide because such questioning violates state law, the department's acting police chief, Andrew Kirkland, said yesterday.

title: Medieval Times for a Traveler Far From King Arthur's Court
description: The funniest scene in the innocuous new Martin Lawrence comedy ''Black Knight'' reworks a surefire formula that has perked up dozens of otherwise routine comedies since the birth of rock 'n' roll: a pied piper of hip brings funky rhythm to the squares who spring to their feet, unable to resist the call of the wild. The messenger of the big beat in this case is a disgruntled theme park employee, Jamal Walker (Mr. Lawrence), who toils grumpily at Medieval World, a dilapidated outdoor fantasy kingdom rapidly heading for the junk heap.

title: In Any Language, Suzuki Is the League's Best
description: The first time Ichiro Suzuki reached second base in a game against the Yankees this year, he turned to Alfonso Soriano and asked in Spanish, ''Qu pasa?'' The next time he reached second, Suzuki spoke English to ask Soriano, ''What's easier, Japanese or English?''

title: To Untangle the Mideast Knot
description: To the Editor:

title: Weather Conditions Force Cancellations
description: Experiencing the warmest November in Colorado in more than 20 years, race organizers decided yesterday to cancel the men's World Cup downhill and super-G races scheduled for Dec. 1 and 2 in Beaver Creek.

title: Composer and Conductor With a Common Interest
description: The Cincinnati Symphony on Saturday night brought us two young men listening to the music of others. Carl Orff was scarcely 18 when his ''Dancing Fauns'' was written. Its floating harmonic systems and pastel orchestra are mirror reflections of Debussy, who in 1913 was very much alive. The transfers between model and artifact are gracefully done, and what Orff has added is new layers of rhythmic and metric complexity, all tending to stir this music from its otherwise agreeable placidity.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Pager Maker Accused In Patent Suit
description: A Virginia holding company has filed a lawsuit against Research in Motion Ltd., the Canadian maker of the tiny Blackberry e-mail pagers, for infringing on patents related to wireless communications used for e-mail. NTP Inc., of Arlington, Va., said it was the sole licensee of eight patents issued since 1995 for ''a wireless mobile e-mail unit and the infrastructure necessary in the e-mail system to update the user's e-mail messages.'' Thomas J. Campana Jr., Michael P. Ponschke and Gary F. Thelen, the Illinois inventors who say they created the patented technology, set up NTP Inc. to protect the patents. The lawsuit was filed earlier this month in federal district court in Richmond, Va. Telephone calls to Research in Motion, whose shares fell $1.45, or 6.1 percent, to $22.34, were not returned.

title: WELLPOINT TO PURCHASE CAREFIRST IN $1.3 BILLION DEAL
description: WellPoint Health Networks Inc., the parent of Blue Cross of California, agreed to acquire CareFirst BlueCross BlueShield for $1.3 billion in cash and stock to add 3.1 million customers in Maryland, Delaware, Washington and Northern Virginia. WellPoint will pay $450 million in cash and $850 million in stock, a spokesman said. CareFirst, a nonprofit company, needs approval from regulators to convert to a for-profit company before the purchase can be completed. CareFirst had revenue of $3.1 billion in the nine months ended Sept. 30.

title: Putting the Chalk In the Right Hands
description: MANY states hand out a teacher's license to any graduate of an education college approved by the National Council for the Accreditation of Teacher Education, a consortium of education colleges, teachers' unions and other established public education groups.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Rare Praise On Chechnya
description: A United Nations official praised Russia for its handling of refugees who have fled fighting in the separatist region of Chechnya. ''There is not much that needs to be improved,'' said John McCallin, the representative of the United Nations refugee agency in Russia. But Ruslan Aushev, president of Ingushetia, a republic next to Chechnya that has taken in most of the nearly 300,000 refugees, said camps for them are unprepared for winter and full of disease. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: The New York Times's N.F.L. Computer Ranking
description: The New York Times's computer football ranking is based on an analysis of each team's scores with emphasis on three factors: who won, by what margin and against what quality of opposition. The quality of an opponent is determined by examining the opponent's record against other teams.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YARIN, BARBARA
description: YARIN-Barbara. Of Bronxville, New York, passed away November 19, after a long illness. Beloved & devoted wife of the late Murray, loving and cherished mother of Susan, Daniel (Louise). Adoring and much loved sister of Howard (Helen) Glick, sister-in-law (Cynthia and Jack, Marvin & Susan Yarin). Cherished aunt, great-aunt and friend. She was an unforgettable person who touched the lives of many with love and laughter. Services, Wednesday, November 21, at 10 AM, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad St. Mount Vernon, NY. The family would appreciate contributions in her memory to: Cancer Care, or Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation both in NYC, or to the charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LYON, ANDY LOGAN
description: LYON-Andy Logan. November 21, 2000. Whose incisive coverage of New York City politics inspired over a generation of New Yorker magazine readers. A revered colleague to the ''kids down at City Hall,'' loved by family and friends. She is missed. Brooks, Jon, and Emily

title: Money Raised for Private Equity Fund
description: MTS Health Partners L.P., a New York merchant bank firm, said yesterday that it had raised $110 million for its first private equity fund, which will focus its investments on the health care industry.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Production Declines
description: Industrial production in the 12-nation euro zone declined 0.5 percent in September from the level reached in the previous month, the European statistical office Eurostat said. This followed a 1.5 percent increase in August. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEVLIN, JEAN
description: SHEVLIN-Jean, 95. Died on November 19, 2001. Wife of the late John F. Shevlin. Beloved mother of Rosemary Weiss. Devoted grandmother of Alison, loving mother-in-law of Marc and dear sister of Joseph Solman. Memorial service, Sunday, December 9, 2 p.m. at The Riverside, 76th Street & Amsterdam Ave. Donations may be made to the Actor's Fund Nursing Home, 155-75 West Hudson Ave, Englewood, NJ 07631.

title: Afghan Factions to Meet And Discuss Interim Rule
description: Representatives of the Northern Alliance and several other Afghan factions will meet in Berlin next week to try to set up an interim administration for Afghanistan, the special United Nations envoy, Lakhdar Brahimi, said today. A similar announcement was made in Kabul.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday showing the extent of airline service changes since Sept. 11 misstated the current number of scheduled nonstop flights by major airlines between Denver and Portland, Ore. It is 12 a day, down 50 percent since Sept. 11; the new number is not 16.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRADDY, JAMES J.
description: DRADDY-James J. We mourn the passing of our retired Board Chairman, the affable and supremely dedicated Jim Draddy. How he reveled in the ''Miracle of Daytop'' (his words) as once hopeless youngsters emerged as sparkling, highly motivated young men and women. His presence in our lives was a special blessing and his dedication to the cause of recovery unfaltering. Our prayerful support to his beloved Pat and his Family. (Msgr.) William B. O'Brien, Pres. Daytop Village, Inc.

title: Devils See the Positive In a Tie With the Flyers
description: After tonight's game, Coach Larry Robinson gushed over the Devils' effort. The players agreed, seeing a potential turning point in their struggles.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Winnie Mandela To Be Tried
description: Winnie Madikizela-Mandela will stand trial on fraud and theft charges next year, a judge decided. Mrs. Madikizela-Mandela, a prominent political leader and the former wife of Nelson Mandela, has been charged with defrauding a bank of more than $103,000. Officials say that Mrs. Madikizela-Mandela, who is president of the African National Congress's Women's League, was involved in a scheme in which a codefendant obtained personal loans for fictitious Women's League employees by using her name and letterhead to support the fraudulent loan applications. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Billy Vessels Is Dead at 70; Won the Heisman Trophy
description: Billy Vessels, the University of Oklahoma running back who won the 1952 Heisman Trophy in an era when Sooner teams coached by Bud Wilkinson dominated college football, died last Saturday at his home in Coral Gables, Fla. He was 70.

title: A Wunderkind Comes To Grief in Germany
description: Michael Steiner, the flamboyant and talented foreign policy adviser to the German chancellor, Gerhard Schrder, lost his job today in the backwash of an airport temper tantrum aimed at German soldiers.

title: Softbank of Japan Marks Down Portfolio
description: The once high-flying Internet conglomerate Softbank said today that it had marked down the value of its sprawling portfolio of major investments in other Internet companies by nearly 51 billion yen ($414 million), resulting in a loss of 54.3 billion yen ($441 million) in the six months ended Sept. 30.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Warning On North's Germ Supplies
description: North Korea has stockpiled at least 2,500 tons of material for use in biological and chemical warfare and perhaps twice that amount, said South Korea's defense minister, Kim Dong Shin. He said the material included anthrax bacteria and the smallpox virus and that the North had the means to mass-produce biological and chemical weapons. The smallpox disease has been wiped out worldwide and the only known stocks of the virus are in the United States and Russia. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: The Hunt for a Truly Grand Turkey, One That Nature Built
description: TOMORROW you'll probably be joining millions of Americans in a true Thanksgiving tradition: slathering giblet gravy over those dry, tasteless slices of turkey and tucking into the really good stuff -- the dressing and sweet potatoes, the cranberry relish and pumpkin pie.

title: Sprewell Is Answer For Knicks' Road Woes
description: It was not supposed to be about Latrell Sprewell tonight. Four years removed from his infamous choking incident as a member of the Golden State Warriors, Sprewell has refashioned himself and his image so nicely that an appearance at the Warriors' Arena in Oakland is no longer a big deal.

title: In 3-Sided Battle for Northern Town, 2 Sides at Least May Be Talking
description: Leaders of the Taliban and the Northern Alliance were poised to strike a deal today at the expense of thousands of foreign Taliban fighters trapped in Kunduz, in northeast Afghanistan.

title: Accounts
description: * Foote, Cone & Belding, part of the FCB Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, was named to handle two accounts with combined billings estimated at $64 million. The Foote, Cone office in Madrid will handle the Spanish airline Iberia, which had been handled by Tiempo BBDO, Madrid, part of the BBDO Worldwide division of the Omnicom Group. The Foote, Cone office in London will handle the consolidated cereal account of Weetabix, in Kettering, England, which had divided its brands, like Weetabix and Ready Brek, among that agency and two others, Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO, in London, also part of BBDO Worldwide, and the London office of Lowe Lintas & Partners Worldwide, part of Interpublic's Partnership division.

title: Two Spies Test Friendship As the Cold War Thaws
description: Many of Tony Scott's movies -- ''Top Gun,'' ''Crimson Tide,'' ''Enemy of the State,'' and now ''Spy Game'' -- are like gadgets in the Sharper Image catalog: sleek, expensive handsome gizmos of doubtful utility. Mr. Scott has an eye for sharp images and cool stuff, and his new movie has the pointless, thrilling kineticism of a sports car commercial. (Perhaps the director has not been recruited by BWM to make one of its high-concept Internet promo films because the project would be, in his case, redundant.)

title: A Touch of Wild Mushroom for the Bird
description: For many cooks at Thanksgiving, making a nice, smooth gravy is the most challenging part of the meal. This year, there's help from a line of French sauce enhancers, Aromont EZ Sauce. The thick, viscous bases are turned into sauces by diluting with warm water and some cream or butter. Turkey roasting juices or other cooking liquids can be used instead. They have more complex flavoring than a typical sauce base, and are made without preservatives. The wild mushroom, red wine or tarragon and herb would be best with turkey. There's also a Cognac sauce for lobster, a white wine sauce, a sherry vinegar and thyme sauce, and a Grand Marnier sauce. Each 2-to-3-ounce package makes up to 12 portions, depending on flavor. They're $4.79 at Fairway markets, $5.99 at Eli's Manhattan and the Vinegar Factory, and $7.45 at the new Garden of Eden, 180 Montague Street (Clinton Street) in Brooklyn Heights, and at the store at 7 East 14th Street.

title: Antics From Silent Movies Accompanied by Bluegrass
description: When it comes to cathartic experiences for young and old, look no farther than the New Victory Theater, where instructions for cheering the good guy -- that's Buster Keaton -- and booing and hissing the villains he encounters in his silent film comedies are accompanied by the final exhortations: ''Enjoy yourselves. Go nuts. Go wild.''

title: U.S. READY TO SEND ADDITIONAL TROOPS TO HUNT BIN LADEN
description: The United States is prepared to send additional ground forces to capture or kill Osama bin Laden if intelligence pinpoints his location, now believed to be somewhere in a lawless corridor of former Taliban territory between Kandahar and Jalalabad in southeastern Afghanistan, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Stabilizing Afghanistan
description: The forces opposed to the Taliban have made more progress on the battlefield than in filling the political vacuum left by the Taliban's retreat. To avert a new round of internal fighting among Taliban foes, the United States needs to act swiftly to promote a broad-based interim government in Kabul, and to help introduce foreign troops to provide security in the capital and elsewhere. It is encouraging that the anti-Taliban Northern Alliance has agreed to meet in Germany with other Afghan factions to discuss the security and political issues. The United States and the rest of those supporting the overthrow of the Taliban must make sure the meeting, in Berlin, is a success.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NICKERSON, CLARKE
description: NICKERSON-Clarke. Died on November 17 of pneumonia. Born to John and Elizabeth Nickerson in New York City 83 years ago, he was an avid sailor with the Noroton Yacht Club in Darien, CT. After graduating from St. Paul's School in 1937 & Hartford's Trinity College in 1941, he joined the U.S. Army and was assigned to the New Caledonia Island Command. After the war, he worked in the securities business with his father at John Nickerson & Co., before beginning his career as a stockbroker with Harris Upham. For the past 20 years, after moving from Darien to his harborside home in South Norwalk, he continued to trade stocks for Fechtor, Detwiler & Co. in New Canaan, CT. A memorial service will be held at 1:30 P.M. December 8, at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, 1848 Post Road, Darien. A reception to follow in South Norwalk.

title: Federal Control Will Be Sought For Protection of Nuclear Plants
description: The federal government should assume responsibility for protecting the country's nuclear power plants to safeguard them from terrorist attack, a group of Democratic members of Congress from New York said today.

title: THE BOSS; Vacations as Early Education
description: My dad is English. After the Second World War, he moved to Canada and joined the Canadian Air Force. He met Mom in Acapulco on one of his flights and fell in love, but she said she would marry him only on the condition that he left the air force.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINCHYTZ, MINDEE
description: LINCHYTZ-Mindee. The members of Shelter Rock Tennis Club record with great sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Mindee Linchytz. She was a friend to all and will be sorely missed. Our sincere condolences to her husband and to her entire family.

title: Fuzzy Creatures vs. Green Ogre; 'Monsters, Inc.' and 'Shrek' Are Likely Foes for New Oscar
description: If ''Shrek'' wins the newly created Oscar for best animated feature film in March, the sole person who will stride to the stage to pick it up will be Aron Warner, who runs Pacific Data Images, DreamWorks's computer animation division.

title: The Women, Veils Shed, Demonstrate
description: Several hundred Afghan women demonstrated for women's rights here today for the first time in at least five years, demanding peace for the country, education for their children and power for themselves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLE, JAMES M.
description: COLE-James M. Of Scotch Plains, New Jersey, on November 20, 2001. Beloved husband of Deborah Langer Cole; loving son of Helen M. Cole and the late Robert A. Cole; devoted brother of Alexander Cole. Services will be held on Friday, November 23rd at the Higgins & Bonner Echo Lake Funeral Home, 582 Springfield Ave., Westfield, NJ at 10:00 AM. Interment Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Iselin, NJ. Please omit flowers.

title: In Network News Battle, ABC Is Gaining Ground
description: With a third consecutive weekly victory in the ratings competition among network newscasts, ABC's ''World News Tonight'' may be ending an extended period of dominance by NBC's ''Nightly News.''

title: To Untangle the Mideast Knot
description: To the Editor:

title: Mix Policing Styles?
description: To the Editor:

title: Places of Memory
description: To the Editor:

title: President Leaving Purchase College of SUNY
description: BILL LACY, left, president of Purchase College of the State University of New York since 1993, said yesterday that he would step down from Purchase's helm at the end of December. The SUNY board of trustees is expected to approve THOMAS J. SCHWARZ, a lawyer who was acting president of Hamilton College in 1999, as interim president at its meeting Monday.

title: After Afghanistan
description: The seven-week military campaign in Afghanistan has given the world a stark view of a new American doctrine to make war on the sources of terrorism in the world. But with the defeat of the Taliban perhaps only days away and the hunt for Osama bin Laden intensifying, the force of the American destruction of Afghan targets has sent an unambiguous warning far beyond the war theater to a number of nations that continue to provide bases and training to terrorist groups. The warning is: this could happen to you.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Governor Divorces
description: Gov. Parris N. Glendening and his wife, Frances Hughes Glendening, have divorced after nearly 25 years of marriage. In a statement, Mr. Glendening, who is 59, said, ''We wish each other well and each remain dedicated to careers in public service.'' Mr. Glendening, a Democrat, has been separated from his 50-year-old wife, a lawyer for the Federal Election Commission, since July 2000. In August, The Washington Post reported that the governor was involved with one of his aides. Gary Gately (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HAAS, RHODA WILLNER
description: HAAS-Rhoda Willner. After 11 years, you are always in our thoughts. Stella, Abbie, Jane, and Jay

title: Israel Denies Groups' Charge That It Is Torturing Detainees
description: Appearing before a United Nations committee, Israel defended itself today against accusations by Amnesty International and other groups that it uses methods amounting to torture during the interrogation of Palestinian detainees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDWEBER, DOROTHY FISHER
description: GOLDWEBER-Dorothy Fisher. Beloved wife of Max, devoted mother of Elyse and Ann, adoring grandmother of Gabrielle, and loving mother-in-law of David and Terry, died November 19, 2001 at the age of 81. A long time resident of Westbury, Long Island, Dorothy grew up in Newport News, VA, and was the daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Israel K. Fisher. She and Max were married for 56 years. She will be remembered for her style, grace, and devotion to her family. Funeral services will be held today at noon at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills. Interment to follow at Cedar Park Cemetery in Oradell, NJ. Donations to the Dorothy Goldweber Memorial Fund may be sent to Temple Sholom, 676 Brookside Court, Westbury, NY 11590.

title: Conspiracy Trial Questions Honesty of Ex-Sotheby's Chief
description: Diana D. Brooks, the former Sotheby's chief executive who has testified that her longtime boss, A. Alfred Taubman, hatched a lucrative price-fixing plot with his counterpart at Christie's auction house, admitted under cross-examination yesterday that she had repeatedly lied to conceal her own willing role.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Possible Compromise On Recovery Plan
description: Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill said he was encouraged by a compromise economic recovery package by a bipartisan group of senators. His comments suggested hope for an end to an impasse on the issue in Congress. The plan calls for $75 billion in tax cuts and new spending in the coming year, including tax breaks for businesses to invest in new equipment and extension of unemployment benefits. Richard W. Stevenson (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Sept. 11 Aid for Small Companies
description: A business and civic group awarded $650,000 in grants and other aid to 14 small businesses in Lower Manhattan yesterday. The aid is part of a $7 million program to assist retailers and manufacturers harmed by the attack on the World Trade Center. The Lower Manhattan Small Business and Workforce Retention Project offers grants of up to $25,000, low-interest loans of up to $100,000 and payments to subsidize up to 50 percent of some employees' wages. Eligible businesses are those south of Canal Street with no more than 50 employees. The project's sponsors include the Alliance for Downtown New York, Seedco, Asian Americans for Equality and the Henry Street Settlement.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Cement Company Chief Resigns
description: Thomas Schmidheiny is stepping down after two decades as chief executive of the cement maker Holcim Ltd. Mr. Schmidheiny, 56, who controls most of Holcim's voting rights, will remain chairman, and named Markus Akermann to succeed him. Holcim said its profit for the year would drop 10 percent. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMPSON, ELIZABETH H.
description: THOMPSON-Elizabeth H. Age: 84 of Bridgehampton, NY on Tuesday, November 20. Wife of Bogart F. Thompson. Mother of Pamela H. Thompson of London, Elizabeth T. Burgess of Verona, NJ, Anne T. Seifert of Camp Hill, PA, Benjamin F. Thompson of Williamsburg, MA, and Sarah B. Thompson of Bridgehampton, NY. Also survived by seven grandchildren. Burial will be private. A memorial service will be held at St. Ann's Episcopal Church, Bridgehampton on Saturday, November 24th at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Bridgehampton Historical Society, Box 977, Bridgehampton, NY 11932 or Animal Rescue Fund of The Hamptons Inc., Box 901, Wainscott, NY 11975.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: UNITED TECHNOLOGIES CORP., Hartford, the military contractor, said it would design and build a testing cell for repaired jet engines at a maintenance center near Hong Kong run by a joint venture of China Southern Airlines and MTU Aero Engines. The deal is valued at $13 million.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''You don't decide need based on an arbitrary line. A line makes it easy for administration, but not for the people who have to suffer through the pain every day.''

title: Church's Male Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Microsoft Aims To Settle Suits By Equipping 12,500 Schools
description: Microsoft filed a proposal in federal court yesterday that could remove another of its legal headaches: more than 100 class-action antitrust suits contending that it overcharged consumers. The proposed deal is an innovative approach because the proceeds would not go to the customers who say they were overcharged but to more than 12,500 schools in low-income neighborhoods around the country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUCCHESI, ALIBRAND
description: LUCCHESI-Alibrand. November 19, 2001. Beloved husband of Rose. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St. Friday, November 23, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, November 24, 10AM Our Lady of Peace Church, 237 East 62 Street, New York City. Contributions in his memory may be made to the American Cancer Society or the Masonic Brotherhood Fund.

title: Reviews of Current Releases
description: For all New York Times film reviews since 1996, go to the Film Archive .

title: Target Net Falls on Accounting Change
description: Net income at the Target Corporation fell in the third quarter because of an accounting change, the company said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about the thriving online travel business misstated the title of Jim Young, an executive at Continental Airlines, who commented on his company's Internet strategy. He is managing director for distribution planning, not vice president for distribution strategy.

title: Bringing Flavor to the Bird (Until It Brings Its Own)
description: WHILE some breeders work to restore true flavor to the American turkey, this year most people will have to make do with a standard commercial bird. Here are ways to add flavor.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Greece: Bank Plans To Buy Rival
description: The National Bank of Greece, the country's leading bank, announced plans to buy Alpha Bank for about 4.1 billion euros ($3.6 billion) in stock. With combined assets of almost 80 billion euros, the acquisition may make National large enough to move into new markets, like Turkey, and attract partners as rising competition at home and a slumping stock market damps its outlook for profit.

title: A Nation Challenged
description: The Anthrax Threat

title: Strahan Criticizes Officials
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 20 — After the Giants' 28-16 beating from the Minnesota Vikings on Monday night, Michael Strahan was livid. The National Football League's sack leader said the officials had let the Vikings mug him all night.

title: TOLL FROM ATTACK AT TRADE CENTER IS DOWN SHARPLY
description: The official count of the dead and missing in the attack on the World Trade Center has fallen sharply in the last few weeks to below 3,900, a total that is nearly 3,000 fewer than the number city officials, in the first weeks after the towers fell, feared had perished.

title: Trade Deficit Posts Decline That Is Largest on Record
description: The trade deficit shrank by a record amount in September after the terrorist attacks disrupted air travel, slowed oil imports and drove up payments from overseas insurance companies, the government reported today.

title: Greengrocers to Pay $315,000 in Back Wages
description: Facing charges that they paid workers less than $3 an hour, three greengrocers in Lower Manhattan agreed yesterday to pay $315,000 in back wages to 31 workers to settle a lawsuit brought by State Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHREIBER, EVELYN MORGEN STERN
description: SCHREIBER - Evelyn Morgen stern, November 16, 2001. Graduate of Brooklyn College, Valedictorian and Propellea Society, with MA. in Geology. National President of Amit Women 1973-1975. Wife of the late Louis J., mother of Saul, Phoenix, AZ; Honey Levinson, West Hempstead; Avram, New York; Simeon, Bethesda, MD. Grandmother of eleven and great grandmother of twenty-one. She was unique in her devotion to her family, faith, Israel and her people. She changed the lives of all who knew her and their world is diminished by her loss. Contributions in her memory may be made to Amit Women, 817 Broadway, New York, NY 10003.

title: Vitamin Makers Fined Record $755.1 Million in Price-Fixing Case
description: BRUSSELS -- The European Commission fined eight chemical and pharmaceutical companies a record-setting 855.22 million euros ($755.1 million) in a vitamin price-fixing scheme that lasted nearly a decade.

title: Virgin Atlantic jumps on a supposed gaffe by British Airways, tweaking its rival one more time.
description: SIR RICHARD BRANSON, the chairman of Virgin Atlantic Airways, has never been shy about seizing an opportunity created by a rival's gaffe.

title: Looking Inward For Outward Expression
description: Ewa Podles, contralto, and Garrick Ohlsson, pianist

title: Liberties; Blessings And Bombings
description: In ''The Crack-Up,'' F. Scott Fitzgerald wrote that ''The test of a first-rate intelligence is the ability to hold two opposed ideas in the mind at the same time and still retain the ability to function.''

title: Foundation Starts $50 Million Fund for Arts Groups Hurt by Terrorism
description: The Andrew W. Mellon Foundation announced yesterday that it was establishing a $50 million fund for museums, theaters, dance companies and other cultural institutions affected by repercussions from the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, as well as for public parks where people congregated after the disaster.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, VICTORIA
description: ROSENTHAL-Victoria. On November 18, 2001 at age 83. Her husband, M.L. Rosenthal, a writer & poetry critic, predeceased her in 1996. Survived by her son Alan Rosenthal, daughter Laura McGarry, brother Julius Hemmelstein, grandchildren Daniel Rosenthal, Margaret McGarry, James McGarry and Julia McGarry. She was a social worker who received her B.A. and M.S.W. from the University of Chicago. She was a psychiatric social worker at the Rockland County Community Mental Health Center. Memorial service Sunday, Decembr 9th, 4PM, Riverside Chapel, 76 Street & Amsterdam Ave, New York City.

title: More Access but Less Security for Journalists
description: As the Taliban's power melted away in much of Afghanistan last week, hundreds of journalists who had been confined to territory of the Northern Alliance spread out into areas controlled by local warlords or by no one.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Ex-Leader May Still Face Death
description: Former President Joseph Estrada lost a bid to evade a capital charge of plunder when the Supreme Court rejected his claim that the law is unconstitutional. Mr. Estrada is accused of plundering nearly $80 million in his two years in office, which ended when he was ousted in January. He is also being tried on lesser charges of perjury and illegal use of an alias. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Bumps Along Their Road Are Unsettling for the Nets
description: The Nets sat on the bus after their loss to the Denver Nuggets on Monday night, weighed down by a feeling of failure. They felt the same way boarding the same bus back to the Pepsi Center today for what would be a determined 90-minute practice.

title: Students Get Back to Routine, but Sept. 11 Fears Linger
description: For many days after she returned to class, Kelly Chan, a sophomore at Stuyvesant High School in Manhattan, could not help but be distracted by the horrific scene she witnessed on Sept. 11.

title: Lives, Lived in America
description: To the Editor:

title: Safer Working Conditions
description: The contractors cleaning up the World Trade Center site signed an agreement yesterday intended to limit the number of injuries at the site. Under the agreement with the city and federal government, the contracts have committed to honoring a detailed safety plan that will increase oversight of the work.

title: In Debate Over Contraction, Devil Is Also in the Details
description: Even though baseball's club owners and players do not agree on contraction itself, lawyers for the two sides have proceeded this week with a discussion of the effects of the proposed elimination of two teams. Based on the owners' proposal for a dispersal draft of the affected players, the two sides are not very likely to agree on the effects either.

title: Pennsylvania Abandons Plan To Privatize School Offices
description: The governor of Pennsylvania last night withdrew a highly controversial proposal to hire a private company to manage the Philadelphia public school system, calling off what would have been the largest such arrangement in the history of American education.

title: Nouveau Naps, And Beaujolais Gets Serious
description: NOT too many years ago, Beaujolais nouveau arrived in New York with all the subtlety of Barnum & Bailey's elephants. Marching bands, parachutists, marathon runners and dancing girls all joined in the hoopla attendant upon the arrival of the so-called first bottle.

title: Ethan Allen Import Plan
description: Ethan Allen Interiors Inc., the furniture maker and retailer, said that several Philippine companies would make some of its furniture. The furniture, made from Ethan Allen designs, will begin arriving in stores in spring 2002. Ethan Allen, which has more than 300 stores, has 18 manufacturing plants and 3 sawmills in the United States. Its shares rose 47 cents, to $38.46.

title: Demonstrators Find That the Web Is a Powerful Tool
description: It was just before Jodie Hemerda set off a family feud by announcing her opposition to the United States bombing in Afghanistan that she began scouring the Internet for others who shared her views.

title: U.S. and 21 Other Nations Vow To Spend Billions on Afghanistan
description: The United States and 21 other nations agreed today to spend billions of dollars to reconstruct Afghanistan after the war, as officials said they were prepared to pay for ''high-impact'' farm, road and school-building projects to try to win over the Afghan people as soon as the Taliban are defeated.

title: U.S. Officials Explain Interview Plans at a Community Forum
description: The Justice Department's top civil rights official tonight defended the department's plans to interview 5,000 young Middle Eastern men, saying the government needed to cast a broad net to obtain sufficient information.

title: Increased Spending on Drugs Is Linked to More Advertising
description: The 50 most-advertised prescription medicines contributed significantly last year to the increase in the nation's spending on drugs, according to a study.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a new Internal Revenue Service policy that lets charities distribute money and benefits without first proving that families are in financial need as a result of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks misspelled the surname of the I.R.S. commissioner, who announced it. He is Charles O. Rossotti, not Rossetti.

title: Jerry Jerome, 89, Tenor Saxophonist of Big Band Era and Beyond
description: Jerry Jerome, a tenor saxophone player who was a featured soloist with the Glenn Miller, Benny Goodman, Red Norvo and Artie Shaw orchestras in the Big Band era, died at his home here on Saturday. He was 89.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Agreement WitH I.M.F.
description: The International Monetary Fund said it had reached agreement with Indonesia on economic reforms that must be carried out in return for the release of the next $360 million allotment of a $5 billion economic support program. The reforms, to be carried out in the next year, include reducing public debt and improving the justice and banking systems. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Portuguese TV Venture Stalls
description: The chairman of PT Multimedia, the Portugal Telecom unit that began the first interactive TV service using Microsoft software, said the company would delay expansion of the service because of technical glitches. PT Multimedia's TV Cabo is the world's first cable network to provide interactive television over a broadband network using the Microsoft system. Just two weeks ago, Charter Communications, a St. Louis-based cable television company, said it would offer products based on the Microsoft software to as many as a million of its customers for the next seven years. Jamie Hoelscher, a Microsoft spokeswoman, said that since the company was still testing the TV system, the problems in Portugal would have no effect on its plans. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Fatal Spray of Stray Bullets Echoes Violent Past in Bronx
description: Long ago, the corner of Rosewood Street and White Plains Road in the Bronx succumbed to the kind of low-level drug dealing that defines life on so many street corners in so many neighborhoods around New York City. But it was still, neighbors thought, relatively safe.

title: At a No-Frills Pizza Spot, a Perfectionist's Pie
description: LIKE most Americans, I know what I will be eating tomorrow. It is the day after Thanksgiving I am thinking about. My postfeast mantra is, ''No more turkey, no more turkey.'' No sandwiches, no stuffing, no cranberry sauce -- well, maybe cranberry sauce. What I want is pizza.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: CurtCo Robb Media, Malibu, Calif., owner of Robb Report magazine, named four employees to posts at its new New York operations. Valerie Allen was named director for advertising for wines and spirits for Robb Report; she had most recently been an account manager at Women's Sports & Fitness, New York, which closed. Heather Cohane was named director for advertising for New York real estate for Robb Report and The Robb Collection; she had been executive vice president for Gotham and Hamptons magazines, New York, published by Hamptons Media. Lisa A. Fischer was named director for advertising for jewelry for Robb Report; she had been United States sales manager at Couture International Jeweler, New York, published by the Bill Communications unit of VNU Business Media, part of VNU. William Gibbons was named marketing director for Robb Report and The Robb Collection; he had been vice president at Right Angle Research, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEAVY, EDWARD T.
description: LEAVY-Edward T. On November 21, 1979. In loving memory. Remembered always. Your Children and Grandchildren

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Auto Parts Maker Plans Cuts
description: Hurt by rising costs and falling demand, NSK Ltd., an auto parts maker, will close or sell four factories in Europe and one in Japan. Six of NSK's nine European factories are in Britain. The company, which expects to lose 7.5 billion yen ($61 million) this fiscal year, will cut 2,500 jobs in the next 18 months. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: F.D.A. CLEARS JOHNSON & JOHNSON BIRTH CONTROL PATCH
description: The drug maker Johnson & Johnson, based in New Brunswick, N.J., has received approval from the Food and Drug Administration for a new birth-control patch slightly larger than a postage stamp. The patch, called Ortho Evra, can be used as an alternative to contraceptive pills. It will be sold by prescription in packs of one-month supplies. The patch is applied to the abdomen or buttocks each week for three weeks, and no patch is worn for the fourth. In studies, the patch was as successful in preventing pregnancy as oral contraceptives.

title: A World Without SAT's
description: To the Editor:

title: In This Company's Struggle, God Has Many Proxies
description: At the ServiceMaster Corporation, the forces of God and Mammon are in a tug of war.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALOMON, ADELINE (ARON)
description: SALOMON - Adeline (Aron). March 2, 1902-November 20, 2001 in Boston, MA. Wife of the late Carl Salomon, beloved mother of Marion Levine (Bernard), Richard Salomon (Nancy). Cherished Omi to Jill Hyde, Heidi, Arthur, the late Carl Rosen, Elizabeth Salomon, Noah Salomon. Great Omi to Alex, Ashley, Cameron and Dylan. Burial today in Sharon, MA. Contributions may be made to the Carl Rosen Fund, Leukemia-Lymphoma Society, 475 Park Ave. South, NY, NY 10016.

title: Enron's Growing Financial Crisis Raises Doubts About Merger Deal
description: Shares of Enron plunged 23 percent yesterday as expectations grew in the stock and bond markets that Dynegy would either back out of its deal to rescue the company or seek to renegotiate terms of their merger.

title: Accord May Be Near on Oil Production Cuts to Prop Up Prices
description: Russia remained the question mark in the standoff between OPEC and oil exporters outside the cartel after two of the largest nonmember exporters signaled today that an agreement was near to reduce output in hopes of propping up prices.

title: Women of Courage
description: To the Editor:

title: Artificial-Heart Patient Is Bleeding in the Brain
description: The first recipient of a self-contained artificial heart, who had a major stroke last week, has now had a small amount of bleeding in the same area of his brain, and doctors are concerned about his condition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRUHL, ANNE
description: STRUHL-Anne. Riverdale Jewish Center extends condolences to our member Bernard E. Struhl upon the loss of his mother. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi David Sable, President

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 10 about covenant marriage, a form of agreement that makes divorce harder, misstated a finding of a study of troubled marriages. It found that after five years, a third of the couples who stayed together described themselves as happy or very happy. It did not find that 33 percent to 45 percent of couples might reconcile if they were prevented from divorcing. The article also misspelled the surname of the author of ''Marriage in Men's Lives,'' who is helping to conduct a different study on covenant marriages. He is Steven L. Nock, not Knock.

title: Continuing Education Jumps at CUNY
description: A record 204,682 students enrolled in adult and continuing education courses at the City University of New York in the last academic year, up from 181,248 the previous year, CUNY announced this week. The program has expanded substantially in recent years. In 1993, only 107,684 students were enrolled in CUNY's adult and continuing education courses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EHRENBERG, RAYMOND WINTERS
description: EHRENBERG-Raymond Winters, 95. Of East Brunswick, NJ (formerly of Larchmont) on November 20, 2001. Husband of the late Helen Stolwein. Father of Richard W. and Frances Ehrenberg-Hyman. Grandfather of four. Funeral on Wednesday at 11:45 A.M. Mount Sinai Memorial Chapels, East Brunswick, New Jersey.

title: Help the Iraqi's Take Their Country Back
description: Watching the collapse of the Taliban and the scenes of Kabul being taken by troops of the Northern Alliance resurrects painful memories of what might have been, but wasn't, in the Persian Gulf war fought against Saddam Hussein.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Incompetent and Maddeningly Oblivious
description: When Becky Boyd was a sales representative for Hewlett-Packard, she stopped bringing her boss along on customer calls because, she said, ''he was so stupid he'd actually jeopardize sales.''

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: High Court Reappointment
description: Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco announced his intent on Monday to reappoint James H. Coleman Jr., left, as a justice in State Supreme Court. The nomination of Mr. Coleman, 68, is subject to the approval of the State Senate. He serves until the mandatory retirement age of 70. A judge since 1973, Mr. Coleman was appointed to the state's highest court in 1994 by Gov. Christie Whitman and became the first black person to serve in that post. Mr. Coleman's current term expires on Dec. 16.

title: A 40-Foot Heron Returns, This Time With a Permit
description: The 40-foot-tall sculpture of a heron was art, its admirers said. It was an eyesore, its critics cried.

title: 22 Countries Pledge Aid for Afghanistan
description: The United States and 21 other nations agreed to spend billions of dollars to reconstruct Afghanistan after the war. Officials said they were prepared to pay for projects like farms, roads and schools to try to win over the Afghan people as soon as the Taliban are defeated. Some officials estimated that the costs of feeding, clothing and housing people and, ultimately, creating a modern society in Aghanistan would reach $10 billion.

title: We 'Feds' Are Dedicated
description: To the Editor:

title: What's In a Name?
description: Before deciding to change its name to Altria, Philip Morris considered "Consumarc" and "Marcade," both of which carried connotations of the consumer marketplace and brand names.

title: An Opera Company With a Story for Every Season
description: MOLTO AGITATO

title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Trevi Extradition Postponed
description: Lawyers for Gloria Trevi, the Mexican pop singer who fled to Brazil after being charged with sexual abuse in her homeland, have obtained an injunction indefinitely postponing her extradition. Ms. Trevi is nearly six months pregnant and has been held in a jail in Braslia for more than a year; local news media are reporting that the singer has been repeatedly raped by the police officers supervising her detention. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Boston Claims Detroit's Clark Off Waivers
description: Tony Clark, who led the Detroit Tigers in runs batted in this year with 75, was claimed off waivers by the Boston Red Sox yesterday.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Securities Firms Plan Online System
description: Microsoft, Merrill Lynch, Citigroup's Salomon Smith Barney and Thomson plan to automate the process of issuing securities over the Internet, the companies said. The companies formed a venture called I-Deal L.L.C. to standardize the way operations like raising capital and issuing stock are carried out. Terms of ownership were not disclosed.

title: Martha Argerich Cancels Concerts
description: Two concerts by the Argentine pianist Martha Argerich that were to be part of the ''Perspectives: Martha Argerich'' series at Carnegie Hall have been canceled, Carnegie has announced.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: AT&T Bid For Affiliate Advances
description: AT&T Wireless Services said it had won antitrust approval from the Federal Trade Commission to buy an affiliate, TeleCorp PCS. The company must still receive clearance for the deal from the Federal Communications Commission and it must be approved by TeleCorp shareholders, an AT&T Wireless spokesman said. AT&T Wireless agreed last month to buy the 77 percent of TeleCorp it did not already own for $4.6 billion to cut costs and add markets with 32 million potential customers.

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article on Monday about changes in the public profiles of politicians since Sept. 11 included an incomplete quotation from Tommy G. Thompson, secretary of health and human services, who has been dogged by a remark he made after a Florida man came down with anthrax. (A similar error occurred on Oct. 5 and was corrected in this space on Nov. 1.) According to a transcript from his office, Mr. Thompson said, "But I want to point out once again that this is an isolated case, and it's not contagious." Before being interrupted by a question, he also said, "There's no evidence of terrorism  at this ." He did not say: "It is an isolated case. There is no terrorism."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYNCH, MICHAEL F.
description: LYNCH-Michael F. Of New Hyde Park, New York, FDNY Ladder 4, heroically in the line of duty at WTC on September 11, 2001, 33 years old. Devoted husband and best friend of Denise (nee Bertrand). Loving father of Michael (three years), and Jack Ryan (nine months). Beloved son of Catherine (nee McGuire) and Daniel of Flushing, NY. Adored youngest brother of Kathleen, Bernadette, Mary, Rory, Barbara, Danny (NYPD), and Maureen. Wonderful caring uncle of Kerry, Katie, Michael, Marcelle, Julia, Liam, Christina, Johnny, Andrew, Danny, Nicholas, Olivia, Morgan, Hank, McKenzie, and Emily. Loyal brother-in-law of John, Joe, John I, Tom, Hank, Chris, Anne Marie, Paul and Brittini. Fond son-in-law of Joan. Dear nephew of Jimmy, Dolores, and Rose. Cherished cousin and friend to many. A Celebration of Life Mass will be held at Notre Dame R.C. Church, New Hyde Park, NY, 9:30 AM on November 24th. Memorial donations may be sent to Michael F. Lynch Memorial Fund, P.O. Box 279, New Hyde Park, NY 11040 (private) or Engine 54, Ladder 4, Battalion 9 Memorial Fund, 782 8th Avenue, New York, New York 10036 (public).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, OGDEN NORTHROP, JR.
description: LEWIS-Ogden Northrop, Jr. Suddenly on November 14, 2001, at age 22. Cherished son of Ogden and Susan Lewis, adored nephew of Margaret Patterson High and William Hall Lewis, III. Beloved by countless friends. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory to The Buckley School, 113 East 73 Street, New York, New York 10021, or Groton School, Box 991, Groton, Massachusetts 01450, would be greatly appreciated. Funeral service, Monday, November 26 at 2 PM. St. Thomas Church, 5th Avenue and 53rd Street, NY, NY.

title: Sports of The Times; Pray Devoutly And Then Hammer
description: THE sign in front of the steepled church read: ''Sunday Sermon: Does God Prefer Particular Sports Teams?'' A man passing by gives the sign a befuddled look.

title: World Briefing
description: AFRICA SOUTH AFRICA: WINNIE MANDELA TO BE TRIED Winnie Madikizela-Mandela will stand trial on fraud and theft charges next year, a judge decided. Mrs. Madikizela-Mandela, a prominent political leader and the former wife of Nelson Mandela, has been charged with defrauding a bank of more than $103,000. Officials say that Mrs. Madikizela- Mandela, who is president of the African National Congress's Women's League, was involved in a scheme in which a codefendant obtained personal loans for fictitious Women's League employees by using her name and letterhead to support the fraudulent loan applications. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: No Break On Holiday As Crews Clear Site
description: While the floats sail down Central Park West and New Yorkers gather around tables loaded with food tomorrow, workers at the disaster site in Lower Manhattan will be busy digging and sifting because, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday, the families of those killed in the collapse want it that way.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEILBRUNN, ROBERT H.
description: HEILBRUNN-Robert H. The volunteers and staff of the American Diabetes Association and the American Diabetes Association Research Foundation mourn the loss of our dear friend, Robert H. Heilbrunn. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Harriet, and to his children and family. Mr. and Mrs. Heilbrunn's friendship, generosity and support have greatly helped to improve the lives of people affected by diabetes. It was through this giving spirit that the American Diabetes Association was able to fund Dr. Edward Horton's study on the endothelial dysfunction in subjects with glucose intolerance at Joslin Diabetes Center.
