Robert Heilbrunn's care and commitment to a cure for diabetes will stand as a shining example for us all. Stephen H. Smith, Chair of the Board Davida F. Kruger, Chair of the Research Foundation John H. Graham IV, CEO Joyce C. Waite, Regional Exec. VP

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINCHYTZ, MINDY
description: LINCHYTZ-Mindy. My heart and tears are with you. The pain of losing Mindy is so sad for the many people who loved her. Kathy Reichenbaum

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHOR, ANNE
description: SCHOR-Anne. Loving daughter, sister, wife and dear mother. Graveside service at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, New York, at 11 A.M. November 21st.

title: Mixed Signals for the Markets
description: Though Wall Street slipped yesterday, the bear market that prevailed since early 2001 has technically expired, with the major indices standing about 20 percent above their September lows. Since the market often offers a preview of the economy's future, the recent gains suggest that a recovery is still on schedule for late next year. The economy itself has shown some promising signs of late, but the markets still face a few big risks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANCIS, PANAMA
description: FRANCIS-Panama. All his greatness, yet a humble man. A wonderful human being. We share in the loss with his lovely wife Alyce, their family and the music world. Susan and Larry Bauman

title: Childhood Recipe Horrors Exorcised
description: A BOOK that makes you laugh out loud on virtually every page is not to be underestimated right now. But James Lileks's ''Gallery of Regrettable Food'' (Crown, $22.95) is more than a collection of easy jokes about gruesome photography and time-warp attitudes in recipe booklets from the 1940's through the 60's. The author sneaks in some serious insights into America's food culture along with all the belly laughs.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Hemingway Papafest for Paul Newman Charity
description: Talk about Americana. At Avery Fisher Hall on Monday night 2,800 people sang ''The Star-Spangled Banner'' together, the orchestra played an overture with the red-white-and-blue chords of Aaron Copland, the movie stars came out -- Paul Newman! Julia Roberts! -- and then the play began, a kind of ur-text for the 20th-century American coming-of-age story. For men anyway. It was Ernest Hemingway, after all.

title: Dozens of Israeli Jews Are Being Kept in Federal Detention
description: Among the more than 1,100 people the government has detained since Sept. 11 are dozens of young Israeli Jews who came to the United States in recent months and took jobs selling trinkets at shopping malls throughout the country.

title: Court Upholds Tougher Rules On Pollution
description: The state's highest court today upheld a July ruling that the Pataki administration had acted illegally in racing to install so-called minipower plants around New York City without conducting environmental reviews.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENMAN, JAMES A.
description: EISENMAN-James A. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory extends its deepest sympathy to the family and friends of Jim Eisenman. Jim, an attorney of counsel to Payne, Wood and Littlejohn, was Director and Treasurer of the Long Island Biological Association at CSHL from 1963 to 1989. He will be deeply missed by all who knew him.

title: Afghan Caves, an Egyptian Courtroom and the Trade Center Toll
description: The war against the Taliban, the campaign against terrorism around the world, and the hunt for Osama bin Laden have all become interlocked puzzle pieces as Afghanistan teeters under the American-led assault. Where American ground troops go from here -- as soldiers, and as de facto law-enforcement agents searching for a wanted man -- is one issue. How the military campaign is perceived by governments outside Afghanistan that continue to harbor terrorists is a question that will resonate far longer.

title: Pumpkin, Pistachio And Pine Nuts, Too
description: The combination of textures and flavors in this tartlet by Petrossian has a decidedly Middle Eastern personality. Tiny, shimmering cubes of candied pumpkin strewn with pumpkin seeds and pine nuts sit atop a lush pistachio marzipan nestled in a crisp phyllo crust. The tartlets are sold at the shop at 911 Seventh Avenue (58th Street) for $5 and at Corrado Bread and Pastry in Grand Central Market for $4.50.

title: Plan Ahead to Assure Your Heritage Next Year
description: IF you want a heritage turkey on the table next Thanksgiving, it's time to start thinking about it. The farmers will grow only the turkeys they can sell, so orders must be placed no later than January or February.

title: Paris Journal; Adopted New Yorker's Latest Isn't Chopped Liver
description: Upstairs, the sleek beige-and-gray dining room with its smattering of art objects on loan from Christie's is filling up. But downstairs, one of the world's most successful chefs, Jean-Georges Vongerichten, is still fine-tuning his dishes, running his eye over computer printouts of recipes that will go up in the kitchen in front of each station.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, HARRY H.
description: GREENE-Harry H. 94 years of age. Of Huntsville, AL., formerly of Belle Harbor, Queens. Died peacefully November 18, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Sylvia Greene. Cherished father of Judith Kunitz, Abbie Lovinger and Rosalind Howard. Adored father-in-law of Paul Kunitz, the late Joseph Lovinger and Dale Howard. Darling Pop-Pop of nine grandchildren and twenty great grandchildren. Successful business owner and loved employer. You will now rest in peace with your Sylvia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEANS, ELISABETH DEB.
description: DEANS-Elisabeth DeB. On November 19, 2001 of Mill Neck, NY. Beloved wife of Robert B. Deans, Jr. Loving mother of Mary Flood (Paul), Robert B. Deans III (Janet), William P. Deans (Wendy), Nicholas W. Deans (Barbara), Elisabeth Mooney (John). Doting grandmother of Caroline, Robert, and Katie. Dear sister of William Prickett, and the late Harry Prickett. Also survived by loving relatives and friends. Memorial service at Christ Church, 61 East Main Street, Oyster Bay, L.I., Saturday 11 a.m. Interment is private. In lieu of flowers donations to: NY Committee of the Garden Club of America, 812 Park Avenue, New York, NY 10021 Attention: Margaret Sullivan or North Shore Wildlife Sanctuary, Inc. P.O. Box 214, Mill Neck, NY 11765 would be appreciated. For further information contact Oyster Bay Funeral Home.

title: Treffinger Enters 2002 Race For Torricelli's Senate Seat
description: The race for the United States Senate seat occupied by Robert G. Torricelli got its first official candidate this morning when the Essex County executive, James W. Treffinger, announced in unusually low-key fashion that he was seeking the Republican nomination.

title: In 60's Turin, Brotherly Love And Deception
description: Soaking in Gianni Amelio's gorgeously atmospheric film ''The Way We Laughed'' is like leafing through an album of beautiful vintage photographs chronicling the lives of people you think you know but don't. They could be your parents before you were born or friends of theirs who are family legends. The faces convey so much character that you can almost imagine the lives these people must have led, even though the pictures are accompanied by captions that tell you only what happened the day the photos were taken.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times yesterday about treatments for post-traumatic stress disorder misstated the title of Dr. Richard McNally of Harvard, a critic of a treatment called eye movement desensitization and reprocessing. He is a professor of psychology, not an associate professor.

title: Yankees Waste No Time in Courtship of Giambi
description: The Yankees opened contract talks yesterday with Jason Giambi on the first day that the free-agent slugger could discuss specific offers from teams other than the Oakland Athletics. There will be more discussions to come as the Yankees try to move quickly to sign their No. 1 target of the off-season.

title: Giants' Blame Game Is Misdirection Play
description: The Giants are a disappointing 5-5, thus the time is right for complaints to sprout from players like grapes on a vine, and for griping and moaning to become an Olympic sport in the locker room. Only this season it is not Giants defensive players who are ripping the offense. The offense is criticizing itself.

title: 12th Graders' National Science Scores Slip
description: Despite the widespread emphasis on raising academic standards, the performance of high school seniors on a nationwide science test has declined since 1996, with 18 percent of those tested last year proving proficient in the subject, results released yesterday showed.

title: Boat Found, but 30 Cubans Are Missing
description: After nearly three days of combing an area of the Florida Straits the size of Texas, Coast Guard officials found a capsized speedboat today that they believe was carrying 30 Cubans who were being smuggled to the United States.

title: Tax Lawyer Is Convicted Of Evasion
description: Max C. Tanner, a former Internal Revenue Service lawyer who contended that he sincerely believed that he did not have to pay income taxes on the millions he made from a stock swindle, was convicted in Las Vegas Monday night of tax evasion, securities fraud and 35 other federal charges growing out of the fraud.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Swissair Employees Protest
description: Employees of the Swissair Group halted several flights at Geneva's airport, protesting a possible cut in pay and loss of benefits as the airline's operations wind down. They were demonstrating against Crossair, Swissair's former regional subsidiary that is set to take over its European and long-haul business. Employees claim they are at Crossair's mercy when it comes to setting wage levels and are demanding a ''social package'' to underwrite any losses. They have given the government until Nov. 30 to come up with another $125 million. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Dylan, Along a Watchtower, Closely Watching the World
description: Bob Dylan was a soothsayer and a comedian, a lover and a crank, an archivist and an entertainer when he performed at Madison Square Garden on Monday night. Love and war were on his mind, along with the boundless ironies and regeneration promised by the blues.

title: Dorsey, Miami's Quarterback, Hasn't Forgotten Late Hits
description: Still smarting over what he describes as numerous late hits by the University of Washington in last season's game, University of Miami quarterback Ken Dorsey yesterday added fuel to Saturday's showdown by asserting that things would be different this time.

title: China Breaks Up a Protest By Falun Gong Foreigners
description: Thirty-five foreign believers in the outlawed Falun Gong spiritual movement were detained by the police today after holding a brief demonstration in Tiananmen Square.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Kuwait: New Theory On Iraqi Shell
description: An Iraqi explosive that landed in Kuwait this month may have been an antiaircraft round fired in self-defense rather than a mortar shell, the United Nations said. A spokesman for a United Nations mission along the border said an investigation had found that Iraq was firing antiaircraft rounds at American and British warplanes that were flying over southern Iraq at the time of the incident. Kuwaiti and United Nations officials initially identified the explosive as an 82-millimeter mortar shell but the United Nations said its investigation had concluded that a crater found in Kuwait ''could have resulted'' from a 57-millimeter antiaircraft round. Douglas Jehl (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Monday about changes in the public profiles of politicians since Sept. 11 included an incomplete quotation from Tommy G. Thompson, secretary of health and human services, who has been dogged by a remark he made after a Florida man came down with anthrax. (A similar error occurred on Oct. 5 and was corrected in this space on Nov. 1.) According to a transcript from his office, Mr. Thompson said, ''But I want to point out once again that this is an isolated case, and it's not contagious.'' Before being interrupted by a question, he also said, ''There's no evidence of terrorism -- at this ----.'' He did not say: ''It is an isolated case. There is no terrorism.''

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Jewish Leader Cites Extremists
description: Right-wing extremism is becoming ''virulent'' again in Germany with regular attacks on Jewish cemeteries and synagogues, the president of the Central Council of Jews in Germany, Paul Spiegel, said at the annual congress of Chancellor Gerhard Schrder's Social Democratic Party. Mr. Spiegel observed that a swastika had been drawn on the wall of the new Dresden synagogue one day after it opened on Nov. 9. Government figures show a slight rise in right-wing crime in the first half of 2001 with 7,729 offenses -- like displaying the swastika -- recorded, including 430 acts of violence. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Government Cuts Sales Tax
description: The government has cut sales taxes on luxury goods by 2 percent to 10 percent, causing a spike in sales of cars and electronics. Share prices in some of Korea's biggest companies, including Hyundai Motor and Samsung Electronics, also jumped in response to the decision, which officials said was needed to encourage consumer spending. The economy this year is expected to grow 2.6 percent, but the finance ministry hopes for a 4 percent increase in 2002. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Food Drops Go Awry, Damaging Several Homes
description: The planes would bring gifts from the sky, 2-year-old Mohebrahman Sedigh kept saying when American planes began bombing near here. He meant food.

title: Like the BBC Without Accents, or 'NPR on Drugs'
description: TALK about dj vu. In the early 1980's, the hostage crisis in Iran propelled Ted Koppel and ''Nightline'' to considerably more than 15 minutes of fame. Then in the early 1990's, the gulf war gave the CNN correspondent Arthur Kent, a k a the Scud Stud, a briefly flaring prominence.

title: Anschutz Group To Acquire MetroStars
description: The Anschutz Entertainment Group, a Los Angeles-based sports and media company started by the Denver billionaire and soccer enthusiast Philip Anschutz, has agreed to acquire the operating rights to the MetroStars.

title: Museum Pieces for the Table (Silverware Not Included)
description: Museum shops, long destinations for gift shoppers, now cater to holiday hosts, too, with distinctive dinnerware being the latest offering. AsiaStore, the shop in the newly refurbished Asia Society (725 Park Avenue at 70th Street), sells Asianera, above left, its exclusive pattern in white bone china with patterned rims. A 10-inch dinner plate is $28.50; the 7-inch salad or dessert plate with an underwater scene, $16.50; a soup bowl, $15; and a mug, $18. The Neue Galerie New York, a museum of German and Austrian Art (1048 Fifth Avenue at 86th Street) has stoneware dishes, center, inspired by the Austrian designer Koloman Moser of the Wiener Werksttte. The white plates have demure blue-and-white checked rims. The dinner plate is $48; a salad plate, $18; the soup bowl, $24. For more casual entertaining, the Metropolitan Museum Shops sell tin plates that are exact reproductions of blue and white English Staffordshire. A set of four is $30. For store locations: (800) 662-3397. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Fassel Issues a Mandate, No Guarantee Attached
description: This was not quite the celebrated promise Jim Fassel made last season, when the coach guaranteed that his Giants, in a two-game slump, would make the playoffs. This was more of a non guarantee guarantee, but like last season's, it came after the Giants had played badly.

title: Rules Change Along With Psyches
description: I WAS supposed to speak at a conference in Austin, Tex., last week. The subject was ''Balancing Life and Work.'' I had long been looking forward to the event, because it was about one of my favorite topics and it was in one of my favorite towns. But, two weeks beforehand, I canceled. I probably don't need to tell you why.

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Congresswoman Will Step Down
description: Representative Eva Clayton, the first woman to win a Congressional seat from North Carolina and one of the first two black members to do so since Reconstruction, said she would retire next year after five terms. A Democrat, Ms. Clayton, 67, is a member of the House Agriculture Committee, winning top ratings from liberal groups. A political ally, State Senator Frank Ballance, said he was considering running for her First District seat. David Firestone (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Palermo: Hate-Crime Inquiry
description: Federal investigators have joined local and state officials in investigating a fire 25 miles north of Syracuse that severely damaged a Sikh temple on Sunday. The investigators, including arson specialists from the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, are looking for evidence of a hate crime, a federal offense. Sikh men, who wear turbans for religious reasons, are often mistaken for Muslims. Undersheriff Robert Lighthall of Oswego County said the fire, reported at 12:53 a.m., at Gobind Sadan, U.S.A., started on the outside of the building. Mr. Lighthall said federal agents are routinely called in when there is a fire at a house of worship. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

title: A NATION CHALLENGED
description: Connecticut Woman, 94, May Have Inhalation Anthrax

title: President Leaving Purchase College of SUNY
description: BILL LACY, president of Purchase College of the State University of New York since 1993, said yesterday that he would step down from Purchase's helm at the end of December. The SUNY board of trustees is expected to approve THOMAS J. SCHWARZ, a lawyer who was acting president of Hamilton College in 1999, as interim president at its meeting Monday.

title: First, Order Comes to Herat, Then Maybe an Election
description: If all goes according to plan, by this weekend Herat will begin to look more like a normal city and less like the setting for a Mad Max movie.

title: Coaches Are Well Known, If Players Are Not, in N.I.T.
description: The semifinals of the Preseason National Invitation Tournament will feature three nationally ranked teams and another from a powerhouse conference, but the focus tonight at Madison Square Garden will be squarely on the coaches.

title: In Utah, a Government Hater Sells a Germ-Warfare Book
description: At the ''Crossroads of the West'' gun show here last weekend, weapons dealers sold semi-automatic rifles and custom-made pistols, and ammunition wholesalers unloaded bullets by the case. But perhaps the most fearsome weapon for sale in the cavernous, crowded exposition center was a book.

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of yesterday, 4,142 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11.

title: FEDEX BRINGS FORWARD ITS ANNUAL RISE IN SHIPPING RATES
description: FedEx said yesterday that it would raise its United States rates an average of 3.5 percent for air and ground shipments beginning in January, joining its rival United Parcel Service in carrying out the yearly increase a month early. The increases take effect on Jan. 7, the company said. FedEx also raised the additional fees for some deliveries to homes. Growth has slowed at FedEx and other shipping companies, but even so, FedEx said last month that its fiscal second-quarter profit would exceed forecasts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEID, ROSE
description: SEID-Rose. The Hewlett-East Rockaway Jewish Centre mourns the loss of its esteemed member Rose Seid and extends heartfelt sympathy to her husband Irving and the entire family. Rabbi Stanley Platek Ferne Skiba, President

title: BULLETIN BOARD; Princeton Withdrawing From Online Program
description: Princeton University has announced that it will withdraw next month from a consortium of colleges offering online courses to their 500,000 alumni for a fee. Princeton said it wanted to start an independent program of offering online courses to the general public.

title: Dean Leaving N.Y.U.'s Business School
description: GEORGE DALY, dean of the Stern School of Business at New York University, announced yesterday that he would step down at the end of this academic year. In nine years as dean, he has raised more than $125 million, presided over an improvement in the quality of the student body and encouraged the growth of interdisciplinary research and teaching programs with other N.Y.U. schools.

title: Vietnamese Cuisine That Plays Long Shots
description: VIETNAMESE may or may not have a word for chutzpah, but TanDa has plenty of it, regardless. Not too many people would look at an old Off-Track Betting parlor on a murky, nearly deserted stretch of Park Avenue South and see the romantic outlines of a swanky Asian bistro and lounge. It takes nerve to unleash a chef like Stanley Wong, whose idiosyncratic interpretation of Southeast Asian cuisine walks a fine line between provocation and insolence. Finally, as a purely commercial venture, TanDa represents a bold gamble for its owners, who landed a coup with the painfully fashionable Moomba but have decided, this time around, to make an impression with serious, adventurous food.

title: Battered by Sept. 11, Chinatown Economy Remains Crippled
description: Chinatown has become a community of waiting.

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: White House Cancels Christmas Tours
description: President Bush said today that the White House was canceling its public Christmas tours, an announcement that set off groans among local officials who fear that the shutdown contradicts the president's call for normalcy and furthers the image of a capital under siege.

title: Like Old Times, but on Snowboards, Not Surfboards
description: When the masters of the drive-in movie at American-International Pictures ran out of ideas for beach party films in the early 60's, they came up with ''Ski Party,'' a 1965 production that simply transferred the eternal themes of the beach genre -- revealing clothing, practical jokes and uncertainty over how far to go in sex and romance in the absence of adult supervision -- to the side of a mountain.

title: 3 Knee Patients Die, Apparently of Rare Germ
description: Minnesota health officials are struggling to solve a local medical mystery: How did a rare bacterium usually found in soil and fecal matter manage to kill as many as three healthy men who underwent routine knee surgery in the last two weeks?

title: Suicide Law In Oregon Wins Round In U.S. Court
description: A move by Attorney General John Ashcroft to overturn an Oregon law permitting assisted suicide suffered a setback today when a federal judge extended a restraining order against it for at least four months.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, JOSEPH
description: GREENBERG-Joseph. Born June 23, 1915. On November 20, 2001 at 86 years of age. Beloved husband for 61 years of Marilyn (nee Green). Loving father of LouEllen and Mel Barkan and William and Martha Greenberg. Proud grandfather of Tony, Sara, Michael and Rebecca. Great grandfather of Samantha, Julia and Jillian. We love you and will miss you everyday. Contributions can be made to Hospice of Palm Beach County.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Dinner Will Be Late

title: No Break on Holiday as Crews Clear Site
description: While the floats sail down Central Park West and New Yorkers gather around tables loaded with food tomorrow, workers at the disaster site in Lower Manhattan will be busy digging and sifting because, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday, the families of those killed in the collapse want it that way.

title: Protection for Testaverde, Dinner for Line
description: Vinny Testaverde planned to take the offensive line out to dinner tonight, piling up a hefty tab as a way to thank them for their protection, which has not allowed a sack in the last two games.

title: Inhaled Anthrax Suspected In Connecticut Woman, 94
description: A 94-year-old woman from Oxford, Conn., appears to have contracted the inhaled form of anthrax, the rarest and most deadly form of the disease, state and federal officials said late yesterday afternoon.

title: Russian Oil Production Still Soars, for Better and Worse
description: While nobody was watching, this country's oil producers so dramatically ratcheted up production in the last two years that they now occupy a catbird seat, able to whipsaw oil prices -- and potentially the global economy -- just by turning down the Russian spigot.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Corsica: Trial Starts For Ex-Governor
description: A former governor of the French island went on trial over his role in a 1999 arson attack that severely embarrassed Prime Minister Lionel Jospin's government. The governor, Bernard Bonnet, 53, is accused of ordering the police to burn down an illegally constructed beach restaurant as part of a ''zero tolerance'' campaign against the Mediterranean island's mafia-style crime. But the operation turned into a fiasco, with one officer badly burned and enough evidence left at the scene for investigators to move swiftly against his four accomplices. Suzanne Daley (NYT)

title: An Invitation to John Ashcroft
description: Attorney General John Ashcroft's first post-Thanksgiving priority should be explaining to Congress his plans for curbing civil liberties.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times yesterday about the medicinal properties of licorice misstated the surname of a researcher who studied the effect of licorice on testosterone levels. He is Dr. Robert A. Josephs, not Robert A. Johnson.

title: Training Teachers for Hard-to-Fill Posts
description: To help school districts fill vacancies in such perennially hard-to-fill fields as foreign languages, mathematics and science, Pace University and the Putnam/ Northern Westchester Board of Cooperative Educational Services are starting an alternative teacher certification program in March.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, NANCY
description: KAPLAN-Nancy. The partners, associates and staff of the firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison express profound sorrow at the death of Nancy Kaplan on Sunday, November 18th. We express our deepest sympathies to her husband, our friend and former partner, Judge Lewis A. Kaplan, and their daughter Merrill, and to all other members of the family.

title: The Rules That Lead to 'The Envelope, Please'
description: Best animated feature film is the first new Oscar category since best makeup in 1981.

title: After Bus Worker's 11th Injury Claim in 20 Years, He's Arrested
description: Maintaining a New York City Transit bus is hard work, and it can be sort of dangerous. But it is not that dangerous.

title: The Thanksgiving Impulse
description: It's pretty hard to explain just how shocking it is to hear Bing Crosby singing ''Jingle Bells'' in the drugstores and malls or to see tins of Christmas crackers and boxes of wrapping paper stacked where the sandbags full of bite-size Halloween candy were just two weeks ago. But here we are, and there's no going back, which is exactly how it feels to Thanksgiving travelers, who are on the move today. Many Americans who have been innocent of air travel since Sept. 11 are hurling themselves back into the system as if it were yesteryear. They may be lined up yea deep at the ticket counters and security checkpoints, but they're also trying to exercise their patience for a good cause. Going home for Thanksgiving used to be moral satisfaction enough. Now we're going home for Thanksgiving for the good of America.

title: Thanksgiving In a Time of Fasting; In Brooklyn, Healing Rhythms of Ramadan
description: Wisps of gloom have settled in the Almontaser home these first days of Ramadan.

title: Stylish Glass
No TV, No Chess, No Kites
Thank You Notes
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWNE, LEONA E.
description: BROWNE-Leona E. On Wednesday, November 21, 2001 of Wayne, NJ. For 18 years a 4th grade teacher at St. Anthony Padua School in Butler, NJ. Beloved wife for 38 years of Kenneth P. Browne; loving mother of Christine Buonpastore and her husband Anthony, Kenneth G. and Christopher Browne; cherished grandmother of Eric, Alexa and Andrew Buonpastore; loved daughter of Gertrude DeAngelis; sister of Christine and George DeAngelis. Funeral services will be held Monday, November 26, 2001 at 9:45AM from the Vander May Wayne Colonial Funeral Home, 567 Ratzer Rd., Wayne, then to St. Mary's R.C. Church, Pompton Lakes, NJ where at 10:30AM a funeral Mass will be offered. Friends may call Saturday 7-9PM, Sunday 2-4 and 79PM. In lieu of flowers memorial donations to American Cancer Society would be appreciated. For a photo and more information visit vandermay.com

title: National Briefings | Northwest: Washington: Facing Huge Deficit
description: State officials said revenue projections for 2001-3 had dropped $813 million since the last forecast, in September, meaning the state faces a $1.2 billion deficit in its $23 billion budget. The officials said the deficit could require severe cuts in many programs and possibly the elimination of some. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: The Outsider column in Weekend last Friday misstated the name of the geologic event that shaped some rock formations east of the Hudson River along Interstate 84 in New York. It is known as the Taconic orogeny, not the tectonic orogeny. Orogeny is the formation of mountains through structural disturbance, especially by folding and faulting.

title: Charlotte Coleman, 33, Film Actress
description: Charlotte Coleman, a British film actress best remembered in the United States as Scarlett, the cheerily punkish roommate of Hugh Grant's Charles in the 1994 comedy ''Four Weddings and a Funeral,'' died on Nov. 14 at her home in London. She was 33.

title: World Business Briefing | The Americas: Brazil: Bank Workers Press For Raise
description: A 24-hour walkout by Central Bank workers in Braslia was extended another day as union officials pressed for a 75 percent raise, among other demands. Complaining that wages had not been increased for seven years, employees at the bank branch in So Paulo have been on strike 15 days, joined by workers from 6 of the 10 bank agencies around the country. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: McGreevey Names Aides For Shift In Trenton
description: Governor-elect James E. McGreevey announced the leadership of his transition team today, including the appointment of Representative Robert Menendez as transition chairman.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: In These Glasses, Any Drink Will Do
description: THIS is the time of year to restock the glassware shelves for holiday entertaining. Any drink, be it cranberry juice or Champagne, tastes better in a stylish glass -- even if it is not the finest crystal.

title: A Thermometer That Squawks When the Bird Is Done
description: ONE of the more stress-inducing traditions associated with Thanksgiving, particularly for first-time hosts, is cooking the turkey. Theoretically, cooking a turkey is on the low end of the culinary difficulty scale: you wash it, you stuff it, you cover it with butter or oil and you stick it in the oven, basting occasionally.

title: A Tablecloth Spread As a Flag Of Welcome
description: FOR Thanksgiving this year, my family is gathering from Florida, Missouri, California and from across town here in Louisville.

title: RIDGE TO REQUEST BILLIONS TO SPEND ON HOME SECURITY
description: Tom Ridge, the director of homeland security, said today that he would seek substantial new spending in President Bush's next budget, placing a priority on more agents and equipment for strapped federal law enforcement agencies and urgent improvements in public health facilities.

title: Economic Scene; In a model for lending in developing nations, a Bangladesh bank relies on peer pressure for collateral.
description: THE village moneylender in Bangladesh charges interest rates of over 150 percent a year. Citibank would love to get that kind of return on its investments -- so why isn't Citibank lending money in Bangladesh villages?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCOOEY, ROBERT H.
description: McCOOEY-Robert H. The American Association of the Sovereign Military Order of Malta wishes to express its deep regret upon the death of its beloved Chancellor and Confrere, Robert H. McCooey. Our prayers and thoughts are with Bob's devoted family at this time.

title: National Briefings | South: Florida: Message License Plate Retained
description: A license plate supported by anti-abortion and religious groups will remain available to drivers, after a Tallahassee judge dismissed a suit contending that the ''Choose Life'' plate was an unconstitutional state-sanctioned religious message. More than 25,000 of the plates, with crayon-like drawings of children, have been sold since the Legislature authorized the plate in 1999. Sales of the plates have generated more than $668,000 for use by nonprofit groups that ask pregnant women to put unwanted children up for adoption. Gary Fineout (NYT)

title: Ken, Help! The Mice Are Coming
description: ''Sugar Plum Princess?'' the Mouse King roars. ''I've never heard of a Sugar Plum Princess.'' Neither has anyone else, but Barbie makes her own rules. She -- or rather Mattel, the toy company that produced this film along with all sorts of tie-in dolls and paraphernalia -- has also made up an entirely new variation on ''The Nutcracker.''

title: Taliban Will Rise Again, Aide to Leader Promises
description: The Taliban said today that they would never give up their stronghold in southern Afghanistan and their spiritual home, the city of Kandahar, ruling out any talks with the Northern Alliance or other opposition groups on a future national government.

title: Bids to Help the Twin Towers Fund
description: Sotheby's, Phillips, de Pury & Luxembourg, Doyle New York, Swann Auction Galleries, Guernsey's and Leland's Auctions have organized an auction to benefit the Twin Towers Fund. On sale will be 100 lots, from furniture to a Steuben sculpture, with items starting at about $500. A Metropolitan Design Center sofa (below) is estimated to bring $2,500. All proceeds will go to the fund, which helps rescuers' families, said Curt Johnson of New World Inc., who organized the event. A preview will be on Sunday, noon to 6 p.m., at Pier 60 at Chelsea Piers; donations are $10 for adults, $5 for children. The auction, which is free, is at the same location on Monday, at 6:30 p.m.; (212) 873-3673, or www.artforamerica.org. N. C. MAISAK

title: Chief of Swiss Electrical Giant Resigns, Citing Declining Profit
description: Percy Barnevik, the chairman of ABB, Europe's biggest electrical engineering group, unexpectedly stepped down today, saying he was taking his share of responsibility for the sagging profits and stock price at the company he was instrumental in shaping.

title: Kean Says He Won't Run For Senate Seat
description: Disappointing New Jersey Republicans who saw him as by far their best potential candidate, Thomas H. Kean, the former governor, announced today that he would not run for the United States Senate next year against Democratic Senator Robert G. Torricelli.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIEN, SADIE
description: WIEN-Sadie. On November 20, 2001. Age 96. Wife of the late Jack. Devoted mother of Joyce Tretick and the late Karen Herbst. For information, call Wein & Wein at 800-322-0533.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Mobile Emergency Response Project
description: Aether Systems, which develops software and wireless data products and services, said it would provide federal, state and local officials with hand-held devices enabling them to share information, even as they responded to emergencies. Aether of Owings Mills, Md., and state officials said the device -- called the PocketBlue -- would improve the efficiency of homeland defense efforts. ''Whether for command and control, incident response or query of government databases, immediate access to and sharing of information is a prerequisite for the successful prevention of terrorist acts and the protection of American citizens,'' Lt. Gov. Kathleen Kennedy Townsend said.

title: The Anschutz Group Takes Over the MetroStars
description: The commissioner of Major League Soccer yesterday defended the fact that 5 of the league's 12 teams are now run by the same company after the sale on Tuesday of the rights to operate the MetroStars to the Anschutz Entertainment Group.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRUHL, ANNE
description: STRUHL-Anne. Our warmest condolences to Bernard Struhl and the whole Struhl family on the passing of your beloved Annie. We will miss her. Bezzy, Rivka, Boaz, Lisa, Avner, Tami, and Jeremy

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLEMENT, ALPHONSE V. JR., M.D.
description: CLEMENT-Alphonse V. Jr., M.D. Died Nov. 19, 2001 surrounded by his family following a lengthy illness. Born to Dr. Alphonse V. Sr. and Constance Cannella Clement on April 25, 1928. Adored husband of Maryjane. Beloved father of Ardith Colonna (Sal), Jeanine Robotti (Bruno), Debra Clement, Gina Fedeli, Anne Walsh Talberth (Jamie) and Thomas Walsh Jr. (Nereida). Devoted Poppy to Maya, Nicholas, Guy, Jennifer, Nicole, Alisha and Daniel. Dr. Clement graduated University of Notre Dame (1949), attended medical school in Bologna, Italy and graduated Temple University School of Medicine, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania (1956). During his thirty years of service to the city of New Rochelle, he was a general practitioner at Sound Shore Medical Center, formerly New Rochelle Hospital Medical Center, from 1963-1993. In addition, he served as City Physician for the Police Department and Board of Education from 1973-1993, and was an active member of the New Rochelle Rotary Club, serving as their president from 1986-1987. He retired to Florida in 1993, but recently returned to New Rochelle. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory to the Hospice of Westchester, The Esplanade, 4th Floor, 95 South Broadway, White Plains, New York, 10601-4403, would be greatly appreciated. Visitation on Friday, November 23 at Lloyd Maxcy Beauchamp Chapel, Shea Place, New Rochelle, N.Y. 10801, 914632-2700, from 2-4 P.M. and 7-9 P.M. Memorial mass will be held Saturday, November 24 at 9:30 A.M. at Blessed Sacrament Church. Interment private.

title: Bankruptcy Plan Is Rejected For Sale of Fruit of the Loom
description: Fruit of the Loom Inc. failed to win court approval today for its proposed bankruptcy sale procedures, jeopardizing an $835 million offer by Berkshire Hathaway Inc.

title: Burning Woods
description: By late November the first squalls of an early winter have often drenched the East Coast, leaving a sodden, sometimes icy spectacle behind them. But this autumn has been different. The days have been as long and as bright as the sun's track allows. The humidity has stayed low, and rainfall has been less than scant. What has made this a beautiful season has also made it a dangerous one. Stream flows across the region have in some cases reached the lowest levels ever recorded, and in parts of New England wells have begun to dry up. After an extended drought, the leaves that have fallen are now just so much tinder in the parching woods.

title: 2 Boys Charged in Sex Abuse In High School Locker Room
description: Two Long Island high school football players were arraigned today on charges that they sexually abused a freshman player in a school locker room.

title: Technology Briefing
description: INTERNET

title: No TV, No Chess, No Kites: Taliban's Code, From A to Z
description: Hefozullah, a seller of cooking oil, was arrested at the marketplace for keeping his shop open during Friday prayers. He was sent to jail for four days and became No. 3,183 in a registry of arrests at the Ministry for the Promotion of Virtue and Prevention of Vice.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: A Soothing Cup of Water, A Vessel of Plain Kindness
description: Before strangers decided to bring cups of water to other strangers, the very air had become an accomplice to the hijackers. ''It was like ground-up glass going down your throat as you were trying to catch your breath,'' Norma Hessic said.

title: On Any Window or Wall, a Portable Touch Screen
description: DOZENS of computer scientists attending a graphics exhibition in Los Angeles in August did something that most people do not associate with computer science: play with M&M's to create a van Gogh portrait.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Swisscom Profit Up
description: Switzerland's big phone company, Swisscom, expects full-year profit to rise marginally, perhaps by a percentage point, beyond the $2.4 billion profit last year, because of cost cuts and stabilizing prices. Operating revenue rose $2.07 billion in the first nine months, but it said it would slow in the final quarter. Revenue growth was highest in the mobile unit, up 15.2 percent. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Timothy W. Tobiason, a Nebraska man who has been selling a germ-warfare book, referred incorrectly in some copies to Dan Rupp, who notified the F.B.I. about Mr. Tobiason in 1998 after speaking to him at a gun show. Mr. Rupp is a former investigator in the federal public defender's office in Kansas, not a former federal public defender.

title: English Pot Smokers' Pub May Prove a Model
description: Until the Dutch Experience cafe opened here earlier this fall, providing marijuana by the bag instead of beer by the pint, Stockport never loomed particularly large in the greater British imagination.

title: Circling the Wagons Around Enron; Risks Too Great To Let Trader Just Die
description: Officials of Dynegy yesterday weighed whether to seek to renegotiate the terms of the company's agreement to acquire Enron, its Houston rival, while Enron and its bankers sought to shore up its finances, executives close to the two companies said.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Netherlands: Phone Company Seeks Equity
description: KPN Telekom is asking shareholders to provide 5 billion euros ($4.4 billion) in new equity to help reduce debt of about 22.3 billion euros from acquisitions and the purchase of wireless permits. The shares fell 15 percent, to $4.24. The Dutch government has promised to buy roughly 1.7 billion euros of the new shares to maintain its 34.7 percent stake. KPN said its banks had pledged to buy any unsold shares. KPN also reported a loss of 342 million euros in the third quarter, less than the 366 million euros a year earlier. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Shaken by Close Calls, A Family Regroups
description: THANKSGIVING came two months early this year for Rudy and Jacquelyn Marisa.

title: Editorial Observer; Mayor-Elect Michael Bloomberg Begins Filling In a Very Blank Slate
description: Michael Bloomberg the public man is untested and pretty much unknown. We've seen his ads, read his autobiography, heard his friends and foes talk about his leadership, his ego, as in his EGO. Now, as he edges toward his first political job as mayor of New York City, the first inklings are beginning to appear.

title: Death of 7-Year-Old Bronx Girl Is Linked to Abuse
description: A 7-year-old Bronx girl died yesterday morning, shortly after police officers responding to a 911 call found her suffering from broken arms, burns, cuts and a broken jaw, the police said. Detectives were questioning the girl's mother and boyfriend last night.

title: Corrections
description: The Online Shopper column in Circuits on Nov. 8, about fear of opening mail, misstated the given name of a doctor who in 1822 mailed a sample smallpox vaccine that turned out to have the live virus. He was James Smith, not William Smith. The article also misstated the reason for the mailing. Congress acted in 1813 to underwrite vaccine shipments by exempting them from postage; the 1822 shipment was not part of an appeal for Congressional financing.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: New Mad Cow Case
description: Just as Japanese beef prices were returning to normal, a second case of mad cow disease has been confirmed in Japan, according to the Health Ministry. The infected cow was found and slaughtered in Hokkaido, the northernmost of Japan's islands, where ranching is concentrated. Two months ago, health authorities announced the first case in Japan of a cow infected with the disease, formally known as bovine spongiform encephalopathy, which has been linked to the deaths of about 100 people in Britain. James Brooke (NYT)

title: One Maryland County Moves To Regulate In-Home Smoking
description: A suburban Washington county has approved a strict antismoking measure that would impose $750 fines against residents if the odor of their smoking irritates neighbors.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO DROPS. The euro fell after a decline in German business confidence fueled concern that the nation's economy is headed for a recession. In New York, the euro settled at 87.94 cents, down from 88.27 cents on Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARZ, PRESTON S.
description: SCHWARZ-Preston S. The Board of Directors and members of the Quaker Ridge Golf Club record with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Preston S. Schwarz, whose many years of friendship, kindness and enthusiastic spirit will always be remebered. Beth Z. Post, President Roger H. Tulcin, Secretary

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANCIS, PANAMA
description: FRANCIS-Panama. All his greatness, yet a humble man. A wonderful human being. We share in the loss with his lovely wife Alyce, their family and the music world. Susan and Larry Bauman

title: Employees' Retirement Plan Is a Victim as Enron Tumbles
description: The rapid decline of the Enron Corporation has devastated its employees' retirement plan, which was heavy with company stock, and has infuriated workers, who were prohibited from changing their investments as the stock plunged.

title: John Babarovic, 69, Architect at Airports
description: John A. Babarovic, an architect who worked on major airport projects as well as residential architecture, died on Nov. 2 in London, where he lived. He was 69.

title: CSX Is Settling Suits Over Spill
description: CSX Transportation Inc., which operates the largest rail network in the Eastern United States, said today that it would pay more than $36 million to settle lawsuits over a 1987 rail-car spill here that forced thousands of residents from their homes.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Palermo: Agents See Fire As Arson
description: Investigators are virtually certain that a fire that destroyed a Sikh temple on Sunday was arson, officials from the Oswego County sheriff's office said yesterday. However, the fire at the temple, Gobind Sadan U.S.A., is not being considered a hate crime because investigators have yet to uncover a motive. The investigation is focusing on arson because the fire was set outside the structure, said Robert Lighthall, Oswego County undersheriff. Sikhs, who wear turbans for religious reasons, are often mistaken for Muslims. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Restoration Job: Chapel and Lives; Bowery Mission Is Improving Itself as It Helps Needy
description: No one goes to the Bowery in search of beauty.

title: Some Wonder Where Pataki Has Been During Uphill Fight for Billions
description: One New York politician after another spoke up last week as the White House and Congress tried to clamp down on federal aid to help New York recover from the recent terror attack. But through it all, one prominent New York politician remained curiously silent: Gov. George E. Pataki.

title: Suspect in the Fatal Shooting Of 2 in the Bronx Surrenders
description: A Bronx man sought by the police in connection with the shooting deaths of a 5-year-old boy and a 25-year-old man turned himself in yesterday and was being questioned last night at a Bronx precinct house, the police said.

title: John W. Nason, 96, Educator; Helped Japanese-Americans
description: John W. Nason, who while president of Swarthmore College during World War II helped get more than 3,000 American students of Japanese descent out of detention camps and place them in institutes of higher learning, died on Saturday in Kennett Square, Pa. He was 96.

title: Vitamin Producers Fined $752 Million
description: The European Commission fined eight vitamin producers a total of just over 855 million euros ($752 million) today for involvement in a number of cartels that fixed prices and market shares of vitamin products in the 1990's.

title: Cell Yell: Thanks for (Not) Sharing
description: WITH just five minutes to takeoff, the young man across the aisle on the Baltimore-bound flight whipped out his cellphone and began a hurried and boisterous conversation, explaining the fine points of marketing his new Christmas-gift Web site to an unseen underling. With glazed eyes staring at the seat in front of him, the executive unconsciously pounded his foot in rhythm to his conversation, oblivious to the 15 surrounding passengers glaring at this human loudspeaker in seat 23B.

title: Debate Centers on Which Court Will Decide Fate of Arab Man
description: Senior Bush administration officials have begun to discuss whether a man in custody in New York should be tried on terrorism charges by a military tribunal rather than a civilian criminal court, senior law enforcement officials said today.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Contract For A Gas Plant
description: Samsung Engineering won a $200 million contract to build a gas separation plant in southern Thailand. Trans-Thai Malaysia, a joint venture of the Thai national oil company PTT and its Malaysian counterpart, Petroliam Nasional, or Petronas, is pushing ahead with the plant despite local opposition. The plant is part of a plan to build a pipeline to carry natural gas from fields offshore across Thailand to Malaysia. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: New Sensors Report, 'I Know They're in There, I Can See Them Breathing'
description: American forces seeking the hide-outs of Osama bin Laden are being equipped with sophisticated new technology -- an array of sensors -- that can pierce darkness, bad weather and as much as 100 feet of solid rock, homing in on heat, magnetic fields, vibrations and other faint cues.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Bridgeport: 2 Lose Appeal In Drug Case
description: A federal appeals court has rejected an appeal by two brothers convicted in multiple murders to overturn their drug trafficking convictions, the United States attorney's office said. The court issued its ruling Monday, leaving one of the brothers, Russell Peeler Jr., to serve his multiple life sentences and the other, Adrian Peeler, above, to serve his 55-year sentence. Russell Peeler was convicted of killing a former drug-dealing partner, then killing two witnesses. Adrian Peeler was convicted of conspiracy to murder the witnesses. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: A Fan of Mysteries Is Now at the Center of One
description: Until she somehow contracted anthrax, Ottilie W. Lundgren's later life had become one of satisfying routines that seemed to take her no farther than the borders of this tiny town. At 94, she had given up driving in the last year and relied on friends and family to pick her up from the white ranch house on the hill where she lived alone.

title: The Road to a New Afghanistan
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRASNER, NORMAN L.
description: KRASNER-Norman L. Died on November 20 in Haifa Israel. Survived by his beloved wife Sondra (nee Wilk), children, Leora, Eitan, Adina & Noah. Brother of Estelle and Daniel. Loving grandfather and great-grandfather. Shiva is in Israel and New Rochelle, NY.

title: A Feast for the Eyes, At Offices in Midtown
description: The lobbies of three soaring office buildings in Midtown will be hung with quilts on Nov. 29, in a free exhibition for passers-by who think to duck in. No longer a quaint domestic practice involving the recycling of fabric scraps, quilting is a $2 billion a year industry, said Shelly Zegart of the Alliance for American Quilts, and an art form that ''holds the memory of women in this country.'' The quilts are contemporary (''Listen to Your Mother,'' top, by Jean Ray Laury, who made her first quilt as a Stanford graduate student in 1956) and classic (an anonymous 1860 quilt in the New York Beauty style, above). The buildings, owned by the Durst Organization, are at 1155 Avenue of the Americas, 1133 Avenue of the Americas and 4 Times Square. The eyeful comes down on Jan. 31. DEBORAH BALDWIN

title: Radio E-Mail Connects Ships to Shore
description: WHEN Jim Corenman wants to get in touch with family and friends while out in the middle of nowhere aboard his 50-foot sailboat, Heart of Gold, he doesn't reach for any newfangled satellite or cellular equipment. Instead he fires up his oldfangled shortwave radio, hooks it up to his laptop computer and starts sending e-mail.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Terra Workers To Be Furloughed
description: Terra Networks S.A., owner of the Lycos group of Web sites, is requiring most of its 800 United States employees to use five vacation days or take unpaid time off between Christmas and New Year's. The company, based in Barcelona, Spain, is shutting its American operations in Waltham, Mass., and Mountain View, Calif., leaving only ''core employees'' needed to keep the Web sites running, a spokeswoman said.

title: Murder Rate Remains Stable Since Sept. 11, Giuliani Says
description: Although shootings and murders in New York City rose in the last month compared with the same period last year, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that there had been no change in the murder rate since Sept. 11 and that there had been a decline of nearly 12 percent in felonies since then.

title: U.S. Stokes the Fire, Adding Gunships and More
description: With Taliban and Al Qaeda fighters still resisting in Kandahar and smaller pockets, the Pentagon continues to bolster American forces near Afghanistan, asking Uzbekistan to accept three AC-130 Special Forces gunships and planning to base warplanes in two other Central Asian nations, senior officials said today.

title: Talk of Surrender, an Influx of Weapons and Another Anthrax Death
description: Would the Taliban forces and their foreign comrades besieged in Kunduz surrender? Or would they be mercilessly slaughtered?

title: Potluck and Bonfires
description: MY wife and son and I will spend this Thanksgiving with friends, a ragtag community scattered among the villages along the southern and eastern fringes of the Ashokan Reservoir, in Ulster County, N.Y. I've never spent the holiday with this particular group of people before, but it's a natural now; we've been getting together quite a lot lately. Some of them are recent acquaintances, some have been my friends for more than 25 years. A few of us are now ex-New Yorkers. My wife and I left the city a little over a year ago, prompted in large part by a need for space; our son, Raphael, turned 2 on Sept. 11.

title: How bin Laden and Taliban Forged Jihad Ties
description: In a reception room at a Taliban ministry of defense building in Kabul, a brightly colored map depicting the American military presence in the Arabian peninsula was painted on a wall. An identical map appears in a book written by Osama bin Laden declaring a holy war on the United States.

title: GOODYEAR CUTS PRODUCTION FOR 10TH CONSECUTIVE MONTH
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company is reducing production for a 10th consecutive month in November because of slowing sales. Goodyear said retail sales of tires for passenger vehicles fell in October amid a 10 percent industrywide decline. The company did not offer specifics. Goodyear, based in Akron, Ohio, said last month that third-quarter profit fell 45 percent. It has eliminated about 7,500 jobs since December. Goodyear shares fell $1.31, to $21.88.

title: Catching the World in the Act of Changing
description: At first it looked like snow. There was a stillness in the city. White dust floated in the air. People looked up to see where it was coming from. The traffic was moving slowly. Then people started running, running north and running east. It was around 9 in the morning on Sept. 11.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 1 about Eddy Curry and Tyson Chandler, teenagers who play in the National Basketball Association, and their adjustment to a new life of wealth and independence, referred incorrectly to the mother with whom Mr. Curry's infant son lives. She is Mr. Curry's wife, not his former girlfriend.

title: Calpine to Build a Power Plant in Virginia
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Nov. 21 (Bloomberg News)  The Calpine Corporation ( news/quote ), the energy supplier, said today that it planned to spend about $500 million to build a power plant in Virginia that could serve a million homes as part of a plan to increase business in the Southeast.

title: Raymond M. Downey, 63; Headed Fire Rescue Units
description: A memorial service has been scheduled for Deputy Chief Raymond M. Downey, who commanded the rescue units of the New York Fire Department and oversaw the search-and-rescue work after the Oklahoma City bombing in 1995. Mr. Downey, who was 63 and lived in Deer Park, N.Y., died in the collapse of the World Trade Center buildings.

title: This Pedometer Is Made For Walking. And Screaming.
description: The latest Brunton pedometer has a feature that you probably don't want to test in a small room. When you remove a pin from one side, a personal safety alarm shrieks at an ear-splitting volume. That should get everybody walking a little faster.

title: National Briefing
description: NORTHWEST

title: An Airman's Homecoming Adds Joy To the Day
description: JIM and Stephanie started dating at the tail end of the Persian Gulf war, and from the first they had an understanding: the Air Force could pull Jim away from her at any time. Like other military families, they learned to live with the uncertainty. The couple -- who on the advice of the military asked that their last name not be used, for reasons of security -- married five years ago and are now raising two boys in North Charleston, S.C., where Jim, a master sergeant, is stationed at Charleston Air Force Base.

title: Birthing the Internet: Letters From the Delivery Room; Enough Glory to Be Shared
description: To the Editor:

title: Clark, in Ninth Place, Is Best the U.S. Can Do
description: By the end of the day, a tear was trickling down the face of a crestfallen Sarah Schleper and frustration was morphing into doubt inside the head of Caroline Lalive.

title: Ballet as Balm In a Tribute To a City On the Mend
description: It was certainly not your usual opening of a winter season by the New York City Ballet. A gala benefit audience on Tuesday night had to negotiate the car barriers recently set up on Lincoln Center's plaza, and bags were checked at the entrance to the New York State Theater.

title: Bondholders And Trump Negotiating Debt Terms
description: Donald J. Trump has begun talks with bondholders to adjust the terms of $1.3 billion in debt and is now expected to pay $73 million in interest past due on those bonds within days, a lawyer for Mr. Trump said yesterday.

title: Of Flames Flickering And Flaring
description: For an evening featuring 19 brand-new songs, Saturday night's recital at the Metropolitan Museum of Art was notably, well, conservative. In fact it had a kind of elegiac tone.

title: An Exclusive Collection of Museum Shop Gifts in a Converted Mansion
description: Just inside the front entrance of the Neue Galerie New York, Museum for German and Austrian Art, which opened on Fifth Avenue last week, is a jewel of a gift shop. The museum and shop, housed in a restored 1914 mansion designed by Carrre & Hastings (top left and bottom right), opened just in time for holiday shoppers searching for a special gift. The shop offers a well-edited selection of high-quality reproductions of decorative arts from the gallery's collection. Each item was chosen by Rene Price, the museum's director. And in contrast to many museum shops, everything is sold exclusively here. Among the reproductions is a bentwood cafe chair designed by Adolf Loos in 1899 and made by Thonet ($900), and a black and white porcelain set (lower left) designed by Josef Hoffmann circa 1925. The pot, meant for serving mocha, is $245; a cup and saucer set is $95; the sugar bowl is $140, and the creamer, $110. Colored glass vases (top right), designed by Mr. Hoffmann in 1915, can also be used as goblets or dessert bowls. They come in three sizes: small ($125), medium ($175) and large ($220).

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Prison Transfer For Embassy Bomber
description: A man convicted in the 1998 bombing of the American Embassy in Tanzania and also accused of assisting in an attack on a Manhattan jail guard has been transferred to a federal prison nicknamed Super Max for its high security, records show. The prison, in Florence, Colo., has held Timothy J. McVeigh, the Oklahoma City bomber, and Theodore J. Kaczynski, the Unabomber. The embassy bomber, Khalfan Khamis Mohamed, above, was one of four men who received life sentences last month for their roles in a conspiracy to kill Americans. Prosecutors said the conspiracy was led by Osama bin Laden. Mr. Mohamed has denied any role in the attack on the guard. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of yesterday, 3,915 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11.

title: Replacement For TV Tower Lost on Sept. 11 Is in Doubt
description: Plans to build an enormous television tower to replace the one atop the World Trade Center are in doubt. The efforts have stalled despite growing pressure from television executives concerned about losing millions of viewers and the advertising dollars they attract.

title: Terror in Beirut, Frustration and Power Politics in Washington
description: Lee Blessing's hostage drama, ''Two Rooms,'' written in 1988, was chosen for production by the Blue Heron Theater before Sept. 11, and it would have been understandable had the theater not followed through. The play, about the kidnapping of an American professor by terrorists in Beirut, might easily have been judged too salty for the national wound. Oddly enough, however, the opposite is true. The attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon and the subsequent education we've all received in the complexities of the terrorist threat make this comparatively simple-minded story too bland to be abrasive.

title: LUXOTTICA BARRED FROM SELLING SOME SUNGLASSES IN U.S.
description: Luxottica, the eyewear company based in Milan, said yesterday that a California court had issued a temporary restraining order barring the company from selling some sunglasses in the United States after a competitor, Oakley Inc., said Luxottica was selling knockoff designs. The Federal District Court for the Central District of California has barred Luxottica from selling three sunglass models until Nov. 30. Oakley contended in a lawsuit that Luxottica bought its biggest customer, the Sunglass Hut chain, and began selling knockoffs of Oakley designs. Sunglass Hut, which has 2,000 stories, accounted for as much as one-quarter of Oakley's sales until Luxottica bought it in April. Luxottica said it would vigorously fight the lawsuit.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Timothy W. Tobiason, a Nebraska man who has been selling a germ-warfare book, referred incorrectly in some copies to Dan Rupp, who notified the F.B.I. about Mr. Tobiason in 1998 after speaking to him at a gun show. Mr. Rupp is a former investigator in the federal public defender's office in Kansas, not a former federal public defender.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''There is going to be some heartburn on the part of police chiefs to take on this role because this is not how we usually do business.''

title: Now Let's Give Thanks for the Nice Guys of Sports
description: ATHENS  On any normal Thursday, the very idea of sports humanitarians would be good for a snide comment or two. But even for an American far from home, this is not a normal Thursday. It is a time to give thanks.

title: ELI LILLY RECEIVES GOVERNMENT APPROVAL OF SEPSIS DRUG
description: Eli Lilly & Company said yesterday that it had received Food and Drug Administration approval of its Xigris drug for severe sepsis, the first treatment approved for the often fatal overreaction to infection. Analysts estimated that sales for Xigris would top $1 billion a year within a few years. Lilly, based in Indianapolis, needs new products to make up for declining sales of its antidepressant Prozac, which lost its American patent protection in August. The company succeeded in developing a sepsis treatment even as about a half-dozen other drug makers failed in the 1990's. Expectations for Xigris have buoyed Lilly shares while Prozac sales declined because of generic competition. The shares rose $2.19, to $83.33.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Gaza: Arab Blocked At Checkpoint Dies
description: A Palestinian died of a heart attack after Israeli soldiers at a Gaza Strip checkpoint held up an ambulance taking him to a hospital, medical officials said. The army said it was investigating. Hospital officials in Rafah said the man, Sami Bassa, 56, a heart patient, had died when they returned to the checkpoint. The army says soldiers are ordered to allow passage in medical emergencies, but Palestinians have reported several cases in which people died after they were stopped or delayed at checkpoints since the Palestinian uprising began last year.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Lawsuit In Suspicious Accidents
description: Allstate is suing 40 people who collected more than $1 million in medical claims in traffic accidents that were later alleged to have been staged. The civil suit, filed in Morris County Superior Court on Tuesday, accuses the defendants of fraudulently staging nine accidents and then seeking medical attention at Allied Trauma and Health Care of Essex County. Allstate won a $5.35 million judgment against Allied Trauma, which closed in 1999 and is not named in the current suit.

title: Blessings to Count but Thanks When the Day Ends
description: WHEN loved ones are snatched instead of taken, the survivors are jarred for life. There is not much anyone can do about their losses, yet they are expected to graciously accept our fumbling attempts. It will be difficult for families who have lost loved ones in recent weeks to endure the most mundane events right now, let alone the holidays, which have come so quickly.

title: VERIZON OFFERING BUYOUTS TO UNION WORKERS
description: The telephone service provider Verizon Communications said yesterday that it offered buyouts to a significant number of its 130,000 union employees in the last week to cut costs after profit dropped. Verizon has 256,000 employees. Jeff Miller, a spokesman for the Communications Workers of America, which represents 88,000 employees, said Verizon wanted to trim 8,000 union jobs before the year ends. Verizon has eliminated 7,500 jobs this year, mainly through attrition, and the equivalent of 14,000 positions by reducing overtime and shedding contractors, a company spokesman, Peter Thonis, said.

title: Educating the World
description: Beyond being horrified by stories of Taliban militants beating a 6-year-old girl for carrying a notebook, as reported by Newhouse News Service, and warning a classroom of girls in an underground school that they would be burned alive if they returned the next day, as related in U.S. News & World Report, Americans are pained by the simple reality that any government would ban school for girls.

title: Developer Briefs Bloomberg On Plans to Rebuild Towers
description: Larry A. Silverstein, the developer who holds the lease on the World Trade Center, met with Mayor-elect Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday and said afterward that he would go ahead with plans to rebuild at the site, probably with new towers reaching about half as high as the ones destroyed on Sept. 11. He also said groundbreaking at 7 World Trade Center would begin in 2002.

title: What Did You Do Before the War?
description: AMERICANS, whether they realize it or not, leave a trail of data with every life step. As soon as a person is married or divorced, basic details about the event go on file at the local courthouse for anybody to browse. The same can be said for anyone who has registered to vote, acquired a professional license, bought a piece of real estate, filed for bankruptcy, been convicted of a crime or simply moved and listed a new address and phone number.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Netherlands: Profit Falls At ING
description: The ING Group, the financial services company, said third-quarter profit fell 7.7 percent as insurance claims mounted, sales slumped and it set aside more money for bad loans. Net income excluding one-time gains dropped to 901 million euros ($792 million), or 47 cents a share, from 976 million euros, or 51 cents, a year earlier. The chief executive, Ewald Kist, left, said he planned to step up cost-cutting.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BADER, NATHAN
description: BADER-Nathan. Happy Birthday, Daddy. You will always be the wind beneath my wings. I will always love and miss you, Ann

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Corrections
description: An article in the special Giving section on Nov. 12 about efforts of charity administrators in the aftermath of the terrorist attacks misstated the length of William C. Nelsen's service at the Citizens' Scholarship Foundation of America. He has been its president for 15 years, not 6.

title: A Struggle to Keep Up For TV Caption Writers
description: Some television captions were baffling, like Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld's mention of the ''instinct for cap larries,'' during a Pentagon briefing.

title: Millen Wants to Cast Spell To End Lions' Brutal Days
description: Matt Millen, the Detroit Lions' president and chief executive officer, was in his Silverdome office yesterday reminiscing about a game he played in 12 years ago as a San Francisco linebacker against New Orleans.

title: Just Crazy About the Place
description: A homeless man known to me as Charlie, who was only a little crazier than the rest of us, decided to set up a living room a few years ago on the sidewalk outside the church at 86th and Amsterdam. He had scavenged and found a spotted sofa, two end tables, a Barcalounger stuck in the recline position, a rug that had probably been orange in the 1960's and a standing lamp that plugged into nothing. It was a pretty nice-looking place, and since I knew Charlie from the neighborhood, I sat down in his outdoor room to talk. After a while, it was clear that I was boring him. ''Well, Roger,'' he said through his four remaining teeth. ''I've enjoyed this chat. But I'm expecting guests.''

title: Fares Plus
description: For independent travelers, Qantas and Air New Zealand are offering an $899 round-trip fare between Los Angeles and Sydney on midweek departures; weekends, it is $949. The add-on from New York and other East Coast cities is $425. Tickets must be issued by Nov. 27 and travel must be completed by Dec. 31. Information: (800) 227-4500 or www.qantas.com for Qantas or (877) 843-3943 and www.airnz.com for Air New Zealand. For $1,699, Qantas has a 14-day package that allows travelers to combine Sydney with two or three other destinations (but Perth is not among them). The price, per person based on double occupancy, includes round-trip air fare from Los Angeles, flights within Australia and accommodations in three-star hotels. It is available for weekday departures through Dec. 7, then again from May 1 to June 21, 2002, and July 23 to Aug. 31. Information: (800) 965-6252 or on the Internet at www.qantaskoala.com .

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAPA, EDITH
description: CAPA-Edith. The Trustees and staff of the International Center of Photography mourn the passing of the beloved wife of our Founder, Cornell Capa. His partner throughout a long and loving marriage, Edie also supported and nurtured the endeavors of all the ICP staff from the start of this institution. Her fierce commitment to the work of Cornell and the late Robert Capa, and the ''concerned'' photographers who inspired the founding of ICP, created the first archives of this institution and laid the foundation for the present-day collections. Her selfless dedication to ICP has been unwavering and an inspiration to us all. Held in the highest respect and affection, and always an important member of the ICP family, she will be deeply missed. Our heartfelt sympathy to Cornell and to Edie's many friends, whose great loss we share. Rita Hillman, Honorary Chair Gayle Greenhill, Chairman Raymond J. McGuire, President Willis Hartshorn, Director

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Syracuse and Duany Handle Michigan State
description: Preston Shumpert, a Syracuse forward, is the closest thing to a name player in the Preseason National Invitation Tournament at Madison Square Garden. When he struggled with his shooting last night, the Orangemen should have been in serious trouble in their semifinal against Michigan State.

title: The Case of the Good Girl Gone Bad
description: FLESH AND BLOOD

title: Lots of Competition for 2001's Hit Toy
description: There were four Billy Blazes, the New York City Fire Department firefighter who is currently the most popular of the hit Rescue Heroes action figures from Fisher-Price, remaining on the spindle at the new Toys ''R'' Us store in Times Square at midday on Monday.

title: The Road to a New Afghanistan
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Old Pianos Go to Live; A Massachusetts Petting Zoo For 19th-Century Instruments
description: The one thing you will never see at the Frederick Historic Piano Collection in Ashburnham, Mass., is a sign that reads, ''Do Not Touch.'' Unlike most museums, this important collection of historic 19th-century pianos is meant to be used.

title: Less Stuff To Strut, But a Show Goes On
description: UNTIL recently, you might have described Comdex, the annual high-tech trade show, as the biggest computer show on earth. It would be safer to describe this year's edition, however, as the biggest computer show in Las Vegas. This month. So far.

title: Reviving an Ancient Italian Art
description: Stucco Veneziano, better known as Venetian plaster, looks and feels like stone. Hand-flaked lime, marble dust, linseed oil, soap and pigment are laboriously mixed and hand-troweled onto the wall. Orazio De Gennaro, 44, who apprenticed at age 13 near Pompeii, Italy, practices the ancient craft in Brooklyn. Custom colors and finishes, including reds and ochres (below), can evoke the Old World or appear modern. Unlike the ready-made version, Mr. De Gennaro's work has translucency and depth. ''Even in Italy, there are very few artisans left who do the traditional method that I do here,'' he said. Count on $20 to $25 a square foot. DONNA PAUL

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: TODAY'S GAMES

title: Contraction and Selig on Owners' Plate
description: Three weeks after they voted to eliminate two teams for next season, baseball's club owners will convene again Tuesday in Chicago to hear a status report on the contraction plan. While they are there, the owners will be asked to act on another matter -- the election of Commissioner Bud Selig to a second term.

title: Family Ghosts And Wild Turkeys
description: WHEN Capt. John Smith sailed up Chesapeake Bay in 1608, the water was so full of fish that his men could scoop them up in a frying pan. That's how the story goes anyway. The shallows were thick with clams and crabs and oysters, and on Thanksgiving, on our family farm near the bay, Baltimore's brackish harbor, we start the feast by slurping raw oysters. They're not as plentiful as in those days, of course, so we savor them all the more.

title: Hints of an Alzheimer's Aid In Anti-Inflammatory Drugs
description: Middle-age and elderly people who took anti-inflammatory drugs like ibuprofen or naproxen for at least two years were apparently protected from Alzheimer's disease, according to a new study by scientists in the Netherlands. Their likelihood of getting Alzheimer's dementia was one-sixth that of people who did not take the drugs.

title: Reports Suggest That Recovery Will Be Soon, But Not Robust
description: The economy remains weak but recent reports suggest it is no longer becoming any worse, giving weight to the increasingly popular view that a recovery is only a few months away. Still, the number of people who lose their jobs will probably remain high in the near future, economists say.

title: FOREIGN MILITANTS SEEK SAFE PASSAGE FROM AFGHAN CITY
description: Foreign militants, trapped inside the besieged city of Kunduz and desperate to save their lives, have asked to leave the country through a protected corridor and travel overland to Pakistan, a senior Northern Alliance official said here today.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Playboy.com Falls Prey To Hacker
description: In a switch, the customers were exposed. Playboy .com was hit this week with a particularly mischievous hacker attack, the company said. The intruder grabbed credit card numbers for customers of the Playboy online store and sent many of the victims a message said to be from the company's founder, Hugh Hefner, left, that included the recipient's credit card number and concluded, ''We'd like to thank the Playboy systems team for providing us with an interesting and challenging target.'' The Playboy.com president, Larry Lux, sent a warning to all online customers; a company spokeswoman, Laura Sigman, said Playboy was shoring up its defenses, adding, ''There's no indication at this point that the credit cards have been used.'' John Schwartz (NYT)

title: Seamless Repairs for Chipped Glass or Porcelain
description: Many a household has chipped wine glasses, tumblers and ceramic bowls, or dented silver trays, thought of only at holiday time. Damaged or not, they may be impossible to throw away because of their sentimental or intrinsic value. In most cases, however, specialists can bring them back to almost-new. Augustine Jochec of Glass Restorations, 1597 York Avenue (84th Street), can grind down the rim of a glass or crystal piece, making it smooth enough for display and safe enough to drink from again. The cost is $20 to $25 a piece, depending on the damage. Mr. Jochec works with porcelain and ceramics, too. Expect a wait of 10 days to two weeks for crystal and longer for complicated porcelain work.
