If silver, brass, copper or bronze goods are damaged, Paul Karner of Restoration and Design Studio, 249 East 77th Street, removes dents and scratches, and solders and replates. He charges $100 an hour. Estimates are free; his minimum is $15. Some repairs can be done overnight; most take two weeks.

title: Refinery Settles Bias Claim
description: Motiva Enterprises, a refinery that is owned by ChevronTexaco and other oil companies, has agreed to pay $9 million to black employees who say they were denied promotions because of their race.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARBERA, AMPARO SANCHEZ
description: BARBERA-Amparo Sanchez. On November 15, 2001 in Valencia, Spain. The entire CMA family mourns the passing of the mother of its President, Jose Juan Sanchez. May her entire family be comforted, as death does not exist it is just a pathway to heaven.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERN, MIRIAM
description: HALPERN-Miriam. Congregation Rodeph Sholom mourns the death of our devoted, longtime member, Miriam Halpern. Our deepest sympathy is extended to her niece, Susie Quill, and all their dear ones. Robert N. Levine, Sr. Rabbi Mark Biderman, President

title: When Prisoners Study
description: To the Editor:

title: The Road to a New Afghanistan
description: To the Editor:

title: North Korean Death Rate Is Said to Be Up Sharply Since 1994
description: The top executive of the World Health Organization said today that North Koreans were dying at a rate that was more than 40 percent higher than in 1994 when the country was hit by the first of a series of devastating floods and famines.

title: Footlights
description: 'Greed,' Reconstructed

title: Viloria, a Professional Now, Starting to Gain Perspective
description: The loss Brian Viloria suffered in the ring at the Sydney Summer Olympics last year seems somewhat less egregious to him now.

title: Birthing the Internet: Letters From the Delivery Room; A Question of Semantics
description: To the Editor:

title: UCONN GAINS ANOTHER PREP STAR
description: Ann Strother, a 6-foot-1 guard who is regarded by many rating services as the best women's high school player in the country, has signed a letter of intent to attend the University of Connecticut.

title: A Fitting Memorial
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Are Split On Questioning Of Mideast Men
description: Police chiefs across the nation are torn between a desire to assist the investigation of the Sept. 11 attacks by following Attorney General John Ashcroft's request that they help interview thousands of Middle Eastern men and a concern that the plan seems like racial profiling.

title: The Neediest Cases; Night of Feasting for Children at an Alternative Home Sweet Home
description: Johnny Soto's father was not at the Thanksgiving dinner table.

title: Editors' Note; Today's Sections
description: News of the Sept. 11 attacks and their aftermath continues to appear in Section B; index, Page B2.

title: Case in a Small Town Compounds a Puzzle For Epidemiologists
description: Epidemiologists investigating the anthrax death yesterday of Otillie W. Lundgren, 94, from Oxford, Conn., are confronting a mystery as baffling as the case of a Bronx woman, Kathy T. Nguyen, who died on Oct. 31 leaving no clue to the source of her infection.

title: Abraham And Ellis Heed Talk By Coach
description: It was about a month ago, when it seems everything that meant anything happened with the Jets, that Coach Herman Edwards called Shaun Ellis and John Abraham into his office. His first message was soothing: you're not on the trading block, Edwards told the defensive linemen, who were both first-round draft picks in April 2000.

title: A New Personal Organizer Knows What Time It Is
description: Chalk up another one for computer evolution. Taking its rightful place beside the desktop, laptop and palmtop is the wrist-top. The Wrist PDA watch, due in February for $145 from Fossil, is a tiny data organizer that accepts information beamed via infrared from your Palm. A four-way rocker switch lets you navigate the menus and icons on the black-and-white, backlighted screen.

title: Metro Matters; Remembrance In the Capital Of Resilience
description: WHAT is it like in New York now, people ask, and you try to tell them, but nothing quite conveys it.

title: A Nation Challenged
description: The Die-Hards

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASSERMAN, FRANK
description: WASSERMAN-Frank. On November 21, 2001. Beloved husband of Florence. Devoted father of Patti, Micki and Karen. Loving brother of Irving. Cherished grandfather and great-grandfather. Services Friday, 10:30AM at ''Gutterman's'' 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Nicaragua: Farmers Losing Crops
description: The drought that wiped out corn and bean crops for hundreds of thousands of subsistence farmers is part of a prolonged crisis that has left many Nicaraguans dependent on emergency food aid, a World Food Program study said. It said Nicaragua's dry zones concluded that while most farmers will have a modestly productive second harvest, it will not be enough to overcome the setbacks of natural disasters and falling agricultural prices.

title: Ground Zero Cleanup Jobs Prove Slow to Materialize
description: A city-financed program seeking work for welfare recipients and dislocated workers has recruited at least 150 people for $9-an-hour cleanup jobs at or near the World Trade Center site.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: UNITED NATIONAL BANCORP, Bridgewater, N.J., operator of UnitedTrust Bank's 35 branches, agreed to buy Vista Bancorp Inc., Phillipsburg, N.J., operator of 10 branches in New Jersey and 6 in Pennsylvania, for $151.8 million in cash and stock.

title: Sluggish Internet? Diagnosing the Problem
description: Q. Why does the Internet seem so slow at times?

title: Interpublic And PepsiCo Settling Suits
description: PepsiCo and the world's largest advertising agency company, the Interpublic Group of Companies, settled a legal battle yesterday stemming from PepsiCo's efforts to restrict an Interpublic agency in working for its main competitor, the Coca-Cola Company, after PepsiCo dismissed the agency.

title: When Big Brother Is Watching, A Device Watches Back
description: Until recently, only paranoids and fugitives thought they were under surveillance. But according to CCS International, a New York company that provides security and monitoring services, the average working person in New York City is recorded about 73 times a day.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Little Rain So Far
description: The scant rain that fell earlier this week did little to relieve dry conditions in the eastern and central parts of the state. The rain on Tuesday amounted to .06 of an inch, adding little to the month's below-normal total of about .30 of an inch, Bob Kilpatrick, a hydrometeorologist for the National Weather Service, said yesterday. Average November rainfall is 2.23 inches. In New Jersey, officials issued a drought warning yesterday for towns in 13 counties, asking residents and businesses in affected areas to curb unnecessary water use. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Once Proudly Carried, and Now Mere Carrion
description: A MACABRE spectator sport has emerged in the mobile communications industry: identifying devices that may become relics of the heady days of the 1990's wireless boom.

title: In America; Hunger in the City
description: If you're interviewing people lined up at soup kitchens and food pantries in New York City, many will offer you their phone numbers and ask if you know where they might find work. Politely, quietly, often a little desperately, they'll ask you to let them know ''if you hear of something.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Arrested In Rooftop Death
description: A homeless man with a history of mental illness killed a homeless woman by punching her in the throat and later threw her body from a Brooklyn rooftop, the police said. Officers arrested the man, Clifton Goring, 19, and said he had been arguing with the woman, Terana Street, 33, over a place to sleep on the roof of 302 Eastern Parkway about 10:45 p.m. Tuesday. The punch apparently killed Ms. Street, and Mr. Goring fled, the police said. They said he returned and, after removing Ms. Street's pants, threw her body from the roof. Mr. Goring was charged in October with setting fire to a mattress in the psychiatric ward of Kings County Hospital Center.

title: Saudi Sees No bin Laden-Iraq Link
description: Saudi Arabia's former intelligence chief said today that his government had seen no evidence that the Iraqi government had provided support to Osama bin Laden's Al Qaeda network. He said Saudi Arabia would not support making Iraq a military target of the war on terrorism.

title: New Anthrax Evidence
description: After a period of relative quiet on the bioterrorism front, two developments over the past week could give investigators new leads to help resolve some of the most puzzling aspects of the continuing anthrax crisis.

title: High-Flying Suns Pull Knicks Back to Earth
description: One night after frolicking in what seemed like a therapeutic blowout of the Golden State Warriors, the Knicks were knocked back into their sad reality by the Phoenix Suns.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, DORIS (GNAUCK)
description: WHITE-Doris (Gnauck). Science educator, biochemical and biophysics researcher, age 74, of Annandale, NJ, formerly of Bernardsville on November 19, 2001. Former wife of Donald Lawrence White, Sr. of Morris Plains, NJ. Devoted mother of Stanley of Hardwick, MA, Dean of Franklinton, NC; Victor of Altadena, CA and Donald Lawrence White, Jr. of Wake Forest, NC. Sister of Alice Ehley of Riverside, CA. Grandmother of Simon and Evan of Hardwick, MA and Matthew of Franklinton, NC. A Memorial Service will be held Saturday November 24, 2001 at 11:00AM in the Bernardsville United Methodist Church, 22 Church Street, Bernardsville, NJ. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the organization of your choice.

title: Kiprusoff and Yashin Give Isles the Edge
description: Islanders defenseman Marko Kiprusoff had barely enough time to steal a glance to his right. He saw Aleksei Yashin cruise over the blue line just behind him. Kiprusoff knew Yashin would find a way to get to the goal. Why should tonight be any different?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEBLASS, PETER GERARD
description: DeBLASS-Peter Gerard. Retired business owner, died at his home on November 19, 2001. His son Peter Michael, daughter Rachelle, and brother Eugene mourn the passing of their beloved father and brother. Family will receive friends at Ortiz Funeral Home, 235 West 72 St, Friday, November 23, from 3 P.M. to 9:30 P.M. Memorial Mass will be held on Saturday at 9:30 A.M., Church of Our Savior, 59 Park Avenue, N.Y., New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMMONS, SAMUEL I.
description: SIMMONS-Samuel I. Temple Beth-El of Great Neck records with profound sorrow the passing of its longtime member. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family. Franklin S. Abrams, President Jerome K. Davidson, Rabbi

title: World Briefing | Asia: Cambodia: No Visas For Adopted Babies
description: The United States Embassy announced that it would not issue visas to any of the 11 Cambodian babies adopted by Americans who have been stranded there because of questions over the backgrounds of the children. The embassy said a two-month investigation had found ''compelling evidence'' that all the babies had been bought or stolen by middlemen who then passed them off as orphans. Previously Cambodia was the ninth-largest source of foreign babies adopted by Americans, with nearly 100 a month. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Alliance Strikes Taliban Troops Outside Kabul
description: Northern Alliance soldiers attacked a stranded and desperate Taliban force early this morning here, about 12 miles west of Kabul.

title: A NATION CHALLENGED
description: Saudi View on Iraq

title: Airports Sleep Through Chase for the Turkey
description: The line to get home for Thanksgiving was mercifully short at the checkpoints in Hartsfield International Airport today -- a mere 15 minutes -- so the waiting passengers were cheerful enough to speculate whether Julie Isom's rhubarb pie would make it through security.

title: Windows XP Users Learn To Switch, Not Fight
description: Learning a new version of the Windows operating system on the job can feel like taking that first horseback-riding lesson during the Kentucky Derby, but for newcomers to Windows XP (or those thinking about upgrading) there is a slow lane. An instructional program, Professor Teaches Windows XP, by Individual Software, will gently lead users through the new features and components of Microsoft's latest operating system with interactive lessons that include exercises, quizzes and plenty of graphics.

title: GUIDANT SHARES CLIMB 8% ON HEART-DEVICE STUDY
description: Shares in the Guidant Corporation, which makes implantable heart defibrillators, rose about 8 percent yesterday after a study showed the devices cut deaths by 30 percent in heart attack survivors, potentially expanding the $1.9 billion market for the implants. The results, which were not expected until late next year, were so positive that a safety board halted the trial early so all patients in the study could have access to the defibrillators, which monitor and restore normal heart rhythm. Shares rose $3.48, to $50.30. The devices, which generally cost $25,000 to $28,000, are designed to prevent sudden cardiac arrest, which causes about 400,000 deaths in the United States each year, the company said.

title: DiFrancesco Says He Saved State Nearly $500 Million
description: Faced with a ballooning budget deficit, Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco announced today that he had curtailed state spending by nearly $500 million and that an audit of last year's budget had identified an additional surplus of $220 million. This $720 million in savings, Mr. DiFrancesco's aides suggested, would leave Governor-elect James E. McGreevey well positioned to balance the budget in coming months.

title: Birthing the Internet: Letters From the Delivery Room
description: AQuestion of Semantics

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Local Foods That Please The Soul
description: THE word cheer just doesn't sum it up this year as the holidays approach. We've had a death in our family this fall, along with the whole world's sorrows, and I feel too sad to hum carols and to shop.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWENTHAL, MILTON, DR.
description: LOWENTHAL-Milton, Dr. At age 84, on November 20, 2001. Proud father of Edward, Susan, Jane, Andrew, & Amy. Devoted fatherin-law of Ilene and Sharon. Loving grandfather to Deborah, Jennifer, David, Jared, Lauren, Joshua, Jeremy, Jason, Daniel, and Sarah. Beloved brother of Janet. He was a healer, a scholar and teacher, and a baker. He cared deeply for people in need. He inspired us and challenged our ideas. He will be greatly missed. Private services will be held. In lieu of flowers, donations to The New York University School of Medicine, 550 First Avenue, New York, NY 10016-6497.

title: Philip Morris Identity Crisis Never Seems To Go Away
description: It could be a wake-up call for Philip Morris.

title: American Icons: My Flag and My S.U.V.
description: To the Editor:

title: Feeding the Hungry, Spiritually and Spiritedly
description: IT is never too early to begin the battle for young hearts and minds, as both the people from French's foods and Julia A. Erickson know.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in World Business yesterday about the Enron Corporation's prospects for selling its interest in the Dabhol Power project in India misstated the size of its stake. It is 65 percent, not 70.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAM, DR. LEONARD
description: BRAM-Dr. Leonard. On November 21, 2001. Beloved husband of Carolyn Bram. Dear father of Benjamin, Jonathan and Elizabeth and father-in-law of Susan. Adored grandfather of Nathan and Henry. Loving brother of Melvin Bram. Services Friday, November 23, 12:45 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIENER, GERTRUDE RODMAN
description: WIENER-Gertrude Rodman. On Nov. 20, 2001 at age 92. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Alexander S. Wiener. Beloved mother of Jane Einhorn & the late Barbara Krevit. Adored grandmother of Gretchen, Nina, David, Ilana and Edward. Loving great-grandmother of 12 children. Business manager of her husband's hematological practice. Her strength and love are an example to us all.

title: French Steel Maker Moves Closer to Takeovers
description: Usinor of France breathed new life today into its faltering $2.76 billion bid to acquire two European rivals and become the world's largest steel maker by sweetening the takeover terms and winning approval for the merger from European Union regulators in Brussels.

title: The Deepest Thanks
description: At dinner today all across the country, someone will offer to say a few words -- a prayer, a toast, an informal welcome -- after everyone has been seated. Most Americans will find that the language of thanks has an unaccustomed eloquence this year. The words haven't changed. We have. We come together today truly hoping to have our most heartfelt thanks articulated, and so we hear what we wish we were able to say in the poor words that are actually spoken.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHULMAN, MAX
description: SHULMAN-Max. The trustees, faculty and staff of NYU Medical Center mourns the passing of our cherished friend, devoted supporter and generous benefactor, Max Shulman. Mr. Shulman provided invaluable support to NYU Medical Center's Department of Urology. He was an exceptional individual who will be missed by all. We send our heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Sylvia Shulman; their children, Gail Koster and Lloyd Shulman; his sister, Ethel Weiss; and his grandchildren, Melinda Koster and Jonathan Koster. Kenneth G. Langone, Chairman NYU School of Medicine Foundation Board of Trustees NYU Hospitals Board of Trustees Robert M. Glickman, M.D. Dean, NYU School of Medicine CEO, NYU Hospitals Center Theresa A. Bischoff, President NYU Hospitals Center Herbert Lepor, M. D., Chairman Department of Urology NYU School of Medicine

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Service Industry Slumping
description: Service providers, long immune to the technology-driven downturn overseas, have fallen into their worst slump in nearly four years. An index tracking sales at telecommunications carriers, airlines and other service companies fell 0.9 percent in September from August, completing the first three-month slide since 1997. The decline, combined with falling exports of electronics, machinery and steel, makes it likely that Japan's gross domestic product figures for July to September, to be released on Dec. 7, will show another contraction. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONOVAN, ROBERT S.
description: DONOVAN-Robert S. On November 21, 2001. Beloved husband of Helen M. (nee McGann). Reposing at Gannon Funeral Home, 152 E. 28 St, NYC on Friday 2-5PM. Funeral Mass Epiphany Church, 22nd St & 2nd Ave, NYC at 10am on Saturday. Interment St. Joseph's Cemetery, Auburn NY.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Guatemala: Assassination Witness Stabbed
description: A witness who helped convict three Guatemalan military men for the assasination of a crusading bishop was stabbed and injured while in prison, Amnesty International said. Gilberto Gmez Limn, in prison on an unrelated charge, was stabbed by someone with easy access to his cell, the rights group said. The three military men are appealing their conviction earlier this year for the murder of Bishop Juan Jos Gerardi, who was bludgeoned to death after he issued a report that blamed the military for most of the murders and atrocities during Guatemala's 36-year civil war.

title: Bigotry Against Muslims
description: To the Editor:

title: SVENSKA CELLULOSA BUYS ENCORE PAPER COMPANY
description: The tissue maker Svenska Cellulosa said yesterday that it had bought the Encore Paper Company for $92 million to increase its market share in the United States. Encore, based in South Glens Falls, N.Y., has annual production capacity of 85,000 tons, said Svenska, which is based in Stockholm. More than half of Encore's annual sales of about $85 million come from paper towels, and it has posted 10 percent annual sales growth in the last five years.

title: Pentagon Commits More Forces to War
description: The Pentagon continues to bolster its forces near Afghanistan, asking Uzbekistan to accept three gunships and planning to base warplanes in two other Central Asian nations. The aim is to intensify pressure on the shrinking havens still held by Taliban and Al Qaeda forces.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: New London: Survey On Women's Earnings
description: A census survey says that Connecticut women earn about 62 cents for every dollar earned by a man, despite the state's having the highest household income in the nation. The survey, released Tuesday, indicates that the median earnings for women is $23,905, versus $38,441 for men. A spokeswoman for the state's Commission on the Status of Women attributed the gap to many women staying home to care for children. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: India, Too, Weighs Antiterror Measure Against Liberties
description: As Americans debate how ruthless a war to wage against terrorism, India's leaders have seized on the Sept. 11 attacks to push a draconian new antiterror law that has stirred furious opposition and promises to dominate the winter session of Parliament that began here this week.

title: Manager Says Tyson Will Face Lewis
description: Mike Tyson will fight the heavyweight boxing champion Lennox Lewis in April, Tyson's manager, Shelley Finkel, said yesterday.

title: Fassel Has the Giants' Optimism Well Above the .500 Level
description: Once a week during the season, usually on Wednesday mornings, Jim Fassel delivers what might be best described as an attitude speech to his assembled team. It was in one of these addresses last season -- the one-year anniversary is Thursday -- that Fassel let his players in on the secret that he was going to guarantee a spot in the playoffs publicly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, NANCY
description: KAPLAN-Nancy. The Inn of Court of the Federal Bar Council expresses its profound sorrow at the death of Nancy Kaplan. We extend our deepest sympathies to our colleague, Judge Lewis Kaplan, and his family.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Steel Maker Cuts Outlook
description: The Nippon Steel Corporation, Japan's largest steel maker, cut its profit outlook for the year by 35 percent as it scrambled to cut production amid falling exports and a sagging domestic construction industry. Nippon Steel, which controls more than a third of the crude steel market, now expects to earn 13 billion yen ($106 million) in the year ending March 2002. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: ONLINE DIARY
description: Holiday Phrasebook

title: Lincoln's Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Man Accused Of Anthrax Threat
description: Federal prosecutors have accused a former postal worker of mailing a letter to a congresswoman in an envelope containing white powder. The letter was received Monday, and its contents tested negative for anthrax spores. The worker, Willard Franklin of Peekskill, placed his correct return address on the envelope, which contained a letter complaining about an injury that he said should have been covered by workers' compensation. The letter was addressed to the Mount Kisco office of Representative Sue W. Kelly. Mr. Franklin's lawyer denied the charges, which carry a potential life sentence.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article and a picture caption in Science Times on Tuesday about a forensic team that is reinvestigating the Boston Strangler murders of the early 1960's misstated its arrangement. The scientists and lawyers, led by James E. Starrs, a law professor at George Washington University, are working as volunteers with the families of Albert DeSalvo, long identified as the strangler, and of Mary Sullivan, a victim; they were not hired by the families.

title: Mixed Signals From Russia On Prospects for Oil Cutbacks
description: Russia sent mixed signals today but no definitive word on whether it would cooperate with other oil exporters outside OPEC in cutting production.

title: Florida Disbars F. Lee Bailey Over Stock Funds
description: F. Lee Bailey, the lawyer who gained fame nearly 40 years ago for his defense of Dr. Sam Sheppard, was disbarred today in Florida.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Argentina: Union Chief Urges Protests
description: Hugo Moyano, the Teamsters union leader, called for a national civil disobedience campaign to protect health insurance for pensioners and wage bonuses. The protests would also oppose a plan he says the government is preparing that would replace the peso with the dollar. With the government struggling to meet payments on its $132 billion debt, Economy Minister Domingo Cavallo and other senior officials recently said they would prefer dollarization to a major devaluation in the event of a total financial collapse.

title: 1.3 Million New Jersey Drivers To Pay More for Auto Insurance
description: Automobile insurance rates will rise for 1.3 million New Jersey drivers as a result of recent settlements between state regulators and insurers, including in some cases a revamping of systems that vary rates according to drivers' records.

title: The Brains Behind The Raiders Is Gruden
description: It is a beautiful November day and only Jon Gruden's boyish smile is brighter than the blue sky. Gruden, the Oakland coach, is standing near a lush practice field, talking about the Raiders' grit. He is clearly fond of this team -- maybe the best in the American Football Conference -- his voice rising with pride when he gushes that the Raiders are going places few thought they would when the season began.

title: Routine Surgery, 3 Deaths and a Mystery
description: Health officials of Minnesota and the federal government are struggling to determine what killed two of three healthy men who died suddenly within the last 11 days while recovering from routine knee surgery in Minnesota hospitals.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Forever Greens?

title: Now if You Can Only Download An MP3 of 'Born to Be Wild'
description: Road-trippers with an ingrained reluctance to ask for directions may soon have a face-saving alternative. Rand McNally has managed to squeeze road maps for the 48 contiguous states into a 16-megabyte Secure Digital, or S.D., card about one inch square.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: There's Life After Pumpkins

title: French Writer Explores Two Cultures Entwined
description: When Annie Cohen-Solal took the position of France's cultural counselor in New York in 1989, her first unexpected discovery was that she felt more comfortable with the American cultural model than with the French. Her job was to promote French culture across the United States, but the freedom and eclecticism of American culture better suited her cosmopolitan background.

title: A Piano, a Voice and the Hours Between Dusk and Dawn
description: The soprano Rene Fleming and the pianist Jean-Yves Thibaudet have recorded an appealing thematic program called ''Night Songs'' (Decca), in which they offer various ruminations on night (literal and allegorical) through late 19th- and early 20th-century German, French and Russian songs. On Saturday evening Ms. Fleming and Mr. Thibaudet performed most of that material, and a few other pieces, in a joint recital at Carnegie Hall.

title: Bush Says War May Go Beyond Afghan Border
description: Speaking to a roaring crowd of soldiers who could be among those sent to fight in Afghanistan if America increases its forces there, President Bush threatened more strongly than ever today that the United States would take its battle against terrorism to other nations.

title: Birthing the Internet: Letters From the Delivery Room; Disputing a Claim
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Some Special Thank-You Notes
description: IN sports, Thanksgiving has a greater meaning this year. It's still a time to thank those who make sports' little corner of the world a better place. But since Sept. 11, many have earned special thank-you notes for honoring those who died and for drying the tears of the rescue workers as ground zero continues to smolder:

title: Breakup Bucks Trend In Mining
description: The Australian mining company WMC Ltd. rejected today a $5.8 billion takeover proposal from Alcoa, a partner since the 1960's, calling the offer inadequate.

title: Missing a Sure Grand Slam And Going Down Instead
description: Two groups of world champions were ahead here today in two major events at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals.

title: Taliban's Brand of Zeal May Survive Their Rule
description: There are worse places to be than in an Afghan jail, though none immediately spring to mind.

title: Kidd and Van Horn Lift Nets in Overtime
description: For the second straight game, Jason Kidd willed his sagging team into overtime, and tonight's contest against Karl Malone and the Utah Jazz had the atmosphere of a fight in which the Nets took -- and made -- the last shot.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Trump Begins Negotiations On $1.3 Billion in Bond Debt

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEILBRUNN, ROBERT H.
description: HEILBRUNN-Robert H. The Long Island University family is saddened by the loss of Robert Heilbrunn, a true friend, honorary alumnus and recipient of the University's highest tribute, an honorary doctorate. Together with his beloved wife Harriet, Bob embraced our vision of access and excellence in higher education and shared his good fortune by establishing endowed scholarships for countless students, so that they, too, would have an opportunity to seek the American dream. His heart had no boundaries and will touch lives for generations to come. We extend our condolences and sympathy to Harriet, our alumna, to his daughters, Helaine and Joan, to his sons-in-law, Sidney and Robert, and to his grandchildren and great-grandson. David J. Steinberg, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAMSEY, NINA
description: RAMSEY-Nina. On November 18, 2001, at age 43. Beloved wife of Gregory. Devoted daughter of Si and the late Nancy Friedman and stepdaughter of Margaret Friedman. Dear sister of Mark Friedman and adoring aunt of James Friedman. Interment private. Memorial service to be announced.

title: Gift Wrap Is More Than the Sum of Its Parts
description: IT'S difficult now to isolate the precise instant in my family's history when we began to consider the act of wrapping gifts an art form.

title: Relief Groups Seek a Peacekeeping Force for Afghanistan
description: Human rights organizations urged today that an international military force be sent soon to Afghanistan to prevent chaos and bloodshed and ease the way to a post-Taliban government more fair to women.

title: Connecticut Woman, 94, Is Fifth To Die From Inhalation Anthrax
description: A 94-year-old woman from Oxford, Conn., who had mysteriously contracted inhalation anthrax died this morning as dozens of law enforcement and medical investigators began searching for clues as to how the widow who rarely left her house had become the country's fifth recent anthrax fatality.

title: Robert H. Heilbrunn, 93, Philanthropist
description: Robert H. Heilbrunn, an investor and philanthropist, died on Sunday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. He was 93 and lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: Columbia-Fordham Is Today
description: Columbia and Fordham will make up the football game originally scheduled for Sept. 15 at 11 a.m today at Jack Coffey Stadium on the Fordham campus in the Bronx.

title: Bronx Priest Fights for Jamaica's Poor
description: If geography had been a seminary requirement, Richard Albert might not have found his life's mission. Living at a Brooklyn rectory and about to be ordained a Franciscan priest in 1976, he applied for an assignment in Jamaica and went to discuss it with his superior.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies yesterday about a community forum in Dearborn, Mich., about the Justice Department's plans to interview 5,000 Middle Eastern men misstated the name of the organization whose regional director, Imad Hamad, questioned the plan. It is the American-Arab Anti-Discrimination Committee, not the American Arab Anti-Defamation League.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Nintendo Sees First-Half Gain
description: The Nintendo Company, the maker of the GameCube and Game Boy video game players, earned a net 34.3 billion yen ($279 million) in the fiscal half-year ended Sept. 30, a 14.3 percent increase over the year-earlier period, as it took advantage of a decline in electronic component prices. The company's sales jumped 18 percent on demand for its Pokmon game cards and other character goods. Nintendo introduced its GameCube console in Japan in September and last Sunday in the United States, where 700,000 units have already been sold. The company expects to earn 130 billion yen ($1.1 billion) for the year. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Corrections

title: A Designer's Flair on Display At a Furniture Store in the Village
description: Steven Sclaroff, a New York interior designer, will open a retail store tomorrow in the West Village where he will offer a mix of 20th-century American, Italian and French furniture, lighting and accessories. Many of the pieces he has taken from his own collection and refinished or, in some cases, remodeled according to his own taste. The French bar cabinet from the 1950's (below), in black lacquer and satinwood, has new legs and is 53 inches wide, 49 inches high and 17 inches deep. It costs $3,400. New table lamps, designed by Mr. Sclaroff and made of wood and glass in different colors (on top of the cabinet), are $1,050 each. A Renaissance-inspired hall chair, made in New York around 1900 (left), costs $1,495. The store, called Steven Sclaroff, is at 801 Greenwich Street (Jane Street).

Morgan Stanley is subleasing 150,000 square feet from another tenant in the building, Getty Images, according to Stephen Meiskin, president of Plymouth Partners, who represented Getty in the negotiations. The mill in Decatur, Ala., began operating in 1997. Nucor's purchase is subject to approval from the court and regulators, Nucor said. Shares rose $1.08, to $46.68.

After a final effort to leave the jury in Manhattan federal court with a favorable opinion of their star witness in the price-fixing trial of A. Alfred Taubman, the former chairman of Sotheby's auction house, prosecutors completed the presentation of their evidence yesterday and turned the case over to the defense for what is expected to be a final week of testimony.

title: National Briefings | Health And Science: Warmest October On Record
description: Scientists said last month was the warmest October on record, based on an average of surface temperatures around the world. The new high was noteworthy because there had been no El Nino warming in the Pacific Ocean to help raise temperatures, said the National Climatic Data Center in Asheville, N.C. The average temperature for the month was 58.2 degrees, a degree warmer than the October mean from 1880 to 2000. The findings are consistent with the conclusion of most climatologists that a global warming trend is at least partly caused by releases of heat-trapping gases. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

title: Microsoft's Top Lawyer Sets Retirement
description: William H. Neukom, the legal field general in Microsoft's antitrust conflicts, said yesterday that he would retire next year. His announcement came on the heels of two major settlements engineered this month by Mr. Neukom and his team --both regarded as victories for Microsoft -- and as the company's antitrust problems appear to be finally receding.

Palestinians said the boys had been killed by an unexploded tank shell, a remnant of recent fighting, but the Israeli authorities said that a Palestinian explosive might be to blame.

description: New York City agencies are scrambling to make 15 percent cuts needed to close this year's $1 billion budget shortfall, but those cuts will do little to lessen next year's gap, which is expected to be about $4 billion, experts said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAPA, EDITH
description: CAPA-Edith, 88. The beloved wife of Cornell Capa, died at home in New York City on November 21 after a long illness. She was born in Budapest, Hungary, on May 3, 1913, the daughter of Lawrence and Hani Schwartz. Edith married Cornell Capa in 1940; in January 2001 they celebrate their sixty-first wedding anniversary. For more than 30 years Edith accompanied Cornell, a distinguished photographer for ''Life'' magazine and a member of the Magnum photo agency, on his assignments throughout the world. She also aided Cornell vitally in his projects that led, in 1974, to his founding of the International Center of Photography, in New York. For many years Edith single-handedly organized and maintained not only her husband's negatives and archives but also those of Cornell's late brother, Robert Capa, who was killed on assignment in Indochina in 1954. Furthermore, for hundreds of photographers from around the world Edith served as a kind of surrogate mother, always ready to provide a home away from home. Although Cornell and Edie have no children, they have a vast and loving extended family of honorary sons and daughters. Edie is survived by her husband, Cornell; by a sister, Miriam Siegel, of Lutz, FL; as well as by numerous nieces and nephews. Her funeral service will take place at Plaza Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue at 91 Street, in Manhattan, on Monday, November 26, at 11:00 AM.

title: Fierce Fighting Erupts Near Kunduz, Despite Surrender Deal
description: Heavy fighting broke out today between Taliban and Northern Alliance troops along the front lines outside Kunduz as a senior alliance leader said Taliban officials had agreed to surrender the encircled city, where thousands of Taliban troops and foreign soldiers are trapped.

title: 24 Cow Clones, All Normal, Are Reported by Scientists
description: Scientists at Advanced Cell Technology in Worcester, Mass., say they have created 24 cloned cows that are normal in every way, an assertion that challenges the widely held view that cloned animals are prey to a host of defects.

title: New Views On Classics
description: A flock of old films is going into the release mix this week and next. With nearly an hour added to the 1979 original, Francis Ford Coppola's ''Apocalypse Now Redux,'' issued on Tuesday by Paramount, becomes ''richer, stranger and more coherent,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. Next Tuesday Kino will release ''The Blue Angel'' (1930) in both the English and German versions on DVD. For sheer aplomb, nothing beats Marlene Dietrich's screen test, one of a half-dozen extra features.

title: Bravery at Home
description: President Bush says veterans should talk to schoolchildren about their experiences during World War II. A fine idea, but I think that those of us who were children on the home front during that war have something to tell, too.

title: Lifting the Veil On a Far-Off World
description: BY now, anyone who reads the newspapers is aware that Kandahar is the name of the city in southern Afghanistan that has become known as the Taliban's main stronghold. It is also the name of an extraordinary film by the Iranian director Mohsen Makhmalbaf that was shown at this year's Cannes and Toronto film festivals and which will be released in New York next month. When I saw ''Kandahar'' at Cannes in May, I was transfixed by its images and moved by its story of an exiled Afghan woman venturing back into her native country to search for her sister. The world it depicted seemed, to me and to other Westerners in attendance, far away and even -- in part because of the lyricism Mr. Makhmalbaf brings to his grimmest pictures of war and deprivation -- exotic.

title: Kai Althoff
description: Anton Kern Gallery

title: Two Bushes and the Everglades
description: Nearly one year has passed since President Clinton signed into law a $7.8 billion measure to restore the Florida Everglades. The bill commanded overwhelming bipartisan support and provided the framework for the most ambitious ecosystem recovery project in history. Because the costs will be shared equally by the federal and state governments, the responsibility for getting this momentous undertaking off to a solid start rests squarely with President Bush and his brother Jeb, the governor of Florida. And that has made many friends of the Everglades a bit nervous.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Scotland: New Leader For Parliament
description: Jack McConnell, leader of the Scottish Labor Party, was elected first minister of the Scottish Parliament to replace Henry McLeish, who stepped down two weeks ago in a scandal over office expenses. The Edinburgh legislature was created in 1999 along with the Welsh National Assembly and the Northern Ireland Assembly in Prime Minister Tony Blair's program to cede the British Parliament's power over local matters to regions of the United Kingdom. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Namibia: Threat To Shoot Dismays Rights Group
description: The National Society of Human Rights condemned the minister of defense, Erkki Nghimtina, for threatening to shoot anyone found to be collaborating with rebels from neighboring Angola. Namibia has suffered from attacks by Angolan rebels ever since it decided to allow Angolan soldiers to fight the rebels from Namibian soil. The human rights group condemned the minister's remarks saying such government action would violate the constitution, which bans the death penalty.

title: Russian Paper Finds Indicted Businessman
description: A Russian newspaper has tracked down Andrei Koudachev, the Russian businessman who was indicted in the United States after $105 million of investors' money vanished when his currency trading firm in the World Trade Center closed after the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Kazakhstan: President Fires Reform Advocates
description: President Nursultan Nazarbayev has dismissed six government officials including the deputy prime minister, the deputy defense minister and the labor minister, who had joined a group calling for democratic political reforms. The dismissals were demanded by Prime Minister Kasymzhomart Tokayev, who had threatened to resign. The prime minister's ultimatum followed an announcement by the officials of their creation of a political movement called Democratic Choice aimed at decentralizing power. Mr. Tokayev called them unprofessional and said the movement's call for reform was a ruse masking the true aim of some of its founders to enrich themselves. Birgit Brauer (NYT)

title: A Parade Steeped in Pageantry, With a Core of Patriotism
description: There were the usual swarms of clowns, the high-kicking cheerleaders and the puffed-up cartoon characters sailing through canyons of steel and glass. But for all its relentless levity and unapologetic commercialism, yesterday's 75th annual Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade was partly transformed by patriotic pomp and recast as a raucous affirmation of New York's resilience in the face of tragedy.

Graveside service at the New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, Long Island at 1:00, Sunday, November 25th. Memorial service to be announced.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Death In A Fire
description: A 21-year-old man fell to his death last night on the Upper West Side after he slipped trying escape a fire in his single room occupancy hotel by sliding down a drainpipe, the police said. The unidentified man lived on the eighth floor at 2612 Broadway and reached the drainpipe through his window, said Sgt. Marian Messina, a police spokeswoman. The man died on the street and there were no other injuries reported, she added. Charlie LeDuff (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Insurer Files For Bankruptcy
description: The Taisei Fire and Marine Insurance Company, Japan's 12th-largest casualty insurer, filed for bankruptcy yesterday because of claims stemming from the terrorist attacks in the United States. The insurer, which planned to merge with Yasuda Fire and Marine Insurance and Nissan Fire and Marine Insurance next April, said its liabilities exceeded assets by 40 billion yen ($325 million). The company held 74 billion yen ($602 million) in claims related to the attacks in September, analysts estimated. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRUHL, ANNE
description: STRUHL-Anne. The Yeshiva of North Jersey, its Executive Board, Board of Directors, faculty and student body mourn the loss of Anne Struhl, matriarch of the Yeshiva's first family, who along with her late husband Teddy, and children and grandchildren, have been the life blood of the Yeshiva for sixty years. Mrs. Struhl was to have graced our annual banquet as guest of honor. Instead, she will will grace the heavenly beings with her presence. Heartfelt condolences to children Bernard and Alice Struhl, and Harold and Miriam Struhl, and grandchildren Warren and Robin Struhl, Teddy & Linda Struhl, Teddy and Phyllis Struhl, Barry Struhl, Lisa and Dean Pastor, Terry Heyman, and Michael Heyman, and greatgrandchildren Adam, Sara, Jessica, Jonathan, Arielle, Jackie and Jacob. title: A Competitor Who Withdrew From the Game

It was not unusual for Gray, a 6-foot-4, 280-pound former offensive tackle for the New England Patriots, to vanish for periods of time. Gray, who would have turned 50 last week, might move and not tell anyone. He would change his telephone number and not tell anyone.

A memorial service will be held at Dorsey-Carlone Funeral Home, Peekskill, N.Y., Monday, November 26, 11 AM, followed by interment at Hillside Cemetery, Cortlandt Manor, NY. 914-737-0848.

title: A Crafty, Deadly Predator

Launched in 1918 from a dolly, it was designed to fly for a fixed length of time, then switch off its engine and jettison its wings, dropping a load of 180 pounds of explosives on its target.

title: Liberty Media Files Kirch Plan

title: Competing Principles Leave Some Professionals Debating Responsibility to Government
description: When the names and photographs were first released, Kathleen Hensman, a public librarian in Delray Beach, Fla., recognized some of the suspected hijackers in the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon as men who had used the computers in her small library.

title: Torch Songs Smoldering Inside an Intimate Hearth
description: If understatement could peak, it would have when Sam Phillips performed at Joe's Pub on Tuesday night. Ms. Phillips never let her songs rise above a hush. She stood utterly still with a dazed, deadpan stare, carefully wafting each smoky note of her melodies, while her band played discreetly: Marc Ribot plinking a banjo, Peter Warren floating echoey piano notes or string tones from an old analog keyboard, J. D. Foster barely plucking his bass, Ted Reichman making accordion chords materialize from afar.

title: Compassion in the Eye of a Storm
description: At one point in ''Jung (War) in the Land of the Mujahedeen,'' Gino Strada, an Italian doctor whose attempt to build a hospital near the front lines in northern Afghanistan is the the focus of the film, remarks bitterly that the conflict in that country is a ''forgotten war.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, LAURA
description: KATZ-Laura. On November 21, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Lester Katz. Adored mother of Carolyn and Jason Moss. Proud grandmother of Georgie & Peter Moss, Susan Moss, and fiancee Michael Weiner. Great grandmother of Andrew Moss. Funeral Friday, November 23rd, 11:30 AM at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapels'', 1895 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, New York 11210.

title: As America Gives Thanks, Military Seeks bin Laden, and Surrender
description: Halfway around the world from the family dinners and joyous celebrations of Thanksgiving Day, the war in Afghanistan slogged on. Northern Alliance forces launched an attack on Kunduz, the Taliban's last stronghold in the north, after a week of siege and a day of confusion over talks seeking a peaceful surrender.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Takeover Bid To Proceed
description: Usinor of France will proceed with a $2.76 billion takeover to create the world's largest steel maker, after agreeing to let its two smaller partners have a larger share of the combined group. Arbed of Luxembourg and Aceralia of Spain last week demanded better terms, as Usinor's stock price continued to decline since the deal was announced in February. They will now own 46.2 percent of the combined company, or 2.7 percentage points more than originally agreed. Usinor will own the remaining 53.8 percent. Usinor shares rose 10 cents, or 0.8 percent, to 13.15 euros. Aceralia shares climbed 1.3 euros, or 8.6 percent, to 16.51. And Arbed's stock advanced 7.25 euros, or 5.9 percent, to 131 euros. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: New Fork in the Mideast
description: To the Editor:

title: A U.S. Favorite Loses Her Focus and Her Form
description: The ringing in Sarah Schleper's ears is from a volume of advice that has frayed her nerves, along with her position as middleman in the bickering between her coaches and her boyfriend.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, SAMUEL
description: JACOBS-Samuel. Age 95, of Palm Beach, Florida, passed away on November 22 in New York City. He is survived by his loving Millie, sisters Mary Bergofin and Kitty Chepovsky, seven grandchildren and their spouses, fourteen greatgrandchildren, his son-in-law Ernest Rubenstein and daughterin-law Eleanore Jacobs Goodman, and many nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by his first wife Anna and both his children Phyllis Rubenstein and Arthur Jacobs. Born in poverty, Mr. Jacobs achieved great success in the liquor industry as one of the three founding partners of Star Industries, Inc., and as one of the principal shareholders of The Paddington Corporation. Generous to a wide variety of charities, he was particularly dedicated to the Educational Alliance, a lower Eastside Settlement house of which he was the largest and most consistent individual donor over the past 20 years. Funeral services will held on Sunday, November 25th at 11:15 AM, ''the Riverside'', Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street in Manhattan. Contributions in his memory may be sent to the charity of the donor's choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAM, DR. LEONARD
description: BRAM-Dr. Leonard. On November 21, 2001. Beloved husband of Carolyn Bram. Dear father of Benjamin, Jonathan and Elizabeth and father-in-law of Susan. Adored grandfather of Nathan and Henry. Loving brother of Melvin Bram. Services Friday, November 23, 12:45 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: It's a Working Holiday But With a Heaping Plate
description: At the ruins of the World Trade Center, Thanksgiving was a day to keep removing debris, to keep pouring water onto the smoldering wreckage, to keep searching intently through the rubble for anything that might be part of a body. But many of the construction workers, police officers and firefighters who spent yesterday at ground zero said they had no complaints about working through the holiday.

title: Former Mystery Giant Has Thrived in Oakland
description: At a time when Ron Dayne, last year's top draft pick, is still trying to find his way in the Giants' running attack, it will be hard to ignore Tyrone Wheatley, the Giants' first-round draft choice in 1995, in the Oakland backfield on Sunday.

title: Utah G.O.P. Endangers a Democrat
description: With the state's largest concentration of Democrats, non-whites and non-Mormons, metropolitan Salt Lake City sent Jim Matheson to Congress last year, making him the only Utah Democrat to serve in a federal or statewide elected office.

title: Helping Countries, and People, to Heal
description: PAUL VAN ZYL is incredibly sunny for a guy whose job takes him to some of the world's darkest places, delving into their darkest days. As a program director for the International Center for Transitional Justice, Mr. van Zyl helps devise remedies for emerging democracies to reckon with the human rights abuses that mark their past.

title: Fordham Prep Keeps Edge With Victory Over Xavier
description: Fordham Prep defeated Xavier, 28-7, yesterday in the 78th Thanksgiving Day meeting between the schools. The first time the schools met on a football field was in 1905, making theirs the city's oldest rivalry. Fordham Prep leads the series, which was first played on Thanksgiving in 1923, by 42-33, with 3 ties.

title: Pop Embraces The Teleconcert
description: When was the last time you marked your calendar to catch your favorite musical artist on television? Such moments are crucial in the history of tube-gazing. Elvis and the Beatles caused youthquakes on ''The Ed Sullivan Show.'' Teenagers in the 1970's, up past bedtime, admired heavy-metal monsters on ''The Midnight Special.'' So many new stars were anointed on ''Saturday Night Live'' that a guest spot on that show became the Olympic Gold of pop.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUCCHESI, ALIBRAND
description: LUCCHESI-Alibrand. November 19, 2001. Beloved husband of Rose. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St. Friday, November 23, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, November 24, 10AM Our Lady of Peace Church, 237 East 62 Street, New York City. Contributions in his memory may be made to the American Cancer Society or the Masonic Brotherhood Fund.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Mozambique: Homeless A Year After Floods
description: Government officials said they were still struggling to resettle victims who lost their homes during the devastating floods of February and March 2000, the state news agency reported. Roberto White, the minister of public works and housing, said that 145,000 people had been resettled but that 30,000 still lack adequate shelter.

title: Van Horn Rescues Nets From a Late Fade
description: Keith Van Horn had experienced sweet satisfaction Wednesday by sinking the winning shot to lift the Nets over the Utah Jazz in overtime. Tonight, with two teammates sidelined by injury, Van Horn returned to his native state and helped the Nets escape with a 95-90 victory over the Los Angeles Clippers.

title: WITH TARGET LIST, U.S. PRESSES HUNT FOR AFGHAN FOES
description: The American military continued its systematic hunt for Taliban and Al Qaeda leaders in Afghanistan by working down a target list of cave networks where Osama bin Laden is suspected to be hiding, officials said today.

title: U.S. AIRPORT TASK BEGINS WITH HIRING
description: Long before Sept. 11, the federal government knew that the nation's system for screening airport baggage was bad and getting worse.

title: Indigestion:Cap Gemini's Merger Struggles
description: LONDON  On Feb. 29, 2000, Cap Gemini SA, the Paris-based software and computer services company, made its bid to become a global consulting firm, buying the management consultancy business of Ernst & Young, one of the grand old U.S. accounting firms.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I'm thankful I'm alive, but I feel guilty I'm alive. I'm trying to remember the guys who aren't here. Their wives and children. It's a hollow feeling. You try to laugh sometimes to keep your sanity, but you feel bad about laughing.''

title: European Team to Discuss Concerns With Zimbabwe's Leader
description: Top European Union diplomats were to meet with President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe on Friday in a new effort to relay the organization's concerns over his government's intensifying crackdown on critics and its effort to seize white-owned farms.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Another Breed Of Hero

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Airline To Halt Some Flights
description: Japan's largest carrier, Japan Airlines, will halt flights on six routes to Europe and extend the suspension of trans-Pacific flights to offset the decline in air travel. The airline will suspend its four weekly flights between Osaka and Paris and its two weekly Nagoya-London flights through March. The company, which expects to lose 40 billion yen ($325 million) this fiscal year, also trimmed the number of flights from Tokyo. The airline previously suspended about one-quarter of its flights between Japan and the United States, including Hawaii. Those flights will not resume until February or March, the airline said. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Clifton Brown's Scorecard
description: Every two weeks, Clifton Brown ranks the 10 best men and women in professional golf. These rankings are from Nov. 23.

title: An Exhaustive Search for Clues, Down to an Anthrax Victim's Hairpins
description: Dozens of F.B.I. agents and 23 epidemiologists and medical detectives from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention spent Thanksgiving Day poring through the home of Ottilie W. Lundgren in Oxford, looking for elusive clues as to how she contracted the rare, inhaled form of anthrax that killed her on Wednesday.

title: China Tours
description: Pacific Delight Tours has eight China itineraries next March priced $135 to $490 less than rates the rest of the year. They run from 11 to 13 days, and include Yangtze River cruises to the Three Gorges area, Beijing, the Great Wall, Shanghai and the terra cotta warriors in Xian. A 13-day departure from Detroit on March 13 is $2,330 a person, based on double occupancy. Two March departures from Los Angeles for 13-day trips are $1,940. Prices of the other tours range from $1,890 to $2,420. These rates include all accommodations, the cruise fare, all meals, round-trip air fare on Northwest, a bilingual tour guide, sightseeing fees, hotel taxes and service charges. Information: (800) 221-7179 or www.pacificdelighttours.com .

title: No Education Is Complete Without Broomsticks 101
description: Harry Potter and The Sorcerer's Stone

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

description: To the Editor:

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of Wednesday, 3,915 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINSON, JO LIST
description: LEVINSON-Jo List. The Board of Trustees, the Sisterhood and the entire membership of Temple Sholom in Greenwich, CT, mourn the passing of Jo List Levinson, daughter of Vera List.

title: Why Does Terror Rear Its Head?
