title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: German Economy Shrinks, Edging Closer to Recession

title: Democracy's Uneasy Steps in Islamic World
description: In a region coping with Islamist movements, tiny Bahrain has made a strategic shift: from ruthlessness to openness.

title: Scott's Quarrel With Malone Pumps Determination into Nets
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 22  Byron Scott grew up 10 minutes from the Forum in Inglewood, a tough section that molded his identity early. There were times as a teenager, he recalled last year in his rookie season as the head coach of the Nets, when bullets whizzed by his head and his friends had to restrain him from jumping into fights to defend them.

title: How to Succeed in Prison Without Serving Time; One-Woman Store Sells Goods to Inmates And Their Visitors for the Trip Upstate
description: The chartered coach idled at the curb, and the cabin stank of engine exhaust. It was an eight-hour ride to the upstate prison, and the women needed more than to just get through it. They needed to get through it looking good.

title: Why Does Terror Rear Its Head?
description: To the Editor:

title: A NATION CHALLENGED
description: TALIBAN EMBASSY CLOSED

title: If Some Say Glory, Others Cry Hubris
description: Was Albert Bierstadt, the 19th-century American painter of visionary Western landscapes, an unconscious racist? Did he take for granted the supremacy of white European settlers over native peoples?

title: 'Saints, Spirits and Strangers'; 'Masks From Malawi'
description: Axis Gallery

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Direct Deutsch, New York, hired two employees. Paula Fedoris was named vice president for data strategy and Claudia Steinhaus was named senior vice president and group account director. Ms. Fedoris had been vice president for customer information management at Goldman, Sachs & Company, New York. Ms. Steinhaus had been a consultant. Direct Deutsch is a unit of Deutsch, part of the Partnership unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: A Spiraling Trip Through Space Without Seat Belts
description: Richard Serra's show was delayed because of the Sept. 11 attacks (the truckers installing the works went to clear rubble), but when it finally opened it helped get people who are interested in art back on the street and talking. The Gagosian Gallery in Chelsea has been packed since then. Thousands of people were there last week. If you want to know why, just take a look.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANCIS, PANAMA
description: FRANCIS-Panama. All his greatness, yet a humble man. A wonderful human being. We share in the loss with his lovely wife Alyce, their family and the music world. Susan and Larry Bauman

title: They're Used to It: A Holiday Without Their Hero
description: Almost everything was in place at Robyn Kelly's Thanksgiving feast. Turkey and trimmings covered a long buffet table, friends had brought their children, and old family pictures hung on the wall. All that was missing were the husbands.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VECCHIONE, EDWARD, JR.
description: VECCHIONE-Edward, Jr. On Nov. 22, 2001 at age 76. Loving brother of Dorothy Martin and cousin of Vincent Lombardi, Marie Pelusso and Lucretia Trisci and companion of the late Lilo Marcus. Dear friend of Bernice & Arthur Weiss and Joan Linsky. Also survived by many nephews, cousins and dear friends. Mr. Vecchione was a member of The Hotel Management Association, a veteran of W.W. II, a prisoner of war and a graduate of Columbia University. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Friday, November 23, 2-4 PM & 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass at Our Lady of Peace Church, 237 East 62 St, Saturday 11:15 AM. Interment to follow at Christ the King Cemetery, Franklin Lakes, NJ. Contributions in his memory may be made to Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, New York 10461.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Militant Separatists Kill 11
description: The police said suspected militants in the northeastern state of Assam killed 11 people yesterday. Guerrillas from the National Democratic Front of Bodoland want statehood for the Bodo tribe and contend that the tribal people's welfare has been neglected. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: London Journal; A Surprise for Blair: There's Life in the Lords Yet
description: Given its habit of doddering and lingering in the past, the House of Lords would seem to be an easy target for Prime Minister Tony Blair's project to bring traditional Britain up to speed.

title: White House Letter; Big Government Is Back in Style
description: Until Sept. 11, Washington had the unmistakable feel of a backwater.

title: World Business Briefing | The Americas: Canada: Merrill Lynch To Sell Unit
description: Merrill Lynch agreed to sell its Canadian retail brokerage and fund-management unit to Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce. Canadian Imperial will pay up to $406 million, depending on how many Merrill brokers join it. A Merrill spokesman, Peter Kahnert, did not elaborate on the price. C.I.B.C.'s chief executive, John Hunkin, like other North America bankers, is pushing into money management as falling stock markets cut fees from merger advice and securities underwriting.

title: New Views on Classics
description: Aflock of old films is going into the release mix this week and next. With nearly an hour added to the 1979 original, Francis Ford Coppola's "Apocalypse Now Redux," issued on Tuesday by Paramount, becomes "richer, stranger and more coherent," A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times . Next Tuesday Kino will release "The Blue Angel" (1930) in both the English and German versions on DVD. For sheer aplomb, nothing beats Marlene Dietrich's screen test, one of a half-dozen extra features.

title: World Briefing
description: AMERICAS

title: A Trial at Ground Zero
description: To the Editor:

title: Oregon, the F.B.I. and Our Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: In Skirmish, Bold Rebel Attack Swerves to Retreat
description: Troops of the Northern Alliance scrambled away in sudden retreat today after launching a misbegotten attack against a stubborn Taliban stronghold near the city of Maidan Shahr, just 12 miles west of Kabul.

title: Why Does Terror Rear Its Head?
description: To the Editor:

title: Elizabeth Peyton
description: Gavin Brown's Enterprise

title: Blair Set to Come Out Strongly for British Integration With Europe
description: Less than six weeks before much of continental Europe adopts the new notes and coins of the euro single currency, Prime Minister Tony Blair is pressing his compatriots to jettison their traditional skepticism toward European integration and see it, instead, as an opportunity to extend their nation's influence.

title: Collapse at Illegal Mine in Colombia Leaves at Least 28 Dead
description: A landslide of mud and rocks swept over gold miners who were illegally excavating a large open pit in central Colombia this morning, killing at least 28 people and trapping dozens of others, rescue officials and survivors said.

title: On the 104th Floor in Two Towers, a Boyfriend and a Brother Are Lost
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Pakistan Closes Down Taliban's Last Link to Outside World
description: The Taliban's last diplomatic link with the outside world was closed today on orders from the Pakistani government, the only country that had still maintained ties with the Islamic militia.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASKETBALL

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-30

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, ERNEST J.
description: NEWMAN-Ernest J., 99. Passed away on November 19. Avid music lover, business man, world traveler and good friend to many, he will be deeply missed.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Editors' Note; Today's Sections
description: News of the Sept. 11 attacks and their aftermath continues to appear in Section B; index, Page B2.

title: The House, The Scandal, The Poet
description: No hint of scandal today disturbs the peaceful decrepitude of the Evergreens, the picturesque Italianate house at 214 Main Street, next door to Emily Dickinson's house, the Homestead.

title: Fugues From a Foursome
description: The excellent Brentano Quartet is making its eager audience think about -- and feel -- how well fugal writing lies on the textures of a conversational medium. On Monday at Merkin Concert Hall, the group gave the second of three programs devoted to fugal quartets, or quartettish fugues (plus some for trio), ending with the biggest of them all: Beethoven's ''Grosse Fuge.''

title: Album of the Week
description: ''TENACIOUS D'' (Epic). A mistake is being made. And as a longtime supporter of Tenacious D, I hate to see it happen. Tenacious D is a musical comedy team consisting of the actors Jack Black and Kyle Gass. For some seven years, they have slowly built a large cult following for their hilarious performances (originally in Los Angeles alternative comedy clubs) and HBO television appearances. The first time I saw them (and the second and third), tears were rolling down my face from laughter.

title: Officials Predict Upturn in Unstable South Korean Economy
description: The volatile South Korean economy is perking up, new forecasts showed today, just as pessimists were predicting a prolonged slump aggravated by the worldwide economic downturn after the terrorist attacks in the United States.

title: The Neediest Cases; Fresh Start in a New Land With the Help of Others
description: Konstantine Rykhlevsky has not seen his wife or three children since leaving them behind in Russia a year and a half ago.

title: Chase and J. P. Morgan's Paper Anniversary; A Year After the Merger, Rosy Plans Meet Reality
description: When William B. Harrison Jr. speaks of last year's $31 billion merger of J. P. Morgan and the Chase Manhattan Corporation, he speaks proudly of a deal that he considers to be a capstone to his 34-year career of helping build a giant of the banking business.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Chip Plant Opened
description: A computer chip maker, the Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corporation, said it had completed construction of its first silicon wafer fabrication plant in Shanghai. The plant is expected to produce 42,500 eight-inch wafers a month when it reaches full capacity by the end of 2003. Semiconductor Manufacturing, led by Richard Chang, a well-known chip industry executive from Taiwan, is among several semiconductor plants being set up in China, part of a trend that analysts say will make China a major player in the industry within 10 years. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Works by Playwrights Too Young to Drink
description: As a critic, one approaches the annual Young Playwrights Festival with the knives tucked safely away in a drawer. One doesn't want to carve up any fledgling talent before it flies the nest. The fact is, the precaution often turns out to be unnecessary; the plays generally rise to high standards.

title: V. Pasechnik, 64, Is Dead; Germ Expert Who Defected
description: Dr. Vladimir Pasechnik, a senior Soviet biologist whose defection in 1989 alerted Western intelligence to the scope of Moscow's clandestine efforts to adapt germs and viruses for military use, died on Wednesday in Wiltshire, England. He was 64 and lived in a nearby village.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Police Protest In Paris
description: Thousands of police officers marched through the capital in the latest of three weeks of police protests. Officers are demanding raises, bulletproof vests and the suspension of new laws giving suspects the right to lawyers, shortening the time they may be held without trial and making it harder to detain witnesses. The recent killing of two officers by an armed robber who had been released despite a long criminal record prompted police fury at what they call the ''hoodlum law.'' Donald G. McNeil Jr. (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOWICZ, MARY ELIZABETH (NEE MONAGHAN)
description: DOWICZ-Mary Elizabeth (nee Monaghan). Of Wall, NJ formerly of New York City on Nov. 21, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Zenon ''George'' Dowicz. Devoted mother of Therese, Celeste, Karen, Michele, Stephen, Christopher, Paul and Andrew. Dear sister of Therese Monaghan, O.P. and Kathleen Monaghan. Loving grandmother of 14 grandchildren. Funeral from the O'Brien Funeral Home, Hwy 35 at New Bedford Rd, Wall, NJ, Monday, November 26th at 11:15 AM. Mass St. Mark's Church, Sea Girt, NJ at 12:15PM. Visiting Saturday, November 24th from 2-4 and 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers memorial donations to the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson Research, Grand Central Station, P.O. Box 4777, NY, NY 10163, would be appreciated.

title: Seeking a Fly to Fool The Crafty Trout
description: Anyone who saw the movie ''A River Runs Through It'' knows about the religion of fly-fishing -- the mystique, the devotion, the incredibly tiny flies cast with such delicacy and devotion to the lovely and noble trout.

title: Attacks at Hubs Could Disrupt Phone Lines
description: Public safety experts and telecommunications executives are growing increasingly concerned about the possibility of attacks on the telephone system, a century-old network of copper wires and newer fiber optic strands that wind their way through critical but vulnerable hubs.

title: Owner of Casual Corner Chain Seen in Deal for Brooks Brothers
description: Brooks Brothers, the retailer of classic American men's wear that popularized the button-down collar, is close to being sold to the owner of the Casual Corner women's apparel chain for about $225 million, executives close to the talks said yesterday.

title: Taliban Expel 100 Journalists, Canceling a Tour of Kandahar
description: The Taliban expelled about 100 foreign journalists today from this town near the Pakistani border, a day after a spokesman for Mullah Muhammad Omar said that the Taliban's spiritual home, Kandahar, was in their control and promised journalists to take them on a visit there.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BLOOM, BERNARD D., DDS.
description: BLOOM-Bernard D., DDS. April 11, 1922 to November 23, 1992. Nine years ago today. Alive in our hearts always. Jack

title: Message Board / Letter to the Technology Editor
description: I tried the route you recommended for Macs. Be advised that Open Door no longer supplies DoorStop personal fire wall for Macs, but has transferred marketing rights for this application to Symantec. Unreasonably, Symantec's price for this is $20 higher than the same product for a PC. I shall not buy one.

title: A Claim to Help Choose Baby's Sex Sets Off Furor in India
description: The advertisement in The Times of India would be easy to overlook. It's small -- not quite 3 by 4 inches -- and features a plump, jolly baby with a fringe of bangs.

title: The Timeless Spell of Empire
description: BY now, the movement of portions of famously stationary museum collections across international borders is a familiar occurrence. In recent years, despite debate about the risk-benefit ratio of such projects, the Hermitage, the Vatican and the Barnes Collection have all sent some of their most important art on the road.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCOOEY, ROBERT H.
description: McCOOEY-Robert H. The Behavioral Health Services Board, Administration and Medical Staff of Saint Vincent Catholic Medical Centers expresses its deep regret upon the passing of Robert H. McCooey. We mourn the loss of a dedicated leader who for 28 years, as member and chairman of our St. Vincent's Westchester Advisory Board, friend and supporter, demonstrated an untiring commitment to our mission that inspired all of us. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his devoted family. Saint Vincent Catholic Medical Centers Edward V. Lahey, Jr., Chairman Behavioral Health Services Board Brian L. Fitzsimmons, Ph.D. Senior Vice President-SVCMC, Pres.-Behavioral Health Services

title: Reynolds Agrees to Buy Santa Fe Natural
description: R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Holdings agreed today to buy Santa Fe Natural Tobacco for $320 million in cash, surpassing a bid from Rothmans of Canada.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLEMENT, ALPHONSE V. JR., M.D.
description: CLEMENT-Alphonse V. Jr., M.D. Died Nov. 19, 2001 surrounded by his family following a lengthy illness. Born to Dr. Alphonse V. Sr. and Constance Cannella Clement on April 25, 1928. Adored husband of Maryjane. Beloved father of Ardith Colonna (Sal), Jeanine Robotti (Bruno), Debra Clement, Gina Fedeli, Anne Walsh Talberth (Jamie) and Thomas Walsh Jr. (Nereida). Devoted Poppy to Maya, Nicholas, Guy, Jennifer, Nicole, Alisha and Daniel. Dr. Clement graduated University of Notre Dame (1949), attended medical school in Bologna, Italy and graduated Temple University School of Medicine, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania (1956). During his thirty years of service to the city of New Rochelle, he was a general practitioner at Sound Shore Medical Center, formerly New Rochelle Hospital Medical Center, from 1963-1993. In addition, he served as City Physician for the Police Department and Board of Education from 1973-1993, and was an active member of the New Rochelle Rotary Club, serving as their president from 1986-1987. He retired to Florida in 1993, but recently returned to New Rochelle. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory to the Hospice of Westchester, The Esplanade, 4th Floor, 95 South Broadway, White Plains, New York, 10601-4403, would be greatly appreciated. Visitation on Friday, November 23 at Lloyd Maxcy Beauchamp Chapel, Shea Place, New Rochelle, N.Y. 10801, 914632-2700, from 2-4 P.M. and 7-9 P.M. Memorial mass will be held Saturday, November 24 at 9:30 A.M. at Blessed Sacrament Church. Interment private.

title: French Prime Minister Now Has Legal Problems of His Own
description: Suddenly it seems that it is French Prime Minister Lionel Jospin, not his archrival, President Jacques Chirac, who is embroiled in legal difficulties.

title: Shades of Surrealism On San Francisco Streets
description: Did San Francisco ever swing with the Surrealists? The city had no Man Ray, no Max Ernst, no Giorgio de Chirico. But once upon a time it did have a photographer called John Gutmann, who took some fantastic pictures that almost always included more than one of the following Surrealist staples: limbs, masks, windows, words, streets, slanting angles. Born in Breslau, Silesia (then part of Germany), Gutmann picked up his Surrealistic sensibility in Berlin, where he was a painter, and took it to San Francisco in the 1930's.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 8.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trade Surplus Shrinks
description: Japan's merchandise trade surplus shrank in October for the 16th consecutive month as exports continued to tumble on the back of weaker demand for electronics, automobiles and machinery worldwide. The country's surplus stood at 463 billion yen ($3.8 billion), 32.9 percent less than in the period a year earlier and a faster decline than expected by economists. Exports fell 9 percent while imports dipped 4.7 percent. The decline in exports, which make up about 10 percent of Japanese gross domestic product, are hurting an already struggling domestic economy. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Cyberspace Seen as Potential Battleground
description: Government officials are warning that cyberattacks are likely as retribution for the United States campaign in Afghanistan, and at the same time, computer security experts are seeing increasingly numerous and more powerful attacks from traditional hackers.

title: Malls Are Tightening Security as the Holiday Rush Begins
description: The life-size harlequin jesters that decorate the sparking atrium at the Water Tower Place Mall in Chicago will be just as dazzling this year as they have been in the past. But in the garage beneath the mall, shoppers might experience a new holiday sensation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, OGDEN NORTHROP, JR.
description: LEWIS-Ogden Northrop, Jr. Suddenly on November 14, 2001, at age 22. Cherished son of Ogden and Susan Lewis, adored nephew of Margaret Patterson High and William Hall Lewis, III. Beloved by countless friends. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory to The Buckley School, 113 East 73 Street, New York, New York 10021, or Groton School, Box 991, Groton, Massachusetts 01450, would be greatly appreciated. Funeral service, Monday, November 26 at 2 PM. St. Thomas Church, 5th Avenue and 53rd Street, NY, NY.

title: Big-Hearted City
description: To the Editor:

title: Wake Forest in Finals Thanks to a Hot Tip
description: Wake Forest might as well have assembled a float and crashed the Thanksgiving Day Parade. The Demon Deacons were the surprise team of the four that advanced to the Preseason National Invitation Tournament semifinals and then knocked off Fresno State, 62-61, in a mild upset late Wednesday night.

title: Blair Urges Britain to Embrace Europe and, Implicitly, the Euro
description: LONDON, Nov. 23  Prime Minister Tony Blair delivered a passionate plea today for closer ties with Europe in a speech that was taken by many as an endorsement of Britain's adoption of the single European currency.

title: A Town Where Football Is the Glue and the Hope
description: The sugar cane harvest is under way, as trucks line up to transport the sweet stalks, acrid fires burn off the leafy undergrowth and smokestacks puff from the sugar mills. In a verdant town where the welcome signs say, ''Her Soil Is Her Fortune,'' this is the money season.

title: Olaf Breuning
description: Metro Pictures

title: We Have The Right Courts for Bin Laden
description: If we should capture Osama bin Laden or his accomplices in the days ahead, where should we try them? Two unsound proposals have recently emerged. The first, and by far more dangerous, is already law: the president's misguided and much criticized order authorizing secret trials before an American military commission. The second, more benign approach, offered by prominent international lawyers, is to try terrorists before an as yet uncreated international tribunal.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ALKOFF, ABRAHAM
description: ALKOFF-Abraham. Nov. 23, 1901-Jan 14, 1984 ''For tho' from out our bourne of Time and Place/ The flood may bear me far,/ I hope to see my Pilot face to face/ When I have crost the bar.'' Happy 100th Birthday. Love, Rene, Jerry, Gay, Rose

title: Reviews of Current Releases
description: For all New York Times film reviews since 1996, go to the Film Archive .

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about John W. Nason, who was president of Swarthmore College during World War II and helped thousands of Japanese-American students leave detention camps and enter colleges, referred incorrectly to his second wife, the former Elizabeth M. Knapp. She is not a survivor; she died in 1998.

title: Bruckner and Shostakovich In a Homecoming Program
description: On Monday night the New York Philharmonic made one of its infrequent visits to the place it used to call home, Carnegie Hall. The orchestra had not played there in two years. Many people within the organization must rue the day that the orchestra was tempted with the prospect of having its own spanking new concert hall in Lincoln Center. Philharmonic Hall, as it was initially called, did not turn out well. After several major renovations and a name change, yet another reconstruction project is being planned to make Avery Fisher Hall an acoustically rewarding place.

title: Cookies and Spam Provide The EU Much to Chew Over
description: PARIS  The European Union's proposal to protect Internet users from an unappetizing meal of cookies and spam has become a lot harder to digest than expected.

title: Chairman Of ABB Hints At Revamping
description: One day after the chairman of ABB, Europe's largest electrical engineering group, resigned unexpectedly, his successor, Jrgen Dormann, acknowledged today that the company had lost ''the credibility of the market'' after a series of reorganizations failed to prevent a drastic slide in its share price or produce profits.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MAHLER, DAVID Q.
description: MAHLER-David Q. A hard and lonely year of remembering and missing you. Grace and the Famil

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: A Duet With a Past

title: 'Urban Pornography'
description: Artists Space

title: Foreign Affairs; Terrorist Software
description: Over coffee the other day here in the gulf, an Arab friend -- a sweet, thoughtful, liberal person -- confided to me something that was deeply troubling him: ''My 11-year-old son thinks bin Laden is a good man.''

title: Not Home for the Holidays
description: Michael Bloomberg, the next mayor of New York City, doesn't intend to live in Gracie Mansion, the traditional 200-year-old residence on the East River. The current incumbent, Rudolph Giuliani, preferred bunking in a friend's apartment to sharing a historic building with his estranged wife. Meanwhile in Albany, the governor's mansion has become a sort of official nonresidence, since George Pataki prefers to live with his wife and children in their 24-room Victorian mansion in Garrison, N.Y.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Menem To Run
description: Former President Carlos Sal Menem announced that he would run for president in the 2003 election, proclaiming himself the only answer to Argentina's deepening economic and financial crisis. Mr. Menem was released from house arrest this week after the Supreme Court ruled that prosecutors had insufficient evidence to back their assertion that he led a conspiracy to sell arms illegally to Croatia and Ecuador between 1991 and 1995 when he was in office. Mr. Menem is expected to be challenged by at least three powerful governors, and his leadership of the Justicialist Party, founded by Juan Domingo Pern in the 1940's, is being contested by one of his former vice presidents. ''If there is a solution for Argentina's crisis it passes through the Peronist party and, more modestly, through me,'' he said. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: A Gallery of Portraits, Always Intimate
description: SACRED MONSTERS, SACRED MASTERS

title: Alliance Reports Planes Flew Into Kunduz to Rescue Fighters
description: BANGI, Afghanistan, Nov. 23  Northern Alliance soldiers said today that Pakistani airplanes had once again flown into the encircled city of Kunduz to evacuate Pakistanis who have been fighting alongside Afghan Taliban forces trapped there.

title: INSIDE
description: Mary Kay Ash Dies

title: From Sunbeam to Enron, Andersen's Reputation Suffers
description: THIS has been the worst year ever for Arthur Andersen, the accounting firm that once deserved the title of conscience of the industry. The Securities and Exchange Commission filed civil fraud complaints against the Andersen partner who audited Sunbeam and against the firm itself in the Waste Management case.

title: Corrections
description: A Nov. 17 Op-Ed article said incorrectly that computer databases had superseded The New York Times Index. The index is still published.

title: Gun Control Policy, Jalalabad Style: He Who Grabs All the Rifles Writes the Rules
description: A sound truck rumbles down the street, blaring a message from Hazarat Ali, the new sheriff: ''Don't carry weapons, night or day. If you are found with a weapon, you will be punished, no questions asked.''

title: A Nation Challenged
description: On the Ground

title: 5 Palestinian Schoolboys Killed by an Explosion in Gaza
description: Five Palestinian boys walking to school were killed today when a powerful explosive detonated beneath them at the crest of a sand dune here, near an Israeli settlement.

title: Patty Chang
description: Jack Tilton/Anna Kustera

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/International; Trucks of the Taliban: Durable, Not Discreet
description: THEY hanged television sets, and draped trees with videotape pulled in fury from cassettes. Computers were ''executed'' on the spot, with rifle butts to the monitors. The Taliban and technology were enemies from the start, as Afghanistan's former rulers sought to drag the country back across centuries to their own medieval, village-culture form of Islam.

title: NATO PLAN OFFERS RUSSIA EQUAL VOICE ON SOME POLICIES
description: The NATO secretary general, Lord Robertson, proposed today to give Russia equal status with the alliance's 19 permanent members in devising and executing some policies, a change that probably would bring Moscow into the center of NATO deliberations on terrorism and other issues.

title: Russia's Economic Rebound
description: When Communism collapsed in Moscow a decade ago, the Russian economy was in a stupor. It is only now springing back to life. The revival is good for Russia and its new friends in the West, but it will not be sustained unless President Vladimir Putin makes further reforms.

title: Much More Than the Sum of Their Tests
description: To the Editor:

title: Oil Prices Jump 6% After Talk of Cutbacks
description: Crude oil jumped more than 6 percent and neared $20 a barrel after Norway said today that it would cut output and Russian oil executives signaled that they would follow suit if ordered to by the Kremlin.

title: South Korea Launches Missile In Its First Test Since Last Year
description: South Korea announced today that it had test-fired a missile that was believed by defense analysts to have the capability of landing almost anywhere in North Korea.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CARTER, DAVID
description: CARTER-David I'm up before the crack of dawn still tired from the day before I sit in front of Eckford Street in my car I nap and snore I close the shop in the dark my body strained from the day my eyes keep closing while I drive and I fall asleep in my dinner tray Love, Larry

title: Mary Kay Ash, Who Built a Cosmetics Empire and Adored Pink, Is Dead at 83
description: Mary Kay Ash, who built a billion-dollar beauty empire from a $5,000 investment in 1963, and who motivated hundreds of thousands of consultants around the world with a combination of rewards, recognition and religion, died yesterday at her home in Dallas. She was 83.

title: Saudi Says Bush's Words May Soothe Arab Feelings
description: Saudi Arabia's foreign minister said tonight that he was ''very much encouraged'' by fresh statements from the Bush administration on reviving the quest for Middle East peace.

title: Disaster Gives The Uninsured Wider Access To Medicaid
description: In a city of lines, some of the longest are now for health insurance.

title: Apocalyptic Theology Revitalized by Attacks
description: Aaron M. Hopper, a 23-year-old middle-school teacher, was scanning the bookshelves of the Family Christian Store in Gainesville, Ga., today when a new paperback caught his attention.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Trading Britain For America

title: Camby's Return Is Crucial but Dogged by Doubt
description: They get routed, not just defeated, every three or four games. Their point guard situation is once again in flux. They come up short against their opponents in every category on the chart -- field-goal percentage, free-throw percentage, 3-point percentage, rebounding, assists, turnovers, steals, blocked shots and, of course, scoring.

title: Since Attack, More Landlord-Tenant Clashes Downtown
description: Tensions between landlords and tenants of buildings close to ground zero in downtown Manhattan have led to more rent strikes and threatened evictions in the last week, with several cases to go to mediation in Housing Court over the next month.

title: Economic Contraction Puts Germany Close to Recession
description: Germany moved closer to a recession today, and may already be in one, because new statistics show that its economy, Europe's biggest, contracted slightly in the third quarter.

title: Hairbreadth Win in Fall Bridge Contest
description: Two teams of world champions battled to the wire at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here on Wednesday. In the Open Board-a-Match Teams, the American group that won the Bermuda Bowl world title in Paris earlier this month eked out a victory by one-hundredth of a board, the narrowest possible margin and the closest ever in the event's history.

title: In Quest of the Perfect Fly
description: Anglers often use artificial flies to imitate the blue-winged olive.

title: Gardner McKay, 69, TV Heartthrob Who Turned to Writing, Is Dead
description: Gardner McKay, who became famous as the star of the 1960's television series "Adventures in Paradise" but abandoned the spotlight to move to the Amazon jungle, died at his home in Honolulu on Wednesday. He was 69 and had been fighting prostate cancer while trying to finish his memoirs.

title: Bomb Remnants Increase War's Toll
description: Most children in Afghanistan, lacking toys, play with what they find. In this tiny, dusty village, they have been finding pieces of a cluster bomb.

title: Fuel Targets for Sport Utilities Pose Difficulties for Automakers
description: Top executives of the Big Three automakers pledged anew in recent interviews to improve the fuel economy of their fleets of sport utility vehicles. But some of them are casting doubt on whether the goal set by Ford Motor last year -- a 25 percent improvement by 2005 -- can be met.

title: Mental Health Parity
description: To the Editor:

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Ugly Duckling Turns Out to Be Formidable In the Air
description: In the vast armada of sleek jet fighters, helicopter gunships and cruise missiles that have pounded Afghanistan from the air, the unmanned drone known as the Predator is a decidedly ugly duckling.

title: Some Mideast Immigrants, Shaken, Ponder Leaving U. S.
description: Not once in the 33 years he has lived here has Haitham Bundakji thought about leaving. Even when he slept on floors, with a jacket for a blanket and a towel wrapped around his shoes for a pillow, he always considered America to be home.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: N.T.T. Posts 6-Month Loss
description: Nippon Telegraph and Telephone, Japan's dominant telecommunications carrier, said yesterday that it lost 262 billion yen ($2.1 billion) in the six months ended Sept. 30 after writing down soured investments made overseas. Sales at N.T.T., which includes the nation's largest mobile operator, NTT DoCoMo, rose 5.8 percent. But the company booked a $4.4 billion one-time loss on its stake in the Verio, the United States Internet company. N.T.T. also faces stiff competition in the local phone service business, where it earns about half its sales. The group now expects to lose 331 billion yen ($2.7 billion) in the full year ending March 2002. To cut costs, N.T.T. plans to shift 100,000 workers to lower-paying jobs at subsidiaries. The company will offer severance packages as compensation to persuade employees to move. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Columbia Is Overmatched As Fordham Rolls in Finale
description: With a 41-10 home victory over Columbia yesterday at Jack Coffey Field in the Bronx, Fordham (7-4) wrapped up its best season since jumping to Division I-AA in 1989.

title: Homeland Security
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Cumulative Pain
description: Sissy Spacek, below, endures the pain of a son's murder in ''In the Bedroom.''

title: U.S. Hunting Antiviral Drug To Use in Case Of Smallpox
description: Government scientists are conducting studies to find out whether any existing antiviral drugs will work against smallpox.

title: A World Not Neatly Divided
description: When people talk about clashing civilizations, as so many politicians and academics do now, they can sometimes miss the central issue. The inadequacy of this thesis begins well before we get to the question of whether civilizations must clash. The basic weakness of the theory lies in its program of categorizing people of the world according to a unique, allegedly commanding system of classification. This is problematic because civilizational categories are crude and inconsistent and also because there are other ways of seeing people (linked to politics, language, literature, class, occupation or other affiliations).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARRATY, RITA ANGELO
description: GARRATY-Rita Angelo. On November 22, 2001 at age 71. Beloved wife of John. Loving mother of Marco Angelo and grandmother of Danielle, Nicholas and Natalie. Devoted sister of Dorothy Gold. Graveside service is at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, New York, Sunday 1:00 PM.

Friday in Afghanistan

Paid Notice: Deaths  SLOANE, HERMINE PATRICIA
description: SLOANE-Hermine Patricia, 67. Passed away suddenly November 22, 2001. Dr. Sloane was a painter, an author, filmmaker, and a professor of fine arts at NYC Technical College-CUNY. Dr. Sloane's books included topics on fine arts, art history, principles of color, and the works of T.S. Elliot. Dr. Sloane is the widow of Dr. Kenneth Campbell, a noted sculptor & artist. She was the daughter of Dr. David Sloane & Dr. Miriam Frauenthal. She is survived by her sister, Elaine Sloane Roemer of Miami, FL; her aunt, Beatrice Krulwich of Manhattan; her two stepchildren of Kenneth Campbell; her niece, Michelle Sloane Wolf; her nephew, Alan Sloane Roemer; a great-niece and great-nephews. Services for Dr. Sloane will be held on Sunday, November 25th at Riverside Funeral Home in Brooklyn, (718) 633-0400.

title: Bloomberg's Official Trip Will Be Made on His Jet
description: In yet another sign of how the next administration could diverge from those it follows, Michael R. Bloomberg will travel in his own plane on Monday on his first official international trip since winning the office of mayor.

title: 'A Hero of Our Own'
description: Early in the afternoon of August 4, 1940, Varian Fry crossed the ramp at La Guardia Airport to board a Pan American Airways Boeing B-314 to Europe for what would turn out to be the greatest adventure of his life. His wife and a small group of friends were there to see him off. As he walked toward the water where the seaplane was docked, sunlight danced off Fry’s glasses, mirroring the delight in his eyes. A slender man, above-average height, with dark brown hair and green eyes, he sparkled, pressed and immaculate, eager to be on his way. Over the gangplank, onto the Clipper, and belted in, Fry sank back finally to wave farewell to his wife and friends through the tiny window. His destination was Marseille, a large, dirty port city near the southernmost tip of France that had become the last stop for many thousands of refugees from Hitler. From there, they hoped to embark to the United States, Britain, Canada, Mexico, Cuba—any country without a Nazi presence. By the time of Fry’s trip, Marseille was jammed with penniless, bedraggled exiles from all over Europe struggling to emigrate. Long before he left New York, he was aware that most were failing at these attempts, that some were already interned in French concentration camps under primitive and inhumane conditions. His mission, once he arrived, was to assist in any way he could, a handful of people, the intellectual elite of Europe, whose names had been given him by various leaders in American arts and sciences. Fry left behind his wife of nine years, Eileen Hughes Fry, who had expressed a hope that he would return with a French child for them to adopt. He had taken a four-week leave of absence from his job as an editor at the Foreign Policy Association’s Headline Books. Naively thinking his mission to save the refugees could be accomplished in that short time, he had purchased a return Clipper ticket for August 29. Just before he left New York, worried whether he had the correct clothing, Fry went on a last-minute shopping spree, buying items that he imagined necessary for a month on the Continent. Taped to his leg were a list of two hundred names, the most endangered refugees, and three thousand dollars in cash. As European representative for the Emergency Rescue Committee (ERC), an ad hoc group organized days after the fall of France, his mandate was to help German and Eastern European refugees obtain the visas and other documents they needed to escape from France. Just before he left, Fry’s conversations with his wife revealed how little he understood public opinion in America regarding the European war and its refugees. He did not realize that it would be nearly impossible to mobilize Americans to support both refugee rescue and the liberalization of U.S. immigration policy. Eileen tried to explain the state of mind of the American people, but he never got it. Fry, who cared deeply about the well-being of all people, could not comprehend the narrow, selfish isolationist viewpoint of a majority of Americans who wanted neither to fight in the war nor to help its victims. This inability to understand American attitudes would hurt and hinder him during his year in Marseille as he came up against them repeatedly while he was dealing with American officials. In some ways, Varian Fry was a likely candidate for the job he had undertaken. He spoke good French and some German, was Harvard-educated, and had a liberal Protestant background with a strong family emphasis on helping others. His paternal grandfather, Charles Reuben Fry, had been a prominent social worker and “child saver.” Varian Fry was also a passionate antifascist who would now be able to act on his beliefs. Despite his political predilection for this work, however, his personality did not lend itself to his becoming a foreign emissary. He was outspoken and undiplomatic, and often anxious and moody. In addition, the leadership of the ERC, and Fry himself, had doubts about sending him to Europe because of his lack of experience in this type of political work. In the end, however, he was the only volunteer, and therefore the one to go. His antifascism had been reinforced on a visit to Europe five years earlier, during the summer of 1935, when he witnessed Nazi storm troopers beating Jews on the streets of Berlin. His memory of this incident, of a victim’s “hand nailed to the table beside the beer mug,” influenced his decision to volunteer for the mission to Marseille. Haunted by what he had seen in Berlin, Fry wrote about it. Working at a series of editorial positions from 1935 on, he tried desperately but unsuccessfully to bring public attention to the coming Holocaust. Even front-page articles he wrote for The New York Times about the storm troopers’ brutality and its aftermath did not bring condemnation of Nazi actions. The majority of Americans were not interested. With isolationists dominant in American society, Fry and others with like views were generally ignored. Since September 1939, Germany had vanquished the nations of Europe, including, during the April, May, and June 1940 “Blitzkrieg,” Belgium, Holland, Denmark, Norway, and Luxembourg. “The enemy is aiming for the heart of France,” wrote Russian émigré Victor Serge, “and Paris is threatened.” In New York, as they waited for the inevitable invasion of France, Fry and other politically concerned people were frantically trying to figure out how to help their European friends. Fry became involved in a number of different groups that were forming. He lunched often at Child’s restaurant on Fortieth Street in Manhattan with the dashing and mysterious Karl Frank (aka Paul Hagen) and his second wife, activist-heiress Anna Caples. (It was at these meetings that the groundwork was laid for the formation of the Emergency Rescue Committee.) He joined the American Friends of German Freedom, which Frank had created along with the progressive theologian Dr. Reinhold Niebuhr. When Frank first arrived in New York in 1935, he had read Fry’s New York Times article about the Nazis beating Jews in Berlin and sought out the young journalist. A psychoanalyst and “professional revolutionary,” Frank had been a communist militant in Austria during the twenties, then head of the German Socialist Party in Prague. Niebuhr, formerly a pacifist, was now urging “Christians to support the war against Hitler.” Fry also met the daring and glamorous Buttingers. From 1934 to 1938, Joseph Buttinger led the underground Austrian Socialist Movement, then emigrated to the United States with his wife, Muriel Gardiner, the scion of a wealthy American family.* As other bright politically concerned young people gathered around the locus of the Franks and the Buttingers—including Ingrid Warburg, of the influential banking family, and Eileen Hughes Fry—Fry became involved in yet a third group, the International Relief Association (IRA). Founded in 1934 by Albert Einstein to aid refugees from Hitler, this group operated independently in Europe for a time. On June 14, 1940, German forces, which had been bombing on the outskirts of Paris, entered the city and marched triumphantly down the Champs Elysées to the Arc de Triomphe. As French citizens cried tears of “heartbroken rage,” Fry and his circle across the Atlantic were also grief-stricken. France fell days later, on June 22 Article Nineteen of the Franco-German Armistice called for France to “surrender on demand” to the Nazis all Germans who sought asylum “in France as well as in French possessions, colonies, protectorate territories, and mandates.” “ ‘Germans’ included Austrians, Czechs, and, in practice, any others whom the Nazis chose to terrorize . . . no one doubted that the Gestapo would soon start tracking down these old enemies.” At that time, how the French would respond to Article Nineteen was unclear, and as a result all refugees in France felt at risk because the Nazis could demand they be surrendered. When Germany conquered France, the country was divided into “unoccupied” and “occupied” zones, with the unoccupied sector under a nominal French government headquartered in Vichy. This government, led by Marshal Henri-Philippe Pétain, immediately forbade expressions of French nationalism, such as the national anthem, “La Marseillaise,” and substituted “Work, Family, Fatherland” for the French motto of “Liberty, Equality, Fraternity.” *Gardiner has claimed to be the model for the underground hero “Julia,” described by Lillian Hellman in her memoir Pentimento. In New York, Fry and his friends, horrified that refugees in France might have to be handed over to the Germans, were appalled by Vichy’s plans to rid France of its foreigners, particularly Jews. Germans and other European exiles who had fled Hitler were now outcasts in the country where they had sought refuge. They had chosen France for asylum over Belgium and Switzerland. Refugees in Belgium were often pushed back and forth over the French-Belgian border, nor was the Swiss government much better; it was stingy with permits allowing refugees to remain. Although it was difficult for refugees to gain entry into France, once inside, it was easier for them to remain. Unfortunately, after the fall of France, the Vichy government passed legislation preventing refugees from leaving the country. Vichy, if it so decided, could then surrender them on demand to the Germans. As a result, antifascists, writers, “degenerate” artists, scientists, labor leaders—most of them Jewish—were trapped in France, waiting for the Germans to pounce. Since, from the spring of 1940 on, there were fewer and fewer passenger ships sailing from Europe until “points of departure . . . narrowed almost to Lisbon and the British ports,” the refugees’ dilemma was how to get from France to Lisbon, and then to a free nation. This was one of the chief questions considered by Fry and his friends in New York as they held meeting after meeting. But there was no resolution, no plan of action. On June 24, the American Friends of German Freedom wrote to Eleanor Roosevelt asking for her support, which she gave. A day later, the group held a fund-raising luncheon at the Hotel Commodore in Manhattan. Radio commentator Raymond Gram Swing spoke on the plight of the European refugees. Fry, an organizer of the luncheon, was moved by Swing’s eloquence. Reinhold Niebuhr asked the two hundred guests to donate money, then led a discussion about resolving the problems of the refugees. Many spoke out, including Erika Mann, Thomas Mann’s daughter. Everyone agreed that a new organization was needed, an amalgam of Einstein’s IRA and the American Friends of German Freedom, whose sole purpose would be to help the European refugees. Finally, Fry thought, some action. The Emergency Rescue Committee was born that day. Although most of its members were journalists, religious leaders, and activists from the traditional American left, Fry’s background was more intellectual and humanitarian. His instincts were the same as the other founders of the ERC, but his political agenda was always second to his strong desire to help people. The leaders of the ERC, including Fry, met again a few days after the luncheon, at Ingrid Warburg’s apartment on West Fifty-fourth Street, to discuss the desperate need to send someone to France to see what was actually going on. Fry said he would consider volunteering if no one else could be found. The ERC took shape with an office at 122 East Forty-second Street and several new members: Methodist minister and University of Newark president Dr. Frank Kingdon; New School for Social Research president Dr. Alvin Johnson; perennial presidential candidate and socialist Norman Thomas; and other leaders in the arts, education, religion, labor, and the media. Kingdon became the committee’s chairman, David F. Seiferheld was its treasurer, and Mildred Adams its secretary. Harold Oram, a socialist militant who had raised funds for Spanish Civil War refugees in the thirties, would oversee fund-raising, and Ingrid Warburg volunteered to be Kingdon’s assistant. A national committee to boost the fledgling organization’s profile included writers John Dos Passos and Upton Sinclair; the presidents of Yale University, Smith College, and the University of Chicago; and journalist Dorothy Thompson. In late June, Fry wrote to the president and received an answer from Eleanor Roosevelt: “The President has seen your letter of June 27,” she wrote. “He will try to get the cooperation of the South American countries in giving asylum to the political refugees.” By early July, lists were being compiled of endangered refugees, including not only Jews but communists, leftist political activists, religious war objectors, and other outsiders. The ERC was still seeking a representative to send to France. “In the end,” Fry wrote, “I volunteered myself.” He had no “experience in the underground” and made his offer “out of impatience at delay,” as well as his real desire to do some good. “I believed in freedom,” he wrote later. “I remembered what I had seen in Germany. I knew what would happen to the refugees if the Gestapo got hold of them. . . . It was my duty to help them. . . .” Despite Kingdon’s conservative tendency toward safety first, action later, the ERC moved ahead and appointed Fry, an unknown quantity, as its European representative. He would travel to France and meet with as many endangered refugees as possible, helping them acquire visas and other necessary documents so they could escape Europe before they were arrested and turned over to the Nazis.

title: Harry Potter's Triumph
description: To the Editor:

title: Hamilton Needs Time For His Injury to Heal
description: It has taken a lot to keep defensive tackle Keith Hamilton off the field in his 10 seasons with the Giants. He has played in 147 of 154 games, missing one game in 1994 with a sprained knee, two in 1995 with a bulging disk, two in 1996 with torn knee cartilage and a compound thumb dislocation and two this season with a separated right shoulder.

title: Taliban Holdouts, Europe's Reservations and Anthrax Frustrations
description: Down but not out. That seemed the simplest way to describe the Taliban in the complex arrangements under way to get their forces to surrender in Kunduz, the last northern city in Afghanistan that they hold. In fact, there were signs of new Taliban determination to carry on the struggle.

title: An Oil Trader, an Avid Cyclist and a Leader Dedicated to His Firehouse
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Club St. Lucia
description: Club St. Lucia by Splash, a 369-room beachfront resort on St. Lucia, has a six-night all-inclusive package that offers savings of $495. The rate per day, including the savings, is $257 for a double room. Children ages 2 to 12 are $40 a night extra. The rate is valid Dec. 19 to March 31, 2002, and includes all meals, all drinks, tennis lessons, nonmotorized water sports, children's programs, evening entertainment and all taxes and tips. Ask for the St. Lucia Winter Wonderland rate when reserving; (877) 927-7527 or www.splashresorts.com .

title: No Room for Riches Of the Indian Past
description: Few motorists speeding along the newly widened U.S. Highway 89 to the canyons and parklands north of Flagstaff, Ariz., know of the archaeological treasure that once lay beneath the road's smooth surface. In just a 17-mile stretch, archaeologists who preceded the road crew's bulldozers found more than 100,000 artifacts, the remains of Native American agricultural and trading cultures that sprouted in the fifth century A.D. and lasted for more than 800 years.

title: Journal; Wait Until Dark
description: In the immediate aftermath of Sept. 11, the Arab world was riveted by the rumor that Israel was somehow behind the attack on the World Trade Center. Al Jazeera went so far as to report that 4,000 Jews had been given advance notice not to go to work at the towers that day. You'd think that no one in American officialdom would do anything to fan the flames of such noxious fictions, but if so, you'd be underestimating John Ashcroft. As part of his mass dragnet prompted by the attacks on America, our attorney general has rounded up about 50 Israeli Jews, some of whom have been detained for nearly a month on the pretext of minor offenses involving working papers.

title: S.E.C. IS INVESTIGATING NAVIGANT CONSULTING
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating whether Navigant Consulting Inc. violated securities laws in 1998 and 1999, the company said in a filing with the S.E.C. Navigant shares reached a record $54.25 in September 1999, before the newspaper Barron's questioned the Chicago-based management consulting company's reported growth rate. The stock fell 45 percent on Nov. 22, 1999, when the chief executive, Robert Maher, was ousted and the company said it was reviewing $17 million in loans to him and other executives. Two other officers were fired. ''We don't know the full scope of the S.E.C.'s investigation, but it's our understanding they are looking at potential violations of securities laws in 1998 and 1999,'' Ben Perks, Navigant's executive vice president and chief financial officer, said. ''We want to get things behind us and are fully cooperating with the S.E.C.'' The company also reviewed accounting treatment for four transactions during the first quarter of 1999 and later restated its figures.

title: Two Fires, Still Burning
description: To the Editor:

title: PAKISTANIS AGAIN SAID TO EVACUATE ALLIES OF TALIBAN
description: Northern Alliance soldiers said today that Pakistani airplanes had once again flown into the encircled city of Kunduz to evacuate Pakistanis who have been fighting alongside Afghan Taliban forces trapped there.

title: New Works That Borrow As Much as They Create
description: Tuesday's concert at Alice Tully Hall was a typical evening with Joel Sachs and the New Juilliard Ensemble. Four big works were on the program, all dating from the last 10 years, and together covering a wide spectrum of styles, including some that were not their composers' own.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Oil Company Breakup
description: Japan said that it would dismantle the Japan National Oil Corporation, a state-run oil producer with $19 billion in debt, in the next three years and issue shares in a new company to be wholly owned by the government. The government will set up a clearing company to liquidate or sell shareholdings Japan National Oil has in exploration companies. Proceeds will be used to pay off debt, said Taro Aso, policy chief at the ruling Liberal Democratic Party.

title: Man, 67, Dies After Being Hit by Police Car
description: A 67-year-old Brooklyn man was killed yesterday after being struck by a police car responding to an emergency call.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JEROME, JERRY
description: JEROME-Jerry. The Board of Governors and we of North Shore Country Club record with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed former member Jerry Jerome. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. Peter J. Baum, President Dan Klonsky, Secretary

title: Mix of Physics and Politics May Produce Lab in Mine
description: A century-old gold mine in the town of Lead, S.D., just a few miles from where Wild Bill Hickok and Calamity Jane are buried, would be converted into the world's deepest underground physics laboratory under a bill passed in the Senate last week with the sponsorship of Senator Tom Daschle, the South Dakota Democrat who is the majority leader.

title: Hard Times in Borough of Airports; As Airlines Cut Back, Queens Loses Jobs and Business
description: John Dupre, a mechanic for United Airlines, moved out of his apartment in Queens this month after his job at Kennedy International Airport was eliminated. The airline was transferring him to Indianapolis, and he said he had no choice but to go, leaving behind his friends and his favorite haunts on Metropolitan Avenue.

title: INSIDE
description: Genocide Charge for Serb

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VECCHIONE, EDWARD, JR.
description: VECCHIONE-Edward, Jr. On Nov. 22, 2001 at age 76. Loving brother of Dorothy Martin and cousin of Vincent Lombardi, Marie Pelusso and Lucretia Trisci and companion of the late Lilo Marcus. Dear friend of Bernice & Arthur Weiss and Joan Linsky. Also survived by many nephews, cousins and dear friends. Mr. Vecchione was a member of The Hotel Management Association, a veteran of W.W. II, a prisoner of war and a graduate of Columbia University. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Friday, November 23, 2-4 PM & 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass at Our Lady of Peace Church, 237 East 62 St, Saturday 11:15 AM. Interment to follow at Christ the King Cemetery, Franklin Lakes, NJ. Contributions in his memory may be made to Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, New York 10461.

title: 'The Raw and the Cooked'
description: It is a few degrees above zero and I'm far out on the ice of Bay de Noc near Escanaba in the Upper Peninsula of Michigan, beyond the last of the fish shanties. It doesn't matter how far it is but how long it takes to get there—an hour out, and an hour back to my hotel, the House of Ludington. Unfortunately, I've been caught in a whiteout, a sudden snow squall out of the northwest, and I can't see anything but my hands and cross-country skis, a short, broad type called Bushwhackers, which allow you to avoid the banality of trails. I turn myself around and try to retrace my path but it has quickly become covered with the fresh snow. Now I have to stand here and wait it out because, last evening, a tanker and Coast Guard icebreaker came into the harbor, which means there is a long path of open water or some very thin ice out there in the utter whiteness. I would most certainly die if I fell in and that would mean, among other things, that I would miss a good dinner, and that's what I'm doing out here in the first place—earning, or deserving, dinner.

title: At Miami, Tradition Attracts a Faithful Flock
description: Bennie Blades will drive down Route I-95 from Fort Lauderdale to see his alma mater play a critical game against the Washington Huskies on Saturday. Santana Moss of the Jets is taking advantage of a rare bye week to make his debut among the distinguished football alumni who haunt the sidelines whenever the University of Miami plays at the Orange Bowl.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNGLIEB, LILY
description: YOUNGLIEB-Lily, 95. On November 22, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Herman. Loving mother of Judith Cohen. Devoted mother-inlaw of Norman D. Cohen. Treasured grandmother of Leslie Siben and David Schalit. Great grandmother of Odile Schalit and Michael Siben. You will be missed beyond words. Private service.

title: MITSUBISHI TO EXPAND ELECTRIC POWER BUSINESS IN U.S.
description: The Mitsubishi Corporation, Japan's largest trading company, plans to invest $130 million to expand its electric power generation businesses in the United States. Mitsubishi said that its American unit, the Diamond Generating Corporation, and an independent power provider, Tenaska Inc., would build three natural-gas-fired power plants in Alabama, Oklahoma and Washington. The company said the three plants would have a combined generation capacity of 2,400 megawatts, of which Mitsubishi's share would be 680 megawatts. The planned generators are scheduled to come onstream in 2003.

title: In Kabul, Happiness for Sale
Despite Ruling, Logan Official Predicts Ouster of Security Firm
description: Despite a judge's decision to let the beleaguered Argenbright Security Inc. continue to operate temporarily in Massachusetts, the interim security director for Logan International Airport in Boston still believes he will be able to revoke its permit and eject the company from the airport.

title: Citing Some Progress, U.N. Panel on Torture Urges Israel to Take More Steps
description: The United Nations Committee Against Torture said today that while Israel had made progress in ending some practices that amounted to torture, it should install ''effective complaint, investigative and prosecution mechanisms'' to handle continuing protests.

title: The World According to Colin Powell
description: The night of Oct. 15 found Colin Powell inside the heavily fortified residence of the American ambassador in Islamabad, dining with his improbable new best friend, the president of Pakistan. Just a few months earlier, when the Bush administration was beginning to compose its tableau of friends and foes, a Powell deputy was sent to court India, a democracy and possible counterweight to China, as America's darling in South Asia. Pakistan was passed over as a terrorist-cradling rogue nation. But war changes everything, and Gen. Pervez Musharraf was now our partner against the terrorists in neighboring Afghanistan. This was Powell's first face-to-face meeting with the Pakistani strongman, and he was impressed with what he found. Like Powell himself, Musharraf was a pragmatic military man, brimming with self-assurance, equally at ease talking tactical soldiery or political strategy, a man given to thinking three or four steps ahead.

title: If bin Laden Is Brought to Trial
description: To the Editor:

title: Nebraska's Loss Opens Door to Other Title Hopefuls
description: Miami Coach Larry Coker learned his Bowl Championship Series lessons well. He has preached a simple weekly sermon to his team: win games, all of them, and the Hurricanes are certain to have a berth in the B.C.S. championship game on Jan. 3 at the Rose Bowl.

title: Medelln Journal; A Coffee Icon Rides His Mule Off Into the Sunset
description: Carlos Snchez saw it coming. Nevertheless, he still had a lump in his throat when, just a few days ago, he received the news: Juan Valdez, the tradition-bound coffee farmer Mr. Snchez has played in countless American commercials, would soon be shelved.

title: Democrats Say Now Is Time To Raise Security Spending
description: Two influential Congressional Democrats today seized on Tom Ridge's call for spending billions more on homeland security late next year and said it showed that the Bush administration should drop its opposition to their proposals for spending more right now.

title: If bin Laden Is Brought to Trial
description: To the Editor:

title: Editors' Note; Today's Sections
description: News of the Sept. 11 attacks and their aftermath continues to appear in Section B; index, Page B2.

title: Parents Say Proposal for College-Preparatory School on Upper East Side Falls Short
description: A group of Upper East Side parents who have been fighting for a college-preparatory high school in their neighborhood say the Board of Education is offering them a watered-down version they cannot accept, a high school that would have a weak curriculum and be open to students from outside the neighborhood.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOURAUD, SHEILA MARGUERITE
description: GOURAUD-Sheila Marguerite. In loving memory, Jackson, Meg, George, Charles, Steven, and Tracey.

title: Respect for Treaties
description: To the Editor:

title: Delta Town's Hopes Are as Scarce as Inmates
description: With all the jobs it promised upon opening less than two years ago, the $35 million Tallahatchie County Correctional Facility seemed the salvation of the flat and tattered Mississippi Delta town of Tutwiler, population 1,364. But the prison, encircled by cotton fields and shimmering coils of razor wire, has left the town little better off than it ever was.

title: The Neediest Cases; Art Exhibition to Help Holiday Appeal
description: These are tough times for many, including charities. The economy is contracting and Wall Street is in a slump, shrinking potential donations. The Federal Reserve has cut interest rates 10 times this year, whittling away at the interest income crucial to charities with endowments. In addition, some charities fear, the public's spirited reaction to the terror attacks on Sept. 11 could divert attention from enduring problems. These are tougher times for those in need of help in New York City. Last month, 79,000 jobs disappeared. Next month, 32,800 families will reach the five-year federal limit for cash welfare assistance. They can still receive money for rent and utilities through the state, but must reapply.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Medical College Overseer Accused
description: Two High Court justices ordered the removal of Dr. Ketan Desai as president of the Medical Council of India, a government agency that oversees medical education, saying he was involved in corruption and had misused his official position. The justices directed prosecutors to open a case against him and said: ''It is shocking to see how the Medical Council of India is being run. We can now say with certainty that it is a den of corruption.'' P. J. Anthony (NYT)

title: SPAIN SETS HURDLE FOR EXTRADITIONS
description: Spain will not extradite the eight men it has charged with complicity in the Sept. 11 attacks unless the United States agrees that they would be tried by a civilian court and not by the military tribunals envisioned by President Bush, Spanish officials said today.

title: 'Janet and Jackie'
description: Janet and Jackie: the first a private woman, and the latter a public woman. During her lifetime, we knew Jackie as Jackie Bouvier, Jackie Kennedy, and Jackie Onassis. As her life drew to a close, she acknowledged her legend and accepted the name that most people identified her with: Jackie Kennedy Onassis.

title: The Arbiters Of Recession Stand Ready
description: It's almost official: the economy is in recession, ending the longest uninterrupted expansion in American history.

title: Russia Delays Any Decision On Oil Cuts
description: Russia surprised world oil markets today by rebuffing OPEC's demands to cut oil output for 2002, postponing a decision until next month.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Loans For Airlines
description: The government plans to lend $195 million to Korea's two airlines, which have been hurt by a decline in passengers since the attacks of Sept. 11. The construction and transportation ministry said Korean Air would get $110 and Asiana, $85 million. Both airlines have announced plans to sell bonds and cut jobs. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Devils' Offense Still in Short Supply
description: The rookie goaltender making his National Hockey League debut tonight played well, but the Devils' troubles continued, and this time against a team they usually dominate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCUS, HARRIETT
description: MARCUS-Harriett. On November 23, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Carl. Loving aunt of Sandy Ward, Ani Hurwitz, Ray Ward and Leah Fineberg. Service Sunday 1PM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Suit Over British Nuclear Site
description: The government has filed suit at the International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea, a United Nations body in Hamburg, seeking an injunction to stop the operation of a new plant to process nuclear materials at Sellafield, on Britain's west coast. The existing nuclear site at Sellafield, across the Irish Sea from Dublin, has concerned Ireland as a potential target for terrorist attacks. The injunction seeks to halt the shipment of additional nuclear materials through the Irish Sea and the dumping of nuclear waste at a new plant there. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Life on Mars? A New Study Reads Those Crystals Differently
description: Research into the structure of tiny crystals produced by bacteria casts renewed doubt on a claim by NASA scientists that a Martian meteorite shows evidence that life once existed on Mars.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Back To School For Blair?
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair misspelled the word ''tomorrow'' as ''toomorrow'' three times in an open letter of support for a Labor candidate in Ipswich explaining his regret at not being able to show up on the day of a by-election. The education spokesman for the Conservatives, Damian Green said, ''It looks as though the government's so-called commitment to lifelong learning needs reinforcing at the top.'' Mr. Blair said: ''Somebody in my office suggested it may have been my handwriting that was at fault, rather than my spelling, but I have to say that I believe it was both.'' Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Better Gas Mileage, Greater Security
description: It has become clear to most Americans that maintaining our national security will require reducing our dependence on foreign oil. But Republicans are using the current crisis to push through a reckless energy agenda, including drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, that will not improve America's security. Even the conservative Cato Institute has called President Bush's claim that Arctic oil would reduce gas prices or American dependency on foreign oil ''not just nonsense, but nonsense on stilts.''

title: A Dismal End To a Season Full of Misery
description: Rutgers was somewhat competitive against a team that came in 0-10, had the third-worst defense in Division I-A and had to cross the country to play a meaningless game after a narrow loss to its bitterest rival. Such is the state of Rutgers football. It is not whether you lose but how bad you look doing so.

title: Orange Withstands Drought With Smothering Defense
description: Syracuse would appear to be the Big East's most predictable team. Play the Orangemen and a team knows it will face a zone defense and the perimeter scoring of Preston Shumpert and DeShaun Williams.

title: Pataki Paints By Numbers To Create Dim Picture
description: Gov. George E. Pataki has tried hard in recent days to paint a spectacularly bleak fiscal picture for New York State, saying that because of the Sept. 11 attack the state faces the worst economic crisis since the Great Depression.

title: 'Mrs. Kennedy'
description: Had it not been for the fact that Jacqueline Kennedy was married to the President of the United States, it is unlikely that a single book about her would have been written. And yet, in the dozens of books about her, specific details of that presidency have been largely excluded. Even more striking, and of greater consequence, is the fact that the histories of John F. Kennedy's presidency are comparably flawed, missing as they do the story of Jacqueline Kennedy and her crucial role. In an effort to fill the gap, I have tried to tell her story in those years with as much attention to the presidency as to the events of her private life. The role of Jacqueline Kennedy is probably less understood than any other part of the Kennedy presidency; equally, her personal story cannot be grasped without seeing it in the context of the unfolding events of one of the twentieth century's most dramatic presidencies. Her life was changed by historical events in ways she had never anticipated. She, in turn, influenced certain of those events in ways that until now have remained largely unexamined.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The customer has the means. What we are watching now is do they have the will.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGMAN, KLAUS
description: BERGMAN-Klaus. Beloved husband of Barbara, devoted father of Cathy Lanza and Nicole Fong. Cherished grandfather of Abigail, Sandra, Danielle, Adam and Elizabeth. Services Sunday 12 Noon at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: Acceptance, in a Revival, For an Abstract Work
description: The Limn Dance Company showed off its eclectic repertory and the skill of its dancers on Wednesday night at the Joyce Theater.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: More Job Cuts
description: Faced with crippling debt, Royal KPN, the largest phone company in the Netherlands, said it would cut 1,300 more jobs over the next three years to trim its work force by a total of 9,300, or about 20 percent. The company is also planning to sell assets and new shares to reduce debt of about $20 billion incurred in acquisitions and the purchase of wireless licenses. Its shares rose by almost 7 percent, to 5.87 euros, after losing half their value this year. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Medical Research
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Sales and Big Discounts Attract Holiday Shoppers

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, ANNETTE
description: BERGER-Annette. 77, of Fort Lee and formerly Teaneck, NJ, died Nov. 19, 2001. Annette awaited her childhood sweetheart's return from World War II to become a loving wife to Leon Berger for 56 years and a devoted mother to Douglas and the late Andrew Berger. She is also survived by brother, Albert Richmond and sister, Sylvia Pierce. Annette participated in the struggle for human rights. She was the administrator for her family's business, Creston Optical in NY. A talented sculptor, Annette loved theater and the arts. She enjoyed life and will be forever remembered. Services will be held noon on Sunday, November 25th at Louis Suburban Chapel, 13-01 Broadway, Fair Lawn, NJ.

title: Much Maneuvering Around German TV
description: John C. Malone made his fortune in the United States by playing hardball in the cable television industry. Now he is trying to do it again in Germany.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Stocks Reach High
description: The Korean stock market surged to a yearlong high, closing the week at 645.10, largely on the strength of a positive report on Thursday on economic growth. The Kospi index of prices on the Korean Stock Exchange rose 20.63 points, or 3.3 percent, after the central bank said that the gross domestic product rose 1.8 percent in the third quarter over the period last year. Reports of possible mergers by several Korean banks helped to spur the surge in the market, which reached its highest level in 14 months. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Don't Intervene in Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Editors' Note; COMING ON SUNDAY
description: THE WORLD ACCORDING TO POWELL

title: U.S. Envoy to Pakistan Thrust Into Limelight
description: Like so many other Americans, Wendy J. Chamberlin, the United States ambassador to Pakistan, found herself in a changed world on a late-summer day 10 weeks ago -- a world that transformed her, in an instant, from envoy to a country in a diplomatic deep freeze to occupant of one of America's most important ambassadorial postings.

title: A Nation Challenged
description: Giving Up or Digging In?

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Planning A Trip To The Moon
description: Chinese officials affirmed their goal of sending a person into space by 2005, to be followed eventually by a manned mission to the moon. In 1999 and last year the country sent unmanned capsules into space and retrieved them but a top scientist said more test flights were needed before a manned flight is tried, The China Daily reported. China is pursuing space flight for national prestige and is investigating economic and military uses. Erik Eckholm (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Prices Fall
description: German producer prices in October fell the most in 15 years after the economy shrank in the third quarter and energy costs declined. Producer prices fell 0.9 percent from September, the Federal Statistics Office said. Import prices declined 1.6 percent, the second-biggest drop since 1986. Economists had expected a fall of 0.3 percent in producer prices and a 1 percent drop in import costs. Germany's economy, the largest in Europe, shrank 0.1 percent in the third quarter after stalling in the second.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article last Saturday about the Sheepshead Bay High School football team, in Brooklyn, reversed the references to two linebackers who also play on offense. Glenroy Watkins is a fullback on offense and entered the game against Campus Magnet with 620 yards and 5 touchdowns. Ed Lindsay plays tight end on offense.

title: Turning Greek Tragedy Into Domestic Drama
description: No matter how a director approaches it, there is no way Oedipus can be made to go quietly in Sophocles' play. But the production directed by Eve Adamson for the Jean Cocteau Repertory company sounds a bit like the flight of the Taliban as it draws to a close, and many viewers will think it loses something in all the hyperventilation.

title: A Peace Force After the War?
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing
description: NORTHWEST

title: Condo Life at 1,000 Feet: Tight Security, Great View
