description: The other day in an elevator of the John Hancock Tower, the world's tallest residential building, a young woman told Bettylou Taradash that she was moving out. Night after night, the woman said, she lies awake, imagining a plane hurtling through her picture window or a bomb going off in the garage. The beloved tower, she fears, could be terrorists' next mark.

title: Afghans' Unhappy Ending: Castaways in Indonesia
description: The smell of frying garlic fills the narrow stairwell. From a warren of small rooms, people emerge to brush their teeth or scold their children. In the dark foyer below, the television is tuned to news of the war in Afghanistan -- home.

title: 'Riot'
description: The New York Journal Late Edition MONDAY, OCTOBER 2, 1989 AMERICAN SLAIN IN INDIA

title: I.O.C. Heartened By Progress In Athens
description: Officials of the International Olympic Committee expressed cautious optimism today on Athens's often maligned preparations to play host to the 2004 Summer Games.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a slowdown in the Manhattan party planning business misstated the anniversary being observed by Gourmet magazine, which postponed a party. It was the 60th anniversary, not the 16th.

title: Volkswagen Realigns Itself Into 2 Divisions
description: Volkswagen said today that it would shuffle top managers as it reorganized into two groups to minimize competition between brands.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LAZARUS, MEYER ''FLIP''
description: LAZARUS-Meyer ''Flip''. November 24th is the 100th anniversary of the birth of Meyer ''Flip'' Lazarus. His friends and family celebrate his warmth, his humor and his loyalty. We celebrate his life. He is missed and loved, always

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Corrections
description: The Sports of The Times column on Thursday, about blessings to be counted this Thanksgiving -- including the United States Open quarter final match between Pete Sampras and Andre Agassi -- referred incorrectly to the final in some copies. It was not all-Australian; the Australian Lleyton Hewitt defeated the American Sampras, not Patrick Rafter of Australia.

title: Man Dies Trying to Avoid Fire By Sliding Down a Drain Pipe
description: A 21-year-old man fell to his death Thursday on the Upper West Side as he tried to escape a kitchen fire at a residence hotel by sliding down a drainage pipe.

title: 'The Feast of the Goat'
description: Urania. Her parents had done her no favor; her name suggested a planet, a mineral, anything but the slender, fine-featured woman with burnished skin and large, dark, rather sad eyes who looked back at her from the mirror. Urania! What an idea for a name. Fortunately nobody called her that anymore; now it was Uri, Miss Cabral, Ms. Cabral, Dr. Cabral. As far as she could remember, after she left Santo Domingo (or Ciudad Trujillo—when she left they had not yet restored the old name to the capital city), no one in Adrian, or Boston, or Washington, D.C., or New York had called her Urania as they did at home and at the Santo Domingo Academy, where the sisters and her classmates pronounced with absolute correctness the ridiculous name inflicted on her at birth. Was it his idea or hers? Too late to find out, my girl; your mother was in heaven and your father condemned to a living death. You'll never know. Urania! As absurd as insulting old Santo Domingo de Guzmán by calling it Ciudad Trujillo. Could that have been her father's idea too?

title: Islanders Move Back Into First, Ahead of, Ahem, the Rangers
description: Watching scoreboards in November? When you are an Islanders fan and you have been down so long, why not roar for first place with the season barely a quarter over? And when the Isles leap over the Rangers to get into first place, so much the better.

title: The Return of the Shopper
description: In some parts of the world, shoppers must worry about pipe bombs and suicide bombers. Now that terrorists have targeted the United States, some Americans have been feeling nervous enough about going to malls to give the phrase ''fear of shopping'' a grim new meaning.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Trial In Attacks On Foreigners
description: Three men have gone on trial in connection with the fire-bombing of a hostel for asylum-seekers in the northeastern city of Rostock in 1992. The three, who were teenagers at the time, are charged with attempted murder and causing a serious breach of the peace for forcing their way into the hostel and throwing firebombs. No one was killed in the incident, which came during several days of riots by neo-Nazi youths trying to drive out foreigners. Originally scheduled for 1996, the trial was repeatedly postponed; a verdict is expected next month. Thirty other people have been convicted of crimes committed during the riots, receiving sentences of up to three years' in prison.

title: Hospitality Mixes With Hostility When the Taliban Meet the Press
description: Inside the abandoned United Nations compound where the Taliban hosts kept their foreign guests for three days, rank-and-file Taliban soldiers and journalists from all over the world had exchanged tentative smiles and furtive conversations.

title: L-3 COMMUNICATIONS EXTENDING SPAR AEROSPACE BID
description: L-3 Communications Holdings, whose offer for Spar Aerospace Ltd. expired Thursday night without drawing the required two-thirds of shares outstanding, said it would buy what stock was tendered and extend its offer to Dec. 3. L-3, a New York-based maker of military-communications systems and flight-data recorders, said its bid of 15.50 Canadian dollars a share ($9.69) was accepted by holders of 65.8 percent of Spar's outstanding shares. Spar, which is based in Toronto, provides aviation services to customers including the United States Navy. If it fails to reach the two-thirds threshold, L-3 said it would consider leaving Spar as a publicly held unit of the company.

title: In Las Vegas, Meltzer Team Wins Board-a-Match Title
description: The American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals has had a notably international flavor here this week. The Life Master Open Pairs was won by two Polish world champions, Piotr Gawrys and Jacek Pszczola. Four Italian world champions came within a hair of winning the Open Board-a-Match Teams, but the title went to the Rose Meltzer team that won the Bermuda Bowl world championship in Paris earlier this month. The final of the Board-a-Match Teams included 54 players from outside North America. Most of these were from Europe, but there were also representatives of China, Australia and Israel.

title: ECOLAB TO BUY REST OF JOINT VENTURE FOR $445 MILLION
description: Ecolab Inc., a provider of sanitation and maintenance services, will pay about $445 million in cash to buy Henkel's 50 percent stake in a joint venture the two companies operate in Europe. Ecolab will issue 60-day notes to Henkel, the German maker of Duck brand duct tape and Schwarzkopf hair products, and will repay them by taking on bank debt, Ecolab said. The acquisition, the largest in Ecolab's history, is expected to close next Friday, the company said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  IGNATOW, ARCHIE
description: IGNATOW-Archie. Our family has grown and we all miss you. Remembered with love. Gene and three generations

title: Let's Keep Our Natural Resources Alive
description: To the Editor:

title: With Ban Loosened, Some Small Aircraft Return to Manhattan Skies
description: Helicopters and small airplanes, banned from flying over New York City since the Sept. 11 terrorist attack, are once again taking to the local skies, case by case.

title: Grandpa Picasso: Terribly Famous, Not Terribly Nice
description: Among creators of genius, Picasso was not alone in carving a path of emotional destruction through the lives of those closest to him, but his record is nevertheless chilling: in the years following his death in 1973 his second wife, a longtime mistress and a grandson committed suicide; his oldest son was killed by drink; and almost everyone else related to him was scarred by the experience.

title: The Emancipation
description: To the Editor:

title: The Revival of Lower Manhattan
description: Almost 11 weeks after the attack on downtown New York City, planning for the revival of Lower Manhattan has stalled. Gov. George Pataki and Mayor Rudolph Giuliani announced a new authority to oversee the area's restoration three weeks ago, but the directors of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation have yet to be named. Restoration obviously cannot proceed until the site is cleared and vital transportation links are repaired, which will take many months. But it is not too early to assemble a core group of wise and creative minds to help chart the right course for this project and to ensure that the neighborhood that emerges from the tragedy of Sept. 11 is even more robust, imaginative and appealing than what went before.

title: Girl Found Dead in Garage
description: A girl was pronounced dead after she was found yesterday in the parking garage of the Trump Taj Mahal casino in Atlantic City, the authorities said. A woman found near the girl was listed in critical condition early this morning at Atlantic City Medical Center.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Gay Rights
description: A gay rights law took effect on Wednesday after opponents conceded that they lacked enough valid signatures to force a referendum on the measure next November. The law, proposed by Gov. Parris N. Glendening and approved by the General Assembly in April, bans housing and employment discrimination against gays. It had been scheduled to take effect on Oct. 1, but was held up by the referendum drive by Take Back Maryland, a coalition of Christian activists and social conservatives.

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Biotech Loss Narrows
description: British Biotech reported a smaller loss in the fiscal first half as it sold assets and began focusing on developing products. The loss for the six months ended Oct. 31 narrowed to 8.4 million ($11.8 million), or 1.3 pence a share, from 12.2 million, or 1.8 pence, in the period a year earlier. British Biotech shares have lost almost half their value since February, when its lead drug, Marimastat, was shown to treat lung cancer no better than a placebo. The company has since raised 20 million by selling assets and now aims to make products with other companies.

title: Saying Farewell in a Rush of Witty Ragas
description: Ravi Shankar, 81, looked frail as he walked onstage on Sunday night for what was billed as his final Carnegie Hall concert and last full-scale tour. His daughter and musical disciple, Anoushka Shankar, had, as planned, played the first half without him. But once Ravi Shankar picked up his sitar, there was nothing hesitant or autumnal about the music.

title: States Head Into the Red
description: It was only a short time ago that state government was hot. The states, it seemed, had figured out how to do things right, and they were being hailed as the model Washington ought to follow.

title: GENCORP TO REGAIN OWNERSHIP OF AEROJET FINE CHEMICALS
description: GenCorp Inc., which makes aerospace supplies and chemicals, agreed to regain ownership of Aerojet Fine Chemicals from the closely held NextPharma Technologies and expects $1 million in costs for the purchase. GenCorp, based in Rancho Cordova, Calif., said it would pay $13 million in cash and return its stake in NextPharma for the 40 percent of Aerojet it did not already own. GenCorp expects $1 million in costs related to the purchase after the transaction is completed. GenCorp will have to pay NextPharma as much as $11.8 million more if GenCorp sells Aerojet in the next two years, the company said. Aerojet, which is based in Sacramento, makes compounds used in drugs that treat diseases like brain cancer and AIDS.

title: Choreography That Makes The Most of Young Talent
description: The challenge of programming an evening of choreography for relatively inexperienced performers is to create dance that will acknowledge and expand their gifts without losing the audience. Three choreographers did just that for their Barnard College dance students last Saturday night at the Miller Theater.

title: A Quest to Promote the Quality Of Cars Made in South Africa
description: When Gnter Butschek, chief manufacturing executive for DaimlerChrysler South Africa, began his presentation in Tokyo last year, he knew how much South Africa stood to lose. His challenge was to persuade his colleagues to embrace luxury cars assembled in South Africa with the same enthusiasm they had long shown for shipments from Germany.

title: West's Envoys, Unhappy, Find Zimbabwe Unhelpful
description: The police found the battered body of Cain Nkala on Nov. 13 in a shallow grave in Bulawayo, Zimbabwe's second largest city. He was a small-town supporter of President Robert Mugabe and a man virtually unknown in the West. But the government's response to his killing has touched off an international furor.

title: Religion Journal; American Islamic Media: Assorted and Aspiring
description: When a visitor stopped by his office, Ahmed Osman pointed to a table laden with paperbacks that Amana Publications, a publisher of Islamic books, had been producing at its headquarters in Beltsville, Md., a Washington suburb, where Mr. Osman is director of publications.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Electricity Restrictions Eased
description: With the Southern Hemisphere summer, vacation and holiday seasons approaching, the government has eased electricity rationing restrictions in place since June 1, reducing the amount by which consumption must be cut from 20 to 12 percent for most of the country. In more than 400 cities that depend heavily on tourism, including Rio de Janeiro and So Paulo, the quota has been reduced to 7 percent.

title: For Holiday Shoppers, Sale Is the Only Thing
description: Lured by sales and discounts, consumers kicked off the holiday shopping season and ventured to stores yesterday in most parts of the country with rekindled appetites. The potentially sparkling start to the season was dulled, however, by sluggish sales in the nation's shopping capital, New York, and by fear that consumer interest could be sustained only with profit-demolishing prices.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a slowdown in the Manhattan party planning business misstated the anniversary being observed by Gourmet magazine, which postponed a party. It was the 60th anniversary, not the 16th.

title: Taliban Dig In And U.S. Uses Pakistan Bases To Join Hunt
description: With Taliban troops establishing strong pockets of resistance across a wide swath of Afghanistan, the United States is using two bases in Pakistan to send in several hundred Special Operations forces in an attempt to kill Taliban troops and capture Osama bin Laden.

title: Mexico to Ignore A Trade Ruling
description: The Mexican government said today that it would ignore a World Trade Organization ruling to lift duties on high fructose corn syrup, turning instead to the North American Free Trade Agreement to protect sugar producers.

title: Residents Near Indian Point Plant Question Evacuation Plans
description: Before Sept. 11, people in New York City's northern suburbs used to crack jokes about the booklet they were mailed every year telling them what to do in the event of a disaster at the Indian Point nuclear power plant, about 30 miles north of the city on the Hudson River. With its colored maps and refrigerator magnet cheerfully reminding people where to go to escape radioactive fallout, the booklet seemed too absurd -- and the threat too unlikely -- to be frightening.

title: Gardner McKay, 69, TV Heartthrob Who Turned to Writing
description: Gardner McKay, who became famous as the star of the 1960's television series ''Adventures in Paradise'' but abandoned the spotlight to move to the Amazon jungle, died at his home in Honolulu on Wednesday. He was 69 and had been fighting prostate cancer while trying to finish his memoirs.

title: Some Clues About Victim In the Bronx Lead Nowhere
description: Three weeks after Kathy T. Nguyen, a hospital worker who lived in the Bronx, died of inhalation anthrax, investigators have excavated her discreet and simple life, turning up briefly provocative coincidences and evidence of curious habits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRUHL, ANNE
description: STRUHL-Anne. The Yeshiva High School Board of Directors, Faculty and Students mourn the loss of the Struhl family matriarch. By her example, Anne Struhl taught her family the importance of being leaders in Jewish education. Her legacy is immortalized in her children, grandchildren and greatgrandchildren's actions. May the family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Kenneth Brander, Founder Mrs. Pam Turk, President Rabbi Perry Tirschwell, Principal

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Agreement On Moldova Rebels
description: President Vladimir V. Putin and his Moldovan counterpart, Vladimir Voronin, pledged to cooperate on reining in Transnistria, a separatist region of the impoverished former Soviet republic of Moldova. Transnistria, which borders Ukraine and is primarily Russian speaking, declared independence from Moldova in 1992, spurring a short, brutal war. Moldova borders Romania and Ukraine and is populated mostly by ethnic Romanians but depends completely on Russia for its energy supply. Russian forces are still based in Trans-Dniester but Russian officials say they have withdrawn all military hardware and will soon cut the force to 1,500 troops.

title: Boxer Arrested for Knockout That Comes After His Defeat
description: A night of bouts in Midtown Manhattan that was supposed to be dedicated to charity and goodwill ended in unexpected bloodshed when a losing boxer knocked out his opponent after the fight had ended and the winner had been announced.

title: Closeup: 2 Homeland Security Proposals
description: Highlights of proposals offered by Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, right, and Representative David R. Obey of Wisconsin, far right, to increase money for homeland security in the current fiscal year. Senator Byrd proposes $15 billion, while his fellow Democrat, Representative Obey, proposes $7 billion.

title: In Herat, TV Man Is King, Veil Seller Is Lonely
description: The merchants on Pay Hassar Street a center, in pre-Taliban days, for the sale and repair of electronic equipment -- are having a very good week.

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of Wednesday, 3,915 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11.

title: If bin Laden Is Brought to Trial
description: To the Editor:

title: Simplify, Simplify
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DIANON SYSTEMS INC., Stratford, Conn., the nation's largest provider of clinical testing services for urological disorders, said its largest shareholder, a board member, G. S. Beckwith, sold 202,500 shares for $9.2 million, reducing his stake in the company to 21.8 percent from 24.5 percent. Dianon shares dropped 15 cents, to $44.90.

title: LUCENT TECHNOLOGIES TO SELL WIRELESS NETWORK
description: Lucent Technologies Inc. plans to sell the $336 million wireless network of the failed phone company One.Tel Ltd. by the end of March, a spokeswoman said. Lucent took control of the network it built for One.Tel after One.Tel, an Australian phone company, collapsed in May. Lucent, One.Tel's largest creditor, says it is owed more than 950 million Australian dollars ($492 million), while One.Tel's receiver, Ferrier Hodgson, said in July that Lucent might recover 500 million Australian dollars. ''In the first quarter of next calendar year we expect a resolution,'' said Luisa Megale, a spokeswoman at Lucent Technologies Australia and New Zealand. She declined to identify bidders for the network.

title: Israeli Forces Kill a Top Leader Of Islamic Group in West Bank
description: Firing missiles from helicopters at a van on a West Bank road, Israeli forces tonight killed a top leader of the Palestinian extremist group Hamas who had eluded them for years, Hamas officials said.

title: A Rare Defeat For a Florida Power
description: Rockledge High School accomplished something last night that no other team could in more than three years. It beat Florida's Glades Central High.

title: Abroad at Home; Right And Wrong
description: The war in Afghanistan has gone well for the United States so far in two senses, military and moral. The Taliban has been driven from most of the country. And what we have learned about it and its Al Qaeda allies has shown that this is a necessary war, a just war.

title: No Anthrax Is Found at Victim's Home or Two Nearby Postal Centers
description: The initial but extensive testing for anthrax at two postal centers near the home of the 94-year-old woman who died from inhalation anthrax this week turned up no trace of the spores, nor did a battery of samples taken from her home, Gov. John G. Rowland said today.

title: Afghans in U.S. Seek Role in Forming Homeland Government
description: They fled Afghanistan in waves over the last three decades, settling by the tens of thousands in New York and surrounding cities and towns. They built two mosques, started a school in Queens and bought hundreds of plots in cemeteries on Long Island and in New Jersey to bury their dead. They had children, even grandchildren, in the United States, and over the years some became American citizens.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABEL, BERNARD
description: ABEL-Bernard. On November 22, 2001. Beloved husband of Shirley. Loving father of Mark and Judy (Michael). Adoring grandfather of Joshua, Rebecca and Noah. Service Sunday, 9:15 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: AUTOMAKER FORMS UNIT TO OVERSEE BRITISH-BASED BRANDS
description: The Ford Motor Company's Premier Automotive Group luxury division said it formed a strategy committee to oversee its British-based Jaguar, Land Rover and Aston Martin brands in a move to bolster efficiency. The brands will combine legal, information technology and purchasing employees, the company said. The engineering work forces will remain mostly separate, it said. The realignment will not involve job cuts, the group said. It did not estimate potential cost savings.

title: 2 Families Fault Nassau For Deaths From Virus
description: The families of two East Meadow residents who died of West Nile virus, one four weeks ago and the other yesterday, are blaming Nassau County for not spraying against infected mosquitoes and say they will sue for wrongful death.

title: McGreevey Sidesteps Politics In Ramadan Speech at Mosque
description: Governor-elect James E. McGreevey greeted Muslim worshipers today after a Ramadan prayer service at a large mosque here, offering a message that carefully avoided divisive political issues related to the Middle East.

title: 'Delicate Balance' Awaits Buyer of Brooks Brothers
description: Can the button-down set survive into the dress-down 21st century? The new owner of Brooks Brothers thinks it can.

title: As Fiscal Engine Stalls, the Mechanics Line Up
description: As Congress struggles to pass a stimulus package, a debate is breaking out among economists over whether the $75 billion to $100 billion that the House and Senate seem willing to spend will be enough to pull the economy out of its downturn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARRATY, RITA ANGELO
description: GARRATY-Rita Angelo. On November 22, 2001 at age 71. Beloved wife of John. Loving mother of Marco Angelo and grandmother of Danielle, Nicholas and Natalie. Devoted sister of Dorothy Gold. Graveside service is at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, New York, Sunday 1:00 PM.

title: Imports Climb At Biggest Ports
description: Imports through the ports of Los Angeles and Long Beach, Calif., the two largest in the United States, rose in October from the year-earlier period as shipments of clothing, toys, consumer electronics and other holiday merchandise arrived.

title: On Paper Scraps, Talk of Judgment Day and Words to Friends at Home
description: Scrawled on tiny pieces of notebook paper in a steady hand, the author was sure of his allegiance and sure of his fate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, SAMUEL
description: JACOBS-Samuel. Age 95, of Palm Beach, Florida, passed away on November 22 in New York City. He is survived by his loving Millie, sisters Mary Bergofin and Kitty Chepovsky, seven grandchildren and their spouses, fourteen greatgrandchildren, his son-in-law Ernest Rubenstein and daughterin-law Eleanore Jacobs Goodman, and many nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by his first wife Anna and both his children Phyllis Rubenstein and Arthur Jacobs. Born in poverty, Mr. Jacobs achieved great success in the liquor industry as one of the three founding partners of Star Industries, Inc., and as one of the principal shareholders of The Paddington Corporation. Generous to a wide variety of charities, he was particularly dedicated to the Educational Alliance, a lower Eastside Settlement house of which he was the largest and most consistent individual donor over the past 20 years. Funeral services will held on Sunday, November 25th at 11:15 AM, ''the Riverside'', Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street in Manhattan. Contributions in his memory may be sent to the charity of the donor's choice.

title: Mary Kay Ash, Builder of Beauty Empire, Dies at 83
description: Mary Kay Ash, who built a billion-dollar beauty empire from a $5,000 investment in 1963 and who motivated hundreds of thousands of consultants around the world with a combination of rewards, recognition and religion, died Thursday at her home in Dallas. She was 83.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CARTER, DAVID
description: CARTER-David. Eight years in heaven. Remembered with love and continued respect. We will all be thinking of you at Thanksgiving dinner. Tune in. Love, Donny

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DETONE, LESLIE H.
description: DeTONE-Leslie H. Beloved wife of Steven. Loving mother of Alana, Kyra and Miles. Cherished daughter of Selma and Dr. Sidney Hammer. Dear sister of Jeff Hammer. Service Sunday, 2:30 PM at ''The Riverside'', 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York.

title: 'Futureland'
description: eth he did too. Popo called me on the vid hithelf an' he wath on'y two year ole," Misty Bent said to her wide-eyed niece, Hazel Bernard. They were sitting out on the screened porch above the Tickle River. Misty's drooping left eyelid and gnarled, half-paralyzed hands did not mask her excitement. "You kiddin'?" Hazel exclaimed.

title: World Briefing | Europe: European Union: Expansion Has Limits
description: The European Union's top negotiator with countries seeking membership discounted speculation that more than 10 countries would be in the first round of new entrants. Gnter Verheugen, the commissioner in charge of enlargement, said as many as 10 countries would be eligible by 2004, implicitly leaving out Romania and Bulgaria, which have stepped up reforms and won cautious support for early entry from France and Italy. The 10 leading candidates are Cyprus, the Czech Republic, Estonia, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Malta, Poland, Slovakia and Slovenia. Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)

title: Disbelief And Tears For Victim, 5
description: Hunching over the body of her 5-year-old great-great-grandson in a white casket, Valley Byrd touched the edge of his starched suit, her hand shaking and her sight lingering on his smooth round face. Then she turned, walking back to her seat with the help of a stick, tears rolling down her cheeks.

title: Scientific Americans
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONNELLY, JOSEPH R.
description: DONNELLY-Joseph R., 63. Of Briarcliff Manor, New York died on November 22, 2001. Joseph was born in Brooklyn, NY on October 9, 1938 to Joseph Edward and Helen Bennet Donnelly. Joseph worked as a High School Special Education Teacher in the NYC Public Schools for 26 years. Joseph served in the U.S. Army. Survived by his wife Mary Roache Donnelly. Reposing at Maher Funeral Home, 117 Washington Avenue, Pleasantville, NY Saturday 7-9 PM & Sunday 2-4 & 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, 10:30 AM, Holy Innocents Church, Pleasantville. Interment St. Charles Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEEDS, CHARLES ARTHUR JR.
description: LEEDS-Charles Arthur Jr. On November 20, 2001. Beloved husband of Susan and father of Charlie III and Susannah. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Sunday, November 25 at 10AM and stay for a memorial service at 11:30AM. Donations in his memory may be made to the Caron Foundation, 130 East 40th Street, New York, New York 10016, attn: John Hoving.

title: If bin Laden Is Brought to Trial
description: To the Editor:

title: Edith Schwartz Capa -- Photography Collaborator, 88
description: Edith Schwartz Capa, who helped found the International Center of Photography in Manhattan in 1974, died Wednesday at her Midtown home. She was 88.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Leader Seeks Help Against Rebel
description: President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo said she had appealed to the country's Muslim neighbors, Malaysia and Indonesia, for help in dealing with a Muslim rebel leader in the southern Philippines. Nur Misuari broke a five-year-old peace agreement this week and resumed his war against the government. Mrs. Arroyo did not say what help she had asked for, but there are concerns that Mr. Misuari could try to flee the country. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELLER, SHIRLEY
description: SELLER-Shirley. On November 22, 2001. Beloved wife of Marvin. Devoted mother to Larry & Meri, grandmother to Hannah, Jacob, Sheryl and Stephanie. We will miss her sharp wit, generous spirit and unconditional love. Service Edwin L. Bennett, 824 Scarsdale Ave., Scarsdale, NY 1:30 PM. Interment to follow at Mt. Eden Cemetery.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN FALLS. Signs the U.S. economy is recovering and news that Japan may increase long-term bond purchases helped the dollar rise against the yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 124.38 yen, up from 123.10 on Wednesday.

title: Blair Speech Is Seen by Many As Endorsement of the Euro
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair delivered a passionate plea today for closer ties with Europe in a speech taken by many as an endorsement of Britain's adoption of the single European currency.

title: For Twins, a Lost Double and a Missing Half
description: When Gregory and Stephen Hoffman were in college, their dormitory held a ''Come As Your Roommate'' party. The Hoffmans' costumes could not have been simpler to assemble. The young men swapped shirts and rearranged their hair, Gregory parting his in the middle and Stephen parting his on the side.

title: Pakistanis Again Said to Evacuate Allies of Taliban
description: BANGI, Afghanistan, Nov. 23  Northern Alliance soldiers said today that Pakistani airplanes had once again flown into the encircled city of Kunduz to evacuate Pakistanis who have been fighting alongside Afghan Taliban forces trapped there.

title: A Powerful Combatant in France's War on Terror
description: Eleven days after hijacked jets slammed into the World Trade Center towers, the Pentagon and a field in Pennsylvania, France's chief antiterrorism judge, Jean-Louis Bruguire, was in Dubai negotiating the extradition of one of Osama bin Laden's most important operatives in Europe.

title: St. Francis' Longtime Coach Seeks First Title Since 1990
description: Earlier this season Rich Reichert, in his 15th year as head coach at St. Anthony's, won his 100th game. But his milestone looks minor when compared with the feats of the coach who will be on the opposing sideline tomorrow when St. Anthony's plays St. Francis Prep of Queens in the Catholic High School Football League title game at Hofstra University.

title: Jiggling Its Way Into History
description: Giddily artificial and perpetually in motion, Jell-O is arguably more American than apple pie, and certainly more versatile. (Ever try to wrestle in pie?) To most of the world, it may look more like a prank than a food: immigrants at Ellis Island were unnerved when offered a confection that shuddered when touched. But since Jell-O's invention (or more crucially, the advent of its near-viral advertising) in 1897, Americans have proudly made it their own, studding it with peaches and pimentos, gulping it with vodka and on at least one occasion, forming it into a prize-winning art project containing live but cryogenically slowed-down bugs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, ALICE KREINDLER
description: LEVINE-Alice Kreindler. Died on November 22, 2001. Loving wife of Burton Levine and caring mother of Peter Levine, Nancy Huggins, & Patty Pensak; doting grandmother to Shanon, Jeremy, Carrie, Josh, Sara, Erin, and Dustin; and great grandmother to Anna & Andrew; dear sister to Betty Streim. Cpntributions in her memory may be made to The Beth Healthcare Foundation, 201 Lyons Avenue, Newark, New Jersey 07112.

title: Manila's Muslim Policy Left in Tatters by Revolt
description: MANILA  Nur Misuari was once the shining example of the success of the Philippines in integrating its Muslim minority into a largely Christian nation.

title: Camby's Not Quite Ready, but the Knicks Need Him Now
description: Marcus Camby worked his way around the perimeter of the lane, taking one jump shot after another. But after joining his first full Knicks practice since Oct. 27, Camby, who has a sore left foot, decided today that he was still not ready to play.

title: Taliban Dig In and U.S. Uses Pakistan Bases to Join Hunt
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 23  With Taliban troops establishing strong pockets of resistance across a wide swath of Afghanistan, the United States is using two bases in Pakistan to send in Special Operations forces in an attempt to kill Taliban troops and capture Osama bin Laden.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Nov. 13 about the choice of Ichiro Suzuki of the Seattle Mariners as the American League rookie of the year referred incorrectly to his accomplishment in leading the league in batting average and stolen bases. He was the first rookie ever to lead both categories, not merely since 1949. Jackie Robinson, the previous player to achieve the feat, did so in 1949, two years after his rookie season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAPA, EDITH
description: CAPA-Edith. The Trustees and staff of the International Center of Photography mourn the passing of the beloved wife of our Founder, Cornell Capa. His partner throughout a long and loving marriage, Edie also supported and nurtured the endeavors of all the ICP staff from the start of this institution. Her fierce commitment to the work of Cornell and the late Robert Capa, and the ''concerned'' photographers who inspired the founding of ICP, created the first archives of this institution and laid the foundation for the present-day collections. Her selfless dedication to ICP has been unwavering and an inspiration to us all. Held in the highest respect and affection, and always an important member of the ICP family, she will be deeply missed. Our heartfelt sympathy to Cornell and to Edie's many friends, whose great loss we share. Rita Hillman, Honorary Chair Gayle Greenhill, Chairman Raymond J. McGuire, President Willis Hartshorn, Director

title: Sports of The Times; Right Way, Wrong Way, Knicks' Way
description: JEFF VAN GUNDY loves the Knicks.

title: Riveted by War and Grief, Italy Mourns Slain Writer
description: Maria Grazia Cutuli, one of the four journalists killed in Afghanistan on Monday, is to have a school named after her in Rome. There will also be a Maria Grazia Cutuli center for immigrants here in her hometown and a Maria Grazia Cutuli newsroom at a journalism school in Milan.

title: Liberating the Women of Afghanistan
description: America did not go to war in Afghanistan so that women there could once again feel the sun on their faces, but the reclaimed freedom of Afghan women is a collateral benefit that Americans can celebrate. After five years of Taliban rule, women in Afghanistan are uncovering their faces, looking for jobs, walking happily with female friends on the street and even hosting a news show on Afghan television.

title: Man Killed During Fight With Family
description: When Lissy Thachil returned home on Thanksgiving morning after working an overnight shift, she found her husband slain, her mother injured and her father with a horrifying story to tell, the Suffolk County Police said today.

title: 'Hateship, Friendship, Courtship, Loveship, Marriage'
description: Years ago, before the trains stopped running on so many of the branch lines, a woman with a high, freckled forehead and a frizz of reddish hair came into the railway station and inquired about shipping furniture.

title: If bin Laden Is Brought to Trial
description: To the Editor:

title: A Full Charge Of Genocide For Milosevic
description: The United Nations war crimes tribunal in The Hague issued a sweeping new indictment today of the former Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic, charging him with genocide in connection with the war in Bosnia in 1992-95.

title: Putin Says Russia to Study Plan for Broader NATO Role
description: President Vladimir V. Putin told NATO's secretary general today that Russia would give urgent attention to a proposal to accord the Kremlin an equal voice with the alliance's 19 members in setting policies on some issues, like terrorism.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASKETBALL

title: Rangers Show Fighting Spirit, but Little Else, in Collapse
description: Dan Blackburn, the Rangers' 18-year-old rookie goaltender, had not been born when Billy Smith won four consecutive Stanley Cups in the early 1980's as the Islanders' goaltender with a mean streak.

title: On the Lookout For Patriotic Incorrectness
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson made the list for remarking to an audience at Harvard Law School that America should ''build bridges and relationships, not simply bombs and walls.'' Joel Beinin, a professor of Middle Eastern history at Stanford University, earned a place on it for his opinion that ''If Osama bin Laden is confirmed to be behind the attacks, the United States should bring him before an international tribunal on charges of crimes against humanity.'' And Wasima Alikhan of the Islamic Academy of Las Vegas was there simply for saying ''Ignorance breeds hate.''

title: Nets Trying to Shake Off 2 Injuries on Road Trip
description: The rookie Richard Jefferson thought the worst. The veteran Kerry Kittles thought, ''Here we go again.''

title: Is it Clammy in Here?
description: GLENDO, Wyo., bought a potato cellar to house all of the towns 294 residents. The Rand Corporation proposed a $150 billion complex of tunnels with 91 convenient entrances into which four million New Yorkers could flee in case of atomic attack. The notion of retreating underground for days or weeks to wait out nuclear war even became the stuff of fiction (remember the sex scene in Robert Henleins Farnhams Freehold and the inevitable hierarchal order of death in Mordecai Roshwalds Level 7?).

title: South Korea Planning To Build a 'Hong Kong'
description: Never mind the remote geography or even a global recession: Korean planners are dreaming very big dreams for Jeju.

title: The Mayor Prepares, Tearfully, To Depart
description: Yesterday, for perhaps the first time since Sept. 11, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani sounded like a departing mayor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGLYNN, JOHN JOSEPH
description: McGLYNN-John Joseph, 87. Of Avon, CT. Husband of Eileen (Whalen) McGlynn died on Wednesday, November 21. He was the former VP of Marketing at IBM and was married to the late Marie O'Keefe McGlynn. Besides his wife, his survivors include his two sisters & 7 children. Funeral services will be held today in Avon, CT. Donations may be made to St. Michaels College, 1 Winooski Park, Colchester, VT. 05439.

title: In Hills of South Africa, Rural District Is Engulfed
Surrender of Taliban Begins at Kunduz
Paid Notice: Deaths  BERENHOLTZ, HARRY
description: BERENHOLTZ-Harry. On November 22. Beloved husband of Edna. Devoted father of Gary and Lorraine, and loving uncle. He had a zest for life for over 94 years. He will always be in our hearts. Services today 1 PM at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY.

title: The Wizard King
description: Q: Hollywood seems to be having an incredible run of blockbuster children's movies right now. Why is it so good at speaking to kids, given that it's not always so good at finding its adult audience?

title: Writers and Artists First
description: A HERO OF OUR OWN

title: Changed Climate
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Safety First
description: To the Editor: Airlines would benefit from Betsy Rubiner's article ''Flying With Kids and Qualms,'' (Oct. 28). Perhaps after reading the interviews with concerned parents and children, airline industry heads will finally understand that people will fly again once they feel safe, not because fares are low.

title: A Brief Appearance by a SoHo Star Draws Mixed Reviews
description: When Joe Amrhein, a Conceptual painter, moved to Williamsburg 13 years ago, the neighborhood was teeming with artists but there were few galleries. A handful of alternative spaces like Brand Name Damages, Minor Injury and Test-Site, came and went. Other galleries like Pierogi, which Mr. Amrhein opened in 1994, stuck around. Today, Williamsburg has about 30 galleries, many of them artist-run.

title: N.J. TRANSIT REPORT
description: New Jersey Transit has been diverting money intended for capital improvements to pay daily operating costs for at least the last decade, creating a financial crisis, according to a Rutgers study. The agency has not increased fares for 11 years and has not received enough money from the state to cover operating expenses, the study said. New Jersey Transit does not plan fare increases for now, Jeffrey Warsh, its executive director, said, but would ask the state for more money. Karen DeMasters

title: G.I.'s at the Airport
description: To the Editor:

title: Three User's Manuals For Modern Management
description: SOMETHING funny happened on the way to the future of business. It turned out to be hard work. Technology is not magical. There is no single catch phrase, whether ''re-engineering'' or ''business-to-business software,'' that can automatically transform the nuts and bolts of how companies operate. And chief executives with ''visions'' cannot necessarily ride in on their white horses to save organizations single-handedly.

title: Guest Conductors Lead Yonkers Philharmonic
description: AN apt motto for these difficult days, ''Let the Music Continue,'' takes on even deeper significance for the Yonkers Philharmonic as the banner of its new season. For the first time in more than 30 years, the orchestra must carry on without Jerome Sala, its music director, who died Sept. 6 at the age of 75.

title: Elizabeth Moser, Douglas Chamberlain
description: Elizabeth Ann Moser, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Christian Moser of Morristown, N.J., was married yesterday to Douglas William Chamberlain, a son of Mr. and Mrs. H. David Chamberlain of Tarpon Springs, Fla. The Rev. John Mitchell performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Chapel in Manchester, Vt.

title: A 5-Finger Exercise In Stylish Warmth
description: Society folk have always had a love affair with gloves -- long, sleek opera gloves; little white wedding gloves; chic driving gloves. This season, however, is all about the mitten (though not Gore-Tex). Although impractical for the slopes, this year's mittens have a warm, fuzzy aprs-ski look. They are also nostalgic and youthful, which is just what people want right now, says Sarah Hailes, an owner of Kirna Zabte, a SoHo boutique that offers bright, fluffy old-school mittens from Fifi & Romeo ($195).

title: Taliban Foes Say Kunduz Is Theirs
description: KHANABAD, Afghanistan, Nov. 25 -- Northern Alliance commanders said tonight that their troops had captured the city of Kunduz in the dark, overrunning the last Taliban stronghold in northern Afghanistan.

title: Corrections
description: Arts & Leisure

title: Truth, Justice, Quaker Oats and Corvettes
description: THERE is this movie, not just any movie but the American movie. The setting is a small town. The story is a complex one about success and failure, friendship and family relationships. It's funny and upbeat and light, but also dark and tragic.

title: Administration Revising Its Drug Discount Proposal
description: President Bush will try again to force drugstores to give discounts on medicines sold to elderly people, even though a federal court has ruled that he lacks the authority for such a program, administration officials say.

title: Robert T. Lane: A Son's Cake and Candles
description: Robert T. Lane was a man whose size might have been intimidating were it not for his magnetic smile. Name a sport, and this towering firefighter played it, but his favorite hobby was cooking.

title: Jennifer Sokol, Greg Goldberg
description: Jennifer Beth Sokol, the daughter of Ricki Anne Sokol and Dr. Barry A. Sokol of Morris Plains, N.J., was married yesterday to Greg Michael Goldberg, a son of Andrea Goldberg and Dr. Sheldon Goldberg of Ambler, Pa. Rabbi David Nesson performed the ceremony at the Morristown Jewish Center-Beit Yisrael in Morristown, N.J.

title: Fire and Ice Cream
description: ON a recent November afternoon at the Brooklyn Ice Cream Factory, a new shop in a historic fireboat house under the Brooklyn Bridge, Mark Thompson was mixing chocolate. He was using Valrhona, the premier French chocolate, for his two chocolate-flavored ice creams, but he was not quite happy with it.

title: Wild Turkeys Stage Comeback on Island
description: TIMOTHY GREEN set out in his car the other day, creeping along the dirt roads that run through Brookhaven National Laboratory's pine barrens. The B.N.L. zoologist rounded a corner and came to a quick stop. Up ahead about 50 yards were three wild turkeys, standing nearly three feet high.

title: Devils Discover Offense To End Winless Streak
description: John Madden knew the importance of what he had just done. Madden, a center for the Devils, pumped his fist after his breakaway goal in the third period assured the Devils of ending one of their most frustrating stretches in recent seasons.

title: On the Periphery
description: To the Editor:

title: Embrace the Urge
description: If ever a move expressed the moment, it is the hug -- the default maneuver of the last couple of months. Grasping the consoling power of human touch, Americans have grasped one another at almost all opportunities.

title: In Mr. Gore's New Job, a Drexel Connection
description: When former Vice President Al Gore announced last week that he was joining Metropolitan West Financial, based in Los Angeles, the response among many people was "Joined what?" Most people are more familiar with Drexel Burnham Lambert, the former employer of the MetWest founder, Richard S. Hollander. Drexel, the defunct investment bank, was the home of the former junk bond trader Michael R. Milken, who pleaded guilty to violating securities laws in 1990. Mr. Hollander worked at Drexel for four years and headed its high-grade-bond sales team on the West Coast.

title: After a Glimpse or Two, the Choice Is Thai
description: OUR visit to Thai Pan Asian, a new restaurant in New Haven, was serendipitous. We had left the Yale Repertory Theater after a matinee and were walking along Chapel Street, trying to decide whether to dine in town or drive elsewhere.

title: Days of Wine and Ritalin
description: WHY DID I EVER

title: Wolves Wander Into Germany, Aiding a Resettlement Effort
description: The Society for the Protection of Wolves was founded in Germany in 1991, partly to create the conditions to resettle wolves there. It was an optimistic project. Wolves had been violently eradicated from German soil 140 years earlier.

title: Now That the Fences Are Gone, How About a Steak for Dinner?
description: The newly opened Sir William's Dog Run is the city's only run whose fence keeps dogs out, not in.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Jugglers as Idiots

title: Choice Tables; In and Around South Beach, Focusing Squarely on Food
description: GLANCING casually around the pastel paradise of South Beach in mid-October, I could see the signposts of a simpler time everywhere. New restaurants were opening, old Art Deco hotels were still being resurrected -- most recently the Hotel Nash -- and construction and beautification projects pressed on, creating one-lane turmoil on Collins Avenue, Miami Beach's central artery.

title: Going From Surplus to Deficit in One Year
description: LAST June, the state had a surplus of $644.8 million, left over from fiscal year 2001. The General Assembly held a special session to decide what to do with the money as they approved the 2002 budget.

title: The New York Times Top 50
description: The New York Times's computer football ranking is based on an analysis of each team's scores with emphasis on three factors: who won, by what margin and against what quality of opposition. The quality of an opponent is determined by examining the opponent's record against other teams.

title: RESPONSIBLE PARTY/KEITH McNALLY; Holding the Mayo, Efficiently
description: WAITERS can retire their pens and pads as the 21st Century Restaurant, a system based on hand-held ordering devices, dishes up a new kind of service.

title: Long Islanders On a Quest for Local History
description: FOR Long Islanders interested in local history, two exhibitions at historical societies provide a glimpse of the Island's origins and development. At the Bridge Hampton Historical Society, the focus is on East End farming families who sowed their first seeds 350 years ago. At the Oyster Bay Historical Society, a collection of family photographs and heirlooms celebrates the lives of Italian-American immigrants who flocked to the area in the late 19th and early 20th centuries.

title: A Reclaimed Park Is Due in Fall 2002
description: For generations, there were rumors around Canal Street that an asphalt covered sliver of land by the West Side Highway had once been a city park. Although the Department of Sanitation had long parked its snow plows and salt trucks there, something about the almost triangular space was, as one resident put it, ''too perfect and geometric for a parking lot.'' It had, he said, a sense of place.

title: Denis Lavelle: A Mother's Devoted Son
description: Denis Lavelle idolized Rush Limbaugh and had cleared rooms at many a family gathering arguing his hard-line conservatism, but the last thing his relatives expected him to do was run for public office. But there was Mr. Lavelle over the summer, 42 and an absolute newcomer to retail politics, going door to door around Yonkers, where he was born and raised, collecting signatures for a run for the City Council on the Right to Life line.

title: Rail Link From New York to Newark; Canadian Airline Shuts
description: ARail Link From New York to Newark Airport

title: Two if by Rail
description: To the Editor: We have just returned from the journey described by Adam Clymer in ''Traveling Like a Magnate'' (Sept. 23) on the Royal Canadian Pacific, called the Golden/Crowsnest Excursion.

title: As Alliance Deals With a Warlord, Taliban Fighters Slip Away
description: The warlord of this dusty collection of villages just 12 miles from Kabul today surrendered to, joined or made a deal with the Northern Alliance. Just which it was still was not clear after a day of frantic negotiations and marshaling of forces.

title: JUSTICE REAPPOINTED
description: Acting Governor Donald T. DiFrancesco told the Senate this week that he intended to renominate Justice James H. Coleman to the state Supreme Court. Mr. Coleman, whose term expires Dec. 16, became the first African-American on the Supreme Court when former Governor Christie Whitman appointed him to the position in 1994. At 68 years old, he could serve until the mandatory retirement age of 70 if the Senate approved his reappointment. Sarah Rubenstein

title: Denease Conley: Tough, With a Studious Side
description: The seeds of Denease Conley's toughness could be seen early on. She once had a fight with an older sister who locked herself in the bathroom, and to get her out, Denny, as she was known, threw a cherry bomb at the bathroom door.

title: November 18-24; The City Steps Out
description: The annual Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade took on an unaccumstomed gravity this year: honoring those who lost their lives in Lower Manhattan. Also new this year was the patriotic tenor of many of the floats, clowns and cheerleaders, as well as a tattered American flag found at ground zero. Children of those lost in the attacks helped cut the rope that kicked off the 75-year-old spectacle.

title: Silicon Beach
description: SUPER-CANNES

title: Pass the Bicarb
description: THE RAW AND

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONNER, JULIUS
description: DONNER-Julius. Of Boca Raton, Florida. Passed away November 19, 2001. After 40 years in the life insurance and pension business, Mr. Donner retired to Boca Raton, where he developed a passion for wildlife photography. His photography is on permanent display at Florida Atlantic University and Boca Raton Community Hospital. Mr. Donner is survived by his loving wife of 45 years, Nancy, children Lisa & Richard Goldman of Coral Springs, Florida, Eric and Robin Donner of Warren, New Jersey, Stacey & Mark Hallerman of Port Washington, New York, and six grandchildren.

title: Private Sector; In Mr. Gore's New Job, A Drexel Connection
description: When former Vice President Al Gore announced last week that he was joining Metropolitan West Financial, based in Los Angeles, the response among many people was ''Joined what?'' Most people are more familiar with Drexel Burnham Lambert, the former employer of the MetWest founder, Richard S. Hollander. Drexel, the defunct investment bank, was the home of the former junk bond trader Michael R. Milken, who pleaded guilty to violating securities laws in 1990. Mr. Hollander worked at Drexel for four years and headed its high-grade-bond sales team on the West Coast.

title: The Affordable Housing Complex That Works
description: Eight children sit around a conference table; one struggles with subtraction, another studies a map and tries to identify the Great Lakes. All of them have raced over to this makeshift after-school program in a temporary office trailer at the Ethel R. Lawrence Homes.

title: Romantic Bench; Safety First; Hyde Park
description: Romantic Bench

title: Rock Around the Table
description: For hip parents who prefer Barneys New York to Barney the Dinosaur, ''Family Dance,'' the long-awaited second album from the kiddie rocker Dan Zanes, has arrived. Mr. Zanes, whose summer concerts in Manhattan were popular with adults who are children at heart, like Gwyneth Paltrow, Stella McCartney and David Duchovny, sings with his band, Rocket Ship Review, as well as with Loudon Wainwright III, Sandra Bernhard and Barbara Brousal. The new compact disc (as well as Mr. Zanes's first album, ''Rocket Ship Beach'') is available for $15.98 at www.festivalfive.com. Just in time for holiday hokeypokey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAGGIOLO, MARY
description: MAGGIOLO-Mary. On November 22, 2001. Beloved aunt and greataunt. She will be remembered and loved. Reposing Stout Funeral Service, Inc., 352 E. 87 St, NYC on Monday November 26, 2001 from 1-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday 10AM, Our Lady of Good Counsel Church. Interment Calverton National Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADAMS, GERTRUDE G.
description: ADAMS-Gertrude G. 90. Beloved wife of the late James F. Adams. Devoted mother of Rosemary Hummel, John, Virginia, and James. Interment services 1:30 pm Monday, November 26, St. Peter's Cemetery, Poughkeepsie, NY.

title: Seeking Freedom and Security at a Time of War
description: To the Editor:

title: Hewlett-Packard's Destiny
description: There are few dramas in the corporate world as messy -- and riveting -- as a battle between the founding family of a company and its present management. Hewlett-Packard, the patriarch of Silicon Valley, is now enduring such a struggle. It reveals a good deal about not only the state of a troubled company, but also the state of the industry Hewlett-Packard did so much to create.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: STUDY OF REVENGE

title: Farrell P. Lynch: Strivers, Like Their Parents
description: Whatever their achievements, the Lynch boys were products of their upbringing. The children of Irish immigrants, Sean P. Lynch, top, and his brother Farrell P. Lynch were strivers like their parents.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Westerleigh, Staten Island; Where Flags Fly Outside Historic Homes
description: FLAGS have always been flown on American holidays on Burnside Avenue in the Westerleigh neighborhood of Staten Island, but since Sept. 11, more houses are flying flags supplied by one neighbor -- John Nappi, a 77-year-old veteran of World War II -- and they're out every day. ''Driving down that block,'' said Michael Morrell, president of the Westerleigh Improvement Society, ''makes you feel like you're in a procession.''

title: November 18-24; Still Unbearable, but Better
description: Shortly after the attack on the World Trade Center, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said the death toll, whatever it turned out to be, would be ''far more than any of us can bear.'' More than two months later, it appears that that terrible number has at least fallen considerably from the estimates made just days after terrorists flew planes into the Twin Towers.

title: An Apparel Rent-a-Closet
description: What to get the New Yorker who has everything? More closet space might be the practical answer. Fashion fanciers who require more than a musty locker to store precious threads can call on Garde Robe, a new company with a deluxe solution: For a monthly fee, Garde Robe dry-cleans and stores off- and on-season apparel, as well as evening wear, bridal gowns and even bedding. Each item is insured, photographed and catalogued in a leather-bound portfolio; the information is also available on a secure Web site, for 24-hour access.

title: The Swimmer
description: Like Burt Lancaster before him, David Hasselhoff plays the part of the charming and winsome Neddy Merrill, who pool-hops his way home as a cast of backstabbing neighbors lounge around in the season's hottest resort clothes.

title: Bill Walton's Inside Game
description: In the 20 years since I wrote about the Portland Trail Blazers in an earlier book, Bill Walton and I have become good friends, and I have spent a good deal of time with him and with his sons (Pat Jordan, Oct. 28). The relationship between father and sons has always struck me as loving, supportive and mutually generous; I think it is not unimportant that in a home where the father let all of his sons follow their own stars, all four wanted to play basketball. More important, what Pat Jordan missed was the story right in front of him: the rarest kind of courage and exuberance on the part of an athlete, once gifted, whose ability to maximize the uses of his body is so critical to his psyche but is now so seriously jeopardized by the cruelest kind of injuries to both feet.

title: The Health Care Spark
description: To the Editor:

title: Stojakovic and Kings Stop Nets From Coming Back
description: Comebacks have become the Nets' specialty and Jason Kidd's mission. But tonight, in making yet another fourth-quarter run, they were a step behind on defense and were never able to climb out of the deficit they created.

title: Most Parties Will Go On, Even If They're Quieter
description: Still reeling from the terrorist attacks and from the weak economy, which has squeezed profits and produced layoffs, corporate America may hardly be in the mood for merriment. Yet many companies plan to hold some type of holiday celebration, though maybe on a less lavish scale, two surveys show.

title: Heron Lands Again On Beach in Southold
description: A 40-foot-high great heron reappeared last week on the beach at Paradise Point in Southold after building officials decided it was permitted under town law.

title: Edwards Is Serious Student of the Jets' Desultory History
description: It has not started this well for the Jets since 1986. (You do not want to know how it ended.) But with a 7-3 start, Herman Edwards has presided over the finest opening 10 games of any rookie coach in Jets history.

title: Footlights; A Sharing of Images
description: ''I've always wanted to have an environment where people could come and share their love of the medium,'' said Mark Sadan, a longtime photographer from Ossining. ''A place where there's no guilt, and people just come and talk.''

title: November 18-24
description: Still Unbearable, but Better

title: Dumbing Down
description: To the Editor:

title: A Forgotten Creator of Modern Comedy
description: BACK when radio was more than all news, all talk or all-preprogrammed disc jockeys, one of the biggest stars on the air was a baggy-eyed, nasal-sounding former juggler. The audience could not see the eyes, of course, and what made Fred Allen a household name in the 1930's and 40's was not the way he juggled objects but the way he juggled words.

title: Too Late the Potoroo
description: Sometimes extinction is like an execution. There is a time and place, and someone does the deed. The last of the great auks, for example, was clubbed to death off the coast of Iceland on June 3, 1844. A bird collector named Rollo Beck shot 9 of the last 11 hawks known as Guadalupe caracaras on Dec. 1, 1900. The last passenger pigeon died in the Cincinnati Zoo on Sept. 1, 1914. Other species, however, have simply faded into the Darwinian twilight. In A GAP IN NATURE: Discovering the World's Extinct Animals (Atlantic Monthly, $34.95), Tim Flannery has collected the stories of many of the world's now vanished creatures. Each page is an obituary for one of them, giving the concise facts of its life and death. Peter Schouten's graceful accompanying portrait of each of the deceased gives readers a face that says even more about the finality of extinction. The criteria for inclusion in the book -- among them, extinction between 1500 and 1999 and sufficient material to sketch from -- results in a collection of obscure animals from far-flung places (I did not know a bilby from a Bavarian pine-vole or a potoroo from an 'o'o). These species vanished for any number of reasons, including volcanic eruptions and avian malaria. Humanity has been a major factor, out of ignorance more often than malice. Only recently have we even realized a species could disappear. The naturalist Thomas Molyneux, describing the remains of an Irish elk in 1697, wrote, ''No species of living creatures is so utterly extinct, as to be lost entirely out of the World.'' Readers of ''A Gap in Nature'' will know otherwise. Edward McSweegan

title: Habitats/White Plains; From Rental to Co-op In the Same Building
description: WHITE PLAINS is only 30 minutes by train from Midtown Manhattan, but Ivy Bacote says it's very different from the city, certainly from the eastern Bronx, where she was raised and where her parents still live.

title: A Favorite of Tal's in Nimzo-Indian Defense
description: Four grandmasters tied for first place in the fifth open International Bavarian Championship, which this year was in Bad Wiessee, Germany, Oct. 27 to Nov. 4: Vladimir Akopian of Armenia; Vladimir Baklan of Ukraine; Alexander Shabalov of Pittsburgh; and Michal Krasenkow of Poland. All tallied 7 1/2-1 1/2 to top a nine-round Swiss-system field of 512.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KLEBAN, FRANCIS J.
description: KLEBAN-Francis J. Lovingly remembered and deeply missed.

title: Kevin Pfeifer: Shouting With His Life
description: To the casual acquaintance, Kevin Pfeifer had a manner -- a quiet, thoughtful demeanor -- that seemed of a piece with all the philosophy courses he took at Marist College. His gift for abstractions, though, was far exceeded by his taste for the concrete. And adventure.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCUS, HARRIETT
description: MARCUS-Harriett. On November 23, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Carl. Loving aunt of Sandy Ward, Ani Hurwitz, Ray Ward and Leah Fineberg. Service Sunday 1PM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Because Too Many Sequins Is Not Enough
description: IF the first rule of Los Angeles is You Are What You Drive, Nolan Miller is the textbook example. Known as the designer who made Linda Evans's padded, sequined shoulders on ''Dynasty'' as prominent a symbol of the 1980's as Gordon Gekko's greed, Mr. Miller is big, has classic lines and is in mint condition, calling to mind Ronald Reagan's on-the-ranch, barrel-chested good looks. And he is, he said, expensive to maintain.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LAZARUS, MEYER ''FLIP''
description: LAZARUS-Meyer ''Flip''. November 24th is the 100th anniversary of the birth of Meyer ''Flip'' Lazarus. His friends and family celebrate his warmth, his humor and his loyalty. We celebrate his life. He is missed and loved, always

title: A Harmony Of Voices Is Raised For Opera
description: AS Christmas approaches, the students at Westminster Choir College of Rider University are again expected to present their choral concerts, for which they are well known.

title: United Nations
description: Sullivan's article resonated with me because of ties to London I made 23 years ago, while there on a medical fellowship. One of the first telephone calls I received after Sept. 11 was from Harry, an ebullient London cabbie who first picked me up at Heathrow 10 years ago, when I arrived for my annual summer holiday. Harry has met me there each summer since. As with Andrew Sullivan's experience, these are the ties that bind.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report on Nov. 4 about a rally by part-time professors for better pay and working conditions referred incorrectly to an average salary for full-time professors in New Jersey. Such a figure is not available; $96,428 was for full professors -- as opposed to associate or assistant professors -- at the state's public universities.

title: On the Witness Stand
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARRATY, RITA ANGELO
description: GARRATY-Rita Angelo. On November 22, 2001 at age 71. Beloved wife of John. Loving mother of Marco Angelo and grandmother of Danielle, Nicholas and Natalie. Devoted sister of Dorothy Gold. Graveside service is at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, New York, Sunday 1:00 PM.

title: November 18-24; A Ray of Hope in Kosovo
description: After 10 years of violence in Kosovo, the results of the vote to elect the province's first democratically chosen assembly were not nearly as surprising as the fact that the election process was peaceful.

title: Houston Is Bright Spot in Dismal Game by Knicks
description: He has struggled along with his team for almost the entire season, missing open shots and disappearing for quarters at a time. That he became the richest player in franchise history a few months ago only magnified his shortcomings.

title: One Jersey Girl's Advice to Afghan Women
description: THE day after the Taliban fled Kabul, I saw a picture in the newspaper of how the women were celebrating their new freedom: washing clothes in the Kabul River.

title: A Boom Built Upon Sand, Gone Bust
description: THE trailer is white and narrow, a starter model with black shutters. It sits off a wooded road outside this rundown town, which missed most of the last decade's boom but is catching every bit of this year's bust.

title: Martin's Exuberance Is Symbol of New Nets
description: SACRAMENTO, Nov. 24 — When Kenyon Martin dunks, he doesn't just yell. He roars, swinging on the rim for punctuation, as if to proclaim his territory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIANNASCA, BARBARA LYNN
description: GIANNASCA-Barbara Lynn. Tragically on November 12, 2001, aboard flight #

title: Yankee Heartbreak
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Mohammed Refai
description: Mohammed Refai became a detainee on Sept. 18, after federal investigators in Arkansas found documents that appeared to connect one of the terrorist hijackers, Saeed Alghamdi, with an apartment complex in Akron, Ohio.

title: Two if by Rail
description: To the Editor: The chart entitled ''How Punctual Is Amtrak?'' (Travel Advisory, Sept. 9) inspired me to write about the excellent experience my husband and I had in April, when we took Amtrak around the United States. Starting with the Crescent in New York City, we arrived on time in New Orleans. The Sunset Limited from New Orleans arrived one hour earlier than scheduled in Los Angeles. The Coast Starlight was on time from Los Angeles into Seattle.

title: The Baffling Voyage of the Staten Island-Australia Ferry
description: Frank Allis has a tongue-in-cheek theory about how a copper masthead light that may have been used on a Staten Island ferryboat made its way to a junk shop in Perth, Australia. He says that one day in the 1950's a ferry captain dozed at the wheel, drifted off course and landed in Western Australia. It's a good story, even though the historical record, with its dreary insistence on facts, says otherwise.

title: Deborah Hofmann, Eric Asimov
description: Deborah Anne Hofmann and Eric Asimov were married on Tuesday at the Sea Ranch Chapel in Sonoma County, Calif. Kathleen Gregory Henschel, a minister of the Universal Life Church and a sister-in-law of the bride, officiated.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: TRUE HISTORY OF THE KELLY GANG, by Peter Carey. (Vintage International, $14.) The author, who fused Victorian grandeur with Australian earthiness in works of fiction like ''Jack Maggs'' and ''Oscar and Lucinda,'' again walks the line between the fantastical and the realistic in his latest novel, the confession of Ned Kelly, an Australian Jesse James who -- according to this version -- was less a thuggish murderer than an anticolonial freedom fighter. ''Packed with incident, alive with comedy and pathos,'' this outlaw tale, which won this year's Booker Prize, ''contains pretty much everything you could ask of a novel,'' Anthony Quinn wrote here earlier this year.

title: What if Terror Went Nuclear?
description: To the Editor:

title: What if Terror Went Nuclear?
description: To the Editor:

title: Practical Traveler; To Europe, On the Cheap
description: DISCOUNT air fares to Europe this time of year are nothing new; fares to Europe usually drop markedly between November and mid-March, with some exceptions for the holidays around Christmas. But this fall, with trans-Atlantic travel in a slump, there are more seats available at these low fares and fewer time restrictions.

title: Homer's Odyssey
description: I recently watched two ''Simpsons'' episodes that are now forever tinged with sadness. (Needless to say, I saw them on my own taped collection and not on TV.) In one, Homer and Bart are howling in delight while watching a show called ''When Buildings Collapse'' (''I like the part when the buildings fall down,'' Homer says.) In the other, Bart's boy band stars in a video in which they fight dark-haired terrorists in a desert and sing that it's time to ''drop da bomb.'' Later in the episode, a New York City skyscraper (in the show, it houses the offices of Mad magazine) is destroyed and collapses to the ground. Now I wonder how I could ever have thought those bits were funny.

title: The City Of Our Dreams
description: ON a clear, crisp November morning, Betty Comden and Adolph Green are seated side by side in Ms. Comden's sunny apartment near Lincoln Center, high above the Hudson River. Finishing each other's sentences, adding a gentle correction here, a quick clarification there, the two 80-something writers, who have been collaborating for more than 60 years and still meet daily, moved easily through fond remembrances of their days working with Leonard Bernstein, Rosalind Russell, Judy Holliday, Gene Kelly.

title: Kabul's New Rulers Lament a Leader Who Died Too Soon
description: The dead man's face is everywhere, looking down from walls, staring through windshields, decorating storefronts. Ahmed Shah Massoud is Kabul's inescapable poster boy, his symbolic presence eclipsed only by his corporeal absence.

title: Making Golf Courses Ecologically Greener
description: IF you ask Ed Wachter, golf course superintendent at the Innsbrook Resort and Conference Center in Innsbrook, Mo., about his course, he will describe his carefully maintained playing areas. He will also tell you about his native prairie grasses and wildflowers. At times he sounds more like a home gardener than someone responsible for keeping 250 acres of golf courses in prime playing condition.

title: A Space Station Out of Control
description: The international space station -- the centerpiece of the American manned space program -- has encountered severe cost and management difficulties that could damage its value as a platform for conducting ''world class'' science, the supposed goal of the project. No more urgent task will confront the next administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration than to get this troubled program under control.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITING, JANE (NEE RENDLEMAN)
description: WHITING-Jane (nee Rendleman). Of Rochester, NY, on November 21st, 2001. Beloved wife of Alan. Loving of mother of Judy (Arthur Baer), Nancy Adams (Brian), and Emily (Christa Torrens). Grandmother of Audrey and Evan Adams. Jane was raised in Anna, IL, graduated with honors from the Unversity of Illinois and earned advanced degrees from the University of Vermont and the University of Rochester. Contributions in her memory to Rochester Public Library, Rundel Branch, 115 South Ave, Rochester, NY 14604.

title: Appetizers For Romance
description: Since even the most independent New York singles are suddenly yearning for the coziness of a relationship, two restaurants have decided to help out. Eugene, 27 West 24th Street, has introduced a first-date menu that includes a raw bar selection, fondue, lobster and Champagne ($100 a couple, tax and tip not included). ''Since September, so many people are saying, 'I just want to be with the right person,' '' Sam DeMarco, Eugene's consulting chef, said. ''All the food on the menu is for sharing. It's tactile and sexy.''

title: What Happens When a Star Vehicle Is Staged Without a Star
description: IS ''Pride's Crossing'' a surpassing play or merely a vehicle for a star who is passing through?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORMAN, SOL
description: FORMAN-Sol. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJAFederation of New York mourn the passing of Sol Forman who, with his family, expressed an admirable commitment to Jewish and other humanitarian causes. Sol's daughter, Amy Rubenstein, is a dedicated leader of UJA-Federation and is active in our Jewish Community Relations Council. Amy's husband, Howard Rubenstein, is an exemplary leader of our community, earning the admiration and respect of friends and colleagues for his generosity and commitment to those in need. Sol's daughters, Elissa Cullman & Marilyn Spiera, and their families are also cherished friends of UJAFederation. We extend our deepest sympathies to Sol's children, Amy and Howard Rubenstein, Elissa and Edgar M. Cullman, and Marilyn and Harry Spiera; to his grandchildren and great-grandchildren; and to his entire family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO Joan Ginsburg, Chair of the Women's Campaign

title: What if Terror Went Nuclear?
description: To the Editor:

title: Chyron to Pare Jobs
description: The Chyron Corporation (OTC: CYRO) of Melville plans to cut its work force by more than 20 percent after reporting a net loss in the third quarter of $10.1 million, compared with a net loss of $2.4 million in the same quarter a year ago. The company currently employs 326 people.

title: Dead Girl and Mother Found In Casino Garage Are Identified
description: Detectives in Atlantic City said yesterday that they had few leads in the investigation into the death of a 5-year-old girl from Mays Landing, N.J., whose body was found Friday lying next to her seriously injured mother on the floor of a parking garage of the Trump Taj Mahal Casino and Resort.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, HUGH J.
description: KELLY-Hugh J. Of Olive Bridge, New York, died Nov. 19, 2001. Husband of the late Catherine M. Rice Kelly, father of Sr. Agnes Kelly, OSU, of Kingston, NY, Hugh Jr. of Weston, MA, Edmund of Bedford, NY, Neill of Briarcliff, NY, Daniel of Ossining, NY and the late Christopher Kelly, deceased in 1959. Grandfather of 18, great-grandfather of 30. Visiting hours at the Pelham Funeral Home, 64 Lincoln Ave, Pelham, NY, Tuesday from 2-4 & 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Catharine's Church on Wednesday at 10:00 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers the family suggests donations in his memory to the Christopher J. Kelly Scholarship Fund, Iona Preparatory School, New Rochelle, New York 10804 (914-632-0714).

title: In (and Around) a Giant's Footsteps
description: WHEN Robert Shaw conducted a chorus, he fashioned it into a precision instrument capable of the most translucent pianissimo, the creamiest legato, the slowest diminuendo and the most crystalline diction. His lifelong pursuit of exacting musical standards changed expectations for choral music. His interpretations -- unfailingly meticulous and vigorous in orchestral as well as choral repertory -- can be heard on many recordings, including more than 40 with the Atlanta Symphony, which he led for 21 years, beginning in 1967.

title: A Sanctuary That Soothes the Spirit
description: USUALLY, by this time, most of the foliage has already fallen. The maple trees are the only ones that still have leaves, but their gold, yellow and red are brilliant. Penny, our dog, is eager for a walk and I'd like to lure my son Jared away from his Nintendo. I tell him we're going to the wetland sanctuary up the road and he surprises me by his enthusiasm to come along.

title: Ali al-Maqtari
description: In the two months he spent in a detention center in Mason, Tenn., Ali al-Maqtari had a lot of time to think about why he had lost his liberty. But even now, two weeks after he was released with a simple, ''You're free to go,'' he is unable to explain it.

title: A Small Food Thing
description: In Raymond Carver's story ''A Small, Good Thing,'' a baker feeds warm rolls and coffee to a couple who have just lost their only child. ''You have to eat and keep going,'' he says. ''Eating is a small, good thing at a time like this.''

title: Amy Gittelman, Kenneth Miller
description: Amy Beth Gittelman, a daughter of Susan Gittelman of Forest Hills, Queens, and the late Edward M. Gittelman, was married yesterday to Kenneth Jordan Miller, a son of Eleanor and Sheldon L. Miller of Boca Raton, Fla.
