Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel officiated at the Angel Orensanz Foundation in Manhattan.

title: Corrections
description: A picture of Plcido Domingo last Sunday, with an article about the emergence of Monday as the favorite night out for many New Yorkers, was published in error. The picture, among a group illustrating recent social events that had taken place on Mondays, showed Mr. Domingo performing at the Metropolitan Opera on Sept. 22, which was a Saturday.

title: Leave It To Cheever
description: ''All Swimmers Must Take a Shower Before Using the Pool. All Swimmers Must Use the Footpath. All Swimmers Must Wear Their Identification Disks.'' Signs at the recreation center in ''The Swimmer.''

title: Edward R. Pykon: Fast Eddy From Lehigh
description: Life was proceeding more or less on schedule for Edward R. Pykon and his wife, Jackie.

title: Stitch by Stitch, a Daughter of Islam Takes On Taboos
description: WHAT is going on now politically is like a mirror of what has always gone on in myself, because I am a hybrid of the West and the East,'' says Ghada Amer, a 38-year-old Egyptian-born artist who lived in France from the age of 11 and moved to Manhattan four years ago. ''It's a clash between civilizations that of course don't understand each other. I've lived with these contradictions all my life.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTMAN, MANNY
description: ALTMAN-Manny. On November 17, 2001. The family of Leonard & Harry Altman and Milton & Freda Pasternack mourn the loss of Manny Altman of Fountain Valley, CA, formerly of Roslyn, NY.

title: Sarah LaValley, Marcel Gttinger
description: Sarah Elizabeth LaValley, the daughter of Caroline J. LaValley of Whitehouse Station, N.J., and the late Joseph F. LaValley, was married on Friday to Marcel Gttinger, the son of Hans Gttinger of Mhlin, Switzerland, and the late Margarethe Gttinger. The Rev. Charles Eastman performed the ceremony at the Coral Gables Congregational Church in Coral Gables, Fla.

title: Corrections
description: The contents listing on Page 1 of Arts & Leisure today reverses the numbers in some copies for two music pages. The articles about the choral legacy of Robert Shaw, about the Boston Symphony and about the pianist Ivan Moravec are on Page 27. The ones about Mick Jagger and Sarah Dougher are on Page 29.

title: FLORIDA
description: ROCKLEDGE defeated GLADES CENTRAL, 21-14, in the Class 3A regional final in Belle Glade, Fla., on Friday night, snapping the three-time defending state champion's 47-game winning streak, the second longest in Florida history.

title: QUICK BITE/Red Bank; We All Live in Elsie's Submarine
description: The pink-and-blue neon sign in the window stood out on the quiet nighttime streets of downtown Red Bank. I stepped into Elsie's Submarines, and was warmly greeted by an older fellow in a black knit cap. Elsie's is quite narrow, so it was hard to miss him. He sat at one of the four tables for two, sipping from a giant mug of tea. I nodded hello, and walked to the deli display case. Now I was confronted with a list of 25 regular submarine sandwiches, 12 specialty subs, 6 other sandwiches, salads, soup, chili, mac-and-cheese and desserts. Sandwiches ranged from $2.45 for half a veggie sub to $6.95 for a whole Red Bank Reuben. I ordered the chicken parm. I always order chicken parm. I also picked up a root beer, one of six varieties of Elsie's Own bottled sodas. The cow print on the bottle's label was an obvious tribute to Borden's Elsie the Cow. During my Plainsboro days, I lived just down the road from the tombstone of the original Elsie (1932-1941), whose real name was You'll Do Lobelia. Elsie's Subs opened its doors in 1959. Forty-two years later, I enjoyed my chicken parm and root beer. The older gentleman -- his name is Harry -- struck up a conversation with me. We talked about the Taliban, the Count Basie Theater and Elsie's tuna wrap. (Harry pronounced it ''good.'') I don't know if Harry is always sitting inside Elsie's, giving a friendly hello to all who enter. But I like to think he is.

title: An Old House Reveals The State's Black History
description: PETER MOTT might have liked the idea that his old homestead would later sit amid 20 modern town houses in a bright new cul-de-sac.

title: A Night Sky Obscured By Dusk-to-Dawn Light
description: IN this quiet town there are only two traffic lights, no shopping center, not even a diner to mar the quiet rhythms of country life. Yet some residents insist the town's rural character is in jeopardy.

title: What's Doing In Orlando
description: Warm weather doesn't stand in the way of holiday celebrations at Orlando's theme parks, which typically include carolers, holiday lights and even fake snow. Travelers may also find good deals on air fares and room rates as Florida tries to recover momentum it lost after Sept. 11, when people became skittish about flying.

title: Travel Advisory; Handel's London Home Opens as a Museum
description: The recently restored London house in which the German composer George Frideric Handel wrote ''Messiah'' opened Nov. 8 as the Handel House Museum.

title: Erin O'Brien, Pablo Cubarle
description: Erin Patrice O'Brien, a daughter of Maureen Hoffmann of La Jolla, Calif., and Joseph P. O'Brien of Media, Pa., was married yesterday to Pablo Cubarle, the son of Olga Beatriz Mammanna de Cubarle and Rodolfo Agustin Cubarle of Crdoba, Argentina. The Rev. Ralph J. Chieffo performed the ceremony at St. Mary Magdalen Roman Catholic Church in Media.

title: Peter Siracuse: Game Day, Every Day
description: Peter Siracuse lived for competition. As a child he jockeyed for attention with his three older brothers. As a young adult, he took his aggression out on the gridiron and in lacrosse. He also played football in college.

title: Court Clears Way For Vote in Brookhaven
description: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn has cleared the way for a vote on council districts in Brookhaven. Town voters will be asked to decide whether council districts should replace the current system of at-large elections for town board members.

title: Australia Wants More People, but Without More Immigration
description: Australians recently made it clear in a national election that they want to limit immigration, but they also recognize that they need more people for their country.

title: Giving Women a Voice
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: THE CHOSEN ONE

title: Land Rover Franchise Opens With a Gift to Red Cross
description: Though the economy is retrenching, Thomas Coughlin is not. Already an owner of nine auto franchises, he just opened a 10th: Land Rover Larchmont/New Rochelle, at 1 East Main Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MYERS, EUGENE
description: MYERS-Eugene. On November 19, 2001. Beloved husband of Doris, adoring father of Sue. Services were held Tuesday, November 20.

title: Footlights; Music to Watch By
description: Sara Davis Buechner is about to begin her own marathon. This one is at the piano, and it begins today at 5:30 p.m. at the Jacob Burns Film Center in Pleasantville. The occasion is the showing of the 1925 silent film ''Ben-Hur,'' with Ms. Buechner playing an uninterrupted two-hour accompaniment. The score was composed by William Axt and David Mendoza.

title: Ideas & Trends; Notes From Underground
description: AS Taliban forces retreat under pressure, many are trying to regroup in the crags and caverns of Afghanistan's mountains. Then the real war will start, Osama bin Laden recently told a Pakistani journalist. But President Bush has repeatedly vowed to ''smoke them out of their holes,'' conjuring an image of burrowing rodents whose eradication is a only a matter of fumigation.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the poet Billy Collins misstated the title of his latest collection at two points. As noted elsewhere in the article, it is ''Sailing Alone Around the Room,'' not ''Sailing Around the Room.''

title: After Sept. 11, Complaints of Job Bias Mount
description: The complaints are coming from all corners of the country and from people in all types of industries -- from an airplane mechanic in Texas to a Wal-Mart greeter in Virginia.

title: Where Western Technique and African Wisdom Meet
description: ALONZO KING is the latest among a small but growing number of dance makers for whom the stage is a meeting place between African and Western culture. In their work, performance styles mingle and sometimes fuse to create subtly altered forms of ballet and modern dance.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: DON'T you love it when the Cohen brothers get it right? O BROTHER, WHERE ART THOU? (2000) begins with a 1930's Mississippi chain gang singing mournfully, and George Clooney looks great in chains and horizontal strips. He's also hysterically funny. As Ulysses Everett McGill, he and two other escaped convicts are on the road, and like the men of Homer's ''Odyssey'' they run into memorable beings and situations, including a Ku Klux Klan lynching. The down-home Depression-era music is elating. The cast also includes John Turturro and Tim Blake Nelson as Ulysses' pals, Charles Durning as a comically corrupt politician, John Goodman as a deceiving one-eyed Bible salesman and Holly Hunter as Ulysses' wife, who has told their seven daughters he was hit by a train - Saturday at 8 p.m. and Saturday/Early Sunday at 3:25 a.m. on Starz.

title: Increase Foreign Aid
description: To the Editor:

title: What a Difference a Year Makes: Raiders Doing What Giants Did
description: A timely tackle or a favorable bounce for the Oakland Raiders 10 months ago could have substantially altered the billing for today's game at Giants Stadium. A break here or there in last January's American Football Conference championship, and the meeting of the Giants and the Raiders on this Thanksgiving weekend would have also been the rematch of Super Bowl XXXV.

title: Mysteries In Thriller At Penguin
description: IF Guy Fawkes, and all he symbolizes, is foreign to American audiences, an explanatory note in the program for the Penguin Theater, where ''A Penny for the Guy'' is being produced, could have helped to explain this title. But only Lanie Robertson, the playwright, could help to decode the whole play, or at least he could try.

title: BackTalk; Athletes Offer Straight Talk About Cancer
description: The holidays are almost over for Lance Armstrong. Soon, there will be no more beer with meals and every morsel of food will be weighed before he eats it. His daily bicycle rides will become too speedy for casual conversation. The European racing season is approaching, although most Americans won't be aware of it until sometime this summer during the Tour de France, that mad carnival of endurance, pain and drugs.

title: Art Listings
description: Museums/Institutions

title: 'Special Providence'
description: Lord Bryce, a British statesman who served as Britain's ambassador to the United States from 1907 to 1913, once wrote that the role of foreign policy in American life could be described the way travelers described snakes in Ireland: "There are no snakes in Ireland."

title: Travel Advisory; African-Americana: An Alexandria Guide
description: ''A Remarkable and Courageous Journey,'' a 20-page guide to important places in the African-American history of Alexandria, Va., has been published by the Alexandria Convention and Visitors Association.

title: SURRENDER OF TALIBAN BEGINS AT FINAL NORTHERN STRONGHOLD
description: Hundreds of Taliban soldiers streamed out of the besieged northern city of Kunduz today, some to the welcoming arms of joyous crowds, others to the custody of their adversaries, each group following a script of surrender that culminated a two-week standoff in one of the last Taliban strongholds.

title: Molding Audiences
description: To the Editor:

title: A Murder Mystery With Aspirations
description: RELEASED in 1973 -- the same year as ''The Exorcist'' -- the equally chilling ''Wicker Man'' was initially ignored. Eventually, it became a cult sensation. But as indicated in the documentary that accompanies the current Anchor Bay ''Special Edition'' DVD release, ''The Wicker Man'' was in horror-movie no man's land at first: nobody knew what to make of it.

title: The World; After the Taliban, Who? Don't Forget North Korea.
description: WITH the Taliban badly battered in Afghanistan, and Osama bin Laden on the run, the biggest parlor game in Washington has now boiled down to one question: What will Phase II of the war look like?

title: Nepal Rebels End Cease-Fire, Carrying Out Wave of Attacks
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, Nov. 24 (Agence France-Presse) — At least 36 police officers and soldiers were killed as Maoist rebels in Nepal ended their four-month cease-fire with a wave of attacks across the country, Home Ministry officials said today.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHARNAS, JULIET
description: CHARNAS-Juliet. 100, on November 21. Survived by her sister Lila Obletz, sons Stephen and Jonathan, daughter-in-law Suzy, grandchildren Charles and Joanna, and great-grandchildren. A loving, sacrificing, elegant mother, and wife of the late attorney, Theodore Charnas. Memorial service Sunday, in Albuquerque, NM.

title: James R. Paul: Finding Their Place
description: In 1993, when James R. Paul decided to move to New York after two decades in Chicago, he was walking around Gramercy Park one day with a real estate broker when a building caught his eye. Built in 1883, it appealed to Mr. Paul's taste for the old and beautiful. "I wish we could find a place there," he told the broker, pointing to the red-brownish brick facade. They did.

title: BMW M5: It's Nice To Drive the King
description: IF everything seems under control,'' Mario Andretti once declared, ''you're just not going fast enough.'' That is a risky proposition to apply to the BMW M5. Most of the time I was in a gleaming black version of same, everything seemed so under control that I repeatedly ended up going far too fast.

description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

description: The bets are in and the wheel is spinning, but observers of Atlantic City's devil-may-care political landscape say the new mayor, Lorenzo Rennie Langford, should escape the fate of many recent predecessors.

description: Within hours after Assemblyman Joseph V. Doria Jr. conceded in the bitter fight among Assembly Democrats over who would be the next speaker, some of the state's most powerful Democrats began making backroom noise about ousting the Senate Democratic leader, Richard J. Codey.

title: Ideas & Trends; Is it Clammy in Here?
description: GLENDO, Wyo., bought a potato cellar to house all of the town's 294 residents. The Rand Corporation proposed a $150 billion complex of tunnels with 91 convenient entrances into which four million New Yorkers could flee in case of atomic attack. The notion of retreating underground for days or weeks to wait out nuclear war even became the stuff of fiction (remember the sex scene in Robert Henlein's ''Farnham's Freehold'' and the inevitable hierarchal order of death in Mordecai Roshwald's ''Level 7''?).

title: A Struggle Over an Empty Store
description: CVS/PHARMACY is moving forward with its plans to open a third store here, despite opposition from neighbors who say they want a grocery store instead.

title: William H. Bernstein: The Late Bloomer
description: William H. was the oldest of four sons -- arriving three minutes before his fraternal twin, Robert. The two younger brothers, Steven and David, also twins, were born four years later.

title: NEWARK ARENA STALLS
description: A bill to build a sports arena in Newark and an entertainment complex in the Meadowlands stalled last week in the Legislature for the second time in three months. The Assembly Appropriations Committee voted down amendments that would have added $100 million for projects in South Jersey, but refused to vote on the bill itself. Many involved in the process said they thought the nonvote effectively killed the bill under the current administration, but some thought it could resurface in a different form under the McGreevey administration. Sarah Rubenstein

title: 401(k) Participants Hold On
description: Most participants in company 401(k) plans rode out the market decline last year without altering their investment allocations, according to a new study.

title: Return for Senators?
description: To the Sports Editor:

description: MARINA ZENOVICH is indulging in one of her favorite pastimes, sitting at an outside table at the SoHo cafe Le Gamin on a brilliant autumn morning, nursing a caf au lait. And asking someone about Bernard Tapie.

title: CAMDEN TAKEOVER
description: A Senate committee last week took the first step toward the state's assuming control of Camden, with its financial problems and high crime rate. The Senate Economic Growth, Agriculture and Tourism Committee unanimously passed a bill that would provide $173 million for Camden in exchange for granting a court-appointed master to control some aspects of city operations for at least five years. If the bill, which has bipartisan sponsorship, is to pass, it must be before the end of the current session Jan. 8. Acting Governor Donald T. DiFrancesco, who also leaves office that day, has said he supported the bill. Karen DeMasters

title: Settlers Find Solace in an Isolated Gaza Community
description: With more than three soldiers for every four residents and a view of the glittering Mediterranean Sea, this community is either one of the safest and most pleasant spots for Israelis to live or one of the most dangerous and damaging to any hopes for peace.

description: What the readers wrote:

title: There Goes the Neighborhood
description: IT'S said that Americans don't like to discuss class. Often enough, this is true. For one thing, our myths of self-improvement and self-invention (from Horatio Alger to Madonna Ciccone) make definitions of privilege and status somewhat flexible. We have also reinvented the ways in which we perceive class. We like to disguise it, hide it inside those issues we do talk about openly and obsessively, like culture (high versus mass), sex, race, ethnicity or religion, and celebrity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAKOWSKY, RALPH
description: RAKOWSKY-Ralph. November 22, 2001, age 92. Beloved husband of the late Irene. Loving father of Howard and his wife Sheila. Devoted grandfather of Debbi, Holly and Jeffrey Neitlich. Adoring great-grandfather of Ariel and Joshua. Caring brother of Sadie Vamos. The kindness and wisdom that he gave to all of us will live like a legacy of love and will forever remain with us to cherish.

title: Travel Advisory; A Rail Link From New York to Newark Airport
description: A new train station now makes it possible to get from Manhattan to Newark International Airport by rail in about 30 minutes. The new station, which opened in late October, is three miles south of Penn Station in Newark and connects to the 1.9-mile airport monorail. The monorail leaves every three minutes, taking 7 minutes to get to the closest terminal, C, and 10 minutes to the farthest, A.

title: Andrew M. King: A Real Golfer
description: Alot of the Cantor Fitzgerald crowd played golf. And a lot of them were good at it. But Andrew M. King was REALLY, REALLY good. He had a four handicap and had shot three holes-in-one. "He had a beautiful swing," said his wife, Judy King.

title: Blending In Quickly In Margaritaville
description: THE truth is, ever since my college boyfriend moved, albeit temporarily, to Key West some 20 years ago to do something fantastically groovy -- write a novel, I think -- I've wanted to see the place for myself. But that didn't mean I was going to be excited about the prospect of a weekend visit when I finally got the chance to go last month. After all, I've always been a nervous flier; now, imagining the worst, I was so anxious that I could feel hair follicles tingling in my scalp, like thousands of tiny electrical shocks. I was sure that, even if I survived the trip, I couldn't possibly enjoy it.

description: REVIEWS

title: Concerns About Heading by Youth Soccer Players Set Off Debate
description: Corinne Spurrier was as enthusiastic as any soccer mom in Manhattan. On a crisp Saturday morning in Riverside Park, her 9-year-old son's team, the Golden Eagles, played their final game of the season on the banks of the Hudson River. She cheered as her son, Ian, raced across the grass in his yellow jersey. She clapped whenever one of his teammates scored and yelled when a player missed an opportunity.

title: DataBank; Investors Inch Their Way Toward Optimism
description: Stocks wandered slightly higher this week, and bonds fell, as investors began to envision a more distant and gradual economic recovery.

Williams, in blue satin slacks and a red boucl satin blouse, sang ''God Bless America,'' while her husband, the Laker forward Rick Fox, watched proudly. The crowd, responding in part to the glamour of the celebrity couple, roared its approval.

title: Ideas & Trends; Holy Guano!
description: HERE'S an idea for the Pentagon: what if a battalion of bats armed with tiny bombs could be dropped at dawn near Afghan caves? Wouldn't they flock underground, where they could detonate their weapons?

title: A Repeat Champion At Regionals
description: In a duel between undefeated state champions, Natasha Roetter of Lexington, Mass., outran Molly Huddle of Elmira, N.Y., to repeat as the girls winner in the Foot Locker High School Northeast Regional Cross-Country Championships yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WILLIAMS, DOLORES CLARKE
description: WILLIAMS-Dolores Clarke. A memorial service will be held for Dolores Clarke Williams (''Dee'') at The Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street, on December 17, 2001 at 12:00 Noon. She passed away on Wednesday, November 14 at Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn, following surgery to repair a broken hip. Mrs. Williams was born in Panama to Audrey and Samuel Clarke. She came to the United States as a child and attended high school and college (New York University) in New York City. She was married to Michael D. Williams, then a medical resident, on March 12, 1944. The couple had two children (Saundra and Steven) and lived together, happily, until Dr. Williams' death in 1989. Dolores Williams took an active role in her children's educations and social lives. She served as President of The Metropolitan Chapter of Jack & Jill, as well as President of the Parent Teacher Association of The Columbia Grammar School, where her son was a student. Having remained at home to shepherd her children through their pre-college years, Mrs. Williams went on to teach at The Modern School, an independent school in Harlem. Following her retirement, she continued teaching as a volunteer tutor at P.S. 180 in Manhattan and in the after school program of The Church of the Masters. In keeping with her motto, ''Do something for somebody,'' Mrs. Williams was deeply committed to the concept of volunteerism and to her involvement in civic and charitable projects. She was an enthusiastic volunteer for The Harlem School of the Arts. Having served on the Board of the institution, she later taught a class there in African History and Culture. She was also a docent at the Studio Museum in Harlem. In the early 1970's she served as President of the Manhattan, Bronx, Westchester Women's Auxiliary to the National Medical Association. Under her leadership, the New York Auxiliary hosted the 1973 NMA Convention, sponsored seminars focused on issues of black women's health and raised a substantial fund for financially disadvantaged African American medical students. Mrs. Williams played a leadership role in founding The Group, a fundraising organization which has contributed impressive sums to not-forprofit institutions, including The United Negro College Fund and The Harlem School of the Arts. Up until the time of her death, Dee remained active in several social organizations, including the Alumni Chapter of the Metropolitan Chapter of Jack and Jill and the New York Hillbillies. She enjoyed playing bridge, loved music and dancing, summers in Sag Harbor, entertaining at home and, especially, spending time with her grandchildren. Her two children, Saundra Williams-Cornwell and Steven Williams, their spouses Don Cornwell and Barbara Evans Williams, her two beloved grandchildren, Samantha Cornwell and Michael Evan Williams, her stepgrandson, K. Don Cornwell, as well as many good friends, survive Dolores Williams.

title: Rice's Competitive Spirit Is Younger Than His 39 Years
description: In a game against Denver on Nov. 5, Oakland Raiders wide receiver Jerry Rice watched his teammate Tim Brown have one of his best pass-catching nights of the season with nine receptions. As Brown made grab after grab, Rice mostly played the role of Hall of Fame decoy, running his routes with only a few passes going his way, concentrating on doing the dirty work of blocking.

title: All in the Sale
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: 1 Dead, 2 Wounded in Shooting
description: A man was killed and at least two people were injured last night in a burst of gunfire in front of the Hammerstein Ballroom on West 34th Street in Manhattan, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a review on Nov. 4 about ''Vernon Can Read! A Memoir,'' by Vernon E. Jordan Jr. with Annette Gordon-Reed, misstated Gordon-Reed's affiliation. She is a professor at New York Law School, not New York University Law School.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLST, SPENCER
description: HOLST-Spencer. November 22, 2001, 75. Author, storyteller, painter. Recipient of the Rosenthal award of the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters, 1977. Created a genre of short story collected in The Language of Cats (1971), Spencer Holst Stories, a New York Times notable book, (1976), The Zebra Storyteller (1993) and Brilliant Silence (2000), etc. His stories are widely translated, for example, into Swedish, Spanish and Japanese. Survived by his wife, Beate, a painter whose drawings often graced his work; his son, Sebastian, and daughterin-law, Dawn, and grandchildren, Spencer and Adrianna, of Chevy Chase, MD; and sister, Mary-Ella Holst. Son of the late Spencer ''Doc'' Holst and Ruth McCullough Holst, both newspaper reporters, he moved from Detroit, MI, to New York City in the 1940's. U.S. Army veteran. Regularly appeared on the Greenwich Village reading circuit as well as on WBAI, at the Brooklyn Museum, colleges, Carnegie Hall, and other venues. His most recent reading was on July 7, 2001, a celebration of his 75th birthday, at Westbeth, the artist's residence and studios in the West Village, where he and his family were original tenants. A memorial reading will be held at a later date.

title: Q and A
description: In Harry Potter's Footsteps

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: November 25, 2001
description: Weeks

title: Taming the Piano With Touch and Tools
description: WHEN the Czech pianist Ivan Moravec visited New York before the start of his current tour, one of his first stops was at Steinway Hall, on West 57th Street, to test pianos. Waiting in the elegant, silent showroom before being led downstairs to the workshop, Mr. Moravec couldn't resist trying out a nearby instrument, an expensive-looking baby grand with elaborate golden trim. He touched the keys gently, just enough to feel the action but not hard enough to make a sound.

title: Candis Peterkin and Timothy James
description: Candis Marie Peterkin, a daughter of Deborah and James Peterkin of Hillside, N.J., were married yesterday to Timothy Lawrence James, a son of Sheila and Willie James of Gary, Ind. Eugene Duck a minister, performed the ceremony at the Kingdom Hall of the Jehovah's Witnesses in Rahway, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HURNEY, JOSEPH J.
description: HURNEY-Joseph J. Age 88, Nov. 12, 2001. A lifelong resident of Baldwin, NY, & recently Sayville, NY. Retired pressman of 49 years. Survived by five children, Eileen, Joe, Mary, Michael and Teresa. Father-in-law to Roy, Gerianne, John and Gabriel. Grandfather of ten and great-grandfather of ten. Predeceased by his beloved wife of sixty years, Rose. Dearest ''Pop'' in our hearts forever.

title: Yagudin Facing Pressure From Former Understudy
description: PARIS, — Just outside the Bercy sports arena, dozens of French teenagers, dressed in urban battle gear, were skateboarding on and above the high stone steps, stoically pulling off tricks and taking risks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMAN, MICHAEL E.
description: HOFFMAN-Michael E. On November 23, 2001. Extraordinary husband of Melissa Harris; loving father of Matthew Perkins (Ana) and Sarah Warren; dear brother of Jill H. Shore; sweet grandfather of Isabel K. Service private. A memorial service will be held in fall 2002. Contributions may be made in his memory to Montana Wilderness Society, Aperture Foundation, and The Central Park Conservancy.

title: 'Type B' Chief Guides G.M. On a Course To Revival
description: EIGHT years ago, addressing an auto industry conference in Traverse City, Mich., Rick Wagoner strode from the lectern to the front of the stage. Mr. Wagoner, now the chief executive of General Motors, had just been named its head of purchasing, replacing Jos Ignacio Lpez de Arriorta, a storied executive who had forced steep price cuts and quality inspections on G.M.'s suppliers and, in the process, become a reviled figure in Motor City.

title: Letters
description: The concerns raised by Jonathan Rosen in his essay on anti-Semitism were shared by scores of readers. Andrew Sullivan's salute to his adopted country was seconded by expats. And many saluted "The Simpsons," insensitive jokes and all, for supplying post-Sept. 11 cheer.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Rarely Canceled Parade

title: November 18-24; Microsoft Tries to Settle
description: Microsoft agreed to settle more than 100 class-action antitrust suits alleging that the company overcharged consumers. Under the five-year agreement, Microsoft will donate roughly $1 billion in cash, hardware and software to bring computing to 12,500 public schools in low-income neighborhoods. The deal extricates the company from another legal battle, and the class-action lawyers can point to the settlement as an answer to their critics, who portray them as mercenary legal vultures. Anthony Amato, the superintendent of schools in Hartford, called the settlement a phenomenal gift. Steve Lohr

title: Tastes of the Great Southwest (Nassau)
description: EATING at the three-and-a-half-month-old Sedona Grill in Rockville Centre is a bit like kissing your sister: it's not unpleasant, but it isn't memorable or exciting either. There were few complete disasters or delights at a recent dinner; instead, most dishes fell into a rather ordinary middle ground. (Prices are in the same category, neither bargains nor budget busters).

title: An Expert in the Neglected History of Food
description: STANDING by the open fire, Alice Ross stirred the pot of chicken and dumpling stew. With a hook, she lifted the lid on a Dutch oven to check on her ginger cake, then rustled the glowing embers on the lid to add a little more heat. On the far edge of the crackling fire, potato croquettes sizzled in a pan of lard.

title: Private Sector; A Corporate Believer's Turnabout
description: YOUNG David C. Korten would be shocked to see himself now.

title: Bottle of Cognac Is Used to Lure Suspect Into Hands of the Police
description: After a two-hour standoff, the police arrested an Asbury Park, N.J., man on Thursday on murder and armed robbery charges. The suspect surrendered peacefully after officers showed him a bottle of Hennessy Cognac, which he had requested.

title: Jan Maciejewski: A Guy Just Like Him
description: Jan Maciejewski had a knack for being in the right place in the right time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLOANE, HERMINE PATRICIA
description: SLOANE-Hermine Patricia, 67. Passed away suddenly November 22, 2001. Dr. Sloane was a painter, an author, filmmaker, and a professor of fine arts at NYC Technical College-CUNY. Dr. Sloane's books included topics on fine arts, art history, principles of color, and the works of T.S. Elliot. Dr. Sloane is the widow of Dr. Kenneth Campbell, a noted sculptor & artist. She was the daughter of Dr. David Sloane & Dr. Miriam Frauenthal Sloane. She is survived by her sister, Elaine Sloane Roemer of Miami, FL; her aunt, Beatrice Krulwich of Manhattan; her stepchildren Alan Campbell and Janet Campbell; her niece, Michelle Sloane Wolf; her nephew, Alan Sloane Roemer; a greatniece and great-nephews. Services for Dr. Patricia Sloane will be held on Sunday, November 25th at 2:15 PM at Riverside Funeral Home, 180 West 76th St, New York City. (212) 362-6600.

title: Swept Up in a Dragnet, Hundreds Sit in Custody and Ask, 'Why?'
description: Osama Elfar was dozing on a hard bench under the ever-present drone of the prison television set when a guard's voice crackled over the intercom, "Happy birthday." Otherwise, Nov. 9 would have passed without Mr. Elfar even noticing he had turned 30.

title: Seeking Freedom and Security at a Time of War
description: To the Editor:

title: Travel Advisory; Canadian Airline Shuts, Stranding Thousands
description: The shutdown this month of Canada's second-largest airline, Canada 3000, left an estimated 50,000 passengers stranded midtrip and perhaps 300,000 others holding worthless tickets. The company, which started as a charter airline 13 years ago, carried about five million passengers a year. It grounded its planes on Nov. 9 and filed for bankruptcy two days later.

title: Travel Advisory: Correspondent's Report; Hard By Victoria Falls, No Flood of Tourists
description: THE horn wails and the luxury train lurches from the station in Pretoria, South Africa, and glides toward Zimbabwe and its glorious waterfall. The dining car bustles with tourists from Japan, Britain, Spain and the United States, who sup on crayfish and crme brle. But the smiling waiters pouring champagne know all is not well on the famous Blue Train. This day in October, a season when the train is often booked solid, half of the 82 cabins are empty.

title: Swaddling the Neck, Simply
description: Enough with the too-voluminous pashminas and those fluffy fur collars that stick to lip gloss. This winter's neck warmer of choice is the neat, streamlined little muffler.

title: South Beach: Restaurant Information
description: The prices are averages for two people and include a modest bottle of wine or a couple of drinks, but not tax and tip. All these restaurants accept major credit cards.

title: Time Out of Joint In a Ruined Land
description: The story of Afghanistan is like Job's, except God has not yet appeared in the whirlwind to explain the suffering and set things right. This is a land where war has put time out of joint, where people live in ruins resembling archaeological sites, using the tools of centuries gone by. The tools -- hand-hewn wooden furrows plowing the earth, hand-shaped clay ovens baking bread -- create the beautiful necessities that make life bearable.

title: American Marines Land Near Kandahar
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Hundreds of marines landed at a makeshift airfield near the southern city of Kandahar today in the first major infusion of American grounds troops into Afghanistan. Their arrival began what Pentagon officials said would be a period of sustained assaults against Taliban and Al Qaeda forces.

title: Double-Parked Limousines Are Also a Pollution Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: Community Radio
description: To the Editor:

title: Beyond Chutney
description: Manhattan is full of generic Indian restaurants that offer a dreary repertory of lackluster chutneys and dull curries. But the following neighborhood places offer authentic regional dishes with the spicing, vibrancy and diversity that make Indian one of the world's glorious cuisines.

title: For Francophiles' Thirst
description: The 2000 estate chardonnay from Macari Vineyards resembles a Giacometti sculpture: lean, taut (some may say wiry), crisp, firm and to the point.

title: More Workers Skimp as Drug Costs Rise
description: In recent years, many employers have responded to the double-digit increases in prescription costs by raising the co- payments for workers covered under their drug plans. And many workers, it seems, have responded by cutting back on their medications, according to survey results released last week.

title: Quality King and FatWire Lead Hofstra's Top 50 List
description: The largest private companies on Long Island increased their work forces by nearly 5 percent last year, while the fastest-growing companies expanded theirs by nearly 27 percent, creating nearly 2,100 jobs, according to data analyzed by Hofstra University.

title: Seeing the Outsized Outsider in a (Slightly) New Way
description: AS played by squat, leering Jack Black, the title character in the new comedy by the Farrelly brothers, ''Shallow Hal,'' has earned his nickname for the superficiality of his approach to the opposite sex. Traumatized as a child, when his dying father (a minister, played by Bruce McGill) advises him that the road to marital bliss lies in finding a classic beauty with a perfect body, he has spent his adult years judging women strictly by their appearance.

title: Conservation-Minded Housing in Indiana
description: The story of American housing development is told in lyrical names -- Golden Meadows, Redgrove Orchards, Wildwood Acres -- that are usually the sole remnant of what was wiped off the land once the sewers, roads and houses were built.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAPA, EDITH
description: CAPA-Edith, 88. The beloved wife of Cornell Capa, died at home in New York City on November 21 after a long illness. She was born in Budapest, Hungary, on May 3, 1913, the daughter of Lawrence and Hani Schwartz. Edith married Cornell Capa in 1940; in January 2001 they celebrate their sixty-first wedding anniversary. For more than 30 years Edith accompanied Cornell, a distinguished photographer for ''Life'' magazine and a member of the Magnum photo agency, on his assignments throughout the world. She also aided Cornell vitally in his projects that led, in 1974, to his founding of the International Center of Photography, in New York. For many years Edith single-handedly organized and maintained not only her husband's negatives and archives but also those of Cornell's late brother, Robert Capa, who was killed on assignment in Indochina in 1954. Furthermore, for hundreds of photographers from around the world Edith served as a kind of surrogate mother, always ready to provide a home away from home. Although Cornell and Edie have no children, they have a vast and loving extended family of honorary sons and daughters. Edie is survived by her husband, Cornell; by a sister, Miriam Siegel, of Lutz, FL; as well as by numerous nieces and nephews. Her funeral service will take place at Plaza Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue at 91 Street, in Manhattan, on Monday, November 26, at 11:00 AM.

title: Seeking Freedom and Security at a Time of War
description: To the Editor:

title: Defining Heroism
description: To the Editor: In ''When the Spirit Isn't Willing'' (Oct. 21), Eve Schaenen contrasted the heroism, the ''right stuff,'' of the hijacked passengers ''who went down fighting'' with the caution of Americans who are curbing activities, thus displaying the ''wrong stuff.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRINCE, ELAINE CORINNE (KATZBERG)
description: PRINCE-Elaine Corinne (Katzberg). Beloved wife and mother, quintessential New Yorker, retired at age 79, just two years ago. She spent a lifetime of rejoicing in New York's culture and atmosphere, going to the opera, visiting museums and possessing an encyclopedic knowledge of every great little store and cultural event in the City. Proud mother of son Dr. Stephen Elliot Katzberg and daughter Elizabeth Kennedy; grandmother to Melanie and Rachel; and step-grandmother to Sarah and Bridget. Her incredible insight, superlative advice, majestic dignity, and decisive intellect will be terribly missed.

title: The Uncomfortable Question of Anti-Semitism
description: Jonathan Rosen is right. Osama bin Laden would seek to destroy Israel and the United States even if the occupation of the West Bank and Gaza ended tomorrow. But America is not seeking to win over the bin Ladens. The success of our war against terrorism may depend on a coalition that includes millions of Muslims, who do indeed care about the West Bank and Gaza.

title: A Music Retailer Is Back, And So Is the Volume
description: Contrary to the general impression, not all stores in Lower Manhattan are crippled, at least not when your customer base includes electronics geeks and the mayor of New York.

title: Salvatore F. Pepe: For Family, a Tomatofest
description: Salvatore F. Pepe was an assistant vice president for technology at Marsh & McLennan, but to the Pepe clan he will be remembered as the originator of Tomatofest and the Pepe family calendar.

title: Basem Diab
description: Nearly nine months pregnant, Basima Diab sits by the phone most days, waiting for her husband, Basem, to call from the detention center where he has spent the last two weeks.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the sluggishness of Champagne sales in the United States after Sept. 11 misspelled the surname of an entertainment industry caterer who said he had arranged a Los Angeles party where Champagne was served nonstop. He is Colin Cowie, not Crowe.

title: Homer's Odyssey
description: I enjoyed A.O. Scott's article on ''The Simpsons'' (Nov. 4). In the days following Sept. 11, my wife and I were in desperate need of some classic episodes. Watching them was like a shot of medicine -- or crab juice. Jeff Jotz

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: A FAMILY PLACE

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 11 about current plays in London misidentified the theater at one point for the revival of ''Cat on a Hot Tin Roof.'' It is the Lyric, not the Gielgud.

title: Gains Seen in College Savings
description: Assets in state-sponsored college savings plans, sometimes called 529 plans, are expected to reach $7.2 billion by year-end and to grow to more than $51 billion by 2006.

title: Love the Service Around Here
description: Robert Berschinski is that rarest of creatures, an Ivy League member of the R.O.T.C. Each Thursday, he wears his Air Force uniform around the Yale campus. Until Sept. 11, almost nobody commented on it. But now people come up to him, and the response is all positive. People thank him for serving. They ask what service entails. But he's struck by how little some of his peers know. ''These are incredibly bright people, but many have no idea what the military does,'' he says. Some don't know that there are different service branches.

title: A Bump and No Shake
description: IN September, when Carleton S. Fiorina, the chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, and her counterpart at Compaq, Michael D. Capellas, held a news conference to announce a $25 billion merger, the assembled photographers crouched to catch the symbolic handshake that would seal the deal between the computer giants. But at the climactic moment, that time-honored symbol of good faith got the kiss-off; the executives lightly bumped their fists instead.

title: Introduction
description: The concerns raised by Jonathan Rosen in his essay on anti-Semitism were shared by scores of readers. Andrew Sullivan's salute to his adopted country was seconded by expats. And many saluted ''The Simpsons,'' insensitive jokes and all, for supplying post-Sept. 11 cheer.

title: Closure? A Buzzword Becomes a Quest
description: A legal secretary who lives in Brooklyn returned to the site of the twin towers on Oct. 11 in search of it. A Bronx businessman designed an itinerary so his relatives, visiting from Nigeria for their daughter's funeral, could get it. The mayor has sought to give it to bereaved families in the form of urns filled with ashes. A woman whose husband's body was identified does not mention that she has it, because other widows do not.

title: Private Sector; Tapping the Wall Street Melting Pot
description: The past honorees at the annual Wall Street Dinner held by the UJA-Federation of New York is a list of Jewish power brokers in finance: Henry R. Kravis, John H. Gutfreund, Alan C. Greenberg. So, at this year's event on Dec. 5, they plan to toast . . . John A. Mulheren Jr.?

title: Skating on the Edge of a Dream
description: SARA WHEAT dances over to the face-off circle at the University of Delaware ice rink. On the way, she slows down as two stern-faced Russian ice dancers slide by, glaring at her.

title: Christopher S. Epps: Accounting and Poetry
description: Geneva Epps has not given up hope that the son she had late in life is alive. "I'm just being hopeful and prayerful," she said of Christopher S. Epps, her seventh child and second son. "I just can't seem to give up. I know that I'm not considered very wise and not facing reality. But the reality is that no one has showed me any proof that he is not alive."

title: French Dishes, but Lighter, in Hartsdale
description: THE dining rooms, although refreshed, remain unaltered; the menu is still written in unnecessary French with an approximate English translation beneath each item; the old name with all its past associations is still intact. It would appear that little has changed at Auberge Argenteuil, but nothing could be further from the truth.

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of Wednesday, 3,915 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11.

title: Road Map Not Included
description: HATESHIP, FRIENDSHIP, COURTSHIP, LOVESHIP, MARRIAGE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MIYOSHI, AICHI AUGUSTUS
description: MIYOSHI-Aichi Augustus. 69, on November 17th. He will be greatly missed. He was an expert tennis player, gourmet cook, fine golfer and avid reader with an aesthetic, sensitive soul. He loved animals, especially his dog Alex. Aichi leaves his love Judith and her sister Gloria, as well as his siblings Marti, Kiki and Al. There will be a memorial service at a later date.

title: Swept Up in a Dragnet, Hundreds Sit in Custody and Ask, 'Why?'
description: Osama Elfar was dozing on a hard bench under the ever-present drone of the prison television set when a guard's voice crackled over the intercom, ''Happy birthday.'' Otherwise, Nov. 9 would have passed without Mr. Elfar even noticing he had turned 30.

title: James R. Paul: Finding Their Place
description: In 1993, when James R. Paul decided to move to New York after two decades in Chicago, he was walking around Gramercy Park one day with a real estate broker when a building caught his eye. Built in 1883, it appealed to Mr. Paul's taste for the old and beautiful. "I wish we could find a place there," he told the broker, pointing to the red-brownish brick facade. They did.

title: Bargains for Buyers May Also Hold Risk Of Slower Recovery
description: Attention, shoppers: America is now on sale.

title: Edna Cintron: Her Courage and Strength
description: For Edna Cintron and her husband, William, every evening fit into a comforting routine. "She had everything prompt, clean, neat, organized," Mr. Cintron, a 44-year- old doorman, said of his 46-year-old wife, an administrative assistant for Marsh & McLennan. "She would come out of work, come home, cook, make sure that when I would come out of work there was food on the table and everything. And every night we would have ice cream and we would watch TV."

title: Frank Schott: In the Garden, at the Stove
description: Dina Schott could set her watch by her husband's daily routine. Every morning, Frank Schott was up at 5:20 a.m., on the train to his job in Manhattan at 6:09 a.m., and opening the front door again of their home in Massapequa Park, N.Y., at 7:00 p.m.

title: The View From/North Canaan; Fire Burns Old Station And Hits a Town's Heart
description: THERE is a blaze-burned hole in the center of North Canaan. No one was hurt in the fire, but many have been hurt by it, from business owners to employees to residents who no longer see what used to be.

title: Now, the Envelope, Please. Uh, Never Mind.
description: WHEN it first became clear that bioterrorism would change the world forever, it probably didn't occur to many people that this meant models would have to stop snorting cocaine.

title: November 18-24; NATO and Russia Woo
description: Six months ago Russia was boycotting NATO meetings, protesting plans to expand the alliance to its borders. But Sept. 11 appears to have changed everything. Lord George Robertson, the NATO secretary general, unveiled a proposal to give Russia equal status with the 19 NATO nations in developing policies on issues like terrorism and arms proliferation, and Russian President Vladimir V. Putin said he would give it urgent attention. Mr. Robertson said that the plan has the backing of President Bush and Prime Minister Tony Blair, among others, but that four other ''radical'' plans to engage Russia in the alliance also were being floated. ''Russia and NATO are both essential security players in Europe,'' he said. ''Neither can be ignored.'' Michael Wines

title: For Starters, a Tribute to Stern
description: THE first concert in the Hersher Foundation Chamber Series this year is dedicated to the memory of Isaac Stern, who died two months ago.

title: East End Germ Lab Getting an Upgrade
description: AS the federal government moves to heighten protection against bioterrorist attacks, the Plum Island Animal Disease Center off the tip of the North Fork appears to be in line for major new financing to upgrade its laboratories and tighten security. But for now at least, local opposition appears to have thwarted a renewed push to allow the lab to conduct research on diseases that kill humans.

title: Streetscapes/The Metro-North Tracks; A Look Down at the Rail Tunnels Below Park Ave.
description: NEXT Sunday, the Christmas lights will shine on Park Avenue, as they have every year since 1945. The lighting ceremonies will feature a carol service at 91st Street and Park, and with the wide boulevard closed, it will be one of the rare times that New Yorkers walk on the central malls that cover the Metro-North railroad tracks below.

title: Muslims in Gray
description: TO face Mecca from West Point, one must look across the Hudson River, over the rugged highlands of Garrison and past Putnam Valley.

title: A Business Designed To Help Restore Order
description: It was Sept. 10 when the product line for Amy Shwartzstein's new business, Stop2Organize, was delivered to her Chappaqua home. Then on Sept. 11, Ms. Shwartzstein's husband, Allan, was killed in the attack on the World Trade Center. Ms. Shwartzstein, who has two children, ages 5 and 4, has persevered and Stop2Organize is now marketing the organizational aids she designed last summer to manage the clutter and disorder that seem a requisite part of raising children. Offerings include Got Kids-Get Organized, a binder with sections for emergency, medical, school, camp, sports, activities and miscellaneous information; as well as notepads for the gamut of parenting needs including shopping lists, teacher notes, baby sitter information and daily schedules. Coming soon are two additional binders, Got Bills-Get Organized and Got Important Papers-Get Organized. Products are available by mail order (telephone: (914) 769-2375, fax: (914) 773-1741, online: www.Stop2Organize.com). They are sold in Chappaqua at Penny Auntie, and Ms. Shwartzstein said, will be available in other stores before the holidays. Susan Hodara

title: Talks, and Accusations, Resume Over a World Tobacco Treaty
description: A third round of negotiations for an international treaty to help stamp out smoking began here this week with wrangling over proposals for a global ban on advertising and promotion of cigarettes as well as proposed provisions covering the tobacco industry's liability.

title: Sean P. and Farrell P. Lynch: Strivers, Like Their Parents
description: Whatever their achievements, the Lynch boys were products of their upbringing. The children of Irish immigrants, Sean P. Lynch, top, and his brother Farrell P. Lynch were strivers like their parents.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CANNON, VICTOR M., JR.
description: CANNON-Victor M., Jr. November, 1991. Eternally, eternally with you. Ellen and David

title: Investing; Competition Rages On How Stocks Trade
description: IN a television commercial, a client of Ameritrade, the online brokerage firm, boasts to a co-worker that he paid 5 cents less a share for a stock they bought at the same time.

title: SOAPBOX; Family Reflections
description: SPRING is the traditional time to do a sweeping, whole-domicile cleaning. For me, however, fall is when I roll up my sleeves and get out the scrubbing and polishing gear.

title: What if Terror Went Nuclear?
description: To the Editor:

title: The World's Economies Slide Together Into Recession
description: With American economic malaise spreading as seamlessly as the technology-driven surge that preceded it, many economists now agree that the world is suffering its first recession in two decades and that recovery may come more slowly than once expected.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LONG, AUGUSTUS C.
description: LONG-Augustus C. The Board of Trustees, Faculty, and Staff of New York-Presbyterian Hospital are saddened by the death of Augustus C. Long, a former Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Texaco, who was a Trustee of The Presbyterian Hospital in the City of New York beginning in 1955, President of the Hospital beginning in 1961, and Chairman of the Board of Trustees from 1970 to 1974. Mr. Long was a greatly esteemed leader who presided skillfully over the Hospital's service to patients and the community, and who directed the institution through some of its most vigorous development. The Augustus Long Medical Library at the Columbia Presbyterian site of the Hospital was named in his honor. His contributions and devotion to the Hospital's mission are still deeply appreciated. We extend our condolences to his family. John J. Mack Chairman, Board of Trustees Herbert Pardes, M.D. President and CEO New York-Presbyterian Hospital

title: A Whole World
description: To the Editor:

title: What They Were Thinking
description: Kathy Frazer, Pete Carino, Joe McGovern, Mike Dilena, Belle Harbor, N.Y., Nov. 12, 2001

title: Mr. Right Is Mr. Wrong
description: RIOT

title: Hold the Mayo, and the Sandwich: Exchange Bans Deliveries
description: In embattled Lower Manhattan, major corporations have fled, businesses have folded, and now, even lunch is under siege.

title: He Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Bomb
description: MEMOIRS

title: Bouncing Back in Chappaqua
description: THE adopted hometown of the Comeback Kid just witnessed one that would make the master proud. In Chappaqua, Horace Greeley's varsity football team began the school year ingloriously. To celebrate the start of the season, the Quakers (yes, that's the team's name) decided to have a party. To the party, the Quakers invited an exotic dancer. Then, as she danced for money in front of Quakers as young as 14, the host parents looked on.

title: Accounting Peer Review Gets More Scrutiny
description: The accounting industry's watchdog group is examining the industry's "peer review" process in light of enormous accounting problems at the Enron Corporation ( news/quote ).

title: More Budget Games in Nassau County
description: All the suburban counties around New York City are facing tough times, with falling revenues and a slowing economy. Only one still shies from making the hard choices needed to deal with its problems. In Nassau County, incumbent officials remain locked in the same old avoidance games that plunged this wealthy county into its ongoing fiscal crisis.

title: Reckonings; An Alternate Reality
description: Most Americans get their news from TV. And what they see is heartwarming -- a picture of a nation behaving well in a time of crisis. Indeed, the vast majority of Americans have been both resolute and generous.

title: Have a Bonny Day
description: Scottish tartans, plaids, checks and tattersalls are a sign of fashion's change of mood since Sept. 11, a time when exaggerated silhouettes and theatrical flourishes have seemed out of touch. Many women reached into their closets for the toned-down style of plaids, which suggest the security of tradition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARKUSS, CLAIRE
description: ARKUSS-Claire. On November 23, 2001 at age 83. Beloved wife of the late Albert. Devoted mother of Neil and his wife Nancy, David and his wife Donna. Sister of Zephie Hermel and Alfred Pomerantz. Dear grandmother of Jeffrey, Brett and Emily. Funeral Services Monday, 11:30 AM, Schwartz BrosJeffer Memorial Chapels, Queens Boulevard, at 76th Road, Forest Hills, NY.

title: Garnet Bailey: Ace of 'Bailey-baisse'
description: When Garnet Bailey would come to scout a game in Worcester, Mass., he would announce himself by saying, "table for two, please" as a tribute to the legendary meals served when the IceCats were at home.

title: Fast-Paced Thrillers, Brought to You by the Letter 'M'; M3: Complex Pursuit of Simple Pleasure
description: THE Shaker hymn reminds us that it's a gift to be simple. The BMW M3 reminds us that there are no Shakers working for BMW.

title: Sports of The Times; The Giants' Inspiring Tight End
description: AFTER the Giants' 28-16 loss in Minnesota last Monday night, Howard Cross was walking toward the locker room when he was greeted by a Viking rookie.

title: Cablevision Rates To Rise 6 Percent
description: Cablevision television customers will pay another 6 percent next year, the fifth rate increase in as many years. In that period, rates have gone up more than 30 percent.

title: Chinatown's Ordeal
description: To the Editor:

title: As Sept. 11 Widows Unite, Grief Finds Political Voice
description: A new political group has emerged from the cinders and ash of the World Trade Center disaster site. It is a group that no city official wants to offend, one whose broad powers are only beginning to be realized by its members. In the verbal shorthand of these troubled days, it is known simply as ''the widows.''

title: Escape Into New York
description: I LIVE near Washington Square and would probably walk there daily, even if it weren't on my way to just about anywhere. The stately brownstones on the north end of the square retain the look they had when Henry James walked past them. Closing my eyes, I can will myself for an instant into James's 1881 novella ''Washington Square.'' Returning home, where the book awaits me in a choice of editions, I can complete my act of literary escapism.

title: Reclaiming the City, Movie by Movie
description: MOVIES have always been a comfort to me. As a law student at New York University, I often took refuge from civil procedure class at the Waverly. Later, feeling misplaced as a rookie business reporter for The Wall Street Journal, I'd sneak uptown to Times Square at lunchtime. Even before multiplexes, a movie was always playing there. Eventually, The Journal's editors decided to get a full day's work out of me and moved me to the arts section, where I became a film critic.

title: The Uncomfortable Question of Anti-Semitism
description: Rosen's observations offer a frightening reminder of the past, a powerful analysis of the present and a disturbing glimpse at what the future might bring.

title: Business; When a Workplace Dispute Goes Very Public
description: ON a warm, clear morning last Sunday, on the Pebble Beach golf course in Carmel, Calif., 40 professional and 40 amateur golfers were in the final round of the Callaway Golf Invitational when a small plane began circling the long, narrow course beside the Pacific. It towed a banner that read ''Merrill Lynch Discriminates Against Women.''

title: A Reclaimed Park Is Due in Fall 2002
description: For generations, there were rumors around Canal Street that an asphalt covered sliver of land by the West Side Highway had once been a city park. Although the Department of Sanitation had long parked its snow plows and salt trucks there, something about the almost triangular space was, as one resident put it, "too perfect and geometric for a parking lot." It had, he said, a sense of place.

title: OPINION; The Rise and the Fall of Gulotta
description: ONE must apologize to Charles Dickens, but truly the best way to describe the three terms of the Nassau County executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, is to suggest that they have been the best of times and the worst of times. As Mr. Gulotta prepares to leave office taxpayers need to step back, consider his legacy and determine how he went from such high promise to such low pity.

title: A Sea Cliff Standby in a Time of Change
description: TUPELO HONEY, the funky, spirited Sea Cliff restaurant, still looks the same, but its food tastes like that at the Mill River Inn. Michael Meehan, Tupelo Honey's chef for more than five years, left in April to devote his time to Clearwater, his seafood restaurant in Massapequa. He is succeeded by Henry Barone, formerly the top toque at the Mill River Inn. (Tupelo Honey and the Mill River Inn have a common ownership.)

title: Dot-Com Is Dot-Gone, And the Dream With It
description: MARK LEIBOVICH recalled the day in 1999 when he showed up early for an appointment at a Washington dot-com. Mr. Leibovich, a reporter for The Washington Post, was there to interview the company's executives. ''I got there just in time to see the C.E.O. himself wheeling a foosball table into the lobby'' to give the impression that the high-tech firm possessed the desired quantum of wackiness that its Silicon Valley counterparts are famous for.

title: Paris for Real vs. Paris on Film: We'll Always Have the Movies
description: I'VE been to Paris, France, and I've been to Paris, Paramount,'' the German-born director Ernst Lubitsch once said. ''Paris, Paramount, is better.''

title: The Uncomfortable Question of Anti-Semitism
description: My wife and I moved to New Hampshire 12 years ago and had never experienced anti-Semitism here. Now, twice in past weeks, I have been present when speakers twisted facts to make Israel responsible for the attack on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. In both cases, a member of the audience asked why the terrorists hated America enough to give their lives to destroy our buildings and our people. Both speakers responded that the hatred was caused by United States support of an Israeli government that stole Arab land and killed Palestinian children.

title: Best Little Warehouse In New Jersey
description: BLINK and you won't miss it. Nod off and you still might not.

title: John Adams, Banned In Boston
description: IN his essay in the program booklet for the 1992 recording of John Adams's opera ''The Death of Klinghoffer,'' the critic Michael Steinberg made a chilling prediction.

title: Mount Laurel: A Battle That Won't Go Away
description: BACK in 1975, when Justice Frederick Hall of the State Supreme Court first railed against discriminatory zoning practices in New Jersey, he probably never imagined how little the landscape would have changed 26 years later.

title: The Anthrax Front: Let's Be Vigilant
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JUSTER, HOWARD H.
description: JUSTER-Howard H., 76. Died of a heart attack Sunday, Nov. 18, 2001 in San Diego, CA. Formerly of Scarsdale, NY., beloved husband of Muriel (Uchitelle), father of Andrew (married to Janet Lob) & Kenneth, grandfather of Allison and Eric, and brother of Norton. Graduate of the University of Pennsylvania and naval officer in WW II. He was an influential force and recognized authority in the fields of medical planning and health care architecture, and recipient of many architectural awards and honors. Fellow of the American Institute of Architects, Trustee and past Chairman of the National Institute for Architectural Education, he was noted for his analytical approach and innovative designs for hospitals and educational facilities. Active in civic affairs in Scarsdale, he was past Chairman of the Board of Zoning Appeals and Member of the Planning Board. A talented photographer, avid pianist, and eternally optimistic golfer, he will be sorely missed.

title: The Neediest Cases; Children's Long-Term Illnesses Mean a Strain on Families' Resources
description: A Washington Heights boy hospitalized with lupus a few days shy of his graduation from fifth grade.

title: Parents Reconsider Teenagers' City Trips
description: BEFORE Sept. 11, M'Elena Holder and her friends headed into Manhattan at least one Saturday a month, for a concert, some shopping, or just a change of scene from their Chappaqua neighborhood. They were comfortable on Metro-North, and beginning to master the subway. These days, however, M'Elena, who is 15, spends her weekends at home, trips to the city vetoed by her parents out of fear of another terrorist attack.

title: Postings: Guidelines Board's Annual Publication; Analyzing Rental Market
description: Offering insights into the rental market, from what a landlord should pay for a pushbroom to the economic factors that make Manhattan different from the rest of the city, the New York City Rent Guidelines Board's annual publication, ''Housing NYC: Rents, Markets and Trends 2001,'' is now available.

title: Passing the Baton
description: AFTER nearly 30 years as an abortion rights advocate in Westchester, Polly Rothstein has accumulated extensive files. She has a new folder thick with accolades, letters and cards congratulating her on her retirement, and thanking her for her advocacy on behalf of women. Another file is full of stories that supporters and strangers alike feel compelled to share: letters that describe individual experiences, some of them heartrending, from the days when getting an abortion was a criminal act. And then there is the file labeled, somewhat wryly, nonsupportive correspondence.

title: TREFFINGER'S IN, KEAN'S OUT
description: The Republican jockeying to unseat Senator Robert G. Torricelli, a Democrat, in 2002 began in earnest last week when the Essex County executive, James W. Treffinger, announced that he would seek the Republican nomination. No sooner had Mr. Treffinger made his low-key announcement than former Gov. Thomas H. Kean, currently the president of Drew University, told party leaders that he was not interested in re-entering the political fray. After Bret D. Schundler's decisive loss to James E. McGreevey in the gubernatorial election, Republicans were hoping to draft the popular Mr. Kean, 66, to unify the battered party. In addition to Mr. Treffinger, two other Republicans are testing the water to see if they should jump in -- State Senator Diane Allen of Burlington County and Assemblyman Guy Gregg of Morris County. Mr. Torricelli is viewed as vulnerable because of a federal investigation into fund-raising for his 1996 Senate victory. Steve Strunsky

title: Rooms In Quest Of Guests
description: PETER ILLCHUK, president of the Lodging Association of the Florida Keys, had never seen anything like it. He was in the lobby of a Key West hotel the Friday afternoon before the final weekend of that city's annual Fantasy Fest, a Mardi Gras-like celebration held in late October. A couple had just walked in off the street without a reservation, and they secured a room. ''In years past, they would have been lucky to find one 50 miles up the road,'' he said.

title: The Uncomfortable Question of Anti-Semitism
description: Anti-Semitism is as deadly as anthrax or smallpox or any other biological terror. Thank you for exposing this ongoing plague. Paradoxically, public exposure to the problem may help to combat its spread.

title: Dance Listings
description: ALVIN AILEY AMERICAN DANCE THEATER  Wed., 7: Opening night gala with live music accompanying "Caravan," "Pas de Duke" and "Revelations." Thur., 8: `'Night Creature," "Sweet Bitter Love," "Following the Subtle Current Upstream" and "Grace." Fri., 8: "Blues Suite," "Serving Nia," "Revelations." Sat., 2: Family matinee with "Serving Nia," "Night Creature," "Chocolate Sessions" and "Grace." At 8: "Blues Suite," "Serving Nia," "Caravan." Next Sun., 3: "Serving Nia," "Night Creature," "Chocolate Sessions" and "Grace." At 7:30: Live music to "Caravan," "Following the Subtle Current Upstream" and "Revelations." City Center, 131 W. 55th St. (212-581-1212) Through Dec.

title: Music Listings
description: Opera

title: Liberties; Uncivil Liberties?
description: A friend of mine, a liberal editor at a magazine, has been trying to get some of his staffers interested in writing about whether the Bush team's anti-terrorism measures are scorching our civil liberties.

title: Greener Golf Courses, Ecologically, That Is
description: IF you ask Ed Wachter, golf course superintendent at the Innsbrook Resort and Conference Center in Innsbrook, Mo., about his course, he will describe his carefully maintained playing areas. He will also tell you about his native prairie grasses and wildflowers. At times he sounds more like a home gardener than someone responsible for keeping 250 acres of golf courses in prime playing condition.

title: Editors' Note; A Nation Challenged
description: News of the terrorist attacks and their aftermath appears today in Section B; index, Page B2.

title: Seeking Freedom and Security at a Time of War
description: To the Editor:

title: November 18-24; Killed for Covering the War
description: Four foreign journalists in Afghanistan were murdered by armed gunmen on the highway halfway between Jalalabad and Kabul. A witness said the gunmen shouted: ''The Taliban are still here!''

title: Generalissimo
description: THE FEAST OF THE GOAT

title: Sharon Litwin, Ethan Hoberman
description: Sharon Jill Litwin, a rabbinical student, was married last evening in Rockleigh, N.J., to Ethan Scott Hoberman, a chemical engineer. Rabbi Sarah Messenger officiated at the Rockleigh Country Club.

title: GOING OUT
description: An guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Amy Johnson, James Cox
description: Amy Elizabeth Johnson, a daughter of Claire and Thomas Johnson of Middletown, N.J., was married yesterday to James William Cox, a son of Kathleen Brooks of Rockaway Beach, N.Y., and the late James William Cox. The Rev. Bartholomew Daly, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of Our Lady of Peace in New York.

title: The Uncomfortable Question of Anti-Semitism
description: While Arab-Americans rightfully plead for tolerance and understanding, seldom do you hear them condemn the vicious anti-Semitism so prevalent in the Arab and Muslim world. What stunning hypocrisy.

title: Romantic Bench
description: To the Editor: Marylin Bender's essay ''Sitting With Memories in a London Park'' (Nov. 11) brought nostalgic tears to my eyes, especially as we are family friends of one of the couples mentioned. The plaque was a surprise wedding gift in 1997 from a very romantic groom, Richard Currie, to his beloved Libby. I immediately called them in England.

title: A Chardonnay Is a Mainstay
description: Jos A. Montilla, the Barcelona-born winemaker at Macari, says fruity, non-oaked, food-oriented dry whites will become Long Island's forte. His tasty, crisp 2000 estate chardonnay validates his theory. Useful as an aperitif and with fish, chicken and pork, it may remind francophiles of Mcon and Rully chardonnays. Vintage New York, 482 Broome Street (Wooster Street), SoHo, charges $16. HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

title: Lori Turk, Michael Parizman
description: Lori Gaye Turk and Michael Adam Parizman were married last evening by Rabbi Ronald L. Androphy at the East Meadow Jewish Center in East Meadow, N.Y.

title: Nacer Fathi Mustafa
description: Nacer Fathi Mustafa and his father, Fathi Mustafa, went to Mexico on Sept. 9, on what was supposed to be a four-day business trip to buy leather jackets to sell at their store in Labelle, Fla.

title: Sports of The Times; It's 'One More for Danny and Courtney'
description: NO game this weekend because, officially, the season is over, though Pudgie Walsh has had the inescapable feeling of it being one game and a grand gesture short.

title: Quarterback Quiz: Who Plays? Why?
description: In New England, Coach Bill Belichick, after several days of agonizing analysis, took the starting quarterback job away from Drew Bledsoe, he of the $103 million contract, and gave it to Tom Brady, the former Michigan player. Bledsoe has a Super Bowl and nine years of experience under his belt; Brady has eight starts.

title: Lori Ann Krushefski, James Miller
description: Lori Ann Krushefski, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Chet Krushefski of Southampton, Pa., was married yesterday to James Michael Miller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Albert Miller of Randolph, N.J. The Rev. Carol St. John, an interfaith minister, performed the ceremony at the Lake Valhalla Club in Montville, N.J.

title: Footlights; Talking and Sketching
description: When Jean Craighead George talks on the phone, her African parrot is apt to join in. ''Who cares?'' he says. Or ''Get to work, Jean.'' Ms. George, the author of more than 90 books for children and young adults, hardly needs coaxing. Over the years there have been many pets and books based on them, like ''How to Talk to Your Cat''' and ''How to Talk to Your Dog.'' She may be best known for two Newberry Medal-winning books: ''My Side of the Mountain,'' published in 1959, and ''Julie of the Wolves,'' published in 1972. A movie of ''Julie'' is now being filmed in Canada starring a 13-year-old Inupiat Eskimo girl, and is tentatively scheduled to open next Christmas.

title: Ideas & Trends; Worm Warfare
description: ''SUBTERRANEAN warfare may be the answer for the enemies of the United States,'' wrote Maj. Donald M. Helig in a research paper for the Air Command and Staff College at Maxwell Air Force Base in Alabama last year.Over the past 100 years, subterranean warfare has evolved from a tactic to evade potential enemies into an extremely effective and efficient means to counter the effects of superior air power.

title: Commercial Property/New Jersey; Waterfront Projects Planned North of Jersey City
description: TIMES may be uncertain, but Steven J. Pozycki says he is sure. His company, SJP Properties, is going to build a 550,000-square-foot office building on the Hoboken waterfront on speculation that the property and location will attract corporate clients.

title: Long at Odds With the U.S., Yemen Is Now Cooperating to Fight Terror
description: American intelligence officials and Yemeni authorities, putting aside the diplomatic strains of the last 10 years, including friction over the inquiry into the bombing of the destroyer Cole, have begun to work more closely on tracking terrorists here, Yemeni officials and Western diplomats said this week.

title: City Refines Its Counting Of the Dead
description: City officials have refined their method for tabulating the number of people missing or killed after two hijacked planes struck the World Trade Center on Sept. 11. As a result, they expect to have more reliable figures by the end of the year, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday.

title: November 18-24; An Al-of-all-Trades
description: First Al Gore was a journalist. Then a congressman. Then a senator. Then vice president (and almost president). Now Mr. Gore will be a rainmaker. He has taken a job as the vice chairman of Metropolitan West Financial Inc., a 10-year-old financial services company based in Los Angeles. His mission will be to use his contacts to broaden the company's private equity investments into biotechnology and information technology. Mr. Gore will continue to teach at colleges and work on a book on family, with his wife, Tipper. And his advisers say he has not ruled out trying again for the White House. Richard L. Berke

title: Pakistan's Anxiety Grows as Taliban Collapse
description: A senior Pakistani official watched in dismay today as the television in his office showed Taliban fighters, streaming out of Kunduz, Afghanistan, to surrender to the Northern Alliance.

title: Unearthing The Notebook That Unnerved Society
description: ROBERT E. LAUNEY was rummaging in his closet the other day, sifting through the relics of a former life, when a tidy black notebook caught his eye. Uncertain what to make of it -- a schoolboy's composition book with the single word ''Dance'' handwritten on the cover -- he strolled to the next room to show it to his wife, Deborah. She leafed through the ledger, and asked incredulously: ''Do you know what you have here?''

title: Hands-On; America Tries, Again, to End the Endless Conflict
description: RARELY has there been such an urgent, unanimous sense among the world's powers that the long, violent impasse in the Israeli-Palestinian struggle must now end.

title: Sondheim, Young and Dazzling
description: WHICH playwright is worthier of reincarnation, George Bernard Shaw or William Shakespeare?

title: Don't Expect Happy Clowns In This Show of Circus Art
description: IT is often said that the circus mirrors life, with its thrills and feelings of elation, and in its sad aspects too. But life can be boring, and the circus never is. Neither is ''Images From the World Between: The Circus in 20th-Century American Art,'' an exhibition at the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art, in Hartford.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLOCH, ELLEN ''RUTHIE'' (NEE ROSENBERG)
description: FLOCH-Ellen ''Ruthie'' (nee Rosenberg). Beloved wife of the late Walter. Devoted mother of Vivian Floch and Valerie Jablonski and Raymond and Anne Floch. Adoring ''Omi'' of Benjamin. Service today 10:15 AM at ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Exp., Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: Letters: Public Radio
description: PUBLIC RADIO

title: Counterfeiters Turn Magic Into Cash
description: In front of a gleaming shopping center here, not two miles from the Great Hall of the People and Tiananmen Square, a small man in a dark suit jacket, a messenger's bag slung over his chest, quietly peddles his wares.

title: Alice Munro
description: REVIEWS

title: The Uncomfortable Question of Anti-Semitism
description: Jonathan Rosen's essay (Nov. 4) was a thoughtful and nuanced discussion of a topic usually sounded in hyperbolic tones. I would like to make special note of his recognition of the recent Durban conference as a watershed resurrection of Nazism's worst propaganda. The events of Sept. 11 have all but expunged Durban from the popular consciousness, but it was a glimpse into the open global convergence of truly spectacular evil. In that connection, it is important to acknowledge the debt we owe President Bush. Alone, literally, among all the world's leaders, he spurned the conference.

title: Will New York Be Told, Once Again, to Drop Dead?
