description: NEARLY 11 weeks after the worst terrorist attack in history, New York is discovering just how much the rest of the United States cares about the nation's business and financial center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURKHARDT, WILLIAM
description: BURKHARDT-William. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of William Burkhardt, associated with The Times from 1931 until retiring in 1978.

title: A Barber's Soothing Aria
description: PEPE SANSELI is an Upper East Side barber, coiffeur to titans of industry, lawyers, poets, playwrights and some minor journalists. He has good hands constructed of long, fine bones, and when they are at work, his scissors make the tick-a-tack sound of a stenotype machine.

title: BENEFITS
description: Through a Glass, Brightly

title: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 11-25-01: On Language; The Arab Street
description: Peppered by questions from senators about why the Bush administration supported a Saudi monarchy that oppressed political or religious dissenters, Secretary of State Colin Powell gave a reply that struck many as puzzling: ''Unto dust thou shalt return the day you stop representing the street.'' He explained, ''When you don't have a free, democratic system, where the street is represented in the halls of the Legislature and in the executive branches of those governments, then they'' -- the Saudi rulers -- have to be more concerned by the passions of the street.''

title: Ideas & Trends: Getting What You Pay For; Now, Uncle Sam Wants You
description: FOR the first time since the Reagan years, a president has formally recognized that the federal government is a more appropriate employer than the private sector in a host of areas where the public good is the primary consideration.

title: Postings: On East 68th St., a Center for Prostate and Urological Cancers; New Sloan-Kettering Building
description: A six-story building housing a center for treatment and research of prostate and urological cancers is nearing completion at 363 East 68th Street, diagonally across from the main Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. Upon completion next month, two months before it will see its first patients, it will be named the Sidney Kimmel Cancer Center.

title: The Health Care Spark
description: To the Editor:

title: A Raised Voice by a Noted Feminist, This Time Over Rental Politics
description: Kate Millett, the feminist author and artist, is not a creature of the night by choice. She believes that city agents are stationed outside her door, ready to boot her from her outsized loft at 295 Bowery.

title: Private Sector; Toning It Down in Hollywood
description: Frank Pierson, the film writer and director who is the new president of the Academy of Motion Pictures Arts and Sciences, said the Sept. 11 attacks had a direct impact on a script he is still writing for Paramount: He's deleted the blood and gore. Mr. Pierson, 76, who is making his first visit to New York as academy president next week, said the attacks had ''changed my thinking about how secure we feel in our lives, how we depict our lives.'' His screenplay, begun before Sept. 11, is about Russian spies who have lived for years in the United States and are dying mysteriously. Mr. Pierson said the screenplay was now about ''what happens when someone is caught between two ideologies and two loyalties, about Russians who have grown American.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JEROME, JERRY
description: JEROME-Jerry. Tenor saxophonist, at 89, on November 17. Beloved, devoted husband of Elaine; loving father of Al, Bill, Jim and Jerry; step-father of Joanne, Barbara and David; brother of Dorothy, Elsie and Irving; brotherin-law of Evelyn; grandfather of 11; great-grandfather of one. Your music, humor and loving kindness will be with us always. A memorial concert is planned for January in Sarasota, FL.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 11 about the director Jacques Demy misstated the location of Nantes, France, the setting of his film ''Lola.'' It is on the Atlantic, not the Mediterranean.

title: Selling Through the Slump
description: Rob Bohlen (right), Brighton, Mich.

title: The Slide Begins
description: MORE than 10 weeks after terrorists leveled the World Trade Center, statisticians have begun to measure the shock waves from the attack as they reverberate through Long Island's economy.

title: Most Parties Will Go On, Even If They're Quieter
description: Still reeling from the terrorist attacks and from the weak economy, which has squeezed profits and produced layoffs, corporate America may hardly be in the mood for merriment. Yet many companies plan to hold some type of holiday celebration, though maybe on a less lavish scale, two surveys show.

title: Their Demeanors Don't Betray The Desperation
description: IN her worst weeks, Wai Chun Ng at least had a $50 paycheck. After 40 years of sewing in Chinatown factories, job cuts had reduced Ms. Ng to working as a finisher, earning a penny for every two buttons she cut the thread on. Last month, when Ms. Ng finally lost her job, she turned to the Red Cross to help put food on the table for herself and her retired husband.

title: Delay Only Complicates Contraction
description: The contradictions of contraction:

title: Bin Laden Reported Spotted in Fortified Camp in Afghan East
description: Osama bin Laden was seen this week at a large and well-fortified encampment 35 miles southwest of this city, a minister of the self-proclaimed government here said tonight.

title: A Big Farewell Afternoon For Velazquez and Pletcher
description: The quality trainers and jockeys who dominate New York racing from April through November have their bags packed, ready to flee for Florida and New Orleans before the temperatures dip and the racing cards become filled with cheap claimers. Before saying goodbye, two of New York racing's biggest human stars fattened their already healthy bank accounts. For the trainer Todd Pletcher and the jockey John Velazquez, coming up with shipping money will not be a problem.

title: Gregory Richards: The Call of the City
description: Gregory Richards just could not stay away from New York. He was born here, grew up in Greenwich Village and went to Stuyvesant High School.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Big Man Temporarily On Campus
description: A silver Mercedes pulls up in front of the Four Seasons Hotel in Philadelphia and out steps Dajuan Wagner, the 6-foot-2-inch graduate of nearby Camden, N.J., High and last year's high-school basketball player of the year. Wagner is accompanied by his 14-year-old sister, Dashonda, and by William Wesley, the man who has helped manage Wagner's career ever since Juanny, as his friends call him, was 11.

title: Corrections
description: A classical music listing on Page 39 of Arts & Leisure today for a concert by the Vox Vocal Ensemble in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University was printed in error. The concert is scheduled for Jan. 26, not tomorrow.

title: Try Soccer's Way
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Quiet One, the D.J., A Man of November, And the Head of the Table
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: The World: Ripping Yarns; The Spy Novel Returns
description: AFTER the Berlin Wall fell in 1989, it seemed that even before the dust had settled the obituary of the spy novel was being written. With the end of the Evil Empire, spies seemed obsolete, and so did the labyrinthine narrative of the intelligence operative, with its tradecraft, safe houses, moles and dead drops.

title: Return to New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAIN, HERBERT
description: HAIN-Herbert, 92. On November 16, 2001. Survived by his wife Rosalind, sons Jack of Santa Cruz, CA, and Sandy of Palo Alto, CA; and grandchildren Jason, Sam and Emily. Contributions may be made to the Jewish National Fund for trees to be planted in Israel in his name.

title: The Original Hall of Fame Tries to Get Back on Its Feet
description: Natasha Quinn never expected to find such beauty in the Bronx.

title: Bush's New Rules to Fight Terror Transform the Legal Landscape
description: As Pentagon officials begin designing military tribunals for suspected terrorists, they are considering the possibility of trials on ships at sea or on United States installations, like the naval base in Guantnamo Bay, Cuba. The proceedings promise to be swift and largely secret, with one military officer saying that the release of information might be limited to the barest facts, like the defendant's name and sentence. Transcripts of the proceedings, this officer said, could be kept from public view for years, perhaps decades.

title: Nutcracker Behind Glass
description: Mounting a George Balanchine ballet in a window cannot be easy, but for the past five years, Bonnie A. Behrman, director of the Bay Head School of Ballet and Violin, has been doing just that.

title: INVESTING WITH/Peter F. Spano; Preferred International Value Fund
description: PETER F. SPANO named his firm, Mercator Asset Management, for Gerardus Mercator, the 16th-century cartographer whose world map helped sailors navigate the globe.

title: Howling With Wolves in an Unseasonable Minnesota
description: Seated in a 12-foot-high platform on the edge of a canary grass meadow that is being invaded by willows and an occasional tamarack, I was snapped from my usual predawn deer stand musings -- a blend of retrospection and anticipation -- by the wailing of wolves.

title: The Gift Tightrope
description: Although times are tough, many people still intend to exchange holiday gifts with co-workers this year. And that leads to the usual question: What is appropriate? Aside from the standard no-fruitcake rule, here are some suggestions from business etiquette experts:

title: Ahmed Abou el-Kheir
description: Ahmed Abou el-Kheir was among the first wave of people arrested following the Sept. 11 attacks. He arrived in the United States on a tourist visa on Sept. 7. He was arrested and has been in jail ever since on a variety of charges.

title: Residents' Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Parrish Breaks Silence as Isles Beat Anaheim
description: The Islanders pay Mark Parrish to score goals, and he had not scored one in 16 days. Just one day without a goal, Parrish said late tonight, might as well be an eon for a goal-scorer.

title: Singing Solo From Her Irish Roots
description: A NEW album, her first extensive West Coast tour as a solo performer and a planned radio program on the BBC -- all this adds up to a solid career for the singer-songwriter Cathie Ryan.

title: Unclaimed and Mostly Forgotten: A Testament to Troubled Lives
description: ROW by somber row, beside a tranquil, tree-lined lane behind Connecticut Valley Hospital, lie the long-forgotten -- nearly 1,700 of them.

title: Improv on the World Stage
description: SPECIAL PROVIDENCE

title: Staging To Songs, It's Blissful Night Music
description: IN the best of all possible theater fantasies, Stephen Sondheim's ''A Little Night Music'' would be performed in a jewel box of a theater. Imagine an opera house in Vienna, or perhaps a chamber music hall in Sweden, in homage to Ingmar Bergman's 1955 film, ''Smiles of a Summer Night,'' the inspiration for Mr. Sondheim's operetta.

title: Open Ears
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMON, FLORENCE SIMET
description: KRAMON-Florence Simet. The world lost a fabulous women Friday November 23rd when Florence Simet - Kramon - Peate passed away. Loving mother of Falene and Paul Gottbetter and Linda and Bruce Klein. Devoted grandmother of Franklyn and Tracy Gottbetter, Adam and Lori Gottbetter, and Vanessa Klein. Adored and adoring great-grandmother of Taylor, Sophia, and Rebecca Gottbetter. Florence was a dedicated educator, talented decorator, tireless volunteer and author of the ''Eugene'' series of children's books. Her love for flora and fauna excelled in her ability to nuture and grow plants, trees and flowers. Florence was all about style and elegance, and she brought unique flair to whatever she did. A world traveler and hostess extraordinaire. A shining gem whose luster may dim but never fade. Services Sunday, November 25th, 11 AM, at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street.

title: Mark Francis Broderick: A Remarkable Smile
description: Mark Francis Broderick had a remarkable smile. It made everyone feel at ease with him, said Chris Dowd, his friend since they were fraternity brothers at St. John's University on Staten Island, N.Y.

title: Nereida De Jesus: Life With Lauren
description: For Nereida De Jesus, life equaled Lauren. Lauren was her daughter, a bubbly 7-year-old whom Ms. De Jesus, 30, was raising alone in Woodlawn in the Bronx. Mother and daughter would do everything together -- get their hair done, go to movies, take bubble baths.

title: High-Flying Gymnast Faces Sideline Season
description: THIS was supposed to be the season the girl without a team made her mark in the state high school gymnastic championships.

title: Yael Antebi
description: At 2:30 a.m. after Halloween night, when she heard the knock on the door at her Columbia, Mo., apartment, Yael Antebi was on the phone, calling her father in Israel, where it was morning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALBERG, GYULA PETER
description: HALBERG-Gyula Peter. Born 1915, Budapest, Hungary, died November 24, 2001, in his beloved NYC. Dr. Halberg, an early pioneer of color photography of the retina and optic nerve-head was a developer of glaucoma diagnostic instrumentation and organizer of medical contact lens fitting. He served as Director of Glaucoma Service, New York Eye and Ear Infirmary and Chief of Glaucoma Service, NY's St. Vincent's Hospital. After over 30 years as member of New York Medical College academic staff, he retired as Professor Emeritus of Ophthalmology. During the Korean War he served with the 121 Evacuation Hospital, promoted to Major, US Army Medical Corps, decorated with Bronze Star Medal. He is survived by his wife of 42 years, Marion Emily, three children and two grandchildren: daughter, Marion, married to Michael Hardiman, their children Bridget and Katherine Hardiman of Mt. Kisco, NY; son Peter of New York; son Paul of Maui, Hawaii. He is also survived by his sister and brother-inlaw, Dorothea and Nicholas Wenckheim of NY. Plans for memorial service are being arranged.

title: For a Dealer in Stones, a Showcase of Folk Art Gems
description: LONG before Ralph Esmerian developed the nonstop passion for American folk art that would lead him to assemble one of the most distinctive collections in the field, he had already succumbed to the joys of collecting.

title: Your Home; Renovating Without Permission
description: MOST residential leases in New York City -- for both regulated and nonregulated apartments -- contain a provision that prohibits a tenant from making any ''alterations, decorations, additions or improvements'' to an apartment without the landlord's written consent. Some leases are even more specific, prohibiting tenants from installing ''any paneling, flooring, built-in decorations, partitions, railings'' or from painting or wallpapering the apartment without first getting the landlord's written consent.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We surrendered so no more blood would be shed, our own blood. All the Taliban are running away.''

title: More Workers Skimp As Drug Costs Rise
description: In recent years, many employers have responded to the double-digit increases in prescription costs by raising the copayments for workers covered under their drug plans. And many workers, it seems, have responded by cutting back on their medications, according to survey results released last week.

title: Travel Advisory
description: The Practical Traveler column on Nov. 4, about discounts at hotels in New York, misstated the lowest nightly rate offered by Morgans and the Royalton hotels through March under a promotion that gives three nights for the price of two. The rate is $250, not $150.

title: Afghan-Style Surrender, Entrepreneurial Zeal and a Powerful Grief
description: There was a sense of watching a skins-vs.-shirts basketball game as hundreds of Taliban soldiers streamed out of Kunduz in northern Afghanistan and surrendered to the Northern Alliance. It was as if all it took to join the other side was to remove one's jersey. Enemies a few hours earlier embraced as if they were old friends. In some instances, they were.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZEIGEN, SAMUEL L., LLB
description: ZEIGEN-Samuel L., LLB, CLU. Past President of the CLU, of New York City. Died peacefully on November 20th in his 99th year. Loving husband of Bess, father of H. Lylla Kleiman and L. Marshall Zeigen, and father-in-law of George Kleiman. A memorial service will be announced.

title: The Morphing of Czernowitz
description: IN THE SHAPE OF A BOAR

title: Hyde Park
description: To the Editor: Kevin Baker's description of Springwood, the Franklin Delano Roosevelt home in Hyde Park, N.Y. (''American Treasures,'' Oct. 7), reminded me of my first visit to the estate in 1989. Arriving in my wheelchair, I found the beautiful front of the house scarred by an unsightly and very steep wheelchair ramp -- one of the most difficult and frightening ramps I ever climbed.

title: Flag Flying Causes Stir At Palace In Honolulu
description: It was meant as a respectful gesture for the victims of Sept. 11: raising the American flag over a historic state building downtown that had not flown the Stars and Stripes since the 1960's.

title: MEADOWLANDS SUPPORT WANES
description: State financial support for the Meadowlands Sports Complex will decrease next year to $31 million, less than this year's subsidy, according to numbers released last week by the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority. The decrease is mainly due to the completion of big-ticket items like installing a grass field, replacing scoreboards and renovating the Winners Club restaurant. A spokesman for the authority said it expected no problems next year, despite lower ticket sales this football season. Jo Piazza

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUSHEL, LILLIAN
description: KUSHEL-Lillian. 86, on November 23rd, 2001. Beloved wife of Bernard, devoted mother of Kenneth, cherished grandmother of Marika. Sister of Milton Shapiro, the late Miriam Fox, Edwin Shapiro, and Adele Leonard. She was a revered professor of fashion, buying, and merchandising for over forty years. The lives of thousands of her students were graced by her wisdom, expertise and generosity. Services Sunday, noon, at Sherman's Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, NY.

title: It May or May Not Be Great. But Immortal? Never!
description: ONCE it was possible to have your cake and eat it, too. This, after all, was an essential function of art: to preserve fleeting pleasures, to give permanent form to the perishable. Art's longevity was the consolation for life's too brief span. What could be more satisfying, sensually or spiritually, than a basket of wild strawberries painted by Chardin, or a tableful of apples and peaches by Czanne? Succulent, mouthwatering and never in need of refrigeration, these fruit provide nutrition regardless of season. Their eternal perfection is a reproach to mere produce, which must be consumed or left to rot.

title: Investing; Fund Strategies to Soothe Tax Pain
description: MOST stock mutual funds have lost money this year, but there is a nugget of good news. Because of their dismal performance, most funds will cause only small tax bills for shareholders.

title: Virtual Rape
description: Like many criminal offenders, James Maxwell is not a particularly appealing character. At worst, he's a dangerous sexual predator; at best, he's a sexual deviant. Maxwell, a 51-year-old New Jersey resident, likes talking dirty to children. In April, he acknowledged making obscene phone calls to 12 girls, ranging in age from 8 to 14, and pleaded guilty to multiple counts of child endangerment. This would have been an unsavory but unremarkable case, except that in one instance, Maxwell was also charged with aggravated sexual assault. The victim was a 10-year-old girl known in court documents as S.M. During one phone call, in which Maxwell posed as her mother's gynecologist, he persuaded S.M. to insert her finger into her vagina.

title: German Greens Patch Rift And Support Use of Military
description: Members of Germany's Green party defied their pacifist roots and voted overwhelmingly tonight in favor of sending German soldiers to Afghanistan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VECCHIONE, EDWARD, JR.
description: VECCHIONE-Edward, Jr. On Nov. 22, 2001 at age 76. Loving brother of Dorothy Martin and cousin of Vincent Lombardi, Marie Pelusso, Lucretia Trisci and Michael Trisci. Companion of the late Lilo Marcus. Dear friend of Bernice & Arthur Weiss and Joan Linsky and Danny Vitanzo. Also survived by many nephews, cousins and dear friends. Mr. Vecchione was a member of The Hotel Management Association, a veteran of W.W. II, a prisoner of war and a graduate of Columbia University. Funeral Mass was held at Our Lady of Peace Church, 237 E. 62 St, Saturday 11:15AM. Interment followed at Christ the King Cemetery, Franklin Lakes, NJ. Contributions in his memory may be made to Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, NY 10461.

title: Losing a Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Carlton W. Bartels: Wraparound Buddha
description: Her father was aghast: there on the doorstep of her family's West Brighton home in Staten Island stood Carlton W. Bartels, suitor. "Carl had thick, wavy brown hair, down to his shoulders," recalled Jane Bartels, the object of his affection, decades later. "And a suede fringe jacket."

title: William H. Kelly Jr.: Mr. Long Beach Island
description: If you lived on Long Beach Island in New Jersey, you knew William H. Kelly Jr. Although Mr. Kelly grew up in Bucks County, Pa., his family spent summers on the island, where he was able to indulge his passion for the water, learning to sail and surf. "My friends would joke around; they used to call him `Mr. L.B.I.,' " said his girlfriend of three years, Sue Magee, an employee of Bloomberg L.P., where Mr. Kelly also worked.

title: November 18-24; Even Little Oil Gets Bigger
description: Consolidation in the U.S. oil business continued as the Phillips Petroleum Company and Conoco Inc. announced that they would merge in a $35 billion stock swap. Their new company, ConocoPhillips, will be the nation's third-largest oil company and largest gasoline retailer, selling gas under the Conoco, Phillips 66, Union 76 and Circle K brands.

title: Best Address in Jerusalem
description: THE ROCK

title: Collateral Damage In Lower Manhattan
description: For many people trying to make a living in Lower Manhattan, the weeks since Sept. 11 have been devastating. Shops were closed or inaccessible, and so no money came in, putting business owners behind in their rent. Once these businesses did reopen, they discovered that their customer base had largely vanished.

title: Lydia Payne, Jacob Johnson III
description: Lydia Eleanor Payne and Jacob Bernard Johnson III were married on Friday at the Lambert Beach Resort and Hotel on Tortola, in the British Virgin Islands. Graham Farinha, the marriage registrar on Tortola, officiated.

title: Security Quest Also Offers Opportunities
description: Tom Ridge, the director of homeland security, likes to say the home-front battle against terrorism is not just the business of government but of business. Business agrees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGEIM, HILDEGARDE E.
description: BERGEIM-Hildegarde E. Formerly of Greenwich Village, died Tuesday, in Pennsylvania. She received her architectural degree from the Univeristy of Illinois and later became a Fulbright Scholar. She was an architect for Philip Johnson and Edward Larrabee Barnes. Survived by brother-in-law Harold Schneider, two nephews and one niece. Services are private.

title: Anthony Jovic: A Special Plaque
description: Anthony Jovic videotaped his sons, Matthew, 10, and Peter, 9, at every swimming meet they entered. He went to their practices. And he took them along when he and his wife, Cynthia, went on a cruise in the Caribbean. And whenever he came home from work, the boys would rush up to him and say, "What did you do? Did you fight any fires?"

title: Death on the Trail
description: When I'm mountain biking, I sometimes find a small animal (e.g., snake or lizard) that was accidentally injured by another biker or hiker and appears to be suffering. I want to help, but I am far from the nearest veterinarian. Usually I move the creature off the trail and hope it will live, but I wonder about putting it out of its misery. What should I do next time? S.S., California

title: Irving Crane, a World Champion Who Brought Decorum to Billiards, Is Dead at 88
description: Irving Crane, whose gentlemanly, cautious approach to the game of pool resulted in the nickname the Deacon and seven world championships, at least one in each decade starting in the 1940's, died on Nov. 17 at a nursing home in Rochester. He was 88.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-31

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEONARD, ALICE (NEE EBERT)
description: LEONARD-Alice (nee Ebert). On November 24, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Eugene S. Loving mother of Virginia and Bill Gorman and Joseph and Mary Leonard. Cherished grandmother of Brendan, Meghan, Billy, Christopher, Terrence and Elizabeth. Dear sister of George and Gigi Ebert. Visiting Sunday 7-9 PM, and Monday 2-5 and 7-9 PM, at M.J. Smith Sons Inc., 248 Prospect Park West at Prospect Ave., Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 9:15 AM, at Holy Name R.C. Church.

title: Theater Listings
description: Approximate running times are given at end of Broadway and Off Broadway listings.

title: Learning From Israel And Its Mistakes
description: When I accepted a one-semester teaching position at Rutgers University's Bildner Center for the Study of Jewish Life, I hoped to get away for a while from the tense atmosphere in Israel; I was looking forward to a quiet academic fall. The fall has been magnificent indeed, but I arrived in New York on Sept. 10. Instead of finding relief, I've been much reminded of life back home.

title: Remembering An Old Scandal
description: Amy Fisher, where are you?

title: Minnesota Fans Are Being Punished
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Once Again, Soaries Says He May Want to Run
description: Secretary of State DeForest Soaries -- who for an instant last year considered running for governor on the Republican ticket -- is at it again. This time he is thinking about challenging Rush Holt, the Democrat who currently represents the 12th District in Congress.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAILEY, ROBERT W.
description: BAILEY-Robert W. On November 22, 2001, of Cliffside Park, formerly of NYC, age 50. Beloved life partner of Brian O'Dell. Devoted son of Therese C. Bailey and the late Vincent J. Bailey. Dear brother of Kevin F., Vincent J. Jr., & James P. Bailey. Loving uncle of Shannon, Andrea, Sean, Kyle, Jack and Russell. Funeral will assemble at the A.K. Macagne Funeral Home, 495 Anderson Avenue, Cliffside Park, NJ, on Tuesday, November 27, 2001, at 9:30 AM. Interment at Ascension Cemetery, Monsey, NY. Visiting hours Sunday, 7-9 PM, and Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

title: Targeting Sponsors
description: To the Editor:

title: Accounting Peer Review Gets More Scrutiny
description: The accounting industry's watchdog group is examining the industry's ''peer review'' process in light of enormous accounting problems at the Enron Corporation.

title: What the Fed Can't Do About This Recession
description: MONETARY policy could not be better. The Federal Reserve has reduced interest rates so aggressively that lenders are almost giving away money. The economy should be rising again in response to so much easy credit. It is not rising, but there is some response, which helps to explain why the current, potentially severe recession is still a mild one.

title: Word for Word/Bounties; Everybody's Got a Price: Hunting Public Enemy No. 1, No. 2....
description: THE United States has a long history of offering bounties to jar memories or entice accomplices to rat out outlaws: Jesse James, the Unabomber and the terrorist Ramzi Yousef, to name a few.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, LUCILLE I., DPM
description: GOLDMAN-Lucille I., DPM. Died at age 85, November 10, 2001. Wife of the late Milton Sanes Goldman, M.D., mother of Rose H. Goldman, M.D., and Lynne E. Goldman, sonin-law Alan Drabkin, and sister of David S. Werman, M.D., Grandmother of Miles, Anya and Ben. She will be deeply missed by loving family and friends.

title: Shari Blumenthal, Bryan Mintz
description: Dr. Shari Nan Blumenthal, a medical resident, and Bryan Howard Mintz, a lawyer, were married on Wednesday by Rabbi Chaim Rogoff at Temple Beth Ahm in Springfield, N.J.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: THE BRIGADE

title: Mick Jagger Is Off And Rolling Again
description: I MESSED up!'' Wyclef Jean said after flubbing a note in the Spanish guitar part he was working on for a song he was helping produce for Mick Jagger's new solo album. Mr. Jagger, who had been dancing around the control room as the song's bass-heavy chorus thumped out of the speakers, stopped, smiled at Mr. Jean and grabbed a handful of grapes from a fruit bowl nearby. He popped a couple in his mouth and took a seat on a couch in the back of the room.

title: Miami Beach's Down-to-Earth Eating Spots
description: Idon't know about you, but the fashionable oxygen of Miami Beach strikes me as lighter than real air. If I breathe it for too long, I become untethered and feel as if I'm floating away. The high-end restaurants can produce the same effect, with their luxury ingredients and elevated prices. Luckily, the Miami area has more than a few down-to-earth joints worth visiting if, like me, you want to keep your feet on the ground.

title: In Defense of Sontag
description: To the Editor:

title: Bartlesville Journal; Oil Company Town Has a Sudden Identity Crisis
description: The phrase ''significant presence'' -- tends to stick in the throat like a diagnosis from a doctor. Except that the people in this small Oklahoma town who are bracing for the unexpected loss of the Phillips Petroleum Company after more than eight decades still do not know if it means life or death.

title: A Nation Challenged
description: A Surrender Begins

title: Freeport's 20-Game Streak Is Ended by Farmingdale
description: It was a case of too little, too late. Despite a fourth-quarter rally, Freeport ended up a yard short and Farmingdale ended the Red Devils' 20-game winning streak with a 13-6 victory in the Nassau County Conference I title game yesterday at Hofstra University in Hempstead, N.Y.

title: Sailing Success in Toms River
description: When considering the hotbeds of sailboat racing in the United States, a number of locations come immediately to mind: Long Island Sound; Newport, R.I.; San Francisco; Annapolis, Md.; San Diego; Toms River, N.J.

title: A Country on the Brink of Default? It May Not Hurt Much
description: ARGENTINA is on the verge of default, but investors don't seem to care.

title: Thinking About the Flag
description: Visitors to the Newark Museum are getting the chance to think about flag and country and write their thoughts in a book. Former Senator Frank R. Lautenberg has lent the museum a 12-foot oil painting of the American flag by Ed Ruscha that hung in his office in Washington and more recently in his current office in Rochelle Park.

title: Ulster Protestants to End Demonstrations Against Schoolchildren
description: Protestant residents of a Belfast neighborhood have decided to end a 12-week-old protest that has forced Catholic schoolchildren to walk to their classes under the protection of riot squad police and military escorts.

title: Israeli Soldier Killed in Gaza; Nablus Mourns a Hamas Leader
description: An Israeli soldier was killed tonight and two others were slightly wounded when Palestinians fired a mortar shell at a settlement in the Gaza Strip, the Israeli Army said.

title: Somber Notes From the Underground: A Folk Music Landmark Faces Uncertainty
description: Beneath the stained glass windows and mahogany pews of St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University, Rebecca Josephson and Adrienne Baranowicz filed into the basement crypt to practice their weekly ritual: devotion to the guitar-strumming patron saints of folk music.

title: Kevin S. Cohen: Friends Everywhere
description: When Kevin S. Cohen was 4, his family moved to a new house in Edison, N.J. Rather than being daunted by the move, little Kevin, the youngest of two boys, set out to make new friends. Soon, he was standing at his front door pointing to all the houses where he had made a friend.

title: November 18-24; Congressional Anthrax
description: An anthrax contaminated letter sent to Patrick J. Leahy, the chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, contained what authorities strongly suspected was same highly refined and virulent form of the bacteria that was sent last month to Senate Majority Leader Thomas Daschle. Authorities concluded that the letter to Mr. Leahy, a Vermont Democrat, was written by the same person who sent an anthrax letter to Mr. Daschle, NBC News and the New York Post. Investigators sent the letter to an Army biomedical research lab for forensic tests that they hoped would help solve the baffling case. David Johnston

title: November 18-24; Anthrax Two: Another Baffling Case
description: Late Wednesday, 17 epidemiologists and other scientists from the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta flew to Oxford, Conn., to help with the search for the source of the anthrax that killed Ottilie W. Lundgren.

title: Deals and Discounts
description: Ski resorts aren't waiting to see how much snow falls this winter. The enticements have started.

title: The Truth Is Out: How Realists Could Be So Realistic
description: THOMAS EAKINS had a secret. For decades he engaged in a practice that many in late-19th-century Philadelphia would very likely have regarded as scandalous had they known. Not wanting to risk exposure, he kept quiet about it all his life. If any of his students or friends ever guessed -- and someone could easily have discovered him in the act -- they never talked either. His wife said in an interview that if he did it, he didn't enjoy it.

title: Film Series Listings
description: AMERICAN MUSEUM OF THE MOVING IMAGE  Master Class: The Art of Film Editing. Sat., 2: Lee's "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon" (2000); discussion with Tim Squyres. Shadow Play: Avant-Garde Views of Early Cinema. Today, 2: Schmidlin's 1999 reconstruction of von Stroheim's "Greed" (1924). Repertory Nights. Today, 6:30: Gilliam's "Brazil" (1985). Sat.-next Sun., 6:30: Lang's "M" (1931). 35th Ave. at 36th St., Astoria, Queens. (718-784-0077)

title: Danielle Elon, Andrew Feigenbaum
description: Danielle Elon, the daughter of Beryl Elon and Cantor Gadi Elon of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married yesterday at the Whitby Castle in Rye, N.Y., to Andrew Paul Feigenbaum, a son of Barbara and Gary Feigenbaum, also of New Rochelle. Rabbi Melvin Sirner officiated, and the bride's father took part in the ceremony.

title: Ideas & Trends; Cheer Up. It Used to Be Even Colder.
description: IN the Midwest, the land of the cold, every citizen learns that the greatest football game ever played took place in Green Bay, Wis., on Dec. 31, 1967, when the kickoff temperature was -13 degrees and the wind chill was -46. Legend has it that those frigid numbers dealt a psychological blow to the visiting team, the warm-weather Dallas Cowboys, who lost the game at the last second when the Green Bay Packers quarterback, Bart Starr, sneaked the ball across a frozen goal line.

title: Once Kept at Arm's Length, Torricelli Is Again Embraced
description: Only a few months ago, it was difficult to find many politicians who were very eager to defend Robert Torricelli, New Jersey's embattled senator, much less appear with him publicly.

title: Museums Of Civil War Are Torn By Debate
description: One hundred thirty-six years after Grant took Richmond, reconciling the bloody shards of the Civil War is not getting any easier.

title: The World; A War on Terror Meets a War on Drugs
description: FROM the first days of the war in Afghanistan, United States officials have pointed to a dangerous weapon in the desolate Afghan countryside: the poppy fields that have spread over thousands of acres in recent years, turning the nation into by far the largest source of opium and heroin in the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBBINS, BEATRICE NOBACK (BEA)
description: ROBBINS-Beatrice Noback (Bea), 77, past away October 13, 2001. Survived by dear husband Frank E. Robbins, 5400 Vantage Point Road, Suite 1109, Columbia, MD. 21044. Six children, five grandchildren, two brothers. Preceded in death by beloved son Robert Bruce Robbins. Eastchester, NY High School 1940, Cornell University 1944, BA Mathematics, BS Chemical Engineering. Patent agent, Washington DC. Tireless volunteer for many causes. Memorial service on December 2, 2001, 2:00 PM, Unitarian Universalist Church of Silver Spring, 10309 New Hampshire Avenue, Silver Spring, MD.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKELSTEIN, HUBERT
description: FINKELSTEIN-Hubert. Born in Pampa, Texas in 1931, Mr. Finkelstein died on Thursday, November 22, 2001 in Houston, Texas. He is survived by his children, David Finkelstein and Susan Finkelstein, his mother, Betty Finkelstein, his sisters, Gail Nusenow, Rona Streit, & Glenda Kaufman, & his beloved companion, Pamela Strate. He is also mourned by his many friends, his nephews and nieces, and his former wife, Ann Nachman Finkelstein. Mr. Finkelstein was the founder of Medallion Oil Company and well known in the oil and gas industry. A generous and modest philanthropist, he was a driving force in the Neurofibromatosis Society which bestowed upon him their Founder's Medal. He was a major benefactor of Cardiovascular Sciences Research at Baylor College of Medicine and The Methodist Hospital, Project Row Houses, and The Asia Society, upon whose board he served. In addition, friends and associates knew him as a perennial and generous doer of good deeds. Graveside Services: 4:00 P.M. Sunday, November 25, 2001, Beth Yeshurun Cemetery-Allen Parkway, Rabbi Jack Segal, officiating. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests that a contribution be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Critics Fault Lobbyists' Work for Pataki
description: A top adviser to Gov. George E. Pataki is also a lobbyist who has pressed the governor's office for legislation, in an unusual situation that critics of Mr. Pataki and of New York's lobbying practices say raises ethical concerns.

title: A Fire Along the Border Hits Kent
description: THE state's largest forest fire in years, fueled by abnormally dry conditions because of a lack of rain, burned 570 acres of woods on Schaghticoke Mountain starting on Veterans' Day, closed a four-mile section of the Appalachian Trail, and sent smoke and ashes into downtown Kent for two days.

title: And Bear In Mind
description: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about lobbying for corporate tax cuts in Washington misstated the relationship between Kenneth J. Kies, a Washington lobbyist, and a tax-relief coalition put together by the United States Chamber of Commerce. While Mr. Kies and the coalition are both lobbying for Congressional enactment of such tax cuts, he is not providing strategic help to it.

title: Tall Enough For the World to See
description: Every February, David Murback, a garden division manager of Rockefeller Center, boards a helicopter and whirs over the northeast (and sometimes beyond), skimming treetops in pursuit of a Norway spruce with model-perfect dimensions and an indefinable star quality. When he finds what he's looking for, the tree's owners get a knock on their door and an invitation to join an elite group. If they say yes (and they usually do), another Rockefeller Center Christmas tree is born.

title: What if Terror Went Nuclear?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, SAMUEL
description: JACOBS-Samuel. Age 95, of Palm Beach, Florida, passed away on November 22 in New York City. He is survived by his loving Millie, sisters Mary Bergofin and Kitty Chepovsky, seven grandchildren and their spouses, fourteen greatgrandchildren, his son-in-law Ernest Rubenstein and daughterin-law Eleanore Jacobs Goodman, and many nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by his first wife Anna and both his children Phyllis Rubenstein and Arthur Jacobs. Born in poverty, Mr. Jacobs achieved great success in the liquor industry as one of the three founding partners of Star Industries, Inc., and as one of the principal shareholders of The Paddington Corporation. Generous to a wide variety of charities, he was particularly dedicated to the Educational Alliance, a lower Eastside Settlement house of which he was the largest and most consistent individual donor over the past 20 years. Funeral services will held on Sunday, November 25th at 11:15 AM, ''the Riverside'', Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street in Manhattan. Contributions in his memory may be sent to the charity of the donor's choice.

title: The Point, Front and Center
description: THE United States Military Academy at West Point has not always been the darling of the region. During the war in Vietnam, there were angry protests outside its gates. In those days, when cadets ventured off base, they sometimes wore civilian clothes and even wigs to avoid being hassled.

title: Fragrance Merger
description: Technology Flavors and Fragrances (Amex: TFF) of Amityville said Tuesday it had signed a letter of intent to merge with Belmay, a competitor in Yonkers. Ted Kesten, the president and chief executive of Belmay, would become the chairman and chief executive of the combined company, which would be called Belmay/TFF and would have combined sales in excess of $60 million a year. Compiled by Warren Strugatch

title: An Anxious Community Ponders Its Own Patrols
description: Even Eli Taub, who regularly repeats the story about a pair of Arab-American men seen in a white van taking photographs of synagogues and Jewish homes in Kew Gardens Hills, Queens, says it's only a rumor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOBELMAN, DAYNA LYNNE
description: SOBELMAN-Dayna Lynne. Age 35, of Tampa, FL, died November 21, 2001, as a result of an automobile accident. Dayna was born in Brooklyn, NY. Survivors include her mother Goldie Lang of Delray Beach, FL, father Alan Sobelman of Tappan, NJ, sister and brotherin-law Gayle & Ted Millison of Tampa, brother David Sobelman of Washington, DC, grandmother Regina Sobelman of Far Rockaway, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the charity of your choice. Funeral services were held in Tampa. For information, Beth David Funeral Chapel, 813-874-3330.

title: SOAPBOX; Beside the Point
description: I AM offended as a New Jerseyan and as a hiker. I have the credentials for both. I am a native and a resident of central New Jersey and a longtime hiker with a specialty in climbing high points. So it rankles that many climbers consider New Jersey's high point -- aptly named High Point -- at 1,803 feet to be an inferior peak.

title: Ignoring Advantages, Few Teams Use Zone
description: LaPhonso Ellis was exasperated by Minnesota's switching defenses the other night. Ellis, a veteran forward, asked for a timeout that the Miami Heat did not have as he was trying to inbound the ball underneath the basket. He essentially pulled a Chris Webber. Not wanting to risk a five-second call in the final minutes of a game the Heat wound up losing, Ellis resorted to the same desperate, infamous reaction that overtook Webber in a national championship game as a sophomore at the University of Michigan.

title: Giants Audio
description: Postgame audio from the Giants vs. the Oakland Raiders provided by SportsAudio.net.

title: CRIME
description: After 25 years in the business, Lawrence Block's unlicensed private eye, Matt Scudder, still strolls New York's mean streets as if he had personally laid the cobblestones. It may take the 62-year-old P.I. longer to cover a city block, and he's defensively smug about the creature comforts he enjoys as a domesticated Upper West Sider. But this seasoned pro has a sixth sense for criminal anomalies, and in HOPE TO DIE (Morrow, $25) he smells something fishy when a couple in his affluent neighborhood are murdered during a routine brownstone burglary.

title: Planning Ahead for Peace of Mind
description: A FEW months before my father died in January, at 77, he told my mother the words she had long vowed never to heed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE MONTMOLLIN, LAURENT GUILLAUME
description: de MONTMOLLIN-Laurent Guillaume. Beloved brother of Edmee de M. Firth, step-brother of Robin McKinney Martin, cherished uncle of Marie-Louise and John Slocum and Olivia Beckwith-Smith. Son of the late Marielle McKinney and Henry de Montmollin. Age 52. Died unexpectedly of a heart attack at his home in Tampa, FL, on November 17. Funeral service and burial on December 10, at Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Middleburg, VA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, SOL
description: KAUFMAN-Sol. Beloved husband of the late Rose, devoted father of Harvey and Alan. Loving grandfather of Jack, Julie, Ezra and Noah. Loving brother of Bertha Rosenbloom. Services Monday, 9:30 AM, at Norman L. Jeffer Community Chapel, 4620 Fort Hamilton Parkway, Brooklyn.

title: Travel Advisory
description: A chart on Nov. 11 listing the cost of ski lift tickets misidentified the state for Alta. It is Utah, not Colorado.

title: Speaking of Trouble, Meet Assemblyman Tucker
description: Mr. McGreevey's troubles did not end after trying to cool Mr. Doria's temper.

title: Jews in New Jersey
description: Rutgers University Press has published two books this month that tell of the lives of New Jersey's Jews. ''The Jews of New Jersey'' ($29) is subtitled ''A Pictorial History,'' and it is a sort of photo album. Patricia M. Ard, an English professor at Ramapo College, and Michael Aaron Rockland, an American studies professor at Rutgers, focus mainly on storekeepers, farmers, children, homemakers and factory workers. There are wonderful photos of Weingarten's Corset Factory in Newark, for example, and of Fanny Dubnik with chicks at her poultry farm in Farmingdale. The book includes a chapter on the Holocaust and its aftermath, which is the subject of the other Rutgers Press book, ''Holocaust Memories: European Survivors and American Liberators in New Jersey'' ($25), edited by Joseph J. Preil, an education professor at Kean University. The book is a collection of first-hand accounts by 153 survivors and testimony of 20 liberators of concentration camps.

title: A Loaf of Bread
description: To the Editor: Regarding the articles with the headline ''Following French Traces in Vietnam'' (Sept. 9), there is something more basic that is part of Vietnam culture.

title: For the American Schindler, Writers and Artists First
description: Varian Fry was the American Schindler. He even had a list. He arrived in Vichy-controlled Marseille on Aug. 15, 1940, with $3,000 taped to his leg and a charge from the organization he worked for, the Emergency Rescue Committee, to help save some 200 endangered refugees, mainly artists, writers and intellectuals, from the Nazis. He expected to stay a month, but quickly realized that the job was much larger and more complicated than he or his sponsors had imagined. Those fleeing the Third Reich numbered in the thousands, and the French authorities were cooperating with the Germans by refusing to issue exit visas. Getting anyone out would require subterfuge and deceit, a willingness to take risks and break laws. Fry was up to the job. He stayed for 13 months, until he was thrown out of the country, and assisted approximately 2,000 people, among them an all-star lineup that included Hannah Arendt, Marc Chagall, Max Ernst, Andre Breton, Arthur Koestler, Alma Mahler Werfel and Max Ophuls. Along with a television film broadcast earlier this year, Sheila Isenberg's book ''A Hero of Our Own'' helps rescue Fry from obscurity. And with its stories of desperate exiles, menacing Nazis, forged documents and midnight escapes through the mountains, it reads at times like the script for some old Hollywood movie. Think Warner Brothers in the 1940's. Think ''Casablanca'' (even down to the transit visas for Portugal). All that's missing is Peter Lorre.

title: Funny, but That Voice Sounds So Familiar . . .
description: WHEN Charlie Pellett takes the subway from his home in Brooklyn Heights to his office at Bloomberg News in Midtown Manhattan, he regularly warns fellow passengers to stand clear of the closing doors. Since he's been in New York for about 20 years, Mr. Pellett, a radio anchor at Bloomberg, knows better than to scold other straphangers in person.

title: Travel Advisory; Water Buses Cruising In Fort Lauderdale
description: Visitors who want to beat the road traffic in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., can try new Water Buses. The first two of the new 42-foot, 70-passenger buses, the Clay Shaw and the B-Sea-T, began service this month. Six more will gradually join the fleet, replacing the 27-seat Water Taxis that cruise the inland waterways of Fort Lauderdale.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLL, SANFORD ''SANDY.''
description: SOLL-Sanford ''Sandy.'' On November 23, 2001. Loving husband to Lila; devoted father, father-inlaw and grandfather to Larry, Joy, Wyll and Cory. Services Sunday, Riverside Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, 12:45 PM.

title: A Shelter Plan Wins in Court, But Residents Aren't Swayed
description: Pigeons roost in rows along the yellow brick building at 89-111 Porter Avenue in eastern Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Sea gulls murmur. But this is a deceptive calm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABEL, BERNARD
description: ABEL-Bernard. On November 22, 2001. Beloved husband of Shirley. Loving father of Mark and Judy (Michael). Adoring grandfather of Joshua, Rebecca and Noah. Service Sunday, 9:15 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: The Smart Set Wastes Brainpower on Socializing
description: To the Editor:

title: Amy Bressler, Eric Shuffler
description: Amy Lauren Bressler and Eric Benjamin Shuffler were married yesterday evening by Rabbi Nechama D. Goldberg at Bridgewater's, a caterer in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELLER, SHIRLEY
description: SELLER-Shirley. On November 22, 2001. Beloved wife of Marvin. Devoted mother to Larry & Meri, grandmother to Hannah, Jacob, Sheryl and Stephanie. We will miss her sharp wit, generous spirit and unconditional love. Service Edwin L. Bennett, 824 Scarsdale Ave., Scarsdale, NY, November 25, 1:30 PM. Interment to follow at Mt. Eden Cemetery.

title: November 18-24; Begging Pardon
description: President Bush pardoned a turkey, dispatching it to a petting zoo. But over the last two months the president has quietly denied roughly 1,000 applications for pardons and commutations, clearing nearly a third of the backlog from the previous administration.

title: Pulitzer Pictures
description: They crawled through smoke to safety and a world of pain. The recovery of Shawn Simons and Alvaro Llanos, two Seton Hall University students badly burned in the Boland Hall dormitory fire that killed three and injured 58 on Jan. 19, 2000, was chronicled in a seven-part Newark-Star Ledger series, ''After the Fire.'' The pictures won Matt Rainey, left, a staff photographer, a Pulitzer Prize in 2001 for feature photography.

title: X, Y and Me
description: TREMOLO

title: Family Buries Boy, 5, Who Died in Shooting
description: A 5-year-old Bronx boy was buried yesterday, mourned by family, friends and strangers alike who paid tribute to a young life cut short by a stray bullet from a gun battle between two men on Monday evening.

title: Hurricanes Show Why They Are Ranked No. 1
description: Early this week, Ken Dorsey was thinking about last season, about how the Washington Huskies had hung the Miami Hurricanes with their only loss, which had kept his team out of the national championship game. Dorsey, normally mild-mannered, let loose with an emotional outburst at the memory.

title: Turner's Foundation to Spend Millions to Fight Bioterrorism
description: Ted Turner, who invented all-news television and is helping to subsidize the United Nations, has taken on a new challenge: reducing the threat of biological weapons.

title: New Battles in Old War Over Freedom of Speech
description: On campuses across the country, heightened tensions and sensitivities following the Sept. 11 attacks have unleashed an avalanche of clashes over free expression.

title: South Africa's AIDS Vortex Engulfs a Rural Community
description: The dusty road rolls past the builders hauling bricks from the Easi-Build Hardware store, past the women braiding hair at Ruby's Beauty Salon, past the butchers grinding beef at Isipho Supermarket, deep into the heart of rural South Africa.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KERNER, MARGARET (PEGGY) (NEE HANS)
description: KERNER-Margaret (Peggy) (nee Hans). Age 75, on November 23, 2001, lost a nine-year, valiant fight against breast cancer. Beloved wife of Lawrence A. Kerner, devoted mother of Ellen Girardi (Michael), Nancy Barton (Patrick) and Richard J. Kerner. Adored grandmtoher of Jessica and Nicole Girardi and Max, Jesse and Amy Barton. Daughter of the late Alma and Vincent Hans. Sister of Mary Lou Eber, Patricia Schreck, Vincent Hans Jr., Carol Sfarra and the late Dorothy Riedel and Eileen Cortes, nieces and nephews, grand-nieces, grand-nephews and countless dear friends. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to The Breast Cancer Research Foundation, 654 Madison Ave, Suite 1209, NY, NY 10021. Funeral services at Leo P. Gallagher Funeral Home, 2900 Summer St. Stamford, CT, 203327-1313, at 1 PM, on Monday, November 26, 2001.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VALLAS, GEORGE
description: VALLAS-George. On November 23, 2001. Passed at 62 years. Beloved husband of Monica. Cherished father of Elizabeth and Gregory Kreder and Nicholas Vallas. Survived by two grandchildren, Eric and Lauren. Devoted brother of Venus Dimou, Bess and John Papandon. Uncle and dear friend to many. Graduate of NYU School of Engineering with a Master's degree in Industrial Engineering. Founder and President of C.L. International. He built a successful consulting practice deliverying projects around the world. He was deeply loved and will be missed by family, friends and associates. Funeral Tuesday, 10:30 AM from the Litras Funeral Home (Arlington Chapels) 83-15 Parsons Blvd., Jamaica (at Grand Central Parkway). Funeral Liturgy 11:30 AM at St. Demetrios G.O. Church, 84-35 152 St., Jamaica. Interment Flushing Cemetery. Visiting hours Sunday and Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to the Salvation Army.

title: Personal Business; It's Not Grandma's Clearance Sale. It's Online and Worth Billions.
description: ''EVEN our mistakes are edible'' is the slogan at Johnny's Po Boys, a New Orleans sandwich shop. Other retailers make mistakes, too, and they hope to make them more palatable to consumers by using the Internet to unload their returned, refurbished, damaged or overstocked merchandise.

title: When More Was More
description: IN 1949 the architect Morris Lapidus was asked to design one of his outrageously modern hotels on Collins Avenue in Miami Beach.

title: Oxford Journal; A Bit of Peace for a Town Exposed
description: Ever since she joined the church in Ansonia that later merged with Immanuel Lutheran Church here 36 years ago, Ottilie Lundgren was someone who inspired the independent little community around her.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CITRIN, CEIL
description: CITRIN-Ceil. 90, on October 26, 2001, of Ft. Lauderdale, FL, formerly of NYC. Devoted wife of the late Max Citrin, adored mother of Beverly Sunshine, Stuart Citrin and Marlene Borey. Dear mother-inlaw of Dr. Ian Sunshine and George S. Borey, Esq. Loving grandmother of Toby (Ken Savell), Jonathan Sunshine and Douglas (Rachel) Sunshine. Adored great-grandmother of Morgan and Brooke Savell. Services were held in New York at Riverside Chapel, 76th St and Amsterdam Ave, NYC. Her brave spirit celebrated her joy and wonder of life around her and her deep love of family. We all rejoiced in her loving spirit and warm, radiant personality and shall cherish her life and memory forever.

title: United Nations
description: Andrew Sullivan's article rang true with me (The Way We Live Now, Nov. 4). I, too, am proud of my British heritage and, having married an American two weeks after Sept. 11, share his strong feelings of American patriotism. Hilary and I were wed at the Water's Edge Restaurant on the East River overlooking the changed Manhattan skyline. The presence of our friends and relatives at such a happy event contrasted with those who lost their friends and relatives in the tragedy and whom we remembered that day. The American and British flags fly proudly together outside our New York home.

title: Lou Reed, The Tell-Tale Rocker
description: IN 1845, four years before his death, Edgar Allan Poe first published ''The Imp of the Perverse,'' a short story about a murder. It identified a human compulsion toward transgression and self-destruction. ''The assurance of the wrong or error of any action is often the one unconquerable force which impels us, and alone impels us to its prosecution,'' Poe wrote. ''Nor will this overwhelming tendency to do wrong for the wrong's sake, admit of analysis, or resolution into ulterior elements. It is radical, a primitive impulse -- elementary.''

title: Are Ethics an Elective?
description: Most business schools offer ethics courses, but a survey suggests that many students who take them are not paying close attention.

title: How Much Of a Surge For Security Stocks?
description: AMERICANS spend a lot on protection. David Hale, chief economist at Zurich Financial Services, estimates public and private sector spending on security at $250 billion a year. That excludes the Pentagon.

title: When Repair Shrinks Closet Space
description: Q I live in a 40-year-old rent-stabilized building with 240 units. The closets in my apartment have accordion-type doors that reach from floor to ceiling and are nearly eight feet tall. Over the years, the doors and the mounting hardware have broken down and the doors are unrepairable. In other apartments, the owner has been replacing the original doors with louvered sliding doors that do not reach from floor to ceiling. (The top track is built down from the ceiling a foot or more, which results in the loss of important storage space in the closets.) I consider this unsatisfactory.

title: Students Learn the Art of Curating
description: VISITORS to the Rutgers-Camden Center for the Arts' new show, ''Shared Visions: Print Impressions,'' an exhibition of prints by artists ranging from Rembrandt to Andy Warhol, might not immediately realize what is so unusual about it: Its curators are eight students at the Creative Arts High School here, one of 18 high schools across the state that focus primarily on the arts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNGLIEB, LILY
description: YOUNGLIEB-Lily, 95. On November 22, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Herman. Loving mother of Judith Cohen. Devoted mother-inlaw of Norman D. Cohen. Treasured grandmother of Leslie Siben and David Schalit. Great grandmother of Odile Schalit and Michael Siben. You will be missed beyond words. Private service.

title: A Neighborhood Beacon Gets a Last-Minute Rescue
description: For the people of West Harlem, the Hamilton Grange Library, at 145th Street and Amsterdam Avenue is not just a place to borrow books.

title: Chronic Illness, Acute Need
description: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund helped pay the Peas' rent. Michael, 5, and Charlie, 8, have sickle cell anemia. Their parents, Yvonne Mercado-Pea, with Kyle, and Carlos Pea, struggle to make ends meet.

title: Big Issues, Petty Debate in Taiwan
description: By any conventional political yardstick, President Chen Shui-bian ought to be in deep trouble.

title: In the Region/Long Island; New Owner for Industrial Core of Ex-Grumman Site
description: IN October 2000, an F-14 Tomcat fighter jet came home to stay when it was donated by the Navy to the town of Riverhead and placed at the entrance of the former Grumman plant in Calverton, where it had been built more than 20 years ago.

title: Mattresses Move In Where Books Used to Be
description: The appearance of another national chain is no surprise to Mount Kisco shoppers, where independent businesses along South Moger Avenue abut the likes of the Gap, Banana Republic and Victoria's Secret. Now they have a new neighbor, Kleinsleep, the mattress and bed retailer with headquarters in Bethpage, Long Island, perhaps best remembered for its television slogan, ''Have more fun in bed.''

title: The World According To Powell
description: The night of Oct. 15 found Colin Powell inside the heavily fortified residence of the American ambassador in Islamabad, dining with his improbable new best friend, the president of Pakistan. Just a few months earlier, when the Bush administration was beginning to compose its tableau of friends and foes, a Powell deputy was sent to court India, a democracy and possible counterweight to China, as America's darling in South Asia. Pakistan was passed over as a terrorist-cradling rogue nation. But war changes everything, and Gen. Pervez Musharraf was now our partner against the terrorists in neighboring Afghanistan. This was Powell's first face-to-face meeting with the Pakistani strongman, and he was impressed with what he found. Like Powell himself, Musharraf was a pragmatic military man, brimming with self-assurance, equally at ease talking tactical soldiery or political strategy, a man given to thinking three or four steps ahead.

title: November 18-24; Raising a Happy, Healthy Clone
description: Cattle that were cloned from fetal calf cells can be perfectly normal and healthy by every medical and biochemical test, researchers report.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, IRVING
description: BERNSTEIN-Irving. Of Monroe Township, NJ and Delray Beach, FL formerly of Brooklyn and Long Island. Beloved husband of Evelyn (Pelner) devoted father of Stephen Bernstein and Renee Rosenzweig, dear brother of Jack Bernstein, Helen Bergson and Sylvia Krugman. Loving grandfather of Matthew Rosenzweig. Funeral services were held on Friday, November 23rd. For further information, call Menorah Chapels 908-964-1500.

title: Greener Golf Courses, Ecologically, That Is
description: IF you ask Ed Wachter, golf course superintendent at the Innsbrook Resort and Conference Center in Innsbrook, Mo., about his course, he will describe his carefully maintained playing areas. He will also tell you about his native prairie grasses and wildflowers. At times he sounds more like a home gardener than someone responsible for keeping 250 acres of golf courses in prime playing condition.

title: Music as News
description: To the Editor:

title: In Her Songs, She Puts Everything on the Line
description: SARAH DOUGHER is a 34-year-old musician in Portland, Ore., best known for her singing and organ playing in the dress-up punk trio Cadallaca. The group posed in an El Dorado for its first record; for its second the band appeared as two saloon floozies and a customer. ''Two Beers Later'' is as serious as they get.

title: The Jumpy Ones
description: FRIENDS call from out of town and say, ''So apart from that, how are you?'' I tell them that, generally speaking, there is no Apart From That. As on a recent Friday morning:

title: Credits
description: Slide 1

title: A Hometown Hero for Ridgewood
description: UNTIL recently, few in this town realized that Varian Fry, who helped save more than 2,000 artists, intellectuals and others from Hitler's concentration camps, grew up here. But now, as the United States again finds itself at war, people here are rediscovering Fry, who has been called the American Schindler.

title: The Long Drive Home
description: This Thanksgiving, my family and I were clear on two things: we wanted to be together and we didn't intend to fly. Not that it was a problem. What could be cozier than bundling into the car and heading home for the holidays? It's old-fashioned. It's safe.

title: Ideas & Trends; How To Put a Nation Back Together Again
description: THE assignment is Afghanistan. But even after a decade or more of rescuing imploded countries, the United Nations and its members have never faced anything like this. A quarter century of war and repression in the name of Islam has left Afghanistan less a country than a drought-stricken shambles of a battlefield with up to a fifth of its 27 million people huddled in refugee tents or makeshift hovels with scant food and no medicine. And, yet again, they are at the mercy of narrow-minded warlords.

title: Creative Outlet
description: IN the alternate reality of outlet malls, the usual meals are factory-bistro: the tabletops are bare, the brass is shiny, the reproduction antiques plentiful, the French fries previously frozen.

title: Meir in Milwaukee
description: To the Editor: I'm surprised that ''What's Doing in Milwaukee'' by Carolyn Kott Washburne (Sept. 30) did not mention the city's most famous daughter.

title: Smoke Out: A Lesson Before Lighting Up
description: ANTHONY COVINGTON looked appalled and emphatically shook his head when asked by a visitor whether he smoked cigarettes. Anthony, a fifth-grader at the Harry A. Conte West Hills Magnet School in New Haven, is one of thousands of students across the state who is learning what tobacco can do to the body through a program called Science, Tobacco and You.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REIT, SEYMOUR VICTORY
description: REIT-Seymour Victory. On November 21, 2001. Dearly beloved husband of Edmee (nee Busch), devoted brother to Phyllis and Irwin Nelson and Guy Busch, loving uncle to his many nieces, nephews and their children. Born on Armistice Day, 1918, he graduated from New York University and served with distinction as a Captain in the Army Air Corps in World War II. He began his career as a cartoonist and animator and created the character of Casper the Friendly Ghost. He was the author of many children's books and two works of nonfiction. Friends may pay respect at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave. at 81 St. on Monday, November 26, from 6 to 9 PM. A memorial service will be held there on Tuesday, November 27, at 11:30 AM, with interment to follow at Fairview Cemetery, Westfield, NJ. Contributions in his memory may be made to the School of American Ballet, 70 Lincoln Center Plaza, New York, NY 10023, or the organization of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARCH, HANS, M.D.
description: BARCH-Hans, M.D. Died on November 21, 2001. Survived by his sister Lisa, his son Greg, and his accomplishments.

title: The View From on High
description: A dozen photographs of skylines and landscapes taken by Robert Cameron from a helicopter are featured in ''Above New York,'' which opens Dec. 18 at the Urban Center of the Municipal Art Society (457 Madison Avenue). All photographs are available for purchase, with proceeds going to Sept. 11 relief efforts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTS, ELAINE (NEE FINK)
description: ROBERTS-Elaine (nee Fink). Wife of the late Irving, mother of John and Nora, grandmother of Catherine and Daniel Roberts, passed away on November 20th. We will always love you.

title: The Noise Barrier They Hate (and Love)
description: THREE commercial property owners who say they don't want their businesses hidden behind the noise barrier being built along a stretch of the Long Island Expressway have won a temporary injunction against its construction. The case could pose a challenge to every other noise-barrier project in the state.

title: Arthur Warren Scullin: A Schmoozer Extraordinaire
description: Arthur Warren Scullin schmoozed with everyone, even telemarketers. "He never hung up on them," said Mr. Scullin's widow, Cathy. "He'd ask them where they were calling from. He would ask them what the weather was like, what time it was."

title: IMMIGRANTS' LICENSES LIMITED
description: The Division of Motor Vehicles has stopped issuing licenses to immigrants whose visas expire in one year or less, and those whose visas are a year or longer will get licenses good only for the length of the visa rather than for four years. The purpose is to curb fraudulent use of licenses as proof of legal residence; 2 of the Sept. 11 hijackers used New Jersey licenses to rent cars and buy airline tickets. John Holl

title: Giving a Lift To Dancers Moving On After Dance
description: WE'RE dancers, we need to move,'' said Suzie Jary, the director of client services for Career Transition for Dancers. She was encouraging an intergenerational group of men and women to arrange themselves along an unusual chorus line. At one end stood those just starting to think about life after dance, at the other those who felt confident in new careers. She called this lineup a ''human spectrogram,'' one of many tools she uses to guide former, current and soon-to-be-ex dancers through the forward-and-back tango of moving on.

title: The Uncomfortable Question of Anti-Semitism
description: Rosen fails to discern between racists and those of us who just want to think critically about Middle Eastern politics, be free to discuss events in Israel and the Palestinian territories and perhaps propose changes that would be more just and compassionate for all involved without being unfairly judged anti-Semitic. My American Jewish friends whisper to me that even they cannot question Zionism to other Jews without being labeled anti-Semitic. Did the horrors of World War II take out our common sense, too?

title: Alexandra Wentworth, George Stephanopoulos
description: THREE months is hardly a long time -- perhaps enough for a chapter of a doctoral thesis or for a failed diet -- but it was long enough for George Stephanopoulos and Alexandra Wentworth to decide they had found their life partners.

title: Jason Sekzer: Campers, United
description: Jason Sekzer started going to Camp Sussex as a boy, one of hundreds of city children who grabbed the chance to spend part of each summer in the country in New Jersey.

title: For Tony Kushner, an Eerily Prescient Return
description: LONG before Kandahar and Jalalabad became household words, before CNN began familiarizing viewers with the hostilities between Pashtuns and Tajiks, before Al Jazeera was reporting nightly on military sorties over the Hindu Kush, the American playwright Tony Kushner had developed an obsession with Afghanistan. And it was a fascination that inspired what is likely to be his most talked-about play in a decade.

title: Sex, Even Love, Whatever It Takes to Connect
description: In ''Freak,'' his first one-man show on Broadway, the performer John Leguizamo seemed to channel multiple generations of his family, if not a whole city, as he described growing up Latino in New York. In his latest show, ''Sexaholix . . . a Love Story,'' opening next Sunday at the Royale Theater and directed by Peter Askin, the focus is also on development. Here, though, Mr. Leguizamo is exploring relationships between . . . but maybe it's better to let him tell it, with the help of his cynical twin, Doppelgnger Leguizamo, who interviews him in this article.

title: Learning To Take It Seriously
description: PASSIVE. He looked just too darn passive. Other times my son and I have flown together he was excited -- almost hyperactive. The engine noise at the start of the runway would get his own engines going. The first time he was on a plane with me Blake was about 3, and as we sped down the runway, he slapped my leg and said, in his Elmer Fudd voice, ''This is going to be fun!''

title: Environment at Risk
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Cry Over Failed Rice
description: IS THERE A NUTMEG

title: Personal Business; Digital Cameras Are No Longer Just for the Digerati
description: KIM LOWERY grew tired of taking snapshots that wound up more often stashed away in her desk than inside a photo album. Out of focus, overexposed or just plain wrong, the shots were doomed to stay forever in thick piles inside the film processing envelope.

title: E. H. Colbert, 96, Dies; Wrote Dinosaur Books
description: Dr. Edwin H. Colbert, an authority on paleontology who helped popularize the study of dinosaurs through his work as a curator at the American Museum of Natural History in New York and as a prolific writer of dinosaur books for a lay audience, died on Nov. 15 at his home in Flagstaff, Ariz. He was 96.

title: In Litchfield, Will Fridays Ever Be The Same?
description: TYPICALLY when a newspaper is sold, there is some initial commotion and concern among the staff about potential changes, but the public for the most part could not really care less.

title: A Parents' Party? Make a Wish
description: Thanksgiving has come and gone, but I'm still getting over Veterans Day. Two of the most stoic veterans I know, my parents, who have endured marriage despite the odds, got hitched on Nov. 11, 1951. For their 50th wedding anniversary, something elaborate was in order. But what? A surprise party at the Rainbow Room? Nope. We already did that for my mom's 70th birthday -- for 75 guests -- three years ago, when we felt flush with the economy.

title: Sands Point Center Introduces Deaf-Blind to a Wider World
description: MICHELLE SMITHDAS has been through hell.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMMONS, DR. SAMUEL IRA
description: SIMMONS-Dr. Samuel Ira. Beloved husband of Dorothy for 58 years; adored father and father-inlaw of Susan Simmons & Jeffrey Rubenstein, Laurie Simmons and Carroll Dunham, Bonnie Simmons & Bart Wenrich. Loving grandfather to Jenna Rubenstein, Jesse and Julie Ross, Grace and Lena Dunham. We mourn his passing. Funeral services will be held on Monday, at 11 AM, at RiversideNassau North Chapels, Great Neck, New York.

title: Thomas M. Brennan: Rock Tunes and Giggles
description: When Jennifer Brennan was pregnant with her first child, her husband, Thomas M. Brennan, would play Grateful Dead tapes loudly, hoping the music would reach the ears of his unborn daughter. When the baby kicked, as she invariably did, Mr. Brennan was delighted. She, too, he would say, was a fan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIGHT, CHRISTIAN F.
description: WIGHT-Christian F. Retired vice president of IFF Inc. in NYC, died October 18, 2001 at the age of 89. He is survived by his wife Suzi, two sons, David and William, his daughters Anne Minotti and Constance Harada, six grandchildren and three great-grandchildren.

title: Janice Ashley: A Renaissance Woman
description: Janice Ashley was a modern-day Renaissance woman: literary, artistic and skilled in finance, as comfortable on Rollerblades as ordering a meal in a fancy restaurant. She was also outspoken and bubbly, someone who kept her friends from elementary school but relished new experiences, like a trip to Turkey in August.

title: David Alger: Tales From a Lunch Table
description: For a generation of up- and-comers in the money world of Lower Manhattan, the scene was deeply familiar: David Alger's lunch table. Nothing fancy about it -- Mr. Alger seemed to thrive on cheeseburgers and apple pie, and any nondescript Wall Street coffee shop would do. His stories are what live on, and the lessons embedded within them about the stock market, and about life.

title: 'Update' Anchor: The Brains Behind Herself
description: UH-OH. In the NBC studio where ''Saturday Night Live'' is produced, a tour group was heading down a hallway straight toward Tina Fey. ''It's O.K.,'' she said tentatively as they approached. ''I don't have my glasses on. No one will recognize me.''

title: Behind Every First Lady . . .
description: MRS. KENNEDY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RANDALL, DAVID
description: RANDALL-David. The Board of Governors and Members of Hampshire Country Club are deeply saddened by the passing of our esteemed member David Randall. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to his dear wife Ada, and to all of his family. Hampshire Country Club Board of Governors Paul Seidenberg President

title: The Grand Prize: A Chance to Laugh
description: Laughter, it is often said, is the best medicine, and never more so than in dark days. So this may be a good time to celebrate the imp of mischief who ladles out practical jokes as an antidote to stress.

title: A Week Of Thanks
description: EVENING HOURS Correction: December 2, 2001, Sunday A picture caption in the Evening Hours column last Sunday about the New York City Ballet's opening night gala on Nov. 20 misidentified the woman shown with Darci Kistler. She was Candace K. Beinecke, not Angela Ismailos.

title: The Enemy of My Enemy
description: IN THE NAME OF IDENTITY

title: Abandoned Houses Are Reborn in Style
description: SHORTLY after Sebastian Russell and Joseph Kuharic moved into their new home in Harlem, they invited the Rev. John Luce, a priest from the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, to bless their house.

title: Live From Dystopia
description: FUTURELAND

title: Shrouded in Contradiction
description: I grew up wearing the miniskirt to school, the veil to the mosque. In the Tehran of my childhood, women in bright sundresses shared the sidewalk with women swathed in black. The tension between the two ways of life was palpable. As a schoolgirl, I often cringed when my bare legs got leering or contemptuous glances. Yet, at times, I long for the days when I could walk the streets of my country with the wind in my hair. When clothes were clothes. In today's Iran, whatever I wear sends a message. If it's a chador, it embarrasses my Westernized relatives. If it's a skimpy scarf, I risk being accused of stepping on the blood of the martyrs who died in the war with Iraq. Each time I return to Tehran, I wait until the last possible moment, when my plane lands on the tarmac, to don the scarf and long jacket that many Iranian women wear in lieu of a veil. To wear hijab -- Islamic covering -- is to invite contradiction. Sometimes I hate it. Sometimes I value it.

title: 'The Swimmer' Revisited: A Fashion Portfolio
Paid Notice: Deaths  D'ANGELO, RITA Y., PH.D.
description: D'ANGELO-Rita Y., Ph.D. Professor Emerita CUNY. Dear sister of Alice DeSantis. Beloved aunt of Darlene, Anthony and Thomas DeSantis. Visiting November 26, 24 and 7-9 PM, at Waterbury & Kelly Funeral Home, 1300 Pleasantville Road, Briarcliff Manor. Funeral mass November 27, 10 AM, at St. Theresa Church, Briarcliff Manor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, JAMES O.
description: ROSS-James O. On November 24, 2001, of Thornton, PA, formerly of North Bergen, NJ. Beloved husband of Cindy. Devoted father of Dana and Meredith. Son of Agnes and the late Honorable Wilbur L. Ross, and brother of Karen Ross Tanzola, and of Wilbur L. Ross Jr. After graduating from Phillips Academy, Andover, MA, and receiving both AB and MBA degrees from the University of Rochester, he had a wonderful career in investments, and served as an Elder of his church.
