His funeral service will take place at Concord Liberty Presbyterian Church, 256 Bethel Rd, Concordville, PA, on Wednesday, November 28, at 10 AM.

title: The Wrong Time to Fight Iraq
description: The surprisingly swift successes of the American military campaign in Afghanistan have spurred talk about military action to oust Saddam Hussein from power in Iraq. The world would be a safer place with Mr. Hussein's cruel dictatorship removed. At this point, however, there are no good short-term options for getting rid of him. The Bush administration would make a serious mistake by moving to wage war in Iraq.

title: Intel Says Design Innovations Will Aid Chip Performance
description: Intel plans to announce semiconductor design innovations today that it expects will help it continue doubling the performance of microchips every 18 to 24 months through the end of the decade.

title: Print the Articles
description: Mignonette

title: A Hunger Emergency in New York
description: One of the first big challenges the Bloomberg administration will face is dealing with the crowds of people who are surging into food pantries and soup kitchens. The lines of hungry New Yorkers were already growing noticeably longer before Sept. 11, when terrorist attacks combined with the already faltering economy, costing the city nearly 80,000 mainly low-income jobs in the month of October alone.

title: TALIBAN FOES SAY KUNDUZ IS THEIRS
description: Northern Alliance commanders said Sunday night that their troops had captured the city of Kunduz in the dark, overrunning the last Taliban stronghold in northern Afghanistan.

title: Where Thousands Of Drought Refugees Wait for Food or Death
description: On the rocky, rutted road that runs from the border with Iran toward the Afghan city of Herat, traditional villages rise from the desert as if they are part of it, their rounded earthen roofs swelling smoothly out of the square walls.

title: Raiders Set to Play Well Into Next Year
description: The Raiders had not played the Giants in three years, but that did not prevent them from duplicating a formula that they absolutely love when they see Giants' blue and white: hit 'em hard and hit 'em quick.

title: Shift in Pain, as Growing Up Hits Home
description: The perspective shift that comes with growing up hit Ben Folds abruptly. Until recently he was writing about finding himself, breaking up or getting even with bullies and ex-girlfriends.

title: In America; Justice, 200 Years Later
description: Perseverance. Fortitude.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TREUHAFT, ROBERT E.
description: TREUHAFT-Robert E. Died at his daughter's house in New York on November 11, 2001, after a brief illness. Bob lived in the Bay Area, California, since he married the late Jessica Mitford in 1943. He formed several radical law firms in San Francisco and Oakland, representing labor unions, victims of police brutality, the Free Speech Movement, and working people seeking workers' compensation. During the McCarthy period, Bob was named ''one of the 10 most dangerous Communist lawyers in Northern California.'' Bob assisted his wife in the research and writing of ''The American Way of Death,'' in 1963, and finished ''The American Way of Death Revisited'' after Jessica Mitford's death in 1996. He is survived by his son Benjamin, daughter Constancia Romilly and son-in-law Terry Weber of Manhattan, sister Edith Lourie McKelvey of Los Angeles, grandsons James Lumumba Forman of Washington, DC, Chaka Esmond Forman of Hollywood, CA, and Ben Weber of Hanoi, Vietnam, as well as numerous friends on both coasts and abroad. Neighbors on Regent Street in Oakland have been leaving flowers on the porch. A memorial service is planned for February 23, 2002, in the Bay Area. Contributions (taxdeductible) may be made to Send a Piana to Havana, 39 E. 7th Street, New York, NY 10003.

title: The World's Oppressors
description: To the Editor:

title: Brother of a Champion Shows His Talent, Too
description: After Ivica Kostelic had glided gracefully over the ruts of a deteriorating slalom course as if clouds were beneath his skis, after his first slalom run from the 64th starting spot of the World Cup had put him in seventh position, he was handed a cellphone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINBERG, IRWIN L.
description: FEINBERG-Irwin L. Died Sunday, November 25, 2001. Beloved husband of Helen. Cherished father of Phyllis Feinberg and Marjorie Feinberg Clark and father-in-law of the late Fred Clark. Adored grandfather of Everitt and Emily Clark. Dear brother of Joyce Zankel. Private graveside service Tuesday.

title: Penalty-Prone Rangers Drop Second in a Row
description: Yesterday was Kids Day at Madison Square Garden. The way the Rangers played, it should have been Turn Back the Clock Day.

title: Communist Effort to Prosecute Czech Priest Raises Ghosts of Past
description: When Senate elections rolled around last fall in the small southern Czech village of Rakvice, the 32-year old parish priest, the Rev. Vojtech Vlastimil Protivinsky, warned his parishioners against voting for the local Communist Party candidates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AGHASSI, MORRIS
description: AGHASSI-Morris. On November 24, 2001. Beloved husband, brother and uncle. Services Tuesday, 11:30 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Game Systems Ready for Battle
description: With the release of Microsoft's Xbox video game console on Nov. 15 and Nintendo's GameCube three days later, the market for video game consoles is poised for a shift, but it may not be much of one.

title: On Television; Competitive Twists and Turns In Hardly an Ordinary Season
description: Had the terrorists not struck, had war not broken out, you would probably be hearing all sorts of interesting tidbits about the annual television ratings contest. But they did, and it has, so you are probably not hearing much at all.

title: A War Game (Sort of), but You Can't Control the Action
description: As a teenager John Klima spent his allowance at the video arcade, plunking quarters into Donkey Kong in a relentless quest to defeat the evil ape. Now Mr. Klima, a New York artist, is playing a different sort of game, using the visual language of computer amusements to depict the not at all amusing war in Afghanistan.

title: This Week
description: The Cabaret Act That Stole Christmas

title: Miami Leaves Questions To Others
description: Two weeks ago, after Miami barely beat Boston College, doubts surrounded the undefeated Hurricanes. Were they good enough to be first in all the polls and computer rankings? After some inconsistency against lesser opposition, did they deserve to appear in the national championship game at the Rose Bowl?

title: Moving Bioterrorism From the Back Burner Singed U.S. Disease Centers
description: When a letter containing anthrax was mailed to a Senate office last month, the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said antibiotics were not necessary for postal workers in the nation's capital, and two of the workers died. But when a 94-year-old woman in Connecticut contracted a lethal case of anthrax last week, the disease control agency quickly recommended treatment for postal workers, even though there is no evidence as yet that a contaminated letter was the source of her infection.

title: Parking Garages Suffering From Manhattan's Single-Driver Restrictions
description: Although it is unlikely there is a celebrity telethon in the works to support them, parking garage operators in Manhattan say that in the aftermath of the World Trade Center attack they, too, are suffering.

title: Democrats Say Pataki Hurt Efforts to Secure Disaster Aid
description: The two Democrats seeking to challenge Gov. George E. Pataki next year -- H. Carl McCall and Andrew M. Cuomo -- are accusing him of hurting New York's effort to secure billions of dollars in federal aid to help the state recover from the terrorist attack.

title: Patents; Using a seaweed to counteract a fungus that can harm cattle but is needed to help the grass grow.
description: VIVIEN GORE ALLEN and her colleague Korinn E. Saker have come up with a novel way to keep cattle healthy: just sprinkle a pasture with seaweed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUER, JULIUS NORMAN (JO, JO)
description: BAUER-Julius Norman (Jo-Jo) of Carle Place on November 22, 2001. Beloved husband of Hildreth (Hilly). Devoted father of Joan Zuckerman (Jay), Amy Brinkworth, Lynn DiPierro (Tom), and Scott (Margaret). Cherished grandfather of Maxim, Anya, Jared, Maureen and David. Dear brother of Albert, brother-in-law of Bea, Ruth and Norma (Rosen). Partner and Vice-President of Operations of Jarchem Industries, Newark, NJ. Interment at Beth Moses Cemetery, Farmingdale, New York. Contributions may be sent to Congregation Ahavas Israel, Hebrew Educational Alliance of Greenpoint, 108 Noble Street, P.O. Box 32, Brooklyn, New York 11222-0032.

title: Line Plays Part in Loss
description: Giants quarterback Kerry Collins had another uneven day in the 28-10 loss to the Oakland Raiders today, but he was pressured on nearly every pass he attempted. Left tackle Lomas Brown said it was time the offensive line took some of the blame for Collins's woes and the offense's inconsistency.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINTROB, HARRY
description: WEINTROB-Harry. 89, of Brooklyn and Belle Harbor, NY, on November 24, 2001 (9 Kislev, 5762). He is survived by his children Barry Weintrob, Erma Bressler and Edward Weintrob; grandchildren Gary, Lori, Karen, Cindy, Suzanne, Paul Samson, Rachel Leah and Sara Rivka; great-grandchildren Elizabeth, Joshua and Joelle Rebecca; son-in-law Robert Bressler, and daughters-in-law Sheila and Celia Weintrob, as well as nephews and nieces. He was the devoted husband to the late Roslyn Weintrob. Born in Wolochisk, Ukraine, Harry with his mother and sister emigrated to the US at age 8 to rejoin his father; he grew up in Brooklyn, attending Thomas Jefferson HS and Pace Institute, and in retirement earned a BA degree from Touro College. He was a garment manufacturer and real estate broker, Master of Composite Lodge No. 819 F&AM, active in civic causes and in later years as Chairman of Interagency Council CD15 and at the Kings Bay Senior Center. Always, he was devoted to his family, and generous with his time and wisdom. Services were held Sunday, November 25.

title: Sports of The Times; Guaranteed: No Playoffs for the Giants This Season
description: JIM FASSEL could issue another guarantee this season with five games remaining -- a guarantee that the Giants will not make the playoffs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRENNER, RICHARD
description: BRENNER-Richard. On November 24. Devoted husband of the late Mary. Beloved father of Chris and Sara. Loving son of Sidney and Thelma. Dear brother of Ann Silverman. He will be missed by all who knew him. Services Tuesday, 10 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 21 West Broad St., Mt. Vernon, NY.

title: All-Terrain Zealotry
description: Dismayed by its status as the Taliban's favorite automaker, Toyota today rolled out a new line of S.U.V.'s and pickup trucks for 2002. Named ''Northern Alliance'' after the Afghan rebels, the new vehicles are specifically designed, according to a Toyota spokesman, ''for today's all-terrain freedom fighter.''

title: Editors' Note; A Nation Challenged
description: News of the terrorist attacks and their aftermath appears today in Section B; index, Page B2.

title: Essay; Kangaroo Courts
description: As soon as German U-boats put eight saboteurs on U.S. shores during World War II, one of the eight called the F.B.I. to betray the mission but was brushed off as a crackpot. Days later, he called again and managed to persuade the F.B.I. he was an authentic saboteur. Partly to keep this embarrassment of bungled enforcement from becoming known, the eight were secretly tried by a military court inside the F.B.I. headquarters.

title: Barnes & Noble Will Try to Squeeze Better Deals From Publishers
description: Leonard Riggio, chairman of Barnes & Noble, is sometimes described as the most powerful figure in the book business. But that is not how he sees it.

title: Power Meets Modern Art in Los Angeles
description: Thirty years ago Eli Broad, a multimillionaire, purchased his first important artwork, a van Gogh drawing, for $95,000. Soon Mr. Broad and his wife, Edythe, began slowly buying art: a Matisse drawing, a work by Modigliani, a Henry Moore bronze.

title: Agfa-Gevaert Moves Ahead On Mitra Deal
description: Agfa-Gevaert, a Belgian company that is Europe's biggest manufacturer of X-ray products and film, said today that it had signed a definitive agreement to buy Mitra, a Canadian provider of imaging and information-management systems for the health care industry.

title: The Giants Continue Their Downward Slide
description: The 2001 season marches on and the Giants await a defining moment, the victory that sustains dimming playoff hopes or the show of resolve that revives a collective loss of confidence. After stumbling through most of the last two months, today's crossroads game at Giants Stadium with Oakland was the best chance yet at redemption for the downtrodden Giants, who surely had more to gain than the ascendant Raiders.

title: TRANSACTIONS

description: * Teach for America, New York, to McCarthy Mambro Bertino, Boston, to handle a national brand campaign for the organization, which enables recent college graduates to teach in low-income public schools.

title: Nature Made The Perfect Hiding Place
description: If Osama bin Laden is hiding in a cave in Afghanistan, as American officials suspect, he has plenty to choose from. The country's varied landscape and geology make it ideal for caves.

description: What did you think of the movie? Was it faithful to J.K. Rowling's book? Do you agree with the opinions in the Times review ?

title: Clams Casino
description: Another much-maligned classic, clams casino has seen its stock fall since its heyday in the 50's. Our version retains the natural moisture of the clams with a layer of prosciutto (instead of chopped bacon), which shields the clams from the heat.

title: On Campuses, Seeing the Military With New Eyes; After Sept. 11 Attack, Students Reconsider Old Perceptions
description: At Seton Hall University, some students who previously ignored the R.O.T.C. cadets roaming around campus now regard their uniformed classmates as -- of all things -- cool. Some have been so inspired that they say they may join the military, too.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JONES, MARY MYERS
description: JONES-Mary Myers,l71. Of Albany, NY, November 19 after a courageous battle with cancer. A longtime resident of Woodstock, NY, she was the daughter of the late Howard Myers, publisher of the Architectural Forum, and Louise W. Myers. She attended the Brearley School and Bard College. She is survived by her husband of 48 years, Roger Jones, 4 children; Barbara LaPointe, Sara Jones, Michael Jones, and Nicholas Jones; eight grandchildren; and her sister Barbara Greenwood. Donations in her memory may be made to: The Community Hospice, ''Mary M. Jones Educational Fund'', 295 Valley View Boulevard, Rensselaer, New York 12144.

title: As Attacks' Impact Recedes, A Return to Religion as Usual
description: On the first Sunday after the terrorist attacks, people filled the pews at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Louisville, Ky., seeking solace in a sermon about grief and joining together to sing ''America the Beautiful.'' That day, the church drew 200 people, significantly more than the average Sunday attendance of 150, and for the next two Sundays the crowds kept coming.

title: Company Assesses Impact Of Book Award on Sales
description: As the host of the annual National Book Awards ceremony this month, the author and comedian Steve Martin called the prizes ''the most prestigious acknowledgment a book can receive and still remain unknown.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Dies In Car Crash
description: A Bronx man was killed when the car he was driving jumped the center divider along the Henry Hudson Parkway, flipped in the air and landed on its roof, the police said yesterday. The car then slid into an oncoming vehicle, the police said, slightly injuring two people. The man who died, identified as Imre Borsos, 44, had been speeding south in a 1999 Cadillac shortly after 9 p.m. on Saturday when he lost control of the car, the police said. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REIT, SEYMOUR VICTORY
description: REIT-Seymour Victory. On November 21, 2001. Dearly beloved husband of Edmee (nee Busch), devoted brother to Phyllis and Irwin Nelson and Guy Busch, loving uncle to his many nieces, nephews and their children. Born on Armistice Day, 1918, he graduated from New York University and served with distinction as a Captain in the Army Air Corps in World War II. He began his career as a cartoonist and animator and created the character of Casper the Friendly Ghost. He was the author of many children's books and two works of nonfiction. Friends may pay respect at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave. at 81 St. on Monday, November 26, from 6 to 9 PM. A memorial service will be held there on Tuesday, November 27, at 11:30 AM, with interment to follow at Fairview Cemetery, Westfield, NJ. Contributions in his memory may be made to the School of American Ballet, 70 Lincoln Center Plaza, New York, NY 10023, or the organization of your choice.

description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Shooting Victim Was a Bystander
description: A29-year-old Brooklyn man who was fatally shot Saturday night outside the Hammerstein Ballroom in Midtown was a bystander to a dispute that resulted in gunfire, the police said yesterday.

title: Film Critics With a Keen Eye for Violence
description: The usher carried a rubber whip and the policeman on duty toted a submachine gun. Patrons had to check their knives, brass knuckles and other weapons at the door. And audience members had enough combat experience to criticize the film's climactic shootout scene as unrealistic.

title: Smaller Spotlight for a Big-Time Correspondent
description: This is how Peter Arnett assesses his reputation right now: ''Damaged goods.''

Loving greataunt of Kathleen and Sean Donovan, William and Nancy Bresnan III, Vanessa Bresnan, Jennifer Bresnan, Seanie Donovan and Kaela Bresnan. Family will receive friends at Wiliams Funeral Home, 5628 Broadway at 232nd Street, Bronx, NY, on Monday evening, 7-9 PM. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery, Tuesday, November 27, at 10 AM.

title: Compressed Data; Professors Study Method for Doing Well on EBay
description: Trying to put markets for everything under the sun -- think groceries and pet food -- on the Internet was a demonstrably bad idea. But clearly, there are some markets made for the online medium, like the virtual auctions managed by eBay. Price discovery, in economic terms, is easy and open, a wealth of data can be presented, and transaction costs are low.

title: Editors' Note; Potter Pursues Titanic
description: It had the biggest Wednesday-to-Sunday Thanksgiving weekend in movie history. The biggest three-day, Friday-to-Sunday Thanksgiving grosses. The most lucrative week in movie history. And it took in $150 million at the box office faster than any other movie. ''Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone'' continued to topple records over the weekend, accumulating an estimated $188 million in 10 days in North American theaters. Still elusive, though, and likely beyond its reach, is the biggest record of them all, more than $600 million earned at the North American box office by ''Titanic,'' the most successful theatrical run in movie history. E1

title: Grisly Uprising, Famed Hide-Outs and Altered American Attitudes
description: Of late, the war in Afghanistan has been a split-screen affair, focused on Kunduz in the north and Kandahar in the south. Half of the screen may now be fading to black. Northern Alliance commanders say they have finally taken encircled Kunduz, leaving Kandahar as the Taliban's last redoubt. It was a gruesome day, with many Taliban prisoners killed when they tried to revolt. And the fighting took a profound new turn as the United States committed itself more than ever to a land war. It sent in marines, by the hundreds.

title: Beijing Journal; Mao's Buried Past: A Strange, Subterranean City
description: Twenty-five feet below the streets of Beijing, Feng Guangbin rattled off the remarkable attributes of the maze of vaulted tunnels that stretched out in four directions from the dim intersection at which he stood.

description: LEIGHTON-Miriam, nee Kaback. Of West Palm Beach, FL, formerly of Ft. Lee, NJ. Devoted mother of Elayne Rosen, Jo-Ann Sorrentino. title: Oysters Rockefeller
description: The dish known as Oysters Rockefeller was born not in the kitchen of that famous family, but at a turn-of-the-century New Orleans restaurant, where the chef combined oysters on the half-shell with butter, spinach and absinthe (a now-illegal liqueur that has since been replaced in most versions by Pernod or anisette). The chef presumably added the "Rockefeller" moniker for a touch of class. There are numerous versions of the dish, but all include the basics: oysters, spinach and breadcrumbs. In our recipe, we've included mayonnaise for additional moisture, and a chiffonade of lettuce and diced peppers for texture.

Their arrival began what Pentagon officials said would be a period of sustained assaults against Taliban and Al Qaeda forces.

title: Nets Beginning to See What Oakland Knew
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 25  On the last day of the Nets' five-game trip  after he sank 3-pointers to send two games into overtime, after he drained six game-clinching free throws in 27 seconds, after he hit a 3-pointer to give his team a chance to win in the final seconds, after he notched his first back-to-back triple-doubles of the season  Jason Kidd returned home.

title: Europe Plans a Constellation of Satellites
description: Around the world, countries are mobilizing to build independent satellite navigation networks, troubled that the Global Positioning System, the only functioning worldwide network, is run by the United States military and controlled by the government.

title: Nassau Faces Tax Increase Of Up to 15%
description: Trying to avert a state financial takeover of Nassau County's government, Democratic leaders in the County Legislature are considering a package of budget cuts and an increase in property taxes of 9.5 to 15 percent.

title: Belgium Says Swissair Suits Seek Almost $1.75 Billion
description: The Belgian government said on Friday that public and private lawsuits against the Swissair Group demand almost two billion euros ($1.75 billion) as compensation for what it said was the airline's failure to provide money to help the Belgian carrier Sabena before its collapse.

title: Barber Can Run, And Hit
description: It was a simple play called 34 Bob, and as he often does, Tiki Barber turned a basic running play into something spectacular, while trying single-handedly to save the Giants' season against the Oakland Raiders.

title: U.S. Bomb Hurts G.I.'s in Fight at Fort
description: QALA JANGI, Afghanistan, Nov. 26 -- A battle raged here today between Taliban prisoners and the American-backed troops of the Northern Alliance, and the Bush administration revealed that five Americans had been wounded.

title: Rebuilding a Ravaged Land
description: Afghanistan has great potential for economic development. For decades investment, principally foreign but also domestic, has gone into either the opium business or politics -- that is, into guns. The amounts have been large; the return has been mainly devastation. But Afghanistan can be rebuilt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINTRAUB, BRONKA
description: WEINTRAUB-Bronka. Widow of Jacob Weintraub, Harry Rabin and Abraham Stawski, passed away on November 23, 2001, and brought to her eternal rest on Sunday, November 25, 2001. A vivacious and dedicated leader in philanthropy and the very noblest of causes on behalf of Israel, the Jewish people and Jewish education. She will be sorely by all who knew her, admired her and loved her. May her memory be a blessing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAGGIO, GERTRUDE E.
description: MAGGIO-Gertrude E. On November 25, 2001, of Hampton Bays, L.I. Beloved wife of the late John S. Loving mother of Joseph, John and Barbara Mulkern. Devoted sister of Emma Thornhill. Cherished grandmother of nine and great-grandmother of six. For information, contact R.J. O'Shea Funeral Home, 94 East Montauk Highway, Hampton Bays, L.I. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday at 9:45 AM at St. Rosalie's Catholic Church. Interment Sacred Hearts Cemetery, Southampton, L.I. Family will receive friends Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations to the American Heart Association would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMON, FLORENCE
description: KRAMON-Florence. NCJW, New York Section, is saddened by the passing of our former vice president and Board member. Sincerist condolences to her family. Rita Fishman, President Judith Golub, Exec. Dir.

title: Half Brother's Death Is Inspiration for Thomas
description: On Friday, after the Oakland Raiders boarded their charter to fly here for today's game against the Giants, there was an urgent message for William Thomas, their outstanding outside linebacker. When Thomas hurried off the plane, his teammates were baffled.

title: Accounts
description: * Allied Domecq, London, expanded its relationship with Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos by naming the Hill, Holliday San Francisco office to handle its Togo's restaurant chain, part of the Allied Domecq Quick Service Restaurants unit. The account, with spending estimated at $10 million, had been at VitroRobertson, San Diego. The Hill, Holliday Boston office handles the Dunkin' Donuts chain owned by Allied Domecq. Hill, Holliday is part of the McCann-Erickson World Group division of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TIETSORT, JOHN R.F.
description: TIETSORT-John R.F. There will be a memorial service in honor of John R.F. Tietsort at 12:30 P.M. on Thursday, November 29, 2001, at Baruch College, where he taught for many years. The service takes place in the Oak Room, 137 E. 22nd St. Donations to the John R.F. Tietsort Memorial Fund, which provides tutoring to Baruch students for whom English is not a native language, may be sent C/O The Baruch College Fund, 1 Bernard Baruch Way, Box D901, New York, New York 10010.

title: Readers Comment on 'Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone'
description: What did you think of the movie? Was it faithful to J.K. Rowling's book? Do you agree with the opinions in the Times review ?

title: Camby Returns Tonight To Height-Starved Knicks
description: Marcus Camby was one of the last players on the floor after the Knicks' light workout today at Purchase College, working with the assistant coach Tom Thibodeau on a spin move in the post. He repeated the move over and over, sweat dripping off him as he twirled to his left and right. While few of the shots actually made their way into the basket, Camby landed each time without a wince, a good enough test to allow him to declare himself ready to play.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINER, IRWIN
description: WEINER-Irwin. Died on November 24, 2001, after a long illness. Beloved husband of Suzanne Weiner. Devoted father of Ellen Scappatura, Mark Weiner, Kim Perrault, Jeff Weiner, and Justine De Nunzio. Cherished grandfather and Poppy to Melissa and Joey Scappatura, Samantha and Marc Anthony Weiner, Brianna and Mathew Weiner, and Alexa De Nunzio. President and founder of Irwin Weiner Sports Enterprises. President and founder of Dr. I Fund Foundation. Trustee New York Medical College. Board Member of the Rachmiel Levine Diabetes Foundation, The Maurice Stokes Foundation, The Lautenberg Center at Hebrew University, Hospital for Joint Disease Orthopedic Institute. Former Chairman Westchester Holocaust Commission. Recipient of the Terrance Cardinal Cooke Medal, The Torch of Learning Award from American Friends of Hebrew University, Westchester County Humanitarian Award. Donations in lieu of flowers in memory of Irwin Weiner Scholarship Fund, New York Medical College, Valhalla, NY 10595. Service will be held on Tuesday, November 27, at 12 noon, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York 10552, 914-664-6800.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Murder Conviction
description: A Brooklyn woman has been found guilty of the 1999 murder of her half-brother's fiance, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. The woman, Nicki Havner, 27, was convicted of first-degree murder last week in the death of Tracie Harrison. Ms. Havner, who faces life in prison without the possibility of parole, is to be sentenced on Jan. 3.

title: Flag to Carry Sentiments From Ground Zero to Afghanistan
description: No one is exactly sure how the flag started, or who wrote what first.

title: Time Out of Joint in a Ruined Land
description: The story of Afghanistan is like Job's, except God has not yet appeared in the whirlwind to explain the suffering and set things right. This is a land where war has put time out of joint, where people live in ruins resembling archaeological sites, using the tools of centuries gone by. The tools  hand-hewn wooden furrows plowing the earth, hand-shaped clay ovens baking bread  create the beautiful necessities that make life bearable.

title: Heavily Fortified 'Ant Farms' Deter bin Laden's Pursuers
description: The Qaeda military base called Zhawar Kili Al-Badr also has a nickname: Wolf's Hole.

title: Turning Brazilian Migrant Workers Into Japanese
description: HAMAMATSU, Japan  Joining a flood of Brazilians lured here a decade ago to fill vacancies on Japan's assembly lines, Benedito Vilela Garcia came planning to make some quick yen then to go back home, hoping to open a pharmacy in his native ranching country.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Rochelle Park: 50 Hurt In Collapse
description: A plywood and plexiglass dance floor set on top of a motel swimming pool collapsed early yesterday, injuring more than 50 partygoers who plunged into the water, the police said. The most serious injuries were concussions and deep cuts that were not life threatening, officials said. The incident occurred about 2:15 a.m. at the Ramada Inn. Several hundred people may have been on the dance floor, the police said. No arrests have been made, and the incident is still under investigation. Officials for Metro Lounge, the party's organizer, did not immediately return phone calls seeking comment. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE MONTMOLLIN, LAURENT GUILLAUME
description: de MONTMOLLIN-Laurent Guillaume. Beloved brother of Edmee de M. Firth, step-brother of Robin McKinney Martin, cherished uncle of Marie-Louise and John Slocum and Olivia Beckwith-Smith. Son of the late Marielle McKinney and Henry de Montmollin. Age 52. Died unexpectedly of a heart attack at his home in Tampa, FL, on November 17. Funeral service and burial on December 10, at Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Middleburg, VA.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Four longtime agency executives have opened Bochanis Rogan Zoom, a marketing services agency with offices in Baton Rouge, La., and Westport, Conn. The agency opens with billings estimated at $2.5 million from clients like Fresh Express, Pennzoil-Quaker State and the Snapple Beverage Group. The principals of Bochanis Rogan Zoom, with the titles of partners, are Jordan Bochanis and Lee Rogan, formerly partners at B. Little & Company, along with David Worrell and Kendyl Worrell, the former principals at Zoom Design.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JADEK, PHILIP
description: JADEK-Philip. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun mourns the passing of its esteemed member, the beloved husband of its devoted member, Julia Jadek, and extends heartfelt sympathy to the entire bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Rabbi Joshua Lookstein Chaim Edelstein

title: Canada's Global City (Not Toronto)
description: Call it the un-Toronto.

title: Clam and Oyster Chowder  la Frdric
description: Acolorful, Asian-tinged variation on Manhattan clam chowder, this creation by our chef features a host of interesting ingredients: the apples lend their tartness, the lime adds acidity, the bok choy and veggie mixture provides added texture, and the coconut milk echoes the dairy component normally found in New England chowder. This soup is a good one to try if you have a hard time finding fresh shellfish, since it uses the canned varieties and bottled clam juice (of course, fresh may be used as well).

title: Can Democracy Stifle the Rage?
description: To the Editor:

title: Company Says It Produced Embryo Clones
description: A small, privately financed biotechnology company said yesterday that it had created the first human embryos ever produced by cloning. But the embryos died before they had even eight cells, and most died long before that. Cloning experts outside the company said the experiment was a failure.

title: This Week's Economic Events
description: MONDAY

title: Panel Says U.S. Economy Entered Recession in March
description: The American economy entered a recession in March, snapping the longest period of uninterrupted economic growth in the nation's history, a panel of noted economists for the National Bureau of Economic Research said today.

title: Compressed Data; Mass Voicemailing Seeks Volunteers to Leave Jobs
description: Last week thousands of staff members of Cap Gemini Ernst & Young, one of Europe's largest computer services firms, received a rather unusual voicemail message from a top executive, inviting them to quit, take early retirement or a leave of absence by the end of the year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBERMAN, NETTIE
description: LIEBERMAN-Nettie. A retired New York City school teacher, died suddenly at her home on November 23. She was predeceased by her husband, David, and son, Daniel. She will be missed by her many relatives and friends.

title: Treasury Chief Sees an Economic Brightening
description: Faced with the likelihood that the United States is about to be declared officially in a recession, Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill said today that the economy was ''poised for recovery'' and that the outlook for Wall Street remained bright.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATTHEWS, WILLIAM T.
description: MATTHEWS-William T. Age 92, on November 23, 2001. Loving husband of Helen (nee Thompson). Dear father of the late William P. and Margaret T. Matthews. Loving grandfather of William T. II, Charles P. and Colleen Matthews. Also survived by a daughter-inlaw, Eva, and nieces and nephews. Reposing at Austin F. Knowles, Inc., Funeral Home, 128 Main St., Port Washington, NY. Visiting hours Monday, 2-4 PM only. Mass Tuesday, 9:30 AM, St. Peter of Alcantara, Port Washington. Interment Green-Wood Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY.

title: Jean-Louis Palladin, 55, a French Chef With Verve, Dies
description: Jean-Louis Palladin, a fearless and passionate cook who helped to free French cuisine in the United States from a hidebound orthodoxy while influencing a generation of chefs and food lovers, died yesterday in McLean, Va. He was 55.

title: Hucksters or patriots? You be the judge. It's again time for 20 questions on Madison Avenue.
description: IT'S time again to ask 20 questions about advertising, marketing and the media, in this instance a special edition that could be called ''The selling of Sept. 11.''

Widow of Dr. Paul H. Holliday, DDS. Surviving children: Nancy Holliday, Barrett H. Thompson, Paul H. Holliday Jr., and four grandchildren. Memorial celebration to be held early April.

title: Credit Offerings Planned This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, tomorrow's sale of four-week bills and Wednesday's sale of two-year notes.

title: Alarm Rings at NBC as 'Today' Loses Ground; ABC Morning Program Narrows Gap. Will Katie Couric Stay?
description: Over the last several weeks, Neal Shapiro, the president of NBC News, has held a series of meetings with the staff of ''Today.'' The mood was bound to be tense. Recent ratings indications had revealed that the program's dominant, six-year lead over ABC's second-place ''Good Morning America'' was shrinking.

title: Can Democracy Stifle the Rage?
description: To the Editor:

title: Oysters and Clams: The Raw and the Cooked
description: Oysters and clams represent the kind of food some people are willing to enjoy in a restaurant, but not in their own kitchens. Given that it is easy to be scared away by tales of "bad oysters," eating them on the half-shell at home is often considered an unnecessary risk. And purists will tell you that cooking a good oyster is a sin, mainly since the oyster's appeal lies in its brininess and gooey texture, both of which can be lost through cooking.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLIOTT, MARGARET K.
description: ELLIOTT-Margaret K. Of Key Biscayne, FL, and Mt. Kisco, NY, died at home on November 22. The wife of Michael S., and the beloved mother of Jessica and Michael C. Elliott. Margaret was the daughter of Marguerite Kirby and the late Charles F. Kirby. She is also survived by her sister Marie Brennan, brother Captain John Kirby and many loving nieces and nephews. A Memorial Mass will celebrate her life at St. Francis of Assisi Church in Mt. Kisco, on Wednesday, November 28, 2001, at 11 AM. A second Memorial Mass will be celebrated at St. Agnes Church, Key Biscayne, on Friday, December 7, at a time to be determined. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Westchester Exceptional Children's School, 520 Route 22, North Salem, NY 10560, or The Vincent J. Fontana Center for Child Protection, New York Foundling Hospital, 590 6th Avenue, New York, NY 10011, celebrating Margaret's love of children and her many years of work for children and their families.

title: We   New York Because We   the Arts
description: To the Editor:

title: Bear Market for Personal Finance Magazines
description: On Sept. 11, the staff of Money magazine was two days away from finishing a special issue recommending 100 mutual funds. When the twin towers fell, the managing editor, Robert Safian, knew the monthly magazine, a publication of Time Inc., did not have the resources to remake the issue completely.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLEARY, KEVIN F. ESQ.

Kevin graduated from UW Madison and Fordham School of Law and studied acting with Lily Lodge at the Actor's Conservatory, Stella Adler and the Michael Howard Studios. Kevin is survived by his mother Elizabeth, sisters Cathleen, Maureen and Patricia, his brothers Thomas, Michael and Chris, his in-laws Gina, Christine and Paul and nine nieces and nephews. His father Thomas and brother Brian predeceased him. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Community Funds Inc. and sent to Mr. Owen Wincig, Esq. 574 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY 10036. Celebration of Life Mass was celebrated on September 27 at St. Ignatius Loyola, NY, NY. Private burial was held November 26 at Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Falling Science Scores

title: Amazon Plant Proliferates Again in African Lake, Causing Economic Peril
description: In the fishing villages along Lake Victoria, locals sneer at the very mention of the water hyacinth. It is an evil weed, they say, a destroyer of their livelihood, far more dangerous than it looks.

title: E-Commerce Report; Used-car wholesalers see promise in the Web. Dealers can benefit, too, but how much will they buy into it?
description: IN the business arena, there is perhaps no more mismatched pair than the used-car industry and e-commerce. The used-car business is like an offensive tackle, a not-so-pretty giant that goes about its duties mostly unnoticed. E-commerce is like a promising running back, a first-round draft pick that has preened and danced its way to ignominy.

title: Landlord Kills Tenant and Tries To Commit Suicide, Police Say
description: A Queens landlord who had been feuding with a tenant for months beat her to death and then poisoned himself by swallowing a bottle of drain cleaner, the police said.

title: Tired of Stereotyping, Bikers Turn to Law
description: When Carl Campbell says he is tired of being asked to leave bars and restaurants, one may wonder who the brave souls are who are doing the asking.

title: Milton Shaw, 80, Who Oversaw First Nuclear Submarine Project
description: Milton Shaw, who oversaw the design and construction of the reactors that powered the first nuclear submarine and the first nuclear aircraft carrier, died on Saturday at his home in Chevy Chase, Md. He was 80.

title: Miscellany
description: * Coca-Cola, Atlanta, is introducing a television commercial that for the first time presents an animated version of the company's familiar Santa Claus character created by the artist Hadden Sundblom. The commercial was created by McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising, New York, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group division of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Tremblant Ski Deals
description: Through Dec. 21, there are a number of deals at this Quebec ski area. All the following are for five nights with six days of lift tickets. Club Intrawest has a one-bedroom condo with a Jacuzzi for two, kitchen, a mountain view and shuttle service for $294 a person and up, double occupancy, at $1.62 Canadian to the United States dollar. And a one-bedroom suite with fireplace and kitchenette at the Marriott Residence Inn starts at $344 a person, double. Information: (866) 836-3030 or www.tremblant.com .

title: Sorest Loss in Colombia Mine Collapse: The Children
description: As usual, John Vlez, 13, and his younger brother, Jaime, 11, did not go to school last Thursday. The boys awoke at 4 a.m. as always, put on the same dirt-caked trousers and rubber boots they had worn the day before and, following their father, began a long walk along the muddy Cauca River to the huge open-pit gold mine just outside this village.

title: Turks Take Narrow Victory In Pairs Event at Nationals
description: Two players from Turkey snatched a victory Saturday night in the Blue Ribbon Pairs at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here and became the first players from their country to win a major American title. The players, Salvador Assael and Nafiz Zorlu, have been partners for 17 years and have represented Turkey in many international events. They are the first foreign partnership to win in this event's 39-year history.

description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FRANK, CLAIRE LERIT
description: FRANK-Claire Lerit. Lovingly remembered. You were special. The Diamond Family Evelyn, Norman, Leslie and David

title: Sondheim's Kabuki Hybrid May Have Found Its Moment
description: ''Pacific Overtures,'' the musical by Stephen Sondheim and John Weidman about the emergence of modern Japan, may have come 25 years too soon. It opened on Broadway in January 1976, and with its theme of the West's reckless insinuation of itself into the affairs of the other hemisphere, the echoes of Vietnam were evident, purposeful and badly timed. Not exactly balm for an American audience -- even a liberal one -- less than a year removed from the fall of Saigon.

title: Australian Company Agrees To Buy Control of Virgin Blue
description: The Lang Corporation, Australia's No. 1 port cargo handler, agreed to buy a majority stake in the discount airline Virgin Blue and to provide it with $155 million to finance faster growth and compete with Qantas Airways.

title: White House Letter; Shrinking From View But Still Looming Large
description: Now comes the strange case of Dick Cheney, the phantom vice president. Did he spend his Thanksgiving in his ''secure and undisclosed location'' or in the sleekly redecorated Naval Observatory, the vice president's official residence that has taken on the characteristics of an armed camp?

title: Shoppers' Solid Start Makes Retailers Cautiously Hopeful
description: Deep discounts on things like CD's and turtleneck sweaters lured shoppers back to the malls over the Thanksgiving weekend, but consumers did not swell the crowds the way they did last year, and it is still unclear whether they will spend robustly enough to pull the economy from its downturn.

title: Leahy Anthrax Letter Remains Unopened; Scientists Are Wary
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26  Forensic scientists have not yet opened the anthrax-contaminated letter sent to the Democratic chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, law enforcement officials said today.

title: With Taliban Gone, Opium Farmers Return to Their Only Cash Crop
description: Come spring, the poppies will be blooming in Afghanistan again.

title: An American Is Said to Be Killed During a Failed Prison Uprising
description: Surrendered Taliban troops staged a revolt today at a prison where hundreds of them were being held under the control of the Northern Alliance, and American warplanes bombed the prison to help quell the uprising.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAROLY, GEORGE
description: PAROLY-George. Age 86, on November 22, 2001. Beloved husband of Miriam for 62 years. Dear brother of Bernard, and the late Ruth. Devoted father to Warren and Janet Paroly, Stan and Barbara Paroly, Laraine and Peter Lerner. Loving grandfather of Jill, Lisa, Michael, Lauren, Daniel and Julie. Owner, for over 30 years, of Paroly & Rosenberg, Inc., manufacturer of fine fur wearing apparel.

title: An Archive of the Bid
description: Here is an archive of stories chronicling the controversy surrounding Salt Lake City's bid for the 2002 Winter Games.

title: Disappointing Finish To Nets' Western Trip
description: Two victories on the Nets' first Western Conference trip would have been a blessing last season. This season, it is a disappointment.

title: A South African Hospital Fights AIDS and Despair
description: It is just past 7 on a Tuesday morning, and the nurses at Hlabisa Hospital are praying for deliverance. The stronger patients straighten their ailing bodies and chime in on wobbly legs. The bedridden croon through cracked lips.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMAN, MICHAEL E.
description: HOFFMAN-Michael E. On November 23, 2001. Extraordinary husband of Melissa Harris; loving father of Matthew Perkins (Ana) and Sarah Warren; dear brother of Jill H. Shore; sweet grandfather of Isabel K. Service private. A memorial service will be held in fall 2002. Contributions may be made in his memory to Montana Wilderness Society, Aperture Foundation, and The Central Park Conservancy.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Shooting Victim was Bystander
description: A 29-year-old Brooklyn man who was fatally shot Saturday night outside the Hammerstein Ballroom in Midtown was a bystander to a dispute that resulted in gunfire, the police said yesterday. The man, Jorge Correa Garcia of East Williamsburg, was shot once in the back around 10 p.m. and pronounced dead at St. Vincent's Manhattan Hospital, the police said. A man and a woman, bystanders in their 20's, were also hit, but their injuries were not life threatening. There were no arrests and no suspects. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Europe Plans to Compete With U.S. Satellite Network

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIGG, ELIZABETH SCHULTZ
description: RIGG-Elizabeth Schultz. A 25 year resident of Greenwich, CT, died Friday, November 23, at Greenwich Hospital, after a brief illness. The cause of death was pulmonary fibrosis. She was born in NYC on June 9, 1921, the daughter of the late William Lightfoot and Mabel LaVie Schultz. Her father was the founder and longtime CEO of Shulton, Inc, the makers of Old Spice. She was raised near Morristown, NJ, and attended Miss Beard's School there. She studied at the Juilliard School and graduated with a concentration in music from Sarah Lawrence College in 1943. An accomplished pianist, she became a professional cabaret singer against strenuous family opposition. Adopting Suzanne Gilbert as her stage name, she performed at the Stage Door Canteen, the American Theater Wing and the Biltmore Hotel, among other popular World War II night spots. A member of the Belle Haven Club and the Greenwich Country Club, Mrs. Rigg was well known in Greenwich as a philanthropist to both public and private causes. Throughout her life she was a serious student of both French and Italian, and was a member of the Alliance Francaise in Greenwich. She was an avid traveler, especially to Europe, and an enthusiastic tennis player. Until very recently, she was an active participant in the Fred Astaire ballroom dance competitions, where she won numerous first place awards. Mrs. Rigg was descended from Francis Lightfoot Lee, a signer of the Declaration of Independence from Virginia. Her brother, George L. Schultz, predeceased her. She is survived by three sons, William L.S. Rigg of Williamsburg, VA, Geoffrey B. Rigg of Greenwich, and Douglas G. Rigg of Mill Valley, CA. A memorial service will be held on Friday, November 30, at 11 AM, at Christ Church, 254 East Putnam Avenue, Greenwich. At Mrs. Rigg's request, those attending should wear joyful colors. In lieu of flowers, gifts may be made to the Betty Schultz Rigg Scholarship Fund, Sarah Lawrence College, One Mead Way, Bronxville, NY 10708.

title: The Neediest Cases; Girl's Cancer Complicates An Already Difficult Life
description: In a busy Bronx living room, a cloth tablet hangs on a plaster wall. It reads ''My Family,'' and underneath is a picture of a handsome, dark-haired young man, smiling next to his beautiful young girlfriend with piercing brown eyes, and their two children -- a girl with long brown hair and an infant boy. Though taken just months ago, it has come to represent a much happier time for a family just starting out.

title: States and the Disabled
description: To the Editor:

title: Can Democracy Stifle the Rage?
description: To the Editor:

title: Bloomberg a Man of Contradictions, but With a Single Focus
description: Throughout most of his 59 years, there have been two distinct sides to Michael R. Bloomberg, the mayor-elect. Those who know him well say that New York City should expect to see plenty of both.

title: Choosing Peacekeepers
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Teenagers Held in Plot At Massachusetts School
description: Three teenage boys were being held today, charged with plotting a murderous attack at a high school in New Bedford, Mass., and law enforcement officials said a massacre may have been averted by their use of techniques and studies developed after the 1999 killings at Columbine High School.

title: New Economy; The time may have come for a national corps of technology experts to protect and repair vital information systems.
description: IN the aftermath of Sept. 11, a new spirit of civil service is sweeping the country. Volunteers and donors have swamped the Red Cross, the Salvation Army and other agencies with offers of help. Seizing on the national mood, President Bush has called for the creation of a civil defense service that would supplement security efforts by the police, fire departments and public health agencies. That call to civic duty mirrors a bipartisan Senate proposal that would quintuple the size of AmeriCorps, the domestic Peace Corps initiated by President Bill Clinton.

title: A New Mission Statement
description: Picabo Street was searching for her rescue party in a hotel lobby, stretching her neck like a periscope to see above the fans, while scribbling her autograph as the minutes ticked by.

title: Congressional Countdown
description: Congress has only a few weeks left before adjourning for the year. Yet there is still no legislative agreement on measures to boost the economy and improve protections against terrorist attacks. President Bush needs to help break the impasse on both issues, or legislators will go home covered with failure.

title: Redskins' Unexpected Recovery Continues
description: The Eagles lead the National Football Conference East, but they did not play like a first-place team today.

title: Mignonette
description: Mignonette is a classic, spicy accompaniment to raw oysters (other possibilities include cocktail sauce, or Alonso sauce, which is red onion, tomato and celery, chopped into tiny flecks and seasoned with hot sauce, lemon juice and black pepper). Mignonette's name comes from the raw cracked pepper (usually of the white variety) in the sauce, which always contains some kind of vinegar.

title: Former Inhabitants Trickle Back to Area Ravaged by Taliban
description: Of all the Taliban's misdeeds, few were worse than what the overzealous militia did on the Shamali Plain in the summer of 1999.
