title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GROSS, SIDNEY
description: GROSS-Sidney. No matter the years, forever in our hearts and memories. Zenith and the Family

title: INSIDE
description: Human Cloning Reported

title: Economy Puts Schools in Tough Position
description: Nearly all 600 students at Carl Harvey Elementary School arrive for class for the first time speaking Spanish, not English, which is why the school's three-hour after-school literacy classes have been so critical.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIEMER, JOSEPH G. III
description: RIEMER-Joseph G. III. 53, of Scarsdale, NY, on November 22, 2001, of pancreatic cancer. Beloved husband of Peggy. Adored father of Andrew, Timothy and Meaghan. Loving son of Joseph G. and Catherine E. Riemer of Elkton, FL. Cherished brother of Kenneth, Douglas, Mary and John. Graduate Fordham College (C'70) and Fordham Law School (C'74). Member: Association of the Bar of the City of New York; the Supreme Court of the United States; and Bars of numerous other federal courts. Partner, Brown Wood; Managing Director, Merrill Lynch; Founder and Managing Director, Sherbrooke Consulting Group; Partner, Riemer and Raymond LLP; Co-Owner, Summit Ventures, NE, who recently acquired Sugarbush Ski Resort, Warren, VT. Member, Board of Trustees and assistant football coach, Brunswick School, Greenwich, CT. For information, Bennett Funeral Home, Scarsdale, NY (914) 725-1137. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Pancreatic Cancer Clinical Research Foundation, 9 Benedict Pl., Greenwich, CT 06830.

title: For the Sake of Security
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Images of Suffering
In Kunduz, a Deathly Peace Settles In
A Deathly Peace Settles on Kunduz's Streets
description: The bodies of the Taliban soldiers lay stiff and straight at odd points across the intersection of Khanabad Road and Chugha Street. The big toes on their bare feet were tied together, an Islamic burial custom, and their white turbans were unfurled to reveal bullet holes through the tops of their heads.

title: Sol Forman, 98, Owner of Famed Steakhouse
description: Sol Forman, who sometimes ate a steak or two a day at Peter Luger, the steakhouse across the street from his Brooklyn metalware factory, and then rescued the restaurant from oblivion by buying it at auction and owning it for a half century, died on Thursday at Maimonides Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 98.

title: Sale of U.S. Vision Falters
description: U.S. Vision, a company that sells prescription glasses and contact lenses through J. C. Penney Company department stores, said today that a group of shareholders had canceled an agreement to buy the company for about $24.9 million.

title: Rewards at Any Age
description: To the Editor:

title: War and Politics in Afghanistan
description: Americans should be encouraged that the early phases of the war against terrorism have gone relatively smoothly in Afghanistan, but some of the most important and difficult tasks in that nation now lie ahead. The Pentagon has been airlifting hundreds of marines into southern Afghanistan in recent days, preparing for more extensive American ground combat missions. Rival Afghan opposition groups meet this morning in Germany in a preliminary effort to fashion a unified government. Neither of these ventures promises quick or easy results. How they unfold will help determine whether the United States achieves its main objectives in Afghanistan.

title: A NATION CHALLENGED
description: Talks on Terror Finances

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: A Peaceful Walk To School
description: Catholic children walked to their North Belfast school peaceably yesterday for the first time in three months after Protestants ended a protest that had forced them to seek protection of riot squad police officers and British troops. A pipe bomb was found in the garden of a house 600 yards from the school and dismantled but it went unnoticed by the students and their parents. The Protestants agreed to end daily demonstrations after obtaining assurances of security cameras and extra policing for their neighborhood, which they said had been repeatedly attacked by Catholic residents. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Learning to Care for Patients, in Truest Sense
description: Scholars have spent centuries trying to understand the doctor-patient relationship, and they have not gotten very far at all. Is it a friendship, a partnership or just a fee-for-service arrangement? Are the parties peers, or more like parent and child, or priest and parishioner (or sergeant and grunt)? Might ''necessary evil'' be the phrase each would secretly pick for the other? After several millennia, the model is still under construction.

title: Hungry and Poor (And Right Here)
description: To the Editor:

title: Remedy to Exclusive Zoning Goes on Trial in New Jersey
description: More than a quarter century after it gave birth to one of the nation's most ambitious attempts at trying to shape the demographics of suburbia, the State Supreme Court will hear arguments Tuesday on a case that could reshape New Jersey's Mount Laurel doctrine, a set of rules that were intended to open up suburbia to poor and working-class families.

title: British Defense Secretary Says Troops for Afghanistan Are Being Taken Off High Alert
description: Defense Secretary Geoff Hoon said today that most of the 6,400 British troops who had been put on 48-hour alert earlier this month for action in Afghanistan were having their readiness downgraded to a week. Some 400 troops from a parachute regiment and an air assault brigade would remain on the two-day standby, he said in a statement to Parliament.

title: But for the Young and Brave, Love Conquers Fear
description: In countless ways, New York City is not the same place that it was before Sept. 11. But that has not kept some people away from the city that they have loved from afar.

title: AIDS Crisis Leaves Africa's Oldest Ways at a Loss
description: Of the 10 mud huts in Mama Mtshali's compound, the most impressive is her ''pharmacy.'' The walls are festooned with dried birds and the skins of a python she stabbed herself and a crocodile her husband speared -- from which, she says, she can make a lotion that renders a man's skin bulletproof.

title: A Cross, a Shield, and a Prayer for Firefighters
description: THE REV. CHRISTOPHER KEENAN'S pager was purring again. Its screen was alight with news of a fire in Chelsea, and instantly he was checking in with the Fire Department's war room in Brooklyn. ''No? Don't need me? O.K.,'' he said. ''Peace, my brother.''

title: A Breakthrough on Cloning? Perhaps, or Perhaps Not Yet
description: When Advanced Cell Technology, a small biotechnology company in Worcester, Mass., announced on Sunday that it had taken the first steps in producing human embryos through cloning, it could not report lasting success; all the embryos it created had died.

title: PROVIDIAN FINANCIAL REPLACES CHIEF EXECUTIVE WHO QUIT
description: The Providian Financial Corporation hired Joseph Saunders as chief executive yesterday to help stem mounting credit card losses that have sent the company's shares down 94 percent this year. Mr. Saunders, 56, succeeds Shailesh Mehta, who resigned after the company reported a 71 percent decline in third-quarter earnings last month because more customers were not able to pay their bills. Mr. Saunders was the chief executive of the credit card unit at the FleetBoston Financial Corporation and helped fix credit standards and collection methods after it bought $11 billion in loans from the Advanta Corporation, an issuer stung by similar losses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADAMS, REBBITZEN BERNICE
description: ADAMS-Rebbitzen Bernice. Congregation Ohab Zedek Manhattan, records with deep sorrow the passing of Rebbitzen Bernice Adams, wife of the late Rabbi Theodore L. Adams. To her children Larry Adams and Howard Adams, Sivi Greenberg and Myril Zomick, & to all her grandchildren & great grandchildren we extend our sincerest condolences. Shiva will be observed at the Zomick residence, 1364 Milford Terrace, Teaneck, New Jersey, until Friday morning. Rabbi Allen Schwartz Murray Zucker, President

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Profit Up At Tobacco Concern
description: Imperial Tobacco, which makes Embassy and John Player cigarettes, said its full-year after-tax profit rose 10 percent, to $521 million, as it overtook its rival, Gallaher, to become Britain's biggest cigarette maker and expanded in Africa. Cigarette consumption is shrinking in the company's home market. Imperial has responded by promoting a budget brand in Britain and expanding overseas. After early gains, Imperial's shares slid by as much as 2.6 percent. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Idaho: Deeper Cutbacks Offered
description: State agencies submitted proposals on how to cut another $17.7 million from their budgets to comply with the second of Gov. Dirk Kempthorne's orders to reduce spending: cuts totaling $55 million of Idaho's $2 billion budget for the current fiscal year. The governor mandated cuts of 2 percent, or 1.5 percent for schools, in August; another order for 1 percent in cuts came on Nov. 13. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Selig Isn't Ready To Call Off Contraction
description: A rumor was circulated in some baseball circles yesterday that Commissioner Bud Selig would meet with the owners in Chicago today and pull the plug on contraction 2002. The only problem with that plan is it would come as a surprise to Selig and other baseball officials.

title: Sprawl Seen to Hurt South's Forests
description: The Forest Service has concluded in a study released today that the biggest threat to Southern forests is urban sprawl, a finding that to some degree absolves the timber industry for the effects of a logging boom that has transformed the South in recent decades.

title: Ignoring the Real Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: An Insider in Harlem
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday about Gregory Hoffman, who lost his twin brother in the World Trade Center attack, referred incorrectly in some copies to the place where he posed in front of a mirror. It was at his brother's home, not his.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Park City
description: Get a holiday preview of the 2002 Olympic Winter Games site in Utah and save a little, too. ResortQuest is cutting holiday rates up to 30 percent at its rental condos and homes, for Dec. 20 to Jan. 3. For example, a four-bedroom house that normally is $1,000 a night is $675. Rentals also available in Deer Valley and The Canyons. Information: (800) 899-1798 or www.parkcityski.com .

title: The Panic of 1837: Those Were the Days
description: Our story begins during the Panic of 1837. The unscrupulous New York banker Gideon Bloodgood (Ray DeMattis, who manages to look like Mr. Magoo dressed as Ebenezer Scrooge) is preparing to skip town. ''As I expected, every stock is further down still,'' he announces, ''and my last effort to retrieve my fortune has plunged me into utter ruin.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARNETT, CHARLES J., ESQUIRE
description: BARNETT-Charles J., Esquire. Of Syosset, N.Y. and Boynton Beach, Florida, on Nov. 25, 2001. Survived by his beloved wife Audrey (Applebaum). Adored father of Ruth Berland (Lawrence), Jeffrey (Stephanie), Suzanne Plotch (William), Steven (Jeanne). Devoted grandfather of Michael, Alyssa, Stuart, Madeline, Lindsey, Daniel, Cayla and Liana. Dear brother of Albert and Edgar. Esteemed Nassau County trial lawyer (retired). Services on Wednesday at noon, Gutterman's, Woodbury, L.I. Donations to the Charles J. Barnett Memorial Fund may be made through North Shore Synagogue, (516) 921-2282.

title: Hudson's Bay Reports 3rd-Quarter Loss
description: The Hudson's Bay Company, Canada's largest department store chain by sales, had a loss of 2 million Canadian dollars ($1.3 million) after excluding the benefits of an accounting rule change in its most recent quarter, as shoppers bought less clothing.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Concern Over Monitored Web Sites
description: Human rights advocates expressed concern that the police are monitoring what the authorities call ''immoral'' Web sites. Last week the monitoring unit arrested Shohdy Naguib after he posted his father's banned poems on the Internet. One of the poems by Naguib Sorour, who died in 1978, condemned Egyptian leaders in graphic language for losing the 1967 war with Israel. Abeer Allam (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINTRAUB, BRONKA
description: WEINTRAUB-Bronka. Widow of Jacob Weintraub, Harry Rabin and Abraham Stawski, passed away on November 23, 2001, and brought to her eternal rest on Sunday, November 25, 2001. A vivacious and dedicated leader in philanthropy and the very noblest of causes on behalf of Israel, the Jewish people and Jewish education. She will be sorely missed by all who knew her, admired her and loved her. May her memory be a blessing.

title: Top Companies Issuing Debt At a Fast Pace
description: In the weeks since the attack on the World Trade Center, blue-chip corporations have issued a torrent of debt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOURGEOIS, VIOLET
description: BOURGEOIS-Violet on November 25. Beloved wife of Rano Bourgeois. Visiting Chas. Peter Nagel Funeral Home, 352 East 87th Street Thursday 6-8 PM.

title: Dragging Out Essentials of a Holiday Perennial
description: Drag is dead, or close to it. So it's lucky for ''Christmas With the Crawfords'' that Connie Champagne is alive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLOVER, PRICE PERKINS
description: GLOVER-Price Perkins, 83. On November 23, 2001 of cancer. Beloved husband of Isobel, loving father of Jonathan and Julie, devoted brother of Dorothy Johns. A native Virginian and long-time resident of Manhattan, he was a pilot both in the Navy and for 35 years with Pan American Airways. A respected collector of American furniture and the English decorative arts, Price founded his antique shop in 1971 with his close friend Dunbar Bostwick. We will miss his loving presence, gentle charm, keen humor and rare dignity. The family would like to extend its deepest gratitude to the doctors and nursing staff of New York Hospital for their tireless and devoted care. A memorial service will be held at the Brick Presbyterian Church, 1140 Park Avenue, December 10 at 4 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations would be appreciated to: Genitourinary Oncology Research Fund, C/O David M. Nanus M.D., 525 East 68th Street, ST-359, New York, NY 10021.

title: Gas-Guzzling in a Patriotic Age
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNGER, REV. DR. GEORGE D.
description: YOUNGER-Rev. Dr. George D. On November 21, 2001, at age 75. Our family mourns the passing of our father, beloved partner of our mother Dodie for over 50 years, grandfather to our children and special friend to so many. Dad will always be remembered as a pioneer in urban ministry, an advocate for peace and racial justice and a spiritual leader and counselor. Memorial services will be held December 8th, 10:30AM at the First Baptist Church of Westfield, N.J. and December 9th, 4:30PM at Riverside Church in New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Rev. Dr. George D. Younger Scholarship Fund for Inner City Youth at Riverside Church, 490 Riverside Dr, N.Y. N.Y. 10027 or the Annual Rev. Dr. George D. Younger One in Christ Conference, American Baptist Churches of New Jersey, 3752 Nottingham Way, Trenton N.J. 08690. We will cherish our memories of you always. Judy, Dana, Stephen and Sam

title: Sapp Awakens And Keeps The Bucs Alive
description: Tampa Bay defensive tackle Warren Sapp slowed down what he called the greatest show on turfjust in time to keep the Buccaneers alive in the playoff race.

title: With Biotechnology, a Potential to Harm
description: Some biological weapons experts fear that terrorists have gotten hold of the smallpox virus, the last two official repositories of which are kept under guard in the United States and Russia. But some experts say a sophisticated adversary would not have to obtain the natural virus, but could make it from scratch.

title: Professor to Be Deported After Secret Evidence Case
description: A Palestinian man who was held in United States custody for more than three and a half years on secret evidence was jailed again this weekend after an appeals court ruled that the government could deport him.

title: White House Offers a Choice For Prosecutor
description: James B. Comey, a native New Yorker and veteran federal prosecutor who has won wide acclaim for his aggressive approach to prosecuting gun violence in Richmond, Va., is in line to be the next United States attorney in Manhattan, officials said.

title: Dance Floor Above Pool Broke Codes, Official Says
description: The portable plexiglass dance floor that collapsed into a motel swimming pool here early Sunday, plunging partygoers into eight feet of water, violated New Jersey's building code, a town official said today.

title: Off to Mars, Then to the Drugstore
description: Besides the obvious perils, hazards for long-distance space travelers may also lurk within their own bodies.

title: Tunnel Vision; New on the PATH: Crowding, Just Like the Subway
description: Compared with the New York City subway, the PATH system has always seemed a little like an exhibit at a world's fair, titled ''The Fabulous Future of Commuting!''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GUINNESS NORTH AMERICA INC., a unit of Diageo P.L.C., London, the world's largest maker of liquor, purchased a former Pabst Brewing Co., brewery in the Lehigh Valley in Pennsylvania, where it will produce its Smirnoff Ice malt beverage. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Aircraft Safety and the Case of the Plastic Tail
description: Until an Airbus A300 crashed on Nov. 12 near Kennedy International Airport, the specialists whom the National Transportation Safety Board called to the wreckage when structural failure was suspected were called metallurgists. Now, one veteran investigator said at the scene of the crash, ''They've renamed themselves 'materials scientists.' ''

title: Slippery, Eccentric And Yet In Control
description: The settings seem highly variable in Dave Holland's quintet: time appears in odd meters, or shifting from twos to fours and fives, in funk that becomes swing. Short cyclical themes suddenly sprout into longer, harmonized passages that twist off into melodies and twist again into improvisations, from which the soloist suddenly drops out.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERNANDEZ, JOSE J., JR.
description: HERNANDEZ-Jose J., Jr. On November 25, 2001. Teacher NYC Board of Ed. Beloved son of Jose Sr. and Rosa E. Loving brother of Vivien Garcia. Memorial service to be held at a later date.

title: Taliban Find Themselves Isolated in the South, With Escape Routes Cut Off
description: As United States marines secured their position today near the Taliban's headquarters in Kandahar, anti-Taliban tribal groups made gains that deepened the Taliban's isolation in southern Afghanistan and cut off their main access points to Pakistan.

title: A Fictional Understudy
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Loss At Technology Group
description: The Cambridge Antibody Technology Group reported a wider loss for the year that ended Sept. 30, and it said David Chiswell, the founder and chief executive, would step down. The biotechnology company, based in Cambridge, England, lost 11.8 million ($16.6 million) in the recently completed year, or 33.3 pence a share, compared with a loss of 8.3 million, or 27.5 pence a share, the previous year. Mr. Chiswell, who owns about 2 percent of Cambridge Antibody, said he would step aside to make room for an executive with more business experience. The company faces rising costs in 2002, as three of its six drugs enter clinical trials. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YEPEZ, GUMERSINDO
description: YEPEZ-Gumersindo. Ecuadorian scholar, 1912-2001. He was Secretary Emeritus of La Academia Norteamericana de La Lengua Espanola and one of its Founders. He is the author of ''Ensayos Filosoficos''. He will be missed so much by wife Consuelo, children and family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCUS, HARRIETT
description: MARCUS-Harriett. The Jewish Braille Institute of America records with sorrow the loss of a much respected and devoted Honorary Life Trustee, Harriett Marcus. A woman of great generosity and compassion, she will be remembered for her devoted service to the Jewish community. She will be sorely missed. May her memory serve as a blessing. Barbara B. Friedman, President Dr. Ellen Isler, Executive V.P.

title: Miller Takes Big Step To the Salt Lake Games
description: For so long, Bode Miller has barged down mountains with the pedal-punching approach of a drag racer, only to streak past the smart move on his way toward calamity.

title: Foreign Affairs; The Real War
description: If 9/11 was indeed the onset of World War III, we have to understand what this war is about. We're not fighting to eradicate ''terrorism.'' Terrorism is just a tool. We're fighting to defeat an ideology: religious totalitarianism. World War II and the cold war were fought to defeat secular totalitarianism -- Nazism and Communism -- and World War III is a battle against religious totalitarianism, a view of the world that my faith must reign supreme and can be affirmed and held passionately only if all others are negated. That's bin Ladenism. But unlike Nazism, religious totalitarianism can't be fought by armies alone. It has to be fought in schools, mosques, churches and synagogues, and can be defeated only with the help of imams, rabbis and priests.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HASSETT, MARIAN C.
description: HASSETT-Marian C. On November 24, 2001, of the Bronx. Beloved daughter of John Francis and the late Bridget. Dear sister of Joseph. Also survived by many aunts, uncles and cousins. Funeral Mass, Wednesday 12 noon, at St. John's Church in Greenville, New York with burial to follow at Greenville Cemetery. Visiting hours will be today, 2-4 & 7-9 PM at the Moritz Funeral Home, 98 Route 303, Tappan, NY (845) 359-0890.

title: Editors' Note; A Nation Challenged
description: News of the terrorist attacks and their aftermath appears today in Section B; index, Page B2.

title: Convincing Innocence on Stage
description: usannah,'' which opened at the Juilliard Opera Center on Nov. 14, is a good opera for young singers. Whatever the merits of Carlisle Floyd's piece as a work of art -- some people despise its open melo drama, others like its enduring ac cessibility -- it gives its performers something to sink their teeth into. Its characters are clearly defined and often colorful; its orchestra is beefy and solid. And since it was written in English, it allows young singers an emotional connection with the action that can be harder to establish when singing in a language you know more as a theory than a means of every day communication.

title: Alliance Declares Revolt Is Crushed
description: QALA JANGI, Afghanistan, Nov. 27 -- Northern Alliance soldiers, backed by American and British Special Operations forces, said today that they had crushed a revolt by Taliban prisoners inside a 19th-century fortress, and described a deadly final battle in which they drove the rebels from their last stronghold by pouring oil into a basement, setting it alight and then opening fire with their lone Soviet T-55 tank.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLIEDMAN, MARVIN L., M.D.
description: GLIEDMAN-Marvin L., M.D. November 25, 2001. Distinguished surgeon and educator, beloved husband of Natalie, loving father of Chip and his wife Linda, Joanna and her husband Marc, devoted grandfather of Nathan. The Funeral Service will be held at Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI, Tuesday at 12:30. Friends may call at home Wednesday through Friday from 3:00-8:00PM. Contributions in his memory may be made to the ''Department of Surgery'' for the Marvin L. Gliedman Professorship of Surgery and sent to Dr. T.S. Ravikumar, Chairman, Department of Surgery Montefiore Hospital and Medical Center, 111 East 210th Street, Bronx, New Yprk 10467.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Potentially Mad Cows To Die
description: Widening a fight against mad cow disease, the government plans to slaughter 5,129 cows that have been fed meat and bone meal. Last month Japan banned all sales of meat and bone meal, which are believed to be the transmission route for mad cow disease, or bovine spongiform encephalopathy. A second case of an infected cow was discovered last week and wholesale prices for beef have dropped by 20 percent. James Brooke (NYT)

title: Bush Denounces Cloning and Calls for Ban
description: President Bush, joined by a chorus of religious and political leaders in the United States and abroad, today condemned the work of a Massachusetts biotechnology company that says it has created human embryos through cloning. The White House called on lawmakers to ban the practice.

title: For Radiation, How Much Is Too Much?
description: In their efforts to protect Americans from the hazards of radiation, federal agencies have found themselves in a quandary. People are constantly exposed to radiation from natural sources -- from cosmic rays, radon seeping out of the earth and radioactive substances in soil, water, food and even from potassium in the human body itself.

title: Hamamatsu Journal; Sons and Daughters of Japan, Back From Brazil
description: Joining a flood of Brazilians lured here a decade ago to fill vacancies on Japan's assembly lines, Benedito Vilela Garcia came planning to make some quick yen then to go back home, hoping to open a pharmacy in his native country.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Job Fair For Displaced Workers
description: New Jersey has organized a job fair, to be held tomorrow, for workers whose jobs were lost after the attack on the World Trade Center. The fair is scheduled for the Continental Airlines Arena at the Meadowlands and will run from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m., the State Department of Labor said. More than 200 employers have been invited and as many as 8,000 job seekers are expected. The job fair is free and employers and job seekers can learn more about the fair at www.wnjpin.net, the department said.

title: U.S. Couple Held in Philippines Describe Their Ordeal on Tape
description: An American missionary couple who have been held for six months near here by Muslim guerrillas described the hardships of captivity in a videotape shown on television on Sunday and Monday.

title: Lazard Partners Will Get Shares
description: Lazard L.L.C. said today that it would give equity to its 140 partners, a move that analysts said would take the firm, a leading adviser on mergers, a step closer to being sold.

title: Standing Up to China
description: To the Editor:

title: Transitions Announced for Two Fixtures on Wall Street
description: Two fixtures on Wall Street announced expected changes in their careers yesterday.

title: Q & A
description: Skunk Versus Dog

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIGHTON, MIRIAM
description: LEIGHTON-Miriam. The officers, board and staff of the Women's Division/American Technion Society express profound regret at the loss of Miriam Leighton. Miriam demonstrated the highest level of commitment to the Technion, the American Society of Technion by her support of Women's Division. Our deepest sympathy to her sister Adele Faye and daughter Elaine Rosen. Natalie Lyons, Women's Division/ATS National President

title: Israeli Analysis Raises New Doubt About Arafat's Power
description: As the Bush administration begins its first intensive drive for peace here, senior Israeli officials have concluded that no solution will be possible until new leaders replace Yasir Arafat at the top of the Palestinian movement.

title: Sunshine for Windy Dreamscapes
description: Wind-bent palm trees, sand, surf, billowing clouds and vivid sunsets were the essentials of Florida landscape painting that emerged following World War II. Occasionally moss-draped cypress trees in the still water of a marsh presented a more contemplative view, while a royal poinciana in full, flaming red bloom or a storm-tossed shore provided dramatic relief.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARUCH, HANS, M.D.
description: BARUCH-Hans, M.D. Died on November 21, 2001. Survived by his sister Lisa, his son Greg, and his accomplishments.

title: Trial of 2nd Man Starts in Suffolk In Attack on Mexican Laborers
description: The trial of a young Queens man charged with attempted murder in an assault on two Mexican day laborers began today in much the same way that his friend's trial began last summer: a prosecutor said the two had plotted to murder the men ''for the sole reason that they are Mexican.''

title: Audience Stands Up To Cheer A Stand-In
description: When the Chilean soprano Veronica Villarroel took her first curtain call after singing the title role in Puccini's ''Madama Butterfly'' at the Metropolitan Opera on Saturday afternoon, everyone in the hall, this critic included, had the same immediate impulse: stand up and cheer. Though not technically flawless, Ms. Villarroel's affecting performance is vocally distinguished and unerringly honest. It comes as an unexpected highlight of the season, since Ms. Villarroel was taking the place of Daniela Dess, who withdrew from the Met's revival of this Giancarlo del Monaco 1994 production, which opened on Nov. 1.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Device Can Stop Trucks
description: Gov. Gray Davis plans to demonstrate the state's latest crime-fighting weapon today, a device that could stop a rampaging truck. The device, developed by a Lawrence Livermore Laboratory consultant, Bill Wattenburg, is a metal bar, installed on a truck's bumper, that is attached to the air-brake system. It is activated when a patrol car bumps the back of the runaway truck, pressing the bar. The demonstration is to take place at the Oakland Coliseum parking lot. Evelyn Nieves (NYT)

title: The Home Front, Through a Child's Eyes
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An explanatory note yesterday and on Sunday with the continuations of front-page articles about the effect of AIDS on a community in South Africa referred incorrectly in most copies to the country's percentage ranking for adults infected with the virus that causes AIDS. While South Africa has the largest number, 4.2 million, the infection rate is not the highest for any country, according to the United Nations. Botswana has the highest, with 35.8 percent infected in 1999. South Africa, with 19.9 in 1999, ranked fifth.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''He just doesn't feel to me like the surrendering type.''

title: Dressing Up in Strange Times: From Sparkle to Sputter
description: For 14 years, Francine DeCicco has worked as the event coordinator of Leonard's of Great Neck, the fabled Long Island catering hall that has arguably seen enough sea-foam taffeta pass through its doors to cover the Hermitage twice. Leonard's has long been a place where police officers, firefighters and soldiers have gone to slice their wedding cakes. Predictably, since Sept. 11, things haven't felt quite so celebratory. ''I don't see gowns anymore,'' Ms. DeCicco said. ''I don't see full-length, beaded, backless. I just went to an affair myself -- my husband's godchild's wedding -- and I wore a black suit. I mean, who even wants to have a wedding these days if your grandmother can't be there because they're taking apart her wheelchair at the airport?''

title: Under Tight Security, Shuttle Is Set for First Post-Sept. 11 Flight
description: Working under an umbrella of new security measures, the space shuttle Endeavour is ready to take up a new crew to live in the International Space Station and to return three other space travelers to a world very different from the one they left four months ago.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Applied Materials Buys Chip Inspector
description: The world's largest manufacturer of chip-making equipment, Applied Materials, said yesterday that it had purchased a defect-detection business from Schlumberger Semiconductor Solutions. Financial terms were not disclosed. Applied Materials, based in Santa Clara, Calif., said Schlumberger's technology would complement its existing defect-detection techniques. Applied Materials, which supplies leading chip makers like Intel, uses light to find defects quickly on the surface of silicon wafers, while Schlumberger's Odyssey 300 technology uses electron beams to scan chips for flaws below the surface. As part of the deal, Applied Materials will receive patents, equipment and about 100 employees from Schlumberger Semiconductor Solutions, a division of Schlumberger Ltd. Shares of Applied Materials rose $1.30, to $40.06, while shares of Schlumberger fell $1.18, to $46.30. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Pakistanis Concerned Over Deaths Of Prisoners
description: Pakistan's government expressed concern today over the deaths of foreign Taliban prisoners in an uprising at a mud-walled fort near the northern Afghan city of Mazar-i-Sharif.

title: Robots Learn Soccer (and the Game of Life)
description: Tucker Balch is an unusual kind of soccer coach.

title: Keeping Malaria at Bay, With Garlic
description: Two recent reports at a tropical disease conference focused on malaria, which kills 1.5 million to 2.7 million people a year.

title: The Name of Recession
description: For most of us, economics is an experiential fact, not a matter of science or data or even market performance. We tend, at best, to know only what we feel, and this is never truer than when the national economy is troughing or peaking. The National Bureau of Economic Research in Cambridge, Mass., acts as the semiofficial cartographer of those peaks and troughs. Yesterday it announced that the country was ''officially'' in a recession that began in March. That news is a little like going to the doctor and being told that the mild flu-like symptoms you've been feeling are actually the flu. The recession is real. Now we know why it feels as if we're in a recession.

title: Facing Up to Depression After a Bypass
description: For many people who have had coronary artery bypass surgery, regaining emotional strength is a tougher challenge than recuperating physically.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Jennifer Cacioppo, vice president and account director at Frankel, Chicago, part of the Publicis Group, was named senior vice president and group account director on the McDonald's account. She succeeds Cathy Crain, who recently retired.

title: Sotheby's Trial Witnesses Attest to Chief's Integrity
description: The defense case in the price-fixing trial of A. Alfred Taubman, the controlling shareholder and former chairman of Sotheby's, took shape yesterday with testimony from friendly witnesses who vouched for his integrity and disputed his main accuser and longtime chief executive, Diana D. Brooks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, HUGH J.
description: KELLY-Hugh J. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York, records with profound sorrow the death of Hugh J. Kelly. A member of the Society, and extends sincere sympathy to his family. John H. FitzSimons, President Henry F. White, Jr., Historian

title: Fizzling Finale on the Nets' Trip Reveals a Work Still in Progress
description: The Nets shuffled out of Oakland with a heavy sigh Sunday night. Their five-game road trip was not supposed to end with their worst blowout of the season, especially not in the city where Jason Kidd owns the key.

title: Guitar and Conversation: A Singer at Ease With Her Roots
description: Luciana Souza's new album, ''Brazilian Duos'' (Sunnyside), presents a set of lithe, poignant, voice-and-guitar partnerships covering old sambas, bossa novas, progressive Brazilian pop music and baios, a democratic music of city and country, of different eras and classes. When Ms. Souza performed at Joe's Pub on Wednesday, she replicated songs from the album and others, and she gave her performance its same fresh spontaneity.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO GAINS. The dollar fell as some investors concluded that a three-week rally in the dollar reflected too much optimism on a quick economic rebound. In New York, the euro settled at 88.03 cents, up from 87.78 cents on Friday.

title: The New York Skyline
description: The New York skyline was dramatically changed on September 11, and it will change again as the city rebuilds. Here is a collection of articles about architecture and New York.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Over the River and Off the Map

title: Afghan South Is New Front
description: For all the Pentagon's talk about waging an unorthodox war, the campaign in northern Afghanistan has been fairly conventional, culminating today in the fall of the city of Kunduz. But the situation in southern Afghanistan, where hundreds of United States marines are now deployed near the Taliban's last stronghold, Kandahar, is strikingly different.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Namibia: President Chooses Not To Run
description: President Sam Nujoma, who has run the country since all-white rule ended in 1990, has decided that he will not stand for re-election in 2004, ending months of speculation about whether he would seek a fourth term. Two years ago, the Constitution was changed to allow Mr. Nujoma, 72, to run for a third term, a move that was sharply criticized by opposition parties. ''He feels that somebody else should take over and that he's getting old and that the pressure is getting too much,'' a senior party official told The Namibian. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMAN, MICHAEL E.
description: HOFFMAN - Michael E. The Trustees and staff of Aperture Foundation mourn the passing of Michael Hoffman, Aperture's Publisher and Executive Director since 1965. A true visionary, Michael Hoffman made Aperture a leading force in the creation of a widespread audience for significant photography. During his tenure, he expanded Aperture from a small quarterly magazine to one of the world's most respected publishers of photography books and exhibitions. His commitment and selfless dedication to Aperture has been an inspiration to us all and he will be deeply missed. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to Michael's wife and our friend and colleague, Melissa Harris, and to his entire family. A memorial service will be held in 2002. John Gutfreund, Chair Janice B. Stanton Interim Executive Director

title: F.D.U. Robbery Is Comedy Of Errors
description: Tom Green and Dipak Patel have spent most of the past two decades carving out their livings in Teaneck, N.J., Green coaching the Fairleigh Dickinson men's basketball team, Patel running Rocklins, a convenience store nearby. Last week, their lives collided came to a sudden, bumbling collision.

title: Belgium and France Hold 14 in Bombing Plot
description: The Belgian and French police detained 14 people today suspected of involvement in the plot to assassinate Ahmed Shah Massoud, the leader of Afghanistan's Northern Alliance.

title: A Different Approach For Ventura This Year
description: For the past week, Robin Ventura has gotten in touch with his inner New Yorker.

title: A Sense of Optimism After a Season of Doubt
description: Chamber choirs often take a more adventurous approach to repertory than their orchestral counterparts, and having a composer and arranger on the podium no doubt helps tip the balance. The Gregg Smith Singers have a long tradition of offering new works as well as unusual works from the past, and on Saturday evening at St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Mr. Smith led his 17-voice choir in a typically varied program that was devoted mostly to contemporary American music.

title: Corrections
description: A classical music listing in Arts & Leisure on Sunday for a concert by the Strathmere Ensemble at the Society for Ethical Culture has become outdated. The concert, formerly scheduled for tomorrow, has been rescheduled for Dec. 13.

title: Airline Sees Sept. 11 as a Turning Point
description: How could Sept. 11 have been anything but a calamity for the world's airlines?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARLSON, JOEL
description: CARLSON-Joel. Husband of Jeanette. Father of Gabrielle, Jeremy, Meredith and Adam. Father-in-law of Matthew and April. Grandfather of Madeleine and Miranda Rose. Passed away November 25. Services 10:30 AM at the ''Riverside Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York.

title: PIER 1 IMPORTS RAISES ITS QUARTERLY PROFIT FORECAST
description: Pier 1 Imports Inc., the largest North American retailer of imported home furnishings, raised its quarterly profit forecast for the second time this month after it sold more products at full price. Earnings in the third quarter, ending Saturday, will be 21 cents to 23 cents a share, compared with net income of $23.6 million, or 24 cents, a year earlier, the company said. Earlier, Pier 1 raised the estimate to 19 cents to 21 cents. Analysts' average forecast was 20 cents, according to Thomson Financial/First Call. Sales at stores open at least a year are rising more than forecast because of new products and an increased focus by consumers on their homes after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, Pier 1 said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, LOU
description: NEWMAN-Lou. My Darling Looie, you were my loving and supportive lifeline. Tragically on November 17 you were taken away. I will never forget you and will cherish the wonderful years we had together. You are in my heart forever and will be missed beyond words. Your Loving Sweetheart, Marian

title: Failures of Intelligence
description: To the Editor:

title: Enchanted by Finland's Mythological World
description: Finnish music is faring well in the world these days, and it is possible that the Helsinki Philharmonic could have sold out its afternoon concert on Nov. 11 at Avery Fisher Hall with a program devoted entirely to, say, recent works by Magnus Lindberg and Einojuhani Rautavaara. Leif Segerstam, the orchestra's music director, played it safer, but not much. Most of the program was devoted to Sibelius's early ``Kullervo,'' a grandly tragic 90-minute work for orchestra, chorus and soloists, based on the ``Kalevala,'' Finland's national epic.

title: Economists Make It Official: U.S. Is in Recession
description: The group of economists that tracks business cycles made official today what has been apparent to laid-off workers and struggling businesses for months: the longest economic expansion on record gave way earlier this year to the first recession in a decade and the 10th since World War II.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 4 about Tom Ridge's plans for the Office of Homeland Security misstated the role of David Girard-diCarlo, a former aide who said that when Mr. Ridge was governor of Pennsylvania his care and deliberateness led some to call him overcautious. Mr. Girard-diCarlo was treasurer, not chairman, of Mr. Ridge's two campaigns for governor.

title: Rescue Season Follows Vacation Season for Rare Turtle
description: For six or seven weeks every fall, just after high tide, 100 naturalists and volunteers comb the beaches of Cape Cod Bay. They are looking for summer visitors who have overstayed their welcome -- dozens of stranded sea turtles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, JOAN SCHNUR
description: GOODMAN-Joan Schnur. Passed away at her home in Manhattan on Nov. 5, 2001. She is survived by her son, Robert Goodman of New York City and Tel Aviv, Israel. Donations may be sent in her name to the Simon Wiesenthal Center, 1399 S. Roxbury Drive, Los Angeles, CA. 90035.

title: Readmit Inspectors, President Tells Iraq; 'Or Else' Is Unstated
description: President Bush warned Saddam Hussein today that if he did not admit United Nations inspectors to determine if Iraq is developing nuclear, chemical or biological weapons, he would face consequences.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Trial In Lawyer's Killing Ends
description: The trial of a Protestant police informer accused of a role in the 1989 killing of a prominent Catholic human rights lawyer, Pat Finucane, collapsed in Belfast when the chief witness withdrew, saying he would suffer a nervous breakdown if he testified. William Stobie was acquitted after Neil Mulholland, a former journalist, was excused from testifying. Irish republican groups have accused Royal Ulster Constabulary policemen of colluding in the death of Mr. Finucane, who defended republicans in high-profile cases. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Wines of the Week
description: Before bringing out the creme brulee, fruit tart or cheese platter, offer your dinner guests a little sugar...a dessert wine. Though these sweet treats should be served very cold, they warm the soul and are the ideal way to end a meal.

title: Nassau Democrats Form Plan to Cut Spending and Raise Taxes
description: Facing a Wednesday deadline to balance Nassau County's budget or risk a state fiscal takeover, the County Legislature's Democratic majority agreed tonight on a package of spending cuts and a 15 percent increase in the county property tax. The increase would cost homeowners about $150 a year.

title: 'Stimulus' for Enron
description: To the Editor:

title: Ailey Troupe Goes in Search Of Big Money
description: With the economy in decline and contributions flooding into charities related to the terrorist attacks, now is a tough time to ask people to think about donating money to cultural institutions. But the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater is optimistic. The company plans to start asking the public to contribute to its $60 million capital campaign tomorrow, when it opens its five-week season at City Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNGLIEB, LILLY
description: YOUNGLIEB-Lilly. The American Committee for the Weizmann Institute of Science mourns the passing of Lilly Younglieb, beloved mother of dedicated ACWIS Board member Judith Cohen & motherin-law of Norman D. Cohen, ACWIS Board member and Chairman Emeritus. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Robert H. Asher, Chairman, American Committee Albert Willner, M.D., President Martin S. Kraar, Exec. V.P. Gershon Kekst, Chairman Weizmann Institute of Science Prof. Haim Harari, President

title: Experienced Teams From Italy and U.S. Lead Bridge Event
description: Two of the world's best bridge teams were in the lead going into the semifinal stage of the Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here today.

title: Foreign Diplomats Lose Optimism on Colombia Peace Talks
description: Foreign diplomats here had high expectations when President Andrs Pastrana's government and Colombia's largest rebel group embarked on a long-awaited peace effort three years ago.

title: Crash Deals New Blow to Revival of Swiss Airline
description: Switzerland's already fragile efforts to salvage a viable airline out of the remains of its bankrupt national carrier, Swissair, were set back substantially by the crash over the weekend of a plane operated by its designated successor, Crossair.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Oil Project Advances
description: Russia advanced an oil pipeline project to ship Russian crude directly to Western European markets; the oil will go through the Croatian pipeline system to that country's Adriatic Sea port of Omisalj. In a meeting with Croatian officials, the Russian energy minister, Igor Yusufov, agreed to guarantee shipments of Russian crude for the pipeline and to hold talks with other participating countries. Under the project, pipeline and storage equipment would be upgraded to ship 100,000 barrels of oil a day from Russia's main oil artery into Central Europe to the Croatian oil terminal by 2003. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Footlights
description: A Glass Premiere

title: Talking About Trauma
description: To the Editor:

title: Choreography With a Touch of the Olympics
description: In art, unlike in sports, the goal has nothing to do with winning and losing. Yet anyone watching the Olympics on television knows that the artistic component in competitions involving skating, synchronized swimming and gymnastics has become increasingly important.

title: Evaluating Athens, a City of Extremes
description: Impossible tasks successfully completed are part of Greek lore. Hercules, after all, found a way to clean the Augean stables.

title: Hungry and Poor (And Right Here)
description: To the Editor:

title: Camby Expected to Lift Defense
description: When Marcus Camby took the floor last night against the Atlanta Hawks, it was the first time he suited up for an N.B.A. game in nearly seven months. Despite the hype and expectation surrounding his return, rust was to be expected.

title: A Move to Force South Africa to Give AIDS Drug for Newborns
description: With hundreds of demonstrators cheering their efforts, a team of lawyers went to court today to try to force the government to widely distribute a drug that significantly reduces a pregnant woman's risk of transmitting the AIDS virus to her newborn.

title: Bank One Set to Hire 600
description: The Bank One Corporation said today that it would hire 600 people to work on computer systems and World Wide Web development to improve customer service.

title: Justices Deal Utah a Setback In Its Bid to Gain a House Seat
description: The Supreme Court today upheld the Census Bureau's refusal last year to count Mormon missionaries or other nongovernment American workers living overseas. The policy cost Utah, a state with a large number of missionaries, a chance to pick up a fourth House seat in the reallocation that followed the 2000 census.

title: The Home Front, Through a Child's Eyes
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: New Computer Security Woes
description: Several computer security companies warned yesterday that two new computer ''worms'' were affecting personal computers and networks. One, called BadTrans.B, is a new variant of an existing program and was detected over the weekend in Europe. It is propagated by sending itself out to people who have recently sent messages to the victim, and then it records the user's keystrokes and gathers private data, including user passwords. BadTrans messages contain no text, just an attachment named randomly from a list including ''YOU_ARE_FAT,'' ''Sorry_About_Yesterday'' and ''ME_NUDE.'' A second, W32.Aliz.Worm, takes advantage of a security flaw in Microsoft's browser, Internet Explorer, that allows some e-mail messages to launch programs automatically. Both programs can be blocked by the latest versions of current antivirus software, and the newest version of Internet Explorer, IE6, has fixed the flaw that Aliz exploits. John Schwartz (NYT)

title: In Like a Lion but Out Like a Lamb
description: CHRIST

title: Letter Sent to Chile Tests Positive for Anthrax
description: A letter mailed to Chile has tested positive for anthrax, the director of a Miami laboratory affiliated with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said yesterday. The agency has not yet verified the finding in its own laboratories.

title: Delegates Meet in First Step Toward Post-Taliban Rule
description: With the fighting in Afghanistan outpacing the effort to shape a post-Taliban order there, representatives of most of the key factions gathered here today for informal consultations before a conference to try to organize a broadly based and representative government.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Burundi: New Offensive Against Rebels
description: Heavy fighting was reported northeast of the capital, Bujumbura, as government soldiers mounted a major offensive to drive back Hutu rebels of the National Liberation Forces from their stronghold in the forested area of Tenga. Ethnic clashes in Burundi dating to 1993 have killed some 250,000 people. The latest fighting broke out after a new government in which Tutsi and Hutu share power was sworn in this month. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Vanguard of Marines Digs In and Directs Air Attacks
description: Just hours after establishing a base in Afghanistan, American marines helped direct air attacks today on an armored column, inaugurating a new phase in the war that will deploy 1,000 American ground troops, Pentagon officials said.

title: Miami and Florida 1-2, but Nothing's Settled
description: Last week, Colorado was 15th in the Bowl Championship Series ranking. After a stunning 62-36 victory over Nebraska on Friday, the Buffaloes vaulted to seventh in the standing, which determines participants in the four major bowl games, including the national championship at the Rose Bowl.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALAKOFF, LOIS MAURER
description: MALAKOFF-Lois Maurer. The Village Temple community mourns the passing of Lois Malakoff. She was Treasurer of the Sisterhood for several years. Beloved wife of Harry and devoted mother of Michelle. Lois was a kind and gentle presence in our community and we will all miss her. Services Tuesday, November 27, 2001 at 11:15 AM at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Susan Jones, President Village Temple Sisterhood

title: Weather Won't Give New York What the Calendar Says Is Here
description: The end of summer came and went. Clocks fell back and the days shortened. The cutout witches and goblins in the windows gave way to fantailed turkeys and now prancing reindeer. But though the sun slants ever lower in the sky, it is still, more often than not, awfully warm out there, and it is getting a little disorienting.

title: Senate to Consider Railroads' Plan to Invest on Wall Street
description: After heavy lobbying by railroads and unions, the Senate was scheduled this week to take up legislation that would allow the federally administered railroad pension system to take its assets out of government bonds for the first time and invest the money on Wall Street.

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Plan for Smallpox Rules Out Mass Vaccination
description: Should smallpox occur in the United States, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention will recommend isolating victims and vaccinating a ''containment ring'' of people exposed to an infected patient rather than mass vaccinations, according to guidelines sent to state health officials.

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of Monday, 3,786 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11.

title: Troops Seize Airstrip NearTaliban Base : U.S. Marines Land in Afghanistan
description: WASHINGTON  Hundreds of U.S. Marines consolidated a bridgehead Monday at an airfield in southern Afghanistan, poised to dramatically increase pressure on the Taliban in their final redoubt of Kandahar and to intensify the hunt for Osama bin Laden.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Rwanda: A Gathering Of Genocide Survivors
description: Rwandan survivors opened an international conference in Kigali with Jews who endured the Holocaust and others who lived through mass killings in the 20th century. ''Every genocide is unique in its own way, though none is absolutely so,'' President Paul Kagame said at the start of the session, which was called ''Life After Death.'' The weeklong gathering, organized by Rwandan Tutsi, who lost more than half a million people to mass killings by Hutu in 1994, drew American Indians, Cambodians and Armenians among others. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: The Neediest Cases; After Losing High Hopes, A Chance to Hope Again
description: There was a time when things looked promising for Gavin Dutchin. It was the early 90's, he had recently graduated from Massachusetts Institute of Technology and had landed his first job on Wall Street, at Cowen & Company, an investment banking firm.

title: Technology Briefing
description: INTERNET

title: Rights to Heart Drug Extended 6 Months
description: AstraZeneca and Merck & Company said today that the Food and Drug Administration had approved six-month extensions of exclusive marketing rights for lisinopril, a heart drug that both companies sell in the United States but under different names.

title: A Harvard Professor's Baffling Vanishing
description: The disappearance of a prominent Harvard biochemist in Memphis earlier this month has baffled his family, friends and law enforcement. But because the professor, Don C. Wiley, is a leading expert on dangerous viruses like Ebola, the mystery of his disappearance has provoked wider attention as well.

title: For Foreign Taliban Prisoners, a Wretched and Uncertain Trip
description: KHOLM, Afghanistan, Nov. 27  Like some lost caravan, the trucks rumbled across the steppe bearing their wretched cargo, 800 Taliban prisoners bound for an uncertain fate.

title: Recreating the Splendor of a French Baroque Church
description: Friday's concert by the New York Collegium Musicum turned the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer, on Lexington Avenue, into a substitute more than three centuries later for St. Louis's, in the Marais district of Paris. The transformation was worked by the music of Marc-Antoine Charpentier, who wrote for that highly musical church.

title: Hungry and Poor (And Right Here)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Practical Way to Make Power From Wasted Heat
description: Scientists at M.I.T. and a small company in Salt Lake City are scheduled to announce today that they have developed technology that can efficiently and inexpensively transform heat pollution into electricity.

title: Star Publisher Lands a Second Act, Causing Many to Wonder About the New Script
description: The Random House division of Bertelsmann named Phyllis E. Grann, departing chief executive of Penguin Putnam, to the newly created position of vice chairman yesterday, fueling speculation among editors and agents that she might seek to lure away some of Penguin Putnam's star authors.

title: U.S. Pressuring Foreign Airlines Over Manifests
description: The United States has told Saudi, Russian, Chinese and other foreign airlines that their passengers arriving in this country will be put through extremely rigorous, lengthy searches, starting Thursday, if the airlines did not provide information needed to identify potential terrorists.

title: The Jets Get Up Off the Couch And Eagerly Go Back to Work
description: Herman Edwards warned his players not to spend too much time on the sofa watching television during the four-day holiday weekend. He did not want the Jets to become engrossed in the endless talk about playoff possibilities.

title: Nurses Strike at Hospital on Long Island
description: More than 450 registered nurses went on strike yesterday at St. Catherine of Siena Medical Center in Smithtown, Suffolk County. But hospital officials said the 273-bed center continued to operate normally, helped in large part by the hiring of 105 replacement nurses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORMAN, SOL
description: FORMAN-Sol. The Trustees and Staff of The Jewish Museum mourn the passing of Sol Forman, beloved father of our devoted Trustee, Amy Rubenstein. Our thoughts and sympathies are with Amy and her husband Howard, and their entire family at this difficult time. Robert J. Hurst, Chairman Joan Rosenbaum, Helen Goldsmith Menschel Dir.

title: Justices Dismiss Case on Affirmative Action
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27  The marquee affirmative action case of the Supreme Court's current term evaporated today when the justices dismissed a constitutional challenge to a federal highway contracting program and conceded that the case had been "improvidently granted."

title: Tests Negative From Near Where Woman Died
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 26  In what has become a frustrating daily double dose of good and bad news, the Connecticut Department of Public Health announced today that several dozen more samples taken from locations near the home of Ottilie W. Lundgren, a 94-year-old woman from Oxford, Conn., who died of inhalation anthrax last week, had all turned out negative for the bacteria.

title: Scientists Ponder Limits On Access to Germ Research
description: With concern about bioterrorism growing, government officials, ethicists and scientists are beginning to grapple with a thorny question -- whether the nation's biologists and biotechnology companies should be regulated, or regulate themselves, to restrict access to information and materials that might be used for biological weapons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENSCHEL, EDNA DAVIS
description: HENSCHEL-Edna Davis, 86. Of Remsenburg, NY, on November 25, of heart failure. Survived by her husband, George F. Henschel, son George F. Henschel, Jr. of Bedford, NY, daughter, Sandra H. McKeveny of Pelham Manor, New York and five grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to East End Hospice, Box 1048, Westhampton Beach, New York 11978.

title: Gas-Guzzling in a Patriotic Age
description: To the Editor:

title: A Nation Challenged
description: On the Ground

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Early Release For Inmates
description: Faced with overcrowded prisons and a backlog of state prisoners in city and county jails, the state's Board of Correction voted to grant early release to 560 inmates. The inmates, all nearing their parole eligibility dates, are to be freed in the next three months. Almost 900 prisoners are backlogged in local jails awaiting transfer to state custody, and recent state budget cuts will not let the correction department open new prisons.

title: Frontiers of Cloning
description: The announcement by a small biotechnology company that it has successfully created a human embryo with cloning techniques may have done as much to hinder as to help this new science. The company's work is at best only a modest advance along the road toward therapeutic cloning, a field that holds great promise for curing a wide range of human ailments, including Alzheimer's, diabetes, heart disease and strokes. But the achievement, which was hyped by the company, almost immediately set off alarms in Congress and the White House.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, HENRY
description: NEWMAN-Henry. Congregation Ahavath Torah of Englewood, NJ, mourns the passing of our esteemed member. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Shmuel Goldin, Rabbi Jeffrey R. Parker, President

title: Stock Exchange Fines Firm $1 Million
description: The American Stock Exchange has fined Spear, Leeds & Kellogg, a unit of the Goldman Sachs Group, $1 million for failing to supervise an executive who was accused of conducting fraudulent trades for a brokerage firm that cleared its trades through Spear.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKS, SALLY H.
description: MARKS-Sally H. On November 15, 2001 at age 89. Survived by Frederick Marks, beloved wife of the late Frank A. Sherer. Loving mother of Dunham B., Sally, Frank A. Jr. and Dr. Clark B. Sherer. Cherished grandmother of Frank Alexei, Miriam, Rick, Frank, Edward, Marie, John, James, Benjamin; and adoring great-grandmother. Interment private. Memorial service at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park ave and 91 St, 11am Saturday December 1st.

title: McCall to Stress Education and Recall His Roots in Speech Ratcheting Up Campaign
description: Harking back to his own poor-child-made-good life story, H. Carl McCall, in the first major speech of his run for governor, will promise to make education the centerpiece of his campaign.

description: WEST

description: Ignoring the Real Issue

title: Baxter International Closes Two Plants
description: Baxter International Inc., a leading maker of treatments for blood diseases, said today that it had shut two plants that made a blood filter possibly linked to the deaths of more than 50 kidney patients worldwide.

title: Boxer Barred and Charged For Sucker Punch After Loss
description: A boxer who punched his opponent after their bout last Friday night and was charged with assault is awaiting a boxing commission hearing that will determine his punishment and whether he will receive his $10,000 purse.

title: U.S. Bomb Wounds G.I.'s as Battle Rages at Fort
description: A battle raged here today between Taliban prisoners and the American-backed troops of the Northern Alliance, and the Bush administration revealed that five Americans had been wounded.

title: In Heart Disease, Head Can Be an Ally
description: Two recent studies offer new evidence that when it comes to fighting heart disease, a patient's state of mind can play an important role.

title: Russia Puts Equipment And Troops Near Kabul
description: Twelve Russian military cargo planes carried equipment and troops to Afghanistan today in what President Vladimir V. Putin called a new stage in Russia's cooperation with the American-led anti-Taliban coalition.

title: A Law Student, a Firefighter Who Played One in Movies, a Cricketer
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Market Place; Stock promoters are sending e-mail ads to users of news sites to push up shares that have little track record.
description: STOCKS of companies that have no history -- or at least no history that they have disclosed to the Securities and Exchange Commission -- are suddenly moving higher as stock promoters put out information that is impossible to verify and, in at least one instance, is apparently false.

title: Sports of The Times; Real Fans Don't Mind Rebuilding
description: THE optimism of starting over permeated Madison Square Garden last night. Marcus Camby was back in the lineup and Jeff Van Gundy was visibly content, if not downright cheerful, to have back the man he extolled as ''a good game-plan player.''

title: Catching the Urban Wave
description: The words ''urban'' and ''Los Angeles'' look uncomfortable in each other's presence, in the same way most Angelenos look uncomfortable in the shoulder-rubbing crowds that other cities take for granted. The region's anti-urban domesticity is its 100-year-old sales pitch, and the success of the pitch to waves of exiles from elsewhere has depended until now on maintaining the carefully planned suburban distances that separate me from my neighbors here. Even 800 square miles of cityscape have failed to evoke the loyalties that real cities demand of their residents.

title: Mediator Named to Run Sept. 11 Fund
description: Attorney General John Ashcroft today appointed Kenneth R. Feinberg, a Democratic lawyer with extensive experience in mediating complex and emotionally charged disputes, to run the multibillion-dollar federal fund set up to compensate the families of those killed or physically injured in the September terrorist attacks.

title: MICHIGAN 'INVITES' MEN FROM MIDEAST TO BE INTERVIEWED
description: Rather than send investigators out knocking on doors, law enforcement officials in Michigan are sending letters today to hundreds of young Middle Eastern men who have come to the United States on temporary visas in the last two years, inviting them to make appointments for interviews regarding the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: For Foreign Taliban Prisoners, a Wretched and Uncertain Trip
description: KHOLM, Afghanistan, Nov. 27  Like some lost caravan, the trucks rumbled across the steppe bearing their wretched cargo, 800 Taliban prisoners bound for an uncertain fate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NATELLI, ANTHONY JR.
description: NATELLI-Anthony Jr. On Novvember 24, 2001. Beloved husband of Joan (nee Schwartz). Loving father of Shari, Anthony IV, Adam and Jennifer. Devoted grandfather of seven. Dear brother of Louis, Michael and Daniel. Family will receive friends at Leo F. Kearns Funeral Home, 61-40 Woodhaven Blvd., Rego Park Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Thursday 11AM. Burial Wellwood Cemetery.

title: Front Row
description: Mrs. Vreeland's Memos

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JONES, MARY MYERS
description: JONES-Mary Myers, 71. Of Albany, NY, November 19 after a courageous battle with cancer. A longtime resident of Woodstock, NY, she was the daughter of the late Howard Myers, publisher of the Architectural Forum, and Louise W. Myers. She attended the Brearley School and Bard College. She is survived by her husband of 48 years, Roger Jones, 4 children; Barbara LaPointe, Sara Jones, Michael Jones, and Nicholas Jones; eight grandchildren; and her sister Barbara Greenwood. Donations in her memory may be made to: The Community Hospice, ''Mary M. Jones Educational Fund'', 295 Valley View Boulevard, Rensselaer, New York 12144.

title: BAUSCH & LOMB GIVEN APPROVAL ON CONTACT LENS USE
description: Bausch & Lomb Inc., a maker of contact lenses and eye-surgery tools, said the Food and Drug Administration extended the length of time users can wear the company's PureVision soft contact lenses to as long as 30 days. The PureVision product was approved in 1999 for as long as one week of continuous use, said the company, which is based in Rochester. There are about 13 million people in the United States eligible to wear the contact lenses, said a spokeswoman, Margaret Graham.

title: Bure Is Expected To Miss Two Games
description: Florida Panthers right wing Pavel Bure, who has led the N.H.L. in goals each of the past two seasons, will miss at least the next two games because of a mild concussion, the club said yesterday.

title: Now Bonds Pose a Problem For Japan's Troubled Banks
description: Japan's largest banks, already plagued by mounting bad loans and sinking stock portfolios, face yet another booby trap: losses on their seemingly benign bond holdings.

title: Fight or Flight? Two Primal Urges at War; With Small Children, Prudence Is the Rule
description: They have seen the twin towers fall, smelled the burned air, maneuvered around police barricades, sensed the intangible but inescapable mood of a city on edge. Now they want out.

title: Spying on Greece's Planes? No, Tourists Say, Just Spotting
description: It is perhaps one of the odder diplomatic rifts between two NATO partners.

title: Watch Exports Rose in October
description: Swiss watch exports rebounded in October from September's drop, advancing 6 percent to 1.14 billion Swiss francs ($690 million) because of higher demand for platinum and plastic models.

title: She Spoke for Taliban And Now Pays a Price
description: Until Sept. 11, the most vocal advocate in the United States for the Taliban was a woman.

title: Surgeons Need Steady Hand, and Sleep
description: A single night on call can impair a surgeon's steadiness of hand, leading to possibly serious mistakes, a new study reports.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CAPLAN, RONALD J.
description: CAPLAN-Ronald J. Remembering you on your birthday and always. With love, Mom and Dad

title: Corrections
description: An explanatory note yesterday and on Sunday with the continuations of front-page articles about the effect of AIDS on a community in South Africa referred incorrectly in most copies to the country's percentage ranking for adults infected with the virus that causes AIDS. While South Africa has the largest number, 4.2 million, the infection rate is not the highest for any country, according to the United Nations. Botswana has the highest, with 35.8 percent infected in 1999. South Africa, with 19.9 in 1999, ranked fifth.

title: Dazed and Confused Giants Get Some Welcome Days Off
description: In the wake of the Giants' most demoralizing defeat of the season, Coach Jim Fassel today stood by his belief that his team would win its remaining five games.

title: Four Factions Begin Talks on Interim Afghan Government
description: BONN, Nov. 27  Under considerable international pressure to act quickly, four Afghan factions began talks today on the establishment of a representative, interim administration that can begin to govern an Afghanistan still at war.

title: 24 Songs From Schubert, Without the Usual Tornado
description: Beauty isn't a word that always applies to a baritone voice: strong, powerful or resonant is a more expected accolade. But while all of these words could be used to describe Sanford Sylvan's voice, its most striking quality is sheer beauty, emerging in sudden flashes in rich, dark low notes or the majesty of full high fortes.

title: The Home Front, Through a Child's Eyes
description: To the Editor:

title: Oil Prices Decline on Pessimism Over Russian Production Cuts
description: Crude oil prices fell yesterday on speculation that Russia would not reduce its output beyond the 50,000 barrels a day it has already set for this year, a 0.7 percent decline that is about a quarter of what OPEC wants to help counteract slowing demand.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CIECIUCH, HELENA M.
description: CIECIUCH-Helena M. On Nov. 26, 2001 at the Mary Manning Walsh Home, New York City. Wife of the late Leon Robert Cieciuch. Mother of the late L. Robert (Cieciuch) Charles, Sr. Jorene Cieciuch, O.P. of Manhattan and Richard T. Cieciuch, Sr. of Oyster Bay. In addition to her children, Mrs. Cieciuch leaves behind six grand children and twelve great grandchildren. Wake at the Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 1st Avenue at 70 St., N.Y., Wednesday, 2-4 and 7-9PM. Funeral Mass Thursday, 10:30AM in the Mary Manning Walsh Home Chapel, 72 St at York Ave. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery, Arlington, N.J. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation, 60 East 42 St, Suite 1563, N.Y., N.Y. 10165, would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMAN, DAVID
description: HERMAN-David, 88. Nov. 25. Died peacefully at home after a courageous battle with Leukemia. Beloved husband of Florence for 56 years. Loving father of Paul & Lauren Herman, Randi & Michael Applebaum. Adoring Poppy to Rachel, Matthew, Brett & Breton. Devoted brother to Della Kraus, the late Lester Herman and brother - in - law Robert Greenes. David touched the lives of all he knew with his warmth, wisdom and endearing smile. In his true entrepreneurial spirit his career spanned for more than 60 years from manufacturing to president and CEO of Publicker Industries where at the age of 70 he held that leadership position for ten years. He also served on numerous boards. He will remain in the hearts and memories of all his many friends and family. Donations may be made to the American Cancer Society, or Hospice Care of Westchester and Putnam County. Funeral services will be held Tuesday, November 27, 10 AM at Temple Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Avenue, White Plains.

title: Muslim Women as Symbols -- and Pawns
description: On the morning of Nov. 20, the world awoke to the promise of a new era in Afghanistan, reflected in the hasty retreat of the Taliban from Kabul and the timid smiles of Afghan women emerging from beneath their burkas.

title: Brosius to Retire After Four Seasons With Yankees
description: Scott Brosius felt the pull from his Oregon home throughout his four seasons with the Yankees, perhaps never more than on the afternoon of Sept. 11. His 9-year-old daughter, Allison, got on the phone and told him how she really wanted the family to be together, and Brosius fretted about being away.

title: Bankruptcy Auction Begins for Speech Technology Company
description: The bankruptcy auction for the assets of Lernout & Hauspie, a once highflying Belgian speech technology company, started yesterday afternoon at a New York law office. The proceedings, which could be over as soon as today, are expected to produce only a fraction of the hundreds of millions of dollars that Lernout & Hauspie owes.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: It Takes a Thief

title: Violinist Guides His Audience Across a Changing Landscape
description: Samuel Barber's Violin Concerto mediates between the 20th century's kinder beginnings and the increasing anger of the times. Written just as World War II was gathering its terrible energies, and spotlessly played by Joshua Bell and the New York Philharmonic on Wednesday night, Barber's first movement is gentle, songful lyricism; his second, equally gentle songfulness building to almost melodramatic climaxes; the third, busier, rapid-fire and tough. Much is made of the split between the first two-thirds of this piece and its ending, but here Mr. Bell convinced listeners at Avery Fisher Hall of a natural, if not wholly pleasant, transition.

title: Corrections
description: A biographical sketch on Wednesday about Sharon Balkcom, a World Trade Center victim whose aptitude for mathematics as a girl in Harlem led her to some of the city's most selective schools and a career as a computer systems manager with Marsh & McLennan, misstated the location of the Robert F. Wagner Jr. Middle School, which she attended. It is on East 76th Street in Manhattan, not on the Upper West Side.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Competition For Miner
description: AngloGold, which is vying with the Newmont Mining Corporation for Normandy Mining, an Australian company, is formally challenging its rival through the Australian Takeover Panel. The comparative analysis that ''Newmont has presented in selling its offer and its characterization of AngloGold are misleading,'' said AngloGold's executive director, Jonathan Best. AngloGold's earnings and production costs outpace Newmont's, he said. In addition, conditions in Newmont's merger proposal, which also involves Franco-Nevada Mining of Canada, contravene Australian takeover law, Mr. Best said. The company will ask the panel to remove some conditions in Newmont's bid. AngloGold said it might also start legal proceedings in Canada. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: National Briefing | West: Hawaii: Tourism Suffers After Attacks
description: The number of visitors to Hawaii fell more than 30 percent in the first full month after Sept. 11, putting the state's year-to-date figures 7 percent behind those of last year. Visitors from Japan were the scarcest, with 54 percent fewer than in the previous October. Tourism accounts for a quarter of Hawaii's economy, and analysts estimate that a 30 percent drop for the fourth quarter could cost the state 25,000 jobs and $1 billion. The state will spend an additional $10 million on marketing through March to try to stem the drop. Michele Kayal (NYT)

title: Grants to Help Post-Traumatic Stress
description: On Sept. 11, as schoolchildren across the country learned of the attack on the twin towers, there was a rush of students in Jerry Kerne's sixth-grade class asking to go to the bathroom. Actually, they just wanted to look out the hall window and see the smoking towers for themselves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULLIVAN, KENNETH H.
description: SULLIVAN-Kenneth H., 50. Of York Harbor, ME. died November 24, 2001 as a result of an automobile accident. Beloved husband of Sharon (Tyska) & devoted father of Nolan, Nicholas, and Kyle. You will be missed beyond words. Funeral Mass will be held 11AM Wednesday in Saint Christopher Church, York St., York Harbor, ME. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the charity of one's choice. For information Lucas and Eaton Funeral Home, York.
