title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Online Shopping Strengthens
description: Suggesting the holiday shopping rush is not merely the domain of the bricks-and-mortar world, a survey released yesterday indicates that Internet retailers enjoyed a sharp uptick in business on the day after Thanksgiving. The survey, from Nielsen/NetRatings, which researches Internet traffic patterns, found that 22 percent more Internet users shopped online on Friday, compared with the average number of shoppers during the four previous days. Still, the increase was smaller than last year, when the post-Thanksgiving shopping was up 27 percent from the average of the preceding days. Nielsen also said that this year's survey found that virtual department stores had a particular rise in traffic. The survey found that Amazon.com had 1.69 million visitors on Friday, a 32 percent rise from the previous Friday; Wal-Mart Stores, with 355,000 visitors, was up 132 percent; and Target, with 227,000 visitors, had an increase in traffic of 152 percent. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LESHEFSKY, YOCHANAN
description: LESHEFSKY-Yochanan. Jewish educator. Beloved by all. November 27, 1961

title: Massachusetts School Opens After Bomb-Plot Arrests
description: Classes resumed today at New Bedford High School after a holiday weekend in which three students were charged with plotting an attack on the school that the police said was intended to be bloodier than the 1999 killings at Columbine High School.

title: Talking About Trauma
description: To the Editor:

title: Norman Granz, Who Took Jazz Out of Smoky Clubs and Put It in Concert Halls, Dies at 83
description: Norman Granz, the gruff impresario who in 1944 created Jazz at the Philharmonic, a touring group that took the jazz idiom out of the smoky, noisy bars and dance halls and tucked it into sumptuous concert halls where it flourished, died on Thursday in Geneva, where he had lived, mostly in retirement, since 1959. He was 83.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Chip Maker Raises Profit Forecast
description: Taiwan's largest chip maker, the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, raised its forecast for pretax profits, saying it had received a surge in customer orders. The company, which is viewed as a bellwether for Asian technology companies, estimated that it would report a profit of $271 million on sales of $3.64 billion in 2001. In September, it had forecast net income of $170 million. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: Saudis Balk At Request On Accounts
description: Saudi Arabia is balking at American requests to freeze the bank accounts of those the United States says are linked to terrorism, Saudi and American officials said today. The Saudis' hesitancy has prompted the Bush administration to prepare to send a delegation to the kingdom to discuss the standoff.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARRETT, WILLIAM L.
description: BARRETT-William L. On November 23, 2001, at age 66. Former Vice President of D.L. Elliman & Co. and later President of William L. Barrett, Real Estate Corp. Loving father of Jason, Eleanor, and grandfather of Elizabeth, Lauren and Danielle. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Monday and Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, with services Wednesday, 9:30 AM. Interment to follow at Cemetery of The Gate of Heaven. Contributions in his memory may be made to the American Heart Assocation, Heritage Affiliate, 2550 US Highway 1, New Brunswick, NJ 08902.

title: Torre's Role Is Familiar In Yanks' Pursuit of Giambi
description: Mike Mussina signed with the Yankees last year after a phone call from Manager Joe Torre swayed him, and yesterday Torre joined in the team's pursuit of the free-agent slugger Jason Giambi, speaking to him by telephone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLOTKIN, FREDERICK SHELDON, PH.D.
description: PLOTKIN - Frederick Sheldon, Ph.D. Born May 25, 1937, grew up on the Lower East Side of Manhattan where he studied violin at the Henry Street Settlement House and once played at Carnegie Hall. Considered a child prodigy, he was offered a scholarship to Harvard which was not accepted because his parents felt he was too young. He attended Stuyvesant High School, and then left for France where he soon found work as a journalist for a major Paris newspaper. After returning to the U.S. he received his B.A. magna cum laude in 1961 and M.A. in Mathematics in 1962 from Columbia University. In 1966, he received his Ph.D. in Literature and the History of Ideas from Columbia where he was a recipient of a Ford Foundation Fellowship and President's Fellowship (1964-66). Dr. Plotkin taught at Columbia College and held professorships at SUNY Buffalo and Yeshiva University where he was Director of the Humanities Division. He has published several books on the philosophy of religion, including Faith and Reason, and Judaism and Tragic Theology which won the Best Book in America Philosophy and Religion Award from the American Philosophical Society in 1974 and from the American Library Association the same year. Dr. Plotkin is also the author of the Milton study, Inward Jerusalem, which explores the philosophic activity of Paradise Lost. He was for several years a contributor to the Encyclopedia Britannica, and for a number of years wrote book, art and film reviews for a variety of national magazines, including Commentary, Film Quarterly and Musical America. One of the last of the ''great romantics,'' he has had numerous poems published in the Minnesota Review, the Cimarron Review, and North American Review, among others. In the early 1960s he was one of three founders of Meridian Books, the first quality paper-back publishing company in America and he served as the firm's editor until it was sold. In 1980 Dr. Plotkin conceived his brainchild, Comtex Scientific Corporation, one of the first to put research data online to telecommunications networks, a company which he took public in 1981. Though ill since his retirement from both the academic and business worlds, he continued to write until he died. He is survived by his beloved wife Kathy Lyles Plotkin, of New York City (also a writer) and his beloved son Avi of Haines, Alaska, his child from a previous marriage. Fred was known as ''Shel'' to his family and ''Shepsel'' (Yiddish for ''little lamb'') by his wife. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue at 76th Street on November 28, 2001 at 11:30 am. Burial following will be in the family plot at Riverside Cemetery in Saddlebrook, New Jersey.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: More Cuts At Isuzu
description: Isuzu Motors, the Japanese automaker (General Motors owns 49 percent), lost 24 billion yen ($193 million) in the half-year that Sept. 30. Isuzu's sales fell 6.5 percent in the first half of the fiscal year as it struggled to compete with rivals like the Toyota Motor Corporation and Honda Motor. To compensate, Isuzu will eliminate an additional 3,300 jobs. The company expects to lose 25 billion yen in the full year to March 2002, the third consecutive loss. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEROLD, JUDITH (NEE WINOGRAD)
description: HEROLD-Judith (nee Winograd). Nov. 25, 2001. Wife of Seymour, of Cherry Hill, NJ. Mother of Stuart (Patricia) Herold and David (Lynn) Pravda. Grandmother of Samantha, Gillian, Douglas and Jacqueline. Relatives and friends are invited to services Tuesday 10:30 AM, Platt Memorial Chapels, Inc, 2001 Berlin Rd., Cherry Hill, NJ. Interment Cedar Park Cemetery.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: More Brands For Computer Associates
description: The software manufacturer Computer Associates International, which was criticized during a proxy fight this year for supposedly having a confusing array of products, said yesterday that it would market its corporate software under six brands, up from four. The company has 1,244 products that run on mainframe and server computers, Kenneth F. Fitzpatrick, its chief marketing officer, said. The six brands cover areas the company considers the biggest challenges of corporate customers: databases, business intelligence, developing new applications, securing networks, storing data and managing networks. ''There wasn't a lot of clarity in what business sectors we played in,'' Mr. Fitzpatrick said in an interview. ''It's a further simplification of who we are.'' In August, shareholders defeated an attempt by the Texas billionaire Sam Wyly to gain one-third of the seats on the company's board. He argued that the company had too many products, and initially said it needed four independent business units, one each for security, data storage, databases and network management. The company argued that it was already focusing on those four areas and that separate units would be unnecessarily costly.

title: All's Well As Camby Jump-Starts The Knicks
description: The return began with Mark Jackson penetrating the lane, attracting attention and passing to an open Marcus Camby. With a force not seen by a Knick since the last time he played, Camby left the floor like a rocket and dunked two-handed over a helpless Atlanta Hawks defender.

title: Islanders Appreciate Decibels of Success
description: The volume has been turned up almost to full blast at Nassau Coliseum. The Islanders are winning, and the fans finally have a good team to cheer. But that is only part of the story. There are a lot more fans in the stands, and a lot more fans tend to make a lot more noise.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: AT&T Drops Low-Cost Service
description: Signaling another vote of no confidence in free or advertiser-supported Internet access, AT&T has informed customers that it plans to discontinue its low-cost Internet service, i495, beginning Jan. 4. Subscribers who were paying $4.95 a month for 150 hours of Internet access will automatically be switched to a plan offering 50 hours of access time for $10.95 a month. They can also choose to maintain 150 hours of Internet access for $16.95 a month or upgrade to an unlimited access plan for $21.95 a month, and receive a $25 gift certificate redeemable at Amazon.com. The discontinued plan, introduced in July 2000, was subsidized by advertisements that appeared on screen while subscribers were online. But with the downturn in Internet advertising, which has led to the closing of several free access services, an AT&T spokeswoman said yesterday that the low-cost business model was no longer sustainable. AT&T's other Internet access plans do not carry similar advertising. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: Help for Those Willing to Kick a Habit
description: One might expect that smokers who decide to have themselves checked for lung cancer with a CAT scan must also be giving some serious thought to giving up cigarettes.

title: Corrections
description: An explanatory note yesterday and on Sunday with the continuations of front-page articles about the effect of AIDS on a community in South Africa referred incorrectly in most copies to the country's percentage ranking for adults infected with the virus that causes AIDS. While South Africa has the largest number, 4.2 million, the infection rate is not the highest for any country, according to the United Nations. Botswana has the highest, with 35.8 percent infected in 1999. South Africa, with 19.9 in 1999, ranked fifth.

title: Bus Drivers Say Trip Across Bandit Region Was 200 Hellish Miles
description: Hundreds of square miles of southern Afghanistan around the Taliban stronghold in Kandahar are empty, lawless, no man's lands ruled by wayward gunmen and local rulers beholden to no central authority, according to bus drivers who arrived here today after traveling across the area.

title: Bo Belinsky, 64, the Playboy Pitcher, Dies
description: Bo Belinsky, whose pitching prowess as a rookie with the Los Angeles Angels catapulted him to the life of a Hollywood playboy and the fleeting glitter of a 1960's celebrity, died Friday at his home in Las Vegas. He was 64.

title: Indiana Utility Deal
description: NiSource Inc., the owner of Indiana's largest gas and electric utility, agreed to sell its Indianapolis Water unit to the City of Indianapolis for $515 million, meeting a demand by federal regulators.

title: FOUR COMPANIES JOIN ROLLS-ROYCE ENGINE PROJECT
description: Rolls-Royce P.L.C., a leading maker of jet engines, said yesterday that Honeywell International Inc., the Goodrich Corporation and units of Fiat S.p.A. and the United Technologies Corporation had agreed to share the development costs of its Trent 900 engine. The companies are joining Volvo A.B. of Sweden, which became a partner in May, Rolls-Royce said. The Trent 900 is being developed to power the four-engine Airbus SAS A380 superjumbo airliner, which is due to enter service in 2006. Honeywell will supply the engine's pneumatic system, while Goodrich will produce the rear and center portions of the fan case. The contract is valued at $1 billion over the expected 25-year life of the A380, said Bill Reavis, a spokesman for Honeywell.

title: The New York Skyline
description: The New York skyline was dramatically changed on September 11, and it will change again as the city rebuilds. Here is a collection of articles about architecture and New York.

title: Conflict Ends A Relationship
description: Reckitt Benckiser in London said yesterday that it had agreed to part ways with offices of the McCann-Erickson World Group, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, on its worldwide creative account because of a conflict with another large Interpublic client, SC Johnson.

title: Restless Legs: Treatable, if Recognized
description: At least 12 million people in this country have a condition affecting their limbs that could give even the calmest among them the heebie-jeebies. It goes by the exceedingly apt name of restless legs syndrome and is characterized by a variety of discomforting sensations that occur at rest and compel sufferers to get up and move around.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Sunday about the potential use of military tribunals and other special methods to investigate and prosecute terrorism misstated the given name of a former deputy solicitor general who supported the use of tribunals. He is Philip Allen Lacovara, not Phillip.

title: New York Needs Relief
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE MONTMOLLIN, LAURENT GUILLAUME
description: de MONTMOLLIN-Laurent Guillaume. Beloved brother of Edmee de M. Firth, step-brother of Robin McKinney Martin, cherished uncle of Marie-Louise and John Slocum and Olivia Beckwith-Smith. Son of the late Marielle McKinney and Henry de Montmollin. Age 52. Died unexpectedly of a heart attack at his home in Tampa, FL, on November 17. Funeral service and burial on December 10, at Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Middleburg, VA.

title: Metropolitan Flavor In Round of 16
description: Shalrie Joseph and St. John's Coach Dave Masur believe that sometimes to move forward you have to be willing to move backward first.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Clinton: Mother Who Killed Newborn Is Freed
description: Melissa Drexler, who admitted strangling her newborn son in 1997 after giving birth in a bathroom stall at her senior prom, was released yesterday after the parole board determined that she did not pose a threat to the public. She had pleaded guilty to aggravated manslaughter and served three years of a 15-year sentence in state prison. Ms. Drexler, 23, will be on parole until October 2008. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Hurricanes' Buchanon Might Be the Best of the Best
description: Art Kehoe, the University of Miami offensive line coach, was showing several people around the football offices when he noticed Hurricane cornerback Phillip Buchanon talking to someone in the hallway.

title: Nepal Curbs Rights After Maoist Attacks
description: After attacks by Maoist rebels that peaked this morning, Nepal's constitutional monarch, King Gyanendra, declared a state of emergency tonight, suspending most civil liberties and authorizing the 50,000-man army to join the police in battling the five-year old insurgency.

title: Before Sept. 11, Spain's Police Kept Eye on Terror Suspects
description: Police officers carrying out surveillance of two Spain-based Islamic terror cells working in Osama bin Laden's network saw the groups' two leaders approach each other on a Madrid street, shake hands and carry on a conversation in what the police believe was intended to be a clandestine meeting.

title: Public Feuding At Pension Fund; Dirty Laundry Keeps Flying At Calpers, No. 1 Plan in U.S.
description: If the governing board of the nation's largest and most influential public pension plan were being judged by the standards it sets for the companies it invests in, it might be calling for a shake-up.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Friends Can Observe Vote
description: Justice Minister Patrick Chinamasa told Parliament that the government would invite election observers from friendly countries to assess the coming presidential election, expected early next year. He emphasized that the observers would not be from groups or countries that have called for sanctions against Zimbabwe, which has been criticized for harassing opposition members, white farmers and journalists. ''We cannot allow people who are our enemies to come to our soil,'' Mr. Chinamasa said. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Research offers insights on the mood of college students since Sept. 11.
description: THE Sept. 11 terrorist attacks have not significantly dampened young Americans' purchasing plans, but they have made them more cynical about advertisers' intentions, according to several surveys.

title: Gas-Guzzling in a Patriotic Age
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUSACK, JOHN
description: CUSACK-John. Our deepest sympathy is extended to the family of John Cusack, a former Administrator of Personnel and Employee Relations. His concern for the morale of the System's employees was heartfelt and his knowledge of labor law outstanding. He was a deeply religious man who practiced the basic tenets of Christianity. He will be sorely missed. John S.T. Gallagher, CEO Roy J. Zuckerberg, Chairman, Board of Trustees North Shore-LIJ Health System

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINBERG, IRWIN L.
description: FEINBERG-Irwin L. Died Sunday, November 25, 2001. Beloved husband of Helen. Cherished father of Phyllis Feinberg and Marjorie Feinberg Clark and father-in-law of the late Fred Clark. Adored grandfather of Everitt and Emily Clark. Dear brother of Joyce Zankel. Private graveside service Tuesday.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Congressman To Step Down
description: Representative Bob Schaffer declared in his home district, Fort Collins, that he would not seek re-election next year. Mr. Schaffer, a Republican who was first elected in 1996, said he was honoring a pledge to serve only three terms. He ran unopposed in the general election last year and has previously said the pledge was a mistake but now says it is important to keep it. A local lawyer, Jeff Bedingfield, has said he would seek the Republican nomination if Mr. Schaffer did not run; Angie Paccione, an assistant professor at Colorado State University, has said she will seek the Democratic nomination. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Marines in Afghanistan's South, Riots in North, Invitations in Michigan
description: The arrival of United States marines at a desert base near the Taliban stronghold of Kandahar effectively opened a southern front in the Afghan war, distinct in purpose and means from the battle fronts north of the Hindu Kush mountains.

title: Careful Plan Devised for Anthrax Letter
description: Forensic scientists have formulated an elaborate plan for opening the anthrax-contaminated letter found more than a week ago that was addressed to Patrick J. Leahy, chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, law enforcement officials said today.

title: Enron Talking With Dynegy As They Work To Rescue Deal
description: The Enron Corporation and its would-be rescuer, Dynegy Inc., are renegotiating the terms of their deal, originally valued at $9 billion, executives close to the discussions said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about objections made by the Altria Healthcare Corporation to Philip Morris's decision to assume the name Altria Group misstated the Latin word that Philip Morris said was the basis of the name. It is altus, meaning high, not altrus.

title: Bloomberg, in Dominican Republic, Meets With Crash Victims' Relatives
description: The mayor-elect of New York landed here today in his private jet, then rode in a full motorcade to the Palacio Nacional, the center of the federal government, where he swept past a large gaggle of reporters outside. Inside, he was ushered with little ceremony into a large conference room, and seemed a bit stunned to see about 25 Dominicans whose loved ones were killed in the crash of American Airlines Flight 587.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Fund For Queens Air Crash
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that the city had started a charity to raise money for the families of those killed when a plane crashed in the Belle Harbor section of Queens. Two hundred and sixty-five people died on Nov. 12 when American Airlines Flight 587 crashed on its way to the Dominican Republic. The fund will be administered by the same nonprofit organization that is operating the Twin Towers Fund, a charity for relatives of victims of the World Trade Center terrorist attack. The new fund is called the Flight 587 Relief Fund and donations can be sent to General Post Office, P.O. Box 26878, New York, N.Y. 10087. Chase Bank is administering the deposits. Sarah Kershaw (NYT)

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Ex-Penguin Putnam Chief Is Moving to Random House

title: Metro Briefing | New York: New Rochelle: Amtrak Service Restored
description: Normal service was restored yesterday to Amtrak's Washington-New York-Boston route after a Sunday rail accident outside New York City cut off power and delayed trains for hours. A derailed CSX Corporation freight train hit a pole connected to an electrical supply wire, leading to a power failure that affected 10 miles of Amtrak-owned tracks from New York City to New Rochelle. Passengers traveling between New York and Boston on Sunday faced delays of more than two hours, as diesel engines were temporarily used to tow the electric trains to their stations.

title: What's Death To a Mother With Work To Be Done?
description: Fanny Stern is not a mother who turns in her grave when her son goes astray after she's gone; she climbs out of it and comes back to set things straight. The confusion she produces among the living makes for a great deal of laughter in Eduardo Rovner's play ''Volvi Una Noche'' (''She Returned One Night''). The comedy, which opens Repertorio Espaol's festival of Jewish Latin American theater, is a collaboration between the New York company and Teatro Andamio 90 in Argentina, headed by Alejandro Samek, who directs this production.

title: Gas-Guzzling in a Patriotic Age
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLIOTT, MARGARET K.
description: ELLIOTT-Margaret K. Of Key Biscayne, FL, and Mt. Kisco, NY, died at home on Nov. 22. The wife of Michael S., and the beloved mother of Jessica and Michael C. Elliott. Margaret was the daughter of Marguerite Kirby and the late Charles F. Kirby. She is also survived by her sister Marie Brennan, brother Captain John Kirby and many loving nieces and nephews. A Memorial Mass will celebrate her life at St. Francis of Assisi Church in Mt. Kisco, Wednesday, November 28, 2001, at 11 A.M. A second Memorial Mass will be celebrated at St. Agnes Church, Key Biscayne, Friday, Dec. 7, at a time to be determined. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Westchester Exceptional Children's School, 520 Route 22, North Salem, NY 10560, or The Vincent J. Fontana Center for Child Protection, New York Foundling Hospital, 590 6th Ave, New York, NY 10011, celebrating Margaret's love of children and her many years of work for children and their families.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: 4 Movers Accused Of Fraud
description: Four Brooklyn moving companies were accused by state officials of bilking customers out of tens of thousands of dollars through false advertising, fraud and other offenses. The attorney general's office and the Department of Transportation said yesterday that they had sued the four companies for what the officials said were ''low ball'' cost estimates that were followed by inflated bills with ''significant and undisclosed fees.'' A court hearing is scheduled Dec. 13. The firms -- the Best American Movers, A&M Affordable Movers, Atlantis Movers and Aaaa All Right Moving -- could not be reached for comment because a temporary restraining order led to the disconnecting of their telephone lines. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Making Christmas Cookies the Right Way
Surrounded by Radiation
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Our Towns; A Newborn In the Trash, On the Mind
description: ''YEAH, it's kind of a miracle,'' Detective Joe Lamparelli was saying into the phone to the man from the state prosecutor's office. On normal days in this quiet suburb, the detective might work a bad-check case or a burglary. But since Friday, he's been going nonstop on the case of the abandoned newborn boy, found alive after spending the first five hours of life in a restroom garbage can at the Red Colony Diner.

title: Science, Morality and Cloning
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Shots Exchanged In DMZ
description: A North Korean soldier fired two or three bullets at a South Korean outpost in the demilitarized zone about 25 miles northeast of Seoul, officials said, and South Korean forces immediately returned fire. There were no casualties and the North did not fire back, according to the South Korean defense ministry. It was the first such incident in more than three years in the zone, which has divided the Korean peninsula since the signing of a Korean War truce in 1953. Cabinet-level talks between the Koreas this month ended abruptly and the North recently accused South Korean troops of moving two armored vehicles into the zone. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Envoy Forges Bonds and Reaps Benefits
description: In the anxious, early days of the American-led relief mission in Somalia in 1992, Gen. Anthony C. Zinni defused tensions by meeting daily over sandwiches with Gen. Mohammed Farah Aidid, a powerful Somali clan leader, to allow him to air grievances and to earn the warlord's trust.

title: New Pollution Rules
description: To the Editor:

title: Ground Broken for Fish Market
description: Work has begun on a new Fulton Fish Market in the Bronx to replace the historic but cramped market in Lower Manhattan.

title: U.S. Sees Limited Mission In Postwar Afghanistan
description: The United States is seeking to avoid future military obligations in Afghanistan once its mission to defeat the Taliban government and destroy Al Qaeda's terrorist network is over, a senior administration official said today.

title: Belgian Hope In Software Sells Assets At Auction
description: The speech technology empire that Lernout & Hauspie had cobbled together was dismantled Monday night in a somber bankruptcy auction at a law office in Lower Manhattan.

title: Reservists Drop What They Were Doing to Join the Fight
description: Shane Fink had almost made it through the morning of his first day at a new job when the secretary waved him over. Just like that, he sighed, he was a corporal in the Marine Corps again.

title: A Secret Trial: It's Not Our Way
description: To the Editor:

title: From Jihad To Thoughts Of Studying Computers
description: At least on the outside, Mullah Amirjan Selabe had already begun to reinvent himself. After slipping across the border out of Afghanistan, he unfurled the Taliban's telltale black turban, replacing it with a gray one with white stripes.

title: Lawmakers Break an Impasse on Education
description: Senate and House negotiators moved closer today to compromising on an education bill as four top lawmakers tentatively agreed on student testing and on a formula to give states and school districts more control over federal money.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HOROWITZ, SARAH GAYER
description: HOROWITZ-Sarah Gayer November 28, 1967. You are always in my heart Mommy. Your Baby

title: Science, Morality and Cloning
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Following Up column on Sunday about the whereabouts of Amy Fisher, the Long Island student who shot Mary Jo Buttafuoco in 1992, misstated the location of her school, John F. Kennedy High. It is in Bellmore, N.Y., not Merrick.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Somalia: The 'Forgotten Emergency'
description: The United Nations called on countries to step up aid to Somalia, describing the situation there as a ''forgotten emergency.'' The country's woes are many, ranging from civil conflict to food shortages to economic collapse stemming from the closing of some of Somalia's remittance banks because of suspected terrorist ties. ''Global events have placed emphasis on the need for the international community to assist societies undergoing violent social and economic transition,'' the United Nations said in a statement issued in neighboring Kenya. ''Nowhere is this more important than Somalia.'' Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: The New Regulation
description: Following are the text of a new regulation on the detention of immigrants, issued by Attorney General John Ashcroft for the Immigration and Naturalization Service on Oct. 26, and excerpts from a Justice Department background paper on the regulation:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RAINE, SYDONIA
description: RAINE-Sydonia. November 28, 1999. In loving memory we are keeping an eye out for each other. You are forever in our hearts. Murray, Caren, Josh, Bonnie, Alan & Coli

title: Political Memo; Cash, Race and Rancor? No, It's Not the Mayoral Race
description: New Yorkers have just watched a political race that featured harsh attacks, racial divisions, piles of money, a badly fragmented Democratic Party and enormous challenges for the eventual winner.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARRY, ELI
description: BARRY-Eli. Of Cranford, NJ. Former partner with Fedway and Perrone Liquor Distributors of Kearny, NJ. Husband of the late Leona (Reisfeld) Barry. Father of Douglas and the late Russell Barry. Brother of Martin Barry, brother-in-law of Ted and Carole Reiss and Elaine Barry. Uncle of Scott and Harmon Barry and Mark and David Reiss. Great uncle of Shana and Robert Reiss. Services are at Higgins and Bonner Echo Lake Funeral Home, 582 Springfield Ave, Westfield, NJ, Thursday, November 29, 1 P.M. Interment Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, NJ.

title: What New York Will Have to Give Up
description: By now, only the most inattentive New Yorker could be unaware of the multibillion-dollar budget deficit awaiting the new mayor. Add to that well-known financial worry another, less visible one: an onerous $40 billion debt load.

title: Fordham's Hill Says He Is Feeling Well
description: When Coach BOB HILL missed Fordham's first game, the university announced that he was having minor surgery. He has not missed either of the Rams' games since, but Hill announced yesterday that the surgery was anything but small.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Science Times on Nov. 6 about a yellow fever epidemic in 1793 in Philadelphia, then the nation's capital, misstated the death toll. About 5,000 people died, not 55,000.

title: Police Teamwork: A Perennial Right-Hand Man
description: THE years come, the years go, and there are special moments in a relationship that somehow, even apart, you both remember.

title: MY JOB; Up to My Ears in Medical Claims
description: Although my workweek is long, my commute is very short, just 28 steps. I run my own business, a medical billing service, from home. My business comes from referrals. I meet with doctors when they are either going into a practice or changing their affiliation. It is a long process; one that takes many months of follow-up.

title: BULLETIN BOARD; Bronx Science Tries Ads
description: Calling itself ''the Ivy League High School,'' the Bronx High School of Science is advertising this week in several newspapers, including The Wall Street Journal and The Village Voice, trumpeting its five alumni who became Nobel laureates and its 17 Intel finalists last year. Bronx Science, one of New York City's most prestigious public schools, has seldom had an image problem, but wanted to promote itself before prospective students choose a high school, partly because of the controversy surrounding the Board of Education's protracted search for a principal. The new principal, VALERIE REIDY, said: ''It's a very mild reminder that we're still as focused as we always were. We're still here and doing what we do best: educating gifted children.'' Peter Valdina

title: Piazza's Wish Is Another Slugger
description: When Mike Piazza talked with Steve Phillips shortly after the Mets' season ended, the conversation probably sounded like one between a child and a department store Santa Claus.

title: Statistics, a Tool for Life, Is Getting Short Shrift
description: MANY educators want all high school seniors prepared for calculus. That means taking algebra in the eighth grade and covering geometry, intermediate algebra and trigonometry by the junior year. This leaves too little room for study of statistics and probability.

title: Shore Leave Is Casualty, Too; Foreign Sailors Must Stay Aboard Ships in New York
description: Yanis Matthews, 55, the captain of this international cargo vessel, is a pious and superstitious man. An icon of St. Nikolas, the sailor's patron, hangs in his wheelhouse, and when the weather blows rough over his bow, he will kiss the icon with his fingers and cross himself in the manner prescribed by the Greek Orthodox Church.

title: Accusations Against 93 Vary Widely
description: The federal criminal charges against 93 people in the terrorist investigation range from relatively minor counts that seem to have only the most tenuous connection to terrorism to a few that involve actions that would raise suspicions in any climate.

title: Technology Briefing
description: INTERNET

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Wireless Phone Recall
description: NTT DoCoMo, which unveiled the world's first third-generation mobile phone network in October, will recall 1,500 handsets because of software glitches. The phones were made by the NEC Corporation and were erasing e-mail messages and other data when certain Web sites were called up. It was the first failure for DoCoMo's 3G service, which allows users to download video and audio files to their phones. The company has initially limited its service to only a few thousand customers.

title: Washington Hotel Savings
description: The Swissotel Washington, The Watergate, has a space problem: over half its 250 rooms are suites. To help get guests into these accommodations, it will upgrade them into a suite for $199 a night (a lot easier than, say, breaking into one). The offer is good through Dec. 31. The hotel also offers free transfers to and from Dulles and Ronald Reagan airports, a health club and an indoor pool. Information: (888) 737-9477 or www.swissotel.com .

title: Kmart's Adjusted Loss Almost Doubles but Is Less Than Forecast
description: The Kmart Corporation posted a wider quarterly loss yesterday as it struggled to reinvent itself in a shriveling economy, and its credit rating was lowered further below investment grade.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: 13 Die In Kashmir Battle
description: An Indian Army spokesman in the state of Jammu and Kashmir said at least five soldiers and eight Islamic militants had been killed in a gun battle in the Surankot district after an army convoy was attacked in a forest. He blamed Lashkar-e-Toiba, a group of Islamic holy warriors based in Pakistan that wants predominantly Muslim Kashmir to be part of Islamic Pakistan. The group's attacks in Kashmir have intensified India's denunciations of Pakistan for harboring terrorists. Pakistan calls them freedom fighters. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: Shootings Rise In Last 3 Weeks
description: For the third straight week, the number of shootings in New York City has risen compared with the same period a year ago, but criminologists say it is too early to draw conclusions about the data.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Utah: Opposition To Grazing On Monument
description: The Grand Canyon Trust, an Arizona environmental group, has bought the grazing rights to a 256,000-acre parcel in Utah's Grand Staircase-Escalante Monument. The permit to graze on the land, which makes up about 15 percent of the 1.8 million-acre monument, was sold by a rancher for an undisclosed amount. The trust plans to ask the Bureau of Land Management, which oversees the monument, to end most grazing on the site. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Shake-Up At EM.TV
description: EM.TV & Merchandising A.G., the owner of the Muppets, fired its chief financial officer, Marius Schwarz, after three months in the position, the latest management reshuffle since Werner Klatten took charge. Mr. Klatten, who bought a 25.1 percent stake in EM.TV in July, will take over Mr. Schwarz's duties, the company said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIVIRGILIO, DANIEL F.
description: DiVIRGILIO-Daniel F. Riverdale Country School extends its deepest sympathies to the family and friends of Daniel F. DiVirgilio, who suffered a fatal heart attack on Thursday, November 22, 2001. The Director of Lower School Admission for the past year and a half, Dan was a ''school man'' in the best sense of that phrase. An educator who made a difference in the lives of those who knew him, Dan was bringing the same sense of dedication and love to Riverdale Country School that made him a legendary figure at Hackley School, where, for fourteen years, he served as Director of the Lower School. Dan made a powerful and positive impact on the School community, and he will be sorely missed. Our thoughts and prayers reach out to his wife, Maris Kastan, and to the other members of his family. Richard S. Zinman, Chairman John R. Johnson, Headmaster

title: Witnesses to an Epidemic Shrug Off Shame to Fight a Dangerous Fear
description: Of some 50,000 people in the Hlabisa area believed to be H.I.V. positive, eight publicly admit it. Guitor Mthembu is one.

title: Up to My Ears in Medical Claims
description: Although my workweek is long, my commute is very short, just 28 steps. I run my own business, a medical billing service, from home. My business comes from referrals. I meet with doctors when they are either going into a practice or changing their affiliation. It is a long process; one that takes many months of follow-up.

title: A New Normandy, North of the Golden Gate
description: CAN this be the place? Dubiously, you drive up a muddy, unmarked road potted with water-filled holes, park next to a worn army-surplus generator, poke your head into a metal farm building and peer down a corridor.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Asia Society Cafe

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: US Airways Chief Resigns; Chairman to Succeed Him

title: A Custody Battle for a Baseball's True Owner
description: Alex Popov had the ball first.

title: Tailoring A Child's Story For Adults
description: What is this? The Irondale Ensemble Project without politics? It may come as a shock to the company's regular audience, but there is little political comment, and apparently little political intent, in Irondale's dramatization of James M. Barrie's ''Peter Pan'' at the Theater for the New City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORWICH, SALLY B.
description: HORWICH-Sally B., 94. After a short illness, on November 21, at Mount Sinai Hospital. Born in Winnipeg, she grew up on her father's ranch in Saskatchewan, became a nurse, & emigrated to the United States, where she married David, her devoted husband until his death in 1957. She was a cooking teacher for many years; a brilliant chef herself, she is remembered for the lessons that made cooks of many of her friends. She is survived, and will be greatly missed, by her son Richard, granddaughter Danielle, daughter-in-law Nancy, and sister Eve Rother. A memorial celebration will be held for family and close friends sometime next Spring. Contributions in her memory may be made to any worthy charity or cultural institution.

title: Tamil Leader Talks Peace, With a Catch
description: From a hide-out in northern Sri Lanka, the leader of an ethnic Tamil rebellion that has been described as separatist for the past 18 years unambiguously declared today for the first time that he would settle for less than an independent nation.

title: Budget Deal In Wee Hours May Not Solve Nassau Woes
description: It was not until 5 a.m. today that Nassau County's bleary-eyed and cranky legislators were finally able to agree on a budget intended to beat a Wednesday deadline for a possible state takeover of the county's finances.

title: The Ebb and Flow of a Religious Calling
description: Scott Sokol was a Fulbright scholar and a professor at Harvard Medical School, but he never felt famous until he became cantor at a Boston synagogue. Now he is recognized on the street, and barely has a private moment.

title: Man's Death Not Related To Anthrax, Governor Says
description: Gov. John G. Rowland, seeking to calm nerves already frayed by the anthrax death of Ottilie W. Lundgren of Oxford, Conn., today defused one rumor that had emerged from the government's investigation into her case and shed some light on other aspects of the continuing inquiry.

title: Sports of The Times; Yashin Is Helping to Revive an American Dynasty
description: WHEN Aleksei Yashin was a boy, his favorite team was Red Army, which was like rooting for the Yankees in baseball, or the old Boston Celtics in basketball, or even the Islanders in hockey, but Yashin did not know about those foreign dynasties back then.

title: Landmarks Group Approves Bold Plan for Hearst Tower
description: The Landmarks Preservation Commission gave its blessing yesterday to a remarkable architectural union that would permit the Hearst Corporation to complete the mid-Manhattan headquarters it began building 74 years ago.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Ex-Radical's Lawyer Urged Plea
description: A lawyer for Sara Jane Olson, the former radical who pleaded guilty to trying to bomb two police cruisers in 1975, has said in a court filing that he pressured her to do so and that she should be allowed to withdraw the plea. Ms. Olson made her guilty plea on Oct. 31 but renounced it minutes later outside court. Ordered back to court to clear up the matter, she pleaded guilty again. But she has since asked to withdraw the plea and go to trial. J. Tony Serra, the lawyer, said, ''I, in part, take responsibility for creating conditions in her mind that amounted to psychological duress'' by arguing that she could not get a fair trial after the Sept. 11 attacks. A hearing on her request is set for Dec. 3. James Sterngold (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: Foreigners Remain Jailed
description: Fourteen British and Dutch plane enthusiasts accused of spying will remain behind bars until a panel of judges is formed to review their case, a judge ordered after they testifed at a 12-hour hearing. The group has been in detention since Nov. 8 on charges of taking photographs and taking notes of military jets' movements during their plane-spotting trip to Greece. Their lawyer, who had appealed for the group's release on bail, said they could spend as much an another month in jail until the special tribunal is formed. Anthee Carassava (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLEICHER, WILLIAM
description: GLEICHER-William. On November 26, 2001, beloved husband of Esther, devoted father of Judith Seiff and the late Ellen Kushner, cherished grandfather of Joanne, Joshua, Daniel, Lauren, and Dana. Dear father-in-law of Henry and Kenneth. Service today, 12:15 PM, ''Parkside'' Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Ave, Brooklyn, NY (opposite King's Plaza). Donations can be made to Temple Rodef Shalom, Falls Church, VA.

title: With Many Leaders Absent From Talks on Post-Taliban Rule, a Kabul Meeting Is Suggested
description: Under international pressure to act quickly, four Afghan factions began talks today on setting up a representative, interim administration that could begin to govern an Afghanistan still at war.

title: C.I.A. Officer Dies in Afghan Prison Riot
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28  The American who died in a prison riot in Afghanistan was a Central Intelligence Agency officer, the C.I.A. said today.

title: Business Travel; Private charters, although languishing this year, are expected to fill a future air travel niche.
description: AIR fares dropped 19.2 percent last month compared with October 2000, according to the Air Transport Association's Office of Economics.

title: Error Put Body of One Firefighter In Grave of a Firehouse Colleague
description: Perhaps it was bound to happen. The dimensions of the carnage were just so great. And so it did.

title: Defusing a Standoff
description: The impending departure of Mary Jo White from the United States attorney's post in Manhattan touched off a furious backstage struggle between Gov. George E. Pataki and Senator Charles E. Schumer. Each had his own thoughts on how to go about filling the job.

title: Rights Report Holds Mexico Responsible For Torture
description: The Mexican government was responsible for detaining and torturing hundreds of men and women who have been missing since the 1970's, says a report released today by the National Human Rights Commission.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREZINSKY, PHILIP
description: BREZINSKY-Philip, 86. On Monday, November 26, 2001 of natural causes. Husband of the late Sylvia, father of Kenneth and Helene (and Robert Wigness), grandfather of Stephan, brother of Beatrice and the late Dorothy and Morris, and long time friend of Beverly. Donations in his memory may be made to Montefiore Medical Center (geriatric program), 111 East 210 Street, Bronx, NY 10467. Please mention his name. Private graveside service Wednesday.

title: Corrections
description: A biographical sketch on Nov. 18 about Richard D. Rosenthal, a World Trade Center victim who was treasurer of the Dysautonomia Foundation and a Cantor Fitzgerald vice president, misstated the given name of his oldest son, who has familial dysautonomia, a serious genetic disease. He is Evan Rosenthal, not Ethan.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Satellite Radio Company Names Chief
description: Sirius Satellite Radio in New York said yesterday that it had named Joseph P. Clayton, 52, president and chief executive. Mr. Clayton, left, had been vice chairman at Global Crossing in Rochester, a worldwide Internet and long-distance services provider, and had held numerous posts in consumer electronics over the years. Mr. Clayton succeeds David Margolese, the Sirius Satellite Radio chairman, whom the company said had given up the chief executive post last month. Sirius plans to introduce its 100-channel digital radio service on Feb. 14 in Denver, Houston and Phoenix. Allison Fass (NYT)

title: Nary a Sheep Is Lost for Fleece Fashion
description: Mention fleece to the uninitiated, and the word still conjures up bucolic images of grazing sheep -- or even Jason's mythical quest.

title: Vouvray, Going to Extremes
description: APART from its mellifluous name, Vouvray is a white wine with big marketing problems. First of all, it is not made from chardonnay, the world's most popular grape, or even from riesling, which has its devotees, or sauvignon blanc, which at least is well known. It is 100 percent chenin blanc, a versatile, fascinating grape that deserves to be thought of as among the world's elite, but instead is neglected.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Grocer's Profit Is Up
description: Royal Ahold, the large Dutch supermarket operator and food distributor, reported a 17 percent increase in third-quarter profit. Third-quarter net income climbed to 304.2 million euros ($268.5 million), or 34 cents a share, from 259.6 million euros, or 33 cents a share, a year earlier. With the United States economy in a recession and people tending to eat more at home, sales at Ahold's Giant and Stop & Shop chains along the Eastern Seaboard are benefiting, analysts said.

title: Paul Hume, 85, Washington Music Critic
description: Paul Hume, whose opinions on music raised him to an almost statesmanlike stature in the minds and hearts of Washington's concertgoers, died on Monday at a nursing home in Baltimore. He was 85 and was suffering from pneumonia.

title: 4-Game Suspension For Seattle's Springs
description: Seattle Seahawks cornerback Shawn Springs was suspended for four games yesterday for violating N.F.L. policy on anabolic steroids and related substances.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALBERG, G. PETER, M.D.
description: HALBERG-G. Peter, M.D. The Department of Ophthalmology of Saint Vincents Hospital and Medical Center of New York notes with sadness the death of its esteemed colleague on November 24, 2001. Dr. Halberg served as Attending Ophthalmic Surgeon and Chief of the Glaucoma and Contact Lens Services at this institution from 1974 to 1990. He was widely recognized for his avid pursuit of new technology in the ophthalmic field and served on numerous professional committees nationally and internationally. His energy and enthusiasm were inspiring and his great sense of humor and love of life endeared him to his colleagues, patients and friends. Robert A. D'Amico, M.D., Chairman

title: Witness Says Price-Fixing For Auctions Began Earlier
description: Two executives of Sotheby's and Christie's initiated their own scheme to fix rates for auction buyers as early as 1992, one of them reluctantly testified yesterday.

title: Test Prep Memoir
description: A memoir by STANLEY H. KAPLAN, who turned a modest Brooklyn basement tutoring business into a multimillion-dollar enterprise, does its part to keep the College Board on the defensive. In ''Test Pilot'' (Simon & Schuster), written with ANNE FARRIS, Mr. Kaplan portrays himself less as a shrewd businessman than as a David trying to level the playing field against the Goliath of the testing service. So long as college admission tests exist, and matter so much, Mr. Kaplan argues, then let students prepare themselves for them. ''My company has tried to shrink the divide between the have and the have-nots,'' he wrote.

title: Memo to NASA: Rethink the Space Shuttle
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANE, SARA
description: KANE-Sara, 85. Wife of the late Albert Gold and William Kane. Beloved mother of Barbara Gold Kane, Ellen Bayer and Howard Kane. Best in the world Grandma to Jennifer Bayer Gamulka, Shimon and Aaron Bayer, Jennifer Kane Crapo, Suzanne & Anthony Gabriele. Great Grandma Sara to Eliana, Avi and Noam Bayer Gamulka, and William and Kelsey Crapo, Benjamin and John Wisdom, Sara and Maya Gabriele. She will be missed always. Services 10 AM, November 28 at Plaza Community Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue at 91st Street.

title: Camby a Big Help, Not the Whole Solution
description: Despite a couple of thousand empty seats on Monday, there was a buzz in Madison Square Garden for the first time since Michael Jordan showed up on opening night. Fans paid close attention to the game, and the reason was Marcus Camby.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Mark Drucker opened the Cambridge Media Group, Cambridge, Mass., where he is chief executive. Cambridge Media offers advertising sales and marketing services to magazine publishers and advertisers in the New England region. Mr. Drucker had been advertising director at Boston Magazine Publications, a division of Boston Magazine, owned by MetroCorp.

title: A Secret Trial: It's Not Our Way
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Food Companies Hire New Agencies
description: Two large marketers are expanding their agency rosters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAUN, LILLIAN
description: BRAUN-Lillian. On November 27, 2001. Beloved wife of 60 years of Joseph. Loving mother of Laurence and his wife Ariela, and Shelley and his wife Pamela. Devoted grandmother of Andrew and his wife Rabbi Laurie, Carolyn and her husband Daniel, Jeffrey and Randi. Dear sister of Samuel Noble. A 1932 graduate of Hunter College with a B.A. in French and Education, she was a Junior Phi Beta Kappa. She had an endless love of learning, language, art, living American artists and design. Services today, 11:15AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th and Amsterdam Ave. She will be deeply missed.

title: The Torch Relay at a Glance
description: On November 19, 2001, the Olympic flame left Ancient Olympia, Greece, and began its journey to Salt Lake City. The first leg of the relay was run by Lefteris Fafalis, a Greek cross-country skier. Greek runners then carried the torch to Athens to burn in Panathenian Stadium, site of the first modern Olympics in 1896.

title: Istanbul Journal; Campus Crowd Shrugs At Marital-Equality Law
description: Lounging on the grassy square in the heart of the prestigious Bosporus University campus here, Selen Yenmez, a silver stud pinned to her nose, a Jimi Hendrix button pinned to her bag, could muster only scant enthusiasm for a new Turkish law that offers equality to a husband and wife.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOEHM, LEONORE
description: BOEHM-Leonore. On September 26, 2001. Wife of the late Edward H. Boehm, sister of Rose Heiman, beloved mother of Arthur Boehm. No funeral is planned. Contributions in her name to The Lilian and Benjamin Hertzberg Palliative Care Institute of the Mount Sinai/ NYU Medical Center, 212-241-1446, would be greatly appreciated.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Airline Seeks Damages
description: AirTran Airways, which uses Hartsfield Atlanta International Airport as a major hub, has filed a federal lawsuit against Michael Shane Lasseter, the Gainesville, Ga., man whose breach of security temporarily shut the airport down on Nov. 16. The airline said the resulting delays and cancellations cost it more than $1 million. It has asked for at least $100,000 in damages. Mr. Lasseter, who dashed past security guards and ran down an up escalator, was charged with disorderly conduct. Kevin Sack (NYT)

title: U.S. and Russia Reach Deal To Keep Sanctions on Iraq
description: After an agreement between the United States and Russia, other major members of the United Nations Security Council agreed today to postpone changing the rules for sanctions on trade with Iraq for another six months, diplomats said, keeping the existing ''oil for food'' program in force until then.

title: VIVENDI AND ARENAS TO CREATE MOVIE LABEL FOR HISPANICS
description: The Universal Pictures unit of Vivendi Universal and the Arenas Group advertising and public relations firm formed a movie label that will produce and market films to Hispanic audiences. Universal Pictures and a Spanish venture capital firm, Marco Polo Investments, will have an unspecified equity stake in the Arenas Entertainment label, which will distribute four or five films a year. Universal and Arenas Entertainment will jointly finance all of the films, the companies said. Santiago Pozo, the founder and president of the closely held Arenas, was named chief executive of the venture.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORMAN, SOL
description: FORMAN-Sol. The Trustees and staff of the Museum of Jewish Heritage-A Living Memorial to the Holocaust mourn the passing of Sol Forman, beloved father of Amy and father-in-law of our ViceChairman, Howard Rubenstein. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his children, grandchildren, great-grandchildren, and his entire family. Robert M. Morgenthau, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Level 3 To Be AOL Supplier
description: Level 3 Communications, a money-losing operator of a phone and data network, won a contract to provide services to AOL Time Warner's America Online. The shares of Level 3 Communications rose as much as 26 percent. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed. America Online will buy space on Level 3's network to offer high-speed Internet services to customers. America Online will also lease space at Level 3 operations that store high-speed data equipment, the companies said. The shares of Level 3 Communications rose 84 cents, to $6.54, after earlier reaching $7.19.

title: A Saudi Prince With an Unconventional Idea: Elections
description: A prominent member of Saudi Arabia's royal family called today for a transformation that would bring elections, ''the faster the better,'' to a kingdom whose only bow to democracy has been the establishment of an appointed advisory council.

title: Justices Pondering Old Barriers in Housing
description: The State Supreme Court heard arguments today on whether a lower court was correct in allowing a developer to build hundreds of single-family homes in a township that was putting up fierce resistance. Despite the courtroom references to sewer hookups and traffic volume, however, the seven justices hearing West Windsor Township v. Toll Brothers Inc. seemed to be more concerned with a broader issue: the housing barriers that make New Jersey one of the most racially segregated states.

title: For Passion and Justice, A Transforming Kiss
description: Nothing less than life-or-death questions impel the songs of Jaguares, the Mexican band, which played for a euphoric full house at the Hammerstein Ballroom on Sunday night. Sal Hernndez, the band's songwriter and singer, spoke onstage about ''these moments of darkness, war and death'' and urged sympathy for all victims. He didn't need any new material to address a time of uncertainty and resolve.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRISSAN, BONNIE (NEE MUNRO)
description: CRISSAN-Bonnie (nee Munro). In Westerly, R.I. on November 25, 2001. Wife of the late Michael G. Crissan. Loving mother and mother-in-law of Michael M. and Holly Crissan. Sister and sister-in-law of Almedia M. and John Livingston. Grandmother of Sadie O. Crissan. Also survived by several nieces and nephews. Bonnie was a graduate of the American Academy for Dramatic Arts in New York City. A memorial service will be held Thursday, 11 AM in Christ Episcopal Church, Elm and Broad Streets, Westerly, R.I. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Westerly Adult Day Care Center, 65 Wells St, Westerly. R.I. 02891. Inquiries to The BucklerJohnston Funeral Home, (401) 596-2465.

title: Marines Land in Afghanistan With Panache, Semper Fi and Press Tagging Along
description: When the few and the proud landed in Afghanistan on Monday, they took some of the ink-stained with them. The decision by the United States Marine Corps to take three print reporters, a television cameraman and a photographer into combat so early in their mission was a welcome surprise to many news organizations.

title: 2 Palestinian Gunmen Kill 2 as U.S. Begins Peace Effort
description: Two Palestinian gunmen went on a suicidal shooting rampage today through the heart of this northern Israeli city, killing 2, seriously wounding 10 and providing a billboard for Israelis' security fears during the visit of American envoys seeking a cease-fire.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Antismoking Ban Loses Support
description: The Montgomery County executive decided not to sign an antismoking measure that would fine residents up to $750 if odor from their smoking irritated neighbors. Last week, after the County Council approved the measure as part of an indoor air-quality bill, the executive, Douglas M. Duncan, said he planned to sign it. Opponents called the measure an infringement on the rights of residents to smoke in their homes. Gary Gately (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Cities Shrinking
description: Connecticut residents continue to migrate out of the state's largest cities, a study by the University of Connecticut's Center for Geographic Information and Analysis shows. The reports says the state lost about 50,000 residents since 1990, part of a 40-year migration to the south and west. Between 1990 and 2000, according to Robert Cromley, director of the center, about 32,000 people moved out of Hartford, 15,000 out of New Haven and 13,000 out of Bridgeport. Small towns reported growth, however, with Sherman increasing by 1,018 people, more than 36 percent, the largest percentage gain in the study. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: W. Glenn Campbell, Shaper Of Hoover Center, Dies at 77
description: W. Glenn Campbell, an economist and friend of President Ronald Reagan who built the Hoover Institution at Stanford University into one of the world's most influential conservative research groups, died on Saturday at his home in Los Altos Hills, Calif. He was 77.

title: ASHCROFT OFFERS ACCOUNTING OF 641 CHARGED OR HELD
description: Faced with growing criticism over his refusal to identify people jailed since the Sept. 11 attacks, Attorney General John Ashcroft today provided for the first time the names of 93 people charged with crimes arising from the government's investigation.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: $220 Million In Budget Cuts
description: Gov. George Ryan ordered $220 million in budget cuts, among them measures to shut the state's oldest prison and withhold a day's pay from state workers. Mr. Ryan said 60,000 workers would have staggered one-day furloughs from their jobs in the next seven months, saving the state $8 million. And closing the 141-year-old Joliet Correctional Facility would save the state $4 million. The cuts are part of the governor's plan to slice $500 million from the state's $53.4 billion budget. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Coke Subsidiary To Diversify
description: The Indian subsidiary of the Coca-Cola Company is planning an expansion into the country's ready-to-drink coffee and tea market. ''Our mission is to lead the beverages revolution in India,'' said Irfan Khan, a spokesman for the subsidiary, Coca-Cola India. The beverages are currently being developed by Coke's Zurich-based joint venture with Nestl. More than 70 percent of Indians drink tea and coffee as compared with the 2 percent who consume carbonated drinks. ''This is the segment we'd like to lead,'' Mr. Khan said.

title: Fire Could Not Stop A Mill, but Debts May
description: It is another unhappy holiday season for Aaron M. Feuerstein, the widely admired New England mill owner whose textile company, Malden Mills, is again in crisis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERMAN, LAWRENCE, M.D.
description: SILVERMAN - Lawrence, M.D. Died on Sunday, November 25, 2001 at his home in South Orange, NJ. Graveside services were held on Monday at the Riverside Cemetery, Saddlebrook, NJ. Dr. Silverman graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Columbia University and New York University Medical School. He was a diplomat of The American Board of Internal Medicine and a fellow of The American College of Physicians. He also served in The United States Air Force. Dr. Silverman practiced medicine in Jersey City for 35 years, retiring in 1995. Survived by his beloved wife Eleanor, his son Daniel, his daughter-in-law Susan, his daughter Nancy and son-in-law Jake, granddaughters Maude, Lily and Georgia. Also surviving are his cherished sisters Brenda Winters and Sandra Schneider. Donations in his memory can be made to The American Heart Association.

title: Bonding, Tenderly
description: TRUE rag is a magnificent pasta sauce, a slow-simmered blend of meat, tomatoes and, usually, milk. The real thing takes hours, for the meat must become tender and contribute its silkiness to the sauce, the tomatoes must dissolve, and the milk must pull the whole thing together.

title: U.S. Judge Questions Plan For Deal in Microsoft Case
description: A federal judge today questioned whether Microsoft's $1 billion plan to give computers to schools to settle consumer antitrust claims would give it an unfair advantage in one of the few markets where it faces competition from Apple Computer Inc.

title: Aquarium Bonds Worth 25 Cents on Dollar
description: Bondholders in the oceanside aquarium in Marineland, Florida's smallest town, are getting 25 cents on the dollar for their investment.

title: Las Vegas Bridge Tourney at Its Finale
description: The American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals reaches its conclusion here today with 14 star-studded teams fighting for the prestigious Reisinger Board-a-Match Team title. Eight of the teams consist partly or wholly of players who have crossed the Atlantic to compete, providing an international flavor.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the World Briefing column yesterday about a plan to slaughter cattle in Japan to control mad cow disease misstated the percentage drop in wholesale prices for beef there after the discovery of two cases. It was 50 percent; retail prices have fallen 20 percent.

title: Ashcroft's About-Face on the Detainees
description: In bold and unilateral strokes, the Bush administration has in recent weeks reshaped the American legal system to fight terrorism in ways unthinkable before Sept. 11, from monitoring the conversations of suspected terrorists and their lawyers to creating special military tribunals to prosecute terrorists without the usual Anglo-Saxon niceties.

title: A Smarter Cookie
description: PASTRY chefs often feel driven to the inventive and elaborate to be sure their high-paying customers won't feel cheated.

title: TWO INVESTORS MAY SELL OLD STAKES IN GOLDMAN SACHS
description: The Goldman Sachs Group said yesterday that a charity in Hawaii and a unit of the Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation of Japan may sell $1.27 billion of Goldman shares, the last of the investments they made when the firm was Wall Street's largest private partnership. Goldman filed with regulators to allow the charity, the Kamehameha Activities Association, and the Sumitomo unit, SMBC Capital Markets, to sell 14.1 million shares. The investments by Kamehameha and SMBC made them the largest outside investors in Goldman before its initial stock sale in 1999. Kamehameha, which invested in Goldman in 1992 and 1994, and SMBC, which bought a stake in 1986, sold 18 million shares in the initial offering and have sold more since.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, FRANCIS DANIELS, MD.
description: MOORE-Francis Daniels, MD. Husband of Katharyn (Watson) (Saltonstall) Moore and his first wife who predeceased him, Laura (Bartlett) Moore, father of Nancy Moore Hill of Stratham, NH, Peter B. Moore of North Haven, CT, Sarah Moore Warren of Grafton, VT, Caroline Moore Tripp of NYC and Dr. Francis D. Moore, Jr., brother of Harriet Moore Gelfan of Brattletboro, VT and the late Philip W. Moore. Also survived by 17 grandchildren and four great grandchildren. A service will be held on Saturday December 1st at the First Congregational Church, 10 Cottage St. Marion, MA at 2:00 P.M. Another Memorial Service will be held in the Boston area on December 21st at Memorial Church, Harvard Yard, Harvard University at 11:00 A.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Laura B. and Francis D. Moore Endowment Fund for Surgical Research at Harvard Medical School, 25 Shattuck St. Boston, MA 02115. For information, J.S. Waterman - Eastman - Waring Funeral Service, Boston, MA (617) 536-4110.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NISENSON, ESTELLE (ABRAMS)
description: NISENSON-Estelle (Abrams). Of Natick, MA, formerly of Queens, NY, on November 26. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Arnold. Devoted mother of Rita Edelman and Roy Nisenson. Dear grandmother of Larry and Laurie Edelman, Marci and Seth Drizen, Amanda, Oliver, Peter, Caroline and Ashley Nisenson. Private services in New York. Information, Brezniak-Rodman, Directors: 617-969-0800.

title: Want to Join the Telecommuting Crowd? Most Bosses Just Say No
description: Will Sept. 11 turn American workers into a labor force of telecommuters? Probably not anytime soon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NERI, JOSEPHINE
description: NERI-Josephine. Age 65. Of Saint Cloud, FL. Died Saturday, November 17, 2001. Mrs. Neri was the Editor of Crafts for Family Circle magazine. Born in The Bronx, N.Y., she moved to Saint Cloud from Brooklyn. She was Catholic. Survivors are son Joseph Michael Neri, Jr., daughter-in-law Ellen Neri, granddaughter Nicole Neri, all of Massapequa, very special sister, Theresa Shock of Saint Cloud, brother Vincent Jansky of Flushing, N.Y., beloved godson Michael Tavalare of Brooklyn. A memorial mass will be celebrated Friday, November 30, 3PM, Saint Rose of Lima Catholic Church, Massapequa, New York. Inquires, Osceola Memory Gardens Funeral Home, 407-957-2511.

title: Executive In Bergen Will Retire Next Year
description: After 30 years in public office, the Bergen County executive, William P. Schuber, said today that he had abandoned his plan to run for Congress next fall and would retire from politics at the end of next year.

title: OXFORD HEALTH PLANS PAYS $20 MILLION TO END CONTRACT
description: Oxford Health Plans, one of the biggest health insurers in the New York area, has paid Caremark Rx $20 million to end a contract to provide mail-order prescription-drug services to its 1.5 million plan members. Caremark will supply specialty biotechnology products to Oxford members through Sept. 12, 2004, as part of the settlement, Caremark's chief financial officer, Howard McLure, said. Oxford signed a five-year agreement with Merck's Medco unit in October to manage its pharmacy benefits, replacing existing contracts with Caremark and another rival, Express Scripts Inc.

title: Racial Tensions Lead to Student Protest at Colgate
description: The tranquility of Colgate University, tucked on a hillside in central New York State, has been ruffled in recent weeks by several incidents centered on the treatment of minority students on campus.

title: Shares Fall on Unexpected Drop in Consumer Confidence
description: Stocks fell yesterday, sending the Dow Jones industrial average to its biggest loss this month, after consumer confidence slid to its lowest level in seven and a half years.

title: For the Big Canadian Banks, Profit Is Retail and Domestic
description: After a decade of spreading their wings into investment banking and across the border into the United States, Canada's big five banks are growing to appreciate their own backyard.

title: The Neediest Cases; Jobs Lost, Found and Lost, But a Life Still to Be Led
description: David Johnson's Sunday morning routine was two-thirds complete. he had already phoned his two daughters to say ''I love you,'' and he had already delivered an I-love-you in person to his mother, who lives near his South Bronx apartment. ''And now,'' Mr. Johnson said, his fingers dancing in anticipation on his computer keyboard as he spoke, ''it's time for The Times.'' Reaching beneath his keyboard for the classified section of The New York Times, Mr. Johnson began the third phase of his routine: looking for a job. As he held the section in his hands, Mr. Johnson's eyebrows went north. He lifted it into the air, then bounced it lightly as if he were weighing it on an imaginary scale.

title: Confidence Index Drops, but Housing Sales Rise
description: Consumer confidence unexpectedly slumped this month, but housing was a surprise bright spot in the economy in October, reports showed today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLACKIN, EDWARD J., JR.
description: GLACKIN-Edward J., Jr. Of Huntington, NY, on November 27, 2001, died peacefully at age 72 surrounded by family. He will be lovingly remembered by his wife Bobby, his 10 children and their spouses, his 25 grandchildren, and many friends and family whose lives he filled with joy over the years. The wake will be held at A. L. Jacobsen Funeral Home in Huntington Station, NY at 1380 New York Avenue on Thursday, November 29 between 2 and 5 PM and 7 & 9 PM. The funeral service will take place Friday, November 30 at 1 PM at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Huntington, New York at 400 Main Street.

title: Now Appearing: A Prosciutto in the Round
description: When prosciutto di Parma ham is boned before it is sold, it is pressed into a flattened shape, resulting in the typical elongated slice. But there is another kind of prosciutto, called rotondo, with a fuller, rounded slice that results from rolling and tying the boned ham. It has the usual nut-sweet flavor but is a little moister. Rotondo is now available at Agata & Valentina, where Eric Menal, the deli manager, sells it for $17.99 a pound. It is also sold at Citarella for $19.96 a pound.

title: Selig Offers His Forecast For the Game
description: Commissioner Bud Selig underwent what seemed more like a coronation than a re-election today, then proceeded to produce as bleak a picture of baseball's economics as he has ever painted.

title: Editorial Observer; Putting a Price Tag on the Legacy of Martin Luther King
description: Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. received the Nobel Peace Prize at the age of 35, when most people are still struggling to find out who they are. By the time of his assassination four years later, he had played the starring role in a movement for racial justice that transformed the country and caused him to be spoken of in the same breath as figures like Abraham Lincoln, Thomas Jefferson and Mohandas Gandhi.

title: Tender Tortes, Awaiting Oven and Fork
description: Tender-crusted Italian tortes based on family recipes are the fortes of Carol Rollo and Christine Bellini. Their company, Two Italian Girls, makes the tortes in Sag Harbor, N.Y., for Dean & DeLuca, Jefferson Market, Citarella, Todaro Brothers and Grace's Marketplace. They are thick, with six assorted fillings involving vegetables, cheese, sausages, eggs and olives. There are seven-inch tortes, which easily serve four and are convenient to heat for a quick lunch or supper with a salad. They are $18 to $20. A five-inch size is $8 to $10. Cut in skinny wedges, it could accompany cocktails. Two Italian Girls also makes a sweet raisin-studded torte called Dolce Marie, which is like a giant rugelach; $22 for a nine-inch size, $12 for six inches.

title: Detention Power Expanded
description: The Justice Department has given itself greater power to detain foreigners. It can now hold a person even if a federal immigration judge has ordered a release. Page B7.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMAN, MICHAEL
description: HOFFMAN-Michael. The International Center of Photography is saddened by the passing of Michael Hoffman, whose relentless creative energies for the Aperture Foundation and the world of photography have resulted in many of the finest photography books and exhibitions of our time. Michael's intense dedication to bringing to a wider audience photographic work of importance and quality has been reflected in the multiple projects of the Aperture Foundation. We at ICP will long remember his brilliant talents, intellectual presence in the photographic dialogue, his friendship and our many successful collaborations. Our sincere condolences to Melissa and to Michael's family and the people of Aperture. Cornell Capa, Founding Director Emeritus Willis Hartshorn, Director Int'l Center of Photography

title: Swedish Journalist Slain as Fears Rise for Safety of Reporters
description: A Swedish journalist was killed early this morning in northern Afghanistan, where the fighting and static front lines between the Northern Alliance and Taliban soldiers have been replaced by pockets of lawlessness and roaming bands of young gunmen.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Austria: Compensation For Jews
description: The government will pay $22.5 million in compensation for assets seized from Jews during the Nazi era, the Jewish Council of Austria said. The government's contribution will be in addition to $16 million promised to Austrian Jews by provincial governments earlier this week. The government money will be used for Jewish schools, the reconstruction of a synagogue and improved security measures. Historians estimate that the Nazis seized between $450 million and $700 million worth of assets from Austria's Jews. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: In Chinatown, A Taste of Revival
description: IF every day were the Sunday after Thanksgiving, Chinatown would almost feel like its old self again. But the bustling streets, crowded markets and long lines at so many restaurants last weekend were unlike what the area has generally experienced since Sept. 11, when the attacks less than half a mile away left the neighborhood sealed off and without phone service.

title: Spain Pledges Support to U.S. on Terrorism
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28  President Bush got a pledge of cooperation from the Prime Minister of Spain in the fight against terrorism today as a dispute over extradition of suspected terrorists seemed to recede, at least for the moment.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GRIFFON CORP., Jericho, N.Y., a maker of electronics, garage doors and specialty plastic films, said its Telephonics unit had won a $13.5 million contract from the Air Force to upgrade detection and identification systems for Awacs, or airborne warning and control systems, planes.

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of Monday, 3,771 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11.

title: Rangers Put Pieces Together for a Tie
description: Eric Lin dros played and even scored -- with one hand tonight. A tired Theo Fleury said he had no legs. But Mike Richter, on his two surgically reconstructed knees, proved more than enough to keep the Rangers in another game.

title: Red Hat Supplying I.B.M.
description: Red Hat Inc., the distributor of the Linux operating system, said today that it would supply software and services for all I.B.M. server computers. Red Hat had previously supplied its Linux version only for the I.B.M. xSeries servers. Under the latest agreement, Red Hat will supply Linux for all I.B.M. servers, including the zSeries mainframe. Like other distributors of Linux, Red Hat gains sales by making it easier for companies to install, service and upgrade the free software.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLASS, WALTER, M.D.
description: GLASS-Walter, M.D. Devoted husband of Eva for 53 years. Loving father of Michael and Richard. Beloved grandfather of Lisa and David. A founding physician of the North Shore University Hospital and of the Long Island Jewish Medical Center. Served as president of the Medical Staff Society and on the Medical Board of both institutions. He was the physician in charge of Otolaryngology at the North Shore University Hospital for 11 years.
