Served as a medical officer aboard a U.S. Navy destroyer in World War II and served as a medical volunteer at an Israeli Government Hospital during the Six Day War in 1967. Dr. Glass was in the private practice of Otolaryngology in Great Neck and Manhasset, LI for 48 years, prior to his retirement in 1997. Services will be held on Thursday, November 29, at 11:30 AM at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. For further information call Riverside-Nassau North Chapels at 516-487-9600.

title: A Hospital Gets Patients, but Nothing to Help Them With
description: The child rested on her back on a dirty bed, looking trance-like at the ceiling and biting a green scarf.

title: National Briefing | West: Oregon: Changes To Protect Sucker Fish
description: The federal Bureau of Reclamation is planning a $5 million renovation to increase security at the head gates of Klamath Basin's irrigation district and install fish screens to allow greater flexibility in maintaining water levels in Upper Klamath Lake. Local farmers repeatedly forced the gates open last summer after regulators limited irrigation water to 180,000 acres of farmland to protect the sucker fish, an endangered species that lives in the lake. Screens should prevent fish from being washed into the system's main canal, and floodlights and a high fence will assist security personnel protecting the gates, a bureau spokesman said. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Drugs and Advertising
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Promotions Division At Draft to Expand
description: Draft Worldwide in Chicago is opening a unit with 14 executives who worked at Simon Marketing, the premium-promotions company that was dismissed in August by McDonald's after a Simon employee was implicated in a plan to rig many of McDonald's big promotional games.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Member Quits M.T.A. Board
description: A consumer advocate resigned yesterday from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority Board, citing clashes with Gov. George E. Pataki. Larry Silverman, left, was a nonvoting member of the advisory board and had served as chairman of the Long Island Rail Road Commuters Council, a watchdog group. Mr. Pataki, a Republican, dismissed Mr. Silverman, a Democrat, from the council in February, citing Mr. Silverman's unsuccessful bid last year for a State Senate seat as an indication of personal ambition that he said was a disservice to commuters. Mr. Silverman said the clash was rooted in Mr. Pataki's dislike of his criticism, however. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: New CUNY Student Trustee
description: RICHARD J. NUNEZ-LAWRENCE is the new student trustee on the 17-member board of the City University of New York, and he already knows many of the 17 campuses. A Harlem resident, Mr. Nunez-Lawrence, 25, attended Hostos Community College and got degrees from La Guardia Community College and City College, where he was an English major. He is working on a graduate degree in political science at Brooklyn College.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LENTAKIS, JOHN E.
description: LENTAKIS-John E. On November 25, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Cynthia. Devoted father of Michael, Tom and Diane. Dear grandfather of Christopher, Meagan and Fleming. The family will receive friends at the Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Post Road, Rye, N.Y. Wednesday, 7-9PM, Thursday, 2-4 and 7-9PM. Funeral service will be held at the Church of Our Saviour, Westchester Ave, Rye, New York. Friday, 12 Noon. Interment Greenwood Union Cemetery. Friends may send either flowers or memorial donations to Ronald McDonald House, or Saint Michael's Home, 3 Lehman Terrace, Yonkers, NY 10706.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Danube River: Shipping Revival
description: Shipping on the Danube River should return by the spring to levels that were normal before the 1999 Kosovo war, the Danube Commission said. The commission, which groups the 11 countries through which the river flows, said work would begin soon on removing ruined bridges and unexploded bombs near Novi Sad, Yugoslavia, left by the NATO bombardment of Kosovo. The commission said Yugoslavia had also agreed to open a temporary pontoon bridge at Novi Sad as often as three times a week, beginning in March. About 800 vessels passed by Novi Sad in October, and that should rise to 10,000 a year when clearing work is complete.

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Today: Scaffolding Hearing
description: The City Council has scheduled a public hearing on a bill requiring stricter training and a certificate of fitness for workers who build or repair scaffolding. Committee Room, City Hall, Manhattan, 1 p.m. Information: (212) 788-7069.

title: In San Juan, Bloomberg Promises Closer Ties
description: He stopped short of calling Puerto Rico the sixth borough, but Mayor-elect Michael R. Bloomberg today proclaimed his commitment to working closely with its government to meet business and education goals on the island and in New York City, where almost 800,000 Puerto Ricans live.

title: US Airways' Top Executive Is Leaving at a Critical Time
description: The chief executive of US Airways, Rakesh Gangwal, resigned yesterday, departing at one of the most critical times in the airline's history. He will be succeeded by his longtime mentor, Stephen M. Wolf, who has served as chairman since handing the reins to Mr. Gangwal three years ago.

title: $38 Billion Tax Hiatus Proposed
description: Republicans in the Senate said today that they would support a new idea for giving the economy an immediate boost -- freeing employers and employees from paying Social Security payroll taxes for one month -- in an effort to break a partisan impasse over the proposed economic stimulus package.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Dealer Charged In Car Smuggling
description: The owner of a used-car lot in Brooklyn was arrested yesterday on charges that he smuggled or tried to smuggle 20 stolen luxury cars to Russia and Latvia, the United States Customs Service said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: New Subway Line To Start
description: Gov. George E. Pataki announced yesterday that service on the new V subway line between Queens and Manhattan, delayed by the attack on the World Trade Center, will begin on Dec. 16. The line is intended to relieve overcrowding on the E and F lines in Queens. It was made possible by a $645 million tunnel that connects the subway lines along Queens Boulevard to the 63rd Street tunnel beneath the East River. Transit officials say the new line will increase subway service along Queens Boulevard by as much as 20 percent. The line will run weekdays from 6 a.m. until midnight between Forest Hills-71st Avenue in Queens and the Second Avenue station on the Lower East Side. Randy Kennedy (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, MILTON
description: SINGER-Milton died in his sleep November 26, 2001 just short of his 90th birthday. He was a high school educator and the owner and director of Camp Dunmore for Boys in Salisbury, Vermont, which he founded in 1946 with his partner and long time friend, Edward Jacobson. He played football for Dickinson High School in Jersey City, Syracuse University and the New York Giants organization (1935-36). He also served in the Navy (1941-1946) achieving the rank of Lieutenant Commander. He is survived by his wife of 54 years, Beatrice; sons, Lawrence and Andrew; and grandchildren, Robert and Catherine.

title: Innovative Sportswear Labels Customize Clothes  and Ads
description: PARIS  Ask Renzo Rosso, the jeans-clad, scraggly haired founder of the iconoclastic Italian jeans giant Diesel, what he likes best to do at work and he will probably say "Drive my product managers crazy."

title: Purloined Harem Girls, and Other Russian Mysteries
description: Since the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991 and the opening of its borders, Russia's cash-starved museums, as well as private collections and churches, have come under increasing attack from thieves hoping to cash in on the country's treasures by selling them in the West.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Chip Machine Sales Slip Further
description: In the third quarter, companies that produce chip-making equipment, still suffering through their worst slump ever, shipped products worth less than half as much in total and took in a quarter as many new orders as in the period a year earlier. Semiconductor Equipment and Materials International, a trade association based in San Jose, Calif., said equipment suppliers worldwide had reported shipments worth $5.6 billion, a 56 percent drop from the $13 billion in the 2000 period and a 20 percent drop from the second quarter of this year. Projecting a bleak outlook for shipments in the fourth quarter and early next year, when goods ordered from July to September will be shipped, new orders last quarter were $3.47 billion, down 77 percent from the $15.49 billion in the third quarter of 2000. ''We don't see clear signals for a sustainable recovery in the near term,'' said Elizabeth Schumann, the association's director of research and statistics. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: School Volunteers Up
description: The urge to help that sprang up after the Sept. 11 attacks has produced a bumper crop of school volunteers. Learnings Leaders, a nonprofit organization that trains and places volunteers in New York City public schools, says that since Sept. 11 more than 1,400 volunteers have signed up, a fourfold increase compared with the same period last year, the group says. CAROL KELLERMANN, its executive director, said, ''People need to feel connected to the city in a meaningful way now, and there is nothing that makes you feel more connected or more hopeful than working with our children.''

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the arts pages on Monday about the exhibition ''Weegee's Story: From the Berinson Collection,'' at the Philadelphia Art Alliance, misstated the ownership of the collection. It is a private holding in Germany, not part of the International Center of Photography in New York.

title: National Briefing | South: Tennessee: Tornado Kills 1, Injures 8
description: A tornado with wind gusts reaching 160 miles an hour struck Oakland, a rural community about 80 miles west of Nashville, Monday night, killing a 32-year-old woman and seriously injuring her husband and two sons, along with five others. The Henry County sheriff's department said the eight injured were in critical to stable condition at Vanderbilt University Medical Center in Nashville. The state's Emergency Management Agency said that at least 10 homes were destroyed in the county and 46 other homes were damaged. Emily Yellin (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about talks in Bonn on Afghanistan's political future misstated the whereabouts of the president of Afghanistan's Northern Alliance, Burhanuddin Rabbani. His comments were made on television from the United Arab Emirates, not in Germany.

title: Turks Train 13 Guards For Allies
description: Turkey, one of the Bush administration's strongest allies in the Muslim world, is training 13 security guards sent by the Northern Alliance, government officials here said today.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Public Security Criticized
description: Security professionals, terrorism experts and academics told the City Council's Public Safety Committee yesterday that security in the city's public spaces must remain high or be improved to avoid a repeat of the Sept. 11 terrorist attack. Shalom Oz Uziel, owner of an Israeli security firm, said he saw a ''lot of holes'' in the city's security. But Richard Dietl, a retired detective perhaps best known for his 1988 autobiography, ''One Tough Cop,'' criticized the hearing itself for not having security officials testifying, including the police. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Nets' Defense Takes Bow Against Bulls
description: The Nets had at least two things in their favor tonight. They were home after a five-game road trip and they were playing the Chicago Bulls.

title: In Drive to Extradite Pilot, U.S. Tones Down Charges
description: The United States pushed ahead today with legal moves to extradite an Algerian pilot arrested here two months ago in connection with the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Diamond Diplomacy
description: It is a perverse alchemy of diamonds that they are so easily transformed into arms. In Angola, Sierra Leone and Congo, warlords and terror groups mine diamonds to finance wars -- whose main purpose is control of those very diamond fields. This week legitimate diamond-producing nations, other governments and industry leaders are meeting in Botswana, a country that has used its diamonds wisely, to limit the ability of warlords to profit from the diamonds under their control.

title: Russian Statement Lifts Oil Price
description: A government oil commission here said today that Russia might make deeper cuts in oil exports beginning in January.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMAN, ALICE HAUSMAN
description: HERMAN-Alice Hausman. 93 died Friday. A long time Career gal/advertising executive for many of New York City's top agencies beginning in the 1930's. Writing catchy copy for accounts ranging from Gerber Baby Food to Underwood Typewriters; Clairol, Crisco, Cover-Girl, Fab and Halo shampoo to name a few -''You can always tell a Halo girl'' -she was elected Vice President at SSC&B in the 1960's and later Compton serving also as Creative Supervisor. Always wearing her trademark hats and winning professional awards including Effie, she mentored countless young aspirants, used hard-earned clout for her fee free head-hunting service and fought doggedly for women's recognition in business. Born Alice Valentine Hausman Febrary 14, 1908, she met Art Director Al Herman while working together briefly and married in 1938 until his death in 1977. After ''retirement'' she remained active as a hospital volunteer until two years ago, as well as counseling, through AWED and on her own. Alice Herman is survived by her sister, Ruth Hausman, her son Alan, granddaughters Alex and Drew and many dear friends.

title: Whole Lotta Rememberin' (and Baldin') Goin' On
description: The hair alone is enough to keep cultural anthropologists busy for years. Sam Phillips, the founder of Sun Records and the first man to record Elvis Presley, says Presley ''made his hair beautiful'' not with the aid of styling products but by willing it to be so. ''Now do you all believe I'm telling you a lie?'' he drawls, leaning across a table at a Memphis cafe and peering at a bunch of white-haired guys who played for his label in the old days.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Rebels Attack Again
description: Maoist rebels answered the government's decision to mobilize the army against them with another attack on a police post, killing four policemen and wounding six others about 250 miles west of the capital, Katmandu. More than 280 people have been killed in the conflict since Friday. The government hopes a newly declared state of emergency, which suspends most civil liberties and allows use of the army, will help quell the rebellion, which has spread to about a third of the impoverished nation's districts. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VANDOW, BENJAMIN
description: VANDOW-Benjamin. Age 85, on November 24, 2001 after a brief illness. Beloved husband of Blanche, cherished father of daughters, Marjorie Vandow and Ellen Klein, and step-sons, Alan Chodosh and the late Daniel Chodosh. Adored grandfather of Gabriel and Rebecca Fields, Michelle and Amy Chodosh, Jonathan, Ethan and Yael Chodosh, and Lonnie and Brielle Klein. Dear brother of Jeannette Silverstein. Devoted husband for 34 years to the late Lillian Vandow. Ben was a manufacturers representative in the gift industry for over 50 years as owner and president of Van Dow-Fenton, Inc., a leader in its industry. He was loved by all who knew him. His memory will be an inspiration to all who had the privilege of knowing this dear gentle man. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Whitestone Hebrew Centre, 12-45 Clintonville Street, Whitestone, New York 11357.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: The Bronx: Work Begins On Fish Market
description: Work has begun on a new Fulton Fish Market in the Bronx to replace the historic but cramped market in Lower Manhattan. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani broke ground on Monday on the $85 million, 450,000-square-foot refrigerated center in the Hunts Point Market. The 59 fish wholesalers and 400 sales clerks and journeymen are expected to move in by summer 2003. The present market is the largest in the United States but has been considered for years to be too antiquated to accommodate its daily tonnage of fish. Charlie LeDuff

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Cuts At Military Contractor
description: The military contractor BAE Systems said it would end production of regional jetliners and cut more than 1,650 jobs because of falling demand for new aircraft after the Sept. 11 terror attacks. The chief executive, John Weston, said BAE's small and unprofitable regional aircraft business was ''no longer viable in this environment.'' The company said the moves and other restructuring would cost about $330 million after tax this year. BAE Systems got 70 percent of its sales in the half-year to June 30 from military projects.

title: Czerkawski Finally Has Puck Roll His Way
description: Mariusz Czerkawski had known this night would come sooner or later -- a night when even his passes would bank off a defenseman, roll off the goaltender and go into the goal, as if designed by Rube Goldberg.

title: Soft as Flowers, Fresh as Fruit And Low Calorie
description: Elder flowers, handpicked in summer, are pressed and mixed with sparkling spring water to make Elderflower Press, a fragrant soft drink by Bottle Green, a company in England, which has a branch in Ontario. Lime flowers, or linden, are crushed with whole limes to make a delicately tart Limeflower Press. Cranberry-orange, lemon grass and ginger, and citrus are the other flavors, and all are 50 to 70 calories a bottle. They could serve as bar mixers. They are about $2 for 8.4 ounces and about $3 for 25 ounces at Fairway, Whole Foods Chelsea, Life thyme and some Food Emporiums. Bottle Green's concentrates, called cordials, in spiced berry, raspberry-grapefruit, elder flower, ginger-lemon grass and cranberry-orange, will be available for $6 or so for 17 ounces in some stores in coming weeks. They can be poured over fruit or diluted to make drinks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKHEIMER, GEORGE A. DR.
description: BERKHEIMER-George A. Dr. Of Harrisburg, PA, New York City and Nantucket, MA, died on November 22, 2001, at his home in Manhattan of heart failure after a long illness. He was 89. The son of Dr. George C. and Bess Fisher Berkheimer, he was born in Windber, PA, graduated from Mercersberg Academy and Princeton University. In 1938 he graduated from the Johns Hopkins School of Medicine in Baltimore and by 1942 was completing his residency in orthopedic surgery when he left to serve in the U.S. Army, volunteering to join a group of his Hopkins medical colleagues, the 118th General Hospital, heading for duty in the Pacific Theater of World War II. The group, headquartered primarily in Sydney, Australia, eventually moved north, and Dr. Berkheimer, by 1946 a lieutenant colonel, was in Leyte when he was discharged to go home. Soon after he joined the medical staff of Harrisburg Hospital and by 1950 had become its Chief of Orthopedicsthereby embarking on his 35 year career as a surgeon and teacher, the latter a commitment that he cherished increasingly as the years passed. ''A splendid man, industrious, conscientious and dedicated,'' the Hospital's Board termed him in a tribute given when he retired from active practice in 1980. He was also a Fellow of the American Academy of Orthopedic Surgeons and a Diplomate of the American Board of Orthopedics. To his friends and family, he was a gentle man with a wonderful sense of humor and a devoted companion. A member of Rolling Rock Club in Ligonier, PA, he also belonged to the Nassau Club in Princeton and The Union Club of New York City. On Nantucket Island, he was a member of The Nantucket Yacht Club, the Sankaty Head Golf Club and The Wharf Rat Club. Dr. Berkheimer is survived by his wife of 21 years, Margaret Yates Berkheimer. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, November 29th at 11A.M. in the East Hall of St. James Episcopal Church at Madison Avenue and 71st Street, in New York, entry through the 71st Street door. Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to The Nantucket Conservation Foundation, 118 Cliff Rd., Nantucket, MA 02554, or the Nantucket Cottage Hospital, 57 Prospect Street, Nantucket, MA 02554.

title: ALLIANCE DECLARES REVOLT IS CRUSHED
description: Northern Alliance soldiers, backed by American and British Special Operations forces, said today that they had crushed a revolt by Taliban prisoners inside a 19th-century fortress, and described a deadly final battle in which they drove the rebels from their last stronghold by pouring oil into a basement, setting it alight and then opening fire with their lone Soviet T-55 tank.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: EMI Buys Video Distributor
description: The EMI Group agreed to buy a 4.76 percent stake in the Newsplayer Group, which distributes videos over the Internet, for 32,903, or $46,448, in cash. EMI has the option to raise its stake to 5 percent next year, the companies said. The agreement allows Newsplayer, based in London, to include EMI video of bands like Genesis and artists like Nat King Cole in its database. Like other music companies, EMI, also based in London, has been seeking ways to make money from online music, as sales from conventional retail outlets fall. EMI shares, which are traded in London, fell 7.50 pence, or 2.14 percent, to 343 pence. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: New CUNY Student Trustee
description: RICHARD J. NUNEZ-LAWRENCE is the new student trustee on the 17-member board of the City University of New York, and he already knows many of the 17 campuses. A Harlem resident, Mr. Nunez-Lawrence, 25, attended Hostos Community College and got degrees from La Guardia Community College and City College, where he was an English major. He is working on a graduate degree in political science at Brooklyn College.

title: Giants: Issues, but Few Answers
description: An exasperated Jim Fassel gathered his players on Monday and bluntly told his team that they had his head spinning. He said he had tried being nice and then more demanding. Conducted practices with pads and then no pads. Coddled them, pushed them, asked for their input and had given them every chance to find the right leadership mix and answers among themselves.

title: 2 Pakistanis Linked to Papers on Anthrax Weapons
description: Pakistan said today that it had detained two retired nuclear scientists after the recent discovery in offices they had used in Afghanistan of documents describing ways to use anthrax as a weapon and other suspicious material.

title: Guatemalan Family Ties
description: I grew up in Quebec and went to college in the late 60's and early 70's. I was a student demonstrator, and when I graduated, I wanted to do something entrepreneurial and different. I had a tremendous desire to see the world and decided to go to Mexico and import handicrafts. After a few months there, I had to renew my visa, and Guatemala was the closest place to go.

title: The Workers on an Assembly Line of A's
description: To the Editor:

title: Science, Morality and Cloning
description: To the Editor:

title: G.M. NAMES EXECUTIVE TO OVERSEE TAKEOVER OF DAEWOO
description: D. Nick Reilly, General Motors' vice president for European sales, marketing and aftersales, will oversee the transition of Daewoo Motors to G.M. control, beginning on Jan. 1. Once G.M. has completed due diligence and the takeover of Daewoo is final, Mr. Reilly will become president of the new company, G.M. said. Jonathan Browning, the former managing director of Ford Motor's Jaguar Car unit, will succeed Mr. Reilly at G.M. Europe.

title: Brosius Exits, but Who Is Behind Door No. 2?
description: More parts are officially peeling away from the Yankees. We knew about Paul O'Neill and Luis Sojo going home and staying home. We figured that Scott Brosius, Tino Martinez and Chuck Knoblauch would play elsewhere next season. We realized that Orlando Hernndez might be given a new baseball address, too.

title: U.S. PLANES BOMB TALIBAN COMPOUND IN KANDAHAR AREA
description: American warplanes bombed a compound southeast of Kandahar today that the Pentagon said was used by leaders of the Taliban, Al Qaeda and Al Wafa, an Islamic foundation accused of terrorist activities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, DOROTHY R. MEYER
description: GOLDSTEIN-Dorothy R. Meyer. Beloved wife of Lawrence. Dearest aunt of Thomas S. Meyer, Brendan S. Meyer and Ellen N. Sandoval. Reposing at Morton Funeral Home/Ridgewood Chapel, 663 Grandview Ave., Ridgewood, Queens, Wednesday 2-5 and 79PM. Religious service Thursday 10AM at Emmaus Lutheran Church. Interment Maple Grove Cemetery.

title: Nokia Sees Weak Sales Into 2002
description: Smarting from slowing demand for mobile phones and the aggressive rollout of new products by competitors, Nokia, the world's biggest manufacturer of such devices, reduced estimates today for the number of handsets it expects consumers to buy in 2001, and said the market would continue to shrink through the early part of next year.

title: George Vecsey's Postcards
description: George Vecsey contributed e-mail postcards from the Summer Games in Sydney. He will continue his daily deliveries during the Winter Games in Salt Lake City. Here are some examples of his dispatches from Down Under.

title: A Secret Trial: It's Not Our Way
description: To the Editor:

title: Poetry Award Given Out
description: KENNETH KOCH, the poet and Columbia University English professor, won the first award of the Phi Beta Kappa poetry competition this month for a recent collection, ''New Addresses: Poems'' (Knopf). He got $10,000 and a bronze medal. The other finalists were ANN LAUTERBACH of Bard College; CHARLES NORTH of Pace University; AMY GERSTLER of the College of Design in California; and DARA WIER of the University of Massachusetts-Amherst. JOHN ASHBERY was the judge. Nearly 200 poets submitted work to the competition. Karen W. Arenson

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SURREY, JANE
description: SURREY-Jane. On November 25. Mourned by cousin Susan and her many beloved friends. A future memorial celebration is planned.

title: A Conductor and a Soprano Take New Roles at the Met
description: The Metropolitan Opera has long been accused of inviting too few first-rank conductors to the house for the nights when James Levine is absent. So the overdue Met debut of Christoph Eschenbach on Monday night in Strauss's ''Arabella'' was an important step.

title: C.I.A. Officer Dies in Afghan Prison Riot
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28  The Central Intelligence Agency said today that one of its officers was killed in the Taliban prison uprising in Mazar-e-Sharif on Sunday, the first American death in Afghanistan since the United States' military campaign began.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Terrorists and invaders, come to ruin our country. I wonder what they are thinking now.''

title: A Russian Voice in NATO
description: Just a few months ago the idea of giving Russia a role in NATO management would have seemed far-fetched. The cold war was receding, but not quite that fast. Then came Sept. 11, and with it a potentially historic shift in Russia's relations with the West. Last week NATO's top official proposed a partnership with Russia that would let Moscow help shape alliance decision-making in certain areas of shared concern. It is a bold idea. While those specific areas need to be more precisely defined, combating terrorism, limiting the spread of advanced weapons and managing peacekeeping responsibilities are likely candidates.

title: Science, Morality and Cloning
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: No Verdict In Gibson Trial
description: The federal jury considering bribery and fraud charges against Kenneth A. Gibson, the former mayor of Newark, said it was deadlocked yesterday after six days of deliberations. The trial judge urged them to try again. In a departure from the standard instruction to deadlocked juries, Judge William G. Bassler told jurors they need not be unanimous on all counts and could report a partial verdict, but on only those charges on which they were unanimous. The instruction was delivered over defense lawyers' objections. Judge Bassler also said one more impasse would trigger a mistrial.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLOVER, PRICE PERKINS
description: GLOVER-Price Perkins, 83. On November 23, 2001 of cancer. Beloved husband of Isobel, loving father of Jonathan and Julie, devoted brother of Dorothy Johns. A native Virginian and long-time resident of Manhattan, he was a pilot both in the Navy and for 35 years with Pan American Airways. A respected collector of American furniture and the English decorative arts, Price founded his antique shop in 1971 with his close friend Dunbar Bostwick. We will miss his loving presence, gentle charm, keen humor and rare dignity. The family would like to extend its deepest gratitude to the doctors and nursing staff of New York Hospital for their tireless and devoted care. A memorial service will be held at the Brick Presbyterian Church, 1140 Park Avenue, December 10 at 4 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations would be appreciated to: Genitourinary Oncology Research Fund, C/O David M. Nanus M.D., 525 East 68th Street, ST-359, New York, NY 10021.

title: Junk Bonds May Rise Again if Economy Is Near a Bottom
description: If the reports are true that the economy is already near the bottom of its 10th recession since World War II, then high-yield junk bonds are going to look inviting again.

title: Egypt Puts Up Vacancy Signs
description: The developers who initially conceived of building Egypt's first private airport three years ago had visions of tourists by the thousands whisked every week from Europe's cold, gray winter directly to the warm sunshine and azure waters of a $1.2 billion resort on Egypt's southern Red Sea coast.

title: Official Says He'll Miss Screening Goal
description: The secretary of transportation said today that his department could not meet the January deadline established in the new aviation security law for screening all airline baggage for explosives, drawing criticism from Congressional authors of the measure.

title: A Road Map to Coping With Disaster, Legally
description: THE PRICE OF TERROR

title: Syracuse to Play In Bowl in Phoenix
description: Syracuse, Stanford and Fresno State accepted bowl invitations yesterday, and Southern California will play Utah in the Las Vegas Bowl on Dec. 25.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, LENARD S.
description: JACOBS-Lenard S. Of Morristown, on Tuesday, November 20, 2001 formerly of Manhattan and Rye, New York. Father of Michelle. Grandfather of Jagger and Stryker. Brother of Barbara, Mildred and Edward. He was a pioneer in the entertainment licensing business at Warner Brothers and in his own business before retiring. He served in the Navy in World War II. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Valerie Fund, 2101 Milburn Avenue, Maplewood, NJ 07040.

title: Q & A / Michael Zaoui : A Pause in Consolidation
description: Michael Zaoui, head of European mergers and acquisitions at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, is a longtime adviser to the Italian fashion house Gucci, one of several companies that have built sprawling luxury goods stables through a series of high-profile acquisitions. With Eric Pfanner of the International Herald Tribune, Zaoui discussed the outlook for mergers and acquisitions in the industry.

title: In Auctions, Vive the Opened Market; Legal Changes Allow Sotheby's and Christie's to Hold First Sales on French Turf
description: As Sotheby's lives through the uncertainty of the price-fixing trial of its former chairman in New York, it can at least boast to be making history this week in Paris when it becomes the first foreign auction house to hold a public sale in France. Christie's, its main competitor, will follow suit next week, but it was stubborn campaigning by Sotheby's that broke the monopoly granted to French auctioneers by Henri II in 1556.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCANENY, ERNEST
description: McANENY - Ernest. Riverdale Country School extends its deepest sympathies to the family and friends of Ernest McAneny, the son of the School's first Chairman of the Board, an alumnus (Class of 1925), a revered former faculty member, and, in recent years, the School archivist. Ernest taught math, English and history to generations of fourth, fifth and sixth graders. An avid thespian and musician, he also coached actors throughout twenty-four years of Gilbert and Sullivan productions at RCS. As the School's first archivist, Ernest compiled a documented history of the School and was particularly proud of the photo catalogs of faculty and students. In recognition of his work as archivist, the Class of 1957 dedicated the Ernest McAneny '25 Alumni Room and Archives in his honor in 1997. An active alumnus, Ernest was twice awarded the School's Alumni Spirit Award in recognition of his work on behalf of the School. In 1998, he was honored when the Alumni Association Executive Committee unanimously voted to re-name the award the Ernest McAneny '25 Alumni Spirit Award. Part of our School family for more than eighty years, Ernest, or ''Mr. Riverdale'' as he was affectionately known, will be greatly missed by generations of Riverdalians. Richard S. Zinman, Chairman John R. Johnson, Headmaster

title: Questioning the President's Authority
description: America is fighting against ''the most evil kinds of people,'' President Bush said last week, explaining his executive order creating special military tribunals for foreign terrorists. ''I need to have that extraordinary option at my fingertips.''

title: LVMH Completes Donna Karan Deal
description: LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton, the maker of luxury goods, said yesterday that it had completed its acquisition of Donna Karan International Inc. for $243 million in cash and assumed debt.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Jospin Inquiry Dropped
description: Citing a lack of evidence, a magistrate has dropped an investigation into accusations that Prime Minister Lionel Jospin was involved in paying two people for nonexistent jobs at a development agency he led before coming to power. The inquiry had been requested by a taxpayers' association in the southwest Haute-Garonne region. Lawyers representing the association said they intended to appeal the decision. Suzanne Daley (NYT)

title: Vehicle Sales Stayed Robust In November
description: Auto sales have remained surprisingly strong this month easing the recession, economists say, and possibly shortening it, with automakers beginning to announce plans to increase production more than initially expected early next year to rebuild inventories.

title: Jordanian Charged With Lies To Grand Jury Is Granted Bail
description: Over the government's objections, a federal judge in Manhattan granted bail yesterday to a Jordanian student who was charged with lying before a grand jury investigating the Sept. 11 terror attacks. The judge said that the student was not likely to flee, and she questioned the strength of the perjury charges against him.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Albany Court Rejects Suit Against Clergy
description: New York's highest court has ruled that members of the clergy may not be sued for divulging information given to them in confidence.

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Growth Slows
description: South Africa's economic growth slowed to an annualized 1.2 percent in the third quarter, a two-year low, as manufacturing and mining production slid because demand for exports fell and agricultural output declined. Growth slowed from a revised 1.8 percent in the prior quarter and from 3.4 percent last year.

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Pope Appeals For Clemency
description: Pope John Paul II has asked Gov. Michael F. Easley, a Roman Catholic, to spare the life of John Hardy Rose, a convicted murderer who is scheduled to be executed on Friday. At the request of a Durham priest, the Vatican ambassador to the United States wrote Mr. Easley on behalf of the pope to grant clemency to promote ''a culture of life and nonviolence.'' A spokesman for the governor said he would consider the appeal. Kevin Sack (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; Nets Have New Look: Winners
description: IF a pro basketball team leads the Atlantic Division and no one is there to see it, does it really lead the division?

title: A Lonely Crusade Warning Africans of AIDS
description: As early as 1990, when AIDS was almost unknown in South Africa, there was one man in the Hlabisa Health District who saw the rising dust of the epidemic over the horizon and tried to stop it.

title: Torre Tells Giambi First Base Will Be His
description: Yankees Manager Joe Torre told the free agent Jason Giambi that he would be the starting first baseman, not a designated hitter for any extended period, if Giambi signed to play for the Yankees. Torre contacted Giambi on Monday and they talked for about 10 minutes.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about talks in Bonn on Afghanistan's political future misstated the whereabouts of the president of Afghanistan's Northern Alliance, Burhanuddin Rabbani. His comments were made on television from the United Arab Emirates, not in Germany.

title: JOHNSON & JOHNSON UNIT WILL PAY $45 MILLION SETTLEMENT
description: The Lifescan unit of Johnson & Johnson agreed to pay $45 million to settle a class-action lawsuit brought by consumers who said that meters used to test diabetics' blood-sugar levels were defective. More than 100,000 plaintiffs will receive refunds of about $300 each under the settlement. The agreement remains subject to the approval of Judge Jeremy Fogel of United States District Court in San Jose, Calif. The accord comes almost one year after LifeScan, of Milpitas, Calif., agreed to pay $60 million in civil and criminal penalties to the federal government after pleading guilty to failing to report known defects in the SureStep blood-glucose monitoring devices. This settlement ''in no way implies or acknowledges any wrongdoing by LifeScan,'' Johnson & Johnson said in a statement.

title: Improvisations on Chat, Taken From the Internet
description: Program notes describe Daniel Aschwanden, the founder of the Austrian performance art troupe Bilderwerfer, as an experienced improviser. In ''back2private,'' the improvisational evening-long piece with which the company made its New York debut at La MaMa E.T.C., Mr. Aschwanden took an enormous risk and lost.

title: 'TOMORROW IN THE TIMES'
description: A new daily guide gives a sampling of the paper's coming events and offerings -- in print, online and on the air. It also lists reader services, with e-mail addresses for executives and departments. Today, Page S5.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Election Disaster For Leftists
description: Center-right parties won 15 of 16 mayoral elections in Sicily over the weekend. Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi's coalition was expected to do well, especially after winning all 61 of formerly left-leaning Sicily's parliamentary seats in last May's general election. But the rout was a surprise and a new low for the Italian left. Melinda Henneberger (NYT)

title: Assembling Scattered Works By the Cognoscenti's Painter
description: Many a reliable judge has been fascinated by the work of the American painter Louis M. Eilshemius (1864-1941), 45 of whose paintings are on view until Dec. 30 at the National Academy of Design in New York.

title: Student Charged in Plot She Warned About
description: A 17-year-old girl who the police say warned a teacher about a student plot to stage a Columbine-style rampage killing at her New Bedford high school even as she continued to participate in it was charged today with conspiracy to commit murder.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, LOU
description: NEWMAN-Lou. Happy Birthday, Darling. You had Star Billing yesterday! I can hear your cheers! Forever Your Sweetheart, Marian

title: Family Awaits News on Cubans Lost at Sea
description: Last week, David Castro believed that his daughter and granddaughter had drowned along with 28 others aboard a boat trying to make its way from Cuba to Florida. This week, he is not so sure.

title: A Very Special Rivalry
description: Late Sunday night at the Naval Academy, Michael Wagoner awakened to an odor unlike any he had ever smelled. Being a defensive end, having lived a life around football locker rooms, he was not unfamiliar with pungent aromas. Still, he had not previously encountered the fragrant bouquet of spoiled crab meat and sour milk with which Navy plebes had swabbed the deck of Bancroft Hall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, BERNARD I.
description: HELLER-Bernard I. Died peacefully November 27, 2001. He is survived by his loving daughters Abbe Heller and Cynthia Flowers, sons-in-law Scott Kurnit and Robert Flowers, grandchildren Perry and Lindsey Flowers and loving companion Phyllis Weiss. His wit and wisdom will carry on within all those he touched. Memorial services will be held Thursday, November 29, 2001, 10 AM, at the Glascott Funeral Home, 102-03 Metropolitan Avenue, Forest Hills, NY, (718) 268-4466.

title: One Spoonful And You're in Bilbao
description: Miguel & Valentino ice creams from Spain offer rich rewards for those with an adventurous palate. Some flavors are tangy edged like Roquefort cheese with walnuts, Greek yogurt with caramelized pineapple and fresh cheese with raspberries. Tamer choices are Spanish clementine, mellow pear and dulce de leche. The ice creams, in 17-ounce tubs, cost $8.99 at Gourmet Garage stores and $7.99 at Tuller Premium Food, 199 Court Street (Bergen Street), Brooklyn.

title: A Red Trying to Live Down Its Name
description: IT is time to stand up for petite sirah. These days, if a red wine isn't ''exploding with flavor,'' a ''blockbuster'' or ''super rich,'' it doesn't count for much. Petite sirah can be all those things, but it has never really caught on.

title: Judge Dismisses All but One Lawsuit From Columbine Attack
description: A federal judge today dismissed all but one of the lawsuits in which relatives and survivors of the 1999 Columbine High School shootings accused the sheriff's department and school officials of not doing enough to prevent the attack.

title: Lead Bidder for Red Sox Has The Times as Investor
description: One of the most intriguing sales of a team in baseball history is scheduled to reach its climax Thursday when prospective buyers submit their final bids for a majority interest in the Boston Red Sox.

title: Census Said to Misplace Many Prisons and Dorms
description: There are two basic mistakes you can make in a census: You can miscount people, and you can put them in the wrong place.

title: McGreevey Seeks to Bolster State's Chain of Command in Medical Disasters
description: Governor-elect James E. McGreevey said today that he would give New Jersey's emergency-management officials more decision-making power in future medical disasters, after the anthrax crisis here revealed missing links in the state's chain of command for responding to bioterrorism.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Mount Holly: Rescuers Accused Of Arson
description: Two volunteer rescue workers are being held on arson charges involving 15 fires in Burlington County, including one at the building where they worked, the Burlington County prosecutor's office said. The workers -- James T. Shue, 23, of Pennsauken, and Douglas S. Mandichak, 19, of Maple Shade -- were members of the Maple Shade Heavy Rescue Company. They were ordered to undergo psychiatric tests. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Supreme Court Dismisses Challenge in Its Main Affirmative Action Case
description: The marquee affirmative action case of the Supreme Court's current term evaporated today when the justices dismissed a constitutional challenge to a federal highway contracting program and conceded that the case had been ''improvidently granted.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANDELMAN, RUTH
description: HANDELMAN-Ruth. On November 26, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Victor, loving mother of David and his wife Janet, and Howard, devoted grandmother of Joanna, Peter and Michael, great-grandmother of Siri and Emily. Services Thursday 11:30 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Brodeur Wanders and the Devils Get Lost
description: One of Martin Brodeur's strengths is that he handles the puck around his goal so deftly, teams consider him an extra defenseman. Tonight he showed that he is not as sharp when he ventures away from his net, and the Devils paid for it in a 6-0 loss to the Pittsburgh Penguins.

title: Chile Letter to Be Retested for Anthrax
description: Federal officials said last night that they were doing extra tests to check findings from Chile and a Miami laboratory indicating that a letter received by a doctor in Santiago contained anthrax.

title: Footlights
description: Downtown Goes Far Uptown

title: Now Appearing: A Prosciutto in the Round
description: When prosciutto di Parma ham is boned before it is sold, it is pressed into a flattened shape, resulting in the typical elongated slice. But there is another kind of prosciutto, called rotondo, with a fuller, rounded slice that results from rolling and tying the boned ham. It has the usual nut-sweet flavor but is a little moister. Rotondo is now available at Agata & Valentina, where Eric Menal, left, the deli manager, sells it for $17.99 a pound. It is also sold at Citarella for $19.96 a pound.

title: Parents in TriBeCa Cast Votes On When to Reopen P.S. 234
description: Parents at one of the elementary schools closest to the smoldering ruins of the World Trade Center are voting to decide how soon to move their children back to the school, now that emergency workers are no longer using it.

title: Fed Official Backs Aggressive Rate Cuts
description: An influential member of the Federal Reserve said today that it should not shy away from continuing to ease monetary policy aggressively just because its benchmark interest rate is beginning to approach zero.

title: Genome Offers 'Fingerprint' For Anthrax
description: Scientists have decoded the genome of the anthrax bacterium and are sharing their findings with law enforcement officials eager for clues about who is using the lethal microbe as a deadly weapon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLIEDMAN, MARVIN, DR.
description: GLIEDMAN-Marvin, Dr. A great doctor, a loving friend. We will treasure our memories. Alice and Fred Rudin

title: On Third Avenue, Sightings of Cinnamon Puffs
description: Yura & Company, an Upper East Side catering shop, has opened a spacious bakery with a broad antique oak-and-marble counter. It is at 1659 Third Avenue (93rd Street). The counter is laden with ten der muffinlike cinnamon puffs ($1 each); marble, lemon and chocolate tea cakes ($4.50 each); moist gingerbread cake that serves eight ($18); and apple-cider pies ($18), baked or ready to bake. The icing on a New York-style black and white cookie ($1.50) is particularly yummy. Tiny Christmas cupcakes, $12 a dozen, can be ordered. A few cafe tables are available for those who cannot wait to take their treats home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAVALIERI, NILINDA M.
description: CAVALIERI-Nilinda M. On November 26, 2001. Beloved mother of Frank. Cherished sister of Joseph and Jeanne. Mass of Christian Burial, Thursday 10:00 AM, Our Lady of Peace Church.

title: On the Upper West Side, Italian Food Without Tricks
description: AS goes the bread, so goes the restaurant, or so one old saw puts it. The link is rarely so direct, but in the case of Meridiana, a middle-aged Italian restaurant on the far Upper West Side, it's a precise statement of fact.

title: Bats in the Belfry?
description: In 1941, a dental surgeon from Pennsylvania, hit on the notion of outfitting bats with incendiary devices and dumping them from planes onto Japanese cities and factories. The White House gave the green light to this proposal, but a series of tests with dummy bombs proved disastrous.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCABE, EUGENE J.
description: McCABE-Eugene J., 83. Of Rumson, N.J., died Sunday at home. Born on February 14, 1918, Mr. McCabe lived in NYC before moving to Rumson 43 years ago. He was predeceased by his parents, Eugene J. & Katherine McCabe, and his sister Catherine, all of NYC; a son Michael, of Rumson, killed in the 9/11 WTC attack; and a granddaughter Shannon. Survivng are his beloved wife of 48 years, Eleanor; two daughters, Mary Ellen Kirschner (Robert) and Suzanne, both of NYC; two sons, Eugene J. (Maureen), Newport, R.I., and Nicolas (Rob Florczak) of NYC; his daughter-in-law Lynn McCabe of Rumson; and 7 grandchildren: Cassidy, Regan, Liam, Nicholas, Kevin, Jack, and Riley. The family will receive friends Friday from 3 to 8 at the Molly Pitcher Inn, Red Bank, NJ. Those wishing to pay respects may also call at John E. Day Funeral Home, 85 Riverside Ave., Red Bank, NJ during those hours. A funeral Mass will be celebrated Saturday at 10AM at Holy Cross Church, Rumson. In lieu of flowers, donations to the VNA of Central Jersey Hospice Program; Rumson First Aid, or the Michael McCabe Children's Education Fund, P.O. Box 526, Rumson, NJ, 07760, would be greatly appreciated.

title: For Cheese, Farm to Home, the Easy Way
description: Most of the cheeses in this article can be bought at cheese shops and specialty food stores around the country for about $13 to $24 a pound. All are available at Artisan Cheese, 2413 California Street, San Francisco, (415) 929-8610, and in New York at Murray's Cheese Shop, 257 Bleecker Street, (212) 243-3289.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NERI, JOSEPH MICHAEL
description: NERI-Joseph Michael. Age 69. Of Saint Cloud, FL. Died Saturday, November 10, 2001. Mr. Neri was retired from the New York City Sanitation Department. Born in Manhattan, N.Y., he moved to Saint Cloud in 1984 from Brooklyn. He was a member of the Knights of Columbus in New York and he was Catholic. Survivors are son Joseph Michael Neri, Jr., daughter-in-law Ellen Neri, granddaughter Nicole Neri, all of Massapequa, sisters Marie Beeg of West New York, N.J., Ann Coppolla of North Bergen, N.J. and brother Richard Neri of Brentwood, New York. A memorial mass will be celebrated Friday, November 30, 3PM, Saint Rose of Lima Catholic Church, Massapequa, N.Y. Inquires, Osceola Memory Gardens Funeral Home, 407-957-2511.

title: Lloyd's Sees Higher Losses From Attacks
description: Lloyd's of London, one of the world's best-known insurance organizations, said yesterday that its losses from the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks were greater than initially calculated. But both Lloyd's and analysts said the new estimates were no cause for alarm.

title: Syrup's Fine, but Pancakes Have a Flip Side
description: CALL me pancakecentric, but I'd guess that a peek into the warmest, fuzziest part of America's collective culinary heart would reveal flapjacks cozied next to roast chicken, mashed potatoes and hot fudge sundaes in the pantheon of comfort foods. Never mind that pancakes are ancient -- a recipe appears in a cookbook by the Roman epicure Apicius. Or that they are almost universal -- it is nearly impossible to find a culture that does not have a griddlecake of some kind. It is Americans who have folded them into their daily lives, varied them with the most ingenuity and made them the stuff of memory.

title: Morocco Is Next Stop for a Corner Bistro
description: SOMETIMES, the only thing worse than a bad location is a good location. Anyone who doubts that might consider the tortured history of Zitoune, a little restaurant perched on the edge of the meatpacking district and therefore destined, like so many others, to languish in the shadow of Pastis.

title: Jets Adapting To Cottrell's Point of View
description: In Bill Belichick, the Jets will face a coach about whom they often speak in reverent tones usually reserved for religious figures or Bill Parcells.

title: After Defeat, Journey to Uncertain Fate
description: Like some lost caravan, the trucks rumbled across the steppe bearing their wretched cargo, 800 Taliban prisoners bound for an uncertain fate.

title: A Surfing Firefighter, a Thrill-Riding Hunter, a Mormon Composer
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Afghans Do a Double Take And See Russians Again
description: The Russians are back.

title: Giuliani Reproaches Teachers For Insisting on a 22% Raise
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani ripped into the teachers' union yesterday, accusing it of risking grave damage to the city for continuing to seek a 22 percent wage increase even after the city's budget has plunged into deficit following the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: How Secure Is Pakistan's Plutonium?
description: A deeply disturbing picture of terrorist intent has emerged in recent weeks as blueprints for building nuclear weapons have been discovered in the wreckage of abandoned Al Qaeda safe houses. These blueprints and other documents, while largely available in the public domain, sharpen the need for a vigorous American policy to deal with unsecured nuclear, chemical and biological materials. Even if terrorist manufacture of nuclear bombs is unlikely, substantial dangers remain of terrorists using radioactive material in low-tech ''dirty'' bombs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPTON, NORMAN C.
description: LIPTON-Norman C. On November 26, 2001. Beloved husband of Pearl. Loving father of Thomas, William and Deborah, and loving stepfather of William Silverman. Cherished grandfather of Eva, Joshua, Ilene and Steven and Lisa. Dear great - grandfather of Tankred and Ronja. Service on Wednesday, 12:45PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: The Spirit of the Olympics
description: The International Olympic Committee is asking for a halt to violence worldwide during the 2002 Winter Olympics in February in Salt Lake City, the president of committee, Jacques Rogge, said today.

title: Microsoft Move May Hasten Settlement of European Case
description: Offering a strong signal that it wants to settle its antitrust case in Europe, Microsoft has told the European Commission that it will forgo its right to a hearing next month, company officials and European regulators said yesterday.

title: Intellectual Property, Pardons and Recent Cases
description: Q. The Supreme Court has recently issued decisions that say the state governments are not bound by federal copyright laws. This would seem to allow state government offices, for example, to legally use pirated computer software. But doesn't the constitutional provision of eminent domain require that if the state seizes private property, then the owner of that property must be properly compensated? Or does that provision apply only to physical, and not intellectual, property?

title: Ralph Burns, 79, an Arranger and Composer From Big Bands to Broadway
description: Ralph Burns, an arranger and composer who rose to prominence in the big band era and later won awards for his work on Broadway and in Hollywood, died on Wednesday in Los Angeles. He was 79.

title: Astronomers Hit Milestone As They Study Distant Planet
description: For the first time, astronomers have detected and made a preliminary chemical study of the atmosphere of a planet beyond the solar system.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Writing, And Living, The Lit Life
description: It was like a story from old New York, something O. Henry might have written, about a young artist, struggling in the city's shadows, whose true love brings him a sudden burst of good luck.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the arts pages on Wednesday about the competition between ''Monsters, Inc.'' and ''Shrek'' for the Oscar for best animated feature film, to be awarded in March, misstated the name of an unreleased film mentioned as a contender for best picture. It is ''A Beautiful Mind,'' not ''A Beautiful Life.''

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR SLIPS. The dollar was little changed against the euro and the yen. In New York, the euro settled at 88.25 cents, up from 88.03 cents on Monday. The dollar traded at 124 yen, down from 124.09 yen.

title: Science, Morality and Cloning
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Norway: Airline Offer Reduced
description: Scandinavian Airlines System, the Nordic region's largest carrier, cut its offer for a Norwegian rival, Braathens A.S.A., by 23 percent as the terrorist attacks in the United States hurt passenger traffic and earnings. SAS said it would pay 27 kroner a share, valuing the company at 869 million kroner ($96.1 million), 5.3 percent less than Monday's closing price.

title: Limits Sought on Access to Company Data
description: The Bush administration is seeking to limit the public's access to information that private companies voluntarily provide to the government about critical infrastructure systems like energy, telecommunications and banking to help protect against terrorist attacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TYNION, JAMES T. JR.
description: TYNION-James T. Jr. in his 79th year on November 27, 2001. Beloved husband of 47 years to E. Beverly (nee Ryan). Devoted father of James T. III, Eileen, Patrick A., Virginia Coughlan and Donald W. II. Loving grandfather of twelve. Also survived by his brother Donald W. and sister Louisemary McDonald. Mr. Tynion, as an alumnus of Brooklyn Prep and the College of Mount St. Mary, was former Secretary-Treasurer of The Hamilton Press and retired from Appeal Printing. A veteran of WWII, he was Knight Commander with Star of the Order of the Holy Sepulchre, member of the Holy Name Society and Bay Ridge Post 157 of the American Legion. Visiting Wednesday and Thursday 2-4 & 7-9PM at The Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Ave, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial 9AM Friday, St. Anselm's RC Church.

title: A Nation Challenged
description: The Investigation

title: 2 Food Companies Hire New Agencies
description: Two large marketers are expanding their agency rosters.

title: Liberties; Hunks And Brutes
description: Women used to get in a snit when a hardhat with a flag decal wolf-whistled at them.

title: Technology Briefing | Research: Genomics-Derived Drug To Be Tested
description: Millennium Pharmaceuticals said yesterday that the first drug discovered using its genomics technology had entered clinical trials. Millennium Pharmaceuticals, based in Cambridge, Mass., is widely considered a leader in sifting through genetic data to find genes that might be involved in disease, and big drug companies have paid hundreds of millions of dollars for access to its technology. But pressure was growing on the company to show that it could actually develop a drug. ''People were beginning to say, 'When are we going to see the proof here?' '' said Rachel Leheny, an analyst at Lehman Brothers. The drug, taken orally, is for obesity and is being developed with Abbott Laboratories. The drug inhibits an enzyme that may play a role in regulating metabolism. The new drug, called MLN4760, joins only a handful of other drugs in the pharmaceutical industry that were developed using genomics. Millennium has several other drugs being tested in patients, but those were acquired from other companies. Millennium's shares rose 2 cents, to $33.52.

title: Change in S.& P. 500
description: Equity Residential Properties Trust, a leading owner of apartments, will replace National Service Industries in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index after the close of trading on Friday, Standard & Poor's said. National Service, which is spinning off Acuity Brands to shareholders, is being removed because it does not meet requirements for inclusion, S.& P. said in a statement posted on its Web site.

title: Tints From Nature
description: WHEN the Dancing Deer Baking Company of Boston could not find chemical-free food colors for its all-natural baked products, it developed its own, suspending plant pigments in sugar syrup. The resulting soft, magical colors can be used like traditional food colorings in frostings, baked goods and confections, or mixed with liquid gelatin and painted on sweets like marzipan, cookies and white chocolate.

title: E.P.A. Weighs Pesticide Tests on Humans
description: The Bush administration is considering allowing data from human testing of toxic pesticides to be part of regulatory decisions, a step that would run counter to a Clinton administration scientific advisory panel. Critics say it would violate the Nuremberg Code adopted after World War II.

title: Federal Effort Does Not Violate Law, Oregon Attorney General Says
description: The Oregon attorney general today tried to defuse the controversy over a police refusal to cooperate with the federal government's bid to interview Middle Eastern students. He said that such questioning did not violate state law and that his investigators as well as state police officers would help with the interviews.

title: INSIDE
description: Palestinians Kill 2 Israelis

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Trying to Restore Confidence in Enron to Salvage a Merger
description: The Enron Corporation and Dynegy Inc. worked yesterday to find ways to bolster confidence in Enron's weakened energy-trading business as the companies' negotiators continued talks on revising the terms of their merger, executives close to the talks said.

title: Death and Denial
description: The following articles are part of a series about the H.I.V. epidemic in South Africa and one ravaged community, Hlabisa. SEXUAL BRAVADO

title: Carol Burnett, Armed With Old Clips, Is New Hit
description: In a development that stunned most television industry executives, a CBS special on Monday night that featured old clips and outtakes from ''The Carol Burnett Show,'' which left the air in 1978, attracted almost 30 million viewers, one of the biggest audiences this season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUSTGARTEN, IRVING
description: LUSTGARTEN-Irving. The Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale notes with regret the passing of Irving Lustgarten, beloved father of Scot and Brian and our dear friend, the late Marc Lustgarten. Irving was a proud and strong man who was devoted to his family and friends. We will miss his warmth and friendship. We pray that his family will be comforted by fond memories. Daniel Reingold, Exec VP

title: Justices Ponder Online Porn Law
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28  Four years after the Supreme Court overturned the federal government's first effort to shield children from pornography on the Internet, the justices were back today to consider whether the government's second try can pass First Amendment muster.

title: A Crushed Revolt, a Switching of Sides and Complaints at Home
description: Their fighters have been routed in all but one Afghan city, Kandahar. Many now being held prisoner are a bedraggled lot -- all rags and filth and lowered heads, as 800 taken in trucks from Kunduz to heaven knows where were described. But whipped though they may be, Taliban troops can still make life miserable for their enemies, as amply proved by their blood-soaked uprising at the Qala Jangi fortress.

title: U.S. Makes It Easier to Detain Foreigners
description: The Justice Department has quietly expanded its power to detain foreigners, letting the government keep a foreigner behind bars even after a federal immigration judge has ordered him to be released for lack of evidence.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Last Great Mystery

title: Justices Hear Case On Privacy Of Students
description: For 27 years, a federal education law known as the Buckley amendment has been on the books, intended to protect the privacy of students' records, from elementary through graduate school, and shaping aspects of the relationship between parents and schools.

title: A Few Newly Discovered Jewels
description: BACK when Chinatown was thronged and thriving, I always stuck to the same timid trail as I went store to store for Asian ingredients and cookware. It was too hard to do anything except go with the flow. But last week, with the sidewalks so deserted, I suddenly spotted five ''new'' places.

title: Taliban Uprising
description: U.S. and British Special Forces helped suppress a violent uprising by Taliban soldiers in a Northern Afghanistan jail over the weekend.

title: Tonight's N.F.L. Matchup
description: Philadelphia (6-4) at Kansas City (3-7)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOEHM, LEONORE
description: BOEHM-Leonore. The date of death was November 26, 2001.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANIELL, BLANCHE
description: DANIELL-Blanche, 99. Of Rye, NY, died on November 24, 2001. Mrs. Blanche N. Daniell was the first wife of F. Raymond Daniell, a correspondant for The New York Times. She was a writer for the Voice of America during and after World War II. She is survived by her two children, Curtis Guild Daniell, of Germany and Elizabeth Lake Daniell of New York City. Funeral services will be held at the Rye Presbyterian Church, Rye, NY on Friday, November 30, 1 PM.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about AIDS epidemic in a community in South Africa quoted a statistic incorrectly from a doctor who has been fighting AIDS and sexually transmitted diseases there. The doctor, Neil E. Jorgensen, said that venereal disease cases among workers at a local sugar mill had declined "from 10 a day to one a month." He did not say the drop was from 10 a month.

title: A Voice in Rebuilding
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECK, MARGIT
description: BECK-Margit. Of Yonkers, NY. On November 27, 2001. Wife of the late Alfred Beck. Survived by two sons Robert Beck of Rye Brook, NY and William Beck of Ardsley, NY, five grandchildren Lisa Rosenfeld, Tracey Ruth, Julie Behar, David and Michael Beck and eight grandchildren. A Funeral Service Thursday 10 AM at the Hebrew Institute of White Plains, Greenridge Ave., White Plains, New York. Interment in Sharon Gardens Cemetery.

title: Ducks, Dinosaurs and Others for Under $25
description: 1. REEL IN -- Folding fishing rod comes with all-purpose tool, tackle box and canvas carrying case; $22, at Mxyplyzyk, 125 Greenwich Avenue (13th Street).

title: Rare Condoms, Deadly Odds For Truck-Stop Prostitutes
description: In the 13 years that Thandi has been a prostitute, she has seen a few changes in the attitudes of the truckers at the stop where she works.

title: America's War on Terror Ends Years of Indifference to Region : U.S. Woos Southeast Asian Allies
description: SINGAPORE  After years of seeming indifference, the United States is again courting Southeast Asian countries  this time in its search for allies in the global war against terrorism.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Arris To Buy Modem Maker
description: The Arris Group, a maker of telecommunications equipment, plans to buy Cadant Inc., a closely held cable modem equipment maker, for about $45.7 million in stock. Arris will exchange 5.25 million of its shares, which closed yesterday at $8.70 apiece, for Cadant's assets. Arris will also assume $17 million in liabilities, it said. Arris, based in Duluth, Ga., also may pay as many as two million additional shares based on future sales of modem equipment made by Cadant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEBERT, CHARLES ALEXANDRE
description: HEBERT-Charles Alexandre. Age 95, on November 26, 2001. Lt. Commander in U.S. Naval Reserve. PT Squadron in South Pacific. Witty conversationalist, lifetime jogger, and Upper Broadway denizen.

title: Elephant Is An Attraction And a Feat
description: The fifth elephant ever to be conceived by artificial insemination appeared in public, albeit shyly, for the first time today at the Smithsonian National Zoological Park.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBURGER, INGRID (NEE GRUTTENFIEN)
description: GREENBURGER - Ingrid (nee Gruttenfien). Born July 14, 1913, in Berlin, Germany, died November 25 in New York. Mrs. Greenburger was a painter, writer, literary agent and book scout. She is the widow of Sanford J. Greenburger, the founder of the Sanford J. Greenburger Literary Agency. Her family and many friends mourn her passing. A person of charisma, outspokenness and integrity, no one was unmoved by her. She leaves a place in our hearts no one else can fill. Mrs. Greenburger is survived by her sons, Andre, of Colrain, MA, a photographer, and Francis, of New York, NY, a real estate investor and sponsor of several arts programs, daughterin-law Isabelle, an architect, grandchildren Michael, Holleran, Morgan, Noah, Julia, Claire, and a nephew, Peter Stonehill. A memorial service will be held Thursday, November 29 at 5:00 P.M. at Calvary Episcopal Church, Park Avenue South and 20th Street. Donations may be made to the Ingrid Greenburger Fellowship at Art Omni, 55 Fifth Avenue, New York, New York 10003.

title: U.S. Holds Gathering on Renewable Energy
description: Saying the Bush administration wants to promote renewable energy, Interior Secretary Gale A. Norton led a conference here today for dozens of manufacturers of solar, wind and geothermal energy sources who want to set up shop on federal lands.

title: Counting on Coffee Lovers; Struggling Merchants Hope New Brews Build Business
description: Hong Park runs a greengrocery on Prince Street in Manhattan, in a land of lattes, fancy beans and chic cafes, on the front line of a raging battle for the coffee customer.

title: Reisinger Victory Overturned On Appeal
description: The Reisinger Knockout Team Championship, concluding the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals, ended here on Tuesday night with considerable confusion.

title: CONTINENTAL PLANS SHARE SALE TO RAISE MONEY
description: Continental Airlines plans to raise about $151.7 million by selling common shares next week, giving the company more cash as it contends with a loss this quarter. The 6.74 million shares of Class B stock, expected to be issued Monday, will be priced at $22.50 each, the airline said. Continental, which has about 55.4 million Class B shares outstanding, plans to use the money for general corporate purposes. Stock in Continental, which is based in Houston, fell $2.40, to $21.70 a share.

title: Citigroup and J.P. Morgan Are Left With Bruised Egos and Exposure to Loans
description: Dynegy's decision to walk away from Enron leaves Citigroup and J. P. Morgan Chase licking their wounds after an effort to burnish their reputations as deal makers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VALES, MARIA
description: VALES-Maria, who passed on November 27, 2001. Beloved wife of Manuel. Beloved daughter of Manuela. Dearest mother of Mark, David and Lisa. Devoted grandmother of Bobby, Nicholas, and Rebecca. Viewing Thursday 79PM, Friday 2-5PM and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian burial on Saturday 9:30AM at Our Lady of Fatima, Jackson Heights.

title: ENRON COLLAPSES AS SUITOR CANCELS PLANS FOR MERGER
description: Enron, the champion of energy deregulation that grew into one of the nation's 10 largest companies, collapsed yesterday, after a rival backed out of a deal to buy it and many big trading partners stopped doing business with it.

title: 2 Copyright Cases Decided in Favor of Entertainment Industry
description: The entertainment industry won two closely watched cases yesterday that pit owners of copyrighted works against the people who develop technologies that can be used to copy those works.

title: House Votes to Combat Sale of Diamonds for War
description: The House voted today to give President Bush the power to impose trade-related sanctions on nations that sell diamonds to finance war or terrorism, a step that supporters say will help stem the trade of so-called blood diamonds.

title: Gifts More Personal Than a Monogram
description: A CASHMERE sweater, a new set of titanium golf clubs -- sure, those are wonderfully generous presents. And there may be no way around buying the new PlayStation with the ''Hoshigami: Ruining Blue Earth'' game to go with it. But this year, it is tempting to take a different route to gift giving, one that bypasses cashmere, monograms and electronics in favor of a warmer, more personal approach.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: I.N.S. Review Of Airport Workers
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service is examining immigration documents for 18,000 workers at Seattle-Tacoma International Airport as part of a nationwide review to improve security. Irregularities could lead to the detention or deportation of airport service employees, said Robert Okin, deputy director for the service in Seattle. The service is checking whether roughly 40 airport contractors collected immigration documentation for their employees. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Economic Scene; In Sept. 11's aftermath, the cure for the economic ills of our democracy is more democracy.
description: SINCE Sept. 11, this nation has thought more deeply about itself and its values than it has in a long time. Foreign criticism has stunned many Americans because we think of ourselves as a good people and are surprised that others may not. America's values are exemplary, we believe, and in many ways that is true.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMPSON, MARY TYSON
description: THOMPSON-Mary Tyson. Age 92, died peacefully on November 27, 2001, at her home in New Jersey. A prolific and award-winning artist, she was a member of the American Watercolor Society and her work is in many collections. She was the wife of the late Kenneth W. Thompson, and is survived by her sons Kenneth S. Thompson and Loran T. Thompson and her granddaughter Kirsten D. Thompson. In keeping with her wishes, there will be no service.

title: Footlights
description: East and West

title: Florida Urologist Investigated In Dilution of Cancer Drug
description: Federal authorities are investigating whether a urologist gave prostate cancer patients diluted doses of an expensive drug prescribed for the disease.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: E.D.S. Wins Xerox Work
description: The computer services giant Electronic Data Services announced yesterday that it had won a $1.5 billion contract extension from Xerox. Under the terms of the new contract, E.D.S. will continue to operate the Xerox communications network, as well as offer additional services. The new contract extends for 5 years a 10-year contract originally signed in 1994. The extension includes an initial service period of two years and a three-year option. E.D.S., based in Plano, Tex., also said it was dropping a 1999 lawsuit against Xerox over the original contract. In a separate pact, E.D.S. awarded Xerox a five-year contract to install office equipment in 300 military sites, as part of a $6.9 billion E.D.S. military contract. E.D.S. also said it had selected Xerox, based in Stamford, Conn., as its preferred printer provider.

title: U.S. Confirms Anthrax in Chilean Letter
description: Federal health officials yesterday confirmed the presence of anthrax in samples Chilean authorities said they had taken from a letter from Florida. But the anthrax was not the strain that had killed five Americans and was most likely to have originated in Chile, officials said.

title: A Phone Answers the Question 'How Are You?' With a Photo
description: Nokia, long in the vanguard of innovative cellphone design, has a new model that has mobile-phone aficionados panting. Last week, the company introduced the Nokia 7650, a cellphone that has a large color screen and a built-in digital camera.

title: Christmas Past in the House That Jimmy (and Rosalynn) Built
description: A FEW days before Thanksgiving, Jimmy Carter stood on his patio here, talking turkey. The sun was out, the morning was warm, and cotton lay bundled in truck-size stacks in fields around town. Mr. Carter, 77, wore a denim shirt, cowboy boots and a belt buckle with a horseshoe enclosing the initials J. C. He looked fit and at ease. Secret Service agents in sunglasses kept a discreet distance.

title: Smoke Alarm Can Distinguish Between Emergency and Bacon
description: When properly installed and powered, smoke alarms can be lifesavers. But for those who like to sear a steak or deep fry chicken occasionally, many smoke alarms can also be a nuisance by going off and driving innocent cooks out of the kitchen, frantically flailing their arms or, worse, taking the batteries out of the alarm.

title: Torre Makes His Intentions Perfectly Clear to Martinez
description: When Joe Torre called Tino Martinez to let him know that he would be making a recruiting call to Jason Giambi, Torre felt that Martinez knew that he had become the former first baseman of the Yankees. Everyone, even Martinez, realized the Yankees had made Giambi their top priority, a major signing that could happen in a few days.

title: A Constituency Ready for Peace
description: As the Bush administration begins its new round of Middle East shuttle diplomacy, officials are nervously watching for reactions not only among Israelis and Palestinians, but also in the Jewish community at home.

title: Mistrial For Ex-Mayor Of Newark
description: A judge declared a mistrial today in the federal bribery and fraud trial of Kenneth Gibson, the former Newark mayor, after jurors who had deliberated for nearly seven days indicated that they were unable to agree on a verdict on any part of the 18-count indictment.

title: Knicks Beat Hawks and Reach .500, but Nobody's Cheering
description: The sparse Philips Arena crowd of 10,997 was finally getting loud. Their Atlanta Hawks were making a charge, chopping a 16-point deficit to 4 and threatening to steal a game that had belonged to the Knicks all night.

title: Relations at Last Normal, Vietnam Signs U.S. Trade Pact
description: After five years of fits and starts, Vietnam joined the United States today in approving a far-reaching trade agreement that throws open its economy and brings an end to a final chapter of the war.

title: Afghan E-Mail Seen as Too Geek to Be True
description: IT seemed a perfectly innocuous, even uplifting little story.

title: Left Side of Giants' Line Is Growing Old Together
description: So why have the Giants, a Super Bowl team 10 months ago, lost five of their last seven games? Every critic has a handful of theories: overconfidence, fat cats, too casual, not hungry, too little passion, a quarterback with too many shortcomings, too much youth in the secondary, too much age on the offensive line.

title: Dance Floor's Owner Is Fined And Hotel Pool Room Is Shut
description: The owner of a portable dance floor that collapsed into a motel swimming pool early Sunday, injuring about 30 revelers, was charged today with violating the state building code and fined $3,000.
