title: House Passes Insurance Plan for Losses From Future Attacks
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29  The House of Representatives voted 227 to 193 today to provide as much as $100 billion in government loans to the insurance industry to cover losses from future large-scale terrorist attacks.

title: U.S. Envoy Meets Arafat and Asks for End to Violence
description: After surveying the impasse here from the Palestinian perspective today, Gen. Anthony C. Zinni, the Bush administration's new envoy, declared, ''Both sides have suffered far too much in the last months.''

title: Collusion Was Widely Disregarded, Says Witness for Sotheby's
description: What the government has presented as a flagrant collusion agreement between the leaders of Sotheby's and Christie's was widely disregarded by both auction houses, a defense witness testified yesterday in the price-fixing trial of the former Sotheby's chairman A. Alfred Taubman.

title: Editors' Note; Today's Sections
description: News of the Sept. 11 attacks and their aftermath continues to appear in Section B; index, Page B2.

title: Al Qaeda Link Seen In Only a Handful Of 1,200 Detainees
description: The nationwide search for terrorists after Sept. 11 has resulted in the arrests of more than 1,200 people, but law enforcement officials said yesterday that only a small number of those detained are believed to have any links to terrorism. The approximately 600 people still in custody are mostly being held on immigration violations or unrelated crimes from child pornography to credit card fraud that agents came across while pursuing the investigation.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Protest Against New Terror Law
description: Schools and businesses closed in Srinagar, the summer capital of Kashmir, to protest a new antiterror measure that must be approved by Parliament or lapse. The strike, called by the High Court Bar Association, came after the ordinance was invoked for the first time in Kashmir, where an anti-India insurgency has raged since 1989, to seal a house in Srinagar where suspected Islamic militants were hiding. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: CUNY Has Balance, but It Doesn't Have the Big Names
description: Burt Beagle, statistician and unofficial basketball historian for the City University of New York Athletic Conference, remembers the 1960's of CUNY basketball, when parity meant which one of four schools would dominate the conference tournament, which began in 1966.

title: End Food-Stamp Shame
description: To the Editor:

title: There Aren't Any Dinosaurs In Washington, They Say
description: It's nicknamed the Dinosaur Garden, but don't expect a topiary triceratops. The Garden Primeval is in the United States Botanic Garden's expanded $33 million conservatory, which reopens on Dec. 11 after a four-year renovation. The garden, right, has hundreds of ferns, mosses and cycads that have survived since the Jurassic Period, when dinosaurs stalked the earth and flowering plants had not yet evolved. If it's blossoms you need, they will be on display in adjacent greenhouses devoted to world deserts, botanical expeditions, plants used in commerce, medicinal plants and genetically modified plants. The conservatory's subtle redesign, by the architectural and engineering firm of DMJM and Rodney Robinson, a landscape architect, includes new climate-control systems. The conservatory, at 100 Maryland Avenue SW, will be open 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. daily, including Christmas. Admission is free. Information: (202) 225-8333.

title: Snowmass Savings
description: Several resort properties in this Colorado resort are discounting rates or reducing restrictions during the holidays. Rooms at the Stonebridge Inn will be $215 a night Dec. 26 to Jan. 2. At Crestwood Condominiums, guests may arrive and depart any day they wish and there is no minimum stay. Top of the Village condos have cut the minimum stay to four nights from seven, and will give one night free with bookings of six nights or longer. The ski-in, ski-out Silvertree Hotel has dropped nightly rates on its standard rooms to $345 from $395 Dec. 26 to Jan. 4. Information: (800) 766-9627 or www.snowmassvillage.com .

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW JERSEY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLOVER, PRICE PERKINS
description: GLOVER-Price Perkins, 83. On November 23, 2001 of cancer. Beloved husband of Isobel, loving father of Jonathan and Julie, devoted brother of Dorothy Johns. A memorial service will be held at the Brick Presbyterian Church, 1140 Park Avenue, December 10 at 4 P.M. In lieu of flowers, donations would be appreciated to: Genitourinary Oncology Research Fund, C/O David M. Nanus, M.D., 525 East 68th Street, ST-359, New York, New York 10021.

title: About 150 Employees Are Said to Be Accusing AT&T of Bias
description: About 150 AT&T employees are accusing the company of discrimination and are considering filing federal lawsuits, according to the law firm representing the employees. A third of the employees have already made formal complaints with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. Twelve filed the complaints yesterday.

title: Engineers Have a Culprit in the Strange Collapse of 7 World Trade Center: Diesel Fuel
description: Almost lost in the chaos of the collapse of the World Trade Center is a mystery that under normal circumstances would probably have captured the attention of the city and the world. That mystery is the collapse of a nearby 47-story, two-million-square-foot building seven hours after flaming debris from the towers rained down on it, igniting what became an out-of-control fire.

title: Buyers of Units Of Lernout Are Disclosed
description: ScanSoft, a digital imaging software company, purchased the main speech technology assets of Lernout & Hauspie for approximately $40 million in stock and cash in a bankruptcy auction on Monday, company officials said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Currents column last Thursday about Venetian plasterwork by Orazio De Gennaro of Brooklyn omitted his telephone number. It is (718) 855-5379.

title: Memo Adds To Suspicions Of Immigrants On Interviews
description: A week ago, the Justice Department's top civil rights official came here to defend a federal plan to interview 5,000 young Middle Eastern men who had entered the United States on temporary visas. The official, Ralph Boyd Jr., said the interviews would be voluntary and were needed to help the government investigate the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: A Personal Shopper For Online Bargains
description: THE number of online merchants may have dwindled, but price competition among the survivors is fierce. For shoppers, the savings can be substantial: the new Billie Holiday CD box set sells for $154 at one online store but for $127 at another; a top-of-the-line Nikon digital camera that lists for $899 and typically sells online for $799 can be found for well under $700. And why buy that ''Citizen Kane'' DVD for $29 when you can have it for $21?

title: Giving Hidden Opera Classics a Moment in the Sun
description: Fiora Contino, a gentle, diminutive woman of 76, is talking about a love affair. ''After he had first been with her,'' she says, ''he felt guilty, so he tried to hand her a 100-ruble note.'' Her lip curls in scorn. ''Pitiful.''

title: Mortgage Limit Is Raised to $300,700
description: Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac have raised the limit on the size of single-family home mortgages they buy from banks by 9.3 percent, to $300,700, opening up lower-cost financing to more people.

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of Wednesday, 3,613 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIALT, BERNARD A.
description: BIALT-Bernard A. Age 61, of Westerville, OH, formerly of Woodbridge/Fords, N.J. on Tuesday, November 27, 2001 at his residence. Beloved husband for 21 years to Betty ''Julienne'' Bialt. Retired after 25 years as Treasurer for Cofinco Inc. of 99 Park Avenue, New York, NY. Since coming to Columbus Bernard enjoyed being Finance Manager for ProMusica Chamber Orchestra. Preceded in death by mother, Sophie and father, Stephen Bialt; sister, Sonia Gundrum. Also survived by children, Celina, Bernard, Doris, Jeanine, Mark and Alfred; brother, Daniel Bialt and wife Carolyn; sister, Stephanie Duffus and husband, Harold; nieces, nephews and grandchildren. For information Schoedinger Northeast Chapel, Gahanna, Ohio.

title: H.I.V. 'Explosion' Seen in East Europe and Central Asia
description: H.I.V. infections are rising faster in Eastern Europe and Central Asia than anywhere else in the world and are 15 times as high as they were three years ago, the United Nations said yesterday, in its yearly report on worldwide AIDS.

title: Pharmacia Planning Spinoff Of Its 85% Stake in Monsanto
description: The Pharmacia Corporation said yesterday that it intended to spin off its 85 percent stake in the Monsanto Company to shareholders in the second half of next year.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: New Sept. 11 Victim Center
description: Westchester County and a group of charities have opened an office where families of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack can receive assistance from several agencies. The Family Response Center, at 143 Grand Street, was organized by the United Way of Westchester-Putnam in an existing county office. The center is expected to serve more than 500 Westchester residents who have not already sought help from the principal assistance center at Pier 94 in Manhattan. It will be open Tuesdays and Thursdays from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.

title: Sept. 11 Death Faked, Police Say
description: A Georgia couple have been charged with insurance fraud after a man falsely claimed that his wife died in the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center, police officials in Georgia said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POGALL, JEANNE
description: POGALL-Jeanne. The Jewish Center of the Hamptons mourns the passing of Jeanne Pogall, beloved mother of our congregant Ellen Arzt. We extend our deepest condolences to Ellen and family. Rabbi David J. Gelfand Rabbi Alon Levkovitz Cantor Debra Stein Donald Zucker, President

title: Afghans Plunge Into Talks, Differing on Peacekeepers
description: Delegates from the four Afghan factions here began intensive negotiations today over the shape of an interim post-Taliban government. But United Nations officials warned that these talks were not likely to end with a full agreement.

title: Corrections
description: Areport in the Currents column last Thursday about an auction held at Chelsea Piers last Monday to benefit the Twin Towers Fund listed one auction house incorrectly among the organizers. Sotheby's did not participate.

title: Military Tribunals
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Arizona: Independent Run For Governor
description: Former Secretary of State Richard Mahoney, a Democrat who left the party earlier this year, said he would run for governor as an independent. Mr. Mahoney, 50, blamed the two-party system for many of the state's ills and vowed to cut prescription drugs prices by 20 percent if elected. The front-runner in the race to succeed Gov. Jane Dee Hull, a Republican, is Matt Salmon, a former congressman who is also Republican. Attorney General Janet Napolitano, a Democrat, is expected to announce her candidacy in January. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Essay; Enemy Of My Enemy
description: Here is the modern corollary to a Middle Eastern proverb: The enemy of my enemy can be my enemy, too.

title: Michael Hoffman, 59, Director Of Art Photography Publisher
description: Michael E. Hoffman, the longtime director of the Aperture Foundation, a nonprofit publisher of fine-art photography books and Aperture magazine, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 59 and lived in New York City and Shekomeko, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENGELMAN, HOWARD
description: ENGELMAN - Howard. Adored husband of Ethel Roseman Engelman for 57 years, loving father of Augusta Kaiser and Arnold Engelman, brother of Isidore, grandfather of Allegra, Marnie and Francesca Kaiser, Nora and Audrey Engelman, father-in-law of William Kaiser and Carol Rosegg, brotherin-law of Phil and Leonard Roseman, uncle of Dr. Richard Engelman and family, Dr. Hal Roseman and family, and of the Roseman/ Fishkin nieces and nephews, died suddenly Tuesday at the age of 89. Howard Engelman was a partner in the real estate firm of Engelman & Co. which he founded with his brothers in 1950. He was widely known as a pioneer in the development of residential and commercial real estate in Greenwich Village in the 1950s and 1960s and the later management of those properties. Those properties included 30, 40, 55 and 60 East 9th Street and 50-54 East 8th Street. His vision is credited for the economic growth and widespread popularity of Greenwich Village. Service Friday, 11:15AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Albert Einstein School of Medicine.

title: MP3 Players Let the Music Go On and On and On
description: It's not as flashy as the new Apple iPod MP3 player, but if you are planning a music marathon, the latest version of the Remote Solution player, PBJ100, with 540 hours of storage, may go the distance.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Fee-Based Music Services Take On Free Alternatives

title: I Think I Hear Voices
description: To the Editor:

title: Community Recalls a Native Son With Clear Goals
description: Johnny Michael Spann was the rare student at Winfield City High School who knew exactly what he wanted to do with his life even as a teenager.

title: From the Weavers of Thailand, Silks With a Modern Look
description: Exotic silk pillows usually carry exotic prices. But the owners of Simply Home, near Dupont Circle, work with rural Thai craftsmen to produce affordable fabrics, tableware and furniture. The designs are by Somsak Pollert; his sister Nannapat, who runs the Bangkok end of the business; and their partner, Monchai Chamchong. The silk for the store's pillows, priced from $45 to $95, is woven in the provinces of Nakhon Ratchasima and Chiang Mai. ''We ask the weavers to make traditional Thai patterns a little differently, to make them more contemporary,'' Mr. Pollert said. Mr. Chamchong's redwood beds, also available at the store, run from $2,000 (full size) to $2,600 (king). Simply Home is at 1811B 18th Street NW, or www .simplyhomedc.com; (202) 986-8607.

title: Transcending Trauma
description: To the Editor:

title: For One Night, The Legend Rules the Court
description: In one crackerbox room today at the First Union Center, Allen Iverson, the N.B.A.'s reigning most valuable player, signed a lifetime contract with Reebok -- one of those reported $10 million-a-year deals that ensures him diamonds and sneakers for the remainder of his earthly existence.

title: Foundation Gives Way On Chief's Big Dream
description: Well before anyone could imagine that Enron might collapse, Kenneth L. Lay was stumped. In an interview in August, he dismissed questions about a vague clause in the energy company's annual report that hinted at bigger problems if its stock price or credit rating fell below certain levels.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STORY, REV. EDWARD M.
description: STORY-Rev. Edward M. died Nov 26. Memorials: Rectors Discretionary Fund, St. Paul's Church, 2430 ''K'' St NW, Washington, DC 20037.

title: Pluck and Publicity Elevate a Young Poet
description: On any given day, for all its problems and lamentations, book publishing can still have a wondrous and exciting unpredictability. Who could possibly have conjured the idea that two of the biggest word-of-mouth best sellers of the year would be written by a boy who is 11 years old? A boy suffering a chronic, life-threatening disease? And both of them books of poetry?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MAXIM, LESLIE M.
description: MAXIM-Leslie M. November 29, 1917-June 23, 1996. Happy Birthday. Happy Thanksgiving. Celebrating Your Life. Remembering You Today And Everyday. Your loving wife Pear

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURNS, RALPH
description: BURNS-Ralph. It is Early Autumn and I owe it all to you. Emile

title: Educating Ourselves
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, SARAH
description: JOHNSON-Sarah. Of Westwood, NJ on November 27, beloved wife of the late Dr. Milton Johnson. Devoted mother of Dorothy Corwin and adored mother-in-law of Dr. Norman Corwin, dear sister of the late Edith Cumings. Loving grandmother of Janice Linett, Michael Corwin and Susan Yaros and great-grandmother of Steven, Jenny, Ethan and Matthew. Services private.

title: In the Capital, It's Scrooge's Season
description: Only a few privileged Americans will get to see the decorated rooms of the White House this Christmas, with the 100-pound gingerbread house and glittering theme of ''Home for the Holidays'' securely battened down by guards on terrorism alert.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Scientists Find the New Field of Threat Assessment Full of Uncertainties
description: Shaken by suicide jets and anthrax deaths, scientists are working to better predict the likelihood of major terrorist attacks, and thus to clarify what protections the nation needs most urgently out of a nearly endless lineup of potential defenses.

title: Army Star Set to Serve on Another Field
description: When David McCracken selected West Point over Syracuse, Notre Dame, Virginia Tech, Tennessee and a handful of other universities that had offered him a football scholarship, he made a promise to his concerned mother.

title: After a Veto Threat, Vote In House Goes Bush's Way
description: Bowing to President Bush's veto threat, the House today decided not to vote on whether to increase spending for homeland security, aid to New York and military operations in Afghanistan.

title: Technology Briefing
description: HARDWAREE.D.S. WINS XEROX WORK The computer services giant Electronic Data Services announced yesterday that it had won a $1.5 billion contract extension from Xerox ( news/quote ). Under the terms of the new contract, E.D.S. will continue to operate the Xerox communications network, as well as offer additional services. The new contract extends for 5 years a 10-year contract originally signed in 1994. The extension includes an initial service period of two years and a three-year option. E.D.S., based in Plano, Tex., also said it was dropping a 1999 lawsuit against Xerox over the original contract. In a separate pact, E.D.S. awarded Xerox a five-year contract to install office equipment in 300 military sites, as part of a $6.9 billion E.D.S. military contract. E.D.S. also said it had selected Xerox, based in Stamford, Conn., as its preferred printer provider.

title: Sports of The Times; Brady Is a New Traveler On the Yellow Brick Road
description: About 11:45 this morning, the New England Patriots' unexpected savior walked through the door, navy blue cap turned backward, gray sweats, cross-training shoes. He had the countenance of a 24-year-old with the world on a string.

title: Taliban Foes Move on Kandahar
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29  Aided by American air power and ground troops, opposition forces in southern Afghanistan have encircled and are on the verge of laying siege to the city of Kandahar, the last major bastion of Taliban military power, senior United States military officials said today.

title: Metro Matters; Left Forlorn Not at Altar, But at Border
description: LAST year, Olga and Joseph Rosi of Guilderland, N.Y., decided that come December 2001, they would celebrate their fifth wedding anniversary in style, at a real church wedding. Ms. Rosi wanted her parents there. She wanted her father to walk her down the aisle. She wanted her sister to be her maid of honor.

title: Speeding Breakneck Toward the Future, Dangerously Free
description: BALLISTICS

title: Should We Battle The Iraqis, Too?
description: To the Editor:

title: Accounts
description: * ING Direct, New York, the online banking division of the ING Groupof the Netherlands, is beginning a review for its account, with billings estimated by Advertising Age and Adweek at $30 million to $50 million. The incumbent agency, Howard, Merrell & Partners, Raleigh, N.C., will not take part in the review, being managed by Pile & Company, Boston. The ING Group awarded its account in September to DDB Worldwide, New York, part of the Omnicom Group.

title: In the Bronx, an Ounce of Connection
description: ENTERING the lobby of the new Children's Hospital at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx, one can hardly tell it's a hospital, at least not a hospital in this century.

title: 2 Parties Embrace New York And Look to '04 Conventions
description: New York has long held a cherished, but narrow, role in national politics. It is where candidates go to raise money, only to quickly vanish. In the presidential campaign last fall, George W. Bush never stumped there because the state was a shoo-in for the Democrats. And Al Gore never stumped there because he did not have to.

title: Injury Sidelines Islanders' Hamrlik
description: Islanders defenseman Roman Hamrlik will miss tonight's game against Montreal because of a sprained knee. The injury is not believed to be serious, however, and Hamrlik could return for the home game Saturday against Buffalo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REXING, GEORGE LEE
description: REXING-George Lee. Of Glen Cove, L.I. on November 27, 2001, age 67. Father of George E. (Michelle), Candy Mary, Susan Busch (Howard), Brian Lee and Sally Ann. Brother of Melba Rose Schultheis, Dorothy Addy, Kleo Selby, Ruth Maas, Norman and the late Gladys Schapker and Mildred Keil. Visitation at DiMiceli Funeral Home, 182 Lexington Avenue, NYC, Friday 2-4 and 68PM. Mass St. Francis of Assisi R.C. Church, NYC. on Saturday, AM. Interment to be held in Fort Branch, Indiana.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: Spain to Study U.S. Requests To Extradite Terror Suspects
description: Spain's prime minister, Jos Mara Aznar, avoided a potential confrontation with the White House today when he said he would consider any request by the United States for his country to hand over eight men charged with complicity in the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Free Music Service Is Expected to Surpass Napster
description: Several Internet music ventures backed by the record industry are poised to start next week, with others to follow in the next two months. But the long-awaited subscription services will enter an online world where the free music swapping they are meant to counteract is at record levels.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: JOHNSON CONTROLS, Milwaukee, said it had won a contract with J. C. Penney, Plano, Tex., to maintain systems at 1,080 stores.

title: Advertising Group to Meet in China
description: The International Advertising Association said yesterday that its China chapter would be host to the 39th World Advertising Congress in Beijing in May 2004.

title: Bin Laden On Trial: Television Anticipates
description: Court TV's big story this week followed the closing arguments in the case of Richard Sharpe, described as the ''cross-dressing dermatologist'' from Massachusetts. He said he was insane when he killed his wife. But tonight at 10 on its regular series ''The System,'' Court TV plugs into larger events with ''Osama bin Laden on Trial,'' a contemplation of how ''the world's most wanted'' might be prosecuted and defended in an American courtroom.

title: A Bazaar Is Newly Abuzz and the Talk Is of a New Era: After the Taliban, What?
description: With the Taliban gone from this northeastern city, the bazaar is once again a marketplace of ideas. Trading is heavy as people taking pleasure in thinking out loud argue how to run this country.

title: Jets Need Long Ball Against Patriots
description: Each week, Wayne Chrebet waits for what rarely comes. He has caught only 25 passes this season, Vinny Testaverde has had only one 200-yard game and the Jets' passing game is ranked 29th in the N.F.L. The Jets' longest pass this season was only 39 yards.

title: A Bankruptcy Filing Might Be the Best Remaining Choice
description: Enron, facing the collapse of a deal with Dynegy that might have rescued it from disaster and a tidal wave of debts suddenly coming due, may now have little choice but to enter bankruptcy, lawyers and analysts said yesterday.

title: The 50's and 60's, Through 3-D Glasses
description: FOR Modernist buffs, the only place to see legendary buildings in their original 50's and 60's splendor is usually in coffee-table books. But tonight, the Los Angeles Conservancy will present ''3-D L.A.: Modernism in Three Dimensions -- The Stereo Photography of Jack Laxer, 1953-1965,'' a slide show, at an Imax theater at the California Science Center downtown. ''There's a real sense of immersion when you view these images on the wide screen,'' said Alan Leib, chairman of the conservancy's Modern committee. ''You really feel like you can walk right into these buildings.''

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: A Love Story, a Letter From a Firefighter, a Proud Moment in Church
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Computerized Gears Pave Smooth Path for Bicycles
description: A new bicycle system from Shimano automatically shifts gears, a feature found on even the most basic of automobiles. But the system, the Nexave Di2 component set, also shares a feature with costly luxury cars: a suspension that automatically and electronically adjusts for maximum comfort. ''With this you can create the Lexus of comfort bikes,'' said Josh Woodbury, a spokesman for Shimano's United States operation.

title: I Think I Hear Voices
description: To the Editor:

title: Andean Trade Renewal Stalls
description: The Bush administration wants to renew and expand a trade agreement with four financially troubled South American nations, but with just days to go before the pact expires, on Dec. 4, a last-minute split in Congress has put the deal into question.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Tuesday about Norman Granz, record producer and founder of the Jazz at the Philharmonic touring group, misstated the timing of some artists' performances with the group. Illinois Jacquet, Les Paul and J. J. Johnson did appear with Nat (King) Cole in the group's first concert, not eventually, and Lester Young and Billie Holiday appeared only later, not at the first concert.

title: The Casino Jinx
description: While most New Yorkers were focused on emergencies elsewhere, the governor and the State Legislature in Albany took advantage of our distraction and passed a law designed to convert New York into a gamblers' paradise. The decision happened swiftly and covertly. There were no public hearings, and the final vote came after midnight, before an audience consisting mainly of high-priced lobbyists. The fruit of this unseemly process was an agreement that Gov. George Pataki should conduct negotiations for six new Indian-run casinos. As bargains go, it is not a good one, and Mr. Pataki and the Legislature should bail out of this package before it's too late. In the end, Mr. Pataki's casinos will cost New York far more in social problems than they can ever deliver in state or local benefits.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Shots Fired At Post Office
description: A former postal worker fired gunshots at postal police officers outside a Postal Service processing center in East New York last night, the police said. No one was injured. The man, Jerry Pope, 53, of Queens, was dismissed from his job at that center for alcohol-related reasons three weeks ago, said Peter Nash, a postal inspector. Last night, Mr. Pope went to the center, at 1050 Forbell Street, just after 9 p.m. and was escorted out by postal police officers, Mr. Nash said. Mr. Pope drove off in a car, and the police then heard about four gunshots and pursued him, the police said. Emergency services officials were able to remove him from his car, the police said. They did not find a weapon in the car, Mr. Nash said. Charges were pending. Robert F. Worth (NYT)

title: When Faith Is Taken to Extremes
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Endicott: I.B.M. To Cut 1,000 Jobs
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it planned to cut about 1,000 management and other positions, or nearly 5 percent, in its microelectronics division, which makes microchips for I.B.M. and other companies. I.B.M. cited a slowing demand for semiconductors. The job cuts will be concentrated in Endicott and East Fishkill, as well as in Burlington, Vt. In its third quarter earnings announcement, I.B.M. said profit had dropped 17 percent.

title: Pared-Down Election Ballot Reopens a Divide in Iran
description: When seven members of Parliament died in a plane crash in May, few expected that replacing them would prompt a national political showdown that has called into question, once again, the degree to which the Islamic Republic of Iran is a republic at all.

title: Making the Music Sway to Your Beat
description: RIDING the subway, walking through the mall, waiting at the airport lounge, a tune plays inside your head. You want to hum, hum out loud, really, to share it with someone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EBENSTEIN, CLAIRE
description: EBENSTEIN-Claire. Reaching Up mourns the passing of the beloved mother of our Executive Director William Ebenstein. We extend our deepest condolences to her entire family and friends.

title: The Neediest Cases; Program Helps Ex-Gang Member Change Her Colors
description: Everything was just too much for Jessica Nivar to handle. Her teachers told her she could do better in school, her mother wanted her to pay her own bills, and her younger sisters were pestering her to initiate them into her gang.

title: After U.S. Objects, World Fails To Agree to Curb Smoking Ads
description: The latest round of talks to forge an international antitobacco agreement ended today with some of the most contentious issues, particularly a sweeping ban on cigarette advertising, left for next year.

title: Emulator Is the Software Of a Thousand Interfaces
description: Maybe Microsoft's new Windows XP operating system really is better than the Windows version you might currently be using. Then again, maybe it isn't. If too many ''maybes'' leave you wondering about the nifty features you may miss by not upgrading, or familiar ones you may lose if you do, one answer is to keep your present operating system and emulate the others.

title: On Their Way to the City: Bigger Taxis (and Higher Fares)
description: With the arrival of what is being called the stretch taxi, New York City's cabs are about to get roomier and, almost certainly, more expensive.

title: Tourism ads that started running after Sept. 11 are getting a midcourse correction.
description: TOURISM advertisers are making midcourse corrections to campaigns they introduced after Sept. 11 to lure consumers who, while still nervous, are showing a greater inclination to travel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINSON, JO LIST
description: LEVINSON-Jo List. The Trustees and staff of The Jewish Museum observe with great sadness the death of Jo List Levinson, beloved daughter of Vera List, our devoted Life Trustee and generous benefactor. We extend our deepest condolences to the extended Levinson and List families. Robert J. Hurst, Chairman Joan Rosenbaum, Helen Goldsmith Menschel Dir.

title: NORTHROP SETS EXCHANGE FOR NEWPORT STOCK
description: The Northrop Grumman Corporation has set the exchange ratio for its $2.6 billion acquisition of Newport News Shipbuilding. Newport stockholders who want to be paid only in Northrop common stock will get 0.7193 share for each Newport share. Newport News shareholders will receive $67.50 a share for their holdings no matter how they choose to be paid, Northrop has said. Northrop has about $633.4 million available for Newport News shareholders who receive cash and stock. Northrop will recalculate the exchange ratio if its tender offer is extended beyond tomorrow's deadline. Northrop, which is based in Los Angeles, agreed this month to buy Newport News and create the largest military shipbuilder.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTESMAN, HAROLD AARON
description: GOTTESMAN-Harold Aaron, 75. Died peacefully at home in Old Lyme, Conn., on November 28. A longtime figure in the New York real estate community, Mr. Gottesman co-founded the Edison Parking Corporation, parent of ParkFast garages and lots, Manhattan Mini Storage and the Hippodrome office building. After serving more than four decades as president of the company, he retired in 1998 to establish Edison Investment Advisors, a familyowned fund. Loving companion of Madelaine Goldish, devoted father of Ellen Garber, Robin Gottesman Levine and Andrew, father-in-law of Lawrence, Richard and Christine, grandfather of Trudy, Kate, Molly, Amy, Peter and Zachary, and brother of Jerome, A. Edward and the late Arlene Reff. Mr. Gottesman earned B.S. and M.S. degrees in mechanical engineering at the Carnegie Institute of Technology in 1946. He graduated from the United States Military Academy at West Point in 1950 and became a bomber pilot in the U.S. Air Force. Mr. Gottesman was a board member of the U.S.S. Intrepid Sea, Air and Space Museum and the Avenue of the Americas Association. He also was a member of the group that founded the West Point Jewish Chapel and remained an active participant on the Board of Overseers. Services will be held at the West Point Jewish Chapel on Friday, November 30. Guests must leave from the William F. Hogan Funeral Home, 135 Main St. in Highland Falls, 845-446-2868, at 9:15 A.M. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Harold A. Gottesman E'46 Honarary Scholarship fund at Carnegie Mellon University (checks to Carnegie Mellon University), C/O Kristin Sullivan, Warner Hall #

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief report in the Pop Life column last Thursday about a new band called Zwan misstated the name of a group with which its bassist, David Pajo, used to play. It was Slint, not Flint. The report also misidentified the instrument he played then. It was guitar, not bass.

title: I Think I Hear Voices
description: To the Editor:

title: The New Air War: Fewer Pilots, More Hits and Scarcer Targets
description: Each day in Afghanistan, American commandos spot enemy targets miles away using binoculars equipped with laser range-finders. They relay the coordinates by satellite phones or laptop computers to warplanes circling high overhead. Then they get back on their horses to ride to the next target.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Should We Battle The Iraqis, Too?
description: To the Editor:

title: Camby Feeling Little Pain in Foot
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 28  After acing his first test against the Hawks on Monday, Marcus Camby passed his second when he awoke Tuesday with little pain in his left foot. Coach Jeff Van Gundy's decision not to practice had Camby feeling even better heading into tonight's rematch with the Hawks.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Teenage-Oriented Marketer Has a Loss
description: Alloy Inc., a New York media and direct marketing company focused on teenagers, announced a net loss of $2.7 million, or 11 cents a share, for its fiscal third quarter, ended Oct. 31. In the year-earlier quarter, Alloy reported a loss of $9.7 million, or 48 cents. Total revenue for the latest quarter increased 58 percent, to $44.5 million, from $28.1 million in the year-earlier quarter. On Tuesday, Alloy announced the acquisition of 360 Youth, a division of the MarketSource Corporation, a marketing and services company that helps advertisers direct messages to teenagers and college students. Shares of Alloy fell 16 cents, to $15.90. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: The Civil Right to Life
description: To the Editor:

title: In America; The Tourism Crisis
description: Michele Angerosi, a well-dressed man in his 30's, was sitting at the bar in Il Bocconcino restaurant in Greenwich Village on Tuesday evening. But he wasn't drinking. He'd come in to tell a friend, the restaurant's owner, Gilberto Petrucci, that he'd just been laid off.

title: Editorial Observer; Distracting Ourselves in the Glow of the Tube
description: After Sept. 11, it seemed for a moment as if the triviality of American popular culture had been completely unmasked. You didn't have to agree with Jerry Falwell that we had caused our own punishment to sense that something about the way America had been diverting itself suddenly looked immature at best. People blinked in the smoke of Lower Manhattan as though someone had flicked on a third-degree lamp. Peering through that tainted haze, Americans believed they saw themselves more clearly than they ever had. Perhaps in the comfortable vacuity of reality television, celebrity-watching and lowbrow movies there was reason for a kind of self-accusation. Maybe we had lost our security because our national seriousness had slipped away first.

title: New Daily Newspaper Is Planned in New York City for 2002
description: An investment group that includes the company of the publisher Conrad M. Black said yesterday that it planned to start printing a new daily newspaper in New York City in the first few months of next year.

title: The Red, White and Blue Dominates Tree Lighting
description: The celebrity-sprinkled ritual of lighting Rockefeller Center's huge Christmas tree turned into a civic pep rally last night as the first lady, Laura Bush, told an overflowing crowd that ''America loves New York.''

title: Joe Modise, 72, Fighter Against Apartheid
description: Joe Modise, a guerrilla fighter who led the armed struggle against apartheid and became South Africa's first black defense minister, died in his home near Pretoria on Monday night, government officials said Tuesday.

title: Board Backs A New School On East Side Of Manhattan
description: The Board of Education unanimously approved the creation of a new high school in Manhattan last night, responding to years of lobbying by Upper East Side parents who say that public schools in their neighborhood are not strong enough to adequately prepare children for college.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCABE, EUGENE J.
description: McCABE-Eugene J., 83. Of Rumson, N.J., died Sunday at home. Born on February 14, 1918, Mr. McCabe lived in NYC before moving to Rumson 43 years ago. He was predeceased by his parents, Eugene J. & Katherine McCabe, and his sister Catherine, all of NYC; a son Michael, of Rumson, killed in the 9/11 WTC attack; and a granddaughter Shannon. Survivng are his beloved wife of 48 years, Eleanor; two daughters, Mary Ellen Kirschner (Robert) and Suzanne, both of NYC; two sons, Eugene J. (Maureen), Newport, R.I., and Nicholas (Rob Florczak) of NYC; his daughter-in-law Lynn McCabe of Rumson; and 7 grandchildren: Cassidy, Regan, Liam, Nicholas, Kevin, Jack, and Riley. The family will receive friends Friday from 3 to 8 at the Molly Pitcher Inn, Red Bank, NJ. Those wishing to pay respects may also call at John E. Day Funeral Home, 85 Riverside Ave., Red Bank, NJ during those hours. A funeral Mass will be celebrated Saturday at 10AM at Holy Cross Church, Rumson. In lieu of flowers, donations to the VNA of Central Jersey Hospice Program; Rumson First Aid, or the Michael McCabe Children's Education Fund, P.O. Box 526, Rumson, NJ, 07760, would be greatly appreciated.

title: Miscellany
description: * CMR, New York, the division of Taylor Nelson Sofres that tracks advertising spending, is expanding its Broadcast Verification Service outside the United States for the first time. The service, which tracks television programming and commercials, will now be available in six Canadian markets like Montreal and Toronto.

title: Mousetrap Or Palmtop, The Quest Never Ends
description: THERE'S an old saying in the high-tech industry: Give a man a fish and you feed him for a day. But let him license your operating system and he has the foundation for a thriving enterprise that through selective innovation and cooperative cross-promotion expands market share for both licensee and licenser.

title: Senior Tour Plans to Bring Fans Closer to Action
description: In an effort to increase interest in the Senior Tour, Tim Finchem, the commissioner of the PGA Tour, announced significant changes yesterday aimed at bringing fans closer to the action. Some of the changes will occur next year, while others will not be fully in place until 2003.

title: Should We Battle The Iraqis, Too?
description: To the Editor:

title: Inowroclaw Journal; Terrorists, Beware! Pole Says His Bullet Is Better
description: Wojciech Stecki, a modest if quietly quirky soldier, opened an interview here by reaching into his black briefcase. First he took out a tray of eggnog-flavored cookies, which were not bad. Then he pulled out a second item: a sleek 9-millimeter pistol.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARRETT, JACK
description: BARRETT-Jack, 98. Of Coconut Creek, FL, died on November 26, at 4:30 P.M. in Boca Raton, FL. The memorial service will be (today) Thursday, November 29, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, New York at 12:00 noon.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: New Investigator Of Torture
description: The United Nations has appointed a Dutch law professor as its new investigator for cases of torture. Theo van Boven was named special rapporteur for torture and other forms of cruel and unusual punishment. He replaces Nigel Rodley of Britain, who held the post since 1993 but stepped down citing overwork and his new duties on the United Nations Human Rights Commission. During his term, Mr. Rodley criticized the refusal of China, India and Indonesia, in particular, to allow him to freely investigate accusations of torture. Mr. van Boven, 67, who teaches at Maastricht University, is experienced and outspoken in the human rights area. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Agency Weighs Buying Drug to Protect Against Radiation-Induced Ailments
description: Spurred by the attacks in September, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission is moving toward buying millions of doses of a drug that protects against thyroid cancer that might result from radiation exposure.

title: Survivor Security
description: One of the funds giving financial help to the families of the Sept. 11 victims has quietly gone about its business, performing smoothly and with low administrative costs, according to clear rules. This fund has plenty of practice; it is Social Security.

title: ID, Please? Digital Wallets Are Getting Another Try
description: DIGITAL wallets, providing portable identification and currency for online shoppers, were often touted during the dot-com bubble as the next big thing. They never caught on, but two companies with big stakes in online commerce -- Microsoft and Sun Microsystems -- are now putting their weight behind variations on the idea.

title: Liberty Satellite Bid Is Criticized
description: Bill Gates, who holds a 7.5 percent stake in Liberty Satellite and Technology, is urging it to reject a buyout bid by Liberty Media, which is controlled by John C. Malone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TYNION, JAMES T. JR.
description: TYNION-James T. Jr. in his 79th year on November 27, 2001. Beloved husband of 47 years to E. Beverly (nee Ryan). Devoted father of James T. III, Eileen, Patrick A., Virginia Coughlan and Donald W. II. Loving grandfather of twelve. Also survived by his brother Donald W. and sister Louisemary McDonald. Mr. Tynion, as an alumnus of Brooklyn Prep and the College of Mount St. Mary, was former Secretary-Treasurer of The Hamilton Press and retired from Appeal Printing. A veteran of WWII, he was Knight Commander with Star of the Order of the Holy Sepulchre, member of the Holy Name Society, of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick and Bay Ridge Post 157 of the American Legion. Visiting Thursday, 2-4 & 79 p.m. at The Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Ave, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial 9AM Friday, St. Anselm's RC Church. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory to St. Anselm's RC Church would be appreciated.

title: Just Like In Hollywood, Only at Home
description: EVER wonder what becomes of the furniture from movie and television sets? Some, hired from Props for Today, a rental company, goes back to its Midtown warehouse, which is having a giant garage sale today, Saturday and Sunday. An end table that saw it all in ''Sex and the City,'' a Breuer side chair featured in ''Riding in Cars With Boys,'' a George Nelson bench that played a supporting role in ''Zoolander'' -- it's all here, and at bargain prices.

title: BAXTER SETTLES SUIT OVER DIALYSIS DEATHS IN SPAIN
description: Baxter International is to pay 55 million pesetas ($292,000) in compensation to each of the families of 10 kidney dialysis patients in Spain who died last summer after treatment with Baxter dialysis filters. Manuel Mata, a lawyer for several of the families, said his clients would withdraw a lawsuit against Baxter as part of the agreement. ''Our goal is to do the right thing,'' said Harry Jansen Kraemer Jr., chairman of Baxter. ''Our hope is that this settlement helps to minimize the distress to the families involved.'' Emma Daly (NYT)

title: Deficits Are Foreseen For at Least 3 Years
description: The Bush administration said it expected federal budget deficits for at least the next three years, confirming that the recession and the war on terrorism had wiped out huge projected surpluses.

title: S.& P. Cuts Credit Rating Of Japan
description: Standard & Poor's reduced its rating of Japan's credit by a notch, to AA, today, penalizing the government of the world's second-largest economy for failing to curtail its fiscal deficit or revive its faltering economy.

title: Visions of Sugarplums Dance on the Web
description: SOME people, when they remember childhood Christmases, think first of a special present: the year of the red bike. Others can't forget certain trees that glittered more than they ever could today. Others have sweet memories of midnight church services when candles lighted worshipers' faces with a glow of love, or of pink-cheeked carolers in the snow.

title: I Think I Hear Voices
description: To the Editor:

title: ABC's 'Millionaire' May Not Survive Beyond the Current Season
description: Less than two years after the ABC game show ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire'' changed the competitive face of American television, ABC executives are saying the show may not survive beyond the current season.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SOYBEANS FALL. Soybeans fell after a report showed grain processors were increasing output as demand is expected to weaken. In Chicago, soybeans for January delivery fell 8.5 cents, or 1.9 percent, to $4.355 a bushel.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Norway: Construction Acquisition
description: After a battle with Yukos Oil of Russia, Aker Maritime of Norway won control of a rival engineering and construction group, Kvaerner. Aker Maritime is the biggest shareholder in the ailing Kvaerner, and Yukos Oil is the second biggest. As part of a rescue plan, Kvaerner and Aker Maritime agreed to combine key businesses and Kvaerner will issue new shares. Yukos said it supported the deal, seen as a triumph for Kjell Inge Roekke, a Norwegian tycoon and chairman of Aker Maritime. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: The People and Cars of a Crowded Island
description: To the Editor:

title: Troop Buildup, an Aggressive Dragnet and the High Price of Terror
description: The buildup of United States forces in Afghanistan is far from over, said their commander, Gen. Tommy R. Franks of the Army. The operative word seemed to be ''more.'' More marines will soon arrive, bringing the total to about 1,000. More makeshift bases will be built as needed around the country. And more attack planes will be sent to Central Asia, with the former Soviet republics of Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan the likely staging areas.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Retail Sales Fall
description: Japanese large-store retail sales fell 7.1 percent in October from the month last year, the largest slide in two years and another sign that consumers are tightening their belts and bracing for a deep recession. With the jobless rate at a record 5.3 percent and wages falling, consumers have cut back on purchases of everything from clothing to cars. Sales were also depressed in October as consumers bought less beef after the country's first case of mad cow disease was discovered. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERS, BERTHA (NEE WISCH)
description: PETERS-Bertha (nee Wisch). Wife of the late Henry. Devoted and beloved mother of Marion. Sister of the late Sophie Meyer. Reposing Thursday 2-5 & 7-9PM at Hillebrand Funeral Homes Inc. 6317 Woodhaven Blvd, Rego Park. Prayer service Friday 10:30AM, interment Maple Grove Cemetery.

title: When Faith Is Taken to Extremes
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The same compassion that caused me to root for the New York Yankees for the first time in 51 years makes me think it would be fun to go to New York and show the presidential flag there.''

title: The Old Rock Reborn as New
description: In the last year an imprinting of sorts has been taking place on the unconscious of rock musicians. Suddenly dozens of bands, most unconnected to the others, have released new albums around the same time to try to save rock 'n' roll from its current doldrums with raw energy and influences from the 60's and 70's, particularly the British Invasion, garage rock and early punk.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, DR. LEO A.
description: GREEN-Dr. Leo A. On Tuesday, November 27, of Jackson Heights. Husband of Angela (O'Brien and the late Mary G. (Cohen). Father of Dr. Stuart A. Green & his wife Adrienne of CA and Joyce Green Moss & her husband Guy of MA. Grandfather of Andrew & Hillary Green and Jason & David Moss. Brother of Clara Weitz of MA, Constance Bernstein of FL and the late Sydney Green. Funeral services at the Levine Chapels, 470 Harvard St., Brookline, MA on Friday, November 30. A memorial service will be held in NY at a later date. Remembrances may be made to American Friends of ALYN Hospital, 19 West 44th St., Suite 1418, NY, NY 10036.

title: When Love Has Flown, Dreams Follow
description: Before Ricky Martin, before Jennifer Lopez, there was Ballet Hispnico, founded by Tina Ramirez in New York in 1970 to reconfirm the role of a Hispanic heritage in American life.

title: Justices Revisit the Issue of Child Protection in the Age of Internet Pornography
description: Four years after the Supreme Court overturned the federal government's first effort to shield children from pornography on the Internet, the justices were back today to consider whether the government's second try could pass First Amendment muster.

title: France Is Seeking a Fine in Trial of Algerian War General
description: The trial of a former French general who has admitted torturing and executing dozens of Algerians during France's brutal colonial war ended here today with prosecutors seeking a $15,000 fine, rather than imprisonment, if the general is found guilty.

title: Northern Alliance Troops Depart From Kunduz
description: Thousands of Northern Alliance soldiers withdrew from this city today, leaving suddenly for the outskirts, where their commander said they would begin disarming, then assume civilian jobs that would help a new interim government that was appointed as they were leaving.

title: World Business Briefing
description: AMERICAS

title: Military Tribunals
description: To the Editor:

title: Power Deal In Pretoria Seems Tilted To the A.N.C.
description: The old enemies exchanged wedding vows with grins and handshakes. Then the two men, one black and one white, toasted their political marriage in a news conference that flashed across the nation's television screens.

title: Advertising Group To Meet in China
description: The International Advertising Association said yesterday that its China chapter would be host to the 39th World Advertising Congress in Beijing in May 2004.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, BERNARD I.
description: HELLER-Bernard I. Died peacefully November 27, 2001. He is survived by his loving daughters Abbe Heller and Cynthia Flowers, sons-in-law Scott Kurnit and Robert Flowers, grandchildren Perry and Lindsey Flowers and loving companion Philis Weiss. His wit and wisdom will carry on within all those he touched. Memorial services will be held Thursday, November 29, 2001, 10 AM, at the Glascott Funeral Home, 102-03 Metropolitan Avenue, Forest Hills, NY, (718) 268-4466.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Yugoslavia Protects Mladic, Prosecutors Say
description: Ratko Mladic, left, the former Bosnian Serb general charged with genocide and other war crimes, is living in Serbia and moving around freely because he is protected by the Yugoslav Army, according to prosecutors for the United Nations war crimes tribunal in The Hague. The chief prosecutor, Carla Del Ponte, told the United Nations Security Council on Tuesday that General Mladic had ''official protection of the Yugoslav Army.'' Yugoslavia's interior minister, Zoran Zivkovic, said the assertion was ''completely unfounded.'' The deputy prosecutor, Graham Blewitt, who would not identify the source of the tribunal's information, said that General Mladic lived part of the time in Belgrade and part of the time elsewhere in Serbia. That would put him out of the reach of NATO forces that are based in the region and put the burden of his arrest on the Yugoslav authorities.

title: U.S. Official Sees Russia in Oil Catbird Seat
description: In American eyes, Russia has taken on crucial importance as a world energy producer, and its role will grow even larger when the Russian government clears the way for extensive foreign investment in its energy sector, the United States secretary of energy, Spencer Abraham, said here today.

title: Why Won't Bloomberg Call? Giuliani's Staff Is Wondering
description: When asked about what his next administration will look like, a common response from Mayor-elect Michael R. Bloomberg is that he wants ''the best and the brightest.'' When many members of the current administration heard that, they apparently believed Mr. Bloomberg was referring to them.

title: AIDS and Death Hold No Sting for Fatalistic Men at African Bar
description: The bar nicknamed K. F. C. does not serve fried chicken, and working up an appetite might be tricky if it did. It is a cinder block garage on a dirt street next door to a funeral parlor. It has roll-down steel doors, one pool table, one plastic table, two coolers full of beer and shelves full of cheap Richelieu brandy.

title: INSIDE
description: In a South African Bar, Zulu Men Mock Risk of AIDS

title: For the Reader or Listener With an Expanding Collection
description: Marin Pollosson's felt bookcase ''looks like a radiator,'' said Jenny Pedersen, the owner of Vega, a lively home-furnishings store in the Gallery Place neighborhood near the modern furniture store Apartment Zero. The pliable shelf, which comes in white or gray and holds up to 200 books or videotapes and even more CD's, adds a relaxed note to a room. ''We want to show that the contemporary can be comfortable,'' Ms. Pedersen said, ''not cold and uninviting.'' Vega also carries fuzzy ottomans in challenging colors like orange, gold and chartreuse, and vases made of delicate papier-mch. The felt bookcase is 48 inches wide, 35 inches high and 6 inches deep; $524 at Vega, 819 Seventh Street NW; (202) 589-0140.

title: In Turbulent Bond Market, Enron's Woes Exacerbate Turmoil
description: The swift downfall of Enron has contributed to extreme turbulence in the United States Treasury market in recent weeks, causing violent swings in interest rates not seen since Russia defaulted on its debt and the Long-Term Capital Management hedge fund nearly collapsed in late 1998.

title: U.S. Citizenship May Be Reward in Terror War, Ashcroft Says
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29  Foreigners who provide useful information about terrorists may be rewarded by being put on a quick path to American citizenship, Attorney General John D. Ashcroft said today.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Bush Signs Internet Tax Ban
description: President Bush renewed a ban on Internet taxes for two years, saying the legislation would ''ensure the growth of the Internet is not slowed by additional taxation and that holiday shoppers will not be burdened by new taxes on their online purchases.'' Congress passed the original ban on Internet taxes in 1998 to prevent states and local governments from imposing taxes that some thought might stunt the growth of the World Wide Web. The moratorium lapsed on Oct. 21. Some governors and state officials have argued that millions of dollars are lost in taxes every year when people shop on the Internet. Others, including online retailers and technology companies, say taxation of online transactions could impair Internet commerce -- particularly during the current recession. Mr. Bush said online spending was expected to account for about 15 percent of holiday purchases this year.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: IThink I Hear Voices

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Loss At Deutsche Telekom
description: Deutsche Telekom said it lost 627 million euros ($554 million) in the third quarter and would probably report its first full-year loss since it became a publicly traded company five years ago. But its operating profit was somewhat stronger than analysts had expected, and there was some evidence that Telekom's downward spiral might have hit bottom. The company continued to be burdened by depreciation costs associated with its investment in third-generation wireless licenses as well as losses at VoiceStream, its wireless company in the United States. But earnings before interest, taxes and depreciation were up about 20 percent over the previous year, at 4.08 billion euros. Operating profit in the wireless division, before interest, taxes and depreciation, more than doubled, to 807 million euros. Profits also seemed to have stabilized in the fixed-line business, which had been hit hard by competition in long-distance service. But analysts remained cautious about declaring that Telekom's turnaround had begun. Deutsche Telekom's chairman, Ron Sommer, above, has said he will reduce debt to 50 billion euros by the end of next year. Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Washington: Interior Secretary To Stand Trial
description: Gale A. Norton, the interior secretary, has been ordered to stand trial on Monday on charges that she violated court orders and misled a federal judge concerning the status of more than $10 billion in royalties from Indian land. The order stems from accusations in a lawsuit filed during the Clinton administration that the government had mismanaged the royalties from mining, grazing and timber since 1887. Eric Ruff, a spokesman for Ms. Norton, said that her recent reorganization of the Indian trust reflected her determination to improve the program.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Airlines Withdraw from Boeing Venture
description: Boeing said yesterday that the top three United States airlines had canceled plans to invest in Connexion, its planned airborne Internet service, because of a sharp slowdown in air travel. The high-speed data service, first announced in April of last year, was to have provided passengers with two-way Internet connections, as well as access to live television, travel information and news. The airlines -- American, Delta and United -- viewed the venture as a distraction at a time when United States air travel was in a slump. Boeing originally planned to equip as many as 1,500 planes to provide the digital services. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: With Free Agents Not in Budget, Mets Must Give in Order to Get
description: In the Mets' minds, there is a major difference in the value of two of the slugging outfielders who could be available in trades. Gary Sheffield, a player the Mets passed on last spring, might be worth three established players. Jeromy Burnitz, a former Met, might not be worth one.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: India Is Asked For Help To Fight Rebels
description: The government has asked India for helicopters and ammunition to fight a Maoist rebellion that began in 1996 and has cost about 350 lives in just the past week. A spokeswoman for India's Ministry of External Affairs said India's prime minister, Atal Behari Vajpayee, had assured King Gyanendra, the constitutional monarch of Nepal, ''that India was ready to extend whatever assistance was required.'' Nepal declared a state of emergency on Monday so it could mobilize the army against the rebels. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: Lou Reed, Exploring Poe's Plutonian Shore
description: The past never stopped singing in the fevered brain of Edgar Allan Poe, always chanting on about things lost, things dead, the women (starting with Mother, who died when he was 3) who got away.

title: Bodies Hang in California, And Bullets Fly in Florida
description: ORCHID BLUES

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Granada's Profit Falls
description: Profit at Granada P.L.C. fell in its last fiscal year as advertising revenue declined and spending on its ITV Digital television joint venture with Carlton Communications increased. For the year that ended Sept. 30, Granada said it earned 98 million ($139 million), or 3.8 pence a share, from continuing operations before investments in digital media and exceptional items. That compares with 105 million, or 6.4 pence a share, the prior year. Including investments and special charges, Granada lost 132 million, or 5.2 pence a share, in contrast to a profit of 550 million, or 35.1 pence a share, the prior year. Granada said it planned to cut ITV Digital costs by 104 million in 2002, partly by eliminating jobs. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: A Nation Challenged
description: The Hot Pursuit

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about hundreds of miles of tunnels dug under Beijing in the late 1960's out of fear of a Soviet nuclear attack referred incorrectly in some editions to troops who seized an Amur River island on the border between Russia and China in 1969. They were Soviets, but not under Stalin, who died in 1953.

title: The New York Times's N.F.L. Computer Ranking
description: The New York Times's computer football ranking is based on an analysis of each team's scores with emphasis on three factors: who won, by what margin and against what quality of opposition. The quality of an opponent is determined by examining the opponent's record against other teams.

title: Badly Embarrassed Devils Are Searching for Answers
description: One victory in nine games and last place in their division is not the route to the Stanley Cup, and the Devils are well aware of it. They are not efficient anywhere, especially at scoring. The Devils have been shut out in three of the last five games, and their only victory in the stretch came against the lowly Florida Panthers.

title: Chisholm Trail Designated, but Purists Object
description: Like other central Texas towns, this quiet ranching community has long celebrated its place along the Chisholm Trail, the famous cattle-driving route of the Old West. Lockhart has an annual Chisholm Trail Rodeo and Roundup, a Chisholm Trail barbecue joint and even a Chisholm Trail nursing home.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Suit Filed Over Access To Presidential Papers
description: Public Citizen, a liberal public interest group, filed suit to block President Bush from limiting access to the historical records of previous presidents. Earlier this month, Mr. Bush signed a executive order that gave a sitting president authority to keep secret the papers of previous presidents. The suit, filed in federal district court, contends that the order violates the 1978 Presidential Records Act, which makes public a former president's records 12 years after leaving office. The suit was filed on behalf of the American Historical Association, the National Security Archive and others. In January, the Bush administration blocked the release of 68,000 pages of President Reagan's papers, which included confidential communications with Mr. Bush's father, George Bush, who was then vice president.

title: 19 Countries Join in Raids On Internet Pornography
description: The police in 19 countries took part in a coordinated crackdown today aimed at people who distribute child pornography electronically.

title: When Faith Is Taken to Extremes
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: Military Tribunals
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLASER, JACOB
description: GLASER-Jacob. Riverdale Jewish Center extends condolences to our Board member Dr. Stephen Glaser upon the loss of his father. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi David Sable, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, HENRY
description: NEWMAN-Henry. Boys Town Jerusalem mourns with profound sorrow the passing of a most cherished member of our extended family. Henry Newman was a survivor in every sense of the word. As one who lived through the horrors of the Holocaust he had a keen understanding of the importance of Jewish education, the State of Israel, and Jewish continuity. The care, concern and love he showed for his beloved wife Helen, especially during her recent illness, was extraordinary. The Newmans suffered an irreplaceable loss with the untimely passing of their young son, Steven Mark. At Boys Town, the Newmans saw vibrant youngsters who represented the future of the Jewish people in the State of Israel. They established a major Scholarship Endowment in his name by dedicating the Steven Mark garden in the school's Children's Park, feeling that Steven's life would vicariously be lived by these young boys. We extend heartfelt condolences to his daughter Sylvia Safer and the entire family. Rabbi Moshe Linchner, Dean Josh S. Weston, Hon. Chairman Raphael Benaroya, Chairman Michael J. Scharf, President Rabbi Ronald Gray, Exec. V.P.

title: With Photo Software, Fiddle a Little or a Lot
description: Q. My photo scanner came with a free bare-bones image-editing program, but I'm wondering if I'm missing anything by not having a professional-level program. What features do I gain with more expensive software?

title: Justice Dept. and Senate Clash Over Bush Actions
description: The growing debate over the Bush administration's antiterrorism initiatives broke onto the public stage today during a Senate hearing where a senior Justice Department official was forced to deal with questions about the planned use of military tribunals and the arrest and interrogation of hundreds of mostly Middle Eastern men.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN GAINS. The dollar fell after Standard & Poor's cut Japan's credit rating by less than it was considering last week. In New York, the dollar settled at 123.16 yen, down from 124.00 yen on Tuesday.

title: Where's bin Laden? Here's One Hunch
description: American forces have enlisted commanders in eastern Afghanistan to help search for Osama bin Laden in isolated mountain hide-outs south of this city, a senior minister of the regional government said today.

title: When Faith Is Taken to Extremes
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Francis Moore, 88, Dies; Innovative Leader in Surgery
description: Dr. Francis D. Moore, a giant of 20th-century surgery who made profound contributions to the understanding of how bodily fluids and chemicals change during surgery, the development of organ transplantation and the care of critically ill surgical patients, died on Saturday at his home in Westwood, Mass.

title: At Site of Quelled Prisoner Revolt, Afghan Fort's Walls Tell a Tale of Death
description: With the mud walls of this 19th-century fort shell-pocked and still smoldering from three days of battle, Northern Alliance soldiers today picked over the bodies of more than 150 Taliban prisoners -- many apparently Pakistanis, some Arabs -- who were killed in an uprising against their captors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANDELMAN, RUTH
description: HANDELMAN-Ruth. The community of West End Synagogue mourns the loss of this quiet, gracious, always stylish lady. We extend our sympathies to her sons, grandchildren and their families. West End Synagogue: A Reconstructionist Congregation Rabbi Yael Ridberg Cantor Deborah Jacobson Jane Weprin-Menzi, President

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Secret Records Proposal Falters
description: A bill that would let the state temporarily close public records in terrorist-related investigations is not likely to be approved during the current special session of the Legislature. The measure, approved by a Senate committee on Tuesday, would let the state Department of Law Enforcement seal normally public records with court approval; the records could be withheld up to three weeks in the Senate bill or six weeks in the House version. But House members said that they are not likely to take up the bill before the session ends Dec. 6.

title: Shopping Outsided the Box
description: FAMILY TIME

title: If You Care, Wrap
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Wall Township: Shootings And Suicide
description: A man shot and killed himself yesterday after shooting and wounding his former girlfriend and a bystander who tried to help her. The man, Joseph O. Davis, 39, of Belmar, confronted Jennifer Missel, 31, of Eatontown, at her office and then shot her in the head and shoulder, said Peter E. Warshaw Jr., an assistant prosecutor for Monmouth County. Mr. Davis also shot Eugene Brown, 37, of Manahawkin, in the shoulder before killing himself, the police said. Ms. Missel was listed in in stable condition last night at Jersey Shore Medical Center in Neptune. Mr. Brown was treated and released. Ms. Missel had told friends that Mr. Davis was abusive, the police said.

title: As Light as a Snowflake, Even in a Blizzard
description: Rain and snow regularly sabotage the escalators at some of Washington's 53 exposed Metrorail subway stations, forcing commuters to hike up hundreds of idle steps. In the spring, the Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority will begin building lightweight steel and glass canopies to shelter 46 of the exposed escalators, at a cost of $27 million. Jon Lourie, Richard Chenoweth and Richard Houghton, the Silver Spring, Md., architects who won the design competition in July, derived the canopy shape, above, from the iconic coffered vaults of the station interiors, designed by the architect Harry Weese. ''Nothing touches those coffers,'' Mr. Lourie said. ''So we went with something simple, lightweight and airy.''

title: When Faith Is Taken to Extremes
description: To the Editor:

title: C.I.A. NAMES AGENT KILLED IN FORTRESS
description: The Central Intelligence Agency said today that one of its officers was killed in a chaotic uprising by Taliban prisoners near Mazar-i-Sharif on Sunday, the first American combat death in Afghanistan since the military campaign began.

title: Ducks, Dinosaurs and Others for Under $25
description: Aselection of gifts for less than $25. Items include a folding fishing rod, a ceramic cookie jar, duck-shaped soaps, asparagus tongs and more.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Chile: Good News On Economy
description: After months of climbing joblessness, the unemployment rate slipped to 9.7 percent from 10.1 percent for the quarter that ended in October, with a particular improvement in the rural provinces. The figures suggested that some parts of Latin America may be starting to shrug off an economic slowdown that was worsened by the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks and comes as good news for the government as congressional elections approach next month. The economy in neighboring Argentine, however, continues to worsen. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: LAWSUIT AGAINST BANK OF NEW YORK IS DISMISSED
description: A federal judge has dismissed a shareholder lawsuit against the Bank of New York Company that accused 19 senior officials of permitting the bank to launder money when it expanded in Russia in the 1990s. Judge Denny Chin of United States District Court in New York dismissed the lawsuit, which also named the company's chairman, Thomas Renyi, as a defendant. Judge Chin said plaintiffs bought shares in the company in 1998, after the reported wrongdoing. A spokesman for the bank declined to comment. The plaintiffs contended that officers and directors had acted recklessly. Melvyn I. Weiss, a lawyer for the shareholders, characterized the ruling as a ''technical decision.''

title: Miami's Sure-Fire Formula: Winning
description: As the college football regular season nears its close, fans and pundits will take aim at the nation's top-ranked team and question everything from the quality of opponent to the margin of victory. This annual exercise has become more scientific now that the Bowl Championship Series uses a formula to determine which two teams play for the undisputed national championship.

title: TOP GENERAL SAYS U.S. MAY ESTABLISH NEW AFGHAN BASES
description: The commander of American forces fighting in Afghanistan said today that the United States might establish more makeshift bases inside the country, making it easier to dispatch marines and soldiers quickly wherever they are needed in the intensifying hunt for the leaders and fighters of the Taliban and Al Qaeda.

title: Remarks by President Bush to U.S. Attorneys Conference
description: Following is the full text from President Bush's remarks on Thursday at a conference of United States attorneys in Washington, as provided by the White House:

title: Omnicom Acquires Promotion Network
description: The Omnicom Group in New York has acquired the Promotion Network in Dallas, which specializes in national consumer promotions. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Bush Gives Tight-Fisted Support to Bigger Farm Subsidies
description: President Bush jumped into the debate over American farm policy today, saying he supported generous federal subsidies for farmers as long as those payments stayed within the budget.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, BRUCE
description: COHEN-Bruce. On November 28, 2001. Beloved son of Leo and Joyce Cohen and the late Muriel. Dear brother of Joy Cohen and Bobby Owens. Devoted childhood friend of Steven Kleinman and his wife Arleen. Cherished by countless others. He left us too early, he will be deeply missed.

title: Izon Finally Gets Opponent
description: David Izon, the heavyweight boxer, had little to be grateful for on Thanksgiving Day. He had finished training and sat down to dinner with his wife when the phone delivered bad news. The man Izon was to fight in New York on Dec. 1, the 6-foot-7 Russian Wladimir Klitschko, was pulling out because of a shoulder injury.

title: Layoffs Feared as Consultant Examines Mount Sinai's Budget
description: Facing growing expenses and dropping patient revenue, Mount Sinai Hospital has hired a budget-cutting consultant, sending fears of layoffs rippling through the medical facility's staff.

title: Reuters Group Will Close Financial TV Unit and Cut 45 Jobs
description: Reuters Group P.L.C., the provider of financial information, said yesterday that it would close its financial television service, cutting 45 jobs, to reduce costs.

title: A Newspaper Building Rises, Shimmering, on the Way to the Airport
description: For 1,700 Gannett Company and USA Today employees, it's a workplace. To everybody else, it's a roadside hallucination on the way to Dulles International Airport. Last month, Gannett began moving from downtown Arlington, Va., to its new horseshoe-shaped, 800,000-square-foot headquarters in McLean, Va. The building, designed by William Pedersen of Kohn Pedersen Fox Associates in New York, stirs up the drab Dulles toll road with two improbably angled office wings that rise 12 stories and are wrapped in watery blue glass. Slender glass vertical fins bend light on the buildings' surfaces, making them seem, at 55 miles an hour, to warp, wrinkle and evaporate. The buildings surround a stone terrace slope designed by Michael Vergason, a landscape architect based in Arlington. Two elevator towers covered in grids of glass, inset, stand like command posts over the entrance's crystalline cubes.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Currents column last Thursday about an auction held at Chelsea Piers last Monday to benefit the Twin Towers Fund listed one auction house incorrectly among the organizers. Sotheby's did not participate.

title: When Faith Is Taken to Extremes
description: To the Editor:

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Confusion About a Guest Role

title: U.S. Citizenship May Be Reward in Terror War, Ashcroft Says
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 — Foreigners who provide useful information about terrorists may be rewarded by being put on a quick path to American citizenship, Attorney General John D. Ashcroft said today.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about foreigners detained in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 attacks misidentified a student whose name appeared on a slip of paper in a car rented by a hijacker. He is Osama Awadallah, not Mohdar Abdallah. Mr. Abdallah is being held on charges that he lied on his application for political asylum.

title: Teachers Renew Threat to Strike Over Pay at 10 Catholic Schools
description: Teachers at 10 Roman Catholic high schools in New York City and its suburbs yesterday renewed their threat to go on strike against the Archdiocese of New York, resuming a stance they first adopted on Sept. 10, the day before the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Brokerage Firm Sold
description: Credit Suisse First Boston has sold its online brokerage operation CSFBdirect to the Bank of Montreal for $520 million. The bank plans to integrate CSFBdirect with the online brokerage unit of Harris Bank, its Chicago-based subsidiary, to create Harris Direct Investing. CSFBdirect has 467,000 active accounts, four times the number presently held by Harris. The merged unit will have about $20.9 billion in assets under administration. CSFBdirect, based in Jersey City, with 450 employees, reported a second-quarter operating loss of $12.6 million on $60.2 million in revenues. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Tommy Held by Police, Yet One More Time
description: He's back. Smiling and waving, Indonesia's best-connected fugitive, Tommy Suharto, was taken into police custody today after more than a year in comfortable hiding.

title: An Implosion on Wall Street
description: Enron, the energy-trading company, may be on the verge of extinction with the collapse yesterday of its proposed acquisition by Dynegy, a smaller competitor, and the downgrading of its debt to junk status. But its name has attained immortality on Wall Street.

title: The Gadget Vernacular
