description: From time to time, I've used this column to make fun of high-tech marketers who try to inflate their own importance with a lingo all their own ("form factor" instead of size, "price point" instead of price, and so on).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, FRANCIS DANIELS, MD.
description: MOORE-Francis Daniels, MD. Husband of Katharyn (Watson) (Saltonstall) Moore and his first wife who predeceased him, Laura (Bartlett) Moore, father of Nancy Moore Hill of Stratham, NH, Peter B. Moore of North Haven, CT, Sarah Moore Warren of Grafton, VT, Caroline Moore Tripp of NYC and Dr. Francis D. Moore, Jr., brother of Harriet Moore Gelfan of Brattletboro, VT and the late Philip W. Moore. Also survived by 17 grandchildren and four great grandchildren. A service will be held on Saturday December 1st at the First Congregational Church, 10 Cottage St. Marion, MA at 2:00 P.M. Another Memorial Service will be held in the Boston area on December 21st at Memorial Church, Harvard Yard, Harvard University at 11:00 A.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Laura B. and Francis D. Moore Endowment Fund for Surgical Research at Harvard Medical School, 25 Shattuck St. Boston, MA 02115. For information, J.S. Waterman - Eastman - Waring Funeral Service, Boston, MA (617) 536-4110.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURKS, ALVIN
description: BURKS-Alvin. On November 22, 2001. Beloved husband of Harriette J. Burks. Devoted father of Juanita, Ruth, and Roslyn Burks. Loving grandfather of Gyasi Burks-Abbott and Natasha Burks. Cherished brother of James Burks. Reposing at Benta's Funeral Home, 630 St. Nicholas Ave., NY, on Thursday, November 29, 2:00-8:30 P.M. Funeral service Friday, November 30, 10:00 A.M., Riverside Church, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMS, ROSE
description: ABRAMS-Rose. November 28. Beloved wife of the late Percy Abrams. Loving mother of Robert Abrams. Cherished grandmother of Meredith Meegan and Robert Abrams, Jr. and great grandmother of Connor Meegan. Devoted sister of the late Ann Feinman, the late Rae Levine, the late Herman Sutton, the late Jack Sutton and the late Joseph Sutton. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Funeral private.

title: Taliban Prisoner Wounds Two as Revolt Continues at Fort
description: MAZAR-I-SHARIF, Afghanistan, Nov.29 — Four days after Taliban prisoners seized weapons and launched a prisoner revolt, and one day after the authorities here thought they had quelled it, the Taliban surprised them once more and cost them more casualties.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Record In Legal Settlements
description: New York City paid a record level in settlements and damages for personal injury claims in 2000, according to a report issued yesterday by the city comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi. Last year, the city paid $459 million for settlements of this type, up 10.5 percent from the 1999 level and the highest amount ever recorded for a single year.

title: As the Rich Do Without Extras, Service Workers Do Without
description: A nanny on the Upper East Side had her work schedule cut to three days a week from five because the wife in the household lost her job on Wall Street. Limousine drivers complain of carrying fewer passengers and earning 40 percent less than they did before.

title: Collecting $600 Million in Art, or a Tiger by the Tail
description: In his two decades as a physician in Africa, Gustav Rau took breaks several times a year, boarding a ''small rattletrap of a plane,'' as he called it, to fly across the bush to Kigali in Rwanda. Then he would return to his native Europe, and sometimes to the United States, where he used his inheritance to buy works by old masters at auction.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Economy Slows
description: Ireland's economic growth plummeted in the second quarter, while unemployment rose in the third quarter for the first time in five years, according to the government's statistics office. The gross national product, which includes income from abroad, increased by just 1.6 percent in the three-month period that ended on June 30, compared with 15.8 percent in the second quarter of 2000. Growth in the gross domestic product fell to 9.2 percent from 12.7 percent in the first quarter. Third-quarter unemployment rose by more than 14,000 people, the first increase since April 1996, to 4 percent of the labor force. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DALEY, SR. CATHERINE
description: DALEY-Sr. Catherine, RSHM, 75, November 27, Tarrytown, New York. Religious of the Sacred Heart of Mary for fifty years. Teacher at Marymount School, Quebec, Canada; Sacred Heart of Mary, Rolling Meadows, IL; president Marymount College, Quebec; associate dean of students Marymount College, Tarrytown, NY. Survived by a sister, Sr. Kathleen Daley, RSHM of Cleveland, OH. Visiting Friday, November 30, 3:30-7:30 PM. Mass Saturday, 10:30 AM. Both at Marymount Convent, Tarrytown, NY. Gifts may be made to the Religious of the Sacred Heart of Mary, 50 Wilson Park Drive, Tarrytown, NY 10591.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Nov. 15 with a theater review of ''The Petrified Forest,'' a revival of a Robert E. Sherwood melodrama, misidentified the actor wearing a fedora. He was Gavin Goren in the role of Dutch, not Tyler Reign, who played Ruby.

title: Alliance Official at Talks Shows Openness to Peacekeepers
description: BONN, Nov. 29  The four Afghan factions represented at talks here on a provisional government for Afghanistan have begun to discuss the names of possible legislators, but they have yet to grapple with key issues like how many seats each faction might get and what role the former king of Afghanistan might play, diplomats and delegates said here today.

title: AT HOME WITH/Janice Blackburn; Wood And Wire Recast in Gold
description: CRAFTS are versatile things.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELDER, O.R. (DOUG)
description: ELDER-O.R. (Doug). Died at home on Wednesday 28 November 2001 at the age of 87. Loving husband and father, he is survived by his wife Ann, sons Robert and Richard Elder, daughter Diane Schindler, and six grandsons. He is also survived by brothers, Burl and Proctor Elder, and his sister, Opal Patterson of Fort Worth, Texas. Visitation 2-5 and 7-9PM Thursday 29 November at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Avenue, New York, NY 10010 212475-2024. Services Friday, November 30th, 10 AM at Epiphany Church, 375 Second Ave (cor of 22nd St) in Manhattan. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Jacob Perlow Hospice, Beth Israel Medical Center, First Ave at 16th Street, New York, NY 10003.

title: U.S. Orders Vast Supply Of Vaccine For Smallpox
description: The Bush administration said today that it had awarded a $428 million contract for 155 million doses of smallpox vaccine. That amount, when coupled with supplies that already exist or have been ordered, should be enough to protect every American against the deadly virus.

title: A Digital Spider's Web to Help Protect High-Security Areas
description: AS any spider sitting in the center of its web knows, a tautly spun line is an excellent conductor of vibration.

title: Corrections
description: The Personal Health column in Science Times on Nov. 13 about osteoporosis misspelled the name of a class of drug prescribed for people with serious bone loss. The class, which includes Fosamax and Actonel, is bisphosphonate, not biphosphonate.

title: A Big Fall Evoking Nasty Old Memories Of a Run on a Bank
description: The final collapse of Enron amounted to something that few living Americans have ever seen: a bank run like those in the days before deposit insurance.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Alaska: Inquiry Into Sinking Of Fishing Boat
description: The owner of the Arctic Rose, the 92-foot fishing vessel that sank without warning in the Bering Sea on April 2 -- killing all 15 fishermen aboard -- fielded questions from a Coast Guard board of inquiry. The owner, Dave Olney, was granted immunity by the Justice Department in exchange for his testimony, which is expected to last until Friday. Investigators pressed Mr. Olney on modifications he made to the vessel after purchasing it in 1999. Mr. Olney told the board that the vessel handled well. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Girl Reported Missing
description: Police were searching last night for a 14-year-old Brooklyn girl who was reported missing after she did not come home from school on Tuesday. The girl, Hanna Nahari, was last heard from at 4:30 p.m. Tuesday when she called home after school, the police said. Her father was unable to give her a ride home because the family car was not working, and she said she would walk. The school is about seven blocks from the family's home in Borough Park, said Ms. Nahari's brother, Zak Nahari, last night. ''I couldn't sleep last night,'' he added. ''My mother, she is going crazy.''

title: Market That Deals in Risks Faces a Novel One
description: When members of the International Swaps and Derivatives Association gathered in Washington last April, the man they all wanted to hear was Jeffrey K. Skilling, then the president and chief executive of Enron.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Subway Repair Will Take Years
description: A top engineer for the subway system said yesterday that three stations in Lower Manhattan, closed since Sept. 11, would not reopen for at least three years. ''We would want to have it done in three years, but that is very ambitious,'' Connie Crawford, director of New York City Transit's engineering services division, told The Associated Press. The stations, all on the No. 1 and No. 9 lines, are Cortlandt Street, Rector Street and South Ferry. Al O'Leary, a New York City Transit spokesman, said yesterday that no timetable for repairs could be set until the World Trade Center cleanup was complete and a plan to rebuild the twin towers site was begun.

title: U.N. Study Says Nairobi Is Inundated With Crime
description: A United Nations study of crime here in Kenya's capital was issued yesterday, and it indicated that the city's disparaging nickname -- ''Nairobbery'' -- is not far from reality.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROCKOWER, SADIE
description: ROCKOWER-Sadie. Beloved wife of the late Harris Katzman and the late Abraham Rockower. Devoted mother of Paula Davidson and Edythe Guzik. Dear sister of Jack Gilbert. Loving grandmother of Alan, Samuel, Lynn, Honey, Harris and Ronald and great-grandmother of Eric, Jeremy, Lisa, Jessica, Laura, Steven, Matthew, Michael and Stefanie. Services BernheimApter-Kreitzman Suburban Chapels, 1600 Springfield Avenue, Maplewood, N.J. Thursday at 1 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATTLEMAN, HAROLD
description: KATTLEMAN-Harold. Congregation Sons of Israel, Woodmere, records with sorrow the passing of its member and extends its condolences to the bereaved family. Bruce Ginsburg, Rabbi Dr. Saul I. Teplitz, Rabbi Emeritus Stephen A. Kreiss, President

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Season for Sage

title: Time Inc. Said to Have Plans To Close 3 Small Magazines
description: Faced with a slowdown in advertiser spending, AOL Time Warner plans to close three of its smaller magazines -- Asiaweek, Family Life and On, which was formerly Time Digital, people close to the company said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMIGEL, HORTENSE
description: SMIGEL-Hortense, 95. On November 27. Wife of the late Allan Smigel. Beloved and devoted mother of Howard & Betty Smigel of Denver, and Eileen and Walter Kern of Riverdale. Cherished and adored grandmother of Robert and Mayva Kern, and Stuart and Andrea Kern. She will always be in our hearts. Services Friday, November 30, 11:30 AM at Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Avenue, Yonkers, NY.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Prisoner Starts Hunger Strike
description: A Chinese-born permanent resident of the United States who has been held by the Chinese police for nearly nine months started a hunger strike at the hospital where he is being held prisoner, his wife said. Liu Yaping, a small businessman based in Weston, Conn., was detained on March 8 in the capital of Inner Mongolia and charged with minor economic crimes that usually carry only a fine. During his unexplained detention Mr. Liu developed symptoms from a previously undetected brain aneurysm and has been denied proper treatment, his family says.

title: Debt Rankings Finally Fizzle, but the Deal Fizzled First
description: In the end, the rating agencies hardly mattered.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANGER, BERNICE C.
description: LANGER-Bernice C. The Jewish Center of the Hamptons mourns the passing of Bernice C. Langer, beloved wife of our congregant H. Edward Langer. We extend our deepest condolences to Edward and family. Rabbi David J. Gelfand Rabbi Alon Levkovitz Cantor Debra Stein Donald Zucker, President

title: More Restrictions Are Eased for Drivers
description: New York City officials yesterday eased several restrictions on cars coming into Manhattan and on roads below Canal Street, rules that were imposed after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: TRUMP TO PAY INTEREST IT WITHHELD AND GET DEBT TALKS
description: Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts will make $91 million in interest payments it withheld from bondholders in an effort to force a restructuring of the debt. Trump Hotels, led by the developer Donald J. Trump, agreed to make the payment on $1.6 billion in debt after a bondholders' committee was established for negotiations, the company said. The company owns three casinos in Atlantic City, including the Taj Mahal, and a riverboat casino in Indiana. Trump skipped the Nov. 1 payment. The Sept. 11 attacks and New York's plan to permit as many as six casinos will draw revenue away from the company's Atlantic City casinos, Trump has said. A lawyer for Trump's bondholders said talks would begin when the payment was received.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Montana: Capitol Security Relaxes
description: Gov. Judy Martz is scaling back security measures taken at the state Capitol in Helena after the Sept. 11 attacks. Concrete barriers that were installed at the Capitol's driveways will be removed and a requirement that all visitors show identification and sign in when entering the building will be discontinued. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BANSCHICK, SHEREN
description: BANSCHICK - Sheren. Beloved husband of Helen. Loving father of Mark & Josefa, Kenneth, David and Tzippora. Adored grandfather of Gabriel, Micah & Chana Yetta. Owner of ''House of Jacks'', a mens clothing store in Flushing, Queens for forty-five years. Services Friday, 9:15AM ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expy, Fresh Meadows, New York.

title: British Terror Suspect Still to Get Benefits
description: A High Court judge ruled today that a man identified in court testimony in the United States as a terrorist and ally of Osama bin Laden is entitled to the ''bare necessities'' of life. The ruling potentially undermined the British government's effort to snare the suspect in a financial stranglehold.

title: Old Masters Pursued By Artistic Gumshoes; Debating Whether Artists Used Optics
description: More than 25 curators and scholars, artists and art historians will gather at New York University this weekend to discuss -- and, presumably, to debate -- David Hockney's iconoclastic theory that old masters, all the way back to 1430, used optical devices to help them produce realistic images.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: U.N. Envoy Optimistic
description: On his sixth visit to the former Burma, Razali Ismail, a special representative of the United Nations, met with government officials and the opposition National League for Democracy. He has been shepherding private talks between the sides that appeared to have flagged in recent months. Although the specific goals of the talks are not clear, he said he was ''optimistic about the eventual outcome.''

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption on Tuesday about New Yorkers who are moving out of the city because of fears about terrorism misspelled the surname of a couple with children who moved to Suffolk County. They are Dana and Adrian Courtenay, not Courtney.

title: New Uses Help Introduce Linux Operating System to Non-Geeks
description: WHEN people think about Linux, they usually associate it with industrial-strength computing uses, servers and workstations. But Linux is sneaking into unexpected places, like robotic oil drills, roadside gas pumps and, increasingly, hand-held computers.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about AIDS epidemic in a community in South Africa quoted a statistic incorrectly from a doctor who has been fighting AIDS and sexually transmitted diseases there. The doctor, Neil E. Jorgensen, said that venereal disease cases among workers at a local sugar mill had declined ''from 10 a day to one a month.'' He did not say the drop was from 10 a month.

title: Love and Religion Soothe a Wild Hip-Hop Queen
description: FOR a fleeting moment, no one approaches Mary J. Blige, the queen of hip-hop soul. She sits very still near the back of a classroom at Long Island City High School in Queens, her head lowered, her eyes hidden from view, clutching a black Prada handbag across her chest.

title: Deal Is Reached on Trucks From Mexico
description: The Bush administration and Congressional negotiators reached agreement today on a plan to permit long-haul Mexican trucks into the United States as long as the trucks and their drivers are routinely inspected before entering the country.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the acquisition of Donna Karan International by LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton for $243 million misstated part of the terms. They do not include an assumption of debt.

title: Inmates' Self-Incrimination Debated at Supreme Court
description: The Supreme Court heard arguments today on whether a state violates a convicted sex offender's right against compelled self-incrimination by taking away prison privileges if the inmate refuses to accept responsibility for any previously undisclosed crimes as part of a therapy program.

title: Shopping Outside the Box
description: YOU may not be able to promise the world in a gift this year, but it is possible to offer a gift that reminds each recipient how fortunate smaller pleasures can be.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Three employees were promoted at Adient, Parsippany, N.J., a unit of CommonHealth. Melissa Gray, group business manager, was named director for business management. Larry Fiori II, account executive, was named senior account executive. Al Stern, art supervisor, was named vice president and group art supervisor. CommonHealth is part of the WPP Group.

title: Five Surprises in a Row On a Victorian Block
description: Division One, an architectural firm in Rockville, Md., designed club interiors for the swizzle-stick crowd at the 18th Street Lounge and the Saint downtown, but could not find a Washington client who wanted a modern house. ''We were frustrated,'' said Ali Honarkar, who runs the firm with Craig Williams and Mustafa Ali Nouri. So the three men hired themselves to design five contemporary row houses on 10th Street NW. The new houses' cantilevered cubes and gregarious facades, shown in the rendering at left, give a jolt to a staid Victorian block. ''You can't wait for the client to come along to do something different,'' said Mr. Honarkar, who plans to live in one of the houses. The 2,000-square-foot houses, to be completed in the spring, will sell for around $500,000 to $600,000; Division One is at (301) 424-1674.

title: Maverick Internet Unit Chief Resigns From Bertelsmann
description: The German media company Bertelsmann announced the resignation yesterday of Andreas Schmidt, the chief executive of its Internet division, who was known for an aggressive and sometimes freewheeling style that contrasted sharply with the demeanor of his German colleagues.

title: German Police Arrest Associate Of Hijacker Cell
description: German police have arrested a Moroccan man who they say had intense contacts with Mohamed Atta and other Sept. 11 suicide hijackers, managing one of their bank accounts and moving money to several of the men while they underwent flight training in the United States a year before the attacks.

title: White House Says It Expects At Least 3 Years of Deficits
description: The Bush administration said today that it expected the federal government to run budget deficits for at least the next three years, confirming that the recession and the costs of fighting terrorism had combined to wipe out huge projected surpluses and complicate the agendas of both parties.

title: An Alliance Move South of Kabul Could Aid U.S. but Irk Pakistan
description: Commanders for the Northern Alliance, which reneged on a pledge to Washington not to enter the Afghan capital, said today that they plan to send their forces south of Kabul after they secure their position around the city.

title: A People Changing
description: As bombs rained on the last Taliban positions Thursday, Afghans continued to enjoy freedoms unknown under the repressive regime's rule.

title: School Safety Net
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Ripples Spreading From Enron's Expected Bankruptcy
description: As lawmakers expressed outrage over how the company could collapse so quickly with so little warning, Enron sought protection from some of its creditors in Europe yesterday and allowed traders to dissolve positions through its online unit.

title: Corrections
description: A biographical sketch yesterday about Kelly Ann Booms, a certified public accountant who died on American Airlines Flight 11 in the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center, misstated the given name of her father. He is Richard Booms Sr., not Robert.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Retailer Recovering
description: Great Universal Stores, a British retailer, said sales at its designer outlets under the Burberry brand and its Experian information subsidiary had begun to recover after a sharp downturn following the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11. Great Universal also said profit in the six-month period ended Sept. 30 increased 13 percent, with Burberry expanding its profit by more than half, to 42.1 million ($60 million). Burberry's sales fell 15 percent after Sept. 11, and growth at its Experian North America component slowed in the same period, the company said earlier. But Great Universal Stores said both businesses began to recover in October. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 12 about moves by the Bush administration to take a more active role in Israeli-Palestinian contacts misidentified a group in Washington to which Foreign Minister Shimon Peres of Israel spoke on Nov. 11. It was the United Jewish Communities. (The Council of Jewish Federations was a part of the merger that created the organization in 1999.)

title: 'Ten'
description: Kaikodo

title: World Briefing | Europe: Norway: New Theory On Norse God
description: The Norwegian anthropologist Thor Heyerdahl says the Norse god Odin is based on a real chieftain who led a band of warriors from his kingdom in southern Russia to Sweden almost 2,000 years ago. He said excavations in Azov, Russia, revealed jewelry, belt buckles and other articles from around the time of Christ but resembling those of the Vikings, who terrorized much of Europe from 793 to 1100. The Azov findings, he said, lend credence to a fanciful 13th-century saga that portrays Odin as a human king who fled north to escape Roman expansion.

title: An Upstate Menagerie, a Surprise Vacation and College Connections
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Cable and Wireless in Deal to Acquire Exodus for $850 Million
description: Cable and Wireless ( news/quote ) on Friday confirmed it had agreed to acquire the assets of Exodus Communications ( news/quote ), the leading US web hosting group which in September filed for bankruptcy protection, in an $850m cash deal.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 14.

title: Justice Dept. Says Evidence Connects An Indonesian Man to the Hijackings
description: The Justice Department said today that it had gathered evidence of ''extraordinary'' ties between the Sept. 11 hijackings and an Indonesian man under arrest in Virginia, including documents showing that he had tried to help one hijacker obtain his visa to enter the United States.

title: Accounts
description: * Playmates Toys, Costa Mesa, Calif., which sells dolls, action figures and collectibles, to Rotter-Kantor, New York, to handle its account, which had been at the Sachs Group, Los Angeles. Billings were estimated at $15 million.

title: Using the Pedal Sparingly And Overstating Nothing
description: Since the 1960's the Czech pianist Ivan Moravec has built a devoted following among connoisseurs, mostly through a series of recordings that show him to be a refined but powerful player and a supremely inventive interpreter. He has visited New York frequently but usually as a concerto soloist, rarely for recitals. On Tuesday evening Mr. Moravec gave a recital at Carnegie Hall and showed that at 71 he is as illuminating as ever.

title: Marco Brambilla -- 'In Action'
description: Henry Urbach Architecture

title: The Families Bush and Kennedy
description: The recent ceremony that featured the Republican Bush administration naming the Justice Department headquarters after the Democrat Robert Kennedy was a startling political event. Rows of Kennedys gathered to watch President Bush give a speech about ''the spirit of Robert Kennedy, a spirit that tolerates no injustice and fears no evil.'' Mr. Bush was then on the receiving end of plaudits from former Representative Joseph Kennedy, for being ''a profile in leadership.''

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about the collapse of the Enron Corporation misstated the size of its work force and the Wednesday closing price for the stock of its former merger suitor, Dynegy. Enron has 21,000 employees, not 13,000. Dynegy shares closed at $36.81, not $35.97.

title: Technology Briefing
description: SOFTWARE

title: Eyebrows Raised in Hindsight About Outside Ties of Some on the Board
description: In hindsight, there appears to have been ample evidence that Enron's board might not have been up to the job of preventing what is becoming one of the greatest debacles in the history of corporate America. Some directors had consulting contracts or other business arrangements with Enron. Others were affiliated with institutions that benefited from gifts from the company or its chief executive, Kenneth L. Lay.

title: In South Africa, The Havoc of AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Northern Alliance Refuses to Submit Candidates for Interim Government
description: BONN, Nov. 30  Negotiations on a future government for Afghanistan stalled badly today, after the leader of the Northern Alliance, holding power in Kabul, refused to authorize his delegation to submit a list of proposed candidates for a new, temporary administration intended to be broadly representative of the nation as a whole.

title: The Autonomy of Sotheby's Chief Is Scrutinized in Antitrust Case
description: A leading law firm, retained by Sotheby's in 1997 to investigate possible collusion in the auction industry, repeatedly questioned the company's chief executive, Diana D. Brooks, but not its chairman, A. Alfred Taubman, the lawyer who headed the inquiry acknowledged yesterday in the price-fixing trial of Mr. Taubman.

title: When a Somber Rite Becomes a Routine
description: Elaborate farewells to firefighters who died Sept. 11 have come to symbolize a country in mourning, and have drawn firefighters from around the world. But the emotionally draining ceremonies are held so often that a reluctant air of the routine has settled upon a once-singular ritual.

title: Jamie Shannon, 40, Chef Who Embraced Creole Cuisine
description: Jamie Shannon, the chef who succeeded Emeril Lagasse at Commander's Palace in New Orleans and brought its kitchen national acclaim, died on Nov. 23 at the M. D. Anderson Cancer Center in Houston. He was 40 and was being treated at the center.

title: North Korea Threatens U.S. Over Demand for Arms Inspections
description: North Korea threatened ''countermeasures'' today against the United States because Washington insists on ''raising questions over our human rights record and religion, and demanding an inspection of weapons of mass destruction.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Romulus: Man Accused Of Killing Family
description: A man who escaped an early-morning fire that claimed the lives of his wife and four small children this month has been arrested after trying to flee from the police and charged with the arson murder of his family, the authorities said. The man, Eric Parsons, 25, is a volunteer firefighter near the Finger Lakes. He told the police that on Nov. 5, around 2:30 a.m., his wife alerted him to the fire and that he escaped from a first-floor window but was unable to save his family. Officials said tests indicated a petroleum distillate had been spread in the house. When officers sought to arrest him Wednesday, Mr. Parsons led them on a high-speed chase, they said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONNEBORN, ANNE
description: SONNEBORN-Anne, 94. Of Middletown, NJ, on November 26, 2001. Wife of the late Milton. Mother of Gail (Gerson) Witkowski and Jesse Sonneborn. Grandmother of Skye Sonneborn, Nadine Gerson Wodarczyk, Collette Gerson Finck and Joseph Gerson. Great-grandmother of Joshua Finck, Justin and Haley Wodarczyk. Services were held Thursday. Shiva will be observed at the home of Gail and Ed Witkowski, 126 Alexander Dr., Middletown, NJ. For information contact Fiore Funeral Home, West Long Branch, NJ.

title: First Boston Says Justice Dept. Has Ended Initial-Offerings Case
description: Credit Suisse First Boston said yesterday that the Justice Department had dropped a criminal investigation into how it distributed shares in initial public offerings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEMPEN, PATRICIA C.
description: KEMPEN-Patricia C. Of Manhasset, NY on November 25, 2001. Former service manager at Lord & Taylor. Beloved wife of the late Stanley D. Kempen. Cherished mother of Michael of Douglaston, NY. Also survived by her sister Denise Keily of Las Vegas, Nevada. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Home, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, NY, Sunday December 2, 2001 from 3-5 & 7-9 pm. Funeral service Tuesday 11AM at the Cathedral of the Incarnation, Garden City. Interment Calverton National Cemetery.

title: A Salute to the Holidays, In Red, White and Blue
description: The cabaret world has no more devoted pop traditionalist than Michael Feinstein, whose new show at the club that bears his name, Feinstein's at the Regency, is an unabashedly sentimental and patriotic tribute to Christmas and New York, filtered through the events of Sept. 11.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Trust To Reduce Stake
description: The Wellcome Trust, which ranks as the world's biggest medical charity, said it would reduce its 2.5 percent stake in the pharmaceutical company GlaxoSmithKline by selling a minimum of $1.42 billion and possibly up to $3.3 billion worth of its shares in the company. The trust, which was established by Sir Henry Wellcome, a founder of one of the company's original components, said it wanted to rearrange its investment portfolio. GlaxoSmithKline, the world's second-biggest drug maker, said it would buy up to $1.42 billion of its own stock as part of a $5.6 billion buyback. GlaxoSmithKline's shares fell by up to 1.5 percent. The Wellcome Trust contributes the equivalent of $850 million a year to scientific research, including the mapping of the human genome. The Wellcome family had a controlling stake in the Wellcome drug company before it was taken over by Glaxo in 1995. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Settlement Lifts Storage Computer
description: The stock of the Storage Computer Corporation soared $2.15, or 41 percent, to $7.40 yesterday after the company said it had agreed in principle to settle a patent infringement suit against Seagate Technology Inc. and its Xiotech unit. Seagate sued Storage Computer, contending that the Nashua, N.H., company's storage devices and software infringed Seagate's patent on error detection and correction systems. Seagate had filed the suit in response to an existing infringement suit filed by Storage Computer in March, which said there was infringement against Seagate and Xiotech, which are both closely held. Storage Computer said it had two similar suits pending and expects to file additional suits against big server and memory companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELL, STANLEY P.
description: BELL-Stanley P., age 69. Awardwinning sailor died on Tuesday, November 27, 2001. 1953 graduate of Dartmouth College, former President of Executive Health Examiners. A sailor all his life, he was Chairman of the Winner Race Committee at the Larchmont Yacht Club where he was a life member. He is survived by his wife Cynthia W. Bell of Mattapoisett, MA, two sons Stephen of Amherst, NY, Stuart of Princeton, NJ and six grandchildren. A Memorial Service will be held at St. John's Church, Larchmont, 11 AM, December 1st. In lieu of flowers donations to the Dartmouth College Alumni Fund Class of '53 Scholarship, Hanover, NH 03755.

title: Editors' Note; Today's Sections
description: News of the Sept. 11 attacks and their aftermath continues to appear in Section B; index, Page B2.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 12 about moves by the Bush administration to take a more active role in Israeli-Palestinian contacts misidentified a group in Washington to which Foreign Minister Shimon Peres of Israel spoke on Nov. 11. It was the United Jewish Communities. (The Council of Jewish Federations was a part of the merger that created the organization in 1999.)

title: Haven for Refugees
description: To the Editor:

title: Deal for Exodus Said to Be Near
description: Cable and Wireless is close to a deal to pay more than $500 million to acquire the assets of Exodus Communications, the once-highflying Web site operating company that filed for bankruptcy-law protection this fall, executives close to the talks said yesterday.

title: South African Victims Face Rapists and H.I.V.
description: The rapist seemed to have no sense that there could be consequences to what he had done. The morning after, the rapist gave his 17-year-old victim money for a cab home and asked her to make sure she locked his door on her way out, after he left for work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEFLORIO, MARY LUCY
description: DeFLORIO-Mary Lucy. November 28. Beloved wife of Robert Shapiro. Loving daughter of Bernice DeFlorio and the late Anthony DeFlorio. Devoted sister of Catherine DeFlorio, Rosalie DeFlorio and Ralph DeFlorio. Beloved grnaddaughter of the late Lucy and the late Ralph DeFlorio. Cherished by all who knew her, and will be deeply missed. She was born in Chicago, IL, and graduated from the University of Wisconsin, later receiving her M.D. and M.Ph. degrees with honors from the University of Illinois at Chicago. She did her medical and psychiatric residencies at Mercy Hospital in Chicago and St. Vincent's Hospital in NYC. Dr. DeFlorio completed a Fellowship serving as Chief Fellow, and later attending psychiatrist at Memorial Sloan-Kettering. Memorial service Sunday, December 2, 2001, 11 AM, at Casa Italina, West 117th St at Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELLER, ANN
description: BELLER-Ann. Beloved wife of the late Charles. Devoted mother of Miles and Laurette. Cherished grandmother of Eli. Dear sister of the late Frances Hyman & Harry Lind. Loving aunt. A graveside service at Mt. Golda Cemetery, 500 Old Country Rd., Huntington Station, LI, today at 1:00 PM.

title: Novice Directors, Be Careful What You Pray For
description: On the first day of directing his first movie, Pete Jones finds out how clueless he is. What's worse, this amateur has been cushioned by a professional crew that has let him make boneheaded choices.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Questions Surround Assets Abroad
description: Lenders, partners, customers and governments in some 40 countries struggled today to determine what might become of the Enron Corporation's far-flung empire of overseas operations and investments, most of them in the energy sector. Enron, which is based in Houston, derived almost one-quarter of its revenue from outside the United States.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Freemarkets Surges On Forecast
description: Shares of FreeMarkets Inc. rose $4.59, or 33.8 percent, to $18.18 yesterday, after the company raised its forecast for revenue in the fourth quarter. The company, which makes software for conducting Web auctions and business-to-business e-commerce, announced after the close of trading on Wednesday that it expected its fourth-quarter revenue and fees to rise 10 percent to 15 percent, to $44.7 million to $46.7 million. Company officials attributed the higher-than-expected revenue to strong sales to current customers, some of whom renewed long-term contracts during the fourth quarter. The new forecast is $2 million to $4 million more than previous company estimates and the consensus estimates of analysts. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Many Eager to Help, but Few Are Chosen
description: America's military allies in the war on terror are encamped here in a cluster of temporary trailers on a parking lot just outside the headquarters of the United States Central Command.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHOENFELD, FRANCES
description: SCHOENFELD-Frances. On Wednesday, November 28, 2001, after a long illness. Widow of Dr. William Schoenfeld, mother of Henry, Alice and Andrew, beloved grandmother & aunt. Services Sunday, December 2, 10:00AM, Gramercy Chapel, 152 2nd Avenue.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Smuggling Charges Dismissed
description: A federal judge in Brooklyn yesterday dismissed charges against two men accused of smuggling more than $140,000 in cash to Yemen, most of it hidden in a shipment of honey. The charges were dismissed without prejudice, allowing prosecutors to reinstate the charges within five years. Federal authorities had identified several honey businesses in Yemen that they said were linked to Osama bin Laden and his network, Al Qaeda. Prosecutors sought the dismissal of the charges, which were brought last month. The men, Ali Al-Fatimi and Basam Nashal, had been held without bail. Yesterday, Mr. Al-Fatimi was released. Mr Nashal, 22, who had been on probation in an unrelated state case, was being held for a court appearance in that case today. Prosecutors would not say why they had asked that the charges be dismissed. Mr. Nashal's lawyer, Trevor L. Headley, said his client did not know there was money in the boxes of honey. Mr. Al-Fatimi's lawyer could not be reached for comment.

title: Virginia Governor Resigning as Republican Party Chairman
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30  Gov. James S. Gilmore III of Virginia said today that he was resigning as chairman of the Republican National Committee to spend more time with his family.

title: Suspect Named in Fake Anthrax Mailings to Abortion Clinics
description: Attorney General John Ashcroft said yesterday that Clayton Lee Waagner, who has been on the F.B.I.'s 10 Most Wanted List since September, is the primary suspect in the mailing of anthrax threats to hundreds of abortion clinics nationwide this fall.

title: Schumer Backs Bush Choice for U.S. Attorney
description: Senator Charles E. Schumer offered a strong endorsement yesterday of the federal prosecutor from Richmond, Va., who is President Bush's likely choice for the post of United States attorney for the Southern District of New York.

title: India Prepares to Sell Its Stake As Phone Monopoly Nears End
description: The Indian government will put up for sale in December its 53 percent stake in Videsh Sanchar Nigam Ltd., which has a soon-to-expire monopoly on international long-distance calling and is the country's largest Internet service provider.

title: Men Linked To Al Qaeda Rounded Up At 2 Mosques
description: The Italian police raided two mosques here early today and arrested two men accused of recruiting fighters for Al Qaeda, Osama bin Laden's terrorist network. A warrant was issued for a third man who is believed to be in Afghanistan, and the police disclosed that a fourth man has been in detention for two weeks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEMAN, BEVERLY SHY
description: FREEMAN-Beverly Shy. On November 26th, 2001 of cancer. Beloved wife of the late Frank Freeman, loving mother of Howard and James, adoring grandmother of Carter, Katharine and Bennett. A memorial service will be held at 2PM on Saturday, Dec. 1st at the Brick Presbyterian Church on Park Ave. at 91st Street.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Maria Arnone was named publisher for the mining and construction properties of Primedia Business Magazines and Media, Chicago, a division of Primedia that publishes magazines like Coal Age and Rock Products. She had been interim marketing director for the division's telecommunications properties.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Officers Sentenced In Dog Attack
description: Four police officers who used their police dogs to attack three illegal immigrants from Mozambique were sentenced to prison terms ranging from four to five years. The officers were videotaped by a colleague as they were encouraging their dogs to bite the immigrants. The tape touched off an outcry when it was broadcast on state television last year. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Richter Gets a Shutout, With Plenty of Help
description: None of the Rangers could recall the date of the team's last shutout, but most knew it had been a very long time.

title: In South Africa, The Havoc of AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: TOP EXECUTIVE RESIGNS FROM THE AILING STEEL MAKER LTV
description: The LTV Corporation's chairman and chief executive resigned yesterday, a week after the company asked a bankruptcy court for permission to close its steel mills and put them up for auction. The executive, William H. Bricker, an LTV director since 1982, took the jobs after Peter Kelly quit in November 2000. Mr. Bricker also resigned from the board, along with two other directors. LTV filed for bankruptcy protection in December. LTV has also asked a bankruptcy court judge for permission to abandon its labor contracts.

title: 'Everybody Now' -- 'The Crowd in Contemporary Art'
description: Bertha and Karl Leubsdorf Art Gallery, Hunter College

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Court Denies Euthanasia Request
description: In a decision upholding a ban on euthanasia, England's highest appeal court, the Law Lords of the House of Lords, turned down a terminally ill woman's request to allow her husband to help her die without being prosecuted for assisted suicide. Diane Pretty, 43, who suffers from motor neuron disease and is paralyzed from the neck down, argued that her deteriorating state robbed her of her right to control her own life and death. The couple said they would abide by the decision.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Garden City: Suozzi Names Deputies
description: The Nassau County executive-elect, Thomas R. Suozzi, left, is crossing party lines in his first two senior appointments, announced yesterday. Mr. Suozzi, a Democrat, picked as deputy county executives Anthony Cancellieri, a Republican who is now the village administrator of Rockville Centre, and Arthur Gianelli, a Democrat who is the North Hempstead finance director. The appointments bridged internal political divisions as well, because Mr. Gianelli had supported Mr. Suozzi's rival in the Democratic primary, Thomas DiNapoli. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

title: Inviting Birds for Dinner (But Not to Be Eaten)
description: We were late setting up our bird feeders this season. I put them out only a few days ago. So far, our only visitors have been juncos and a chickadee. As the winter comes, and the birds find the seed or remember that we're a soft touch, I expect the usual crowd: two pairs of cardinals, nuthatches (which I love to watch come down a tree trunk upside down), finches, jays, titmice, sparrows, the odd woodpecker, some pigeons, doves, starlings and, of course, the squirrels.

title: Corrections
description: A theater review yesterday about ''POEtry,'' the production about Edgar Allan Poe by Lou Reed at the Gilman Opera House of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, misstated the closing date. It is Dec. 8, not this Sunday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LARNED, WILLIAM E. JR.
description: LARNED-William E. Jr., 82. Of Greenwich, CT. on November 27, 2001. Served in WWII, Executive Vice President Halaby International, President DMS. Survived by wife, Margaret Klipstein; children, Gay, William, Cynthia; grandchildren, Kate, Cole, and Alexander.

title: World Business Briefing | The Americas: Brazil: Slow Economic Growth
description: The Brazilian economy grew just 0.34 percent in the third quarter compared with the period a year earlier. Growth was stifled at home by energy rationing and high interest rates and abroad by weak export markets. Despite the marked slowdown, aggravated by a contraction of 1.29 percent in the industrial sector, economists said the economy was still on track to meet the 2 percent growth target the government set for this year. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COPPER RISES. Copper rose to a five-month high, as government reports signaled a recovery in demand from U.S. manufacturers and builders. In New York, copper for March delivery rose 0.9 cent, to 72.4 cents a pound.

title: Bhutto Pursues a Pakistani Comeback, in India
description: It is hard to imagine a stranger place for the comeback bid of a leading Pakistani politician than the enemy territory of India, but that is just what Benazir Bhutto tried to pull off here in the capital this week.

title: Bloomberg Names Governmental Advisers
description: Mayor-elect Michael R. Bloomberg offered a peek yesterday into how his transition is shaping up, and a few tidbits on what has been on his mind this week, including the notion that housing should be part of any rebuilding plan in Lower Manhattan.

title: Plan Backed to End Diamond Trade That Fuels War
description: After more than a year of talks, government and industry negotiators from dozens of countries agreed today on a framework for a system to certify legitimately traded diamonds and stamp out the market for stones mined by rebels in war zones.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Panel Calls For Service Subsidies
description: A federal research group recommended that companies receive tax credits and grants for offering high-speed Internet services, particularly in rural areas. The National Research Council, which is part of the National Academy of Sciences and advises Congress on scientific issues, said the educational and economic value of broadband Internet access outweighed logistical difficulties and the expense of providing the services. The council said tax credits could ''provide incentives for what is ultimately uneconomic activity.'' Telecommunications companies have questioned whether it makes sense to expand their networks to areas where there may not be many potential customers. About 8 percent of American households have high-speed Internet access, the council said. Most people connect through cable television lines, telephone lines or via satellite. Senator John D. Rockefeller, a Democrat from West Virginia, has already introduced legislation calling for a tax credit of 10 percent to 20 percent for companies that provide broadband services to rural areas.

title: Considering 'Community Standards' and Internet Pornography
description: Under the local community standards rule, issued in the 1973 case of Miller vs. California, the Supreme Court said that different communities have different ideas of what is obscene. The upshot is that a piece of art depicting a nude subject that is perfectly acceptable in San Francisco could put its purveyor at risk of arrest in Salt Lake City, where a more conservative jury might find it beyond the sexual pale.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Turning Bloopers Into Comedies of Errors
description: No one really knows when the days of bloopers and flubbed lines became entertainment. But they're more popular now than ever.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN FALLS. The yen fell on fear Enron's troubles would cause losses at Japanese banks and companies that lent the company money or bought its bonds. In New York, the dollar settled at 123.73 yen, up from 123.16 yen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCELROY, VIRGINIA
description: McELROY - Virginia. Visitation Nov. 30, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, Gannon Funeral Home. Services on December 1, 10:30AM, Church of our Saviour, 38th and Park Avenue.

title: Hokies Say a Perfect Game Will Topple Miami
description: Andr Davis did not watch Miami dismantle Washington on Saturday. For the first time in his football career at Virginia Tech, the Hokies had the Thanksgiving weekend off, so Davis, a senior wide receiver, went home to Niskayuna, N.Y., to be with his family. Quarterback Grant Noel watched only snippets of the Hurricanes' 65-7 victory in the cut-and-paste of game tape.

title: Unsure Ground for Fight Against Atrocity
description: The conflict in Afghanistan has posed a broad spectrum of concerns for human rights organizations, not the least of them the absence of credible information from the scene.

title: Afghan Talks Advancing, But Crucial Issues Remain
description: The four Afghan factions negotiating the shape of a provisional government for Afghanistan have begun to offer names of possible council members, but they have yet to grapple with such vital issues as how many seats each faction might get or what role the former king might play, diplomats and delegates here said today.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Rains Result In Disaster Declaration
description: Eight counties drenched by two days of torrential rains will be declared disaster areas by Gov. Mike Huckabee, a spokesman said. Significant damage to homes and businesses occurred in eastern and southeastern Arkansas, in the heart of the state's delta region. Four traffic fatalities were attributed to rain-slicked highways or reduced visibility. Mr. Huckabee was to tour the areas hardest hit by flooding on Friday.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: DNA Clears Imprisoned Man
description: A man who said he pleaded guilty to robbery and rape to avoid a harsher sentence could be released from prison now that DNA test results have shown he did not commit the rape 11 years ago, the Essex County prosecutor's office said. The case against John Dixon, 37, will likely be dismissed today. But officials must first decide what to do about the 15-year sentence Mr. Dixon is also serving for armed robbery, said Robert Laurino, deputy chief assistant prosecutor. Mr. Dixon confessed to the Dec. 23 1990 rape and was sentenced in 1991 to 45 years in prison. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Why Walk Picket Line? To Make Ends Meet
description: Deanna Grad says that the last time she ate out at a restaurant was four years ago when her husband was still alive. Ms. Grad also has not stepped into a movie theater for years. She always waits for the video versions to arrive, because renting a tape is cheaper.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HAVERTY FURNITURE, Atlanta, a chain of 104 stores in the central and southeastern United States, will buy four stores from a bankrupt competitor, HomeLife, for $11 million and lease three others.

title: Chip Maker to Combine Its Regional Accounts
description: The chip maker Advanced Micro Devices ( news/quote ) in Sunnyvale, Calif., said yesterday that it would consolidate its regional accounts into a single worldwide assignment and seek an agency to handle that task. Combined billings were estimated at $25 million to $30 million.

title: Time Reveals the Delicacy Within Lichtenstein's Playful Pop
description: Almost 40 years ago Roy Lichtenstein made paintings based on dime-store notebooks, the ones with the marbleized black-and-white cardboard covers and the black tape spines. The books had ''COMPOSITIONS'' boxed on the front with ''NAME'' and several blank lines followed by the price (59 cents in the 1960's), then ''Made in U.S.A.''

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: With Designs On Broadway

title: Nassau G.O.P. Wants Gulotta to Limit Tax Increase
description: Nassau's county executive could cut the Legislature's planned 15 percent property tax increase to under 10 percent by vetoing budget fat without triggering a state fiscal takeover, Republican county officials say. And they are urging him to do just that.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Uzbek Dissident Arrested
description: Muhammad Solih, a prominent Uzbek dissident, was arrested in Prague and faces extradition to Uzbekistan on charges that human rights groups say are politically motivated. Mr. Solih, who was traveling in Prague at the request of Radio Free Europe, ran against President Islam Karimov of Uzbekistan in 1991 and later fled the country because he feared arrest. He lives in Norway where he was granted political asylum after authorities ruled that he risked persecution if returned to his home country. Human Rights Watch called on Czech authorities to release Mr. Solih and warned that he faces possible death if returned to Uzbekistan.

title: Industrial Output in Japan Hit a 13-Year Low in October
description: Japanese industrial output fell in October to a 13-year low, as Japan's economy, the world's second largest, slipped deeper into recession. The government reported that output was 11.9 percent below levels of October 2000, and 0.3 percent lower than September 2001.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: New York City Job Losses
description: New York City lost more jobs in the last year than any other major metropolitan area, according to data released in Washington this week by the federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. The 58,700-job drop in the 12 months that ended in October, which the bureau attributed largely to the Sept. 11 terror attack, surpassed a 38,200 decline in Detroit. But New York's unemployment has risen less than one percentage point, to 6.2 percent, while the rate for the San Jose metropolitan area, which includes Silicon Valley, surged by 4.8 percentage points, to 6.4 percent.

title: Martial Justice, Full and Fair
description: Like presidents before him, President Bush has invoked his power to establish military commissions to try enemy belligerents who commit war crimes. In appropriate circumstances, these commissions provide important advantages over civilian trials. They spare American jurors, judges and courts the grave risks associated with terrorist trials. They allow the government to use classified information as evidence without compromising intelligence or military efforts. They can dispense justice swiftly, close to where our forces may be fighting, without years of pretrial proceedings or post-trial appeals.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Phone Maker Expects A Profit
description: Alcatel, one of Europe's largest makers of telecommunications equipment, said it expected to post an operating profit for 2002 despite the downturn in the industry. The chairman of Alcatel, Serge Tchuruk, said in a meeting that sales would dip slightly from 2000 and that the French company was still increasing its market share. He also said that ''telecommunications will probably be a persistent growth sector in the economy'' in the long term and that the global market would probably expand 10 to 15 percent in the next few years. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VALLONE, FRANK G.
description: VALLONE-Frank G. Beloved husband of the late Carol and brother of the late Judge Charles J. Vallone. Sole surviving sister: Pauline V. Rao; nephews: City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone and Peter J. Costa; beloved sister-in-law Grace Vallone; many loving nieces and nephews. Esteemed member of Ravenswood Lions Club and Astoria Civic Association. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Judge Charles J. Vallone Scholarship Fund, 22-45 31 St, Astoria NY 11105. Viewing at Farenga Funeral Home, 38-08 Ditmars Blvd, Astoria, today, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Saturday morning, 9:30AM, Mass of Christian Burial, St. John Vianney Catholic Church, 140-10 34th Ave, Flushing NY.

title: Buying Domestic? Good Luck
description: THE nation is at war, displays of patriotism are ubiquitous and millions of Americans have rushed out to buy new cars, lured by low- or no-interest financing and encouraged to spend money to stimulate the economy. But despite the star-spangled tenor of the times, the phrase ''buy American'' has seldom been heard.

title: Seton Hall Is Out to Avenge Last Year's Tourney Snub
description: The men's soccer team at Seton Hall has something to prove in the national tournament this year after it was left out last year when it deserved better. The Pirates have already left their mark in this tournament by eliminating Virginia, the second-seeded team.

title: Sacred Heart Finds Right Combinations
description: The record-breaking quarterback from California had never heard of the school before it recruited him. The fullback is a poet who hopes to publish a book of his work. The star wide receiver is a former member of the basketball team who had not played football since his junior year in high school. And one of the starting defensive ends had initially gone to Kansas to play football, only to wind up on an undefeated team 60 miles from his hometown of Neptune, N.J.

title: Trump Buys Hotel Delmonico for $115 Million
description: In a sign that the real estate market has not collapsed, Donald J. Trump outmaneuvered three other bidders Wednesday night to buy the Hotel Delmonico on the Upper East Side for $115 million.

title: WATCHING MOVIES WITH/John Travolta; You Never Get Over Yankee Doodle Fever
description: JOHN TRAVOLTA sat quietly in a square, well-cushioned chair along the back wall of his home screening room. He had just finished watching ''Yankee Doodle Dandy,'' a glossy Warner Brothers bio-pic about the legendary George M. Cohan, a movie that's been dear to him since he was a little boy in New Jersey dreaming about a life on the stage. Mr. Travolta rubbed his eyes as the screening room door swung open and his wife, Kelly Preston, arrived with their 18-month-old daughter, Ella Bleu, on her hip.

title: Polish Populist, Stripped of His Post, Accuses Parliament of Corruption
description: Poland's new government tonight stripped a savvy pig farmer turned populist politician, Andrzej Lepper, of his brief hold on official power, demoting him from his post of deputy speaker of the Parliament.

title: Crime Spurt Puts Detectives On Extra Days
description: Responding to a recent surge in shootings and murders in New York City, the Police Department has ordered all detectives in the narcotics division to work six-day weeks, possibly until the end of the year.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Body Of Woman Is Found
description: The nude body of a 41-year-old Brooklyn woman was found yesterday morning in a park a block from Public School 40, the police said. The woman, whose name was not immediately released, had marks around her neck that indicated she might have been strangled, the police said. Her body was discovered around 8:40 a.m. in Carver Playgrounds on Marion Street in Ocean Hill. A passer-by had called the police saying that neighborhood children had been scared by what appeared to be a mannequin.

title: In South Africa, The Havoc of AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Economy Shrank Much More Than First Thought in Third Quarter
description: WASHINGTON (Reuters) - The U.S. economy shrank at a faster rate than first thought during the third quarter, contracting at the steepest pace in more than a decade as corporate profits tumbled for a fourth straight quarter, the Commerce Department reported Friday.

title: 'Grinch' Sales Prompt Cheer
description: A family video-watching scene is on the cover of the 2002 catalog from Movies Unlimited, a Philadelphia chain and mail-order house. Grandma is in charge of the remote control, and videocassettes and DVD's are scattered on the floor. Cassettes outnumber discs 4 to 3, the sign of a video scene in flux.

title: European Confrontation Over Privacy Rights on the Internet
description: The two institutions that vote on Europe-wide laws are facing a confrontation over how much access law enforcement authorities should have to the digital trails left by phone and Internet users.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENGELMAN, HOWARD
description: ENGELMAN - Howard. Adored husband of Ethel Roseman Engelman for 57 years, loving father of Augusta Kaiser and Arnold Engelman, brother of Isidore, grandfather of Allegra, Marnie and Francesca Kaiser, Nora and Audrey Engelman, father-in-law of William Kaiser and Carol Rosegg, brotherin-law of Leonard and Gwen Roseman, Phil Roseman and Anne Engelman, uncle of Dr. Richard Engelman and family, Dr. Hal Roseman and family, and of the Roseman/Fishkin nieces and nephews, died suddenly Tuesday at the age of 89. Howard Engelman was a partner in the real estate firm of Engelman & Co. which he founded with his brothers in 1950. He was widely known as a pioneer in the development of residential and commercial real estate in Greenwich Village in the 1950s and 1960s and the later management of those properties. Those properties included 30, 40, 55 and 60 East 9th Street and 50-54 East 8th Street. His vision is credited for the economic growth and widespread popularity of Greenwich Village. Service Friday, 11:15AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Albert Einstein School of Medicine, 1300 Morris Park Ave., Bronx, NY 10461.

title: Post-Soviet Poverty: Children's Burden
description: Although countries in the former Soviet bloc have benefited economically in the decade since their shift from Communism, the United Nations reports, nearly 18 million children in those countries are living in poverty.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: XO Communications Gets Infusion
description: Telfonos de Mxico and Forstmann Little, the leveraged-buyout firm, reached a deal yesterday to take control of XO Communications through an infusion of $800 million cash into the troubled telecommunications company. The restructuring deal, which provides the largest lifeline of its kind for a broadband concern, is expected to allow XO to avoid filing for bankruptcy protection, but it will wipe out the value of much of its stock and debt. ''This is a bittersweet event for our stakeholder constituencies,'' Dan Akerson, XO's chief executive, said. ''But this is what we need to do to strengthen our business.'' The transaction is the latest effort by Forstmann Little to seek value in battered telecommunications companies. For Telmex, Mexico's largest telephone company, the deal offers an opportunity to expand its business in the United States. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTMAN, EDITH (MILLER)
description: ALTMAN-Edith (Miller). Devoted wife of David, loving mother of Mel, Louise Stern, Alan and Judi, caring grandmother of Ilene, Marc, Matthew and Joshua. We'll always remember your kindness and love to us all. Graveside services private. Shiva will be observed at the Altman residence.

title: Mainstream Sites Serve as Portals to Hate
description: EARLIER this month, in a cramped airport lounge in San Jose, Calif., two seemingly unrelated parties sat down to talk about hate.

title: Even With Roads Still Open, Security Fears Are Choking the Flow of Food Aid
description: When allied forces routed the Taliban from Kabul and most of northern Afghanistan, international aid organizations predicted that the roads would soon be filled with truck convoys bearing food and supplies to the millions of Afghans thought to be at risk of starvation.

title: Warehouse Holds Trove for Artists; Need 50,000 Buttons? They're Here, and Free
description: Like a Kmart reimagined as ''Pee-wee's Big Adventure,'' a New York City-run warehouse in Queens is now giving away: 50,000 buttons donated by a button business; crates of neatly coiled bra straps from Victoria's Secret; rattan handbags in the shape of clam shells; and cans stacked floor to ceiling of Martha Stewart's interior decorating paint. And that is only a sample.

title: Abroad at Home; Wake Up, America
description: It is the broadest move in American history to sweep aside constitutional protections. Yet President Bush's order creating military tribunals to try those suspected of links to terrorism has aroused little public uproar. Why? Because, I am convinced, people do not understand the order's dangerous breadth -- and its defenders have done their best to conceal its true character.

title: World Briefing
description: MIDDLE EAST

title: U.S. Envoy Accuses Militants of Bid to Subvert Israel Mission
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 30  The American envoy sent here to broker a cease-fire between Israel and the Palestinians after 14 months of violence accused Palestinian militants today of trying to sabotage his mission.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, ANITA L.
description: MILLER-Anita L. On November 27, 2001. Loving wife to Ron, caring mother to Amanda and cherished sister of Allen Abramson. Service 10:15AM today at Stephen Wise Free Synagogue, 30 West 68th St., NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her memory to The New York Times Neediest Fund, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, NY 10036.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAUNSTEIN, SYDELL
description: BRAUNSTEIN - Sydell. Beloved mother of Joan Rosenblum and Lois Sloane. Mother-in-law of Robert Rosenblum and Allan Sloane. Adored grandmother of Carol Levin (Gary) and Kenneth Jedding (Bette), Leslie Zelnik (Cory) and Stephanie Sloane. Great grandmother of Samantha Levin. An independent woman who was ahead of her time; bright, curious, caring, loving and generous. Died peacefully in her sleep November 29, 2001. Funeral private.

title: 'Code Unknown'
description: Directed by Michael Haneke

title: Saving Artifacts of Our National Memory
description: To the Editor:

title: Militias From South Closing In On Taliban's Last Major Bastion
description: Aided by American air power and ground troops, opposition forces in southern Afghanistan have encircled and are on the verge of laying siege to the city of Kandahar, the last major bastion of Taliban military power, senior United States military officials said today.

title: Third City in Oregon Balks at Assisting Federal Interviews
description: A third city in Oregon is balking at the Justice Department request for help in interviewing 5,000 Middle Eastern men.

title: 'Naked Since 1950'
description: C&M Arts

title: Janet Cardiff
description: P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIGH, MONROE
description: LEIGH-Monroe, 82. Died on November 27, 2001 at his law office, Steptoe and Johnson, LLP in Washington, DC. He is survived by his wife of 50 years, Mary Gallaher Leigh, two sons, Edward M. Leigh and Parker Leigh and a daughter, Elizabeth Leigh all of Washington and three grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, December 1 at 4PM at St. Columba's Episcopal Church, 4201 Albemarle St NW.

title: 'Grinch' Sales Prompt Cheer
description: Afamily video-watching scene is on the cover of the 2002 catalog from Movies Unlimited, a Philadelphia chain and mail-order house. Grandma is in charge of the remote control, and videocassettes and DVD's are scattered on the floor. Cassettes outnumber discs 4 to 3, the sign of a video scene in flux.

title: ALL IN POLICE DEPT. FACE COUNSELING
description: The New York Police Department has ordered all 55,000 employees, including uniformed officers, to attend mental health counseling to relieve the stress and strain imposed by the attack on the World Trade Center and its aftermath.

title: Captured Missionaries' Family Prays and Waits
description: After seeing a picture of her mother's sallow face beamed over the Internet the other night, 12-year-old Mindy Burnham changed her bedtime prayer. Instead of asking for the release of her parents, missionaries being held hostage by Muslim militants in the Philippines, she just begged God to stop their suffering.

title: Lufthansa Near Order With Airbus
description: Lufthansa is close to concluding a multibillion-dollar order for the new Airbus A380 superjumbo jetliner, despite the industry downturn after Sept. 11, Jrgen Weber, the German airline's chief executive, said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTESMAN, HAROLD
description: GOTTESMAN-Harold. We are deeply saddened by the tragic loss of our dear friend Harold Gottesman, our mentor, friend and compatriot. In the 30 years that we have worked together, Harold's advice, knowledge and friendship will always be remembered and cherished. There is an empty space in our hearts but the many fond memories will always be with us. To the entire Gottesman family, our prayers and heartfelt sympathy are with you. Arthur and Barbara Lerner, Newmark & Company Real Estate, Inc.

title: Hevesi Says He'll Run for State Comptroller
description: Alan G. Hevesi, the New York City comptroller who just completed a weak run for mayor, plans to run for state comptroller, his top political adviser said today.

title: Once Again, Banishing Hate And 'Humbug'
description: What a difference a Scrooge makes.

title: PRESIDENT DEFENDS MILITARY TRIBUNALS IN TERRORIST CASES
description: President Bush today strongly defended his decision to establish military tribunals to prosecute terrorists as well as the arrests and detentions of hundreds of Middle Eastern men in the response to the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: House Votes to Shield Insurers and Limit Suits by Future Terror Victims
description: Voting largely along party lines, the House of Representatives adopted a measure today that would provide as much as $100 billion in government loans to the insurance industry to cover losses from future large-scale terrorist attacks. The money would be repaid by insurers, policyholders and, if the administration wanted, taxpayers.

title: Californians See a Kind of Rough Justice for Enron
description: The rapid downfall of the Enron Corporation is likely to hasten the end of California's freewheeling experiment in energy deregulation, industry executives and government officials said today.

title: The Latest in Luxury Boxes
description: IN its three decades, the venerable Range Rover has had only two designs. That will change in January when the 2003 model makes its public debut at the Detroit auto show.

title: Showdown Protestant Meeting Points to Persistent Ulster Splits
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Nov. 30 - A showdown meeting of the Ulster Unionists here on Saturday is calling attention to the persistence of dangerous divisions in the province's Protestant majority at a time when the end of a stalemate over paramilitary disarmament seemed to have cleared the way for progress to peace.

title: Making Message Movies With Plenty of Cleavage
description: If you've been longing to see the semilegendary Vietnam War film ''Brothers Divided,'' ''The Independent,'' a documentary portrait of the director Morty Fineman, offers a searing glimpse. His ''Brothers Divided'' follows Siamese twins, one of whom is an ardent hippie dove and the other a saber-rattling hawk, into Southeast Asia, where one is killed and the other survives. Later, back in Washington, the surviving twin, cradling his dead brother's head, delivers a fiery antiwar speech.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEDINE, MOIS
description: MEDINE-Mois. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun mourns the passing, at the age of 100, the revered father of our devoted member Hayim Medine. We extend our condolences to the entire bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Rabbi Joshua Lookstein Chaim Edelstein, President

title: A Voice in Rebuilding
description: To the Editor:

title: Sheffield Would Cost Mets a Lot
description: The Mets want to trade for Los Angeles Dodgers outfielder Gary Sheffield, but doing so would cost them more than players. A person close to Sheffield said yesterday that he would use his right to refuse a trade to the Mets so he could renegotiate his contract.

title: Foreign Affairs; Pay Attention
description: I really enjoyed those pictures of President Bush and President Vladimir Putin of Russia back-slapping and barbecuing down at the Bush ranch in Crawford the other day. It was heart-warming. You don't see that very often. But you know what else you don't see very often? Such a personal, important summit meeting that doesn't reach any agreement. Now that's unusual. But because the Taliban were falling at the time, no one paid attention. We should.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, DOLORES
description: WILLIAMS-Dolores. The entire family of Long Island College Hospital and Continuum Health Partners, Inc., mourns the passing of Dolores Williams, beloved mother of esteemed LICH Regent and Beth Israel Medical Center Trustee, Ms. Saundra Williams Cornwell. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the family and to those who loved her. John Wren, Chairman, Board of Regents, Long Island College Hospital Peter Kelly, CEO, Continuum Health Partners, Inc. Mark McDougle, Exec. VP & COO, LICH Edmund Giegerich, MD, Senior VP Medical Affairs, LIC

title: Killing the Future in Roosevelt, L.I.
description: When schools fail in New York, the state has considerable power to do something about it. In city districts, the State Board of Regents can close and restructure as many failing schools as it deems necessary. The Regents' powers are even greater in unincorporated areas, where the state sometimes dissolves entire districts, distributing their students among nearby systems that offer a reasonable education. The dissolution law has been used sparingly since the Legislature created it nearly a century ago. But the Regents were right to invoke it against Roosevelt, on Long Island, easily the most troubled district in the state, which has failed to improve even after a decade of scrutiny.

title: Germ Defense Said to Cost Nearly Twice Bush Proposal
description: As Congress debates how much to spend to bolster the nation's defenses against bioterrorism, two leading federal health officials today put the figure at roughly $2.8 billion, almost twice the $1.5 billion the Bush administration has proposed.

title: Jackson Takes Advice From Man on the Street
description: The day after Thanksgiving, Mark Jackson was walking in Manhattan when a stranger approached and gave him something he has truly become thankful for: a challenge.

title: Teachers at Catholic Schools Strike Over Pay and Pensions
description: Teachers at 10 Roman Catholic high schools in and around New York City went on strike yesterday in a long-simmering dispute over salaries and pensions, forcing at least five of the schools to send students home early.

title: America Sends In the Marines
description: To the Editor:

title: Teenager Is Learning His A B C's at the Q-School
description: According to his father, Ty Tryon's decision to become a professional golfer at age 17 really wasn't that daring. He has talent. He has confidence. He has desire. So why worry about criticism when he can make history by becoming the youngest player ever to earn a PGA Tour card?

title: Sports of The Times; Law of Jungle Has Its Limits In the Stands
description: It's too bad Barry Bonds pulled his 73rd home run into a mosh pit of landlubbers on the last day of the baseball season.

title: 'Porn Star' 'The Legend of Ron Jeremy'
description: Directed by Scott J. Gill

title: Abrupt Walkout by Teachers Closes Schools in Middletown, N.J.
description: For the second time in three years, teachers went on strike today in this sprawling suburb in Monmouth County, forcing officials to shut the 17 public schools that serve about 10,500 pupils.

title: Westchester Official Resigns at Boss's Request
description: The top deputy to the Westchester county executive resigned yesterday, a month after a local newspaper reported that he had used his position to help award construction contracts to a former client and political ally.

title: The Big City; Patriotic Act: Asking Waiter For a Steak
description: IF you are looking to do good in these difficult times, Brian Kahn has a proposition perfectly in sync with the zeitgeist.

title: Reports Suggest an Economic Recovery Soon
description: Orders for durable goods rose more in October than in any other month in the last nine years and new-home sales unexpectedly increased, according to reports released today. The reports suggested that the economy might soon recover from nine months of recession.

title: Troops on Call
description: Some nations' military commitments to the international fight against terrorism:

title: Albert Pirro Is Released to Halfway House
description: After serving 11 months of a 29-month federal prison sentence for tax fraud, Albert Pirro Jr., the prominent lawyer and husband of Jeanine F. Pirro, the Westchester district attorney, was released from prison today to serve the remaining six months of his sentence at a halfway house in the Bronx.

title: From Sun-Dappled Innocence To a Lustrous Sophistication
description: Imogen Cunningham once described her mother, a quietly devoted wife and parent, as a woman who ''never expressed an opinion of any kind.'' Cunningham, a live wire until shortly before her death in 1976 at 93, had no shortage of opinions or ideas, especially in her photography.
