Taking after her father, a self-taught freethinker who didn't confine himself to one profession, Cunningham experimented freely with cameras, photographic printing techniques and styles, creating an uncommonly varied body of work.

title: A Nation Challenged
description: Security and Civil Rights

title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Singer's Asylum Request Rejected
description: A government commission has rejected a request for political refugee status submitted by Gloria Trevi, a Mexican pop singer, who fled her homeland after she was charged with the sexual abuse of minors and was arrested in Rio de Janeiro last year. The action came a day after Ms. Trevi, who is six months pregnant, told congressional investigators that she was repeatedly raped by senior police officials supervising her incarceration in Braslia and that she feared for her life.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: Art in Review
description: Janet Cardiff

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Immersed in War (in Bosnia for a Change) With Gusto and Gadgetry
description: ''Behind Enemy Lines,'' a taut wartime rescue thriller that sustains a relentless buzzing energy, feels very much of the moment, even though it is set in the Balkans and not in Afghanistan.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Higher Bid For Gold Miner
description: AngloGold added a cash component to its initial stock-based takeover offer for Normandy Mining Ltd., Australia's largest gold producer, lifting the price by $231 million and topping the offer of the Newmont Mining Corporation. AngloGold said it identified an additional $15 million a year in savings it could reap by acquiring Normandy. The revised $1.9 billion bid comes after AngloGold's proposal won approval from the Foreign Investment Review Board of Australia. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: Jury of One Finds the Accused Not Guilty
description: THE WRONG MAN

title: Afghan Women Trade Shadows for Washington's Limelight
description: It has been a momentous week for a group of Afghan women who were living quiet lives in exile until America went to war in their homeland, starkly profiling to a horrified West the medieval treatment of women under the Taliban.

title: Glorifying Powerful Women Without Their Power Suits
description: ''The more you throw your chest out, the better it will be for everyone.'' So said the fashion photographer Helmut Newton to the model Cindy Crawford in the Htel de Paris. ''Greensleeves'' was playing in the background. Sexual kitsch was in the making.

title: Album of the Week
description: THE AVALANCHES: ''Since I Left You'' (Sire/Modular). The Avalanches, a five-man group of Australian musicians and disc jockeys, build their bouncy tracks from so many samples that the songwriting credits on ''Since I Left You'' are longer than some screenplays. Nearly every sample is a glittering artifact from some variety of good-time music: disco, suave jazz, soundtracks (with dialogue), 1950's pop, novelty discs and easy-listening orchestras for starters, along with party chatter and a panoply of laughs, giggles and turntable scratches.

title: Shares of Tiny Smallpox Vaccine Maker Soar
description: Bad news for humankind can be very good news for a small biotechnology company making vaccines to combat some of the world's worst diseases.

title: John Dawson, 71, Authority on Plasma Physics, Dies
description: Dr. John M. Dawson, a leading authority on plasma physics, died on Nov. 17 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 71.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, EDWARD G.
description: WEINSTEIN - Edward G., 75, Thursday, November 29th. Beloved husband for 51 years of Barbara, devoted father of Kenneth (Elizabeth), Ellen Adnopoz (Stephen) and the late Peter. Cherished grandfather of Matthew, Timothy, Taylor, Kara, Dana and Hayley. Loving brother of Paul J. Weinstein and brother-in-law of Ada V. Ciniglio. Graduate of The Horace Mann School, NYU, served in the Army Air Force in World War II, involved in the printing industry for more than 50 years, avid railroad enthusiast and expert in military hisotry. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St., Sunday, December 2nd, 11:30 AM. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Government Rejects Rebel Request
description: The government -- which may or may not survive Dec. 5 national elections -- said it would refuse the demand of the Tamil rebel leader, Velupillai Prabhakaran, to lift the ban on his group, the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, before peace talks could begin. Mangala Samaraweera, an adviser to President Chandrika Kumaratunga, called Mr. Prabhakaran ''a megalomaniac, a cheap third-grade terrorist who wants to come to power and have a fascist dictatorship in the north.''

title: Creditors' Move Puts Excite@Home's Service at Risk
description: A judge will be asked on Friday to rule that Excite@Home can cut off Internet access to its 3.7 million subscribers, who are caught in a battle over the bankrupt company's assets and future.

title: Against Patriots' Brady, Jets Face the Unknown
description: When Jets linebacker Mo Lewis knocked New England quarterback Drew Bledsoe out of the first meeting between the teams on Sept. 23 with a sheared blood vessel, and perhaps out of his Patriots career, Bledsoe was not the only one hoping he would return for this Sunday's game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAWRENCE, BRUCE
description: LAWRENCE-Bruce. Passed on November 28 at age 66. His family mourns with profound sadness. Deeply beloved wife of 43 years, Linda. Most devoted son and daughter Rand and Tracy, adored father-in-law of Murray Brookman, cherished brother-in-law of Joan and David Gottlieb and soon to be exalted grandfather. A most fine human being with integrity & honor that will be remembered throughout time by all who knew him. Funeral services to be held Sunday, December 2, at 11:30AM at Boulevard Riverside, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: New Video Releases
description: Pearl Harbor

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERSTEIN, LAWRENCE I.
description: SILVERSTEIN-Lawrence I. Of Clifton, NJ and Delray Beach, FL, passed away on Wednesday in Florida at age 76. Mr. Silverstein was born in the Bronx and lived in Spring Valley, Brooklyn and Passaic before moving to Clifton 30 years ago. Mr. Silverstein served in the U.S. Navy as a Signalman Third Class during WW II, and was stationed in Zamboyanga and Mindanao, the Philippines. He attended St. John's University and had a law degree from The NewYork Law School. He was employed by J.I. Kislak and Co., of Newark, and was a partner in Buchbinder, Silverstein and Solove, a Springfield, NJ based mortgage brokerage firm, before retiring in 1998. Mr. Silverstein, an avid sports fan, was a Board member of the Foundation of The General Hospital Center of Passaic, The Boys and Girls Club of Clifton, and The Clifton Optimist Club. He was also an active member of Temple Emmanuel of Passaic. Mr. Silverstein is survived by his wife, Hermine (nee Neuman), daughter, Lori Solomon, son-in-law Jerry of North Caldwell, NJ, granddaughter Hannah, sister Bernice Schoenberg, and many loving nieces and nephews. Services will be held 10:30 AM Friday at the GuttermanMusicant Funeral Home, corner Park and Passaic Streets, Hackensack, NJ. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to The Children's Center for Therapy and Learning Capital Campaign, 15 Halko Drive, Cedar Knolls, New Jersey 07927.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARONSON, IRIS
description: ARONSON-Iris. Stephen and Donna Leeb and Leeb Capital Management mourn the tragic death of Iris Sherry Aronson, administrative assistant and den mother extraordinaire. We were privileged to know her and will miss her daily. Her unassuming but astounding competence kept our lives in order, while her warmth, good humor and devotion nurtured us. Our deepest condolences to Jonathan, Ralph and Joyce.

title: INSIDE ART
description: Musical Chairs In London?

title: Bankrupt Analysis
description: In early 2000, Enron, the natural gas pipeline company turned online phenomenon, held a daylong conference in Houston for Wall Street analysts and investors. The audience, packed with financial experts on the natural gas and power industries, was wowed by all the talk of Enron's online capabilities, especially its rapidly growing business of electronically matching buyers and sellers of numerous commodities like electricity and even network bandwidth.

title: Jeter Feels Like a Rookie as a TV Host
description: Derek Jeter seems most at ease when he is playing baseball in front of millions of fans, in a stadium and on television. He acknowledged having some jitters yesterday, however, after he began rehearsals as he prepared to be the host of ''Saturday Night Live'' this weekend.

title: Disney TV Units to Show 'Harry Potter' and Sequel
description: Capitalizing on the record-breaking release of ''Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone,'' Warner Brothers has sold the basic cable and broadcast television rights for the film, and the next in the Harry Potter series, to the Walt Disney Company in a deal worth at least $130 million, the companies said last night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ERNST, NATAN
description: ERNST-Natan. Condolences to JCLL's Executive Director, Juki (Yocheved) Weinfeld and daughter, Talia Kasher on the loss of their father and grandfather. May they be spared further sorrow. At family's request, donations may be made to JCLL, 426 West 58th Street, New York, New York 10019. Jewish Children's Learning Lab Ricky Shechtel, President Janie Schwalbe, VP Debbie Gibber, Secretary Stephanie Posen Levi, Treasurer Aviva Sussman, Assoc Director

title: Another Arab Bombing Kills 3 Israelis
description: A Palestinian bomber blew himself up on an intercity bus near here tonight, killing three Israelis and wounding nine, while Palestinian negotiators were meeting with the Bush administration's new envoy in hopes of ending the 14-month-old conflict.

title: In South Africa, the Havoc of AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: California's Record
description: To the Editor:

title: Boys, 12 and 13, Accused of Killing Father
description: In a case that has stunned a Florida Panhandle town, a 13-year-old boy and his 12-year-old brother have been charged with bludgeoning their father to death.

title: Traces of the Place at High Tide
description: ''The Atlantic Ocean was something then. Yes, you should have seen the Atlantic Ocean in those days.''

title: EMERSON ELECTRIC IS SELLING UNIT TO JPMORGAN PARTNERS
description: Emerson Electric, a leading maker of power systems for telecommunications and computer networks, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell a heating-systems unit to JPMorgan Partners for $165 million. The unit, Chromalox, is based in Pittsburgh and makes heating systems, controls and parts used in industrial equipment. The business has about $150 million in annual sales, Emerson said. Christopher Behrens, general partner at JPMorgan Partners, said his firm would try to extend Chromalox internationally and would be more aggressive with acquisitions and new products. JPMorgan Partners is a unit of J. P. Morgan Chase.

title: Lucky Goal by Montreal Forces Islanders to Settle for Tie
description: Islanders goaltender Chris Osgood was asked if he was mad. No, not particularly, he said. Then he smiled. The game-tying goal he allowed was simply a fluke. There will be nights like this. Fluky nights.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Strong Gamecube Sales Reported
description: Nintendo said it had sold $150 million in GameCube video-game consoles, games and accessories in the first eight days after its North American introduction on Nov. 18. A fierce competitor of Sony and Microsoft in the booming game console business, Nintendo said it had sold 510,000 GameCube machines, which would set a record for the biggest console introduction in the United States. The company has shipped 740,000 of the systems, which sell for $200, about two-thirds the price of Sony's PlayStation2 and Microsoft's Xbox. Nintendo has begun pumping 125,000 more machines a week into the market to keep up with demand. But the biggest surprise, analysts said, was the sharp increase in sales of Nintendo's less expensive hand-held game systems during Thanksgiving week. The GameBoy Advance sold 310,000 units, compared with 145,000 the previous week. Sales of GameBoy Color jumped to 504,000 from 35,000, spurred largely by steep price cuts at two retail chains. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: In Greenwich Town Lot, Valet Parking
description: Like many towns, this one suffers from a shortage of parking. But affluent Greenwich is experimenting with a solution in keeping with its high-end soul: valet parking in a municipal lot.

title: In Tunnels Full of Bodies, One of Them Kept Firing
description: The forces trying to crush an uprising by Taliban prisoners at the 19th-century Qala Jangi fort here had, for two days, fired rockets and poured oil into the warren of underground rooms underneath the fort. Incredibly, at least one Taliban prisoner was still alive down there today, and still firing his gun.

title: In Bonn, Three Champions for Afghan Women
description: Sima Wali left Afghanistan 23 years ago when the Soviet Army swept into her country. Afghanistan was thrown into a downward spiral of violence, rivalry, civil war and harsh religious rule that finally forced Afghan women out of public life, jobs and education.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELDOR, PROFESSOR AMIRAM
description: ELDOR-Professor Amiram. An old friend, a loving husband, a caring father, a healing doctor, an inspiring teacher, a world renowned scientist. An unbelievable loss. Love, Renee and Nahum

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Arrests In Thefts From Parking Meters
description: Five men were arrested and accused of stealing more than $250,000 in quarters from Manhattan and Brooklyn parking meters, Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer said yesterday. The men were charged with grand larceny and criminal possession of stolen property, punishable by up to 15 years in prison. They are accused of making keys to open meters and then stealing as much as $3,000 a night since January 1999. The men, Andrezy Nehailo, Roman Plisak, Ostap Kapelioujnyi, Gregory Bazar and Oleg Manzheley, exchanged the quarters for currency at delicatessens and restaurants, the authorities said.

title: South Korea Finds Misuse Of Bailouts
description: An agency of the South Korean government said in a report today that thousands of Korean executives had helped themselves to billions of dollars in bailout funds that were meant to rescue their financially troubled companies.

title: Immigrants Offered Incentives To Give Evidence on Terrorists
description: Attorney General John Ashcroft today offered a deal to foreigners -- if they provide useful evidence against terrorists, the administration will help them remain in the United States and may even offer a fast track to American citizenship.

title: America Sends In the Marines
description: To the Editor:

title: Standard Chartered Is in New Hands
description: A boardroom shake-up at Standard Chartered, a major British bank with large operations in Asia, has claimed Rana Talwar, the chief executive, as a casualty, and raised questions about the bank's ambitions to remain independent.

title: Football, Friendship and Cancer in 'Brian's Song,' Again
description: Maybe once was enough.

title: Deadline For Hartford To Shed A House Seat
description: As Connecticut neared a Friday night deadline for redrawing its Congressional districts, state Democrats and Republicans jockeyed today to keep from losing out as the state gives up one of its six House seats.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOYLE, CONSTANCE T.
description: DOYLE-Constance T., 59. Died from intestinal cancer on November 21, 2001 in Los Angeles. Native of Larchmont, NY. Graduate of Sacred Heart in Greenwich, CT. Attended Skidmore College, Boston Museum School, and Parsons / New School. Career in jewelry and graphic design began in NYC and since 1992, continued in Los Angeles. Held editorial positions at Knopf and American Heritage Publications. Survived by her sisters Aidan Fogarty of Huntington Beach, CA, Tracey Doyle of Marina del Rey, CA., & brother Griffin Doyle of Chevy Chase, MD. Contributions may be made to Wells Hospice Program, 245 Cherry Avenue, Long Beach, CA. 90802.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENCHER, EDWARD W.
description: MENCHER-Edward W., MD. In Florida, on November 27, at age 95. Survived by son Stephen Mencher and daughter, Pamela Swerdlick, grandchildren: Julie, Jane, Marissa, Diana, Melanie and great-grandchildren: Avery and Ivy. Graveside services at Mt. Judah Cemetery, Sunday 10:45 AM.

title: Giants' Secondary Hoping To Get Itself Turned Around
description: When practice ended today for the Giants, it resembled the end of the last day of classes, with players hurriedly gathering their belongings to depart for a three-day vacation.

title: Bargains Galore, if You Make the List
description: Have you been invited? If not, you might want to ask why. Suddenly, this holiday shopping season, special invitation-only promotions are everywhere.

title: The Art of Inhabiting Secondhand Roles
description: The wig was loose. The dress was tight. The lift was botched. The turn was late.

title: World Business Briefing
description: AUSTRALIA

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Idaho: A Challenge To Redistricting
description: Plans to redraw the state's legislative districts violate the equal protection clause of the Constitution, the State Supreme Court ruled. The court ordered the state Redistricting Commission to redraft the political borders, saying population differences among the 35 legislative districts should be no greater than 10 percent. Residents and commissioners from counties in eastern Idaho, which lost population in the 1990's, challenged the plan after its completion in August. It is unclear whether the commission's six members will all agree to reconvene.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article last Friday about the prospects for democracy in Islamic countries referred incorrectly to the views of Mounira A. Fakhro, a professor at the University of Bahrain, about the nature of recent changes in her country. She expressed relief over the reform that followed the death of the late emir, Sheik Issa al-Khalifa, in 1999, but not relief over the death itself.

title: Equality on East Side
description: To the Editor:

title: Economy Contracted at Sharpest Rate in 10 Years in 3rd Quarter
description: The nation's economy declined more sharply in the third quarter than initially estimated, shrinking by a revised annual rate of 1.1 percent, its biggest drop since the last recession in 1991, the Commerce Department said today.

title: 2 Sons of Imprisoned Sheik Took Up the Taliban Cause
description: Shortly before he traveled to the United States in 1990, Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman, the blind Muslim cleric who was later convicted of plotting a wave of terror across New York City, dropped off his two eldest sons in Afghanistan.

title: Russian Oil Power
description: Russia may no longer be a military superpower, but in recent years it has quietly become a behemoth in the oil business, a development with important political and economic implications for the United States and its allies. Moscow is now in a position to sharply limit the ability of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to manipulate oil prices. By refusing to go along with production cuts that OPEC favors, Russia can enhance its reputation as a responsible and reliable supplier of Europe's energy needs. That is an opportunity President Vladimir Putin should not squander.

title: Complaints About Police Fall After Attack
description: The number of misconduct complaints filed by civilians against New York City police officers dropped sharply after the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center, according to statistics from the Civilian Complaint Review Board.

title: United Is Expected To Ask Its Employees For Cuts in Wages
description: United Airlines is preparing to ask its employees for wage cuts, according to people close to the company, while the rest of the country's struggling airlines wait to see the outcome before seeking concessions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAUFIELD, ELLA F.
description: TAUFIELD-Ella F. Died peacefully on November 28, 2001 at 88. She is survived by her beloved son and daughter-in-law, Jeff and Loren, and her treasured grandchildren, Elizabeth and William. Never was there a more beautiful human being. She will be missed.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about President Bush and the Spanish prime minister, Jos Mara Aznar, omitted crucial words from a comment by Ari Fleischer, the White House press secretary, about the desired extradition of eight men from Spain to the United States. He said the White House was ''not asking for every person arrested all around the world to be brought to America.'' (He did not say ''asking for every person all around the world to be brought to America.'')

title: Anthrax Found on Envelope Lends Clue to Woman's Death
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30  An envelope sent to a home in Connecticut, only about a mile from the house of an elderly woman who died of anthrax last week, has tested positive for anthrax bacteria, Connecticut officials said today.

title: America Sends In the Marines
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULLIVAN, ROBERT J.
description: SULLIVAN-Robert J., 84. Of Princeton, NJ, and Vero Beach, FL, died on November 21, 2001, at the Medical Center at Princeton. He was a proud member of the Class of 1939 at Princeton University. He is survived by his wife of 56 years, Janet, and children Barbara Sullivan of Wilmington, NC, Robert J. Sullivan Jr. of Sag harbor, NY, and Martha Sword of Princeton, NJ, as well as five grandchildren. His professional career spanned 45 years at Lenox, Inc. A memorial service was held in Princeton on November 26.

title: Dead and Missing
description: Officials estimate that as of Thursday, 3,533 people had died, or were missing and presumed dead, as a result of the attacks on Sept. 11.

title: Groups Gird for Long Legal Fight On New Bush Anti-Terror Powers
description: The Bush administration's aggressive expansion of the government's powers to arrest and prosecute people in fighting terrorism has stirred a legal battle that could last many years and redefine the powers of the executive branch, lawyers and leaders of civil liberties groups say.

title: Youngster Quickly Joins Elite
description: When Michael Phelps was 8 years old, his two older sisters started swimming for a team. Whereupon their little brother said he wanted to try it, too.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Motorola Wins AT&T Order
description: Motorola said yesterday that AT&T Broadband, the largest United States cable provider, would buy 200,000 of its digital set-top boxes next year. The new set-top boxes -- which will be shipped in mid-2002 -- offer additional memory and processing power, and better video signal conversion. According to a statement by Carl McGrath, a vice president at Motorola, the purchase will allow AT&T Broadband to ''cost-effectively offer digital subscribers a greater variety of exciting applications and enhancements, including faster speeds and improved graphics.'' AT&T provides television services to about 14 million customers across the nation. Shares of Motorola closed at $16.60, down 41 cents. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: FAMILY FARE
description: A Season Of Miracles

title: By Turns Exuberant and Subdued, an Ailey Gala
description: By customary standards, the gala benefit that opened the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater's season at City Center on Wednesday night was relatively subdued.

title: Uncertainties Loom As New Yorkers Hit Welfare Time Limit
description: Tonight, after many drumrolls and much confusion, tens of thousands of families in New York will reach a five-year lifetime limit on federal welfare aid. They are by far the largest group yet to face the federal cutoff that has long loomed in the nation's welfare overhaul, and they are among the first to face it in a recession.

title: Reviews of Current Releases
description: For all New York Times film reviews since 1996, go to the Film Archive .

title: N.Y.U. Shuts Down An Internet Venture
description: New York University said yesterday that it was closing down its for-profit Internet learning venture, NYUonline, but will move some of the company's activities into its School of Continuing and Professional Studies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TYNION, JAMES T. JR.
description: TYNION-James T. Jr. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York, records with profound sorrow the death of James T. Tynion, Jr. A life Member of the Society, and extends sincere sympathy to his family. John H. FitzSimons, President Henry F. White, Jr., Historian

title: Deal Is Over but Not Dynegy's Troubles
description: A day after walking away from a deal to buy the collapsing Enron Corporation, Dynegy is having trouble making a clean break from Enron after all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SNOWDAY, JANE MORIN
description: SNOWDAY-Jane Morin. On November 28, 2001, at age 76. Beloved wife of the late Michael Snowday. Loving mother of Cass Collins and the late Christopher Collins. Adored grandmother of Sarah, Ben, Abby, Conor and Callison. Dear sister of Dr. Eleanor Davis and George Morin. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St., Sunday, December 2nd, 3:30 PM. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, 919 Michigan Ave., Chicago, IL. 60611.

title: Spencer Sweeney
description: American Fine Arts

title: Relishing The 70's, With Newer Intrusions
description: Elton John played the first chord from ''Bennie and the Jets'' and paused, knowing it was all he would need to get a roar from his sold-out audience at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night. It was a roar of familiarity, savoring the easy recognition of a song delivered once again by one of pop's long-haul troupers. ''Bennie'' celebrates the frivolity of pop fashion, but the song, like its performer, has been durable. Sir Elton was playing his 53rd show at Madison Square Garden.

title: Kunduz Radio Drops Hard Talk for Easy Listening
description: Last month he was the voice of militant Islam, Enayatelah Khaliq, news correspondent for Voice of Shariat, the Taliban radio station found here at 1520 kilohertz on the medium-wave dial.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Warner and Disney in Deal On Rights to 'Harry Potter'

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: ALCOA SAYS IT WON'T CONTINUE BID FOR WMC OF AUSTRALIA
description: Alcoa said yesterday that it would look elsewhere for opportunities to grow after WMC Ltd. spurned a takeover bid of 11.3 billion Australian dollars ($5.9 billion) last week. Alcoa said it was walking away even though WMC's chief executive, Hugh Morgan, agreed that his board would recommend Alcoa's offer if it matched an independent valuation and no better offer came in. WMC, Australia's third-largest mining company, plans instead to split up and to list separately its base metals business and its 40 percent share of the world's largest alumina supplier, a joint venture with Alcoa, to attract higher offers.

title: Salvador da Bahia Journal; Simmering Over Who Can Cook a Favorite Fritter
description: Take a heaping of skinless black-eyed beans, pound into a paste, add onions, deep-fry in palm oil, cool and slice open. Stuff with coconut-flavored shrimp, nuts, chili peppers and cilantro -- and you have acaraj, the savory, African-inspired fritter that is as integral a part of life here as soccer or samba.

title: Giambi's Strength Is Yanks' Weakness
description: The Yankees' ace pitchers have occasionally alluded to the inherent pressure they felt in 2001, the sense that they needed to dominate opponents because there was a very good chance runs would merely trickle from the Yankees' offense. Club executives are determined to change that in 2002, to build a more potent lineup.

title: The Good Old Days Were Not as Good as We Thought
description: THE late 1990's in America were a wondrous time, when the economic statistics heralded a new era and the stock market confirmed it.

title: A Trend Toward Liquidation, Not Company Reorganization
description: As the number of bankruptcy filings by public companies surges to a record, companies are increasingly being forced to liquidate instead of reorganizing as viable businesses, according to lawyers, investment bankers and other specialists.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It was really something to see a Fire Department

title: Ashcroft's New Powers
description: To the Editor:

title: Northern Alliance and Tribes Both Claim Advances : Drive on Kandahar Reported
description: WASHINGTON  Kandahar, the final Taliban stronghold in Afghanistan, reportedly came under attack Thursday by both Northern Alliance fighters and tribal leaders striking from the south.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Insurer Posts Loss
description: The Munich Re Group, the German reinsurance company that faces huge claims from the World Trade Center attacks, reported a loss of 1.2 billion euros ($1.06 billion) in the third quarter. But its shares jumped nearly 4 percent after it predicted that sales and profits would climb sharply next year. Munich Re said both the volume of business and the size of insurance premiums increased as a result of the attacks. Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)

title: San Francisco Finds Ballots in Machines
description: Two weeks after the last ballot was cast, it appears that the city's election is not over.

title: Chip Maker to Combine Its Regional Accounts
description: The chip maker Advanced Micro Devices in Sunnyvale, Calif., said yesterday that it would consolidate its regional accounts into a single worldwide assignment and seek an agency to handle that task. Combined billings were estimated at $25 million to $30 million.

title: A Filmmaker's Initiation
description: In ''Project Greenlight,'' a documentary series about the making of a movie, Pete Jones, a novice writer-director, oversees filming under the Chicago El of a scene from his ''Stolen Summer.'' The HBO series chronicles a contest in which the winner got a $1 million budget from Miramax to create his movie and a commitment to distribute it. What results is a cautionary tale about the realities of filmmaking and the odds against achieving a Hollywood ending.

title: Ruling to Dissolve Independent Russian TV Network Draws Protests
description: A Moscow court decided this week to dissolve Russia's last independent national television network, leading to an outcry by journalists and human rights leaders who say the decision leaves Russians with little choice of news.

title: INSIDE
description: Bomber Kills 3 Israelis

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Opening Doors To Her Intuition

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Is One Who Acts an Actor?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENNICK, ALFRED H.
description: BENNICK-Alfred H. on November 29, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Frances, devoted father of Elizabeth, Amy, and Chris. Cherished grandfather of Steven, Nicole, and Tyler. Loving brother-inlaw of Judy Morofsky and Joan Brown. His life touched so many and he will be missed deeply. Services Friday, 3 PM at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, Queens Blvd & 76 Rd, Forest Hills.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the arrest of three teenage boys on charges of plotting an attack on New Bedford High School in Massachusetts misidentified a woman who told The Boston Globe her son was not guilty but had been rebellious since the death of his father. The woman, Susan St. Hilaire, is the mother of one of two 15-year-old suspects, Steven Jones -- not of Eric McKeehan, a 17-year-old who was also charged.

title: Study Says Bad Data by China Inflated Global Fishing Yields
description: For years, marine scientists have warned that too much fish has been caught from the world's oceans and have called for drastic measures to curb widespread overfishing.

title: Rachel Gurney, 81, Actress; 'Upstairs, Downstairs' Matriarch
description: Rachel Gurney, the British actress best known to American audiences as the elegant Lady Marjorie Bellamy on the popular 1970's serialized drama ''Upstairs, Downstairs,'' has died, according The Daily Telegraph of London. She was 81.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Expansion At Airport
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has approved a $390 million expansion plan for the Gary-Chicago Airport that allows for the 700-acre field to expand by 350 acres and add runways. City officials hope that the airport will ease congestion at O'Hare International Airport and expect it will become the Chicago area's third largest airport, behind O'Hare and Chicago Midway. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LICHTIG, MILDRED
description: LICHTIG-Mildred. The Trustees and Staff of National Kidney Foundation of New York/New Jersey mourn the passing of our Vice President Mildred Lichtig. Midge was a Charter Member of the Foundation and spent a lifetime of devotion and dedication to our work. We extend our deepest condolences to the family. We will miss her greatly. Ira Greifer, MD, President NKF NY/NJ 1250 Broadway, #

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Officials Move to Aid Families Of Embassy Bombing Victims
description: More than a dozen members of Congress, led by an influential Missouri Republican, have introduced legislation to make the families of the Americans killed or injured in two American Embassy bombings in Africa in 1998 eligible for the federal compensation fund set up for victims of the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11.

title: New Daffodils for Garden That Outlived a Creator
description: J. A. Reynolds knew that a mesh bag of daffodil bulbs had been sitting under a tree at the corner of his block since October, awaiting him, his trowel and his bent back. A Dutch businessman had sent a million bulbs to New York residents, a gift that has kept hands busy across the city during an anxious season.

title: Ski School at Vail and Beaver Creek
description: These two resorts are offering three days of beginner group lessons in skiing or snowboarding for the price of one (with rentals and ski passes). It costs $135 at Vail and $145 at Beaver Creek through Dec. 13 and from April 7 to 14. For $10 more, the resorts repeat the offer Jan. 15 to Feb. 15. Participants must be 15 or older and lessons must be taken on consecutive days. Information: (970) 476-9090 for Vail or (970) 845-9090 for Beaver Creek.

title: Intelligence Failures
description: To the Editor:

title: Irwin Weiner, 69, Entrepreneur Who Succeeded as Sports Agent
description: Irwin Weiner, a sports agent whose clients included Julius Erving and Walt Frazier, died last Saturday at a nursing home in Rye Brook, N.Y. He was 69.

title: Quiet But Very Much Alive
description: THERE'S absolutely nothing still about a good still-life painting. And because a high number of the 90 works in ''Impressionist Still Life'' at the Phillips Collection here are exceptionally good to outright great, a show that doesn't promise much on paper feels very active, very alive.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: With a dozen tables, Fleur de Sel barely has room for the pastries, much less a pastry chef, but it has one. When Cyril Renaud opened his restaurant, he brought along Yvan Lemoine from La Caravelle. It was a good personnel decision. From the beginning, he has made some very nice desserts. Now they verge on spectacular. The evidence is there to see, and taste, in his new menu.

title: Bush Speaks of Security To Group of U.S. Attorneys
description: Following is an excerpt from President Bush's remarks yesterday at a conference of United States attorneys in Washington, as provided by the White House:

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Workplace page on Wednesday about people who switch jobs between the religious and the secular worlds referred incorrectly to a figure for students at the Jewish Theological Seminary in New York who are in second careers. About 85 percent of the students in the seminary's cantorial program are in second careers; the figure is not for the seminary over all.

title: The Neediest Cases; Unhappy Boys Need Aid And Mother Needs a Job
description: Madeline Diaz's son Rafael returned home from school crying, threatening to jump out the window of their apartment in the projects of the South Bronx. He had been teased at school again, called a nerd and a big head.

title: Marines Find No Resistance So Far in Southern Afghanistan
description: WITH THE 15TH MARINE EXPEDITIONARY UNIT, in Southern Afghanistan, Nov. 30  From a dry, isolated lake bed here in the high Afghan desert, American helicopter gunships and armored vehicles are probing the last military strongholds of Afghanistan's crumbling Taliban government.

title: DOLE SELLS STAKE IN HONDURAN BREWERY FOR $537 MILLION
description: The Dole Food Company said yesterday that it had sold its 97 percent stake in a Honduran brewery to South African Breweries P.L.C. for $537 million in cash. Dole said the brewery, Cerveceria Hondurena, had annual sales of about $250 million and pretax profit of about $50 million, and was the biggest in Honduras. Dole, based in Westlake Village, Calif., said it would use the proceeds to pay down debt. The sale will reduce Dole's earnings by 22 cents a share in 2002, but it will be mostly offset by the company's restructuring efforts. The sale is part of Dole's plan to focus on its fresh fruit and vegetable, flower and processed-food businesses.

title: By giving their staffs an extra-long holiday, agencies are making lemonade out of lemons.
description: AFTER an awful year, Madison Avenue cannot wait for 2001 to end, so it will in effect be declared over after the close of business on Friday, Dec. 21.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SABBAGH, DONNA L.
description: SABBAGH-Donna L. of Westbury, LI on November 28, 2001, in her 45th year. (Ironworkers Local #

title: A Tale of the Necklace That Ate the Monarchy
description: According to no less an authority than Napoleon Bonaparte, the events related in ''The Affair of the Necklace,'' a new movie directed by Charles Shyer, were among the main causes of the French Revolution. You will have to take Napoleon's word for it, since this swooshy, bejewelled period melodrama sheds precious little light on the political history of France. This in itself need not be a major failing, since movies set in the 18th century have much to offer besides historical instruction -- women in tight bodices, men in wigs, and elegantly turned-out people laughing uproariously at remarks that don't sound, to our vulgar modern ears, funny at all.

title: Pondering the Mystery Of the Taliban's Collapse
description: The collapse of Taliban military forces in northern Afghanistan was so sudden and so unexpected that government officials and commentators on strategy, here and elsewhere, are finding it hard to explain why it happened and what lessons it bears for the rest of the war.

title: George Harrison, Former Beatle, Dies at 58
description: George Harrison, the Beatles' lead guitarist and the composer of several of the group's most beautiful songs including "While My Guitar Gently Weeps" and "Something," died Thursday at a friend's home in Los Angeles. He was 58.

title: Print Ads to Promote Arts in New York City
description: The Empire State Development Corporation in New York said yesterday that it would introduce a print campaign to stimulate interest in the city's cultural institutions after the terrorist attacks. The estimated $1 million for the campaign is part of the $40 million recently earmarked for a special post-Sept. 11 version of the ''I Love NY'' campaign.

title: 300th Funeral: Firefighters' Ritual of Grief Is Now Somber Routine
description: The three firefighters from Illinois, all dressed in their formal blues, got off at the Long Island Rail Road station in New Hyde Park and squinted into the midmorning light. With only a vague idea of where they were, they flagged down a taxi.

title: 'ABCD'
description: Directed by Krutin Patel

title: Committee Leader Says Victims' Memorial Will Be Main Priority
description: The newly appointed chairman of a commission charged with rebuilding Lower Manhattan said yesterday that establishing a memorial to the victims of the World Trade Center attacks would be among the first priorities for the panel.

title: Legal Maneuvers, Stalking Kandahar, Stalling and Speeding Up Aid
description: However the war on terrorism goes, the civil liberties questions that it has spawned are not about to go away. Nor is the White House budging under pressure from critics, both from the left and the right, who say it goes too far with its plans for military tribunals and for eavesdropping on suspected terrorists and their lawyers. This is war, President Bush said, and ''we must not let foreign enemies use the forms of liberty to destroy liberty itself.''

title: N.F.L. Matchups Week 12
description: SUNDAY 1 P.M.

title: Bush Panel Outlines 3 Plans for Social Security Overhaul
description: President Bush's Social Security Commission set out three options today for allowing workers to establish individual investment accounts and acknowledged that the proposals would have to be accompanied by benefit cuts or other painful steps if the retirement system was to avert a long-term financial crisis.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Charged With Fraud Is Extradited
description: A man who authorities say posed as a firefighter and received free meals and other amenities while pretending to help with the Sept. 11 rescue effort was extradited to New York yesterday to face criminal charges, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. The man, Jerome Brandl, 34, was arrested in Pennsylvania on an unrelated charge of driving a stolen vehicle. From Sept. 18 to 25, posing as a volunteer firefighter from Milwaukee, Mr. Brandl stayed at Engine Company 39 in Manhattan, where he ate catered meals, collected relief donations and stole a Fire Department parking pass, officials said. Sarah Kershaw (NYT)

description: Theater

title: Neiman Marcus Profit Slips 54%
description: DALLAS, Nov. 29 (Bloomberg News)  The Neiman Marcus ( news/quote ) Group said today that its profit dropped 54 percent in its fiscal first quarter as the recession sapped demand for designer goods and expensive jewelry.

title: America Sends In the Marines

description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Confections of an Enterprising Candy Lover
description: DYLAN LAUREN simultaneously smiles and squirms in a yellow plastic chair at her spanking new sweets emporium, Dylan's Candy Bar, strategically located cater-corner to Bloomingdale's on Third Avenue, the street she calls home. Time to get the usual label-bashing out of the way.

title: Crash Test Raises Questions on 2 S.U.V.'s
description: A test released today by a research group financed by auto insurers raised questions about the design of two new sport utility vehicles.

title: In Houston, a 'Nonpartisan' Race Is Anything But
description: The winning formula for Democrats running for mayor in this diverse city has long required patching together ethnic coalitions, so the campaign rally at the sports bar had a familiar feel: a mariachi band, outfitted in matching spangled pants, belted out Mexican ballads as the Hispanic candidate shook hands with a smattering of local Asian business leaders.

title: WITH DEMAND WANING, BROADWING TO ELIMINATE 900 JOBS
description: Broadwing, the parent of Cincinnati Bell, will eliminate 900 jobs, or 15 percent of its work force, to lower expenses amid waning demand for telecommunications services, the company said yesterday. The job cuts, along with office closings and a write-down of assets, will result in fourth-quarter costs of $250 million to $300 million, it said. Broadwing also said it would combine its 11 Web-site-operating centers into three offices, in Cincinnati; Austin, Tex.; and Newark, Del. The company will close its construction business, which built fiber optic networks for other carriers, and close six sales offices.

title: At Tribute to George Harrison, Songs and Many TV Cameras
description: On a bench in Central Park in Manhattan today, a bearded man in sneakers and an old brown vest pulled a gently repetitive melody from his violin in listless staccatos.

title: A Giant Armoire, 300 Years Old And Up for Sale
description: Sometimes a piece of furniture is like a building. Today Phillips, de Pury & Luxembourg, the Manhattan auction house at 3 West 57th Street, puts on view a monumental armoire, made by the cabinetmaker Andr-Charles Boulle around 1700, that is the Empire State Building of antiques: among the tallest, most elegant and most iconic examples of its day. It is to be auctioned on Wednesday at Phillips, with an estimate of at least $5 million.

title: Legal Experts Question Legality of Questioning
description: To the Bush administration, the interviews it wants to conduct with about 5,000 Middle Eastern men will generally be nothing more than relaxed chats.

title: Space Station Problem Stalls Shuttle Liftoff
description: The launching of the space shuttle Endeavour was delayed this morning for at least a day because of a problem at its destination, the International Space Station.

title: Red Sox Close Bidding For Majority Ownership
description: The Boston Red Sox took the next-to-last step in the sale of this century yesterday, accepting final bids for a majority ownership of a team that is one of the crown jewels of Major League Baseball. Perhaps the most critical element of the competition is that the 53 percent share of the Red Sox up for sale does not have to go to the highest bidder.

title: Top-Ranked Minnesota Enjoying Its Fast Start
description: Last April in Albany, goaltender Scott Clemmensen rushed the length of the ice to celebrate a national championship with his teammate Krys Kolanos. Boston College had defeated North Dakota, 3-2, in overtime to end the Fighting Sioux's bid for a second consecutive title.

title: PATH Trains Added to Ease Surge Since Sept. 11
description: PATH trains will be added during rush hours to lines connecting Newark, Hoboken and Jersey City to the 33rd Street station in Manhattan starting Monday, officials announced yesterday. The new trains are intended to ease overcrowding resulting from the loss of the terminal beneath the World Trade Center.
